column2: The Times's David Sanger reports that the White House and international community must now decide how to respond.  (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)
President Jacques Chirac announced that a contested labor law would be rescinded, handing a victory to student groups and labor unions. (Produced by Naka Nathaniel and Ursula Pawlowski)
Times reporter Donald G. McNeil Jr. discusses the eradication efforts for lymphatic filariasis. (Producer: Kassie Bracken)
Howard W. French explores the mess when scavengers sift through the trash at Shanghai's largest dump.(Producer: Adam B. Ellick)
As part of a Times series on diseases on the brink of eradication, former President Jimmy Carter discusses The Carter Center's work to combat Trachoma in Ethiopia. (Producer: Craig Duff)
The Times's Celia W. Dugger and Donald G. McNeil Jr. discuss five diseases on the brink of eradication. (Producer: Kassie Bracken)
Craig Smith, the European correspondent for The Times, explains how the current protests in France are related to last year's riots.
The Times's Howard French reports how China continues to unveil layers of its horrid history with neighboring Japan. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)
Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.
Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.
Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.
Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.
Michael R. Gordon explains his reporting for a series of articles adapted from his book, "Cobra II: The Inside Story of the invasion and Occupation of Iraq."
Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.
Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.

The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardt's May 30 column on Lou Dobbs.
Thom Shanker reports on the training progress of elite Iraqi and Afghani soldiers. (Produced by Matthew Orr)
There's a lot of real estate speculation on Wall Street.
Steven R. Weisman discusses President Bush's reaction to the Hamas victory in the Palestinian elections.
Steven R. Weisman discusses the Palestinian elections and the Bush administration's strategy of promoting victory in the Middle East.

In their tortured quest to take Clear Channel Communications private, the radio giant's two bidders have locked up a key constituent. One of the company's largest shareholders disclosed Wednesday that it would approve the latest version of the deal, which has dragged amid resistance from some investors.

Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, has wooed two investment bankers away from bulge-bracket firms in what might be the start of an aggressive expansion strategy. The firm, which went public less than a year ago, said Tuesday it had hired Francois Maisonrouge, who had been a managing director and chair of life sciences at Credit Suisse, and Mark Vander Ploeg, who was previously a vice chairman of investment banking at Merrill Lynch. Both join Evercore as senior managing directors.

We've now confirmed that former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson is taking formal steps toward a presidential bid, through the formation next week of a "testing-the-waters" committee that will allow him to do some fundraising.

Update: A grand jury in Manhattan indicted four Ernst & Young employees on charges including conspiracy to defraud the Internal Revenue Service, tax evasion, making false statements to the I.R.S., and impeding and impairing the lawful functioning of the I.R.S. See the updated story by The New York Times here.
- Tobin Harshaw

Valerie Plame Wilson's covert status at the C.I.A. is old news for many observers of the inquiry into the leaking of her identity. One side of the political divide argued that she was actually on desk duty at Langley at the time of Robert Novak's infamous column naming her, which would mean that the leaking of her identity was, if not exactly nice, not illegal either. The other side, and Ms. Wilson herself, said the opposite.
Funny thing happened on the way to last weekend's Super Sunday of auto racing telecasts. The announcing crews seemed as if they had been switched in the delivery room.

The New York Times Magazine preview now available is itself a preview of a new book by Jeff Gerth and Don Van Natta Jr., former and current Timesmen, respectively. Their full book, "Her Way: The Hopes and Ambitions of Hillary Rodham Clinton," will be published by Little, Brown next week. In the adapted article, the investigative reporters examine Mrs. Clinton's Oct. 11, 2002 vote authorizing the use of force in Iraq-calling into question whether she read the national intelligence estimate-and the subsequent political fallout and shifts on the issue.

IntercontinentalExchange, hoping to bolster its unsolicited bid for the Chicago Board of Trade, said Wednesday it had reached a deal with the Chicago Board Options Exchange to settle a longstanding dispute over trading rights at the CBOT. The deal applies only if ICE merges with CBOT.
A standoff between the Lebanese Army and Islamists has focused attention on a jihadist element.

Though Tuesday's nomination of Robert B. Zoellick as the new president of the World Bank is newsworthy in its own right, there's a Wall Street angle as well: It marks yet another top political post for a Goldman Sachs alumnus.

Amid rising political tension in Canada over a recent spate of foreign takeovers, Henry R. Kravis, co-founder of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, sought Tuesday to play down the level of his firm's involvement in the bidding war for BCE and offer reassurances he was not masterminding the acquisition of the country's biggest telephone company.
David Pogue reviews three removable cartridge systems.

It often seems as if Goldman Sachs, the highly profitable securities firm, knows how to pluck money from thin air. But the firm is losing its touch with Global Alpha, its flagship hedge fund, which manages money for some of Goldman's wealthiest clients and employees.
Morpheus Developments is developing three "eco" homes on Clareville Street in Southwest London where it has installed boreholes to provide geothermal heat.

The British want more hedge fund access, and that might suit the Financial Services Authority just fine. Just 10 percent of the public in Britain think the asset class should be the sole domain of the professional investor, with the majority favoring wider access, according to a study commissioned by F&C.

Cantor Fitzgerald agreed to sell BGC Partners to its listed ESpeed unit for $1.3 billion in stock, combining the voice and electronic bond trading divisions a month after rejecting a takeover offer for ESpeed.

Deutsche Telekom said it was backing Web telephone-calling start-up Jajah, embracing a technology that undercuts rates for the German telecommunication giant's established long-distance and mobile phone businesses.

There was little doubt that the Federal Trade Commission would thoroughly investigate Google's planned purchase of DoubleClick, but, says BusinessWeek, there's even less doubt that the FTC will eventually sign off on the $3.1 billion deal for the online advertiser.

A joint venture between Cascade Investments, a private equity firm controlled by Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, and PNM Resources will buy a gas-fired power plant in Texas from Dynegy for $467.5 million.

CBS is buying a popular social-networking Website organized around musical tastes for $280 million, combining a traditional broadcast giant with an early leader in online radio, according to the Los Angeles Times. CBS is expected to announce today that it has acquired London-based Last.fm, which claims more than 15 million monthly users, including more than 4 million in the United States, the report said.

Airband Communications said Tuesday that it had received $12.5 million in its latest round of venture funding. M/C Venture Partners of Boston was the lead investor in Dallas-based Airband, which provides wireless broadband networks for businesses.

A New York real estate appraiser testified Tuesday in the federal fraud trial of Conrad Black that the Manhattan apartment bought by the former media baron in 2000 had a market value nearly three times the $3 million he paid the newspaper company for it.

The Web site dedicated to the pole vaulting internet star has closed down, apparently bowing to her complaints lodged from the front page of The Washington Post on Tuesday. Renaming itself the "Former Unofficial Allison Stokke Fan Page," the site left a message for her:

Thanks in part to such increasingly global and sophisticated management, tech startups in Russia are coming of age, according to BusinessWeek. Indeed, after years of promise and potential, Russia finally looks poised to become the next hot destination for foreign V.C. investment.

As attorney general of New York, Eliot Spitzer made a name for himself as a tough cop willing to take on deep-pocketed industries like Wall Street and insurance. Now, writes The New York Times's Jenny Anderson, as governor, he may be making life a little easier for them in an effort to keep financial services in New York competitive in the global market.

In the latest example of resistance to private equity buyouts, the deal for the medical-device maker Biomet got a thumb downs from the influential proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services, which recommended Biomet holders vote down a $10.9 billion private-equity deal for the company, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Viacom has agreed to sell its Famous Music publishing business to Sony/ATV Music Publishing for about $370 million, the Wall Street Journal reported, adding that a deal may be announced Wednesday.

The private equity consortium bidding for the Australian retailer Coles Group, responding to rumors that two more members had pulled out, said on Wednesday it could not confirm whether all four participants were still in the group.

Bradley Pharmaceuticals' founder and chief executive wants to take his company private, but he may have inadvertently put it into play on Tuesday with a $352.6 million bid, Forbes says. Bradley's stock soared 21.2 percent Tuesday, rising $3.91, to $22.35, a premium to the $21.50 offered by the company's chief executive, Daniel Glassman.
A real estate developer, DLF, on Tuesday kicked off the sales effort for an initial public offering to raise $2.4 billion, the largest yet in India.

The debate continues: Are the recent deals involving online-advertising firms -- Google-Doubleclick, Microsoft-aQuantive, WPP-24/7 Real Media -- signs of a bubble, or wise, strategic, long-term plays?

An appeals court on Tuesday upheld the conviction of two senior executives at the Samsung Group on charges that they helped the only son of its reclusive chairman, Lee Kun Hee, inherit control of Samsung, the country's largest conglomerate.
I.B.M. disclosed Tuesday that it was taking on $11.5 billion in debt to finance an acceleration of its stock repurchase plan, which the company believes is one of the largest such steps ever.

VeriSign, which manages the dot-com and dot-net domain names registry, said on Tuesday that its chief executive, Stratton D. Sclavos, had resigned for undisclosed reasons. Analysts were startled by the abrupt departure. The company gave little information about the reason for Mr. Sclavos's departure after 12 years as chief executive.
A look at what Fred D. Thompson has said on the issues.
Additional images from the Anselm Kiefer exhibition at the Grand Palais in Paris.
You look better in less if you're in pretty good shape. And if you're not, who cares?
Bryant, who has grown disillusioned with the Lakers’ direction and its front-office leadership, made the request in a radio interview today.
“Hidden Palms,” a teenage soap opera that makes its debut Wednesday on CW, would be an inspiring home design show if one removed the sex, sociopathology and possible filicide.
Choquequirao, a sister city of similar significance to Machu Picchu, is harder to reach, but still sufficiently free of tourists.

In his early days as a parent he regarded children's menus as a great thing, David Kamp writes in today's Dining section, but he has come to conclude that the kids' menu is regressive, encouraging youngsters to believe that there is a rigidly delineated "kids' cuisine."

Between innings here in Toronto, the Blue Jays sometimes run a skit on their scoreboard that's a take-off on the George Steinbrenner character from Seinfeld. "The Big Stein" is shown from the back, in a wood-paneled office, barking orders at the Blue Jays' mascot.
Lucky Eight is a small place with a big repertory spread across three menus.
Blending documentary elements and some dramatic material, “Radiant City” is an acerbic position paper on the cultural damage done by postwar architectural fads.
Red wine this summer? The panel samples the barberas from Asti and Alba.
Andy Roddick lost to Igor Andreev and James Blake was beaten by Ivo Karlovic, meaning both seeded Americans disappeared in the same day.
America is in the grips of a nefarious chicken-finger pandemic, in which a bland tasting foodstuff has somehow become the de facto official nibble of our young.
Robert B. Zoellick, a senior diplomat and trade envoy, has been chosen to lead the World Bank.
The former senator is creating a committee that will let him begin raising money towards a full-blown campaign.
President Bush asked Congress to increase the United States’ commitment to $30 billion over a five-year period.
A man who flew to Paris for his wedding knew he was infected and had been advised not to travel overseas.
President Bush will host the Russian president in Kennebunkport, Me., where the two leaders are to discuss several issues that have curdled relations between Washington and Moscow.
Earl Ubell was a science reporter and editor familiar to generations of New Yorkers for his wide-ranging reports in the old New York Herald Tribune and on WCBS-TV.
American and Iraqi troops conducted raids in Baghdad’s Sadr City a day after five British citizens were abducted.
The rulings were described as one of three major hurdles for the government as it attempts to steer the country back to democracy.
There is far more nuance in the public’s views of social issues than suggested by the characterization of the country as a divide of red states and blue states.
Arms control negotiators from the United States and China met today in an effort to revive a stalled agreement under which North Korea would begin to dismantle its nuclear weapons program.
Malaysia’s highest court ruled today that the matter was beyond the jurisdiction of the country’s civil courts and should be handled by religious authorities.
An index of Chinese stocks slumped to a 6.3 percent loss by midafternoon, but other Asian markets fell only slightly.

An article last Wednesday about a decision by the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, to remove at least five members of Community Board 6 who oppose the Atlantic Yards development project — which Mr. Markowitz supports — misstated the reason for the absence of a response by Mr. Markowitz. At the time the article was being reported, Mr. Markowitz could not be reached by his aides because he was on a ship at sea, had no telephone access and was not regularly checking his e-mail messages. He did not “refuse” to comment.
Each team scored a run in the 12th inning in bizarre small-ball fashion, followed by Carlos Delgado’s second home run of the game that sent the Mets to a victory.
LeBron James proved for the second straight game that he could be the clutch player that has been advertised by his star status as the Cavaliers tied the series at 2-2.

A 46-year-old Brooklyn man was found shot to death in his apartment yesterday afternoon, and his brother was being sought as the leading suspect, the police said. The victim, whose name had not been released pending family notification, was shot several times in the torso. His body was found shortly after 3 p.m. in the apartment at 109 Butler Street in Boerum Hill.
The Yankees came back to tie the score in the top of the eighth inning, but lost the lead again in the bottom of the eighth, wasting another strong start by Andy Pettitte.

A lawyer representing the estate of Sean Bell, the Queens man who was fatally shot by the police after leaving his bachelor party in November, has called for a federal investigation of the New York Police Department for possible civil rights violations.
The police said that the woman ran over her companion while he was riding a bicycle, then put the vehicle in reverse and struck him again.
Corrections

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about elections in Ireland referred incorrectly to televised endorsements for Bertie Ahern’s campaign for re-election as prime minister. The broadcasts had Prime Minister Tony Blair and former President Bill Clinton praising Mr. Ahern’s role in negotiations that led to the 1998 Good Friday peace accords in Northern Ireland. The endorsements did not praise Mr. Clinton’s role in the talks.

Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about a legal immigrant and Persian Gulf war veteran who has been detained in a New Jersey jail for three years while immigration authorities try to deport him for a firearms conviction misstated his surname at one point in some copies. He is Warren Joseph, not “Mr. Warren.”.

A headline on a report in The Caucus roundup yesterday, about The New York Post’s error in reporting that Senator John Kerry had chosen Richard A. Gephardt as his running mate in 2004, misstated the famous headline in The Chicago Daily Tribune in 1948 when the paper declared the wrong winner in the presidential race. The headline was “Dewey Defeats Truman,” not “Dewey Beats Truman.”.

A caption with an article on May 15 about the trial of Jose Padilla, who is charged with conspiring to support terrorism, incorrectly rendered the name of his mother, who was shown outside federal court in Miami. She is Estela Ortega-Lebron, not Estrela Ortega. The article also misstated the year of his transfer from military custody to civilian custody. It was 2006, not 2005.
The Books of The Times review yesterday, about “A Thousand Splendid Suns,” by Khaled Hosseini, misspelled a character’s name. She is Laila, not Lila.

An article in The Arts yesterday about the impact of plunging CD sales on big music companies and the companies’ efforts to sell more recordings misidentified the electronic file format in which Apple’s iTunes will sell EMI’s music catalog without protection against copying. It is AAC, not MP3.

Because of editing errors, the Critic’s Choice column yesterday, about a new box set of DVDs of Katharine Hepburn films, referred incorrectly to a brother of Hepburn who committed suicide, and it misstated his date of birth, part of which Hepburn said for years was her own birthday. He was an older brother, not younger, and was born on Nov. 8, 1905 — not 1909. (Katharine Hepburn, whose centenary was May 12 this year, claimed for years that she was two years younger than she actually was and that her birthday was Nov. 8.).

An article on Sunday about early and absentee voting in next year’s presidential primaries misidentified the academic affiliation of Paul Gronke, a professor of political science who is an expert on early voting. He is at Reed College in Portland, Ore., not the University of Oregon.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about a clinical study that tests the risk of the diabetes treatment Avandia on the heart misspelled the surname of the F.D.A. spokeswoman who cautioned about misinterpreting data from early findings. She is Julie Zawisza, not Zawisa.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the position of Greenwich, Conn., as a must stop on the campaign fund-raising trail misidentified the birthplace of former President George Bush. He was born in Milton, Mass. — not Greenwich, where President Bush outraised Democrats in the 2004 campaign.

A television column on May 19 about the prime-time fall schedules at the major television networks misspelled the surname of the star of a new Fox drama, “Canterbury’s Law.” She is Julianna Margulies, not Marguiles.

An executive of the energy company BP felt compelled to hold a news conference in Baku, the capital of oil-rich Azerbaijan, to deny allegations that the company had tried to stage coups in 1992 and 1993. The executive, Bill Schrader, the country president for BP, said such an action would “contradict corporate philosophy,” according to a report by the Interfax news agency. Mr. Schrader was responding to articles in Azeri newspapers and the British tabloid Daily Mail citing accusations of a former BP employee.

Almaz Atambayev, left, a moderate opposition politician appointed prime minister in March by President Kurmanbek Bakiyev to defuse a gathering political crisis, was poisoned this month with “a toxin of unknown origin,” government doctors said in a report. They said he was undergoing therapy to rid his body of the toxins, and the security service said it had opened a criminal case. Mr. Atambayev said last week that his enemies had tried to kill him on May 11 by putting poison in his water. He said he was unconscious for two days after drinking the water. “I have many enemies,” Mr. Atambayev said. “I will not resign. I do not like being intimidated.”.

Russia resumed accepting visa applications from Georgian citizens, a step toward easing tensions that have strained relations between the countries after Georgia chose to align closely with the West. Russia also suggested the possibility of a meeting between President Vladimir V. Putin and his Georgian counterpart, Mikheil Saakashvili. Disputes remain. Russia has not lifted its import ban of Georgian wine and mineral water, or its block against direct postal service and air traffic with Georgia.

A federal court granted amnesty to three policemen accused of negligence in failing to prevent a Chechen terrorist group from seizing a public school and more than 1,100 hostages in Beslan in 2004. Their trial, which began last year, had been seen as another chance to expose official bungling of the three-day siege, in which 333 people died, 186 of them children, and to turn up more information about lingering mysteries. Survivors and relatives, who accuse the government of a whitewash, reacted with dismay, shouting and rushing the judge, who was forced from the courtroom in North Ossetia before finishing reading his decision, according to local reports.
A raid by the authorities on a train carrying undocumented Central American immigrants in southern Mexico ended in tragedy as a man jumped to his death from a moving rail car.

President Bashar al-Assad won 97.6 percent of the vote in a national referendum on Sunday that anointed him to a second seven-year term, officials said. The 41-year-old president was the only candidate allowed to put his name forward in the procedures leading to the vote. Parliament held a session to ratify the results. Then all 250 members rose and chanted “Syria has only God and Bashar!”.
The International Whaling Commission approved extending bowhead whaling quotas for Eskimos for subsistence hunting.
The Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney said that if elected he was likely to give his salary of $400,000 to charity.
Wells Fargo, one of the largest companies in the student loan business, has agreed to follow a code of conduct governing relationships between lenders and universities.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago paid $6.65 million to settle claims by 14 people who say they were abused by priests, the church and plaintiffs’ lawyers said.
A truck driver pleaded guilty to reckless homicide for a wreck that killed five Taylor University students and staff members last year.
Two humpback whales that swam from the Pacific Ocean far up into Central California’s inland waterways appear to be heading back toward open ocean, wildlife officials said
Baseball Prospectus figured out which day Barry Bonds is most likely to hit his 756th career home run and the chances he will not do it at all this season.
A reading program helps children gain reading confidence by sharing a book with a dog.
The senator’s plan aims to cover uninsured Americans and to reduce premium costs for everyone else.
Passengers on the flights may have been exposed to a man infected with a dangerous form of tuberculosis.
Gunmen wearing police commando uniforms abducted five British civilians from a Finance Ministry complex in Iraq, British officials said.
Madison Dearborn Partners will acquire the CDW Corporation, a leading online computer reseller, for $7.3 billion.
Conflict between Arabs and Kurds is intensifying in Mosul, adding another dimension to the civil war.
Russia held a test launching of a new intercontinental ballistic missile and said it had successfully fired the weapon almost entirely across its northern airspace.
A set of experts is calling harsh techniques used since the 2001 terrorist attacks outmoded, amateurish and unreliable.
Cindy Sheehan announced on a liberal Web site Monday that she was essentially resigning as the face of the American peace movement.
So many planes are expected to be full this summer that bumped passengers could end up waiting days for a seat.
Derailed by a hip injury last year, St. Louis Cardinals reliever Jason Isringhausen has been better than ever the first two months of the season.
Robert B. Zoellick, a Goldman Sachs executive, has been tapped to try to heal rifts from Paul D. Wolfowitz’s ouster.

MOUNT LAUREL, N.J., May 29 (AP) — An electronics store worker credited with calling in the tip that exposed what the authorities have said was a plot to kill soldiers at Fort Dix said Tuesday that it took a day of pondering before he alerted officials.
U.S. sanctions aim to squeeze Sudan’s economy by freezing its companies out of American financial institutions.
Federal prosecutors charged a high-level investment banker in Pakistan with earning illegal profit from an insider-trading scheme.
A string of travails has taken a toll on Gov. Jim Gibbons, who had a 28 percent approval rating in a recent poll.
If the arguments of Lou Dobbs were really so good, surely you think he would be able to stick to the facts?
A woman who was said to be struggling with depression apparently hanged her four young daughters in their North Texas mobile home before hanging herself, the authorities said.
The underlying question regarding what Yankees owner George Steinbrenner will do with general manager Brian Cashman and Manager Joe Torre is his health.
President Bush has presided over a Republican Party in “collapse,” and Karl Rove’s strategy in the 2004 presidential election was “maniacally dumb,” Newt Gingrich said.
Ben Silverman has been named as a co-chairman of both the entertainment division and its television studio.
Microsoft plans to unveil a new computing device called Surface, featuring a 30-inch screen embedded in an acrylic tabletop.
A shotgun-toting partygoer shot and killed a 17-year-old youth and injured a 15-year-old boy early yesterday during a gathering at a Staten Island housing complex, the police said.
The U.S. and its European allies scheduled a vote on a resolution establishing an international court to try those suspected of killing Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.
Parren J. Mitchell was the first black elected to Congress from Maryland and led the Congressional Black Caucus.
Roger Clemens, who will have a throwing session on Wednesday, will likely throw again over the weekend and meet the Yankees in Chicago for Monday’s game.
Officials say the man used the Yale University name to persuade illegal Irish immigrants that they were paying him to get their papers, but they received nothing.

New Jersey’s largest utility said yesterday that it would replace nearly one-third of its fleet with hybrid vehicles over the next decade in an effort to reduce tailpipe emissions. The hybrid vehicles, along with the use of alternative fuels and other changes, should reduce the carbon dioxide output of the utility, Public Service Electric and Gas, by 81,000 tons, company officials said. The company, which has about 5,000 vehicles, plans to replace 1,300 of them with hybrids, which use a combination of gasoline and electricity for power.

Eight people have been indicted on charges of robbing 97 small businesses in New Jersey and southeastern Pennsylvania, including a large number of doughnut shops, prosecutors said yesterday. Members of the group were charged with traveling to the businesses in rental cars, breaking in after they had closed and using crowbars to pry open cash registers, said Attorney General Stuart Rabner. In some cases, they also stole safes. Mr. Rabner said 50 police departments participated in the investigation.

In 1973, Matt Centrowitz of Power Memorial High School in Manhattan ran a mile in 4 minutes 2.7 seconds. On Saturday, his son, Matthew, will go after the family high school record. Officials of the Reebok Grand Prix announced yesterday that Matthew, an 18-year-old high school senior from Annapolis, Md., would run the mile in their meet Saturday at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island in New York. A month ago, the younger Centrowitz set a Penn Relays high school record of 4:08.38 for the mile. Last weekend, he ran 4:04.09 for 1,600 meters, the equivalent of 4:05.5 for the mile. His father, the track coach at American University, had a career best of 3:54.94 for the mile. The son is bound for the University of Oregon, his father’s alma mater.

Most New York voters do not think state legislators deserve a pay raise, according to a poll released yesterday by the Siena Research Institute at Siena College. Lawmakers have not received a raise since 1999, but the poll found that 62 percent of voters opposed the increase, while 32 percent supported it. The telephone survey of 620 voters was conducted May 18-20 and has a margin of error of four percentage points, the institute said. Pollsters also found that voters were divided on Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s call for legalization of gay marriage, with 43 percent in favor and 47 percent opposed.

Four teenagers were seriously wounded early yesterday when a gunman walked into a fast-food restaurant on Archer Street and opened fire, the police said. The shooting occurred just after midnight near Taylor Avenue, the police said. The police did not provide a motive for the shooting. The victims were a 17-year-old boy who was hit in the chest, wrist and leg; an 18-year-old woman hit in the leg; a 19-year-old man hit in the leg; and another 19-year-old man who was struck in both legs, the police said. The police did not identify the victims. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.
lacrosse.

A 45-year-old woman was found dead in her home at 247 Malcolm X Boulevard in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday, the police said. She had been stabbed several times in the neck. The woman, who was not identified, was found by police officers shortly after 11:30 a.m. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.

The Adirondack Park Agency has ruled that a man’s houseboat does not violate land-use rules for the six-million-acre park, provided that he does not leave it in one spot all season. The 70-by-24-foot wooden houseboat is anchored at a marina on Lake Flower, but its owner, Bruce Darring, a woodworker in Saranac Lake, said he planned to move it between his property on Lake Flower and Oseetah Lake. “There’s no way it’s going to stay in one place,” he said. Agency rules would not allow a boat moored permanently along the shore to be used as a cabin, but the agency concluded that it could not bar a boat from anchoring temporarily along a lakeshore.

A cargo worker at Newark Liberty International Airport died early yesterday after he was struck by a 750-pound piece of equipment used to stabilize the rear section of a plane during loading and unloading. The worker, Timothy Gallagher of Jersey City, an employee of Worldwide Flight Services, was towing a tail stand for an EVA Airlines Boeing 747 about 12:25 a.m. when the 16 ½-foot-tall structure fell over and struck him in the head and upper body, said Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport. The Port Authority is investigating.
Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles is one of the most powerful Democrats in California and among the most influential Hispanics in the nation.
Jerry Buss, the Los Angeles’ Lakers’ owner, was arrested early Tuesday in an investigation of driving under the influence of alcohol.
Gov. Rick Perry commended Texas lawmakers for passing a last-minute budget.
The facts, according to the Department of Justice, about immigrants and prisons.
Consumer confidence bounced back unexpectedly in May, helped by optimism about the job market.
The former director of China’s top food and drug safety agency was sentenced to death on Tuesday after pleading guilty to corruption and accepting bribes.
The move was aimed at braking what many inside and outside China now see as a stock market bubble.
The City Housing Authority wants to raise $50 million by selling land and then use the income to help preserve housing for the poor.
A homeless panhandler arrested on loitering charges is contending in court that a state law banning begging violates his right to free speech.
Experts said Tuesday’s Supreme Court decision would have broad ramifications in cases involving employment discrimination because of race or national origin.
Amid technical fouls and anguished looks, and debris that rained down from the stands Monday night, the Utah Jazz learned a hard lesson.
Mahmoud Abbas and Ehud Olmert will continue a Washington-sponsored dialogue that will likely focus on another round of Israeli-Palestinian warfare.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice rejected linking Iran’s arrest of several Iranian-Americans in Tehran to the Bush administration’s capture of members of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard in Iraq.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,449 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Neil Bush, brother of the President of the United States, is behind a teaching method that is intended to bypass textbooks.
An ambitious new type of pen-based computer system could bridge the gap between paper and the digital world.
The deal was valued at about $2.4 billion, Boeing’s largest sale in the former Soviet Union.
The sharp decline in the prevalence of smoking over the past four decades shows signs of slowing while the death toll from cigarettes remains disturbingly high.
The company was found guilty of infringing three patents owned by a smaller rival, the Broadcom Corporation.

President Bush rightly served notice that America has run out of patience with the duplicity of Sudan’s president, Omar Hassan Bashir, and will press the international community to stand up to the genocide.
The many “energy independence” bills circulating in Congress will likely be disastrous from a global warming perspective.
A confidential report concludes that the chain’s reputation for discounts has worked against its efforts to move upscale.
Soon after Barry Bonds arrived at Shea Stadium on Tuesday, the San Francisco Giants announced that he was not starting and not talking.
Iran has charged three Iranian-Americans with spying a day after Washington and Tehran held their highest-profile talks in nearly 30 years.
Advanced Medical Optics had no explanation yet of why its contact lens care product might be contributing to an outbreak of eye infections.

A raid by the authorities on a train carrying undocumented Central American immigrants in southern Mexico ended in tragedy on Monday as a man jumped to his death from a moving rail car and a boy had his leg severed by the train's wheels. ''We were all on top of the train when the police began chasing us,'' the boy, Luis Carlos Hernández, 14, from Honduras, told The Associated Press from a hospital in Veracruz, where he was recovering from an amputated right leg. The unidentified man who jumped fell onto the tracks and was decapitated, officials said. MARC LACEY

Four teenagers were seriously wounded early yesterday when a gunman walked into a fast-food restaurant on Archer Street and opened fire, the police said. The shooting occurred just after midnight near Taylor Avenue, the police said. The police did not provide a motive for the shooting. The victims were a 17-year-old boy who was hit in the chest, wrist and leg; an 18-year-old woman hit in the leg; a 19-year-old man hit in the leg; and another 19-year-old man who was struck in both legs, the police said. The police did not identify the victims. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.

A television column on May 19 about the prime-time fall schedules at the major television networks misspelled the surname of the star of a new Fox drama, ''Canterbury's Law.'' She is Julianna Margulies, not Marguiles.

BILLIK--Gene, of Livingston, NJ, and Boca Raton, FL, died at home on May 29, 2007, after a five year battle with cancer. Devoted husband of the late Marilyn Billik. Born January 1, 1927 in Flushing, NY, attended Storm King School and Brown University. He began his long career in the spirits industry with Popper Morson and later became a VP at William Grant & Sons. He is survived by son Buzz (Beth) Billik, daughter Nancy (Ken) Weinrib and grandsons, Britton, Cameron and Cole Billik, and Craig, Doug and Miles Weinrib. Funeral Service will be held at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ on May 31st at 2:30pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (Fred's Team), PO Box 27106, NY, NY 10087.
To the Editor: Re ''A Great Idea Lives Forever. Shouldn't Its Copyright?,'' by Mark Helprin (Op-Ed, May 20):

Eight people have been indicted on charges of robbing 97 small businesses in New Jersey and southeastern Pennsylvania, including a large number of doughnut shops, prosecutors said yesterday. Members of the group were charged with traveling to the businesses in rental cars, breaking in after they had closed and using crowbars to pry open cash registers, said Attorney General Stuart Rabner. In some cases, they also stole safes. Mr. Rabner said 50 police departments participated in the investigation.

Ronnie was a compassionate and loving artist who brought beauty and perspective into everybody's lifes. A memorial service will be held, June 5th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about elections in Ireland referred incorrectly to televised endorsements for Bertie Ahern's campaign for re-election as prime minister. The broadcasts had Prime Minister Tony Blair and former President Bill Clinton praising Mr. Ahern's role in negotiations that led to the 1998 Good Friday peace accords in Northern Ireland. The endorsements did not praise Mr. Clinton's role in the talks.

Ready or not, after serving a 50-game suspension for violating baseball's policy on performance-enhancing drugs, Guillermo Mota will be reinstated today. Mota went 0-1 with a 7.04 earned run average in seven appearances for Class AAA New Orleans, including a scoreless inning Monday in his final outing. ''I'm not going to treat him any differently than anyone else out there,'' Willie Randolph said. The Mets will send Ambiorix Burgos to New Orleans to make room on the roster for Mota. BEN SHPIGEL

Gov. Eliot Spitzer named a commission on Tuesday to recommend how to overhaul higher education in New York, saying he wanted to improve the reputation of the state's public universities. At the same time, Mr. Spitzer disclosed he was nominating Carl Hayden, a lawyer in Elmira and one of the commission members, as chairman of the State University of New York.

Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants did more singing than playing at Shea Stadium yesterday. He rolled into the clubhouse with a digital music player on his arm and headphones over his ears. Soon after his arrival, the Giants announced that Bonds was not starting and not talking. But Bonds did sing as he strolled around the 40 reporters who were waiting to see if he would discuss his pursuit of Hank Aaron's career home run record. Bonds hit his 746th homer against the Colorado Rockies on Sunday and is 10 short of surpassing Aaron's mark.

Russia resumed accepting visa applications from Georgian citizens, a step toward easing tensions that have strained relations between the countries after Georgia chose to align closely with the West. Russia also suggested the possibility of a meeting between President Vladimir V. Putin and his Georgian counterpart, Mikheil Saakashvili. Disputes remain. Russia has not lifted its import ban of Georgian wine and mineral water, or its block against direct postal service and air traffic with Georgia. C. J. CHIVERS

For ''Mike Wallace: Some of My Favorite Stories,'' a retrospective to be broadcast on Sunday at 7 p.m. on CBS, this (mostly) retired ''60 Minutes'' correspondent was not content merely to walk down memory lane. He wanted to make news. And so on Friday Mr. Wallace plans to be in Coldwater, Mich., to nab the first interview with Dr. Jack Kevorkian after he is paroled from a federal prison. Dr. Kevorkian, the advocate for assisted suicide who has served eight years for second-degree murder, was the subject of a piece by Mr. Wallace on ''60 Minutes'' in 1998. In that segment Dr. Kevorkian, above right, could be seen administering the lethal injection that resulted in the charges against him. That Mr. Wallace, 89, above left, has not lost his zest for a big ''get'' was obvious even over the phone yesterday, as he described securing the Kevorkian meeting through an intermediary and then plotting how to outwit others seeking the same interview. In the special Mr. Wallace will also be seen conducting a new interview with Vanessa Redgrave, whom he profiled on ''60 Minutes'' in 1979, and talking to Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the Iranian president, in a segment first broadcast last year. JACQUES STEINBERG

A caption with an article on May 15 about the trial of Jose Padilla, who is charged with conspiring to support terrorism, incorrectly rendered the name of his mother, who was shown outside federal court in Miami. She is Estela Ortega-Lebron, not Estrela Ortega. The article also misstated the year of his transfer from military custody to civilian custody. It was 2006, not 2005.

The Supreme Court on Tuesday made it harder for many workers to sue their employers for discrimination in pay, insisting in a 5-to-4 decision on a tight time frame to file such cases. The dissenters said the ruling ignored workplace realities. The decision came in a case involving a supervisor at a Goodyear Tire plant in Gadsden, Ala., the only woman among 16 men at the same management level, who was paid less than any of her colleagues, including those with less seniority. She learned that fact late in a career of nearly 20 years -- too late, according to the Supreme Court's majority.

Leaders of the State Assembly and Senate agreed on Tuesday to an extension of the loft law, which protects tenants who live in old commercial lofts from eviction, two days before the legislation was set to expire. The Assembly passed the measure later on Tuesday, and a vote is expected soon in the Senate.

A 45-year-old woman was found dead in her home at 247 Malcolm X Boulevard in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday, the police said. She had been stabbed several times in the neck. The woman, who was not identified, was found by police officers shortly after 11:30 a.m. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.

If Brian Cashman is ''on a big hook,'' as George Steinbrenner said last week in one of those interviews he rarely grants, would the Boss fire him? After all, Steinbrenner hasn't fired a general manager or a field manager in this century -- yet he has all the power he needs to do so. But has the sharpness of the principal owner's old ax dulled behind the benign statements issued in his name by his spokesman, Howard Rubenstein? Has he gone touchy-feely in the seven seasons since his team has won a World Series?

European cheeses have inspired American cheesemakers, and a Finnish one called juustoleipa (YOO-sto-lay-bah) may be among the most unusual. It's a semi-soft cheese, traditionally made from reindeer milk but here, pasteurized cow's milk will have to do. It is baked a bit during the cheesemaking, so it acquires a dappled, lightly caramelized crust. Warm it in a microwave or toaster oven, in a pan or on a grill, and it turns glossy and soft, with a flavor that echoes French toast. It's an ideal foil for fresh strawberries for breakfast or dessert. Carr Valley Cheese of La Valle, Wis., calls it by its translation, bread cheese; $7 at carrvalleycheese.com. At Murray's Cheese shops (a tasting in the West Village store, right), it's $6.99: murrayscheese.com. Bass Lake Cheese in Somerset, Wis., sells juustoleipa on its Web site; $9.13 at blcheese.com.

Fleet Week, a visit by sailors and other members of the armed forces, has been part of life in New York City since 1984. This year, six ships docked in Manhattan and at Staten Island. They were open to the public, and the city was open to about 3,000 members of the Navy and the Marine Corps. This serviceman passed some time in a bar on Ninth Avenue in Midtown.

To the Editor: Re ''The Quiet Americans'' (column, May 27): As a Brown alumnus in the class of 2004, I agree with Thomas L. Friedman's observations regarding the widespread optimism of my friends and colleagues.

President Bush has presided over a Republican Party in ''collapse,'' and Karl Rove's strategy in the 2004 presidential election was ''maniacally dumb'' for focusing so heavily on the conservative base. The words, perhaps, of Howard Dean, the Democratic national chairman? Or John Edwards? Nancy Pelosi, maybe?

Bowery Kitchen Supplies will open Bowery Kitchen East, specializing in knives and chef's clothing, Friday, just a few steps from the Bowery. And if you've ever wondered why the larger parent store in the Chelsea Market has Bowery in its name, it's because Howard Nourieli, an owner, had a store on the Bowery for about 10 years before moving to Chelsea in 1996. Now he is back in the old neighborhood, offering a broad range of cutting utensils. The knives, mostly from Germany and Japan, start at $30 and go up into the thousands. There are excellent light, dishwasher-safe Epicurean cutting surfaces made from pressed board, too, starting at about $10, including a generous oblong for fish ($34). Another specialty is cocktail-making equipment: 5 Rivington Street (Bowery), (212) 477-8681.

''If you want to scare the American people, what you say is the bill's an amnesty bill. That's empty political rhetoric trying to frighten our citizens.'' PRESIDENT BUSH, on the proposed immigration bill. [A16]

A headline on a report in The Caucus roundup yesterday, about The New York Post's error in reporting that Senator John Kerry had chosen Richard A. Gephardt as his running mate in 2004, misstated the famous headline in The Chicago Daily Tribune in 1948 when the paper declared the wrong winner in the presidential race. The headline was ''Dewey Defeats Truman,'' not ''Dewey Beats Truman.''

An executive of the energy company BP felt compelled to hold a news conference in Baku, the capital of oil-rich Azerbaijan, to deny allegations that the company had tried to stage coups in 1992 and 1993. The executive, Bill Schrader, the country president for BP, said such an action would ''contradict corporate philosophy,'' according to a report by the Interfax news agency. Mr. Schrader was responding to articles in Azeri newspapers and the British tabloid Daily Mail citing accusations of a former BP employee. ANDREW E. KRAMER

VAN BAAREN--Karren (nee Robertson), died at home in Devon, after a long illness, aged 61. Much loved by all her family and friends. She will be remembered with huge affection and respect, for her brilliant and warm personality. The Funeral service will be held at the Parish Church of St. John the Baptist in North Bovey, on Monday June 4th, at 11am, followed by a recption at nearby Bovey Castle. Donations in her memory, if so desired, in aid of ''The Friends of St. John's'', as well as all further enquiries, may be directed to Coombes & Sons, 73 Fore St., Bovey Tracy, Devon, UK, TQ139XY, 44-1626-833409

A federal court granted amnesty to three policemen accused of negligence in failing to prevent a Chechen terrorist group from seizing a public school and more than 1,100 hostages in Beslan in 2004. Their trial, which began last year, had been seen as another chance to expose official bungling of the three-day siege, in which 333 people died, 186 of them children, and to turn up more information about lingering mysteries. Survivors and relatives, who accuse the government of a whitewash, reacted with dismay, shouting and rushing the judge, who was forced from the courtroom in North Ossetia before finishing reading his decision, according to local reports. C. J. CHIVERS

The Farmers' Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., has a sure crowd-pleasing exhibition on view until the end of October: ''Ice Cream: Our Cool Obsession.'' There are photographs, historical artifacts like antique ice cream machines and old trucks, and a retro ice cream parlor serving treats. The history of the confection, starting with water ices in ancient times, is explored. The museum, 5775 State Highway 80 (Lake Road), Cooperstown, is in a colonial-style stone barn and is open daily; admission is $11 for adults, $9.50 for those 65 and older, $5 for children 7 to 12 and free for younger children and members. Hours vary: (888) 547-1450.

Death Shapes a Reality Show Impending death and organ donation are the attractions of a planned Dutch reality show that has been condemned as unethical and tasteless, The Associated Press reported. But the BNN network plans to proceed with the program on Friday, saying it believes that the show will draw attention to a shortage of organ donors. At least one parliament member said he would ask the government to block the broadcast of the ''Big Donor Show,'' produced by Endemol NV, creator of the ''Big Brother'' series. On the show a donor identified only as Lisa, 37, who is terminally ill with an inoperable brain tumor, will hear interviews with three candidates, their families and friends before deciding who will receive one of her kidneys. ''We know that this program is super-controversial, and some people will think it's tasteless,'' said Laurens Drillich, chairman of BNN, ''but we think the reality is even more shocking and tasteless: waiting for an organ is just like playing the lottery.'' Marieke Saly, a spokeswoman for BNN, said there could be no guarantees that the donation would actually be made, but said ''the intention'' was that the transplant would be carried out before Lisa died. Under Dutch rules, her designation of a recipient would become invalid after her death. Books Take the Spotlight Beginning on Thursday, authors, publishers, booksellers and librarians will gather by the thousands at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan for the annual BookExpo America, which runs through Sunday, The Associated Press reported. Amid networking, discussions of new books and developments in the industry and anticipation of ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,'' a hot coming attraction seems to be ''The Age of Turbulence'' (Penguin Press) by the former Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, due on Sept. 17. Mr. Greenspan, 81, is to be the keynote speaker at the convention. Sales have been flat in 2007, according to the American Booksellers Association, and the number of independent bookstores has continued to shrink, to 1,580 this spring from 1,660 a year ago. Three panels at BookExpo will focus on newspaper reviews after cutbacks at a number of newspapers, including The Los Angeles Times and The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. More Legal Troubles For Brandy The singer and actress Brandy, below, and a man injured in a deadly San Diego Freeway crash involving her Range Rover are suing each other, The Associated Press reported. Brandy, 28, whose full name is Brandy Norwood, and Mallory Ham of Simi Valley, Calf., accuse each other of negligence in the lawsuits, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court. Brandy contends that Mr. Ham caused the crash on Dec. 30 in Sherman Oaks, Calif. His suit, seeking unspecified damages, contends that she drove recklessly. A California Highway Patrol report said Brandy's 2007 Range Rover failed to slow in traffic and was moving at 65 miles an hour when it struck another car that was hit in turn by Mr. Ham's vehicle. The crash killed Awatef Aboudihaj, 38, of Los Angeles. Yesterday Frank Mateljan, a spokesman for the city attorney's office in Los Angeles, said it was still deciding whether to charge Brandy with misdemeanor vehicular manslaughter, which carries a maximum penalty of a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Alagna Cancels Performances The French tenor Roberto Alagna, below, has canceled three performances of ''Il Trovatore'' in Madrid to undergo surgery on his nose, The Associated Press reported yesterday, citing the Madrid Opera house and Mr. Alagna's manager. Ines Toston, a spokeswoman for the Teatro Royal, said, ''Roberto Alagna is undergoing surgery between June 2 and 4, and after that he needs a recovery period of six weeks.'' In his first performances ever in Spain, Mr. Alagna had been scheduled to sing in ''Il Trovatore'' three times from June 7 to 29. He made headlines last year when he walked off the stage at La Scala in Milan after some members of the audience reacted with boos and whistles to his performance in a new production of ''Aida.'' A costume worn by the opera star Maria Callas has been stolen from an exhibition in Athens, Agence France-Presse reported. The theft took place on Friday at the Italian cultural center, where a two-week exhibition of Callas memorabilia, including costumes, jewelry and accessories, was in progress. Besides an opera competition, Greece has organized events this year to honor Callas (1923-1977). She was born to Greek immigrants in the United States and took Greek citizenship in 1966. Footnote Six previously unreleased versions of his classics and six new songs by Merle Haggard are featured on his new CD, ''Working Man's Journey,'' priced at $11.99 and available at the 559 Cracker Barrel Old Country Stores in 41 states and online at crackerbarrel.com.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the position of Greenwich, Conn., as a must stop on the campaign fund-raising trail misidentified the birthplace of former President George Bush. He was born in Milton, Mass. -- not Greenwich, where President Bush outraised Democrats in the 2004 campaign.

Through the first round of balloting for the All-Star Game on July 10, Carlos Beltrán leads the National League in votes and heads a contingent of four Mets who lead the league at their positions. In the outfield, Beltrán has 586,815 votes, leading Barry Bonds by more than 200,000. At third base, David Wright leads Chipper Jones by more than 100,000 votes. At shortstop, José Reyes leads J. J. Hardy by more than 150,000. At catcher, Paul Lo Duca is more than 50,000 votes ahead of Brian McCann. BEN SHPIGEL

Because of editing errors, the Critic's Choice column yesterday, about a new box set of DVDs of Katharine Hepburn films, referred incorrectly to a brother of Hepburn who committed suicide, and it misstated his date of birth, part of which Hepburn said for years was her own birthday. He was an older brother, not younger, and was born on Nov. 8, 1905 -- not 1909. (Katharine Hepburn, whose centenary was May 12 this year, claimed for years that she was two years younger than she actually was and that her birthday was Nov. 8.)

PAKIER--Teri. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Teri Pakier, beloved sister of Stephen Greenberg and sister-in-law of Sandra Greenberg, whose dedication, and boundless generosity, sets an example of philanthropic leadership imbued with compassionate generosity, which profoundly impacts our community and enriches the lives of millions around the globe. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sandra and Stephen; to their children, Seth, Sindy and Scott; and to the entire Greenberg family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

An article in The Arts yesterday about the impact of plunging CD sales on big music companies and the companies' efforts to sell more recordings misidentified the electronic file format in which Apple's iTunes will sell EMI's music catalog without protection against copying. It is AAC, not MP3.

STADELMAN--Egon, P. A native of Berlin, Germany, adored husband of Marian (nee Stern) passed away peacefully in his home in Riverdale at age 96 on May 27, 2007 after suffering a stroke four and a half years ago. He was the son of Ferdinand and Margarete Stadelman. His father died in WWI. His mother was a victim of the Holocaust. During WWII, Egon proudly served in the US 76th Infantry Division. After the war, he worked as Special Events Officer for German Affairs with the NBC International Division until 1968. From then on, he worked in the same capacity for the Voice of America. In 1968, he joined the German Language Newspaper, New York Staats-zeitung as drama and music critic. He became Managing Editor of the newspaper until 1995. Stadelman was awarded the Great Cross of Germany and Austria for being instrumental in furthering the cultural relations between these countries and the U.S. In 1999 his autobiography Ein Leben lang Journalist was published. The cremation at Ferncliff Cemetery was private.

An article last Wednesday about a decision by the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, to remove at least five members of Community Board 6 who oppose the Atlantic Yards development project -- which Mr. Markowitz supports -- misstated the reason for the absence of a response by Mr. Markowitz. At the time the article was being reported, Mr. Markowitz could not be reached by his aides because he was on a ship at sea, had no telephone access and was not regularly checking his e-mail messages. He did not ''refuse'' to comment.

An appeals court upheld the conviction of two senior executives at the Samsung Group on charges that they helped the only son of its reclusive chairman, Lee Kun Hee, inherit control of Samsung, the country's largest conglomerate. CHOE SANG-HUN

PALIN--Caryl. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and extend our deepest condolences to her family. James Mitchell and Tony Manning $(6$)PALIN--Caryl. The National Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of Caryl Palin, a member of our New York Chapter Executive Board. The Palin family has been an integral part of Einstein's Family Day in the Hamptons, and Caryl's participation will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to our very dear friends, Roxanne and Dean Palin, to Caryl's beloved husband Michael, and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, MD The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean National Women's Division Bambi Felberbaum National President Judy R. Rosenberg Chairwoman Executive Committee Jackie Harris Hochberg President, New York Chapter

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former President Bill Clinton have delivered another one-two punch that reflects their combined political power: corralling the endorsement of Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles, one of the most powerful Democrats in California and among the most influential Hispanics in the nation. With the endorsement, which is to be announced today in Los Angeles, Mrs. Clinton has outflanked her Democratic presidential rivals -- including Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, the first Hispanic to seek the party's nomination -- in a crucial primary state with a large number of Hispanic voters and Democratic convention delegates.

Local 802, the union representing Broadway musicians, has agreed on a three-year contract with Broadway producers, a deal that was overwhelmingly approved by its members. Under the terms, the musicians agreed to give up two wage increases in return for increased contributions from producers to the union's health plan. In 2003, the last time the two sides met for negotiations, the musicians went on strike, and Broadway theaters went dark for four days. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

GREW--Henry Sturgis, of New York City and West Palm Beach, Florida, died suddenly on May 25th, 2007 in Florida. He had lived in Boston and Newport, Rhode Island. He is survived by a sister, Selina Grew Rossiter of Lincoln, Massachusetts, and two brothers, Joseph Clark Grew of Boston and Robert Sturgis Grew of Raleigh, North Carolina; as well as five nieces, four nephews, six grandnieces and one grandnephew. A memorial Service will be held on August 4, at 11 am, at St. Mary's By-The-Sea, Northeast Harbor, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Dublin School, Inc., Dublin, New Hampshire.

COLTEN--Harvey R. M.D., was an esteemed colleague who contributed to Columbia University Medical Center in immeasurable ways during his time as vice president and professor of pediatrics. In administering our research and academic programs as CUMC vice president, Dr. Colten added value to our research infrastructure and refined our criteria for faculty appointments, promotions, and searches. His role at Columbia followed a long successful career in patient care, education, and research at some of our country's leading academic health sciences institutions. He served as dean of Northwestern University's medical school, chairman of pediatrics at Washington University's medical school, clinical professor of pediatrics at the University of California, San Francisco, professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School, director of the cystic fibrosis program at Children's Hospital in Boston, and an NIH researcher. We were honored to benefit from the scientific acumen, boundless energy, and interdisciplinary wisdom that made Dr. Colten one of academic medicine's best. We offer our condolences to his family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive V.P. for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Columbia University Medical Center

An article on Sunday about early and absentee voting in next year's presidential primaries misidentified the academic affiliation of Paul Gronke, a professor of political science who is an expert on early voting. He is at Reed College in Portland, Ore., not the University of Oregon.

DEMMERLE--Peter K., on May 24, 2007. The partners, counsel, associates and administrative staff of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae deeply mourn the passing of our esteemed partner, colleague and dear friend, Peter, after his courageous and inspirational 8-year battle with ALS. Peter was a leader in the firm's insurance practice, particularly in the 1990s when he was instrumental in preserving the trading position in the United States of the Lloyd's insurance market. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Kate, and his four daughters, Cara, Alice, Tessa and Nina. Funeral mass on Wednesday, May 30th at 10:30 a.m., St. Michael's Catholic Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made in Peter's memory to charities that support ALS research.

Wells Fargo, one of the largest companies in the student loan business, has agreed to follow a code of conduct developed by the New York attorney general's office governing relationships between lenders and universities. The code, which came as a result of a continuing investigation by the attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, prohibits practices including giving a university money or other incentives in exchange for steering students to a particular lender. Mr. Cuomo's investigation identified instances in which loan companies paid universities based on the amounts borrowed by students, as well as questionable ties between financial aid administrators and lenders. The latest agreement means that the five largest student loan companies in the country have agreed to follow the code. JONATHAN D. GLATER

GRASS--Louise. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of our cherished friend Louise Grass. A dedicated humanitarian known for her work on behalf of Israel, the Jewish people and the cause of higher education, Louise Grass, along with her beloved husband Alex, maintained a longstanding commitment to advancing human progress in myriad ways. Louise and Alex Grass, a former Chairman of the Board of Governors of The Hebrew University and an Honorary Vice President of AFHU, enhanced the University's intellectual growth and international stature in ways that have benefited Israel's people and humanity. Collectively and individually, the Grasses have made the world a better place. We extend our profound sympathies to Alex and the entire Grass family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Prof. Menachem Magidor, President AFHU Ira Lee Sorkin, Chairman George A. Schieren, Pres. Peter T. Willner, National Exec. Dir.

To the Editor: Re ''Out of Grief Grows Desire for Birth Certificates for Stillborn Babies'' (news article, May 22): Our daughter Caroline was stillborn. Her papers consist of a death certificate and receipts from the hospital, the cemetery and the funeral home. That's a lot of sad.

To the Editor: ''Chaos Is Seen in Iraq Exit, but Experts Split on Degree'' (front page, May 27) shows that we are still failing to address the real questions about Iraq. Rather than discuss the violence that would follow a United States withdrawal, we should consider the desolation and death caused by a continued American presence. Rather than address what's needed to make an American-imposed government work, consider whether such an artifice has the potential to do anything more than cause suffering and hostility, if not among Iraqi sects, then between Iraqis and Americans.

FLASTER--Edith. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member Edith Flaster. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein Howard F. Sharfstein, President

A 46-year-old Brooklyn man was found shot to death in his apartment yesterday afternoon, and his brother was being sought as the leading suspect, the police said. The victim, whose name had not been released pending family notification, was shot several times in the torso. His body was found shortly after 3 p.m. in the apartment at 109 Butler Street in Boerum Hill. JENNIFER 8. LEE

AT a symposium on Spanish cuisine last November, I anticipated two days of deconstructed, itsy-bitsy food, the hallmark of molecular cuisine that has captivated top chefs worldwide. But amid the clouds of garden soil foam (no lie) and quivering plates of clam jelly, what captured my attention was the sweetly pungent perfume that wafted from the food station of María José San Román, chef of Monastrell in Alicante. It was the aroma of the dried crimson stigma of the purple crocus sativus linnaeus -- saffron.

MATTHEWS--Kenneth. Age 60, the ''Mayor of 93rd Street'' passed away in his home on May 28, 2007. Beloved husband of Jane, father of Joshua and Jesse, brother of Robert, and friend of too many to mention. An iconoclast in every way he left a mark on everything he touched. Nothing will ever be the same. The family will be sitting Shiva at the Matthews' home, 23 East 93rd St., Wednesday and Thursday night.

When Shawn Green walked into the doctor's office yesterday morning, he was not wearing an immobilizing boot on his broken right foot. ''Thought I was going to impress him,'' Green said. ''Apparently not.''

On a Memorial Day evening of low-rated television all around, NBC's broadcast of the 56th annual ''Miss Universe'' pageant, won by Riyo Mori, below, of Japan, delivered the event's lowest ratings in 12 years in the sought-after demographic of adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated the show attracted 7.1 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., about 2.5 million fewer than last year's broadcast on a Sunday in July. CBS led the night over all with a lineup of repeats. ABC and NBC tied for second among adults 18 to 49. Wedged between ABC's ''Wife Swap'' at 8 (6.3 million) and ''Supernanny'' at 10 (5.3 million), the debut of ABC's new reality show, ''Ex-Wives Club,'' made an unexceptional showing at 9 (5.3 million). Fox finished a distant fourth for the night as the official time-period premiere of ''On the Lot'' earned just 2.9 million viewers from 8 to 10. BENJAMIN TOFF

WHAT'S that noise? Sort of like a whoosh, a collective exhale, a sigh of relaxation? Is it a signal that summer may finally be upon us? Regardless of the calendar, here in the Northeast Memorial Day is the figurative beginning of summer. Sure, school has a few more lumbering weeks to go, and the water isn't yet warm enough to shed the wet suit. But outdoor cooking has begun, and that, my friends, means it's time to open up that top button, loosen up those shoulders and allow that pent-up anxiety to ease itself away.

GALAMBOS--Peter. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Peter Galambos. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Irene and family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas and Lawrence Glass, Pres.

BUMPED FLIERS TO WAIT DAYS -- So many airplanes are expected to be full during the summer travel season that passengers bumped from flights could end up waiting days for a seat on another flight to the same destination. [Page A1.] TOO CHEAP FOR ITS OWN GOOD? -- A report prepared for Wal-Mart offers an explanation why the retailer has stumbled so badly when it comes to selling higher-end merchandise: ''Our low prices actually suggest low quality.'' [C1.] COMPUTER RETAILER IS SOLD -- The CDW Corporation, a leading online computer retailer, said that it had agreed to sell itself to Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in cash, the latest big acquisition by a private equity firm. [C1.] THE DIGITIZATION OF PEN AND PAPER -- An ambitious new pen-based computer system that could bridge the gap between paper and the digital world, and perhaps even change the way millions of people interact with the Internet, will be introduced at a technology conference. [C1.] A $95.6 BILLION BID FOR AMRO -- The Royal Bank of Scotland Group and two other European banks made a formal $95.6 billion bid for ABN Amro of the Netherlands, challenging Barclays in what would be the richest banking takeover. Some 79 percent of the offer, more than investors expected, will be paid in cash and the rest in Royal Bank of Scotland shares. [C2.] A CHANGE AT NBC -- NBC Universal shook up its entertainment operations, hiring one of the hottest young production talents in television, Ben Silverman, as a co-chairman of both the entertainment unit and its TV studio. [C3.] SELLING A PALER SHADE -- Cosmetics and skin care companies are expanding their product lines and advertising budgets in India, offering a message that the modern Indian woman is independent, in charge -- and does not have to live with her dark skin. Advertising. [C5.] DEATH SENTENCE IN CHINA -- The former director of China's top food and drug safety agency was sentenced to death after pleading guilty to corruption and accepting bribes, the state-controlled news media reported. The unusually harsh sentence was ordered amid heightened concern about the quality and safety of China's food and drug system. [A7.] EASING FINANCIAL REGULATIONS -- New York's governor, Eliot Spitzer, is creating a commission focused on streamlining regulation in the financial services industry. [C1.] FEW ANSWERS ON RECALL -- Advanced Medical Optics offered no explanation on why its leading contact lens care product might be causing eye infections. And it said it would be next week before it could gauge the financial impact of the recall of its lens cleaner, prompting a sharp sell-off in the company's stock. [C2.] ZOELLICK CHOSEN FOR WORLD BANK -- President Bush has chosen Robert B. Zoellick, a senior diplomat and trade envoy who became a top executive at Goldman Sachs last year, to lead the World Bank and try to heal the bitter rifts left by the ouster of Paul D. Wolfowitz. Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said that Mr. Zoellick, above, had emerged as the first choice of economic ministers around the world, who have been calling for someone to overcome the bank's credibility problems among donor and recipient countries alike. [A1.] RULING ON PAY DISPARITY -- The Supreme Court made it harder for many workers to sue their employers for discrimination in pay, insisting in a 5-to-4 decision on a tight timeframe to file such cases. The dissenters said the ruling, in a case involving Goodyear Tire, ignored workplace realities. [A1.] FINANCIAL STRATEGY ON SUDAN -- The Bush administration's new sanctions against Sudan aim to squeeze the country's economy by freezing Sudanese companies out of American financial institutions and curtailing their dollar transactions. [C3.] EUROPEAN FARMERS' NEW CROP -- Farmers in Europe, following their counterparts in the Americas, are beginning to grow crops that can be turned into fuels meant to produce fewer emissions than gas or oil. [C3.] BOEING'S BIGGEST DEAL IN RUSSIA -- Boeing sold 15 of its next-generation 787 jets to a private Russian airline, in a deal valued at about $2.4 billion, Boeing's largest sale in the former Soviet Union. [C10.] MARKETS EDGE UP -- Stocks ended higher, but China's move to cool its stock market raised concern about a global equity sell-off. [C10.] PRINTING WEB PAGES -- Hewlett-Packard will announce a new wide-ranging strategy that will make the trillions of pages crowding the Internet easier to print out. [C8.] SLOWING CHINA'S STOCK MARKET -- China's finance ministry announced that it would triple the tax on stock trades, a move aimed at braking what many business executives and economists inside and outside China now see as a stock market bubble. [C8.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. I.B.M. disclosed that it was taking on $11.5 billion in debt to finance an acceleration of its stock repurchase plan, which the company believes is one of the largest such steps ever. (AP) VeriSign, which manages the dot-com and dot-net domain names registry, said that its chief executive, Stratton D. Sclavos, had resigned for undisclosed reasons. (AP)

THERE may be no bad way to prepare soft-shell crabs. They contain so much moisture they're just about impossible to overcook, and they cook so quickly they're hard to undercook. They have built-in crispness: that slightly leathery soft shell always has some snap, and it's enhanced by any kind of cooking.
