I was going to move on this week and write a column about end-of-school-year dyspepsia, but your answers to last week's post have been so voluminous and so passionate that I don't feel ready to let that topic - the response to Madeleine McCann's abduction - go just yet. You will note the phrasing: the topic here (as last week) is "the response to Madeleine McCann's abduction," not the abduction itself.

It's always interesting to read the comments on this and other Yankees blogs. Many fans make terrific points. But one thing people sometimes say is that the Yankees simply don't try hard enough, or they're content to collect their big paychecks and lose.
Is this the beginning of the end of an independent Dow Jones & Company?

The seemingly endless bidding process for the state's horse racing franchise took its latest turn this evening, as one of the bidders, Empire Racing, accused two of the others, the Excelsior Group and the New York Racing Association, of holding secret talks in violation of state procurement laws.

Gata Kamsky of the United States and Peter Leko of Hungary won their fourth round games to clinch victories in their preliminary candidates matches. Alexander Grischuk and Evgeny Bareev, both of Russia, also won and now have commanding 3 to 1 leads over their opponents (3.5 points are needed to win a match, with a win worth one point and a draw worth 0.5). The matches are taking place in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.
The Times's A. O. Scott reviews "Knocked Up" from the director of "The 40-Year-Old Virgin."
Jessica Michault of the IHT discusses fashion at the Cannes Film Festival.

Although I didn't hear back this afternoon from Georgette Farkas, a spokeswoman for Daniel Boulud, I did get a call from Alexandre A. Montagu, a lawyer who represents Mr. Boulud's restaurants, at least in relation to trademarks and in regard to issues like the one I described in a post earlier today.

Former Senator John Edwards, a Democratic presidential candidate, told an interviewer on Wednesday that he had read the classified October 2002 National Intelligence Estimate before voting to authorize force in Iraq, even though he had previously maintained that he had not read the report and had only been briefed on it.
Did anyone have the same reaction that I did this past January to President Bush's State of the Union address?

At his news conference in Manhattan today, Rudolph W. Giuliani revealed a new detail about his rapprochement with his old police commissioner, William Bratton. He said that he met in Los Angeles yesterday with Mr. Bratton, who now is the police chief there.

Most people have reacted enthusiastically to Al Gore's new book, "The Assault on Reason." He seems to have hit a nerve with his assessment of what ails our democracy - the unchecked power of special interests backed by big money, the pervasive influence of mindless and addictive television, and the relentless triumph of image and style over content, which makes us read more articles about John Edwards' haircuts than about our failing education system. "Gore understands our problems," as one reviewer put it, "as does no other politician of our time."

Mercury Interactive became the second company to pay a fine to settle charges that it illegally backdated stock options, regulators announced on Thursday. But the Securities and Exchange Commission said it is also suing four former executives, alleging fraud and deception to to enrich themselves and select employees.

"Seeking to end America's isolation on the issue of global climate change, President Bush called today for the 15 countries that are major producers of greenhouse gases to confer this fall and adopt a common goal on curbing emissions," The Times tells us.

Lehman Brothers plans a $500 million initial public offering of a private-equity fund next month, even after similar vehicles by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Management have struggled to return investors' money, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources.

Is that someone's cat in a living room window? And a neighbor taking out the garbage? Wait -- The Battery Tunnel in Brooklyn. Haven't cameras been banned from there since 9/11? And is that a burglary in progress or just another Spider-Man wannabe? O.K., now that is really disturbing: E.T.'s ghost!?!
After learning of Wachovia's plan to buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion, Wall Street immediately set about betting on which regional brokerage firms might be acquired next.

Shares of Molson Coors Brewing were up more than 2 percent to $92.08 on Thursday, but it was the frothy action in the company's options that raised eyebrows at OptionMonster.com. The Web site noted heavy trading in June options to buy Molson Coors shares at $95 apiece, a move that it attributed to "takeover chatter." These options would see a big jump in value if Molson were acquired or taken private at a premium in the next month.
Just how weird are your daydreams?

Louis Freeh, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation under President Bill Clinton, plans to endorse Republican presidential candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani this afternoon, according to officials close to the campaign. The two have been longtime colleagues; both were federal prosecutors in the Southern District, where Mr. Giuliani served as United States Attorney.
Enough with the baggy polo. Lose the pleated pants. After years of languishing in the bunkers of fashion, golf gear steps out.

Remember when dot-com companies were being criticized for underpricing their initial public offerings in order to create first-day trading pops, and helping expand the market bubble? The World Bank thinks much the same thing is happening now -- in China.

William Lerach, the star plaintiff's attorney who has become a target of a federal investigation into illegal kickbacks by Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, has told clients and others that he will retire, Fortune's Legal Pad reported Wednesday evening and The Washington Post on Thursday.

How many times have you arrived in Paris for a leisurely visit, suddenly paralyzed by a well known tourist trauma known simply as: Fear of French. The FOF antidote is relatively painless and as accessible as an mp3 player or iPod (make that eePod if you want to pronounce it correctly in French.)

Whether or not the world needed another profile of Carl Icahn (who, depending on the era, is variously described as a "financier," a "corporate raider" or an "activist investor"), Fortune magazine has a long one in its latest issue. The general thesis is that although the "New Icahn" may be different from the old one, his, ahem, expansive personality hasn't changed that much through the years.
Earthquake-resistance technology! Nanotubes! The latest rackets have far-out features that give players more control, better feel and a hard-to-miss sweet spot.
The competition to digitally map New York City is heating up.

A previous bid to invest in Delphi may have fallen through earlier this year, but the bankrupt auto parts maker may have found a new set of backers. In a regulatory filing on Thursday, Highland Capital Management said that it had reached a confidentiality agreement with the company, the first step in potentially creating an investment plan as Delphi prepares to exit bankruptcy protection.
Can two measly letters of the alphabet be proprietary? Off-limits? Denied even to someone whose initials match them?

It didn't take long for the first joint appearance by Bill Gates and Steve Jobs in 20 years to get around to the latest chapter in their intense, decades-long rivalry: The Apple television ads pitting a cool Mac Guy against a dorky PC Guy.
Last week, there were snakes on a plane -- almost. The man was stopped at customs. This week, another man stepped boldly into a movie-imitating mission, and succeeded.
China’s rush to build megacities is part of a major push to spread China’s economic boom to the vast interior.
Just how Canadian is telecom mogul Richard Li?

It was just about the strangest call I'd ever received from Microsoft. "We have a new product we want to show you," said the PR woman (I'm paraphrasing). "But we can't tell you what it is, or even what category. But it's truly revolutionary. It's going to change the way people work with their computers."
Following is the draft script of the weekly "Only in New York" audio podcast. Listen at left or download it to a portable player.
... that what's wrong with humor videos online.

As Wachovia revs its deal-making machinery, the bank seems to be spreading its advisory work around -- though the names are familiar ones for the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank. A year after its $25 billion purchase of Golden West Financial, it turned to some different firms for financial advice and legal counsel on Thursday's $6.8 billion deal for A.G. Edwards.

Genesco, the maker of Johnston & Murphy and Dockers brand shoes, has received several preliminary takeover offers from private-equity firms that could rival a rejected $1.2 billion hostile offer from Foot Locker, the New York Post reported Thursday citing unnamed sources.

Today's front page of the "Daily Express" in London, which bills itself as the world's greatest newspaper, screams "House Prices Still Soaring." The lead article says that the average home in England and Wales shot up by more than £1,200 -- or $2,400 -- every month in the past year despite Bank of England attempts to dampen the market with hikes to the base rate.
Microsoft's version of the multi-touch computer adds one very cool, though impractical, twist: interaction with other electronics.

USA Today has an interview with Fred D. Thompson, the former Republican senator from Tennessee and "Law & Order" actor (though not for much longer). Speaking with Susan Page, he "not only makes it clear that he plans to run, he describes how he aims to do it," she writes.

If you really want to splurge, I recently visited a couple of hotel rooms in the center of Rome where I would happily spend the rest of my life -- thanks to their magnificent views and private terraces.

Northwest Airlines emerged from bankruptcy protection Thursday, and its new shares were set to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speaking with the Star Tribune, Doug Steenland, the company's chief executive, acknowledged that the airline considered various options during its Chapter 11 stay, including a merger with another airline -- such as Delta Air Lines -- or bringing in a private equity investor.
“Four Lane Highway” stars Frederick Weller as Sean, a famous (dead) writer’s son who became a writer himself but has been blocked for some time.
Sweetness and whimsy fill the screen to capacity in “I’m Reed Fish,” a rural coming-of-age tale that’s so laid-back that its cast is almost horizontal.
Unfolding in a decrepit, present-day Moscow, “Day Watch” dazzles and confuses with equal determination.

Brocade Communications Systems has reached a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over charges that it illegally backdated its stock options, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources.
A familiar underdog story told with unusual sensitivity, Davis Guggenheim’s “Gracie” depicts the obstacles faced by a young girl who dreams of playing on her high school soccer team.

Rupert Murdoch got the first show of support on Wednesday for his $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company when T. Rowe Price, Dow Jones' largest outside shareholder, said that News Corporation's $60 a share bid is attractive and should be considered.
Motorola on Wednesday revealed the final tally of votes in the proxy fight waged by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, and according to the numbers, Mr. Icahn lost soundly.

The Spanish government filed a lawsuit in a United States federal court on Wednesday seeking to block claims to any Spanish property recovered from shipwrecks by Odyssey Marine Exploration, whose biggest investors include several hedge funds.

As deal-making sweeps through the real estate investment trust sector, Morgan Stanley has a made a bet on a real estate investment trust down under. The bank has agreed to buy the Investa Property Group of Australia, for 4.7 billion Australian dollars ($3.9 billion).
California's First District Court of Appeal brushed aside claims Wednesday that Overstock.com, the online retailer, tried to gag a financial analysis company when it sued for libel two years ago.

Post-nuptial agreements, once a novelty, are becoming increasingly more popular -- and in some cases mandatory -- in the world of hedge funds. The Financial Times reports that the post-nuptial agreement, where the married parties sign on the dotted line after the wedding bells have rung, is soaring in popularity among newly wealthy hedge fund managers.

Jo-Ann Stores is on the auction block with a price tag just shy of $1 billion, and final bids for the specialty chain are due in June, according to The Deal.com. Lehman Brothers, which was hired to run the auction for the Hudson, Ohio, company, one of the largest retailers of fabrics and arts and crafts supplies in the United States, has approached a select group of middle-market private equity firms, according to the report.

Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, Citigroup's largest individual shareholder and a vocal critic of the bank's lagging performance, said he has confidence in Charles O. Prince III, the bank's chief executive, and does not want to see a breakup of the bank.

The British government said Wednesday that it was selling a 2.2 billion pound ($4.3 billion) stake in British Energy, the nuclear power generator, as the company announced a sharp rise in profit and its first dividend since a state-backed rescue operation in 2002.

And then there were three. Bain Capital became the third buyout firm this week to quit a team of bidders considering an offer for the Coles Group, Australia's second-largest retailer, leaving the Carlyle Group, the Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group in the running.
Is a pharmaceutical company whose biggest-selling drug is considered as dangerous as heroin or LSD a good investment?

Ceridian, a human resources company, said Wednesday night that it had sold itself to the private equity firm Thomas H. Lee Partners and the specialty insurer Fidelity National Financial for $5.3 billion.

One day before announcing it would spend $6.8 billion to buy the retail brokerage A.G. Edwards, Wachovia talked about a different kind of green. On Wednesday, the nation's fourth-largest bank said it would build only environmentally friendly branches by the end of 2008, starting with eight it plans to open soon in southern California. The move follows large "green" commitments recently announced by the nation's largest banks, Citigroup and Bank of America.

Barclays Bank, which is competing to buy ABN Amro in the world's largest banking takeover, has agreed to pay about $10.9 million to settle charges of illegal insider trading in bond securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday.
Kobe Bryant said a lot of things in a lot of interviews yesterday. At the end of the day, it was still unclear where he stood:

Over the last five decades, the Small Business Administration has propelled the likes of Federal Express, Intel, Staples and thousands of lesser-known small businesses. But advocates say recent policy changes and severe budget and staffing cuts in the last six years have left the agency unable to fulfill its mission to provide programs and services to the nation's 25 million small companies, which the agency defines as businesses with 500 or fewer workers.

CBS confirmed on Wednesday that it had acquired Last.FM, an online radio and social-networking site, for $280 million to expand its digital offerings. CBS, one of the nation's biggest radio broadcasters, said the founders of the five-year-old service would continue to operate it as an independent unit.
Chinese stock markets plummeted Wednesday and continued their decline in early trading Thursday after the authorities in Beijing moved to impose higher taxes on trading activity.

As part of its push to become a bigger player in cancer drugs, Genzyme said Wednesday that it would buy out a business partner, Bioenvision, for $345 million, consolidating its ownership of a cancer treatment to which the two companies had been sharing rights.

Viacom has agreed to sell its Famous Music unit, a publishing catalog with rights to about 125,000 songs, to Sony/ATV Music Publishing for about $370 million. The deal, which was announced Wednesday, includes a wide range of songs, among them classics like "That's Amore" and "Moon River" and newer hits by songwriters including Linda Perry and Akon.

Farzad Nazem, Yahoo's chief technology officer and one of its longest-serving executives, said he would leave on June 8 after 11 years at the company. Yahoo said its co-founder, Jerry Yang, would assume Mr. Nazem's responsibilities while it searches for a replacement.
Prosecutors rested their racketeering and fraud case against the media mogul Conrad M. Black on Wednesday, minutes after announcing they were dropping one money-laundering count against him.

Fox Interactive Media, a unit of the News Corporation, has agreed to acquire the photo-storage site Photobucket, just weeks after a public spat in which the popular networking site MySpace partly blocked content from Photobucket.
Following its $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick earlier this month, Google has gone a mini-shopping spree this week.

Radian6 Technologies, whose software helps public relations firms track blogging and user-generated media coverage of their clients, took in $4 million in seed funding from Brightspark Ventures and BDC Venture Capital.

eBay has acquired StumbleUpon, a Web browsing recommendation site, for $75 million in cash. StumbleUpon recommends pages within sites like Flickr, MySpace or YouTube based on "thumbs up" or "thumbs down" votes from other Web users with shared interests. It has 2.3 million users and is adding more rapidly.

Wachovia said Thursday it would buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion in cash and stock, forming the second-largest retail stock brokerage in the United States after Merrill Lynch. The deal for St. Louis-based A.G. Edwards marks the latest big grab for Wachovia Securities, Wachovia's brokerage unit, which nearly doubled in size in 2003 when it took control of Prudential Financial's brokerage division.
The New York painter Hunt Slonem purchases a plantation house in Louisiana that a psychic told him to buy.

President Bush has nominated Bob Zoellick for the World Bank, and I think it's a good choice. Zoellick and I have had our differences -- he once blasted me publicly for focusing too much on the negative in Darfur -- but he's intelligent and really cares about these issues. He also understands trade and private capital flows, and those are the best way to get Africa going again.

President Bush has finally gotten around to doing what he should have done in April 2004: Imposing sanctions on Sudanese leaders for the genocide in Darfur. It's a step in the right direction, but I still don't see signs that the administration is tackling the issue with the energy and enthusiasm necessary.
There's a giraffe in the bedroom, creepy-crawlies in the dining room and birds everywhere.
McKim, Mead & White, reinterpreted by Hass and more.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
American workers, on average, spend 45 hours a week at work, but describe 16 of those hours as "unproductive," according to a study by Microsoft.

That's what John Gibbons, the straight-shooting manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, thought about Alex Rodriguez's verbal interference in the top of the ninth inning of the Yankees' 10-5 victory on Wednesday.

Hong Kong's annual dragon boat races combine a fast, furious sport, ancient Chinese lore and an all-out carnival atmosphere.There will be races all month (more info below), but the Stanley races, which take place June 19, are the biggest and most popular. More than 200 teams compete from 8 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. But the party -- on hired junks and yachts ringing the bay, and at packed seaside pubs and restaurants -- goes on late into the night.Dragon boating is a little like Western rowing, only spiced up with the chaos of a Chinatown street festival. Up to 20 paddlers cram, in pairs, into long, narrow wooden boats that -- to the delight of onlookers -- are apt to tipping over at the hands of the unskilled. The front is adorned with a colorful, ornate dragon's head. This is also where the drummer sits, to beat out time for the rowers to row to. And what's there not to love about a sport with a designated drummer? At the back is the steerer, like a coxswain.The races are short -- sprints, actually -- done in heats. It's simple enough that everyone from the little kids playing on the beach to the drunk guys on their yachts can follow the action.
The Yankees can only hope that the last game of the Toronto series could propel them to their next series, in Boston, thinking positively, even if the standings hardly matter anymore.
Gotham Early Music Scene hopes to bring cohesiveness and vitality to the city’s patchwork of early-music groups.
Newly constructed houses have ruined a couple’s scenery, but now they turn their gaze inward, to the garden of their own making.
The meeting between Mahmoud Abbas and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert is expected to take place in the Palestinian territories for the first time, aides said.
Michelle Wie said she withdrew because she hurt one of her wrists, but she was also in danger of being disqualified from playing in another L.P.G.A. event this year.
New Jersey Republicans filed a lawsuit today charging that Gov. Jon S. Corzine was violating the state’s open records act by refusing to release e-mail messages he exchanged with his ex-girlfriend.
The former C.I.A. operative at the heart of the leak scandal sued the agency today over its refusal to allow her to publish a memoir.
Jean-Claude Brialy was a dashing leading man of the French New Wave films of the 1960s and ’70s.
The sequencing of James D. Watson’s genome could be the gateway to an era of personalized genomic medicine.
Columbia University will also submit its student loan operation to monitoring by the attorney general.
The search for five British civilians kidnapped from an Iraqi government building intensified today and the Iraqi government pledged its support for an investigation.
The infected man’s father-in-law insisted that neither he nor his laboratory was the source of the infection.
Webdenda.
President Bush called today for the 15 countries that are major producers of greenhouse gases to confer this fall and adopt a common goal on curbing emissions.
The suspect in the fatal poisoning of Alexander V. Litvinenko said today that a British intelligence agency and a Russian tycoon had organized the killing.
The ambush took place amid reports of fighting near where a helicopter crashed Wednesday night.
Tim Duncan, who led the Spurs to titles in 1999, 2003 and 2005, was at his casually dominant best, with an effortless 21 points in 28 minutes. Tony Parker added 21 points.
Bill Gates and Steven P. Jobs appeared in public to relive old battles and speculate about the future of digital culture and technology.
The Blue Jays were incensed after Alex Rodriguez interfered with a play at third base in the ninth inning. The Yankees went on to snap a five-game losing streak.
The A.C.L.U. filed suit against a Boeing subsidiary, alleging that the company provided flight plans for C.I.A. aircraft transporting terrorism suspects to overseas prisons.

Representative Sylvester Turner, left, Democrat of Houston and a longtime ally of Speaker Tom Craddick, Republican of Midland, said he was joining the candidates challenging Mr. Craddick for the House’s top spot in 2009. Mr. Turner, the speaker pro tempore, is the seventh lawmaker to announce his candidacy, part of a movement among Republicans and Democrats unhappy with Mr. Craddick’s leadership. “I don’t ever want to have another legislative session like the one just completed where taking care of the people’s business took a back seat to political agendas,” he said.
A marijuana advocate was convicted again in federal court of illegally growing hundreds of marijuana plants that he said were meant to treat sick people, which state law allows.
Two humpback whales may have found their way back into the Pacific Ocean through San Francisco Bay after wandering off their migration path for more than two weeks.
Sex offenders who lived within 1,000 feet of a school or day care center before lawmakers made it illegal cannot be evicted, a county court judge ruled.
New Orleans City Park, a landmark inundated by salt-laden floodwater when Hurricane Katrina struck in 2005, will receive $8.6 million in federal help.
A man accused of shooting six women, one fatally, at a Jewish center in Seattle pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity as prosecutors added 11 counts against him.

An internal investigation at the Justice Department into whether politics influenced hiring practices is being expanded after last week’s testimony by a former senior aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales.
A Guantánamo detainee apparently committed suicide Wednesday, military officials said in a succinct announcement last night.
Barry Zito produced a dominant pitching performance, pitching seven scoreless innings in the Giants’ shutout victory over Tom Glavine and the Mets.
Nascar is considering opening up its restrictive testing policy, which several teams have already skirted this season.
A federal judge has ordered a third trial in a lawsuit by a woman who blamed Merck’s painkiller Vioxx for the heart attack that killed her husband.
For a few hours in Midtown Manhattan, the Yankees’ hideous start to the season was essentially forgotten as Roger Clemens and former Yankee stars visited with fans.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a deadly clash between the police and supporters of Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, an ethnic Uzbek strongman in northern Afghanistan, referred incorrectly to Rais Qurban, deputy leader of a pro-Dostum youth movement. Mr. Qurban was one of the people reportedly killed; he was not the resident who said he thought that Rais Qurban had been killed.
Annika Sorenstam, who will be the Ginn Tribute host, is set to return to competitive golf in this week’s $2.6 million event.

A front-page article on Tuesday about a push by lawmakers to pass subsidies for coal misidentified the state represented by the Republican Senator Larry E. Craig, who is a supporter of the coal-to-liquid fuel concept. It is Idaho, not Wyoming.

An article yesterday about Congressional districts where Republican supporters of the war are taking political heat referred incorrectly to a House resolution on the president’s decision to increase troops in Iraq, a decision opposed by Representative Mark Steven Kirk, Republican of Illinois. The resolution opposed the president’s plan, it did not back it.

A headline and picture caption on Monday with the Critics’ Choice column, about new CDs, referred incorrectly to R. Kelly, who has a new album, “Double Up.” He is an R&B singer, not a “rap” or a “hip-hop” performer.

A picture caption in some copies on Tuesday with a sports article about Anaheim’s victory against Ottawa in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals misidentified the Ducks’ player in front of the Senators’ net when his team tied the score in the third period. It was Brad May — not Ryan Getzlaf, who scored the goal but who was not in the picture.

An article on Saturday about the robbery of Representative Rodney P. Frelinghuysen in Washington’s Georgetown neighborhood referred incompletely to his Congressional district, New Jersey’s 11th. It comprises all of Morris County and parts of Somerset, Essex, Sussex and Passaic counties. It is not limited to Morris and part of Somerset County.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on May 23 about plans to save a house designed by Paul Rudolph from demolition by moving it to Catskill, N.Y., from Watch Hill, R.I., misspelled the name by which it is known. It is the Cerrito House, not Cerritto.

A film review last Thursday about “Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End” misstated a word in a line spoken by the character Lord Beckett early in the film. He says, “The immaterial has become immaterial,” not that it has become “material.” The review also misidentified the site of a meeting of the Pirate Brethren Court. It is Shipwreck Cove, not Singapore.

An article on Tuesday about new sites of variation in the human genome that increase the risk of breast cancer misstated the number of sites found by a team at the Harvard School of Public Health. Of the six new sites that have been identified, the Harvard team co-discovered one, not two.
Corrections: For the Record

An E-Commerce Report in Business Day on Monday about a new breed of Web site developers, and the use of niche sites like one on Ford Mustangs, misstated the year that the Mustang was available. It was introduced in 1964; it was not available in 1957.

PARAMUS, N.J., May 30 — After a week of confusion and worry that led the mayor here to step in and close a middle school, state environmental workers on Wednesday carted away two truckloads of soil contaminated with old, banned pesticides unearthed last fall.

An article on Monday about Israeli-Palestinian fighting referred incorrectly to two Palestinian gunmen killed by Israeli police in Jerusalem on Saturday. They were permanent residents of Jerusalem, not Israeli citizens.

A fare increase averaging 9.6 percent will take effect on New Jersey Transit trains and buses tomorrow. The increase, approved in April, will be the third since 2002. The income will help the agency close a $60 million budget gap and expand service, New Jersey Transit said. Train and interstate bus tickets will increase by 9.9 percent, while the price of tickets for a single one-zone bus and for local light-rail service will rise by 8 percent, to $1.35 from $1.25. Each weekday, New Jersey Transit serves 857,000 riders, a record high, the agency said.

A private club serving Princeton University students and alumni is entitled to a property tax exemption as a historic site, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday. The club, University Cottage Club, is situated in a century-old mansion in Princeton Borough. The borough and the New Jersey Historic Preservation Office opposed the exemption, which the borough said would cost it $60,000 in tax revenue. The club applied for the exemption in 2001 and was told that 12 days of public access each year were required to qualify; the state later changed the rules to require 94 days of public access, and the Supreme Court found that state officials could not change the rules after the application was submitted.

The city will open a center in East Harlem to improve the treatment of asthma, officials said yesterday. Observing that East Harlem had the highest asthma rate in the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the East Harlem Asthma Center of Excellence would train health care workers in the most effective treatments, provide walk-in screening and help reduce exposure to environmental factors that worsen the condition. “With the resources of this great city, no child’s place of birth should determine whether they suffer from asthma,” Scott Stringer, above, the Manhattan borough president, said in a statement.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has set up a task force to find ways to reduce flight delays at the region’s three main airports, authority officials said yesterday. The group will include airline executives and federal, state and city government officials. The Port Authority, which operates Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports in Queens and Newark Liberty International Airport, will lead the group.

A Queens woman was killed yesterday at her home in a fire, which officials attributed to careless smoking. The woman was identified as Stephanie Pronchick by her neighbors, who said she was in her late 70s, in failing health and a heavy smoker. She died about 10:45 a.m. in her two-story home at 22-14 43rd Street in Steinway, where the neighbors said she lived alone and rarely had visitors. Employees of a nearby deli said that before the fire they had delivered coffee, newspapers, a sandwich and two packs of cigarettes to Ms. Pronchick.

A federal appeals court in Atlanta upheld a ruling yesterday awarding New York City more than $40 million from the trust for a bankrupt Florida-based asbestos company, the latest development in litigation that has lasted more than two decades. The company, the Celotex Corporation of Tampa, was among the companies sued by the city starting in 1985 to reclaim expenses incurred in removing asbestos from city-owned buildings. Celotex later filed for bankruptcy. New York City filed more than 740 claims in the case, but the Celotex trustees refused to pay some of them, arguing they were wrongly decided. Two judges and a federal court in Florida previously ruled in the city’s favor, most recently in April 2005. Yesterday, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, upheld the lower court rulings, bringing the total payments from Celotex, including $11 million from previous claims, to more than $55 million.
The City Council Wednesday rejected a measure that would have named a street after Sonny Carson, a radical black activist who more than once described himself as “antiwhite.”

A Bronx man has been charged with gun trafficking after a federal sting operation in which he bought four guns, federal agents announced yesterday. The man, David Gonzalez, 23, was indicted yesterday on charges of buying and reselling guns without a license, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Gonzalez was arrested after agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives traced several guns seized by the police to a site in Pennsylvania, said Joseph Green, an agency spokesman. The investigation in Pennsylvania led to Mr. Gonzalez, who was arrested after he bought guns in the sting operation in the Bronx, Mr. Green said.

A bank has agreed to pay New York State for part of the cleanup of a closed chemical factory in Wallkill. The bank, HSBC Bank U.S.A., has agreed to pay $850,000 in penalties and to reimburse the state $68,000 for the cleanup of hundreds of drums and containers at the abandoned Westwood Chemical Company plant in Orange County, said Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Mr. Cuomo said that when the bank seized the company’s operating funds in 2004, it did not leave enough to pay for environmental measures. The bank denied wrongdoing.

The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who had robbed eight taxi drivers since May 17. In one case, the man showed a gun to the driver before demanding money, the police said. The robberies have occurred at various spots in Manhattan, all at night or in early morning, the police said. The suspect is described as a black man, 30 to 40, 6 feet 1 inch to 6 feet 3 inches tall, with a muscular build and a mustache and wearing a baseball cap. Drivers have been alerted to the robberies and urged to take precautions, said Matthew W. Daus, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

South Korea’s industrial output rose in April, helped by increased exports of chips and cars. Manufacturing production jumped 3.1 percent from March, the largest gain in seven months, the National Statistical Office said. Output rose 6.7 percent from a year earlier. Corporate investment in factories surged 15.6 percent in April from a year earlier, the biggest gain since September 2006, the report showed. The figures also showed an index of economic indicators climbed 5.1 percent in April from a year earlier after rising 4.9 percent in March.

Qatar Airways ordered 20 more Airbus A350s to become the largest customer for the wide-body jet, with a total order of 80 planes worth a listed price of $16 billion. Louis Gallois, chief executive of Airbus, said it was one of Airbus’s biggest orders ever. The Qatar Airways agreement for 20 A350-800s, 40 A350-900s and 20 A350-1000s, as with most large orders, would probably come with deep discounts from the listing price. The agreement replaces one for 60 A350s signed in 2005. The commitment for 20 extra planes brings Airbus’s total orders for the A350 to 268.

Morgan Stanley has agreed to buy a real estate investor, the Investa Property Group of Australia, for 4.7 billion Australian dollars ($3.9 billion) in cash. Including debt, the offer values Australia’s biggest publicly traded owner of office buildings at 6.6 billion Australian dollars. The bid is subject to an independent expert’s report confirming that the offer is in the best interests of shareholders.

BP, the British oil company, said the chief executive of its refining and marketing operations is leaving to run Talisman Energy of Canada. The executive, John Manzoni, had been passed over for the chief executive’s position at BP when Tony Hayward was named to the job this month. Mr. Manzoni will become president and chief executive of Talisman. He will be succeeded at BP by a fellow executive, Iain Conn, BP said. Mr. Manzoni was criticized for his handling of safety management after an explosion killed 15 workers at a BP refinery in Texas in March 2005.

Japan Tobacco’s Canadian unit was ordered by an Ontario judge to stand trial on charges it defrauded the Canadian government out of about a billion Canadian dollars ($931 million) in the 1990s by shipping cigarettes to the United States to avoid paying taxes. The judge, David Fairgrieve of Ontario Provincial Court, said in a 29-page ruling that prosecutors had presented enough evidence to warrant a trial of the unit, JTI-MacDonald. The company has denied any wrongdoing.

Gildan Activewear, a maker of clothing like T-shirts, tank tops and golf shirts, said it would close two sock plants in North Carolina and lay off 520 employees as part of its plan to shift production to lower-cost factories in other countries. The North Carolina factories will close by the end of August, leaving one American plant, in Hillsville, Va., for making socks. Gildan is based in Montreal.
Mark Messier has not talked to the Rangers’ about their front-office vacancy, but he would listen if they called.
soccer.
The outcome of U.S. asylum cases can be influenced by things like the location of the court and the sex and professional background of judges, a study has found.

Four Americans seized May 9 by gunmen in the oil-producing Niger Delta region were freed and handed over to the authorities. United States Embassy officials were not immediately available for comment. Some 200 foreign workers have been kidnapped since late 2005 by militants who want regional control over the impoverished region’s oil wealth; most have been quickly released for ransom.

Israel killed two men it described as Hamas militants in an airstrike in the Gaza Strip and said again that it was not considering a cease-fire with the group despite appeals from Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president. Describing the strike, an Israeli military spokeswoman said a “group of armed terrorists” near the Jabalya refugee camp was the target.

Shimon Peres, a leading figure of Israeli political life, said he would again ask Parliament to elect him president, a symbolic and largely powerless post. Mr. Peres, 83, is supported by his latest party, the centrist Kadima, but he may not win the secret ballot on June 13. In a shock, Mr. Peres, left, lost in the last election, in July 2000, to Moshe Katsav, 61, a relatively unknown Likud politician who is ending his term accused of rape and sexual misconduct. Other candidates are Colette Avital from the Labor Party and Reuven Rivlin of Likud. “The president does not have much authority,” Mr. Peres said. “But he does have the authority to do good deeds.”.

Ewa Sowinska, the conservative government’s watchdog for children’s rights, said she no longer suspected the television series “Teletubbies” and its purple, bag-carrying character, Tinky Winky, of promoting homosexuality. After widespread criticism and ridicule, even from her own party, she said her fears had been allayed by “the opinion of a leading sexologist.”.
Gov. M. Jodi Rell and the General Assembly are facing the possibility that they may not pass a state budget before the legislative session ends.

The police arrested four men in the killing of Syed Hammad Raza, who worked as the chief of staff to Pakistan’s suspended chief justice. The interior minister, Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao, said the four belonged to a gang of robbers from Kashmir and shot Mr. Raza when they broke into his house in Islamabad on May 14. The police, who said they had recovered the gun used in the shooting and a stolen watch, maintained from the start that the killing was robbery-related. Mr. Raza’s wife denied there had been a robbery attempt and termed the shooting politically motivated because of Mr. Raza’s close association with the suspended justice, Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry.

Unaddressed envelopes, each containing a bullet, were left on or in the cars of three Pakistani journalists in Karachi working for Agence France-Presse and The Associated Press. Journalists groups reacted quickly, describing the act as an attempt to intimidate the press and linking it to a shady group with ties to the Muttahida Quami Movement, the party that controls Karachi and is allied with the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. According to news reports, the group recently issued a list naming a dozen journalists as “enemies,” including two who received the bullets.

Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill arrived in Beijing to work with Vice Foreign Minister Wu Dawei on reviving the stalled agreement under which North Korea would begin to dismantle its nuclear program. Mr. Hill maintained that the impasse was a technical matter and that North Korea remained committed to the deal. He declined to give any details of the talks.
Mel Renfro, a former star defensive back for the Dallas Cowboys and a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, participated in a recent study linking concussions to clinical depression.
As locations go, things do not get much more impressive than Block 4375, Lot 1 in East New York, Brooklyn.
Officials are seeking to advise more than 100 passengers who sat closest to him on the longest flights and crew members to be tested for the infection.
A manufacturing plant in Ohio was using the banned substance that ended up in feed for farmed fish, shrimp and livestock.
Fred D. Thompson could shake up a field of candidates that has failed to strike a chord with the Republican base.
The company will pay a $1 million criminal fine for lying to the government about a patent deal on its blood-thinning drug Plavix.
Barry Bonds and the Mets’ Guillermo Mota, who finished served a 50-game suspension for using performance-enhancing substances, are linked this week by more than coincidence.
Experts say that women and men are becoming more alike in their attitudes toward balancing life at home and at work.
The Bush administration should try to secure full financing for what is arguably the single most important survey on the effects of government programs on Americans’ lives.
The near doubling of financing is part of an  effort to burnish the president’s humanitarian credentials.
Concerns over the approval of drugs that turned out to be dangerous have led Republicans and Democrats in the House and the Senate to call for investigations.
A video with Will Ferrell has become a sensation on a Web site that has the backing of a major venture capital firm.
The company will cut more than 6 percent of its shrinking work force, as part of a plan to improve sagging financial and operational results.
The company reversed itself and said that it would begin selling a two-handed laptop-size machine called the Foleo.
The Supreme Court’s latest ruling indicates that a court that once proudly stood up for the disadvantaged is increasingly protective of the powerful.
Robert Zoellick is just about everything Paul Wolfowitz was not.
Congressional oversight committees ought to examine what steps can be taken to ensure that patients infected with deadly contagious diseases protect others from infection.
The announcement of a battery of new standardized tests for students rekindled the debate over whether such testing is emphasized too much.
The Democratic-led Assembly has passed a bill rolling back scalping restrictions, and the Republican-led Senate is expected to approve the bill.
Lake Okeechobee, a vital reservoir in Florida, sank toward a new low because of a once-a-century drought.
In Edison, N.J., President Bush focused mostly on Iraq and terrorism in a 27-minute speech at a political fund-raiser.
The Web auction leader has acquired StumbleUpon, a Web browsing recommendation site, for $75 million in cash.
Beyond the soaring dunks and 3-point fadeaways LeBron James used to spark the Cleveland Cavaliers’ two playoff victories, he added something more subtle to his highlight package: substance.
Internet-based alternatives to traditional polls are trying to make inroads, offering greater accuracy for far less money.
Two Marine junior officers said they had no reason to suspect a possible war crime after they inspected the scene after an infantry attack that killed 24 civilians in Haditha, Iraq, in 2005.
The departure of Farzad Nazem will follow other senior executives who have left in the wake of the overhaul.
This Supreme Court term will be remembered as the time when Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg found her voice, and used it.
A proposed ban of alcohol on New York-area commuter trains received an overwhelmingly negative response.
The independent Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta began sales of a collection of articles and commentary by a correspondent who was killed last year.
Islamist groups are vying for influence in Gaza in a race to fill the security vacuum created by fighting between Fatah and Hamas.
The bond-trading firm is selling its privately held BGC Partners brokerage unit to eSpeed, in a deal valued at $1.3 billion.
TiVo posted a small quarterly profit reversing a year-ago loss on higher revenue from subscribers to its digital video recording service.
International Business Machines cut about 1,570 jobs to help improve profit margins in its technology services unit.
McDonald’s won dismissal of three out of five claims in a lawsuit over allergens said to be in French fries and hash browns.
The success of an experimental high school in Dayton may not be enough to save it from a budget cut.
People close to Robert B. Zoellick, President Bush’s pick to head the World Bank, say he is likely to bring a demanding approach that could disturb the status quo.
The company reported a second-quarter loss after the company cut jobs to compensate for declining sales.

A Middle Eastern man jailed for nearly four years must be released by June 8 because the government, which wants to deport him, has taken too long to find a country that will take him, a federal judge has ruled.
It was a softball grudge match between Mickey Werner, 93, and Paul Rotter, who pitched more than 70 years ago in Brooklyn sandlots.
Policy changes and severe budget cuts at the Small Business Administration have left the agency unable to fulfill its mission.
The International Olympic Committee began an investigation Wednesday into possible doping violations in cycling at previous Olympics.
Prosecutors rested after announcing they were dropping one money-laundering count against him.
The human resources company has sold itself to Thomas H. Lee Partners and Fidelity National Financial for $5.3 billion.
Grants for those who lost their houses are expected to cost far more than the $7.5 billion the government provided.

The top diplomats for the U.S. and Russia openly sparred at a meeting of foreign ministers of the Group of 8 industrialized nations in Germany.
Sam Kagel was a mediator and arbitrator whose career settling labor disputes ranged from the rough-and-rowdy San Francisco docks of the 1930s to the N.F.L. fields of the early 1980s.
To win the Giants’ place kicking job, former Kansas City Chief Lawrence Tynes will have to beat out the free-agent rookie Josh Huston, a former Ohio State player.
CBS said the $280 million deal will allow the service to continue to operate as an independent unit.
A divided Security Council approved a resolution establishing an international tribunal to prosecute suspects in the assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister.
Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia and its founder will pay shareholders $30 million for losses suffered during the ImClone trading scandal.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 30 — A homeless panhandler arrested for loitering after asking a police officer for a dollar won a legal battle on Wednesday when a City Court judge dismissed the charge, finding the arrest unconstitutional.
U.S. and Iraqi troops raided Sadr City on Wednesday, looking for five British citizens abducted a day earlier from a nearby government building.
A unit of the Police Department is reaching out to communities that often have little faith in law enforcement.
The National Transportation Safety Board ranked regulatory failure as an equal cause of a crash that killed all 20 people long with the failure of the airline.
Jörg Immendorff was a German painter best known for crowded scenes depicting an acidic, often autobiographical comedy of art, politics and history.
The two soft drink giants have agreed to stop directly financing research that uses animals to test or develop their products.

Paul Byrd won his fifth consecutive decision and extended his streak without issuing a walk to 43 innings, and the Cleveland Indians came from behind for an 8-4 victory yesterday against the Red Sox at Fenway Park.
New Yorkers earn and spend much more than most other Americans do, but they no longer spend more than the residents of Chicago and Los Angeles.
A constitutional court on Wednesday banned the political party of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra after finding it guilty of election fraud.
Trainer Carl Nafzger said he would discuss Street Sense’s short-term future with the owner Jim Tafel and announce a decision Thursday.
The main union representing 120,000 British college teachers voted Wednesday to endorse a Palestinian trades’ union call for a boycott of Israeli academic institutions.
Fox Interactive Media agreed to acquire the photo-storage site weeks after MySpace partly blocked content from Photobucket.
From the moment José Reyes led off the 12th inning with a walk Tuesday night, he planned to do his best to rattle the Giants’ Armando Benítez.
A new protective case from Digital Lifestyle Outfitters has a spool on the back that takes up slack in the cord when headphones are worn.
The decision came two weeks after the mayor of West New York denied a permit to organizers because he said that the event did not do enough to recognize the plight of the Cuban people.

Mr. Ubell was a science reporter and editor familiar to generations of New Yorkers for his wide-ranging reports in newspapers and on television.
The most widely followed benchmark of American stocks surpassed a previous high set amid the Internet boom.
Dave Balon played parts of eight seasons for the Rangers but achieved hockey glory with the Montreal Canadiens, helping them to win two Stanley Cups in the 1960s.
Seven soldiers died when their helicopter crashed in southern Afghanistan, the site of some of the heaviest recent fighting between Western forces and the Taliban.
I believe wholeheartedly that there cannot be any contradiction between faith and reason.
The organization advised health workers in countries hard hit by AIDS to urge every patient to be tested for H.I.V. rather than to simply offer tests in limited circumstances.
The two soft drink giants agreed to stop financing animal experiments, except where such testing is required by law.
It’s not easy to tell great whales what to do; it is even harder to figure out what drives them.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,454 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
The City Council passed a bill Wednesday giving the city broad new powers to go after landlords with histories of serious code violations.
Malaysia’s highest court refused to recognize the conversion of a Muslim-born woman to Christianity, ruling that the matter was beyond the jurisdiction of the country’s civil courts.
Chinese stock markets plummeted after the authorities in Beijing moved to impose higher taxes on trading activity.
Google will make applications like Gmail and Docs and Spreadsheets available offline, in a move that will challenge Microsoft.
Jazz Pharmaceuticals has filed to sell as much as $180 million in stock in its first public offering.
The N.C.A.A. granted a waiver Wednesday for an extra year of eligibility to 33 members of Duke’s lacrosse team, a surprising and controversial decision.
I keep getting a message that says “Critical error message — Registry damaged and corrupted.” Is this a virus?
The Enano E2 is a tiny, silent PC with a footprint, and a carbon footprint, that makes most standard-size PCs look like S.U.V.’s.
Odin Sphere has cute bunny shopkeepers and a pretty talking bluebird. It also has war, death and vengeance.
Radiosophy's HD100 pulls in HD Radio signals, a digital format that is broadcast alongside standard radio by more than 1,200 stations in this country.
The Panasonic Lumix DMC-FX100 uses a built-in image stabilization to prevent blurring while on the move and even in low light.
Aspiring Cousteaus can now record all of their undersea adventures on video, provided their adventures don’t take them deeper than five feet.
A collective in San Francisco is pushing the limits on practicing and advocating the use of graywater— recycled dish and bathwater.

This week’s PLAY e-mail newsletter previews the issue of PLAY magazine that will be distributed in The New York Times this weekend. It offers an advance look at two articles from the magazine: Joe Nocera’s exclusive report on a new pro football league that plans to challenge the N.F.L., and an article by Buzz Bissinger (“Friday Night Lights”) on Kerry Wood, the Chicago Cubs pitcher whose long string of injuries threatens to end his career. Also, there are brief summaries of three other articles in the magazine.
Like Britney Spears before her, the spectacle of Lindsay Lohan’s self-destruction seemed to demand expressions of sympathy along with the requisite scorn.
Britney Spears ponders life after rehab, dance takes center stage at the Next Wave Festival and more culture news.
Covent Garden’s purchase of a for-profit maker and producer of performance DVDs is unheard of in the performing-arts world.

Anselm Kiefer, who has a penchant for working on a monumental scale, inaugurates an annual solo show in the cavernous space of the Grand Palais in Paris.
Velina Hasu Houston’s play is rife with purple language and melodrama, and packed into an hour and a half that feels like a four-hour television epic.
Kobe Bryant issued a trade request Wednesday that left the Los Angeles Lakers stunned, and then he made a series of conflicting remarks that left the basketball world mystified.

Wood, still virtually unknown to the casual fan, had just equaled Roger Clemens’s single-game record for strikeouts. All of a sudden, he found himself mentioned alongside the heady company of hard throwers like Clemens, Sandy Koufax, Juan Marichal and Bob Gibson. “The expectations were ridiculous for someone at 20,” Wood says. “I had pitched five games. I had, like, 17 innings. It’s tough when you punch out 20 guys in your fifth start and then everybody expects you to do that from here on out.”.

The June issue of PLAY will be published this weekend in The Times. Next week’s newsletter will follow up on developments concerning our big stories, including Phil Mickelson’s performance in the Memorial Tournament and the America’s Cup action in Valencia, Spain.
Pianist Bill Charlap, who performed with his trio at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday, seems less interested in stylistic eras of jazz than its ever-relevant ideal of melody and efficacy.
A modest rally pushed the most widely followed benchmark of U.S. stocks past a previous high set amid the dot-com boom.
The $370 million deal includes such classics as “That’s Amore” and “Moon River,” along with newer hits.

It’s no secret that elite athletes will take extreme measures to improve their performance, sometimes ignoring rules and their own health. Next stop down the performance-enhancing highway: gene doping, the introduction of a specialized gene into a person’s DNA. In “Outlaw DNA,” Gretchen Reynolds reports there have been no confirmed cases of gene doping— yet -- and that gene-therapy trials have yielded largely disappointing results. Still, she says, that won’t stop the dopers who want it, because

Phil Mickelson, new coach in tow, may be peaking just in time for the United States Open in a few weeks. Along with him for the ride will be his loyal following, and count Charles McGrath among them. In his essay about Mickelson for PLAY, “Just Like Us -- Only Better,” McGrath explains why Mickelson’s daring style of golf resonates with fans.
Only three teams remain in contention for this year’s America’s Cup, but rest assured that there are still plenty of characters. As John Tayman writes in “Cast Off, Characters” for PLAY:

9 P.M. (USA) THE STARTER WIFE Debra Messing stars as Molly Kagan, the buffed-and-Botoxed spouse of a Hollywood studio president who finds herself spiraling into oblivion — both personally and professionally — after she gets dumped for a barely post-pubescent pop star. This six-part mini-series was adapted from the novel by Gigi Levangie Grazer, who has managed to hold on to her own producer husband, Brian Grazer. Judy Davis plays Joan, Molly’s oldest friend, sobering up from a stint in rehab; Anika Noni Rose plays Lavender, a security guard and Molly’s newest confidante; Miranda Otto is Cricket, divided between loyalty to her girlfriend Molly and to her husband, a director who wants Molly’s ex, Kenny (Peter Jacobson), to back his latest project; and Joe Mantegna (above with Ms. Messing) is Lou, Kenny’s boss, whose flirtatious advances help remind Molly that it’s not all over. Yet.
An article last week about the International Contemporary Furniture Fair gave an incorrect price for smashed-glass panels by Yorgos Papadopoulos. They cost $22,000 for a set of six, not $22,000 each.

A report in the Currents column on May 17 about flower arranging classes at some Four Seasons hotels incorrectly described the classes. At Four Seasons hotels in New York, Toronto and Paris, classes are offered to large groups of guests, but not to individual guests. In Dallas, classes for individual guests are offered, but only at Thanksgiving and Christmas.
This week the Billy Hart Quartet is back at the Village Vanguard with a clearer sense of itself, judging by a potent and well-balanced first set on Tuesday night.
Saatchi & Saatchi in New York has been selected to handle the familiar tourism campaign for New York State, known since 1977 by its theme, “I Love New York.”

From deep inside the lavender murk where performance art meets pop-jazz nostalgia with a wink and a smirk come the Puppini Sisters, a British novelty trio that made its North American debut on Tuesday.

CHERNEY--Geraldine, 83, New York, NY. Loving mother to Darryl and Jennifer; wife of Abraham; sister to Albert, Danny, Dorothy; daughter of Mark and Molly; friend to Josephine. Funeral is today, May 31 at 2pm at Mt. Jacob Cemetery, Glenolden, PA. Inquiries to Darryl (707)223-3788.

An article yesterday about Congressional districts where Republican supporters of the war are taking political heat referred incorrectly to a House resolution on the president's decision to increase troops in Iraq, a decision opposed by Representative Mark Steven Kirk, Republican of Illinois. The resolution opposed the president's plan, it did not back it.

The city will open a center in East Harlem to improve the treatment of asthma, officials said yesterday. Observing that East Harlem had the highest asthma rate in the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the East Harlem Asthma Center of Excellence would train health care workers in the most effective treatments, provide walk-in screening and help reduce exposure to environmental factors that worsen the condition. ''With the resources of this great city, no child's place of birth should determine whether they suffer from asthma,'' Scott Stringer, above, the Manhattan borough president, said in a statement.

A picture caption in some copies on Tuesday with a sports article about Anaheim's victory against Ottawa in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals misidentified the Ducks' player in front of the Senators' net when his team tied the score in the third period. It was Brad May -- not Ryan Getzlaf, who scored the goal but who was not in the picture.

Dance is on center stage for the 25th Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this fall. The season begins on Oct. 2 with Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan. Engagements include the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel and a commission by the New York choreographer John Jasperse. Other commissions include ''The BQE'' by the indie-rock prince Sufjan Stevens; ''One Loss Plus'' by the violinist and composer Daniel Bernard Roumain; and a work by Erik Sanko (of the band Skeleton Key) to be performed by the Kronos Quartet. The Chinese-born composer Tan Dun offers a New York premiere, ''The Gate.'' Theater presentations include the return of the SITI Company in Charles L. Mee's ''Hotel Cassiopeia'' and the Thalia Theater's production of Frank Wedekind's ''Lulu,'' directed by Michael Thalheimer. James Thiérrée, a grandson of Charlie Chaplin, performs in his own acrobatic dance-theater piece, ''Au Revoir, Parapluie.'' The season runs through Dec. 16, and subscription tickets go on sale on June 18. Information: (718) 636-4100 or bam.org. BEN SISARIO

The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who had robbed eight taxi drivers since May 17. In one case, the man showed a gun to the driver before demanding money, the police said. The robberies have occurred at various spots in Manhattan, all at night or in early morning, the police said. The suspect is described as a black man, 30 to 40, 6 feet 1 inch to 6 feet 3 inches tall, with a muscular build and a mustache and wearing a baseball cap. Drivers have been alerted to the robberies and urged to take precautions, said Matthew W. Daus, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission.
To the Editor: Re ''Targeting Human Trafficking'' (editorial, May 21):

Despite the absence of ''American Idol'' from its schedule, Fox remained dominant in the ratings Tuesday, as the season finale of ''House'' (starring Hugh Laurie, left) towered above the competition on the night. Nielsen estimated that 16.9 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m. for the conclusion of medical drama's third season, about 7 million more than the night's second most watched shows, CBS's 8 p.m. repeat of ''NCIS'' and ABC's 10 p.m. finale of ''Boston Legal.'' Both of those shows drew 9.8 million viewers. Meanwhile, Fox's ''On the Lot'' at 8 p.m. (4 million) improved slightly over the dismal ratings for its Monday installment. NBC, which broadcast three reruns of its ''Law & Order'' franchises, tied ABC for second place for the night among adults 18 to 49. CBS was fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF

New York Delft is Demian Repucci and Nicholas Lovegrove's take on classic 18th-century, blue-and-white delftware. Each piece is decorated with an icon of the city: a taxicab, a hot dog stand, a delivery truck. And instead of the typical flowery borders, the porcelain dishes are rimmed in what looks like blue graffiti. ''Actually the borders started with real New York graffiti,'' Mr. Repucci said, ''but I manipulated it so that nothing is understandable. It just looks like the real thing.'' A five-piece place setting is $80 and can be ordered at www.lovegroveandrepucci.com or (908) 832-2518. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

A headline and picture caption on Monday with the Critics' Choice column, about new CDs, referred incorrectly to R. Kelly, who has a new album, ''Double Up.'' He is an R&B singer, not a ''rap'' or a ''hip-hop'' performer.

GEORGE--Sally. Died May 31, 1991. Your spirit, joy of life and smile live on in my heart. Through all your struggles and pain, your love of life dimmed not. I love and miss you so very much. Catherine

To the Editor: The assumption in your May 23 editorial ''Propping Up the General'' that United States aid can prop up any leader in Pakistan -- a country of 150 million with a $150 billion G.D.P. -- is insulting. Most of the United States money reimburses the use of our military facilities and cost of operations in support of the United States-led counterterrorism war in Afghanistan.

Unaddressed envelopes, each containing a bullet, were left on or in the cars of three Pakistani journalists in Karachi working for Agence France-Presse and The Associated Press. Journalists groups reacted quickly, describing the act as an attempt to intimidate the press and linking it to a shady group with ties to the Muttahida Quami Movement, the party that controls Karachi and is allied with the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. According to news reports, the group recently issued a list naming a dozen journalists as ''enemies,'' including two who received the bullets. SALMAN MASOOD

To the Editor: David Brooks (''The Vulcan Utopia,'' column, May 29) criticizes Al Gore's style (although the sentence he cites is clear and perfectly understandable), speaks disparagingly of Mr. Gore's ''best graduate school manner,'' pans his knowledge of history and distorts the central message of Mr. Gore's new book, ''The Assault on Reason.''

If you've ever felt as though you can't keep up with the pace of life, well, it could have been worse. You could have been a computer disk. The history of removable disks is one sad ''couldn't keep up'' story after another. Remember the floppy disk (800 kilobytes)? The SyQuest cartridge (44 megabytes)? The Zip disk (100 megabytes)? The Jaz disk (1 gigabyte)? The recordable DVD (4.7 gigabytes)?

A RECORD CLOSE FOR THE S.& P. -- The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the most widely followed benchmark of American stocks, gained 12.12 points to close at 1,530.23, breaking a seven-year-old record as the market clawed its way back to where it was during the heady days of technology and the Internet boom. [Page C1.] Chinese stock markets plummeted after the authorities in Beijing moved to impose higher taxes on trading activity. [C4.] MY FUNNY INTERNET -- The Internet is already filled with cheap laughs. But now many experienced comedians, talent agents and financiers are seeing the Web as a way to showcase talent while trying to turn a profit. [C1.] NEW SOURCE OF CONTAMINATION -- Melamine, the industrial chemical that was traced to shipments of wheat flour from China, has been used by a company in Ohio to make binding agents that ended up in animal feed, federal officials said. [C1.] UNTYING GOOGLE FROM THE WEB -- Sharpening its rivalry with Microsoft, Google is trying to make many of its free Web-based applications, like Gmail and Docs and Spreadsheets, available offline, say when a user is on an airplane. Google released a set of tools to software programmers, which it calls Google Gears. The company is making the technology available in an open-source model, so programmers can use it free, test its abilities and extend them as necessary to fit their needs. [C3.] ZOELLICK FORESEES NEW AGENDA -- Robert B. Zoellick, whose nomination to lead the World Bank was formally announced, said he sees himself not simply as a healer but as a leader ready to establish a new agenda to help the world's poor. People close to Mr. Zoellick say he is likely to bring a tough and demanding approach. [A3.] 4 CHARGED IN FRAUD CONSPIRACY -- Four current and former partners of the accounting firm Ernst & Young have been charged with tax fraud conspiracy over their work on questionable tax shelters. [C3.] SOFT DRINKS TO QUIT ANIMAL TESTS -- Coca-Cola and PepsiCo have agreed to stop directly financing research that uses animals to test or develop their products, except where such testing is required by law. [C3.] CERIDIAN IS SOLD FOR $5.3 BILLION -- The Ceridian Corporation, a human resources company, said that it had sold itself to the private equity firm Thomas H. Lee Partners and the specialty insurer Fidelity National Financial for $5.3 billion in cash. [C6.] A SMALLER S.B.A. -- The Small Business Administration's budget has been sliced nearly in half since 2001, and staffing cuts have been deep, leading advocates to say the agency has been unable to fulfill its mission to provide programs and services to the nation's 25 million small companies. Its loan program has higher fees and less money to lend. Steven Preston, above, who became the S.B.A. administrator last June, acknowledges that budget and staffing cuts have hurt, but he still sees the agency's loan programs and services as vital to small business. [C6.] WHERE'S THE REST OF THE SONG? -- People are getting much more savvy about bitrates and audio compression now that an increasing number are connecting their iPods to sophisticated home music systems. [C9.] FOX UNIT BUYS PHOTOBUCKET -- Fox Interactive Media has agreed to acquire the photo-storage site Photobucket, just weeks after a public spat in which the popular networking site MySpace partly blocked content from Photobucket. [C11.] POLLING, VIA THE INTERNET -- Internet-based alternatives to traditional polls are trying to make inroads, offering to predict election outcomes and consumer preferences with greater accuracy for far less money than ever before. Advertising. [C5.] CRISIS ON THE 6:52 IS AVERTED -- A Metropolitan Transportation Authority panel has backed off a plan to ban alcohol on the Long Island and Metro-North Railroads, after hearing from more than a thousand riders who were overwhelmingly opposed the idea, including a group called the Commuters Allied for Responsible Enjoyment. [A1.] PALM THINKING BIG -- Fifteen years after pioneering personal computers that nestled comfortably in a user's hand, Palm reversed itself and said that it would begin selling a two-handed laptop-sized machine called the Foleo. [C6.] ONLINE FAMILIAR FACE AT THE WORLD BANK -- Robert B. Zoellick is a loyal servant of the Bush administration and an experienced diplomat. But what will he do at the World Bank? Daniel Altman, global economics correspondent for The International Herald Tribune, explores the issue in his Managing Globalization blog at nytimes.com/business. THE ENERGY CHALLENGE -- A series of articles in The Times has been examining how the world is, and is not, moving toward a more energy-efficient, environmentally benign future. The series is online at nytimes.com/business.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Islamist Groups Vie to Fill Palestinian Power Vacuum Islamist groups like the ones the Lebanese Army is trying to drive from Palestinian refugee camps in Lebanon are also vying for influence in Gaza, joining the race to fill the security vacuum created by fighting between Fatah and Hamas. A1 Bush Seeks More to Fight AIDS President Bush called for Congress to spend $30 billion to fight global AIDS over the next five years, a near-doubling of financing that is part of an effort to burnish Mr. Bush's humanitarian credentials before he meets with leaders of the Group of 8 industrialized nations next week. A6 The World Health Organization advised health workers in countries hit hard by AIDS to urge every patient to be tested for H.I.V. rather than to simply offer tests in limited circumstances. That is a more aggressive approach than what is commonly taken now or has previously been approved by the health organization. A6 U.N. Approves Hariri Tribunal A divided United Nations Security Council approved a resolution establishing an international tribunal to prosecute suspects in the assassination of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister. A3 U.S. and Russia Spar at Meeting The United States and Russia, with relations between them at their most contentious since the collapse of the Soviet Union, openly sparred at a meeting of Group of 8 foreign ministers. A10 Slain Reporter's Writing on Sale The independent Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta officially began sales of a bound collection of articles and commentary by Anna Politkovskaya, its special correspondent who was killed last year, and renewed its demand for an honest investigation of the crime. A10 NATIONAL A13-16 Study Finds Disparity Among Asylum Seekers Asylum seekers in the United States face broad disparities in the nation's 54 immigration courts, with the outcome of cases influenced by such things as the site of the court and the sex, professional background and worldview of judges, a new study has found. A1 Former Senator Likely to Run Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee shook up the Republican presidential field by making clear that he is likely to run for the White House. A1 Cost Overruns in Louisiana The Road Home, the Louisiana grant program for homeowners who lost their houses after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, is going to cost far more than the $7.5 billion provided by the federal government, in part because many more families have applied than expected. As a result, Louisiana officials set a July 31 deadline for applicants. A13 School May Revert to Old Model In Ohio, voters' rejection of a school tax levy on May 8 is forcing a school district to slash $30 million from its budget and may result in an experimental academy's reverting to a more traditional model despite success stories. A13 Findings in Tuberculosis Inquiry A series of near misses accounted for a Georgia man's trip to Europe in which he may have exposed passengers on a series of flights to a dangerous form of tuberculosis, federal officials said. A13 Detainee Found Dead in Cell A Guantánamo detainee apparently committed suicide, military officials said. The announcement, which immediately brought new criticism of the administration's detention practices, included few details. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Vote to Keep Liquor Sales On Commuter Trains A Metropolitan Transportation Authority committee has recommended that alcohol service continue on the trains and platforms of the Long Island and Metro-North railroads, according to a committee member and two people briefed on its findings. A1 Schools to Expand Testing Chancellor Joel Klein announced that the New York City school system would spend $80 million over five years on a significant expansion of standardized tests in reading and math, to begin this fall for most of the city's 1.1 million public school students. B1 Scalping Agreement Close New York State lawmakers are nearing an agreement on removing restrictions against the resale of tickets to musicals, concerts and sporting events, but concerns raised by the Yankees and Mets appear to have held up a final deal. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Showing Talent on the Web For Will Ferrell, who commands up to $20 million for a movie, starring in a short Web video may not seem like the best use of time. But many experienced comedians, talent agents and financiers are seeing the Web as a way to showcase talent while trying to turn a profit. C1 S.& P. Ekes Out a Record Stocks struggled after markets fell in Asia, but fought back with some mildly upbeat words from the Federal Reserve, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index back to where it was during the heady days of the Internet boom. A17 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Injustice 5, justice 4; isolating an evasive TB patient; the continuing saga of SIPP; a clean start at the World Bank. Columns: Atul Gawande and Nicholas D. Kristof. The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit against a Boeing subsidiary, alleging that the company provided flight plans for Central Intelligence Agency aircraft transporting terrorism suspects to overseas prisons where they say they were tortured. The latest of several legal challenges to the agency's program of extraordinary rendition, the practice of seizing suspects and delivering them to security services in other countries, was filed in federal court in Northern California against the subsidiary, Jeppesen Dataplan, which provides flight plans, overflight permits and other services. The A.C.L.U.'s plaintiffs are Binyam Mohamed, an Ethiopian, and Abou Elkassim Britel, an Italian, who were allegedly taken to Morocco; and Ahmed Agiza, an Egyptian taken to Egypt. A Boeing spokesman declined to comment on the lawsuit or to confirm that the C.I.A. is a customer. SCOTT SHANE

An article on Tuesday about new sites of variation in the human genome that increase the risk of breast cancer misstated the number of sites found by a team at the Harvard School of Public Health. Of the six new sites that have been identified, the Harvard team co-discovered one, not two.

In a highly anticipated encounter, Bill Gates of Microsoft and Steven P. Jobs of Apple took the stage Wednesday evening to relive old battles and alliances and speculate about the future of digital culture and technology. Rivals for three decades, the two executives have rarely appeared in public together and have generally been viewed as bitter rivals, despite occasional partnerships.
An article last week about the International Contemporary Furniture Fair gave an incorrect price for smashed-glass panels by Yorgos Papadopoulos. They cost $22,000 for a set of six, not $22,000 each.
