Rocking Beauty, right, a chair with a bar code design of plywood, aluminum and Makrolon plastic on the outside and a cluster of delicate flowers in the hollow interior, is part of ''Magma: Contemporary Icelandic Design,'' one of the exhibitions at SOFA New York, a show and sale of furniture, decorative objects and art that opens to the public tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Gudrun Lilja Gunnlaugsdottir, the interior designer in Reykjavik, Iceland, who created the chair and curated the exhibit, said the chair is cut by water-jet, layer by layer, and sells for $13,500. (So far, she has made two.) The show, which will also include work from 58 galleries from around the world, continues through Sunday, at 643 Park Avenue (67th Street); (212) 472-3290 or sofaexpo.com. ELAINE LOUIE

A bank has agreed to pay New York State for part of the cleanup of a closed chemical factory in Wallkill. The bank, HSBC Bank U.S.A., has agreed to pay $850,000 in penalties and to reimburse the state $68,000 for the cleanup of hundreds of drums and containers at the abandoned Westwood Chemical Company plant in Orange County, said Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Mr. Cuomo said that when the bank seized the company's operating funds in 2004, it did not leave enough to pay for environmental measures. The bank denied wrongdoing.

To develop a line of pet accessories for her housewares collection, Gaia & Gino, Gaye Cevikel sponsored a class at the California College of the Arts in San Francisco. She gave the students a pretty slim brief: to create whatever they wanted, out of any material, to fit a brand that was, she said, ''sophisticated, intelligent and witty.'' Seven of their creations will carry her Gino the dog label, including Chew ($35), right, a table-leg cover by Jennifer Yoko Olson. Chew is a deceptively simple invention that deploys impish wit to solve an age-old problem: providing succor for the dog who likes to gnaw but is not allowed to trash the home of the human with whom he lives. Gino, Ms. Cevikel's golden retriever, for whom the label was named, is not a gnawer, she said proudly, ''but he does like to use Chew as a toy.'' For stores: gaiaandgino.com. PENELOPE GREEN

An article on Saturday about the robbery of Representative Rodney P. Frelinghuysen in Washington's Georgetown neighborhood referred incompletely to his Congressional district, New Jersey's 11th. It comprises all of Morris County and parts of Somerset, Essex, Sussex and Passaic counties. It is not limited to Morris and part of Somerset County.

The celebration began shortly after Fabricio Oberto, a relative unknown in 49 states, left the AT&T Center court to a raucous and sustained standing ovation. When the wave began circling the arena minutes later, it was clear that delirium had taken hold of the city. San Antonio Spurs fans have grown accustomed to hoisting championship banners here, and the mere anticipation of another one had them ready to do the river dance across the Riverwalk.

For those thinking of installing a new wood floor, there is an easier, less messy alternative: Chilewich's signature Plynyl flooring now comes in Wood Grain, an amusing take on wide-board hardwood floors. The vinyl wall-to-wall floor covering has a cushioned layer of polyurethane and is available in four colors -- Dogwood, Driftwood, Pecan and Tan -- that can be installed by handy do-it-yourselfers in little time. Wood Grain comes in 72-inch rolls ($8 to $10 a square foot, depending on the quantity ordered), as well as tiles and area-rug-size pieces. Available in July; information is at chilewich.com or (212) 679-9204. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

SO you want to run a marathon? During the first running boom three decades ago, aspirants embarked upon a six-day regimen of arduous runs hellbent on crossing the finish line in the fastest time possible. Hollow cheeks, hobbled feet and an overuse injury or two were badges of honor for the mostly middle-class men who tackled the 26.2-mile challenge. Their icon was Frank Shorter, a Yale-educated lawyer whose victory in the 1972 Olympic marathon ignited the mass running movement.

Shimon Peres, a leading figure of Israeli political life, said he would again ask Parliament to elect him president, a symbolic and largely powerless post. Mr. Peres, 83, is supported by his latest party, the centrist Kadima, but he may not win the secret ballot on June 13. In a shock, Mr. Peres, left, lost in the last election, in July 2000, to Moshe Katsav, 61, a relatively unknown Likud politician who is ending his term accused of rape and sexual misconduct. Other candidates are Colette Avital from the Labor Party and Reuven Rivlin of Likud. ''The president does not have much authority,'' Mr. Peres said. ''But he does have the authority to do good deeds.'' STEVEN ERLANGER

To stay hydrated, athletes must replace electrolytes like sodium and potassium that are lost in sweat. But many triathletes and runners prefer to eat their carbohydrates (like chewy bars) instead of gulping Gatorade or Cytomax, carb-loaded drinks with a hint of electrolytes. This long-distance set now has a new option that leaves carbohydrates out of the equation: electrolyte-drink tablets. Tablet makers figure athletes already eat enough energy bars and gels to meet the roughly 80-gram limit that their bodies can shuttle to their muscles in an hour.

The rate of diagnosed clinical depression among retired National Football League players is strongly correlated with the number of concussions they sustained, according to a study to be published today. The study was conducted by the University of North Carolina's Center for the Study of Retired Athletes and based on a general health survey of 2,552 retired N.F.L. players. It corroborates other findings regarding brain trauma and later-life depression in other subsets of the general population, but runs counter to longtime assertions by the N.F.L. that concussions in football have no long-term effects.

No canvas is too big for Richard Haas, a Manhattan-based artist whose trompe l'oeil murals embellish the urban landscape from New York to California. Mr. Haas's latest project is a 12-story mural at 110 Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn, a building that once housed the New York City Board of Education. Two Trees Management, which is converting the 1926 McKim, Mead & White building into a 300-unit condominium, asked Mr. Haas to dress up the walls of the courtyard in back. Mr. Haas, left, obliged by extending the ornate vocabulary of the facade, creating faux cornices, columns, trellises and a pediment with a giant clock and two sculptural figures, above. But residents should be forewarned: Legend has it that at another building with a Haas mural, a woman walked straight into a wall. 110 Livingston (Court Street), Brooklyn, (718) 222-4110, 110livingston.com. ROBERTA HERSHENSON

Dear Fans: Life Lessons à la Britney While Lindsay Lohan was heading into rehab, Britney Spears, right, was pondering life after getting out. In a ''Dear Fans'' letter posted on her Web site, britneyspears.com, she referred to attention deficit disorder when she wrote: ''Recently I was sent to a very humbling place called rehab. I truly hit rock bottom. Till this day I don't think it was alcohol or depression. I was like a bad kid running around with ADD.'' She continued: ''This letter is not to place blame on anyone, although I do see the world with a completely different set of eyes now I think the whole problem was letting too many people into my life.'' She went on to say: ''I am only 25 and I do still have a lot to learn, and I am going to make mistakes everyday, and I am sure every mistake I make will probably be on CNN or Good Morning America. I am only human people and I love you for still loving me.'' Ms. Spears decided, ''Life in general is so surreal and crazy.'' She finished by writing: ''I guess we will never really understand or figure out life completely. That's God's job. I can't wait to meet him or her.'' Two Novelists, Obscure No Longer Maybe it's not ''American Idol,'' but two agentless novelists have been plucked from obscurity and were anointed the winners yesterday of ''First Chapters,'' a writing contest sponsored by Simon & Schuster, the Borders Group and the social media site Gather.com. Besides prize money, each winner will have his novel published in the fall and receive an advance of less than $50,000. Designated the winner of the first prize of $5,000, Terry Shaw, 44, is the author of ''The Way Life Should Be,'' a mystery set in coastal Maine. Although only one winner was planned, Geoffrey Edwards, 30, was named runner-up and will receive $2,500. His novel is ''Fire Bell in the Night,'' a thriller set in the antebellum South. The contest allowed writers at no charge to submit manuscripts to Gather.com; more than 2,600 entries were narrowed to a final five. The winners were chosen by a panel including Mark Gompertz, executive vice president of Touchstone, a Simon & Schuster imprint; George Jones, chief executive of Borders, and Tom Gerace, chief executive of Gather.com. La Scala Salutes Puccini Teatro alla Scala in Milan will commemorate the 150th anniversary of the birth of Puccini next season with productions of ''Il Trittico'' and ''La Bohème,'' Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. La Scala's director, Stéphane Lissner, said Riccardo Chailly would conduct ''Il Trittico,'' the triptych of three one-act operas comprising ''Il Tabarro,'' ''Suor Angelica'' and ''Gianni Schicchi''; and the Venezuelan conductor Gustavo Dudamel would conduct ''La Bohème.'' The season will open on Dec. 7 with Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde,'' conducted by Daniel Barenboim. The Orchestre de Paris has appointed the Estonian-born American Paavo Jarvi its music director beginning in 2010, when he will succeed Christoph Eschenbach, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Jarvi, 44, is the music director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, the artistic director of the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie in Bremen, Germany, and the principal conductor of the Frankfurt Radio Symphony Orchestra. Sentencing Set For George Michael A cocktail of drugs was in George Michael's system when he was arrested in his car last year, prosecutors told the Brent Magistrates' Court in London yesterday, the BBC reported. The prosecutor, Andrew Torrington, said the drugs included the illegal dance club drug GHB, marijuana and an antidepressant. Mr. Michael, 43, the former Wham! singer, pleaded guilty on May 8 to driving while unfit because of drugs, saying his condition was attributable to ''tiredness and prescribed drugs.'' His lawyer said a sleeping drug was the most likely explanation. District Judge Katherine Marshall said the issue was not the specific drugs but Mr. Michael's condition when found in the car after motorists reported a driver slumped over the wheel at traffic lights. Mr. Michael is to be sentenced on June 8, a day before he is to perform in the first concert at the new Wembley Stadium in London.

FELDMAN--Robert D., age 87, Roslyn Harbor, NY. Beloved husband of the late Shirley Feldman. Devoted father of Donald Feldman and his wife Ellen, and Lesley Decker Lucas and her husband Stephen. Treasured grandfather of Ilana Decker, Doug Feldman, Rachel Decker and Matthew Feldman. Loving brother of the late Murray Feldman. We will forever remember and miss your guiding hand, unwavering devotion to family, loyalty to friends, limitless generosity, and unique sense of humor. You had a tremendous impact on everyone you touched. Contributions can be made to the Chemotherapy Foundation, 183 Madison Avenue, NY, NY 10016. $(6$)FELDMAN--Robert. Dear Bob, my friend, my partner for 53 years. A kind and caring man. To know you was to love you. You were a part of our lives and will be forever. Ginger and Larry $(6$)FELDMAN--Robert D. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Chemotherapy Foundation mourn with deepest sorrow the passing of Honorary Trustee, distinguished benefactor and friend Robert Feldman. His sophisticated understanding, humanitarian concern, generosity and dedicated efforts profoundly influenced the expansion and scope of the Foundation's grant programs. His staunch support of over 35 years has been instrumental in advancing chemotherapy research and clinical science for the control, cure, and prevention of cancer through innovative medical therapies. Bob has been a driving force and an inspiration to us all to pursue the promise on the horizon. Progress achieved through our aggressive research efforts will forever remain a tribute to his vision and unwavering encouragement. His warmth and kindness and his steadfast loyalty will be remembered with gratitude and affection always. Franco M. Muggia, M.D. Chairman and Medical Dir. Barry Richter, President Chemotherapy Foundation $(6$)FELDMAN--Robert. The Officers, Board of Governors, Members, and Staff of Engineers Country Club mourn the passing of our beloved member Robert Feldman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his children, Lesley Decker-Lucas and Donald Feldman and their families. Les Genatt, President

Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill arrived in Beijing to work with Vice Foreign Minister Wu Dawei on reviving the stalled agreement under which North Korea would begin to dismantle its nuclear program. Mr. Hill maintained that the impasse was a technical matter and that North Korea remained committed to the deal. He declined to give any details of the talks. DAVID LAGUE

He is survived by a sister, Selina Grew Rossiter of Lincoln, Massachusetts, and two brothers, Joseph Clark Grew of Boston and Robert Sturgis Grew of Raleigh, North Carolina; as well as five nieces, four nephews, six grandnieces and one grandnephew. A memorial Service will be held on August 4, at 11 am, at St. Mary's By-The-Sea, Northeast Harbor, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Dublin School, Inc., Dublin, New Hampshire.

Holy Cow, an eco-friendly wallpaper by Louise Body, a London designer, is decorated with a water buffalo pattern and printed with water-based inks and nontoxic solvents on paper from managed forests; $400 for an 11-yard roll, to the trade, at Stark, 979 Third Avenue (59th Street), (212) 752-9000. 3. Night Owl, a 70-inch-high floor lamp with a branchlike stainless steel base, takes a 60-watt bulb and is operated by a touch-sensitive dimmer switch; $2,500, from a limited edition of 100 by Rick Lee, the designer. Wedgwood's 13 1/4-inch-diameter Chinoiserie serving platter, by Jasper Conran, is $195 at the Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street, (866) 755-9079. 5. Iguana is a 53 1/2-inch-wide cotton fabric by Timorous Beasties, a British company; $264 a yard, by special order, from the Future Perfect, (718) 599-6278 or thefutureperfect.com.

The United States men's under-20 national soccer team will play Chile at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on June 23 in the first game of an afternoon doubleheader, the United States Soccer Federation said yesterday. The United States senior women's national team will play Brazil in the second game. The match for the men's under-20 team is part of its final preparations for the FIFA U-20 World Cup, which begins June 30 in Canada. The United States has been drawn into a first-round group with South Korea, Poland and Brazil.

A federal appeals court in Atlanta upheld a ruling yesterday awarding New York City more than $40 million from the trust for a bankrupt Florida-based asbestos company, the latest development in litigation that has lasted more than two decades. The company, the Celotex Corporation of Tampa, was among the companies sued by the city starting in 1985 to reclaim expenses incurred in removing asbestos from city-owned buildings. Celotex later filed for bankruptcy. New York City filed more than 740 claims in the case, but the Celotex trustees refused to pay some of them, arguing they were wrongly decided. Two judges and a federal court in Florida previously ruled in the city's favor, most recently in April 2005. Yesterday, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, upheld the lower court rulings, bringing the total payments from Celotex, including $11 million from previous claims, to more than $55 million. JENNIFER 8. LEE

An article on Monday about Israeli-Palestinian fighting referred incorrectly to two Palestinian gunmen killed by Israeli police in Jerusalem on Saturday. They were permanent residents of Jerusalem, not Israeli citizens.
EDELMAN--Hilda W. Nearly three decades with us always, forever loved. Diana and Alex

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a deadly clash between the police and supporters of Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, an ethnic Uzbek strongman in northern Afghanistan, referred incorrectly to Rais Qurban, deputy leader of a pro-Dostum youth movement. Mr. Qurban was one of the people reportedly killed; he was not the resident who said he thought that Rais Qurban had been killed.

A report in the Currents column on May 17 about flower arranging classes at some Four Seasons hotels incorrectly described the classes. At Four Seasons hotels in New York, Toronto and Paris, classes are offered to large groups of guests, but not to individual guests. In Dallas, classes for individual guests are offered, but only at Thanksgiving and Christmas.

A front-page article on Tuesday about a push by lawmakers to pass subsidies for coal misidentified the state represented by the Republican Senator Larry E. Craig, who is a supporter of the coal-to-liquid fuel concept. It is Idaho, not Wyoming.

A Bronx man has been charged with gun trafficking after a federal sting operation in which he bought four guns, federal agents announced yesterday. The man, David Gonzalez, 23, was indicted yesterday on charges of buying and reselling guns without a license, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Gonzalez was arrested after agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives traced several guns seized by the police to a site in Pennsylvania, said Joseph Green, an agency spokesman. The investigation in Pennsylvania led to Mr. Gonzalez, who was arrested after he bought guns in the sting operation in the Bronx, Mr. Green said.

Whatever else may be said about the Supreme Court's current term, which ends in about a month, it will be remembered as the time when Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg found her voice, and used it. Both in the abortion case the court decided last month and the discrimination ruling it issued on Tuesday, Justice Ginsburg read forceful dissents from the bench. In each case, she spoke not only for herself but also for three other dissenting colleagues, Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter and Stephen G. Breyer.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on May 23 about plans to save a house designed by Paul Rudolph from demolition by moving it to Catskill, N.Y., from Watch Hill, R.I., misspelled the name by which it is known. It is the Cerrito House, not Cerritto.

An E-Commerce Report in Business Day on Monday about a new breed of Web site developers, and the use of niche sites like one on Ford Mustangs, misstated the year that the Mustang was available. It was introduced in 1964; it was not available in 1957.

An internal investigation at the Justice Department into whether politics influenced hiring practices is being expanded after last week's testimony by a former senior aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales. The department's inspector general and the top lawyer at the agency's Office of Professional Responsibility notified the chairmen of the Senate and House Judiciary Committees in a letter that ''we have expanded the scope of our investigation.'' The inquiry by the two internal units will widen to examine accusations of wrongdoing by the aide, Monica M. Goodling, who said in House testimony last week that she had ''crossed the line,'' allowing partisan considerations to affect hiring for lower-level civil service jobs. DAVID JOHNSTON
To the Editor: Re ''Rethinking Old Age,'' by Atul Gawande (column, May 24):

A fare increase averaging 9.6 percent will take effect on New Jersey Transit trains and buses tomorrow. The increase, approved in April, will be the third since 2002. The income will help the agency close a $60 million budget gap and expand service, New Jersey Transit said. Train and interstate bus tickets will increase by 9.9 percent, while the price of tickets for a single one-zone bus and for local light-rail service will rise by 8 percent, to $1.35 from $1.25. Each weekday, New Jersey Transit serves 857,000 riders, a record high, the agency said. KEN BELSON

A film review last Thursday about ''Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End'' misstated a word in a line spoken by the character Lord Beckett early in the film. He says, ''The immaterial has become immaterial,'' not that it has become ''material.'' The review also misidentified the site of a meeting of the Pirate Brethren Court. It is Shipwreck Cove, not Singapore.

Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Eiko and Koma, Garth Fagan Dance, the Joffrey Ballet, John Jasperse, Pacific Northwest Ballet, Paul Taylor Dance Company and Pilobolus. CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has set up a task force to find ways to reduce flight delays at the region's three main airports, authority officials said yesterday. The group will include airline executives and federal, state and city government officials. The Port Authority, which operates Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports in Queens and Newark Liberty International Airport, will lead the group. KEN BELSON

The familiar tourism campaign for New York State, known since 1977 by its theme, I Love New York, is getting a new agency as well as an increased budget. The Empire State Development Corporation selected Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, to handle the campaign. The decision, announced yesterday by Gov. Eliot Spitzer, came after a required review that began in February.
To the Editor: Re ''They Came, They Toured, They Offended'' (Week in Review, May 27):

Bryant Park had the feel of Yankee Stadium last night. Vendors sold hot dogs, peanuts and Cracker Jacks. Thousands of fans, many in Yankees hats and T-shirts, covered the grass. They even sang the national anthem. The only thing missing was the Yankees. But that did not seem to matter. Their game against the Blue Jays in Toronto was being shown live on a large television screen. For a few hours in Midtown Manhattan, the Yankees' hideous start to the season was essentially forgotten. It helped that they scored five runs in the first inning, setting a festive tone as they went on to win, 10-5. Even before the game began, the third annual Pinstripes in the Park, presented by Continental Airlines, did not seem weighed down by the huge margin between the Yankees and the first-place Boston Red Sox.

The police arrested four men in the killing of Syed Hammad Raza, who worked as the chief of staff to Pakistan's suspended chief justice. The interior minister, Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao, said the four belonged to a gang of robbers from Kashmir and shot Mr. Raza when they broke into his house in Islamabad on May 14. The police, who said they had recovered the gun used in the shooting and a stolen watch, maintained from the start that the killing was robbery-related. Mr. Raza's wife denied there had been a robbery attempt and termed the shooting politically motivated because of Mr. Raza's close association with the suspended justice, Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry. SALMAN MASOOD

In a busy week for new music, Maroon 5's ''It Won't Be Soon Before Long'' (Octone/Interscope) opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with 429,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan; 102,000 of those purchases were digital downloads, a new weekly record. Linkin Park's ''Minutes to Midnight'' (Warner Brothers) -- which set the record for downloads last week -- fell one spot to No. 2 with 198,000 sales, a 68 percent decline. Ozzy Osbourne has his highest chart position with ''Black Rain'' (Epic), which sold 152,000 copies. ''Cold Summer: The Authorized Mixtape'' (Def Jam) by the Atlanta rapper Young Jeezy and his new group, U.S.D.A. (that's United Streets Dopeboyz of America), moved 95,000 units to reach No. 4 in its first week. The Utah hard-rock band the Used opened at No. 5 with 92,000 sales for its new ''Lies for the Liars'' (Reprise). Down the chart the soundtrack to ''Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End'' (Disney) opened at No. 14 with 35,000 sales. BEN SISARIO

A Queens woman was killed yesterday at her home in a fire, which officials attributed to careless smoking. The woman was identified as Stephanie Pronchick by her neighbors, who said she was in her late 70s, in failing health and a heavy smoker. She died about 10:45 a.m. in her two-story home at 22-14 43rd Street in Steinway, where the neighbors said she lived alone and rarely had visitors. Employees of a nearby deli said that before the fire they had delivered coffee, newspapers, a sandwich and two packs of cigarettes to Ms. Pronchick. THOMAS J. LUECK

Two columns in the June 30 issue of Wine Spectator provide a fascinating counterpoint in one of the most important aesthetic arguments in wine today. The first, by James Laube, one of the Spectator's senior editors, takes a swipe at those who complain about the high alcohol content in many of today's wines. "If you taste a wine and it seems to be balanced,'' Laube writes, "the alcohol content shouldn't matter.''

With a draw against Vladimir Malakhov of Russia, Alexander Grischuk, also of Russia, joined Gata Kamsky of the United States and Peter Leko of Hungary as victors in their preliminary candidates matches. Judit Polgar, another Hungarian, staved off elimination by beating Evgeny Bareev of Russia, although she still trails 3 to 2 with one game to play. (If matches are tied after six games, there will be tie-breaker games to determine who goes through to the next round.) Magnus Carlsen of Norway also won, squaring his match with Levon Aronian of Armenia at 2.5.

Few companies have done more to make toll roads sexy than Macquarie Bank. Though not exactly a household name in the United States, the Australian bank has blazed a trail in infrastructure investments, wringing billions of dollars in profits from buying up bridges, airports and utilities in more than 100 countries, using a model that has inspired much bigger and better-known rivals.

The Washington Note has an interesting post saying that David Gordon, now the vice chairman of the National Intelligence Council, will be announced as the new head of Policy Planning at the State Department. That's very interesting, because David Gordon is first rate and not ideological, and because Policy Planning is a key portfolio in any administration in developing long-range policy. Of course, hard-liners in the Office of the Vice President can still out-maneuver the sensible people, as they have for most of the last six years, but it's nice to see good people appointed to top posts. Steve Clemons, who writes the Note, says that Gordon's appointment is indicative of better people going into posts more recently, and maybe there's some truth to that. If the administration had started with Bob Gates and Gordon England at the Pentagon, instead of Rumsfeld and Wolfowitz, with Zoellick at the World Bank -- and, best of all, with somebody like Tom Ridge as vice president rather than Cheney -- then Bush might have avoided a failed presidency. Bush also might have done better in preserving his reputation if he had just been defeated for reelection, so that his fans could blame today's problems on John Kerry.
Apologize -- if it makes you feel better. But it's not necessary.

Your blogger rates it a safe bet that many a reader reacted the way he did to the reports about That Guy With TB and the fact that his new father-in-law just happens to be, of all things, a scientist who studies that very disease and has worked for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the agency that isolated him:

It's quickly approaching a full year since I returned from Iraq, but it really doesn't seem that long ago. However, the calendar doesn't lie, and the end of August will mark the day in 2006 when I reunited with my wife, Christina, on the steps in front of my unit's barracks in Camp Pendleton, Calif. Of course, we managed to miss each other as I got off the bus, and then we both proceeded to circle the crowd in a clockwise direction, maintaining equal distance and obliviousness of each other until we finally gravitated towards the center and met. After exchanging the required hugs and kisses I thought, "What do I do now?" I thought for a moment and offered the suggestion, "Let's go home." And that's what we did. At T plus four minutes from setting foot in the continental United States it was already as if I was just coming home from another day of work.The feeling actually started on the bus on our way from March Air Reserve Base to Camp Pendleton. I looked out at the Southern California countryside and thought, "It's so familiar. It's like I never left." Then a cell-phone laden motorist in an S.U.V. swung around our bus at a high speed and I thought, "Whoa! I see those didn't die out while I was gone."

Few subjects have stirred up New York City public school parents more than the ban on cellphones in schools that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is determined to enforce.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals, a biopharmaceutical company, priced its initial public offering below the forecast range, which had already been reduced. The 6-million-share offering raised $108 million, providing sorely needed cash for the money-losing drugmaker. Since 2003, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and other private equity firms have invested $265 million in Jazz, whose main product, gamma hydroxybutyrate, is used to treat narcolepsy but also has a history of use in date rape and risks of overdose.

Man Group's brokerage unit filed for a $1 billion initial public offering in New York on Thursday, leaving the London-based asset-management company to focus on its hedge fund business, which is one of the largest in the world.

As the subprime mortgage business finds itself in tatters -- loan volume is plummeting, defaults are rising and some of the biggest lenders have cut back or shut down -- private equity, hedge funds and investment banks are swooping in and taking over the battered businesses, seeing opportunity amid the wreckage.
Is Warren Buffett waking up and smelling the Maxwell House? Rumors that the chief of Berkshire Hathaway is eyeing Kraft Foods caused a surge in call option activity in the company.
The tax shelter business is under attack.

A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

Bally Total Fitness, the health-club chain, said Thursday it would file for bankruptcy protection as part of a plan to reduce its debt. The proposed restructuring would make Phil Anschutz, a Denver financier, a major shareholder. Tennenbaum Capital Partners and Goldman Sachs would also get stock in the reorganized company in exchange for their notes.

A lawyer for General Electric, Lorene F. Schaefer, has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Connecticut, accusing G.E. of systematically discriminating against women in both pay and promotions.

Richard Caring, the millionaire owner of the British celebrity haunt The Ivy, has sold off his Strada pizza chain for 140 million pounds ($277 million), less than a month after buying a 3 percent stake in the Carluccio's restaurant chain, prompting speculation that he could bid for the company.

WellPoint, the biggest American health insurer, ousted its chief financial officer on Thursday after an external investigation found that he violated the company code of conduct. The board named its chief accounting officer, Wayne S. DeVeydt, to succeed the finance chief, David C. Colby, effective immediately. Angela F. Braly is to become chief executive and president on Friday, succeeding Larry C. Glasscock, who is retiring.

William S. Lerach, one of the most powerful securities class-action lawyers in the nation, is considering plans to leave the law firm he founded three years ago. In a hastily called meeting this week at his San Diego law firm, Lerach Coughlin Stoia Geller Rudman & Robbins, it was disclosed that Mr. Lerach, 61, was weighing his departure, said a lawyer inside the firm who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Wachovia's $6.8 billion deal for A.G. Edwards touched off speculation that more midsize brokers may succumb to potential suitors. Among those being bandied about as possible targets are Stifel Financial, Raymond James Financial and Charles Schwab .

Shares of the Forzani Group continued to climb to record highs on Thursday morning amid talk that the Canadian sporting goods chain is in takeover talks with private equity bidders. Cerberus Capital Management is a prime suitor, according to The Globe and Mail.

Quebecor is poised to become one of Canada's biggest newspaper publishers with the acquisition of the Osprey Media Income Fund. Montreal-based Quebecor, which owns the Le Journal papers in Quebec and the Sun Media chain across Canada, bought Osprey's chain of 54 daily and weekly newspapers for 517 million Canadian dollars ($484 million), in a deal announced Thursday night.

Shares of Northwest Airlines, newly emerged from bankruptcy protection, began trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday after the airline's chief executive, Douglas M. Steenland, and other employees rang the opening bell.
Eton Park Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm founded by Eric Mindich, a former Goldman Sachs Group partner, raised $518.5 million for a private-equity fund to invest in developing countries.

Jefferies, the investment bank, has agreed to acquire LongAcre Partners, the British media mergers and acquisitions adviser behind deals such as the sale of "Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?" producer Celador and ITV's acquisition of Friends Reunited.

Shares of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce headed lower Thursday after the bank reported second-quarter earnings of 807 million Canadian dollars ($756 million), up 38 percent from the same period a year ago. The results topped analyst forecasts. But "we think [the] quarter missed expectations that have been rising in recent weeks," UBS Investment Research analyst Jason Bilodeau wrote in a note to clients.
Genzyme's planned takeover of a cancer drug maker, Bioenvision, has hit a bump: A key Bioenvision shareholder is calling the deal a lowball offer and digging in against it.

Navteq shares hit a 10-month high after an analyst said a buyout firm may be interested in acquiring the company, which makes maps used in car navigation systems. William Benton of William Blair & Company wrote in a research note that a private equity fund could be attracted to Navteq's growth potential, strong cash flow and lack of debt. It has a market capitalization of about $4 billion.
Western Refining completed its $1.13 billion purchase of rival Giant Industries Thursday after a federal appeals court denied a last-minute effort by the Federal Trade Commission to block the deal.

While the Bancroft family's announcement Thursday that it would consider selling Dow Jones & Company represents a remarkable about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch's $5 billion bid, it does not necessarily mean that Mr. Murdoch will capture Dow Jones, which he has long coveted.

BHP Billiton, the mining company, chose the head of its copper and aluminum division, Marius Kloppers, to succeed its American chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, when Mr. Goodyear steps down Oct. 1.

Cardinal Health, the medical products and services company, agreed Wednesday to pay $600 million to settle a lawsuit filed by shareholders accusing it of accounting irregularities and inflated earnings. In a regulatory filing, the company denied any wrongdoing and said it settled to eliminate the uncertainties and expense of further litigation. The settlement is subject to approval in Federal District Court.

It is a truth universally acknowledged that the one thing central Florida most desperately needs is more theme park attractions. Likewise, children these days can never have too many ways to satisfy their craving for all things Hogwartsian. And J.K. Rowling could always do with another few million.

Multiverse, an online game and virtual world developer on Thursday announced the completion of a Series A financing round worth $4.175 million. The funding was led by Sterling Stamos Capital Management and included unnamed angel investors.

Though market watchdogs have brought several insider-trading cases lately, Marketwatch's David Weidner argues that regulators find the most commonplace cases of insider trading to be "generally irrelevant" as they concentrate on the big, flashy scandals while small-time criminals "fly under the radar."
Is a view ever worth $56 million? The developers of the Plaza Residences in New York City hope so.
Gizmoz, a company that aims to let people make digital avatars of themselves, raised $6.3 million in its first round of venture funding from Benchmark Capital and Columbia Capital.
What I'm wearing now, flipping and flopping and toning, shimmers of elegance and more.
Hundreds of patients are not receiving vital care as a result of what many doctors and patient groups say is the poor management of federal assistance.
Are shareholders entitled to receive a list of all the other shareholders and their addresses, phone numbers, etc.?
Cockfighting continues in Louisiana, the last outpost of a tradition in its twilight.
New plans for the Old Vic, new revivals of “Morning Star” and “The Ritz” and an extension for “Passing Strange.”
Performances of the London production of “The Lord of the Rings” were suspended for two days after the hydraulic stage machinery trapped an actor’s leg.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
There’s a reason this series about witches lasted only two seasons in Britain:  Its mythology doesn’t cast a spell, and its dialogue relies patronizingly on clichés.
Adrian Grenier’s documentary about fathers on HBO is largely colored by his self-absorption.
M/M (Paris) didn't become the fashion world's go-to graphic design duo by being polite.
With “The Fifth Empire,” the prolific 98-year-old director Manoel de Oliveira pushes his minimalist style as far as it can go.
It may be a bit, um, premature to say so, but Judd Apatow’s “Knocked Up” strikes me as an instant classic, a comedy that captures the sexual confusion and moral ambivalence of our moment.
Love is blind, and so too is Linda Pugach, one of the loony-tuners in the somewhat sickening, mildly gonzo documentary “Crazy Love.”
There is nothing more enthralling than a good yarn, and “Ten Canoes” interweaves two versions of the same story.
In “Mr. Brooks,” serial killing is an addiction that sufferers hope to overcome by attending 12-step meetings.
Ian McEwan has inexplicably produced a small, sullen, unsatisfying story that possesses none of those earlier books’ emotional wisdom, narrative scope or lovely specificity of detail.

An obituary on Monday about Indar Jit Rikhye, an Indian general who was a top adviser to United Nations peacekeepers, referred incompletely to the circumstances of the withdrawal overseen by General Rikhye of the United Nations Emergency Force in Gaza and the Sinai in June 1967. While he and some peacekeepers were caught in the path of Israeli forces, the Israelis were not responsible for their expulsion. Egypt had expelled the peacekeepers from Sinai and Gaza in mid-May, which Israel viewed as part of an Egyptian plan for war. General Rikhye — who was trying to appeal that expulsion — and some men remained. When Israel pre-emptively attacked Egypt in early June, starting the Six-Day War, the remaining peacekeepers were in their path.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about plans by Mike Wallace to have the first interview with Jack Kevorkian, the assisted suicide advocate, after he is released from prison in Michigan today referred incorrectly to the prison. It is a state prison, not a federal one.

A front-page article on Jan. 21 about the presidential prospects of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton referred incorrectly to the results of a Washington Post/ABC News poll on Jan. 19. The poll found that Mrs. Clinton had the support of 41 percent of Democrats questioned, not a favorability rating of 41 percent among all respondents. (Her favorability rating among all of those questioned was 54 percent.) The error was pointed out on Wednesday in a posting on the Web site of Media Matters for America.

Nepal’s main political parties, which now include the Maoists, agreed to hold elections in November. The vote will be to choose a national assembly to rewrite the Constitution, which in turn will determine whether Nepal will retain its monarchy.

Xiang Xiang, the first panda bred in captivity and released into the wild, has died after less than a year, apparently the victim of a fall. Officials said that the body bore injuries inflicted by wild pandas and that Xiang Xiang might have died trying to escape. The body of the 5-year-old panda was found Feb. 19 on snow-covered ground in the forests of Sichuan, the Xinhua News Agency said. He survived less than a year despite nearly three years of training on surviving in the wild. An official said an announcement of the death was delayed because of the need for an investigation.

The Cairo Criminal Court rejected a new attempt to secure the release of the former presidential candidate Ayman Nour on health grounds in a hasty session that Mr. Nour’s lawyers were unable to attend. The court said it accepted a report by doctors who deemed Mr. Nour, 42, who is serving a five-year prison term on charges widely viewed as politically motivated, healthy enough to serve out the sentence he started in 2005. The court dismissed a report by an alternative panel of doctors who said that prolonging his imprisonment would threaten his health and possibly his life. Mr. Nour has diabetes and has had heart problems. His wife, Gamila Ismail, had brought a wheelchair to court in the hope that the court would free her husband.

A court convicted 15 policemen in the 1981 shooting deaths of nine miners protesting martial law, a crackdown intended to crush the Solidarity movement. The televised ruling drew loud applause in the packed courtroom in the southern mining city of Katowice. The court sentenced the police division leader, Romuald Cieslak, to 11 years in prison and declared the shootings a “Communist crime.” Fourteen officers under his command received two- and three-year terms. The victims were among several hundred workers who barricaded themselves in the mines to protest the crackdown and the jailing of Solidarity leaders. They were the first of 100 fatalities in the period of martial law that ended in July 1983. A regional court acquitted the officers in 1997 and 2001, but an appeals court overturned both verdicts. The new verdict is open to appeal.

Zdravko Tolimir, a former Bosnian Serb general charged with genocide and crimes against humanity by the international war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, was arrested on the Bosnia-Serbia border, the police said. General Tolimir, above, was a top aide to the Bosnian Serbs’ wartime military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, during the 1995 massacre of nearly 8,000 unarmed Muslim men and boys at Srebrenica and is considered the third-most-wanted war crimes suspect still at large in the Balkans, after General Mladic and the Bosnian Serb wartime political leader, Radovan Karadzic. General Tolimir, who was reported to have organized General Mladic’s escape from justice, was arrested after a sweep of the border region that included helicopters and antiterrorist units, the Bosnian Serb police said. He was charged in 2005 with genocide, extermination, murder, persecution and forcible transfer and deportation.

An inquiry into the shooting death by the police of an aboriginal man during a land claim protest in 1995 called on the government to establish an independent land claims agency to settle a growing number of claims by Native Canadians. The protester, Dudley George, was shot by a police sniper during the protest in Ontario. The inquiry’s report comes as Native leaders are threatening rail blockades and occupations this summer to protest more than 1,100 unsettled claims across the country.

The National Research Council said it had found traces of cocaine and marijuana in the air of Rome. It said it made the discovery during a study of toxic substances in the air of Rome and the southern city of Taranto, as well as in Algiers. Small traces were found in Taranto and none in Algiers. The highest concentrations of cocaine were found in the center of Rome, and especially in the area of La Sapienza University. The report said the maximum concentration of cocaine in the city was just 0.1 nanograms per cubic meter, but nonetheless a cause for concern.
Former President Frederick Chiluba is well enough to stand trial on corruption charges, a judge ruled.
Niger’s government dissolved after a no-confidence vote led by an opposition group in Parliament.

BHP Billiton, the mining company, chose the head of its copper and aluminum division, Marius Kloppers, to succeed its American chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, when Mr. Goodyear steps down Oct. 1. Mr. Goodyear has overseen a wave of record-setting earnings since taking charge of the company in 2003 as the company benefited from a China-led boom in demand for iron and other metals. But in the last two years, soaring prices for copper have fueled BHP’s results. Mr. Kloppers, a 44-year-old South African, played a crucial role in BHP’s merger with Billiton in 2001 and in the $7.6 billion takeover of WMC Resources in 2005.

Shareholders of Alliance Boots, the British pharmacy chain, approved an £11 billion ($21.8 billion) takeover bid from its deputy chairman and a private equity firm. It expects the takeover to be complete in July, although the deputy chairman, Stefano Pessina, and the equity firm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, remain in talks with pension trustees about financing the pension plan. Mr. Pessina and Kohlberg Kravis raised their offer three times, to 1,139 pence ($22.53) a share, to secure their bid for Alliance Boots after a consortium led by Terra Firma Capital Partners made a rival bid. Alliance Boots has about 3,000 Boots drugstores in Britain, seven other European countries and Thailand, and supplies 125,000 pharmacies, health centers and hospitals.

The Canadian economy grew more than twice as fast in the first quarter of 2007 as in the previous quarter, setting the stage for the Bank of Canada to begin raising interest rates soon. Statistics Canada said that gross domestic product grew an annualized 3.7 percent, up from 1.5 percent in the fourth quarter, and topping analysts’ estimate of a 3.5 percent gain. It was the fastest rate of quarterly growth since the third quarter of 2005. Steady consumer spending and output of goods and services offset weakening exports and slower growth in domestic demand, resulting in an accumulation of inventories.

An investment bank in Estonia, Lohmus Haavel & Viisemann, and a former worker agreed to pay $15 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission allegations that they had made illegal trades based on information from stolen news releases. The former employee, Oliver Peek, will forfeit $13 million in profit and will pay a $1.35 million fine. The bank will pay a $650,000 penalty, the S.E.C. said. They neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing in agreeing to the sanctions. The S.E.C.’s lawsuit accused Lohmus Haavel, which is based in Tallinn, of using a computer program to retrieve information on more than 200 United States companies from Business Wire’s secure Web site before announcements were made public from January to November 2005.

India’s economy grew at the fastest rate in almost 20 years in its last fiscal year as companies lifted production to meet surging consumer demand. The economy expanded 9.4 percent in the year, which ended March 31, the biggest gain since 1989 and more than the government’s initial estimate of 9.2 percent, the Central Statistical Organization said. India’s economy grew 9.1 percent in the three months to March 31, according to the report, averaging a quarterly pace of 8.8 percent in the last two years compared with 5.7 percent in the 1990s. Manufacturing gained 12.4 percent while mining rose 7.1 percent and electricity output climbed 6.9 percent in the quarter. Agriculture, which accounts for a fifth of the economy, grew 3.8 percent.
About 1,000 die-hard supporters of Thailand’s ousted prime minister demonstrated against a court ruling that banned his party and barred its entire leadership from politics for five years.

A former curator at the Historical Society of Rockland County here was charged yesterday with stealing an antique atlas, valued at $60,000, from the society, the police said. The former curator, Rebecca Chen, 50, of Highland Park, N.J., was arraigned yesterday on a charge of second-degree larceny in Clarkstown Town Court, said Detective Robert Schine. Ms. Chen is charged with taking the 1823 book, a New American Atlas, from the historical society, where she worked for several years until last fall, Detective Schine said. After the atlas was reported missing, antiquarian book dealers were notified, and a shop in Philadelphia called the police after receiving an e-mail message about the atlas. Detective Schine said Ms. Chen was arrested when she came into the shop with the atlas.

A man was arrested yesterday in connection with eight robberies of taxi drivers since May 17, the police said, and a realistic-looking toy pistol, which they believe he used to carry them out, was recovered. At a news conference, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly identified the man as Earl Bradley Evans, 36. He was arrested when he returned to the building where he lived, at 231 Vernon Avenue in Brooklyn, Mr. Kelly said, by officers who had been staking it out. Mr. Kelly declined to say what led detectives to Mr. Evans, who was carrying a Tennessee driver’s license, and said the charges against him had not been determined. But Mr. Kelly said he chose to announce the arrest yesterday to allay taxi drivers’ fears that a serial robber armed with a real gun was on the loose.

New Jersey Republicans yesterday filed a lawsuit in State Superior Court charging that the Democratic governor, Jon S. Corzine, was violating the state’s Open Records Act by refusing to release e-mail messages he exchanged with his former companion, the president of a state employees union, during recent contract negotiations. Lawyers for the governor say that the e-mail messages between Mr. Corzine and Carla Katz, president of the Communications Workers of America Local 1034, are protected by gubernatorial privilege. Mr. Corzine’s lawyers also point out that a state ethics panel has reviewed the messages and concluded that the governor acted appropriately. But Mark Sheridan, a lawyer for the Republican State Committee, said the law required Mr. Corzine to disclose any correspondence that discusses the contract negotiations because they involve state business.

A teacher and an aide at a school for troubled children have been charged with rape after having sex with two of their students, the police said yesterday. The teacher, Rebecca Becker, top left, 28, of Walden, and the aide, Maria Zurita, bottom left, 28, of New Windsor, in Orange County, had sexual encounters with two 16-year-old boys after they disappeared from McQuade Children’s Services, the school in New Windsor where they had been living, the police said. Both have been charged with third-degree rape, the police said. Ms. Becker and Ms. Zurita have been fired, school officials said yesterday. The 145-year-old organization serves children referred by social service, family court and school district authorities from seven counties north of New York City.

An ex-convict pleaded not guilty yesterday to raping and torturing a Columbia University graduate student in her Hamilton Heights apartment in April. The suspect, Robert A. Williams, 30, was arraigned in State Supreme Court on attempted murder, rape, kidnapping, sexual assault and other charges. Police have said that Mr. Williams, who served eight years in prison for attempted murder, tied the 23-year-old woman to her bed, raped and sodomized her, slit her eyelids and poured bleach and scalding water over her. During his arraignment, Mr. Williams was watched over by about 20 court officers. A prosecutor said he had been found concealing two razor blades on May 21, the day before he was scheduled to be in a lineup.

New Jersey has surpassed its goal of enrolling an additional 50,000 children in the state’s health insurance program by July, state officials said yesterday. Jennifer Velez, the acting human services commissioner, said 96,000 additional children had enrolled in the program since Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced the goal in February 2006. The program, NJ FamilyCare, provides free or low-cost health insurance to people, depending on their income. Currently, 536,102 children and 163,303 adults are covered.

A Queens man was charged yesterday with killing an elderly relative with a baseball bat after beating his own companion, prosecutors said. The man, Michael Alexander, 54, was charged with murder, manslaughter and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The police had been looking for Mr. Alexander since the beating death of Rudolph Campbell, 71, who was married to Mr. Alexander’s aunt, in June 2006 at Mr. Alexander’s Queens Village home, Mr. Brown said. The fatal beating followed an attack on Mr. Alexander’s companion, then 22, during a dispute, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Alexander was found working at a Brooklyn auto body shop after his story was broadcast last month on the television program “America’s Most Wanted,” Mr. Brown said.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed new regulations yesterday that are expected to increase by more than fourfold state spending on civil legal services for the poor. The regulations will require banks to pay a far higher interest rate on funds deposited in special accounts that lawyers use to temporarily hold money deposited by clients. Interest from these accounts has traditionally been used to pay for civil legal services, but banks have been paying an interest rate of 0.5 percent, on average. The new regulations will require banks to pay a more competitive rate of about 2.7 percent. The change, which requires a 45-day comment period but not legislative approval, is expected to increase financing for civil legal services for the poor from more than $13 million to as much as $65 million.
The action was a change in direction for the department, which had failed to respond to calls for it to be more aggressive in policing the industry.
President Bush also prodded members of Congress to act despite their worries of a backlash at home.
The secretary's comments came after the head of the U.N. nuclear watchdog agency warned against what he called the “new crazies” pushing for military action against Tehran.
It was unclear whether the fighting was driven by differing ideologies or was a battle for control of an area.
One German official warns that the president’s plan would be a “Trojan horse,” but the chancellor’s climate adviser sees it as a welcome sign.
Wal-Mart executives announced on Friday that they would reduce the number of new supercenters to be opened this year by 35 percent to hold down the chain’s mounting expenses.
Lebanon’s army today moved into a besieged refugee camp in northern Lebanon where a group of militants have been hiding.
The advocate for assisted suicide walked out of a prison this morning after serving eight years.
As counselor to President Bush, Dan Bartlett has been at the center of White House decision-making.
Iran’s nuclear negotiator has promised to give the United Nations answers to longstanding questions about suspicious nuclear activity, a European official said today.
The lawyer who flew on airplanes while infected with tuberculosis apologized to his fellow passengers today.
Dennis Hastert was an advocate of governing the House by a “majority of the majority.” Nancy Pelosi has shown she will deviate from that approach.
It was unclear when the video, the first evidence that the BBC reporter was still alive, was recorded.
A 27-year-old man described as one of the world’s most prolific spammers was arrested Wednesday.
A furor has erupted at private high school over a history teacher’s satirical novel and accusations that the school barred the student newspaper from publishing a letter defending the teacher.
The biopharmaceutical company raised $108 million in an initial public offering that priced below a reduced forecast range.
Orlando Hernández’s curveball  kept the Giants at bay, but Carlos Beltrán left the game after the first inning with a bruised right knee.

The Ink feature on Tuesday, about a nonprofit group that collects grease from restaurants at no cost and sells it to a company that converts it into biodiesel fuel, misstated the name of the group. It is RWA Resource Recovery, not RWA Natural Resource Recovery. The article also misstated the reason that the organization does not use biodiesel fuel in the truck that transports the grease. The biodiesel would have to be mixed with the petroleum diesel that the truck now runs on, and the group says it does not yet have the resources to mix the fuels. Vehicles powered by petroleum diesel do not, however, need to be retrofitted to use biodiesel.

A listing on the Calendar page in the Westchester section on Sunday for a tour and program tomorrow, “Afternoon Tea with Mrs. Dyckman,” at the Boscobel Restoration in Garrison, N.Y., misstated the telephone number for information. It is 845-265-3638.

A sports article on Wednesday about the auction of letters written by the Olympic champion and football player Jim Thorpe to the woman who became his second wife misstated her surname. She was Freeda Kirkpatrick, not Fitzpatrick.

An article last Friday about the families of two soldiers missing in Iraq, including Pvt. Byron W. Fouty of Waterford, Mich., misstated the timing of a telephone call Private Fouty made from Iraq in March to his former high school. He called during a rehearsal of an extracurricular play, not during class.

A front-page article on Jan. 21 about the presidential prospects of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton referred incorrectly to the results of a Washington Post/ABC News poll on Jan. 19. The poll found that Mrs. Clinton had the support of 41 percent of Democrats questioned, not a favorability rating of 41 percent among all respondents. (Her favorability rating among all of those questioned was 54 percent.) The error was pointed out on Wednesday in a posting on the Web site of Media Matters for America.

A chart on Sunday about occupations in which illegal immigrants account for a large proportion of all workers misstated the size of the civilian labor force in 2005. It was 148.6 million, not 48.6 million.

Because of an editing error, a brief art review in Weekend last Friday about an exhibition of works by Luigi Ontani used an outdated name for the gallery where the works are being shown. It is just Bortolami, not Bortolami Dayan.

An article last Friday about fund-raising efforts for historic cemeteries, including one where some Titanic passengers are buried, referred incorrectly to the victims of the Titanic. About 1,500 passengers died — not 2,200, which was the approximate number on board.

A State Supreme Court judge has granted Sotheby’s auction house a temporary restraining order that blocks its landlord from selling its longtime home on York Avenue while the two sides wrestle over the property. The developer Aby Rosen bought the 10-story building from Sotheby’s in 2002 for $175 million and leased it back to the company. The two sides had a falling out earlier this year when Mr. Rosen put the building up for sale. Sotheby’s contends that it has the right under the terms of its lease to buy the building for a fraction of the $465 million Mr. Rose has demanded. The injunction, granted on Wednesday, allows the two to proceed with what is known as baseball arbitration, in which an arbitrator declares one side or the other the winner.

A Ronkonkoma man was charged yesterday with manslaughter after he told the police that he had strangled a woman during consensual sex at her home, prosecutors said. The man, Christopher Bayer, 22, is accused of strangling Laura Giampino, 20, and setting her house in Ronkonkoma on fire to destroy the evidence, the Suffolk County district attorney’s office said. Mr. Bayer, who was arrested after Ms. Giampino’s body was discovered after the fire on Monday, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday in First District Court in Central Islip. Ms. Giampino had been married for several months; her husband, Michael Giampino, was sentenced last week on a menacing charge to 45 days in jail, the police said. The charge was unrelated to his wife, said Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick of the Suffolk County police.
Jason Giambi tore the plantar fascia in his left foot while trotting around second base after hitting a home run on Tuesday in Toronto.
Bobby Abreu’s is in good health, but he is still in a slump, and the Yankees can’t quite figure out why.
Such an agreement would be a major shift for a White House that has resisted setting firm limits on emissions.
The decision represents an about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch’s bid and could end more than a century of family ownership.
A customs agent let the infected man re-enter the country despite knowing that he was being sought by authorities.
Pro basketball.
A roadside bomb killed 10 paramilitary troops in southern Thailand on Thursday, while in a separate attack gunmen fired into a mosque and killed five people.
A new online feature of Google Maps called Street View is stirring up a debate over privacy concerns on the Web.

Gov. Bob Riley signed a resolution expressing “profound regret” for Alabama’s role in slavery and apologizing for slavery’s wrongs and lingering effects. “Slavery was evil and is a part of American history,” said Mr. Riley, a Republican. “I believe all Alabamians are proud of the tremendous progress we have made and continue to make.” The Democrat-controlled Legislature approved the resolution last week.

A woman whose dogs fatally mauled a neighbor could get more prison time, after the California Supreme Court ordered a trial judge to consider convicting her of second-degree murder rather than involuntary manslaughter. A jury had first found the woman, Marjorie Knoller, guilty of second-degree murder in the 2001 death of her neighbor, Diane Whipple, 33. But the presiding judge ruled that Ms. Knoller was not aware that her two leashed Presa Canario dogs would escape her and kill Ms. Whipple and lowered the conviction to involuntary manslaughter. An appeals court reinstated the second-degree murder conviction. The State Supreme Court said the trial judge had set too lenient a standard, while the appeals court had set too harsh a standard.

This year’s federal budget deficit probably will be about $200 billion, $44 billion less than the Bush administration first forecast, said the White House budget director, Rob Portman. In a briefing on budget negotiations with Congress, Mr. Portman attributed the lower number to a growing economy that is bringing in higher tax revenue combined with efforts to hold down government spending. “There’s no magic to it,” he said. “The point is the deficit is going down, and it has been going down.”.

Troubled by testimony showing support for Nazis, gang connections and plans for violence, a federal judge ordered a Liberty University student held without bond on a charge of possessing a napalmlike bomb that the authorities found the night before the Rev. Jerry Falwell’s funeral. Magistrate Judge Michael Urbanski sent the charge of possessing an unlawful destructive device against the student, Michael David Uhl, 19, to a federal grand jury. Mr. Uhl, of Amissville, told the authorities he planned to set the bombs off in a field and did not intend to hurt anyone, a federal agent testified. Campbell County investigators initially said that Mr. Uhl had problems with a group that sent protesters to Mr. Falwell’s funeral, but no such plan was discussed in court.
Talks ended late Thursday with few signs the sides were closer to breaking their deadlock over Iran’s nuclear ambitions.

State lawmakers are adequately financing public schools, the Arkansas Supreme Court ruled in ending a long-running lawsuit. The court cited the Legislature’s additional spending in this year’s session, including a $122 million increase in per-student financing and $456 million from the state’s surplus to pay for building repairs. Gov. Mike Beebe, left, said he was pleased with the decision. But, he said: “Anybody who thinks we’re through has missed the point. This is an ever-changing and evolving target that requires constant vigilance.” A school district in eastern Arkansas sued the state in 1992, alleging that it did not spend enough money on schools and that funds were distributed unfairly. Justices ruled against the state in 2002 and again in 2005.

A Border Patrol agent shot and killed a man who tried to grab his gun in a remote dirt lot, the authorities said. The agent and the victim scuffled in a parking lot in Escondido, about 30 miles north of San Diego, and again in an adjacent lot after the victim tried to run away, said Sheriff’s Sgt. Roy Frank of San Diego County. The agent had tried to handcuff the man, believed to be in his 30s, after a records search identified him as an illegal immigrant. The Sheriff’s Department is investigating. It did not identify the agent or the victim.

Former President Frederick Chiluba is well enough to stand trial on corruption charges despite being hospitalized last week after collapsing at his home with an acute heart ailment, a judge ruled in the capital, Lusaka. Mr. Chiluba, 64, was convicted last month by a London court of embezzling $46 million while serving as president from 1991 to 2002. Zambian prosecutors have charged him with stealing nearly $500,000 during his years in office. His trial has been delayed since May 2006 because of health concerns. A Zambian magistrate, Jones Chinyama, said that Mr. Chiluba could be tried either via a video link from his home or by moving court proceedings there. MICHAEL WINES

In a mildly crowded, modestly happy locker room Wednesday night, R. C. Buford traded smiles and handshakes, soaking in the San Antonio Spurs' fourth Western Conference title in nine years. Then Buford, the low-profile general manager of the N.B.A.'s low-key dynasty, spotted a reporter for a certain 24-hour sports network. ''Hey, did we even make 'SportsCenter?' '' Buford asked with a chuckle.

This festival is a bit of a grab bag: The only thing the 50 features and shorts have in common is that they've recently been the subject of preservation work by archives, studios or distributors somewhere in the world. But it's a bag full of fascinating curiosities. A few of the films, like tonight's opening feature, John Cassavetes's ''Faces,'' are relatively familiar. But where else will you see ''Cabiria'' (1914), left, an epic Italian silent set in the Punic Wars and made two years before ''Intolerance''? (It shows at 2 p.m. tomorrow.) Not to mention Jean Renoir's first solo film, ''La Fille de l'Eau'' (1925), or ''Terje Vigen'' (''A Man There Was,'' 1917), a silent film, based on an Ibsen poem, by the great Swedish director Victor Sjostrom, or a full-length, color-tinted print of the King Vidor masterpiece ''The Big Parade'' (1925). Choices from (somewhat) more recent years include Andy Warhol's ''Chelsea Girls'' (1966), properly split-screened; the rarely seen, unusually experimental Satyajit Ray film ''Nayak'' (''The Hero,'' 1966); and the terrific thriller ''Pretty Poison'' (1968) with Anthony Perkins and Tuesday Weld. (Through June 18, Museum of Modern Art Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters, 212-708-9400, moma.org; $10.) MIKE HALE

Growing up often entails simple acts of courage, no less intimidating because they're small: mustering the nerve to climb a daunting jungle gym, conquering the mysteries of using the library or, eventually, getting up the nerve to ask someone for a date. These are the challenges explored in ''The Little Gorilla,'' ''The Librarian From the Black Lagoon'' and ''Karma Café,'' 3 of the 20 shorts in kidsfilmfest, an offshoot of the Brooklyn International Film Festival. Although the festival's adult version is celebrating its 10th anniversary -- yes, it's older than the one in TriBeCa -- the children's is still maturing, having had its debut in 2005.

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Zackary Adler 93 minutes Sweetness and whimsy fill the screen to capacity in ''I'm Reed Fish,'' a rural coming-of-age tale that's so laid-back that its cast is almost horizontal. Set in the fictional town of Mud Meadows -- a cross between Stars Hollow and Lake Wobegon -- this movie is about a guy who makes a movie about his life. Moreover, it was written by the real Mr. Fish, drawing from events in his own life. Try to stay with me now.

Before heading off on your summer vacation, beach reading in tow, you have another chance to join Lawrence Wright, above, on his disturbing voyage into the netherworld of international terrorism. Mr. Wright brings ''My Trip to Al-Qaeda,'' his illuminating monologue about the rise of the Islamist movement, to Town Hall for two more performances next week, a follow-up to its popular Off Broadway run at the Culture Project this spring. A staff writer for The New Yorker, Mr. Wright is an expert on Mr. bin Laden and friends. His deeply researched book ''The Looming Tower: Al-Qaeda and the Road to 9/11,'' from which this show is adapted, just won the Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction. Directed by Gregory Mosher, Mr. Wright's friendly lecture (with slides and video) mixes contemporary history with his personal observations about the widening schism between Western values and the rigid tenets of Islamic fundamentalism. It provides a gripping, intimate and informed account of the web of social, economic and political factors that gave rise to the conflicts now inflaming the Middle East. (Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, 212-307-4100; $25 and $40.) CHARLES ISHERWOOD

The history of takeovers begins with real estate. More recently, there has been a growing surge of deals for property companies and real estate investment trusts, including this week's announced acquisition of Archstone-Smith Trust for $22.2 billion.

DUSHKIN--David, 70, of Guilford, Connecticut, died on May 28th, 2007. He was born in Evanston, IL, on June 7th, 1936 and grew up in the neighboring town of Winnetka. His family later moved to Weston, Vermont where his parents founded the Kinhaven Music School. He was educated at the Cambridge School of Weston, Harvard College (cum laude, class of 1958), and received a Masters in Publishing from New York University. He started his career at Random House where he eventually served as the Director of its College Text Book department. After Random House he worked as Publisher of Psychology Today's book division and in 1971 founded the Dushkin Publishing Group, best known for its Annual Editions series. In 1994 it was sold to McGraw Hill. He will be lovingly remembered by his wife Maria, his two sons Peter and Samuel, his sisters Lelah and Nadia, his stepdaughters Vanessa and Melina, and grandchildren Max and Isabel. He brought warmth and character to everything he did and was dearly loved by his family and friends. Memorial services will be held July 7th in Guilford, CT.

UBELL--Earl. The Staff of PARADE Magazine mourns the loss of longtime friend and colleague, Earl Ubell, author, journalist, and PARADE Health Editor from 1982 to 1998. During his tenure at PARADE, Ubell was often ahead of the news, covering issues such as depression in children, obesity, gene testing, hormone therapy, and Parkinson's Disease, with which he was diagnosed in the late 1980s. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Shirley, his children and grandchildren. Walter Anderson, Chairman PARADE $(6$)UBELL--Earl. The Parkinson's Disease Foundation mourns the loss of a dear and gentle friend, our former Board member, Earl Ubell. His wisdom and intelligence enriched our conversations while his humor and decency warmed our hearts. We wish every comfort at this time to Shirley and their talented family. Page Morton Black, Chairman Lewis P. Rowland, M.D., President

MESSELOFF--Lillian Vivian Levinson, wife of the late Charles R. Messeloff M.D., died peacefully on May 30, 2007. She was a devoted mom to Alice Fraenkel and Reva Greenberg, a loving motherin-law, supportive and concerned grandma and sweet, caring great-grandma. Her family will miss her. October 1908-May 2007.

BECK--James H. The Board of Directors, officers, and members of ArtWatch International, Inc., are greatly saddened by the passing of our founder and president, Professor James H. Beck, whose dedication to artists and their work, and whose perseverance in preserving the world's great works of art will long be remembered. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Darma, and the entire Beck family. Board of Directors, Artwatch, International

After leading Florida to consecutive men's national basketball titles, Coach Billy Donovan will accept an offer to become head coach of the Orlando Magic today. Donovan was expected to accept an offer for five years worth more than $5 million a year. A news conference is scheduled for 11 a.m. today in Orlando; Florida will hold a news conference at 4 p.m. A spokesman for the Magic declined to comment, saying the team would have nothing to say until its search for a coach was complete.

To the Editor: In ''Small Incidents Are Creating a Big Problem With the N.Y.P.D.'' (column, May 29), Bob Herbert writes that police harassment of black and Hispanic young people is ''often the norm'' rather than ''unusual police behavior.''

SOULE--Hilda, Denver and formerly of St. Louis. One of the first licensed female CPA's in the state of Missouri. Wife of the late Zollmy Soule; Mother of Nathan Soule and Ken (Christine) Soule; Grandmother of Jessica, Zechariah, Grey and Cole; Services Sunday, New Montefiore Cemetery in West Babylon, NY.

Triple Candie 461 West 126th Street, Harlem Through Sunday Triple Candie is an alternative space like no other. Among other things, it has a permanent art collection almost as encyclopedic as the Metropolitan Museum's, and probably more up to date. A generous selection of the holdings, from Egyptian goddesses to John Currin's ''Cafe Girls,'' is on first-time view in this show.

Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition. Theater Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater. Previews and Openings 'BEYOND GLORY' In previews; opens on June 21. War stories from Stephen Lang in this solo play based on the tales of eight veterans from World War II, Korea and Vietnam (1:20). Laura Pels Theater, 111 West 46th Street, (212) 719-1300. 'THE BUTCHER OF BARABOO' In previews; opens on June 11. Did the butcher of Baraboo, Wis., kill her husband? Find out in this black comedy (2:00). McGinn/Cazale Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street, (212) 246-4422. 'CRAZY MARY' In previews; opens on Sunday. In A. R. Gurney's new play Sigourney Weaver stars as a woman who discovers that her cousin, the title character and a patient in a psychiatric hospital, holds the keys to the family fortune (2:00). Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. 'ELVIS PEOPLE' Previews start on Wednesday. Opens on June 21. Explore the obsessive world of Elvis fans in this new drama about the influence of the King (2:00). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. 'EURYDICE' In previews; opens on June 18. The hot young playwright Sarah Ruhl (''The Clean House'') gives her spin on the classic myth of Orpheus and Eurydice (1:30). Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422. 'HORIZON' Previews start today. Opens on Tuesday. The latest work of story and song by the adventurous Rinde Eckert (''An Idiot Divine'') is based on the writings of the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr (1:25). New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 460-8996. 'IN A DARK DARK HOUSE' In previews; opens on Thursday. Neil LaBute's latest drama features Frederick Weller and Ron Livingston as hostile siblings sorting out a history of abuse (1:30). Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 279-4200. 'INTIMATE EXCHANGES' In previews; opens on June 14. Alan Ayckbourn's eight different (but related) plays all begin with the same very modern question: should I smoke? Part of the Brits Off Broadway festival (1:30 to 2:15). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200. 'OLD ACQUAINTANCE' Previews start today. Opens on June 28. The Roundabout presents a new revival of John Van Druten's drawing room comedy about two childhood friends who grow up to be very different adults (2:15). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300. 'ROMEO AND JULIET' Previews start on Tuesday. Opens on June 24. Oscar Isaac and Lauren Ambrose play the star-crossed lovers in this new Shakespeare in the Park production. Michael Greif (''Rent'') directs. Delacorte Theater in Central Park, (212) 539-8750. 'SESSIONS' In previews; opens on June 10. Albert Tapper's comic new musical takes place in a therapist's office. Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. '10 MILLION MILES' In previews; opens on June 14. A new musical by the singer Patty Griffin and the playwright Keith Bunin (''The Busy World Is Hushed'') is about a road trip from Florida to New York (1:40). Atlantic Theater, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 279-4200. 'XANADU' In previews; opens on June 26. The 1980 cult roller-disco film about a Greek muse sent to earth goes Broadway -- and it's about time. Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. Broadway 'A CHORUS LINE' If you want to know why this show was such a big deal when it opened 31 years ago, you need only experience the thrilling first five minutes of this revival. Otherwise, this archivally exact production, directed by Bob Avian, feels like a vintage car that has been taken out of the garage, polished up and sent on the road once again (2:00). Schoenfeld Theater, 236 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200.
