(Dunning) STREB S.L.A.M. 9 (Tonight through Sunday) High-flying, wall-crashing thrills and chills, and popcorn besides. (Through June 17.) Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 3 and 7 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Streb Laboratory for Action Mechanics, 51 North First Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (212) 352-3101, strebusa.org; $20; $10 for children. (Dunning) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums * BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'GLOBAL FEMINISMS,' through July 1. Too much of the work in this assembly of pieces by nearly 90 women from nearly 50 countries is body-oriented and doesn't venture beyond the essentialism of Judy Chicago's indomitable 1975-79 installation opus, ''The Dinner Party,'' whose enshrinement in the new Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art this exhibition celebrates. Thoroughly dominated by photography and video, with a documentary slant to many of its better moments, the show is more about information, politics and the struggle for equality than it is about art in any very concentrated or satisfying sense. That doesn't keep parts of it from being energetic and illuminating. 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org. (Roberta Smith) BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'KINDRED SPIRITS: ASHER B. DURAND AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE,' through July 29. This show of about 60 works by Durand has as its centerpiece ''Kindred Spirits'' (1849), a tribute to the landscapist Thomas Cole and his friend the poet and journalist William Cullen Bryant. A founder of the Hudson River School, Durand (1796-1886) favored the realistic approach to landscape. He explored forest interiors with close attention to the ways of trees, foliage and rocks and ground cover in smaller works, while his larger and more elaborate exhibition pictures, influenced by European masters, are Arcadian visions suffused with light, color and atmospheric perspective. 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org. (Grace Glueck) GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: 'DIVISIONISM/NEO-IMPRESSIONISM: ARCADIA AND ANARCHY,' through Aug. 6. Ultimately this rare, compressed, mercurial exhibition of work by the Italian Divisionists of the 1890s is long on history and short on truly convincing paintings. The inclusion of works by Seurat and his French, Dutch and Belgian followers clarifies how the Italians pushed Pointillism, Seurat's invention, in all directions: toward realism, academic classicism, Symbolism, class consciousness and even Impressionism. The show opens a new, albeit small, window on the genesis of Modernism beyond the French canon. If many of the works are period pieces, they are also immensely appealing, big-hearted and physically robust period pieces. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500. (Smith) * INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'BIOGRAPHICAL LANDSCAPE: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF STEPHEN SHORE, 1969-1979,' through Sept. 9. In 1971 the Metropolitan Museum of Art gave Stephen Shore its second-ever exhibition by a living photographer. (Alfred Stieglitz had the first.) He was 23 when it opened. What he did makes up most of this wonderful show. Mr. Shore has reprinted the photographs digitally, with rejuvenated colors as fresh and subtle as the day the pictures were shot. The work's laconic eloquence speaks of an era and a nation. Its wit and affection add buoyancy to scenes of threadbare America from a moment when the country was depressed by war and years of civil unrest. Its formal rigor makes an uncanny order out of images that, at first glance, look like no place or nothing. Look again. His show reminds us of a period when cutting-edge American art and the tradition of straight, documentary photography got together. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at West 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000. (Michael Kimmelman) * INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'LET YOUR MOTTO BE RESISTANCE: AFRICAN AMERICAN PORTRAITS,' through Sept. 9. This show of photographic portraits is a praise-song in pictures, a shout-out to history. It's also a fancy-dress inaugural party for the yet-to-be-built National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington. It tends to be a little too fancy, too heavy on glitz, too short on grit. Still, what a party it is, with a Who's Who of charismatic black statesmen, from Frederick Douglass to Malcolm X, and with Leontyne Price, Mahalia Jackson and the Supremes sharing a stage. (See above.) (Holland Cotter) THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'IMPRESSIONIST AND EARLY MODERN PAINTINGS:THE CLARK BROTHERS COLLECT,' through Aug. 19. The Met examines the lives and collecting habits of two feuding brothers, heirs to the Singer sewing machine fortune, who were among the leading 20th-century art patrons. Sterling Clark was founder of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass. His younger brother Stephen was a trustee of both the Met and the Museum of Modern Art (and established the National Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.) The brothers shared a love of Renoir, Degas and Americans like Winslow Homer, but Sterling ''drew the line'' at Cézanne and considered Matisse and Picasso ''bad painters and fakers.'' Tracking their taste and how they dispersed their collections is interesting -- and perhaps instructive for contemporary collectors. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Martha Schwendener) * THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'POIRET: KING OF FASHION,' through Aug. 5. A revolutionary in revolutionary times, the fashion designer Paul Poiret introduced unstructured garments that freed women from corsets in 1906, the year before Picasso committed his decidedly uninhibited (and unstaid) ''Demoiselles d'Avignon'' to canvas. But the modern painter whom Poiret most resembles, in his love of the exotic, his brilliant use of color and pattern and his penchant for simplified, almost rudimentary form, is Matisse. This rare exhibition -- from the Met's Costume Institute -- does his sartorial genius justice with a spare installation rendered radiant by hand-painted silk backdrops of the leafy parks and luxurious drawing rooms of Paris. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Smith) THE MET: 'FRANK STELLA: PAINTING INTO ARCHITECTURE,' through July 29. Crammed into a gallery that feels like an obstacle course, this exhibition spans 43 years with 25 paintings, reliefs, drawings and architectural models, all with the goal of tracing an evolution that has not yet occurred. Taking up most of the space are enlarged versions of models that are considered sculptures -- and that look as if they date from the early 1960s. The main draws are the examples of the paintings and reliefs that are the basis of Mr. Stella's importance as an artist. (See above.) (Smith) THE MET: 'FRANK STELLA ON THE ROOF,' through Oct. 28. Two large Pop Art sculptures, two architectural models and a model enlarged into a sculpture-installation piece confirm that one of the greatest American artists of the postwar era doesn't do himself or anyone else any favors when he strays from the wall to work fully in the round. The results have a certain Stella-like verve but are otherwise generic. (See above.) (Smith) MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM: 'APOCALYPSE THEN: MEDIEVAL ILLUMINATIONS FROM THE MORGAN,' through June 17. The symbolism of the Book of Revelation, with its demons and lakes of fire, has a subversive appeal. This exhibition at the Morgan Library celebrates a facsimile of ''Las Huelgas Apocalypse'' (1220), the largest surviving Spanish illuminated commentary on the Apocalypse. The show, which includes 50 leaves from the original text, unbound and installed around the gallery's perimeter, offers a walking tour of the medieval imagination. 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 685-0008, morganlibrary.org. (Andrea K. Scott) * EL MUSEO DEL BARRIO: 'THE DISAPPEARED (LOS DESAPARECIDOS),' through June 17. The most potent show of contemporary political art of the season, and one of the most moving shows of any kind in the city right now. The title refers to a peculiarly chilling form of violence associated with political upheavals in Latin America over the past 40 years, and now becoming more common in Iraq. 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272, elmuseo .org. (Cotter) MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: 'COMIC ABSTRACTION: IMAGE-BREAKING, IMAGE-MAKING,' through June 11. This unimaginative and uniformed treatment of a big idea -- the healthy and essential contamination of Modernist abstraction by popular culture -- should be seen if only because it is such a dispiriting symptom of the Modern's paralysis where contemporary art is concerned. Including 30 works by 13 artists from the last 16 years, it alternates between the literal and the arbitrary and favors sincere political intent over genuine artistic quality. Although it promises work that addresses ''perplexing questions,'' nearly everything here is perfectly pleasant and innocuous. The exceptions are provided by Gary Simmons, Ellen Gallagher and Sue Williams. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Smith) STOREFRONT FOR ART AND ARCHITECTURE: 'CCCP: COSMIC COMMUNIST CONSTRUCTIONS PHOTOGRAPHED,' through June 16. This show, packed with obscure architectural gems, reopens on Tuesday. Covering a period ignored by academics and mainstream architects, it relies almost exclusively on the photographs of Frédéric Chaubin, who spent five years traveling across the former Soviet Union, uncovering forgotten architectural works in cities like Tbilisi, Yalta and Yerevan. The results are a revelation. Among the outright gems is Georgy Chakhava's 1975 Roads Ministry building, a monumental grid of interlocking concrete forms rising on a steep, wooded site in Tbilisi, Georgia. Set on an incline between two highways, the building's heavy, cantilevered forms reflect the Soviet-era penchant for heroic scale. Yet they also relate sensitively to their context, celebrating the natural landscape that flows directly underneath the building. What's refreshing about this exhibition is its lack of an ideological agenda: it is open to all sorts of possibilities. The Gaudíesque romanticism of a sanitarium in Druskininkai, Lithuania, for example, spins the aesthetic off in yet another direction. Compelling and easy to digest, this show piques our interest in ways that some larger institutions, ever more averse to risk, often fail to do. 97 Kenmare Street, Little Italy, (212) 431-5795, storefrontnews.org. (Nicolai Ouroussoff) WHITNEY MUSEUM AT ALTRIA: MATTHEW BRANNON, 'WHERE WERE WE,' through Aug. 26. Matthew Brannon brings together art, poetry and advertising in a series of letterpress prints that hark back to 1950s and 1960s textile designs by Astrid Sampe and Marimekko. Texts written by the artist and accompanying the images read like song lyrics crossed with Conceptual Art and Language Poetry (which emphasized experimentalism and reader interaction). Consumption and excess are frequent references, as well as how art, design and fashion feed these modern yet primordial urges and desires. 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453, whitney.org. (Schwendener) WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'LINCOLN KIRSTEIN,' through Aug. 27. In the middle of the last century Lincoln Kirstein particularly relished attacking the Museum of Modern Art. Pure abstraction was ridiculous, he thought. It had no standards. Against Mondrian and Pollock, he endorsed, among others, the artists in this show. They are the sculptors Elie Nadelman and Gaston Lachaise and the painters Paul Cadmus, who was Kirstein's brother-in-law, Walker Evans and Pavel Tchelitchew. With the exception of Evans, Kirstein's taste clearly hasn't won the day, but it's never bad to re-examine received opinions or to be reminded of a generous advocate. 945 Madison Avenue at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600. (Kimmelman) * WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'SUMMER OF LOVE: ART OF THE PSYCHEDELIC ERA,' through Sept. 16. Tear gas, pot and patchouli were the scents of the 1960s. You can almost detect the last two wafting through this two-floor display of rock posters, light shows, photographs and paintings. But the burn of tear gas, with the association of political emergency it brings, is missing in a show that remembers a lot, but forgets much more, about what was happening 40 years ago, when America was losing its mind to save, some would say, its soul. (See above.) (Cotter) Galleries: Uptown YAYOI KUSAMA: FROM HERE TO INFINITY Spanning 50 years, this 24-piece overview is notable for its high quality and for unfamiliar works that sharpen the understanding of this artist's protean talent, among them several small, pungently colored folk-arty paintings that deploy her signature (and obsessive) webs, dots and scale patterns as effectively as her more abstract works do. Barbara Mathes Gallery, 22 East 80th Street, (212) 570-4190, through June 8. (Smith) Galleries: Chelsea * FRANCESCO CLEMENTE: PORTRAITS The works in this show reveal Mr. Clemente's relatively recent endeavors as a suave society portraitist, working on commission in single, daylong sittings. His subjects, while horizontal, don't so much recline as float toward the picture plane, surveying us with enormous eyes. The images can border on illustration, but sometimes color, space and personality collude to enchanting effect. Mary Boone Gallery, 541 West 24th Street, (212) 752-2929, through June 30. (Smith) * VALSAN KOORMA KOLLERI This Indian artist turns found objects, castoff materials and local stone from Kerala, where he lives, into large but delicate abstract sculptures. Copper vessels become containers for air and space; metal clock springs are woven into a time-rusted open-work basket; the simplest forms are ornamented with embedded glass beads. Talwar Gallery, 108 East 16th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 673-3096, through June 16. (Cotter) Galleries: Other * MARTIN KIPPENBERGER: PREIS PAINTINGS Seven canvases from two series of paintings rarely exhibited in this country play on the double German meaning of preis (price and prize), some variation of which appears on each surface. They show this famous bad-boy sculptor conveying his usual sarcasm in surprisingly beautiful terms that couldn't get much flatter. Hard-edged and brushy techniques contrast the main tactics of formalist painting while converting the Modernist grid into designs redolent of drapery and checked tablecloths. A preponderance of hot pink argues for the pleasure principle. 1018 Art, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 537-0453, www.1018art.net, through July 27. (Smith) OLIVER TWIST Each month this new gallery will rent its space to hip out-of-town galleries, a plan that could unsettle the home-away balance of powers in New York. The inaugural show, while something of a mish-mash, presents works by 29 artists represented by the renters of the coming season. Enjoy the sixth-floor space's Chelsea-like light and view, and stay tuned. Rental, 120 East Broadway, at Allen Street, Lower East Side, (212) 608-6002, through June 16. (Smith) Public Art MAD. SQ. ART 2007: ROXY PAINE This installation is made up of two stainless-steel tree sculptures -- ''Conjoined'' and ''Defunct'' -- and a glacierlike boulder, ''Erratic,'' by Mr. Paine. The tree sculptures are made from thousands of pieces of metal pipe and rod elements that have been cut, welded and polished. They are real enough to resemble actual trees but not so real that they form a continuum with the surrounding foliage. What captures your immediate attention is ''Conjoined,'' a 40-foot-tall-by-45-foot-wide sculpture of two trees whose gleaming steel branches cantilever and then improbably connect in midair. It is impossible to tell where the branches of one tree begin, and the other's end. But the piece is also beautifully eccentric, a futuristic fantasy of streamlined vegetation manufactured in imitation of the real thing, only much more appealing and exciting. Madison Square Park, 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, (212) 538-4689, www.madisonsquarepark.org, through Dec. 31. (Benjamin Genocchio) Last Chance * MEQUITTA AHUJA AND CHARLES RITCHIE Ms. Ahuja makes her New York solo debut with large paintings on paper of mythical beings,half woman, half animal, dressed in robes as brilliantly colored as the tropical fruit and flowers around them. Referring to the artist's African-American and East Indian background, the pictures turn marginality into a regal condition. The gallery also kicks off its new artist's book program with a display of sketch books by Mr. Ritchie, an artist based in Maryland. Each small book is filled with marvelous watercolors and all but indecipherable writing. Mr. Ritchie has been making such books for 30 years. They are extraordinary. BravinLee Programs, 526 West 26th Street, 2nd floor, (212) 462-4406, closes tomorrow. (Cotter) * FRANCESCO CLEMENTE: WORKS, 1971-1979 A selection of nearly 70 little-known early drawings and intriguing photo-works shows this young, restless proto-Neo-Expressionist overcoming the gravitational pull of Arte Povera and Conceptual Art, and broaching themes of the body, sexuality and the inner life that would blossom in his large paintings of the 1980s. Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 343-7300; closes tomorrow. (Smith) * JOANNA MALINOWSKA Joanna Malinowska traveled to windswept Baffin Island in the Canadian Arctic last year in the footsteps of the anthropologist Franz Boas, who studied the Inuit there a century ago. The subject of Ms. Malinowska's research turns out to be a Native American musician and Elvis impersonator named Jimmy Ekho, and the film they made together is funny and moving. For another video Ms. Malinowska set a solar-powered boom-box in the middle of the Arctic wasteland, where it will play Glenn Gould's 1981 version of Bach's ''Goldberg Variations'' for as long as the sun shines. Venetia Kapernekas Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, eighth floor, (212) 462-4150, closes tomorrow. (Cotter) WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'GORDON MATTA-CLARK RETROSPECTIVE' I have no doubt that Matta-Clark is now being turned into a hot commercial commodity, but at least at the Whitney you can see what he aspired to be. He came up with various wonderfully harebrained ideas. Literally, in one case: after letting his hair grow for a year, he cut it off as a kind of performance and phrenological gag. The preserved hair, dutifully tagged piece by piece, opens the show like a holy relic. At the center of the exhibition is ''Splitting.'' To a plain single-family suburban frame house in Englewood, N.J., he made a cut straight down the middle, bisecting the building, then severing the four corners of the roof. The retrospective consists of films, drawings, photographs and some of the architectural pieces he cut out of buildings. The drawings are casual and not too interesting, but the luxurious black-and-white photographs from Paris speak more to Matta-Clark's formal elegance. The big message was: Life as art, and art as life, a philosophy dependent on our being properly attuned and keen to the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org, closes on Sunday. (Kimmelman)

TALKS OVER SELLING DOW JONES -- The Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, agreed to meet with Rupert Murdoch just weeks after the family rejected an initial $5 billion takeover offer from Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation. [Page A1.] LERACH MAY LEAVE LAW FIRM -- William S. Lerach, one of the most powerful securities class-action lawyers in the nation, is considering plans to leave the law firm he founded three years ago. His possible departure suggests that a long-running criminal investigation into accusations of kickbacks paid to class-action plaintiffs has gained momentum. [C1.] SEEING OPPORTUNITY IN DEFAULTS -- The subprime mortgage business is in tatters, but that hasn't stopped some private equity companies, hedge funds and investment banks from swooping in and taking over those battered businesses, seeing opportunity amid the wreckage. [C1.] WIND POWER'S TAX BREAKS -- The nation's investment in wind energy continues to grow. But there is uncertainty over whether lawmakers in Congress will extend the tax benefits that encourage companies to invest in wind power. [C1.] PICTURES, FOLLOWED BY WORDS -- A new online feature of Google Maps that offers panoramic ground-level photographs of miles of streets around San Francisco, New York, Las Vegas, Miami and Denver is stirring up a debate over privacy concerns on the Web. [C1.] PUBLISHERS SEEKING BLOCKBUSTER -- In the absence of a new Harry Potter book or a blockbuster by Dan Brown, the publishing industry struggled to sell more copies last year than it did the year before, according to a report to be released today by the Book Industry Study Group, a publishing trade association. [C3.] QUESTIONS OVER MAN WITH TB -- The man with a dangerous form of tuberculosis who flew to Europe for his wedding and honeymoon was identified as Andrew Speaker, 31, a lawyer in Atlanta, who homeland security officials said entered the country when a customs agent who knew Mr. Speaker was being sought by health authorities let him pass. Congress plans to hold hearings on the way the case has been handled. [A1.] DELL TO LAY OFF 10% OF WORKERS -- Dell said that it would lay off 10 percent of its 88,100 employees over the next 12 months as it tries to increase profit. [C3.] WACHOVIA BUYS A. G. EDWARDS -- The Wachovia Corporation swallowed up A. G. Edwards in a $6.8 billion cash and stock deal that highlights the continued consolidation of the retail brokerage sector. [C5.] FINES PAID IN BACKDATING CASES -- Two technology companies, Brocade Communications Systems and Mercury Interactive, became the first two companies to pay fines to settle federal accusations of civil fraud in connection with backdated stock options. Brocade has agreed to pay $7 million and Mercury is paying $28 million. [C8.] WELLPOINT OUSTS FINANCIAL CHIEF -- WellPoint, the biggest American health insurer, ousted its chief financial officer after an external investigation revealed he violated its code of conduct. The board named its chief accounting officer, Wayne S. DeVeydt, to replace the finance chief, David C. Colby, effective immediately. [C6.] GREEN ISSUES AND AUTOMAKERS -- Labor and management in the auto industry are often at odds, but they have agreed on something critics have been telling them for years: Detroit must act to reduce its vehicles' impact on the environment. [C3.] N.J. COURT RULES ON WAL-MART SUIT -- In a setback for Wal-Mart, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that a lawsuit claiming that the company refused to allow workers to take rest breaks and meal breaks could proceed as a class action on behalf of nearly 80,000 current and former Wal-Mart employees. [C7.] CONGRESS TAKING UP TAX SHELTERS -- Congress is taking another close look at reining in questionable tax shelters that have deprived the government of hundreds of billions of dollars in taxes in recent years. [C5.] ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE IS CUT -- The Commerce Department revised the broadest indicator of economic strength, measuring all goods and services produced in the United States, to show a 0.6 percent advance over the first three months of the year. [C3.] 'MISCONDUCT' BY 2 CHINESE FIRMS -- Chinese regulators acknowledged that two Chinese companies had ''engaged in some misconduct'' in the way they labeled and sold a poisonous ingredient that ended up in cold medicine, killing at least 100 people in Panama last year. But the regulators said primary responsibility for the deaths rested with traders in Spain and Panama. [A6.] ONLINE RETIREMENT -- As life spans lengthen, experts on aging say it is more important than ever to prepare for the physical and psychological aspects of retirement. A special section is at nytimes.com/retirement. BUSINESS OF GREEN -- Consumer products are beginning to carry details about their environmental impact, and restaurant owners are finding ways to handle garbage with less affect on the environment. Those articles and more are in a special section at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are available at nytimes.com/business. The Justice Department approved Monsanto's $1.5 billion acquisition of the cotton company Delta and Pine Land, but required both companies to sell assets related to cottonseed production. (AP)

Columbia University will pay $1.1 million to a fund to educate students about loans and has agreed to have its financial aid office monitored by state officials for five years, under a settlement that New York State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday. The settlement, the most stringent Mr. Cuomo has reached with any university so far in his investigation of the $85 billion student loan industry, grew out of his finding that David Charlow, the financial aid director for Columbia's undergraduate college and its engineering school, was promoting a lending company in which he had a financial stake.

An ex-convict pleaded not guilty yesterday to raping and torturing a Columbia University graduate student in her Hamilton Heights apartment in April. The suspect, Robert A. Williams, 30, was arraigned in State Supreme Court on attempted murder, rape, kidnapping, sexual assault and other charges. Police have said that Mr. Williams, who served eight years in prison for attempted murder, tied the 23-year-old woman to her bed, raped and sodomized her, slit her eyelids and poured bleach and scalding water over her. During his arraignment, Mr. Williams was watched over by about 20 court officers. A prosecutor said he had been found concealing two razor blades on May 21, the day before he was scheduled to be in a lineup. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

A listing on the Calendar page in the Westchester section on Sunday for a tour and program tomorrow, ''Afternoon Tea with Mrs. Dyckman,'' at the Boscobel Restoration in Garrison, N.Y., misstated the telephone number for information. It is 845-265-3638.

Almost 40 years ago the Tony Williams Lifetime pioneered a brand of superheated fusion that brooked no qualms or disclaimers. There were just three musicians in the original incarnation of the band -- John McLaughlin on guitar, Larry Young on Hammond B-3 organ and Tony Williams on drums -- but its sound could be crushingly massive. This had a lot to do with the intensity of its namesake leader, who had been pushing toward jazz-rock even during his celebrated tenure with the Miles Davis Quintet. Mr. Williams, who died in 1997, played the drums with a forward-tilt aggression that was matched by his intuitive sophistication. In Lifetime the balance often tilted to favor power over finesse. (Not that there's anything wrong with that.) That isn't the case with Trio Beyond, above, a tribute band consisting of the drummer Jack DeJohnette, the guitarist John Scofield and the keyboardist Larry Goldings. Formed by Mr. DeJohnette, Mr. Williams's loose-limbed successor with Miles Davis, the group recently released a live double album -- ''Saudades'' (ECM), recorded in 2004 -- that features not only Lifetime staples but also milestones of Mr. Williams's sideman career, songs associated with Mr. Young and even a bit of original material. The point seems to be a particular species of interaction, more than a repertory or even a style. So Mr. Scofield, another Davis alumnus, has no imperative to imitate Mr. McLaughlin; he sounds like a pumped-up version of himself. The same is true of his bandmates, who allude to their predecessors without overdoing the emulation. Appropriately, the musicians sound best when they're blazing together through an anthem like ''Emergency,'' seemingly without much concern for how the music might be classified. It's in their fierce commitment that they honor Mr. Williams best. (Tuesday through June 10 at 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, 212-475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum.) NATE CHINEN

Casey Kaplan 525 West 21st Street, Chelsea Through June 14 Trisha Donnelly is not interested in your ''getting'' her work. The gallery release she has written omits the customary introductions and explanations but features an abstruse poem (well, it resembles a poem) composed by the artist: I incline towards the minds of others and all it is all it is -- is the vert panic the mind mass of cantled freaks th. constant triple knock of 3 parallel pains I am the all star epileptic truth- x4 x4 x4 africa take me in your form. The works here include a series of C-prints made by placing a shipping tube wrapped with a photograph of an unidentified woman on a scanner; a scan of a trumpet's bell partly obscured by a slip of paper that reads ''Peralta'' (a reference both to the skateboarder Stacy Peralta and to a town in Spain); stele-shaped armatures covered with peach-colored fabric; a small photograph of the interior of a B-17 bomber; drawings showing fragments of movement or objects; and a sound piece with booming church bells whose frequency increases over the course of the show.

An obituary on Monday about Indar Jit Rikhye, an Indian general who was a top adviser to United Nations peacekeepers, referred incompletely to the circumstances of the withdrawal overseen by General Rikhye of the United Nations Emergency Force in Gaza and the Sinai in June 1967. While he and some peacekeepers were caught in the path of Israeli forces, the Israelis were not responsible for their expulsion. Egypt had expelled the peacekeepers from Sinai and Gaza in mid-May, which Israel viewed as part of an Egyptian plan for war. General Rikhye -- who was trying to appeal that expulsion -- and some men remained. When Israel pre-emptively attacked Egypt in early June, starting the Six-Day War, the remaining peacekeepers were in their path.

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Dylan McCormick Not rated; 100 minutes The affable but dull ''Four Lane Highway'' stars Frederick Weller as Sean, a famous (dead) writer's son who became a writer himself but has been blocked for some time. He lives rent-free in his dad's spacious home, drinks to excess, picks up young women at the college where Dad used to teach and bops around town with his best friend, Lyle (Reg Rogers), a full-blown alcoholic.

A man was arrested yesterday in connection with eight robberies of taxi drivers since May 17, the police said, and a realistic-looking toy pistol, which they believe he used to carry them out, was recovered. At a news conference, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly identified the man as Earl Bradley Evans, 36. He was arrested when he returned to the building where he lived, at 231 Vernon Avenue in Brooklyn, Mr. Kelly said, by officers who had been staking it out. Mr. Kelly declined to say what led detectives to Mr. Evans, who was carrying a Tennessee driver's license, and said the charges against him had not been determined. But Mr. Kelly said he chose to announce the arrest yesterday to allay taxi drivers' fears that a serial robber armed with a real gun was on the loose. THOMAS J. LUECK

A Queens man was charged yesterday with killing an elderly relative with a baseball bat after beating his own companion, prosecutors said. The man, Michael Alexander, 54, was charged with murder, manslaughter and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The police had been looking for Mr. Alexander since the beating death of Rudolph Campbell, 71, who was married to Mr. Alexander's aunt, in June 2006 at Mr. Alexander's Queens Village home, Mr. Brown said. The fatal beating followed an attack on Mr. Alexander's companion, then 22, during a dispute, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Alexander was found working at a Brooklyn auto body shop after his story was broadcast last month on the television program ''America's Most Wanted,'' Mr. Brown said.

I was pregnant with my daughter -- very pregnant -- when my sister called and said: ''Ann, you have to get up to Door County because there are these 1890s holiday cottages going up for sale.'' They were these dumpy little places that had gone into disrepair. There were four of them, all built around a funny fish-shaped swimming pool. Today, they are all privately owned; there's a homeowners association, and it's all very charming. Our cottage is teeny -- about 700 square feet -- but it's fully equipped, and frankly, we don't think twice about having four adults and the kids with their friends. There's a screened porch with wicker chairs for reading and we have a back deck, too.

The Ink feature on Tuesday, about a nonprofit group that collects grease from restaurants at no cost and sells it to a company that converts it into biodiesel fuel, misstated the name of the group. It is RWA Resource Recovery, not RWA Natural Resource Recovery. The article also misstated the reason that the organization does not use biodiesel fuel in the truck that transports the grease. The biodiesel would have to be mixed with the petroleum diesel that the truck now runs on, and the group says it does not yet have the resources to mix the fuels. Vehicles powered by petroleum diesel do not, however, need to be retrofitted to use biodiesel.

To the Editor: Re ''The Vulcan Utopia'' (column, May 29):

A State Supreme Court judge has granted Sotheby's auction house a temporary restraining order that blocks its landlord from selling its longtime home on York Avenue while the two sides wrestle over the property. The developer Aby Rosen bought the 10-story building from Sotheby's in 2002 for $175 million and leased it back to the company. The two sides had a falling out earlier this year when Mr. Rosen put the building up for sale. Sotheby's contends that it has the right under the terms of its lease to buy the building for a fraction of the $465 million Mr. Rose has demanded. The injunction, granted on Wednesday, allows the two to proceed with what is known as baseball arbitration, in which an arbitrator declares one side or the other the winner. CHARLES V. BAGLI

The congressman overseeing plans to stage a debate among Democratic presidential hopefuls on the Fox News Channel said yesterday that the forum would go on as planned, despite the defection of two more candidates, Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico. The congressman, Representative Bennie G. Thompson of Mississippi, said in an interview that he was disappointed in Senator Dodd and Governor Richardson for following the lead of three other candidates who had previously announced they were skipping the debate: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York and Barack Obama of Illinois, and John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina. The debate is being co-sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus.

HOROWITZ--Diana Cooper, in her 107th year, died on April 26th in Ridgewood, NJ. Mother to David, aunt to Deborah Eigen Graifman, her husband Gary and son, Michael. Wife of the late Herman. Born in Philadelphia to Dora and Samuel Cooper. Graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. Her 50 year career in social work included Director of Community and Volunteer services for the National Council of Jewish Women, New York Section. She was a founder and director of the Widows Consultation Center in NY in the 1970's. Her's was a life lived with grace, dignity, intelligence, generosity and kindness. Diana was a truly amazing and extraordinary woman who will be greatly missed and forever loved.

KUTSCHER--Austin H., D.D.S., Professor Emeritus of Dentistry (in Psychiatry) within the Section of Hospital Dentistry, passed away on May 30, 2007. Dr. Kutscher received his B.A. in 1945 from New York University and the D.D.S. in 1946 from Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery (SDOS). Dr. Kutscher was first appointed as Research Assistant in 1947 at Columbia University SDOS and became Director, New York State Psychiatric Institute Dental Service in 1970. He was a leading figure in the areas of oral medicine and thanatology, and published many articles in clinical oral pathology and pharmacology. His text, Pharmacotherapeutics of Oral Disease, was a standard in its time. He established the Foundation of Thanatology in 1967 which supported research and symposia on the problems surrounding dying and bereavement. Our thoughts and prayers are extended to his wife, Charlotte; sons Harlan, Austin, Jr., and Martin Kutscher; stepsons, Michael, Robert and Richard Goldberg; stepdaughter Carol Maeder; and extended members of the family. A funeral service will be held at the Holcombe-Fisher Funeral Home, 147 Main Street, Flemington, NJ 08822 on Sunday, June 3, at 12:30 pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Flemington Jewish Community Center, 5 Sergeantsville Road, Flemington, NJ 08822 or to the Hunterdon Medical Center Foundation, 2100 Westcott Drive, Flemington, NJ 08822. Ira B. Lamster, D.D.S., M.M.Sc., Dean Columbia University College of Dental Medicine

To the Editor: Re ''What I Think About Evolution,'' by Sam Brownback (Op-Ed, May 31):

A chart on Sunday about occupations in which illegal immigrants account for a large proportion of all workers misstated the size of the civilian labor force in 2005. It was 148.6 million, not 48.6 million.

Puerto Rican food, music, dance and cultural exhibitions will fill the city starting this weekend as New York gears up for the 50th annual Puerto Rican Day parade. Though the parade is next Sunday, the organizers have arranged a number of activities as a warm-up. Today a photo exhibition, ''Bomba, Plena y Ponce,'' goes on display at the Manhattan Valley Golden Age Senior Center. Bomba and plena are both forms of music rooted in African tradition that slaves brought to the island. The exhibition will focus on the history of this musical genre, which originated in Ponce, Puerto Rico. ''The parade is dedicated to Ponce,'' said Carlos Velasquez, marketing director for the Puerto Rican Day parade. Tomorrow, a cultural festival on 152nd Street in the Bronx will offer Puerto Rican food and music, including a performance by the salsa singer Choco Orta. And on Sunday, a salsa contest at the Copacabana nightclub will give anyone who pays the $15 admission and takes to the dance floor a shot at dancing on the main stage the day of the parade, which will be televised. About 500 dancing couples are expected and, through a process of elimination they will be judged on the elegance of their steps, their spirit and their ability to stick to custom. (Photo exhibition, through June 10, 135 West 106th Street, Manhattan; free. Street festival, 152nd Street between Jackson and Union Avenues, South Bronx; free. Salsa contest, Sunday from 5 p.m. to 10 p.m., 560 West 34th Street, Manhattan; $15. For information: nationalpuertoricandayparade.org.) ROJA HEYDARPOUR

OLDHAN--Brent, on May 22, 2007. One of the good guys is gone. We will miss your humor, your wit, your passion and those long, interesting, meandering conversations. Stanley and Ronni Monsky Joel and Rose Monsky

PaceWildenstein 32 East 57th Street, Manhattan Through June 23 Commercial galleries frequently mount exhibitions of museum-quality works. Not so often do they base such shows on their own groundbreaking, museum-quality research. PaceWildenstein, prompted by Arne Glimcher, one of its owners, has done just that with this stunning if somewhat overdesigned exhibition. It puts a fascinating new contextual spin on the genesis of Cubism's glissandos of transparent, stuttering, revolving, shattering forms: both Picasso and Braque were fans of the infant art of motion pictures during their Cubist years.

To the Editor: Re ''No More Excuses on Darfur'' (editorial, May 30):

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Wednesday about plans by Mike Wallace to have the first interview with Jack Kevorkian, the assisted suicide advocate, after he is released from prison in Michigan today referred incorrectly to the prison. It is a state prison, not a federal one.

The vibrations are somewhere on the brink between good and bad in the songs of Animal Collective, a group formed in New York seven years ago by old friends from Baltimore whose songs are as joyous are they are eerie. Building on loose improvisations with lo-fi instrumentation that makes them sound like a folkier version of Pavement, the four pseudonymous members of Animal Collective -- (shown, from left) Geologist, Avey Tare, Deacon and Panda Bear, though they don't seem to mind being called Brian, Dave, Josh and Noah -- send the sunniest and most playful Beach Boys melodies through endless, sometimes frightening psychedelic transformations, guided by dream logic and a love of the carnivalesque. ''I think it's all right to feel inhuman,'' sings Avey Tare over weirdly pulsating electronics and thudding tribal rhythms on ''Strawberry Jam'' (Domino), their outstanding new album, to be released in September. The band plays tonight with Danielson at the opening of the Seaport Music Festival at South Street Seaport, an essential indie-rock series that runs through the end of August as part of the River to River Festival in Lower Manhattan. Others at the Seaport this summer include Fujiya & Miyagi, Menomena, Bishop Allen, Camera Obscura, the National and Battles. (Tonight at 7, Pier 17, Fulton and South Streets, Lower Manhattan, 212-835-2789, seaportmusicfestival.com or rivertorivernyc.com; free.) BEN SISARIO

William Meredith, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who used the rigorous constraints of meter and rhyme to subdue some of the most uncontrollable aspects of the human condition -- fear, loneliness, destiny, mortality -- died Wednesday in New London, Conn. He was 88 and had homes in Uncasville, Conn., and West Palm Beach, Fla. The cause was heart and respiratory failure, according to Byles-MacDougall Funeral Service in New London.

Now Alex Rodriguez knows what is like to be Lindsay Lohan, a serial mainstay of celebrity culture. There he was Wednesday on the front page of The New York Post, pictured in a Toronto hotel with a woman, who, as the tabloid noted, was not his wife. ''STRAY-ROD,'' read the perfect headline. A day earlier, the Post's front page featured a stark image of Lohan, apparently unconscious in her car. ''SMASHED,'' the headline said.

With a two-hour edition of ''So You Think You Can Dance'' on Wednesday, Fox easily won the night's ratings, overshadowing the debuts of two new shows on other networks. According to Nielsen's estimates, 9.2 million viewers tuned in for the dancing competition from 8 to 10 p.m. Meanwhile the series premiere of ABC's ''Next Best Thing: Who Is the Greatest Celebrity Impersonator?'' managed to tie for first in the 8 p.m. hour in total viewers (7.7 million) while lagging behind among adults 18 to 49. CW's ''Hidden Palms'' also made its debut in the hour, but came in last place with a disappointing 1.8 million viewers. At 10, a repeat of CBS's ''CSI: NY,'' the night's most-watched show, led the hour over all, lifting CBS into second place for the night behind Fox. ABC ranked third as its new series ''Traveler'' garnered mediocre audiences with a rebroadcast of its pilot at 9 (5 million) followed by a new episode at 10 (6.2 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

An inquiry into the shooting death by the police of an aboriginal man during a land claim protest in 1995 called on the government to establish an independent land claims agency to settle a growing number of claims by Native Canadians. The protester, Dudley George, was shot by a police sniper during the protest in Ontario. The inquiry's report comes as Native leaders are threatening rail blockades and occupations this summer to protest more than 1,100 unsettled claims across the country. CHRISTOPHER MASON

Gerald Peters Gallery 24 East 78th Street, Manhattan Through June 8 The art of Marguerite Zorach (1878-1968), painter, textile artist and wife of the sculptor William Zorach, is usually visible one or two works at a time in gallery and museum shows devoted to early American Modernism. This exhibition of about three dozen canvases ranging in dates from 1910 to the mid-1960s is the first in recent memory devoted solely to her work. It is not quite as top-notch as previous glimpses had led me to hope, but it is a moving and informative homage to a woman who was something of a pioneer of European Modernism in the United States.

New Jersey Republicans yesterday filed a lawsuit in State Superior Court charging that the Democratic governor, Jon S. Corzine, was violating the state's Open Records Act by refusing to release e-mail messages he exchanged with his former companion, the president of a state employees union, during recent contract negotiations. Lawyers for the governor say that the e-mail messages between Mr. Corzine and Carla Katz, president of the Communications Workers of America Local 1034, are protected by gubernatorial privilege. Mr. Corzine's lawyers also point out that a state ethics panel has reviewed the messages and concluded that the governor acted appropriately. But Mark Sheridan, a lawyer for the Republican State Committee, said the law required Mr. Corzine to disclose any correspondence that discusses the contract negotiations because they involve state business. DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

Minute after hypnotic minute, LeBron James lifted into the air, suspended in a stratosphere where only he could breathe and only he could see the basket. Every time his feet hit the ground a split second before his improbable jumpers hit the bottom of the net with Detroit Pistons all over him, the Palace of Auburn Hills fell into stunned silence. It was as close to reverence as a home team could show, after seeing James take over the game and the series.

WHAT do Brad Pitt, Barack Obama and Garrison Keillor have in common? At some time in their lives, they've all sung in choirs. An estimated 23 million American adults are doing so now, according to a survey by Chorus America, an association of vocal ensembles. With numbers like that, it's not hard to understand why so many people love choral music. Whether experienced from within the chorus or from the audience outside, the unique sound of music made by groups of people using their own voices has a universal appeal. At choral festivals this spring and summer, audiences will hear classic and modern choral works, often directed by renowned conductors, in settings ranging from a lavish California performance hall to a hockey rink in Massachusetts. And some music lovers will also be able to mingle with singers or do some singing themselves.

Former Senator John Edwards, a Democratic presidential candidate, told an interviewer on Wednesday that he had read the classified October 2002 National Intelligence Estimate before voting to authorize force in Iraq, but his campaign retracted the statement yesterday. A spokesman for Mr. Edwards said the candidate had ''simply misunderstood the question'' and noted that Mr. Edwards had read only a declassified version of the intelligence report.

PACKARD--Margaret Waldo ''Pat'', May 26, 2007. Beloved mother of Bruce Waldo Remick and the late Lee Remick, cherished grandmother of Kate Minelian, Matthew Colleran, Stacey RemickSimkins, Shelby Brambach, and great-grandmother of Remick Minelian and Georgia Minelian. Memorial service Sunday, June 3, 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed new regulations yesterday that are expected to increase by more than fourfold state spending on civil legal services for the poor. The regulations will require banks to pay a far higher interest rate on funds deposited in special accounts that lawyers use to temporarily hold money deposited by clients. Interest from these accounts has traditionally been used to pay for civil legal services, but banks have been paying an interest rate of 0.5 percent, on average. The new regulations will require banks to pay a more competitive rate of about 2.7 percent. The change, which requires a 45-day comment period but not legislative approval, is expected to increase financing for civil legal services for the poor from more than $13 million to as much as $65 million. DANNY HAKIM

Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to nominate Attorney General Stuart Rabner to be the next chief justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, potentially leaving his imprint on the state's legal landscape for the next two decades, administration officials said yesterday. If Mr. Rabner, who turns 47 on June 30, is confirmed by the State Senate and serves until the mandatory retirement age of 70, he will break by six years the record for the longest tenure of a New Jersey chief justice.

An article last Friday, about summer weekend destinations in and near New York City, misstated the age of the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y. The hotel dates to 1983, not 1874. No part of any of the three previous Garden City Hotel buildings was used in the construction of the current building, which is in a different location on the property.

HARRISON--Augusta, on May 29, 2007. Beloved mother of Peyton and Virginia. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, June 2nd, 4:30 pm, at St. John's of Lattingtown Church, Locust Valley, NY. Donations to Glen Cove Animal Lovers League will be appreciated.
To the Editor: Re ''Danger: Playground Ahead,'' by Allison Arieff (Op-Ed, May 29):

Opens today nationwide. Directed by Davis Guggenheim 95 minutes A familiar underdog story told with unusual sensitivity, Davis Guggenheim's ''Gracie'' depicts the obstacles faced by a young girl who dreams of playing on her high school soccer team. Yet the movie's follow-your-heart simplicity masks deeper concerns; like the recent ''Flicka,'' this perceptive family drama is really about a daughter's struggle for her father's attention.

SHAPIRO--Howard I. Devoted husband of Dorothy, his wife of over 53 years, father of Jay, Lawrence, Gail, and Daniel, grandfather to Rachel, Sarah, Brian, Adam, David, Derek, Benjamin, and Jayme passed away peacefully on the morning of Thursday, May 31, 2007, surrounded by his loving family. Howard was a distinguished civil engineer and author, practicing with his sons Jay and Lawrence since 1983. He proudly served his country as an officer in the U.S. Army. Despite his unassuming nature, he was a major force in his chosen field of crane engineering. All who knew him admired him for his integrity, honesty and playful wit. Funeral services will be held at 12:30pm on Sunday, June 3rd, at Gutterman's Chapel, 175 North Long Beach Rd., Rockville Center, LI.

Because of an editing error, a brief art review in Weekend last Friday about an exhibition of works by Luigi Ontani used an outdated name for the gallery where the works are being shown. It is just Bortolami, not Bortolami Dayan.

Two men were shot, one fatally, in the Olinville section of the Bronx shortly before 10 p.m. yesterday, the police said. One man was dead at the scene, in front of an apartment building at 3553 Holland Avenue, near 212th Street, from a gunshot to the head. The other man, who was shot multiple times in the torso, was taken to Jacobi Medical Center in critical condition. A man believed to have fired the shots fled in a gray vehicle, the police said. JENNIFER 8. LEE

A sports article on Wednesday about the auction of letters written by the Olympic champion and football player Jim Thorpe to the woman who became his second wife misstated her surname. She was Freeda Kirkpatrick, not Fitzpatrick.

A front-page article on Jan. 21 about the presidential prospects of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton referred incorrectly to the results of a Washington Post/ABC News poll on Jan. 19. The poll found that Mrs. Clinton had the support of 41 percent of Democrats questioned, not a favorability rating of 41 percent among all respondents. (Her favorability rating among all of those questioned was 54 percent.) The error was pointed out on Wednesday in a posting on the Web site of Media Matters for America.

INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Bush Calls for Global Goal In Curbing Greenhouse Gas President Bush, fending off international accusations that he was ignoring climate change, proposed for the first time to set ''a long-term global goal'' for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, and he called on other industrial nations to join the United States in negotiations aimed at reaching an agreement. A1 U.S. Official Assails Putin A top Russia expert at the State Department issued an unusually sharp public criticism of Moscow's behavior under President Vladimir V. Putin. A1 New Twist in Poisoning Case The suspect in the fatal poisoning of Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer and Kremlin critic who died last year in Britain, said Britain's foreign intelligence agency and a self-exiled Russian tycoon had organized the killing and framed him to create a political scandal. A3 Hunting for Kidnapped Britons The search for five British civilians kidnapped from an Iraqi government building intensified with American troops conducting raids in Sadr City, a Shiite stronghold, and the Iraqi government pledging its support for an investigation. A8 Union to Weigh Israel Boycott A movement in Britain to boycott Israel economically gathered pace as the country's biggest labor union said it would follow the union of university instructors in weighing punitive measures against Israel. A15 New U.S.-India Nuclear Talks Talks intended to restart negotiations on a landmark nuclear pact between India and the United States began in New Delhi amid disagreement over India's right to continue testing nuclear weapons. A11 NATIONAL A16-22 Officials Identify Man With Dangerous TB The man with a dangerous form of tuberculosis who flew to Europe for his wedding and honeymoon was identified as a 31-year-old Atlanta lawyer. Department of Homeland Security officials said he re-entered the country from Canada when a customs agent let him pass despite knowing that the man was being sought by health authorities. A1 Secret Program is Under Fire The Senate Intelligence Committee questioned the continuing value of the Central Intelligence Agency's secret interrogation program for terrorism suspects. A18 Agent in Leak Case Sues C.I.A. Valerie Wilson, the former intelligence operative at the heart of an investigation that reached into the White House, sued the Central Intelligence Agency over its refusal to allow her to publish a memoir that would discuss how long she had worked for the agency. A18 Gene Scientist's DNA Decoded The full genome of James D. Watson, who jointly discovered the structure of DNA in 1953, has been deciphered, marking what scientists believe is the gateway to an impending era of personalized genomic medicine. A19 Library Dedicated to Minister Hundreds of friends, family members, ministers and politicians gathered to dedicate a library commemorating the ministry of the evangelist Billy Graham. A16 Increase in Minority Students The nation's minority student population, driven by an extraordinary influx of Hispanics, surged to 42 percent of public school enrollment, up from 22 percent three decades ago, according to an annual report. A21 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Columbia Will Let State Oversee Student Aid Office Columbia University will pay $1.1 million to a fund to educate students about loans and has agreed to have its financial aid office monitored by state officials for five years, under a settlement reached with the New York State attorney general. B1 New Jersey Pension Inquiry The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into New Jersey's handling of its pension fund for public employees, suggesting that federal regulators are concerned that the state treasury did not properly disclose its contributions to the fund. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Bancrofts Open to a Sale In a remarkable turnaround, the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, agreed to meet with Rupert Murdoch, just weeks after the family rejected an initial $5 billion takeover offer from Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation. A1 Law Firm's Founder May Go William S. Lerach is considering leaving the law firm he founded. While the exact reasons behind his career considerations remain unclear, it suggests that the investigation into accusations of kickbacks paid to class-action plaintiffs has gained momentum. C1 Google and Privacy Issues A feature in Google's map service that allows users to zoom in on urban images is raising privacy concerns. But Google said it had consulted with public service organizations in designing the service. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES A23 William Meredith A Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who used the rigorous constraints of meter and rhyme to subdue some of the most uncontrollable aspects of the human condition -- fear, loneliness, destiny, mortality -- he was 88. A23 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Ahead of the Group of 8 meeting, talking about warming and a real plan for AIDS; witness protection; knowledgeable furniture. Column: David Brooks. Crossword E32 Public Lives B2 TV Listings E24 Weather D7

Opens today in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. Directed by Timur Bekmambetov In Russian, with English subtitles 140 minutes The second installment of Timur Bekmambetov's bustling supernatural trilogy cares not if you're familiar with the first. Save for a brief recap of its overcooked mythology, this movie picks up without explanation a number of years after ''Night Watch'' concluded, rejoining the champions of Light and Dark and their forever fragile truce.

It was clever or childish, cunning gamesmanship or borderline cheating, or maybe something in between. But when Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees shouted something to a Toronto Blue Jays infielder Wednesday night, helping cause a pop-up to drop and leading to three runs, the debate began. The only certainty is that the play further blurred the line between what is fair or foul in the unwritten code of baseball -- and solidified Rodriguez's reputation as a player willing to test boundaries. Players, coaches and baseball observers interviewed yesterday routinely struggled to articulate what was permissible and what was not, and why.

Two Russians, Sergei Rublevsky and Evgeny Bareev clinched their preliminary candidates matches today at the expense of Ruslan Ponomariov of Ukraine and Judit Polgar of Hungary, respectively. Alexei Shirov of Spain avoided elimination when he beat Michael Adams of England to tie the match and force a playoff tomorrow. Joining them in the playoffs are Magnus Carlsen of Norway and Levon Aronian of Armenia and Rustam Kasimdzhanov of Uzbekistan and Boris Gelfand of Isreal.

The Yankees will not start Roger Clemens on Monday in Chicago, after all. Clemens hurt his groin during his last minor league start for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre on Monday and has been unable to shake the discomfort. He will miss the Chicago series and perhaps be lost for two more weeks. Kei Igawa, who has been in the minors for about a month as he revamps his delivery, is expected to start on Monday against the White Sox.
Spain has witnessed a 7.4 percent drop in the number of properties sold in 2006, with new-builds down 10.11 percent to 389,594 units. Is more trouble on the horizon?
This week's mix of guests and journalists on the Sunday shows is rather eclectic, but it covers some of the ground again on the topics of the day, week, the month, and yes, the year.
If you have high ethical standards, I have two opportunities for you to contribute to the cause of science.
The author of "The Kite Runner" and the new best seller "A Thousand Splendid Suns" talks with The Times's Motoko Rich.

With a pair of debates Sunday (Democrats) and Tuesday (Republicans) putting the focus on New Hampshire, many in the Democratic field are swinging from that critical early primary state where there's an event this morning, to Iowa tonight for the state party's annual Hall of Fame Dinner.
Oakland receiver Jerry Porter said he will keep number 84 for one more year, after learning he would have to pay $210,000 to switch to number 81.
If you're worried that the airwaves are no longer safe for rudeness, you’ll be buoyed by “The Graham Norton Show.”
A glance at four seasons over 60 years suggests that the decline of the straight play is real.  Everything else seems to be going up.

When catcher Jorge Posada came to the mound before the bottom of the ninth inning tonight, this is what Scott Proctor said he told him: "Listen, you don't need to do anything here. Just get out of here."
LeBron James stripped the Pistons of their defensive identity, not to mention their dignity during his 48-point romp in Game 5 of the Eastern Conference finals.
A former airport worker was in custody in Brooklyn and two other men were in custody in Trinidad.

I get plenty of ribbing from my husband about being an only child. His theory, after spending most of his life with a younger sister, goes something like this: The size of the bite one mooches off a cupcake is inversely proportional to the number of siblings one has. Only children never got pinched by anyone for taking more than their share, so they never learn.
The destruction of Sarha bridge appeared to be part of an effort by Sunni insurgents to isolate Kirkuk and limit interaction between residents of different areas and sects.
The Lebanese Army intensified its offensive against the Fatah al Islam militia at the Nahr al Bared refugee camp.
The Yankees kicked off the month of June with an outburst of offense to put them 12½ games behind Boston in the division race.
Third baseman Mike Lowell left in the top of the fifth inning with a bruised left hand. Right fielder J. D. Drew left in the top of the sixth with a strained right hamstring.
The F.B.I. is expected to report a 1.3 percent rise in violent crime nationwide in 2006, an increase for the second straight year.

HARTFORD, June 1 (AP) — A measure legalizing the medical use of marijuana won final legislative approval in Connecticut’s State Senate on Friday night, capping a five-year struggle that pitted broader concerns about patients’ rights against fears of easing access to an illicit drug.
Cathrine Kraayeveld scored 21 points and Shameka Christon had 11 to give New York the win.
The Mets managed four singles — only one of them out of the infield — and were baffled by the Diamondbacks’ starter, Brandon Webb.
In a conciliatory tone, the defense secretary said he was hopeful about future dealings between the U.S. and China.

A fire that severely damaged the Hekhal Haness synagogue in Geneva in the early hours of May 24, or Shavuot, the Jewish festival, was deliberate, the investigating magistrate, Michel Graber, said, ruling out an accidental cause. He said there was no indication that it had been set by extremists. The synagogue, Geneva’s largest, is owned by the Swiss businessman Nessim D. Gaon.

Col. Théoneste Bagosora, left, considered to have been the military organizer of the Rwandan genocide, pleaded for his name to be cleared in the closing arguments of his five-year trial at the United Nations tribunal court in Arusha, Tanzania. “I didn’t kill anyone, nor give any order to kill anyone,” he told the court. Colonel Bagosora, 66, who has been in prison for 10 years, was the cabinet director for the Defense Ministry at the start of the slaughter by Hutu of 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu in 1994. He and three other senior army officers on trial with him since 2002, Gratien Kabiligi, Aloys Ntabakuze and Anatole Nsengiyumva, are charged with genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. A date for the verdict has not been announced, but the court’s presidency has said it does not expect it before 2008.
An 8-year-old boy was being questioned after he was accused of killing his infant sister and cousin and another baby.
The European Union’s enlargement commissioner, Olli Rehn, said suspended pre-entry talks with Serbia could resume potentially this month.
A rail worker in a coma since 1988 has woken up and is amazed by people who walk around with their mobile phones.

A federal judge gave doctors for John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot President Ronald Reagan in 1981, more flexibility to help Mr. Hinckley, left, rejoin society. Officials at St. Elizabeths Hospital here, where Mr. Hinckley is under treatment, sought to loosen restrictions on how far in advance they must alert the Secret Service when they take Mr. Hinckley into the community to attend baseball games, the theater and other events. Hospital officials were required to alert the Secret Service of any outings two weeks in advance, but the judge, Paul L. Friedman of Federal District Court, said the hospital need only give four days’ notice.

The governor signed new fire safety requirements for the state’s long-term care facilities in response to a deadly fire at a group home for the mentally ill and disabled. The governor, Matt Blunt, a Republican, signed the bill at the site of the fire, the former Anderson Guest House in southwest Missouri, where 11 people died in the blaze on Nov. 27. The legislation requires complete fire alarms and heat detector systems by the end of 2008. It also requires sprinkler systems by the end of 2012, though lawmakers concerned about the costs exempted many residential care and assisted-living facilities from that requirement. Of the state’s 616 long-term care facilities, about half lack sprinkler systems.

Two whale sharks arrived at the Georgia Aquarium in Atlanta, after making an 8,000-mile journey from Taiwan. Their arrival comes just over four months after the death of Ralph, another whale shark who was a star of the aquarium when it opened in 2005. Ralph had stomach problems that led to an inflammation of a membrane in his abdomen, aquarium officials said. But some animal rights groups have questioned whether his death involved a chemical used in the tank to treat parasites.

A man convicted of murdering a photographer three and a half years after his release from prison for a rape he did not commit was sentenced to life in prison with no chance for parole. The man, Steven Avery, 44, was convicted in March of killing the photographer, Teresa Halbach, 25, on Halloween 2005 near his family’s rural auto salvage lot. Judge Patrick Willis of Manitowoc County Circuit reviewed Mr. Avery’s previous offenses, including a case in which he doused a cat with gasoline and tossed it in a bonfire. “You are probably the most dangerous person ever to set foot in this courtroom,” Judge Willis said. Mr. Avery previously spent 18 years in prison for rape. He was freed in 2003 after DNA samples proved him innocent.

Fuqua School of Business at Duke University in Durham, N.C., rejected appeals from 24 students who were punished earlier this year in a cheating scandal. The master’s of business administration students were given until June to appeal. In April, 34 students were punished after a professor noticed similarities among their work. Nine students faced expulsion and 15 faced a one-year suspension and a failing grade in the course. Ten others were found guilty of lesser offenses.
President Fidel Castro is almost recovered from intestinal surgery that put his life at risk in 2006, according to the National Assembly president, Ricardo Alarcón.

A whale carcass spotted near the Golden Gate Bridge was that of a California gray whale — not one of the two humpbacks that had roamed the Sacramento River for weeks, officials said. A boater reported seeing a whale carcass shortly before 6 a.m. Coast Guard crews searched and found the carcass under the bridge around 1 p.m. Jim Oswald, a spokesman for the Marine Mammal Center in Sausalito, said the dead whale had numerous boat-propeller wounds. Mr. Oswald said the humpback mother and her calf had not been spotted since Tuesday, and scientists believe they are back in the ocean.
The government banned demonstrations in the capital in the latest effort to quell turmoil over President Pervez Musharraf’s decision to suspend Chief Justice Iftikhar Mohammed Chaudhry.
Parliament passed a package of legislation needed to stage new parliamentary elections in September.
Four defendants allegedly filed claims for 20 brain operations that did not take place.

An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day yesterday about Congressional efforts to rein in tax shelters referred incompletely to a tax shelter case involving United Parcel Service. Although a federal court did indeed rule that U.P.S. engaged in sham transactions to avoid hundreds of millions of dollars in corporate income taxes, that ruling was rejected in 2001 by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit.

The listing of lottery results on Tuesday misstated two winning numbers for Monday’s New York Take 5 in some copies. The winning numbers were 5, 12, 35, 36 and 37; the numbers 17 and 26 were not drawn.

An article last Saturday about efforts by Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey to promote seat belt safety referred imprecisely to a public service announcement in which he appears. Mr. Corzine, who was not wearing a seat belt when he was badly injured in a crash in April, is standing throughout the ad; he does not rise from a chair before walking off on crutches in the final moments.

An article yesterday about Robert B. Zoellick, President Bush’s nominee to be the next president of the World Bank, gave an incorrect figure in some copies for the bank’s total lending to poor countries. It is $23 billion, not $23 million.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the possibility that global warming could lead to an increase in hurricanes misstated part of the name of an organization that studies hurricane formation. It is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, not “Oceanographic.”.
Corrections

Because of an editing error, several words are missing in some copies from an article this weekend on Page 12 of the special Tony Awards section of Arts & Leisure about indelible moments on Broadway. The passage — the first two paragraphs of an item on “The Coast of Utopia” — should read:.

An article on Wednesday about the impact that a Senate proposal to overhaul immigration law could have on New York misstated a provision of the bill. Immigrants who are relatives of United States citizens and have overstayed their temporary visas could indeed qualify for legalization on the same terms as illegal immigrants who crossed the border surreptitiously. Also, the article referred incompletely to another provision of the bill. While it would eliminate the right of citizens to sponsor their parents — a right that is now unlimited — it would create an annual quota of 40,000 visas for which citizens could compete to bring parents into the country.

An article on May 18 about a contemporary-art auction at Phillips de Pury & Company referred incorrectly to the buyer of one of two Andy Warhol camouflage images that were sold. While one went to a telephone bidder for $1.4 million, the other, which sold for $712,000, was bought by Yung Hee Kim, who was in the auction room, not bidding by telephone.

A sports article on Sunday about late-game decisions by LeBron James of the Cleveland Cavaliers, and about how his development as a star player compares to that of other N.B.A. greats, referred imprecisely to two defining plays involving Michael Jordan’s Chicago Bulls in the 1990s. It was Horace Grant, not Jordan, who passed to John Paxson for the title-clinching 3-pointer in the 1993 N.B.A. finals against Phoenix. And in the 1997 finals, Jordan’s teammate Steve Kerr made a 2-point shot, not a 3-pointer, to lift Chicago over Utah.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) — Now the Chicago Cubs are really being beat up — by each other.
New Education Department rules would set new standards for universities and ban practices that have resulted in loan company payoffs to college officials.
The New York City Council is poised to introduce one of the most sweeping campaign finance overhauls in the country.
There are no reports of anyone being harmed, but the U.S. is the seventh country to find a poison in toothpaste.
Facing an outcry over plans to slaughter 300 bison that repeatedly migrate out of a national park, Gov. Brian Schweitzer has proposed a plan to truck them further in.
The retailer said it will reduce the number of new supercenters to be opened this year by nearly 30 percent, or roughly 75 stores.

The three pieces presented by Ben Munisteri Dance Projects on Thursday at Dance New Amsterdam use ballet so extensively that you start to think that the work might look even better coming from a ballet company.

Connecticut has picked a fight with the independent board that tells state and local governments how to report their financial affairs.
The Brazilian Federal Police said that the two Americans had not knowingly caused the crash, but that their negligence had contributed to Brazil’s worst air disaster.
More cars than light trucks were sold in the U.S. last month, as gasoline prices nationwide soared to more than $3 a gallon.

Mr. Anderson, a longtime Republican leader in the New York State Senate, helped bail New York City out of its fiscal crisis in the mid-1970s.
Adm. Edmund P. Giambastiani Jr., who has guided Pentagon efforts to rewrite strategy and budgeting, will retire from the military.
The Bush budget strategy boils down to never-ending tax cuts for the rich, big increases for the Pentagon and spending cuts for everything else.
Steve Yeager has learned the hard way about being in the wrong place at the wrong time. He is just grateful to have survived.
A company that fixed a mangled freeway worked so fast that some residents have recalibrated their respect for the California Department of Transportation.

Gregory Zalevsky is playing for sympathy as he defends himself in a Brooklyn murder trial.

Maj. Gen. Richard A. Huck testified that all his superiors, including the top commander in Iraq, knew of the killings in Haditha within hours.
An organization that supports the United States’ continued presence in Iraq plans to buy property used by the antiwar activist Cindy Sheehan since 2006.
Yankees Manager Joe Torre said it was inappropriate for Alex Rodriguez to have distracted a Toronto fielder by shouting as he ran past him on the bases Wednesday.
After days of relative quiet, Lebanese troops fought much of the day to seize positions that had been occupied by Fatah al Islam militants.
The government transferred jailed leftist rebels to a holding center on Friday as part of President Álvaro Uribe’s bid to win freedom for 60 rebel-held hostages.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer wants to make New York the third state to give workers paid leave to care for newborn children or seriously ill family members.
David Dellucci singled home the winning run with two outs last night to cap a five-run ninth and lead the host Cleveland Indians to a 12-11 victory against the Detroit Tigers.
The Mets have been dealing with injuries for much of the season. So far nothing has slowed them down, as reserves have played an integral role in maintaining the team’s momentum.

Chinese markets swooned, but American investors reached new heights. The World Bank has big money-raising needs for its new leader.

(Hallmark Channel) MARCO POLO (2007) Ian Somerhalder (“Lost”), left, plays that 13th-century rambling man who barely survived a trek from Venice to the far side of the world, where he spent 20 years in the court of the Mongol ruler Kublai Khan (Brian Dennehy) and discovered mysteries like timepieces, paper currency, a postal system, pasta and ice cream. INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Makeshift Bombs Sow Rising Frustration in Iraq American commanders are expressing frustration at the increasing death toll in Iraq caused by makeshift explosives, which have killed 80 percent of the American forces who died in combat in the past three months, despite the billions of dollars being spent to combat the threat. A1 The number of unidentified corpses discovered in Baghdad soared more than 70 percent during May, according to the Iraqi Interior Ministry. A6 Sudan Aid Group in Upheaval Even with the seeming triumph of helping attain President Bush's new sanctions against Sudan, the Save Darfur Coalition, which helped bring the conflict to the world's attention, is in upheaval. A5 18 Killed in Clashes in Lebanon Lebanon's army moved closer to a Palestinian refugee camp where a group of militants has been hiding, seizing new ground in a fight that left 18 dead. A7 Video of Abducted Journalist For the first time since his abduction, a British reporter kidnapped in Gaza on March 12 was shown in a video released to an Islamic militant Web site. A7 Rice Tries to Ease Fears on Iran Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice sought to minimize any sense of division within the Bush administration over Iran after the head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency warned against what he called the ''new crazies'' pushing for military action against Tehran. A5 NATIONAL A8-11 Toothpaste From ChinaIs Said to Contain Poison Consumers were advised to discard all toothpaste made in China after federal health officials said they found Chinese-made toothpaste containing a poison used in antifreeze in three locations -- Miami, the Port of Los Angeles and Puerto Rico. A1 New Rules on Student Loans The federal Education Department released proposed rules that would set new standards for universities and ban lenders' marketing practices that have resulted, in some cases, in loan company payoffs to university officials. A1 Close Bush Aide to Step Down Dan Bartlett, President Bush's longest-serving aide and one of his closest confidantes, said he was leaving the administration this summer, the latest departure in what has been a shrinking of President Bush's inner circle. A10 Kevorkian Leaves Prison Jack Kevorkian, the former pathologist who brought the debate over physician assisted suicide into the national spotlight a decade ago saying he had helped 130 terminally ill people in their deaths, stepped out of a Michigan prison having pledged not to assist anyone else. A8 Police Less Driven by Bias In making snap decisions about whether to shoot a potentially armed suspect, police officers are far less influenced by racial bias than students or community members forced to make the same decision, a large study has found. A8 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Spitzer Pressing for Plan To Give Paid Family Leave Gov. Eliot Spitzer is pushing to win legislative backing for a plan that would give workers in New York State paid leave to care for newborn children or seriously ill family members. B1 Campaign Finance Limits The New York City Council is poised to introduce some of the most sweeping campaign finance restrictions in the country, aimed at limiting the influence of contractors, lobbyists, developers and others who do business with the city. B3 Religion Journal B5 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 U.S. Economy on the Rise The economy appears to have shaken out of its slumber. In May, employers added nearly twice as many jobs as they did in April. C1 Meeting on Dow Jones Bid The decision to meet with the News Corporation could be a pivotal moment in the history of Dow Jones & Company and the Bancroft family, which has controlled it for more than a century. The meeting will take place Monday. C1 Sex Industry Declines The Internet was supposed to be a boon for the pornography industry, with wider distribution and social acceptance increasing sales. Now the business is in decline -- and the Internet is being held responsible.
