To the Editor: Dalton Conley's call for unbundling the marriage contract into its constituent parts (''Spread the Wealth of Spousal Rights,'' Op-Ed, May 20) overlooks the fact that the rationales for many marriage-based benefits are inextricably linked to the obligations spouses supposedly have to each other.

Cherished grandmother of the late Suzanne, Meredith (Joey), Deborah (Rich), Christopher and Hilary. Beloved great-grandmother of Joseph, Samantha, Michael, Zoie and Zachary. An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day yesterday about Congressional efforts to rein in tax shelters referred incompletely to a tax shelter case involving United Parcel Service. Although a federal court did indeed rule that U.P.S. engaged in sham transactions to avoid hundreds of millions of dollars in corporate income taxes, that ruling was rejected in 2001 by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit.

An article on May 18 about a contemporary-art auction at Phillips de Pury & Company referred incorrectly to the buyer of one of two Andy Warhol camouflage images that were sold. While one went to a telephone bidder for $1.4 million, the other, which sold for $712,000, was bought by Yung Hee Kim, who was in the auction room, not bidding by telephone.

The listing of lottery results on Tuesday misstated two winning numbers for Monday's New York Take 5 in some copies. The winning numbers were 5, 12, 35, 36 and 37; the numbers 17 and 26 were not drawn.

Darian Barnes has done some of his best work creating comic-book characters like Paradox, Outback and Ironbound in a series called the ''National Triumph League.'' He has created the story lines of their lives and has overseen their illustration. Now, after signing with the Jets as a free agent during the off-season, he will try to bring stability to a revamped backfield as the team's starting fullback.

In an unusual twist, draft prospects for the Nets and the Knicks will work out for both teams simultaneously Tuesday. Call it a marriage of convenience. The N.B.A. this year pushed back and condensed the time frame for working out players. The changes have forced teams to become creative, in some cases holding joint workouts.

BECK--Darma. The Department of Art History and Archaeology at Columbia University mourns the death of Mrs. Darma Beck, wife of our late colleague and mentor Professor James H. Beck. We extend our deepest sympathy to the Beck family.

A sports article on Sunday about late-game decisions by LeBron James of the Cleveland Cavaliers, and about how his development as a star player compares to that of other N.B.A. greats, referred imprecisely to two defining plays involving Michael Jordan's Chicago Bulls in the 1990s. It was Horace Grant, not Jordan, who passed to John Paxson for the title-clinching 3-pointer in the 1993 N.B.A. finals against Phoenix. And in the 1997 finals, Jordan's teammate Steve Kerr made a 2-point shot, not a 3-pointer, to lift Chicago over Utah.

The World Trade Center Memorial Foundation announced a partial list of its major donors yesterday, showing a wide range of contributions from well-known figures and companies. Leading the roster, with a $25 million gift, was the Starr Foundation, and closely behind at $15 million were Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who took over as chairman of the fund-raising effort last year; Deutsche Bank, the memorial's neighbor in Lower Manhattan; and David Rockefeller.

SHERER--Leslie, The Independent Suwalk & Vicinity Benevolent Association mourns the passing of our Honorary President and longtime leader, Leslie Sherer. Born in Suwalki, Poland, Mr. Sherer was active in the Association from his arrival in the United States in the 1930's and served as its President for many decades. He was the heart and soul of our organization and will be missed by all the members. Our heartfelt condolences go to his beloved wife Fay and his extended family and many friends. Services will be at Sigmund Schwartz Chapel, 2nd Avenue at 9th Street, Sunday, June 3, at noon. Arthur S. Leonard, President

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the possibility that global warming could lead to an increase in hurricanes misstated part of the name of an organization that studies hurricane formation. It is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, not ''Oceanographic.''

An article last Saturday about efforts by Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey to promote seat belt safety referred imprecisely to a public service announcement in which he appears. Mr. Corzine, who was not wearing a seat belt when he was badly injured in a crash in April, is standing throughout the ad; he does not rise from a chair before walking off on crutches in the final moments.

To the Editor: Lawrence J. Korb (''Over Here,'' Op-Ed, May 27) notes that some 80 percent of our National Guard has served overseas and that this is largely responsible for the pitiful federal responses to the disasters in New Orleans and Kansas. But the solution is most certainly not to create another pseudo-branch of the military. It is to use our current branches appropriately, a logic that has seemed to fly over the head of the current administration.

China's stock market plummeted Wednesday after Beijing imposed higher taxes on stock trading activity in an attempt to cool off a sizzling market. China's two major stock indexes fell sharply in a huge sell-off, and the Shanghai composite index was down 6.5 percent.

An article yesterday about Robert B. Zoellick, President Bush's nominee to be the next president of the World Bank, gave an incorrect figure in some copies for the bank's total lending to poor countries. It is $23 billion, not $23 million.

BAGATELLE--Warren D. Devoted husband of Hedy, his wife of over 44 years; father of David, Tracy and Adrien; grandfather to Olivia, Molly, Emma and Alexander passed away peacefully the morning of Thursday, May 31, 2007. Warren was a wellknown investment banker and partner at Loeb Partners Corporation. He also served on numerous corporate and not-for-profit boards. Prior to joining Loeb Partners, he ran the NYSE member firm of Rosenkrantz Ehrenkrantz Lyon & Ross. Prior to his career on Wall Street he was a turn-around specialist and ran several publicly traded and privately held companies. He began his career at Arthur Andersen & Co. He was educated at Union College (Class of 1960) and received an MBA from Rutgers University. He was a Certified Public Accountant. He proudly served his country as a member of the United States Coast Guard. He was well respected for his integrity, honesty, dignity, and intelligence. His favorite pastimes included spending time with his friends at his summer home on Lake Hopatcong, NJ, his antique wooden boats, his family, and Union College. He was an outstanding husband, father, grandfather and friend who will be greatly missed by all whose lives he touched. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, June 3 at 11:30am at the Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, 07039. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to the Graduate College of Union University, c/o Union College, Lamont House, 807 Union Street, Schenectady, New York, 12308. Please note on the check that this is for the Warren D. Bagatelle Scholarship Fund.

An article on Wednesday about the impact that a Senate proposal to overhaul immigration law could have on New York misstated a provision of the bill. Immigrants who are relatives of United States citizens and have overstayed their temporary visas could indeed qualify for legalization on the same terms as illegal immigrants who crossed the border surreptitiously. Also, the article referred incompletely to another provision of the bill. While it would eliminate the right of citizens to sponsor their parents -- a right that is now unlimited -- it would create an annual quota of 40,000 visas for which citizens could compete to bring parents into the country.

A human skull cast in platinum and covered with 8,601 diamonds, weighing 1,106.18 carats, went on view yesterday at the London gallery of its creator, the British artist Damien Hirst. The gallery, White Cube, said the skull cost $23.5 million to make and is being offered for $98 million. Timothy Marlow, the gallery's director of exhibitions, said that three collectors had shown interest in buying it. The bejeweled skull, presented in a dark room under a single spotlight, is called ''For the Love of God'' and is part of ''Beyond Belief,'' a larger show of Mr. Hirst's recent work being presented through July 7 at White Cube's Mayfair and Hoxton Square galleries. ALAN RIDING

To the Editor: Your May 31 editorial ''Injustice 5, Justice 4'' is correct. The Supreme Court's Ledbetter v. Goodyear opinion flies in the face of precedent and clear Congressional intent to reduce discrimination by facilitating employees' civil suits, while it fails to recognize the pragmatic realities of the modern workplace.

ADAMS--D. Nelson, of Barneveld, NY and New York City died peacefully May 31, 2007 at Partridge Hill, his beloved Barneveld home. He was 97. He was a graduate of the Buckley School, Hotchkiss School, Yale University where he was a member of the Whiffenpoofs, and Harvard Law School where he was President of the Harvard Law Review. From 1935 to 1936, he served as a law clerk to Judge Learned Hand of the U.S. Court of Appeals. From 1942 to 1946, he served in the Army Air Force, where he achieved the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. Nelson joined the law firm of Davis Polk and Wardwell in 1936. He was elected partner in 1949, named head of the tax department in 1950 and Managing Partner of the firm in 1970. Nelson was devoted to many charitable and community interests. He served as president of the Buckley School and was a trustee of the Bugher Foundation, the National Hypertension Association, the Schuyler Center for Analysis and Advocacy, and the Foundation for Mood Disorders. Nelson was predeceased by his wife Diana and by his brother Howard. He is survived and deeply missed by his son, Daniel, and his grandsons, Bryan and Bruce. Nelsons family will hold him always in their hearts. He was a true gentleman, always kind and generous of spirit. A Memorial Service will be held at 4:00 P.M, June 28, at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave. The Funeral will be in Barneveld. For information: dan@daniel-adams.com. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Danny Adams Fund at The Community Foundation of Herkimer and Oneida County, 1222 State Street, Utica, NY. $(6$)ADAMS--Daniel Nelson. It is with great sadness that The Buckley School of the City of New York announces the death of beloved alumnus, Honorary Trustee and former parent, Nelson Adams. A member of the Class of 1924, Mr. Adams was also an alumnus of The Hotchkiss School, Harvard University and Yale University. Mr. Adams served on the Buckley Board of Trustees from 1950 to 1983. During that time he was elected President of the Board twice and served as an Honorary Trustee until his death. He will be deeply missed by all of us in the Buckley community who benefited from his wisdom, humor and integrity. Our condolences go to his son, Dan Adams of Barneveld, NY; and to his grandsons, Bruce Adams of Hartford, CT, and Bryan Adams of Canton, CT, and their families. There will be a memorial service on Thursday, June 28th at 4p.m. at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue. Jeffrey F. Welles, President Nancy G. Blackford, Vice President Gregory J. O'Melia, Headmaster Brian R. Walsh, Headmaster Emeritus, The Buckley School

WALLER--Leslie, April 1, 1923-March 29, 2007. Author of more than 50 books, Leslie Waller passed away March 29th, 2007, in Rochester, NY, of natural causes attended by family. Waller is most well known for his New York Times best seller, The American, the novelization of Dog Day Afternoon, under his pseudonym, Patrick Mann, and his original story, Hide in Plain Sight, made by James Caan into a movie. Waller was the ghost writer for Steven Spielberg's Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and coauthor, with Arnold Blake, of It Rhymes with Lust, which some have suggested is the first modern graphic novel, recently re-issued by Dark Horse Comics. A memorial will be held for him on Wednesday, June 6th, 2007, at Writers & Books, 740 University Avenue, Rochester, NY, 5-8 pm, with remarks at 6:30 pm. The public is welcome. Contact: David Doser Funeral Home (585) 223-9144

To the Editor: As the author of ''A Farewell to Justice,'' which challenges the conclusions of the Warren Commission, I was taken aback by Bryan Burrough's suggestion in his review of ''Reclaiming History,'' by Vincent Bugliosi (May 20), that those who do not accept Bugliosi's defense of the Warren report should be ''marginalized'' and made to ''stand in the rain with the other outcasts.'' Ideas, after all, are best argued on their merit, and the First Amendment of the Constitution appears to encourage debate even on issues of received wisdom. Burrough apparently has no stomach for the subject, as he attempts to malign inquiry into the assassination of President Kennedy as ''one of the left's more wrongheaded crusades.''

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the artist Sigmar Polke misidentified the country that took control of his birthplace, Oels, Silesia, in 1945. It was Poland, not East Germany. (Mr. Polke's family moved from Silesia to East Germany at the end of World War II.)

WEINSTEIN--George W., M.D. 72. Formerly the Jane McDermott Shott Professor and Chair, Department of Ophthalmology, Robert C. Byrd Health Sciences Center, West Virginia University, Professor and Chair, Division of Ophthalmology, University of Texas Health Sciences Center, San Antonio, Texas. He was a past president of the American Academy of Ophthalmology, former Regent of the American College of Surgeons and faculty member of the Wilmer Eye Institute, Johns Hopkins University. He is survived by his wife, Sheila, his son and daughter-in-law Bruce and Kristen, his daughters, Elizabeth and Rachel, two grandchildren, Carlee and Sammy, a sister, Barbara and brother-in-law, Daniel. Donations may be made in his memory to the Neurosciences Center for Dementia Research, Mayo Clinic Development Office, 4500 San Pablo Road, Jacksonville, FL, 32224.

HAKES--Martha Jean. March 6, 1930-May 24, 2007. Jean Hakes lived and worked in New York from 1964 to 1989. She died peacefully on Thursday, May 24, 2007 at her home in San Francisco at the age of 77. Ms. Hakes, born in Muscatine, Iowa, was the dear daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Crampton Hakes; loving mother of Barbara; grandmother of Benjamin; beloved sister of Mary Anne Gallagher and the late Elizabeth H. Harrer. She was dearly loved by many other family members. Jean had many friends and colleagues on the East Coast who made her life joyful personally and professionally for over 25 years. Jean Hakes, a soprano, was extremely active throughout her career in performances of early and Baroque music. She was a soloist and toured with the New York Pro Musica under Noah Greenberg and appeared with numerous chamber groups such as the New York Baroque Ensemble, the Renaissance Quartet, the Trio Flauto Dolce and the Washington Consort, in addition to her numerous solo appearances including performances at Yale University, the University of California at Berkeley and New York University. She sang the role of ''Galatea'' in the New York Chamber Soloists presentation of Handel's Acis and Galatea in major concert series throughout the United States. She was professor of music at Brooklyn College where she also directed a Collegium Musicum. ''Few are the singers who can spin out a phrase as she does, with an equal mixture of emotional suspense, rhythmic flair and stunning dynamic control,'' commented the Washington Post of her performances. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Conservatory of Music Brooklyn College -The City University of New York 2900 Bedford Avenue Brooklyn, New York 11210. Phone: (718) 951-5286. Fax: (718) 951-4502.

SOMETIMES, after a long day of working with Wookiees, Ewoks, Jedi knights and Mandalorian bounty hunters, even the employees of Lucasfilm need a break. And when they get distracted, like anyone else stuck in an office, they surf the Web. Their own particular fetish is videos, and among their favorites -- no surprise -- has a ''Star Wars'' theme. It is an animated short from ''Robot Chicken,'' the series created by Seth Green and Matthew Senreich for the Cartoon Network's Adult Swim programming block. In it the evil emperor Palpatine receives a weepy phone call from Darth Vader after the Death Star is destroyed. Only the emperor's (heavily bleeped) portion of the conversation is audible as he learns that his battle station has been blown up by a band of meddlesome teenagers. (''That thing wasn't even fully paid off yet,'' he grouses. ''Do you have any idea what this is going to do to my credit?'')

With an unusually high number of state lawmakers retiring this year, voters in the primary election on Tuesday will find more contested races than in the past. Twelve state senators are retiring, and 13 members of the Assembly are forgoing their seats to run for the Senate. There are some hotly contested primaries in Hudson, Bergen and Sussex Counties. Among the most closely watched contests are a handful of legislative races in Essex County, where Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark has endorsed three candidates who are vying for seats held by longtime incumbents.

To the Editor: Re ''Parks for All New Yorkers'' (editorial, May 20): Governors Island is a precious untapped resource, but not only for parks. In October 2001, when Mayor Bloomberg was first running for office, he pledged to place a major high school complex on the island.

Ray Smith, a spirited Yankees fan, once decided the team's lineup with Manager Joe Torre, called catcher Joe Girardi one of his best friends and playfully told the announcer Michael Kay that he would one day have Kay's job on the YES Network. Smith's life revolved around his faith, his family and baseball. That short, determined life ended last Tuesday night when Smith, who was born with a congenital heart defect, died from heart disease at Yale-New Haven Hospital in Connecticut. Smith turned 23 one day earlier. Funeral services are today at Grace Community Church in Lake Katrine, N.Y.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Heinrich Heine Memorial in the Bronx, misstated its location on the Grand Concourse. It is 161st Street, not 164th Street. (It was moved from 164th Street in 1999.)
To the Editor: Re ''Not Your Mom's Prom?,'' by Kate Stone Lombardi (Generations, May 27):

To the Editor: How David Allan in ''36 Hours: Baltimore'' (May 20) can use the phrases ''galleries that specialize in contemporary art'' and ''alternative arts in Baltimore'' and not direct visitors to the American Visionary Art Museum is puzzling indeed. Situated on Key Highway, on the south side of Baltimore's Inner Harbor, the museum has fabulous outsider art. Stop by the Visitor Center on the harbor and ask my 81-year-old father to point you in the right direction. If he's not working, someone else will help you. Leslie Pollack Bethany, Conn.

Founders Park pool in Islamorada, Fla., is a 50-meter oasis of fresh water flanked by the turquoise Gulf of Mexico, a rock's throw to the west, and the white-capped Atlantic, a quarter-mile to the east. This self-proclaimed ''sport-fishing capital of the world'' is as close as I've come to finding aquatic paradise. I'm just trying my best not to, in the parlance of our sport, die here.

An article last Sunday about the movie ''Gracie,'' based on events in the life of the actress Elisabeth Shue and her family, misstated the cause of death of Ms. Shue's brother William. He died of injuries suffered in a fall, not in a car accident.
A column last Sunday on a teach-in at Weston High School featuring Ned Lamont misspelled the writer's name. It is Gerri Hirshey, not Hershey.
FELSEN--Esther. June 3, 1921 -June 28, 1998. Nine years gone, but never forgotten. Always loved. Her loving family

A second stretch of Interstate-78 will undergo major construction this summer. In March the State Department of Transportation began a $42 million reconstruction of 2.3 miles of local lanes on I-78 between Route 24 and the Garden State Parkway in Union. This month the department will begin a $2.1 million project in Bedminster in Somerset County, to repair the I-78 East bridge over I-287 North and to extend the acceleration ramp from I-287 South to I-78 West.

STANGER--Abraham M. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed Trustee and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

Consider this the next time you're tweaking your fantasy baseball lineup: you are part of an intellectual revolution. A minor revolution, perhaps, somewhat less ambitious than the call to arms described in ''Moneyball,'' but a revolution all the same. With every hour you spend ''managing'' your fantasy team, with every moment spent devouring the literary output of experts like Ron Shandler, the fabled publisher of Baseball Forecaster, or Matthew Berry, a writer otherwise known as ''the Talented Mr. Roto,'' with every soul fiber you sink into fantasy baseball, you move one step closer to becoming a postmodern baseball fan. Makes you feel better, no? For three decades, fantasy baseball has been rightly called a despoiler of work and family life, with the only side benefit -- if you can call it that -- being an intimate familiarity with the backup catchers of the Milwaukee Brewers. But lately there seems to be a new elegance in the fantasy universe, a sort of native intelligence. As every baseball fan knows, fantasy has grown in both size -- 15 to 18 million people are now estimated to play some kind of fantasy sport -- and prestige. Open your local sports page and you are likely to find fantasy baseball treated with a reverence formerly reserved for ''real'' baseball. Instead of gazing at box scores, as they did in the 1980s, fans can go to Yahoo and ESPN.com for supercharged scoring. Fox has inserted fantasy statistics into its game-of-the-week broadcasts, and even crusty old Fenway Park puts the fantasy stat WHIP (walks plus hits per inning pitched) on a scoreboard. In baseball's fantasy era, we are beginning to see fans engaging in a metaphysical feat never thought possible: being a fan of fantasy baseball without being a fan of the game as it's played on the field.

INTERNATIONAL 3-26 Bricks Sustaining India's Poor As India undergoes an unprecedented construction boom, more and more Indians are giving up farming for the meager wages of brick making. But the success of the brick business is as much a portrait of a growing industry as it is a testament to the dismal state of the Indian peasantry. 1 Lebanon Closes In on Militants Heavy shelling and gunfire continued for the second day at the Nahr al Bared refugee camp, as the Lebanese Army intensified its offensive against the Fatah al Islam militia. The chairman of the Ford Motor Company has a question for Senator Barack Obama: Have you driven a Ford lately? Mr. Obama, the Democratic presidential candidate, recently lectured Detroit's automakers, saying they were doing too little to reduce oil consumption. Last week, at a policy conference on Mackinac Island in northern Michigan, William Clay Ford Jr. told business leaders that Mr. Obama should have done a little more investigating before he spoke.

Most dearly beloved wife of the late Sigmund Halpern, loving mother of Susan, Jerry, Pam, grandmother of Stephen, Joshua and Michael, aunt of Ruth Gideon and David Gandell. She's in our hearts today and everyday. Funeral June 4, Gutterman's Funeral Home 175 North Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre at noon.

The Cultured Traveler column last Sunday about La Paz, Bolivia, misstated the surname in some copies for Roberto Cazorla Guzman, the owner of the Costilla de Adán bar. As the article noted in other references, he is Mr. Cazorla, not Mr. Guzman.

The Parenting column last Sunday, about a seventh-grade handwriting champion at a Roman Catholic school, St. Pius V, in Melville, N.Y., gave an incomplete account of the circumstances surrounding the suspensions of several students last year. While a parent said the suspensions were for remarks about the school's nuns that students posted on the Internet, the principal, Sister Maria Dolorosa, said the students were suspended because they used the Internet to view movies and listen to music that they knew were prohibited by the school.

Veronica Anne Beke and Christopher Thomas Aquilino were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. Duncan at the United Methodist Church of Southampton in Southampton, N.Y. The bride, 32, is a deputy attorney general with the office of the New Jersey Attorney General. She graduated from Indiana University and received her law degree from Seton Hall.

For years, N.B.A. coaches have tried to achieve optimum productivity from their players, tinkering and toying with various lineups. To find the most effective combinations of players on the court, coaches have played hunches, ridden hot streaks, gone by the book and against it, and searched as high as Yao Ming and as low as Muggsy Bogues for pieces to fit their hardwood puzzles. Although there has never been a proven formula for winning, there is the Lenovo Stat, a plus-minus rating that shows which players as a group are most productive.

A plan to reduce the amount of water and wastewater going into the sewer system in the Village of Northport will soon mean changes for local restaurants, bars, butcher shops and fish markets. The village enacted a law on May 15 that will eventually require restaurants, bars and other places where food and drink are consumed on site to install low-flush toilets and urinals that will cut down on the amount of water used.

FOR most people, a home is an anchor. It secures you to a particular spot and dampens the occasional impulse to set off in pursuit of a crazy dream. But for Brian Nesbitt and Alicia Collins, home exerts just the opposite force: get out of here, it says to them -- the sooner the better. That's because they live with their cat and dog on a 44-foot sloop, the Sarabande, docked at a marina in New Jersey. And on a sailboat, you can't help yearning to see the world.

TRASH MOUNTAIN The News -- Climbers from Japan and Nepal removed about 1,100 pounds of garbage from Mount Everest. Behind the News -- The world's highest mountain, at 29,028 feet, has also been called the world's highest garbage dump. Over the years, would-be summiteers have left behind tons of trash -- tents, oxygen bottles, pots, stoves and other junk, not to mention the corpses of dozens of climbers. The Japanese climber Ken Noguchi says his teams have hauled 19,800 pounds of garbage in five trips since 2000. This year, he says, ''the amount of waste left on the mountain has been drastically decreased.'' SPACE DEBRIS The News -- Two Russian cosmonauts erected protection panels on the International Space Station to shield it from space debris. Behind the News -- The cosmonauts spent about five and a half hours outside setting up the protective panels. Scientists consider space debris, which includes discarded rocket parts and small rocks, to be the biggest threat to the space station, which orbits 220 miles above Earth. NASA says about 11,000 human-created objects larger than 10 centimeters -- about 4 inches -- are in orbit, plus another 100,000 particles between a centimeter and 10 centimeters in size. CALL IN THE BULLDOZERS The News -- Officials in India said Wednesday they are seeking developers to demolish the Dharavi slum in Mumbai, India's financial and entertainment capital. Behind the News -- The slum's tin shanties and garbage-strewn alleys lie on prime land in the heart of the city. Perhaps one million people live in Dharavi, but the city counts just 56,000 families. The United Nations estimates there is 1 toilet per 1,440 people. Mumbai wants to build new housing, shopping, schools and hospitals as part of a $2.3 billion project. Residents will be offered free 225-square-foot apartments, but some say they fear they will end up with nothing. SPAMALOT NO MORE The News -- Federal authorities in Seattle arrested a man they say is one of the world's most prolific e-mail spammers. Behind the News -- Robert Alan Soloway, 27, was accused of using networks of compromised computers to send out millions of spam e-mails. Mr. Soloway advertised that he could send out 20 million e-mails over 15 days for $495, according to the federal indictment. He pleaded not guilty to charges of mail, wire and e-mail fraud and other crimes. ''He's one of the top 10 spammers in the world,'' said Tim Cranton, a Microsoft lawyer. ''He's a huge problem for our customers. This is a very good day.'' NO WHERE LEFT TO GO The News -- Tons of garbage piled up on the streets of Naples, Italy, after the only working dump in the area closed. Behind the News -- Italy's president warned of an ''ecological and health disaster'' in the country's third-largest city. The city's neighborhoods have resisted efforts to build incinerators, recycling centers and new trash sites as existing dumps filled up. One nearby town has opened its dump for 20 days to take some trash, but after that, who knows? Many residents are burning their refuse or leaving it to rot. ''This is a situation that is tied to the incapability of the political structure,'' said one politician.

''Clinical trial investigators must be culled from only the finest physicians in the country, since they work on the frontiers of new knowledge. That drug makers are scraping the bottom of the medical barrel is an outrage.'' DR. Seven hundred students and their teachers from West Brook Middle School in Paramus will begin holding classes at Bergen Community College on Tuesday, a week after Mayor James J. Tedesco III ordered the middle school campus closed because soil on school grounds was contaminated with pesticides. School officials learned in December that the soil was contaminated at a level up to 39 times the state's safety guidelines, but did not inform parents until mid-May.

It was a single line from a longer e-mail message. But when read into the record by prosecutors at the drug trial last year of the German track coach Thomas Springstein, it caused a sensation. ''The new Repoxygen is hard to get,'' Springstein had written. ''Please give me new instructions soon so that I can order the product before Christmas.'' Until that day in the courtroom, Repoxygen was an obscure gene-therapy drug developed at a pharmaceutical lab in Oxford, England, to fight anemia. The lab shelved the product when it seemed unlikely to be profitable. Once it was mentioned in court in January 2006, however, Repoxygen vaulted to celebrity-drug status in Europe. Newspapers and Web sites ran dozens of stories about the imminent danger of the therapy. ''The moment that e-mail was presented in open court,'' a columnist wrote in the weekend paper Scotland on Sunday, was when the ''era of genetic doping . . . arrived.''

BILOON--Sandra, of South Main St., West Hartford, Connecticut, died Friday, June 1, 2007. She was predeceased by her husband, Harold Biloon, and by her parents, Morris and Helen (Antler) Green. She received her Bachelor of Arts degree from Radcliffe College, Harvard University and a Master Of Arts degree from Trinity College, Hartford. She was Director of Personnel and Labor Relations for the State of Connecticut and served as president of the International Public Management Association for Human Resources as well as the National Association of State Personnel Executives. Sandra was an adjunct professor in the Master of Public Affairs program at the University of Connecticut and also served as a neutral labor arbitrator. Funeral services are private. Services entrusted to Weinstein Mortuary, Hartford, Connecticut.

Sunday Money Speed! Lust! Madness! Death! A Hot Lap Around America With Nascar By Jeff MacGregor. Photographs by Olya Evanitsky. 370 pages. HarperCollins, 2005. Early in 2002, as the wounds of 9/11 still throbbed, Jeff MacGregor packed a motor home and pointed it toward Florida. For 40 weeks and 48,000 miles he and his wife, Olya Evanitsky, crisscrossed the nation, caroming from raceway to raceway, immersing themselves in all things Nascar, the ruling body of a sport that ''distills to an essence America's obsession with speed and sex and death,'' he writes.

To the Editor: In her review of my book ''Four Queens'' (May 27), Megan Marshall repeatedly takes me to task for overemphasizing the political roles of the four daughters of Raymond Berenger V, the Count of Provence. What disturbs me most about Marshall's criticism, beyond the obvious, is the implication that she is sufficiently authoritative on the subject to make such a judgment. In fact, Marshall consistently reveals herself to know little or nothing of the period. No further proof is needed than her constant reference to the daughters of the Count of Provence as the ''Berenger sisters,'' a jaw-dropping whopper of an error that no historian even remotely acquainted with the Middle Ages would make. Raymond Berenger was a single appellation, akin to Jean-Louis. Jean-Louis's daughters wouldn't be called the ''Louis sisters.''

An article last Sunday about the transfer of Woodlawn Cemetery's archives to the Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library of Columbia University misstated the connection between Janet Parks, the library's curator of drawings, and Charles Warren, an architect and preservationist who suggested a transfer of archives. Ms. Parks met Mr. Warren through one of her students; she is not a former Columbia classmate of Mr. Warren's. Also, a picture caption with the article referred imprecisely to the occupation of the three women shown with Susan Olsen, executive director of Friends of Woodlawn, who was on the left. The women are members of the library staff, not researchers. In addition, the article and a picture caption referred imprecisely to Isidor and Ida Straus's ownership of Macy's. The Strauses, who died when the Titanic sank, shared ownership of Macy's with Isidor's brother Nathan; they were not the sole owners.

Surf rivalries are generally rather tame affairs, but consider the opening salvo in the war between Ken Bradshaw and Mark Foo, as told in Andy Martin's new book, ''Stealing the Wave'' (Bloomsbury, $24.95). Bradshaw and Foo were the premier big-wave surfers at Hawaii's Waimea Bay, and one morning in the mid-1980s, Foo ''dropped in'' on Bradshaw -- meaning he co-opted his wave. Bradshaw flew into a De Niro-esque rage -- You're dropping in on me? -- and exacted his revenge by clotheslining Foo and taking a bite out of his favorite surfboard. It makes charging the mound seem tame by comparison. Bradshaw and Foo spent a decade snarling at each other, with casual slights in surfing magazines and confrontations at the beach. Martin describes Waimea in its pretourist state as a place of rigid social codes, where surfers enforced the decorum and a proper pecking order. And as he pushes toward the story's tragic finale (Foo died while surfing at California's infamous Maverick's break while Bradshaw bobbed in the water nearby), Martin manages to make the two men seem like they're battling not only for the hearts and minds of Brazilian groupies but for the fate of big-wave surfing itself. When hate seeps through the sunbaked haze of Hawaii, it is something truly majestic to behold.

IN most years, Rick Porcello, the 2007 Gatorade National Baseball Player of the Year, would have no equal as a high school player. He is a big, right-handed pitcher, a senior at Seton Hall Preparatory School in West Orange, N.J., who throws faster than most pros and whose route to the major leagues could be a short one. It is rare for a high school player from the Northeast to be thought of so highly. But this season, an unusual one for high school baseball talent in the region, there may be someone even better than Porcello.

Playful grandmama to Ryan and Brooke. Special pal to her most caring companion and aide, Judith. Services to be held Monday 11am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam.

Judith Ann Kelman and Dr. Peter Thomas Scardino were married yesterday at the GlenArbor Golf Club in Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Rev. William McD. Tully, an Episcopal priest, officiated, with Rabbi Uri D. Herscher taking part. The bride, 61, will continue to use her name professionally. She is the author of many books, including ''The First Stone'' (Berkley Books, 2007), and ''Summer of Storms'' (Putnam, 2001), for which she received the Mary Higgins Clark award for the best suspense novel of the year from the Mystery Writers of America. She graduated from Cornell University, received a master's degree in educational psychology from New York University and another master's, in communication disorders, from Southern Connecticut State University.

To the Editor: Re ''A First in Nigeria: A Peaceful Succession of Power'' (news article, May 30): Let's remember that international and domestic observers called the Nigerian elections fraudulent and the European Parliament issued a robust condemnation.

COVERING THE BASES Balk Talk Armando BenÍtez, who was traded to the Marlins from the Giants on Thursday, was called for two balks in the 12th inning against the Mets two days earlier; the second balk allowed the tying run to score. On May 4, 1963, Bob Shaw of the Milwaukee Braves tied the record for the most balks in an inning with three and set the record for balks in a game with five. Hot Hand John Lackey of the Angels (9-3, 2.37 earned run average) is scheduled to start against the Twins on Wednesday. Lackey has won his last five starts. Rookie Watch Troy Tulowitzki of the Rockies leads all rookies with 53 base hits. Colorado will be home against the Astros for a series that begins Tuesday. Streak on the Line Ichiro Suzuki extended his hitting streak on Friday to 25 games, a Mariners record. It is the sixth time in his career that he has hit safely in 20 or more straight games. Three other active players have at least three streaks of 20 or more games: Nomar Garciaparra of the Dodgers (five), Vladimir Guerrero of the Angels (three) and Manny RamÍrez of the Red Sox (three). Milestone Tracker Frank Thomas is five home runs from 500 and one from 244 as a designated hitter, which would break Edgar Martinez's record. Toronto will be home for a three-game set against Tampa Bay beginning Tuesday, then goes on the road against the Dodgers and the Giants. PLAYERS TO WATCH Chone Figgins, below, might have gotten the message. Figgins, the Angels' starting third baseman, was hitting .133 last week when Erick Aybar, a highly regarded prospect who is normally a middle infielder, started at third. Figgins, after having two days off, collected three hits and stole two bases. Aybar was 0 for 4 in his first start at third and is batting just .252. Figgins has long been the Angels' spark plug and figures to remain a regular. Jorge Julio, Byung-Hyun Kim and now Armando Benítez. The Marlins have a thing for frustrated closers. But Benítez, in addition to having a hittable fastball and an inclination to implode, is also dealing with a knee problem. The team's current closer, Kevin Gregg, should not have to look over his shoulder, unless, of course, it is to worry about the previous closer, Henry Owens, who came off the disabled list Thursday. He has batted .273 in April and May in his career, then .333 the rest of the season. Canó started June with a homer against Boston's Tim Wakefield. Statistics through Friday night. To the Editor: Re ''Grooming a Handwriting Champion,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, May 27): My son would benefit greatly if there were penmanship classes in public school. Every year I complain to his teacher that his handwriting is awful. The usual response is ''It doesn't matter, he can type on the computer'' or ''It's fine, I've seen worse.'' I receive a similar answer when I bemoan his appalling spelling: ''There is spell check.'' Apparently deciphering the incomprehensible is just part of teacher training.

If you saw Lauryn Williams on the street, you wouldn't think she was the reigning world champion in the 100-meter sprint. But the 5-foot-3, 127-pound Williams has always been faster than bigger, taller athletes; in elementary school, she outran boys five and six years her senior. ''That's when I started to know I had talent,'' the 23-year-old Williams says. At 20, she won the silver medal in the 100-meter dash at the 2004 Athens Olympics. The next year she earned gold at the World Championships, a title she'll defend this August in Osaka, Japan. So how is it that someone so small can run so fast? STRIDE FREQUENCY Because she had short legs and an unorthodox technique, Williams wasn't heavily recruited out of high school. But the women's track coach at the University of Miami, Amy Deem, saw her potential. The two have worked together ever since. ''She had frequency,'' Deem says, referring to Williams's high stride rate. Most elite female sprinters take about 4.6 steps per second; Williams takes 4.9. What separates Williams from the pack is her ability to get her feet off the ground quickly. ''The difference between not making the Olympic team in the sprints and making the team is a ground time of less than a hundredth of a second,'' says Ralph Mann, who studies runners' biomechanics for USA Track and Field. Williams reminds Mann of five-time Olympic gold medalist Michael Johnson. ''The coaches call them freaks,'' Mann says, ''because their turnover is simply out there.'' EXPLOSIVE FORCE ''If I want to decrease my ground time, I want to get very, very powerful so I can explode off the ground,'' Mann says. So in the off-season, Williams builds strength. Squats and bench presses prepare her to burst out of the blocks and drive through each step. As the season approaches, she shifts to lighter weights to work on quickness. Her muscles, like those of most speed athletes, have a high percentage of fast-twitch fibers, which contract the muscles faster. ''The slow-twitch fibers take longer to reach their peak tension, whereas the faster ones can peak really fast,'' says Dr. Bob Adams, the head of USA Track and Field's sports medicine and science committee. NEUROMUSCULAR EFFICIENCY Power is only a starting point. What's essential is ''the coordination of the firing of muscles at the right time in the right order in the right pattern,'' says Lisa Kearns, Williams's physical therapist. In a sport where hundredths of a second separate the best athletes from average ones, runners must have flawless technique and perfect balance. ''The center of the body must be stable so there isn't wasted motion,'' Kearns adds. ''The more they're able to stabilize through their pelvis and their core, the more efficiently the legs will respond to the messages being sent by the brain.'' When Williams was younger, she ran in an inefficient crouch. ''She didn't have a lot of what a track coach would call 'front-side mechanics,' '' Deem says. ''Her hips were rotated back, she was leaning forward when she ran and everything was happening behind her.'' Deem taught her to stand up straighter and keep her center of mass in line with her hips. This has lengthened her stride. ''We've shifted her hips underneath her,'' Deem says, ''so that she can bring the knee and the leg through in a better range of motion.'' SPEED ENDURANCE Even the best sprinters in the world slow down during the last 10 to 15 meters of the 100-meter dash. They just decelerate less than their competitors do. Williams trains at longer distances to develop stamina. The 100, she says, seems easy after sprinting for 250 meters: ''That's far. I call it the marathon.'' Most sprinters are now so specialized that they have trouble at different distances. OVERDRIVE None of this matters, though, without the requisite mental toughness, which would seem like a given but isn't. A sprinter's ''talent is very fragile, and it requires tremendous dedication,'' says Ralph Vernacchia, a performance consultant who has worked with the United States Olympic track team. ''Williams is the kind of athlete who thrives on the big-race.'' Deem says, ''She's, very competitive, and that's what sets her apart in a lot of ways.'' Well, that and pride. ''My thing at the Olympics was, I would be on national TV,'' Williams says. ''I just couldn't beout there losing with everybody in the whole country watching.''

To the Editor: John Green, in his review of Chris Raschka's ''Purple Balloon'' (May 13), recalls that colleagues at a children's hospital once told him ''that children were 'better' at dying than adults,'' but adds: ''I never saw it. The death I saw was painful.'' As a child life specialist working in a children's hospital, I can't imagine the death of a child as anything but difficult. However, I think Green may have misunderstood his colleagues.

Apparently, the Bronze Age has an expansion contract. Cosmetics companies are making bronzing-powder compacts the size of salad plates, guaranteed not to leave a square inch of skin unburnished. Color-hungry customers can choose from supersize compacts by T. LeClerc ($55, at Barneys New York), NYX ($16, at Duane Reade stores), Smashbox ($54 at Sephora) and Guerlain ($65, available in late July at Saks Fifth Avenue; call 212-940-2660 to preorder). Estée Lauder's limited-edition azurée soleil compact in blue enamel with gold trim hearkens back to 70s Côte d'Azur glamour in an extra big way ($75 at esteelauder.com). Brush the bronzer on the face, collarbone, even knees and shins for a hint of hue -- click the compacts closed and they could practically double as luxe Frisbees at the season's first barbecues.

LAST week, a battery of witnesses testified before two standing committees of the New York State Assembly citing numerous cases of wrongful conviction throughout the state and focusing on the role of DNA in winning exonerations for certain defendants. But the question remains: What should be done to reduce such mistakes from occurring in the first place? One answer: better investigation by the defense.

BONNEVILLE--Nancy Schneider, 1953-2007. Beloved wife of David Bonneville, devoted mother of Rebecca and Noah Bonneville, cherished daughter of Leila and the late Joseph Schneider. Elder sister to Hallie, Emily and Adam. Nancy was a native New Yorker, and a graduate of SUNY Binghampton. Her pleasures included reading, gardening, traveling, fashion and interior design. She had a truly unique passion for teaching, mentoring and molding thousands of young minds during a long and distinguished career as an English teacher and Chair of the English department at Clayton Valley High School, in Concord, California. Nancy's dedication to her family, friends and students will always be remembered. Donations can be made to the Wellness Community, San Francisco East Bay, 3276 McNutt Avenue, Walnut Creek, California, 94957.

I WAS standing on the curb, uptown, my hand raised for a cab. It was evening, and the sky was clear and the air cool. I had plenty of time, and I was happy: I was on my way to an international literary festival. The idea of this gave me a carnival sort of feeling, a fine fizzing excitement. There would be writers from all over the world, reading from their work, onstage. Why it excited me so I couldn't exactly say. Isn't the written word as powerful as the spoken one? Isn't that the point? But somehow it's thrilling to see the people whose words you have so admired, and to hear them speak those words in person. There is always the longing to be star-struck.

Earthlink, which has not had a permanent chief executive since Garry Betty died of cancer in January at the age of 49, is dangling unusual incentives before five of its top executives. Call them ''please don't leave before the new boss is chosen'' bonuses. Michael C. Lunsford, the interim president and chief executive, will collect $400,000 if he stays until May 1 and an additional $300,000 if he is still with Earthlink on Jan. 1, 2009.

To the Editor: Re ''A Barbaric Relic'' (editorial, May 27): I left England in 1967 when the death penalty had been suspended prior to its final abolition and have followed with alternate hope and distress the evolution of public and government attitudes here, particularly in my state of New Jersey. With the Senate Judiciary Committee vote, hope predominated. Since then there has been a development that had an uncanny parallel in England of the early '50s.

GAYDOS--Eve. The Staff and Graduates of Gestalt Associates for Psychotherapy announce a memorial for our dear friend and colleague, to be held on June 9th, at 10:30am-1pm, at Pilgrim Hill in Central Park, 5th Ave between 72nd/73rd St. We will celebrate Eve's love of color, music, movement, and beauty and honor the magic she brought to her work and life. Eve left us on April 16, 2007.

A season rife with injuries took another discouraging turn for the Yankees on Saturday when they learned that Roger Clemens would miss his start in Chicago on Monday with a right groin injury. Clemens was optimistic that he could return next weekend to face the Pittsburgh Pirates at Yankee Stadium. When Clemens called General Manager Brian Cashman during the early part of Saturday's game, Cashman told him to report to Tampa, Fla., where the Yankees' medical staff will evaluate him.

WHEN my parents moved us from a cramped apartment in an aging industrial city out to a raw new development in the suburbs, it seemed like Disney's Frontierland -- without Uncle Walt's thoughtful amenities. Dad took the Chevy to work, so the rest of us walked everywhere at first. The nearest loaf of bread was about a mile away. My mother adored her new pink ranch with the blue-tiled bathroom, but she missed the corner store and her sisters a short walk away. In a weak moment, as we struggled toward town against a mean November wind with my little brother, she yelled into the gale, ''How do people live here?'' A generation later, as my husband and I moved back out from Manhattan, two wee ones in tow, I understood her discomfiture. I knew the lay of the land; I'd grown up in the adjacent town. But, staring at a local newspaper listing announcing napkin-folding classes, not possessed of sufficient bonhomie for Newcomers Club sock hops, I howled, too: Where can you get a bottle of decent Vietnamese fish sauce? Why are they still selling -- and wearing -- the lime green golf slacks embossed with spouting whales that I hooted at in high school?

STADELMAN--Egon, P. A native of Berlin, Germany, adored husband of Marian (nee Stern) passed away peacefully in his home in Riverdale at age 96 on May 27, 2007 after suffering a stroke four and a half years ago. He was the son of Ferdinand and Margarete Stadelman. His father died in WWI. His mother was a victim of the Holocaust. During WWII, Egon proudly served in the US 76th Infantry Division. After the war, he worked as Special Events Officer for German Affairs with the NBC International Division until 1968. From then on, he worked in the same capacity for the Voice of America. In 1968, he joined the German Language Newspaper, New York Staats-zeitung as drama and music critic. He became Managing Editor of the newspaper until 1995. Stadelman was awarded the Great Cross of Germany and Austria for being instrumental in furthering the cultural relations between these countries and the U.S. In 1999 his autobiography Ein Leben lang Journalist was published. The cremation at Ferncliff Cemetery was private.

RIKLAN--Dr. Manuel (Ricky), of Yonkers, NY, formerly Director of Psychology Department at St. Barnabas Hospital, Bronx, NY, passed away May 26, 2007 at age 80. He was the loving husband of wife, Gloria and the father of three children, Joan Simon, Debra Vekstein and David Riklan, and had the blessings of seven grandchildren and everlasting love of brother Frank, sister - in - law and brother-in-law Shirley and George Mann, sons-in-law Greg Simon and Greg Vekstein and daughter-in-law Michelle Riklan.

It looks as though it may take a while for Starwood Hotels and Resorts to find a chief executive who lives within 700 miles of its headquarters in White Plains. In April, Starwood dismissed Steven J. Heyer, who was criticized about his management style and his insistence on maintaining his home in the Atlanta area. At least temporarily, Mr. Heyer's successor will live just as far away -- and in a different time zone, too.

Virginia Loftin has been spending a lot of time on these recent gorgeous days flying along the New Jersey coast looking, essentially, for scum. What Ms. Loftin, a research scientist for the State Department of Environmental Protection's Cooperative Coastal Monitoring Program, has found is an algae bloom. It is an intermittent film of oily brown organisms that has stretched, at various times over the last several weeks, from Sandy Hook through the Raritan Bay and on down to Seaside Park.

COOK--Dawn Mather, of Boston, age 71, died at home on May 10, 2007, of a brain tumor after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Donald Alexander Cook. She was born in New York City to Andrew Youngberg of Sweden and Eugenie Mather. Beloved mother of Constance, Malcolm and Allison. Beloved stepmother of Michael Cook of New York City. Sister of Desiree Mather of Copenhagen, Denmark and the late Jack Mather of Sag Harbor, NY. Also survived by four grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, June 9 at 12 pm in the Forsyth Chapel of Forest Hills Cemetery, 95 Forest Hills Ave., Jamaica Plain, MA. A reception will follow at the Loring Greenough House in Jamaica Plain.

Children learn a lot at school, not all of it for the better. As the Institute of Medicine reported in April, too many children pick up bad eating habits that can eventually kill them. Part of the problem is what the institute calls ''competitive foods.'' Instead of choosing the standard lunch, students choose junk food, much of it loaded with sugar, fat and salt -- the fuel for future diabetes or heart disease. Lawmakers in Albany have finally started looking seriously at new guidelines for what young people eat or drink on public school property. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the Assembly Democrats and the State Senate have each come up with proposals.
To the Editor: Re ''Grooming a Handwriting Champion,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, May 27):

The Classic Era By Beverly Rae Kimes Illustrated. 720 pages. Classic Car Club of America, 2001. The author presents a detailed year-by-year rundown of the American and European auto industry from 1925 through 1948, but don't expect any mention of plebeian Chevrolets, Fords or Dodges. As the title implies, this is a chronicle of the kings (and princes) of the road -- the higher-priced brands like Stutz, Cord, Auburn and Rolls-Royce (particularly the cars from the American factory in Springfield, Mass.).

It was a short but glorious week for the stock market, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closing on Friday at record highs. On Friday, a government report showed a surge in job creation in May. And an inflation gauge favored by the Federal Reserve -- the core personal consumption expenditure deflator -- rose in April at the relatively modest annualized rate of 2 percent.

The ''Living In'' article last Sunday, about Morningside Heights in Upper Manhattan, misstated the destination of the No. 60 bus. It is La Guardia Airport, not Kennedy Airport. In addition, a map with the article mislabeled the neighborhood's northern boundary. It is 125th Street, not 125th Avenue.

Children learn a lot at school, not all of it for the better. As the Institute of Medicine reported in April, too many children pick up very bad eating habits, habits that can eventually kill them. Part of the problem is what the institute calls ''competitive foods.'' Instead of choosing the standard lunch, students choose junk food, much of it loaded with sugar, fat and salt -- the fuel for future diabetes or heart disease. Armed with mounting data on these dangers, lawmakers in Albany have finally started looking seriously at new guidelines for what young people eat or drink on public school property. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the Assembly Democrats and the State Senate have each come up with proposals this year for better fare for students.

A bill introduced in the state Legislature last month would create a temporary state commission to explore the financial impact on local governments of the proposed Broadwater Energy liquefied natural gas plant in Long Island Sound. The sponsors, Senator Kenneth P. LaValle, Republican of Port Jefferson, and Assemblymen Marc S. Alessi, Democrat of Wading River, and Fred W. Thiele Jr., Republican of Sag Harbor, oppose the project and say too little is known about public costs for the police, firefighters and municipal services to protect a privately owned project and to be prepared for an accident or attack.
HOCHBERG--Marvin. SAR Academy mourns the loss of its longtime trustee and advocate for teachers and families. We owe much of our success to him. He will always be remembered. The SAR Family

After completing his 67-day, 3,278-mile swim down the Amazon River on April 8, Martin Strel, a 53-year-old Slovene, did not make the same mistake he made after finishing his 2,360-mile swim down the Mississippi in 2002 -- this time, instead of going home to Trebnje, he came to Hollywood. ''Jay Leno called us 37 times,'' says Strel's son, Borut, who manages his swimming expeditions, ''but we had appointments in Slovenia.'' But not today. Fifteen days after climbing out of the Amazon in Belém, Brazil, where he was promptly loaded into an ambulance for a ride to a local hospital (''with blood pressure at near heart attack levels,'' his official Web site reported), Strel and Borut are in Los Angeles, sipping red wine with a documentary filmmaker at a yellow-walled Italian restaurant in Marina del Rey. The filmmaker and his crew were with Strel for every stroke of his journey from Atalaya, Peru, to the Amazon's mouth, shooting a documentary, ''Big River Man,'' which is now being edited. Strel and Borut are in California to help with the editing, to brush up Strel's English in preparation for the film's publicity tour (and, they hope, a string of speaking engagements) and to field calls from the news media. ''I tell him, 'Why suffer again?' '' Borut explains. '' 'Why should we swim another river now? We should do show business. This is much more comfortable.' ''

As a senior corps member with the New York City Ballet, 22-year-old Georgina Pazcoguin spends most of each day rehearsing in a leotard, tights and leg warmers, then stepping right into costume for performances at night. That leaves a scant few hours to flaunt her own style, so she tries to make every minute count. ''I usually go out to dinner with friends after the show, so I wear outfits that I can layer,'' said Ms. Pazcoguin, who has been with the company five years. ''With a few really simple changes, I can be casual in the morning and more dressed at night.''

HASTINGS--Baird, 88. Died May 16, 2007; conductor, music educator and writer; predeceased by Lily, his wife and soul mate of 51 years; degrees from Harvard, Queens College and Sussex College; Mozart Festival Orchestra founder and conductor; faculty Trinity College and Juilliard; wrote many books and articles emphasizing French painters and Mozart. Memorial Service: Saturday, June 9, 2007, 11am, First Presbyterian Church, 5th Ave. and 11th St., NYC.
AUERBACH--Leonard W. August 24, 1917-June 3, 2002. Remembered and loved. Elizabeth, Ellen, David, and Maddie

To surf, a small verb lacking filigree or urgency, belongs to magical realism as much as to sport. Hawaiians, who were perhaps the first surfers, prayed for good conditions and venerated those who could truly harness a wave. Mark Twain wrote rapturously of his first encounter with surfing, watching a native Hawaiian ''face the shore and wait for a particularly prodigious billow to come along; at the right moment he would fling his board upon its foamy crest and himself upon the board, and here he would come whizzing by like a bombshell!'' When people started to explore the Internet, which promised endless possibility to anyone with a computer, they called it surfing. The magic and the promise aren't quite so sunny in the newest series from HBO, ''John From Cincinnati,'' which makes its debut on June 10, right after the final episode of ''The Sopranos.'' Despite being set in the Southern California surfing scene, the show is less about mastering the waves than surviving amid them. The first episode is filled with conflicts, scams, addiction and corruption, all familiar concerns to anyone who knows the work of its executive producer, David Milch, who created ''NYPD Blue'' and, more recently, ''Deadwood.'' And there are the usual compelling sidebars and memorable characters -- a lawyer named Dickstein, a retired cop who looks after birds and humans, gangsters in beach casual.

KANE--Lester, died peacefully at age 84 on May 31, leaving his devoted wife of 61 years, Libby, and children Nancy, Robert, Richard and Claudia, sons-in-law Michael and Ross, daughter-in-law Susan, and four grandchildren, Micah, Logan, Diego and Alicia. He was a World War II veteran who served the Judge Advocate General in Saipan with distinction. Les was a court reporter for 39 years, during which time he founded the Association of Surrogate and Supreme Court Reporters Within the City of New York, serving as its president for 18 years. He was a recipient of the Louis Goldstein Memorial Award, and a Fellow of the National Court Reporters Association. He was also the award-winning editor of -SERVE,-the B'nai B'rith (Crestwood Chapter) newspaper. Continuing a life-long interest in art, after retirement Les attended and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College. As a second career, he curated exhibits in Westchester of contemporary New York area abstract expressionist artists. He was an avid tennis player and was watching the French Open on television the day he died. His family and his dog Penny will miss him very much. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity.

To the Editor: I do not share Charles Isherwood's lament about the closing of ''Journey's End.'' Having seen the plodding production, I was distressed by the lack of energy and projection by the actors, the dimly lighted stage and the horrendous bunker set that must cut off all sightlines in the balcony and the mezzanine. We are weary of the war in Iraq, as well as of an old-fashioned play performed lethargically that gets rave reviews. Let's get back to the Greeks for a war play please. Daniel P. Quinn Morristown, N.J.

MIYAJI--Professor Hiroshi, 82, died on Thursday, May 24, 2007 in Burlington, Vermont. He will be fondly remembered as a generous, wise colleague of Middlebury College, and a loving and caring husband and father. He is survived by his wife, Sumiko and daughter Anna. The family would appreciate donations to be made to the Special Olympics in his memory.
MEREDITH--William. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. His loss will be deeply felt.

Eliane Zbinden, 29, a teacher from Fribourg, Switzerland. ''In Alausí, this small locomotive awaited us. For a few minutes, all these cultivated people forgot their manners -- there was pushing and shoving and swearing. Naturally, everyone wanted a place on the roof. The lucky ones had a place to sit and the unlucky ones sat squeezed into the middle. Surrounded by all these tourists, I was thrown back and forth. On one hand, I enjoyed the trip and the view; on the other hand, I felt rather unwell and squeezed in. When one moves through a landscape devoid of people, in such a situation, thousands of things float through the head: What still lies ahead for me? Have I made the right decision to be here? Should I be here? Oh, well. For one and a half hours, one has quite a bit of time to think.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

To the Editor: ''36 Hours; St. Petersburg, Russia'' (May 13) makes travel with children to St. Petersburg, Russia, sound as easy as a trip to St. Petersburg, Fla. Is there more than one Russia? This Russia sounds very much like Western Europe. The Russia I visited is very far away -- a miserable distance to fly with children -- and I can't believe the author recommended using Aeroflot, with its terrible reputation. I didn't read anywhere in the article that the State Department and most Russians will tell you not to drink -- or even brush your teeth with -- the local tap water. Nor did the story include State Department warnings to get updated tetanus and diphtheria immunizations (and preferably immunized against hepatitis A, too) prior to the trip.

Sometime in early July, Roz Savage will climb aboard her boat, the Sedna, in San Francisco harbor and pick up the oars for a long paddle westward. Savage, a 39-year-old former suit from Cheshire, England, decided five years ago that she'd rather die an adventurer than an I.T. project manager. Both she and the Sedna proved their seaworthiness during the 2,550-mile Trans-Atlantic Row in 2006, a race that took her 103 days (she finished 20th out of 26 boats; 6 abandoned the race). This time, the task is even more imposing: she will row 2,600 miles to Hawaii, the first leg of a three-part, 6,700-mile journey across the Pacific that will end in Australia in 2009. Here, a look at Savage's quest to become the first woman to row across the big ocean: 23 X 6

Volunteer firefighters in Larchmont sued the village last week to block the hiring of a paid fire chief, and nearly all active volunteers have resigned in protest, effective this month. The firefighters last Wednesday sought a preliminary injunction in State Supreme Court to block the hiring of Richard Heine as chief. They already have an elected chief, Chris McDonald, and they say a second chief, appointed and paid by the village, is illegal, unworkable and presents command risks.

To the Editor: Re: ''Welcome Back, Starshine'' by John Leland [May 20]: We always suspected a lot of '60s musicians were in it for the money. But even 40 years later it's like a punch in the gut to read Michelle Phillips's words. After saying that the San Francisco groups thought they were ''the real heart and soul'' (in contrast to Los Angeles groups like hers), she adds: ''I think they were just jealous because we were making the money. The whole point, I thought, was to make hit records.''

BAGATELLE--Warren. We are heartbroken at the loss of our dear friend Warren and send our love and condolences to Hedy and the entire family. Leslie and Charles Roden $(6$)BAGATELLE--Warren D. Devoted husband of Hedy, his wife of over 44 years; father of David, Tracy and Adrien; grandfather to Olivia, Molly, Emma and Alexander passed away peacefully the morning of Thursday, May 31, 2007. Warren was a wellknown investment banker and partner at Loeb Partners Corporation. He also served on numerous corporate and not-for-profit boards. Prior to joining Loeb Partners, he ran the NYSE member firm of Rosenkrantz Ehrenkrantz Lyon & Ross. Prior to his career on Wall Street he was a turn-around specialist and ran several publicly traded and privately held companies. He began his career at Arthur Andersen & Co. He was educated at Union College (Class of 1960) and received an MBA from Rutgers University. He was a Certified Public Accountant. He proudly served his country as a member of the United States Coast Guard. He was well respected for his integrity, honesty, dignity, and intelligence. His favorite pastimes included spending time with his friends at his summer home on Lake Hopatcong, NJ, his antique wooden boats, his family, and Union College. He was an outstanding husband, father, grandfather and friend who will be greatly missed by all whose lives he touched. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, June 3 at 11:30am at the Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, 07039. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to the Graduate College of Union University, c/o Union College, Lamont House, 807 Union Street, Schenectady, New York, 12308. Please note on the check that this is for the Warren D. Bagatelle Scholarship Fund.

THE past season has done little to disprove a familiar lament: As far as Broadway is concerned, the straight play is dead. ''Journey's End'' is about to become the latest casualty. Despite six Tony Award nominations for the revival of this 1929 drama by R. C. Sherriff, the final curtain will fall after a run of just under four months, only hours before the awards are presented next Sunday. Broadway is tough on plays, and toughest of all on new ones. ''The Little Dog Laughed'' barely surpassed 100 performances, while ''Coram Boy'' closed last Sunday after only 18 previews and 30 regular performances.

IN those final weeks before summer vacation, when temperatures can soar into the 90s, parents at 5 of Greenwich's 11 elementary schools without adequate air-conditioning could no longer watch their children wilt, along with the crayons, in the heat. So they approached the school board and air-conditioning was installed -- but not at the expense of property taxpayers; the parents raised the money. Students in two other elementary schools in town, without the same deep-pocketed parents, had to wait, however. They were finally granted air-conditioning after town officials squeezed the upgrades into capital budgets financed by taxpayers.
NEUWIRTH--Richard. Dearest Dick, we'll love and miss you always. Rest peacefully. Enid and Harold Rubin
