An article on May 20 about the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban misstated the word stenciled on crates that are part of an exhibit in his Nomadic Museum. It is Cosco, an acronym for the China Ocean Shipping Group Company, not Costco, the American warehouse store.

To the Editor: The ''abbanniata'' described in Danielle Pergament's ''Sicily; In Palermo, Life Vibrates in a Fading Market (Journeys, May 20) was a daily part of my experience as a little girl growing up in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. Although the fruit stands still stretch from 23rd Avenue to Bay Parkway along 86th Street, the tradition is gone, along with the many Italian immigrants who once predominated. Thanks for putting a name on a forgotten memory. Patricia Lobosco Brooklyn, N.Y.

ROSENZWEIG--Maxwell of Coconut Creek, Florida, formerly of Bayside, New York, died peacefully on May 30, 2007. Beloved husband of Mae (Blatt) for over 60 years; father of Robin and Alex Schkrutz and Roy Rosenzweig and Deborah Kaplan; grandfather of David and Eric Schkrutz; brother of the late Martin, Gladys, and Sylvia; ''Uncle Max'' to his nieces and nephews. He graduated from City College in 1938, served in the Army Air Corps during World War II, and worked at the New York State Department of Labor for more than 30 years. His family and friends will dearly miss his good humor, wise stories, and warm presence. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.

TUNICK--Mildred. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of an extraordinary lady who along with her late beloved husband Stanley were Founders of the College and helped advanced research in Ophthalmology. We extend our deepest condolences to her sons Andrew and Richard and to the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, MD The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean $(6$)TUNICK--Mildred S., 98, of Rye, NY, formerly of Palm Beach, FL and Rockville Centre, NY, on May 31. Beloved wife of the late Stanley, devoted mother of Andrew and Ana of New York and Richard and Carole of Scarsdale. Adored grandmother of Sara, Robert, Rebecca, Erica and David. An extraordinary woman who was a source of strength, wisdom and comfort to her family and all those privileged to have known her. Blessed with a remarkable intellect, constant curiosity, and unfailing optimism, hers was a life welllived.

IN those final weeks before summer vacation, when temperatures can soar into the 90s, parents at 5 of Greenwich's 11 elementary schools without adequate air-conditioning could no longer watch their children wilt, along with the crayons, in the heat. So they approached the school board and air-conditioning was installed -- but not at the expense of property taxpayers; the parents raised the money. Students in two other elementary schools in town, without the same deep-pocketed parents, had to wait, however. They were finally granted air-conditioning after town officials squeezed the upgrades into capital budgets financed by taxpayers.

On the eve of a presidential debate in New Hampshire, five Democratic candidates made a quick detour to Iowa on Saturday evening to appeal to nearly 1,000 party activists, seeking to distinguish themselves to the voters who will open the 2008 nominating fight. At the Iowa Democratic Party's Hall of Fame dinner, a parade of presidential hopefuls assailed President Bush's conduct of the Iraq war. Yet as the evening wore on, two candidates, John Edwards and Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, also suggested that their Democratic rivals in Congress have not done enough to end the war.

IN most years, Rick Porcello, the 2007 Gatorade National Baseball Player of the Year, would have no equal as a high school player. He is a big, right-handed pitcher, a senior at Seton Hall Preparatory School in West Orange, N.J., who throws faster than most pros and whose route to the major leagues could be a short one. It is rare for a high school player from the Northeast to be thought of so highly. But this season, an unusual one for high school baseball talent in the region, there may be someone even better than Porcello.

Cardinal Health, which provides drug delivery services for the health care industry, is continuing to shake up its executive tier. The company has appointed two officials to oversee its finances. It has also announced a $600 million reserve to settle a class-action suit, filed by investors, that focuses on its financial reporting and guidance. The company, which is based in Dublin, Ohio, said last week that James F. Hinrichs, 39, would become controller and that Stuart G. Laws, 44, would serve as chief accounting officer.

Descendants of the Indian chief for whom the Village of Katonah is named have joined efforts to block Martha Stewart's home-improvement empire from patenting the town's name for her line of furniture. Ms. Stewart's company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, ''has no right to exploit the name of one of our ancestors for her own profit and gain,'' said Steven Burton, a member of the Deer Clan Council of the Ramapough Lenape Indian Nation. ''Trademarking our ancestor is wrong, wrong, wrong.''

Campbell Robertson hits the campaign trail with a first-time Tony nominee. Charles Isherwood on the uneven alliance between British and American stages. What the critics would pick if they could vote. Plus Indelible moments from the past season and the return of politically engaged theater. Pages 6-15

TYSON--Gene. May 29, 2007. Loving uncle of Joan Wilking of Massachusetts and great uncle of Barbara Evers and Peggy Kasmir. He was a very noted antiquaire of New York City for many years and will be missed by his many friends. Contributions in his memory should be made to the Humane Society of New York.

Joan Murray's Lives column (May 13) about the elderly hitchhiker hit home -- literally. I live in the same region and drive Route 20 frequently as a hospice chaplain. In that role, I visit many older people whose deepest desire is to live and die in their own homes.
RUSSELL--Ed. Great ad man, great friend, great boss. The good news is that Ed and Mary Jane are together again. Thanks for the memories, Ed. Don, John, Jim and Bruce

Few projects have seemed better suited to a network's mission than ''ARMY WIVES'' does to Lifetime's. The dramatic series (Sunday at 10 p.m.) focuses on military spouses, the sisterhood they form, the challenges they face. One wife struggles with a problematic teenager, another with the prospect of financial ruin. In their midst is a husband, a psychiatrist dealing with the return of his wife from service in Afghanistan. Fear not that this borders on the too serious. ''Army Wives'' comes from Mark Gordon, the executive producer of ''Grey's Anatomy,'' and will feel no less soap operatic. Apparently the ''Entourage'' star ADRIAN GRENIER has been living a soap opera of his own. Raised by a single mother, Mr. Grenier discovered as an adult that she had been dating two men at the time of his conception. His documentary ''SHOT IN THE DARK'' (Sunday, 10:30 p.m., HBO) chronicles his search for his biological father, who, he finds, is living in Lancaster, Ohio. Like ''Flirting With Disaster'' and other films, ''Shot in the Dark'' uses the road trip as a metaphor for self-discovery. If the notion of a road trip just leaves you feeling hungry, rest assured, a new season of ''THE NEXT FOOD NETWORK STAR'' begins Sunday at 9 p.m. What will happen now? Well, apparently the contestants, competing for their own show on the network, will be forced to leave the studio and venture into the world outside. One challenge will have them creating food for a basketball game. During her lifetime Ella Fitzgerald collected 13 Grammy Awards. More than 40 million copies of her albums have been sold. On Wednesday, PBS celebrates her with ''WE LOVE ELLA! A TRIBUTE TO THE FIRST LADY OF SONG.'' Natalie Cole and Quincy Jones serve as hosts.

To the Editor: Re ''Not Your Mom's Prom?,'' by Kate Stone Lombardi (Generations, May 27): I was dismayed on Memorial Day weekend to read that only in the 1970s, during and after the Vietnam War, did high school students feel a certain sadness about the war and trim down their prom excesses. Wow! That is really sending the wrong message.

WEINSTEIN--Albert A., of Stanfordville, New York, born June 4, 1930 in Brooklyn, died after a brief illness on May 27, 2007. Albee, engineer and inventor, is survived by his wife Roseanne, daughters Sharon, Laura, Mobee, Erin and Shauna Weinstein, granddaughters Amanda and Ariana Gonzalez, brother Herbert Weinstein and sister Sheila Fleischer. A tribute will be held on June 21, 2007 from 123pm at The New York Botanical Garden.
COLTEN--Harvey, M.D. Physician, scientist, dean, mentor, friend. A strong life force. Our condolences to Sue and your children. Richard Mayeux and Nancy Green

HOMEOWNERS who want to tap into their house's equity typically face three choices: sell and move to a less expensive place, take out a home-equity loan, or refinance the mortgage and pull cash out. For older owners, reverse mortgages are another option. Now yet another alternative has emerged that allows owners to extract cash from their homes without having to take out a traditional loan.
To the Editor: Re ''Make a Bad Bill Better'' (editorial, May 29): There is another argument for a more constructive approach to those currently in the United States illegally.

To the Sports Editor: ''Duke's Comeback Season Ends Short of the Title'' (May 29) gave short shrift to the great accomplishment of the Johns Hopkins men's lacrosse team. The Blue Jays established a record by winning their ninth N.C.A.A. tournament championship.

Karen Elizabeth DiYanni and Ned King Peterson were married yesterday in New York. Msgr. Thomas Leonard performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. The bride, 34, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a violinist and a member of the New York Pops, and has performed with the Orchestra of St. Luke's and the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, and on Broadway in the orchestra for ''The Producers.'' She graduated from the Peabody Institute of Johns Hopkins and received a master's in music and an artist's diploma from Yale University.

Once a year, professional golfers are faced with a course that makes them look like mortals. The United States Open is the sport's four-day stress test, a marathon of frayed nerves, gnashed teeth and shocking scores. (Just ask Phil Mickelson.) Mike Davis of the United States Golf Association is charged with preparing this year's Open -- to be held this month at Oakmont, near Pittsburgh -- just as he was last year at Winged Foot. Playing in his 13th Open, Jim Furyk, the 2003 champion, will try to survive the ordeal. Here, the two men discuss some peculiarities of golf's toughest tournament. A WHOLE NEW MIND-SET The United States Open is golf at its most counterintuitive. Though length off the tee and a willingness to take risks are the tools that win your typical PGA Tour tournament, the Open rewards accuracy and patience. A desire to take dead aim at the flagstick must be tamped down in favor of shooting for the center of the green. The season-long quest for birdies must be replaced by a yearning for par -- not to mention an acceptance of bogeys.

If everything proceeds as planned - not that it ever does - late on the afternoon of July 7, in the Mediterranean waters fronting the ancient Spanish city of Valencia, one middle-aged man's $100 million, four-year-long campaign to win the America's Cup will explode in his face. Precisely to whom this will occur has yet to be decided. Word along the waterfront identifies several good candidates. Larry Ellison, the billionaire software magnate behind the American entry, BMW Oracle, is a popular choice. Another is Patrizio Bertelli, the head of the Italian effort and the C.E.O. of the design house Prada, his boats's main sponsor. Then there is Ernesto Bertarelli, an elegant 41-year-old billionaire from Geneva who is the current holder of the Cup, which his team, Alinghi, wrested away from New Zealand in 2003. One man happily exempt from this specter of sudden heartsick, however, is Xavier de Lesquen, a former French naval officer who, as the executive manager of China Team, oversees that nation's fledgling effort to win the oldest trophy in sports. Cup dreams tend to sour swiftly, with stunning, tearful finality, and it is considered bad juju to prognosticate. Even so, several outcomes are already certain. By the time you read this, China Team will have taken its lumps and been eliminated from the competition, transforming de Lesquen's role from that of participant to interested observer. China's departure will have surprised no one, not even de Lesquen. The campaign started tardily and was woefully underfunded; for every dollar that a superteam like Alinghi or BMW Oracle had to spend, China had only a dime. Lacking the wherewithal to build a team from scratch, the Chinese absorbed a French team, taking possession of most of its assets. These included an America's Cup-class racing yacht, a support staff, several French crew members and de Lesquen. Because China is home to few world-class yachtsmen -- and those who might be said to qualify were focused on the Beijing Olympics -- it took some effort to assemble the 17-man crew required to sail an America's Cup yacht. Officials of the Chinese Yachting Association fanned out across the country and plucked unsuspecting sailors from provincial teams. After congratulating the young men for having achieved their theretofore unknown dream of competing in an America's Cup, the officials hustled them off to Valencia, where they bivouacked in communal flats and communicated with their teammates, who are primarily French, via translators. ''I think our Chinese friends are a little bit homesick, yes,'' de Lesquen admitted when I visited Spain in April. ''It's a very strange thing for them.''

GELSEY KIRKLAND's celebrated and troubled career began at the New York City Ballet and continued at American Ballet Theater, where she formed a celebrated partnership with Mikhail Baryshnikov. Her last role, in 1987, was Aurora in ''Sleeping Beauty,'' which she danced to immense acclaim with the Royal Ballet in London. This week Ms. Kirkland, one of the leading ballerinas of her generation, is returning to the stage with AMERICAN BALLET THEATER in the same ballet. This time she will play the wicked fairy Carabosse, whose revengeful fury propels the narrative. Ms. Kirkland, who also staged this production along with Kevin McKenzie and Michael Chernov, was famous for her meticulous, often obsessive approach to preparing her roles. Here is another chance to watch a great artist work her magic. Monday at 8 p.m., Wednesday at 2 p.m., Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, abt.org; $24 to $110. A new work by CHRISTOPHER WHEELDON is always an occasion unto itself, but his ''Nightingale and the Rose,'' for the New York City Ballet, where he is the resident choreographer, will also be the premiere of the first commissioned score from Bright Sheng, the company's resident composer. The ballet, based on Oscar Wilde's poignant story, features the wonderful Wendy Whelan alongside Sara Mearns and Tyler Angle, two of the company's most promising juniors. There's never any guarantee that two luminous talents like Mr. Wheeldon and Mr. Sheng will burn brighter together, but the possibility is a compelling one. Friday at 8 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570, nycb.org; $15 to $82. Not content with being a ballet legend, having his own arts center, and commissioning and dancing in contemporary work for his touring groups (to say nothing of acting and taking photographs), MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV has found time to write a children's book. Charmingly illustrated by Vladimir Radunsky, ''Because,'' which just arrived in bookstores, tells of an irrepressible Granny who loves to dance. Its message is to be unafraid to reveal your special talents to the world. Mr. Baryshnikov has set a good example. Simon & Schuster, $16.99.

Heather Mary John and John Linehan Fogarty were married yesterday at Meadowood Napa Valley, a resort and private club in St. Helena, Calif. The Rev. Gerald P. Caprio, a Benedictine monk, officiated. The bride, 34, will continue to use her name professionally. She is the senior editor of Bon Appétit in Los Angeles. She graduated from the University of California, Davis, and has a certificate in French language from the University of Paris-Sorbonne.

A picture caption on May 6 with an article about gang violence in Queens referred incorrectly to the significance of the word ''Mecca'' on a T-shirt that bore the logo of the Mecca USA clothing company. Though the word Mecca has been adopted by some gang members as an acronym standing for ''Murder every Crip child alive,'' the company and its logo have no link to gang activity.

HERBST--Seymour, June 6th, 1977. And now it's 30 years. Our memories of you still remain strong. Always loved and missed by your extended family. Charlotte, Todd, Abbe, Robyn, Scott and Carly. You would be so proud.

GREW--Henry Sturgis, of New York City and West Palm Beach, Florida, died suddenly on May 25th, 2007 in Florida. He had lived in Boston and Newport, Rhode Island. He is survived by a sister, Selina Grew Rossiter of Lincoln, Massachusetts, and two brothers, Joseph Clark Grew of Boston and Robert Sturgis Grew of Raleigh, North Carolina; as well as five nieces, four nephews, six grandnieces and one grandnephew. A memorial Service will be held on August 4, at 11 am, at St. Mary's By-The-Sea, Northeast Harbor, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Dublin School, Inc., Dublin, New Hampshire.

Was there ever a golf moment at once more horrific and more riveting than Phil Mickelson's meltdown on the final hole of last year's United States Open at Winged Foot Golf Club? You couldn't watch, and at the same time you couldn't not watch. Not to dwell on painful memories, but some traumas won't go away. Here was the new, reformed Phil, the one who had supposedly curbed his appetite for risky, all-or-nothing shots, coming off victories at the P.G.A. Championship and the Masters. A victory at Winged Foot would make him just the second golfer in 50 years to claim three majors in a row and would erase once and for all his reputation for poor decisions under fire, for being the kind of golfer who once caused Jack Nicklaus to say, ''Phil's a nice player, he's a good player, but he's not a great champion.''

By my count only two Italian films received commercial openings in New York in the first five months of this year, and one of them -- Alberto Lattuada's ''Mafioso'' -- was 45 years old. (The other, Emanuele Crialese's ''Golden Door,'' snuck in under the wire, on May 25.) Which is further evidence, as if any were needed, that festivals like the Film Society of Lincoln Center's OPEN ROADS: NEW ITALIAN CINEMA are more valuable than ever. The 13-movie series opens Wednesday with a big name, Mario Monicelli, who was already in his 40s when he made ''Big Deal on Madonna Street'' in 1958; he's 92 now, and his latest film, ''Desert Roses'' (''Le Rose del Deserto''), is yet another social satire, this time involving an Italian medical unit in Africa in World War II that's not entirely clear on how the war is going. Other films include ''The Unknown Woman'' (''La Sconosciuta''), a thriller about a Ukrainian immigrant to Italy directed by Giuseppe Tornatore (''Cinema Paradiso''); Angelo Longoni's biopic ''Caravaggio,'' photographed by the great Vittorio Storaro and starring Alessio Boni, who played the younger brother in ''The Best of Youth''; and ''Primo Levi's Journey'' (''La Strada di Levi''), a documentary that retraces the tortuous route Levi had to take to return home from Auschwitz in 1945. An older -- and lighter -- European sensibility can be sampled on Tuesday at the French Institute/Alliance Française, where the nine-week series THE SURREAL DELICACY OF RENÉ CLAIR begins with a screening of Clair's Dada comedy ''Entr'acte'' (1924), made with the painter Francis Picabia and the composer Eric Satie; Satie's score will be performed live by Bruce Levingston. Future Tuesdays will feature Clair classics like ''À Nous la liberté'' and ''Le Million,'' along with more rarely seen items like the silent short ''Paris Qui Dort'' and several of his English-language films.

MUCH of upstate New York, from north of Albany to Buffalo, from the Catskills to the Adirondacks, is in danger of being transformed beyond recognition by industrial wind parks. Some 50 of these wind parks are being planned and even built. All of this is being done in the name of clean energy and saving the planet. But it isn't clear that wind power is such a panacea in the battle against global warming that developers of these wind parks should be allowed to run roughshod over some of our loveliest land. What we need are statewide siting guidelines that take other environmental factors, including visual impacts, into consideration.

STEINBERG--Ethel Stoller, 84, resident of Delray Beach, FL, widow of Ted Steinberg; beloved sister of Adeline and Edward Glassman; beloved mother of Leslie Platto, Charles Platto, Marc Stoller and Lenore Rey, Bruce and Kelly Stoller; Lyle and Wendy, Spencer and Paula, Glen, Mary, Vicki and Donna Steinberg; beloved grandmother of Jamie and Lorin, Carey and Ali, Jody, Terry; Jason and Liz, Corey, Andrew, Rachelle, Jared and Erick; beloved great-grandmother of Jake and Skylar as well as nieces, nephews and friends across the country; died on May 30, 2007. Ethel will be loved and remembered always for her warmth, her humor and her love for her family as well as for her talent as a painter, decorator and sculptor. She was an avid golfer and reader and she played a good hand of bridge but she expressed herself best in her art where she found peace and solace when the going got rough. Memorial contributions may be made to Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research Foundation, www.alzinfo.org; to National Museum of Women in the Arts, www.nmwa.org; or to Corey Frederick Stoller Memorial Scholarship, 123 Chappell Drive, Milford, NH 03055

The Kings of the Road Ken W. Purdy A few black-and-white photographs. 256 pages. Little, Brown & Company, 1952. Few car books bear rereading. For marque histories and learned studies, a single pass usually suffices before they are shelved for reference, while coffee-table tomes often have text so thin they're better left unread.

Mindy Rebecca Feinberg and Dr. Stefan Harris Gutow were married yesterday evening at the American Visionary Art Museum in Baltimore. Rabbi William Kuhn officiated. The bride, 35, is an assistant professor of psychology at Towson University in Maryland. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin and received a master's in developmental psychology from Columbia and a Ph.D. in school, clinical and community psychology from the University of Pennsylvania. She also directed an educational program for orphaned and homeless children in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

To the Editor: Re ''Living Larger, and Drawing Fire'' (May 20): I do not have a problem with people building larger homes on land that is of a sufficient size to tastefully accommodate them. But I do have a problem when an older house is torn down and a new ''mansion'' is built that takes advantage of the previously existing, and antiquated, property setbacks designed for the original smaller home.

WHEN my mother reached her mid-80s, it began to dawn on me that I'd have to start intervening in her life. This was not pleasant. Mom had always been fiercely independent, happily living on her own in suburban Boston for the 20 years after my dad died. There was no single event, just a hundred little ones that nibbled away at that solid image of Mom that was stored in my brain. I'd go back to Quincy for a visit and there would be piles of mail all over the house. Overdue bills were mixed in with supermarket stuffers that should have been tossed out weeks earlier. And I'd try to remember: Was this new?

SHERER--Leslie, The Independent Suwalk & Vicinity Benevolent Association mourns the passing of our Honorary President and longtime leader, Leslie Sherer. Born in Suwalki, Poland, Mr. Sherer was active in the Association from his arrival in the United States in the 1930's and served as its President for many decades. He was the heart and soul of our organization and will be missed by all the members. Our heartfelt condolences go to his beloved wife Fay and his extended family and many friends. Services will be at Sigmund Schwartz Chapel, 2nd Avenue at 9th Street, Sunday, June 3, at noon. Arthur S. Leonard, President

LAWRENCE WRIGHT told you so. He is too polite to put it that way of course. But anyone who saw ''The Siege,'' the 1998 film he helped write about a wave of terrorist bombings in New York City, knows that he was prescient about many things. After Sept. 11, Mr. Wright, a writer for The New Yorker, thought the tragedy was familiar. ''This looks like my movie,'' he said in ''My Trip to Al-Qaeda,'' a fascinating slide show and monologue that had a six-week run this spring. The play is based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning book, ''The Looming Tower,'' which was the product of more than 600 interviews, many with terrorists. The show closed in April, but there are two more chances to see it this week, when Mr. Wright returns for encore performances at Town Hall. On Tuesday there will be a post-show talk moderated by Aziz Huq, the director of the Liberty and National Security Project at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University School of Law. On Wednesday the post-show moderator is David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker. 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-4100, ticketmaster.com; $25 and $40. For those who want to forget about terror threats and enjoy ''Summer's ripening breath,'' as Shakespeare puts it, the Public Theater begins its Delacorte Theater season with that romantic old story about Romeo Montague and Juliet Capulet. OSCAR ISAAC, who starred in the Central Park production of ''Two Gentlemen of Verona'' in 2005, will do his best to charm the red-headed beauty LAUREN AMBROSE, who played the moody Claire on the HBO series ''Six Feet Under.'' Michael Greif (''Rent'') directs this crowd-pleaser, which hasn't been produced in Central Park since 1968, when it starred Martin Sheen as Romeo. That's surprising since the play can be lovely to watch outdoors. When Romeo swears by the moon, why, there it is. Previews start Tuesday at 8 p.m., Delacorte Theater, Central Park, (212) 539-8500, publictheater.org.

The Parenting column last Sunday, about a seventh-grade handwriting champion at a Roman Catholic school, St. Pius V, in Melville, gave an incomplete account of the circumstances surrounding the suspensions of several students last year. While a parent said the suspensions were for remarks about the school's nuns that students posted on the Internet, the principal, Sister Maria Dolorosa, said the students were suspended because they used the Internet to view movies and listen to music that they knew were prohibited by the school.
The thrill of victory. The agony of defeat. The voyeuristic pleasure of having the best eye in the house at the major events in sports.

WHEN my parents moved us from a cramped apartment in an aging industrial city out to a raw new development in the suburbs, it seemed like Disney's Frontierland -- without Uncle Walt's thoughtful amenities. Dad took the Chevy to work, so the rest of us walked everywhere at first. The nearest loaf of bread was about a mile away. My mother adored her new pink ranch with the blue-tiled bathroom, but she missed the corner store and her sisters a short walk away. In a weak moment, as we struggled toward town against a mean November wind with my little brother, she yelled into the gale, ''How do people live here?'' A generation later, as my husband and I moved back out from Manhattan, two wee ones in tow, I understood her discomfiture. I knew the lay of the land; I'd grown up in the adjacent town. But, staring at a local newspaper listing announcing napkin-folding classes, not possessed of sufficient bonhomie for Newcomers Club sock hops, I howled, too: Where can you get a bottle of decent Vietnamese fish sauce? Why are they still selling -- and wearing -- the lime green golf slacks embossed with spouting whales that I hooted at in high school?

In James Traub's inspired portrait of Al Gore, NASA's James Hansen is quoted as having written that ''Al Gore may have done for global warming what 'Silent Spring' did for pesticides'' (''Al Gore Has Big Plans,'' May 20). And Traub continues that '' 'An Inconvenient Truth' did a great deal for Al Gore as well.''

A picture caption with an article last Sunday about subway enthusiasts who pursue jobs with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misidentified a part of a subway train shown. It was a train operator's cab, not a conductor's booth.

LeBron James hurled the ball with all his rippling strength high into the rafters, and the confetti -- like everything and everyone else here -- soon followed on cue in Cleveland. James was the rainmaker, catapulting the Cleveland Cavaliers into the N.B.A. finals for the first time with a 98-82 victory over the Detroit Pistons in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals, the easiest and most surprising victory by far in the series.

To the Editor: In his commentary on the American auto industry of recent decades, Ben Stein is on target in saying that Detroit often failed to build cars that people wanted to buy (''The Dream That Once Was Detroit,'' Everybody's Business, May 27).

Bill Hambrecht is a rich old Wall Street guy who has made his money tilting at windmills and disrupting the establishment. ''That's what I do,'' he says. ''It's fun.'' Almost a decade ago, at 62, he founded WR Hambrecht + Company, whose fundamental premise is that companies don't need to use Wall Street investment bankers -- and pay their outrageous fees -- to go public. Hambrecht + Company has since become so threatening to traditional underwriters that they often refuse to be involved in any I.P.O. in which his firm takes part. And now, at an age when most people are well into retirement, he has decided to tackle the establishment again. This time, though, the establishment isn't Wall Street. It's the National Football League. Bill Hambrecht, you see, is starting up a professional football league. So far, he and his partner, Tim Armstrong, a senior executive at Google, have pledged $2 million each. They've hired a C.E.O. and a C.O.O., both of whom cut their teeth at the National Basketball Association. They've got a name: the United Football League. And they've lined up a wealthy, well-known businessman as their first owner: Mark Cuban, the billionaire who owns the N.B.A.'s Dallas Mavericks. Like Hambrecht, Cuban loves nothing more than confronting the status quo.

To the Editor: In his review of Cullen Murphy's ''Are We Rome?'' (May 13), Walter Isaacson notes that Murphy worries that ''members of the educated elite no longer feel it their duty to serve in the military. He reports that 450 of the 750 graduates in the Princeton class of 1956 served, whereas only eight of the 1,100 in the class of 2004 did.''

IN most years, Rick Porcello, the 2007 Gatorade National Baseball Player of the Year, would have no equal as a high school player. He is a big, right-handed pitcher, a senior at Seton Hall Preparatory School in West Orange, N.J., who throws faster than most pros and whose route to the major leagues could be a short one. It is rare for a high school player from the Northeast to be thought of so highly. But this season, an unusual one for high school baseball talent in the region, there may be someone even better than Porcello.

To the Editor: We were thrilled to see your coverage of two books of photographs -- ''New York Rises'' and ''A Living Lens'' -- that are related to exhibitions on view at the Museum of the City of New York, although your article (''The City, Framed: Jewish Life, Soaring Bridges, Fulton Market,'' Reading New York, May 27) mentioned only one of the companion exhibitions.

Because of an editing error, an article today on Page 12 of the special Tony Awards section of Arts & Leisure about indelible moments on Broadway omits, in some copies, several words in the first two paragraphs of an item on ''The Coast of Utopia.'' The passage should read: As the second act opened of ''Voyage,'' the beginning of Tom Stoppard's trilogy, ''The Coast of Utopia,'' the season's most visually sublime moment came into full view. We were in Moscow now, in March of 1834, having left the idyll of Premukhino, the Bakunin family estate, a place of long meals, pastoral languor. '' 'For happiness, apparently, something of the real world is necessary,' '' Ivan Turgenev had told us in the previous scene, quoting another character. And now indeed we were in the world, in a city full of bustle and fervor.

Several museum shows are opening this week, offering viewers everything from monumental sculptures to early American rugs. Perhaps the most anticipated of them is the RICHARD SERRA retrospective that begins Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art. Spanning 40 years of his career and filling the museum as well as its sculpture garden, the show features some of his early experiments with materials like rubber and neon as well as the giant, labyrinthlike steel sculptures that have become his signature. Among the best known of the large works is ''Intersection II,'' a 60-ton sculpture made of four two-inch-thick gentle curves of hot rolled steel, and ''Torqued Ellipse IV,'' a 46-ton sculpture that is a twisted ribbon in the shape of an ellipse standing on its edge. Both are from the Modern's own collection. The show will also feature three new works. Through Sept. 10, moma.org. Next door, opening on Tuesday at the Folk Art Museum, is ''The Great Cover-Up: American Rugs on Beds, Tables and Floors,'' a show devoted to early American rugs. On view will be about 65 rugs dating from the end of the 18th century through the mid-20th century. Through Sept. 9, 45 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, folkartmuseum.org. A peek at one of the greatest libraries of Renaissance Italy will be the subject of ''FEDERICO DA MONTEFELTRO AND HIS LIBRARY,'' an exhibition opening Thursday at the Morgan Library & Museum. Montefeltro, or the Duke of Urbino, was, fittingly, a true Renaissance man, fascinated with everything from theology to poetry. In addition to portraits and illuminated manuscripts, the exhibition will include the duke's horoscope of 1475 (on loan from the Beinecke Library at Yale University), which shows his interest in astrology, and a coded letter of 1478 that documents his secret military involvement in an attempted coup against the Medici in Florence. The duke's library will be recreated in the 20-square-foot, cube-shaped gallery that the Italian architect Renzo Piano designed after Renaissance chambers. Through Sept. 30, 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, morganlibrary.org.

The Baryshnikov Arts Center is presenting a series of free, informal chamber concerts underwritten by Movado. PEDJA MUZIJEVIC, the pianist who runs the series, has been able to lure several first-class soloists and ensembles, often for programs that move off the beaten path. This week the soprano LUCY SHELTON and Mr. Muzijevic join the BRENTANO STRING QUARTET for a program that includes George Crumb's ''Apparition'' and the Brahms Piano Quintet. Tuesday at 7 p.m., 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan, (917) 934-4966, baryshnikovdancefoundation.org; free, but reservations are required. LEON BOTSTEIN'S AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA closes its season Sunday with a program devoted to music by Shostakovich and his lesser-known contemporary and friend Mieczyslaw Weinberg. Weinberg was born in Warsaw and moved to the Soviet Union to escape the Nazis in 1939 but was imprisoned by Stalin in the 1950s. Shostakovich, who admired Weinberg's First Symphony, helped get him released. Mr. Botstein is conducting two large works by Weinberg, the Symphony No. 6 (he wrote 26 of them) and the Trumpet Concerto. Shostakovich is represented by his Symphony No. 13, with its searing setting of Yevgeny Yevtushenko's ''Babi Yar.'' Carl Albach is the soloist in the concerto; the bass-baritone Sergei Leiferkus is the soloist in the Shostakovich; and the Brooklyn Youth Chorus and the Concert Chorale of New York perform in the symphonies. 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $27 to $55.

Quiznos, the national sandwich chain, is further revamping its executive suite under the leadership of Gregory D. Brenneman, a turnaround expert. Last week he named Rusty B. Spinney, a Molson Coors veteran, as the company's chief accounting officer. Mr. Spinney, 40, was in charge of Molson Coors's global technical accounting, financial policy implementation and Sarbanes-Oxley law compliance. He will report to Brandon Turner, Quiznos's chief financial officer, who also joined the chain this year as part of Mr. Brenneman's executive makeover.

FROM the stacks of allergy medicine at Duane Reade to the students ''doing homework'' at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park, it's clear that spring has overtaken New York. Which means it's time for apartment owners to come together in their annual meetings and debate what to do to the spaces they have the fortune, or misfortune, to share. The owners who paid the most for their apartments are usually the first ones to argue for upgrades so their buildings do not lag behind newer condos, and so they can live in a style commensurate with a seven- or eight-figure purchase price.

To the Editor: Re ''Not Your Mom's Prom?,'' by Kate Stone Lombardi (Generations, May 27): I was dismayed on Memorial Day weekend to read that only in the 1970s, during and after the Vietnam War, did high school students feel a certain sadness about the war and trim down their prom excesses. Wow! That is really sending the wrong message. Even in the most privileged of communities -- my hometown, Greenwich, Conn. -- prom night is a more laid-back affair. There are only a few limos, and many private schools have bans on such grandiose extras. Parties before and after are discouraged, in order to discourage drinking and driving.

IN those final weeks before summer vacation, when temperatures can soar into the 90s, parents at 5 of Greenwich's 11 elementary schools without adequate air-conditioning could no longer watch their children wilt, along with the crayons, in the heat. So they approached the school board and air-conditioning was installed -- but not at the expense of property taxpayers; the parents raised the money. Students in two other elementary schools in town, without the same deep-pocketed parents, had to wait, however. They were finally granted air-conditioning after town officials squeezed the upgrades into capital budgets financed by taxpayers.

Standard Catalog of American Cars Various editors and contributors. Illustrated. Krause Publications. Doctors look up medications in the Physicians' Desk Reference; engineers find conversion formulas in the Bosch Automotive Handbook. The equivalent reference standard for American car enthusiasts is the Standard Catalog series, thick soft-cover volumes that detail each model with unembellished descriptions of the year's changes and highlights, along with production numbers, engine offerings, specifications, options and prices.

Tiffany Lee Zientz and Alexander Patrick Heckler were married last evening by Rabbi Terry A. Bookman at the Four Seasons Hotel in Miami. The bride, 31, will continue to use her name professionally. She is in charge of fund-raising at the Women's Fund of Miami-Dade County, a nonprofit organization that distributes grants to programs that help girls and women. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received an M.B.A. from the University of Miami.

To the Editor: In ''Parking, Pollution and the Pricing Zone'' (May 27), three letter writers comment on the congestion-pricing plan for city traffic. One writer assumes that most drivers will not troll for scarce curbside space in neighborhoods outside the pricing zone. The reality is that people already use outer-borough neighborhoods like mine as park-'n'-ride locations.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''To Love and to Cherish for All Eternity, or Not,'' May 27: For lifelong Mets fans like me, it has certainly been sweet knowing that Yankees followers, for a change, are the New York baseball fans suffering through a season to forget. But what kind of fan can Jane Heller possibly be if she's calling it quits on her beloved Bronx Bombers?

McCORMICK--Dr. Charles G., a psychologist in private practice who taught at The New School for Social Research in New York City for 47 years, died May 11th, at age 93 at his home in Manhattan. He was born in New York City. He is survived by his wife, Ella Hansen McCormick of Manhattan; a son, James of Winston-Salem, NC, and a daughter, Margot of Syracuse, NY.

WHEN my mother reached her mid-80s, it began to dawn on me that I'd have to start intervening in her life. This was not pleasant. Mom had always been fiercely independent, happily living on her own in suburban Boston for the 20 years after my dad died. There was no single event, just a hundred little ones that nibbled away at that solid image of Mom that was stored in my brain. I'd go back to Quincy for a visit and there would be piles of mail all over the house. Overdue bills were mixed in with supermarket stuffers that should have been tossed out weeks earlier. And I'd try to remember: Was this new?

Julia Harris Taft, a daughter of Julia V. Taft and William H. Taft IV of Lorton, Va., was married there yesterday to Christof Blackman Putzel, the son of Ann Blackman and Michael Putzel of Washington. Leora Motley, a civil marriage celebrant in Fairfax County, Va., officiated at the home of the bride's parents. Ms. Taft, 26, is keeping her name. She graduated from Georgetown and received a nursing degree this year from New York University. In 2002 and 2003, she worked in Sierra Leone with the International Medical Corps, a relief organization in Los Angeles; she served as a liaison to the country's health ministry and managed the administration of maternal health and H.I.V. and AIDS programs.

WHEN my parents moved us from a cramped apartment in an aging industrial city out to a raw new development in the suburbs, it seemed like Disney's Frontierland -- without Uncle Walt's thoughtful amenities. Dad took the Chevy to work, so the rest of us walked everywhere at first. The nearest loaf of bread was about a mile away. My mother adored her new pink ranch with the blue-tiled bathroom, but she missed the corner store and her sisters a short walk away. In a weak moment, as we struggled toward town against a mean November wind with my little brother, she yelled into the gale, ''How do people live here?'' A generation later, as my husband and I moved back out from Manhattan, two wee ones in tow, I understood her discomfiture. I knew the lay of the land; I'd grown up in the adjacent town. But, staring at a local newspaper listing announcing napkin-folding classes, not possessed of sufficient bonhomie for Newcomers Club sock hops, I howled, too: Where can you get a bottle of decent Vietnamese fish sauce? Why are they still selling -- and wearing -- the lime green golf slacks embossed with spouting whales that I hooted at in high school?

The final results are in, and local elections in Dobbs Ferry will remain in November. The proposal to move elections to March was defeated by 14 votes. The final tally was 793 to 779, according to the County Board of Elections officials, who released the numbers last Wednesday. Elections officials waited a week to count outstanding absentee and affidavit votes to allow time for all the absentee votes to come in.

Reiner, was married on Friday to John Gibson Verkuil, the son of Frances Gibson McGlothlin of Austin, Tex., and Paul R. Verkuil of Miami Beach. Douglas L. Johnson, a Virginia marriage commissioner, officiated at the Wren Chapel of the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va. Last evening, Timothy Dyk, a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington, led a celebration of the marriage, again in the Wren Chapel.

Valerie Witoshkin and Charles Garrett Fox were married yesterday by the Right Rev. Vincent Saverino at St. Michael the Archangel Russian Orthodox Church in Philadelphia. The bride, 36, works in New York as the investment manager for hedge fund allocations at the Alkimia Group, a private investment office of the Kaplan family, whose businesses in South America and Europe include retailing and real estate development. She graduated from Boston University. The bride is a daughter of Natalie Witoshkin and Walter Witoshkin of New Hope, Pa.

To the Editor: Re ''Grooming a Handwriting Champion,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, May 27): My son would benefit greatly if there were penmanship classes offered in public school. Every year I complain to my son's teacher that his handwriting is awful. The usual response is ''It doesn't matter, he can type on the computer'' or ''It's fine, I've seen worse.''

Sue Cox says that her 17-year-old son, Tim, ''started playing sports practically in the womb.'' A standout on junior-league basketball and Pop Warner football teams in Hudson, N.H., he was, by high school, among the top basketball players in the state as well as a starting safety on the football team. ''I lived for sports, you could say,'' Tim says. But could he also have died from them? Last July, at his parents' insistence, Cox had an electrocardiogram, which measures electrical activity in the heart. It's the same test his father had 15 years ago, after experiencing some shortness of breath. That EKG and follow-up tests showed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), a thickening of the heart muscle. Cox's grandfather had been diagnosed with the same condition and died at age 63. But Cox, with the insouciance of youth, was sure that his own heart was fine. He was therefore stunned when the test came back positive. He would never be allowed to play competitive sports again, his cardiologist told him flatly. ''It was a terrible time,'' says Cox's father, also named Tim. ''We wanted to keep our son alive, but to do that, we were taking away everything that he loved most in life.''

HENKEL--Joan, 80, died June 1 at her Rutherford, NJ home. She graduated from the University of Pittsburgh. She taught kindergarten in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Her husband Robert, owner of the Secaucus Home News, predeceases her. Her children Peter, Christopher, Heidi Leyh and Gretchen, five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren survive her. Funeral June 4 at the Collins-Calhoun Funeral Home in Rutherford, NJ: (201)939-1050

If you think you have a dorky hobby, imagine spending several hours a week waiting for a Web site to play simulated baseball games. Then imagine that the teams were constructed using the statistics of nearly every player who has ever played pro baseball, going back to 1885, the vast majority of whom you've never heard of. The games are simulated three times a day, so that a season takes about two months. You're now imagining one of my hobbies. Suddenly your own doesn't seem so dorky anymore, does it? One afternoon a couple of years ago, I followed a link on Major League Baseball's home page and found myself at whatifsports.com, which informed me that within minutes I could be playing SimLeague Baseball, managing a team that included Ichiro Suzuki and Steve Balboni. Commingling those particular greatnesses had never been a dream of mine. I already played regular fantasy baseball, which involves tracking the day-to-day statistics of currently active baseball players. That was time-consuming enough, to the point where it occasionally created tension in my marriage, but this was a more insidious beast, and I sensed its destructive potential. Nonetheless, I was curious. I plunged in. Soon, I was gazing upon baseball-nerd heaven.

DESPITE the rising euro and the near-record pound, Europe is emerging as the unexpected star of this summer's cruising season. With companies from the American cruising giants to boutique lines that specialize in river and Arctic itineraries expanding their presence throughout the Continent, European cruise capacity is expected to increase 23 percent this summer over last, according to Cruise Industry News, with an additional 10 percent more growth predicted for next year. Fueling the rise is a combination of consumer demand and cruising's unanticipated status as a vacation value option this summer. ''There are more ships out there than ever before, and companies have to put them where they will earn a strong return,'' said Henry Harteveldt, chief travel analyst at Forrester Research in San Francisco.

SULLIVAN--Warren Jr. A publishing executive instrumental in establishing overseas markets for American books, died in Englewood, New Jersey, on May 23rd. He was 85 years old. A 1944 graduate of Dartmouth College, Sullivan served with the U.S. Navy during World War II. In 1946, he joined publisher John Wiley & Sons, Inc., traveling widely in Europe, Latin America, and the Far East, to build foreign sales. In the 1960s, he was president of the Macmillan Company and then of Barnes and Noble booksellers, returning to Wiley in 1971. From 1983 to 1988, he served as Chairman of Basil Blackwell, Inc. He is survived by Madeleine (Terry), his wife of sixty years; a daughter, Kathleen; and triplet sons, Peter, William, and Jeffrey. Burial was private. A celebration of his life is planned for early fall. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be sent to the Alumni Fund, Dartmouth College, Class of 1944.

On a Thursday afternoon in early May, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton rose before a nearly empty Senate chamber and proposed that Congress undo one of the most significant acts in its recent history: the authorization of the Iraq war. In remarks lasting just two minutes, she spoke bluntly: The ''authorization to use force has run its course, and it is time to reverse the failed policies of President Bush and to end this war as soon as possible.'' She added, ''If the president will not bring himself to accept reality, it is time for Congress to bring reality to him.''

August marks the 30th anniversary of the death of Elvis Presley, an event that will be anything but ignored by the King's fans. Elvis Week, an annual August event in Memphis organized by Elvis Presley Enterprises, will include an Elvis tribute artist contest for the first time. Winners will be chosen during the eight-day festival (Aug. 11 to 19), which will also include an ''Elvis: Midnight in Vegas'' concert, a Graceland Scavenger Hunt and an Elvis Presley International Art Show.

DUMPSTAPHUNK is the best funk band from New Orleans right now. That's no small thing in a city where rhythm is a natural resource, an art, an advanced science, an incantation and an exorcism as well as a reason to dance. IVAN NEVILLE, the keyboardist who leads Dumpstaphunk, has a funk pedigree. His father is Aaron Neville of the Neville Brothers, which also includes Art Neville of the Meters, the definitive 1960s and 1970s New Orleans funk band. Ivan himself was a longtime member of the Neville Brothers, and like them he sees no reason not to mix messages with a dance beat. Dumpstaphunk follows through on the Meters' and Neville Brothers' snickering, sputtering, wah-wah New Orleans funk, and onstage it charges through songs from Sly Stone and Creedence Clearwater Revival. But Dumpstaphunk is no oldies act. It has new songs that push the New Orleans heritage into the post-Katrina era. ''Ugly Truth,'' ''Meanwhile'' and ''Livin' in a World Gone Mad'' -- all at myspace.com/dumpstaphunk -- are powered by rage and humor as well as rhythm, which doesn't make them any less danceable. Friday at 11 p.m., B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144; $15 in advance, $17 Friday. Funk and hard-headed social consciousness also meet in the music of EL-P. He has been a prime mover in alternative hip-hop since the mid-1990s, first with the duo Company Flow and lately as a busy producer and the founder of the Definitive Jux label. Party chants and drugs-and-bling boasts are not for him; he sees trouble in the streets and around the world. His second solo album, ''I'll Sleep When You're Dead'' (Definitive Jux), is sonically dense and verbally pugnacious: ''Either speak the truth or you leave toothless,'' he warns. ''This is the sound of what you don't know killing you/This is the sound of what you don't believe, still true.'' Saturday at 8 p.m., Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800; $20.

To the Editor: In ''Newark Battles Murder and Its Accomplice, Silence'' (''The Hard Part'' series, front page, May 27), you paint a stereotype of minorities, drugs, crime, troubled families and hopelessness. As director of a large arts school founded in 1968, I have another perspective. I see individuals from the city and the surrounding suburbs working together to establish a cultural identity, building homes and businesses.

To the Editor: ''Illegal Immigrants and Their Employers'' (letter, May 27) criticizes both workers who break the law by entering this country and those who break the law by hiring them. Such widespread violation often occurs when a law is unjust, unenforceable or so poorly conceived that the practical and human considerations come to outweigh the legislative ones.

On the heels of Masai Barefoot Technology-type sneakers comes FitFlops, the latest rage in what is promoted as muscle-sculpting footwear. Supposedly able to tone and trim legs, burn calories, absorb shock and improve posture with their patented ''microwobbleboard'' sole, FitFlops have flapped their way from England, where 18,000 pairs sold out within three days of their May release. (Two women actually got into a brawl over the last pair of size 7s at the London store Running Bare.) While a waiting list of 15,000 still exists in Britain, Americans can now buy FitFlops in red or black at bathandbodyworks.com for $39.95 -- no fisticuffs required.

The Parenting column last Sunday, about a seventh-grade handwriting champion at a Roman Catholic school, St. Pius V, in Melville, gave an incomplete account of the circumstances surrounding the suspensions of several students last year. While a parent said the suspensions were for remarks about the school's nuns that students posted on the Internet, the principal, Sister Maria Dolorosa, said the students were suspended because they used the Internet to view movies and listen to music that they knew were prohibited by the school.

Josephine Baker wasn't the first young woman to shake a scantily clad brown bottom for the music-hall audiences of Paris during the Roaring Twenties. Chorus girls of every make and model had been strutting up and down the stages of Montmartre for more than a decade by the time Baker hit the scene in 1925, and African-American writers and musicians had been arriving by the boatload since the war. Still, no other American entertainer -- male or female, black or white -- was ever to achieve as phenomenal a stardom as Baker. Her 50-year-long triumph was a sociocultural moment yet to be repeated. The story of how an untrained, unexceptionally talented 19-year-old black girl from Missouri managed to enthrall the capital city of Europe from the 1920s until her death in 1975 at 68 -- transforming herself into a world-renowned artist in the process -- is worth telling and retelling. After all, Baker traveled in the rarefied circles of 20th-century celebrity: Picasso, Le Corbusier, Colette, Langston Hughes, E. E. Cummings, Jean Cocteau and Ernest Hemingway were all admirers. Adolf Loos designed a house to showcase her body from every angle, and Alexander Calder created wire sculptures of her form. Among her benefactors were Princess Grace, the Pasha of Marrakesh and Juan and Eva Péron.

UBELL--Earl. The Council for the Advancement of Science Writing (CASW) mourns the passing of its co-founder, Earl Ubell, a trailblazing science writer, who helped enrich for the millions privileged to have borne witness to his extraordinary work in print and broadcast their understanding of the scientific quest and its consequences. He was also the inspiration to the many of us who were called to the craft by his splendid example. Cristine Russell, President Ben Patrusky, Executive Director

To the Editor: I take issue with a statement in Corey S. Powell's review of ''Einstein: His Life and Universe,'' by Walter Isaacson, and ''Einstein: A Biography,'' by JÃ1/4rgen Neffe (May 20). The most precious thing Einstein's example offers ''the rest of us'' -- us ordinary folk -- is assuredly not a ''taste'' of a ''cosmic religious sense'' or ''connectedness to universal truth''; it is, rather, a glimpse of the awesome beauty and wonder of a mind driven by intense curiosity, and an inspiration to protect and nurture the fragile gift of curiosity that is native to young minds. Einstein's genuine cosmic religious sense -- in sharp contrast to the counterfeits peddled by established religion and two-bit gurus alike -- grew directly from his passionate pursuit of the deepest possible understanding of the universe, and is wholly unimaginable without it. Bredo Johnsen Houston

HOROWITZ--Diana Cooper, in her 107th year, died on April 26th in Ridgewood, NJ. Mother to David, aunt to Deborah Eigen Graifman, her husband Gary and son, Michael. Wife of the late Herman. Born in Philadelphia to Dora and Samuel Cooper. Graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. Her 50 year career in social work included Director of Community and Volunteer services for the National Council of Jewish Women, New York Section. She was a founder and director of the Widows Consultation Center in NY in the 1970's. Her's was a life lived with grace, dignity, intelligence, generosity and kindness. Diana was a truly amazing and extraordinary woman who will be greatly missed and forever loved.

LEVINE--Sumner N., Professor Emeritus at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, died on March 20, 2007. A gentleman and a scholar, he is survived by his wife Caroline Gassner Levine, a daughter Professor Joanne Karger, and a grandson Raphael. His memory and legacy shall remain.

Travel books can generally be divided into two categories. First there are the ones in which all the traveling is done in the journey to an intended destination, at which point the writer stays put. And then there are the books in which the writer never stops -- jetting, cycling, cruising or otherwise gamboling about -- often at breakneck, TGV speed. Miss Manners, a k a Judith Martin, is one of those who know where they like to go and don't deviate in their devotion. Her latest book, NO VULGAR HOTEL: The Desire and Pursuit of Venice (Norton, $24.95), takes its title from Henry James's novel ''The Wings of the Dove,'' whose heroine, Milly Theale, declares that in Venice she will stay in ''no vulgar hotel,'' but in ''some fine old rooms, wholly independent, for a series of months.'' As Martin puts it, ''Renting -- not necessarily a palace, but no vulgar hotel -- is also a requirement for savoring the living Venice'' and truly understanding the city. It's the only way, she explains, to reciprocate invitations and entertain the locals, essential aspects of pursuing friendships. (Even on vacation, she remains Miss Manners.)

MARCH--Aaron. The Fire Island Synagogue mourns the passing of Aaron March, beloved father of Trustee Susan March. Aaron's kindness, gentleness and wisdom endeared him to all. Our deepest condolences to Susan, Lou, Zack and Emma. Fire Island Synagogue Shaul Magid, Rabbi. Harry Trattner, Cantor

WHEN my mother reached her mid-80s, it began to dawn on me that I'd have to start intervening in her life. This was not pleasant. Mom had always been fiercely independent, happily living on her own in suburban Boston for the 20 years after my dad died. There was no single event, just a hundred little ones that nibbled away at that solid image of Mom that was stored in my brain. I'd go back to Quincy for a visit and there would be piles of mail all over the house. Overdue bills were mixed in with supermarket stuffers that should have been tossed out weeks earlier. And I'd try to remember: Was this new?

America on Wheels The First 100 Years: 1896-1996 By Frank Coffey and Joseph Layden Illustrated. 304 pages. General Publishing Group, 1996. Standard automotive history treats the machines and the men who made them. ''America on Wheels,'' published as a companion to a three-hour PBS special of the same name, is more of a sociological story: how the horseless carriage changed the character of the country as it metamorphosed from the Age of Cleveland to the Age of Clinton.

This summer, the metal of the moment is neither gold nor silver, but an alloy of the two. The lustrous tone, simultaneously warm and cool, can take on the hue of one or the other metal depending on how light hits the surface. Lambertson Truex's Finley clutch, right, is overlaid with a pixilated silver foil, imparting a shimmery look ($1,490 by special order at Lambertson Truex in Los Angeles, 323-951-9622). Manolo Blahnik describes the color of its strappy high-heeled Tunica sandals, right, as ''alba,'' the Italian word for dawn ($565 at Jeffrey New York, 212-206-1272), while Dolce & Gabbana's thong sandals are called ''platino'' ($495 at Dolce & Gabbana stores; call 212-249-4100 to order). Stella McCartney's ''metallic'' silk and polyester shift pops like a lightning bolt in a heat storm ($1,530 at Intermix stores). What to call this melded color? ''Gilver'' is one suggestion, though retailers would surely prefer ''sold.'' ELIZABETH HAYT

For more than two years, Anahad O'Connor has written the Really? column for Science Times, tackling strange subjects and misleading myths about our health and the world we live in. He's discovered over the years that some commonplace cures and explanations carry weight (tea may help lower your stress levels), while others are just plain bogus (pricking a stroke victim's fingers is no way to help him). Plus, he's looked into some lighthearted myths, such as whether chocolate really is an aphrodisiac.
