Even as Bally Total Fitness prepares to slim down in bankruptcy, several potential suitors, including buyout firms, are expressing interest in the company, The New York Post reported Monday, citing unnamed sources. Among the names the newspaper drops are J.H. Whitney & Company and the Texas Pacific Group.
Accredited Home Lenders, the subprime mortgage lender that said in March its survival might be in doubt, will be sold to private-equity firm Lone Star Funds for about $400 million in cash.

In the Russian response to Britain's effort to get it to extradite a suspect in the murder of Alexander V. Litvinenko, first came a high-road legal argument, then a sensational counter-accusation by the accused man, and now President Vladimir V. Putin has stepped in with a salty dismissal. From The A.P.:

Like their counterparts in the Unites States, European private equity firms are facing criticism for the relatively low taxes they pay on "carried interest," which makes up the bulk of income for buyout fund managers. A leading figure in the industry, Nicholas Ferguson, has "broken the sector's taboo on tax," as the Financial Times puts it, making the observation that he and his cohorts "pay less tax than a cleaning lady." (We're not sure what his cleaning lady earns, but we assume he means a lower tax rate, not a lower dollar figure.)

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was pumped up this morning over her performance in Sunday night's debate, trading a perfectly executed high-five with the tennis legend Billie Jean King at a "Women for Hillary" campaign event and even taking on the "pundits" who suggest she is more than a little ambitious.

Real estate agents for months have been fretting over the market downturn in Florida, where condo sales dropped 32 percent statewide in March compared with the same period last year. And, in what was once red-hot Miami, the inventory of unsold homes was up 58 percent in April.

OK, Lets start with the reality: Central Rome is not made-for-cycling. There are no bike lanes and the streets are narrow. The drivers are nuts. Scooters swarm like bees. It is hilly. Most Italians consider bicycles the lowest form of transportation. If you want a taste what it is like to cycle in the center of Rome, check out this video by Austrian performance artist, Rainer Ganahl, who cycled in the center here with a camera on his helmet. (OK, he was cycling against traffic.) As he noted, he didn't see a single other cyclist during his 16 minute terror ride. On the other hand, the Italian police didn't seem to mind that he was cycling in the middle of the street into oncoming traffic.

Sumner Redstone and Leslie Moonves are nothing if not determined -- or stubborn, depending on whom you ask. The latest proof: Though they have been rebuffed by Time Warner before, CBS's chairman (that's Mr. Redstone) and chief executive (Mr. Moonves) said at the company's annual meeting that they're still interested in acquiring the media conglomerate's cable-news network, CNN.

Bidders for Laureate Education have increased their offer for the company, a for-profit operator of universities. Laureate's board has accepted the new $62-per-share bid, up from a previous offer of $60.50, but it remains to be seen whether the company's shareholders will get on board. After the bidding group, led by members of Laureate's management and including private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and hedge fund SAC Capital Management, made its original, $3.1 billion offer in January, several large stakeholders of Laureate said they thought it was too low.

CORAL GABLES, Fla. - Senator John McCain is about to deliver his full-throated defense of the Senate's proposal to overhaul the nation's immigration laws - coupled with some sharp words for presidential rivals like Mitt Romney who oppose the measure - in a speech here to the Greater Miami Chamber of Commerce.
In the category of celebrity justice, some get away with rehab, others are forced into community service, and then there are the especially unlucky ones.
Drag racing fans were surprised to learn May 30 that the National Hot Rod Association had sold its professional racing series and other assets for $121 million.

Dow Jones's controlling Bancroft family is expected to sit down today with Rupert Murdoch for a meeting that could determine the fate of his $5 billion bid for the company. The next hurdle in the negotiations will likely be what bankers call "social issues," The New York Times's DealBook wrote Sunday -- specifically, how Mr. Murdoch plans to protect the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal. On Monday, The Times's Media Equation column looked at how Mr. Murdoch might play his role as ardent suitor to a skeptical audience.

Flextronics International, a company that manufactures electronics for customers such as Cisco, Dell and Eastman Kodak, said Monday it will acquire rival Solectron in a deal it valued at $3.6 billion. The combination would create company with annual revenue of more than $30 billion, Singapore-based Flextronics said in a press release.
Dominion Resources said Monday it agreed to sell most of its onshore oil and gas exploration business to holding company Loew's Corporation and XTO Energy for about $6.5 billion.

In IndyCar, Tony Kanaan got some redemption. One week after a tough Indy 500, which he had been leading before rain temporarily halted the race on the 113th lap, Kanaan took advantage of a late crash by Helio Castroneves to jump in front with 25 laps to go at the Milwaukee Mile. From that point, Kanaan ran away from the pack, finishing 2.57 seconds ahead of Dario Franchitti, who leads the championship. But after the race, all eyes were on Danica Patrick, who had some heated words with Dan Wheldon. The two had bumped wheels on the 88th lap as she tried to pass Wheldon and Franchitti. "I was clearly inside of him," she said. "I'm not sure what was lost in translation there, but I was clearly inside of him."

Among hedge funds, the activists have been in the klieg lights for a while now -- and have reaped big returns for themselves and for shareholders. But a new academic study, which Financial News described as the most comprehensive yet produced, has found that those returns are falling as more funds chase fewer attractive targets.
Amp'd Mobile, a niche cellphone startup that raised $360 million from backers including MTV Networks and Universal Music, has filed for bankruptcy protection to restructure its business.

Palm, the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, reached a deal on Sunday to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million as part of a plan to reorganize the company, The New York Times reported.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer and lawmakers have been negotiating for several weeks to revive a law that speeds approval of power plants by overriding local ordinances. This week, the issue will be the subject of one of three rare public conference committees held by the Democrat-led Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate.

Avaya was near a deal last night to sell itself to Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group for more than $8 billion in the latest buyout in the telecommunications industry, according to The New York Times.

American Express is expected to sell its private banking business "within weeks," Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the matter. The buyer wasn't identified, but the source told Reuters that the private banking unit would likely be acquired by a "global institution."
The Senate returns today for what could be the decisive week for immigration legislation. Many lawmakers will no doubt prefer debating the bill rather than discussing it with voters back home.
Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy Digene for $1.6 billion in shares and cash to gain tests for a virus that causes cervical cancer and sexually transmitted diseases.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed a law late last week that legalized ticket scalping.

PQ, a specialty chemical manufacturer, is being sold for the second time in less than three years, bringing its owner a huge profit. The Carlyle Group said Friday that it had agreed to pay $1.5 billion for the company, making it a home run for the private-equity arm of JPMorgan Chase, which bought PQ for $626 million in February 2005.

Tribune announced Friday that it had reached a settlement with the Internal Revenue Service that would return to the company as much as $350 million of a disputed $1 billion tax payment it made in late 2005.

It has forged a historic deal to buy Chrysler for $7.4 billion, one of most audacious deals in private equity's history. It has taken stakes in 50 companies around the world, often after bare-knuckled negotiations. It has even purchased Remington Arms and Bushmaster Firearms, two of the top makers of so-called black rifles, styled after the assault weapons used by the military.

As it awaits the green light from federal antitrust regulators, Google disclosed last week in a government filing that it is putting new lobbying muscle, including a former high-ranking Justice Department antitrust lawyer, behind its proposed $3.1 billion acquisition of the online advertising firm DoubleClick.

The buyout shops that want to buy the energy firm TXU may have to raise their offer to persuade shareholders to accept, analysts said. The $45 billion offer by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group to buy the Dallas power company just survived a contentious legislative session unharmed.

In yet another example of hedge funds, investment banks and private equity shops blurring the lines of their respective businesses, Highbridge Capital Management, the hedge fund company with $34 billion of assets, has hired a former Goldman Sachs executive, Scott Kapnick, to start a private-equity business, Bloomberg News reported.

Ferox Capital Management has hired a longtime Morgan Stanley banker, Jack Inglis, as chief executive officer. Mr. Inglis, who left Morgan Stanley in January after 15 years there, will take over the day-to-day operations at the $2 billion British hedge fund so that its founder, Jeremy Herrmann, can concentrate on his role as chief investment officer.

The Empire Zone continues its efforts to create a full historical record of the March 14 dust-up between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, amid tense budget negotiations. As previously reported, words were exchanged and voices were raised in the governor's office, according to several people present or close by. And after Mr. Bruno made a lewd reference to the close political relationship of the governor and the Senate minority leader, Malcolm A. Smith, Mr. Spitzer stormed out of his office, saying, "I'm not going to abide that kind of vulgarity."

Realia, jointly owned by the savings bank Caja Madrid and a construction group, FCC, hopes to confound skeptics of the Spanish property sector by raising more than 1 billion euros ($1.34 billion) in an initial public offering on Wednesday, The Financial Times reported.
the oil and natural gas producer Anadarko Petroleum said late Sunday it is selling natural gas gathering systems and associated processing plants to Atlas Pipeline Partners for $1.85 billion.
There is an elegant way to free snapshots from computer hard drives: the digital picture frame.

The Real Estate Board of New York will start running television commercials today in support of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's long-range environmental plan, which includes a proposal to charge fees to drive below 86th Street during peak hours.

The Blackstone Group struck a deal to buy its first insurance broker, saying Sunday it would purchase the privately held Alliant Insurance Services. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Reuters said the price tag comes to $1.2 billion.
A Dutch financial group, SNS Reaal, is to buy the Dutch insurance operations of France's AXA for 1.75 billion euros ($2.35 billion) to double its domestic market share and cut costs.

IAC/InterActive, the New York-based media and e-commerce conglomerate run by the former Hollywood mogul Barry Diller, is starting a venture investing arm called Primal Ventures, The San Jose Mercury News reported.

Xstrata said Friday it would not match the 6.8 billion Canadian dollars ($6.4 billion), bid by the Russian mining titan Norilsk Nickel for LionOre Mining International. Xstrata, which negotiated a break-up fee of 305 million with LionOre, has extended its offer of 25 Canadian dollars a share to June 15.

A British property firm, Segro, has agreed to sell its life sciences real-estate business in the United States to Health Care Property Investors for $2.9 billion as it moves to focus on Britain and continental Europe. Segro, formerly Slough Estates, said on Monday it would return 250 million pounds ($495 million) of the proceeds from the sale of Slough Estates USA to shareholders via a special dividend.

The war of words in the battle for control of the Chicago Board of Trade continued Friday, as the top executive of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said that he remains convinced the C.B.O.T. will accept his exchange's bid over a rival bid from the Intercontinental Exchange.

Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, is in talks with at least two buyout firms about a possible sale of the company, The New York Times reported.

NanoH2O, a desalination company that grew out of research at UCLA, has raised $5 million. The company is trying to commercialize a membrane that consists of a matrix of porous polymer sheets embedded with specially designed nanoparticles that purify water. Investors include Khosla Ventures.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals, after pricing below its expected range, closed down in its first day on the Nasdaq. The initial public offering of the biotechnology firm, backed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, hit a sour note as a negative press report and skeptical investors depressed demand for its $108 million initial public offering.
Warren M. Anderson, who served as Senate majority leader from 1973 to 1988, died last week at age 91.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to support shareholders suing Wall Street banks for damages over Enron's collapse in a seminal case before the Supreme Court, according to The Washington Post.
Better headphones equal better sound for portable music players.
Tour five-bedroom homes in Boca Raton, Fla., and Boulder, Colo., and a Napa Valley estate with five structures, a pool, a pond and a tennis court.
Phone cameras have become more sophisticated, but most still need to focus more on image quality and ease of use.
“Creature Comforts” is an unusually snooty show for CBS even as it pretends to be something else.
Images from Brad Cloepfil's reworking of Edward Durell Stone's "lollipop" building at Columbus Circle.

Alexei Shirov, Boris Gelfand and Levon Aronian advanced to the final round of the candidates after winning their tiebreak contests. They join Gata Kamsky, Alexander Grischuk, Evgeny Bareev, Peter Leko and Sergei Rublevsky in the candidates final to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. All the matches, preliminary and final, are taking place in Elista, Kalmykia. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

Remember that great catch by Melky Cabrera Sunday night, the one in the third inning where he ran forever to track down Wily Mo Pena's drive on the distant center field warning track? Great moment for the Yankees, right?
Suzanne Daley, who oversees coverage of national news, is answering questions June 4 through 8.
Representative William J. Jefferson of Louisiana was indicted today on corruption charges.
The judge said there was a flaw in the procedure the military has used to file war crimes charges against Guantánamo detainees.
The court decision makes it easier to remove potential jurors who express ambivalence about the death penalty.
The video did not provide proof of whether the two missing soldiers were alive or dead.

HONG KONG, June 4 — A candlelight vigil here this evening to mark the 18th anniversary of the military crackdown on the Tiananmen Square demonstrations drew an unusually large crowd, apparently in response to the recent assertion by the leader of Hong Kong’s pro-Beijing party that no massacre took place in 1989.
The Russian president threatened to point missiles at Europe if the U.S. builds its missile defense system.
The defense secretary said that he and the president of Afghanistan agreed that there was no direct evidence that the Iranian government was behind the arms shipments.
Two Lebanese soldiers and one militiaman were killed in fighting early this morning at a refugee camp in southern Lebanon, the army said.
Charles G. Taylor, once one of West Africa’s most feared men, dismissed his defense lawyer today and refused to appear at the opening of his long-awaited war crimes trial.
The comprehensive strategy calls for improving energy efficiency and controlling greenhouse gas emissions but rejects mandatory caps on emissions.
Today’s sell-off was one of the largest declines in a decade, nearly comparable to February’s sharp drop.
With the score tied, Alex Rodriguez punished a 95-mile-an-hour fastball from Jonathan Papelbon on a line, into the Boston Red Sox’ bullpen, for his 20th home run and the win.

An article on Tuesday about a drop in crime in East Orange, N.J., which city officials attribute to the Police Department’s use of new surveillance technology, misstated the number of precincts in the Queens South division of the New York Police Department, a division that the East Orange police director, Jose M. Cordero, formerly ran. There are 8, not 18.

The Executive Pursuits column in Business Day on May 5, about selling hot dogs at Shea Stadium, misinterpreted a survey by the National Hog Dog and Sausage Council and referred incorrectly to hot dog sales at Shea. Although the stadium sells an average of just under 20,000 hot dogs a game, and ranks No. 1 among major league ballparks who responded to the questionnaire from the hot dog council, Shea does not lead all ballparks in sales. It trails Yankee Stadium, which sells about 30,000 a game but did not answer the survey. (A reader raised the issue after an article on May 11 about the introduction of Latin food at Yankee Stadium mentioned the higher figure for the Yankees. Unfortunately for the reader, who vowed not to “consume any dogs at either stadium until it has been settled,” this correction was delayed for research; but the Mets have a home game tomorrow night.).

An article on Wednesday about Reading to Rover, a program at the Westport Public Library in Connecticut in which children read to dogs as a form of therapy, misspelled the given name of the children’s librarian. She is Lynne Perrigo, not Lynn.

Because of an editing error, two picture captions on Tuesday with an article in Science Times about private rooms in neonatal intensive care units misspelled the surname of a woman whose son was born prematurely in St. Paul. She is Robyn Frandrup, not Frandrep. Also, the article misstated the month that Amillia Taylor, who was born at just over 21 weeks’ gestation, was released from a Miami hospital. It was February, not April.

A credit for an illustration with an essay in Science Times on May 22 about a doctor who witnessed a patient’s last night misspelled the given name of the artist and reversed it with her surname. She is Tifenn Python, not Python Tiffen.

The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the news media’s efforts to cover the war in Iraq, misspelled the given name of a photographer who chronicled the Civil War. He was Mathew Brady, not Matthew.

Artist renderings with an article in Science Times on Sept. 12, 2006, about plans by a biomedical research institute in China to construct a building with a design inspired by cells omitted credit for two artists. Besides Sloan Kulper, the renderings were by Audrey Roy and Shuguang Zhang. The omission was pointed out recently in an e-mail message from Mr. Kulper.

An article on Saturday about charges being brought in Brazil against two American pilots, whose corporate jet was involved in a mid-air collision last year over the Amazon with a Brazilian airliner that went down with 154 people aboard, misstated a Brazilian judge’s position on the case. He said in a statement issued in Portuguese on Friday that the two pilots, Joseph Lepore and Jan Paul Paladino, should be charged with exposing an aircraft to danger; he did not say they were guilty of having done so.

An article on Tuesday about a drop in crime in East Orange, N.J., which city officials attribute to the Police Department’s use of new surveillance technology, misstated the number of precincts in the Queens South division of the New York Police Department, a division that the East Orange police director, Jose M. Cordero, formerly ran. There are 8, not 18.
Abdul Kadir and Russell M. Defreitas met in Georgetown in their native Guyana in late February, according to federal investigators. They walked together with another man to a mall downtown.

The 400-mile Nascar Nextel Cup race scheduled for yesterday afternoon at Dover International Speedway in Delaware was postponed until noon today because of heavy rain. The race is the sixth of the year using the new Car of Tomorrow. Ryan Newman will start from the pole position, and Dale Earnhardt Jr. will start second, his best starting position in 13 races this season.Although skies over the racetrack were still leaden, rain stopped long enough for workers to attempt to dry the track so the race could start just after its scheduled time of 1:45 p.m. But it began to rain again, and the race was postponed a half-hour later.It was the third time in the past four Nextel Cup races, including those at Richmond and Darlington, that a race has been pushed back one day because of poor weather. There is a 60 percent chance of showers today.
CYCLING.
All but one of the deaths were the result of makeshift bombs, which insurgents have been employing with greater lethality.
Three months after the start of the operation, U.S. and Iraqi troops control less than a third of the city.
Mitt Romney’s success at Bain Capital helped finance his campaigns but has also exposed him to criticism.
Ethiopia has become a hot spot for international adoption, but the sudden popularity comes with risks, officials say.
Republicans are seeking to regain control of a once-reliable foothold in a special election Tuesday.
China said that a Food and Drug Administration warning about potentially harmful Chinese toothpaste in the U.S. was “unscientific, irresponsible and contradictory.”
The courts may determine just who owns Curlin, the horse that bested Street Sense to win the Preakness Stakes.
The would-be terrorists who plotted to detonate facilities at Kennedy International Airport seem to have had more evil intent than operational capability.
The Cavaliers’ win over Detroit was the ultimate reversal of fortune for a beleaguered sports city accustomed to big-game failure.
President Bush’s new proposal is a potentially useful tool for gaining consensus on cutting worldwide emissions linked to global warming.
The leading Democratic candidates attacked one another overtly and subtly over Iraq in a debate Sunday night.
The official death toll from the two-week conflict reached 110, including 44 soldiers.
Doug Mientkiewicz’s placement on the disabled list will allow the Yankees to start Matt DeSalvo on Monday in Chicago, giving Kei Igawa more time in the minors to smooth his mechanics.
Bobby Cox remained one ejection shy Sunday of tying John McGraw for a dubious distinction and unofficial baseball record.
Federal authorities are investigating a series of transactions between the Republican leader’s horse breeding business and a major political donor.
Across the country, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a Republican, has emerged as the face of gun control.
Aggrieved graffiti artists have joined to seek a settlement from a photographer who included images of their murals in his book without their permission.
The Senate must make sure a flawed immigration bill doesn’t get worse. That means beating back a particularly noxious amendment from Senator John Cornyn of Texas.
A new, updated version of the board game has all the passivity of the old one, and whether you are a Ph.D. nanny or a 7-year-old daddy, you don’t control where you end up.
Avaya was near a deal on Sunday night to sell itself to Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group for more than $8 billion.
K. J. Choi earn a one-shot victory over Ryan Moore at the Memorial Tournament, firing a seven-under-par 65 in the final round to finish at 17-under-par 271.
Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister, is raising her profile again and positioning herself as savior of Pakistan.
Congress’s ban on even locally financed needle exchange programs in the District of Columbia is an insult to the city’s voters and a clear hazard to public health.
Maria Sharapova advanced to the French Open quarterfinals for the third time in her career.
In an interview, Jack Kevorkian says he will no longer advise terminally ill people how to die. But he still combatively advocates physician-assisted suicide.
The number of births to Mexican women increased 28 percent from 2000 to 2005, a time in which the city’s overall births were down.
After Sultan Ibragimov routed Shannon Briggs to win the World Boxing Organization version of the heavyweight four-ring circus, all the belts belong to fighters from the former Soviet republics.
The passenger helicopter was reportedly carrying soccer officials visiting from Togo.
Mr. Silver’s 1975 application for ordination in the United Presbyterian Church set off a continuing debate in the church over admitting homosexuals into the ministry.
Arthur Brown Jr., 16,  can run a 40-yard dash in 4.47 seconds and he already has more than 50 scholarship offers. What he doesn’t have is a cellphone.

Mark DeRosa hit a grand slam, Alfonso Soriano and Derrek Lee added bases-empty home runs, and the Chicago Cubs closed out a tumultuous weekend by defeating the Atlanta Braves, 10-1, yesterday to snap a six-game losing streak.
Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, the ruler of Dubai, plans to stand the Kentucky Derby winner at stallion when his racing career is over.

A state prison guard was killed and a county jail guard was hospitalized with internal injuries after their vehicles collided head-on yesterday morning near Buffalo, the state police said. The prison guard, Daniel Shanahan, 43, of Buffalo, was driving to work at the Lakeview Shock Incarceration Facility near Brocton, and the county guard, John Mackowiak, 55, of Dunkirk, was headed home after working a shift at the Chautauqua County Jail in Mayville, the state police said. Their vehicles collided about 7:30 a.m. on Route 5 in Portland, 47 miles southwest of Buffalo, the state police said.

The State Senate’s Democratic party leader has introduced a bill that would ban the use of the chemical tetrachloroethylene, known as perc, which is frequently used in dry cleaning and auto body repair. Senator Malcolm A. Smith of Queens said yesterday that he introduced legislation on Friday that would require environmental officials to work with businesses that use perc to facilitate a change to more environmentally friendly products. Slightly elevated levels of perc were found last month in the water supply of an area of Queens, causing concern among residents, Mr. Smith said. Exposure to large amounts of the chemical can affect the nervous system, but city health officials said the minute level detected in Queens was not expected to cause health problems.

More than 200 firefighters battled a fire that started at 6 p.m. Saturday and raged for about 23 hours in a furniture warehouse in Bushwick, the Fire Department said. Nineteen firefighters suffered minor injuries in the fire at the one-story warehouse, at 160 Stewart Avenue, fire officials said. The blaze was under control by about 5 p.m. yesterday, the officials said. The cause was under investigation.

Casino dealers at Bally’s Atlantic City voted in favor of becoming members of the United Auto Workers union yesterday, by a vote of 628 to 255, officials said. The Bally’s vote followed unsuccessful drives to unionize at Trump Marina Hotel Casino and the Atlantic City Hilton. In March, dealers at Caesars Atlantic City and Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino voted to join the U.A.W. Many of Atlantic City’s 45,000 casino workers are represented by unions, but until this year, dealers were not among them.

State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein said yesterday that New York should expand its efforts to encourage young people to register to vote. Senator Klein, a Democrat who represents parts of the Bronx and Westchester County, said a survey of 60 colleges and universities in the state conducted by his staff found that none of the private institutions mailed voter forms to students and only 10 percent of the public ones did so. Only half of the private universities surveyed provided registration information on campus, he said. Senator Klein has proposed requiring the state to mail voter registration forms to all residents when they turn 18.
Jeremy Bonderman remained unbeaten despite another shaky first inning and the visiting Detroit Tigers defeated the Cleveland Indians, 9-2, yesterday to gain a four-game series split.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state lawmakers are negotiating a plan that would expedite the creation of power plants by overriding local laws.
Father Kirk, for decades a presence in the civil rights and antiwar movements, established Emmaus House, a communal residence for the homeless, in the mid-1960s.
If Congress is serious about protecting against terrorism, it will include restrictions on rail transport of deadly chemicals in a new anti-terrorism bill.
Largely confined to a sprinkling of islands off South Africa’s tip, the African penguin, the continent’s only native penguin, is endangered.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,469 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:.
The new drug could become the first effective treatment for liver cancer, one of the deadliest forms of cancer.
After his mixed martial arts loss to Bernard Ackah of the Ivory Coast., former N.F.L. receiver Johnnie Morton was suspended for refusing to take a drug test.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates expressed guarded optimism about the progress of the military campaign against a resurgent Taliban.
The Anaheim Ducks will have to play without Chris Pronger, as the defenseman was suspended for Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals for his forearm to the head of Senators forward Dean McAmmond.
Team New Zealand needs only two more victories in the best-of-nine challenger series to clinch its place in the America’s Cup against Alinghi, the defending champion.
The shelling occurred hours after Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian man in the West Bank city of Jenin.
Senator John McCain is accusing Mitt Romney, a main rival in the presidential campaign, of “pandering for votes.”
The shelling occurred hours after Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian man in the West Bank city of Jenin.
An earthquake struck the county seat of Ninger, in Yunnan Province, on early Sunday.
In calling for a boycott, opposition leaders said President Abdoulaye Wade refused to meet with them to discuss irregularities in the voter rolls in February.
A suicide bomber rammed a pickup truck packed with explosives into the gates of the prime minister’s house.
Among rare-fruit devotees, Mr. Whitman was hailed as the only person to have coaxed a mangosteen tree into bearing fruit outdoors in the continental United States.
In 1960, Mr. Yost fastened two propane tanks to what looked like a lawn chair, attached that to a 40-foot-diameter nylon balloon and sailed above the Nebraska plain.
A new at-home screening test, called Fertell, lets couples find out if they have fertility problems without stepping into a doctor’s office.
A young woman eats pretzels out of a shoe and a middle-aged pedestrian wistfully remembers his jaywalking days.
The Weather Channel has seen its primary subject turn into a hot-button issue because of the topic of climate change.
NBC Universal took another step in revamping its television entertainment operations, appointing a new president of its television production studio.
Palm Inc., the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, has reached a deal to sell a quarter of the company to a private equity firm for about $325 million.
Though Rufus Wainwright casually refers to himself as a superstar — in a tone that’s a few notes short of irony — his last few albums were more like cult hits.

A BREAK IN THE ACTION It will be a relatively slow week for economic news, led by the report on the trade deficit for April (Friday). Other reports will include April factory orders (Monday), the Institute for Supply Management’s nonmanufacturing index (Tuesday), revised first-quarter productivity and labor costs (Wednesday) and April numbers for wholesale trade and consumer credit (Thursday).
“Gone With the Wind” goes musical in London, “Pirates” sails on, Ford’s Theater is closed for renovations,  “West Side Story” goes gold and more culture news.
The race is very close in a contest by Netflix, the online movie rental service, for a better system of recommending movies.
Cadence Design Systems, a maker of the software used to design computer chips, is in talks about a possible sale of the company, two people said Sunday.
American Ballet Theater’s new production of “The Sleeping Beauty” certainly isn’t hidebound by custom.
Amp’d Mobile, a niche cellphone provider aimed at the young and technologically sophisticated, filed for Chapter 11 with the intention of revamping the business.

The Rock Bottom Remainders, whose members include Amy Tan, Dave Barry and Stephen King, are what every garage band dreams of becoming: people with word-processing day jobs who every now and then get to go on tour.
Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy the Digene Corporation for $1.6 billion in shares and cash.
When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton asked YouTube viewers to vote on a theme song for her presidential campaign, she got the attention she wanted.
Maclean’s Magazine has two important connections with Conrad M. Black that complicate its role as an impartial chronicler of his trial.

The Long Island Spring Regional starts in Smithtown tomorrow. The tournament chairman, Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., played on Memorial Day weekend in the Easterns Regional in New York City. He and his teammates, Diana Schuld of Glen Head, N.Y., Ruth Stober of Great Neck, N.Y., and Michael Abramson of Montclair, N.J., finished second in the Open Swiss Teams behind Steven Petersell, Qiang Wang and Sam Wang of New York and Jian Wang of New Milford, N.J. They might have been third but for the diagramed deal.
Real and mythological creatures mingle in the strange looking-glass world of two new museum exhibitions.
Oliver Pérez walked the leadoff hitter in three consecutive innings and allowed two of them to score while Arizona’s Doug Davis shut down the Mets’ lineup.
Rupert Murdoch, a coarse, self-seeking tabloid king, has become a potential savior who will rescue Dow Jones.
A deal could transform the little-known Nano-Terra Inc. into one of nanotechnology’s most closely watched start-ups.
At BookExpo America, the publishing industry’s annual convention, the battering ram of technology was back.

VERMUT--Julius. Born June 4, 1913, died June 1, 2007. Father of Avin, Robert and Ellen (Puhn). Grandfather of eight, great-grandfather of eleven. He will be dearly missed with everlasting love.

Are there more coal-fired and nuclear power plants in New York's future? Gov. Eliot Spitzer and lawmakers have been negotiating for several weeks to revive a law that speeds approval of power plants by overriding local ordinances. This week, the issue will be the subject of one of three rare public conference committees held by the Democrat-led Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,469 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday: DOMINO, Chadrick O., 23, Sgt., Army; Ennis, Tex.; Second Infantry Division.

A credit for an illustration with an essay in Science Times on May 22 about a doctor who witnessed a patient's last night misspelled the given name of the artist and reversed it with her surname. She is Tifenn Python, not Python Tiffen.

To the Editor: ''Lifesaving Opportunities Missed, Before and After Stroke'' (front page, May 28) discusses a number of reasons that stroke patients may not receive tPA as treatment in the emergency department. But there is another reason: the significant controversy in the field of emergency medicine about the use of tissue plasminogen activator, or tPA.

State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein said yesterday that New York should expand its efforts to encourage young people to register to vote. Senator Klein, a Democrat who represents parts of the Bronx and Westchester County, said a survey of 60 colleges and universities in the state conducted by his staff found that none of the private institutions mailed voter forms to students and only 10 percent of the public ones did so. Only half of the private universities surveyed provided registration information on campus, he said. Senator Klein has proposed requiring the state to mail voter registration forms to all residents when they turn 18.

To the Editor: ''Not to See the Fallen Is No Favor,'' by David Carr (The Media Equation, May 28), suggests that the reigning assumption among leaders in Iraq is that we can't handle the truth. In a curious way, it may well be the duty of fallen soldiers to let us see them -- wounded, dying and dead.
DUTT--Eric. To a great teacher, who can't be replaced. We will miss you and never forget you. David and Robert Kaufman

Jerry Bergonzi ''Tenorist'' (Savant Records) A strange development in jazz over the last 30 years has been that many of its players with the most actual, documented influence on other players aren't that well known to the larger world. They are usually teachers in New York or Boston and authors of books on harmonic theory. An axiom of the American respect for show business is that one's reputation as a great teacher can hinder one's reputation as a great player.

PALM SELLS 25% STAKE -- Palm, the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, reached a deal to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million. [Page C1.] A FRENZY FOR IPHONE -- It has been almost six months since Steven P. Jobs introduced the iPhone, and hysteria for what some have called ''the God machine'' is beginning to reach levels usually reserved for video-game consoles at Christmas. [C1.] WEATHER CHANNEL HEATS UP -- The weather may not be controversial, but the broader topic of climate change has generated no end of debate. As the Weather Channel's primary subject turns into a hot-button issue, it has had to grapple with how specifically it wants to address it. [C1.] MAGAZINES GO IN-HOUSE FOR ADS -- Magazine companies traditionally have made money by selling ad space in their magazines or, more recently, on their Web sites. Now some of them have set up internal mini-agencies to design campaigns for their own pages. Advertising. [C1.] DEAL IN CHIP DESIGN -- Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, is in talks with at least two buyout firms about a possible sale of the company. [C2.] THE MINT'S TWO CENTS -- The United States Mint has taken exception to a promotional stunt for the summer movie ''Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer'' -- 40,000 quarters altered to bear an image of the Silver Surfer. [C6.] PAYING TO LOOK AT JOB LISTS -- A growing number of niche sites devoted to high-end jobs are finding that applicants are willing to pay for access. Marc Cenedella, above, chief executive of TheLadders.com, which lists jobs paying $100,000 or more, said the site was on pace to exceed $30 million in sales this year. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C5.] LEG UP FOR A START-UP -- Harvard plans to announce today the exclusive licensing for more than 50 current and pending Harvard patents to a little-known company, Nano-Terra Inc., that could transform it into one of nanotechnology's most closely watched start-ups. [C5.] THE PERIL OF NOT TALKING TECH -- The latest example of the danger of revealing technological weakness is a British judge who, while presiding over an antiterrorism trial, was quoted as saying in open court: ''The trouble is, I don't understand the language. I don't really understand what a Web site is.'' Link by Link. [C4.] BETTER NETFLIX RECOMMENDATIONS -- Netflix announced last year that it would award $1 million to the developer of a system that was at least 10 percent more accurate than its current system for recommending movies to customers. After more than 12,000 sets of guesses, the improvement level to Netflix's rating system is now at 7.42 percent. [C5.] COVERING CONRAD BLACK -- The leading Canadian newsmagazine Maclean's has some connections with Conrad M. Black that complicate its role as an impartial chronicler of his trial on fraud charges. Mr. Black's wife is a Maclean's columnist, and the magazine's editor in chief is a close friend of Mr. Black's. [C6.] BOB MARLEY ON FLASH DRIVE -- For the 30th anniversary of Bob Marley's ''Exodus,'' Island Records produced 4,000 flash drives that come loaded with the original 10 songs and additional tracks and videos. [C6.] CAMPAIGN MUSIC FOR CLINTON -- When Senator Hillary Clinton asked YouTube viewers to vote on a theme song for her presidential campaign, she got the attention she wanted -- and a lot of jokes at her expense. [C6.] LET ME TALK ABOUT MY BOOK -- In an effort to counter shrinking shelf lives of books, disappearing book review sections and a fading audience attention span, several major publishing houses have set up speakers bureaus to sell books after the initial publicity campaign and to help authors earn extra money. [C6.] $1.6 BILLION DEAL FOR DIGENE -- Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy the Digene Corporation for $1.6 billion in shares and cash to gain tests for a virus that causes cervical cancer and sexually transmitted diseases. [C2.] CELLPHONE PROVIDER STRUGGLES -- Amp'd Mobile, a niche cellphone provider aimed at young sophisticated users, has filed for bankruptcy protection. [C4.]

HECHT--Helen, 88, died June 1, 2007. Loving wife of the late Henry Hecht, mother and friend of Judith Gutlerner and Tema Hecht, grandmother of Orin and Jed Gutlerner, great-grandmother of Lilah Sue Gutlerner, mother-in-law of Larry Gutlerner and Richard Bostwick.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.78 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 4.97 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.79 percent.

ROSENZWEIG--Maxwell of Coconut Creek, Florida, formerly of Bayside, New York, died peacefully on May 30, 2007. Beloved husband of Mae (Blatt) for over 60 years; father of Robin and Alex Schkrutz and Roy Rosenzweig and Deborah Kaplan; grandfather of David and Eric Schkrutz; brother of the late Martin, Gladys, and Sylvia; ''Uncle Max'' to his nieces and nephews. He graduated from City College in 1938, served in the Army Air Corps during World War II, and worked at the New York State Department of Labor for more than 30 years. His family and friends will dearly miss his good humor, wise stories, and warm presence. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.

KELLER--Adelaide. The beloved wife of George for 60 years; mother of Bill, Bob and Barry; grandmother to Anna, Matt, Danny, Tom, Molly and Alice; sister of William T. McCague and mother-in-law to Maureen, Lynda and Emma passed away peacefully at the age of 84 just after midnight on Saturday, June 2nd at Sequoia Hospital, Redwoods City, California. Addie was a lover of mystery novels, golf and orchids, an enthusiastic amateur poet and a columnist for several local newsletters. But she will be best remembered as a devoted philanthropist who gave generously to her alma mater Wellesley College, to San Mateo County Hospital and to many other charitable organizations in and around San Mateo where she lived. She won multiple awards for her generosity in the Bay Area including an official recognition by the US House of Representatives in 1993. In 1970 she co-founded the Women's Recovery Association -the nations first residential treatment program for female recovering alcoholics. For several years she was a board member of the San Mateo County Medical Center for which she was a champion fund raiser, creating its annual bed race and parade. But she was always happier offering her services at the grassroots level rather than serving on boards and her legacy can be seen most clearly in The Keller Center for Family Violence Intervention. The Center opened in 2001 because of Addie's strong belief that something more needed to be done to break the pattern of domestic violence. Emphasizing both crisis intervention and communitybased education and prevention the Center was based at the San Mateo County Medical Center, but worked closely with local law enforcement and judicial agencies. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name can be made to the Keller Center for Family Violence at San Mateo County Medical Center.

KANE--Lester P. He was a giant in court reporting who single handedly transformed his profession. We mourn with his wife Libby, his children Nancy (Amanda), Robert (Lee), Richard and Claudia and their spouses and children. You will never be forgotten. ''We feel very stronly about that''. Marvin P. Birnbaum

The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the news media's efforts to cover the war in Iraq, misspelled the given name of a photographer who chronicled the Civil War. He was Mathew Brady, not Matthew.

An article on Wednesday about Reading to Rover, a program at the Westport Public Library in Connecticut in which children read to dogs as a form of therapy, misspelled the given name of the children's librarian. She is Lynne Perrigo, not Lynn.

A BREAK IN THE ACTION -- It will be a relatively slow week for economic news, led by the report on the trade deficit for April (Friday). Other reports will include April factory orders (Monday), the Institute for Supply Management's nonmanufacturing index (Tuesday), revised first-quarter productivity and labor costs (Wednesday) and April numbers for wholesale trade and consumer credit (Thursday). INTERNATIONAL FOCUS -- The Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., will discuss United States-China relations at the Heritage Foundation in Washington (Tuesday). The Group of 8 summit takes place Wednesday through Friday. The International Trade Commission is scheduled to rule on a patent dispute between Qualcomm and Broadcom (Thursday). CANCER DRUGS ON DISPLAY -- The annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology continues through Tuesday in Chicago. Companies like Pfizer, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Genentech are presenting data on their latest drug treatments for cancer. EARNINGS DATA -- It will be a quiet week for earnings, with reports coming from Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (Monday) and National Semiconductor and Smithfield Foods (Thursday). ET CETERA -- Retailers will report their same-store sales for May (Thursday). General Motors will have its annual meeting (Tuesday).

When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton asked YouTube viewers to vote on a theme song for her presidential campaign, she certainly got the attention she wanted -- and a whole lot of jokes at her expense. While her campaign provided a list of upbeat songs to choose from -- like ''I'm a Believer'' and ''Beautiful Day'' -- her detractors suggested alternatives like ''Let's Call the Whole Thing Off'' and ''Cold as Ice.''

'Gone With the Wind' Goes Musical in London When April rolls around, Scarlett O'Hara, Rhett Butler, and Melanie and Ashley Wilkes should be singing and dancing at the New London Theater in the London's West End under the direction of Trevor Nunn in a musical adaptation of Margaret Mitchell's Pulitzer Prize-winning 1936 novel, ''Gone With the Wind.'' Music and lyrics will be by a newcomer, Margaret Martin, in her first work for musical theater; she is a sociologist by training and is working on two new plays. In a statement Mr. Nunn, former artistic director and chief executive of the Royal Shakespeare Company, said, ''Having now worked on adapting two vast novels for the stage, 'Nicholas Nickleby' and 'Les Misérables,' I am drawn to the challenge of telling Margaret Mitchell's epic story through words, music and the imaginative resources of the theater.'' The musical adaptation of ''Gone With the Wind'' will not be London's first; a version with a score by Harold Rome played at the Theater Royal Drury Lane in 1972. 'Pirates' Sails On Treasure beyond the wildest dreams of Henry Morgan, Blackbeard, Jean Lafitte or any other brigand who ever sailed the seven seas continued to swell the coffers of ''Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End'' on its second weekend in North American theaters. The swashbuckler starring Johnny Depp, right, and distributed under the Buena Vista flag, amassed an estimated $43.1 million to continue as the No. 1 film, according to the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers, bringing its domestic total to $216.5 million (although the weekend gross from 4,362 theaters, the same number as last week, represented a 62 percent falloff from the preceding week). Second place in the rankings went to a newcomer: ''Knocked Up'' (Universal), the Judd Apatow pregnancy comedy starring Katherine Heigl and Seth Rogen, attracted $29.2 million. Third place rewarded another of the season's sequels, ''Shrek the Third'' (Paramount), which grossed $26.7 million to bring its total to $254.6 million in its third week in theaters. ''Mr. Brooks'' (MGM), starring Kevin Costner as a serial killer, took in $10 million to capture fourth place. Fifth place was occupied by yet another big-budget sequel, ''Spider-Man 3'' (Sony), which gathered $7.5 million for a five-week total of $318.2 million. Ford's Theater Renovations Ford's Theater in Washington, where Lincoln was shot, has been closed by the National Park Service for 18 months, The Associated Press reported. The closing will permit an $8.5 million renovation of the 144-year-old theater, including its first elevator, new restrooms, and improvements in its heating, air conditioning, lighting and sound systems, in part to improve access for the disabled. The theater was last renovated in the 1960s. 'West Side Story' Goes Gold A 50th-anniversary production of ''West Side Story'' will be presented at the Théâtre du Châtelet in Paris for four weeks beginning on Nov. 20. The show will be performed in English by an American cast. On Friday the North Carolina School of the Arts production of ''West Side Story,'' which grossed $940,000 in Winston-Salem and drew more than 15,000 people in a dozen performances last month, will play the Ravinia Festival in Highland Park, Ill., a Chicago suburb. Footnotes Bobby Short may be gone, but he's not forgotten. Beginning tomorrow night, Michael Feinstein and a succession of special guests will pay tribute to that sophisticated singer and pianist with ''Celebrating Bobby Short'' through June 16 at Feinstein's at Loews Regency. The leadoff guest will be Elaine Stritch. On June 12, Liza Minnelli is to join the entertainment. Kevin Spacey and Vanessa Redgrave, along with performers from ''Frost/Nixon,'' ''Grey Gardens,'' ''Hairspray,'' ''Inherit the Wind,'' ''Jersey Boys,'' ''Legally Blonde,'' ''Mamma Mia!'' and ''Spring Awakening,'' are scheduled to appear on Wednesday at ''Stars in the Alley.'' The free outdoor concert, from 11 a.m. to about 12:30 p.m. in Shubert Alley, west of Broadway between 44th and 45th Streets, celebrates the 2006-7 Broadway season. The eminent jazz pianist Oscar Peterson, 82, will be saluted Friday at 8 p.m. at Carnegie Hall in a ''Master of Swing'' concert featuring Dee Dee Bridgewater, Paquito D'Rivera, Jimmy Heath, Marian McPartland, Billy Taylor and Clark Terry, among many others. Free outdoor movies will return to Bryant Park for a 15th season at sunset on June 18 with a presentation of Woody Allen's ''Annie Hall'' on a 20-by-40-foot screen. The screenings, every Monday night through Aug. 20, will include ''Paper Moon'' (July 2), ''The Sting'' (July 23) and ''Casablanca'' (Aug. 13). Information: (212) 512-5700 or aolcityguide.com/newyork/hbobryantparkfilm/.

Daddy Yankee ''El Cartel: The Big Boss'' (El Cartel/Interscope) The chorus of Daddy Yankee's new single for American radio is ''Make an impacto,'' a bilingual slogan that sums up his goal on ''El Cartel: The Big Boss.'' Reaching the pop mainstream has become the goal of reggaetón, the Puerto Rican rap-and-reggae hybrid. It has spread across the Americas by emulating dancehall and gangsta rap: flaunting street roots while aiming for a mass audience.

SOMMER--Terry. I will always miss you and love you. I miss our weekly calls. Babs

He was down to his last strike with two outs in the ninth inning of Sunday night's game, at the end of what might be the longest week of his life. Alex Rodriguez -- bad boy of the tabloids, violator of baseball etiquette, object of ridicule and scorn at Fenway Park -- was fighting. With the score tied and his teammates seeming to drop all around him with injuries, Rodriguez punished a 95-mile-an-hour fastball from Jonathan Papelbon on a line, into the Boston Red Sox' bullpen, for his 20th home run. With that, Rodriguez led the Yankees to a victory in the game, 6-5, and in the series, two games to one.

Tiger Army Music From Regions Beyond (Hellcat/Epitaph) Bebop. Death metal. Trance. Emo. Most genre names sound a little silly, or a lot silly, at least at first. Still it's not hard to sympathize with Nick 13, leader (and the only constant member) of the Los Angeles-based trio Tiger Army. When asked about his chosen genre, he has no choice but to utter those four risible syllables: psychobilly.

MILLER--Bernard,died June 1, 2007 at age 91. The owner and manager of Miller and Miller Real Estate Company in Manhattan. He was a comedy writer in the early days of television. A graduate of Harvard Law School, he was the writer of Captain Marvel Comics for Fawcett Publications. He donated the third largest private collection of books of humor to Brown University. He was also an active fundraiser for many local and international charities and served on the Town of Harrison Planning Board for 10 years. Survived by his beloved wife Harriet(Schutz), children Robert Miller (Tamora) and Steven Miller (Astrid), grandchildren, Siri, Cara and Marisa, greatgrandson Gavin Vaquer, and siblings Saul Miller, George Miller(Roz) and Hannah Wolff. Funeral service will be held at JCC of Harrison with interment following at Sharon Gardens. For more information, contact Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck. 914 - 381 - 1809. www.zionme morialchapel.com $(6$)MILLER--Bernard. He was a dear and loyal friend to me for 74 years. The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday, about the limitations of the current copyright law and proposals to fix it, misstated the year that changes in the law went into effect. It was 1978, not 1964. (Under the revised law, books published before 1964 could have their copyright renewed in the 28th year after their initial registration.)

9 P.M. (Lifetime) WRITE & WRONG -- (2007) Kirstie Alley can't seem to get a break. As if the fat-actress self-flagellation weren't bad enough, Ms. Alley, now slender, is encountering the pitfalls of middle age in this made-for-television comedy about a 40-something screenwriter who can no longer get a lunch in Hollywood -- until she starts passing off her scripts as the work of her hunky young nephew (Eric Christian Olsen, with Ms. Alley above). When he falls in love with a studio executive, Auntie's plan to reveal her true talents may never see the light of day. 7:30 P.M. (Sundance) THE LAST VICTORY -- (2004) In Siena, Italy, the Palio horse race, a bareback scramble around the main square, has been an annual source of glory for one of the city's 17 districts for centuries. In this colorful documentary John Appel homes in on the pageantry, feasts, flag waving and fisticuffs surrounding the mad 80-second dash and examines the efforts of Civetta, Siena's smallest district, which hasn't won since 1979. 8 P.M. (CBS) CREATURE COMFORTS -- Animal magnetism indeed. Aardman Animations of ''Wallace & Gromit'' fame has adapted its own British series. In the new version, which makes its debut tonight, ordinary Americans lend their voices to a menagerie of creatures, like the lovebirds at left, who discuss things like height differences, attracting the opposite sex, visits to the doctor and difficulties of keeping secrets. 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO -- Yada, yada, yada: Julia Louis-Dreyfus talks about her stint on ''Saturday Night Live,'' her experiences on ''Seinfeld'' and surviving the Seinfeld curse. 8 P.M. (TLC) LITTLE PEOPLE, BIG WORLD -- Two back-to-back episodes focus on surgery to repair Zach's bowed legs, followed by a cheer-up visit from the actor and stunt man Martin Klebba, also a little person. 9 P.M. (ABC) EX-WIVES CLUB -- Marla Maples, Angie Everhart and Shar Jackson help a military veteran from Orlando, Fla., and a nanny in Schenectady, N.Y., rebuild their lives after devastating breakups. 9 P.M. (Fox) HELL'S KITCHEN -- Sharpen your knives and get out the fire extinguisher. The hot-headed Gordon Ramsay, right, dishes up new servings of fury to 12 contestants competing for the post of head chef of an Italian restaurant at the Green Valley Ranch Resort and Spa in Las Vegas in this reality competition's third season. 10 P.M. (WE) PARK CITY MUSIC -- Joss Stone, Johnny Lang, Joan Osborne, Lindsey Buckingham, Kenneth (Babyface) Edmonds and Daniel Powter perform in this hourlong special recorded during four nights at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

The Executive Pursuits column in Business Day on May 5, about selling hot dogs at Shea Stadium, misinterpreted a survey by the National Hog Dog and Sausage Council and referred incorrectly to hot dog sales at Shea. Although the stadium sells an average of just under 20,000 hot dogs a game, and ranks No. 1 among major league ballparks who responded to the questionnaire from the hot dog council, Shea does not lead all ballparks in sales. It trails Yankee Stadium, which sells about 30,000 a game but did not answer the survey. (A reader raised the issue after an article on May 11 about the introduction of Latin food at Yankee Stadium mentioned the higher figure for the Yankees. Unfortunately for the reader, who vowed not to ''consume any dogs at either stadium until it has been settled,'' this correction was delayed for research; but the Mets have a home game tomorrow night.)

Avaya was near a deal last night to sell itself to Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group for more than $8 billion in the latest buyout in the telecommunications industry, according to people briefed on the sale. The two private equity firms appear to have bested a rival bid from Nortel Networks and a deal may be announced as early as today, those people said. But they cautioned that the talks were ongoing and that Nortel could field a higher 11th-hour bid.

An article on Saturday about charges being brought in Brazil against two American pilots, whose corporate jet was involved in a mid-air collision last year over the Amazon with a Brazilian airliner that went down with 154 people aboard, misstated a Brazilian judge's position on the case. He said in a statement issued in Portuguese on Friday that the two pilots, Joseph Lepore and Jan Paul Paladino, should be charged with exposing an aircraft to danger; he did not say they were guilty of having done so.

The governor signed a law late last week that legalized ticket scalping. ''Scalping laws did not make sense,'' he said on Friday, adding, ''This will be good for the venues, good for consumers and good for the artists.''

The 400-mile Nascar Nextel Cup race scheduled for yesterday afternoon at Dover International Speedway in Delaware was postponed until noon today because of heavy rain. The race is the sixth of the year using the new Car of Tomorrow. Ryan Newman will start from the pole position, and Dale Earnhardt Jr. will start second, his best starting position in 13 races this season. Although skies over the racetrack were still leaden, rain stopped long enough for workers to attempt to dry the track so the race could start just after its scheduled time of 1:45 p.m. But it began to rain again, and the race was postponed a half-hour later.

Filing Suggests Nascent Plot A reading of the criminal complaint filed by the federal authorities against four men charged in a plot to bomb Kennedy International Airport suggests a terror plan that was less than fully mature. PAGE B1 Liver Cancer Drug Promising A new drug looks poised to become the first effective treatment for liver cancer, one of the most common and deadliest cancers in the world, doctors said. PAGE A14 At-Home Fertility Test A new at-home screening test with components for men and women lets couples find out if they have fertility problems without stepping into a doctor's office. PAGE A12 Yankees Beat Boston in 9th Alex Rodriguez hit a home run in the ninth inning to lift the Yankees to a 6-5 victory over the Red Sox in the series finale at Fenway Park. SPORTSMONDAY Support for Climate Plan Amid the doubts about President Bush's new plan for cutting greenhouse gases was a substantial dose of support, albeit conditional. PAGE A9

The Empire Zone continues its efforts to create a full historical record of the March 14 dust-up between Mr. Spitzer and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, in the midst of tense budget negotiations. As previously reported, words were exchanged and voices were raised in the governor's office, according to several people present or close by. And after Mr. Bruno made a lewd reference to the close political relationship of the governor and the Senate minority leader, Malcolm A. Smith, Mr. Spitzer stormed out of his office, saying, ''I'm not going to abide that kind of vulgarity.''

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Push for Baghdad Is Short Of Goal, Commanders Say Three months after the start of the Baghdad security plan that has added thousands of American and Iraqi troops, they control fewer than one-third of the city's neighborhoods, far short of the initial goal, according to some commanders and an internal military assessment. A1 Pakistan Exile Talks of Return Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto is stirring up Pakistani politics by talking of a power-sharing deal with the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, and, in an interview, of returning to Pakistan before the end of the year. A1 Lebanon Fears Spread of Battle The shelling and sniper fire in a refugee camp in northern Lebanon intensified and fighting broke out between militants and the army in another camp in the south, increasing fears that the two-week battle between the Lebanese Army and Islamist militants could spread. A3 Senegal Party Boycotts Vote Voters in Senegal largely stayed home from an election to choose a new national assembly amid widespread apathy. The main opposition parties had also called for a boycott of the election. A7 Somali Premier Unhurt by Bomb A suicide bomber narrowly missed killing Somalia's transitional prime minister, Ali Mohamed Gedi, after he rammed a pickup truck packed with explosives into the gates of his home. The explosion killed six bodyguards, along with a student at a Koranic school across the street. A7 NATIONAL A12-16 Ethiopia's New Popularity For American Adoptions Ethiopia now ranks fifth among countries for adoption by Americans, up from 16th in 2000. The growing interest in Ethiopia comes at a time when the leading countries for international adoption -- China, Guatemala, and Russia -- are closing the borders to American agencies. A1 Mitt Romney's Former Career Mitt Romney's past success at Bain Capital, one of the nation's five largest private equity firms, helped to finance his Massachusetts campaigns and has become a cornerstone of his bid for the Republican presidential nomination. A1 Senator John McCain, facing increasing anger from fellow Republicans over his support of the immigration bill in Congress, is ramping up his counterattack against his main rival in the presidential campaign, Mitt Romney, by accusing him of ''pandering for votes'' in opposing the measure. A14 Kevorkian, Unbowed Jack Kevorkian, the former pathologist once known as Doctor Death, says he will never again counsel a terminally ill person on how to die. But eight years behind bars and a strict list of promises to gain parole have done nothing to mellow the advocate for assisted suicide. A12 SCIENCE/HEALTH New Liver Cancer Drug A drug that extends the lives of patients by almost three months looks poised to become the first effective treatment for liver cancer, one of the most common and deadly. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 As Face of Gun Control, Bloomberg Attracts Ire In towns across the country, Michael R. Bloomberg has emerged as the face of gun control, due to his guidance of a coalition called Mayors Against Illegal Guns. In doing so, he has fueled the ire of gun rights groups, many of which contend that the coalition is trying to undermine a constitutionally protected right to bear arms. A1 Filing Suggests Amateur Plot A reading of the formal criminal complaint filed by authorities against a New York man and three others charged in a plot to bomb Kennedy International Airport suggests a less than fully mature terror plan -- a proposed effort longer on evil intent than on operational capability. B1 Increase in Births to Mexicans A new analysis by demographers shows a 28 percent increase in births to Mexican-born women in New York City between 2000 and 2005. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 iPhone Fever Apple executives worry that expectations for the one-button iPhones, to be available this month, may be too high. Apple and AT&T stores have received more than a million inquiries about the product. C1 Magazines Now Design Ads Some magazine companies are handling creative work for their advertisers. The trend poses a challenge to traditional agencies and has created unusual partnerships.
