KLEIN--Nancy. Dear sweet Nancy, in our thoughts and hearts forever. With love, Harold

An article on Tuesday about a drop in crime in East Orange, N.J., which city officials attribute to the Police Department's use of new surveillance technology, misstated the number of precincts in the Queens South division of the New York Police Department, a division that the East Orange police director, Jose M. Cordero, formerly ran. There are 8, not 18.

Two prominent prostate cancer experts have received threats because of their opposition to approval of a new drug, officials attending the conference of the the American Society of Clinical Oncology said Sunday. The experts, Dr. Howard I. Scher of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and Dr. Maha Hussain of the University of Michigan, received e-mail and other threats, spokeswomen for Sloan-Kettering and for the cancer conference said.

To the Editor: John L. Allen Jr. gets it wrong when he predicts that the ''Catholic left'' will decry the pope's forthcoming decision to liberalize the use of the Latin Mass as a step back into traditionalism (''The Pope's Language Lesson,'' Op-Ed, May 30).

The best-selling titles for the Reader, Sony's portable tablet for digital books, have been mysteries, science fiction and thrillers. ''Next,'' Michael Chrichton's mindbending genetic romp, has been the top seller since the Reader's introduction last year. With an 80-book capacity, the Reader is a natural for stocking up on a series. Sony Connect, the online bookstore for the Reader, offers 13,500 titles, including collections from such prolific writers as James Patterson, Tony Hillerman and Stephen King. SHELLY FREIERMAN

The Upper East Side was once the reliable foothold of the liberal Republican politician. It was the home of John V. Lindsay and, most recently, State Senator Roy M. Goodman. But in the last decade, the neighborhood has become increasingly Democratic, and Republican officeholders have become fixtures of the past. But the Republicans are seeking to change that in a special election tomorrow to fill the Assembly seat vacated by Alexander B. Grannis, commonly known as Pete, a longtime Democratic incumbent who recently became commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

Warren M. Anderson, who served as Senate majority leader from 1973 to 1988, died last week at age 91. Former Gov. George E. Pataki called him ''a tremendous gentleman.'' Back when Mr. Pataki was a young Senate staffer -- ''it was the 1890s,'' he said -- Mr. Anderson was not above talking to the hired help. And like many others, Mr. Pataki recalled the garish jackets Mr. Anderson wore at the end of each legislative session.

Marilyn Manson ''Eat Me, Drink Me'' (Interscope) Once Marilyn Manson was the Antichrist superstar, the scourge of the moralistic, a proud magnet for controversy. Now, years later, he's a lovesick ghoul. ''I kill myself in small amounts/in each relationship it's not/about love/Just another funeral,'' he sings in ''They Said That Hell's Not Hot.'' It's one of the many songs on ''Eat Me, Drink Me'' that start out as rock dirges and build melodramatically from there. The songs were written, produced and performed with Tim Skold, the only other musician on the album. Despite some spooky background noises, the music leans toward a glam-gone-grim style, reverting to a sound that predates Marilyn Manson's past industrial-rock stomps.

KLEINMAN--Ruth.Loving wife, mother and grandmother passed away May 30th in Las Vegas, NV. She is survived by her loving husband Alvin, her daughters, Judi, Barbara, and Shari; and her grandchildren Scott, David, Joshua, Abbi, and Ariel.

Rihanna Good Girl Gone Bad (Def Jam) Rihanna's new CD is ''Good Girl Gone Bad,'' although that title seems to overstate her evolution: She has always presented herself as a playful flirt. But that's no reason not to take her seriously. This is her third album in three years, and though it doesn't arrive in shops until tomorrow, its success seems a foregone conclusion. Last week the album's first single, a space-age hip-pop song called ''Umbrella,'' zoomed to the top of Billboard's Hot 100 chart; it's the first serious contender for Song of the Summer.

''Washington has abandoned the gun issue, which makes it extremely difficult for localities to fight gun violence, because it's an interstate problem.'' RICHARD ABORN, the president of New York's Citizens Crime Commission. [B5]
Senator John McCain is ramping up his counterattack against Mitt Romney by accusing him of ''pandering for votes'' in opposing the immigration bill. PAGE A14

The Real Estate Board of New York will start running television commercials today in support of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's long-range environmental plan, which includes a proposal to charge fees to drive below 86th Street during peak hours. ''This is obviously something the industry is concerned about, how the city works in 2010 and 2020 and 2030,'' said Frank Marino, a spokesman for the board.
To the Editor: Re ''The Educated Giant,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, May 28):

Because of an editing error, two picture captions on Tuesday with an article in Science Times about private rooms in neonatal intensive care units misspelled the surname of a woman whose son was born prematurely in St. Paul. She is Robyn Frandrup, not Frandrep. Also, the article misstated the month that Amillia Taylor, who was born at just over 21 weeks' gestation, was released from a Miami hospital. It was February, not April.

The National Basketball Association has been in search of a transcendent star with staying power since Michael Jordan retired in 1998; television viewership of the finals is down 55 percent since that year. The league may have found its savior in LeBron James, who can sometimes score like Jordan or Kobe Bryant but who can also pass like Magic Johnson.
While Fred Thompson, the former senator from Tennessee, wasn't among the Republican candidates on stage at the G.O.P. debate, he appeared just afterward on Fox News Channel's "Hannity & Colmes."

Until recently, my craziest taxi ride occurred a few years ago in Newark, N.J. That escapade involved a shared taxi, a rear window being kicked out, me diving into the passenger footwell, and the cabbie attempting to run over the guy who'd just skipped paying fare. It turns out that I had to go to Hockenheim, Germany, to top this wild tale.

I've been reorganizing the garage all morning. Rearranging journals and notebooks written years ago, weeding through boxes marked "miscellaneous" for any seemingly useful item, throwing out a broken warming plate that never worked to begin with, trash-bagging old clothes for the goodwill bin at the local grocery store - basically sloughing away the material things that seem to accumulate so easily in my life, packrat that I am. But for some reason when I get to my Army duffel bags I don't leave them closed. I undo their snap-links, grab each green bag with my name and unit numbers still stenciled on them, and flip them upside down to dump everything out onto the concrete floor.

For the first time in history, MLB's first-year player draft will be televised. Or at least the first round. The fun begins at 2 p.m. Thursday on ESPN2, but unless you're a Mets fan who has special interest in local players like the New Jersey high school pitcher Rick Porcello or Rutgers shortstop Todd Frazier, you could probably find better things to do with your time.

Hard-luck pitchers often say they are a victim of poor run support. Over his last two starts, Tom Glavine has gotten literally nothing. The Mets did not score against either John Smoltz or Barry Zito while losing, 2-1 and 3-0. Perhaps with Carlos Beltran, who missed the last three games with a bruised right knee, back in the lineup tonight against Philadelphia, Glavine's luck may change.
GOFFSTOWN, N.H.
On Wednesday morning, some Staten Island ferry riders are in for a brush with grayness.

I've known Derek Jeter for six years, and we have a cordial relationship, like he seems to have with every writer. But he's never used my name. Today he sees me and pipes up, loud enough for the other writers to hear, "Hey Tyler, where'd you go to college?"

Is Iowa a more sexist place than the rest of America? Linda Lantor Fandel, the deputy editorial page editor of The Des Moines Register, fears that it is, and that Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign is suffering because of it.
Norris Hall, where a student killed 30 students in nine minutes on April 16, is reopening, but not for classes, Virginia Tech announced today.

When army ants are sweeping across the forest on one of their massive predatory raids, potholes tend to slow them down. And just the other day, British researchers revealed how these hard-charging creatures deal with the impediment: Individual ants fling themselves down and bridge the potholes with their bodies. In fact, the volunteers seem to size-match themselves to the holes they choose to plug. And when the army has tramped across their backs, they get up, dust themselves off, and head home to join the communal feast.

For years European industry has fought off the idea that companies should buy permits to pollute under the EU's program for complying with the Kyoto Protocol. Industry seemed to have a strong argument: The European economy was lagging the United States while China and India were shooting ahead. More regulation, said worried industrialists, was the last thing the region's power, pulp, cement and steel factories needed if they were to keep factories open and workers employed.

GOFFSTOWN, N.H., _ As the 10 candidates for the Republican nomination for president prepare for tonight's debate, the matter of I. Lewis Libby, Vice President Cheney's former chief of staff, has suddenly moved to the front burner. A federal judge sentenced Mr. Libby this morning to 30 months in prison after he was convicted of obstructing justice in the case involving Valeria Plame Wilson.
Next week, the Frugal Traveler is driving to Indiana. He needs your help. Do you know a cheap motel, a great place to eat or a must-see attraction? Share your tips with Matt here.

Nearly 150 Starrett City residents rallied outside the office of the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, this afternoon, clamoring for him to appear. The residents want the Senate to pass a bill that would ensure their rents would not soar if a potential sale of Starrett, the massive Brooklyn apartment complex, goes through.
Just five months into her first term, Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, has been given a leadership position within the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

While the religious views of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and former Senator John Edwards received wide coverage at Monday's forum organized by the evangelical group, Sojourners, four other Democratic presidential hopefuls also had a chance to weigh in during the second hour. Senators Joe Biden and Chris Dodd, New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson and Representative Dennis Kucinich - all Catholics - candidly spoke with CNN's Paula Zahn about faith and politics.

In the latest move by American investment banks into the Middle East, Bear Stearns will join with a group of Saudi executives to form a joint venture to provide financial products compliant with Islamic law, MarketWatch reported Tuesday.
Senators took to the floor today to pay tribute to Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, who died last night after a short battle with acute myeloid leukemia.
An advertisement for GlaxoSmithKline's Avandia Type 2 diabetes medication.
GlaxoSmithKline Avandia advertisement with Della Reese (June 2004 - Dec. 2004).
GlaxoSmithKline Avandia advertisement with Jane Seymour(Fall 2001).

Of all the arguments brought to bear in support of legalizing same-sex marriage, this one appears to be rather original: New York City, according to a new analysis by the city comptroller, could reap $142 million in economic benefits over three years, primarily from a surge in spending by residents and visitors on weddings and by their out-of-town guests.

Anyone who lives in Bangkok is constantly asked for restaurant recommendations by friends flying in for a few good meals. Often my answer is, "How about Italian food?" There are superb Italian restaurants in Bangkok. Within a 15-minute walk of my apartment in the Langsuan area I can count more than a half-dozen. Thais have long had an affinity for Italian food and at some point over the past decade the number of high-end Italian restaurants reached a critical mass. It became profitable to fly in a whole range of meats and ingredients as varied as fresh mozzarella di bufala and Sorrento lemons (one chef insists that only lemons from southern Italy will do the trick for his Tagliatelle al Limone). This week a group of Italian chefs has banded together to put on what they are calling, "The Splendor of Italian Cuisine." I certainly agree with the concept. The festival, which is being held at 11 top Italian restaurants in the capital through June 10, has the faint whiff of a marketing gimmick. But I'm a sucker for gimmicks that involve risotto and prosciutto crudo. Biscotti, the Italian restaurant at the Four Seasons (Tel: +66 2 255 5443), offers a 6-course menu for 1,500 baht ($44). Other restaurants involved in the festival include La Scala at the Sukhothai hotel (Tel: +66 2 344 8888) Spasso at the Grande Hyatt Erawan (Tel: +66 2 254 12340) and Gianni's on Soi Tonson, near Central Chidlom department store (Tel: +66 2 252 1619).
Alex Trebek offers no lifelines to contestants with the audacity to hit their buzzer. Just silence, and then a little needling. And if your brain doesn't bail you out, that's it. You failed.

Concerned that one company might corner the market on organic broccoli and all kinds of other natural fare, federal regulators are suing to block Whole Foods Market's $565 million acquisition of a rival grocery chain, Wild Oats Markets, the two companies said Tuesday. The companies added that they will file a challenge in court.

This week's deal in which Flextronics International will acquire Solectron for $3.6 billion has analysts wondering whether more consolidation is coming in the electronics manufacturing services sector -- the business of making electronics on contract for other companies. There are plenty of potential targets out there, but some analysts warn against overexuberance, largely because buyers seem scarce. Investors seem to be unsure. After gaining on Monday, when the Solectron deal was announced, shares of many of the industry's players fell on Tuesday.
Well, maybe not that much. But not all is well in the land of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

I spent much of last week covering the story of the American lawyer with tuberculosis who flew around Europe potentially exposing others, afraid (he said) of being put in quarantine here in Rome. I was thinking that one of the problems was this: When you're in a strange city, where you may not know the language, it is often hard to get medical advice or care you can trust. To that end, I've asked all our Globespotters reporters to recommend a good English speaking medical practice where they live. We'll put it up in the "travel basics" box for each city. But if you have recommendations, please write in...

Avaya has agreed to be acquired by two private equity firms for $8.2 billion, but it's not a done deal yet. As with many recent buyout agreements, terms call for a go-shop period during which the target company can solicit better offers. Although go-shops haven't tended to smoke out rival bidders (Triad Hospitals is an exception), an analyst at Prudential says he thinks "other parties remain interested." Among those that might peer through the go-shop window, according to Prudential's Inder Singh, is Alcatel-Lucent. Avaya, which sells telecommunications gear, was spun off from Lucent in 2000, so a deal between the two would be reunion of sorts.

When asparagus are in season and on the menu, I always order them. To me they are a total indulgence and it must have something to do with their scarcity in my childhood: they were not available year round.
The 30-month sentence handed down today for I. Lewis "Scooter" Libby could become a rallying cry for Fred D. Thompson, the all-but declared Republican presidential candidate.

Tropical Cyclone Gonu, the strongest storm to hit the strategic sultanate of Oman since the 1970's, has prompted the shutdown of important energy distribution centers, a rush inland, the proclamation of a national holiday until Sunday, concern for turtles and a surfer alert about 40-foot waves.

When he joined the Texas law firm Bracewell & Patterson in 2005 (and put his name on the door), Rudolph Giuliani said the move had nothing to do with a presidential run. Since then, the former mayor of New York has declared his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, collected more campaign contributions in Texas than any other Republican candidate and named the firm's managing partner, Patrick Oxford, as his campaign chairman.
Alison Smale, managing editor of The International Herald Tribune, discusses the Group of 8 summit in Germany.
For each sub-Saharan African who was placed on anti-AIDS drugs last year, five more were infected.
Is Dow Jones becoming a case of deja vu all over again?
By Anant K. Sundaram

I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney known since childhood as Scooter, was sentenced this morning to 30 months in prison for lying to investigators checking into the unmasking of a C.I.A. operative whose husband helped fuel a fierce public debate over the administration's case for going to war in Iraq.
Is Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton preparing to endorse gay marriage?

With the Republican debate tonight in New Hampshire, the differences among the candidates on the compromise immigration legislation now under consideration in the Senate are likely to be enunciated. While some of the Democratic candidates talked about the bill at their debate on Sunday night, the disagreements among them were minor in comparison to the spectrum of views among the G.O.P. field.
So last week, Apple began its experiment of selling non-protected, higher-quality songs on the iTunes Store for a 30-cent premium.

The Harvard Crimson has a fun profile of me, based on digging up old college roommates and bosses. I love Jeff Toobin's reference to me as "the Indiana Jones of our generation of journalists." That's better than many of the things I get called....
Do you know if there are any diving centers and diving places in Punta del Este? I hope you can give me a good answer soon. Please give me a link to a diving center site if you know one.
A prominent family late Monday cut its longstanding ties with the newspaper business. No, not the Bancrofts -- the Chandlers.

The good news about the Spanish property market slowdown is that there are good deals to be had for those still interested in buying a home there. One city that continues to lure buyers is Alicante, one of the most well-known towns on the Costa Blanca. In Alicante -- popular for its university, beautiful beaches, and quality properties -- the average home price is now $341,000.

One quick way to demonstrate Takeru Kobayashi's stature in the world of competitive eating is to refer to a fan-turned-peer named Crazy Legs Conti. "To compare Kobayashi to Michael Jordan or Tiger Woods is to slight Kobayashi," he claimed.

Robert T. Miller, an assistant professor at the Villanova University School of Law, says that part of Sam Brownback's New York Times op-ed on evolution is "obviously wrong." But Miller does not object to Brownback's evaluation of the science. Instead, he opposes the Kansas senator's "general observations on the relationship between faith and reason," which Miller believes are "worrying." Miller writes at On the Square, the First Things blog:

Oscar de la Renta looked mildly stunned last night when Steven Kolb, the executive director of the CFDA, hurried toward the podium to inform the mistress of ceremonies Ellen Barkin that there were TWO winners of the Women's Designer of the Year award. Everyone seemed surprised, not least Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough of Proenza Schouler, the other winner, who got up from their table (with Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen) and joined de la Renta. He made a special point of acknowledging his wife, Annette de la Renta, who was sitting next to Patrick McCarthy of WWD, and noting, not insignificantly, that he had been making clothes for more than 40 years.

Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group agreed Monday night to acquire Avaya, the computer-networking company, for $8.2 billion. The deal, priced at $17.50 a share, puts the two private equity firms in control of the world's biggest maker of corporate phone equipment, letting them go head to head with Cisco Systems in the $5 billion market for Web-based gear. Monday's agreement calls for Avaya to seek out other potential buyers over the next 50 days.

Major labels have fought several legal battles to try to keep fans from listening to music without paying for it. Now one label, the Warner Music Group, has made a deal with an Internet start-up, Lala.com, that will allow anyone to listen to its music free, with the idea that doing so will drive music sales.

Blip.tv, a two-year-old video-sharing Web site, said Tuesday it raised its first round of venture capital funding. The round was led by Ambient Sound Investments, a fund created by founding engineers from Internet-telephone company Skype, Blip.tv said. The amount of the funding wasn't disclosed. Jeffrey Sechrest, co-head of media and entertainment at investment bank Lazard, also participated in the round, Blip.tv said.

As private equity firms continue to gobble up assets at unprecedented rate for unprecedented sums, their deal-frenzy is causing a chain reaction among firms who are eager to escape the clutches of these cash-rich hunters.

The private equity investment in Palm, announced Monday, is just the latest indication of the intense new competition that will increasingly blur the lines between telecommunications, computing and entertainment during the next several years. The stakes are so high that none of the major players in any of those three industries can afford to be left out.

A New York Times report that Cadence Design Systems, a software maker, was in talks with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Blackstone Group about a possible buyout had analysts divided on whether such a deal would materialize.

General Electric's real estate unit agreed to buy office and industrial buildings in Canada from Dundee Real Estate Investment Trust for about 2.4 billion Canadian dollars ($2.3 billion) and will purchase an 18 percent stake in the company. The purchase, which gives G.E. a toehold in faster-growing markets to tap global demand, includes 180 properties located primarily in Ontario, Quebec and Newfoundland.
The six-day Arab-Israeli conflict in 1967 ended in a military victory for Israel, a sober defeat for the Arab armies, and began Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

The start-up behind the mobile matchmaking service "Crush or Flush" is feeling the love from venture investors, who agreed to put $7.2 million into the company. IceBreaker, which markets a cellphone-based dating service, said Tuesday that Frazier Technology Ventures and Lightspeed Venture Partners led its latest financing round. "Crush or Flush," which works a bit like the once-popular "Hot or Not" Web site, is not yet generating revenue, according to the Seattle Post-Intelligencer's Venture Blog. An IceBreaker marketing executive told the blog that his business was considering adding advertising or selling subscriptions.

Shares in Germany's Commerzbank, which has been persistently cited as a possible takeover target, jumped more than 3 percent on Tuesday to near a seven-year peak on market talk that Citigroup was likely to bid about 45 euros ($61) per share for the bank, traders said.

The Children's Investment Fund, the activist hedge fund whose demands put Dutch bank ABN Amro in play, is scouring Japan for deals but sees its struggle to raise the dividend at Japanese electric power wholesaler J-Power as a test case for further investment in the country.

Pershing Square Capital Management, a New York hedge fund with a gift for shaking up corporate boardrooms, has raised $2 billion that will be dedicated to an activist assault on just one specific, iconic American company, The New York Post reported.

Chinese stocks may be slumping now, but Citic Securities, China's most profitable securities house, believes there will still be an appetite for its shares. The company indicated Tuesday that it plans to sell up to 350 million new A shares on the Shanghai market, which could raise some $2.4 billion to back its expansion plan to become a first-class investment bank.

Jesper Koll, one of the best known foreign commentators on Japan's economy, resigned from Merrill Lynch in Tokyo to form an investment company. The move is the latest in a string of departures of investment banking executives looking to start their own firms.
Venture investment in the health business typically chases miracle cures and high-technology gadgets, like bioengineered drugs and new medical devices. They promise much but cost a lot.

Big-ticket acquisitions by Cisco Systems, Oracle and a variety of buyout firms helped drive software mergers and acquisitions to record levels so far this year. An analyst firm, The 451 Group, takes a look at the nearly $28 billion in software deal activity in the first five months of 2007.

Three ex-brokers at Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers face a November retrial on charges they conspired to commit fraud by letting day traders eavesdrop on the firm's internal "squawk boxes."

the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, the British bank leading a takeover bid for ABN Amro, said first-half earnings will rise more than 8.1 percent, beating analysts' estimates, as bad consumer loans declined in Britain.

At least one significant investor in Biomet, an artificial joint maker, plans to vote against a proposed $10.9 billion deal for the company, in the latest instance of shareholder dissatisfaction over buyouts.
The ICICI Bank may raise $2.5 billion in the biggest overseas share sale by an Indian company, Bloomberg News reported.

The high-profile Internet start-up Joost announced Tuesday that it had hired Michelangelo Volpi, a veteran executive of Cisco Systems, as its new chief executive. Joost, which is based in London, is building a global television network of full-length TV shows and movies and sending it to viewers over the Internet.
FBOP, a privately held Chicago bank holding company, is trying to muscle in on Bear Stearns's deal for a controlling stake in cash-strapped Doral Financial of Puerto Rico.

Fast-growing Uranium One extended its aggressive acquisition spree offering 1.8 billion Canadian dollars ($1.7 billion) in stock for Vancouver's Energy Metals. The takeover would give Toronto-based Uranium One a slate of American assets including near-term production from projects in Texas, Wyoming, New Mexico and Utah.

American Express is expected to sell its private banking business within a matter of weeks, according to Reuters, in a sale that could fetch between $1 billion to $2 billion for the credit card and travel services company.

The IntercontinentalExchange, the Atlanta commmodities exchange that is currently pressing an unsolicited $11 billion buyout bid for Chicago Board of Trade parent CBOT Holdings, disclosed Monday that it had agreed to acquire the commodity trading business of ChemConnect of Houston.

In their first face-to-face meeting, the family that controls Dow Jones & Company told Rupert Murdoch on Monday that it would sell him the company only if its jewel, The Wall Street Journal, could be shielded from editorial interference from him, according to a report in The New York Times.

In Canada, at least, the criminal fraud case of Conrad M. Black was billed as "the trial of the century" as it began more than two months ago. Accusations that Mr. Black and three colleagues had looted more than $60 million from the international newspaper conglomerate that he built promised to put not just Mr. Black's oversize ego and life on display, but also a frothy brew of high finance, high society and high intrigue.

The former chief operating officer of Enron's broadband Internet division, Kevin P. Hannon, was sentenced to two years in federal prison and fined $125,000 for his role in the fraud that led to the company's collapse, a court official said on Monday. Mr. Hannon was sentenced by Judge Vanessa Gilmore of United States District Court in Houston.

There is a special election today on the East Side of Manhattan in the 65th Assembly District. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. For details, voters can call the New York City Board of Elections toll free at 1 (866) VOTENYC (868-3692).
Rain washes out the first preview of “Romeo and Juliet” in Central Park, and the Atlantic Theater company announces its fall season.

Additional images of the Steven Holl expansion of the
Nelson-Atkins Museum in Kansas City, Mo.
A look at Web sites mentioned in David Pogue column on June 5, 2007.
A federal appeals panel struck down the government policy that allows stations and networks to be fined if they broadcast shows containing obscene language.

Years ago, two old stock-car racers were in Nascar's Daytona Beach, Fla., headquarters, reminiscing about how fast they used to drive from various racetracks to Daytona. It was "the record," as they called it. Who had it?

Not much to say about this one here in rainy Chicago tonight. The Yankees scored three in the ninth but it wasn't enough in a 6-4 loss. Matt DeSalvo pitched an inning and a third, gave up three runs, and that was about it. Jim Thome and Paul Konerko homered to put the game out of reach.
The Bang on a Can composers still haven’t entirely entered the concert-music mainstream. Still, this year’s marathon indicated that they may have achieved something even more meaningful.
The disclosures in Carl Bernstein’s biography of Hillary Rodham Clinton amount mainly to embroiderings on already well-known aspects of the Clintons’ lives.
Stock photography Web sites have helped amateur shooters turn a hobby into an earnings stream.
Photos printed on inkjet paper will be around for decades. Right?
Like-minded photographers find each other online, then meet off.
Software and hardware are available that try to sweeten digital sound by putting back what compression has taken out.
Many consumers find they need to own multiple models of the same device for different uses. So much for one size fits all.
Tracking down sharing services that are free, quick and technologically foolproof — no matter how old you are.
There is an elegant way to free snapshots from computer hard drives: the digital picture frame.
Better headphones equal better sound for portable music players.
Take the stereo outside with a bit of planning and the right equipment.
Depending on what you want to do with digital pictures, the format in which you save them can make a big difference.
Phone cameras have become more sophisticated, but most  still need to focus more on image quality and ease of use.
Who needs postcards? With a mobile blog, cellphone auteurs can take everyone along.
The war in Iraq and immigration were the dominant subjects during tonight’s presidential debate.
Senator Craig Thomas of Wyoming combined a deep love of Western rural life with a 23-year public career in Cheyenne and Washington.
Up to 18 people were killed south of Falluja  when a suicide bomber driving a truck packed with high explosives plowed into a busy commercial district.
Bill Nelson and three other executives with long careers at HBO will replace Chris Albrecht, who resigned.
All of the 20 to 30 Taliban fighters on board were drowned, according to a spokesman.
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas warned that the Palestinians were “on the verge of civil war.”
Abdel Nur, charged with three others in an alleged plot to blow up jet fuel tanks, was taken into custody in Trinidad.
I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to the vice president, was sentenced for lying during a C.I.A. leak investigation.
ETA, the armed Basque separatist group, today vowed to resume its violent struggle for an independent nation.
President Bush chided President Vladimir V. Putin but assured him Russia has nothing to fear from a missile defense system.
Share prices plunged another 7 percent this morning, only to turn around in the afternoon to finish with gains.
Roger Clemens was not ready to start Monday, and rookie pitcher Matt DeSalvo gave an uninspiring performance in his place.
Under Wyoming’s election laws, the state Republican Party will nominate three people to be his successor.
Andy McDonald bailed out Chris Pronger and moved the Anaheim Ducks one victory from their first Stanley Cup championship.
Two equity firms, Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group, agreed Monday night to acquire Avaya, the computer-networking company, for $8.2 billion.
The online software pioneer Salesforce.com will help the Internet search leader Google sell ads as part of a partnership.
Each year, challenges to property assessments by homeowners seeking tax relief glut the local court in Nassau County.

A front-page article and picture caption on Friday about President Bush’s new proposal for setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions misstated the location of his speech announcing the plan. Mr. Bush spoke in an auditorium in the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington, which also houses the offices of the United States Agency for International Development. He did not speak at the agency.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about the tribute “Celebrating Bobby Short,” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency through June 16, misidentified a performer who will take part on June 12. It will be Wynton Marsalis — not Liza Minnelli, who had been scheduled to perform earlier but will not be taking part.

An article on May 22 about a delay in adding specially equipped computerized train cars to the crowded L subway line misstated the overall growth in subway ridership from 1995 to 2006. It rose 37 percent, not 46 percent. The article also referred incorrectly to the ridership at the Bedford Avenue station in Brooklyn during the same period. Although ridership at Bedford increased significantly, it did not rise 139 percent. (It is not possible to compare total ridership at individual stations from 1995 to 2006 because in 1998 New York City Transit changed the way it counts students who ride the subway at no cost. Excluding students, ridership at Bedford Avenue increased 131 percent from 1995 to 2006.).

A headline on Friday about a growing movement in Britain to boycott Israel economically and culturally referred incorrectly in some copies to a decision reached by the union of public service employees, the largest British labor union. The union said a resolution that would call for a boycott of Israel would be considered at its upcoming annual meeting. The union did not call for such a boycott.

A front-page article and picture caption on Friday about President Bush’s new proposal for setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions misstated the location of his speech announcing the plan. Mr. Bush spoke in an auditorium in the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington, which also houses the offices of the United States Agency for International Development. He did not speak at the agency.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about differing accounts of the travels of an Atlanta lawyer with a dangerous form of tuberculosis misattributed comments about the Italian Health Ministry’s contacts with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. It was Cesare Fassari, a spokesman for the ministry, who told a reporter that Dr. Maria Grazia Pompa, the head of its tuberculosis surveillance program, “contacted the C.D.C. and said, ‘Weren’t you supposed to contact us?’ ” Mr. Fassari also said, “At that time, the disease centers confirmed that there was a case but did not provide details.” The comments were not made to the reporter by Dr. Pompa.

An article in Business Day yesterday about Harvard’s plans to license more than 50 patents to Nano-Terra, a nanotechnology start-up, misstated the surname of the vice chairman of the company. He is Carmichael Roberts, not Rogers.

An article on Friday about the travels of a patient with a dangerous form of tuberculosis misidentified the flight that the patient, Andrew Speaker, took from Atlanta to Paris on May 12. It was Air France Flight 385, not 285. (As the article noted, the flight was also designated Delta 8517.) Because of an editing error, the article misidentified the point where Mr. Speaker crossed the border from Canada when he re-entered the country on May 24. It was Champlain, N.Y., not Plattsburgh, which is just south of Champlain.

A picture caption in the Square Feet section of Business Day on Wednesday with an article on renovations at the Woolworth Building in Lower Manhattan misidentified one of the two people shown. The man at the left is Roy A. Suskin, vice president of development at the Witkoff Group, which is renovating the building — not Richard Woodward, an associate at the architecture firm Gerner Kronick & Valcarcel.
An obituary on Saturday about Wallace Seawell, a Hollywood photographer, misspelled the given name of one of the celebrities he photographed. She was Ava Gardner, not Eva.

Because of an editing error, the Religion Journal column on Saturday, about Web sites that attract Mormons who have left the faith or are questioning it, misattributed an observation about the role of the family in Mormon life. It was Philip L. Barlow, who will lead a Mormon studies program at Utah State University — not Jeff Ricks, executive manager of the Post-Mormon Community — who made the points that the family role “is in-built into the theology” and that because the family is conceived of as eternal, a wayward Mormon is “threatening to that family unit for all eternity.”.
The Yankees are optimistic that Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens will start the first two games of this weekend’s home series against the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Officials and advocates hope the cards will give immigrants better access to services and help the police when immigrants become targets of crime.

There is a primary election today in New Jersey for the State Senate and the General Assembly. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. Voter assistance is available toll free at 1-877-NJVOTER (1-877-658-6837). There is a special election on the East Side of Manhattan in the 65th Assembly District. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Voters can call the New York City Board of Elections toll free at 1-866-VOTENYC (1-866-868-3692).

Four white lion cubs, three females and a male, whose birth last month at the zoo in Jurques, in western France, added to the roughly 30 white lions in captivity worldwide, have died, zoo officials said. The cubs were vulnerable to infection because they had been bottle fed after being rejected by their mother.

A 61-year old man who boarded a night tram and died in his seat rode through Zagreb for six hours before the driver discovered he was dead at the end of his shift, the newspaper Jutarnji List said. The police believe he died of natural causes.

Rescue efforts continued in southwestern Yunnan Province as roughly 180,000 people were evacuated from their homes after a Sunday morning earthquake that registered a magnitude 6.4 killed at least three people and injured more than 300, according to state news media. More than 1,000 aftershocks have rattled the nerves of residents in the city of Pu’er, in a mountainous region of Yunnan. Roughly 2,000 soldiers and rescue workers are at the scene, and evacuees are living in tents or public buildings.

The authorities were investigating why a tsunami warning siren went off accidentally in Banda Aceh, the capital of Aceh Province, and rang out for around 30 minutes. Much of Aceh was destroyed in the 2004 tsunami disaster and 170,000 people died. The siren caused several thousand people to flee their homes and run to higher ground. Many roads in the capital were clogged with people driving inland on motorbikes and cars, the police and witnesses said. “We would like to apologize for causing the panic,” said Suhardjono, a scientist from the Geophysical and Meteorological Agency, which maintains the warning system. He said the siren “went off by itself” and suggested a short circuit.

A Komodo dragon killed an 8-year-old boy in the first known fatal attack on a human in 33 years, a spokesman for Komodo National Park said. The boy was mauled Saturday on Komodo Island, part of the national park system set up to protect the endangered lizard. “The Komodo bit him on his waist and tossed him viciously from side to side,” said the spokesman, Heru Rudiharto. “A fisherman, who just happened to be the boy’s uncle, threw rocks at the lizard until it let the boy go and fled.” The boy died shortly after. Komodos, the world’s largest living lizards, are found in the wild in the park, which also includes the islands of Rinca and Padar. Fewer than 4,000 survive.
The success of  several inauspicious players have underlined how savvy Mets General Manager Omar Minaya and his staff have been the past three seasons.
Togo’s sports minister, Richard Attipoé, was among a delegation of 18 supporters of the country’s national soccer team killed aboard a private helicopter that crashed in Sierra Leone.

Support for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dropped to its lowest since he took office in September, hovering at 30 percent in a poll by the national daily Asahi Shimbun. Other polls indicated a similar slide in Mr. Abe’s approval ratings, which have suffered from the recent suicide of his scandal-tainted agricultural minister and from the government’s mishandling of pension records. The fall increased the possibility that his governing Liberal Democratic Party might lose seats in July’s upper house election; an outright defeat could spur calls for him to step down as party leader and prime minister.
To some veteran political hands in Hudson County, Tuesday’s Democratic primary evokes the alternate universe of the Superman comic planet Bizarro World.
baseball.
The rulings, the latest legal setbacks for the government’s effort to bring war crimes charges against detainees, could stall the military’s prosecutions at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

A federal appeals court opened the way for the state to resume executing inmates, ruling that the state’s lethal injection procedure is not cruel and unusual punishment. The case, filed on behalf of a condemned killer, Michael Taylor, had effectively halted executions in the state since early last year. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit found “no evidence to indicate that any of the last six inmates executed suffered any unnecessary pain,” according to its ruling.

The federal government announced the award of a $500 million contract to a European pharmaceutical company to deliver 20 million doses of an advanced smallpox vaccine. The government already has a stockpile of vaccine that could be used to immunize every American in the event of a smallpox attack by terrorists. But because the existing vaccine sometimes causes serious side effects, the Department of Health and Human Services is asking the company, Bavarian Nordic A/S, of Denmark, to make enough of its vaccine to immunize about 10 million Americans like patients on chemotherapy or people with H.I.V./AIDS. The company said the contract could be worth $1.6 billion.

A medical transport plane carrying six people went down in Lake Michigan shortly after the pilot signaled an emergency, the authorities said. There was no initial word on survivors. The plane, a Cessna Citation, dropped off radar screens just after the pilot requested to return to the airport in Milwaukee, said Tony Molinaro, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman. The plane was headed for Willow Run Airport near Detroit, Mr. Molinaro said.

Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, is in serious condition at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., as he battles leukemia and an infection, according to a statement from his office. Mr. Thomas learned that he had leukemia in 2006, before he was elected to his third Senate term.

A six-foot-tall kangaroo that surprised residents as it bounded through rural central Indiana died after the authorities used a tranquilizer dart to capture it. The animal, named Skippy, had escaped from a private home where it was a pet. The cause of death was not known, said Kenny McConahay, an officer with the Greenfield/Hancock County Animal Control Department.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,474 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
As Congress resumes work on the immigration bill, a point system to evaluate would-be immigrants based on job and language skills will be at the heart of the debate.
The three leading Democratic presidential hopefuls opened up at a televised forum about their faiths, the role of prayer in their lives and the ways religion informs their views on policy.
The abuses that lawmakers were charged with happened too long ago even to be considered, ruled a state ethics committee.
The indictment said that William J. Jefferson sought hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes.

Republicans and Democrats alike expect  Stuart Rabner to be a moderate voice, given his strong belief in social justice and his record as an aggressive prosecutor.
Mr. Boyer played on Yankees teams that won five consecutive pennants in the 1960s.
When a London agency featured images of Kurt Cobain and other dead rock stars in ads for Dr. Martens footwear, it and its client got burned.
Orders placed with American factories rose less than forecast in April, while gains in capital-goods spending might presage stronger business investment.
A decision not to call as a witness Donald J. Trump underscored that the trial of Conrad M. Black has been mostly a muted affair.
Federal authorities have expanded an investigation into allegations that Jackson Hewitt offices helped prepare fraudulent income-tax returns.
The move was an apparent move to curb media coverage of the continuing political crisis over President Pervez Musharraf’s  suspension of Pakistan’s chief justice.
The White House’s attempt to create a justice system for terrorism suspects has yet to complete a single trial.
Dr. David J. Brailer, a former senior health official in the Bush administration, is starting a $700 million private equity fund, Health Evolution Partners.
At least one significant investor in Biomet, an artificial joint maker, plans to vote against a proposed $10.9 billion deal for the company.
Michigan’s third attempt in a decade to ban partial-birth abortion was declared unconstitutional by a federal appeals court on Monday.
The Warner Music Group has made a deal with an Internet start-up, Lala.com, that will allow anyone to listen to its music free.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said it was unclear whether Iran’s government was behind the arms shipments.
Four years after starting college, Iraq’s college graduates are ending their studies shattered and eager to leave.
Former Piston Bill Laimbeer is using his basketball savvy and singular personality to make the W.N.B.A.’s Detroit Shock perhaps one of sports’ most entertaining teams.
I’ve been a close witness of the vegetative life of white spruces, and in my mind I cannot keep up with it.
A Sunni insurgent group released a video  that showed the military identification cards of two missing American soldiers and claimed they had been killed.
Two former directors at Putnam Investments have agreed to pay $400,000 each to settle charges that they had engaged in improper trading.
Mr. France transformed Nascar into a multibillion-dollar enterprise after taking it over from his father.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating what role, if any, a staff scientist played in the health scare set off by the odyssey of his son-in-law.
The United States and Russia appear likely to use the G-8 meeting in Germany to talk about a common interest: slowing Iran’s ability to produce nuclear fuel.
For the third time in six years, operators of video lottery terminals are fighting to lower the state tax on racetrack casino revenues.
The work of the man who would have been Nassau County’s first poet laureate included harsh criticism of the Bush administration.
Ask.com will present answers to queries in a three-panel screen that includes standard links but also lists related searches and results from blogs.
The gas and electric company Dominion Resources said that it would sell some of its operations in the United States for a combined $6.5 billion.
The New York State Senate should pass the Safe Harbor Act, which would place sexually exploited children under state supervision.
Members of New York’s Congressional delegation are criticizing a recent bipartisan proposal on immigration policy from all sides.
Dr. Jack Kevorkian — a k a “Doctor Death” for helping chronically ill and terminally ill patients commit suicide — has emerged from prison as deluded and unrepentant as ever.
Food scares are the latest indications that producing fake goods is still woven into the fabric of China’s economy.
Kelly Kulick and Liz Johnson, the only women in the qualifying field for the Professional Bowlers Association Tour, were eliminated in the trials that ended Sunday.
In Puerto Rico, hundreds of H.I.V. and AIDS patients are not receiving vital medical care, community groups say.
News of the plot to attack Kennedy Airport has been met with bafflement in Richmond Hill, Queens, home to some 25,000 Guyanese immigrants.
The Emirates Team New Zealand is leading Luna Rossa 3 - 0, but Patrizio Bertelli is not yet conceding.
The concerns about Representative William J. Jefferson reflected not just the sobering nature of his potential fall from grace, but a sense that he had let down the city in its time of crisis.
American officials said the men planned to attack government buildings in the Laotian capital, Vientiane, and elsewhere.
President Bush’s latest appeals court nominee, Leslie Southwick, has a disturbing history of insensitivity to blacks and other minority groups.
The plan served at least partly as a rebuff to separate efforts by President Bush and European nations to draw China and other developing countries into a commitment to reduce emissions.
Prosecutors on Monday began playing the wiretapped telephone conversations at the heart of the terrorism case against Jose Padilla.
The league will suspend Johnson for eight games without pay after the discovery of unregistered firearms in his home last December.
By contrast, Tiananmen Square itself remained quiet, if under tight security, on a sunny day, with the usual tour groups and pedestrians milling about.
The high-profile Internet start-up Joost has hired Michelangelo Volpi, 40, as its new chief executive.
The private equity investment in Palm Inc. is a gamble that the history of two companies in the personal computer industry won’t repeat itself.
Rudolph W. Giuliani has come under fire from the Roman Catholic bishop of Providence, R.I., who has criticized his support of abortion rights.
Barry Zito kept getting into jams, only to find a way out each time.
The Campbell Soup Company says it will stay in struggling Camden, N.J. — but only if the historic Sears, Roebuck & Company building is demolished.

A Suffolk County man charged with impersonating a police officer was arraigned yesterday on a series of new charges, including rape, assault and abusing animals, prosecutors said. The man, Henry Terry, 24, who had lived in Holbrook, Islip and Mastic and other places in Suffolk County, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment in Suffolk County Court. His lawyer, George Dazzo, said Mr. Terry “steadfastly maintains his innocence.” Thomas J. Spota, the Suffolk County district attorney, said Mr. Terry was accused of raping a 28-year-old woman after threatening her with arrest in a home in St. James last December. He is also accused of assaulting or abusing teenagers inside his home, setting cats on fire inside milk crates, starving a pit bull and defrauding a 56-year-old bus driver out of $120,000 after convincing him that he was the victim of a credit card scam and that he should hand over his cash for safekeeping. Prosecutors said Mr. Terry had a police uniform and accessories and an office that served as an unofficial “police station.”.

One of the nation’s largest installations for National Guard and Reserve units is planned for government-owned land on Long Island, officials said yesterday. The installation, the $86 million Farmingdale Armed Forces Reserve Center, scheduled to open in 2010, will consolidate 1,275 military personnel and will serve as a central location for the mobilization of National Guard and Reserve forces in the event of a natural disaster or terrorist attack. The four-story center also will serve as a training and military equipment storage.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday appointed a former Nassau County official as the new president of the Long Island Rail Road. The appointee, Helena E. Williams, a lawyer, served as a deputy county executive in Nassau County from late 2002 until February. She had previously worked at the authority and had run its Long Island Bus division from 1993 to 1998. Ms. Williams, who is to begin work on June 18, will be the first woman to run the Long Island Rail Road, the country’s busiest commuter railroad, with 82 million riders each year. The previous president, James J. Dermody, retired in September. Raymond P. Kenny has been serving as acting president. Ms. Williams, a resident of Nassau County since 1985, lives in Garden City. As head of the railroad, she will receive a yearly compensation package worth $272,000.

Crime fell 5.3 percent in New York City last year, and New York is still the safest big city in the United States, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday in releasing statistics from the F.B.I.’s preliminary crime report for 2006. Violent crime in New York dropped 4.6 percent, and the city reported the fewest crimes per 100,000 residents among the nation’s largest cities, the mayor said. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said crime had fallen an additional 8.5 percent in the first several months of this year. Nationwide, crime increased 1.3 percent last year, according to the F.B.I. report.

Looking to create national energy-saving standards and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that he was introducing a measure that would require cities and states to increase energy efficiency in new buildings by 30 percent in the next five years and by 50 percent before 2022. Under the measure, to be introduced next week as an amendment to the Senate energy bill, cities and states would face penalties unless they adopted a standard nationwide code or their own codes requiring energy-efficient systems and designs. Cities that met the standards would be exempt from the penalties even if their states failed to do so, Mr. Schumer said. The amendment, he said, is meant to bring the country in line with the standards in California and New York City, which recently overhauled its building code to require so-called green-building practices.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed legislation yesterday that will broaden consumer protections for New Yorkers who shop online. The law will bring the protections for online shoppers in line with those for consumers who buy goods over the phone or by mail. Among other provisions, it will prohibit online retailers from accepting an order they cannot ship within 30 days and require advertising and promotional materials to include the retailer’s legal name, address and the conditions under which refunds will be issued. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who said that his office’s Internet Bureau received 1,000 consumer complaints last year and that the bill, passed by the Legislature in May, would “put businesses on notice that the Internet is no longer the Wild West of commerce.”.

The State Senate minority leader pleaded guilty in State Superior Court yesterday to a misdemeanor charge for asking a trash hauler suspected of mob ties to threaten someone the legislator believed was hurting a relative. The senator, Louis DeLuca, 73, left, received a six-month suspended sentence and was ordered to pay a $2,000 fine and donate $1,500 to a charity. Outside court, Senator DeLuca, a Republican from Woodbury, would not discuss calls for his resignation. He had been charged with asking James Galante, a businessman facing tax fraud, extortion and racketeering charges as part of a federal inquiry into organized crime in the trash-hauling industry, to threaten someone who Mr. DeLuca believed was having an abusive domestic relationship with one of his relatives.

Officials with the Adirondack Council, an environmental group, are lobbying to reverse planned reductions in the federal budget that would severely limit or eliminate several acid rain monitoring programs. The proposed budget would cut $1 million, about 25 percent, from one program that measures atmospheric gases. Two other programs that sample lakes and streams in the Adirondacks and other areas of the Northeast on an annual combined budget of less than $1 million would also be eliminated. Acid rain remains a serious problem in many parts of the country, but nowhere has it been more damaging than in the Adirondacks, where vast forests have been decimated and more than 500 lakes and ponds have been left unable to support many species of native fish. “Closing down, even for a few months, will wipe out 21 years of continuously collected scientific data,” Brian L. Houseal, the council’s executive director, said in a statement.
President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia could benefit from longer presidential terms, though he again ruled out remaining in office after the expiration of his second term.
The Gujjars want to be considered more socially and economically deprived and thus become eligible for more affirmative action benefits.
A narrow strip of antiquity in a Palestinian neighborhood in north Jerusalem shows that the area once housed a mixed population of Romans and Jews.

The president of two large labor unions has written to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to complain that her pollster and chief strategist heads a public relations firm that is helping a company fight a unionization drive.
Former President Charles G. Taylor of Liberia is on trial on charges of backing rebels who plunged Sierra Leone into civil war.
The Prime Minister, who has said he will take a special interest in interfaith affairs when he leaves office, said the true meaning of Islam had been hijacked by extremists.
The Cubs manager said that “these things won’t happen again,” after being punished for a dirt-kicking tantrum against an umpire.
Samuel A. Garrison III was chief Republican counsel to the House Judiciary Committee in its Watergate investigation in 1974.
The diary of a 14-year-old Jewish girl who is being described as the “Polish Anne Frank” was unveiled Monday by Israel’s Holocaust museum.
Wall Street recovered from a mostly down session on Monday, eking out a gain as investors brushed off another slide in Chinese stocks.
A former television investigative reporter announced that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the U.S. Senate.
The Food and Drug Administration will appoint a panel of outside specialists to advise the agency on how to tell the public about medicines.
Mr. Sarkozy is in only his third week as president, but he is already exuding confidence, even cockiness, in dealing with some of the more arcane areas of foreign policy.
France and Spain condemned President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran for saying that a “countdown button” had been pressed to bring about Israel’s destruction.
The Giants defensive back has cut off the dreadlocks he has worn since his rookie year.
China’s stock markets have tumbled again, worsening one of the biggest sell-offs in years after the government’s move to impose a higher tax on stock trades.
The deaths sealed a night of violence in the country that caused fears that the 16-day siege of a refugee camp on the outskirts of Tripoli may have spread.
Chattanooga’s goats have become the city’s weapon against kudzu, the fast-growing vine that throttles the Southern landscape.
Kevin P. Hannon was sentenced to time in federal prison for his role in the fraud that led to the company’s collapse.
The work of Andrea Dezsö shows sometimes distasteful subject matter in a style that makes it easier to digest.
Many educated nonnative English speakers working in the United States take voice training and accent reduction.
What if Israel hadn’t taken East Jerusalem and the West Bank in the Six-Day War?
Jeff Gerth and Don Van Natta Jr.  have written what will become mandatory reading for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s opponents.
Every summer the radio station Hot 97 organizes Summer Jam, New York’s foremost hip-hop concert where Titans clash, stars show up unannounced and fans render their ruthless judgment.
Animal Collective played as a three-piece band on Friday night at South Street Seaport, and in the absence of its guitarist, Deakin, its music grew even sweeter.
“Faustus, the Last Night” might be called an opera of suspension. It seems to float, a quality borne out in the staging here at the Sottile Theater as part of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A.
Time begins for Paris Hilton, MTV movie treasure, odds against Harry Potter and more culture news.
Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra were persuasive advocates for  Mieczyslaw Weinberg’s Concerto for Trumpet and Orchestra and Symphony No. 6.

The “lollipop” building at 2 Columbus Circle is steadily changing into a new home for the Museum of Arts and Design.
Martin Truex Jr., the often overlooked teammate of Dale Earnhardt Jr., won his first Nascar Nextel Cup race Monday before half-filled grandstands.

Linda J. Gormezano is using scat to track the wanderings, genetics and condition of polar bears, which  have shown signs of stress recently.

Due to the nature of the supervoting stock at Dow Jones, a minority of the family could veto the sale even if the rest of the family backed a transaction.
The rechristened Paley Center for Media is playing down its archive and recasting itself as a place to discuss the role of media in society.

A diagnosis of sensory integration problems is not yet generally accepted, but the number of parent groups devoted to the issue has more than tripled in the last few years.

9 P.M. (ABC) THE 2007 ALMA AWARDS Eva Longoria, left, is host of this ceremony honoring Latino achievement in the United States in film, television and music. Nominees include Gael García Bernal, Jesse Garcia, Cameron Diaz, Eva Mendes, Alfonso Cuarón, “Babel,” “Ugly Betty” and “Quinceañera.” Jessica Alba, Andy Garcia, George Lopez, Mario Lopez and Ms. Mendes are scheduled to appear; Mr. Lopez will be honored for special achievement in television; Los Lobos will receive the Pioneer in Music award. And Prince will perform.
More than half a century has not proved sufficient to solve the mystery of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, nor to diminish their appeal.
Recent research reveals how boys and girls react differently to having their first sexual experience.
Learning to share the road safely is especially important in light of efforts to reduce the nation’s energy needs and greenhouse gases.
Casting Jerry Mathers, also known as TV’s Beaver, in the Broadway musical “Hairspray” could be dismissed as a casting gimmick.  But the role fits him oddly well, as does the show itself.
Rachel Carson’s warning on pesticides in “Silent Spring” ignored the good that they did.
Readers respond to articles in Science Times with thoughts on nitrogen, newborns and tremors.
Neil LaBute’s “Things We Said Today” is the most skillful entry in the first evening of the Ensemble Studio Theater’s annual two-part marathon of short plays.
The Supreme Court on Monday sided with two insurance companies in a case involving alleged violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act.
After controlling for other variables, researchers found no link between prostate cancer and blood concentrations of lycopene or other carotenoids.
Eating more baked soybeans as part of a healthy diet may help lower a postmenopausal woman’s blood pressure, a small study has found.

WASHINGTON, June 5 — Scooter Libby is a patriot and a wonderful family man. He is a criminal who should go to prison. He is a man who may have done something wrong, but he is a good man at heart.

AIRLINE REPORT CARD: OUCH! The airline industry may be back in the black, but passengers are still seeing red, according to a Consumer Reports survey that will be published in its July issue. Over all, the industry’s average score for satisfaction is lower than the scores for hotels and rental car companies and “better only than such perennials of frustration as wireless carriers, cable TV operators and computer tech support,” the magazine reports. Here is how the top 18 major domestic airlines stacked up in customer satisfaction. JetBlue was rated best. Consumer Reports said the carrier’s numerous flight delays in mid-February “seem to have had little effect” on the survey. In descending order, the others are Midwest, Southwest, Frontier, Hawaiian, Aloha, Alaska, Spirit, Continental, AirTran, Delta, American, ATA, Northwest, American Eagle, United, and America West and US Air, which merged in 2005 and recently combined all operations. In the Consumer Reports survey on hotels, Ritz-Carlton, a Marriott luxury brand, was chosen as top in overall satisfaction, while Homewood Suites from Hilton and SpringHill Suites from Marriott were cited as “excellent values.” Ritz-Carlton was also ranked at the top of the Market Metrix hospitality index survey taken in the first quarter of 2007.
Many cancer survivors develop lymphedema. And while there is no cure, experts say effective treatments are not only available but critically important.
Our successors, whoever and wherever they are, may have no way of finding out about the Big Bang and the expanding universe.
Iraqi society has continued to fracture and is so incoherent that it can’t even have a proper civil war any more.

Thursday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97th Street. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday 9:30am, Saint Patrick's Church.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday appointed a former Nassau County official as the new president of the Long Island Rail Road. The appointee, Helena E. Williams, a lawyer, served as a deputy county executive in Nassau County from late 2002 until February. She had previously worked at the authority and had run its Long Island Bus division from 1993 to 1998. Ms. Williams, who is to begin work on June 18, will be the first woman to run the Long Island Rail Road, the country's busiest commuter railroad, with 82 million riders each year. The previous president, James J. Dermody, retired in September. Raymond P. Kenny has been serving as acting president. Ms. Williams, a resident of Nassau County since 1985, lives in Garden City. As head of the railroad, she will receive a yearly compensation package worth $272,000. WILLIAM NEUMAN

Crime fell 5.3 percent in New York City last year, and New York is still the safest big city in the United States, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday in releasing statistics from the F.B.I.'s preliminary crime report for 2006. Violent crime in New York dropped 4.6 percent, and the city reported the fewest crimes per 100,000 residents among the nation's largest cities, the mayor said. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said crime had fallen an additional 8.5 percent in the first several months of this year. Nationwide, crime increased 1.3 percent last year, according to the F.B.I. report.

New York magazine's longtime classical music critic, Peter G. Davis, will be leaving the publication. Mr. Davis, who had been at New York for 26 years, said yesterday he was asked to sign an ''agreement of separation'' because the magazine decided it no longer needed a full-time classical music critic. ''It's euphemistic for being fired,'' he said. A spokeswoman for the magazine, Serena Torrey, said she could not comment on the terms of his departure or whether he would be replaced. ''We do plan to continue robust classical music coverage and criticism,'' she said. DANIEL J. WAKIN

SUMMA--Craig J. The family sadly announces Craig's death on May 31st, 2007. He was born in New Britain, CT on May 10th 1962 to Kenneth and Lorraine Summa. A longtime resident of NYC he recently lived in Long Branch, NJ and Bucks County, PA. His energy, passion, and humor will be greatly missed by the many who loved him or simply crossed his path. He is survived by son Zachary, mother Lorraine, sister Laurie, brother Keith and untold others who loved him dearly. A tribute is planned for Tuesday, June 5th at 4pm at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations for an educational fund for his son (set up through USAA) can be sent to: Zachary Summa, 23 East 10th St. #

To the Editor: Re ''Finding Some Calm After Living With 'the Shakes' '' (Personal Health, May 29): I remember my hands shaking when I was 19, in college. I always thought it was stress, or fatigue, or caffeine. I never imagined there might be a treatment. Finally, at 55, I sought a doctor's assistance, and with a daily dose of propranolol, my tremors ceased. I urge those who suffer from essential tremors to overcome their fears and ask for help. David Tussey New York

A picture caption in the Square Feet section of Business Day on Wednesday with an article on renovations at the Woolworth Building in Lower Manhattan misidentified one of the two people shown. The man at the left is Roy A. Suskin, vice president of development at the Witkoff Group, which is renovating the building -- not Richard Woodward, an associate at the architecture firm Gerner Kronick & Valcarcel.

This is when life gets really simple. Paris Hilton, the socialite and media fixture, spent her first night in jail on Sunday after turning herself in to the Los Angeles County authorities in Lynwood to begin serving a 23-day jail sentence. First, though, she attended the MTV Movie Awards on Sunday night, when she found herself the butt of several jokes. Yesterday the sheriff's office released a photo, left, of Ms. Hilton in full makeup, her blond hair swept to one side and her face tipped downward in a jailbird version of her trademark pose. She was issued an orange top and pants, like other inmates at the women's jail in Lynwood. ''I am trying to be strong right now,'' she told reporters the previous evening. ''I am ready to face my sentence.'' Ms. Hilton, 26, was sentenced for violating probation in an alcohol-related reckless driving case from September. The authorities later caught her driving with a suspended license. SHARON WAXMAN

To the Editor: Re ''Will Gentrification Spoil the Birthplace of Hip-Hop?,'' by David Gonzalez (Citywide column, May 21): The situation in the Mitchell-Lama developments state- and citywide is so dire that the governor and the Legislature should convene a task force led by the state's Housing Finance Agency to draft a comprehensive asset management strategy for preserving them.
