MTV Movie Treasure Capt. Jack Sparrow fared well when the MTV Movie Awards were handed out on Sunday in Universal City, Calif., The Associated Press reported. ''Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest,'' the second of three ''Pirates'' films, was named the best movie of 2006, and Johnny Depp, right, was named best actor for his portrayal of Captain Sparrow. Sacha Baron Cohen earned prizes for best kiss for his smooch with Will Ferrell in ''Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby'' and for comedic performance for his portrayal of Borat Sagdiyev in ''Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan.'' Mike Myers won the MTV Generation Award. Jack Nicholson won the Golden Popcorn trophy for best villain for his portrayal of a mobster in ''The Departed.'' Odds Against Harry Potter British bookmakers are so certain that Harry Potter will die in ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows'' that they have stopped taking bets on his fate, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. ''Every penny was on Harry dying, and it became untenable,'' said Rupert Adams, a spokesman for the London-based bookmaker William Hill. ''People are obsessed about this book.'' Instead, bookmakers will accept wagers on the identity of the killer. Lord Voldemort, who dispatched Harry's parents, is the 2-to-1 favorite at William Hill, followed by the Hogwarts teacher Severus Snape at 5 to 2. ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,'' above, which J. K. Rowling has said is the final novel in the series, goes on sale July 21. Historic Letters Surface In Swiss Laundry Room A filing cabinet in a Swiss laundry room has yielded a trove of nearly 1,000 letters written by Napoleon, Churchill, Peter the Great, Gandhi, Pushkin, John Donne and Queen Elizabeth I, among others, Reuters reported yesterday. Spanning more than half a millennium and ranging across art, science, literature and philosophy, the letters were amassed in more than 30 years of collecting by a wealthy Austrian banker and are to be auctioned by Christie's in London on July 3, when they are expected to fetch as much as $4.6 million. The collector, Albin Schram, kept them in an old metal filing cabinet in the laundry room of his villa in Lausanne. When he died in 2005, his family scarcely knew they were there. One of the rarest letters was written by an apologetic Napoleon on the morning after a furious argument with his wife, Josephine. In a spidery scrawl full of corrections and crossings out, Napoleon wrote, ''I send you three kisses -- one on your heart, one on your mouth and one on your eyes.'' Rain Disrupts 'Romeo' Recent rains have washed out the first preview of the Public Theater's presentation of Shakespeare's ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Originally scheduled for tonight, the first preview will take place tomorrow. Performances continue through July 8. Ethan Coen, below, whose credits as a filmmaker include ''Blood Simple,'' ''Raising Arizona,'' ''Fargo'' and ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?,'' will turn up as a playwright with ''Three Short Plays by Ethan Coen'' in the fall season on the Atlantic Theater Company's Stage 2. The company's main stage season includes the world premiere of ''Trumpery'' by Peter Parnell (who adapted John Irving's ''Cider House Rules'' for the stage); the world premiere of ''Parlour Song'' by the British playwright Jez Butterworth (''Mojo''); the New York premiere of ''Port Authority'' by Conor McPherson (''Shining City''); and the world premiere of ''Scarcity'' by Lucy Thurber (''Bottom of the World''). Footnotes ICM Artists, the classical music management agency, is changing its name to Opus 3 Artists and moving into new offices next month at Park Avenue South and 32nd Street in Manhattan. The moves follow the division's purchase from International Creative Management by managers and Newsweb, a Chicago printing and media company. Frank Price, the former chairman and chief executive of Columbia Pictures, and Jeff Zucker, president and chief executive of NBC Universal, have been elected to the board of the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens. Britain's Crown Prosecution Service, citing a lack of suitable evidence, has decided not to charge Hugh Grant, the actor, in connection with a photographer's complaint that Mr. Grant, 46, threw a container of beans and kicked at him, Reuters reported. The New York Philharmonic and Credit Suisse announced a three-year agreement yesterday to make the bank the first and sole global sponsor of the orchestra. Starting Sept. 1, Credit Suisse will be named in connection with all events in New York, around the United States and abroad. Financial terms were not disclosed.

Support for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dropped to its lowest since he took office in September, hovering at 30 percent in a poll by the national daily Asahi Shimbun. Other polls indicated a similar slide in Mr. Abe's approval ratings, which have suffered from the recent suicide of his scandal-tainted agricultural minister and from the government's mishandling of pension records. The fall increased the possibility that his governing Liberal Democratic Party might lose seats in July's upper house election; an outright defeat could spur calls for him to step down as party leader and prime minister. NORIMITSU ONISHI

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's ratings in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll suggest that unlike her Democratic rivals, her favorability ratings worsen as voters' income and education levels increase. The poll also found that Mrs. Clinton was far better known than her opponents, but more than half of those who had an opinion of her had a negative one. Over all, 42 percent of registered voters have an unfavorable view of Mrs. Clinton, 38 percent have a favorable opinion and 21 percent do not yet have an opinion. That negative rating is far higher than it is for Senator Barack Obama (21 percent unfavorable) or former Senator John Edwards (28 percent).

An article in Business Day yesterday about Harvard's plans to license more than 50 patents to Nano-Terra, a nanotechnology start-up, misstated the surname of the vice chairman of the company. He is Carmichael Roberts, not Rogers.

Sitelines Festival Martha Graham might have smiled at the thought of performing her 1936 antiwar piece ''Chronicle'' on the street in front of the New York Stock Exchange. War and big business have been known to have an affinity, after all. But Graham felt strongly about other issues of the times too, and so when nature intervened to require program changes, there were plenty of dances to draw from.

To the Editor: Re ''Physician, Upgrade Thyself,'' by Thomas Goetz (Op-Ed, May 30): Having electronic medical records is a great idea and would be a step toward simplifying life for all, including the patients.

To the Editor: Re ''Agent at Border, Aware of Alert, Did Not Detain Man Who Has TB'' (front page, June 1): Perhaps one good outcome of this ordeal is a new appreciation of why we, as a nation, need to know and care about public health threats brewing around the globe -- before they cross our borders.

An article on May 22 about a delay in adding specially equipped computerized train cars to the crowded L subway line misstated the overall growth in subway ridership from 1995 to 2006. It rose 37 percent, not 46 percent. The article also referred incorrectly to the ridership at the Bedford Avenue station in Brooklyn during the same period. Although ridership at Bedford increased significantly, it did not rise 139 percent. (It is not possible to compare total ridership at individual stations from 1995 to 2006 because in 1998 New York City Transit changed the way it counts students who ride the subway at no cost. Excluding students, ridership at Bedford Avenue increased 131 percent from 1995 to 2006.)

To the Editor: Re ''Grandma Cooks, They Deliver'' (Business Day, May 29): For the delivery men known as dabbawallas to deliver cooked meals on time to the correct individual without fail in a metropolis like Mumbai with some 18 million inhabitants and incredible traffic jams is a modern-day miracle in ultimate efficiency and unique to Mumbai.

Carnegie Hall The posterity industry found a bonanza in Beethoven's afterlife, inflating his posthumous dimensions to such magnitude that returning to the career-hungry young composer who stalked the streets of Vienna in the 1790s is not easy. Helpful for recognition purposes is the small, blue-chinned, belligerent Beethoven who looks out from contemporary portraiture, a world away from Max Klinger's muscled and towering godhead carved from multicolored marbles in 1902.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed legislation yesterday that will broaden consumer protections for New Yorkers who shop online. The law will bring the protections for online shoppers in line with those for consumers who buy goods over the phone or by mail. Among other provisions, it will prohibit online retailers from accepting an order they cannot ship within 30 days and require advertising and promotional materials to include the retailer's legal name, address and the conditions under which refunds will be issued. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who said that his office's Internet Bureau received 1,000 consumer complaints last year and that the bill, passed by the Legislature in May, would ''put businesses on notice that the Internet is no longer the Wild West of commerce.'' NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

Officials with the Adirondack Council, an environmental group, are lobbying to reverse planned reductions in the federal budget that would severely limit or eliminate several acid rain monitoring programs. The proposed budget would cut $1 million, about 25 percent, from one program that measures atmospheric gases. Two other programs that sample lakes and streams in the Adirondacks and other areas of the Northeast on an annual combined budget of less than $1 million would also be eliminated. Acid rain remains a serious problem in many parts of the country, but nowhere has it been more damaging than in the Adirondacks, where vast forests have been decimated and more than 500 lakes and ponds have been left unable to support many species of native fish. ''Closing down, even for a few months, will wipe out 21 years of continuously collected scientific data,'' Brian L. Houseal, the council's executive director, said in a statement. ANTHONY DEPALMA

A front-page article and picture caption on Friday about President Bush's new proposal for setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions misstated the location of his speech announcing the plan. Mr. Bush spoke in an auditorium in the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington, which also houses the offices of the United States Agency for International Development. He did not speak at the agency.

The likely entrance of Fred D. Thompson, right -- a.k.a. District Attorney Arthur Branch of Manhattan -- into the 2008 presidential race raises the question: who else from the abundant ''Law & Order'' shows might be a good fit in helping run a superpower? The Caucus sounded out casting agents for advice in filling a presidential cabinet and other top positions, and they had more than 50 characters to choose from.

Tonight it will be the Republicans' turn to debate in New Hampshire, and two issues are likely to figure prominently: immigration and terrorism threats, particularly the reported plot to blow up fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, has already incorporated the plot into his stump speech. On Saturday, after three people were arrested in connection with it, he told reporters in Florida that it served as a reminder that ''we're at war.''

Four white lion cubs, three females and a male, whose birth last month at the zoo in Jurques, in western France, added to the roughly 30 white lions in captivity worldwide, have died, zoo officials said. The cubs were vulnerable to infection because they had been bottle fed after being rejected by their mother. JOHN TAGLIABUE

Looking to create national energy-saving standards and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that he was introducing a measure that would require cities and states to increase energy efficiency in new buildings by 30 percent in the next five years and by 50 percent before 2022. Under the measure, to be introduced next week as an amendment to the Senate energy bill, cities and states would face penalties unless they adopted a standard nationwide code or their own codes requiring energy-efficient systems and designs. Cities that met the standards would be exempt from the penalties even if their states failed to do so, Mr. Schumer said. The amendment, he said, is meant to bring the country in line with the standards in California and New York City, which recently overhauled its building code to require so-called green-building practices. DIANE CARDWELL

Carnegie Hall The concert by the Children's Orchestra Society's Young Symphonic Ensemble at Carnegie Hall on Friday night was as much about the young people onstage as the large audience listening to them. Popular music -- its instruments and its culture -- has had an overwhelming influence on how children hear and perform music, but evenings like this one, and an afternoon like it from the New York Youth Orchestra a week ago, show that serious students of orchestral instruments are arriving in numbers and in talent.

The presidents of two large labor unions have written to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to complain that Mark Penn, her pollster and chief strategist, is chief executive of a public relations firm that is helping a company fight a unionization drive. In the letter sent Friday, which a labor official released yesterday, James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters, and Bruce Raynor, president of Unite Here, wrote that they did not want to see Mrs. Clinton or the Democratic Party embarrassed by the anti-union activities of Mr. Penn's firm, Burson-Marsteller, one of the nation's leading public relations companies.

INTERNATIONAL A3-15 New College Graduates Are Planning to Flee Iraq Iraq's college graduates are ending their studies shattered and eager to leave the country. In interviews with more than 30 students from seven universities, all but four said they hoped to flee immediately after receiving their degrees. A1 A Sunni insurgent group released a videotape that showed the military identification cards of two missing American soldiers who were captured last month south of Baghdad and said they had been killed. A14 Taylor Boycotts His Trial Charles Taylor, one of Africa's most tyrannical warlords and the former president of Liberia, refused to appear in court and sent word that he was firing his lawyer, apparently wanting to deflect attention from proceedings that aim to cover a decade of warfare and cruelty. A15 Putin and Bush to Meet on Iran As tensions rise between Washington and Moscow, President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may use a summit meeting in Germany to focus on slowing Iran's ability to produce nuclear fuel. A6 Mr. Putin said Russia could benefit from longer presidential terms, though he again ruled out the possibility that he would remain in office after the expiration of his second term next year. A6 China Offers First Climate Plan With the world's industrial powers gathering in Germany, China released its first strategy on climate change, which promises to improve energy efficiency but rejects any caps on greenhouse gas. A12 NATIONAL A16-21 Judges Dismiss Charges Against Two Detainees The government's new system for trying Guantánamo detainees was thrown into turmoil when military judges in separate decisions dismissed war crimes charges against two detainees. A1 Point System on Immigration As Congress returns from a recess and resumes work on the immigration bill, a point system will be at the heart of the debate because it would change the criteria for picking future immigrants. A1 Congressman Is Indicted Representative William J. Jefferson, the Louisiana Democrat, was indicted by a federal grand jury in Virginia, which charged him with 16 corruption-related felony counts. A1 AIDS Patients in Puerto Rico Hundreds of H.I.V. and AIDS patients in Puerto Rico are not receiving vital medical care. The problem reflects a persistently overstretched health care budget accentuated by destructive rivalries between the commonwealth and the San Juan city governments. A1 Ruling Favors Prosecutors The Supreme Court strengthened the hand of prosecutors in death penalty cases by making it easier to remove potential jurors who express ambivalence about the death penalty. A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Local Guyanese Puzzled By Airport Terror Plot News that three Guyanese and one Trinidadian man have been accused of plotting to attack Kennedy International Airport has met with bafflement in New York's Caribbean immigrant communities. Substituting a half-cup of soy nuts -- baked soybeans -- for other types of protein in a healthy diet may help lower a postmenopausal woman's blood pressure, a small study has found. For four weeks, 60 women, average age 53, followed a low-cholesterol diet that provided 30 percent energy from fat, 15 percent from protein and 55 percent from carbohydrates. Then the researchers divided them into two groups for an eight-week test.

To the Editor: Re ''With Korea as Model, Bush Team Ponders Long Support Role in Iraq'' (news analysis, front page, June 3): The strategic mission of the Korean occupation was to draw a line at the 38th parallel and prevent a North Korean attack on the South. In Iraq, the ''38th parallel'' is everywhere and nowhere; our troops will continue to be fruitlessly enmeshed in tribal and sectarian violence.

An article on Friday about the travels of a patient with a dangerous form of tuberculosis misidentified the flight that the patient, Andrew Speaker, took from Atlanta to Paris on May 12. It was Air France Flight 385, not 285. (As the article noted, the flight was also designated Delta 8517.) Because of an editing error, the article misidentified the point where Mr. Speaker crossed the border from Canada when he re-entered the country on May 24. It was Champlain, N.Y., not Plattsburgh, which is just south of Champlain.
CODY--David S., on May 31, 2007. Loving husband of Susan Hill Cody, devoted father of Gwendolyn and Allyson. Memorial service on June 9 at noon at The Reformed Church in Bronxville, NY.

TALBOT--William F., playwright and former Editor-inChief for 52 years, of Samuel French, Inc. died May 22. A graduate of University of Notre Dame and Columbia University, he served in the Navy during WWII. His play ''Portrait of a Queen'', wa produced on Broadway and London's West End. He is survived by wife Marilyn and their six children.

HOEXTER--Dr. Barton. We were all blessed by your humanity. The world is a better place because you were here. We will miss you everyday, for the rest of our lives. With love, Beverly & Marvin Morse & family $(6$)HOEXTER--Dr. Barton, of Great Neck and Manhattan, died peacefully on June 3, 2007 at the age of 70. Recognized as one of the country's pre-eminent colon-rectal surgeons, Bart studied at Horace Mann, Kenyon College and George Washington University School of Medicine. He was a member of the Phi Delta Epsilon Fraternity, St. George Society, Smith-ReedRussell Medical Honor Society, and the Alpha Omega Alpha Society. He served as a Navy physician, Chief Resident at Mt. Sinai Hospital, President of the LI Gastroenterological Association, President of the NY Society of Colon & Rectal Surgeons, President of Medical Staff at NSUH, founder and President of the Colon & Rectal Surgical Association of LI, and an Associate Clinical Professor at Cornell. Bart was repeatedly named as a Best Doctor by Castle Connolly and Town & Country. Lifelong pleasures included photography, flowers, history, traveling and his family. He was the beloved husband of Nadya (Snaider) Hoexter; father of Jill, Laura, and Ken; stepfather of Leland; grandfather of Zachary, Benjamin, and Samantha; and brother of Joan and David. Bart was a true caregiver, altruist, teacher, friend and pillar of strength to all who knew him. His kind and generous spirit will be deeply missed by all who benefited from his humor, wisdom, and integrity. Funeral services will be at Temple Emmanuel in Great Neck on June 5th at 11am.

POLLENZ--Emmett S., on June 3, 2007. Husband of Joan. Father of Lynne and Stephanie. Brother of Phillippa. Grandfather of Allison and Bobby. We have all lost our best friend. Services Wednesday 12 noon at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L. I.

STEINBERG--Ethel Stoller, 84, resident of Delray Beach, FL, widow of Ted Steinberg; beloved sister of Adeline and Edward Glassman; beloved mother of Leslie Platto, Charles Platto, Marc Stoller and Lenore Rey, Bruce and Kelly Stoller; Lyle and Wendy, Spencer and Paula, Glen, Mary, Vicki and Donna Steinberg; beloved grandmother of Jamie and Lorin, Carey and Ali, Jody, Terry; Jason and Liz, Corey, Andrew, Rachelle, Jared and Erick; beloved great-grandmother of Jake and Skylar as well as nieces, nephews and friends across the country; died on May 30, 2007. Ethel will beloved and remembered always for her warmth, her humor and her love for her family as well as for her talent as a painter, decorator and sculptor. She was an avid golfer and reader and she played a good hand of bridge but she expressed herself best in her art where she found peace and solace when the going got rough. Memorial contributions may be made to Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research Foundation, www.alzinfo.org; to National Museum of Women in the Arts, www.nmwa.org; or to Corey Frederick Stoller Memorial Scholarship, 123 Chappell Drive, Milford, NH 03055.

Rescue efforts continued in southwestern Yunnan Province as roughly 180,000 people were evacuated from their homes after a Sunday morning earthquake that registered a magnitude 6.4 killed at least three people and injured more than 300, according to state news media. More than 1,000 aftershocks have rattled the nerves of residents in the city of Pu'er, in a mountainous region of Yunnan. Roughly 2,000 soldiers and rescue workers are at the scene, and evacuees are living in tents or public buildings. JIM YARDLEY

SULLIVAN--Warren Jr. A publishing executive in strumental in establishing overseas markets for American Books, died in Englewood, New Jersey, on May 23rd. He was 85 years old. A 1944 graduate of Dartmouth College, Sullivan served with the U.S. Navy during World War II. In 1946, he joined publisher John Wiley & Sons, Inc., traveling widely in Europe, Latin America, and the Far East, to build foreign sales. In the 1960s, he was president of the Macmillan Company and then of Barnes and Noble booksellers, returning to Wiley in 1971. From 1983 to 1988, he served as Chairman of Basil Blackwell, Inc. He is survived by Madeleine (Terry), his wife of sixty years; a daughter, Kathleen; and triplet sons, Peter, William, and Jeffrey. Burial was private. A celebration of his life is planned for early fall. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be sent to the Alumni Fund, Dartmouth College, Class of 1944.

REED--Constance Culbertson Feeley. Beloved wife of Henry Hope Reed, died peacefully on May 30th, 2007. She was the daughter of Brigadier General USMC James A. Feeley. Graduate of Punahou School, Honolulu and Stanford University, Class of 1953. Reporter for The Washington Post and short story and staff writer for The New Yorker. A Requiem Mass will be held for her on Wednesday, June 6 at 3pm at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue on 53rd Street. Private burial will take place at St. James the Less Church in Philadelphia.

Walter Thompson, he was retired from the company in 1997 after living three years abroad in London. A celebration of Ernest's life has been planned for June 16th at 10:00am at the First Congregational Church of Washington, CT. The Woodbury Funeral Home of Munson Lovetere, 2 School St., is in charge of services. In lieu of flowers, memorial funds have been established in his name for Yale-New Haven Hospital Family Assistance, and may be given in care of the First Congregational Church of Washington, PO Box 1285, 06793.
DAVIES--Robert Roy, passed away June 1, 2007. Born July 4, 1925. Worked as Display Designer at B. Altman & Co. Leaves beloved partner, Philip H. Rubin. He will be missed.

ANTI-PROFANITY RULE STRUCK DOWN A federal appeals panel struck down the government policy that allows television stations and broadcast networks to be fined if they run shows containing profanities. Network executives and officials at the Federal Communications Commission said the opinion could gut the ability of the F.C.C. to regulate any speech on television or radio. [Page A1.] CHINA'S WILD-WEST FREE MARKET Recent incidents involving Chinese manufacturers trying to cut corners with ingredients used in pet foods and toothpaste are signs of a free market that is driven by entrepreneurs who are taking advantage of a weak legal system, lax regulations and a business culture where bribery and corruption are rampant. [C1.] BANCROFTS AND MURDOCH TALK The controlling family of Dow Jones & Company told Rupert Murdoch that they would sell him the company only if they could keep The Wall Street Journal out of his editorial control. [C1.] A NEW CHIEF FOR JOOST The Internet start-up Joost, which is building a global television network sending programs over the Internet, has hired Michelangelo Volpi, formerly of Cisco Systems, to be its chief executive. [C1.] OPERATING SYSTEMS VS. THE WEB In the battle between Apple and Microsoft, Bertrand Serlet and Steven Sinofsky are the field generals in charge of competing efforts to ensure that the PC's basic software stays relevant in an increasingly Web-centric world. [C1.] A SELL-OFF IN CHINA China's stock market tumbled again. Stocks have fallen by a total of about 15 percent since the government announced last Wednesday that it would triple a tax on stock trades. But there has been little effect on markets outside China. [C1.] Wall Street recovered from a mostly down session, eking out a gain as investors brushed off another slide in Chinese stocks. [C9.] JACKSON HEWITT INQUIRY WIDENS Federal authorities have expanded an investigation into accusations that Jackson Hewitt Tax Service offices helped prepare fraudulent income-tax returns that allowed customers to obtain refunds illegally. The Justice Department filed lawsuits in April accusing more than 125 Jackson Hewitt offices of enabling customers to file false returns. Late last week, Jackson Hewitt disclosed that the company was the subject of an Internal Revenue Service investigation. [C2.] A MUTED DEFENSE FOR BLACK The defense portion of Conrad M. Black's criminal fraud case is expected to wrap up later this week after only a handful of witnesses, none of whom are the bold-faced figures Mr. Black was known for associating with when he built one of the world's largest newspaper companies, Hollinger International. [C3.] INVESTING IN HEALTH CARE A former health official in the Bush administration is starting a $700 million private equity fund with a mission to invest in companies trying to reduce the cost of health care. At the outset, the sole investor will be Calpers, the largest public pension fund in the United States. [C3.] FROM BEYOND THE GRAVE Dead celebrities have a way of showing up in advertising, but when the London office of Saatchi & Saatchi recently featured images of Kurt Cobain, left, and other dead rock stars in ads for Dr. Martens footwear, the agency and its client got burned. What started out as a legitimate use of the photo of Mr. Cobain went wrong because of a series of missteps and the border-hopping power of the Internet. Advertising. [C8.] WARNER MUSIC'S INTERNET DEAL Warner Music Group, has made a deal with an Internet start-up, Lala .com, that will allow anyone to listen to its music free, with the idea that doing so will drive music sales. [C8.] CHINA'S CLIMATE STRATEGY China staked out its position on global warming by releasing its first national strategy on climate change, a plan that promises to improve efficiency but rejects mandatory caps on greenhouse gas emissions. [A12.] OPPOSITION TO BIOMET DEAL At least one significant investor in Biomet plans on voting against a proposed $10.9 billion deal for the artificial joint maker, in the latest instance of shareholder dissatisfaction in the world of buyouts. [C8.] EMISSIONS-TRADING RULES Europe is moving toward making significant changes to its emissions-trading system that could force large polluters to pay for most, if not all, permits to produce climate-changing gases, European officials said. [C8.] PANEL TO ADVISE F.D.A. ON WARNINGS The Food and Drug Administration said that it would appoint a panel of outside specialists to advise the agency on how to tell the public about the risks and benefits of medicines and medical devices. [C3.] AN INVESTMENT IN PALM A private equity investment in Palm Inc. was announced, a signal that new competition that will increasingly blur the lines between telecommunications, computing and entertainment during the next several years. [C3.] ONLINE NEW SQUAWK BOX TRIAL A federal judge has scheduled a second trial for November in the case of a group of former brokers and day-trading executives accused of scheming to profit improperly from ''squawk box'' information broadcast over brokerage loudspeakers. (REUTERS) MORTGAGE ACQUISITION The Accredited Home Lenders Holding Company, a struggling subprime mortgage lender, has agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm, Lone Star Funds, for $400 million, the companies said yesterday. (REUTERS) ENRON SENTENCE The former chief operating officer of Enron's broadband Internet division, Kevin P. Hannon, was sentenced to two years in federal prison for his role in the fraud that led to the company's collapse, a court official said. (REUTERS)

To the Editor: Re: ''For the Tiniest Babies, the Closest Thing to a Cocoon'' (May 29): Christine Hauser notes that the obvious best place for a premature baby would be the ''exquisitely complex environment'' of amniotic fluid and that the womb room is the second best place. That is surely true for preemies born just a few weeks early. But technology, no matter how high, cannot offer extremely premature newborns everything they need for full, healthy development.

It is rare for a person to touch so many lives...Janet did. Her lifelong energy and passion for improving the lives of elders will guide the field in the future. Her contributions to Hunter and its Brookdale Center on Healthy Aging and Longevity will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Janet's family. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College $(6$)SAINER--Janet. Janet and Hy welcomed Alfred and me to New York and New Jersey when we arrived here. We loved them both, and Janet was one of the most effective and beloved people in the field of gerontology. With sympathy and affection for Janet's family, Rose Dobrof $(6$)SAINER--Janet. Citymealson-Wheels Board and staff are deeply saddened by the loss of Janet Sainer, our onetime partner, longtime friend and dedicated Board member, passionate advocate for the city's elderly, an inspiration to women and community-minded citizens everywhere. Citymeals might never have taken root and flourished without her instinctive response, her enthusiasm and creativity in 1981 as the Commissioner for the New York City Department for the Aging. She was a pioneer and tireless activist in the field of aging, developing innovative programs copied nationwide. She was the energy behind the Retired Senior Volunteer Program with over 700 sites across the country and established the city's Alzheimer's Resource Center. And she remained an aggressive activist for the elderly long into her own 80s, bringing her wisdom just this week to a conference in Denver where she delivered her last plea for the cause that filled her life with meaning. Feeling this sad loss ourselves, we send comfort to Janet's family who so clearly adored her.
To the Editor: Re ''Poisonous Police Behavior'' (column, June 2): Bob Herbert was right; I had no idea that black kids were being abused by the police every day in our city.

Q. Is eating nuts and seeds really dangerous for those with diverticulosis but no symptoms? A. Perhaps surprisingly, considering how widespread the recommendation has been to avoid nuts and seeds when the intestinal pouches of diverticulosis are present, the answer is not definitively known. Doctors now advise those without symptoms to proceed with caution if they crave strawberries, raspberries, tomatoes or nuts.

A few months ago, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would ''deck'' anyone who attacked her during the presidential campaign. The idea was that she would fight back rather than allow herself to be ''Swift boated'' the way Senator John Kerry was in 2004, when he found his Vietnam War record assailed. Sure enough, both the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates have been stepping up their verbal attacks on Mrs. Clinton. So far she has stayed above the fray. It is a classic front-runner strategy. But she is also trying not to fuel critics who say she is a polarizing figure.

To the Editor: Re ''The Redolence of Spring? Call It Essence of Nitrogen'' (Basics, May 29): Nitrogen is indeed one of a handful of elements that take center stage in the dance of life on earth. That makes it all the more disturbing that human activities are upsetting the earth's natural nitrogen cycle. The consequences range from water pollution and lake eutrophication to increasing concentrations of nitrous oxide. Addressing the nitrogen pollution problem will involve difficult choices and innovative solutions, but we ignore the problem at our own peril. Bill Chameides New York The writer is chief scientist of Environmental Defense.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column yesterday about the tribute ''Celebrating Bobby Short,'' at Feinstein's at Loews Regency through June 16, misidentified a performer who will take part on June 12. It will be Wynton Marsalis -- not Liza Minnelli, who had been scheduled to perform earlier but will not be taking part.

A headline on Friday about a growing movement in Britain to boycott Israel economically and culturally referred incorrectly in some copies to a decision reached by the union of public service employees, the largest British labor union. The union said a resolution that would call for a boycott of Israel would be considered at its upcoming annual meeting. The union did not call for such a boycott.

THE CLAIM Caffeine can increase the risk of miscarriage. THE FACTS With more than 80 percent of Americans consuming it in some form or another every day, caffeine is easily the nation's most popular drug, far ahead of nicotine and alcohol. So when studies first suggested decades ago that caffeine could increase the risk of miscarriage, it raised alarm. Why exactly it might pose such a risk remains unclear, but numerous studies in recent years have investigated the link.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about differing accounts of the travels of an Atlanta lawyer with a dangerous form of tuberculosis misattributed comments about the Italian Health Ministry's contacts with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. It was Cesare Fassari, a spokesman for the ministry, who told a reporter that Dr. Maria Grazia Pompa, the head of its tuberculosis surveillance program, ''contacted the C.D.C. and said, 'Weren't you supposed to contact us?' '' Mr. Fassari also said, ''At that time, the disease centers confirmed that there was a case but did not provide details.'' The comments were not made to the reporter by Dr. Pompa.

The way this season has gone, the Yankees have learned not to expect too much from their fragile pitchers. But they seem optimistic that Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens will start the first two games of this weekend's home series against the Pittsburgh Pirates. Clemens had a magnetic resonance imaging test in Tampa, Fla., on Monday and was found to have disrupted scar tissue in his right groin. He will throw a bullpen session Wednesday in Tampa.

After a daylong search, John Pike, 23, the drummer for Ra Ra Riot, an indie pop band from Syracuse, was found dead on Sunday. His body was pulled from Wilbur's Point, a shallow body of water in Buzzards Bay in Fairhaven, Mass., around 4 p.m., according to Gary Souza, the chief of police there. Mr. Pike was reported missing on Saturday afternoon. Ra Ra Riot had played in Providence, R.I., on Friday night, and Mr. Pike was last seen around 3 a.m. Saturday, when he left an after-party at a waterfront cottage nearby. He was found fully clothed on the other side of the beach from the party, and not far from his cellphone, which had been left on shore. There were no indications of foul play, Chief Souza said. The band's next show, in Hartford on Friday, was canceled; Ra Ra Riot is also scheduled to play the River to River Festival at the South Street Seaport in Lower Manhattan on June 29. MELENA RYZIK
MOST--Betty, passed away on June 2, 2007. Adored sister of Marica and Jerry Rosenberg. Cherished aunt of Mara Yorizzo. Loving companion of Arthur Ziedenweber.

Studio B Datarock looked like a joke band when it started its set at Studio B in Brooklyn late on Saturday night. Fredrik Saroea and Ketil Mosnes arrived on stage in matching red track suits and dark sunglasses and sang over a backing track of old-fashioned drum and synthesizer sounds. They might have been better-groomed Unabombers or a Beastie Boys tribute band. ''We want you all to know that what we do is for real,'' Mr. Saroea intoned.

Because of an editing error, the Religion Journal column on Saturday, about Web sites that attract Mormons who have left the faith or are questioning it, misattributed an observation about the role of the family in Mormon life. It was Philip L. Barlow, who will lead a Mormon studies program at Utah State University -- not Jeff Ricks, executive manager of the Post-Mormon Community -- who made the points that the family role ''is in-built into the theology'' and that because the family is conceived of as eternal, a wayward Mormon is ''threatening to that family unit for all eternity.''

Robots may one day be routinely used for surgery. The HeartLander prototype below uses suction to adhere to a beating heart. Moving like an inchworm, it can reach areas that now require doctors to deflate a patient's lungs. Other researchers are working on flexible, snakelike robots to operate in the throat, and on another system that provides visual rather than tactile feedback for surgical workstations. FRANK O'CONNELL HOW THE HEARTLANDER ROBOT WORKS 1. The robot is inserted through a small incision below the sternum. 2. Forceps are used to place the robot directly on the heart. 3. After the robot attaches itself, the surgeon guides it over the heart with a joystick. HeartLander moves by alternately applying suction to each of its two chambers. Tethers attach to an external vacuum pump and a control box. It is turned by pushing and pulling on the drive wires. POTENTIAL USES The robot may be used to inject medication into difficult-to-reach areas of the heart; to attach pacemaker electrodes; and to selectively burn heart tissue, in a technique for curing arrhythmia. (Diagrams highlight the following): FRONT BODY FRONT SUCTION LINE POSITION SENSOR FRONT SUCTION CHAMBER: An external pump provides suction. SUCTION APPLIED Front section extended Rear section retracted Extended SUCTION CHAMBER REAR SUCTION LINE REAR BODY DRIVE WIRE DIAGNOSTIC SENSOR INJECTION NEEDLE ALSO ON THE HORIZON SNAKELIKE ROBOT Unlike the rigid instruments used on current surgical workstations, this flexible prototype can more easily work in confined areas like the throat. SUBSTITUTING FOR TOUCH The lack of tactile feedback makes it easy to break sutures accidentally when using a surgical robot. This system superimposes colored dots corresponding to levels of tension over video images of remote manipulators on a monitor. (Diagrams highlight the following): HOLDER SPACER DISKS DETACHABLE GRIPPERS NORMAL TENSION ELEVATED TENSION BREAKAGE IMMINENT (Sources by Robotics Institute, Carnegie Mellon University; University of Pittsburgh; Engineering Research Center, Johns Hopkins University; Advanced Robotics and Mechanism Applications, Columbia University)

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that Iranian weapons were being smuggled into Afghanistan and into the hands of Taliban fighters, but that it was unclear whether Iran's government was behind the arms shipments. But President Hamid Karzai, standing next to Mr. Gates after the two met at the presidential palace here, seemed little concerned about Iranian meddling in his country. He said relations between Iran and Afghanistan had ''never been as friendly as they are today.''
