I've been getting questions about the biochemist Bruce Ames' work, which I briefly cite in the Findings column as evidence that synthetic pesticides in our diet are a minuscule risk for cancer. So let me elaborate on the work done by him and his colleague, Lois Swirsky Gold, the director of the Carcinogenic Potency Project at Berkeley.

In Thursday's column, my last from the China trip, I write about human rights abuses in China -- and the way our own American policies undermine our moral authority and ability to raise these concerns. Please post your comments on it here.

I spent almost a year in the Sunni Triangle. I somehow avoided the hundreds of mortar attacks on my base, the I.E.D.s on some of the most dangerous roads in Iraq, the R.P.G. fired at my convoy. It's the path of the ages I feel I've traveled, where able bodied Americans go to war for their country, either by choice or not, and the best way to illustrate my journey is with a simple then and now. It is a desert full of memories I can conjure up, and every grain of sand is in ultra-sharp focus like a 7-megapixel photo.

Alex Rodriguez is at his best when he's stripped away from the politics of being A-Rod and he just talks about baseball. There are few players I've ever covered who can get as in-depth on the game when they want to.

Willie Randolph will never be confused with, say, Dave Chappelle or Jerry Seinfeld or Insert Your Favorite Comedian Here, but for some reason during his pregame interview session with reporters (perhaps because the ESPN announcers were listening in) he was in a particularly good mood. I even laughed out loud a few times.
I welcome any advice anyone has about a certain problem: How is a person supposed to live without "The Sopranos"?

Most of the injury news coming out of the Mets' clubhouse recently has revolved around their banged-up outfield. Not surprisingly, Moises Alou's left quadriceps and Shawn Green's broken right foot were again on the tip of Willie Randolph's tongue, although a few more injuries emerged, too.
Sure, Kosovo still wants out and grim reminders of war keep emerging, but Serbians are feeling the love lately in European centers of politics, sport and culture.

We get even hungrier than usual on Wednesdays, when the newspapers run their mouth-watering food features. Apparently, the campaigns are responding to the same Pavlovian pages with their food-themed fund-raising gimmicks.
Strike Two for the Ames Iowa Straw Poll. Senator John McCain has decided to follow his Republican rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and not take part in the summer event.
A Greenpeace banner on the Eiffel Tower, Paris. Christophe Ena/AP
Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders met for their latest public meeting this afternoon -- their fifth such session in the last five weeks.
The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "La Vie en Rose," about the legendary French singer Edith Piaf.

A six-game match between two computer programs billed as the Ultimate Computer Challenge kicked off today in Elista, Kalmykia. The match, between versions of commercially available software programs, is running concurrently with the final candidates matches to select human qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. In fact, the computer match is taking place on the same playing stage as the candidates finals.

Conservative bloggers and pundits have been weighing in with their thoughts on last night's Republican debate in New Hampshire, and while the reviews are somewhat mixed, many gave high marks to former mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

Drew Cline, the editorial page editor of New Hampshire's Union Leader, files an on-the-scene report from the "activists' corral" outside last night's Republican presidential debate, where the turnout by Brownback supporters was, to put it politely, unimpressive. Cline writes on his Union Leader blog:
The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "1208 East of Bucharest," a bittersweet look back at the 1989 Romanian revolution.
The war of words over the Chicago Board of Trade grew more hostile on Wednesday as its parent company warned of catastrophe if the IntercontinentalExchange took over the exchange.
Some news items that turned up in our dolphin-safe Web nets.

Levon Aronian, Peter Leko and Alexander Grischuk, all playing White, took the lead in their final candidates matches with victories in the first games. The matches are to determine qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. They are being played in Elista, Kalmykia. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.
The history of the American spacesuit may be missing a chapter if NASA doesn't change its plans.

Given that it's not legal, American law firms are unlikely to be holding initial public offerings any time soon. But it has already happened in Australia, and, according to American Lawyer, it is apt to happen in Britain within a few years.
Want to win elected office? First, become a billionaire.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign operation includes a website called HillaryHub.com -- a campaign newsroom of sorts, with links to articles and blog items that are flattering to Mrs. Clinton.
Dear Betsy, Richard, Julien, Johan, Jay and other readers who commented that the facade is too imposing and formal, and reminiscent of a "McMansion:"

In an otherwise dismal day for the stock market, investors in TD Ameritrade have something to celebrate. Shares in the nation's largest online broker rose 4.75 percent Wednesday, after the company disclosed that two hedge funds are calling for it to explore a sale. And the stock of one of their preferred merger partners shot up even more.

Jonathan Grundy has resigned from Morgan Stanley to join Merrill Lynch as head of energy, power, and infrastructure origination for Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Mr. Grundy had been co-head of Morgan Stanley's power and utilities group.

In this month's issue of PLAY, Bryan Curtis argues that fans who play fantasy baseball are part of an intellectual revolution, having devised a way to interact with the game that doesn't depend on watching the actual games for enjoyment. At PLAY we're wondering: How has fantasy baseball changed the relationship between fans and the game?
In a move that bucks years of tradition, Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided not to compete in the earliest indicator of where Republican primary voters stand, the Ames Iowa straw poll.
Guest Post by DAN SALTZSTEIN

The Federal Trade Commission's decision to try to block the merger of Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets is getting some shocked reactions from Web commentators -- and even the technology-focused blog TechDirt blog is weighing in on the newly troubled supermarket deal.
The Honda Accord Hybrid was killed on Monday. Honda will not have an Accord Hybrid in its line when the next-generation Accord arrives this fall.
The NASA chief regrets but apparently does not retract global warming comments that caused an uproar with climate scientists, The Associated Press reported.

In today's Dining Briefs column, you'll notice that one of the three briefs talks about dishes being "rehearsed," in a sense, for the new sort-of-restaurant Grayz, which is scheduled to open in September in midtown.

Last night's debate among the Republican candidates for the G.O.P. presidential nomination gave the top contenders ample time to explain some of their core beliefs. Among the more memorable moments were Senator John McCain's ardent defense of his belief in the current Iraq war strategy and impassioned defense of his support for the immigration legislation; former Mayor Rudy Giuliani's succinct responses to questions about the Iraq invasion, terrorism and his humorous comeback to the sound glitches caused by lightning from a storm; and former Gov. Mitt Romney's elaborative explanation and embrace of his Mormon faith.

In my column in Wednesday's paper I pay tribute to that under-recognized group on the margins of wine culture known as wine geeks. I try to make the case that these people play a vital role, not only insuring that we have a wonderful diversity of wine selections now but also in being among the first to discover tomorrow's must-have bottles.

On Monday, the day before a fourth man in a suspected plot to bomb jet fuel tankers at Kennedy International Airport turned himself in to the authorities, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg waded once again into the emotional discussions of how ordinary residents can conduct themselves in a post-9/11 world.

Republican hopes to regain a foothold on the Upper East Side were dashed last night. For years, moderate Republicans held a number of elected positions on the Upper East Side, once home to Mayor John V. Lindsay.
Blitzed again? The Republicans debated last night, and Wolf Blitzer won again, suggests another "Talk Clock" infographic from Chris Dodd's campaign.
A man apparently attempted to board the Popemobile without permission today as it carried Benedict XVI to his customary weekly audience in St. Peter's Square.
The analysts at Prudential Equity Group have issued their last buys, holds and sells (or, to be more exact, their last overweights, neutral weights and underweights).
Whoa, did I learn my lesson!

The Blackstone Group, which is preparing for an initial public offering, dropped plans to adopt a new accounting standard that would have let it book profits at the time of a buyout. The change greatly reduced its pro forma earnings and could make it more difficult for the private equity giant to justify a $34 billion valuation, Breakingviews said.

Steven Cohen seems intent on burnishing his nascent image as a swashbuckling activist shareholder. On Tuesday, TD Ameritrade, owner of Ameritrade, the nation's largest online broker, said in a regulatory filing that its board has received a letter from SAC Capital and Jana Partners urging the company to find a merger partner, and quickly.

Alarm bells were sounded on Tuesday by two major lenders to buyout shops about the way loans are being handed out to fund the booming private equity sector. Meanwhile, a deal by the Texas Pacific Group for the Japanese electronics maker JVC might also be jeopardized by banks looking to tighten their belts.

French regulators are examining whether Deutsche Bank enabled hedge funds to trade on inside information, destroying tapes and failing to keep written records of phone conversations when lining up buyers for a 2002 Vivendi Universal securities sale, Bloomberg News reported.

With Elevation Partners' investment in Palm, the buyout deal for telecom-equipment firm Avaya and reports of private equity interest in Cadence Design Systems, private equity firms seem to be leaping with open checkbooks into areas where they once feared to tread: technology and telecommunications.

Italy's Enel , which is poised to take over Spain's biggest utility, will expand its presence in Russia after it beat rivals to buy a one-quarter stake in the Russian wholesale generation company OAO OGK-5 for about $1.52 billion.

The chairman and chief executive of General Motors, Rick Wagoner, sought to reassure shareholders at the auto makers annual meeting that the company was not headed for a private equity buyout like its rival, Chrysler, but he shied away from categorical refusal on the subject.

A copper and zinc miner, Vedanta Resources, is raising $1.65 billion through a share offering in the United States and Japan by its main subsidiary, Sterlite Industries. The proceeds of the offer will be used to fund a move into power generation and to buy back a minority shareholding in its zinc business from the Indian government.
Google said it has purchased closely held PeakStream, a start-up that sells tools for programming chips with multiple processing units.
Tudor Investment, the hedge-fund firm run by Paul Tudor Jones, is shutting its $550 million small-company stock fund after returns failed to meet expectations.
Another bidder for BCE, the parent of Canada's largest telecommunications company, has officially entered the race.

Hedge funds and private equity funds seem to have a good routine going, with activist funds goading many companies into buyout deals and then buying the debt used to fund them. But Thorold Barker of The Financial Times cautions that this symbiosis could unravel if and when many of these big buyout deals start to go bad.
Debitel, the largest German reseller of mobile phone services, agreed on Tuesday to buy Talkline from TDC of Denmark for 560 million euros ($756 million), adding 3.8 million customers to its rolls.

Two former fund managers for Putnam Investments of Boston agreed to pay a total of $1.5 million to settle allegations they inappropriately traded mutual fund shares and potentially harmed other fund investors, federal and state regulators said on Tuesday.

Top investment banks are struggling to cope with the record volume of deals, and their overworked staffs are in danger of making costly mistakes, The Financial Times reports. Many banks are reluctant to bulk up their staff and the shortages are especially keen in financial hubs in continental Europe and Asia, the article says. One headhunter tells the newspaper that "vice presidents are very stretched with many junior staff working beyond their experience."

Shareholders of the owner of the Outback Steakhouse restaurant brand on Tuesday approved a $3.2 billion takeover offer from a private investor group. The consortium, which includes Bain Capital Partners and investment funds affiliated with Catterton Management offered $41.15 a share in cash for OSI Restaurant Partners.

Inverness Medical Innovations may not be a household name, but the Massachusetts medical-testing company is becoming a force to be reckoned with as it continues one of the biggest shopping sprees in the healthcare industry.

The British drugmaker AstraZeneca on Wednesday said its chief financial officer, Jon Symonds, is quitting after 10 years, opting for an investment-banking post instead. Mr. Symonds is leaving AstraZeneca in July, and in September he will become a managing director at Goldman Sachs.
With scrutiny of executive pay practices heating up in the United States, the private equity industry may have something to add to the debate.

Starent Networks, which provides hardware and software for mobile telephone services, raised $126.4 million in an initial public offering Tuesday, above a forecast range. The offering of 10.5 million shares sold for $12 a share, compared with a forecast range of $9 to $11, Reuters reported.
After a very public fall from grace, the ousted chief executive of RadioShack, Dave Edmondson, is gearing up for his second-act as an entrepreneur.

Jerome Abernathy, former head of research at the hedge fund giant Moore Capital Management, opened a new fund on Tuesday that tries to replicate returns generated by the industry, but with lower fees.

Third Avenue Management, an investment firm led by Martin J. Whitman, said it hired Erik Kleinbeck as a managing director in its client services and business development group. Mr. Kleinbeck, previously a managing director at Sparx Investment & Research, will focus on Third Avenue's alternative investment vehicles, Third Avenue said.

IceBreaker has landed $7.2 million in new financing, money that the Bellevue, Wash. startup will use to continue marketing its mobile dating service, Crush or Flush. It also plans to use funds to bolster a research and development center in Beijing, where the company employs more than 20 people and is looking to add more.

The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday that I.B.M. had settled a case in which it had been accused of misleading investors by overestimating the impact of stock-based compensation expenses on quarterly earnings in 2005.

A former sales chief at CA, the software maker, has agreed to pay $29.7 million in restitution after pleading guilty last year to criminal charges in a scheme to raise the company's quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.

Franklin L. Lavin, under secretary of commerce for international trade, said on Tuesday that he will resign to join the real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield. Mr. Lavin, who prodded China to reduce trade barriers by backing new tariffs on Chinese goods, plans to leave on July 13, less than two years after taking the post.

The private equity firm Colony Capital agreed to acquire control of Tamoil of Libya for 4 billion euros ($5.4 billion). The Libyan government will retain 35 percent of the company, which operates refineries and gas stations, Colony said.
The Classical Theater of Harlem’s production of Sophocles’ ”Electra” is more of a spoof of a Greek tragedy than a serious attempt to revive one.
How much you enjoy this show will depend on two things: what sort of activity you’ve engaged in before the performance, and how strong an affection you harbor for the White Lady of Soul.
“Urinetown” and “Gutenberg! The Musical!” have set the bar pretty high for the ironic musical, and this disposable show doesn’t even approach it.
The whole Wellesian legend is simply too much for a presentation like Mark Jenkins’s one-man show.

Open for business: Glenmor seasonal ownership homes, set within the grounds of the Gleneagles hotel and golf resort in Scotland, which hosted the 2005 G8 summit. Available for weekly rental throughout the summer, the scheme gives visitors the chance to rent a holiday home for a week or longer with no obligation to buy.
“The Pirate Queen” sinks, and Theresa Rebeck will make her Broadway debut next season.
The prolific English playwright Alan Ayckbourn will step down as the artistic director of the Stephen Joseph Theater in Scarborough, England.
Despite threats to the local fish population, the Mekong River remains one of the largest fishing resources in the world.
The Frugal Traveler finds himself drawn to the older and grittier aspects of Nashville, the heart of the country music world.
Caution: Tears will flow from watching “Barbaro,” the HBO Sports documentary that tells the life story of a horse Hemingway would have loved, one who exhibited grace under great pressure.
This carefully-updated old town is located on the Delaware River about 80 miles from Manhattan.
The Concacaf Gold Cup, the soccer championship of North and Central America and the Caribbean,  has gained importance.
Guitar makers are rethinking the notion that there is an inexhaustible supply of wood to make their instruments.
Several thousand anti-globalization protesters blocked roads and railway lines leading to the Heiligendamm resort.
Revisiting the Brasserie at Café Gray, a new spot called Thai Market on the Upper West Side and a review of PDT, a bar at St. Mark’s Place.
Though it is modest, almost anecdotal, in scale, “12:08 East of Bucharest” is also characterized by a precise and sneaky formal wit.
In Takeshi Furusawa’s “Ghost Train,” a group of high school students tries to unravel a mystery that leads the teenagers into the bowels of their city.
The world owes a debt of gratitude to wine geeks.
Scientists in university laboratories and medical centers are visible on the Internet, and venture capital is paying attention.
A look at the matchup between the United States and Guatemala.
The board that oversees the city’s Department of Correction has put off a final vote on changes to the rules governing the daily lives of city inmates.
The design for the new playground, which is to transform an aging, underused expanse of grey-pebbled concrete, is to be unveiled later this year.
General Motors, Ford and Chrysler executives met with Senate lawmakers on Wednesday as Democrats move toward a vote on a sprawling energy bill.

COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France, June 6 — Beside a churning sea and an ocean of white marble crosses, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today that the United States and its European allies should honor the thousands of Americans buried here by strengthening the alliance they died defending.
The markets slid for a second straight session today after an increase in labor costs stirred concerns about inflation and interest rates.

KÜHLUNGSBORN, Germany, June 6 — They lurked in the woods, fifty strong, wearing black hoods and bandannas, and wielding tree limbs. At a signal given by one of their number, they sprang forward and threw their debris across a road here, creating a barricade that brought traffic to a screeching halt.
The measure would have made it much harder for many illegal immigrants to eventually achieve legal status.
If a technique used in mice can be adapted to human cells, it would let scientists use a patient’s skin cells to generate new heart, liver or kidney cells.

The strongest cyclone ever recorded by scientists in the northwestern Arabian Sea churned up the coast of Oman today and was on track to hit land in southern Iran, sending high winds and waves through a region that is used for oil exports and civilian and military shipping traffic.
New York’s attorney general said he would examine whether lenders were discriminating against students.

The eight Democratic candidates at a contentious debate in New Hampshire seemed in utter agreement on one thing: It was time to return to that original promise to allow gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the military.
The goal is to improve the quality of patents, which should curb the rising wave of patent disputes and lawsuits, the director of the government's patent office said.
The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, dropped out after the two sides could not agree on an agenda.
Gaps on how to confront emissions and Russia are unlikely to be closed at a meeting of the wealthy economies.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about William F. Whitman Jr., a horticulturist and collector of rare fruit, referred incorrectly to an underwater camera he built with his brother Dudley earlier in his career. It was a film camera, not a video camera.

A front-page picture caption on Thursday and a related article in sports about Mel Renfro, a former star defensive back for the Dallas Cowboys who participated in a health study of retired athletes, misstated part of the name of the shrine in Ohio that honors football greats like him. It is the Pro Football Hall of Fame, not the National Football League’s Hall of Fame.

An article in Business Day on May 3 about an I.B.M. advance in chip-making referred imprecisely to recent developments in the field. I.B.M. and Intel — not Intel alone — announced in January that they would take advantage of a new insulating material for their chips. (It is I.B.M.’s more recent work, involving a manufacturing process that creates insulating vacuum channels in chips, that sets it apart from Intel’s approach.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on May 4; this correction was delayed for research.
A 21-year-old man was killed and a police officer wounded in a shootout in New Brunswick, N.J., last night, the Middlesex County prosecutor said.
For a team still well under .500, the Yankees enjoyed a rare game when timely hitting, shutdown pitching and crisp defense combined for a victory.
JERSEY CITY, June 5 — Democratic voters in urban New Jersey delivered a mixed message to traditional machine politics in Tuesday’s legislative primaries.
The hue and cry over the arrests of about 30 students on the way to a friend’s wake in Bushwick, Brooklyn, last month has spurred a growing youth movement against racial profiling.
Micah Z. Kellner, an aide to the New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., won a special election yesterday for an Assembly seat representing the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
Chase Utley’s leadoff homer in the 11th inning propelled the Philadelphia Phillies to a victory at Shea Stadium and robbed Tom Glavine of a win.

Franklin L. Lavin, under secretary of commerce for international trade, who prodded China to reduce trade barriers by backing new tariffs on Chinese goods, announced his resignation yesterday. Mr. Lavin plans to leave on July 13, less than two years after taking the post. He is joining the Washington office of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company. He led negotiations for the United States at the World Trade Organization over how to rework trade laws.
BCE, the parent of Canada’s largest telecom company, confirmed its suitors in takeover talks include the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan.
The S.E.C. said that I.B.M. had settled a case in which it had been accused of misleading investors.
Loree Moore, Ashley Battle and Cathrine Kraayeveld each scored 15 points last night to lead the Liberty to a 78-67 victory against the visiting Indiana Fever.

The private equity firm Colony Capital agreed to acquire control of Tamoil of Libya for 4 billion euros ($5.4 billion). The Libyan government will retain 35 percent of the company, which operates refineries and gas stations, Colony said. Tamoil, based in Switzerland and owned by the Libyan government under the name Oilinvest B.V., owns three refineries — in Germany, Italy and Switzerland — and 2,500 gas stations in Italy.

The Royal Bank of Scotland, the British bank that is leading a takeover bid for ABN Amro Holding, said it expected lower bad-debt provisions for the first half of the year, indicating its earnings will beat analysts’ estimates. Royal Bank said profit in the first half would be “slightly ahead” of that implied by the market median estimate for full-year earnings per share of 72.1 pence ($1.43). That compares with 66.7 pence in 2006. The earnings update did not include comment on the offer that Royal Bank and its consortium has made for ABN Amro. A group led by Royal Bank has bid 71.1 billion euros ($95.6 billion), or 38.40 euros ($51.59) per ABN Amro share, making its offer about 10 percent higher than one from Barclays, the British bank.

The Lowe’s Companies, the home-improvement retailer, will open up to six stores in Canada by the end of January 2008. At least four stores will be in southwestern Ontario, including Toronto, said Doug Robinson, Lowe’s president of Canadian operations.

Ryanair posted a 33 percent increase in annual net profit, helped by higher ticket prices, but it said profit growth would slow as higher interest rates prompted travelers to seek cheaper deals. Ryanair, the biggest low-cost carrier in Europe, said it expected profit growth of about 5 percent in the year ahead, with average ticket prices falling as higher borrowing costs curb consumer spending in Britain, the Irish airline’s biggest market. Excluding one-time items, profit after taxes rose to 401.4 million euros ($540.4 million) in the 12 months that ended March 31, up from 301.5 million euros a year earlier, and better than the 393.5 million euros expected by analysts. Ryanair said its load factor fell to 80 percent in May from 82 percent a year earlier.

South Korean prosecutors indicted Kim Seung Yun, the chairman of an industrial company, the Hanwha Group, on six charges in connection with what the authorities say was a revenge attack on employees of a bar in Seoul. Prosecutors charged Mr. Kim and a bodyguard, both arrested on May 11, with confinement and causing bodily harm with a weapon, the Seoul Central District Prosecutors’ Office said. A Hanwha Group spokesman, Ju Cheol Beom, declined to comment.
Officials are investigating the shooting of a man with learning disabilities who was shot six times by the police after he ignored a routine traffic stop in New Jersey.
The Knicks and Nets evaluated four potential draft picks on Tuesday at the Knicks’ training facility in Greenburgh, N.Y.
A reputed mobster associated with the Gambino crime family was shot at least three times while sitting in his car on a Brooklyn street yesterday morning, the police said.

Goldman Sachs Group donated $2 million to endow a chair at Morehouse College in Atlanta that will oversee the collected writings of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The chair will supervise the compilation of 10,000 pieces of Dr. King’s writings and manuscripts, Goldman Sachs said. Dr. King was a 1948 graduate of the all-male, historically black college. A group of civic leaders, businesses and philanthropists based in Atlanta bought the collection, which includes a draft of Dr. King’s 1963 “I Have a Dream” speech, last year after it was to be auctioned by Sotheby’s for more than $30 million.

The town of Farmers Branch may not yet begin enforcing its voter-endorsed law barring the rental of apartments to most illegal immigrants, a federal judge ruled. Judge Sam Lindsay of Federal District Court extended his temporary restraining order blocking the law until June 19, when he plans another ruling on whether the measure can be enforced while it is subject to legal challenges. The ordinance requires managers to verify that renters are American citizens or legal immigrants before leasing to them, with some exceptions. Violators face fines of up to $500, and each day would be considered a separate violation.

A military panel in Kansas City recommended Monday that an Iraq war veteran who wore his uniform at an antiwar protest should lose his honorable discharge status. The veteran, Cpl. Adam Kokesh of the Marines, a member of Iraq Veterans Against the War, argued that he did nothing wrong by participating in the protest in Washington in March because he removed his name tag and military emblems from his uniform.
High doses of folic acid do not prevent precancerous colon polyps in people prone to them and may actually increase the risk of developing the growths, a new study has found.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has told a gay rights organization that she supports the repeal of one provision of the federal Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law signed by her husband that says states and the federal government do not have to recognize gay marriages and unions from other states. On the questionnaire for the Human Rights Campaign, Mrs. Clinton said she opposed the part of the law that would prohibit the federal government from recognizing same-sex relationships. Her advisers said that she continued to oppose gay marriage. Her response on the questionnaire puts her in line with her rivals for her party’s nomination.

An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Microsoft and Apple to develop their next operating systems misspelled the surname of a technology executive who commented on the migration of computer functions to the Web. He is Nova Spivack, not Spivak.

A timeline in some copies on Sunday about the events leading up to charges against four men in what the authorities said was a plot to blow up terminals and fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport misspelled the given name of one suspect in some copies. He is Russell Defreitas, not Russel.

An article in Science Times yesterday about sensory integration disorder in children misspelled the surname of a therapist and researcher who first argued that sensory problems were more than symptoms of other disorders. She is A. Jean Ayres, not Ayers. The article also misspelled the given name of a father whose son received therapy for sensory problems. He is Antony Pougnet, not Anthony.

A picture caption on Saturday about high-powered public policy debates held by Robert Rosenkranz, a New York investor and philanthropist, used an outdated title in some copies for one participant, Bob Barr. He is now a consultant on public policy; he is no longer a United States representative.
Corrections: For the Record

The TV Watch column on Friday, about Fred D. Thompson, the former senator and actor on “Law & Order,” who has taken steps to run for president, misstated the year of the Senate Watergate hearings, when he was named minority counsel for the committee investigating the scandal. It was 1973, not 1974.

An article on Saturday about C. C. Myers, a contractor whose company finished repairs well ahead of deadline for a highway ramp that linked parts of the East Bay to San Francisco, incorrectly described the type of cowboy boots he favors. They are ostrich, not peacock.

An article in Business Day yesterday about a private equity investment in Palm Inc. gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a research analyst at Gartner, who discussed the market for cellphones and other hand-held devices. He is Todd Kort, not Cort.

Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Bill France Jr., the former president of Nascar, rendered incorrectly the name of the organization. It is the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing, not the National Association of Stock Car Racing.
A map of Central Asia with an article on Saturday about the construction of a bridge linking Tajikistan and Afghanistan misidentified the country shown in the lower left. It is Iran, not Azerbaijan.
The Mets’ struggling offense received a boost last night against Philadelphia when Carlos Beltrán rejoined the lineup after missing three games because of a bruised right knee.

The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who recently robbed guests at two hotels in Manhattan. In the first robbery, on April 13 at the Millenium Hilton downtown, the man followed a couple and a 9-year-old girl to their room, held them at gunpoint, then bound and robbed them of cash, jewelry and electronics, the police said. In the second robbery, on Thursday night at the Roosevelt Hotel on East 45th Street, the man forced himself into a woman’s room as she was entering, assaulted her and took her handbag, the police said. The robber is described as a white man, about 5 foot 7 and about 25 years old, with a stocky build, wearing a blue baseball cap and a black pea coat. Anyone with information should call 1-800-577-TIPS, the police said.

State officials yesterday released preliminary crime statistics for 2006, reporting a modest decrease in the crime rate over 2005. Violent crime decreased by 4.6 percent in New York City and 2.3 percent in the rest of the state; nationwide, according to federal statistics released this week, the rate of violent crime increased slightly. There were roughly 476,000 reported crimes in the state last year, the lowest volume since statewide reporting began nearly 40 years ago, officials said.
Dale Earnhardt Inc. is thriving after Dale Earnhardt Jr.’s announcement on May 10 that he would leave the company at season’s end.

About two miles of beaches, from Deal south to Bradley Beach, were closed yesterday after a pipe broke at the Asbury Park sewage treatment plant, Monmouth County officials said. Beaches in Allenhurst, Loch Arbour, Asbury Park and Ocean Grove were also closed. The pipe, which has since been repaired, released about half a million gallons of partly treated sewage into the Atlantic Ocean between 3:30 a.m. and 9:30 a.m. yesterday, said William Simmons, the county’s environmental health coordinator. Results from water quality tests, expected this afternoon, will determine whether the beaches can reopen. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Legalizing gay marriage would bring New York City $142 million in economic benefits over the first three years, according to an economic analysis released yesterday by William C. Thompson, the comptroller. Mr. Thompson, a likely candidate for mayor in 2009, wrote in the report that the benefits would come mainly from increased spending of residents and visitors on their weddings, including items like hotel stays.

A Long Island man who worked as a lawyer at a major New York law firm for four years — even though, prosecutors said, he had never gone to law school — pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to charges of impersonating a lawyer and stealing at least $284,350 in salary from his firm. The man, Brian Valery, 32, of Massapequa Park, was promoted from paralegal to lawyer at the firm, Anderson Kill & Olick, in 2002, and was earning $155,000 plus bonuses when he was fired in October 2006, prosecutors said. His lawyer, Joseph R. Conway, said Mr. Valery, who is now unemployed, faced related charges in Connecticut and expected to have charges brought against him in Brooklyn.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer yesterday announced three nominees to fill coming vacancies on the State University of New York board. Besides Carl T. Hayden, whom Mr. Spitzer had identified as his choice as SUNY’s chairman, the governor yesterday named H. Carl McCall, left, a former state comptroller and a former president of New York City’s Board of Education, and Linda S. Sanford, a senior vice president at I.B.M. The governor appoints 15 of SUNY’s 16 board members, subject to State Senate approval. The other seat is held by a student.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it planned to run special trains from the Metro-North Railroad’s New Haven line to Secaucus, N.J., for Giants and Jets football games at the Meadowlands, beginning in the second half of 2009. The trains would switch in New Rochelle from Metro-North tracks to Amtrak tracks and then run through Pennsylvania Station to New Jersey. Riders could take a shuttle train from Secaucus to the Meadowlands. The pilot program would also make it possible for subway or bus riders or riders on other commuter railroads to buy a single ticket allowing them to transfer at Penn Station to the Metro-North football trains or to New Jersey Transit trains bound for the Secaucus-Meadowlands shuttle.

A State Superior Court judge yesterday ordered Essex County to reject the winning bidder for the health contract at the county jail and give it to a company that challenged the award, county officials said. The award, made in December to Correctional Health Services, which has held the contract for 15 years, was challenged by a rival company, CFG Health Systems, said Joyce Wilson Harley, the county administrator. Judge Rachel Davidson found that the county had improperly awarded the contract and ordered that CFG be declared the winner. Lori E. Grifa, a lawyer for Correctional Health Services, said it had filed for a stay of the judge’s order.

The hotelier André Balazs bought Maison Tropicale, a small 1951 aluminum-paneled house by the French designer Jean Prouvé, for $4.97 million yesterday, Christie’s auction house said. Christie’s had estimated that the house would go for $4 million to $6 million. (The final price includes Christie’s commission: 20 percent of the first $500,000 and 12 percent of the rest.) The house had been on view since mid-May in Long Island City. Prouvé designed it as a prototype for prefabricated homes for French colonial officials stationed in Africa. The seller, Eric Touchaleaume, a French antiques dealer, has said he plans to use the proceeds to finance a Prouvé museum that will travel in another Maison Tropicale.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will have to raise revenues significantly to stave off looming deficits in the next several years, increasing pressure on the authority to increase transit fares and bridge and tunnel tolls, according to a study by the city’s Independent Budget Office.
Senator Clinton has been criticized for defying a popular line of argument among some Democratic officials.
Gene Upshaw, the head of the N.F.L. players union, was criticized by a retired player for comments he made.

Denis Clemente transferred to Kansas State after starting 15 games at point guard for Miami last season and drawing a suspension in February for violating team rules.

Bengals linebacker Odell Thurman, who is already suspended, has been accused of kicking and hitting two men in his hometown, Monticello, Ga., during the weekend.

China has reached a “turning point” in reversing its runaway pollution problems and expects to see reductions in air and water pollution in the coming months, according to Zhang Lijun, a top official with the State Environmental Protection Administration. Mr. Zhang, left, used a news conference to predict that emissions of sulfur dioxide in the air and levels of water pollution measured by a process known as chemical oxygen demand would fall this year. Cutting those areas of pollution are the main indicators in China’s nationwide plan for a 10 percent reduction in pollution by 2010. Last year, China failed to meet its goal of two percent reductions in each category and instead registered small increases. But Mr. Zhang said improvements had become evident after government programs to install pollution technology on coal-fired power plants, as well as the installation of new wastewater treatment equipment. He acknowledged that other pollutants, including ammonia, continued to rise. And greenhouse gas emissions like carbon dioxide are increasing rapidly.
Parliament passed a law making Austria the first European Union nation to allow 16-year-olds to vote in national elections. The next general elections are expected in 2010.

The government approved the reuse of grave sites to ease overcrowding in cemeteries, many of which are expected to reach capacity within decades. Under the procedure, cemetery managers would be allowed to exhume old remains, deepen a grave and rebury the body, leaving space on top for a second body. What happens to the headstone would be up to local authorities, but the Ministry of Justice, which is behind the change, said one possibility was adding a second occupant’s name beneath the first.

Nonghyup Bank is offering special interest rates to soldiers jilted by their lovers. Soldiers who can show letters or e-mail to a bank clerk proving their breakup can receive a new deposit plan with better rates and waived service fees, the bank said. Soldiers will get as much as a 0.3 percentage point premium a year for proving they are no longer romantically attached. All young men in South Korea are required to serve two years in the military. The bank plan will also be offered to female soldiers.

President Viktor A. Yushchenko set Sept. 30 as the date for early parliamentary elections, formalizing an agreement with Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich intended to end months of political turmoil. It remained unclear how Mr. Yushchenko’s decree would be put in effect, given that Parliament has been reluctant to dissolve itself.

The health minister, long known for questioning the scientific tenets of the AIDS epidemic, has turned down an invitation to address the nation’s third annual conference on the disease because she was not given a conspicuous spot on the conference agenda, Vice President Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka said. The minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, was excluded from opening ceremonies at the conference, in Durban, but had been scheduled to speak today at a gathering of AIDS experts and activists. Ms. Mlambo-Ngcuka, who did speak at the opening session, criticized the event’s organizers for relegating Dr. Tshabalala-Msimang to a lesser spot on the program. The health minister’s speech was to mark her return to public life after a long illness culminating early this year in a liver transplant.

President Vladimir V. Putin suggested that he would reappoint Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov of Moscow, who had previously said that he would leave office after his term expired in December. The leaders of Russia’s 86 regions, which include Moscow, have served at the president’s behest since constitutional changes passed after the Beslan terrorist attack in 2004. A power broker in his own right, Mr. Luzhkov, above with Mr. Putin, has used his popularity to win two popular elections since his appointment in 1992. At a tour of an experimental affordable housing project in Moscow, Mr. Putin asked the mayor to remain in office, ostensibly to address several outstanding housing problems in the capital. The Kremlin will likely seek to wield Mr. Luzhkov’s influence for its benefit in the forthcoming parliamentary and presidential elections.

The police said they had arrested two men and a woman caught rigging a police vehicle with homemade bombs in the Athens suburb of Palaio Faliro, the first arrests in a months-long wave of nighttime bombings around the capital. They described the suspects as anarchists. Athens and other cities have been the targets of frequent hit-and-run raids this year by unidentified attackers working in small groups and generally under cover of darkness. The nighttime bombings have hit targets like banks and tax offices, causing significant property damage but few injuries. In a separate incident, around 10 people were spotted throwing Molotov cocktail bombs at a Eurobank branch in the suburb of Peristeri, damaging the building’s exterior and destroying a cash machine, the police said. Firefighters put out the blaze, but the bombers disappeared.

The interim government lifted a ban on political party activities that had been imposed last September when the military staged a coup to oust an elected government. The action will allow parties to prepare for a general election tentatively scheduled for December. Parties had been unable to hold public meetings and do organizing. The lifting of the ban, effective immediately, came six days after a court ordered the dissolution of Thai Rak Thai, the party of the ousted prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra. For now, that party’s members will be unable to carry out any organized political activities. They can form a new party under a different name, but only after the National Legislative Assembly acts to reverse a coup order that bans setting up new parties.

A TRIBUTE TO THE FIRST LADY OF SONG “Great Performances” salutes Ella Fitzgerald, left, in honor of what would have been her 90th birthday (April 25) in this concert special taped at the Galen Center of the University of Southern California. Patti Austin, Natalie Cole, K. D. Lang, Nancy Wilson, Wynonna Judd, Stevie Wonder and Ruben Studdard, among others, perform Fitzgerald favorites. In Takeshi Furusawa's ''Ghost Train,'' a group of high school students tries to unravel a mystery that leads the teenagers into the bowels of their city, and into a nest of elements familiar from other Japanese supernatural horror movies. The film's heroine, a straitlaced class president named Nana (Erika Sawajiri, of ''Shinobi''), is entrusted with looking after her kid sister (Sayuri Honda) when their mom is hospitalized; the job becomes harder when the sister finds a briefcase at the train station she uses to commute to school, then vanishes.

Micah Z. Kellner, an aide to the New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., won a special election yesterday for an Assembly seat representing the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The seat was vacated by Alexander B. Grannis, known as Pete, a longtime Democratic incumbent who was named the commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation in January.

Michelin has seen competitors come and go, but none have built the reputation of Gilles Pudlowski, whose Pudlo Paris guide has been published by Little Bookroom in English for the first time and will go on sale in the United States next week for $19.95. Mr. Pudlowski's authority, expressed as ''we'' because it represents a team of reviewers, is taken seriously by Parisians. Listings of about 1,000 restaurants, bakeries, bars, cafes and tea rooms are organized according to arrondissement. The front of the book, now in its 17th edition, highlights the best of the best, giving recognition this year to Hier et Aujourd'hui as best value, for its 26-euro menu. Hélène Darroze is chef of the year; her namesake restaurant receives three plates, the top rating.

A 21-year-old man was killed and a police officer wounded in a shootout in New Brunswick, N.J., last night, the Middlesex County prosecutor said. Bruce Kaplan, the country prosecutor, said officers confronted the man, Sixto Hernandez, shortly after a woman came out of an apartment, screaming and crying around 7 p.m.

Vadim Ponorovsky, the owner of Paradou, a bistro in the meatpacking district, and Paradou Marché, a crepe and sandwich counter in the Essex Street Market, has opened Casa Tua in the market, specializing in freshly made ravioli and other pastas, and sauces. David Shemesh, the chef, may encourage you to try his beet and goat cheese ravioli -- he's making it at right -- or his seven-herb fettuccine. And in a spirit of adventure, you might consider his earthy sumac fettuccine, flavored Middle Eastern style, and toss it with olives, olive oil, lemon zest and chilies. Pasta with sauce at cafe tables is $8 to $10, from 11:30 a.m. until the market closes (at 6 p.m. Monday to Wednesday, and 7 p.m. Thursday to Saturday). Pasta for two, to take home, is $6.50 to $14, and sauces are $3.50: 120 Essex Street (Delancey Street), (212) 477-4177.

President Vladimir V. Putin, a former K.G.B. officer, yesterday awarded the writer and former dissident Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, right, Russia's top honor for a lifetime of humanitarian achievements, the Kremlin press service reported. Author of ''The Gulag Archipelago'' and other incendiary attacks against the Soviet government, the 88-year-old Nobel Prize winner spent two decades in exile before returning to Russia in 1994. Mr. Solzhenitsyn has since lived a reclusive life in Moscow, publishing several works, including a large book on Russian-Jewish relations. His wife, Natalia, told the Interfax news agency that her husband viewed the award as ''an expression of his life's work.'' ''It gives hope that this country will learn from the lesson of self-destruction in the 20th century and will not repeat it again,'' she said. MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

The seller, Eric Touchaleaume, a French antiques dealer, has said he plans to use the proceeds to finance a Prouvé museum that will travel in another Maison Tropicale.

ON Sunday mornings, there's an organic market on Boulevard Raspail in Paris where everything screams ''Eat me.'' Even in early spring, the place manages to make the best markets of the rest of the world look shabby. On display are not only deep black radishes, the darkest green savoy cabbage and the to-be-expected but nevertheless mind-boggling cheese assortment, but also plate-size scallops replete with roe, a dozen types of oysters -- including the coveted but increasingly rare Belon -- crème fraîche, yogurt that looks just as rich as crème fraîche, and the herbs and vegetables Patricia Wells craves: cress (there are two kinds), lemon thyme, spinach, zucchini, fennel, baby cukes, fresh garlic (with stalks), spring onions and more.

IF you've ever suspected that meatballs were a dead end for a restaurant's leftovers, you no longer have reason to fear. These days, chefs are free associating with well-sourced ingredients, clever substitutions and dazzling techniques. Others are refining more authentic variations that highlight the meatball's global appeal (see also: kofte, nem nuong, frikadell, kottbuller, albóndigas, keftedes, tsukune). In New York, at the seafood restaurant Esca, the fish specialist David Pasternack brings a classic Italian veal and pancetta meatball into his comfort zone, substituting tuna for the veal. Joey Campanaro uses his grandmother's recipe for meatballs in the sliders he serves at the Little Owl, in Greenwich Village, but the crispy, yeasty-sweet garlic-and-pecorino buns are an innovation he spent months perfecting.

Legalizing gay marriage would bring New York City $142 million in economic benefits over the first three years, according to an economic analysis released yesterday by William C. Thompson, the comptroller. Mr. Thompson, a likely candidate for mayor in 2009, wrote in the report that the benefits would come mainly from increased spending of residents and visitors on their weddings, including items like hotel stays. DIANE CARDWELL

To the Editor: Re ''Advisers Fault Harsh Methods in Interrogation'' (front page, May 30): The abusive interrogation methods reverse-engineered from the military's Survival, Evasion, Resistance and Escape torture-resistance program cause enormous psychological harm ranging from psychosis and suicidal ideation to post-traumatic stress disorder. They are not only unreliable and immoral; they constitute torture and violate the United States' commitment to respect the most basic human rights.

A State Superior Court judge yesterday ordered Essex County to reject the winning bidder for the health contract at the county jail and give it to a company that challenged the award, county officials said. The award, made in December to Correctional Health Services, which has held the contract for 15 years, was challenged by a rival company, CFG Health Systems, said Joyce Wilson Harley, the county administrator. Judge Rachel Davidson found that the county had improperly awarded the contract and ordered that CFG be declared the winner. Lori E. Grifa, a lawyer for Correctional Health Services, said it had filed for a stay of the judge's order.

DISPUTE OVER AVANDIA STUDY -- GlaxoSmithKline says that preliminary results of a clinical trial provide reassurance that Avandia, its treatment for diabetes, does not raise the risk of a heart attack. But influential doctors argued that the data did nothing to alleviate their concerns about the drug's heart risks. [Page A1.] GlaxoSmithKline won praise when it focused on African-Americans in marketing Avandia. But now that Avandia is dogged by safety questions, Glaxo's advertising strategy could end up working against the company. Advertising. [C1.] PLAYING AT HOME -- Chatting with friends and playing with dolls, all via the Internet -- millions of children and adolescents are spending hours on interactive play sites, which are aimed mainly at girls. [C1.] TIPTOEING INTO U.S. MARKET -- Britain's largest retailer, Tesco, is finally ready to enter the American market, beginning with a relatively modest string of neighborhood convenience stores called Fresh and Easy, in Los Angeles, Phoenix, Las Vegas and San Diego. [C1.] EBAY SELLING RADIO AIRTIME -- The auction giant eBay said it would begin selling radio airtime to advertisers starting Wednesday, expanding into a business that Google entered last year. [C3.] IN A SELLING MOOD -- Signs mounted that Federal Reserve is in no hurry to lower interest rates, leading to a sell-off in the markets. [C3.] The stock market posted its first decline in a week after bond yields surged to a nine-month high. [C11.] F.T.C. ACTS TO BLOCK MERGER -- The Federal Trade Commission said that it would file a legal complaint today to block the proposed merger of Wild Oats Markets and Whole Foods Market, arguing that the deal would lead to higher prices for natural and organic products in markets where the two chains now compete. [C1.] MANURE PLANT GENERATES DEBATE -- Tons of turkey manure and a new $200 million power plant that burns the manure to produce electricity can be found in Benton, Minn. The power plant is the first of its kind in the country, but it is also the target of environmentalists who question the earth-friendliness of the operation. [A1.] MEDIA COMPETITION IN MEXICO -- Mexico's Supreme Court struck down crucial provisions of a media law, in a defeat for Mexico's television duopoly that sends a message favoring greater economic competition. [C2.] MARKETS THAT ARE QUICK TO REACT -- The Chinese government is learning the dangers of intervening in stock markets, as policy shifts by the government and even speculation of policy shifts have led to sharp swings in share prices on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets. [C9.] WAGONER URGES PATIENCE -- Rick Wagoner, the chairman and chief executive of General Motors, faced more than two hours of criticism from shareholders at the annual meeting, but he countered that the company had made major progress in turning around its fortunes last year. ''We're taking the profound actions necessary to transform the company for the long haul,'' Mr. Wagoner, above, said. Shareholders expressed their frustration. ''We've done turnarounds so many times we're going in circles,'' said one. [C5.] HBO'S NEW LINEUP -- HBO announced a new lineup of four top corporate officers to succeed Chris Albrecht, the chief executive who resigned last month. The group will be led by Bill Nelson as the chairman and chief executive. [C3.] DOW JONES WORKERS SEEK BUYER -- The main union of the Dow Jones & Company employees, hoping to head off a takeover by Rupert Murdoch, is shopping around for another bidder and has begun talks with aides to Ronald W. Burkle, a California billionaire, union officials and others said. [C4.] ENTICING SHOPPERS IN MAINE -- Freeport, Me., recently approved the development of a $45 million open-air pedestrian-friendly ''lifestyle center,'' basically a shopping center without walls, to help keep pace with retailers moving into nearby cities in Maine. [C7.] SERVICE INDUSTRY GROWING -- Service businesses, which make up almost 90 percent of the economy, expanded at an unexpectedly high rate last month, a sign the economy is strengthening. [C3.] HE OWNS THE HOTEL -- Laurence S. Geller, the chief executive of Strategic Hotels and Resorts, a real estate investment trust that owns 20 high-end hotels in North America and Europe, represents a new breed of hands-on owners who push managers to wring more profit out of their assets. [C6.] $29 MILLION IN RESTITUTION TO CA -- A former sales chief at CA, the software maker, has agreed to pay $29.7 million in restitution after pleading guilty last year to criminal charges in a scheme to raise the company's quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.[C3.] ONLINE I.B.M. SETTLES WITH S.E.C. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that I.B.M. had settled a case in which it had been accused of misleading investors by overestimating the impact of stock-based compensation expenses on quarterly earnings in 2005. (REUTERS) ANOTHER BCE BIDDER -- BCE, the parent of Canada's largest telecommunications company, confirmed that its suitors in takeover talks include the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan and its American partner Providence Equity Partners.The announcement expands the number of potential bidders to three. (AP)

An article in Science Times yesterday about sensory integration disorder in children misspelled the surname of a therapist and researcher who first argued that sensory problems were more than symptoms of other disorders. She is A. Jean Ayres, not Ayers. The article also misspelled the given name of a father whose son received therapy for sensory problems. He is Antony Pougnet, not Anthony.

HOEXTER--Dr. Barton, of Great Neck and Manhattan, died peacefully on June 3, 2007 at the age of 70. Recognized as one of the country's pre-eminent colon-rectal surgeons, Bart studied at Horace Mann, Kenyon College and George Washington University School of Medicine. He was a member of the Phi Delta Epsilon Fraternity, St. George Society, Smith-ReedRussell Medical Honor Society, and the Alpha Omega Alpha Society. He served as a Navy physician, Chief Resident at Mt. Sinai Hospital, President of the LI Gastroenterological Association, President of the NY Society of Colon & Rectal Surgeons, President of Medical Staff at NSUH, founder and President of the Colon & Rectal Surgical Association of LI, and an Associate Clinical Professor at Cornell. Bart was repeatedly named as a Best Doctor by Castle Connolly and Town & Country. Lifelong pleasures included photography, flowers, history, traveling and his family. He was the beloved husband of Nadya (Snaider) Hoexter; father of Jill, Laura, and Ken; stepfather of Leland; grandfather of Zachary, Benjamin, and Samantha; and brother of Joan and David. Bart was a true caregiver, altruist, teacher, friend and pillar of strength to all who knew him. His kind and generous spirit will be deeply missed by all who benefited from his humor, wisdom, and integrity. Funeral services will be at Temple Emmanuel in Great Neck on June 5th at 11am.

EVANS--Charles. A devoted and much beloved member of the Alzheimer's Association family. An ardent supporter of the Association's national research program, a devotee of the Alzheimer's Association Rita Hayworth Gala since 1984, and a Zenith Fellow. He will be greatly missed by the Alzheimer's Association's Board of Directors, Harry Johns, President and CEO, Jerry Stone, Honorary Chairman, Princess Yasmin Aga Khan, Honorary Vice Chairman and founder of the Rita Hayworth Galas, and the members of the Gala Steering Committee. $(6$)EVANS--Charles. Beloved husband of Bonnie, loving father of Charles Jr. and the late Melissa and Elizabeth, sweet grandfather to Lily, adored brother of Robert and Alice, cherished uncle of Michael, Joshua, and Tony, and extraordinary friend to legions, passed away peacefully on June 2nd. As co-founder of Evan-Picone, he created one of Americas most recognized sportswear firms. He went on to form the Evans Partnership, a real estate development company, with his late brother-in-law Michael Shure. He was Executive Producer of the 1981 film Tootsie, after which he founded Charles Evans Productions, and went on to produce other films. He was National Director of the Alzheimer's Association and founded the Crusade for Fire Detection Ltd. Charles embraced life with passion all over the world. He will be missed by many people in many places. The family will be receiving friends at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday June 6 from 5-8pm. Services will be held Thursday June 7 at 12pm at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the following: The Alzheimer's Association care of Mark Hopkins 225 North Michigan Ave. Chicago, IL 60601, FDNY Foundation, 9 Metrotech Ctr. Room 5E-10 Brooklyn, NY 11201 Helping Hands, care of Robert Stern 541 Cambridge St. Boston, MA 02134. $(6$)EVANS--Charles. You helped us plant the seed that became Chop't. You watered and nurtured the business with your patience, your keen insight, plain logic, your unparalleled sense of style and taste, and mostly your unwavering high standard for quality. We will carry on with your credo: ''better sells better.'' We will always miss you and will never forget the dream that you brought to life. The whole team at Chop't $(6$)EVANS--Charles. Helping Hands: Monkey Helpers for the Disabled fondly remembers Charles Evans for his generosity and concern for his fellow man. We extend our condolences to Mrs. Evans and family. $(6$)EVANS--Charles. Dear friend, business associate. Knowing Charles was a treat. A wonderful generous person with whom we had a long, warm relationship. We always held Charles in the highest esteem. Our sincere condolences to the family. He will be missed. Irving and Ruth Spitalnick

The Republican presidential candidates waged verbal combat last night in the Congressional battle over a proposed immigration overhaul, with Senator John McCain, an author of a pending compromise plan, defending the controversial proposals in a Republican debate in Goffstown, N.H., and demanding that his competitors offer ''a better idea.'' Mr. McCain found himself at odds with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York and former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, who each criticized the Senate plan as woefully lacking in border security and immigration enforcement measures, including a uniform method to identify immigrants and limits on certain types of visas.

MAHBOUBIAN--Esther, on June 4, 2007. Wife of the late Mehdi. Mother of Kourosh and Shahriar. Sister of Yris and Parviz. Grandmother of Nilou and Julian. Family will receive friends on Thursday 6-9pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral services Friday 11:30 am at Frank E Campbell. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery.
RAVID--Rose W., on June 3, 2007. Loving wife of the late Dr. Jacob M. Ravid. Beloved mother of Joyce. Services Wednesday, June 6, 2007, 1pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam.

I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and one of the principal architects of President Bush's foreign policy, was sentenced Tuesday to 30 months in prison for lying during a C.I.A. leak investigation that became part of a fierce debate over the war in Iraq. The sentence ordered by Judge Reggie B. Walton of Federal District Court and his refusal so far to delay its enactment means that Mr. Libby may have to report to prison in about two months. That was expected to prompt Mr. Libby's supporters to accelerate their calls for Mr. Bush to grant him a pardon, although a White House spokeswoman offered a discouraging view of that possibility Tuesday.

To the Editor: Re ''Fighting the Tide, a Few Restaurants Tilt to Tap Water'' (May 30): In reading Marian Burros's article on the increasing deep-sixing of bottled mineral water in restaurants, I knew the foodies were at it again. Heaven help us.

State officials yesterday released preliminary crime statistics for 2006, reporting a modest decrease in the crime rate over 2005. Violent crime decreased by 4.6 percent in New York City and 2.3 percent in the rest of the state; nationwide, according to federal statistics released this week, the rate of violent crime increased slightly. There were roughly 476,000 reported crimes in the state last year, the lowest volume since statewide reporting began nearly 40 years ago, officials said. NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

A front-page picture caption on Thursday and a related article in sports about Mel Renfro, a former star defensive back for the Dallas Cowboys who participated in a health study of retired athletes, misstated part of the name of the shrine in Ohio that honors football greats like him. It is the Pro Football Hall of Fame, not the National Football League's Hall of Fame.
STANGER--Abraham M. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and long time friend, Abraham Stanger, and send condolences to his family.

A sophisticated nonalcoholic quaff is always welcome. Twelve is just such a refreshing newcomer, a fizzy tea-based drink seasoned with herbs, citrus and ginger and only a modest amount of sweetener. It comes in a translucent 750-milliliter wine-style bottle and is classy over ice in a stem goblet. Adding a splash of vodka or dark rum and a wedge of orange gives it another dimension. Twelve makes a delectable partner for ripe melon -- with ham early in the meal, or without for dessert.

There is nothing unusual about the Knicks' working out draft prospects at this time of year. There is nothing unusual about the Nets' doing the same. But the Knicks and Nets working out their players together? Now that's unheard of. Until now. The Knicks and Nets evaluated four potential draft picks on Tuesday here at the Knicks' training facility. They will meet again on Wednesday at the Nets' training facility to work out four more players. This union will be repeated regularly until the N.B.A. draft on June 28.
DAVIES--Robert Roy, passed away June 1, 2007. Born July 4, 1925. Worked as Display Designer at B. Altman & Co. Leaves beloved partner, Philip H. Rubin. He will be missed.

William Chase, of Herefordshire, England, must have had the export market in mind for his new line of potato chips. Why else would an Englishman call them chips instead of crisps? But Mr. Chase -- who grows, slices, fries, flavors and packages the potatoes on his farm, Tyrrells Court -- can call them anything he wants: he has come up with flavors with new personality. How about asparagus and crushed black pepper? Or mature Cheddar and chives? Not that you will go wrong with the simple sea salt variety. Some, like the asparagus, and Ludlow sausage and mustard, are seasonal and available only by calling or visiting Chelsea Market Baskets, the importer, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street). But others are sold online at chelseamarketbaskets.com, $19 for five 5.3-ounce bags. In the store they are $3.99 a bag: (212) 727-1111.

RUSSELL--Edward T., Widower of Mary Jane Russell, died in Savannah on May 20 after a brief illness at 82. He is survived by sons and daughters-in-law John and Cynthia; David; and Mark and Barbara; brother and sister-in-law Alfred and Lynn; and sister and brother-in-law Barbara and Bill Brennan. Ed earned seven battle stars in the Navy during WWII. He worked in advertising, rising in position from mailroom clerk to President of Doyle Dane Bernbach Int'l. Ed was known for his work on VW, Sony, Jamaica Tourism, and Clairol accounts. He later had his own firm, Russell, Harris, Levenson, and also served as President of Della Femina, Travisano Int'l. An accomplished photographer, Ed won the Distinctive Award of Merit from the NY Advertising Club. A 37-year resident of Pound Ridge, NY, Ed founded the PR Land Conservancy, was a recipient of the PR Good Neighbor Award, and was an active member of the PR Fire Department, serving as its President, as President of the PR Firemen's Benevolent Association, and as Chair of the Board of Fire Commissioners. A memorial service will be held on June 9, 1PM, at the PR Fire Department. Donations may be made to the PR Fire Department, 179 Westchester Ave, Pound Ridge, NY, 10576

To the Editor: I am writing to say how much I am enjoying Melissa Clark's ''Good Appetite'' column. The writing is crisp and personal, and the recipes are wonderful. She really captures the essence of why and how so many of us enjoy playing with our food. Karen Brack Garland, Tex.

LITT--Ann Selkowitz On May 30th, 2007, devoted wife and loving mother, Ann Selkowitz Litt, passed away suddenly. Ann was a nationally known nutritionist who helped children and adolescents with eating disorders and assisted developing athletes in reaching their full potential. Ann was the nutritionist for the Washington Redskins and spokesperson for several media campaigns including the Got Milk campaign. Recently, Ann was the nutrition consultant to CosmoGirl magazine 2007. Ann was the author of The College Students' Guide to Eating Well on Campus, Fuel for Young Athletes, and the ADA Guide to Private Practice. Ann frequently appeared on local and national television and was quoted by newspapers and magazines throughout the country. Ann was an avid golfer, skier, fitness enthusiast, and adventurer. Her warmth, kindness and beauty will be missed by her family, friends and all who knew her. Ann grew up in Perth Amboy, New Jersey, and lived in Bethesda, Maryland. She is survived by her devoted husband, Daniel M. Litt; her beloved sons, David L. Litt of New York City, and Jordan M. Litt of Bethesda; daughter of Lenore and Lawrence Kohn of Boca Raton, Florida, and the late Donald Selkowitz; sister of Marsha Brower of Boca Raton; sister-in-law of Lori and Joseph Roth of Morris Plains, New Jersey, and Debbie and Rick Litt of Stamford, Connecticut; aunt of Robert, Shira, and Jonathan Roth, and Jeffrey and Kenneth Litt. Contributions can be made to the Ann Selkowitz Litt Memorial Fund, National Eating Disorders Association, 603 Stewart Street, Suite 803, Seattle, WA 98101, or online at www. nationaleatingdisorders.org

An article in Business Day on May 3 about an I.B.M. advance in chip-making referred imprecisely to recent developments in the field. I.B.M. and Intel -- not Intel alone -- announced in January that they would take advantage of a new insulating material for their chips. (It is I.B.M.'s more recent work, involving a manufacturing process that creates insulating vacuum channels in chips, that sets it apart from Intel's approach.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on May 4; this correction was delayed for research.

Born in Hamilton, Ontario, Nora was the beloved wife of the late Richard Paul Bigger, loving mother of Elizabeth J. Bigger, Sarah K. Burton, H. Stewart Bigger, Richard P. (Karen) Bigger Jr., and Dr. Joel R. (Peggi) Bigger; devoted grandmother of Daniel (Elizabeth) Case, the late Edwin Case, Richard (Megan) Case, Kayne (Thomas) Anderson, Sage (Wesley) Andrews, Rory and Kevin Bigger; also survived by four great - grandchildren. Services will be private. Internment in Stanton, NJ. Family suggests memorials to a library of one's choice. Arrangements by Laughlin Memorial Chapel, Mt. Lebanon, PA. (412)531-5100

To the Editor: Tom Segev poses some interesting ''what if'' questions in connection with Israel's capture of East Jerusalem and the West Bank in the Six-Day War in 1967 (''What if Israel Had Turned Back?,'' Op-Ed, June 5). Here are some additional ''what ifs'' that deserve equal consideration: What if the Arabs had accepted the United Nations partition plan of 1947, dividing the remainder of mandatory Palestine into a Jewish state and an Arab state? What if in the aftermath of Israel's 1948 war of independence the Arab states had assimilated the refugees into their societies, rather than leave them to fester in refugee camps for generations?

The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who recently robbed guests at two hotels in Manhattan. In the first robbery, on April 13 at the Millenium Hilton downtown, the man followed a couple and a 9-year-old girl to their room, held them at gunpoint, then bound and robbed them of cash, jewelry and electronics, the police said. In the second robbery, on Thursday night at the Roosevelt Hotel on East 45th Street, the man forced himself into a woman's room as she was entering, assaulted her and took her handbag, the police said. The robber is described as a white man, about 5 foot 7 and about 25 years old, with a stocky build, wearing a blue baseball cap and a black pea coat. Anyone with information should call 1-800-577-TIPS, the police said.

PDT Inside Crif Dogs, 113 St. Marks Place (Avenue A), (212) 614-2728. It took three centuries, but at last New Yorkers can walk into a bar and order a mint julep with a deep-fried hot dog wrapped in bacon.

A front-page picture caption on Thursday and a related article in sports about Mel Renfro, a former star defensive back for the Dallas Cowboys who participated in a health study of retired athletes, misstated part of the name of the shrine in Ohio that honors football greats like him. It is the Pro Football Hall of Fame, not the National Football League's Hall of Fame.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it planned to run special trains from the Metro-North Railroad's New Haven line to Secaucus, N.J., for Giants and Jets football games at the Meadowlands, beginning in the second half of 2009. The trains would switch in New Rochelle from Metro-North tracks to Amtrak tracks and then run through Pennsylvania Station to New Jersey. Riders could take a shuttle train from Secaucus to the Meadowlands. The pilot program would also make it possible for subway or bus riders or riders on other commuter railroads to buy a single ticket allowing them to transfer at Penn Station to the Metro-North football trains or to New Jersey Transit trains bound for the Secaucus-Meadowlands shuttle. WILLIAM NEUMAN

About two miles of beaches, from Deal south to Bradley Beach, were closed yesterday after a pipe broke at the Asbury Park sewage treatment plant, Monmouth County officials said. Beaches in Allenhurst, Loch Arbour, Asbury Park and Ocean Grove were also closed. The pipe, which has since been repaired, released about half a million gallons of partly treated sewage into the Atlantic Ocean between 3:30 a.m. and 9:30 a.m. yesterday, said William Simmons, the county's environmental health coordinator. Results from water quality tests, expected this afternoon, will determine whether the beaches can reopen. TINA KELLEY

LIPMAN--Roberta. Missed, loved & remembered by us all. You are in our hearts. Larry, Beth, Reed, Samara, Paige, Donna & Matthew

To the Editor: Although Joe Nocera accuses me of having a ''tin ear,'' presumably for differing with his views on executive compensation (''Speaking Up in Fresh Air at Home Depot,'' Talking Business column, May 26), he did not mention several crucial points I made in our dialogue about Home Depot.

China has reached a ''turning point'' in reversing its runaway pollution problems and expects to see reductions in air and water pollution in the coming months, according to Zhang Lijun, a top official with the State Environmental Protection Administration. Mr. Zhang, left, used a news conference to predict that emissions of sulfur dioxide in the air and levels of water pollution measured by a process known as chemical oxygen demand would fall this year. Cutting those areas of pollution are the main indicators in China's nationwide plan for a 10 percent reduction in pollution by 2010. Last year, China failed to meet its goal of two percent reductions in each category and instead registered small increases. But Mr. Zhang said improvements had become evident after government programs to install pollution technology on coal-fired power plants, as well as the installation of new wastewater treatment equipment. He acknowledged that other pollutants, including ammonia, continued to rise. And greenhouse gas emissions like carbon dioxide are increasing rapidly. JIM YARDLEY

Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Bill France Jr., the former president of Nascar, rendered incorrectly the name of the organization. It is the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing, not the National Association of Stock Car Racing.
A map of Central Asia with an article on Saturday about the construction of a bridge linking Tajikistan and Afghanistan misidentified the country shown in the lower left. It is Iran, not Azerbaijan.

Thompson, the former senator and actor on ''Law & Order,'' who has taken steps to run for president, misstated the year of the Senate Watergate hearings, when he was named minority counsel for the committee investigating the scandal. It was 1973, not 1974.

Kyle Farnsworth first met Roger Clemens at one of the lowest points of his career. Farnsworth, then the closer for the Atlanta Braves, had blown the save in the final game of a division series against Clemens's Houston Astros in 2005. ''They beat us in the playoffs, and I saw him in the tunnel there and wished him luck,'' Farnsworth said. ''I have nothing against him at all.''
