A day after two military judges ruled against the Bush administration's system for trying terrorism detainees, Democrats seized on the rulings on Tuesday as evidence that Congress should restore the right of those held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to challenge their detentions. Senator Harry Reid, the Nevada Democrat who is the majority leader, said he would be willing to bring such legislation to the floor. The Senate Judiciary Committee is preparing to approve such a plan on Thursday.

THAI MARKET 960 Amsterdam Avenue (107th Street), (212) 280-4575. Anyone who has eaten at the simple restaurants opening onto the streets of Bangkok will feel transported upon walking into Thai Market. Backlighted blowups of food scenes are so evocative of that city that they make you smile. The food does, too.

SAINER--Janet. The finest of social workers and pioneer in services to older people, Janet's legacy will be felt for years to come. Barbara Silverstone and Ann Burack-Weiss $(6$)SAINER--Janet. With great sadness the NYC Department for the Aging mourns the passing of Janet Sainer. She was a true visionary in the field of aging. Janet Sainer served as Commissioner of the NYC Department for the Aging from 1978-1989. She was a tireless advocate for seniors and senior services until the time of her death. She kept a rigorous schedule advocating on behalf of seniors, grandparents and caregivers. Janet's tremendous legacy includes the creation of the nations first Alzheimer's Unit here at the Department, Citymeals - On Wheels, DFTA's intergenerational work study program, its Grandparent Resource Center, and the Retired Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP) for the Community Service Society. Janet's vision, spirit and legacy will live on through the programs she established at the department. Edwin Mendez-Santiago, LCSW, Commissioner $(6$)SAINER--Janet. The Aging in New York Fund mourns the passing of its founder and continuing mentor and board member, Janet Sainer. The matriarch of ANYF, Commissioner Sainer was a visionary leader and innovator in the field of aging services in New York City and throughout the country. Now in its 23rd year, ANYF derives its mission from Commissioner Sainer's vision for an organization dedicated to enhancing the quality of life for older New Yorkers and their families through public/private partnerships, seeking resources to develop innovative service models that address the unmet needs of New York City's elderly, caregivers and the network of aging service providers. Under Janet Sainer's tenure as Commissioner of the New York City Department for the Aging, ANYF sponsored the City's first annual Mayoral Conference on Alzheimers Disease and numerous initiatives focusing on the needs of personal and professional caregivers and it launched the first home delivered meals program and other activities that serve today as models in other parts of the country. From its inception, ANYF has benefited from Commissioner Sainer's guidance and wisdom. Its initiatives and programs on behalf of New York City's older adults are the enduring legacy of her enlightened inspiration and accomplishment. Allen B. Roberts Chairman Edwin Mendez-Santiago, LCSW, President Ali Hodin-Baier Executive Director $(6$)SAINER--Janet. On June 4th, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Herman. She is survived by two daughters, one son, her sister, two granddaughters, and one grandson. Services Thursday, 11:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

FRIEDMAN--Gabriel (Gary), age 84 years, died peacefully from a cerebral hemorrhage on June 4. Beloved husband of Shirley, his wife of 64 years. Cherished father of Mindy Stevely and son and business partner Richard (Cynthia). Adored grandfather of Dakoda and Skye, Samara and Ross, and greatgrandfather of Zachary. Brilliant and widely respected CPA; Beta Gamma Sigma Honor Society, NYS Society of CPAs, first president, charter member and CPA of the Woodcrest Club. Avid golfer, tennis player, loved mathematical challenges. Great sense of humor and raconteur. Funeral services June 7, 10am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY.

SCHULMAN--Blanche. On June 5th, 2007 at 95 years. Social worker, teacher, homemaker extraordinaire. Devoted to her children, Susan, Steve, and Carol, her grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, and sister. Services June 7th, 11am, Hellman Chapel, Spring Valley, NY.

To the Editor: Re ''Don't Point That Menu at My Child Please'' (May 30): One of my fondest memories of my son's childhood is of a time when we were traveling in California. We walked into a very nice place in Santa

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about William F. Whitman Jr., a horticulturist and collector of rare fruit, referred incorrectly to an underwater camera he built with his brother Dudley earlier in his career. It was a film camera, not a video camera.

TUNICK--Mildred. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Mildred Tunick, beloved mother of Andrew and Richard Tunick. The Tunick family has set a shining example of philanthropic leadership and generosity that strengthens our ability to serve those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to Andrew and Richard, to Mildred's grandchildren, and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

RHUBARB is an alarmingly sour vegetable passed off as a fruit, but requiring a huge mound of sugar to effect the transformation. Crumb cake is a huge mound of sugar disguised as a cake, but demanding a bracing counterpoint -- say a swallow of coffee or tea -- to allay its cloying sweetness.

An article on Saturday about C. C. Myers, a contractor whose company finished repairs well ahead of deadline for a highway ramp that linked parts of the East Bay to San Francisco, incorrectly described the type of cowboy boots he favors. They are ostrich, not peacock.

WHO would have thought that a middle-age couple who held government jobs and were a tad unsure what an entrepreneur was would make a small fortune from their beloved dog's bad breath? I'm kicking off my Web column on entrepreneurship with the story of Joe and Judy Roetheli (pronounced RATE-lee) of Kansas City, Mo., founders of S&M NuTec, maker of Greenies dog treats, because they were as clueless as they come about starting a business and yet, once they got it into their heads that they had a winning idea, they never lost heart.

SCHINELLA--G. Robert, age 68, of New York City on June 5th, 2007. Beloved companion of Marian Javits of many years, cousin and friend to many. Friends may call Thursday, June 7th, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Service Friday, June 8th, 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell. $(6$)SCHINELLA--G. Robert. Dearest Bob, my long time companion and friend. We shared the excitement of life and shared affection and great regard from children; Joy, Joshua, Carla, and grandchildren Emma, Benjamin, Sonya, Tony, and Jacqueline. We love you and miss you. Adrore You, Marian

Pakistani officials said they were investigating two people arrested Monday in Kashmor, a remote town in the southern province of Sindh, for any links to the killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl in 2002. Noor Ahmed Paichuho, the Kashmor police chief, said in a telephone interview that the men, Attaur Rehman and Faisal Bhatti, were being interrogated in Kashmor.

Fans of horror may be interested in ''Devil's Trade,'' an original serial that has its premieres tomorrow on FEARnet, a Web site and on-demand television service devoted to tales of gore and suspense. The story, about three teenagers plagued by a curse, will be told in seven three-to-five minute weekly episodes. ''Devil's Trade'' is produced by Ghost House Pictures, which was formed by the filmmakers Sam Raimi and Robert G. Tapert, in partnership with Mandate Pictures. The film is one of two that Ghost House will produce for FEARnet, a joint venture of Comcast, Sony Pictures Television and Lionsgate that began last Halloween. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

A Long Island man who worked as a lawyer at a major New York law firm for four years -- even though, prosecutors said, he had never gone to law school -- pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to charges of impersonating a lawyer and stealing at least $284,350 in salary from his firm. The man, Brian Valery, 32, of Massapequa Park, was promoted from paralegal to lawyer at the firm, Anderson Kill & Olick, in 2002, and was earning $155,000 plus bonuses when he was fired in October 2006, prosecutors said. His lawyer, Joseph R. Conway, said Mr. Valery, who is now unemployed, faced related charges in Connecticut and expected to have charges brought against him in Brooklyn. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

What happened in the '60s tends not to stay in the '60s. Some of it has found its way to the Whitney Museum of American Art on Madison Avenue, for ''Summer of Love: Art of the Psychedelic Era.'' Verner Panton's ''Phantasy Landscape Visiona II'' (not quite of the '60s, actually; it's a 1970 work) invites visitors to experience art on a highly personal level. Just what, in those days, was the accepted term for ''user-friendly''?

To the Editor: Re ''The Coal Trap'' (editorial, May 30): A recent study by the Department of Energy's Idaho National Laboratory shows that coal-to-liquid diesel fuels will be at least as clean as the fuels they replace, or cleaner. In fact, the laboratory concluded that coal-to-liquid fuels can be up to 46 percent cleaner in terms of carbon dioxide emissions using a biomass co-feed.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 On Way to See Putin, Bush Offers Two-Sided Message President Bush, stopping in the Czech Republic on his way to the Group of 8 meeting, delivered a two-pronged message to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, chiding him for derailing democratic reforms while assuring him that he has nothing to fear from a missile defense system in Europe. A1 Abbas Warns of Civil War The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said that the Palestinians are on the brink of civil war and that their internal battles are as dangerous to their welfare as has been Israeli occupation, if not more so. A11 ETA Calls Off Cease-Fire Spain was bracing for fresh attacks by the Basque separatist group ETA after the group called off a 15-month-old cease-fire and vowed to resume its battle for an independent Basque nation. A6 NATO Kills 20 on Taliban Boat The Afghan Defense Ministry said that a boat full of fleeing Taliban fighters had been fired upon by NATO helicopters and sunk in the Helmand River in Afghanistan. Between 20 and 30 guerrillas drowned, said a ministry spokesman. A10 Huge Cyclone in Arabian Sea Oman and Iran girded for heavy flooding and winds as the strongest cyclone ever recorded by scientists in the northwestern Arabian Sea began to hit coastlines. A12 U.N. Embraces New U.S. Envoy Zalmay Khalilzad, the new American ambassador to the United Nations, has been welcomed with open arms by his fellow delegates since he arrived six months ago. One reason is that he strikes people as so different from John R. Bolton, the combative former ambassador. A12 NATIONAL A14-20 Libby Is Sentenced In C.I.A. Leak Case I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and one of the principal architects of President Bush's foreign policy, was sentenced to 30 months in prison for lying in a C.I.A. leak investigation. A1 Clinton Under Fire for Remarks Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is under attack for saying America is safer now than before 9/11 -- contrary to a popular line of argument among some Democratic officials and liberals. A1 Power Plant Runs on Manure A power plant that burns turkey litter, manure mixed with farm-animal bedding like wood chips, to produce electricity is the first of its kind in the country. A1 Findings on Plane Crash Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board said that they thought mechanical difficulties caused a plane with four members of a medical team and two pilots to crash while racing organs from Milwaukee to Michigan. A14 Egyptian Fights Deportation An Egyptian Coptic Christian who was permitted to stay in the United States because of the threat of torture back home is now fighting deportation. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH Warnings Against Tuberculosis Tuberculosis may reach the point where most new cases are resistant to many drugs unless far greater efforts are made now to stop the spread of the infection, World Health Organization officials said. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Convicted of Corruption, Ex-Officials Surrender Two deposed Brooklyn officials -- former Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., once the borough's powerful Democratic leader, and Gerald P. Garson, a former State Supreme Court justice -- surrendered for sentencing on corruption charges. B1 Campaign Finance Pact Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York City Council leaders have agreed on a major overhaul of the city's campaign finance laws, intended to enhance the power of small donors and reduce the influence of those who do business with the city, including real estate developers. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Avandia's Safety Challenged Several diabetes experts said that the data that was released online by GlaxoSmithKline, the maker of diabetes medicine, Avandia, did nothing to alleviate their concerns about the drug's heart risks. Questions about Avandia's safety are the subject of a Congressional hearing. A1 Grocery Chain Sale Blocked The Federal Trade Commission said it would attempt to block sale of Wild Oaks Market to a rival, Whole Foods Market, arguing that the merger would lead to higher prices for natural and organic products in markets where the two now compete. C1 Clear Sign From the Fed The stock market stumbled as Wall Street grasped that the Federal Reserve is in no hurry to lower interest rates. The sell-off began after yields on the 10-year Treasury note, which is the benchmark for interest rates, inched toward 5 percent. A21 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Gitmo: a national disgrace; jail time for Scooter Libby; expletive policy deleted; keeping a watch on winter. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman and Maureen Dowd. A timeline in some copies on Sunday about the events leading up to charges against four men in what the authorities said was a plot to blow up terminals and fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport misspelled the given name of one suspect in some copies. He is Russell Defreitas, not Russel.

MAILMAN--Virginia S. PEN American Center is enormously saddened by the loss of esteemed trustee and generous friend, Virginia S. Mailman. Virginia joined the Board in 2003, serving on the Board Executive Committee and as Co-Chair of the annual PEN Literary Gala benefit. Coming to New York as a young woman, she had worked as a reporter at Life Magazine and never lost her enthusiasm about words on the page and the role of language in helping a democratic society frame its ideas about itself and the world. Virginia's elegance, style, and imagination were vividly apparent at her annual PEN Authors' Evenings parties, where guests had the pleasure of meeting distinguished authors in her lovely home. In recognition of her services to letters, PEN made Virginia a full member in 2007.

An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Microsoft and Apple to develop their next operating systems misspelled the surname of a technology executive who commented on the migration of computer functions to the Web. He is Nova Spivack, not Spivak.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer yesterday announced three nominees to fill coming vacancies on the State University of New York board. Besides Carl T. Hayden, whom Mr. Spitzer had identified as his choice as SUNY's chairman, the governor yesterday named H. Carl McCall, left, a former state comptroller and a former president of New York City's Board of Education, and Linda S. Sanford, a senior vice president at I.B.M. The governor appoints 15 of SUNY's 16 board members, subject to State Senate approval. The other seat is held by a student. KAREN W. ARENSON

An article in Business Day yesterday about a private equity investment in Palm Inc. gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a research analyst at Gartner, who discussed the market for cellphones and other hand-held devices. He is Todd Kort, not Cort.

BRASSERIE AT CAFÉ GRAY Time Warner Center, Columbus Circle, (212) 823-6338. Gray Kunz is among the most celebrated chefs who have worked in New York in recent decades, but he's not among the most prolific. When he opened Café Gray three years ago, it was his first restaurant in more than five years. And there's been no follow-up.

To the Editor: Re ''Our Green Bubble,'' by Thomas L. Friedman (column, June 3): Mr. Friedman is correct in his advocacy of a gasoline tax to provide incentive for conservation and alternative fuels development. But the regressive nature of such a tax, which might cost an average driver $500 to $1,000 a year, would place an additional burden on lower-income individuals, and it would hardly slow down higher-income individuals in pursuit of high-power automobiles.

President Vladimir V. Putin suggested that he would reappoint Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov of Moscow, who had previously said that he would leave office after his term expired in December. The leaders of Russia's 86 regions, which include Moscow, have served at the president's behest since constitutional changes passed after the Beslan terrorist attack in 2004. A power broker in his own right, Mr. Luzhkov, above with Mr. Putin, has used his popularity to win two popular elections since his appointment in 1992. At a tour of an experimental affordable housing project in Moscow, Mr. Putin asked the mayor to remain in office, ostensibly to address several outstanding housing problems in the capital. The Kremlin will likely seek to wield Mr. Luzhkov's influence for its benefit in the forthcoming parliamentary and presidential elections. MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

That time of year thou may'st in me beholdWhen sitters to their far-off homes hath fled,When camp and health forms make my blood run coldAnd all I want to do is lie in bed.In me thou see'st the frenzied wide-eyed stareOf one whose work time has been cut in twoAnd yet cannot resist the year-end snareOf read-a-louds, teacher gifts, and hot glue.In me thou see'st the envy, vile and greenOf those who smile while Spring turns into heatSuiting up for tennis, Pilates, tooAnd sporting perfectly manicured feet.This thou perceiv'st, all around me I hearOthers expressing their equal ill cheer.

Jimmy Buffett has romanticized Paris in a number of his songs, and the singer, a self-described Francophile, has even owned an apartment in the city. But he has waited until now to play his first-ever Paris concert.

On the day he would be drafted into professional baseball, Andrew Brackman went fishing on the Ohio River with his family. Brackman, who lives in Cincinnati, said he fishes a lot but never catches anything.
A strange feeling came over me as the C-130 landed at Fort Bragg, N.C. After 11 months in Iraq, I wasn't scared any more, but it felt like the rest of America was.

City Lofts Group, the residential developer with properties in Manchester, Liverpool and several other U.K. cities, is taking a trip across the Channel. "Paris, we thought, was a good opportunity for us," said Ross Mansoori-Dara, the company's co-founder.

Although Senator Joe Biden took the lead weeks ago in calling for a 90-minute debate on Iraq among the presidential candidates, his plans to take part in a forum last night on that very topic were all but derailed by the Senate's deliberation on the immigration bill.

Less than a year has passed since the New York Stock Exchange merged with Euronext, forming NYSE Euronext and a major player in the global exchange market. Now, it seems, the firm is hungry for even more partners.

Just in, courtesy of Aaron Naparstek, the guru of Streetsblog: the 154-page bill [pdf] introducing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's comprehensive PlaNYC program to make New York City environmentally sustainable. Expect policy analysts, lobbyists and legislative aides to be poring over this legislation with a magnifying glass over the next few days and weeks.
One of the great pleasures of returning to France on an overnight flight from North America or Asia is arriving in the world's most beautiful city as it wakes.

The Federal Reserve's flow of funds data came out today, and one interesting thing is how rapidly mortgage borrowing is falling. Americans borrowed (on a net basis) $127.6 billion in the first quarter of this year, a figure that is only 40 percent of the borrowing in the peak quarter, the third quarter of 2005.
The best of the deluge of Lede comments and reactions from around the Web on the end of Paris Hilton's prison term:
Bridgecreek, Huntington Beach, CA - Founder Frank Jao's vision was to build bridges between his country of origin and his new home in America.
Café Pilon, Miami, Florida - Enrique Souto and his brothers have grown the business their father started by buying their competitors.
Record Technology, Camarillo, CA - Owner Don MacInnis tells how his top-selling product was invented by customers.
Done Galleries, Sydney, Australia - Painter and entrepreneur Ken Done explains that the market will tell you what to make and how to price it.
E.M. Rose Builders, Branford, CT - Owner Eric Rose has a goal to be the best and his industry has awarded him for his achievement.

At a press conference today in New York City, John Edwards tackled some of the more weighty topics in the race for the White House. After reminding reporters that "terrorism is still alive, and ongoing, and a serious threat to America and to the rest of the world" and outlining his plan for a 10,000 member "Marshal Corps" to win back the hearts and minds of people around the world, one intrepid member of the press corps attempted to hold the feet of Mr. Edwards to the fire on what is surely the issue on the minds of most Americans.

There is probably no other Formula One event that invites a photographer to go quite so mad as at Monaco. I have just completed a day-by-day photo retrospective of the Monaco Grand Prix from the Wednesday to the Sunday, with explanatory descriptions. It seems that it is now or never to take a look at this before we become involved in the Canadian Grand Prix, for which practice starts tomorrow.

A Los Angeles billionaire and the owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer have already acknowledged that they are interested in a potential counteroffer for Dow Jones & Company. Now it appears that YouTube's Chad Hurley or the folks behind Lonelygirl15 may want in as well.

For a few weeks, urban dwellers can revel in a vast, verdant garden that has sprouted outside Paris City Hall. Alongside a giant, gurgling water can and an oversized armchair, upholstered in natural vines, are thousands of plants, trees and micro gardens grouped by categories to tickle the senses or attract butterflies.
Amaranth Advisors has a response for managers of San Diego County's pension fund, who are smarting over big losses they took when the hedge fund collapsed. It goes something like this: We warned you.

Levon Aronian, Alexander Grischuk and Peter Leko preserved their leads in the candidates finals by drawing the second games of their matches. The other match between Gata Kamsky of the United States and Boris Gelfand of Isreal remained tied after their second draw. The matches are being held in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers to the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

Reading the Rob Sass article on TVR last weekend, I was sad to see it end with TVR's 1987 departure from America, which meant no mention of the Peter Wheeler-era Griffith, possibly the most important TVR of my lifetime.

Here's a reason to look forward to 2008: By then, the nonstop speculation about the fate of AOL should finally be over. Richard Parsons, the chief executive of Time Warner, said Thursday that the media conglomerate would make a decision on AOL's future by the end of this year.
The rule of unintended consequences strikes again.

I'm a bi-platform kinda guy. Not just because I need to be conversant in both Mac OS X and Windows for my job, but also because my life revolves around certain Mac programs and certain Windows programs.

Wall Street wizards have been expecting higher long-term interest rates for a couple of years, but some now seem surprised they are arriving. The yield on the 10-year United States Treasury note climbed above 5 percent today, and there have been rises in most other countries as well. Maybe China is less willing to buy American and European bonds. Maybe there is something else.
Sharing your family vacation photos online can help others can discover a place through your travels. What advice can you give others about sharing photos online?
Today we do a little follow-up on some Screens fairy tales:
The intense Senate debate over immigration has produced some memorable exchanges with political overtones.
David Pogue reviews a program that lets you run both Windows and Mac OS X at the same time on one computer.
Although the Clinton event last night in a downtown D.C. parking lot was billed as "Club 44,'' the thousands of women who streamed in and out didn't quite fit the clubbing demographic.
Ann Moore's dream house would apparently include parts of E.W. Scripps.

The PNC Financial Services Group said Thursday it would pay $403 million to acquire the Yardville National Bancorp a central New Jersey bank that has struggled with regulatory problems and complaints from its largest shareholder.

Former North Carolina Senator John Edwards is set to hold a news conference in New York today to detail his own national security plan.Excerpts of his speech show that he will continue the riff off of whether the nation is safer now, a theme produced heated exchanges during the Democratic debate on Sunday, as he criticized the views of his rivals, especially Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

We're not even into the middle of June and the fund-raising expectations game for the second quarter ending this month is already in high gear, as is the decision-making by some campaigns looking ahead to spending in the third quarter this summer.

Wachovia said on Thursday it would hire nearly 300 private bankers to cater to affluent customers as it revamps its wealth management unit. Over the next three years, the Charlotte bank plans to more than double the 240 relationship managers in its private banking unit aimed at clients with investable assets between $250,000 and $5 million. The bankers will target high-growth markets such as Florida, Texas, California and New York.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's congestion pricing proposal got a huge boost this morning.
If the results of a survey are correct, India is no longer the world’s supposed leader of people infected with AIDS.
Porcelain, recycled plastic and a bronze stump adorn the lawn.
After a four night stay in jail, Paris Hilton was released early this morning and put under house arrest, The Los Angeles Sheriff's Department announced today.

Free Scooter! But don't pardon him. William Otis, special counsel for President George H.W. Bush and a former federal prosecutor, thinks Scooter Libby's lies were too damaging to the "fundamental rule of law that the grand jury is entitled to every man's evidence" for Libby to merit a full pardon from the current President Bush.
Frank Gehry's sculptural style comes to the table and more.

Another investor has expressed interest in the idea of putting together a rival bid for Dow Jones, the family-controlled publishing company that is fielding a $5 billion takeover offer from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

Much of Wall Street has been trying to figure out what factors could bring an end to the recent run of big buyout deals. Wilbur Ross, the billionaire financier, has his own view, and it sounds pretty grim.
Evercore Partners, the investment banking boutique, said its chief financial officer, David Wezdenko, was leaving the firm, to be succeeded by Robert Walsh, a senior partner at Deloitte & Touche.

Biomet, the orthopedic device maker, accepted a sweetened takeover bid of $11.4 billion on Thursday from a group of private equity firms after an influential shareholder advisory firm urged the company's shareholders to reject a previous $10.9 billion offer.
Memories of life and death in an architectural masterwork.

John Mayo, the former deputy chief executive of Marconi, is backing a group of investors who are seeking to restructure Vodafone and unlock up to 38 billion ($76 billion) in value from the mobile phone group.
Gerald P. Garson, the disgraced former State Supreme Court judge, has been sentenced to 3 to 10 years in prison for bribery and official misconduct, as Michael Brick reported yesterday.

Newcastle United, the English Premier League soccer club, will be sold to a British sportswear tycoon, Mike Ashley, in a cash deal valuing it at about 134 million pounds ($267 million). The deal comes after Newcastle's chairman, Freddy Shepherd, and his family agreed to sell their 28 percent stake in the club to Mr. Ashley.
Hedge fund managers are accusing Bear Stearns of trying to manipulate the market in securities based on subprime mortgages, according to press reports.

Wall Street has its own language that requires some insider knowledge to speak fluently, according to MarketWatch's David Weidner. So, in his latest, column, Mr. Weidner has put some of the most recent headlines through his decoder.

Shares of Monster Worldwide, parent of the jobs Web site Monster.com, fell more than 2 percent on Wednesday after it said its chief financial officer, Larry Baker, was resigning in a management shake-up. Timothy Yates will succeed Mr. Baker, who was leaving to pursue other interests, the company said.

British antitrust regulators have cleared the acquisition last month of Witness Systems by a software provider in the United States, Verint Systems, for $950 million. In a report released Wednesday, the British Office of Free Trade wrote that the purchase is not expected to result in less competition in Britain.

Sumner Redstone, who controls both CBS and Viacom, said Wednesday that, despite rampant speculation on Wall Street, he has no plans to take either of those media giants private. "That has been suggested to me and Philippe and to Les," Mr. Redstone said during an interview on CNBC, referring to the chiefs of Viacom and CBS, respectively.

Sam Zell's agreement to buy Tribune, the publisher of the Los Angeles Times and owner of the Chicago Cubs, prompted three hedge funds to seek profits in the fine print of $1.26 billion of bonds, Bloomberg News said.

The Biotech giant Amgen said Wednesday it would buy Alantos Pharmaceuticals for $300 million, marking its second acquisition of a private biotech company this week. Alantos' lead drug is a small-molecule treatment for Type 2 diabetes.

New Sun Nutrition, a maker of energy drinks, has swallowed $25 million in a first round of funding from Oak Investment Partners. Oak invested alongside Radar Partners and Thomas Weisel, the chairman and chief executive of Thomas Weisel Partners, the San Francisco boutique investment bank.

The aluminum giant Alcoa, taking the next step in trying to take over its reluctant acquisition target Alcan, said Wednesday it had filed with antitrust authorities in the United States to gain approval for the $27 billion hostile deal.

Two private equity firms whose takeover offer for Aeroflex was scuttled last month in favor of a competing bid are suing the company over the size of a break-up fee that was part of their original purchase agreement.

The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund in the world, is sending future hedge fund managers back to school. Man said on Wednesday that it would pay 13.8 million pounds ($27 million) to set up a research institute at Oxford University. The funds, to be paid over five years, will create the Oxford-Man Institute of Quantitative Finance and endow a professorship.
The story of the discovery of a disputed undersea trove of gold and silver valued at $500 million by an American company continues to unfold like a pirate adventure.

Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that recently agreed to buy Chrysler, has created affiliates that plan to raise more than $11 billion for investments, Reuters reported, citing regulatory filings. The six affiliates have already raised about $10.5 billion, Reuters said.

A British hotel group, Vector pulled the plug on its planned 1.7 billion pound ($3.4 billion) initial public offering Wednesday night after investors failed to support what would have been the biggest share sale in London this year.
Stelco, the Canadian steel company that announced last week that it is exploring the possibility of sale, is likely to be sold whole rather than in parts, its chief executive said Wednesday.
Recently published research confirms what any venture capital investor would tell you: clean tech is hot.

Yahoo's Terry Semel may be heading for a pay cut. As the Internet giant lags behind Google and with its much ballyhooed Panama project - the nickname for the firm's overhaul of its search advertising system -- yet to materialize, investors and industry observers are casting a critical eye on the chief executive's $71 million compensation package.

For the second time in 12 months, the government has moved to block a tax shelter that had been aimed at converting billions of dollars of corporate profits, on which taxes have yet to be paid, into profits that will never be taxed.

NASD, a regulator of brokerage firms, said on Wednesday that Citigroup will pay $15.2 million to settle claims that its brokers had coaxed employees of BellSouth into retiring early on exaggerated projections for investment returns.

The former media baron Conrad M. Black, charged with fraud and racketeering, lost his motion on Wednesday to recall the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler. At the same time, the judge denied a request for a mistrial by one of Mr. Black's co-defendants, Mark S. Kipnis.
“You’re Gonna Miss Me” follows Roky Erickson, the lead singer of the 13th Floor Elevators and maybe the most influential 1960s pop star that most folks haven’t heard of.
This addition to the kiddie canon follows a young Rockhopper penguin with surfing in his blood and dreams of greatness in his head.
The events recounted in the World War II drama “Miriam” are horrific, and the story behind it is moving. Unfortunately, the finished product feels like exploitation.
The Enron Creditors Recovery Corporation, formerly known as Enron, announced on Wednesday that UBS had agreed to pay $115 million to settle litigation over the collapse of Enron.

Genstar Capital, a private equity firm focused on midsize companies, said it closed its fifth private equity fund at $1.55 billion. That amount far exceeded the fund's initial target of $1 billion. Genstar's latest fund was also more than three times the size of the one it raised in 2004.
Eli Roth’s “Hostel: Part II” may sport glossier production values than the first in the series, but its driving motivation remains just as low.
Josh Simonds, cycling coach, tests bike racks.
New shows in New York include "Horizon" and "Crazy Mary."
Additional images from the 2007 international art exhibition.
Images from "Ocean's Thirteen."
Rising prices is causing Chinese companies to raise prices for exports, particularly on one critical commodity: pork.
“Speeders” is “Cops” without the guns and the running.
Images from the movie "Surf's Up."
Two goals from midfielder Julian de Guzman helped Canada come from behind to beat Costa Rica 2-1 in the opening game of the CONCACAF Gold Cup on Wednesday.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Thursday's deaths brings the toll to at least 33 dead so far since hundreds of police swept down on the Mathare slum.

In her Cyberfamilias column today in Thursday Styles, Michelle Slatalla writes about how she joined Facebook, the social networking site that recently expanded its membership beyond students, to keep up with her daughter. The teenager viewed it as super creepy.
With inspiration from "60 Minutes," gadgets too good to pass up in this summer rerun.
Addendum: This event, cancelled because of rain, is now on June 23. Updated info at www.d2adrenaline.com.
Ana Ivanovic defeated Maria Sharapova, 6-2, 6-1. Ivanovic will play Justine Henin on Saturday.
Confronted with fresh allegations of impropriety in an arms deal, Prime Minister Tony Blair defended his decision to cancel an inquiry into the agreement.
The 247 to 176 sent the bipartisan measure to the White House that President Bush has pledged to veto.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan won qualified support from Gov. Eliot Spitzer and a federal official.
A suicide bomber and bus bomb exploded near a police station in northern Iraq today, killing at least nine people and wounding 22, the authorities said.
Lt. Gen. Douglas Lute said the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan represents "the main effort in the long war."
If the results of a survey are correct, India is no longer the world’s supposed leader of people infected with AIDS.
The Russian president suggested that instead of building radar defenses in the Czech Republic, the U.S. should use an existing system in the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.
The missile test drew an annoyed reaction from the United States and a dismissive one from South Korea.
What students must learn to be deemed proficient varies drastically from state to state, a report said.
This evening’s vote is a bitter disappointment for President Bush, who has made comprehensive immigration reform a priority.
The U.S. agreed today to “seriously consider” a European proposal to combat global warming by halving greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
The play, called “Voices in Conflict,” attempts to portray the views of soldiers and others on the Iraq war in their own words.
Endy Chávez injured his left hamstring while trying to beat out a ground ball in the seventh inning of the Mets’ loss to the Philadelphia Phillies.
The Yankees scored in only two innings, but with starter Chien-Ming Wang in control, the outcome never seemed to be in doubt.
The government moved to block a tax shelter aimed at converting billions of corporate profits into profits that will never be taxed.

A man and woman were found dead in their apartment in East New York last night in what investigators are calling a possible murder-suicide, the police said. The couple, identified as Veldora Dixon, 39, and Tito Jemmoot, 35, each had a gunshot wound in the head when they were found in the apartment at 712 Pennsylvania Avenue. Their bodies were found in their bed, and a 9-millimeter gun was found near Mr. Jemmoot’s body, the police said. The police were alerted to the body about 7:30 p.m. by a friend of the family, who wondered why the couple had missed an appointment.
Anaheim beat the Ottawa Senators in Game 5 on Wednesday night, 6-2, killing one of sports’ most tired jokes. The Ducks are no longer funny. They are scary.

China’s car sales rose 23 percent in May, as price cuts and new models attracted more people to showrooms. Customers bought 488,500 passenger cars, multipurpose vehicles and sport-utility vehicles in May, the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers said.
Moises Alou is closing in on his fourth week out of the Mets’ lineup and doubts he can return for this weekend’s series in Detroit.
Shares of Monster Worldwide fell more than 2 percent after it said its chief financial officer was resigning as part of a management shake-up.
A proposal to build houses, offices and shops off the Sprain Brook Parkway in Yonkers has cleared its last hurdle.

The Teamsters union said it had reached a tentative contract deal with the Canadian Pacific Railway and a strike by 3,200 maintenance workers in Canada should end soon. No details of the proposed three-year contract are being released before a ratification vote. The workers have been off the job since May 15. After months of negotiations, the two sides stopped talking when the strike began. Maintenance employees have been without a contract since December.

Ecuador has started to examine its oil agreements to determine if private companies have breached their contracts with the nation, South America’s fifth-largest oil producer, the energy minister said. “A committee will look into all contracts. It will review all we need to review and we are seeking transparency,” the oil minister, Alberto Acosta, said. The nine-member committee of energy officials and specialists is examining exploration and development contracts, which are mostly in the hands of foreign oil companies like Petrobras of Brazil and Repsol-YPF of Spain.

Citigroup, which recently acquired a majority stake in the Nikko Cordial Corporation, said Brandon Ginsberg had resigned as co-head of equities at its Japanese investment bank. Mr. Ginsberg has already left, said Masufumi Yoshino, head of corporate communications at Nikko Citigroup in Tokyo. No further details were available. The departure is the second change of senior managers at the unit since Citigroup bought 61 percent in April.

Australia agreed to stop using names like champagne and port as part of an accord with the European Union that helps protect the union’s wine industry by preserving traditional production methods and names. “The agreement safeguards the E.U.’s wine-labeling regime, gives full protection to E.U. geographical indications, including for wines intended to be exported, and includes a clear Australian commitment to protect E.U. traditional expressions,” the European Commission said. The agreement replaces an existing accord that dates from 1994 and provides for Australia to phase out the use of “a number of important E.U. names” within a year.

The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund in the world, said it would pay £13.8 million ($27 million) to set up a research institute at Oxford University. The funds, to be paid over five years, will create the Oxford-Man Institute of Quantitative Finance and endow a professorship. The initiative is a way for Man, which uses mathematical models to make investments, to find mathematicians, who have become increasingly scarce as students planning careers in hedge funds study business instead.

The country’s central bank cut the benchmark lending rate to a record low as a rally in Brazil’s currency holds inflation at an eight-year low. Policy makers, led by the bank’s president, Henrique Meirelles, 61, lowered the overnight lending rate by half a percentage point, to 12 percent.

A Long Island toddler drowned in a neighbor’s pool yesterday after wandering away from home, the Suffolk County police said. The boy, Anthony Muniz, 3, was reported missing by his mother, Denise Morrisette of Auborn Avenue, shortly after 9 a.m., the police said. After searching the neighborhood and knocking on doors, neighbors and Ms. Morrisette found the boy in a neighbor’s pool. The police said the in-ground pool had been properly fenced. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A Bronx man has been arrested and charged with six counts of robbery in connection with a series of robberies on subway trains, the police said yesterday. The man, Miguel Ortiz, 27, of Morris Avenue, was arrested about 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday after a woman exited a No. 2 train at the Wall Street Station and told a police officer that a man on the train had just stolen her necklace and pocketbook. When officers stopped the train at 14th Street, another woman told them that a man had just robbed her. After his arrest, the police said, Mr. Ortiz was also charged with robbing women on other trains and at 109th Street in Manhattan.

A city employee who was supposed to check the purity of New York City’s drinking water was charged in Federal District Court yesterday with making false entries in official water-monitoring records. The man, Nicholas Miritello, 44, of Wappingers Falls, is charged with four instances of recording test results in 2005 on the cloudiness of water that he had not actually tested, federal prosecutors said. If convicted, he faces a maximum of 20 years in prison. The Department of Environmental Protection, which runs the water system, has been under federal oversight since 2001 because of similar record-keeping irregularities and other violations of federal law.

Congestion pricing could help the Metropolitan Transportation Authority avoid fare increases, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg made his comments at a news conference at Pratt Institute the day after an analysis by the city’s Independent Budget Office showed that transit fares could go as high as $3 over the next three years. “Maybe congestion pricing would generate enough to help them for a long time and postpone a fare increase,” said Mr. Bloomberg, who has been pressuring Albany to approve his plan. “If you don’t give them another source of revenue, then the likelihood of less mass transit and higher fares is clearly there.”.

A detention hearing in Federal District Court for one of four men charged in a plot to blow up fuel lines at Kennedy Airport was postponed yesterday after the defendant, Russell Defreitas, 63, decided not to seek bail at this time, prosecutors said. A new hearing date was not set yesterday afternoon.

A woman who represented clients in Family Court without a license to practice law was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years’ probation. Law enforcement officials said that the woman, Natasha Riley, 44, represented at least seven clients, including minors seeking disposition of criminal charges and parents seeking child custody, charging $300 to $900 per court appearance. At one hearing, law enforcement officials said, Ms. Riley offered an objection couched in a barnyard epithet, raising the suspicions of the judge. Ms. Riley, who pleaded guilty to filing a false instrument, was also ordered to repay her clients $3,267.

Lawyers representing protesters who have sued the city, claiming they were improperly arrested during the 2004 Republican National Convention, do not have to reveal whether they provided confidential information about the case to the news media, a federal judge has ruled. On Tuesday, Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV of Federal District Court denied a motion by the Police Department to compel statements from the protesters’ lawyers, saying that the police first had to establish that the information, reported in The New York Times, did not come from sources within the department. The judge said that the information — documents that detail police intelligence gathering — were nonconfidential. Lawyers for the city said yesterday that they were reviewing the decision.

A man accused of standing by while his wife drove herself and their two young daughters off a 300-foot cliff last year at Bear Mountain State Park was sentenced yesterday in Rockland County Court to three years’ probation. The man, Victor K. Han, 35, left, who has since moved to Queens from Staten Island, pleaded guilty in March to child endangerment in connection with the crash. His children, Ariana and Etana, then 5 and 3, survived without major injuries; his wife, Hejin, 35, was killed. Mr. Han admitted in court that he knew his family was in danger when he stepped out of the minivan in the park last June 14. Just after he got out, his wife drove off the cliff.

The presidents of nine universities in New York City promised yesterday to cut greenhouse gas emissions from their campuses by 30 percent over the next 10 years. The pledges, made during a news conference at Pratt Institute, came in response to a challenge by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has set the same objectives for all city-owned buildings as part of his environmental sustainability plan for the city. According to a city study, buildings account for nearly 80 percent of the city’s greenhouse gas emissions, which have been linked to global warming. The participating schools are Barnard, Columbia, Cooper Union, all 23 campuses of the City University of New York, Fordham, New York University, Pratt, St. John’s University and the New School. Asked if the retrofits might require tuition increases, the president of one university said it was a possibility; others said they would seek other financing.
Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark will have to find a way to live with a powerful opponent in the State House for another four years.
Corrections: For the Record
The listing of lottery results on Monday misstated the dates the winning numbers were drawn. They were from June 3 and June 2, not May 3 and May 2.

An article yesterday about Sameh Khouzam, a man accused of murder who says he will be tortured if he is deported back to Egypt, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement who said there were extensive deliberations within the government about deporting Mr. Khouzam. He is Marc Raimondi, not Raimondo.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about a contest for YouTube viewers to choose a theme song for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign referred incorrectly to a Billy Joel song. The song, “New York State of Mind,” was on the album “Turnstiles”; the album is not named for the song.

The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about GlaxoSmithKline’s efforts to market its diabetes treatment Avandia to African-Americans, misstated the name of a television network that is typically used when marketers want to reach black audiences. It is Black Entertainment Television, or BET — not the Black Entertainment Network.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on May 26, about Home Depot, referred incorrectly to protesters at the company’s 2006 annual meeting for shareholders. A number of workers protested the compensation of Bob Nardelli, the chief executive at the time, but only one employee who attended — not several — wore a chicken suit as part of the demonstration.

An article on Saturday about a plan to return straying bison to Yellowstone National Park referred incorrectly in some copies to the type of animals from a herd north of the park that were found infected with brucellosis last month. They were cattle, not bison.

An article in Business Day on May 26 about Coca-Cola’s acquisition of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, misstated a financial result for Glaceau that is considered a crucial indicator of market value. The company had an estimated $350 million in sales, not earnings, in 2006.

An article in The Arts on May 29 about “Fallujah,” a play in London about the American attack in 2004 on the Iraqi city of that name, misidentified the nationality of a journalist whose account was one of those used for the script. The journalist, Dahr Jamail, is American, not Canadian. The article also referred incorrectly to another documentary play, with which “Fallujah” was contrasted. That play, “Guantánamo: ‘Honor Bound to Defend Freedom,’ ” was a full production; the actors did not sit on the stage and read scripts.

An article in The Arts on Monday about the Rock Bottom Remainders, a rock band of popular authors, misspelled the given name of a singer who performed with the band at Webster Hall on Friday night. She is Lesley Gore, not Leslie.

An article in some copies on May 11 about the arrest of a New York police officer on charges of killing his estranged girlfriend misspelled the name of a Queens restaurant where they had met in an effort to reconcile. It is the Kaieteur Restaurant & Sports Bar — not Kiteur.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Mark Harris, who wrote the baseball novel “Bang the Drum Slowly” and other books, gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the actor who played catcher Bruce Pearson in a 1956 television adaptation of that novel. He was Albert Salmi — not George Peppard, who played another ballplayer, Piney Woods, in the production. The obituary also misidentified a university at which Mr. Harris taught. It was Arizona State University, not the University of Arizona.

A report by the BBC in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday, about the intention of the British playwright Alan Ayckbourn to retire next year from his post as artistic director of the Stephen Joseph Theater in Scarborough, England, misstated the year he was knighted. It was 1997, not this year.
Roger Clemens threw batting practice Wednesday and seemed to have passed the final test before he rejoins the Yankees on Saturday against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Wu Bangguo, the chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress, said at a conference in Beijing that Hong Kong had considerable autonomy only because the central government had chosen to authorize that autonomy. Under the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984, China promised Britain that as part of the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule China would preserve “a high degree of autonomy” for the territory. But Chinese officials focus these days on the Basic Law, a Beijing-drafted document that serves as Hong Kong’s mini-constitution and gives broad powers to the Standing Committee in Beijing to set policy in Hong Kong by interpreting the territory’s laws. Mr. Wu spoke ahead of the 10th anniversary on July 1 of Hong Kong’s return to China.

The police went on alert for a possible terrorist attack a day after the Basque separatist group ETA announced the end of a 15-month cease-fire, and the government stepped up actions against the group. José Ignacio de Juana Chaos, a convicted ETA killer who traded prison for a Basque hospital this year after a hunger strike and expected house arrest, was transferred back to a Madrid prison under a heavy police escort. Meanwhile, The Guardian reported that Judge Baltasar Garzón refused to give Arnaldo Otegi and Pernando Barrena, leaders of the banned separatist party Batasuna, permission to travel to a conference in South Africa. According to the report, the judge said the trip by the two men, who are being investigated for helping to finance ETA, might have “negative effects” on the investigation.

A court in Rome acquitted five people accused of conspiring to murder Roberto Calvi, who was president of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Italy’s largest private banks, and a financial adviser to the Vatican when he was found hanged under Blackfriars Bridge in London in 1982, his pockets stuffed with rocks, bricks and cash. The presiding judge cited a lack of evidence. The defendants included Giuseppe Caló, known as the Mafia’s “treasurer.” Prosecutors argued that Mr. Calvi, known as “God’s banker” because of his Vatican connections, was killed for stealing Mafia money he was supposed to launder. His death was at first ruled a suicide, but the case was reopened in 2003 as a murder inquiry. With yesterday’s court ruling, it remains unsolved.

Edinburgh University in Scotland stripped President Robert G. Mugabe of the honorary degree it awarded him in 1984 for “services to education in Africa” after reviewing evidence of a tribal massacre by soldiers soon after he took power. The unanimous decision by the university’s Senate was on the recommendation of three senior professors who reviewed events in Zimbabwe in the early 1980s, including the massacre of at least 20,000 civilians in Matabeleland, which the university says was not available when the degree was conferred. Mr. Mugabe is to be told of the decision in writing and asked to return the degree. Prime Minister Tony Blair told the House of Commons that he “fully endorsed” the decision to revoke the degree.

The police stopped Budhia Singh, the 5-year-old whose long-distance running set off an outcry from rights activists last year, from setting off on a 60-mile “walkathon” in scorching heat. Dozens of police officers blocked a road in Bhunbaneshwar, in Orissa State, preventing the boy from beginning the 10-day trek to Calcutta. Last year, the Orissa government barred him from running until he was older. Singh’s mother, his coach and nearly 50 supporters argued with the police over the action yesterday, then began a sit-in protest on the road.

Muhammad is now the second most popular name for baby boys in Britain, outstripped only by Jack, The Times of London reported. It said it based its conclusion on an analysis of 3,000 names provided by the Office for National Statistics for births in 2006 and had taken into account 14 different spellings for the name. Using the spelling Muhammad in its article, the newspaper said that the popularity of the name came from the growing number of young Muslim couples having families. Many of these parents chose the name of the prophet in order to show a solidarity with their religion, the newspaper said. According to the Times analysis, Muhammad (5,991) could outscore Jack (6,928) by the end of this year if the name’s current rate of popularity continued. The names Thomas and Joshua followed Muhammad closely in third and fourth places. No other Muslim names showed up in the list of 20 names published by the newspaper.

Ötzi, the Neolithic iceman whose well-preserved body was found in the Alps in 1991, bled to death after being hit in the back by an arrow, Swiss scientists said. The arrowhead itself had already been found, but new CAT scans show that it cut an artery, causing internal bleeding, according to Frank J. Rühli of the Anatomy Institute of Zurich University. “A lesion of an artery close to the shoulder has been found, thanks to a CAT scan,” he said.

Costa Rica has switched its alliance from Taiwan to China and established full diplomatic relations with Beijing, the Xinhua News Agency reported. The switch leaves Taiwan with 24 allies, mostly small and poor nations, compared with more than 170 countries that recognize Beijing.

One of the 29 defendants in the Madrid train bombings trial has been cleared of all charges and is a free man, CNN reported on its Web site, citing his lawyer and a court spokeswoman. It said prosecutors had dropped all charges against the Moroccan-born defendant, Brahim Moussaten, 23, for lack of evidence. He was accused of having helped two suspects escape after the 2004 attacks, one who is now a defendant in the trial and another who is believed to have died in Iraq as a suicide bomber. Mr. Moussaten’s brother and an uncle remain on trial.

NEW HAVEN, June 6 (AP) — Federal agents arrested 29 illegal immigrants in a raid on Wednesday, government officials said, two days after the city approved a program to make municipal identification cards available to illegal immigrants.
The quirky Islanders conceded perhaps their biggest business blunder in franchise history Wednesday when they gave up on Alexei Yashin, buying out the last four years of his 10-year contract.
It was about lunchtime yesterday when Eugene Kaplun stood in front of a pizzeria in Brooklyn, not believing what he was seeing. He read the yellow sign. He read the brown sign. Neither was a menu.
Rarely are the tradeoffs between campaign donations and official favors quite as obvious as in the Coconut Road case.
The State Department has acknowledged long delays from “unprecedented demand” after new rules requiring passports for travelers returning from Mexico, Canada and the Caribbean.
The nearly 20 million homes that rely on rabbit ears for reception will receive as much as $80 to move to digital.
Automakers seem to be making progress in tamping down Democratic proposals for tougher fuel economy requirements.
The stock market tumbled for a second day over fears that inflation is not settling down enough to satisfy the Federal Reserve.
The regular session adjourned just after midnight Thursday and it was still unclear how far budget talks had progressed or even when they would begin again.
In a Senate hearing, Andrew Speaker contradicted some accounts by government officials about the timing of who knew what and when about his plans to travel abroad.
Coca-Cola is hoping its new mobile site for social networking, Sprite Yard, will become the MySpace of the cellphone world.
A business acquaintance of the girl’s stepfather faced charges, along with two women who lived with him in the house where the girl was found.

The board that oversees the city’s Department of Correction has put off a final vote on changes to the rules governing the daily lives of city inmates — the most significant changes since 1978 — after an outcry by the City Bar Association, the Legal Aid Society and other groups that have called the changes draconian and inhumane.
The seven common diseases are bipolar disorder, coronary artery disease, Crohn’s disease, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, and Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes.
If all goes as projected, Mike Moustakas and Matt Dominguez will both be drafted in the first round Thursday, making Chatsworth High School the official capital of prep baseball.
Russia and the United States on Wednesday appeared to step back from their confrontation over American plans for installations in Europe relating to a missile shield.
Women’s Wear Daily has become the latest newspaper to sell advertising space on its front page.
Several thousand protesters clashed with riot police officers on the first day of the Group of 8 meeting in northern Germany.
The National Park Service has demanded that the owner of the land where United Flight 93 crashed remove a box erected to receive donations.
Fendi settled a lawsuit against Wal-Mart that contended the retailer had sold counterfeit handbags and wallets in its Sam’s Club stores.

Jim Clark was the former sheriff in Selma, Ala., whose violent, highly public attempts to maintain the status quo there in the Jim Crow era are widely believed to have contributed to the success of the voting rights movement.
The Bancroft family is trying to come up with a stronger system for keeping the newsroom independent of Rupert Murdoch.
The Patriots’ decision to acquire Randy Moss, one of the N.F.L.’s most electrifying but enigmatic players, is perhaps pro football’s most intriguing off-season move.
Maybe this country can make undocumented life so miserable as to extinguish all hope in an immigrant’s heart.
Victor M. De Leon III — known to rivals and fans as Lil’ Poison — is thought to be the youngest pro gamer.
Documents show that an executive of a prominent conservative legal group offered the Bush administration a recommendation for one replacement candidate for a dismissed U.S. attorney.
The debate over same-sex marriage has catapulted to a new level in Connecticut.
The timing is ripe for Nancy Pelosi to offer Congress the strongest possible proposal for the creation of an independent office to oversee ethics enforcement.
Each of the 32 victims killed in the Virginia Tech massacre will be honored with a $100,000 endowment fund and their families will decide how the money will be used, the university said.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said that disagreements between the U.S. and France should not overshadow what the two nations had in common.
The decision dealt a major setback to opponents of the $4 billion project.
The head of a Republican environmental advocacy group was charged with tax evasion and obstructing a Senate inquiry as part of the Jack Abramoff corruption investigation.
pro football.
Four public housing duplexes are opening in the devastated Upper Ninth Ward of New Orleans.
The police have closed an inquiry into the mauling death of a zookeeper at the Denver Zoo, clearing the zoo of criminal wrongdoing.
A federal judge has extended a stay of deportation for Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian Coptic Christian who faces repatriation for a murder charge in Egypt.
The challenge for leaders of the world’s richest and most powerful nations at this week’s Group of 8 gathering is to back up past declarations with effective action.
Reports emerged late in the day suggesting that Turkish forces had begun a long-threatened incursion into northern Iraq to hunt Kurdish guerrillas.
The meeting was postponed largely over what appeared to be the issue of the conditions under which Israel would turn over tax revenues it collects for the Palestinians.
After seven horses were entered Wednesday for Saturday’s Belmont, Curlin was installed as the 6-5 morning-line favorite, reflective of his status as the nation’s top 3-year-old.
Citigroup will pay $15.2 million to settle claims that its brokers had coaxed BellSouth employees into retiring early on exaggerated projections for investment returns.
Robert B. Asher, a Republican national committeeman who has worked on several major statewide campaigns, was convicted in 1986 of bribery-related charges.
Former Representative Jim Kolbe said that Justice Department investigators found no wrongdoing and have closed their inquiry.
The Bush administration wants better information from inventors and to allow public scrutiny of applications.
As part of the settlement, UBS will withdraw its claim for about $5 million against Enron.
The White House said it would hold firm against concrete long-term targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Tony Finau, a long hitter off the tee who won the 2006 Utah State Amateur title, is one of countless golfers opting to start a career at a young age instead of competing in college.
Architects of the legislation said they hoped they would gain support for a motion to end debate on the legislation.
Carlos Zambrano controlled his temper and his pitches.
The Spurs have three crisp championship banners and a cast of role players who have been there and done that, then done it again. The Cavaliers have LeBron James.
The network reversed course and announced that it had ordered seven new episodes for broadcast late this year or early in 2008.
Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said that he was broadening his investigation to examine whether the criteria lenders use when making loans violate civil rights statutes.
Donald Thomas won the N.C.A.A. indoor title in March, and came to the Division I outdoor championships as the college leader this season at 7-8 and the co-world leader with Aike Onnen of Germany.
If Tompkins Square Park is the living room of the East Village, then the crossroads of East Seventh Street and Avenue A is its front stoop.
A new approach for producing embryonic stem cells faces considerable hurdles, executives from stem cell companies said.
A medical researcher who testified at a House hearing about the safety of the popular diabetes drug, Avandia, said he received the veiled threat of a lawsuit by a high-ranking drug company executive.
Prosecutors said that the teacher clicked on pornographic Web sites and failed to prevent children from seeing pornography that appeared on her classroom’s computer screen.
The architect Frank Gehry is designing a new playground for Battery Park.
A confidential document provided to The Times provides a glimpse of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s successes and failures in fund-raising.
The decisions were a clear indication of how much the new primary calendar is upending  politics.
A burgeoning corruption scandal has suddenly thrust the bosses of the billion-dollar industry known as “the animal game” into an uncomfortable spotlight.
The grant will allow the schools to pay annual performance bonuses of up to $8,000 for school supervisors, $6,000 for teachers and $2,000 for aides.
The latest crackdown comes before a protest planned this week against new government curbs on the news media, a government official acknowledged Wednesday.
Fierce winds and torrential rains forced thousands of people from their homes and shut down oil installations.
Iran says that the United States is using intellectuals and others to carry out a “soft revolution” to topple the Islamic state in Iran.
Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has declared the crisis in Darfur his international priority, and ambassadors from the 15 Security Council countries will visit Sudan this month.
The publisher Steve Ross has been named president and publisher at HarperCollins.
The former media baron lost his motion to recall the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler.
James Deakin was a longtime White House correspondent for The St. Louis Post-Dispatch whose critical reporting put him on President Richard M. Nixon’s “enemies list.”
The man, who was not identified, was questioned by the Vatican police and taken to a psychiatric institution for evaluation.
Now two years old, a police search engine has evolved into one of the department’s most potent crime-fighting tools.
The rollout of London’s new logo for the 2012 Olympics, which has become front-page news, has not been an unalloyed triumph.
Annika Sorenstam lost her No. 1 L.P.G.A. world ranking to Lorena Ochoa after two injured disks in her neck cost her playing time and disrupted her usual ferocious fitness routine.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,485 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
Zakia Zaki was the director of a private local radio station. She was shot seven times as she slept beside her 10-month-old baby.
Six human rights groups released a list of 39 people they believe have been secretly imprisoned by the U.S.
When it comes to high-profile presidential pardons, the big one, of course, was President Gerald R. Ford’s pardon of Richard M. Nixon.
Martin Meyerson was a former president of the University of Pennsylvania and the State University of New York at Buffalo.
Sudanese lawyers are looking ahead to the day when victims of mass rape and torture seek justice in tribunals like the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
Steven C. Preston, the administrator of the Small Business Administration, discusses his efforts and those of Congress to reform the agency.
The Miami-Dade County school board said the book painted too rosy a picture of life in Cuba and removed it from elementary school libraries.
Arnold Lappert was the Army radio technician in Hawaii who received the last messages from the island of Corregidor before its surrender to the Japanese in May 1942.
Elections in the Middle East, it appears, have increasingly become a tool used by authoritarian leaders to claim legitimacy.
The fat phone book, a fixture of the urban American household in the last century, is losing some of its girth as more people give up their land lines for cellphones.
About 420 people will be laid off, with most of the cuts coming in New York. International offices will also close.
Guitar makers are rethinking the notion that there is an inexhaustible supply of wood to make their instruments.
An American defeat in Iraq would throw the entire Middle East into even greater upheaval.
Take judicial compensation out of politics in New York State.
The Yankees’ Jason Giambi created new problems for himself by indicating publicly that he had used steroids.

In his Glass House, America’s most public architect,  Philip Johnson, created an utterly transparent intimacy.
Women are embracing consumer electronics just as the technologies are reaching out to embrace them.
New York City settles an art dispute, changes are announced at the Vienna State Opera and more culture news.
Bill T. Jones’s choreography for the Broadway musical “Spring Awakening” is a perfect fit for a choreographer concerned with storytelling, the power of gesture and sexual identity.
The music industry may seem like a broken record of bad news these days. But in the concert business at least one corner is booming: clubs.

7 P.M. (Cartoon Network) CLASS OF 3000 André Benjamin, a k a André 3000 of the hip-hop group OutKast, lends his voice to Sunny Bridges in the second season of this vaguely autobiographical animated series about a star who gives up everything to teach a group of musical prodigies in Atlanta. In tonight’s episode the students decide to replace all their teachers with celebrities, since things are going so well with Sunny.
The highlight of the evening was a performance of Satie’s music to “Entr’acte,” Rene Clair’s brilliant (and still enjoyably trippy) 1924 silent Surrealist film.

What will a reported $200 million get you en route to the America’s Cup? For BMW Oracle, the American team owned by Larry Ellison, it got them “thumped” by Luna Rossa, the Italian team with more shallow pockets, says John Tayman, who wrote about the America’s Cup for this month’s issue of PLAY.

In this month’s issue of PLAY, Bryan Curtis argues that fans who play fantasy baseball are part of an intellectual revolution, having devised a way to interact with the game that doesn’t depend on watching the actual games for enjoyment.. At PLAY we’re wondering: How has fantasy baseball changed the relationship between fans and the game?.

While he continues to struggle in the pool with the new kicking technique that he learned at the Race Club Swim Camp, Jim Thornton says he’s found that the skill seems natural in open water. On Saturday, he will test that kick in competition for the first time during a two-mile open water swim in western Pennsylvania. As he wrote in this month’s issue of PLAY, his instructor at the camp in Islamorada, Fla., focused on five flaws in his freestyle stroke, providing some simple solutions like keeping his head down and back flat. “It’s amazing how often you have to remind yourself to do these things,” he says. Three weeks after the camp, and while fighting a nasty cold, Thornton, 54, swum his fastest 100-yard race in five years, a performance he called a “triumph over infirmity and petulance.” Thornton recommends the intensive instruction that specialized schools and camps provide. Even those new to the sport, he says, will benefit from learning the right techniques “before they’ve spent years practicing the wrong thing.”.
