SAINER--Janet. Council of Senior Centers and Services has lost a dear friend, mentor and visionary. As a longtime Board member, she set the standard to which we all aspire. We will miss her leadership, enthusiasm, wisdom, and grace. William Dionne, CSCS President Igal Jellinek, CSCS Executive Director $(6$)SAINER--Janet S. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of our former Board member, Mrs. Janet Sainer, a pioneer in the field of aging and intergenerational programs. Her service as a special consultant to the Brookdale Foundation has continued to enrich JDC's efforts on behalf of the elderly in Israel and around the world. A former Commissioner of the New York City Department for the Aging, the country's largest such area agency, Mrs. Sainer was a leader in the policy and practice of aging services for more than 50 years. A pilot program she developed early in her career led to the establishment of the national Retired and Senior Volunteer Program, and her unflagging activism in her own ''retirement'' years was the best evidence for the contribution she knew seniors could make to the world around them. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family, and may her memory be for a blessing. Judge Ellen M. Heller, President Eugene J. Ribakoff, Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager, Executive Vice-President $(6$)SAINER--Janet. With great sadness the NYC Department for the Aging mourns the passing of Janet Sainer. She was a true visionary in the field of aging. Janet Sainer served as Commissioner of the NYC Department for the Aging from 1978-1989. She was a tireless advocate for seniors and senior services until the time of her death. She kept a rigorous schedule advocating on behalf of seniors, grandparents and caregivers. Janet's tremendous legacy includes the creation of the nations first Alzheimer's Unit here at the Department, Citymeals - On Wheels, DFTA's intergenerational work study program, its Grandparent Resource Center, and the Retired Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP) for the Community Service Society. Janet's vision, spirit and legacy will live on through the programs she established at the department. Edwin Mendez-Santiago, LCSW, Commissioner $(6$)SAINER--Janet. The Aging in New York Fund mourns the passing of its founder and continuing mentor and board member, Janet Sainer. The matriarch of ANYF, Commissioner Sainer was a visionary leader and innovator in the field of aging services in New York City and throughout the country. Now in its 23rd year, ANYF derives its mission from Commissioner Sainer's vision for an organization dedicated to enhancing the quality of life for older New Yorkers and their families through public/private partnerships, seeking resources to develop innovative service models that address the unmet needs of New York City's elderly, caregivers and the network of aging service providers. Under Janet Sainer's tenure as Commissioner of the New York City Department for the Aging, ANYF sponsored the City's first annual Mayoral Conference on Alzheimers Disease and numerous initiatives focusing on the needs of personal and professional caregivers and it launched the first home delivered meals program and other activities that serve today as models in other parts of the country. From its inception, ANYF has benefited from Commissioner Sainer's guidance and wisdom. Its initiatives and programs on behalf of New York City's older adults are the enduring legacy of her enlightened inspiration and accomplishment. Allen B. Roberts Chairman Edwin Mendez-Santiago, LCSW, President Ali Hodin-Baier Executive Director $(6$)SAINER--Janet. The entire DOROT community mourns the loss of a beloved friend and a peerless advocate for the elderly. The author of numerous ground breaking programs benefiting the aged, Janet generously encouraged initiative in others. Her support of DOROT's Homelessness Prevention Program was especially welcome. We will miss her warmth, her vision and her passionate leadership, and express deepest condolences to her family. Paula Stamler Resnick and Philip Silverman, Co-Presidents Vivian Fenster Ehrlich, Executive Director

An article on Saturday about a plan to return straying bison to Yellowstone National Park referred incorrectly in some copies to the type of animals from a herd north of the park that were found infected with brucellosis last month. They were cattle, not bison.

A woman who represented clients in Family Court without a license to practice law was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years' probation. Law enforcement officials said that the woman, Natasha Riley, 44, represented at least seven clients, including minors seeking disposition of criminal charges and parents seeking child custody, charging $300 to $900 per court appearance. At one hearing, law enforcement officials said, Ms. Riley offered an objection couched in a barnyard epithet, raising the suspicions of the judge. Ms. Riley, who pleaded guilty to filing a false instrument, was also ordered to repay her clients $3,267. MICHAEL BRICK

AstraZeneca, Britain's second-largest drug maker after GlaxoSmithKline, said on Wednesday that its chief financial officer was leaving to join to Goldman Sachs just months after it paid $15.2 billion to buy MedImmune. Jon Symonds, who joined Zeneca from KPMG in 1997 and was instrumental to the $30 billion merger with Astra of Sweden a year later, will step down at the end of July and join Goldman Sachs, one of AstraZeneca's corporate brokers, as a managing director in London in September.

ACKERMAN--Florence , passed away peacefully on Wednesday, June 4, 2008 at the age of 94 years. Beloved wife of the late Morton Ackerman, daughter of Peter and Jenny Bess. She is survived by her daughter Pamela Cantor and son Richard Ackerman, their spouses Dick and Bobbi, her grandchildren Daniel and Hannah Rose, and her 14 great-grandchildren. She was loved and adored by all who knew her as a wife, proud mother, grandmother and great - grandmother, ''Auntie'', cousin and friend. She was an avid reader and critical thinker, with a brilliant, irreverent wit. She was elegant in every detail. Shiva will be observed on Sunday and Monday evening, 6:30pm at the home of Richard and Pamela Cantor, 14 East 75th, NYC.

GITHENS--Thomas Francis, age 79, of Point Pleasant, NJ died on Tuesday, June 5, 2007 after a 20 year, valiant fight with cancer. He was born in Cleveland Heights, OH and lived in Short Hills, NJ before moving to Point Pleasant in 1998. He was a graduate of Yale University and Columbia University. He was a veteran of the Korean War proudly serving his country in the US Army as a Lieutenant in the Third Infantry Artillery Division. He was employed for over 30 years as an Investment Banker and was a former partner at Morgan, Lewis, Githens & Ahn in New York City. He was a longtime member of The Yale Club, Bay Head Yacht Club and the Glen Meadows Golf Club. He was a parishioner of Sacred Heart R.C. Church in Bay Head, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Mary Alice (McNally) Githens; five sons, Thomas, William, Paul, David and John; a daughter, Suzanne; two sisters, Ann Masters and Marion Kuenhold; 13 grandchildren, John (J.P.), Brian, Paul, Ginger, Andrew, Thomas, David, Taylor, Nicole, Michael, Kimberly, Brooke and Caroline. Friends may call on Friday, 2-4 and 79pm at O'Brien Funeral Home -505 Burnt Tavern Rd., at Hwy. 70 in Brick. Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, 10 am at Sacred Heart R.C. Church in Bay Head. Burial will follow at St. Anne's Cemetery in Wall, NJ. Donations in lieu of flowers can be made in his honor to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. To send condolences, go to: www.obrienfuneralhome .com

GROSS--Susannah D., devoted mother of Seth and Stephanie Andrew, spent her life serving others. A memorial on Friday at 2pm will be held at Plaza Jewish Chapel with Shiva at 2pm on Sunday at 875 WEA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Democracy Prep Social Work Fund will memorialize her commitment to those in need.

A Long Island toddler drowned in a neighbor's pool yesterday after wandering away from home, the Suffolk County police said. The boy, Anthony Muniz, 3, was reported missing by his mother, Denise Morrisette of Auborn Avenue, shortly after 9 a.m., the police said. After searching the neighborhood and knocking on doors, neighbors and Ms. Morrisette found the boy in a neighbor's pool. The police said the in-ground pool had been properly fenced.

The Cleveland Cavaliers bumped into their first logistical challenge here Wednesday, on the eve of their first N.B.A. finals: Who takes the microphone at the league-mandated news conference? Traditionally, each team sends the coach and two star players to the main interview room. San Antonio Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich was followed on the dais, naturally, by Tony Parker and Tim Duncan. The Cavaliers had Coach Mike Brown and LeBron James and, well, then it got tricky.

A court in Rome acquitted five people accused of conspiring to murder Roberto Calvi, who was president of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Italy's largest private banks, and a financial adviser to the Vatican when he was found hanged under Blackfriars Bridge in London in 1982, his pockets stuffed with rocks, bricks and cash. The presiding judge cited a lack of evidence. The defendants included Giuseppe Caló, known as the Mafia's ''treasurer.'' Prosecutors argued that Mr. Calvi, known as ''God's banker'' because of his Vatican connections, was killed for stealing Mafia money he was supposed to launder. His death was at first ruled a suicide, but the case was reopened in 2003 as a murder inquiry. With yesterday's court ruling, it remains unsolved. PETER KIEFER

A Bronx man has been arrested and charged with six counts of robbery in connection with a series of robberies on subway trains, the police said yesterday. The man, Miguel Ortiz, 27, of Morris Avenue, was arrested about 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday after a woman exited a No. 2 train at the Wall Street Station and told a police officer that a man on the train had just stolen her necklace and pocketbook. When officers stopped the train at 14th Street, another woman told them that a man had just robbed her. After his arrest, the police said, Mr. Ortiz was also charged with robbing women on other trains and at 109th Street in Manhattan.

SHULMAN--Alice. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Alice Shulman and extends heartfelt sympathy to her husband Walter, and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Liz Kislik, President

When it comes to high-profile presidential pardons, the big one, of course, was President Gerald R. Ford's pardon of Richard M. Nixon. Ford issued the pardon on Sept. 8, 1974, pre-empting the possibility of a trial for Nixon, who had resigned on Aug. 9 because of the Watergate scandal without being charged with any crimes.

BURKE--Patricia A., of Glen Rock, NJ, died June 6, 2007. Beloved wife of Robert W. of Glen Rock (formerly Senior VP of Moody's Investors Service, Inc). Loving mother of Robert W. and James M. Services C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ.

LITT--Ann Selkowitz On May 30th, 2007, devoted wife and loving mother, Ann Selkowitz Litt, passed away suddenly. Ann was a nationally known nutritionist who helped children and adolescents with eating disorders and assisted developing athletes in reaching their full potential. Ann was the nutritionist for the Washington Redskins and spokesperson for several media campaigns including the Got Milk campaign. Recently, Ann was the nutrition consultant to CosmoGirl magazine 2007. Ann was the author of The College Students' Guide to Eating Well on Campus, Fuel for Young Athletes, and the ADA Guide to Private Practice. Ann frequently appeared on local and national television and was quoted by newspapers and magazines throughout the country. Ann was an avid golfer, skier, fitness enthusiast, and adventurer. Her warmth, kindness and beauty will be missed by her family, friends and all who knew her. Ann grew up in Perth Amboy, New Jersey, and lived in Bethesda, Maryland. She is survived by her devoted husband, Daniel M. Litt; her beloved sons, David L. Litt of New York City, and Jordan M. Litt of Bethesda; daughter of Lenore and Lawrence Kohn of Boca Raton, Florida, and the late Donald Selkowitz; sister of Marsha Brower of Boca Raton; sister-in-law of Lori and Joseph Roth of Morris Plains, New Jersey, and Debbie and Rick Litt of Stamford, Connecticut; aunt of Robert, Shira, and Jonathan Roth, and Jeffrey and Kenneth Litt. Contributions can be made to the Ann Selkowitz Litt Memorial Fund, National Eating Disorders Association, 603 Stewart Street, Suite 803, Seattle, WA 98101, or online at www. nationaleatingdisorders.org

Five days after senior Justice Department officials gave the White House the first official list of possible United States attorneys to be dismissed, an executive of a conservative legal group offered the Bush administration a recommendation for one replacement candidate, documents released Wednesday show. Leonard A. Leo, the executive vice president of the Federalist Society, e-mailed the recommendation on March 7, 2005, to the Justice Department official in charge of the office that supervised the attorneys.

Lawyers representing protesters who have sued the city, claiming they were improperly arrested during the 2004 Republican National Convention, do not have to reveal whether they provided confidential information about the case to the news media, a federal judge has ruled. On Tuesday, Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV of Federal District Court denied a motion by the Police Department to compel statements from the protesters' lawyers, saying that the police first had to establish that the information, reported in The New York Times, did not come from sources within the department. The judge said that the information -- documents that detail police intelligence gathering -- were nonconfidential. Lawyers for the city said yesterday that they were reviewing the decision.

BECKHARDT--Clare , died peacefully on June 5, 2008 after a long illness at the age of 77. Beloved wife of Fred, sister of George and Nancy, loving mother of Seth and Meredith and Laurence and Aimee, adoring grandmother of Molly, Deanna, Layla and Joshua. A dedicated environmentalist and builder of parks in NYC. As Regional Director of the NYS Office of Parks and Recreation, she was responsible for the creation of Riverbank State Park in Manhattan, Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park in Brooklyn, and the Clay Pit State Park and Nature Preserve on Staten Island. She was an outgoing person who will be missed by all. Contributions in her memory may be made to the NYC Council on the Environment or High School of Environmental Studies. Service Sunday 2:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel on West 76th St. and Amsterdam.
To the Editor: Re ''Libby Given 30 Months for Lying in C.I.A. Leak Case'' (front page, June 6): I. Lewis Libby Jr. sentenced to 30 months: justice delivered!

Applying a new genomic technique to a large group of patients, researchers in Britain have detected DNA variations that underlie seven common diseases, discovering unexpected links between them. The variations pinpoint biological pathways underlying each of the diseases, and researchers hope that as the pathways are analyzed, new drugs and treatments will emerge.

Predeceased by his wife Patricia, and sister Melissa Pell Thomson, he was the son of the late Edith Minturn Bonsal Pell and The Reverend Walden Pell II, and is survived by his daughters Alison and Sarah; grandsons James, Sam and Grayson, and his sister Mary Leigh Whitmer. The service will be held Thursday, June 7th, at 3pm at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer Street, Princeton, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to Fort Ticonderoga Association, Inc., Box 390, Ticonderoga, NY 12883 or Trinity Church, Prinecton, NJ 08540.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about a contest for YouTube viewers to choose a theme song for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign referred incorrectly to a Billy Joel song. The song, ''New York State of Mind,'' was on the album ''Turnstiles''; the album is not named for the song.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Mark Harris, who wrote the baseball novel ''Bang the Drum Slowly'' and other books, gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the actor who played catcher Bruce Pearson in a 1956 television adaptation of that novel. He was Albert Salmi -- not George Peppard, who played another ballplayer, Piney Woods, in the production. The obituary also misidentified a university at which Mr. Harris taught. It was Arizona State University, not the University of Arizona.

The presidents of nine universities in New York City promised yesterday to cut greenhouse gas emissions from their campuses by 30 percent over the next 10 years. The pledges, made during a news conference at Pratt Institute, came in response to a challenge by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has set the same objectives for all city-owned buildings as part of his environmental sustainability plan for the city. According to a city study, buildings account for nearly 80 percent of the city's greenhouse gas emissions, which have been linked to global warming. The participating schools are Barnard, Columbia, Cooper Union, all 23 campuses of the City University of New York, Fordham, New York University, Pratt, St. John's University and the New School. Asked if the retrofits might require tuition increases, the president of one university said it was a possibility; others said they would seek other financing. RAY RIVERA

This week R. Kelly, below, continues his winning streak on the Billboard chart, as his new album, ''Double Up'' (Jive), opens at No. 1 with 386,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Of Mr. Kelly's 11 studio albums, each of the last 10 has reached the top two spots on the chart. Last week's chart-topper, Maroon 5's ''It Won't Be Soon Before Long'' (Octone/Interscope), fell to No. 2 with 172,000 copies sold, a 60 percent drop in sales from its first week. Linkin Park's ''Minutes to Midnight'' (Warner Brothers) also slipped one rung, to No. 3; it sold 126,000 copies, a 36 percent drop in its third week of release. Besides R. Kelly's album, the only other new release to reach the Top 20 is ''Relentless'' (Broken Bow), by the country singer Jason Aldean. It sold 98,000, bowing at No. 4. The British singer Amy Winehouse has been climbing the charts steadily since her album ''Back to Black'' (Universal) was released here in March, and last week it made a leap into the Top 10, climbing five slots to No. 6. BEN SISARIO

Ötzi, the Neolithic iceman whose well-preserved body was found in the Alps in 1991, bled to death after being hit in the back by an arrow, Swiss scientists said. The arrowhead itself had already been found, but new CAT scans show that it cut an artery, causing internal bleeding, according to Frank J. Rühli of the Anatomy Institute of Zurich University. ''A lesion of an artery close to the shoulder has been found, thanks to a CAT scan,'' he said. JOHN TAGLIABUE

2 Republican Candidates Say No to Iowa Straw Poll Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain said they would skip what has been an early test of candidate strength, this summer's straw poll in Ames, Iowa. Their decision was an indication of how much the changing primary calendar has upended presidential politics as candidates grapple with the prospect of primaries in crucial states like Florida on Jan. 29 and California, New York and Texas a week later. The Anaheim Ducks got their Disney ending after all. They were named 14 years ago for a children's movie. Their uniform colors were eggplant and jade. They had more mascots than any team in the history of sports. An animated Tinkerbell danced on the scoreboard after goals, sprinkling imaginary pixie dust.

An article yesterday about Sameh Khouzam, a man accused of murder who says he will be tortured if he is deported back to Egypt, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement who said there were extensive deliberations within the government about deporting Mr. Khouzam. He is Marc Raimondi, not Raimondo.

An article in Business Day on May 26 about Coca-Cola's acquisition of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, misstated a financial result for Glaceau that is considered a crucial indicator of market value. The company had an estimated $350 million in sales, not earnings, in 2006.

SPERLING--Irving Leslie, M.D. , died June 4th, 2008 at age 93. Rheumatologist and WWII veteran, survived by wife Lillian, siblings Sandra and Seymour, children and grandchildren. Memorial service at Winchester Gardens, 333 Elmwood Ave., Maplewood, NJ, June 8, 11:30am.

One of the 29 defendants in the Madrid train bombings trial has been cleared of all charges and is a free man, CNN reported on its Web site, citing his lawyer and a court spokeswoman. It said prosecutors had dropped all charges against the Moroccan-born defendant, Brahim Moussaten, 23, for lack of evidence. He was accused of having helped two suspects escape after the 2004 attacks, one who is now a defendant in the trial and another who is believed to have died in Iraq as a suicide bomber. Mr. Moussaten's brother and an uncle remain on trial.

PASTON--Gary . The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member, former Board Member and Charity Chairman, Gary Paston. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Ted Tashlik, President
To the Editor: Re ''Edwards, Clinton and Obama Describe Journeys of Faith'' (news article, June 5):

The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about GlaxoSmithKline's efforts to market its diabetes treatment Avandia to African-Americans, misstated the name of a television network that is typically used when marketers want to reach black audiences. It is Black Entertainment Television, or BET -- not the Black Entertainment Network.

Survived by his wife Jane, brother Joel, children David, Brad, Lauren Primoff, Ellen Blasi and four grandchildren.

SZLACHTER--Morris. The Claremont Preparatory School community is deeply saddened by the death of Morris Szlachter, beloved father of our headmaster, Irwin Shlachter. Morris was a wonderful husband for 59 years to his late wife Frida, as well as a dedicated father to Irwin Shlachter and Celia Kessel. He is also survived by his daughter-in-law, Renee and son-in-law, Shlomo; and his grandchildren, Jordan and Adam Shlachter and Tamar and Sarit Kessel. Morris was a Holocaust survivor and hero who helped save the lives of six others during World War II. He will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Claremont Prep Association

To the Editor: The fine F.C.C. commissioner Michael J. Copps (''The Price of Free Airwaves,'' Op-Ed, June 2) argues that broadcasters, in return for their longtime free use of the public airwaves, should be required, as a condition of their license renewal, to serve the public interest in worthy programming.
The listing of lottery results on Monday misstated the dates the winning numbers were drawn. They were from June 3 and June 2, not May 3 and May 2.

A city employee who was supposed to check the purity of New York City's drinking water was charged in Federal District Court yesterday with making false entries in official water-monitoring records. The man, Nicholas Miritello, 44, of Wappingers Falls, is charged with four instances of recording test results in 2005 on the cloudiness of water that he had not actually tested, federal prosecutors said. If convicted, he faces a maximum of 20 years in prison. The Department of Environmental Protection, which runs the water system, has been under federal oversight since 2001 because of similar record-keeping irregularities and other violations of federal law. ANTHONY DEPALMA

To the Editor: Re ''Company for an Only Child, and for Parents, Peace of Mind'' (news article, June 3): You write that parents of only children fear the persistent stigma in spite of studies that find that only children turn out fine. In collecting personal stories by only children, we found that for every only child who was ever lonely, there is another who is ambivalent about depriving his multiple children of the joys of being ''the one.''

RAFEL--Ellen . Surrounded by family and friends, Ellen Rafel, 63, passed away on June 5, 2008. Serving children of NYC's Public Schools for over three decades, she was chosen by her peers ''Guidance Counselor of the Year'' three times. Paraphrasing Ted Kennedy, to Ellen love meant having a social conscience and battling the wrongs which needed our attention. Each time we act to improve the life of others, or strike out against injustice, we send forth a tiny ripple of hope. Ellen sent out lots of ripples. She was a good and decent woman, who saw wrong and tried to right it, saw suffering and tried to heal it. She will be remembered by her husband, Erwin Rafel-Frankel; sons, Gideon and Saul; sister, Judy Englander; nieces, Freya and Emily; grandnephew and niece, Nathan and Ruby and dear family and friends. Funeral services will take place Sunday, June 8, 10am at Temple Anshe Chesed, West End Avenue and 100th Street. May her memory, like her life be for a blessing.
RAPTOPOULOS--Kit . Loving sister of Bette. Her forty day memorial will be held on Sunday, June 8, 2008 at 10am at St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church, 179th Street and Wadsworth Avenue, NYC.

Roger Clemens threw batting practice Wednesday in Tampa, Fla., and he seemed to have passed the final test before he rejoins the Yankees on Saturday against the Pittsburgh Pirates. ''He is feeling good,'' said Manager Joe Torre, who spoke with Clemens. ''He did a sort of simulated batting practice with the screen in front of it. He said in his estimation, it was better than a side day; he got more out of it. Everything is all systems go for Saturday.''

ZWAIK--Anne Lehman , died June 5 at 89 years old. Adored wife of Stanley N. Zwaik (deceased). Anne was a loving mother, grandmother, sisterin-law and aunt. Her greatest joy was to be surrounded by her beloved daughters, Judith (David) Tarlo and Stephanie (Dan Powers) Greenberg and grandchildren Howard (Toni) and Joseph (Maggie Williams), Andrew (Danielle) and Dori. A graduate of Hunter College, Anne was accomplished in her work for the U.S. Department of the Navy and as an elementary school teacher. Her happiest times were when she stepped aside so those she loved could shine brightly. She left us with dignity and eternal love. Since December 2006, Anne lived at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale where she was surrounded by love and caring hands for which her family will be forever grateful. Funeral services will be held 11:30am Sunday June 8 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations in Anne's name may be sent to The Hebrew Home, Development Office, 5901 Palisade Ave., Riverdale, NY 10471

The Austrian government said yesterday it had appointed Dominique Meyer, the director of the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in Paris, to lead the Vienna State Opera starting in the 2010-11 season. Joining him then as music director will be the Austrian Franz Welser-Möst, who holds the same position with the Cleveland Orchestra. Mr. Welser-Möst, who is also music director of the Zurich Opera, will succeed Seiji Ozawa. Mr. Meyer, 51, will replace Ioan Holender, the long-serving director of the house, who has said that he will not renew his contract. The succession became embroiled in politics when the Austrian chancellor and opera fan Alfred Gusenbauer was perceived as lobbying for his favorite, the American opera singer Neil Shicoff. The appointment was announced by Claudia Schmied, the culture minister, who oversees the opera house. Mr. Meyer has been at the Paris theater since 1999. He is a past director general of the Lausanne and Paris National operas and has held a number of government posts. DANIEL J. WAKIN

A report by the BBC in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column yesterday, about the intention of the British playwright Alan Ayckbourn to retire next year from his post as artistic director of the Stephen Joseph Theater in Scarborough, England, misstated the year he was knighted. It was 1997, not this year.

Good buys abound during Shop the Block, an annual event that takes place today from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., on 53rd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. The four museum shops on the street -- the two MoMA stores, the shop at the Museum of Arts and Design and the American Folk Art Museum store -- are giving 20 percent discounts on all merchandise to anyone who is a member of any of the museums. In addition, Alice Pickett-Lewis, a rug weaver, will demonstrate her craft on a loom set up outside the American Folk Art Museum. Ms. Pickett-Lewis's colorful cotton rugs, above, which are sold at the museum store, are made from excess material from clothing manufacturers, and come in assorted colors and sizes. They start at $58 for a two-by-three-foot carpet. For information: (212) 265-1040. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

The city has settled a federal lawsuit by 18 former Brooklyn College graduate art students and their teacher that charged that the city violated their free speech rights, awarding them $750 each, $42,500 in fees to their three lawyers and issuing a letter of apology. Details of the settlement were released yesterday by Norman Siegel, a lawyer for the students, and by Jonathan Pines, an assistant corporation counsel. ''The lesson here is that the government is not the appropriate body to judge the value of art work,'' Mr. Siegel said. The suit, filed in district court in Brooklyn last June, claimed that the students' First Amendment rights were violated and their work damaged last May when their thesis exhibition was ordered closed by the Brooklyn parks commissioner, Julius Spiegel. Mr. Spiegel wrote the letter of apology, after saying at the time that some of the artwork was inappropriate for families. A live rat and a sculpture of a hand holding a penis were in the show, in a World War II Memorial hall near the Brooklyn Bridge. FELICIA R. LEE

An article in The Arts on Monday about the Rock Bottom Remainders, a rock band of popular authors, misspelled the given name of a singer who performed with the band at Webster Hall on Friday night. She is Lesley Gore, not Leslie.

The Lotus Sanitizing System ($149.99) claims to oxygenate water, turning it into a natural cleanser. At 11 by 14 inches, it may be the bulkiest object on your counter, but the premise is neat: press a button and presto! Oxygenated water, which sucks up bacteria because it has a third oxygen molecule. It had no effect on the mystery stains on my carpet, but on the bathtub it seemed to work as well as Ajax. To test its other application -- nuking the scary things on your food -- I tipped a pint of strawberries into its bowl attachment and let it whir. But how can you tell it's working? Steve Hengsperger, president of Tersano, the company that makes Lotus, pointed me to a number on the box. ''That number is the E.P.A.'s approval of the device as a sanitizer,'' he said. ''Lysol has the same thing.'' Without the nose-singeing smell of bleach or Lysol, it's leap-of-faith territory, but the idea of never buying another bottle of Fantastik or Clorox is appealing. Information: tersano.com. PENELOPE GREEN

As the state legislature prepared to end its regular lawmaking session on Wednesday, there were times when the political leaders could not even agree to disagree. After months of wrangling, the governor, M. Jodi Rell, a Republican, and Democratic legislative leaders were still at loggerheads over the state budget Wednesday night, making it all but certain that a special session would be needed in the coming weeks.

There will be six colts and one filly in Saturday's 139th running of the Belmont Stakes, and it's the filly, the highly rated Rags to Riches, who will be providing much of the intrigue as the 3-1 third choice. New York Racing Association oddsmaker Eric Donovan set the morning-line odds for the race; Joe Drape lists the horses in order of preference and provided the comments. PURSE: $1 million guaranteed DISTANCE: 1 1/2 miles TRACK RECORD: 2:24 (Secretariat, 1973) POST TIME: 6:33 P.M. Eastern WEIGHT: 126 pounds* TELEVISION: ABC, 5-7 P.M. *All horses carry 126 pounds, except Rags to Riches, who carries 121. POST: 6 HORSE: Hard Spun TRAINER: Larry Jones JOCKEY: Garrett Gomez ODDS: 5-2 The runner-up in the Derby and the third-place finisher in the Preakness, Hard Spun finally gets to set the moderate pace he wants and will gallop away from this field. POST: 3 HORSE: Curlin TRAINER: Steve Asmussen JOCKEY: Robby Albarado ODDS: 6-5 The Preakness champ is ultratalented, but he has done a lot in very little time and it will catch up to him in the last quarter of a mile. POST: 7 HORSE: Rags to Riches TRAINER: Todd Pletcher JOCKEY: John Velazquez ODDS: 3-1 This filly is trying to do what only 2 of 21 others have done in the history of this race, which is to beat the boys. But Hard Spun and Curlin are too good. POST: 5 HORSE: Slew's Tizzy TRAINER: Greg Fox JOCKEY: Rafael Bejarano ODDS: 20-1 Victories in the Lone Star Derby, and Lexington Stakes suggest he is improving, but this race is simply too long for this colt. POST: 2 HORSE: Tiago TRAINER: John Shirreffs JOCKEY: Mike Smith ODDS: 10-1 He finished seventh in the Derby, and will be flying late here -- but not fast enough to make a difference. POST: 1 HORSE: Imawildandcrazyguy TRAINER: Bill Kaplan JOCKEY: Mark Guidry ODDS: 20-1 The Derby's fourth-place finisher will also come from the clouds. And again it will not matter. POST: 4 HORSE: C P West TRAINER: Nick Zito JOCKEY: Edgar Prado ODDS: 12-1 He has won once in six attempts, and is not bred at all for this grueling marathon.

President Bush has pardoned 113 people during his presidency, including a Tennessee bootlegger and a Mississippi odometer cheat. But none has drawn the public scrutiny, nor posed the same political challenge, as the candidate that many conservatives hope will be Bush presidential pardon No. 114: I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, who was convicted of lying to investigators in the C.I.A. leak case and sentenced Tuesday to 30 months in prison.

Front, the Swedish collective named Designer of the Future for Design Miami/Basel 2007, will introduce its new Magical! furniture at the fair, which begins Tuesday in Basel, Switzerland. The collection includes the Balancing chair, below left, which appears to defy gravity by resting on a single leg, although when you sit on it all four legs touch the ground. (The secret lies in the plate of steel anchoring the chair to the floor, connected to the leg with a spring; because it is shaped like the chair's shadow, your eye passes over it.) The Levitating lamp, below right, has a shade that seems to float in mid-air. (It actually hangs from the ceiling on thin wire; the light comes from a bulb in the top of the base.) For information on other exhibitions at the fair, which runs through June 16: designmiami.com. ELAINE LOUIE

The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund in the world, said it would pay £13.8 million ($27 million) to set up a research institute at Oxford University. The funds, to be paid over five years, will create the Oxford-Man Institute of Quantitative Finance and endow a professorship. The initiative is a way for Man, which uses mathematical models to make investments, to find mathematicians, who have become increasingly scarce as students planning careers in hedge funds study business instead. JULIA WERDIGIER

ADAMS--D. Nelson. The National Hypertension Association express great sadness upon the death of D. Nelson Adams, beloved and revered Trustee. $(6$)ADAMS--D. Nelson. The Board and staff of the Youth Counseling League, a division of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, acknowledge with sadness the death of Nelson Adams, esteemed lawyer, devoted philanthropist and husband of the late Diana Adams. Among his many charitable activities, Nelson generously carried on the commitment of his beloved wife Diana to the work of the Youth Counseling League, which she served as president and longstanding trustee. John A Herrmann, President, JBFCS Mrs. Lewis Burke Frumkes Mrs. David Schiff Co-Chairs, Youth Conseling League Divisional Board Joan Adams, YCL Director

Changing of the Guard At the Phillips Collection Jay Gates, director of the Phillips Collection in Washington, announced retirement plans yesterday. He will leave when the board appoints a successor, probably next year. Mr. Gates made his announcement exactly nine years after becoming director of the collection, renowned for its Impressionist and Modern American and European Art. The Rolling Stones Jam the Roads Are the Rolling Stones popular in Belgium? A 30-mile traffic jam greeted the band at the start of its European tour in Werchter, Belgium, on Tuesday. While Mick Jagger was starting the performance with ''Start Me Up,'' some of the 33,000 fans were still making their way through the concert grounds after spending hours in the jam caused by the show and worsened by a nearby accident. Besides the big crowd and the big jam, the Stones' act got big praise from Belgium newspapers. Fiction Prizewinners Are Announced Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, above, of Nigeria was named the winner yesterday of the $60,000 Orange Broadband Prize for Fiction, and Karen Connelly of Canada the winner of the $20,000 Orange Broadband Award for New Writers. Ms. Adichie was honored for ''Half of a Yellow Sun'' (Fourth Estate) and Ms. Connelly for her novel ''The Lizard Cage'' (Harvill Secker). The awards were announced in London. Ms. Adichie's novel deals with lives caught up in war in Biafra in the 1960s. ''The Lizard Cage'' tells of a protest singer sentenced to 20 years in solitary confinement in Burma. Both prizes were established to celebrate and promote fiction written by women. Footnotes Matthew Ellinger and Michael Hallam have decided to cool it. The two men, involved in a fistfight that interrupted the Boston Pops' season-opening concert on May 9 at Symphony Hall in Boston, withdrew assault and battery complaints against each other at a closed-door hearing on Tuesday in Boston Municipal Court, The Associated Press reported. They will not face charges, a court official said. Walt Disney Studios, the Spider-Man creator Stan Lee and his production company POW! Entertainment have entered a multiyear agreement that will give the studios the first look at any entertainment developed and produced by Mr. Lee and his company. A Stradivarius violin valued at $2.7 million was returned to its owner yesterday, less than a week after it was stolen from the musician's apartment, Austrian authorities announced yesterday. The country's top security official, Interior Minister Günther Platter, personally handed over the violin to the owner, Christian Altenburger, in Vienna. The violin was recovered unscathed, and several members of a Georgian gang were arrested in connection with the theft.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on May 26, about Home Depot, referred incorrectly to protesters at the company's 2006 annual meeting for shareholders. A number of workers protested the compensation of Bob Nardelli, the chief executive at the time, but only one employee who attended -- not several -- wore a chicken suit as part of the demonstration.

EVANS--Charles. They're no friends like old friends. After 65 years, just 10 of us remain. We shall miss you Charley. The Century's $(6$)EVANS--Charles. Deepest sympathy to his wife Bonnie, sister Alice Shure, and the entire family. Bernie Weiss $(6$)EVANS--Charles. Beloved husband of Bonnie, loving father of Charles Jr. and the late Melissa and Elizabeth, sweet grandfather to Lily, adored brother of Robert and Alice, cherished uncle of Michael, Joshua, and Tony, and extraordinary friend to legions, passed away peacefully on June 2nd. As co-founder of Evan-Picone, he created one of Americas most recognized sportswear firms. He went on to form the Evans Partnership, a real estate development company, with his late brother-in-law Michael Shure. He was Executive Producer of the 1981 film Tootsie, after which he founded Charles Evans Productions, and went on to produce other films. He was National Director of the Alzheimer's Association and founded the Crusade for Fire Detection Ltd. Charles embraced life with passion all over the world. He will be missed by many people in many places. The family will be receiving friends at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday June 6 from 5-8pm. Services will be held Thursday June 7 at 12pm at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the following: The Alzheimer's Association care of Mark Hopkins 225 North Michigan Ave. Chicago, IL 60601, FDNY Foundation, 9 Metrotech Ctr. Room 5E-10 Brooklyn, NY 11201 Helping Hands, care of Robert Stern 541 Cambridge St. Boston, MA 02134. $(6$)EVANS--Charles. The FDNY Foundation remembers, and thanks you, for helping carry our mission of providing fire safety education to the residents of this great city. Our condolences to the family. FDNY Foundation

An article in The Arts on May 29 about ''Fallujah,'' a play in London about the American attack in 2004 on the Iraqi city of that name, misidentified the nationality of a journalist whose account was one of those used for the script. The journalist, Dahr Jamail, is American, not Canadian. The article also referred incorrectly to another documentary play, with which ''Fallujah'' was contrasted. That play, ''Guantánamo: 'Honor Bound to Defend Freedom,' '' was a full production; the actors did not sit on the stage and read scripts.

Congestion pricing could help the Metropolitan Transportation Authority avoid fare increases, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg made his comments at a news conference at Pratt Institute the day after an analysis by the city's Independent Budget Office showed that transit fares could go as high as $3 over the next three years. ''Maybe congestion pricing would generate enough to help them for a long time and postpone a fare increase,'' said Mr. Bloomberg, who has been pressuring Albany to approve his plan. ''If you don't give them another source of revenue, then the likelihood of less mass transit and higher fares is clearly there.'' DIANE CARDWELL

WARNING FOR TWO DIABETES DRUGS -- The Food and Drug Administration has called for the toughest safety warning on two diabetes drugs, Avandia and Actos. The decision comes a year after the agency's safety reviewers strongly recommended just such a step. It also occurs during a Congressional inquiry into why the agency delayed its warnings about Avandia. [Page A1.] A medical researcher told a House hearing about name-calling and a veiled threat of a lawsuit by a drug company executive after the researcher had criticized Avandia. [A30.] CHINA TO OVERHAUL FOOD LAWS -- China said that it was overhauling its food and drug safety regulations and would introduce nationwide inspections. The announcement was a response to growing international concerns about tainted food and counterfeit drugs. [A1.] A BOOMING BUSINESS IN AUTO PARTS -- China's auto parts exports have increased more than sixfold in the last five years, nearly topping $1 billion in April, and are part of a broader shift as China moves up from basic goods like textiles and shoes toward higher-value industrial goods that compete directly with countries like the United States. [C1.] AUTOMAKERS OPPOSE ENERGY BILL -- The chief executives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler met with Senate lawmakers, less than a week before Democrats plan a vote on a sprawling energy bill, and asserted that the bill's proposed increase in mileage requirements would be impossible to meet and would gravely damage the industry. [C1.] BUILDING A BETTER PATENT SYSTEM -- The Bush administration wants to revamp the nation's patent system, requiring better information from inventors and allowing public scrutiny of applications, according to the patent office's chief. The goal, said Jon W. Dudas, above, the director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, is to improve the quality of patents and curb the rising wave of patent disputes and lawsuits. [C3.] LESSONS FROM LONDON -- The Bancroft family, owners of a controlling interest in Dow Jones, is trying to learn from the lessons of The Times of London as they attempt to come up with a system for keeping The Wall Street Journal's newsroom independent of Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation who has bid to buy the company. [C1.] INTEREST RATE JITTERS -- For the second consecutive day, Wall Street recoiled at the prospect that inflation would not settle down enough to suit the Federal Reserve. And investors appeared to worry not only that interest rates will stay where they are, but that the Fed could raise them even higher. [C1.] RABBIT EARS WILL NEED SOME HELP -- A broadcasters group unveiled two versions of devices that television viewers will need beginning Feb. 17, 2009, if they use rabbit ears or rooftop antennas to receive their television signal. On that date, stations must switch from traditional analog signals to digital broadcasting. [C3.] ASTRAZENECA EXECUTIVE LEAVING -- AstraZeneca, Britain's second-largest drug maker after GlaxoSmithKline, said that its chief financial officer was leaving to join to Goldman Sachs, one of AstraZeneca's corporate brokers, as a managing director. Jon Symonds, who joined Zeneca from KPMG in 1997 and was instrumental in the $30 billion merger with Astra of Sweden a year later, will step down at the end of July. [C5.] BUSH OPPOSES EMISSION TARGETS -- The White House said it would hold firm against concrete long-term targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, a major priority for Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, the host of this week's Group of 8 meeting. [A14.] EUROPEAN RATE GOES UP -- The European Central Bank raised borrowing costs to their highest level in nearly six years, pointing to a humming economy that, while welcome, raised the risk of higher inflation. European stock markets fell. [C5.] ORIENTING ELECTRONICS TO WOMEN -- Making a consumer electronic product more appealing to women no longer means offering a pink or pastel version. More manufacturers are discovering that feminizing technology is more about a product's fundamentals, often expressed in its ease of use. [C7.] PRUDENTIAL CLOSES RESEARCH UNIT -- Prudential Financial decided to close its small, struggling equity research and sales business. About 420 people will be laid off. [C3.] CITIGROUP TO PAY $15 MILLION FINE -- NASD, a regulator of brokerage firms, said that Citigroup will pay $15.2 million to settle claims that its brokers had coaxed employees of the BellSouth Corporation into retiring early on exaggerated projections for investment returns. [C4.] FENDI SETTLES WAL-MART SUIT -- Fendi, the Italian fashion designer and maker of luxury products, settled a lawsuit against Wal-Mart Stores that contended the retailer had sold counterfeit handbags and wallets in its Sam's Club stores. [C9.] CBS RELENTS AFTER SERIES PROTEST -- CBS reversed course three weeks after canceling the apocalyptic drama ''Jericho,'' and ordered seven new episodes after a sustained and creative protest by fans of the series. The new episodes are for broadcast late this year or early in 2008. [C4.] PHONE BOOKS ON A DIET -- The fat phone book is losing some of its girth as more people give up their land lines for cellphones. In Manhattan, despite population gains in recent years, the 2007 Verizon White Pages was 142 pages smaller than the 2006 edition. [B1.]

IF you are tired of the same old teak or wrought-iron outdoor furniture, this is the summer to redecorate. Many designers are offering patio and garden furnishings in unexpected materials like recycled plastic and porcelain, and some of the new designs add not just comfort but also bright color to the yard. Most of the pieces shown here can withstand the weather, and many of them would look as nice inside as out. 1. Emu's steel and sheet metal Round Chair ($270) and the Heaven glass and steel table, 47 inches in diameter and 29 1/2 inches high ($1,850), at Property, 14 Wooster Street (Canal Street), (917) 237-0123. 2. Botanist tables come in powder-coated bent aluminum (in various colors, with or without water-jet cut floral patterns) and also in wood veneer (without cutouts), and three sizes: 20 inches high by 20 by 26 inches ($690 to $866); 15 inches high by 25 by 50 inches ($1,356 to $1,817); and 19 inches high by 18 by 60 inches ($1,200 to $1,611). For stores: (213) 972-9922 or orange22.com. 3. Studio JSPR's Plastic Fantastic Softskin (or rubberized) club chair is available in a choice of bright colors; $3,600 from Designfront, 21 E. Front Street, Red Bank, N.J., (732) 741-0955 or designonfront.com. 4. The Peg Chair ($1,850), by Finn Stone, a London-based designer, resembles an old-fashioned clothespin but is made of fiberglass. For information: (011) 44-208-889-3856 or finnstone.com. 5. I Was Here, a recycled-plastic ''lumber'' table, has graffiti scratched into its surface. Made by Jason Miller, a Brooklyn designer, it comes in blue, black, white, light gray, dark gray and brown. The 50-by-30-inch dining table is $1,500; the 21-inch-square, 17-inch-high side table is $400; and the 50-by-14-by-17-inch-high bench is $700; from the Future Perfect, 115 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-6278. 6. The weather-resistant felted acrylic ottoman comes in a choice of patterns; $550 from Liora Manné, 210 11th Avenue (24th Street), (212) 989-2732 or lioramanne.com. 7. John Reeves, a Vietnam-based British designer, created the 18-inch-tall Cadiz porcelain stool ($550) and coordinating table, which has a porcelain base and a 36-inch-square teak top ($1,625). For information: Next Door Trends, (510) 236-1482 or nextdoortrends.com. 8. Timber, a cast-resin stool or end table shaped like a wood stump, is 17 inches high and 21 inches in diameter on top ($295 in white or dark brown, $565 in bronze metallic); custom colors are also available, at different prices, from Fleetwood Fixtures, the manufacturer, (312) 640-1606 or fleetwoodfixtures.com.

Muhammad is now the second most popular name for baby boys in Britain, outstripped only by Jack, The Times of London reported. It said it based its conclusion on an analysis of 3,000 names provided by the Office for National Statistics for births in 2006 and had taken into account 14 different spellings for the name. Using the spelling Muhammad in its article, the newspaper said that the popularity of the name came from the growing number of young Muslim couples having families. Many of these parents chose the name of the prophet in order to show a solidarity with their religion, the newspaper said. According to the Times analysis, Muhammad (5,991) could outscore Jack (6,928) by the end of this year if the name's current rate of popularity continued. The names Thomas and Joshua followed Muhammad closely in third and fourth places. No other Muslim names showed up in the list of 20 names published by the newspaper. JANE PERLEZ

A man and woman were found dead in their apartment in East New York last night in what investigators are calling a possible murder-suicide, the police said. The couple, identified as Veldora Dixon, 39, and Tito Jemmoot, 35, each had a gunshot wound in the head when they were found in the apartment at 712 Pennsylvania Avenue. Their bodies were found in their bed, and a 9-millimeter gun was found near Mr. Jemmoot's body, the police said. The police were alerted to the body about 7:30 p.m. by a friend of the family, who wondered why the couple had missed an appointment. JENNIFER 8. LEE

There are more than 50 new items in the architect Frank Gehry's housewares collection for Tiffany & Company, all recognizably Gehry-esque in their sweeping sculptural forms. Beyond that, though, the aesthetic range is wide -- as is the range of prices. Some pieces come in jewel-like Murano glass (the red and blue Flux bowls, top right, are $1,650 and $2,200), while others are sterling silver, inspired by crumpled paper but priced much higher (the Torque Object, right, is $25,000). The Leaf platters in bubinga wood and sterling silver are more costly still (the 14-inch wood version, top, is $25,000, and the six-inch silver one is $50,000). Mr. Gehry's personal favorites -- because of the ''basic grid pattern,'' he said, and the ''simple but commanding form'' -- are the openwork china and sterling pieces (the Grid Object pictured with Mr. Gehry is $4,500). There is something for smaller budgets, too: the three-inch Rock tumbler, in bone china, is $35. Tiffany & Company, 727 Fifth Avenue (57th Street), (212) 755-8000; 210 North Rodeo Drive, Beverly Hills, Calif., (310) 273-8880; or (800) 526-0649 to order. STEPHEN MILIOTI

''The Pirate Queen,'' above, the $16 million musical by Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schönberg, is giving up the ship on June 17, when it will have played only 85 performances and 32 previews. The closing frees the Hilton Theater for ''Young Frankenstein,'' the new Mel Brooks musical, which has been indiscreetly hovering for weeks. Theresa Rebeck (''The Scene'') will make her Broadway debut next season. Her dark comedy ''Mauritius'' is about a couple of half-sisters and a rare stamp collection. It is scheduled to occupy the Manhattan Theater Club's Biltmore Theater, with an opening date set for Oct. 4. The production will be directed by Doug Hughes (''Doubt'') and will star Bobby Cannavale (''Hurlyburly'') and Alison Pill. The inclusion of Ms. Pill puts to rest any speculation that Manhattan Theater Club's critically acclaimed production of ''Blackbird,'' in which she stars, would transfer to Broadway from City Center, where the show will close on Sunday night. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

Wu Bangguo, the chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, said at a conference in Beijing that Hong Kong had considerable autonomy only because the central government had chosen to authorize that autonomy. Under the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984, China promised Britain that as part of the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule China would preserve ''a high degree of autonomy'' for the territory. But Chinese officials focus these days on the Basic Law, a Beijing-drafted document that serves as Hong Kong's mini-constitution and gives broad powers to the Standing Committee in Beijing to set policy in Hong Kong by interpreting the territory's laws. Mr. Wu spoke ahead of the 10th anniversary on July 1 of Hong Kong's return to China. KEITH BRADSHER

CYCLISTS looking to travel with a bicycle or two face the challenge of how to safely cart them, without damaging the car or their precious cargo. Racks that attach to the back hitch under the bumper are one solution. Sport utility vehicles, station wagons and trucks typically come standard with hitches, with either a 1.25- or 2-inch-diameter receiver. Hitch racks are better for a car's aerodynamics than roof racks. And unlike carriers strapped to the trunk, empty hitch racks usually don't have to be removed from the vehicle to access the back of the car. Raxter Racks, a two-year-old company in Broken Arrow, Okla., sells only hitch racks, and its sales have increased about 300 percent since last year.

The Senate signaled support for major provisions of a comprehensive immigration bill on Wednesday by rejecting many proposed amendments, including one that would have made it much harder for many illegal immigrants to achieve legal status. Architects of the legislation said they hoped that by plowing through the amendments, they would gain support for a motion to end debate on the legislation. The motion, scheduled for a vote on Thursday, needs 60 votes to succeed.

Barbara Barry may have invented the chilly glamour that has dominated much of high interior design for nearly a decade. For Hollywood royalty, she has made homes that look a bit like hotels; for hotels and restaurants, she has made spaces that look a bit like Hollywood homes. She is a branded personality, too, extending her name to teacups and flatware, sheets, towels and furniture. Today, her first American ''gallery,'' as she described it recently, opens at ABC Home in Manhattan. There are 2,500 square feet worth of furniture (Barbara Barry Realized by Henredon) and objects, in a strict black, brown and white palette, with prices ranging from about $155 for a four-piece Wedgwood bone china set called Curtain Call, top left, to $4,780 for the curvy Conversation sofa in white linen, top right.

For three of today's matches, it was dèja vu all over again as the players repeated the openings from the first game of the finals. Peter Leko took a commanding lead in his candidates finals match over Evgeny Bareev and Boris Gelfand won to move in front of Gata Kamsky in their match. The games in the other two finals matches were drawn, but unlike yesterday, all the games today were hard fought. The matches are being played in Elista, Kalmykia, to determine four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

Chiang Mai is a popular get-away from Bangkok, as it's only about an hour's flight away and is relatively cooler in the hot, rainy months. I'd never gone before, but I knew what I was expecting: a small city with ancient temples, old buildings, sprawling markets, outlying villages, cute cafes and homey guest houses.All those things were there, but the whole was bigger and more commercial than I had thought; the main road along one side of the river was packed with cars, scooters, pick-up trucks and some seriously assertive tuk-tuk drivers.There some nice little streets, shops and pubs in the area along the river, but there was also a Starbucks, 7-Eleven, Subway, McDonalds, etc. Further up, somewhat desperate looking, scantily clad women milled around al fresco pool halls where nobody was playing pool. The night bazaar is impressively large, but touristy. Not that I'm going to go on a PC rant against U.S. coffee chains or thinly veiled girlie bars; it just felt too much like a mini-Bangkok to be a peaceful getaway, especially in the evening.

Skoda, part of the Volkswagen Group, has delighted television viewers across Europe (and YouTube subscribers around the world) with its commercial for the newest verson of its Fabia minicar. I think we should all make a pact to gather in 10 years to chew on the Tom Ford empire. Ford put out a statement this morning about a plan to have 100 free-standing Tom Ford boutiques over the next decade. In three years, he says he'll open shops in L.A., Hawaii, London and Milan. Other cities down the road will include Moscow and Hong Kong, and he'll have in-store deals with Neiman's and Villa Moda. Oh, and Daslu in Brazil. Maybe in his spare time he could design Valentino . just a thought.

The other day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told people who worry about terrorist threats to "get a life" -- and got some positive feedback. Now comes the news that Pennsylvania officials hope to capitalize on fears of chaos should another terrorist attack hit New York's financial district. Call it Wall Street West.Gov. Edward G. Rendell's administration maintains that since the region is about 100 miles west of Manhattan, it is outside New York City's theoretical nuclear blast zone. It is ideally situated, they say, to be a safe retreat from the metropolis, but close enough to be linked directly to the computers that run the banking and trading systems.
