The Police Department has begun a monthly series of video podcasts offering an inside look at the department, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday. The videos will be available for download through the iTunes service to iPod users and can also be viewed online at the Police Department's Web site, nyc.gov/html/nypd/home.html. The first episode features a six-minute look at the department's harbor and scuba units.

HOCHBERG--Marvin. The Graenum Berger Bronx Jewish Federation Service Center expresses profound sorrow on the passing of Marvin Hochberg, one of our founders. He personified the fundamental Jewish teaching that we are created to do good for others. His commitment to chesed and tzedakah through compassion, diligence and excellence, inspires and serves as a role model. May the Almighty comfort his beloved wife, Bella, children Rifki, Zev and Shani, and the entire family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

A 26-year-old man was fatally shot about 5:30 p.m. yesterday on Fulton Avenue near East 172nd Street, the police said. The man, who was shot several times, including once in the head, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital in critical condition and later pronounced dead. The police did not release his identity. No arrests had been made. JENNIFER 8. LEE

Was last month the peak? The wave of buyouts continued to rise in May, making it the one of the biggest deal-making months ever. Only January 2000, when the America Online-Time Warner merger was announced, and April 1998 (the Citicorp-Travelers deal) were bigger..
To the Editor: Re ''Company for an Only Child, and for Parents, Peace of Mind'' (news article, June 3):

Hundreds of angry students rioted on Wednesday night in the central city of Zhengzhou after a city inspector beat a female student, according to a Hong Kong-based rights group, the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy. It reported that students from three universities poured into the streets, overturning cars and destroying property for more than four hours. The rampage apparently erupted after an inspector knocked out the front teeth of the female student, who was running an illegal street vending stall. The police later detained a handful of students. A local newspaper also reported that several inspectors were later fired or reprimanded. JIM YARDLEY

A longterm supporter and advocate for the Monell Center, he was an inspired and dedicated leader. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Meyerson family.

Dr. Harvey R. Colten, a pediatric immunologist and a leading medical educator at Columbia University whose research helped isolate a gene tied to respiratory failure in infants, died on May 24 in Manhattan. He was 68. The cause was complications of colon cancer, his family said.

To the Editor: In ''Defeat's Killing Fields'' (Op-Ed, June 7), Peter W. Rodman and William Shawcross condemn those who are ''toying with the idea of American defeat'' in Iraq and list all the horrors that would result. They, like all supporters of this war before and during the conflict, are living in a fantasy world in which one can still be ''for'' or ''against'' defeat.

ALL the world's a stage, sure, but what might Shakespeare have made of the dramatic possibilities of a Lower East Side parking lot, with cars backing out right into the Capulets' masked ball? Or ''Love's Labour's Lost'' on a stroll through Central Park, as helmeted bicyclists whiz by? The outdoor summer theater season had its unofficial opening on Wednesday, when Shakespeare in the Park began previews of ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the open-air Delacorte Theater in Central Park. And for legions of New Yorkers, from theater lovers to park lovers to those who simply love anything free, no warm-weather ritual is more pleasant -- or an easier sell -- than an evening of blank verse in the Delacorte.
An Op-Ed article on May 21, about veganism, mischaracterized an aspect of traditional vegetarian Indian diets. Generally, these diets are lacto-vegetarian; they do not include eggs.

A television review on Wednesday about ''We Love Ella! A Tribute to the First Lady of Song,'' a PBS ''Great Performances'' concert, misidentified the site of the concert. It was Los Angeles, not San Diego.

McGRATH--Camilla, died on May 24, survived by her husband of 44 years, Earl McGrath, and 2 sisters Laetitia and Viviana Pecci Blunt. Mass will be held on Thursday, June 14th, at 11am. St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue.

City officials inspecting a sinkhole yesterday discovered what may be human remains underground, the police said. The sinkhole, near Wilson Avenue and East 214th Street in Williamsbridge, developed several weeks ago and grew to about 3 feet square, neighbors said. Residents had complained to the Department of Environmental Protection, which sent workers yesterday. Department employees found several bones, including what appeared to be a femur and a jaw bone. The remains will be passed to the medical examiner's office, the police said. MATHEW R. WARREN
KONIGSBERG--Natalie. You are always in our hearts. We miss you, and love you. Your loving family

The Department of Defense has identified 3,487 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week: CAMPOS, Juan F., 27, Staff Sgt., Army; McAllen, Tex.; First Infantry Division. HIGGINS, Andrews J. , 28, Sgt., Army; Hayward, Calif.; Second Infantry Division.

Prosecutors have disclosed DNA evidence in a triple-murder case against a bar bouncer connected to the Sweet Cherry strip parlor in Sunset Park. Months after the killings, the defendant, Stephen Sakai, was arrested carrying a washcloth with what appeared to be a bloodstain, his lawyer, Kleon C. Andreadis, said yesterday after a pretrial hearing in State Supreme Court. The Brooklyn district attorney's office is expected to try to link the DNA to Mr. Sakai. Mr. Sakai and two of the victims in the case, both of whom were killed in 2005, worked or spent time at the Sweet Cherry, which the authorities finally shut down last year after nearly a decade of trying. In a separate case in Manhattan, Mr. Sakai is charged with shooting four patrons outside a dance club in Chelsea in May 2006, killing one. MICHAEL BRICK

Since the first SketchFest in Seattle eight years ago, sketch comedy festivals have been popping up in cities from Los Angeles to Toronto. New York has plenty of cutups too, and it joined the fun two years ago with Sketchfest NYC, an annual event taking place this weekend. ''The goal is to make people realize what sketch comedy is,'' said Alexander Zalben, a producer of Sketchfest NYC. ''It's not just people in their fraternities putting on funny skits about their professors.'' Unlike improvisation or standup comedy, sketch consists of short written scenes rehearsed in advance. (Think of ''Saturday Night Live.'') The content may be funny, but Mr. Zalben and his co-producers, Keith Michel, Becky Poole and Elizabeth Ellis, are serious about this type of humor. ''We weren't going to aim for being the biggest,'' Mr. Zalben said. ''It's more important to aim for a consistent level of quality.'' Instead of opening the festival to all performers, the producers watched more than 100 live-performance tapes, and chose 21 groups for the festival.

A front-page News Analysis article yesterday about the possibility of a presidential pardon for I. Lewis Libby Jr., who was convicted of lying to investigators in the C.I.A. leak case, referred incorrectly to Terence Hunt, a reporter for The Associated Press, in describing a scene in which President Bush cut off one reporter's follow-up question about a pardon by moving on to another reporter who asked about Russia. Mr. Hunt was the reporter who tried to ask the follow-up question about the pardon; he was not the reporter who ''changed the subject'' to the new tensions about Russia. And it was an unidentified reporter -- not Mr. Bush -- who said, ''Nice going, Terry.''
MONFRIED--Xenia. 6/8/32 -3/3/95 Happy 75th Mom. Love, A and V.

The authorities yesterday interrupted a sophisticated drug organization operating in Crown Heights, said Charles J. Hynes, the district attorney. Raiding several safe houses around the Brooklyn Children's Museum, the police arrested 11 people, ranging in age from 23 to 67, on conspiracy, drug and weapons charges. Investigators secretly videotaped suspects weighing and measuring drugs, then bought or seized 2.8 pounds of cocaine and 8 pounds of marijuana, Mr. Hynes said. They also seized binoculars and radio equipment used for countersurveillance of the police. MICHAEL BRICK

WOLPER--David J., died on June 6, 2007 surrounded by family at Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL; survived by his wife of 63 years, Sylvia Leon Wolper; father of Steven, Robert and Cathy; grandfather of Caleb, Elizabeth, Andrew, Rachael, Michael and Zachary. We will all miss you, PopPop!

The European Union said Thursday that it would resume negotiations with Serbia next week on an agreement that is the first step toward possible membership in the bloc. The announcement was made a week after the arrest and transfer of a leading Bosnian Serb war crimes suspect to the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague, and it was seen as a victory for Boris Tadic, Serbia's reformist president, who is supported by the United States and the European Union.

The Public Lives profile on May 25, about Martin Garbus, a Manhattan lawyer representing the fired radio host Don Imus in his pending lawsuit against CBS, misidentified the mentor to Mr. Garbus who won all nine cases he argued before the United States Supreme Court. It was Ephraim London -- not Emile Zola Berman, who represented Sirhan B. Sirhan, Robert F. Kennedy's assassin.

The authorities in Milan issued arrest warrants for nine men suspected of providing logistical and financial support to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, North Africa's most active terrorist group. By evening, at least two of the suspects were in Italian custody. British authorities made a separate arrest in North London as part of the sweep. The North African group, formerly the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, claimed responsibility for the suicide bombings in Algiers in April that killed 33 people. PETER KIEFE

Sculpture Sale Is a Record An ancient Roman bronze sculpture of the goddess Artemis with a stag, left, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's in New York for $28.6 million, the highest price ever paid for a sculpture or an antiquity at auction. The London dealer Giuseppe Eskenazi said he bought the work, dating from the first century B.C. to the first century A.D., on behalf of a private European collector whom he declined to identify. Sotheby's had estimated that the sculpture would go for $5 million to $7 million. The sculpture had been in the collection of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo, which is in the midst of a controversial sale of older works so that it can raise money to finance purchases of contemporary art. Richard M. Keresey, an antiquities specialist at Sotheby's, had called the 36-inch-tall bronze ''the best single piece I've seen here in 37 years.'' The previous auction record for a sculpture was set in May 2005 when Brancusi's ''Bird in Space'' went for $27.5 million at Christie's in New York; the previous auction record for an antiquity was the $11.6 million paid for the so-called Jenkins Venus, a marble statue, at Christie's in London in June 2002. Reached on his cellphone Mr. Eskenazi said that he jumped into the bidding after the price reached $14 million and then squared off against one remaining bidder. ''He was very determined -- I thought he'd never give up,'' he said. ''I feel exhaustion, to be honest.'' Mr. Eskenazi triumphed with a hammer price of $25.5 million. (Final prices include Sotheby's commission: 20 percent of the first $500,000 and 12 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.) Akon in Trouble The platinum-selling singer Akon, above, is under investigation after a clash that ended with him tossing a teenage concertgoer off the stage and onto an audience member who said she suffered a concussion, The Associated Press reported. Witnesses said the trouble erupted Sunday at Dutchess Stadium in Fishkill, N.Y., where a spectator threw something at the singer, and Akon, 34, asked the crowd to point out the culprit. A guard singled out a 15-year-old boy, whose name was not released, and sent him to the stage, where Akon hurled him into the audience, The Poughkeepsie Journal reported. The boy landed on Abby Rosa, who said she soon experienced a headache and blurry vision. Detective Lt. John Berlingieri of the Fishkill Police said no criminal charges had yet been filed. Earlier this year Akon caused a furor with a sexually explicit onstage dance with a girl later revealed to be 14. He apologized, saying he did not know she was under-age. Sean Connery Resigns His Professorship Sean Connery said yesterday that he won't be playing dad to Harrison Ford's Indiana Jones anymore, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Connery, 76, played Prof. Henry Jones, father of the intrepid archeologist, in the 1989 adventure ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' below. With a fourth Indian Jones film, directed by Steven Spielberg and produced by George Lucas, scheduled to go before the cameras this month, speculation had mounted that Mr. Connery would return, although he had announced his retirement from acting in 2005. ''I thought long and hard about it, and if anything could have pulled me out of retirement, it would have been an Indiana Jones film,'' he said in a statement posted on the Lucasfilm Indiana Jones Web site (www.indianajones.com). ''But in the end, retirement is just too damned much fun.'' The film is scheduled for release in May 2008. Patricia Cornwell Wins Injunction A federal judge in Richmond, Va., has ordered Leslie R. Sachs, a self-published author, to end an Internet vendetta that leveled accusations of plagiarism, bribery and anti-Semitism against Patricia Cornwell, below, the best-selling author of novels featuring the medical examiner Kay Scarpetta, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Sachs even contended that Ms. Cornwell was plotting to have him murdered. Ms. Cornwell, 50, said Mr. Sachs, 52, had made no direct threats but said his allegations had caused her fear, anxiety and sleeplessness. After long ignoring him she sued Mr. Sachs for libel when the Internet attacks increased. Judge Norman K. Moon granted Ms. Cornwell's motion for a permanent injunction, saying that the statements were false and ''calculated to expose plaintiff to public contempt or ridicule'' and were published with actual malice. Mr. Sachs did not immediately respond to an e-mail message from The Associated Press seeking comment. British 'Big Brother' Contestant Expelled An allegation of racism has led to the ouster of a contestant from the British reality television show ''Big Brother,'' The Associated Press reported. Emily Parr, 19, a student, was removed after using a derogatory term about a black contestant on Wednesday night, Channel 4 in Britain said yesterday. The remark was not broadcast live. Channel 4 was forced to apologize two weeks ago after regulators ruled that the ''Celebrity Big Brother'' program violated broadcasting rules by showing footage of racist insults directed at the Bollywood actress Shilpa Shetty. Channel 4 said that in light of reaction to the ''Celebrity Big Brother'' incident it had not choice but to expel Ms. Parr.

Perry Rubenstein Gallery is serving a cocktail of knockout works by Robin Rhode, a South African-born, Berlin-based artist known for his brilliantly inventive, performance-related artwork. Spread over all three of the gallery's Chelsea spaces, the works take their inspiration from hip-hop music, sports, film and fashion. Standouts include ''Table of Contents'' (2006), a stylish, pyramid-shaped sculptural installation of 36 photographs of the artist playing a game of shadow table tennis with himself on a table spray-painted on a wall. Mr. Rhode paints a representation of a light-colored ball in motion, positioning himself holding a paddle for the next shot. The photographs trace the game's progression. It is fun, devilishly clever and simple, reaffirming his leadership among the latest generation of performance-based artists. He uses the same low-tech, stop-frame animation formula to an equally satisfying effect for ''Juggla'' (2007), above, a display of photographs of himself in a top hat and cape, juggling imaginary balls painted on a wall. Nearby is his first short film, ''Candle'' (2007), a blurry dream adventure in which he lights and somehow controls a live candle flame. It is austerely beautiful, like most everything else in these lovely shows. (Through June 23, Perry Rubenstein Gallery, 527 West 23rd Street, 526 West 24th Street, 534 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 627-8000, perryrubenstein.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

An article on Tuesday in the special Circuits section about the trend for consumers to have two or more models of some digital devices misstated the storage capacity of one model of Apple's iPhone, which will be on the market at the end of the month. The model, which is to cost $599, has eight gigabytes of storage, not five.

A sports headline and an article in some copies yesterday about the Anaheim Ducks' defeat of the Ottawa Senators to capture the Stanley Cup referred incorrectly to the accomplishment. Anaheim is the first West Coast team to win the Cup since the National Hockey League took control starting with the 1927 playoffs; it is not the first West Coast team ever to win the championship. That distinction is held by the Vancouver Millionaires, who took the Cup in 1915. (The Seattle Metropolitans won in 1917, and the Victoria Cougars in 1925.)

The Senate Banking Committee and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York sent joint letters to the nation's 20 largest student lenders, demanding information on how they set rates and fees on student loans, as part of a growing investigation into possible discrimination in student lending. The letter gives lenders until the end of next week to say which criteria they use, including ''college, college location, graduation rate, historic default rate, gender, age, parental income, credit history and any other factors used or considered in underwriting determinations.'' Separately, the House Education Committee made a similar request of the five top student lenders, ''to help determine whether the lenders offer less favorable terms to students at predominately minority colleges, such as historically black colleges and universities, than they offer to students at other four-year public and private colleges.'' DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

SAINER--Janet S. The NYC Family Caregiver Coalition expresses deepest sympathy to the family of our founding member and mentor, Janet S. Sainer. Each of us has been greatly enriched by her wisdom, her kindness, her largess, her knowledge, her creativity and her generosity of spirit and love. Rev. Gregory L. Johnson and James O'Neal, Co-Chairs $(6$)SAINER--Janet. The Board and staff of the Community Service Society of New York mourn the loss of a friend and innovator. Her pioneering work in engaging older adults in service to their communities led to the creation of the Retired and Senior Volunteer Program, now a national program with over 7,500 volunteers in New York City alone. Her leadership in policy, practice, and service for New York City remains an inspiration. Our deepest sympathy goes to her family. David R. Jones, Pres. & CEO Community Service Society
To the Editor: Re ''The Passion of Al Gore,'' by Bob Herbert (column, June 5):

The David Pogue column in the special Circuits section on Tuesday, about Web sites for sharing and printing photos, incorrectly described a feature of one site, Kodak Gallery. While a user with a free or paid account can upload photos to the site (kodakgallery.com) and allow others to view them, the site does not allow others to download them. But it has a ''Print@Home'' feature that lets others print photos without downloading them.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sunday about the Reebok Grand Prix track and field event on Randalls Island referred incorrectly in some copies to the wind speed during the 100-meter dash. It was recorded at 2.2 meters a second, not miles an hour. The allowable wind speed for a world record to count in the event is 2.0 meters a second, not miles an hour.

The Taliban released four members of an Afghan medical team kidnapped and held hostage since March after the government handed over the body of the senior Taliban commander Mullah Dadullah, said Qayum Pukhla, the director of the health department in Kandahar. The four, a doctor, two nurses and a driver described as thin and frail, were quickly reunited with their families. Members of the Taliban said that the Afghan government handed over the body of Mullah Dadullah, killed in fighting last month, on Wednesday evening and that was why they released the four hostages. They said they had killed the fifth member of the team, a pharmacist, because the government did not hand over the commander's body within the ultimatum set earlier this week. CARLOTTA GALL

The Levant Sean Kelly 528 West 29th Street, Chelsea Through June 23 A couple of decades ago James Casebere was in the avant-garde of artists building architectural models and photographing them to look like actual spaces. He has now become so skilled at the building, lighting and photographing aspects of the project that the original illusion-versus-reality game has given way to other concerns.

With good reason, the city of Vienna holds a distinguished place in the history of classical music. Its jazz legacy is much more difficult to pin down, but there have been significant advances in recent years. The city now has a handful of noteworthy clubs, including Joe Zawinul's Birdland, owned by Austria's best-known jazz musician. (He recorded his latest release, ''Brown Street,'' at the club in 2005.) Naturally, there's also a Vienna Jazz Festival, which began in 1991; this year's edition kicks off on June 25. And there have been an increasing number of collaborations between Vienna-based musicians and their American counterparts; one of the newest and best is ''Friendly Travelers'' (Material), by the guitarist Wolfgang Muthspiel and the drummer Brian Blade. The Mostly Jazz Festival, presented by the Austrian Cultural Forum in Midtown Manhattan, celebrates this spirit of transnational exchange even as it makes the case for an independent Austrian jazz aesthetic. '' 'No boundaries' seems to be the unspoken motto of musicians in Vienna,'' writes Helge Hinteregger, the festival's curator, in a program essay. (He doesn't say whether the titular echo of Mostly Mozart, Lincoln Center's venerable festival, is fully intentional, though it probably is.) The series begins tonight with Big Four, consisting of the veteran Austrian saxophonist Max Nagl, the Paris-born guitarist Noël Akchoté and two Americans, the trumpeter Steven Bernstein and the bassist Brad Jones. They perform at 7, followed by an inventive young trio called Kelomat, above, led by the saxophonist Wolfgang Schiftner. Tomorrow there's another group featuring Mr. Schiftner, aptly named Vienna-New York Connection and including the saxophonist Tony Malaby. As for Mr. Nagl, he resurfaces on Tuesday with a project he calls Wumm Zack. The early slot tomorrow goes to Bassinstinct, an assembly of six double bassists. And on Monday, the pianist Hannes Löschel will entrust his own compositions to several well-qualified American improvisers -- the multireedist Ned Rothenberg, the guitarist David Tronzo and the bassist Lindsay Horner -- before a set of free improvisation by the saxophonist Clemens Salesny and the pianist Clemens Wenger. (Tonight through Tuesday night at 7 and 8, Austrian Cultural Forum, 11 East 52nd Street, 212-319-5300, acfny.org; free.) NATE CHINEN

A picture caption on Wednesday with a sports article about the Mets' 4-2 extra-innings loss to the Phillies carried an incorrect credit. The photograph of a play at home plate involving the Mets' David Wright and the Philliles' Carlos Ruiz was by Ray Stubblebine of Reuters, not Barton Silverman of The New York Times.

Two young men were fatally shot on a street in East Harlem early yesterday, the police said. The victims, Manuel Sabatera, 27, and Joshua Agard, 17, were each shot several times about 4:30 a.m. as they gathered with others who were listening to music and playing dice in front of 404 East 105th Street, an investigator said. A separate group approached Mr. Sabatera and Mr. Agard, with at least one of them firing a .40-caliber handgun, the investigator said. The investigator said Mr. Agard appeared to be the target. Mr. Sabatera was pronounced dead at Metropolitan Hospital Center; Mr. Agard was pronounced dead at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday, the police said. Among detectives' leading theories was that drugs played a role, the police said. AL BAKER

1964-1989 Zwirner & Wirth 32 East 69th Street Through June 23 The material in this intriguing little show of one or two works each by nearly 30 artists spans generations and nationalities, from 1970s Arte Povera Italians to post-Pop Germans to 1980s post-Conceptual Americans. It includes some classics by usual suspects, among them Joan Jonas, Dan Graham, Dennis Oppenheim, Vito Acconci and Charles Ray. But there are also just enough oddities to make it feel very personal.

VALUE OF 'FOR SALE BY OWNER' -- Two Northwestern University economists who studied home-sales data from 1998 to 2004 in Madison, Wis., found that people who sold their homes through real estate agents typically did not get a higher sale price than people who sold their homes themselves. [Page A1.] RISE OF PORK PRICES WORRIES CHINA -- China is feeling the pinch of inflation and, as a result, Chinese companies are starting to raise prices for exports, removing what has been a brake on inflation in the West. For Chinese households, the rising prices are seen most dramatically in a critical commodity: pork. [C1.] INFLATION FEARS PULL DOWN SHARES -- Share prices posted their steepest three-day decline since markets dropped around the world in February, and the interest rate on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose above 5 percent for the first time since last summer, as fears about inflation, driving by a strong global economy, preoccupied investors. [C1.] NINTENDO NOW PLAYS WITH OTHERS -- Nintendo is known for turning out hits with memorable characters like Donkey Kong, left, and the Super Mario Bros., but it had a reputation for cold-shouldering game software developers, preferring to make its own hardware and software. But the secretive company is coming out of its shell. Along with its successful Wii game console, Nintendo has made a concerted effort to woo other game makers as part of a broader change in strategy to dominate the newest generation of consoles. [C1.] PATENT RULING AGAINST QUALCOMM -- Millions of cellphones containing certain Qualcomm semiconductors may not be imported into the United States, a federal government agency ruled in a patent dispute. [C1.] U.S. TO CONSIDER CLIMATE PLAN -- The United States agreed to ''consider seriously'' a European plan to combat global warming by cutting in half worldwide greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, averting a trans-Atlantic deadlock at a meeting in Germany of the world's richest industrial nations. [A10.] VODAFONE HEARS FROM INVESTORS -- The Vodafone Group, the world's largest cellphone company, said that it had received a letter from a group of shareholders asking it to return as much as £38 billion ($75 billion) to investors in part by spinning off its stake in Verizon Wireless. The letter is the latest effort by minority shareholders to influence management decisions. [C7.] MEXICO MEDIA LAW OVERTURNED -- Mexico's Supreme Court overwhelmingly voted to declare parts of a new media law unconstitutional, a blow to the country's two main broadcasters. The decision confirmed several preliminary votes that the court's members have taken over the past two weeks. [C2.] EQUAL AND SPLENDA IN NEW RIFT -- An undisclosed settlement between the makers of Equal and Splenda over Splenda's contested slogan of ''made like sugar, so its tastes like sugar'' came apart, prompting a renewed dispute between the two rival makers of artificial sweeteners. [C3.] A HESITANT RETURN TO SHOPPING -- Americans shopped hesitantly in May, giving retailers some relief from a dismal showing in April but still raising questions about how strong consumer spending would be in the months ahead. As the nation's merchants reported results, the disappointments included Wal-Mart Stores, Macy's and Abercrombie & Fitch. Costco Wholesale, Kohl's and luxury retailers like Saks beat expectations. ''It wasn't a blowout, but the gains were a solid snap back,'' said an analyst. [C3.] BIOMET BOARD ACCEPTS HIGHER BID -- A group of private equity firms bidding for Biomet, a maker of artificial joints, sweetened its offer to $11.4 billion after a prominent shareholder adviser criticized its previous bid as too low, and the new offer was accepted by the company's board. [C3.] FEWER SEEK JOBLESS BENEFITS -- Fewer workers signed up for unemployment benefits last week, and inventories at wholesalers picked up in April. [C2.] HAVE CELLPHONE, WILL CRITIQUE -- A leading cellphone maker is taking advantage of the popularity of blogs and other forms of consumer-generated content -- as well as the increasing interest in mobile marketing -- by offering music fans ages 18 and up a chance to play music critic for the summer. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] DOW JONES'S NEW SEVERANCE PLANS -- Dow Jones & Company, which is considering a $5 billion takeover deal by Rupert Murdoch, has amended its compensation plans so that 160 senior managers could take sizable severance payments with them if they were forced out after a sale. [C3.] PAYMENTS BY BRITISH ARMS MAKER -- A major British arms contractor, BAE, paid more than $2 billion clandestinely into bank accounts in Washington controlled by Prince Bandar bin Sultan of Saudi Arabia, two British news organizations reported. Prince Bandar denied accepting ''improper secret commissions.'' [A3.] PROMOTING A 'WALL STREET WEST' -- Hoping to capitalize on fears of the chaos another terrorist attack might cause in New York's financial industry, Pennsylvania officials are promoting a hilly corner of their state as Wall Street West. [B1.] LINKING SMALL LAW FIRMS -- A way to connect small law firms around the country and the world, and provide help in competing against the big national and global firms, is the idea behind the International Network of Boutique Law Firms. [C6.] CATERING TO WEALTHY CUSTOMERS -- The Wachovia Corporation said that it planned to more than double its private banking group over the next three years, in an effort to add wealthy customers as the nation grows more affluent. [C3.]
GROSS--Susannah. We will miss our very smart, funny, dear, good friend. Condolences to the family. Lemakis & Wood Families

A Palestinian man was killed and at least nine other people were wounded in factional fighting in the southern Gaza Strip town of Rafah. Each of the rival factions, Hamas and Fatah, blamed the other for starting the shooting. The dead man belonged to Fatah. A report this week by the Palestinian Independent Commission for Citizens' Rights said 616 Palestinians had been killed in internal fighting since the beginning of 2006. In the first half of May, fierce factional clashes left about 50 dead in Gaza. The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, warned this week that the Palestinians were ''on the verge of civil war.'' ISABEL KERSHNER

An entry in the Transactions column in the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about a recent lease at 15-17 West 18th Street in Manhattan misstated the term of the lease. It is for five years, not 10 years.

MURRAY--Margaret Arnette (Maggie), on June 4, 2007. Beloved wife of Stephen Botkin; devoted mother of Hannah; loving daughter of the late Arthur and the late Charleen Murray; loving niece of Margaret Paris and Frank Murray. A native New Yorker was educated at the Marymount School and earned her B.A. at Middlebury College. Her ardent love of writing and reading lead to a twenty year career in academic publishing. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, June 8, 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 10am, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Marymount School, in her name, at 1026 5th Avenue, NYC 10028.

It helped to be a left-handed pitcher yesterday during the first round of Major League Baseball's first-year player draft, or a pitcher of any kind. Left-handed pitchers are among baseball's most valued talents, and 7 of the 30 players chosen in the first round were left-handed pitchers, including David Price of Vanderbilt, taken No. 1 over all by Tampa Bay. Including right-handers, 17 of the 30 players selected in the first round were pitchers.

The Giants bolstered their offensive line by signing guard Zach Piller, who played eight seasons for the Tennessee Titans. It is the latest signal that the Giants plan to move left guard David Diehl to left tackle to replace Luke Petitgout, who was waived after last season.

How does Hamilton go to a new track and immediately get on the pace? Today he scored pole position, beating Fernando Alonso, his teammate, who won the race at this track last year. Hamilton had never driven on the track in Canada!

The U.S. Men's National Team had little trouble disposing of a Trinidad and Tobago squad made up of second-choice players, thus assuring the Yanks of passage to the Concacaf Gold Cup tournament's knockout stage. But what does a 2-0 victory over such an unprepossessing team, followed by an unimpressive 1-0 over Guatemala, really mean? Cool efficiency, or a vulnerable giant? ... Respond!

An article in Business Day on May 29 about Russia’s strategy to gain a monopoly in natural gas exports to Asia through Gazprom misstated the percentage of ownership in the Kovykta gas field by TNK-BP, which is being accused by the Kremlin of having failed to meet license requirements. It is 63 percent, not 65.

A brief art review in Weekend yesterday about Paul Pfeiffer’s exhibition “Live From Neverland” at the Project gallery in Manhattan misstated the year of his double show at the Project and the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea. It was 2004, not last year.

The Insider column yesterday on the Street Scene page of Business Day, about investment strategies involving hedge funds, misstated the amount of money managed by one such fund, Highbridge Capital Management, which is majority owned by JPMorgan Chase. It is about $34 billion, not $15.7 billion.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about an upcoming Neville Brothers concert at the Prospect Park Bandshell in Brooklyn misstated the time. The concert will be at 8 p.m. on Thursday — not at 5:30, which is the time for a pre-concert gala.
Walter Dix, a Florida State sprinter, ran the 100 meter dash in 9.93 seconds, the fastest time in the world this year and the second fastest ever by a collegian.
Amanda Beard, a swimmer who won an Olympic gold medal at the Athens Games, takes off her clothes in eight pictures certain to create a stir.

Two weeks after stepping down as president, Olusegun Obasanjo is resuming university studies. Mr. Obasanjo, a 70-year-old retired general, began coursework for a postgraduate diploma in Christian theology at the National Open University in Lagos on Thursday. He will attend lectures at the university’s branch in Abeokuta, in Ogun State, where he has a home, his course facilitator, Olubiyi Adewale, told reporters. He stepped down on May 29, having served a constitutional maximum of two four-year terms.

The government has created a 200,000-acre natural park in the Far East to protect the country’s endangered Siberian tigers, the Natural Resources Ministry confirmed. The Russian Far East is home to about 500 Siberian tigers.
The government took aim at the country’s high suicide rate, approving measures meant to reduce the number of deaths by 20 percent by 2016.

Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angles announced that he and his wife of 20 years, Corina Villaraigosa, would separate. “Each of us loves our children more than anything in the world,” Mr. Villaraigosa said in a statement. “And we are committed to working together for their benefit.” The mayor and his wife, a teacher, have two teenage children. Rumors about the Villaraigosas marriage have been swirling for months; the two were rarely seen together, and Mr. Villaraigosa was spotted without his wedding ring, which he attributed to weight loss, denying his marriage was ending.

Federal land managers authorized up to 1,570 new natural gas wells over the next 20 years on a 3,000-foot-high plateau prized for its energy reserves and its wildlife. The Bureau of Land Management decision covers about 115 square miles of federal land. Drilling on top of the Roan Plateau has been debated because of its abundant wildlife and areas of pristine backcountry. The decision follows years of review and public hearings about energy development on the plateau, about 180 miles west of Denver.
The Defense Department said that it would ask two judges to reconsider their decisions earlier this week that stalled the military’s move to put detainees at Guantánamo Bay on trial.
A memorial service for the actress, singer and arts advocate Kitty Carlisle Hart will be held on Tuesday at noon at the Majestic Theater in Manhattan.

A woman who shot and killed her preacher husband was sentenced to three years in prison, but may spend only two months in a mental hospital. The woman, Mary Winkler, convicted of voluntary manslaughter in April, could have received up to six years for killing her husband, Matthew, in the parsonage in Selmer where the family lived in March 2006. The judge said Ms. Winkler, 33, must serve 210 days, but she will be given credit for 143 days already spent in jail. That leaves 67 days, and the judge said up to 60 days could be served in a facility where she could receive mental health treatment.

Gov. Rick Perry signed into law sweeping reforms of the Texas juvenile justice system, which has been rocked by accusations of sexual abuse. “This legislation will change the broken culture at the youth commission,” Mr. Perry said. The commission incarcerates about 4,700 offenders ages 10 to 21. State lawmakers voted for an overhaul of the agency by improving staff-to-inmate ratios, creating strong new investigative powers to look into claims of abuse, and prohibiting courts from sending youths to state lockups for misdemeanors.
The president’s ability to push an agenda has faded to a point where he can fairly be judged to have entered his lame duck period.

SALES INCREASE AT MCDONALD’S The McDonald’s Corporation posted its largest monthly sales increase in more than three years, helped by the popularity of its small sandwiches in France and a big green ogre called Shrek in the United States. The chain said sales rose 8.7 percent in May at restaurants open at least 13 months. Wall Street analysts had been expecting a rise of 5 percent, according to research notes.

9 P.M. (ABC) RUFFIAN (2007) Right on the heels of the Belmont Stakes (5:30 p.m. on ABC), and with the memory of Barbaro still fresh, comes this drama about the horse heralded as the greatest thoroughbred filly of all time. After winning the Filly Triple Crown early in 1975, the undefeated Ruffian went on to run a “battle of the sexes” match against the Kentucky Derby winner Foolish Pleasure on July 6 at Belmont Park. The race ended in sorrow when, with Ruffian leading Foolish Pleasure by half a length, two bones in her right front leg snapped. After a 12-hour surgery, Ruffian caused further damage to herself when she thrashed around on the floor of her padded stall, and she was euthanized shortly after. The film, directed by Yves Simoneau (HBO’s “Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee”), stars Sam Shepard, above, as Frank Whiteley, the trainer who guided Ruffian’s ascent, and Frank Whaley as the sportswriter Bill Nack, who wrote the book the movie is based on.

BOROUMAND--Shahla, age 54, devoted wife, mother and friend, passed away at North Shore University Hospital on Thursday, June 7, 2007, following a courageous battle with brain cancer. Shahla was born April 12, 1953, in Tehran, Iran to Mohammad Taghi Boroumand and Moloud Shariat. Throughout her childhood, Shahla excelled at all levels of her education, graduating number one in her high school class. Upon graduation, Shahla attended Tehran University where she earned a degree in English Literature. 25 years ago, Shahla married Reza Jameh during a beautiful ceremony in Tehran, Iran. After moving to the United States, Shahla earned her real estate broker's license. While working for Caldwell Banker, Shahla developed a passion for interior design. Shahla's home was a showcase for her natural design sense as well as her class, style and sophistication. Shahla will be remembered by family and friends for her boundless acts of generosity and kind heartedness. Shahla is survived by her mother Moloud Shariat; husband, Reza Jameh; two sons, Arjang and Pedrom; two brothers Michael and Parviz; and her sister Giti. She is further survived by nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, cousins and countless friends. Shahla will be dearly missed by all. Words cannot express the void that has been left by her passing.

STIEVELMAN--Harriet. We will miss our sweet and gentle friend. Ellen and Mort Silver $(6$)STIEVELMAN--Harriet. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend Harriet Stievelman. Our condolences to Jack and the family. Bud & Denny Steiner $(6$)STIEVELMAN--Harriet. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend. Our deepest condolences to Jack, Troy and Stacy, Gabi and Mitchell, Jodi and all the grandchildren. Charlotte and Roger Ellen and Marc Lisa and Eric Beth and Peter $(6$)STIEVELMAN--Harriet, was the love of her husband's life Jack for 52 years, a devoted and loving mother to Jodi, Troy and Gabi, mother-in-law to Stacy and Mitchell, loyal and generous sister to Barbara and proud and fun loving grandmother to Chelsey, Casey, Kori, Jared, Jake and Jonathan, passed away on June 7, 2007 in Manhattan. She was 71 years young. To know her was to love her. She would best be described as a delicious person. She touched and enriched so many people's lives with her ever positive attitude, her willingness to listen and her enormous capacity for compassion. She was a beautiful woman inside and out. She wore her elegance and class in a quiet way.Harriet loved to dance, hike, bike, play tennis, ski and adored animals. She was involved in many charities. She was an art collector and at one time owned a gallery in Manhattan. She traveled the world and had a spectacular life. Her smile lit up a room. We will keep that smile in our hearts forever. We miss her already. Services are at Temple Bethel in Great Neck, New York, Sunday June 10th at 10:00 A.M. $(6$)STIEVELMAN--Harriet. In loving memory of Harriet Stievelman, a wonderful friend, wife, mother and grandmother. We will miss and love you always. Howard and Karen Susan and David

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Warm Reception Expected For Bush Visit to Albania President Bush will be the first sitting American president to visit Albania. The country's support for the war in Iraq is nearly unanimous and it was one of the first allies to send troops to Afghanistan and one of the first to join the forces in Iraq. A1 Putin Elaborates on Missiles President Vladimir V. Putin offered suggestions for alternatives to a missile defense system in Europe, saying Russia would not object to American interceptor missiles in Iraq, Turkey or at sea, and proposed that Russia and the West study emerging missile threats together. A6 Report on Secret C.I.A. Prisons In a report, the lead investigator for the Council of Europe gave a bleak description of secret prisons run by the Central Intelligence Agency in Eastern Europe, with information he said was gleaned from anonymous intelligence agents, many of whom wanted to unburden themselves. A7 Separatist Arrested in Spain The Spanish police arrested Arnaldo Otegi, the leader of the political wing of the violent Basque separatist group ETA, according to an official from the National Court. The move signaled a new government crackdown after the group renounced a 15-month cease-fire. A4 A Syrian arms dealer was arrested in Madrid and charged in a plot to ship weapons--including C-4 explosives and surface-to-air missiles--to guerrillas in Colombia seeking to attack American forces serving there on antidrug missions, American prosecutors said. A4 Pakistan Lifts Media Strictures After a barrage of criticism and angry but peaceful nationwide protests by journalists and rights groups, the Pakistani government has suspended its restrictions on independent television stations. The restrictions were originally imposed by Gen. Pervez Musharraf last March. A7 Italy Prosecutes C.I.A. Agents A trial that charges American and Italian intelligence operatives with kidnapping a radical imam in 2003 opened in Milan, the first prosecution involving the contentious American policy of abducting terrorism suspects for interrogation elsewhere. A7 NATIONAL A9-13 Chairman of Joint Chiefs Will Not Be Reappointed The Bush administration said it had decided not to reappoint Gen. Peter Pace to a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, making him the highest-ranking officer to be a political casualty of the fight over Iraq. A1 Court Ruling is Criticized A decision by the Supreme Court earlier this week that made it easier for prosecutors to exclude from capital juries people who express reservations about the death penalty will produce whiter and more conviction-prone juries, experts in law and psychology said. A1 Paris Hilton Returned to Jail The national obsession with celebrity collided head-on with the more serious issue of the equal application of justice, as a judge sent the socialite Paris Hilton back to jail some 36 hours after she was released with an ankle monitor for an unspecified medical problem. A1 New Passport Rules Suspended The State Department and the Department of Homeland Security formally announced they were temporarily suspending new passport requirements for travel to neighboring countries. A9 Wave of Youth Suicide American Indian and Native Alaskan ages 15 to 24 are committing suicide at a rate more than three times the national average for their age group, according to the surgeon general. A9 Nominee Draws Criticism President Bush's nomination of Dr. James W. Holsinger Jr., a Kentucky cardiologist, to be surgeon general is drawing criticism from gay rights groups, physicians and lawmakers who are troubled by his opinions critical of homosexuality that he voiced as a high-ranking layman in the United Methodist Church. A11 A Smooth Shuttle Launching The shuttle Atlantis thundered off the launching pad into a stunningly clear evening sky on a mission to continue building the International Space Station. Already delayed for three months by a hailstormthat damaged the foam covering the shuttle's external tank, the launching was unusually smooth. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Commuters Like Goal, Not Price, of Traffic Plan Commuters who would be affected the most by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's fast-advancing plan to charge $8 to drive in the most congested parts of Manhattan seem to agree on two points: that something desperately needs to be done about traffic and that they do not want to have to pay for it. B1 Citywide Tests May Pay A Harvard economist known for his work on racial inequality in schools is in New York with a big idea: pay students cash for high scores on standardized tests and their performance might improve. And he has captured the attention of Mayor Bloomberg and the chancellor of city schools. B1 Contractors in Name Only Gov. Eliot Spitzer is planning to step up enforcement against thousands of companies in New York that illegally misclassify workers as independent contractors to cheat on taxes and skimp on employee benefits, the state labor commissioner said. Coli bacteria, he was 91. C10 ARTS B7-17 Trimming Classical Critics Classical music criticism, an endeavor that has been around at least as long as newspapers, has taken a series of hits in recent months. Critics' jobs have been eliminated, downgraded or redefined at newspapers around the country. B7 CBS Revives 'Jericho' The resurrection of ''Jericho'' after its cancellation by CBS reflected the efforts of thousands of fans who, because they regularly viewed the show on the Internet or through other nontraditional formats, might not have been counted in the familiar Nielsen television ratings. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Investors With School Ties Mutual-fund managers invest more money in companies that are run by people with whom they went to college or graduate school, a new study shows. C1 Popularity of Pickups Drops The popularity of pickup trucks is in decline, and as sales drop, rebates and other incentives climb. Among the culprits for the decline: a growing sense of environmental responsibility that has flared along with gas prices. C1 Summer Jobs Go Wanting The job market for summer work -- such as life guarding or selling hot dogs -- is strong. But many of the jobs are not filled as students seek out internships or positions that will provide training for a career. Doug Mientkiewicz, the injured first baseman, showed up in the Yankees' clubhouse yesterday afternoon with a cast on his right wrist and a hopeful sound in his voice. He said he would have surgery in New York on Tuesday to put a pin in his wrist to repair a broken bone. He said he wanted to return by late July or, at the latest, Aug. 1. Until then, he said, he will try not to bother his family too much with his anxiety. ''I love playing the game,'' Mientkiewicz said before the Yankees' game with Pittsburgh. ''I hate watching it.''

THE problem with doing something well is that people expect you to do even better next time. Corporate profit margins -- earnings as a percentage of revenues -- have been running at close to all-time highs, but they can improve only so much. High margins in any industry are an invitation for fresh competitors to enter the marketplace and skim some of the cream. That puts a ceiling on margins in the best of times, and as the slowing of economic output in the first quarter showed, these are not the best of times.

To the Editor: In ''What a Mess'' (column, June 6), Thomas L. Friedman quotes from Dr. Seuss' ''Cat in the Hat'' to sum up today's Middle East: ''This mess is so big'' that ''we can not pick it up.'' But in the end, the Cat in the Hat comes through and cleans up the mess.

As summer fast approaches, the temperature in the deal world is rising as well. On Thursday, Biomet, a maker of artificial joints, accepted a sweetened $11.4 billion offer from a group of private equity firms. The new proposal arrived as shareholders indicated that they would reject the consortium's $10.9 billion previous offer as too low. On Monday, Avaya, one of the world's biggest makers of corporate phone equipment, agreed to an $8.2 billion deal with Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group. The two private equity firms, which bested Nortel Networks in the bidding, will pay $17.50 a share.

STERN--Milton, O.D., died on May 17 at age 93. Devoted husband of Frances E. Stern, loving father of Judith Stern Torres and Daniel E. Stern, and grandfather of Julie S. Signor (nee Stern), Joel A. Torres, and Anne F. Stevens (nee Stern). Dr. Stern completed his education at Columbia University, and for over 35 years he maintained one of the largest individual optometric practices in New York City. He provided optometric care and eyewear to employees of the Long Island and Pennsylvania Railroads, as well as to many employees of the main branch of the New York City Post Office. He also had numerous patients in the entertainment and sports world. To his family and friends, Dr. Stern was the fixing daddy, as well as an avid sailor and expert gardener. He will be long remembered for his kindness, generosity, and endless good humor. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Old Westbury Gardens, where he volunteered for many years.

The Boys & Girls Clubs of America, in response to a published report that the organization was pulling television advertisements featuring Alex Rodriguez because of concerns about his off-field behavior, said in a statement yesterday that it would continue to run the ads. ''A recent statement regarding ads featuring Alex was inaccurate,'' Evan McElroy, the Boys & Girls Clubs of America senior vice president of communications, said in written statement. ''We regret any misunderstandings that have occurred as a result of this statement. Major League Baseball continues to run these spots as part of their campaign in support of Boys & Girls Clubs.''
''Mom, this isn't right.'' PARIS HILTON, after being ordered back to jail. [A1]

The Georg Büchner Prize, Germany's most prestigious literary award, will be given this year to Martin Mosebach, the German Academy for Language and Literature said yesterday. In its announcement the academy described Mr. Mosebach, 56, as ''a writer who combines stylistic splendor with original storytelling.'' Mr. Mosebach's latest novel, ''The Moon and the Girl'' (''Der Mond und das Mädchen''), is due in August. The Büchner prize, named after the 19th-century author, is worth 40,000 euro (almost $54,000) and has been awarded since 1923. Mr. Mosebach is to receive the prize on Oct. 27 in Darmstadt. SARAH PLASS

The United States' trade imbalance with the rest of the world narrowed slightly in April, providing a tentative sign that less-lopsided trade could help lift the economy this year. With economic growth expected to be only about two-thirds the pace of last year, trade could be an important factor in keeping the economy from stalling, economists said. Growth has slowed in the United States, but economies in Asia and Europe are surging and snatching up more and more American exports.

The Greek government said yesterday that Verizon Communications had agreed to scrap an advertisement featuring a photograph of the Parthenon. The Greek culture minister, George Voulgarakis, had accused Verizon of ''commercial exploitation'' of that 2,500-year-old temple in a print advertisement published in the American edition of The Financial Times. Greece bans commercial use of images of its ancient monuments unless authorized by the country's supreme archaeological council. ANTHEE CARASSAVA

Norilsk Nickel, the Russian nickel and palladium producer, said its profit more than doubled in 2006, as a result of soaring metals prices. Norilsk reported net profit of $5.99 billion, up from $2.36 billion in 2005, mostly because of a run-up over the period in the price of nickel. Analysts said growth in demand for steel in China was driving the increase. Revenue was $11.55 billion, up from $7.17 billion. Anticipating the jump in profits, two investment banks in Moscow issued reports last week identifying Norilsk's stock as undervalued. Still, the company is in the midst of a potentially destabilizing change in ownership as the two principal Russian shareholders are unwinding a decade-long partnership. Norilsk produces a fifth of all nickel and half of all palladium in the world at its mine above the Arctic Circle in Siberia. ANDREW KRAMER

A report by the anticorruption organization Global Witness found that profits from smuggled and mishandled cocoa had helped pay for the civil war that has split the country for the past five years. It said that at least $118 million from the cocoa trade in Ivory Coast, the world's biggest producer, was used by the government, which controlled the south, and the rebels who controlled the north, to fuel the conflict and enrich its leaders. Valuable mineral resources like diamonds, oil and gold have spawned and fueled vast conflicts across Africa for decades, and the research in Ivory Coast demonstrated how a valuable cash crop can play a similar role, Global Witness said. LYDIA POLGREEN

The Bush administration said Friday that it would not reappoint Gen. Peter Pace to a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, making him the highest-ranking officer to be a political casualty of the fight over Iraq. Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said the decision was reached in order to avoid bitter hearings in a Democratic-controlled Senate that is already confronting the White House over the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Julie Christie Onstage Julie Christie, who has not been on the British stage for more than 10 years, will take part in ''Cries From the Heart,'' an evening produced by Human Rights Watch at the Royal Court Theater on June 17. Ms. Christie, above, last appeared onstage in 1995, in a revival of Harold Pinter's ''Old Times'' in London. She will give an account based on the experience of a Somali woman whose husband and son were killed as they fled from war in Mogadishu. She will also read from the works of several poets. Among others scheduled to take part in the event are Eileen Atkins, Jeremy Irons, Ben Okri, Juliet Stevenson and Tom Stoppard. Pecking Order for Artists The German painter Gerhard Richter, below, enjoys the highest reputation of any living artist, followed by the American installation artist Bruce Nauman, according to an index compiled by the German magazine Capital, Bloomberg News reported. Art Compass (Kunstkompass), which the magazine has published annually since 1970, asks museum curators, critics and others to rank artists according to prestige; the index doesn't measure sales or prices. The German painter Sigmar Polke took third place, followed by the conceptual artist Rosemarie Trockel, the sculptor Louise Bourgeois and the photographer Cindy Sherman. The biggest gainer in this year's survey was Isa Genzken, a sculptor and installation artist living in Berlin who is responsible for this year's German Pavilion at the Venice Biennale. She jumped 69 slots to move into 90th place. A New Boss For Berlin Museums Hermann Parzinger, an archaeologist, was named yesterday to run Berlin's museums, libraries and archives, replacing Klaus-Dieter Lehmann in March. Mr. Parzinger, 48, is the president of the German Archaeological Institute, and his appointment will put him in charge of the Prussian Culture Foundation, the biggest such institution in Germany, with museums like the Pergamon and the Neue Nationalgalerie. He will also oversee the reconstruction of Museum Island, a project that is expected to be completed in 2015 at a cost of 1.2 billion euros ($1.6 billion). No Jail Time for Singer A British judge said yesterday that she would not jail the singer George Michael, below, for driving while impaired, The Associated Press reported. Instead District Judge Katherine Marshall sentenced Mr. Michael to 100 hours of community service and banned him from driving for two years. The singer, whose real name is George Panayiotou, pleaded guilty on May 8; the police said that he was found slumped at the wheel of his car in north London after witnesses observed the vehicle slowly weaving onto the wrong side of the road in the early morning hours last Oct. 2. Mr. Michael, 43, told the court he was ashamed that ''I had done something really wrong in putting other people at risk.'' Footnotes The choreographer Pina Bausch will receive the Kyoto Prize in the category of arts and philosophy, worth approximately $410,000. The Kyoto Prize is presented annually in this area and in the categories of advanced technology and basic sciences. ''More Shreks are coming!'' said Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chief executive of DreamWorks Animation, at a news conference in Berlin. In addition to a fourth movie, he said, there are plans for a half-hour television special, ''Shrek the Halls,'' featuring the Shrek characters' versions of holiday traditions.

METZGER--Bruce L., D.D.S., 65, of Morganville, New Jersey, passed away on Friday, June 8, 2007 at Riverview Medical Center. He was born and grew up in Brooklyn, New York. He obtained a B.A. in history from Brooklyn College and received his D.D.S. from NYU School of Dentistry. After graduating from dental school, he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army and Chief of Oral Surgery at Fort Meade, Maryland, during the Vietnam War. He lived in Morganville for 38 years, where he started and developed a thriving dental practice and raised four children with Miriam, his wife of 44 years. Dr. Metzger held many leadership roles in his community. He served as Town Councilman for Marlboro Township through the mid-1990s. He was Vice President of Jewish Federation of Western Monmouth County. Dr. Metzger was a founding member of the Dental Staff at Centrastate Hospital and served as President of the Dental Society of Monmouth Ocean County. He was also active in raising money for many causes, including Israeli Bonds, United Jewish Appeal and The Chabad House of Western Monmouth County. Dr. Metzger was instrumental in starting the Maimonides Society. He was predeceased by his father, David Metzger, and his father-in-law Philip Fox. He is survived by his wife, Miriam, and his four children: Dr. Scott Metzger and his wife Cheryl; Jodi Pasternak and her husband Marc; Dr. Cory Metzger and her husband Mark Lebovitch; and Daniella and her husband Dr. Michael Adler. Dr. Metzger is also survived by eight grandchildren: Jake, Ben, Mindy, Sam, Max, Olivia, Chloe, and Eden. He is also survived by his mother, Anna Metzger, brother Steven Metzger and his motherin-law, Ruth Fox. The funeral will be held at Marlboro Jewish Center, at 9:30 a.m. on Sunday morning.

Even as a huge cache of Holocaust-era files was being presented publicly at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington this week, a group of organizations representing survivors and their families complained that the announcement came too late for them to use the material in pursuing insurance claims. The existence of the archives, discovered in 2000 in a vacant Vienna apartment, became widely publicized only in recent weeks. Yet the International Commission for Holocaust Era Insurance Claims finished its work in March, while a settlement with the Italian insurer Generali was completed in February, with some exceptions. ''We believe the records may contain asset information of two-thirds of the Austrian Jewish community,'' said Sam Dubbin, a lawyer for the Miami-based Holocaust Survivors Foundation U.S.A. Ingo Zechner, director of the Holocaust Victims Information and Support Center in Vienna, said that the archives contained no insurance or bank records. Still, Mr. Dubbin said, survivors, who in any case wish to learn their families' fates, ''are skeptical, because to date every institution holding information about their past and their assets has concealed relevant information.'' MARJORIE BACKMAN
To the Editor: Re ''Dr. Kevorkian's Wrong Way'' (editorial, June 5):

The Federal Communications Commission and the Bush administration suffered a sharp setback when a federal appeals court struck down the government policy of punishing networks and stations for broadcasting shows with fleeting obscenities. The commission, which recently has stepped up enforcement against broadcasters, is widely expected to appeal the decision either to the full federal appeals court in New York, or directly to the Supreme Court.

The breakthrough on the ''grand bargain'' on immigration a few weeks ago had brought new life to a White House under siege, putting a long-sought goal suddenly within reach. After many grim months, there was almost giddiness at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. But that early euphoria only made the grand bargain's grand collapse on Thursday night all the more of a blow, pointing up a stubbornly unshakable dynamic for President Bush in the final 19 months of his term: With low approval ratings and the race to succeed him well under way, his ability to push his agenda has faded to the point where he can fairly be judged to have entered his lame duck period.

Classical music criticism, a high-minded endeavor that has been around at least as long as newspapers and reached an English-language peak with George Bernard Shaw, has taken a series of hits in recent months. Critics' jobs have been eliminated, downgraded or redefined at newspapers in Atlanta, Minneapolis and elsewhere around the country and at New York magazine, where Peter G. Davis, one of the most respected voices of the craft, said he had been forced out after 26 years.

China said late Tuesday that it was overhauling its food and drug safety regulations and would introduce nationwide inspections. Beijing is moving to crack down on the sale of dangerous food and medicine and trying to calm fears that some of its exports pose health problems.

In 1962, the Food and Drug Administration reviewer who uncovered the dangers of thalidomide got a presidential medal. Yesterday, the F.D.A. safety supervisor who accurately warned about the heart dangers of the diabetes drug Avandia left the agency under a cloud. Times have changed at the F.D.A.
SAMUELS--Margery (nee Stark). Beloved wife of the late Hartley L. Samuels died on June 5 after a prolonged illness. Services will be at The Riverside Memorial on Sunday, June 10, at 4pm.

A memorial service for the Pulitzer Prize-winning war reporter and author David Halberstam is scheduled for 4 p.m. on Tuesday at Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, in Manhattan. Mr. Halberstam died on April 23 at the age of 73.

SORRENTINO--Ezio, on June 7, 2007 at the age of 75. Born in Mazara del Vallo, Sicily. Former owner of LaMancha Hair Dressing, Bay Side, NY. Survived by life partner Jane Syracuse; children Vincenza, Christina, Michael and Simona; sister Caterina and four grandchildren. Reposing Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, NY on Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral mass St. Augustine Church, Ossining on Monday at 10 am. Entombment, Ferncliff Mausoleum. Contributions to Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, NY 10532.

GRECO--Sal. The Officers, Governors, and Members of The Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved honorary officer, Salvatore F. Greco, who was a member for over four decades. We are honored and proud to have been touched by our Patriarch whose generosity and support has helped us to maintain our status as one of the best clubs in New York City. Services will be held at Shrine of Old St. Joseph, 321 Willings Alley, ''Society Hill'', Philadephia, PA, on June 11 at 10 am. Jerry Lewis, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean JeanPierre Trebot, Exec. Dir.

After a decade in which grocery stores have consolidated to compete against the likes of Wal-Mart and Costco, the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday moved to block a merger between the biggest players in the natural foods and organic sector: Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets. In explaining the merger, the companies said they needed to combine forces to compete against larger operations like Wal-Mart and Kroger that are offering more and more organic and natural products.

MEYERSON--Martin. The Directors of the Marconi Society at Columbia University recall the extraordinary contributions of its former chairman and Board member, as a wise, devoted friend and leader. A pioneer in urban planning and a towering figure in higher education, Martin Meyerson tirelessly devoted his energy and acumen through the Society to extending public understanding of the global communications revolution for the benefit of humanity. With sadness, the Society expresses its deep sympathy to his wife Margy and their family.

It is 63 percent, not 65.

Between now and the U.S. Grand Prix in one week, there will be so much to talk about that I have decided to put up only two photographs of the two biggest stories in a Canadian Grand Prix that was just overflowing with stories. Below, the one massive story is that of Lewis Hamilton's victory, and it's obvious repercussions, and the other of the accident from which Robert Kubica miraculously came out alive and with only a sprained ankle and a slight concussion. Writings against God and religion have been around as long as God and religion have been around. But every so often an epidemic of the genre breaks out and a spate of such writings achieves the status of notoriety (which is what their authors had been aiming for). This has now happened to three books published in the last three years: Sam Harris's "The End of Faith: Religion, Terror and The Future of Reason" (2004, 2005), Richard Dawkins's "The God Delusion" (2006) and Christopher Hitchens's "God is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything" (2007). (Were this the kind of analysis performed in Lancelot Andrewes's sermons, I would note the fact that the names of all three authors end in "s," signifying, no doubt, the presence of Sin and Satan.)

An important head's up: Rome, a musical backwater most of the year, is flooded with wonderful concert offerings during the summer. There are more than a dozen music festivals spanning the next two months. And most of the events are held outside, in relatively small parks or venues, under beautiful breezy summer sunsets. Tickets are cheap and the music ranges from mainstream to classical to Italian opera to wonderfully eclectic ethnic bands. Last summer I saw Senegalese superstar Youssou N'Dour, with his crystalline voice, a Portugese jazz flutist and Eric Burden (yes, that Eric Burden -- of the Animals and House of the Rising Sun fame).

We caught up the other day with a conference about campaign politics and the Internet, where Joe Trippi took time out from baking, er, burning pies with the Edwards campaign to trace the arc of the influence of politics on cyberspace, and vice versa. A few of the e-advisers to the campaigns, namely those with the Clinton, Obama and McCain operations, also attended. They didn't give away many trade secrets, but offered some insights into what works and what doesn't at this stage of the election cycle.

GEMSON--Donald H., M.D., One of the nation's foremost experts in preventive medicine and a tireless public health advocate whose efforts helped ensure passage of New York's smoking ban, died on Thursday, May 31, 2007, after a brief illness. He was 55 years old. At the time of his death, Dr. Gemson continued to be a leader in the medical and public health communities. He was medical director for Merrill Lynch, chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society of New York and New Jersey, and an associate clinical professor of public health at the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University. As a champion of tobacco control, at the height of public debate on the city's clean indoor air law in 2003, Dr. Gemson served as chair of the NYC Coalition for a Smokefree New York. He provided key expert testimony at numerous public hearings and was an omnipresent speaker at local forums in support of the law. His many honors included being named one of New York's top preventive medicine physicians for the fourth consecutive year by Castle Connolly Medical Ltd. A 20-year volunteer for the American Cancer Society, in addition to being elected chief medical officer, he chaired the Society's local Professional Education Committee. Dr. Gemson also served as a consultant in the development of the ''Working Well'' worksite health assessment tool, helped design and implement the Society's cancer prevention, education and patient support programs and chaired the organization's Tobacco Strike Force. Donald H. Gemson has authored or co-authored over 30 publications in peerreviewed medical journals. He is survived by his wife Lesley Field, his son Edward and daughter Maya. American Cancer Society Board of Directors, Eastern Division Marguerite K Schlag, President Don Distasio, CEO

To the Editor: Re ''A Nanny Nightmare? Living Without One,'' by Liesl Schillinger (Books of Style, May 27): I was born in London in 1924 to middle-class parents. The custom in those days in England was to hire a well-trained English nanny (with excellent references) to raise the children. My mother was a dedicated and valuable community volunteer but insecure in her role as a mother.

To the Editor: In ''The Road Best Not Taken'' (Op-Ed, May 20), Gabriel Roth implies that Mayor Michael Bloomberg's congestion-pricing proposal would not benefit auto users. In fact, the funds would be dedicated to a proposed fund (called Smart, for Sustainable Mobility and Regional Transportation) whose purposes are to help bring local roads to a state of good repair, as well as pay for mass transit improvements.

Let's not be disingenuous about why we subject our children to standardized testing: we do it for the money it brings into districts that ''perform'' well (Ann Hulbert, May 27). When the funds roll in, property values rise, parents are happy and teachers gain job security.

WINDING up a dirt road not far from the Saw Mill Parkway in Mount Kisco, N.Y., a visitor could easily miss Rocky Hills, hidden behind a 6-foot-tall stockade fence and simple gated entry. But at least once a year, the gates -- geared more to keeping out deer than people -- are thrown open to the public, revealing a garden 50 years in the making.

WINDING up a dirt road not far from the Saw Mill Parkway here, a visitor could easily miss Rocky Hills, hidden behind a 6-foot-tall stockade fence and simple gated entry. But at least once a year, the gates -- geared more to keeping out deer than people -- are thrown open to the public, revealing a garden 50 years in the making.

Mrs. Bayard, 32, is the director of surveillance in the Chicago office of Fitch Ratings, a New York credit rating agency, where she monitors the financial performance of commercial mortgage-backed securities. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin and received a master's degree in city and regional planning from Rutgers.

STEINBERG--Ethel Stoller, 84, resident of Delray Beach, FL, widow of Ted Steinberg; beloved sister of Adeline and Edward Glassman; beloved mother of Leslie Platto, Charles Platto, Marc Stoller and Lenore Rey, Bruce and Kelly Stoller; Lyle and Wendy, Spencer and Paula, Glen, Mary, Vicki and Donna Steinberg; beloved grandmother of Jamie and Lorin, Carey and Ali, Jody, Terry; Jason and Liz, Corey, Andrew, Rachelle, Jared and Erick; beloved great-grandmother of Jake and Skylar as well as nieces, nephews and friends across the country; died on May 30, 2007. Ethel will beloved and remembered always for her warmth, her humor and her love for her family as well as for her talent as a painter, decorator and sculptor. She was an avid golfer and reader and she played a good hand of bridge but she expressed herself best in her art where she found peace and solace when the going got rough. Memorial contributions may be made to Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research Foundation, www.alzinfo.org; to National Museum of Women in the Arts, www.nmwa.org; or to Corey Frederick Stoller Memorial Scholarship, 123 Chappell Drive, Milford, NH 03055.

To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson closed ''Where Is the Yankees' Real First Baseman?'' (June 7) with: ''Now there is no real Yankee first baseman. And until one arrives, there probably won't be any Yankee World Series rings.'' I find this laughable. The Yankees have an All-Star-caliber player at nearly every position. In terms of payroll, they dwarf other teams. There's no level playing field when it comes to the Yankees. But other teams have somehow won the World Series with much less. Ralph W. Blackwood Schenectady, N.Y.
