Whimsical and melancholic, playful and heavy as a heart swollen with emotion, Jean-Luc Godard's 1965 film ''PIERROT LE FOU'' opens with Jean-Paul Belmondo sitting in a bathtub, a cigarette stuck in his mouth, a book clutched in his hands. He's reading about the Spanish painter Velázquez, but what he's really doing is, much as the Good Witch of the North does in ''The Wizard of Oz,'' showing us the road we're to follow: ''Past the age of 50,'' Mr. Belmondo reads, ''Velázquez stopped painting definite things. He hovered around objects with the air, with twilight, catching in his shadows and airy backgrounds the palpitations of color, which formed the invisible code of his silent symphony.'' Mr. Godard was only 34 when he made ''Pierrot le Fou,'' but he was already looking back at the past (including his 1959 feature debut ''Breathless,'' with its movie shots heard round the world), and gazing ahead. Nominally based on the Lionel White novel ''Obsession,'' the film finds Mr. Belmondo as a married man on the lam with the dangerously lovely Anna Karina (then Mrs. Godard) in a self-conscious pantomime of l'amour fou. In between definite things, like stolen cars and bursts of red, there are glorious, witty bits of dialogue, snatches of music, furtive and loving moments (with Picasso, Renoir and van Gogh), splashes of Piet Mondrian yellow, blue and red, invocations of cinema (''Pépe le Moko''), in other words, as Mr. Belmondo explains at one point, a film with ''space feeling.'' ''Pierrot le Fou'' will be presented in a new 35-millimeter print, and there is word that a new Criterion edition is in the works. ''Breathless'' is also being shown for an extra Belmondo-Godard treat. ''Breathless,'' Wednesday and Thursday; ''Pierrot le Fou,'' Friday through June 26; Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org.

About this time every year, the New York Legislature starts to kick into high gear. These are the last few days of the year's official session, and often that deadline is enough to make Albany's regulars summon the final oomph needed to finish six months of business in two short weeks. Here are some of the issues that should be untangled before legislators pack up for the year:
Bryan Caplan's new book, ''The Myth of the Rational Voter: Why Democracies Choose Bad Policies,'' has vaulted to the top of my summer reading list (Gary J. Bass, May 27).
To the Editor: Re ''The Tonys' All-Star Lineup'' [June 3]:

Q. Are condo sale prices public information? I found a Web site that is charging a fee for providing sale prices, but I wonder if there is a free New York City Web site where the same information can be found? How about co-op sales? A. Eric P. Gonchar, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that it is possible to find the most recent sale price for most real property, including condos, in New York City by searching the city's Automated City Register Information System, known as Acris. (Information on most Staten Island transactions are not included.)

ARNDT--Bess R. Died peacefully on June 9th, in her 96th year. Beloved mother of Carol Wolfe of NYC, beloved grandmother of Jessica Lynn Wolfe of Durham, NC, loving mother-in-law of Steven W. Wolfe, loving grandmotherin-law of Reid Barbour and sister of the late Alan Zuker. She was happily married to Arthur A. Arndt for over 43 years, until he passed away 23 years ago. She and her family arrived in the United States in 1914 from Russia and she grew up in Cleveland, OH. She came to Manhattan at age 18 to attend art school. With the arrival of the Depression the next year, she had to leave school and go to work in the fashion field. Many years later, she became an interior designer. After her retirement, she volunteered at the Whitney Museum and at the Brandeis Thrift Shop. She had a long, wonderful life. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Monday, June 11th, at 1pm. The family will be at home Monday evening between 7:30 and 9:30pm. No flowers please.

A photograph with the In Transit column on May 27 about summer music festivals in Tuscany was published in error. It depicted the fortress at Montalcino, not the villa La Foce, which is the site for much of the Incontri in Terra di Siena festival.

To the Editor: Re ''So, Do I Make the Cut?,'' April 29: Neither as renter nor homeowner have I ever come across a dog who: plays his music too loud; blocks my driveway; steals my parking space; lets his trash blow into the street; or leaves the building door ajar. In fact, in social and public settings, the average dog, I have found, is much better behaved than the average human. Want greater civility? Start with the people. The dogs are the least of our problems. Karin J. Lauria Marlborough, Mass. To the Editor: Life is so hard for these people and their pets. When most people in this world can't afford to live decently, the superrich are willing to pay an obscene amount of extra rent for a pet when, somewhere else in the world, that money could house and feed a family of six. I love my pet as much as the next guy, but really, the values in this city and the overall sickness of the real estate mind-set are very, very disturbing. Jason Carey Prospect Heights, Brooklyn

AFTER more than six months of discussion about banning alcohol on commuter trains, a committee put together by the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has recommended that the ''cocktail hour'' be allowed to continue on the trains and platforms of the Long Island and Metro-North railroads. If the board adopts the recommendation, as is likely, bartenders employed by Metro-North will continue to sell alcohol during rush hour near platforms at Grand Central Terminal, and the full-fledged bar cars on the New Haven line, which are run in cooperation with the State of Connecticut, will remain open.

Funeral Services will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave., 11:15am, Sunday, June 10, 2007.

To the Editor: ''Target: Trash,'' your June 3 article about illegal dumping, didn't mention the important fact that the Sanitation Department has eliminated sites where residents can bring common trash. These sites were set up as recycling centers and filled an important community need. I'm sure that reopening these sites wouldn't eliminate illegal dumping, but I would have to assume they would be put to good use. Martin Bernstein Park Slope, Brooklyn

To the Sports Editor: Re ''The Boy Wonders of Lacrosse,'' June 3: I couldn't help wondering after reading Huntington High School Coach Paul McDermott's comment about Rhamel and Shamel Bratton developing lacrosse moves that ''aren't taught'' whether they will match those of another pair of twin brothers, Gary and Paul Gait, whose skills revolutionized lacrosse during their college years. If the Brattons turn out to be greater at Virginia than the Gaits were at Syracuse two decades ago, then we will have seen not only a pair of African-American stars in a predominantly white game, but also two individuals who revolutionized the sport once again. David Bernklau Brooklyn To the Sports Editor: Rhamel Bratton referred to lacrosse as being more laid-back than football, but perhaps that is only in terms of organized practice time. In execution, lacrosse is anything but laid-back. It is one of the most demanding team sports and players have to be excellent athletes; the Bratton twins are tremendous. Fiona D. J. Bayly New York

''May in Venice is better than April, but June is best of all. Then the days are hot, but not too hot, and the nights are more beautiful than the days. Then Venice is rosier than ever in the morning and more golden than ever as the day descends. She seems to expand and evaporate, to multiply all her reflections and iridescences. Then the life of her people and the strangeness of her constitution become a perpetual comedy, or at least a perpetual drama. Then the gondola is your sole habitation, and you spend days between sea and sky.'' Henry James, ''Italian Hours,'' 1909

Bob Barker, the longtime host of ''The Price Is Right,'' recently taped his final episode of the game show. T. Paul Bulmahn, the chairman and president of ATP Oil and Gas, might make a fine candidate to replace him. Last year, Mr. Bulmahn had some practice giving away new cars, according to a recent proxy filing. As part of what the filing called ''a unique incentive program,'' ATP's board agreed in December 2004 to give every employee -- that's 52 people, from receptionists to top managers -- a Volvo sedan if the company met certain long-term performance goals. When they hit their marks last April, everyone was handed car keys or $32,204, the value of the car. (Thirty-eight are now driving their bonus; the others took the cash.)

CROUSE--Eleanor Mae, on May 30, 2007 at age 81. Beloved sister of Sandra Hostetter and Miriam Sitler; loving aunt to many. Funeral services will take place on Thursday, June 14, 2007, at Mt. Olivet Cemetery, North Lima, Ohio. For further information call Andrett Funeral Home (212)475-2024.

The Silk Road is the popular name for a system of caravan trade routes that dates back more than 2,000 years, an important economic artery that stretched roughly 7,000 miles, from the Mediterranean to China's Yellow River Valley. Earlier this year, the photographer Jehad Nga, on assignment for the Travel section, spent three weeks retracing part of the historic route in central Asia, driving from Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, to Dushanbe, Tajikistan. Conditions were at times onerous, ranging from oppressive desertlike heat in Uzbekistan to a blizzard in Tajikistan that made that country's already treacherous roads nearly impossible to navigate. But it was also a journey of discovery: of encountering Kyrgyz sheepherders living in bare-existence yurts set in the vast wilderness; of witnessing an Uzbek bride's joyful preparation for her wedding; of shopping in the historic central bazaar of Samarkand, Uzbekistan.

American art-world eyes are turning eastward to Europe right now as a string of summer extravaganzas -- the Venice Biennale, Documenta 12, the Basel Art Fair and the Münster Sculpture Project -- open in carefully calibrated succession through mid-June. So why not plot an alternative, less crowded course and look west, to Southern California, which has its own festival of summer shows? In Los Angeles you can catch ''EDEN'S EDGE: FIFTEEN L.A. ARTISTS'' at the Hammer Museum, a generational sampling of local talent. From the sculptor Ken Price (born 1935), to the installation artist Jason Rhoades (1965-2006), to bright 30-somethings like Anna Sew Hoy and Elliott Hundley, strange beauty is the connecting link. Through Sept. 2, (310) 443-7000, hammer.ucla.edu. A similar beauty is also the link among certain figures who might be considered the mothers of almost all American contemporary art: women who came of aesthetic age during the women's movement. Three of them share the honors in ''IDENTITY THEFT: ELEANOR ANTIN, LYNN HERSHMAN AND SUZY LAKE, 1972-78'' at the Santa Monica Museum of Art, and each is distinctively great in performance-based work: Ms. Antin with her various enacted ''selves'' (ballerina, bearded king); Ms. Hershman with her lifelong alter ego, Roberta Breitmore; and Ms. Lake with her cosmetically altered self-portraits. Through Aug. 11, (310) 586-6488, smmoa.org. You'll also find these artists in ''WACK! ART AND THE FEMINIST REVOLUTION'' at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, where they're joined by the painter Mary Heilmann, whose first American retrospective is at the Orange County Museum of Art (through Aug. 26). The survey covers some four decades, from Ms. Heilmann's early West Coast days to her many years in and out of sight in New York. With her high-color, faux-casual abstract pictures, she's very much in sight everywhere now, and the retrospective will be heading eastward to New York next year. Through July 16, Geffen Contemporary at Museum of Contemporary Art, moca.org. Through Aug. 26, Orange County Museum of Art, Newport Beach, Calif., ocma.net.

An article on May 27 about war dramas in theater and on film referred incorrectly to the outcome of the battle of Thermopylae, depicted in ''300.'' The small band of Spartans was defeated by the Persians, not the other way around.

HAKES--Martha Jean. March 6, 1930-May 24, 2007. Jean Hakes lived and worked in New York from 1964 to 1989. She died peacefully on Thursday, May 24, 2007 at her home in San Francisco at the age of 77. Ms. Hakes, born in Muscatine, Iowa, was the dear daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Crampton Hakes; loving mother of Barbara; grandmother of Benjamin; beloved sister of Mary Anne Gallagher and the late Elizabeth H. Harrer. She was dearly loved by many other family members. Jean had many friends and colleagues on the East Coast who made her life joyful personally and professionally for over 25 years. Jean Hakes, a soprano, was extremely active throughout her career in performances of early and Baroque music. She was a soloist and toured with the New York Pro Musica under Noah Greenberg and appeared with numerous chamber groups such as the New York Baroque Ensemble, the Renaissance Quartet, the Trio Flauto Dolce and the Washington Consort, in addition to her numerous solo appearances including performances at Yale University, the University of California at Berkeley and New York University. She sang the role of ''Galatea'' in the New York Chamber Soloists presentation of Handel's Acis and Galatea in major concert series throughout the United States. She was professor of music at Brooklyn College where she also directed a Collegium Musicum. ''Few are the singers who can spin out a phrase as she does, with an equal mixture of emotional suspense, rhythmic flair and stunning dynamic control,'' commented the Washington Post of her performances. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Conservatory of Music Brooklyn College -The City University of New York 2900 Bedford Avenue Brooklyn, New York 11210. Phone: (718) 951-5286. Fax: (718) 951-4502.

The Word for Word article last Sunday excerpting a 1956 medical journal article on Communist interrogation methods misstated the name of the journal. It is The Archives of Neurology and Psychiatry, not The Annals of Neurology and Psychology. In addition, the meaning of the acronym SERE, an American military training program, was misstated. SERE stands for Survival, Evasion, Resistance, and Escape -- not Survival, Evasion, Reconnaissance and Escape.

To the Editor: Re ''Concert Hall? How About Music Museum?'' [June 3]: In his stimulating essay Lawrence Kramer asks why classical music still matters. I would be more specific: Why does going to a classical music concert still matter, since the music may be heard anywhere via iPod or CD? I've performed classical music in concert and have recorded the same music. The difference is huge. At a concert there are likely to be more risks taken, more new ideas instantly realized, and more deeply emotional playing in response to an audience. This is not the case in the studio, where care and consistency are the rule. No matter what electronic apparatus we have in our homes, or carry with us, the concert hall is the beating heart of classical music, and it matters enormously. Stephen Louis Bayne San Francisco The writer is a composer.

GINGER KATZ stood at the front of the auditorium at Little Falls School No. 1, waiting for the 200 seventh and eighth graders to settle down. Behind her, projected on a big screen, were photos of her son, Ian, from their family album: Ian as a newborn with his mom. Ian getting his black belt in karate. Ian playing his trumpet in the marching band. Ian beaming at the camera the year he was voted most popular fifth grader. Ian standing happily with his older sister, Candace, who has Down syndrome. Ian playing baseball. Ian, the third-highest scorer on his high school lacrosse team. Ian with his beautiful date at the senior prom. Ian being handed his high school diploma. Ian, the honors college student.

To the Editor: ''Mr. Spitzer's DNA Proposal'' (editorial, May 28) expressed some reservations about Gov. Eliot Spitzer's plan to establish a database to include samples from everyone found guilty of a felony or a misdemeanor.

Unlicensed home contractors would have their equipment seized under legislation proposed last week by the county executive, Andrew J. Spano. The county's Consumer Protection Department received 1,500 complaints last year, of which 375 were related to home improvement, department officials said.

One thing that can be said about the war for Fisher Island is that everyone involved wants only what's best for the place. This 216-acre property with 34 sprawling Mediterranean-style luxury condominium buildings sits conveniently surrounded by Miami Beach, the city of Miami, Biscayne Bay and the Atlantic Ocean. It is an island paradise containing every possible indulgence that someone with a great deal of money and an enormous need to be coddled might desire. Fisher Island's fortunate 1,400, fewer than one-third of them full-time residents, can play on the golf course created by P. B. Dye, of the famed course-design family, or on one of 18 tennis courts -- clay, grass and hard court surfaces. There are two marinas -- one for large yachts and one for larger yachts -- and a state-of-the-art gym, complete with a Roman waterfall for aching backs and, along with yoga and Pilates, classes with names like Waves of Steel and Esto Es Tango! The sand on the beach is imported from the Bahamas and cleared daily of seaweed, so it is always soft and white. There are swimming pools, not just at the health spa, but also in each condo complex. Perpetually blooming tropical flowers perfume the air; caged toucans twitter in banyan trees, flamingos wade lazily in their own private pond. Kids attend a special island private school where cameras, wired into the condos, allow anxious parents to monitor their offspring from home; the playground, naturally, is gently padded.

Gershwin: Piano Concerto in F; 'Rhapsody in Blue,' 'Cuban Overture' Jon Nakamatsu, pianist; Rochester Philharmonic, conducted by Jeff Tyzik. Harmonia Mundi France HMU 907441; CD. IT was the misguided ambition of jazz geniuses like Duke Ellington to write so-called classical music, as if the concert hall were some pinnacle toward which lower musical orders yearned to climb. We have learned better, I hope. Ellington's jazz repertory, divorced from his uneasy stabs at symphonic forms, occupies the high ground these days, with the vast body of American classical music stretched out below it.

To the Editor: ''Health Care as if Costs Didn't Matter,'' by David Leonhardt (Economix column, June 6), focuses on the core issues of cost control in our current system. The biggest problems are unproven and unnecessary procedures that require hospital services with high reimbursement, as well as expensive new drugs that have no advantage over generics or existing brand drugs.

Ms. Constain-Tovar, 33, is a staff lawyer for Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Rockville Centre; she works in the immigration services department in Amityville, N.Y. To the Editor: Stephanie Rosenbloom's article ''Grade-School Girls, Grown-Up Gossip'' (May 27) struck a responsive chord. My husband and I were traveling with our 13-year-old grandson in March. Our grandson was appalled that we were staying at a Hilton, as he thought the profits were going directly to Paris Hilton.

The longest civic losing streak in the nation is now in jeopardy. The city of Cleveland last celebrated a major sports title on Dec. 27, 1964, when the Browns upset the Baltimore Colts in the N.F.L. championship game. In the more than four decades since, the Indians once took a lead into the bottom of the ninth inning of Game 7 of the World Series, while the Browns endured three of the more painful playoff losses in National Football League history.

For the second time in less than a year, a pair of rare Brazilian monkeys has been born at the Beardsley Zoo in Bridgeport. The zoo announced last Monday that two female golden lion tamarin monkeys were born on May 5. A male and a female were born to the same 5-year-old parents last August.

Beach season at the Jersey Shore got off to an ominous start when the water from Deal south to Bradley Beach was closed to swimmers Tuesday after thousands of gallons of partly treated sewage escaped from a broken pipe at an Asbury Park waste treatment plant. But with new water samples showing contaminants to be within allowable levels, the swimming bans at the affected beaches were lifted Wednesday afternoon.

FRIEDLANDER--Arlene. My glamorous mother and best friend passed away peacefully on June 7th, 2007 after a brief illness. Her passion for living led her places she scarcely could have imagined as a child. A public relations executive, actress, lover of theater and the arts, tennis fan, bridge player and world traveler; my Arlette was a force of nature. I shall miss her dearly. Survivors include nephews David (Sheila) and Stephen Heller, former husband Jim and many cherished friends. Predeceased by her brother and guardian angel Leonard Kantor as well as parents Sidney and Henrietta Kantor and sister Florence Heller. Arlene's illness was linked to radiation therapy she received in the 1970s. Please honor Arlene and others impacted by breast cancer by making a donation to Susan G. Komen for the Cure. Love, Susan
To the Editor: Your article on Moscow omitted a number of important facts about the city:

A federal judge in Minneapolis made a tart comparison when he gave the go-ahead last week to a class-action lawsuit against the giant insurer UnitedHealth Group and William W. McGuire, its former chairman and chief executive. United States District Judge James M. Rosenbaum said the suit's accusation -- that the company inflated its share price by not disclosing the backdating of employee stock options -- ''lies at the core of the plot'' of ''The Sting,'' the 1973 film with Paul Newman and Robert Redford as con men who bet on horse races after they are run.

''THE Sopranos'' ends this weekend after seven seasons. The ''Harry Potter'' series ends in a few weeks with the publication of the seventh book, ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.'' Serious assessments are beginning to appear -- see the current Newsweek -- comparing the two wildly popular phenomena. Wisecracks are turning up on blogs and in comedy routines: Tony Soprano will be whacked in the final Potter book, and so on. But all that really needs to be said is contained in this comparative analysis. NEIL GENZLINGER Harry Potter, sorcerer-hero Where we last left them: Saving the world from Lord Voldemort and his Death Eaters Why they're special: Survived attack by Voldemort as baby; thunderbolt scar on his forehead to prove it Psychological issues: Talks to snakes What they would love to catch: The golden snitch Tony Soprano, carting executive-thug Where we last left them: Saving himself from Phil Leotardo, Brooklyn boss Why they're special: Survived his mother's wish to kill him; psychiatry bills to prove it Psychological issues: Attracted to his shrink What they would love to catch: A dirty snitch Dialogue from ''Harry Potter'' that could be in ''The Sopranos'' ''This is devil's snare. You have to relax. If you don't, it'll only kill you faster.'' ''Your dad would have spared me. He would have shown me mercy.'' ''Fasten your safety belts, clench your buttocks. It's going be a bumpy ride.'' Dialogue from ''The Sopranos'' that could be in ''Harry Potter'' ''My family was different from other kids' families.'' ''Does the end of the world concern you?'' ''Gassed? My father told me they took him to a farm.'' ''You sit on an egg for months, one little thing goes wrong, and you're left with nothing.'' Imagined dialogue from ''The Sopranos'' that could be in ''Harry Potter'' ''Get us a bludger and a couple beaters. We're gonna muggle that ungrateful jerk.'' Imagined dialogue from ''Harry Potter'' that could be in ''The Sopranos'' ''The point of the game is to throw the jamook through the goomah before the other team's mortadellas catch you.'' Tatiana Lara Rosak, a daughter of Ellen and Charles J. Rosak of Sparta, N.J., was married yesterday to Craig Nils Birkelund, the son of Brit and Helmer B. Birkelund of Baldwin, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Barnett officiated at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Manhattan, with the Rev. Robert A. Rimbo taking part. Mrs. Birkelund, 36, is a vice president for sportswear merchandising at Polo Ralph Lauren in Manhattan. She graduated from Cornell and received an M.B.A. there. Her father retired as a captain at Delta Airlines, based at La Guardia Airport.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 26, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Editor's Choice ON CHESIL BEACH, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.) Consisting largely of a single sex scene played out on a couple's wedding night, this seeming novel of manners is as much a horror story as any McEwan has written. AFTER DARK, by Haruki Murakami. Translated by Jay Rubin. (Knopf, $22.95.) A tale of two sisters, one awake all night, one asleep for months.Right Livelihoods: Three Novellas, by Rick Moody. (Little, Brown, $23.99.) In the longest story here, New Yorkers react with passivity and denial after a nuclear attack in Lower Manhattan.A DAY AT THE BEACH, by Helen Schulman. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) The events of 9/11 upend the lives of a glamorous TriBeCa couple.CONSIDERING DORIS DAY, by Tom Santopietro. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $25.95.) Avoiding sensationalism, this sympathetic biography concentrates on Day's multifaceted career.The Life of Kingsley Amis, by Zachary Leader. (Pantheon, $39.95.) The author of ''Lucky Jim'' turned drunkenness, bonhomie and lechery into the sources of serious literary pleasure.THE MINISTRY OF SPECIAL CASES, by Nathan Englander. (Knopf, $25.) A novel of a Jewish family caught up in Argentina's ''Dirty War.'' SHROOM: A Cultural History of the Magic Mushroom, by Andy Letcher. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.95.) Letcher's revisionist history is a delightful journalistic addition to the ''trip lit'' genre. SPY WARS: Moles, Mysteries, and Deadly Games, by Tennent H. Bagley. (Yale University, $28.) A former counterintelligence officer takes a provocative view of the case of the K.G.B. defector Yuri Nosenko, an unresolved cold-war mystery.Alias the Cat! by Kim Deitch. (Pantheon, $23.) In graphic-autobiographical mode, Deitch follows Waldo the Cat, his foul-mouthed feline muse, from one strange world to the next.Shadowland, by Kim Deitch. (Fantagraphics, paper, $18.95.) In this crazy, invigorating comic collection, Deitch charts the scoundrel's progress of the creepily clown-faced lout Al Ledicker. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

No more of ''The Sopranos'' after Sunday night, and television will never be the same. At least until Monday night, when the other HBO family drama, the underrated ''BIG LOVE,'' begins its second season (9 p.m.), with a similar premise (sympathetic mobsters, sympathetic polygamists); a similar style, without most of the sex and violence; and, from top to bottom, an equally good cast. In the season opener, Tony -- excuse me, Bill (Bill Paxton) -- struggles to protect his family from the consequences of the big wife Barb's exposure as a polygamist and becomes obsessed with discovering the rat. Summer is high season for basic-cable dramas, with their 8- to 13-week seasons and relatively limited budgets (which seem to enforce a certain level of cheesiness, no matter how good the writing and acting might be). Heavyweights like ''The Closer'' on TNT (June 18) and ''Monk'' on USA (July 13) lie ahead; this week brings us the return of Denis Leary's firehouse passion play, ''RESCUE ME'' (FX, 10 p.m. Wednesday), and the second season of ABC Family's special-child show ''KYLE XY'' (8 p.m. Monday). Many questions will be answered about Kyle's origins in Monday's episode, though not the most pressing one: Why do characters possessed of superhuman intelligence always have such bad haircuts? Speaking of ''The Closer,'' a new installment of ''INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO'' (Bravo, 8 p.m. Monday) features Kyra Sedgwick, a k a Deputy Chief Brenda Johnson. Let's see if James Lipton has the guts to ask her about that Southern accent. For an entirely different type of conversation, check out the new season of the half-hour talk show ''SHARP TALK WITH AL SHARPTON'' (TV One, 1:30 p.m. Saturday), filmed at Levels barbershop in Brooklyn. This week's topic is a certain racial epithet -- the one that served as the title of the 1964 autobiography of Dick Gregory, one of Mr. Sharpton's guests.

INTERNATIONAL 3-24 Gunmen Breach Israeli Barrier At least four Palestinian gunmen using an armored vehicle and grenade launchers broke through Israel's border fence from Gaza and fought a gun battle with Israeli soldiers, while Israeli troops entered Gaza near the town of Rafah. 24 Iraq Looms as Bush Meets Pope President Bush met for the first time with Pope Benedict XVI, and while both men are religious conservatives who share many similar concerns, in their private talk the pope raised his worries about the war in Iraq. 12 Bomber Kills 12 Iraqi Soldiers A suicide bomber killed at least a dozen Iraqi soldiers and wounded 30 more when he drove a truck packed with explosives into an Iraqi Army checkpoint guarding a compound in Iskandariya, a restive village south of Baghdad that has long been an insurgent stronghold. 24 Women Alter Corporate Korea As an increasing number of women have joined South Korean companies as professionals in the past half decade, the country has struggled to change the thoroughly male-centered corporate culture, starting with alcohol. 1 Trinidad Muslims Deny Plot Tie Members of Jamaat al-Muslimeen, denying that their group was tied to a plot to bomb a New York City airport, portrayed themselves as both Islamists and islanders, devoted to God but also part of the multicultural mix that defines the Caribbean nations of Trinidad and Tobago. 3 Chinese Detainees in Limbo At least 15 of 17 Uighurs, Muslims from western China, who remain at Guantánamo Bay have been cleared for release, but without a place to go. American diplomats say the Uighurs have asked nearly 100 countries for refuge, only to find that Chinese officials have warned some of those same nations not to accept them. 1 Legacies of War in Ivory Coast A journey between Abidjan, the seat of the loyalist government in the Ivory Coast, and Bouaké, the rebel capital, reveals a nation eager for reconciliation but saddled with the legacies of war and division. 22 NATIONAL 26-35 Derailing of Immigration Bill Many contributed to the undoing of the immigration bill in the Senate this week, but none more effectively than Republicans who joined a nationwide Internet and talk radio campaign against the measure. 1 Democrats Court Hispanics Democrats seeking their party's presidential nomination are moving to court Hispanic voters. A string of early primary states with huge Hispanic voting blocs are prompting campaigns to hire outreach consultants, start Spanish-language Web sites and fill their schedules with appearances before Hispanic audiences. 1 Private Loans Lure Students As college tuition has soared past the limits on federal aid, unregulated private loans have become the fastest-growing sector of the student finance market. 28 New Tack in Antitrust Policy Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark antitrust effort to try to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company. 1 NEW YORK/REGION 37-42 A Loophole on Donations According to a watchdog group that monitors campaign financing, limited liability corporations now account for $12 million in New York State political donations. The companies make donors' identities difficult to trace, and afford them loopholes to give more than individuals are permitted Under state rules. 37 Chess 42 Weather 32

My husband and I are planning to celebrate our 10th anniversary exploring New Zealand. Since this isn't until 2010, do you have any suggestions for ways to earn points while we wait that would enable us to upgrade to first class for the long flight? We aren't frequent fliers, but we do have credit cards. -- Nancy Timper, Prescott, Ariz. Air New Zealand and Qantas are the only carriers to offer nonstop flights between the United States and New Zealand, both from Los Angeles to Auckland (Air New Zealand also has nonstop service from San Francisco). Qantas offers a Qantas American Express card.

TRIPLING TIGER CURTIS GRANDERSON of the Tigers leads the American League in triples with 12. If he ends up as the leader, he will break Carl Crawford's streak of three consecutive years leading the A.L. STUCK AT 99 Mark Buehrle of the White Sox (2-3, 3.99 earned run average) is set to start against the Astros today. It will be his eighth try at his 100th career victory; his last win came April 23. ROAD TEST With their victory Thursday against the Blue Jays, the Devil Rays won consecutive road games for the first time in almost a year. The Devil Rays were a major-league-worst 20-61 on the road in 2006, including 3-33 after July 1. They had not won back-to-back road games since June 16 and 17 last year at Philadelphia. NOT BAD COMPANY Steve Finley was designated for assignment by the Rockies, probably ending his 19-year career. He is one of six players with at least 300 home runs and 300 stolen bases. The others are Barry Bonds, Willie Mays, Andre Dawson, Bobby Bonds and Reggie Sanders. NO LUCK FOR SUTTON Curt Schilling of the Red Sox lost a chance at his first no-hitter Thursday against the Athletics when Shannon Stewart singled with two out in the ninth. It was Schilling's 425th career start. Don Sutton started the most games, 756, without throwing a no-hitter. PLAYERS TO WATCH The Dodgers' Juan Pierre, below, has hit .214 this month. He is hitting .269 over all, with an on-base percentage of .297. Pierre has hit below .280 only once in his major league career. But he also has not hit .300, something he accomplished in four of his first five seasons, since 2004. Despite his downturn, Pierre said last week that he would not do anything different to break a recent fly-ball tendency. Looking for a spark, the Royals promoted Joey Gathright from Class AAA, where he was hitting .328 with 21 stolen bases. Gathright has hit better than .300 in the minors before, but it has not translated to success in the big leagues. But he had six hits in his first 11 at-bats after the promotion. Pittsburgh center fielder Chris Duffy hit .292 after being moved to the No. 2 spot in the order May 23, but that was not enough to stop the Pirates from starting the Rajai Davis experiment. Davis had a 21-game hitting streak at Class AAA Indianapolis, with a .318 average and 27 stolen bases. Duffy, a left-handed batter, was hitting .239 over all. Manager Jim Tracy has promised it will not be a platoon, but Davis, a right-handed batter, hit better against right-handers. The struggles of the top prospect Andrew McCutchen at Class AA may have the Pirates looking for a longer-term solution in center. Compiled by The New York Times Statistics through Friday. (Sources by MLB.com, STATS LLC)

The Cooking roundup last Sunday, written by Amanda Hesser, included a review of Patricia Wells's ''Vegetable Harvest.'' In 1999, Wells contributed a jacket blurb for Hesser's book ''The Cook and the Gardener.'' The Book Review has a policy against assigning a review in those circumstances, but by the time Hesser told editors about the blurb, the issue had already gone to press. Had the editors known of the conflict, Wells's book would not have been included.

ROSENZWEIG--Maxwell, of Coconut Creek, Florida, formerly of Bayside, New York, died peacefully on May 30, 2007. Beloved husband of Mae (Blatt) for over 60 years; father of Robin and Alex Schkrutz and Roy Rosenzweig and Deborah Kaplan; grandfather of David and Eric Schkrutz; brother of the late Martin, Gladys, and Sylvia; ''Uncle Max'' to his nieces and nephews. He graduated from City College in 1938, served in the Army Air Corps during World War II, and worked at the New York State Department of Labor for more than 30 years. His family and friends will dearly miss his good humor, wise stories, and warm presence. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.

The field of classical music only intermittently engages itself with nonmusical issues, and when it does, it is often in the form of a benefit. But this week ANTHONY DE MARE, a pianist, is presenting a recital as a companion to ''The Missing Peace: Artists Consider the Dalai Lama'' at the Rubin Museum, with spirituality as the common theme. The program ranges from works by Bach to ''Missing Peace'' by James Mobberly, an electro-acoustic piece that includes Tibetan chants and was written for the occasion. Other works include Meredith Monk's ''urban march -- shadow,'' Scelsi's Suite No. 9 (''Ttai''), and Debussy's ''Terrasse des Audiences du Clair de Lune.'' Wednesday at 7 p.m., 150 West 17th Street, Chelsea, (212) 620-5000, rmanyc.org; $25. Wednesday is also the start of the MANNES INSTITUTE AND FESTIVAL FOR CONTEMPORARY PERFORMANCE, which brings in new-music specialists for master classes, symposiums and concerts. The first two concerts include premieres by Keith Fitch and César Camarero, as well as pieces by composers young, old, and late, like Vladimir Tarnopolski and Iannis Xenakis. The performers include Susan Narucki, a soprano known for her contemporary work; Rolf Schulte, a violinist; and the Plural Ensemble, a Spanish new-music group led by Fabián Panisello. Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m., Mannes College The New School for Music, 150 West 85th Street, Manhattan, (212) 580-0210, newschool.edu/mannes; $20. Despite all of this new music, a focus remains on the old. RICCARDO MUTI, one of the few conductors consistently able to get sparks out of the NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, continues his two-week visit, conducting Schubert's Third and Dvorak's Fifth symphonies: hardly trailblazing, though less often performed. Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Saturday at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $28 to $96.

Felicia Beth Feinerman, the daughter of Peppi and Melvin Feinerman of Hollis, Queens, was married last evening to Elliott Howard Einhorn, a son of Barbara and Martin Einhorn of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich officiated at the Riviera, an event space in Massapequa, N.Y. Mrs. Einhorn, 25, is the director of intergovernmental affairs for Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president. In August, she is to become a first-year law student at St. John's University. She graduated cum laude from Syracuse University.
To the Editor: As the proud granddaughter of legal immigrants to this country, one from Brazil and one from Italy, I'm offended by the June 3 editorial ''Republicrats of Long Island.''

THIS spring, when the seed potatoes arrived at our local grain-and-feed store, I circled the barrels of dusty little tubers. I was talking to myself: Should I? Dare I plant a spud -- again? Mortified, our teenage daughter walked away from me, whispering, ''Give it up, Mom. It'll be the same as all the other times.'' She has been with me in the garden, bucket at the ready, as I've gently turned over the potato mounds, anticipating a bounty below. With a child's candor, she has given voice to my suppressed anguish as she peered at my stunted and scant harvests and snorted, ''Is that it?''

REICH--Louis, June 9, 2007, age 104. Beloved husband of the late Kitty. Adored father of Honey and Norman Mann, Jay (deceased) and June. Dear brother of Anne. His grandchildren Alan and Richard Mann, Lori Gluck, Jill and Gregg, Sharon and Ronni, loved him unconditionally as did his greatgrandchildren Chelsea, Kayla, Jake, Casey, Jordan, Justin, Jett, Evan, Lindsay, and Luci. Admired and highly respected by those in Wall St., who knew him as an honest, trustworthy man. He was a mentor and friend to those who needed support and help in good times as well as bad times. Our lives will not be the same without him.

To the Editor: The Bronx's large German population in the 1890s was only one reason that a fountain commemorating one of Germany's greatest poets was placed there (Streetscapes: ''Sturm und Drang Over a Memorial to Heinrich Heine,'' May 27). The site, overlooking 161st Street near the Grand Concourse, was planned as the gateway entrance, to be named Concourse Plaza. The plans called for a fountain in the plaza's center. Fortuitously, here was a fountain seeking a home, available at no cost to the taxpayer, and it was grabbed for the purpose by the thrifty Bronx officeholders of the era. Lloyd Ultan Bronx The writer is the Bronx borough historian.

To the Editor: Corby Kummer's review of Barbara Kingsolver's ''Animal, Vegetable, Miracle'' (May 20) missed the point that the book not only offers ways American families can make food decisions in their daily lives, but also helps them think about how those decisions affect the rest of the world. Industrial farming and food aid can have disastrous effects on developing countries. While food aid and imported food purport to address the problem of hunger, they often exacerbate it by crippling local agriculture's ability to compete and be profitable. Sustainable agriculture, on the other hand, provides a long-term solution that addresses both hunger and its root cause, poverty.

FESTIVATE vi.: to pass the summer in the attendance of arts festivals, especially those of a theatrical nature (see also culture vulture). This useful verb, which has yet to make Webster's, is particularly applicable in New York between Memorial and Labor Days, when it is possible to spend every evening (and many an afternoon) at some celebratory theatrical performance or another, be it earnest (the Lincoln Center Festival) or impudent (the Pretentious Festival). Now joining, and seriously swelling, the roster of citywide theme productions is New York's first National Asian American Theater Festival, beginning with a gala on Monday and performances Tuesday through June 24. It promises to cover the boroughs as assiduously and enthusiastically as the New York-intoxicated sailors in ''On the Town'' did. Staged in locations as far-flung as La MaMa E.T.C. in the East Village and the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island, the festival features more than 25 troupes and solo artists of Asian heritage based throughout the United States (with the expected emphasis on the left and right coasts). Some of the companies are well-known to venturesome New York theatergoers, including the National Asian American Theater Company (which is presenting its popular reinterpretation of García Lorca's ''House of Bernarda Alba''), Ma-Yi (which is restaging the Obie-winning ''Romance of Magno Rubio,'' about a Filipino migrant worker in the 1930s) and Ping Chong & Company. But expect more exotic -- yet oddly familar-sounding -- offerings from performance artists and comedy troupes. Among the titles: ''Wong Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' ''U-Hauls, Bridesmaids and Backwards Mountain,'' ''Guns and Tampons: A History of Violence Against Women I Know'' and ''The Caste & the Furious: Tokyo Drift.'' For those whose appetites range beyond the aesthetic, there is ''Cooking Con Karimi (Con Castro),'' during which, it is promised, ''the audience gets to eat free food prepared by live chefs.'' Schedule and ticket information at naatf.org.

VORDER BRUEGGE--Carl M., 77, of Riverside, CT, died on May 31. Youngest of John and Agnes Vorder Bruegge's six children, born in Memphis, TN on November 12, 1929. B.A., University of TN, Knoxville. M.B.A., Wharton School of Business, University of PA. 1st Lt. awarded Purple Heart and Bronze Star during the Korean War. Married Sarah E. Whitley on June 21, 1955. After Sales/Management positions with IBM and Leasco, from 1971-1986, he was Vice President of Sales and Marketing for MCI. Lecturer, Business School, University of Bridgeport, CT 1985-1993. Worshipped at St. Catherine of Siena Church. Member, Greenwich Country Club, 1968-2007. Predeceased by parents and siblings: Catherine, John, Howard, Vincent and Mark. Survived by his loving wife of 51 years, Sarah, four children, eight grandchildren. In lieu flowers, donations may be made to: Bennett Cancer Center, 34 Shelburne St. Stamford, CT 06902 or St. Catherine of Siena Church, 4 Riverside Ave., Riverside, CT 06878.

The number of illegal immigrants arrested in New Jersey under Operation Return to Sender has more than doubled over the last year to more than 1,700, Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials said. The operation, begun in May 2005, focuses on illegal immigrants with criminal records. A total of 800 illegal immigrants were arrested in New Jersey in the first year of the operation, and 1,772 were arrested in the second year, with 253 of them having criminal records, officials said.

Katrina Claire Cason, a daughter of Julie C. Swaner of Salt Lake City and Lamar H. Cason of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday morning to Matthew Thomas Vernon, the son of Ann Vernon and Tom Vernon of Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Ron J. Grillo, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Brookstown Inn in Winston-Salem. Mrs. Vernon, 25, is a library assistant at the Carolina Population Center Library of the University of North Carolina. She graduated magna cum laude from George Washington and is studying for a master's degree in library science at North Carolina.

To the Editor: Whenever I read an editorial like ''New York's Powerful Ghosts'' (May 27) on the need to curb out-of-control public authorities in New York, I chuckle. While some reforms are needed, like prohibiting employees of the appointers from serving on the boards, legislators calling for reform is like the line in ''Casablanca'' where the police inspector professes shock that there is gambling going on.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority -- worried, in part, about sloppy drunks bothering other passengers and being menaces on the drive home from the train station -- recently entertained the idea of prohibiting the sale or use of alcohol on Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road trains. But the forces of commuter conviviality are apparently far stronger than any agency's nanny impulse. William Neuman reported in The Times recently that a committee of the authority's board had recommended keeping the alcohol status quo, given the ''overwhelmingly negative response'' it received from riders about the proposed ban.

ASHWELL--Thomas Buffum, died June 6, 2007 in New Haven, CT. Born May 28, 1920 and raised in New Canaan, CT, he graduated from Middlesex School and Harvard. He was a PT boat officer in the Pacific during World War II. In 1946, he joined Thomas Ashwell & Co., publishers of Export Trade magazine and The Exporters Encyclopedia. After the company was sold to American Heritage in 1963, he joined The Wall Street Transcript as advertising manager. A longtime resident of Old Greenwich, CT, he moved to North Branford, CT in 2002. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Carolyn, two sons, Tim and Andrew, a daughter Lauren, and a grandson Eamon; also by two sisters, G. Elizabeth Lotowycz and Mary W. Liebtag. A memorial service will be held this summer. Contributions may be made to the Middlesex School, 1400 Lowell Rd., Concord, MA 01742 or the Maritime Aquarium, 10 North Water St., Norwalk, CT 06854.

To the Editor: In ''The Road Best Not Taken'' (Op-Ed, May 20), Gabriel Roth implies that Mayor Michael Bloomberg's congestion-pricing proposal would not benefit auto users. In fact, the funds would be dedicated to a proposed fund (called Smart, for Sustainable Mobility and Regional Transportation) whose purposes are to help bring local roads to a state of good repair, as well as pay for mass transit improvements.

CRUHLAC--Adam Keith, passed June 10th 2006, Dearest Beloved son, brother, uncle, father, nephew, cousin and friend. We miss you every second of every minute of every hour of every day. Love you so very much. We pray you have found peace. Love, Mom

Drinking water during physical exertion is one thing, but I would like to see an exposé on the real or perceived necessity of hydration that warrants water bottles in air-conditioned executive conference rooms, college classrooms and the like (Jon Mooallem, May 27). And what ever happened to water coolers and paper cups at work and on campus, canteens when hiking, coolers at Little League games and a pitcher of water in the refrigerator at home? I am 100 percent behind Oregon's new bottle bill, but the goal that meets sustainability standards is a reduction in the number of plastic bottles we buy.

Canceled flight? Change of plans? Just plain busy? Grab your smart phone or PDA and visit www.tripsync.com to reserve a car, flight or hotel using real-time information. Any portable, Web-enabled device is compatible with the service, which is free. Microsoft Outlook fans should be especially excited about TripSync, as it instantly updates the reserved travel information on each user's calendar. On July 7, the New Seven Wonders of the World are to be announced in Lisbon. The selections are being made by voters who signed on to www.new7wonders.com; among the nominees are Chichén-Itzá in Mexico, the Great Wall of China and the Acropolis in Greece (below). For those champing at the bit to attend the announcement ceremony, Abreu Tours is offering three-night and six-night packages, starting at $431 a person a night (double occupancy). Participants may choose from a variety of hotels, with optional car rental and airfare (www.abreu-tours.com). Intrepid Travel, an adventure tourism company based in Australia, is offering six new family itineraries: Europe, Switzerland, Turkey, Morocco, Egypt and Nepal. The trips are geared toward children ages 6 to 17, and there is a maximum of two children per adult. Rates vary, and don't include airfare and some meals. The Nepal Family Adventure, for example, an 11-day trip that includes white-water rafting, a visit to a crocodile breeding center, elephant rides and camping in the Himalayas, costs $830 a person (www.intrepidtravel.com). An Avis promotion (www.avis.com) is doubling the number of free iTunes downloads with car rentals. Usually, a customer who rents a vehicle for five days or more receives 10 downloads, but through June, customers get 20.

ON some chaotic days and nights, Dr. Peter Viccellio's system to control boarding -- the hospital practice of treating patients in the hallways of overcrowded emergency departments -- is still put to the test at Stony Brook University Hospital. A delay in care or glitch connected to boarding can have extreme consequences for patients. ''Do they drop dead in front of you?'' Dr. Viccellio asked recently at the hospital, where he is vice chairman of emergency medicine and has practiced since 1988. ''No. But has their life permanently changed for the worse? Yes.''

PIONK--Richard, June 5, 2007. Esteemed painter, teacher. The Artists Fellowship, Inc. mourns the loss of our devoted Trustee and dear friend. $(6$)PIONK--Richard Cletus, instructor of Painting at The Art Student's League of New York and President of the Salmagundi Club, died Tuesday, June 5 in New York. Mr. Pionk was a renowned and respected artist who won hundreds of awards and honors during his prolific career. He also served on the boards of many art organizations. In 1984, he was named Master Pastelist by Pastel Society of America for Exceptional Merit and, in 1997, was inducted into the Pastel Hall of Fame. Mr. Pionk exhibited with the Pastel Society of America in Still Life Painters of the 20th Century, at the Hermitage Museum, Norfolk, Virginia; the Monmouth Gallery, New York; the Queens Museum, the Chapellier Galleries; the Oak Tree Gallery, New York; The Allied Artists of America; Portraits Incorporated; Lever House; Union Carbide, New York; Grand Central Art Gallery; and at the Society of Pastelists, Lille, France, among others. Before moving to New York, he studied in a Franciscan monastery in Missouri. He also served in the United States Navy. Mr. Pionk was born April 26, 1936 in Moose Lake, MN to Ester and Ignatz Pionk of Kerrick, MN. Richard died after a long battle with cancer in New York City at NYU Medical Center. He was survived by his sisters Erma Ketchmark of Hinkley, MN and Audrey Rustad of Wrenshall, MN and his brother Duane Pionk of Superior, WI. His many nieces and nephews will miss him deeply. He was preceded in death by his parents, his brother Robert Pionk, and good friend Franz Spielmann. The funeral will be held at St. Francis Catholic Church in Carlton, MN (218)384-4563 at 10:00am on June 12th and his final resting place will be in Kerrick, MN next to his mother and father. A formal memorial will be planned for September 2007 at the Salmagundi Club in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to the Richard C. Pionk Memorial Fund at the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, New York 10003, (212)255-7740. For more information you may contact the Nelson Funeral Home in Cloquet, MN (218)879-3225.
Chapter 10

NORWEB--Elizabeth Gardner. The Officers and Directors of The Garden Club of America express deep sorrow on the death of their former President, Elizabeth (Libby) Gardner Norweb, and extend deepest sympathy to her family and friends. Libby served The Garden Club with great distinction, as its 23rd President (1979-1981) and in many other capacities that began with her membership in the Garden Club of Cleveland. Beginning in 1972, Libby served The Garden Club of America on a national level serving as Bulletin Review Editor, Library Committee Chair, and on the Executive Committee. She was the recipient of the Zone Creative Leadership Award and the Medal of Merit. Libby will be remembered for her wonderful sense of community and her friendly personality. Contributions in her memory can be made to The Garden Club of America, 14 East 60th Street, NY, NY 10022. Alice Mathews, President

"PHOTOGRAPHY is very hot this year,'' said Frank Goodyear, photo curator at the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery. Galleries and museums are mounting huge shows, luminaries like Annie Leibovitz and Ansel Adams are the subjects of traveling exhibits, two museums are adding sizable photography wings, and the Venice Biennale's highest honor is going to a photographer. The premier photo event this year is unfolding in the small French town of Arles, at the 38th Recontres d'Arles (July 3 to Sept. 16, www.rencontres-arles.com). This photography-only festival will feature more than 50 exhibitions, including works from China, India and the globe-trotting photographer-members of Magnum Photos. There will be opening parties, nightly slideshows held in an ancient Roman theater, and a 25,000-euro prize ($34,250 at $1.37 to the euro) for a promising new talent chosen by top museum curators.

FEDER--Walter. The Department of Medicine at Maimonides Medical Center mourns the passing of Dr. Walter Feder. Dr. Feder served as Director of our Division of Cardiology from 1967 to 1976. He is recognized for his significant contributions in the field of Cardiology and to the Medical Center. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family. Edgar Lichstein, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Maimonides Medical Center $(6$)FEDER--Walter, M.D., Loving husband of Cecile (nee Salwen), devoted father of Martin (Danielle), Roslyn Lipsky (Marvin), Carole Simon (Noach), caring brother of Doris Feder Getzler and Aaron Feder, proud grandfather. Interment in Israel.

To the Editor: The comments of Martin M. Fitzgerald, the principal of the Robert E. Bell Middle School in Chappaqua (''Two Mothers, a Camera and a Look at School Lunch,'' June 3), reflect the continued resistance of too many school leaders when it comes to children's health. His claim that the Chappaqua Central School District promotes health is contradicted by the fact that soda, candy, chips and many other poor nutritional choices are served and sold in Chappaqua's schools, even though parents have been advocating for healthier fare since March 2002.

HALDEN--Ilse, loving wife of Fred, beloved mother of Peter and Judith, favorite mother-in-law of Lillian and Noel, devoted grandmother of Daniel, Matthew, Mariel and BJ, loving sister of Marion Kaiser and the late Charlotte Straus, from complications of a stroke on June 8, 2007. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Born February 1, 1916 in Posen, Germany. Emigrated to the United States on June 25, 1937 to escape the Holocaust. She and Fred were married on September 8, 1938 and were childhood sweethearts since 1928. Services noon on Monday at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, New Jersey. Ilse will be remembered for her love of friends and family, her terrible letters in Scrabble in which she excelled throughout her life, and her devotion to Fred, the love of her long life. Contributions may be made to Mazon, The Jewish Response to Hunger.

ROBOHM--Dorothy Bauer, M.D., 97, died peacefully in her sleep, on March 20, 2007, in Columbus, Ohio. Dr. Bauer, practiced medicine in Richmond Hill, Queens, and Southold, New York, with her husband, Dr. Claus H. Robohm, for nearly four decades. Dr. Robohm predeceased her in 1993. Dr. Bauer was born in Brooklyn, New York, on July 3, 1909. She was a graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute, Skidmore College, New York University, and the Long Island College of Medicine, from which she graduated first in her class. Her medical focus was pediatrics. She is survived by four children and their families: Peter and Sharon Robohm of Bath, Maine; John and Johanna Robohm of Jacksonville, Vermont; Dorothy and John Brownley of Columbus, Ohio; Donald and Natalie Robohm, of Ocean Springs, Mississippi; eleven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A sister, Lois (Bauer) Remmer, of Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts, also survives her. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 16, 2007, at 2:00pm, in the Southold Presbyterian Church, Main Road, Southold. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that those wishing to make contributions in Dr. Bauers name do so to the American Cancer Society, the Eastern Long Island Hospital (Greenport, NY), or the Southold Historical Society.

ON some chaotic days and nights, Dr. Peter Viccellio's system to control boarding -- the hospital practice of treating patients in the hallways of overcrowded emergency departments -- is still put to the test at Stony Brook University Hospital. A delay in care or glitch connected to boarding can have extreme consequences for patients. ''Do they drop dead in front of you?'' Dr. Viccellio asked recently at the hospital, where he is vice chairman of emergency medicine and has practiced since 1988. ''No. But has their life permanently changed for the worse? Yes.''
To the Editor: Re ''Whose Katonah Is It, Anyway?'' (editorial, June 3), about Martha Stewart's giving the name Katonah to a line of home furnishings:

With more than 200 Westchester families still struggling to recover from the damage caused by severe flooding in April, county officials have established a Disaster Recovery Fund to give financial help to those who suffer such losses in the future. In announcing the creation of the fund, which will be administered by the United Way of Westchester and Putnam, the county executive, Andrew J. Spano, said its purpose was to provide aid beyond government assistance to victims suffering long-term effects from a natural disaster.

GRECO--Sal. The Officers, Governors, and Members of The Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved honorary officer, Salvatore F. Greco, who was a member for over four decades. We are honored and proud to have been touched by our Patriarch whose generosity and support has helped us to maintain our status as one of the best clubs in New York City. Services will be held at Shrine of Old St. Joseph, 321 Willings Alley, ''Society Hill'', Philadephia, PA, on June 11 at 10 am. Jerry Lewis, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean JeanPierre Trebot, Exec. Dir. $(6$)GRECO--Salvatore F., died of pneumonia on June 7 at the age of 93. Survived by wife Estelle and adored nieces. A well known couture fur manufacturer for over 50 years. Member of the Friars Club for many years, honored with the title Patriarch. Private funeral in Philadelphia.

In response to the increased demand for travel to Middle Eastern cities like Doha, Qatar; Tel Aviv; and Kuwait City, several airlines are adding new routes and destinations to their schedules. Qatar Airways (www.qatarairways.com) recently announced it would fly four times a week from Doha International Airport to Newark Liberty International Airport, via Geneva (another new destination for the airline), beginning June 26. And starting July 19, Qatar will provide daily flights from Doha to Dulles International Airport near Washington.

Carolyn Elizabeth Petersen and Christopher Davis Perera were married last evening by the Rev. Paul Thompson at St. Andrews by the Sea Episcopal Church in Hyannis Port, Mass. Mrs. Perera, 37, is the general manager of the Michael Kors shop in New York. She graduated from Bucknell.

There were mixed results for the state's largest cities in the F.B.I.'s preliminary crime report for 2006, released last Monday. In Bridgeport, there were 1,509 violent crimes reported last year, one more than in 2005. But the murder rate rose nearly 50 percent, with 28 slayings, nine more than in 2005. There were also four more rapes (69, from 65) and 11 more robberies (659, from 648). Categories that fell included assaults (down 23, to 753), burglaries (down 21, to 1,362) and auto thefts (down 58, to 1,225).
An article on April 29 about Angela Lansbury and her return to Broadway misstated the number of times she has been nominated for an Emmy Award. It is 18, not 15. (She has never won.)

Nicholas D. Chabraja, chairman and chief executive of General Dynamics, now knows what a difference a year and two months can make. Mr. Chabraja, 64, was scheduled to retire in April 2008, and he had been promised two years' use of an office and assistant and 500 hours of flying time on the company's Gulfstream jets. In its proxy statement published in March, General Dynamics estimated the cost of those postretirement perquisites at about $3 million.

GOLDENTHAL--Janice Berkowitz, Ph.D., died on May 26th, 2007 at the age of 82. She received her B.A., M.A. and Ph.D. degree's at New York University. A beloved Professor of English Literature at Fairleigh Dickinson University, Rutherford, NJ, Janice was a devoted teacher, and an inspiring role model. Cherished by friends and family for her intelligence, beauty, and thoughtful interest in the lives of others, she is survived by her husband, Edgar J. Goldenthal, D.D.S., as well as three sons, Michael Goldenthal, Ph.D., Mark Goldenthal, Ph.D. and Jonathan Goldenthal, D.M.D. and eight grand-children, Sarah, Emily, Rebecca, Alexander, David, Ethan, Ariel and Isaac. Janice is also survived by her brother Dr. Ellis Berkowitz. Janice taught all of us how to live in and not just survive in this crazy world. We will miss you.

ABRAMOWITZ--Mortimer J., age 90, died April 10. Former Superintendent, Great Neck Public Schools (1967-1982). Remembered for his educational leadership and moral courage by 1970's School Board members Frank Phillips, J. Robert Rosenthal, M.D., Claire J. Speciner, Laz Weiner and Michael S. Zarin.

PRESBY--Philip Alan. After a more than two-year bout with lymphoma and pneumonia, Phil Presby finally succumbed to his illness on Thursday, June 7. He was 43. He was born in Dayton, Ohio on August 8, 1963 to J. Thomas Presby and Elaine Smith Presby and grew up in West Orange and Essex Fells, NJ. After graduating from Newark Academy and Franklin and Marshall College, he attended Brooklyn Law School. He practiced corporate law at Shea and Gould for two years and then studied American history at New York University. Most recently, he was working on a novel and writing for the East Hampton Star newspaper. He is survived by his parents, his wife Jennifer, and his sisters Terry Presby and Mona Presby Bent. After a private family service on Monday, a memorial gathering will take place at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Thursday, June 14 at 6:30pm. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society and the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons.

To the Editor: Re ''Lower East Side Is Under a Groove,'' by Allen Salkin (June 3): I think Sion Misrahi should be ashamed of himself. While dodging ridiculous comparisons to Donald Trump, Mr. Misrahi is not only giving the illusion he cares about the business owners of the Lower East Side, but more insultingly, he is pretending he cares about its residents.

To the Sports Editor: ''Concussion Tied to Depression in Ex-N.F.L. Players'' (May 31), by Alan Schwarz, states incorrectly that the N.F.L. has long asserted that concussions in football have no long-term effects. We have asserted no such thing.

To the Editor: I really enjoyed Seth Kugel's ''Architectural Landmarks: A Tour With Head Tilted Up'' (Weekend in New York, May 27), which proposed a great walking path. It is funny: I have lived in the area my entire life, yet there are parts of the city that always give me a rush of excitement, no matter how many times I've seen them. This is what makes New York the greatest city in the world; its depth and excitement can't be matched. Steven M. Clayton Ocean, N.J.

To the Editor: I read with great enjoyment the article by Roxana Robinson about world literature and cab drivers (''The Novelist and the Curious Cabbie,'' New York Observed, June 3). The combination of New York City cab drivers and a discussion of great literature is priceless.

To the Editor: Why is it so often assumed that the cost of child care is subtracted from the salary of the working mother, rather than that of the working father or, in a two-income household, from both salaries?

To the Sports Editor: Re ''For Red Sox, the Relief Is Almost Beyond Belief,'' June 4: There must be a New York Times curse. What better explanation can there be when Murray Chass just happens to write a column waxing poetic about Boston's relievers the same day that Hideki Okajima and Jonathan Papelbon each give up a run and the Yankees beat the Sox, 6-5? As a Boston fan, I'm begging you: No more stories about how wonderful the Sox are. Lynn Klyde-Silverstein Denver

To the Editor: Emily Brady's Street Level column about the drug dealing at a Kennedy Fried Chicken in the Bronx (''A Corner Once Sunny, Made Dreary by Drugs,'' June 3) was disturbing and depressing. It is disturbing that the mother featured in the column is afraid for her children's safety while they eat their meal. It is depressing because the current strategies employed by our country to address the drug-dealing problems are destined to fail.

Coyote attacks in Middletown have prompted the State Department of Environmental Protection, working with wildlife experts at the United States Department of Agriculture, to equip teams with night-vision equipment to track and kill the animals. ''Unfortunately there is no way to move the pack, so they're going to have to be sacrificed,'' said Lisa P. Jackson, the state environmental commissioner.

To the Editor: The comments of Martin M. Fitzgerald, the principal of the Robert E. Bell Middle School in Chappaqua (''Two Mothers, a Camera and a Look at School Lunch,'' June 3), reflect the continued resistance of too many school leaders when it comes to children's health. His claim that the Chappaqua Central School District promotes health is contradicted by the fact that soda, candy, chips and many other poor nutritional choices are served and sold in Chappaqua's schools, even though parents have been advocating for healthier fare since March 2002.

LITT--Ann Selkowitz. On May 30th, 2007, devoted wife and loving mother, Ann Selkowitz Litt, passed away suddenly. Ann was a nationally known nutritionist who helped children and adolescents with eating disorders and assisted developing athletes in reaching their full potential. Ann was the nutritionist for the Washington Redskins and spokesperson for several media campaigns including the Got Milk campaign. Recently, Ann was the nutrition consultant to CosmoGirl magazine 2007. Ann was the author of The College Students' Guide to Eating Well on Campus, Fuel for Young Athletes, and the ADA Guide to Private Practice. Ann frequently appeared on local and national television and was quoted by newspapers and magazines throughout the country. Ann was an avid golfer, skier, fitness enthusiast, and adventurer. Her warmth, kindness and beauty will be missed by her family, friends and all who knew her. Ann grew up in Perth Amboy, New Jersey, and lived in Bethesda, Maryland. She is survived by her devoted husband, Daniel M. Litt; her beloved sons, David L. Litt of New York City, and Jordan M. Litt of Bethesda; daughter of Lenore and Lawrence Kohn of Boca Raton, Florida, and the late Donald Selkowitz; sister of Marsha Brower of Boca Raton; sister-in-law of Lori and Joseph Roth of Morris Plains, New Jersey, and Debbie and Rick Litt of Stamford, Connecticut; aunt of Robert, Shira, and Jonathan Roth, and Jeffrey and Kenneth Litt. Contributions can be made to the Ann Selkowitz Litt Memorial Fund, National Eating Disorders Association, 603 Stewart Street, Suite 803, Seattle, WA 98101, or online at www. nationaleatingdisorders.org

HABER--Alan W. on June 8, 2007 Loving husband of Carol. Devoted father of Fred and Jill, Melanie and Gerald. Cherished grandfather of Ali, Joseph, Joshua Weiss, Ethan Weiss. Devoted brother of Herbert. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. A gifted musician, a wry sense of humor and eternally youthful. Service at ''The Riverside'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave Monday 9:30 am.
DEGEN--Paul, on May 31, 2007. Sculptor, illustrator, inventor. Beloved father and grandfather. Cherished friend to many. Memorial service, Liestal, Switzerland, June 12.

MOSZKOWSKI--Enrique, M.D., FACS, of Buenos Aires, Argentina and New York, NY; died June 4, 2007, in New York, after a long illness. Dr. Moszkowski was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina on October 29, 1928, and graduated from the University of Buenos Aires School of Medicine in 1952. He came to the US with his wife, Dr. Erica Friedmann Moszkowski, in 1954 for further medical training, including a fellowship in his specialty, general surgery, at Boston's Lahey Clinic, and after a brief return to Argentina, settled permanently in Baltimore in the early 1960s. There they raised their family and conducted successful private medical practices. He became a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons in 1975. Widowed in 1984, Dr. Moszkowski lived in Paris for a time, later settling again in Buenos Aires while keeping a home in New York. He is survived by his son Guy and his wife, Sandra Pinnavaia; his son Neal and his wife Amanda Moszkowski; and loving grandchildren Erica, Jacob, Anastasia, Ethan, and Grey; all of New York. He is also survived by his longtime faithful companion, Maria Elena Demaria Massey. We all miss him terribly, and will remember him with love.
''The Hispanic vote has never been all that important in the presidential primary process. But that is going to change in 2008.'' SERGIO BENDIXEN, a pollster for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. [1]

To the Editor: Re ''Living in High Bridge,'' May 20: I was 12 and growing up just north of High Bridge, at 176th Street and Davidson Avenue, back on Jan. 7, 1963, when the ''Bronx, New York'' post office designation was officially adopted. It was regarded back then as a source of great pride -- a recognition that we were no longer a mere satellite of ''New York, N.Y.,'' despite the fact that the Bronx street numbering system was an extension of Manhattan's.

A New Hampshire woman was injured Tuesday afternoon when her car hit a 500-pound moose on the Merritt Parkway in New Canaan. The driver, Kim Pitcher, 51, of New London, N.H., was taken to Norwalk Hospital. She was in serious condition on Thursday, said a hospital spokeswoman, Sharon Simon.

EACH time the market forces a lender to shut down or to tighten its lending policies, the effect on one subset of consumers -- those in the midst of closing loans with those lenders -- can be earthshaking. Lenders who cannot complete a loan they had promised to finance will often help secure financing elsewhere on short notice. But there are exceptions, and industry executives say that consumers can decrease their chances of being stranded if they monitor the progress of their loans in the early stages, among other important steps.

PAGE--Don. Architect, Graphic Designer, Artist, died June 4, 2007, at the age of 89. Everything he touched was transformed by his love of beauty and function and his genius. He was unique, generous and gentlemanly and had countless dedicated friends. He is survived by his niece Leslie Lopez and his grandnephew Jeremiah Lopez. $(6$)PAGE--Don. We will miss our friend, partner and mentor. Don's brilliance in design and living inspired and enriched us in many ways. His influence will last forever. Dominic Arbitrio and Ken Resen

Joseph P. Nacchio, the former Qwest chief executive convicted in April on 19 counts of insider trading, is hoping that a change of scenery can spare him from the slammer. Mr. Nacchio is set to be sentenced the end of next month, but his lawyers petitioned a federal judge in Denver last week to overturn his conviction and move the case outside the city for a retrial. The odds against Mr. Nacchio seem long. The same judge denied similar requests twice before, saying he was confident that jurors were capable of a fair evaluation, even though many of them acknowledged having heard of the case. Qwest is based in Denver.

Jay Leno Did you hear about that lawyer from Georgia, a guy named Andrew Speaker? He's the first person in 44 years to be placed under federal quarantine after he got a drug resistant strain of tuberculosis. The doctors told him he should just stay in Italy. Which, I believe, is also the Republican's healthcare plan. Sick? Stay in Italy! This week, President Bush is at the big G8 summit in Germany, and many Germans are protesting his visit. See, that's when you know things are bad. When the Germans think you are invading too many countries.

The Q&A column on June 3 about reimbursement options when a tour falls through misstated a recommendation about when to buy insurance policies that cover full refunds. Vikki Corliss, a spokeswoman at InsureMyTrip.com, a travel insurance comparison site, said that it is best to buy coverage before or within 7 to 21 days (varies by plan) after you have made your first deposit on the tour; she did not say within 7 to 12 days.
