A judge ordered the death penalty last week for the man convicted of the 2005 killing of Lindsey M. Bonistall, a college student from White Plains. The man, James E. Cooke Jr., was convicted on March 8 in New Castle County Court in Wilmington, Del., in the murder of Ms. Bonistall, a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of Delaware.

Those of us who speak plain English don't agonize over the meaning of words like benchmark, timetable, guidepost, yardstick, deadline, road map, regarding the Iraq War (On Language, William Safire, May 27).

THOMAS--Jeffrey Furlough, died in San Francisco on June 2, 2007 in the presence of his immediate family. Born in New York City on November 27, 1938 he was the beloved husband of Evelyne Champin, to whom he was married 38 years ago; the adored father of Patrick (and father-inlaw of Rachel) and Fiona Thomas; the cherished brother of Michael M. Thomas, Joan Chatfield-Taylor and the late Robert F. ChatfieldTaylor Jr.; the cynosure of a loving gaggle of nieces and nephews-and we will all miss desperately the pleasure of his company; his wit, erudition, passion for the good things of body and spirit and his generosity. A graduate of Brooks School (1956) and Yale (1960), with a doctorate in American letters from UC Berkeley, he became an antiquarian book seller of great distinction and an admired figure in the trade; as one of his colleagues observed in a remembrance: ''Jeffrey was a wonderful fellow full of good will and knowledge-the latter which he carried lightly.'' (Citizens of the book world and others having recollections of Jeffrey they'd like to share with the family are invited to send them to: pjthomas66@gmail.com). A service of thanksgiving for Jeffrey's life will be held in San Francisco Thursday June 14, 2007 at the Conservatory of Flowers in Golden Gate Park at 5:30pm.

MEYERSON--Martin. The Directors of the Marconi Society at Columbia University recall the extraordinary contributions of its former chairman and Board member, as a wise, devoted friend and leader. A pioneer in urban planning and a towering figure in higher education, Martin Meyerson tirelessly devoted his energy and acumen through the Society to extending public understanding of the global communications revolution for the benefit of humanity. With sadness, the Society expresses its deep sympathy to his wife Margy and their family.
SAMUELS--Margery (nee Stark). Beloved wife of the late Hartley L. Samuels died on June 5 after a prolonged illness. Services will be at The Riverside Memorial on Sunday, June 10, at 4pm.

BROECKER--William, on June 4, 2007. It is with great sadness that the School of Visual Arts announces the death of a distinguished faculty member and dear friend, William Broecker. Born on November 21, 1932 in Detroit, he began teaching in the Photography Department at the School of Visual Arts in the fall of 1967. Over the years he offered his original courses, including Photo Techniques and The History of Photography, and mentored students in independent-study projects. In 2001 he received SVA's Distinguished Art Historian Award, and has also received honors from the Art Directors Club and the Society for Technical Communication. William was a highly regarded historian who applied his writing, editing and design talents to an array of books, magazines, encyclopedias and technical manuals in the fields of photography and magic. He died at his home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, after an extended illness. Our condolences go to his wife Louise and brother Charles.
EISEMAN--Harry A. Ed.D., April 16, 1909 -June 9,1957. Remembered and revered. The Family

Robert Horry hit a 3-pointer late Thursday night, an act so natural, so familiar, so amusingly routine that it seemed as if every N.B.A. finals must have started this way. The degree of difficulty on the shot, from 25 feet out on the left side, was not particularly high. In the broad pantheon of Horry playoff 3-pointers, it did not rate among the most impactful, or the most memorable.

An article last Sunday about a Dutch television show in which kidney patients purported to compete for an organ donation referred incorrectly to organ transplants from live donors. Transplants from cadavers outpace those from live donors, not the other way around.

To the Editor: Re ''Still Needing, Still Feeding the Muse at 64'' by Allan Kozinn [June 3]: So the ''cute Beatle'' might seem even more frivolous in middle age. As a teenager I may have wept and screamed for Paul McCartney's music and his looks, but I respect him now for something more elevated.

WINDING up a dirt road not far from the Saw Mill Parkway in Mount Kisco, N.Y., a visitor could easily miss Rocky Hills, hidden behind a 6-foot-tall stockade fence and simple gated entry. But at least once a year, the gates -- geared more to keeping out deer than people -- are thrown open to the public, revealing a garden 50 years in the making.

MAYNES--Charles William. Center on Philanthropy and Civil Society mourns the passing of its Advisory Board member, Bill Maynes. He was a man of profound intelligence, integrity, kindness and courage, and will be sorely missed.

To the Editor: Your June 5 editorial about Jack Kevorkian calls him ''deluded and unrepentant.'' I disagree. The Jack Kevorkian I know is a warm, engaged, thoughtful and compassionate individual who speaks Japanese, plays the flute, reads voraciously and is of academic bent. His lawyer, Mayer Morganroth, tried unsuccessfully to persuade Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm of Michigan to commute his long sentence because he was in such bad physical shape.

A contractor was charged with reckless endangerment after firefighters had to rescue five workers who were locked inside a Queens supermarket when a blaze broke out yesterday morning, the authorities said. After the fire began, the workers, believed to be immigrants hired to do renovation work while the supermarket was closed, took turns banging on the locked metal gates and crying for help while the others sought refuge in the supermarket's basement until firefighters cut through the gates with chain saws and helped the gasping men out.
Thank you for Stephen Rodrick's authoritative article on the comedy director Judd Apatow (May 27). I count most of his movies among my favorites.

KANE--Lester P., died peacefully at age 84 on May 31, leaving his devoted wife of 61 years, Libby, and children Nancy, Robert, Richard and Claudia, sons-in-law Les Michael and Ross, daughter-inlaw Susan, and four grandchildren, Micah, Logan, Diego and Alicia. He was a World War II veteran who served the Judge Advocate General in Saipan with distinction. A court reporter for 39 years at the State Supreme Court of NY in Manhattan, he founded the Association of Surrogate and Supreme Court Reporters Within the City of New York and served as its president for 18 years. He was a recipient of the Louis Goldstein Memorial Award and a Fellow of the National Court Reporters Association. He was also the award-winning editor of SERVE, the Bnai Brith (Crestwood Chapter) newspaper. Continuing a lifelong interest in art, after retirement Les attended and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College. As a second career, he curated exhibits in Westchester of contemporary New York area Abstract Expressionist artists. He was an avid tennis player and watched the French Open on television the day he died. His family and his dog Penny will miss him very much. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity.

DiJOSEPH--Louis R., a former longtime resident of Darien, CT, died of complications due to Parkinson's disease at his home in San Francisco, CA, on Wednesday, May 30 at age 79. Born in 1928 in Philadelphia, PA, he was the son of the late John and Jennie DiJoseph. Upon graduation from the University of the Arts, in Philadelphia, he embarked on a successful career as an art director in advertising. His first accounts included Rolls Royce Motors, Holland Cheese and KLM Airlines at Erwin, Wasey, Ruthrauff and Ryan in New York. After a seven year stint at Young & Rubicam/NY working on Dr. Pepper and Eastern Airlines, he moved to NW Ayer to help develop the highly effective ''Be All You Can Be'' campaign for the U.S. Army. In 1980, he returned to Young & Rubicam/ NY to become a group creative director for Dr. Pepper, Eastern Airlines, Japan Airlines, AT&T International, and 7-11 Stores, General Foods, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Adidas athletic shoes. Along with more than over 100 awards from the Art Director's Club, the One Show, the Andy Awards, Communication Arts magazine, the Cannes Film Festival and the Clio awards, he was presented with the Civilian Distinguished Service Medal, for his work for the U.S. Army. In 1991 he left his position as an executive vicepresident, worldwide creative director to pursue a career in fine art photography. From 1991 to 1996 working out of his studio in Darien, Connecticut, he exhibited at the Rowayton Arts Center the Silvermine Guild and the Darien Council on the Arts. Since his move to San Francisco in 1996 he had concentrated, almost exclusively, on photo emulsion transfers, exhibiting at the Calumet Gallery and in solo shows at Renzo, Cafe Faba and the Focus Gallery. He is survived by his wife, Melinda W. Mettler; his brother John DiJoseph, Jr, of Springfield, PA, three children: Christopher DiJoseph of Norwalk, CT, Jennifer DiJoseph of Buffalo, NY, and Joshua DiJoseph of Barrington, NH, as well as three grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Nancy Newbold DiJoseph. A memorial reception and show of his artwork will be held at later date. Details will be available at loudijoseph.com. In lieu of flowers, donations in Louis R. DiJoseph's name may be sent to The National Parkinson Foundation, Inc., Office of Development, 1501 NW 9th Avenue/Bob Hope Road, Miami, Florida 33136-1494.

JOHANOS--Donald, one of the first prominent, American-born symphony orchestra conductors, died May 29 in Naples, FL, surrounded by his loving family. Maestro Johanos trained at the Eastman School of Music and served as Associate Conductor of the Pittsburgh Symphony and Music Director of the Dallas and Honolulu Symphonies. He recorded and conducted across the Americas, Europe, New Zealand, Japan and China over a 42 year career. His love, passion for life and music and sense of humor will be missed dearly. A memorial scholarship fund has been established in his honor and donations may be made to Interlochen Center for the Arts for the Donald Johanos Scholarship fund at: Interlochen Center for the Arts, PO Box 199, Interlochen, MI 49643, www.interlochen.org, phone: 231-276-7624

Diane G. Farrell, a Democrat from Westport who lost two close races to Representative Christopher Shays, has been nominated by President Bush to serve on the board of the Export-Import Bank of the United States. Ms. Farrell, whose aggressive campaigns captured national attention, said she had spent the last few months being vetted for the director's post at the bank. If confirmed by Congress, Ms. Farrell will serve out the term vacated by Max Cleland, the former Democratic senator from Georgia. The term expires on Jan. 20, 2011.

To the Editor: The blurb, ''What happens when her weekly reader is People?'' is very telling. My ''weekly reader'' at home was Family Circle and the Ladies' Home Journal, and Readers' Digest and National Geographic when at my grandparents' house. My own children turned to National Geographic when they finished their Ranger Rick and American Girl magazines, and now two of them are pursing science, while the third studied linguistics in college.

More often than not there is flamenco in some form or another to be had on New York stages. More often than not it isn't very good. If you need to be reminded of what the real deal looks and sounds like, head to Theater 80, where the Spanish company NOCHE FLAMENCA has the premiere of ''Aldaba.'' The concerts feature the marvelous Soledad Barrio, one of the great performers of our time. Wednesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m., Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m., and Sundays at 2 and 5 p.m., through July 29, 80 St. Marks Place, at First Avenue, East Village, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $55. The casts promise a host of delights, including several debuts in ''Emeralds'': Ana Sophia Scheller and Tiler Peck on Tuesday, and Sara Mearns and Megan LeCrone on Thursday. This month's event, ''Villains and Heroes, the 100 most influential people who (n)ever lived,'' will have as its host the choreographer Stephen Petronio and will feature eight of his former dancers: Gerald Casel, Ori Flomin, Kristina Isabelle, Ashleigh Leite, Jeremy Nelson, Jimena Paz, Todd Williams and Ellis Wood. THIS spring, when the seed potatoes arrived at our local grain-and-feed store, I circled the barrels of dusty little tubers. I was talking to myself: Should I? Dare I plant a spud -- again? Mortified, our teenage daughter walked away from me, whispering, ''Give it up, Mom. It'll be the same as all the other times.'' She has been with me in the garden, bucket at the ready, as I've gently turned over the potato mounds, anticipating a bounty below. With a child's candor, she has given voice to my suppressed anguish as she peered at my stunted and scant harvests and snorted, ''Is that it?''

PUGLIA--Giacomo. June 6th, 2007, at age 78. Cherished husband of Felice (nee Ochs). Beloved father of Howard and Marianne, father-in-law of Gina, and grandfather of Zackary and Elizabeth. Leaves behind his devoted family in Italy. A wonderful man who embraced life and lived it to the fullest.

TIFFEN--Richard Marc, 51. Educator, IT Director, Naturalist of Norwalk, CT, following a 15 month battle with brain cancer on Wednesday, May 30, 2007. His career reflected his wide interests in technology, science and education. Most recently, Director of Information Technology in Wilton and Hamden B.O.E., he also taught earth science/biology at Townsend Harris High School and had a special gift for integrating technology and education. His passions included nature, birding, yoga and music. He obtained a B.S. from SUNY at Binghamton and an M.S. from Queens College. He is survived by his life partner, Micki, sons Ross and Jesse and sisters Susan Tiffen and Isabel (Marty) Kellerman and many nieces/nephews. Known for his sharp wit, skill as a chef, and his sensitive nature he will be sorely missed but not forgotten because ''love never disappears for death is a nonevent.'' In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to ''Tomorrow's Scholar'' F.B.O. Tiffen; care of Marjorie Morresi, Ameriprise Financial Advisers, 2 Corporate Dr -238 Shelton, CT 06484. A celebration of Richard's life will be held on September 9, 2007 at Temple Shalom, Norwalk CT.

Schubert: Piano Sonata in C minor (D. 958), Lieder, Fragments Leif Ove Andsnes, pianist; Ian Bostridge, tenor. EMI Classics 3 84321 2; CD. AT the end of his terribly short life, Schubert composed three monumental piano sonatas. Though the Sonatas in B flat and A have become standard repertory works, the Sonata in C minor has never quite caught on. There seems to be a general perception that this stormy work is less fully realized. The finale, an episodic Allegro driven by a relentless tarantella rhythm, can sometimes seem awkward and uninspired.

To the Editor: Lawrence Kramer urges readers to ''listen to Mahler the way you would look at Klimt.'' Who looks at a Klimt nonstop for an hour or more, the length of a Mahler symphony? You can look at that Klimt for a bit, look somewhere else, return to it or not. When in its presence you have no choice but to hear that symphony. Hearing sound is coercive; you have to go to considerable lengths not to hear. Looking at images is discretionary; it is usually quite easy to look away. These differences make the notion of a music museum dubious. Rudolph H. Weingartner Pittsburgh

To the Editor: ''New AIDS Cases in Africa Outpace Treatment Gains'' (news article, June 6) makes an excellent argument about the critical importance of prevention programs in responding to the AIDS crisis in Africa.

HOEXTER--Dr. Barton, of Great Neck and Manhattan, died peacefully on June 3, 2007 at the age of 70. Recognized as one of the country's pre-eminent colon-rectal surgeons, Bart studied at Horace Mann, Kenyon College and George Washington University School of Medicine. He was a member of the Phi Delta Epsilon Fraternity, St. George Society, Smith-ReedRussell Medical Honor Society, and the Alpha Omega Alpha Society. He served as a Navy physician, Chief Resident at Mt. Sinai Hospital, President of the LI Gastroenterological Association, President of the NY Society of Colon & Rectal Surgeons, President of Medical Staff at NSUH, founder and President of the Colon & Rectal Surgical Association of LI, and an Associate Clinical Professor at Cornell. Bart was repeatedly named as a Best Doctor by Castle Connolly and Town & Country. Lifelong pleasures included photography, flowers, history, traveling and his family. He was the beloved husband of Nadya (Snaider) Hoexter; father of Jill, Laura, and Ken; stepfather of Leland; grandfather of Zachary, Benjamin, and Samantha; and brother of Joan and David. Bart was a true caregiver, altruist, teacher, friend and pillar of strength to all who knew him. His kind and generous spirit will be deeply missed by all who benefited from his humor, wisdom, and integrity. Funeral services will be at Temple Emmanuel in Great Neck on June 5th at 11am.

COLMORE--Mary Virginia ''Ginny'' (nee Thomas), former long-term resident of Bedford Hills, NY, died peacefully at the Essex Meadows Health Center on May 30 in Essex, CT. She was 94. Mrs. Colmore was married to the late Dr. Henry P. Colmore. She is also survived by two daughters, Julia Colmore and Margo Colmore. A graduate of the Nightingale-Bamford School in New York City, Mrs. Colmore went on to have a 40 year career in real estate at Renwick and Winterling Realty in Bedford, NY. Mrs. Colmore is survived by four grandchildren, a grandson-inlaw, six great-grandchildren and a great-great-grandchild. A memorial service and interment will be held at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mt. Kisco, NY, on Saturday, June 16, at 1:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, the family would be appreciative of donations made to St. Mark's.

To the Editor: Whenever I read an editorial like ''New York's Powerful Ghosts'' (May 27) on the need to curb out-of-control public authorities in New York, I chuckle. While some reforms are needed, like prohibiting employees of the appointers from serving on the boards, legislators calling for reform is like the line in ''Casablanca'' where the police inspector professes shock that there is gambling going on.

The energetic jazz pianist ERIC REED is a kind of rationalist: He likes limits, structure, standards of talent, strict dimensions. There's no question about what he's handing you from piece to piece, whether it's a little suite, or a bebop song, or a ballad, or a piece of gospel, or something American Songbook-like. But he's found two good foils for his newest band, and both are tenor saxophonists. One, STACY DILLARD, comes more from the open-ended conception of Wayne Shorter; deeply beautiful improvised lines can trail off like ellipses. The other, SEAMUS BLAKE, is just as modern but a little more playful and chameleonic. The Eric Reed Quintet plays at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola this week, continuing a two-week run at the club by Mr. Reed, with two different bands. Tuesday to Sunday, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Broadway and 60th Street, (212) 258-9595; $30 cover. Those following jazz ought to keep an ear on the bassist ESPERANZA SPALDING, who is going about things her own way. She's got good tone and conservatory training, but so does everyone else these days. More important, she already sounds distinct. Essentially she's a singer, using both her instrument and her voice to similar ends. Her musicality is all integrated: The Esperanza Spalding experience is light, melodic, joyful, always sort of minimalist and airborne. Recently she was at the Village Vanguard, playing Bill Evans music with the Spanish guitarist Niño Josele; this week she plays one night with her own trio (Leo Genovese, piano; Lyndon Rochelle, drums). Wednesday, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232; $20 cover.

SCHWARTZ--Howard Robert, C.P.A., died June 7, 2007 age 52. Devoted father of Peter, Nina, Greggory, and Zared. Beloved son of Rita and Donald. Cherished brother of Steven and Fredric and Susan Fried. Favorite uncle. To know him was to love him.

To the Editor: Joyce Cohen's article about a young couple's joyous discovery of an Upper East Side rental (The Hunt: ''A Surprise on the East Side,'' April 29) doesn't mention that the place they moved into is an admired New York City complex, listed on both the New York State and National Registers of Historic Places.

To the Editor: Below is a letter I've written in response to the review of my novel, ''My Holocaust'' (May 27). The letter is written in the voice of one of the minor characters in the novel, Lipman Krakowski, who sees himself, among other things, as a veteran letters-to-the-editor writer. I believe the review was wrongheaded and surprisingly ad hominem, reflected no understanding of either fiction or satire, was strikingly at odds with the many other very positive reviews that have appeared, and left your readers with a deeply and relentlessly distorted impression of my book.Tova Reich

To the Editor: Lawrence Kramer is on to something when he suggests that a vibrant concert hall could have much in common with an excellent art museum. But he misses the mark when he laments the lack of a ''classical music equivalent of the contemporary-art market.'' The only reason a contemporary-art market exists is that art can be owned, and collectors have a pecuniary interest in escalating prices. One of the most appealing things about great music is that it belongs to all of us. Daniel Okrent Wellfleet, Mass. The writer is a former public editor of The New York Times.

To the Editor: In ''The Road Best Not Taken'' (Op-Ed, May 20), Gabriel Roth implies that Mayor Michael Bloomberg's congestion-pricing proposal would not benefit auto users. In fact, the funds would be dedicated to a proposed fund (called Smart, for Sustainable Mobility and Regional Transportation) whose purposes are to help bring local roads to a state of good repair, as well as pay for mass transit improvements.

The Habitats article last Sunday, about a couple who live aboard a 44-foot sloop, misspelled the surname of one owner. He is Brian Nisbett, not Nesbitt.
PARKER--Sonie, 74, of Brooklyn, NY, died on June 6, 2007. He leaves behind his wife of 50 years, Georgie Parker, and children Toni, Glenn and New York State Senator Kevin Parker.

To the Sports Editor: One had to love ''Aggressive, Infuriating and Successful'' (June 5) about Bill Laimbeer and the Detroit Shock. Isiah Thomas was probably right when he told Chuck Daly, ''I should have hired Laimbeer; he's so thick-skinned.'' I believe the Knicks would succeed with Laimbeer. Steve Lurie Tucson

To the Editor: Regarding ''Graham Greene's Capri'' (May 27) by Adam Begley: Having visited Capri some 10 times over the last 20 years, I would like to point out that it is not only for the very rich. There are many places to stay that do not strain the budget, and some have private balconies and terraces with incredible views of the ocean and mountains. Of course, they are not luxurious, but who has time to spend more than a few hours a night in their room anyway? Two handy Web sites are www.capritourism.com and www.capri.net. Many lodgings have double rooms for 120 euros or less -- with breakfast and view included. Claude M. Gruener Austin, Tex.

Deborah Beth Swacker, a lobbyist, and Jeff Nussbaum, a political speechwriter, are to be married today by Rabbi Joui Hessel at the Meridian House in Washington. The bride, 30, graduated from the New School and is a vice president at the Downey McGrath Group, a government affairs and lobbying firm in Washington. From 2002 to 2004, she was a legislative aide in Washington for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

GOODWIN--F. Lawrence, Jr., age 88, of Wilton, CT, died peacefully at home Tuesday evening, June 5, after a short bout with pancreatic cancer, surrounded by his wife Terry and his wonderful caregivers. He had not been in his usual robust health since he suffered a stroke in 1994 which ended his lifelong love of sailing and the seas. He was born and raised in Baltimore, attended Calvert, Gilman and Canterbury Schools, worked on the Grenfell Missions. A staff sargeant in World War II, he was shot down in Ploesti and became a prisoner of War in Romania for eight months in 1944. Worked for Woods Hole Oceanographic as a seaman on The Atlantis. Married in 1961, he moved to Wilton, was a salesman for Fayette R. Plumb (Hammers and Hatchets and Axes) and later for Union Fork & Hoe (Garden Tools). He retired in 1984 and turned his interest into land conservation and preservation mainly in Wilton. He is survived by his wife Terry (46 years), his sister Emily Goodwin Kemp (Philip S., Omaha, NE) and bother Charles Goodwin III of Baltimore, MD. Plus many nieces and nephews. Services will be held at 10:00 am, Monday June 11, 2007 at Our Lady of Fatima, 229 Danbury Rd., Wilton, CT. Reception to follow. Contribution may be made to The Wilton Land Conservation Trust, Box 77, Wilton, CT 06897, or WHOI, Woods Hole, MA 02543.

SLIP SLIDING AWAY News -- Those sneakers with wheels embedded in the heels contributed to 1,600 hospital visits last year, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission says. Behind the News -- The sneakers allow children (or adults) to go from walking to rolling by shifting their weight to their heels. It's not always smooth sliding. Broken ankles, arms, feet, a concussion and possibly even one death have resulted,reported the commission, which recommends wearing helmets and knee and elbow pads with the sneakers -- just what a child wants to hear. Heelys, one of the manufacturers, has shipped more than 10 million worldwide. The company says they are much safer than biking, skateboarding or even tennis. 'A SILENT EPIDEMIC' The News -- Accidental deaths rose by more than 20 percent over 10 years ending in 2005, according to a study by the National Safety Council. Behind the News -- Accidents caused 113,000 deaths in 2005, the council said, approaching the high of 116,385 in 1969. Motor vehicle crashes were the leading cause of death and injury, followed by poisonings (including overdoses of prescription, over-the-counter and illegal drugs), falls, choking and drowning. For people up to age 41, accidents were the top cause of death, and ranked fifth in the nation over all, exceeded by heart disease, cancer, stroke and respiratory diseases. ''A silent epidemic,'' the council's president, Alan McMillan, said. LOCK AND UNLOAD The News -- About two-thirds of parents who keep a gun at home fail to store them safely, according to a study published in the medical journal Pediatrics. Behind the News -- More than 3,700 parents in 45 states, Canada and Puerto Rico were interviewed when they brought their children, ages 2 to 11, to their pediatrician for a visit. Twenty-three percent said they owned a firearm, but only one-third said that they stored their guns safely by keeping them in a locked cabinet or safe with gunlocks secured and ammunition stored separately. To the researchers, the numbers suggested that pediatricians should ask parents if guns are present in their homes and offer advice on how to store them safely. READ THE LABEL The News -- The Food and Drug Administration asked two drug makers to place prominent warnings on their diabetes medicine because they may pose increased risks of heart problems. Behind the News -- The agency's safety reviewers urged such a step last year. But F.D.A. officials didn't act until a leading medical journal reported last month that one of the drugs, Avandia, significantly increased the risk of heart attacks. Actos, the other drug, also may pose heart risks. Both treat Type 2 diabetes. The agency's commissioner, Andrew C. von Eschenbach, said he acted because ''despite existing warnings, these drugs were being prescribed to patients with significant heart failure.'' WIIOOPS The News -- A Spanish doctor, Julio Bonis, diagnosed a new medical condition after a patient complained of shoulder pain following a vigorous bout of tennis on his Wii. Behind the News -- A popular Nintendo video game console, Wii lets players punch or swing a wireless wand that translates their motions onto a television screen. There's golf, boxing, bowling, baseball, etc. The games can be quite a workout, and errant wands have caused bruises, broken windows and smashed TV screens. Now comes ''Wiitis,'' the intense shoulder pain described by Dr. Bonis in a letter last week to a leading medical journal. He prescribed ibuprofen and abstinence from the Wii. ''The patient recovered fully,'' he reported.

FRIEDMAN--Gary. The Woodcrest Club of Syosset, NY mourns the loss of our honorable member, Gary Friedman. Mr. Friedman was the club's first president from 1962 to 1963 and will be greatly missed by all the members of the Woodcrest Club. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Shirley Friedman, and family.

DEBLINGER--David B., on June 7th, 2007. A WWII veteran, he worked as an accountant for the City of New York. Patron of numerous organizations devoted to charity, social justice, the arts and conservation. Lifelong student of spiritual concepts. Husband of the late Cecilia. Father of Larry Deblinger, Ann Deblinger Reiner, grandfather of Jessie and Susie Reiner and twin-brother of Sylvia Goldstein. Funeral service Sunday, June 10th at New Mt. Zion Cemetery. For more information, Zion Memorial Chapel 914-381-1809.

To the Editor: Perhaps Lawrence Kramer should get out more. Well-placed display cases, video monitors? For the New York Philharmonic there are several of those at Avery Fisher Hall. Different possibilities of performance? Michael Tilson Thomas did just that at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 28, presenting the Fifth Symphony of Shostakovich, first with altered notes, then as the composer intended. A gift shop in which to linger? The Barbican in London is virtually a shopping mall.

Jennifer Brooke Johnson, the daughter of Deborah Z. Johnson and Glen D. Johnson of Norman, Okla., was married yesterday to Anthony Joseph Hicks, a son of Maryann Hicks and Geoffrey K. Hicks of Haymarket, Va. The Rev. John B. Davis, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York. Mrs. Hicks, 27, is an assistant news editor at the online edition of The Wall Street Journal in New York. She graduated from the University of Oklahoma. She received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia, where she is an adjunct professor of new media. Her father is a broker for Sam B. Rose Oil and Gas Properties, an oil and gas leasing company in Norman. Her mother is the chief reader for Oklahoma Scoring Services, which scores standardized tests.

The Philadelphia Phillies have lost more games than any professional franchise in any sport. The Phillies are 14 losses from a particular threshold of ignominy - the 10,000th defeat for a club that has won one lonely World Series title (in 1980) during its 125 years of often dreadful existence.

At pretty much every other stadium in baseball, the press entrance is on street level, through a team office or a side door. Not Dodger Stadium. It's built onto a hill overlooking downtown Los Angeles, and the media enters at the very top of the stadium. The view is breathtaking. Palm trees ringing the outfield and in the distance. A perfectly-manicured field. And, in homage to the famous Hollywood sign, a "Think Blue" sign well beyond the fence in left-center field. It's amazing to me that this place is two years older than Shea.

I decided very early in my Marine Corps career that I would separate and become a full-time civilian after my initial contract was completed. The decision didn't come from any deep-seeded disgruntlement or dissatisfaction with the Marine Corps, but was merely what I considered the best path for me to meet the goals I set for myself and my family. I wasn't worried about finding a job after separation. There were and are plenty of opportunities for mechanical engineers, so I wasn't sweating that part of it.

When friends come to visit in Paris from abroad they usually make a tour of all the usual museums, the Louvre and the Musée d'Orsay. But I try to steer people seeking a luminous refuge in the City of Lights to the recently refurbished Petit Palais.

My final days in St. Louis have been filled with excitement, anticipation, and trepidation. How does this "win-a-trip" really work, and what would it be like to work with Nick Kristof? What should we expect, and what unexpected challenges will we face? How much DEET and how many pairs of underwear should I pack? What will I write about, and how should I figure out "my" approach? How can I best convey what I see and hear to you, our readers?

As the presidential candidates go through their last round of second-quarter fund-raising that ends June 30, the numbers are clicking at ActBlue, an Internet site that has already collected $23 million for Democratic office-seekers.
David All, of TechRepublican and DomeNation and the DavidAllGroup, has posted tips for candidates to work the YouTube environs. It's instructive, certainly, but also illuminating.

A few days ago, for the first time in our history as a species, the human population of the planet Earth became predominantly urban, not rural. Some bold researchers pinned down this epochal moment of passage to May 23, 2007. The date was of course a polite statistical fiction, based on a United Nations estimate of how fast people worldwide are shaking off the dust of the countryside and moving into town.

I'm in a car headed to the airport with my win-a-trip winners. After coming back from my 25th college reunion on Sunday, I packed and rushed to the office in time to meet Leana Wen and Will Okun, the winners. There they were, sitting in my office - and though I hadn't met them before, they felt like old friends.

War, too, makes for strange bedfellows, and the Bush administration is dealing today with the complications that inevitably ensue from such indiscretions: The Times reports that United States commanders are "arming Sunni Arab groups that have promised to fight militants linked with Al Qaeda who have been their allies in the past"; The Washington Post reports that "A tribal coalition formed to oppose the extremist group al-Qaeda in Iraq, a development that U.S. officials say has reduced violence in Iraq's troubled Anbar province, is beginning to splinter"; while the Baltimore Sun finds that "Sudan has secretly worked with the C.I.A. to spy on the insurgency in Iraq - an example of how the United States has continued to cooperate with the Sudanese regime even while condemning its role in the killing of tens of thousands of civilians in Darfur."

Morgan Stanley's chief United States investment strategist, Henry McVey, will resign after 12 years at the investment bank. He will join the Fortress Investment Group, the hedge fund and private equity group.

The James River Group, an insurance company that went public two years ago, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by D.E. Shaw & Company, a hedge-fund firm, for $575 million. At $34.50 a share, D.E. Shaw's offer did not come with a premium to Friday's closing share price for $35.18; it was nearly 2 percent below it.

The news that Daniel Menaker is leaving Random House hit a lot of people hard this morning - he's been a force for good in the literary world, and during his career at The New Yorker and Random House he's championed so many interesting and important writers it's impossible to count them all.

The problem with lines is that they're impossible to predict. Doubly so here in Rome, where just about everything is hard to predict - try waiting for a bus when you HAVE to get somewhere on time. The longest lines here are for Vatican visits. Here are some stories and strategies to help you factor in the waits:

Three articles in The Times this weekend tell all anyone needs to know about the state of the newspaper industry.Daniel Wakin reports that papers around the country are shedding classical music critics. It is not that publishers suddenly care less about music; it is that papers are cutting staff left and right as they try to maintain profit margins while advertising declines in print editions and papers give away their content on the Internet.
Will a slimmed-down H&R Block look more appealing to private equity? That is what an analyst at UBS Investment Bank was suggesting Monday.

Affiliated Computer Services, the technology services provider, said on Sunday that it had opened up the bidding for the company, ending its exclusive bargaining with Cerberus Capital Management and its founder and chairman. In a news reelase, the company said that Lazard will actively solicit competing bids from June 16 through August 9.

James Cramer says he knows first-hand how badly Rupert Murdoch wants Dow Jones. Writing this week in New York magazine, Mr. Cramer, the former hedge fund manager who is now host of the "Mad Money" show on CNBC, tells the story of how Mr. Murdoch called him 11 years ago to discuss the notion of a bid for Dow Jones, which publishes The Wall Street Journal.

Ford Motor has hired Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and HSBC to sell Jaguar and Land Rover, its two British luxury brands, The Financial Times reported Monday. The planned sale does not include Volvo, Ford's third premium brand, and is said to be in its early stages, the paper said.

Opus Capital and Shasta Ventures co-led funding of the startup, which is based in Mountain View, Calif.

Blankfein, is still intent on proving himself and his firm to the world, writes The New York Times' Jenny Anderson, who in her profile describes Mr. Blankfein as a far cry from central casting's idea of a chief executive.

Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark effort to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company both in the United States and abroad against accusations of anticompetitive conduct, including the recent rejection of a complaint by Google.
Rexam, the world's largest maker of beverage cans, will acquire the plastics business of Owens-Illinois for $1.83 billion, adding as much as 50 percent to its sales in the industry.

YOO, the London developer dubbed the "Prada of the property industry," is breaking ground on a new project in September in Panama City -- an increasingly popular spot among retirees. YOO Panama is a 56-storey single tower on Balboa Avenue, the only stretch of land along the ocean in Panama City.

Sergei Rublevsky of Russia won yesterday to draw even with Alexander Grischuk of Russia in their candidates match. The other three matches were drawn, preserving the leads of Peter Leko of Hungary, Levon Aronian of Armenia and Boris Gelfand of Israel. The matches are being played in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

As the Blackstone Group prepares for its own market opening, the company completed a successful initial public offering of one of its portfolio companies, Gerresheimer, a German packaging company. On Friday, Blackstone set the terms of the offering, which raised 1.01 billion euros ($1.36 billion), the biggest this year in Germany.

Following a $240 million initial public offering, shares of Limelight Networks, a digital content delivery company, rose almost 50 percent in their opening Friday. The Deal.com notes that the offering was a boon for the books of Goldman Sachs Capital Partners. Its investment in Limelight has grown about sixfold in less than a year.

A J.P. Morgan executive will testify to the Greek parliament on Tuesday about its recent role in underwriting a controversial 280 million euro ($374 million) structured bond that was sold to local pension funds this year.

Shareholders of the Canadian mining company Dynatec overwhelmingly approved a takeover bid of 1.5 billion Canadian dollars ($1.4 billion) from the nickel miner Sherritt International. At a meeting in Toronto, Dynatech investors voted 99 percent in favor of the deal that will give Sherritt a 40 percent stake in the coveted Ambatovy nickel project in Madagascar.

Private equity firms bidding for the Texas utility TXU have offered up to $30 million for air pollution-reduction programs in Central Texas, but only if local officials allow three new coal-fired power plants.

Dennis Gomes, a former gambling executive and regulator, wants to be the star of his own casino. Mr. Gomes, whose work as an investigator for the Nevada State Control Board was the basis for Martin Scorsese's film "Casino," is teaming up with JEMB Realty to bid for Donald J. Trump's Atlantic City casino company, Trump Entertainment Resorts.

Advertisements for books have been around nearly as long as books themselves, and in The New York Times, they've appeared since shortly after the first issue of the newspaper went to press in September 1851. They've been part of the stand-alone Book Review since it began appearing on Saturdays, in 1896, and Sundays, in 1911.

Like I said before, I was at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda. Md., when I first returned. This was an interesting time; I was on enough pain medicine to tranquilize a small militia. I had some very creative hallucinations. When I was still in bad shape my nurse left on Univision while I was sleeping. The next morning I woke up speaking Spanish. One night the N.B.A. draft was left on T.V. for the evening. When I awoke the next morning, I hired my brother J.P. as my agent. When you are drafted in the second round by the Dallas Mavericks you need an agent. My first instructions to him were to get me a Rolex. I had to fire him, as it has been almost three years and he has not gotten me signed and I still do not have my Rolex.

A 12-year-old girl was killed by a hit-and-run driver last evening while she was attending the Portuguese Festival, the police said. The girl, identified as Kaitlyn Velez of Pennsylvania, was struck shortly before 6 p.m. near the intersection of Elm and Congress Streets by a blue Econoline van with the word “Construction” on the side, the police said. The van sped off and the girl was taken to University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey Hospital, where she died. The police were looking for the driver last night.

A vague bomb threat called in to the state police early yesterday has prompted dozens of western Connecticut schools to delay opening for 90 minutes this morning. A person called the state police barracks in Litchfield about 12:30 a.m. and said an explosive device at a high school would be detonated at 7:30 a.m. today, the police said. The caller did not name the high school. The districts opening late include Torrington, Litchfield, Plymouth, Watertown, Regional School District No. 6, Regional School District No. 10, Regional School District No. 12 and Oliver Wolcott Technical High School in Torrington.
The 61st annual Tony Awards showed fondness for the 19th century with awards for “Spring Awakening” and “The Coast of Utopia.”

State criminal justice officials are working to eliminate a backlog of DNA samples that need to be analyzed because the database was expanded last summer to include an additional 18 misdemeanors. The database started a decade ago with samples taken from violent felons, but has been expanded several times. About 54,000 samples still need to be analyzed by the state laboratory, said John Hicks, director of forensic services for the state’s Division of Criminal Justice Services. The lab has increased its capacity to about 5,000 samples a month. State officials hope to boost that capacity to 8,500 a month this fall, Mr. Hicks said.

A Brooklyn man was killed when he was struck by a car while crossing East 22nd Street early yesterday morning, the police said. The man, Matthew Hopkins, 26, of Montgomery Street, was crossing near the intersection of Park Avenue South about 4:09 a.m. when he was hit by a 1991 Honda, which continued without stopping, the police said. No arrests had been made yesterday evening.

Two adults were killed and two boys suffered minor injuries when a tree fell onto their car on the Merritt Parkway, the state police said. They were in a 2006 Volvo station wagon near Exit 42 when the tree crashed through the windshield about 9 p.m. on Saturday, the police said. The driver, Joseph Stavola, 46, and front-seat passenger, Jeanne Serocke, 44, both of Pelham, N.Y., were killed instantly, the state police said. The two boys in the back seat were treated at Norwalk Hospital. Their names and ages were not released.

A Brooklyn man was fatally shot shortly after 11 a.m. yesterday in a fight on the street in Bushwick, the authorities said. Acquaintances identified the man as Jose Torres, who they said was in his early 20s. He was pronounced dead at the scene, near the corner of Stanhope Street and Wyckoff Avenue, where, a witness said, he had been shot several times. The witness, who declined to be identified by name, said that Mr. Torres was riding his bicycle when he was approached by the other man. When Mr. Torres got off the bicycle and began fighting, the other man pulled out a gun and fired, the witness said. The police arrested Adrian Aguiliar, 30, of Brooklyn and charged him with murder and criminal possession of a weapon.

Senator Charles E. Schumer and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo yesterday announced a plan to change college loan applications. The proposal, which Senator Schumer said he would introduce as federal legislation, would require that lenders detail loan amounts, interest and fees in a table on loan applications. “A high school graduate shouldn’t need a law degree to pick a loan for college,” Mr. Schumer said in a statement.

Three men were stabbed, one of whom was critically injured, in a fight in Astoria early yesterday, the police said. The men, whom the police did not identify, were arguing with another group near Club Fashion, on Steinway Street, about 3 a.m. when someone in the other group stabbed them, the police said. One man, who was stabbed in the neck and chest, was in critical condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center, the police said. The other two men suffered minor cuts. No arrests had been made.

9 P.M. (HBO) BIG LOVE The Henricksons, America’s favorite polygamists, return for a new season on a new night, with some damage control in the wake of the family’s exposure when wife No. 1, Barb, was being considered for mother of the year. (And with seven children scattered among three homes, why not?) Tonight the patriarch Bill (Bill Paxton, above with Jeanne Tripplehorn) scrambles to find out who betrayed him, and Barb (Ms. Tripplehorn) retreats into her own world, leaving wives No. 2, Nicki (Chloë Sevigny), and No. 3, Margene (Ginnifer Goodwin), to pick up the slack. Meanwhile Roman (Harry Dean Stanton) tries to intimidate Joey (Shawn Doyle) after Joey’s wife, Wanda (Melora Waters), poisoned Roman’s son, Alby (Matt Ross). And back at home, the eldest daughter, Sarah (Amanda Seyfried), catches the eye of Scott (Aaron Paul) at a meeting for ex-Mormons.

VORDER BRUEGGE--Carl M., 77, of Riverside, CT, died on May 31. Youngest of John and Agnes Vorder Bruegge's six children, born in Memphis, TN on November 12, 1929. B.A., University of TN, Knoxville. M.B.A., Wharton School of Business, University of PA. 1st Lt. awarded Purple Heart and Bronze Star during the Korean War. Married Sarah E. Whitley on June 21, 1955. After Sales/Management positions with IBM and Leasco, from 1971-1986, he was Vice President of Sales and Marketing for MCI. Lecturer, Business School, University of Bridgeport, CT 1985-1993. Worshipped at St. Catherine of Siena Church. Member, Greenwich Country Club, 1968-2007. Predeceased by parents and siblings: Catherine, John, Howard, Vincent and Mark. Survived by his loving wife of 51 years, Sarah, four children, eight grandchildren. In lieu flowers, donations may be made to: Bennett Cancer Center, 34 Shelburne St. Stamford, CT 06902 or St. Catherine of Siena Church, 4 Riverside Ave., Riverside, CT 06878.

Queens of the Stone Age ''Era Vulgaris'' (Interscope) Josh Homme, the songwriter who leads Queens of the Stone Age, is cynical, alienated and just plain disgusted as usual on the band's fifth studio album, ''Era Vulgaris.'' He still sings in a troubled croon above the band's hard-rock riffs. But on this album he decisively shakes off the enervation and jokey detachment that made the Queens' last few albums sound like in-jokes. This time Mr. Homme hones his songs. The music dovetails its blend of Led Zeppelin and Cream with punk and grunge. And amid the churn Mr. Homme sustains long-lined melodies to carry lyrics that are blunt but not predictable: ''High and mighty you say selling out is a shame/Is that the title of your book?''
TAMA--Phyllis E. On June 10, 2007. Devoted daughter of the late Fritzi and Louis, cherished sister of Francine and Michael. Services Tuesday, 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

To the Editor: In ''The Inadequacy of Civil Unions'' (editorial, June 7) you claim that ''in establishing civil unions two years ago, Connecticut lawmakers created a separate and inherently inferior institution that continues to deny gay couples the equality they seek and deserve.''

To the Editor: Adam Cohen (Editorial Observer, June 3) disapproves of Justice Clarence Thomas's jurisprudence, because in Mr. Cohen's view it is indifferent to suffering and ''harsh,'' will make various institutions ''less civilized'' and ''less fair,'' and fails to respond to ''moral truth.''

MEYERSON--Martin. The Directors of the Marconi Society at Columbia University recall the extraordinary contributions of its former chairman and Board member, as a wise, devoted friend and leader. A pioneer in urban planning and a towering figure in higher education, Martin Meyerson tirelessly devoted his energy and acumen through the Society to extending public understanding of the global communications revolution for the benefit of humanity. With sadness, the Society expresses its deep sympathy to his wife Margy and their family.

Turf Talk ''West Coast Vaccine (The Cure)'' (Sick Wid' It/30 30/Navarre) ''You ain't no thug; you perpetratin'.'' Such was Judge Joe Brown's verdict when the Vallejo, Calif., rapper Turf Talk appeared on his TV show. Turf Talk was unfazed. ''I got a devastatin' mouthpiece, man,'' he said. ''It can't be tamed by nobody.'' And a few moments later, on the losing end of a $4,945.67 judgment (something about a woman who co-signed for a sport utility vehicle), he strutted out of the courtroom.

Lawmakers waded into the treacherous terrain of botany last week. Earlier this year, Senator Michael F. Nozzolio, an upstate Republican, introduced legislation that would make sweet corn the state vegetable. (The bill originated as a class project by students at the Dana L. West High School in Port Byron, N.Y.)

THOMAS--Jeffrey Furlough, died in San Francisco on June 2, 2007 in the presence of his immediate family. Born in New York City on November 27, 1938 he was the beloved husband of Evelyne Champin, to whom he was married 38 years ago; the adored father of Patrick (and father-inlaw of Rachel) and Fiona Thomas; the cherished brother of Michael M. Thomas, Joan Chatfield-Taylor and the late Robert F. ChatfieldTaylor Jr.; the cynosure of a loving gaggle of nieces and nephews-and we will all miss desperately the pleasure of his company; his wit, erudition, passion for the good things of body and spirit and his generosity. A graduate of Brooks School (1956) and Yale (1960), with a doctorate in American letters from UC Berkeley, he became an antiquarian book seller of great distinction and an admired figure in the trade; as one of his colleagues observed in a remembrance: ''Jeffrey was a wonderful fellow full of good will and knowledge-the latter which he carried lightly.'' (Citizens of the book world and others having recollections of Jeffrey they'd like to share with the family are invited to send them to: pjthomas66@gmail.com). A service of thanksgiving for Jeffrey's life will be held in San Francisco Thursday June 14, 2007 at the Conservatory of Flowers in Golden Gate Park at 5:30pm.

MOVING ON -- Daniel Menaker, the executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group who was hired four years ago for his reputation in literary fiction, is leaving the company. [Page C1.] A QUICK CHANGE -- The outsize robot adventure movie ''Transformers'' was born when the talent agency Creative Artists Agency connected Hasbro -- a client, and owner of the Transformers toy line -- with DreamWorks, Paramount and another longtime associate, Steven Spielberg, among others. But a month before the picture's release on July 4, Hasbro has jettisoned Creative Artists and jumped to the rival William Morris. [C1.] FODDER FOR THE BLOGGERS -- When representatives of the news media asked that the letters in support of I. Lewis Libby Jr., left, be released, Mr. Libby's lawyers argued against it, saying it ''needlessly risks undermining the fair administration of justice.'' Then, alluding to the sometimes combative world of online media, they added there was ''the real possibility that these letters, once released, would be published on the Internet and their authors discussed, even mocked, by bloggers.'' They were right. [C6.] NEWSPAPERS IN TURMOIL -- The McClatchy Company bought Knight Ridder and then sold pieces of it, the Tribune Company took itself private, and Rupert Murdoch has mounted a strong run at Dow Jones & Company-- all in the last year. Struggling with shrinking margins and uncertain prospects, newspapers have seen their stock prices slump, making them takeover targets. But bankers and analysts are skeptical that the takeover bids will continue. [C3.] ORGANIC BATTLE -- The latest battle over what can be called organic involves beer and gelatin, food colorings and casings for sausage. The Department of Agriculture is poised to approve a list of nonorganic ingredients that can be used in food stamped with its green-and-white organic seal. [C2.] SONY GAMES -- Sony Online intends to announce a plan to retake leadership in online gaming by unveiling three games in development. More broadly, the new games represent an attempt to expand the demographic profile of its customers while moving into the console market. [C3.] ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE -- A drug long used in Russia as an antihistamine, Dimebon, is showing what some scientists characterize as surprisingly strong results in treating Alzheimer's disease. Results of a midstage clinical trial are expected to be presented this week. [C2.] AN ONLINE PUSH -- Retailers and manufacturers like Reebok, Adidas and 1-800Flowers.com are setting up shop in Second Life, hoping that users will steer avatars to these stores and buy goods from real stores. So far, retailers have low expectations for their efforts. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C7.] TO EXCERPT OR PUBLISH -- Although excerpts from high-profile books routinely appear in national magazines, some publishers have been having second thoughts about the strategy. Frequently, an excerpt can offer a lift to a book's sales, but there is always the risk that it might offer too much, thus stealing thunder (and revenue) from the book. Magazine editors are now routinely exploring their options, choosing instead to run a feature about the book or an interview with the author. [C6.] HIGH SCHOOL MARKETING -- Decades after marketers began selling products by capitalizing on consumer interest in professional teams, then college teams, they are becoming big boosters of high school sports. Stuart Elliot: Advertising. [C1.]

Militants fired rockets on a district town on Sunday as President Hamid Karzai was giving an address to elders and residents during a visit to Ghazni Province, south of Kabul, officials said. Three rockets were fired by Taliban insurgents, but they landed some distance away without harming anyone or interrupting the proceedings, said the provincial governor, Mirajuddin Pathan. Mr. Karzai was speaking to residents of the Andar district, which has suffered from frequent violence by insurgents. He promised that the government would improve security and build more roads and clinics.

T-Pain ''Epiphany'' (Zomba/Sony BMG) T-Pain is the undisputed heavyweight champion of cyborg soul, and for the past few years his computer-processed voice has been a staple on pop radio. Beneath the electronic ache of his 2005 breakthrough hits, ''I'm Sprung'' and ''I'm N Luv (Wit a Stripper),'' you could detect a sly joke about love's power. Apparently the right woman can turn any man into a robot. His new album, ''Epiphany,'' has already spawned a No. 1 hit, ''Buy U a Drank (Shawty Snappin')''; the similarly-themed follow-up is ''Bartender,'' featuring Akon, who is one of the album's executive producers. And in the opening track, ''Tallahassee Love,'' T-Pain pays tribute both to his hometown and to Roger Troutman, the funk pioneer who helped popularize the vocal effect that T-Pain is known for.

PRESBY--Philip Alan. After a more than two-year bout with lymphoma and pneumonia, Phil Presby finally succumbed to his illness on Thursday, June 7. He was 43. He was born in Dayton, Ohio on August 8, 1963 to J. Thomas Presby and Elaine Smith Presby and grew up in West Orange and Essex Fells, NJ. After graduating from Newark Academy and Franklin and Marshall College, he attended Brooklyn Law School. He practiced corporate law at Shea and Gould for two years and then studied American history at New York University. Most recently, he was working on a novel and writing for the East Hampton Star newspaper. He is survived by his parents, his wife Jennifer, and his sisters Terry Presby and Mona Presby Bent. After a private family service on Monday, a memorial gathering will take place at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Thursday, June 14 at 6:30pm. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society and the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons.

The 61st annual Tony Awards last night were dominated by two shows drawn from the 19th century: ''Spring Awakening,'' about sexually frustrated German teenagers in that era, won best musical and most of the other musical awards, while ''The Coast of Utopia,'' Tom Stoppard's epic period trilogy about Russian intellectuals, set a record for the most awards won by a play in Tony history. ''Coast,'' an eight-and-a-half-hour epic produced by Lincoln Center Theater, won best play, best director, best featured actor and actress, and several design awards.

Wooden Wand ''James & the Quiet'' (Ecstatic Peace) James Jackson Toth has hinted that ''James & the Quiet'' could be his last album as Wooden Wand and that he'll be using his own name instead. Wooden Wand has released more than 20 albums under that name, including plenty of open-ended instrumental noodling, but ''James & the Quiet'' focuses on songs: 11 of them in 38 minutes. The melodies are straightforward and folky, mostly waltzes, and Mr. Toth sings in a knowing, slightly cracked voice along the lines of Tom Petty and T-Bone Burnett. Jessica Toth, his wife, sometimes sings harmony, and they're backed largely by acoustic instruments, but not entirely. Mr. Toth's cunning ally and producer is Lee Ranaldo of Sonic Youth, who slips his own psychedelically reverbed guitar into the arrangements and sometimes brings along Sonic Youth's Steve Shelley on drums. The music is sparse but cagey. And what Mr. Toth sings is verse after verse of enigma, leading to choruses like ''It's gonna be a nightmare.'' With imagery that can be biblical, down-to-earth or absurd, Mr. Toth muses on morality, bloodshed, dream journeys, death and what it's like to be ''dizzy honeybees in a bucket of tar'' -- whatever that means. JON PARELES

FEDER--Walter, M.D. The medical staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Walter Feder. Dr. Feder was associated with Maimonides Medical Center for more than 40 years. He served as chief of the cardiology division from 1967-1976. He was an excellent clinician who treated his patients with great concern and caring. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues, friends and patients. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. I. Mayer, M.D., President W. Wexelman, M.D., Pres Elect S. Farber, M.D., Secy/Treas

The songs that John Lennon wrote helped inspire a generation of activists. ''Give Peace a Chance,'' the antiwar anthem, was recorded during the 1969 Amsterdam Bed-In with Yoko Ono. The couple also used their celebrity to fight for peace with the ''War is Over! (If You Want It)'' poster campaign. Lennon's activist heirs -- among them U2, Yousou N'Dour, Green Day, Lenny Kravitz and Avril Lavigne -- will release ''Instant Karma: The Amnesty International Campaign to Save Darfur,'' a collection of his songs, tomorrow. SHELLY FREIERMAN

READING REPORTS -- Signals on inflation will come from reports on the Consumer Price Index (Friday), the Producer Price Index (Thursday) and the Fed's beige book on regional economic conditions (Wednesday). Other reports this week include May retail sales, May import prices and April business inventories (Wednesday); the first-quarter current-account deficit, industrial production and capacity utilization and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday). CORPORATE EARNINGS -- Wall Street banks will begin reporting their second-quarter results, with Lehman Brothers (Tuesday) and Goldman Sachs and Bear Stearns (Thursday). Other earnings reports will come from Take-Two Interactive Software (Monday) and Freddie Mac (Thursday). PLAVIX INQUIRY -- Bristol-Myers Squibb is scheduled to plead guilty on Monday to charges that it lied to the government about its proposed settlement of a patent dispute related to the heart drug Plavix. SHAREHOLDER MEETINGS -- Annual meetings will be held by Yahoo (Tuesday) and the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial (Wednesday). The Midwest Air Group's annual meeting Thursday could turn into a battle. A rival, AirTran Holdings, has nominated three people to the board as part of its effort to acquire the company. MEETING ON RATES -- The Bank of Japan will make a decision on interest rates (Friday).

A Brooklyn man was fatally shot shortly after 11 a.m. yesterday in a fight on the street in Bushwick, the authorities said. Acquaintances identified the man as Jose Torres, who they said was in his early 20s. He was pronounced dead at the scene, near the corner of Stanhope Street and Wyckoff Avenue, where, a witness said, he had been shot several times. The witness, who declined to be identified by name, said that Mr. Torres was riding his bicycle when he was approached by the other man. When Mr. Torres got off the bicycle and began fighting, the other man pulled out a gun and fired, the witness said. The police arrested Adrian Aguiliar, 30, of Brooklyn and charged him with murder and criminal possession of a weapon. THOMAS J. LUECK

CASALE--Ann Grimshaw, artist, died in Sag Harbor on May 7, 2007 at the age of 78. A remarkable woman who believed in herself and her ability to achieve whatever she reached for. She is survived by her ten children and thirteen grandchildren. There will be a memorial service June 16 at 11am at the Wainscott Chapel in Wainscott, with a reception to follow at The Art Barge in Amagansett, where a collection of her work will be shown. One of the late entries among the issues being discussed in the closing weeks of the legislative session is a proposal to allow video cameras in courtrooms. The issue is of increasing interest to newspapers as well as television networks because of the increasing sophistication of newspaper Web sites. ''I believe the more the public sees of what actually goes on inside the courtroom, the greater the confidence the public will have that justice is being administered properly,'' the governor said at a public meeting of legislative leaders last week.

The governor signed a bill last week that prevents landlords from penalizing victims of domestic violence if they break their leases. ''The sponsors of the bill note that many domestic violence victims would be safer if they could move to a location where their abuser cannot find them,'' Mr. Spitzer wrote in a message explaining his approval of the legislation.

INTERNATIONAL A2-11 New Plan to Arm Sunnis Against Qaeda Militants With the four-month-old buildup of American troops showing only modest success in curbing insurgent attacks, American commanders are turning to another strategy that they acknowledge is fraught with risk: arming Sunni Arab groups that have promised to fight militants linked to Al Qaeda -- in many cases, their former allies. A1 Iraq's leading political blocs agreed to remove the speaker of Parliament from his position after accusations that his bodyguards assaulted a Shiite lawmaker as the speaker cursed him. Members of Parliament and a spokesman for the speaker's party confirmed the assault and the plans for removal. A6 Gaza Infighting and Air Strikes The Israeli Air Force struck at least two buildings in Gaza City in what appeared to be a response to a raid across the Gaza-Israel border by Palestinian militants. Also, internal violence between the main rival Palestinian organizations, Hamas and Fatah, flared again in the Gaza Strip, with at least four people killed over the weekend. A9 Flooding in China Kills 66 Torrential rains in southern China have unleashed surging floodwaters that have swept through small cities and farming villages, claiming at least 66 lives, forcing nearly 600,000 people to be relocated and destroying millions of dollars in property, the state news media reported. A11 Bush Tour Reaches Albania President Bush's visit to Albania was the fifth stop on his eight-day, six-country swing through Europe. The first sitting president to visit the country, he told the Albanians that he supported their effort to join NATO and wanted independence soon for Kosovo without making any fresh commitments. A3 Sri Lankan Rights Panel Report An international panel appointed by the government of Sri Lanka has issued a stark indictment of a presidential commission intended to investigate serious human rights violations, saying that its activities so far ''do not satisfy international norms and standards.'' A11 NATIONAL A12-17 State Budgets Get Boost From Booming Economy State lawmakers across the country have found themselves with more money than they planned as they wind down their regular sessions. Burned by several years of shortfalls, states have kept their estimates of total revenues on the conservative side and are now reaping plenty from higher than expected tax collections and booming local economies. A1 Mixed Views of Romney Bid To many Mormons, Mitt Romney's bid for the presidency is both a proud sign of progress and a cause of real trepidation. Even his many Mormon supporters find the moment fraught with anxiety because his candidacy is bringing intense scrutiny to their church and could worsen longstanding bigotry. A1 Repatriation of the Dead The repatriation of remains has become increasingly commonplace as towns across Mexico have sent their children to find work in the United States. As debate rages in Congress over a proposed immigration law, the journey of the dead suggests that for many Mexicans the sojourn in the United States, legal or not, is meant to be temporary. A1 Immigration Unresolved Senate Democrats opened the door to reviving the stalled immigration measure, calling on Republicans to resolve their internal divisions and produce an agreement on how to move the legislation forward. Republican critics of the bill have called for more chances to eliminate provisions they describe as amnesty. A12 Transit Expansion Project After operating for 32 years, efforts are under way to expand the transit system designed to shuttle between West Virginia University's two campuses, which sit two miles apart. At a cost of up to $40 million a mile, the expansion would extend the system, once derided as a waste of money but now relied on by the city of Morgantown. A12 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Medical Marijuana Bill Advances in Connecticut On June 1, the Connecticut State Senate, following the House, passed a bill that allows people with certain medical conditions to grow as many as four marijuana plants for ''palliative use.'' It is unclear whether Gov. M. Jodi Rell will sign the bill, which would make Connecticut the 13th state in the nation to permit marijuana for medical purposes. B1 Border Rules May Hurt Tourism Many people in the Niagara Falls tourism industry fear that a set of new rules suggested by the 9/11 Commission requiring Americans traveling by land or sea to Canada, Mexico, Bermuda and the Caribbean to present a passport could discourage millions of visitors from crossing the border and result in billions of dollars a year in lost revenue. B1 The Pull of Homelessness After reading an article about Johnny Five, a homeless man who lived beneath an abandoned train station in the Bronx, a nonprofit group arranged for him to move into an apartment. But for the next several months, Johnny would drift between his old life and his new one. B1 ARTS E1-10 Two Big Winners at Tonys ''The Coast of Utopia,'' Tom Stoppard's eight-and-a-half-hour epic, was the big winner at the 61st annual Tony Awards, setting the record for the most awards won by any play in Tony history. Meanwhile, the musical ''Spring Awakening,'' won best book, score, direction and choreography and best featured actor. E1 OBITUARIES B7 Richard Rorty A scholar whose inventive work on philosophy, politics, literary theory and more made him one the of world's most influential contemporary thinkers, he was 75. B7 John P. McGovern A Houston real-estate investor whose philanthropy helped endow medical facilities at Duke University and other institutions, he was 85. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Editor Leaves Publisher Daniel Menaker, the executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group, is leaving the company at the end of June. C1 Agency Loses Big Client Creative Artists Agency has tried expanding its client base from mainstream entertainment companies to a widening ring of customers, but the loss of Hasbro in the month before the release of the movie ''Transformers'' is an example of how cruel the corporate world can be. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Pakistan's dictator; a test of the Senate; economic life after college; mental health in prisons. Columns: Nicholas D. Kristof and Paul Krugman. Bridge E6 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather B8

A 12-year-old girl was killed by a hit-and-run driver last evening while she was attending the Portuguese Festival, the police said. The girl, identified as Kaitlyn Velez of Pennsylvania, was struck shortly before 6 p.m. near the intersection of Elm and Congress Streets by a blue Econoline van with the word ''Construction'' on the side, the police said. The van sped off and the girl was taken to University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey Hospital, where she died. The police were looking for the driver last night. JENNIFER 8. LEE

President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called Sunday for a new global economic framework that would play down the role of institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization and instead emphasize regional alliances. Such a system, he said, would reflect the rising power of emerging- market economies like Russia, China, India and Brazil, and the decline of old heavyweights like the United States, the Europeans and Japan.

Senator Charles E. Schumer and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo yesterday announced a plan to change college loan applications. The proposal, which Senator Schumer said he would introduce as federal legislation, would require that lenders detail loan amounts, interest and fees in a table on loan applications. ''A high school graduate shouldn't need a law degree to pick a loan for college,'' Mr. Schumer said in a statement.

President Nicolas Sarkozy's center-right party was on course to win an overwhelming parliamentary majority after the first round of French legislative elections on Sunday, cementing his power to enact changes that he says are needed to rescue France from economic and social malaise. Mr. Sarkozy's party, the Union for a Popular Movement won 39.54 percent of the vote, according to a final tally by the Interior Ministry. That could give the party and its allies as many as 501 seats in the 577-seat National Assembly after the second-round vote on June 17, pollsters said.

ARNDT--Bess R. Died peacefully on June 9th, in her 96th year. Beloved mother of Carol Wolfe of NYC, beloved grandmother of Jessica Lynn Wolfe of Durham, NC, loving mother-in-law of Steven W. Wolfe, loving grandmotherin-law of Reid Barbour and sister of the late Alan Zuker. She was happily married to Arthur A. Arndt for over 43 years, until he passed away 23 years ago. She and her family arrived in the United States in 1914 from Russia and she grew up in Cleveland, OH. She came to Manhattan at age 18 to attend art school. With the arrival of the Depression the next year, she had to leave school and go to work in the fashion field. Many years later, she became an interior designer. After her retirement, she volunteered at the Whitney Museum and at the Brandeis Thrift Shop. She had a long, wonderful life. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Monday, June 11th, at 1pm. The family will be at home Monday evening between 7:30 and 9:30pm. No flowers please.

The original press box at the 16-year-old U.S. Cellular Field was a fine place to cover a White Sox game. From their nest behind home plate, reporters could easily discern the spin of a curveball or hear the thwack of bat on ball. But this year, the White Sox gutted it and remade it into the Jim Beam Club, with 200 theater seats and barstools that cost $260 to $315 each; when sold out, the club could generate $4 million or more in revenue.

It is unborn, eternal, everexisting, undying and primeval. It is not slain when the body is slain''. Bhagvad Gita, Chapter 2, Verse 20. Pallavi and Kunjali Shah.
