So, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales escaped the wrath of Congress after the Senate bill for a vote of "no confidence" in him fell short last night.
Why are institutional investors continuing to pour money into venture capital despite that industry's recent history of abysmal returns?
Hedge fund managers have been heating up the art market lately, and Adam Sender of Exis Capital is single-handedly fanning the flames.
Sometimes being a Congressman is not so different from being a telemarketer.
I haven't much read The Village Voice - a publication I wrote a lot for in the late 80s and early 90s - since it was bought by New Times Media. But maybe I should be reading it.

As they look toward the 2008 election, Republican voters are less satisfied with their field of presidential candidates than are Democratic voters, and strong majorities of both parties disapprove of the current Congress according to the latest Los Angeles Times/Bloomberg Poll.

Building up its shareholder-activist credentials, D.E. Shaw has raised its holdings in Investment Technology Group and is urging the maker of brokerage technology to consider a sale, the company said in a regulatory filing Tuesday.
Alison Smale, Managing Editor of the International Herald Tribune, discusses the events in the world this week.
The Fred Thompson for President campaign - assuming it happens, which is a pretty good assumption -- has scored a fairly high-profile hire.

Set in the snowy Alps of Leukerbad, Switzerland, a popular spa village, is the Palace Therme development with a twist -- some of the development's apartments will actually be fitted with a whirlpool-style bathtub for six people with specially pumped natural Alpine thermal waters. Indeed the bathrooms in these apartments will be their centerpieces and are aimed at taking in the scenery of Leukerbad with the mountains as a backdrop.

Failure, it seems, can actually be measured as success. Failed executives often profit handsomely from lucrative pay packages. They are booted out, generous stock options in hand. Golden parachutes break their fall from grace.

Kobe Bryant sold more jerseys than any other player last season, the N.B.A. announced, completing a rebound after his popularity dipped as he faced rape charges that were later dropped and a string of early exits from the playoffs.

There is at least one parallel between the housing market and the private equity industry: In both areas, banks have, at least until recently, been lending money on very borrower-friendly terms. An important question is whether the trend will turn out differently for private equity funds than for homeowners, many of whom have begun defaulting on the mortgages that they obtained so easily.

BEDFORD, NH, June 11 - Rudolph W. Giuliani, seeking to bring together a variety of issues that he has talked about in recent months and outline an agenda for his campaign, said that among his top priorities were overhauling the education system, achieving energy independence, and moving towards more consumer driven health care.
Are games imitating life?
All the air has leaked out of the deflating cricket murder mystery.

Martin Amis's recent profile of Tony Blair, "The Long Kiss Goodbye," which ran in The Guardian, is one of the year's great pieces of literary journalism. Amis followed Blair to the White House, where, in a surreal scene, he was offered a "bonbon" by a passing Karl Rove. (Not quite a Nixon/Elvis moment, but close.) Amis also flew with Blair to Iraq.
In the Gold Cup tournament which has already seen some interesting upsets, the United States will have to do more to sustain an effective attack against El Salvador.
Another day, another highly placed equity researcher leaves for buyout-land.
The United States, already through to the Gold Cup quarter-finals, beat El Salvador 4-0 in their final Group B match to make it three wins out of three for the tournament hosts.
Vast migrating herds, rivaling those of the Serengeti plains, have been photographed in Sudan.
Some guys who may not remember the '80s are dressing like they do.
A quick hike through this past Sunday's book sections.
A shake-shingle home on Martha's Vineyard, a townhouse in the in the Uptown district of Houston, and a three-bedroom house in Superstition Mountain, Ariz.
There is no word on what's being served for lunch today when President Bush makes a rare visit to the weekly Senate Republican policy lunch on Capitol Hill.

The first primary votes are still more than a half-year off, but the next installment of an important proxy contest -- the money primary -- is only weeks away. So the presidential candidates are all shaking the money tree this week, hoping for impressive tallies after the second-quarter reporting period ends June 30.

When the social networking site Facebook opened itself up to third-party businesses a few weeks ago, users found new features from a few dozen outside sites, including Microsoft, Amazon and just one political candidate: Senator Barack Obama's.
We're filing this under our continuing coverage of nonlethal weapons ...

A former mayor and his police chief, who have long since parted ways, renew ties. Two former lawmakers - once bitter adversaries - find common cause. And, a presidential candidate and her Senate colleague seek to tighten their alliance with an endorsement today. Seems there's something about campaign season that brings people together.
Lehman Brothers reported Tuesday that its profit in the second quarter had increased 27 percent, a record for the firm and potentially auguring a good week for Wall Street earning reports.

Hedge funds and those who do business with them were warned Monday by a Treasury official not to operate "under the false illusion" that systemic risk from their activities was not a "real possibility."

London market regulators are planning to conduct a twice-yearly survey of banks that lend to private equity houses to monitor the "excessive" levels of debt the fast-growing industry has been injecting into the businesses it controls, according to The Guardian

As hedge fund managers continue to play an increasingly active role in trying to steer companies to improve their value, one British investment manager is expressing concern that this new breed of activist investor is undermining long-term planning with a calculated assault to boost share prices
It may be a stretch to argue that beginning lawyers at big law firms need more money, but those practicing in New York could make a strong case for a raise, says The National Law Journal.

Alcoa's chief executive, Alain Belda, indicated Monday he was reluctant to raise his company's hostile $28.4 billion bid for its Canadian rival Alcan. "At the moment, we think this is a full price," he said, speaking on the sidelines of a J.P. Morgan conference in New York. "I'd hate to have to go higher than that at this point."

The family that controls Dow Jones is preparing to submit a new set of proposals to News Corporation on how to protect The Wall Street Journal's editorial independence in a potential sale, The Journal reported. Separately, The Times of London, which is owned by News Corporation, reported Tuesday that General Electric is still considering an offer for Dow Jones after talks of a joint bid with Microsoft broke down.
Enel, Italy's largest utility, set initial terms on a sale of at least $4.7 billion of bonds denominated in pounds and euros to help fund its acquisition of a Spanish rival, Endesa.
DLF, a developer attempting to raise a maximum 96.3 billion rupees ($2.4 billion) in an initial share sale, got bids for all the stock offered on optimism the company will gain from a property boom.

FastSoft, which has developed software to speed up Internet data transmissions, said Monday it had raised $4 million in funding led by Miramar Venture Partners. The funds will be used for sales and marketing and product development.

Allianz, Europe's biggest insurer, sold 463 billion won ($497 million) of shares in Hana Financial Group, a South Korean bank, ending a seven-year equity partnership with the company, Bloomberg News reported.

Veolia Environnement, the world's biggest water company, plans to raise 2.6 billion euros ($3.5 billion) from a sale of new shares for expansion following a series of acquisitions in Europe and the United States.

Pzena Investment Management, which oversees more than $28 billion in assets for institutions, wealthy individuals and mutual funds, filed to raise as much as $150 million in an initial public offering. Goldman Sachs and UBS Securities are lead underwriters for the proposed offering.

A private equity firm, Providence Equity Partners, has bought a two-thirds equity-only stake in a privately held Internet shopping site, NexTag, for $830 million, The Deal.com reported. Morgenthaler Ventures, which has backed NexTag since 1999, will retain an equity stake in the company, which allows people to compare prices for a wide range of goods from real estate to car insurance to groceries, according to the report.

Peru Copper of Vancouver said Monday that the Aluminum Corporation of China had agreed to buy the company for about 840 million Canadian dollars ($791 million) as the Chinese firm expands to meet booming domestic demand.
The doorman occupies a complex spot in the New York City class system: the doorman is at once status-symbol, diplomat and taxi-hailer. And now, he may be virtual, if one start-up has its way.
Jana Partners, the hedge-fund manager run by Barry Rosenstein, agreed to buy a 30 percent stake in the Shenyang Machine Tool Group.
When Terry S. Semel, Yahoo's chief executive, faces shareholders at the company's annual meeting on Tuesday, questions over his pay package are expected to be a hot topic for some investors.

The Dubai Mercantile Exchange's chairman told Reuters that the company is considering an initial public offering as one of its options for growth, but added that it is "still early days." The exchange, which is backed by the New York Mercantile Exchange, opened on June 1, trading futures contracts in Oman sour crude.

Richard C. Notebaert, who is credited with bringing Qwest Communications back from an accounting scandal and the brink of bankruptcy, surprised investors Monday by announcing that he planned to resign as chief executive and chairman.

New management of Take-Two Interactive Software, publisher of the popular Grand Theft Auto video games, said on Monday that the company would cut jobs and costs as it posted its sixth quarterly loss in a row. The company, whose management was replaced by dissident investors in March, said that it expected to cut costs by $25 million a year.

Fidelity Investments said on Monday in a regulatory filing that it held a 10.5 percent stake in Delta Air Lines, making it the third-largest shareholder in the airline, which emerged from bankruptcy last month. The FMR Corporation, the holding company of Fidelity Investments, said that it controlled 25.1 million shares of the carrier. The stock is valued at $461.1 million based on Monday's closing price of $18.38.

The Justice Department said Monday that the proposed $10.3 billion merger between Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings and Chicago Board of Trade Holdings would not pose a threat to competition. The decision gives a leg up to the Merc as it tries to fend off an $11.2 billion unsolicited offer from the IntercontinentalExchange of Atlanta.

In an interview with The Newark Star-Ledger, David Chase responded to angry fans, critics, bloggers and neighborhood gadflys about how he ended his show. In short, he wasn't being sadistic, as some have suggested.

Brookfield Asset Management, the Canadian real estate investor, on Monday bid 4.2 billion Australian dollars ($3.55 billion) for Multiplex, a troubled Australian developer and contractor. The directors of Multiplex, which was sued over repeated delays in the construction of the new Wembley Stadium in London, have approved the offer. Now, it is subject to shareholder approval.

Onex, Canada's largest investment firm, has joined the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board in its bid for Bell Canada, the country's largest telephone company. Onex will bring additional capital to the bid and help ensure that the pension fund's bid meets Canadian ownership requirements for telecommunications companies.
The documentary “The Rhythm of My Soul: Kentucky Roots Music” feels like an attempt to cut into the dominance of Nashville.
See inside a new fractional ownership residence in Florence, which will offer 36 apartments by spring 2008.
La Cocina is a shared-use space created two years ago to provide a platform for women entrepreneurs without assets.

When I posted on research by Bruce Ames and Lois Swirsky Gold showing that humans ingest a lot more natural pesticides than synthetic pesticides, I expected a sequel to the earlier denunciations from Rachel Carson's admirers. (To answer their most frequent question: No, I am not accepting bribes from chemical companies.)
The performers who played in Zankel Hall on Saturday were among the brightest, most promising postgraduate musicians the city has to offer.
A new study has found that some young women may be eating so little that they endanger the health of their bones.
Michael B. Nifong, who brought rape charges against three Duke University students, could face disbarment.
Deputy Secretary of State John D. Negroponte met with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to push for political changes intended to reconcile the country’s warring sects.
In every grade tested, New York City saw jumps, often in double-digits, in the proportion of students performing at grade level over the year before.
President Bush said "the time is now to move a comprehensive piece of legislation. The White House will stay engaged."

PARIS, June 12 — The U.N. war crimes court hearing cases from the former Yugoslavia today found a former henchman of president Slobodan Milosevic guilty of multiple crimes while heading a Serbian separatist rebellion and sentenced him to 35 years in prison.

BANGKOK, June 12 — By freezing bank accounts on Monday holding $1.6 billion, the ruling generals of Thailand have hit Thaksin Shinawatra, the tycoon turned politician, where it hurts. But they also emboldened the former prime minister’s supporters and stirred sympathy among what were Mr. Thaksin’s most ardent detractors.
Reversing course, police said today that Bob Woolmer, a Pakistani cricket coach, died of natural causes in March.
Prime Minister Tony Blair today used one of his last speeches in office to settle scores with the press corps.
Afghan police officials said the exchange of fire today was a result of mistaken identity.
The home of the prime minister and the office of the president were attacked today, taking the factional fighting closer to what seemed like civil war.

A sports article in some copies yesterday about Eric Snow’s role with the Cleveland Cavaliers in this year’s N.B.A. finals misstated the year of a previous trip to the finals by Snow when he was with Seattle. It was 1996, not 1995.
The Dodgers scored five unanswered runs off Mets starter Orlando Hernández to exact a slice of revenge against the team that swept them in the division series last October.

The owner of an Ozone Park bodega was shot last night in what investigators believe was an attempted robbery of his store, the police said. Three men entered the bodega, at 133-45 135th Street, around 9:30 p.m. and shot the owner in the face, the police said. He was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where he was in critical condition.

A police officer was critically injured yesterday when his motorcycle and a van collided. The officer, Doug Menist, 45, was struck about 2 p.m. while responding to an alarm call at a home, the authorities said. The van was pulling out of a driveway when the collision occurred, the police said. Officer Menist was taken to Hackensack University Medical Center. The van driver was also injured. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The state Supreme Court threw out a challenge to the state’s voter identification law, but sidestepped a decision on the law’s validity when it ruled that the plaintiff did not have legal standing to challenge it. The court’s unanimous opinion reversed a decision made in September by Judge T. Jackson Bedford of the Fulton County Superior Court, who ruled that the voter identification law was unconstitutional and an undue burden on voters. After that ruling, the State Election Board decided not to require voters to show a photo ID to cast a ballot in the November elections. A federal challenge to the law is pending.
Take-Two Interactive Software, publisher of the popular Grand Theft Auto video games, said on Monday that the company would cut jobs and costs.
NASA managers said that they would extend the mission of the space shuttle Atlantis for a spacewalk to repair a problem that could cause damage during re-entry.
The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that a class-action lawsuit against Philip Morris should not be decided in federal court, handing a defeat to the tobacco company.
TheStreet.com said it would cancel the first round of its “Beat the Street” competition because some players used trading strategies that compromised the integrity of the system.
MARATHON.
Google says it will soon begin testing a long-awaited system that can block unauthorized copyrighted clips from being uploaded to YouTube.

Barry Bonds hit his 747th home run last night in the San Francisco Giants’ 4-3 victory against the visiting Toronto Blue Jays. The two-run shot was his first of the month and only his second since May 8.
The state assembly voted overwhelmingly to allow voters to decide whether to use new sales tax revenue to lower local property tax rates.

A front-page article yesterday about the American military’s new strategy of arming some Sunni Arab groups in Iraq gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the river where the body of a kidnapped American soldier was found last month. It was the Euphrates, not the Tigris.

The Asian-American Legal Defense and Education Fund filed four lawsuits yesterday on behalf of six Sikh and Bangladeshi laborers who are seeking to win thousands of dollars in what they claim are unpaid wages from five construction contractors. The suits — one filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, two in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and one in State Supreme Court in Queens — accuse the companies of breach of contract and violations of minimum-wage laws at construction sites, including a veterans hospital in Northport and a residential building in the Bronx.

A Brooklyn man admitted in Federal District Court yesterday that he had violated federal law by taking part in a widespread effort to send spam e-mail messages to America Online customers, federal prosecutors said. The man, Adam Vitale, 26, was charged with sending junk e-mail messages to 1.2 million subscribers in August 2005, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said that Mr. Vitale admitted hiding the origin of the mail by using other computers to relay and transmit the spam. He faces up to 11 years in prison when he is sentenced in September, prosecutors said.

Nearly six years after the attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has appointed a public relations specialist to coordinate New York City’s response to the mounting health issues of people who were exposed to dust and smoke from the collapsed towers. The new coordinator, Jeffrey Hon, will advise the mayor on 9/11 health issues and oversee the way municipal pension programs respond to requests from employees who were exposed to the toxic dust. Mr. Hon, 53, was a spokesman for the American Red Cross September 11 Recovery Program, which provides financial assistance for mental and physical health care for those most directly affected by the attack. Yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg also named a 15-member panel to review findings on the effects of exposure at ground zero and the adequacy of medical services available to those exposed, The Associated Press reported. The panel includes representatives of Mount Sinai Medical Center and the city Fire Department.

Mayor John DeStefano Jr. asked the federal government yesterday to “back off” from any further raids on illegal immigrants until allegations that agents broke rules in conducting one such raid last Wednesday could be addressed. The mayor said yesterday that another raid was “imminent.” At the same time, three Connecticut lawmakers — Senators Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman and Representative Rosa L. DeLauro — wrote to Michael Chertoff, left, the homeland security secretary, seeking answers to questions about procedures used during the raid. The lawmakers also asked whether the timing of the raid was tied to a decision by city officials to provide identification cards to all residents, including illegal immigrants.

An article in the special Circuits section on June 5 about ways to restore rich sound to digital music misstated the data rates at which compressed MP3 music files are recorded. The standard rate is 128 kilobits per second, not 128 bits per second. Higher, and better-sounding, rates are 160 and 190 kilobits per second.

An article on Sunday about commencement speeches at colleges around the country referred imprecisely to comments by Boyd Tinsley, an electric violinist in the Dave Matthews Band, at his alma mater, the University of Virginia. He spoke the day before graduation at the university’s valedictory exercises, not at the commencement. As the roundup of speeches noted, the novelist John Grisham was the commencement speaker.

A front-page article yesterday about the American military’s new strategy of arming some Sunni Arab groups in Iraq gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the river where the body of a kidnapped American soldier was found last month. It was the Euphrates, not the Tigris.
A map with an article on Friday about a decision by Turkey to step up its military presence along its borders misstated the name of the country’s largest lake. It is Lake Van, not Lake Gölü.

A judge in Trinidad denied bail yesterday for three of the men accused of plotting to bomb Kennedy Airport, ordering them to remain in jail until a hearing on a request for their extradition to the United States. The three men — Kareem Ibrahim, Abdul Kadir and Abdel Nur — smiled and waved to about 20 supporters and family members in the courtroom in Port of Spain but did not speak. Chief Magistrate Sherman McNicols said he was denying bail “given the nature and the seriousness of the offense,” and he ordered the suspects to remain in jail until an Aug. 2 extradition hearing. They are accused of participating in a Muslim terror cell that planned to blow up a jet fuel artery that runs through Queens neighborhoods and feeds Kennedy. The fourth suspect, who is accused of being the mastermind — Russell M. Defreitas, a United States citizen — is a native of Guyana who was a cargo handler until 1995. He is in custody.

The Our Towns column on Thursday, about Sue Sadik, a woman from Clifton, N.J., who reflected on her passion for all things “Sopranos” in advance of the series’ final episode, misspelled the name of the real street and town where the fictional Satriale’s Pork Store is located. It is Kearny Avenue in Kearny, not Kearney. The article also gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for a restaurant chain that Ms. Sadik referred to in disparaging catering options in California, a state she compared unfavorably to New Jersey. It is Applebee’s, not Appleby’s.

An article in The Arts yesterday about the leading movies in ticket sales over the weekend misstated the given name of the vice chairman of Lionsgate, who commented on the recent decline in sales for horror films like “Hostel: Part II,” which ranked sixth over the weekend. He is Michael Burns, not Mark.

Six men were charged yesterday with altering identifying marks on hundreds of stolen cars and reselling them over the past eight years, federal prosecutors said. Operating from New York City, the men applied for automobile titles from states including New Jersey and Georgia, then altered them to disguise the fact that the cars were stolen, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. They also altered vehicle identification numbers, a practice known as retagging, Mr. Garcia said.

The Onex Corporation, Canada’s largest investment firm, has joined the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board in its bid for Bell Canada, the country’s largest telephone company. Onex will bring additional capital to the bid and help ensure that the pension fund’s bid meets Canadian ownership requirements for telecommunications companies. Others in the bidding group include Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Caisse de Dépôt et Placement du Québec, that province’s biggest pension fund. Bell, which changed its name from BCE last week, has formally recognized two other bidding groups, one led by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, Bell’s largest stockholder with 6.3 percent of its shares, and the other led by Cerberus Capital Management working with unnamed Canadian investors.

The British packaging company Rexam said that it had agreed to acquire the plastic packaging unit of Owens-Illinois for nearly $1.83 billion. The division makes plastic prescription bottles, tamper-proof closures and plastic medical devices. Rexam, based in London, said that the unit reported a profit of $114 million on sales of $760 million in 2006. “The acquisition of O-I Plastics will transform our plastic packaging business and is consistent with our strategy to expand our positions in growth markets,” Rexam chief executive, Leslie Van de Walle, above, said.
There have been no arrests in the killing of a 24-year old man who performed under the name Stack Bundles.

Japan revised its first-quarter economic growth to an annual pace of 3.3 percent, from 2.4 percent, because business investment was stronger than initially estimated. The report confirmed that Japan’s economy remained on a healthy recovery path in the first three months of the year. The bulk of the revision came from capital investment, which rose 0.3 percent from the previous quarter, better than the preliminary figure of a decrease of 0.9 percent. Consumer spending, which makes up more than half of Japan’s gross domestic product, was up 0.8 percent from the previous quarter, the data showed. That was slightly below the preliminary reading of a 0.9 percent rise. Compared with the previous quarter, the G.D.P. rose 0.8 percent in the January-March quarter, the cabinet office said.

International Business Machines said that it had agreed to buy a software provider, Telelogic, for $745 million, bolstering I.B.M.’s portfolio for the defense, telecommunications and automotive industries. I.B.M. said that Telelogic will fit into its Rational Software division, which also was expanded with I.B.M.’s purchase last week of the Watchfire Corporation, a maker of security software. Telelogic, based in Malmo, Sweden, has its North American headquarters in Irvine, Calif., and has more than 900 workers in 20 countries. Telelogic’s products help companies develop and test software used in complex systems such as aircraft radar and antilock braking systems.
Construction at 15 Union Square West has revealed part of the cast-iron facade of the building that housed Tiffany & Company during the glittering end of the 19th century.
The changes come after investigators discovered that a convicted felon was placed on the list of experts and billed the city $61,000 for work he did not do.

Two members of Congress have asked the Government Accountability Office to investigate what they called the H.I.V./AIDS crisis in Puerto Rico and the federal oversight of money provided for care of indigent AIDS patients there. In a letter to Comptroller General David M. Walker, the two lawmakers, Representative Nydia M. Velázquez, Democrat of New York, and Representative Hilda L. Solis, Democrat of California, cited testimony from community and patient groups in Puerto Rico and recent news accounts indicating that the Puerto Rican authorities have mismanaged federal money meant for groups helping AIDS patients, and that many patients have endured waits for lifesaving drug therapies. The letter called on the G.A.O. to scrutinize actions taken by the Health Resources and Services Administration, the federal agency that dispenses money under the Ryan White Care Act, to ensure that that money is better spent. Some $53 million went to Puerto Rico last year.

A developmentally disabled man who was born and raised in Los Angeles County and is a United States citizen was illegally deported to Mexico last month by immigration agents screening inmates at a jail, according to a federal lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California. The man, Pedro Guzman, 29, of Lancaster, Calif., has now been reported missing in Tijuana, Mexico, family members said. The lawsuit accuses federal authorities of failing to ascertain his citizenship and refusing to help find him in Mexico. Mr. Guzman, who was serving a sentence for misdemeanor trespassing, said in a brief telephone conversation with a family member after he was removed that he told jailers he was born in California, the lawsuit said. Virginia Kice, a spokeswoman for the federal immigration agency, said it “had no reason to believe that it improperly removed” Mr. Guzman.

The state Supreme Court upheld the murder conviction of a teenager who claimed antidepressants led him to kill his grandparents and set their house on fire when he was 12. The court ruled against several arguments made by the teenager, Christopher Pittman, including the contention that he was denied a speedy trial before he was sentenced to 30 years in prison in February 2005. He was 15 at the time of his sentencing. His lawyers argued that he had been involuntarily intoxicated by the antidepressant Zoloft at the time of the shooting. Pfizer, the manufacturer of Zoloft, has said the drug “didn’t cause his problems, nor did the medication drive him to commit murder.”.

A condemned inmate won a reprieve from a divided state Court of Criminal Appeals that will keep her from being executed this week for the killing of a 3-month-old child in her care. The inmate, Cathy L. Henderson, 50, was scheduled to be executed tomorrow for the death of the child, Brandon Baugh, whose skull was bashed in while she was baby-sitting him. The state’s highest criminal court voted 5 to 3 to send the case back to the trial court to examine arguments that Ms. Henderson was innocent of capital murder and that constitutional errors led to her conviction. In an appeal filed late last month, Ms. Henderson’s lawyers said new scientific evidence bolstered her contention that the child died when she accidentally dropped him.
Although they fell short of the 60 votes needed to bring the no-confidence resolution to a vote, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales’s critics mustered a majority with some Republican support.
Overseas trips were once common for Ivy League track teams. Now it is rare for college teams to venture so far, and ever rarer for a group like the Princeton track team to compete in China.

A French aid worker with the group Doctors Without Borders was killed in a volley of gunfire in an area of this vast and lawless country that had recently suffered through a rebel attack and army reprisals. The worker, a 27-year-old logistics specialist named Elsa Serfass, was part of an assessment mission that was sent to evaluate the medical needs of displaced villagers, the latest victims of an increasingly violent conflict between rebels in the northwest of the country and government troops. Dozens of villages have been set on fire in the last 18 months as the army has tried to flush out the rebels, forcing nearly 300,000 to flee their homes.

The Supreme Court agreed to allow its suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, to contest his removal by President Pervez Musharraf before the full court. Mr. Chaudhry, who had become increasingly independent, was suspended in March on the ground that he had misused his office. The dismissal set off a nationwide backlash that has created the greatest challenge to the rule of General Musharraf since he seized power in a coup in 1999.

An anti-corruption committee of the new army-backed government ordered more than $1.6 billion in assets belonging to the country’s ousted prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, and his wife to be frozen pending a court determination of whether it was obtained illegally. The Assets Examination Committee, set up after Mr. Shinawatra, a billionaire telecommunications tycoon, was deposed in a coup in September while he was abroad, said money in 21 bank accounts and other financial assets belonging to the couple could be seized if they were found to have been gained illegally. “The committee found evidence that Thaksin, during his time as prime minister, committed corruption and illegal acts as well as being unusually rich,” it said in a statement. In July 2006, Forbes magazine put the fortune of Mr. Thaksin and his family at $2.2 billion. Last month, the military-appointed Constitutional Tribunal dissolved his political party and barred him from public office for five years. He has been splitting his time between staying at a residence in London and traveling around Asia.

José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, the Socialist prime minister, and Mariano Rajoy, the leader of the Popular Party, the conservative opposition, fiercely divided over Mr. Zapatero’s earlier efforts to broker a peace deal with the violent Basque separatist group ETA, held their first meeting since the group called off a cease-fire last week. Officials from both sides offered an upbeat assessment of the meeting as a step toward healing the leaders’ bitter rift and forging a united front against ETA.

Slobodan Milosevic’s widow, Mira Markovic, and son, Marko Milosevic, face charges in Serbia that they were involved in a cigarette smuggling ring, the authorities said. A group led by them is believed to have earned tens of millions of euros from 1996 to 2001 by smuggling cigarettes while the country struggled under international sanctions, said Serbia’s organized-crime prosecutor, Slobodan Radovanovic. He said he would issue an international arrest warrant for the pair and freeze all their bank accounts and property in Serbia. Both are thought to be living in Russia.

Mudslides caused by monsoon rains buried bamboo and straw shacks in shantytowns and collapsed brick houses in the southeast, killing at least 67 people. Eleven more died when they were struck by lightning, rescue officials said. The port city of Chittagong was hardest hit by the rains, officials said. Nearly 8.5 inches of rain fell in three hours, submerging the downtown in four feet of water. The mudslide deaths were in the city. The deaths from lightning occurred in the neighboring districts of Cox’s Bazar, Noakhali and Brahmanbaria.

Belgium’s political parties shifted into horse-trading mode to come up with a new coalition government after voters handed a stinging defeat to Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt. After eight years in power, he gave his resignation to King Albert II, but will stay on as caretaker in the weeks, perhaps months, needed to form a government that can satisfy Belgium’s main linguistic municipalities. The leader of the Flemish Christian Democrats, Yves Leterme, is widely seen as most likely to emerge as the next prime minister after his party came out on top in the Flanders region in Sunday’s legislative elections. But he will have to convince the French-speaking municipalities in the Wallonia region that he really has their interests at heart, after disparaging them for their general failure to master the Dutch language.

Two local Red Cross workers were killed and a third wounded when they came under fire from inside the Nahr al Bared Palestinian refugee camp in the north where the Lebanese Army has been fighting militants inspired by Al Qaeda who are holed up inside. In a separate shooting, a Palestinian Muslim scholar trying to mediate the conflict was wounded as he left the camp.
The United States Supreme Court upheld federal regulations that exempt most home care workers from minimum-wage and overtime protections.
The worst factional fighting in nearly a month raged among Palestinians in Gaza, with gunmen reportedly firing at the prime minister’s home and office.
The only ambidextrous pitcher in college baseball, Pat Venditte, was taken by the Yankees on Friday in the 45th round of Major League Baseball’s first-year player draft.
Tehran and Washington were warned that their yearlong stalemate over Iran’s nuclear activities was turning into a “brewing confrontation.”
The U.S. hopes to get North Korea to begin to dismantle its nuclear arms program by releasing $25 million in frozen assets.
Religious and political leaders say that there is a crisis in Islam because too many religious edicts are being issued.

WEBER--Martin J. died at home on June 9, 2007 at the age of 102. Born in New York City on March 7, 1905, son of Rebecca and Philip Weiner. He is survived by Naomi, his wife of 48 years, his children Ellen, Carl, and Joy Weber and Marilyn Marsden, 10 grandchildren, and 15 greatgrandchildren. His first wife Natalie pre-deceased him in 1956. He was well known in the field of graphic arts as an innovator and pioneer

Devoted husband of Toby; beloved father of Franklyn and Rosalyn, Robert and Jacqueline Willens; cherished ''Papa'' of Dr. Ari and Alyson Walfish, Gary and Dina, Dovid and Emily Feinberg; loving great-grand''papa'' of Avi, Uri, Leora, Yosef, Chaya, Yisroel and Akiva. MARATHON RUNNERS SELECTED BY LOTTERY -- Patricia Plasencia was anxious about waiting until today to learn whether a computer chose her in the lottery to run the 2007 New York City Marathon. But at 5:55 a.m. yesterday on the WNBC Today in New York Show, the two-time defending women's champion of the race, Jelena Prokopcuka, drew Plasencia's name in a ceremonial drawing. Plasencia, 37, is a physical therapy assistant from Del Rio, Texas, a town on the Mexico border of about 37,000 people. Last year she did not get into the lottery, but ran in New York for the charity Team for Kids. In her first marathon, Plasencia finished in 4:52:20.

Tim Duncan's team is halfway to its fourth championship, and in the distance, one can almost hear the commemorative DVDs being pressed and labeled. By dominating the Cleveland Cavaliers in the first two games of the N.B.A. finals, the San Antonio Spurs, led by Duncan, are again setting the standard for precision, dedication and teamwork. The greatest tribute to the Spurs' way, however, had already been delivered, through a flurry of news releases from the other corners of the league.

Computer Game Outrages The Church of England The Church of England, accusing Sony of ''virtual desecration,'' called on the company yesterday to apologize and withdraw a PlayStation computer game that depicts a shootout in the nave of Manchester Cathedral, Reuters reported. ''For the global manufacturer Sony to recreate the interior of any religious building such as a mosque, a synagogue or in this case a cathedral with photo realistic quality and then encourage people to have gun battles in the building is beyond belief,'' said the Very Rev. Rogers Govender, the dean of Manchester Cathedral, who noted that three youths had been shot in the city within the past 72 hours. The church also called on Sony to contribute financially to combating the gun crime that has plagued Manchester. ''The video footage of the cathedral battle on YouTube has shocked and dismayed us beyond words,'' the dean said. Defending the game, ''Resistance: Fall of Man,'' and denying Manchester Cathedral's contention that it had not sought permission, Sony said, ''We believe we have sought and received all permissions necessary for the creation of the game.'' A spokesman said yesterday, ''We are now in contact with the cathedral authorities and will be dealing with them directly.'' Guarneri Quartet Calls It Quits After 45 years, the Guarneri String Quartet will retire at the end of the 2008-9 season. In a statement the members of the ensemble -- the violinists Arnold Steinhardt and John Dalley, the violist Michael Tree and the cellist Peter Wiley -- said they had decided that its 45th anniversary would be an appropriate time to exit. The quartet was founded in 1964 at the Marlboro Music Festival, and its personnel changed only once, in 2000, when Mr. Wiley replaced his mentor David Soyer. Violinist Turns Busker David Juritz, the 49-year-old internationally renowned violinist who is concertmaster of the London Mozart Players and guest concertmaster of the Royal Philharmonic and London Philharmonic Orchestras, has taken to the streets. During the next five months he plans to play his way across 60,000 miles in 25 countries as a busker, to raise $1 million for charities that bring music to poor children, The Times of London reported. ''Having spent the last 25 years in concert halls, I thought I would give myself something different to do,'' said Mr. Juritz, who will turn 50 during his travels. Starting out last week with an empty wallet on what he calls his ''Round the World and Bach'' tour, Mr. Juritz, who was heard on the soundtrack of ''The Last King of Scotland'' and has recorded with the Sugarbabes, said he would play mainly Bach partitas. If all goes well, he will visit Europe, Africa, Australia, India, Hong Kong and South America before finishing in the United States. ''From now until October, I will just have my backpack and violin and hope the people I play for on the street enjoy what I do enough to make a contribution,'' he said. ''I will rely on my busking earnings to finance the trip. I may have an audience of a man and a dog at some places, but I hope they like what I do.'' New Stephen King Thriller A secluded Florida key. A newly arrived bereaved mother. A madman for a neighbor. These are the ingredients of a new Stephen King thriller to be published today in the July issue of Esquire, The Associated Press reported. ''Over the last year we've been trying to breathe life back into magazine fiction,'' David Granger, the magazine's editor in chief said yesterday. ''The best way to do that is to publish nothing other than event fiction-stories that have something in addition to their literary merit to call attention to themselves.'' Mr. King's 21,000-word, 23-page novella is titled ''The Gingerbread Girl.'' Esquire has a long history of publishing original fiction, including works by F. Scott Fitzgerald, Truman Capote and Norman Mailer. Home Crowd Roots For Rolling Stones Some 60,000 fans turned out to hear the Rolling Stones perform at a British music festival for the first time in more than 30 years, when they delivered a two-hour set on Sunday night to close the Isle of Wight Festival, Agence France-Presse reported. Besides hits including ''Satisfaction,'' ''Sympathy for the Devil'' and ''Brown Sugar,'' the Stones played songs from their new album, ''A Bigger Bang,'' and featured duets with Amy Winehouse and Paolo Nutini. ''Coming back home is always like a bit more special,'' the guitarist Keith Richards, above, told Virgin Radio. ''We just carry Britain with us really, our little bubble of it.'' The Stoneshad not performed in Britain since the Knebworth Fair in 1976.

SCHEIBE--Kaete Loebhardt. Kaete Scheibe, 95, of Syracuse, passed away Sunday morning, June 10, 2007. Kaete was born in Germany and immigrated to the United States in 1936. She lived in Manhattan until 2004 when she moved to Syracuse. An independent woman with a spirited personality, Kaete and her husband Erich raised two sons and led an active life. A lover of art and music, a volunteer in community organizations and temple groups, and an avid photographer, she embraced life. Kaete was predeceased by her husband Erich Scheibe in 1981 and her daughter - in - law Judith Scheibe in 2005. She is survived by her son Robert Scheibe of Scarsdale, her son Peter Scheibe (Margaret Gelfuso) of Syracuse and her granddaughters, Alexandra Scheibe (Kyle Taylor) of New York City and Gabrielle Scheibe of Los Angeles. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, June 13 at Sisskind Funeral Service in Syracuse.

Two former Senate leaders who were once fierce adversaries, Bill Frist and Tom Daschle, joined together Monday to promote a bipartisan effort to make global poverty a central issue of the 2008 presidential race. The antipoverty drive, called the One Campaign, which was founded by the rock star Bono to combat hunger and draw attention to the plight of children in African countries, is pledging to invest $30 million to persuade presidential candidates to address the issue.

An article in The Arts yesterday about the leading movies in ticket sales over the weekend misstated the given name of the vice chairman of Lionsgate, who commented on the recent decline in sales for horror films like ''Hostel: Part II,'' which ranked sixth over the weekend. He is Michael Burns, not Mark.

On the looks-are-just-superficial-anyway front, John Edwards has been lampooned for his ''I Feel Pretty'' primping in front of a mirror. Now Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is drawing notice, though decidedly positive notice, for a glamorous turn at last week's New Hampshire debate. Her new look, right, was the work of Kriss Soterion, a makeup artist and former Miss New Hampshire, who runs a salon in Manchester and was freelancing for CNN, a co-sponsor of the debate.

The Canadian real estate investor Brookfield Asset Management made a cash offer worth 4.2 billion Australian dollars ($3.55 billion) for Multiplex, a troubled Australian developer and contractor. The directors of Multiplex, which was sued over repeated delays in the construction of the new Wembley Stadium in London, have approved the offer. It is subject to approval by 51 percent of shareholders. For Brookfield, based in Toronto, the chief attraction is Multiplex's real estate, valued at about $7.6 billion, rather than its construction operations. ''This is a company that has assets similar to ours: high-quality office buildings in central business districts,'' said Jeff Blidner, a managing partner at Brookfield. ''They have an approach to their portfolio that's very similar to ours.'' IAN AUSTEN

José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, the Socialist prime minister, and Mariano Rajoy, the leader of the Popular Party, the conservative opposition, fiercely divided over Mr. Zapatero's earlier efforts to broker a peace deal with the violent Basque separatist group ETA, held their first meeting since the group called off a cease-fire last week. Officials from both sides offered an upbeat assessment of the meeting as a step toward healing the leaders' bitter rift and forging a united front against ETA. VICTORIA BURNETT

KNITTLE--Dr. Arthur, age 97, on June 11, 2007. A dentist in Manhattan for 62 years. Survived and remembered with love by son Charles and granddaughter Sarah. Graveside services Wednesday 1:15pm, Mount Lebanon Cemetary, Glendale, Queens.

The first primary votes are still more than half a year off, but the next installment of an important proxy contest -- the money primary -- is only weeks away. So the presidential candidates are all shaking the money tree this week, hoping for impressive tallies after the second quarter-reporting period ends June 30. Several candidates are prospecting in California, including Senator Barack Obama, Mitt Romney and Senator John McCain.

A nanny was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 17 years in prison for the death of a 19-month-old boy. The nanny, Tammy Williams, 43, of East New York, pleaded guilty to manslaughter, admitting that in March 2005 she put duct tape over the boy's mouth to stop his crying. The boy, Jaylen Robinson, suffocated. Prosecutors have said that Ms. Williams's daughter was a witness to the killing. In court yesterday, an assistant district attorney, Jacqueline Kagan, said the plea agreement ''will save the defendant's own child from having to testify against her.'' A defense lawyer, Peter J. Guadagnino Jr., said that Ms. Williams was in poor mental health and that ''I know she's very sorry for what she did.'' MICHAEL BRICK

To the Editor: Re ''New Study Finds Gains Since No Child Left Behind'' (Education page, June 6): The problem of judging whether the law has had a beneficial impact on students is greater than you report. Leaving aside the problems of determining whether there has been a gain and, if so, of attributing it to the legislation, note the question the Center on Education Policy did not even address: What side effects did the law produce?

SILVERS--Lainie Zee. Died peacefully after a long illness on June 10th. Daughter of the late Ruth and Eugene Zee. Beloved niece of Charlotte and the late Herbert Wool. She will be missed by her aunt, friends, and many caring cousins. Services will be held Tuesday, 10:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. $(6$)SILVERS--Lainie. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Lainine Silvers beloved niece of our devoted leader Charlotte Wool, cousin of our Trustee Ronald and Poppy Wurtzburger. To them and the entire family our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier

Google says it will soon begin testing a long-awaited system that can block unauthorized copyrighted clips from being uploaded to YouTube, the popular video-sharing site it bought last year. Company executives have predicted that the technology, once deployed, would lead to a détente with the studios and television networks that have bitterly complained about the proliferation of their copyrighted clips on YouTube.

When the social networking Web site Facebook opened itself to third-party businesses two weeks ago, users found new features from a few dozen outside sites, including Microsoft, Amazon, and just one political campaign: Senator Barack Obama's. The Obama campaign's inclusion in the much-publicized opening of Facebook set off immediate buzz in the online political world. The campaign got an early crack at the millions of Facebook users, and Mr. Obama gained some free publicity. Some argued that he was getting an in-kind campaign contribution. And the fact that a Facebook founder, Chris Hughes, is an adviser to Mr. Obama added fuel to the fire.
KEMPINSKI--Theodore B., Jr. On your birthday, I miss you and love you more each day. Mom

As the presidential candidates go through the round of fund-raising that ends June 30, the numbers are clicking at ActBlue, an Internet site that has already collected $23 million for Democratic office-seekers. ActBlue seeks to be to the campaign fund-raising world what PayPal is to bill paying: an Internet mechanism for making payments. Rather than attending dinners or flying around the country, candidates get money by posting their information on ActBlue or linking to it through their own campaign Web sites.

Two members of Congress have asked the Government Accountability Office to investigate what they called the H.I.V./AIDS crisis in Puerto Rico and the federal oversight of money provided for care of indigent AIDS patients there. In a letter to Comptroller General David M. Walker, the two lawmakers, Representative Nydia M. Velázquez, Democrat of New York, and Representative Hilda L. Solis, Democrat of California, cited testimony from community and patient groups in Puerto Rico and recent news accounts indicating that the Puerto Rican authorities have mismanaged federal money meant for groups helping AIDS patients, and that many patients have endured waits for lifesaving drug therapies. The letter called on the G.A.O. to scrutinize actions taken by the Health Resources and Services Administration, the federal agency that dispenses money under the Ryan White Care Act, to ensure that that money is better spent. Some $53 million went to Puerto Rico last year. ERIC ECKHOLM
A map with an article on Friday about a decision by Turkey to step up its military presence along its borders misstated the name of the country's largest lake. It is Lake Van, not Lake Gölü.
TAMA--Phyllis. Beloved sister of Francine and Michael. She will be dearly missed. Joan and David Mandel

The Supreme Court agreed to allow its suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, to contest his removal by President Pervez Musharraf before the full court. Mr. Chaudhry, who had become increasingly independent, was suspended in March on the ground that he had misused his office. The dismissal set off a nationwide backlash that has created the greatest challenge to the rule of General Musharraf since he seized power in a coup in 1999. SALMAN MASOOD

An article on Sunday about commencement speeches at colleges around the country referred imprecisely to comments by Boyd Tinsley, an electric violinist in the Dave Matthews Band, at his alma mater, the University of Virginia. He spoke the day before graduation at the university's valedictory exercises, not at the commencement. As the roundup of speeches noted, the novelist John Grisham was the commencement speaker.

To the Editor: Re ''The Universe, Expanding Beyond All Understanding'' (Essay, June 5): Thank you, Dennis Overbye, for your essay about the implications of the continued expansion of the universe. I have never quite internalized the notion that space, which feels finite, is actually infinite. And life, which feels infinite, is finite. Now I know that were I born in the predicted future, space would feel finite. But how will life feel? Hannah I. Lipman, M.D. New York
KLEIN--Bernard L. 6/12/02. Five years later, this day and always, you are loved and cherished. Alice Klein & Family

COOK -- Richard A. The Trustees and staff of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York & New Jersey, together with George M. Isdale, Jr., Chairman of the Board of Trustees, and the Rev. Jean R. Smith, D.D., Executive Director, express their deepest sorrow at the passing of Richard A. Cook. Since 1998, Mr. Cook served on the Institute's Board of Trustees with distinction and was devoted to our ministry to mariners. We send our condolences to his family.

To the Editor: Re ''Fateful Voice of a Generation Still Drowns Out Real Science'' (Findings, June 5): John Tierney joins an odd, dissonant chorus of cavilers who have chosen to disparage if not completely dismiss the legacy of Rachel Carson. Although we live in a time of unprecedented climate change, ecological devastation and species extinction, Tierney and his ilk critique Carson for supposed miscalculations regarding DDT.

Mayor John DeStefano Jr. asked the federal government yesterday to ''back off'' from any further raids on illegal immigrants until allegations that agents broke rules in conducting one such raid last Wednesday could be addressed. The mayor said yesterday that another raid was ''imminent.'' At the same time, three Connecticut lawmakers -- Senators Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman and Representative Rosa L. DeLauro -- wrote to Michael Chertoff, left, the homeland security secretary, seeking answers to questions about procedures used during the raid. The lawmakers also asked whether the timing of the raid was tied to a decision by city officials to provide identification cards to all residents, including illegal immigrants. ALISON LEIGH COWAN

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Iraqi Minister Pressured By U.S. for War Progress The top American military commander for the Middle East warned Iraq's prime minister in a closed door conversation that the Iraqi government needed to make tangible political progress by next month to counter the growing opposition to the war in Congress. A1 The Iraqi Parliament approved a resolution that would force the resignation of the speaker, Mahmoud Mashadani. The vote underscored the widespread discontent with Mr. Mashadani, a Sunni Arab politician who has done little to build consensus among Iraq's political blocs. A8 In Egypt, Abundant Fatwas Fatwa, or Islamic religious edicts, have become a cause for controversy in Egypt. The complaint has been the subject of recent conferences as government-appointed arbiters of Islamic standards say the fatwa free-for-all has led to the promotion of extremism and intolerance. A1 U.N. Warning to U.S. and Iran The director general of the United Nations nuclear inspection agency warned Tehran and Washington for the first time that their stalemate over Iran's nuclear activities was turning into a confrontation that ''urgently needs to be defused.'' A8 Palestinian Infighting Rages The worst factional fighting in nearly a month raged among Palestinians, with gunmen reportedly firing at the prime minister's home and office. Violence elsewhere in Gaza left at least nine people dead. A12 Nairobi Hit by Blast An explosion rocked Nairobi, killing one person and wounding 31 others. Witnesses said three men carrying a small bomb tried to squeeze onto a crowded bus, but when they were pushed off by other passengers, the bomb exploded. A12 In Kabul, Bomb Like Ones in Iraq Afghan security forces found a bomb of the type used in Iraq in Kabul last month, the first time such a device has been discovered in the capital. The bomb was primed to hit a convoy of Afghan officials or international forces, the official said. A8 NATIONAL A13-21 Detention of 'Combatants' In U.S. Rejected by Court The federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled that the president may not declare civilians in this country to be ''enemy combatants'' and have the military hold them indefinitely, a stinging rejection of the Bush administration's central assertions about the scope of executive authority to combat terrorism. A1 Vote Against Gonzales Blocked Senate Republicans blocked a symbolic no confidence vote against Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, dismissing the measure as an irrelevant gesture, though Democrats had hoped it might intensify pressure on Mr. Gonzales to resign. A1 Dog Breeders Using DNA Tests As dog breeders apply scientific precision to their art, they find that the quest for genetic perfection comes with unforeseen consequences. And the lessons of intervening in the nature of dogs may ultimately bear as much on humans as on their best friends. A1 Senate Debates Energy Bill With gasoline prices hovering near all-time highs, the Senate began debating a sprawling energy bill that has already kicked off an epic lobbying war by huge industries. A14 Man in Sex Case Ordered Freed A judge ordered the release of a man who is serving a widely criticized 10-year prison sentence without parole for having consensual oral sex with a 15-year-old girl at a party four years ago. But Georgia's attorney general, Thurbert E. Baker, said he was appealing the order. A13 Guards Accused of Smuggling Three members of the Texas National Guard helping patrol the Mexican border have been charged with human smuggling after federal agents found one of the soldiers in uniform driving a van crammed with 24 illegal immigrants north of Laredo. A13 Disparity in Law to Be Reviewed The Supreme Court, expanding its review of federal criminal sentencing, agreed to consider the proper judicial response to the sharp disparity in the way the law treats crack cocaine and cocaine powder. A15 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Police Cite Gang Activity In Rash of Parade Arrests The New York police disclosed that 208 people were arrested at the Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday -- far more than in previous years -- after reports that members of the Latin Kings gang planned to join the parade. But several of those arrested said they had simply been swept up with the crowd and denied having any gang associations. B1 Silver Criticizes Traffic Plan Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, in his strongest language yet against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to charge people who drive into the most congested parts of Manhattan, suggested that many of the environmental goals the mayor has outlined could be met without congestion pricing. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Science Flirts With Invisibility Increasingly, physicists are constructing materials that bend light the ''wrong'' way, an optical trick that could lead to sharper-than-ever lenses or maybe even make objects disappear. F1 Findings in Animal Migration The first aerial survey of southern Sudan in 25 years has revealed vast migrating herds, rivaling those of the Serengeti plains, that have managed to survive 25 years of civil war, the Wildlife Conservation Society and Southern Sudan will announce at a news conference. F1 Cancer Drug's Limitations Studies show that the breast cancer drug Herceptin is given only to the 20 percent of breast cancer patients whose tumors have a particular genetic characteristic. F5 Health & Fitness F5 OBITUARIES B7 Lee Nagrin A noted Off Broadway performance artist, director and charter member of Meredith Monk's theater company, she was 78. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 Counseling on Mortgages With a number of homeowners running into problems paying off their mortgages, Illinois came up with a new mandatory state program to counsel borrowers on their mortgages. But the Illinois approach raises questions about how far regulators can go into trying to safeguard consumers. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: A ruling for justice; misdirected studies on Avandia; still dying in Congo; the discoverer's DNA. Columns: David Brooks and Bob Herbert. Crossword E2 TV Listings E11 Weather B8
FLAHERTY--Mark, Sr. February 20, 1927-June 12, 2003. Still living in the hearts of those who love him. Ruth, Patricia and Mark Jr.
DRAZNIN--Irving, 94, Holocaust survivor, survived by children and grandchildren, Esther and Warren Feldman, Arthur and Sharon Draznin, Bari, Andrew, Haley, Ross, Annie, Marla, and Michelle.

As Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) bid adieu on HBO, on network television CBS and ABC fought it out for first place in the ratings Sunday. While numbers for the final episode of ''The Sopranos'' were unavailable yesterday, Nielsen's estimates show that CBS attracted the most viewers for the night with its combination of a ''60 Minutes'' repeat at 7 p.m. (9.3 million) followed from 8 to 11 by ''The 61st Annual Tony Awards,'' which drew 6.2 million viewers, down more than a million from a year ago. Despite its edge in total viewers, CBS finished fourth over all among adults 18 to 49. ABC posted a solid win for the night in that demographic, aided primarily by its coverage of game two of the N.B.A. Finals match-up between the Cleveland Cavaliers and the San Antonio Spurs. Due to the nature of live broadcasts, reliable estimates for the game's television audience were unavailable yesterday. BENJAMIN TOFF

FEDER--Walter, M.D. The Yeshiva University/Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary family mourns the passing of a distinguished cardiologist, admired scholar of rabbinics and Jewish History, who served on the Board of Directors of the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies, and with his wife, Cecile, was a YU Guardian. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Cecile Feder, a former academic leader of Stern College for Women; to his children: Martin (and Danielle) Feder, Roslyn (and Marvin) Lipsky, and Carole (and Noach) Simon; to his cherished siblings: Doris Feder Getzler; Yeshiva College Board member, Rabbi Aaron (and Shirley) Feder; and to his beloved grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor and Rosh HaYeshiva Morry Weiss, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Mordecai Katz, Chairman BRGS Board of Directors

To the Editor: Re ''Accents on the Wrong Syl-LA-ble'' (Itineraries, Business Day, June 5): Bravo to Jennifer Pawlitschek, the accent coach from your article, for her statement that the term accent reduction ''is learning an American accent.''

The Our Towns column on Thursday, about Sue Sadik, a woman from Clifton, N.J., who reflected on her passion for all things ''Sopranos'' in advance of the series' final episode, misspelled the name of the real street and town where the fictional Satriale's Pork Store is located. It is Kearny Avenue in Kearny, not Kearney. The article also gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for a restaurant chain that Ms. Sadik referred to in disparaging catering options in California, a state she compared unfavorably to New Jersey. It is Applebee's, not Appleby's.

GOLDEN--Jean Stanley. Born in Calgary, Canada and raised in Portland, Oregon, Jean died peacefully at home June 6, 2007. Beloved of the late Myron. She was greatful for the care and comfort she received from her caregivers Rose, Joyce, Laurette, Kade, Ann and Jack, and her cat, Daisy, and from the staff at the Manhasset. Jean spent many years on staff of the music publisher Boosey and Hawkes in New York. She was a kind and generous friend to all who knew her. Jean donated her body to science. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Mohonk Preserve (Jean was a life member), New Paltz, NY 12561 or to the Multnomah County Central Library, 801 SW 10th St., Portland, OR 97205. RIP, dear Jean.

The Onex Corporation, Canada's largest investment firm, has joined the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board in its bid for Bell Canada, the country's largest telephone company. Onex will bring additional capital to the bid and help ensure that the pension fund's bid meets Canadian ownership requirements for telecommunications companies. Others in the bidding group include Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Caisse de Dépôt et Placement du Québec, that province's biggest pension fund. Bell, which changed its name from BCE last week, has formally recognized two other bidding groups, one led by the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, Bell's largest stockholder with 6.3 percent of its shares, and the other led by Cerberus Capital Management working with unnamed Canadian investors. IAN AUSTEN

The owner of an Ozone Park bodega was shot last night in what investigators believe was an attempted robbery of his store, the police said. Three men entered the bodega, at 133-45 135th Street, around 9:30 p.m. and shot the owner in the face, the police said. He was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where he was in critical condition. JENNIFER 8. LEE

FIGHTING RISKY LOANS A case in Illinois raises issues about what lawmakers and regulators can do when trying to keep consumers from entering into risky and expensive mortgage loans. [Page A1.] APPLE TAKES ON MICROSOFT Apple, showing its willingness to compete with Microsoft's desktop computing monopoly, is making its Safari Web browser available for Windows-based PCs. Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, said Safari would outperform Microsoft's browser, Internet Explorer. Wall Street, however, was unimpressed. [C3.] QUESTIONING YAHOO The last 18 months have not been easy for Yahoo, which holds its annual meeting today. Now some shareholders are questioning the salary of its chief executive, Terry S. Semel. [C1.] A LESSON IN CANCER CARE Two years ago, the federal government made an effort to reduce to reduce Medicare payments to doctors for certain procedures. Those payments fell, but Medicare costs for cancer treatment rose over all, proving how hard it may be to control health care spending without changing the way doctors are paid. [C1.] A RUSSIAN BET ON NUCLEAR POWER Russia is wagering that the world is on the verge of a boom in construction of nuclear power plants, which it intends to build in smaller countries that are trying to end their dependence on fossil fuels. [C1.] PLIGHT OF A URANIUM PROCESSOR The only company in the United States that enriches uranium is struggling to survive, worrying specialists that its failure would leave Russia as the world's major uranium processor. [C4.] NICE PAYDAY IF YOU CAN GET IT Financial data in a filing shows that the two co-founders of the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, will earn $2.33 billion and keep 28 percent of the company after an initial public offering. Both earned hundreds of millions in salary in 2006. [C1.] NOT A GOOD DAY FOR FLYING When an air traffic control computer failed in Atlanta last Friday, the ripple effect delayed flights up and down the East Coast. On the Road: Joe Sharkey. [C1.] AN EFFORT TO BREAK OIL'S GRIP In the wake of its failure on immigration reform, Congress is embarking on another controversial subject: reducing America's seemingly endless desire for oil. The effort is sparking a lobbying battle involving car and oil companies, electric utilities, coal producers and corn farmers. [A14.] RULING AGAINST NURSES AIDES The Supreme Court has ruled that a home-care aide from Queens -- and the nation's 1.4 million other home-care aides -- are exempt from federal minimum wage and overtime protections. [B3.] WAS IT THE VACCINATIONS? Arguments have begun in the first of several test cases that may help decide whether the government should pay millions of dollars to parents of autistic children who are claiming the shots caused their children's illness. [A21.] MAKEOVERS FOR RADIO STATIONS American radio corporations are working to halt the flow of listeners to iPods, podcasts and other sources for entertainment by trying to merge their over-the-air music and D.J. chatter with the Web while adding online streams of their broadcasts and features already found on many independent Web-based stations. [E1.] SCARED OF A LITTLE TURBULENCE? Don't be. While it can be disconcerting, airliners are built to withstand it and the chief cause of injuries in bad turbulence is from passengers failing to fasten their seatbelts. [C10.] A PHILATELIST SELLS William H. Gross, the bond investor and chief investment officer of Pimco, auctioned his collection of 19th- and early 20th-century British stamps in New York for $9.1 million, donating the proceeds to Doctors Without Borders. [C2.] DRUG MAKER PLEADS GUILTY The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb has pleaded guilty to making false statements to a federal agency, ending an unusual criminal case involving its blockbuster blood-thinning drug Plavix. [C3.] QUITTING EADS Jean-Paul Gut, below, the chief operating officer of EADS, the parent of the European airline company Airbus, has resigned over what he referred to as disagreements over policy and strategy. The departure adds more upheaval in EADS top management one week before the Paris air show. EADS has endured criticism about production delays at Airbus and severance payments to its departing co-chief executive amid an insider-trading investigation. [C2.] INSURER SUED OVER KATRINA CLAIMS Jim Hood, Mississippi's attorney general, has sued State Farm Fire and Casualty, saying the company failed to honor an agreement for a mass settlement of claims over Hurricane Katrina damage. [C2.] QWEST CHIEF RESIGNING In an announcement that surprised analysts, Richard C. Notebaert said that he planned to resign as chief executive and chairman of Qwest Communications, which he brought back from an accounting scandal and the verge of bankruptcy. [C3.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE SUPREME COURT ruled unanimously that Philip Morris could not move a lawsuit by cigarette smokers into federal court. The decision came in a case filed by consumers in state court in Arkansas. (AP) HENRY H. MCVEY, Morgan Stanley's chief United States investment strategist, is joining the hedge fund Fortress Investment, the latest departure of a stock specialist from a major firm to a younger one. (AP)

Senate Republicans blocked a symbolic no-confidence vote against Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales on Monday evening, dismissing the measure as an irrelevant gesture, though Democrats had hoped it might intensify pressure on Mr. Gonzales to resign. The Democrats had sought a showdown that would force Mr. Gonzales to retreat or President Bush to abandon his support of the attorney general, who has come under strong criticism from both parties for the dismissals of federal prosecutors and recent disclosures about partisanship in hiring at the Justice Department.

To the Editor: Re ''Cars and Bikes Can Mix, When the Rules of the Road Are Clear'' (Personal Health, June 5): I applaud Jane Brody's column on bicycle safety, but I differ strongly on one point. If you're the cyclist, the first rule of safe cycling is to prevent violent contact between any human and anything harder than a human, such as an automobile. All the subsequent rules are only means to this end. The laws of physics are applied without favoritism, and there is no court of appeal. Leslie Walden Detroit

BRONSTEIN--Murray. Died June 12, 2005. Your essence remains constant. My love is eternal. Love, Anne

To the Editor: Re ''Listen Up, Everybody: I'm in Menopause'' (Thursday Styles, June 7): Congratulations for highlighting something many of us have now realized for several years. That menopause is not a taboo subject, and women have been expressing openly their thoughts, concerns, fears of certain treatments, and yes, jokes, for quite some time.

Nearly six years after the attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has appointed a public relations specialist to coordinate New York City's response to the mounting health issues of people who were exposed to dust and smoke from the collapsed towers. The new coordinator, Jeffrey Hon, will advise the mayor on 9/11 health issues and oversee the way municipal pension programs respond to requests from employees who were exposed to the toxic dust. Mr. Hon, 53, was a spokesman for the American Red Cross September 11 Recovery Program, which provides financial assistance for mental and physical health care for those most directly affected by the attack. Yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg also named a 15-member panel to review findings on the effects of exposure at ground zero and the adequacy of medical services available to those exposed, The Associated Press reported. The panel includes representatives of Mount Sinai Medical Center and the city Fire Department. ANTHONY DePALMA

An article in the special Circuits section on June 5 about ways to restore rich sound to digital music misstated the data rates at which compressed MP3 music files are recorded. The standard rate is 128 kilobits per second, not 128 bits per second. Higher, and better-sounding, rates are 160 and 190 kilobits per second.

In Sudan, a Migration To Rival the Serengeti's An aerial survey of southern Sudan has revealed vast migrating herds, including gazelles, antelopes and elephants, rivaling those of the Serengeti plains, that have managed to survive 25 years of civil war.
