FRIEDMAN--Norma. Cherished wife of Morris, beloved mother of Ruth and Philip, died peacefully at home on June 10th after a long bout with Alzheimer's. She was a fashion writer who spent a decade at Vogue and Harper's Bazaar. Dedicated to community service, she volunteered for many years at the Helen Keller National Center in Port Washington and helped low-income students gain scholarships to college. Norma was known by all for her extraordinary warmth and compassion. In addition to her immediate family, she is survived by her adored neice and family, Lorna, Dale, Zachary and Seth, and by the many friends who loved her. A service will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, June 13th, after which the family will welcome visitors at home. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, her memory will be honored by donations to the Alzheimer's Foundation and the Helen Keller National Center. Norma was smart, witty, loving and beautiful. We miss her terribly.

A sports article in some copies yesterday about Eric Snow's role with the Cleveland Cavaliers in this year's N.B.A. finals misstated the year of a previous trip to the finals by Snow when he was with Seattle. It was 1996, not 1995.

PASACHOFF - Anne. Died peacefully on June 11, aged 97. Beloved mother of Jay (and Naomi) and Nancy Kutner, grandmother of Eric, Eloise and Tom, Deborah, and Jeffrey, and sister of Mary Konvitz. Funeral at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, 2pm.

To the Editor: Re ''The Disorder Is Sensory; the Diagnosis, Elusive'' (June 5): As a teacher I attended workshops on Sensory Integration Dysfunction, and while I was never convinced that it should be labeled a disability, studying the ''symptoms'' allowed me to understand those children better and to help parents see them not as problem children, but as kids whose skills were still maturing.

The celebrities came out to Dodger Stadium in droves Monday night to watch two of the most struggling teams in baseball. Wearing their Mets hats, Jerry Seinfeld and Hilary Swank came out to cheer a team with two victories this month, but no amount of star presence could prevent them from falling, 5-3, to the Dodgers for their seventh loss in eight games. The Dodgers, who had lost five of six, scored five unanswered runs off Orlando Hernández to exact a slice of revenge against the team that swept them in the division series last October. The Mets' lead over idle Atlanta narrowed to two games with no relief in sight. This series is the second of six in a row against playoff teams from last season.
ROSENTHAL--Harry K. 6/12/06 Lovingly remembered. Carol

Gelsey Kirkland, right, returning to American Ballet Theater as a performer after 23 years, suffered a burn to her hand during a performance of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday night, the company said. Ballet Theater, in a terse statement, did not describe how the burn happened or its seriousness, but appearances by Ms. Kirkland's character, the evil fairy Carabosse, are accompanied by pyrotechnics. Ballet Theater said Ms. Kirkland had been treated by doctors from the company and the Met and was taken to the emergency room at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital as a precaution. She was treated and released, and returned to work, the company said. Kristi Boone replaced her in the second act on Saturday. Ms. Kirkland joined Ballet Theater in 1974 and danced with it for 10 years. She collaborated with Kevin McKenzie, the company's director, in staging this ''Sleeping Beauty.'' DANIEL J. WAKIN

To the Editor: Re ''School to Prison Pipeline,'' by Bob Herbert (column, June 9): Educators and teachers are now in a position in which their only recourse with violent or disruptive children is to expose them to the legal system. While I agree that this is ridiculous in many settings, Mr. Herbert must also accede to the notion that teachers no longer have the legal authority to discipline disorderly kids, leaving only the mechanism of calling the cops.

MARASHINSKY--Julius, World War II Veteran, of East Rockaway, New York, died June 10. Survived by wife, Myra, of 57 years, he will be remembered with love, and affection by her and children Amy Sophia and Andrew Marashinsky, Amanda Lundberg, son-in-law, Marcel, and grandchildren Charlotte and Jem, and by a grateful country, in whose service he earned a Purple Heart.

The Asian-American Legal Defense and Education Fund filed four lawsuits yesterday on behalf of six Sikh and Bangladeshi laborers who are seeking to win thousands of dollars in what they claim are unpaid wages from five construction contractors. The suits -- one filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, two in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and one in State Supreme Court in Queens -- accuse the companies of breach of contract and violations of minimum-wage laws at construction sites, including a veterans hospital in Northport and a residential building in the Bronx. ALAN FEUER

To the Editor: Re ''Grass Roots Roared, and an Immigration Plan Fell'' (front page, June 10): While waiting for a new immigration plan, let's enforce the existing laws to prevent anyone from illegally working in the country. If employers had followed and the government enforced the existing laws for hiring only workers legally entitled to work in the United States, we wouldn't be in this situation.

A Brooklyn man admitted in Federal District Court yesterday that he had violated federal law by taking part in a widespread effort to send spam e-mail messages to America Online customers, federal prosecutors said. The man, Adam Vitale, 26, was charged with sending junk e-mail messages to 1.2 million subscribers in August 2005, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said that Mr. Vitale admitted hiding the origin of the mail by using other computers to relay and transmit the spam. He faces up to 11 years in prison when he is sentenced in September, prosecutors said.

PETRIE--John A. II, It is with tremendous sadness and deep affection that the entire New York Hospital Queens family mourns the passing of one of our own, John A. Petrie II, our Vice President for Regulatory Affairs and Corporate Compliance Officer. Mr. Petrie was a strong and ever-calm source of expertise and excellence during his life and his 38-year tenure at the Medical Center. He will be remembered with fondness. During his distinguished career, his contributions permeated the fabric of the hospital's evolution and growth, as he rose from accounts manager and assistant controller, through a variety of critical administrative and operations positions, and then to vice president in the mid-1980s. As a member of the management team, he successfully guided our organization through innumerable accreditation surveys. Additionally, he was a Fellow of the American College of Healthcare Executives. Along the way he was a mentor and friend to many-and he helped to shape the delive ry of healthcare in Queens. He focused on doing right by the patient, their concerned families, our community, and our employees. While we know his passing will bring his body peace, many will feel the loss of this man. On behalf of all our management and administration, clinical leadership and medical staff, employees, volunteers and auxilians, we offer our condolences to his family, including his beloved wife Daphne, his children John Petrie, III, M.D. and Randall Petrie, Esq., his four grandchildren, and his brothers and sisters. His sister Grace Goveia and his son John are also members of the New York Hospital Queens family. Stephen S. Mills, President and CEO John E. Sciortino, Sr. VP and COO, William G. Wolff, M.D. Chairman, Medical Board David H. Snyder, M.D. President, Medical Staff Society $(6$)PETRIE--John A. II, with tears in our eyes and smiles in our memories, the employees of New York Hospital Queens say farewell to our colleague and friend John A. Petrie II. Mr. Petrie was a trusted colleague and friend for 38 years and he made remarkable contributions to the growth of this hospital's capacity to take care of people. All that have had the pleasure of knowing him will miss him. Perhaps the best way we can communicate how important he has been as a person and as an influence to us is by sharing some of his words from a ceremony during which he was honored with the 2002 Healthcare Chaplaincy's Wholeness of Life Award: ''This is a special day for me. Today my colleagues and the Chaplaincy of New York are recognizing me. I say thank you for expressing kind thoughts. It is a humbling experience to stand here and listen to such accolades. Indeed, I consider myself a dedicated healthcare worker, whose adult life has been immersed in addressing the wholeness of life. Over the years, I have not used scapels or stethoscopes, but I am attuned to the beating heart of the newborn, the aching heart of the sick, and the greiving heart of the relatives and families who visit from the community... I accept this honor with humility and pride.'' His words from that special day define how Mr. Petrie lived and worked. Now it is our hearts that grieve the loss of a wonderful role model and kind friend. We offer our condolences to his family, including his beloved wife Daphne, his children John Petrie III, M.D. and Randall Petrie, Esq., his four grandchildren, and his brothers and sisters. His sister Grace Goveia and his son John are also members of the New York Hospital Queens family. The Employees of New York Hospital Queens $(6$)PETRIE--John A. II. With great sadness, the Board of Trustees of New York Hospi tal Queens mourns the passing of John A. Petrie II, Vice President for Regulatory Affairs and Corporate Compliance Officer. Mr. Petrie was the consummate professional in each of the many responsibilities he took on during his 38-year career at the Medical Center. We always counted on him to build new paths and lead the way down them. This was something he did with quiet, determined strength, and an equal dose of warmth and humor. On behalf of all our trustees, we offer our condolences to his family, including his wife, Daphne, his children, John Petrie III, M.D. and Randall Petrie, Esq., his four grandchildren, and his brothers and sisters. George F. Heinrich, M.D. Chairman Stephen S. Mills, President and Cheif Executive Officer Members of the Board of Trustees

To the Editor: In two recent articles -- ''After Sanctions, Doctors Get Drug Company Pay'' (front page, June 3) and ''Psychiatrists, Troubled Children and Drug Industry's Role'' (front page, May 10) -- you focused on psychiatrists in Minnesota, presumably because it's the one state with a robust law on disclosing pharmaceutical company payments to physicians.

A French aid worker with the group Doctors Without Borders was killed in a volley of gunfire in an area of this vast and lawless country that had recently suffered through a rebel attack and army reprisals. The worker, a 27-year-old logistics specialist named Elsa Serfass, was part of an assessment mission that was sent to evaluate the medical needs of displaced villagers, the latest victims of an increasingly violent conflict between rebels in the northwest of the country and government troops. Dozens of villages have been set on fire in the last 18 months as the army has tried to flush out the rebels, forcing nearly 300,000 to flee their homes. LYDIA POLGREEN

''The president cannot eliminate constitutional protections with the stroke of a pen by proclaiming a civilian, even a criminal civilian, an enemy combatant subject to indefinite military detention.'' JUDGE DIANA GRIBBON MOTZ, writing for the majority in a ruling by the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va. [A20]

Of the five presidential debates so far, this month's Democratic debate on CNN had the most viewers. The Democratic debates had an average of 2.5 million viewers, while the average for the Republican debates was 2.1 million viewers. The Democratic debates also attracted a large share of younger viewers.

A front-page article yesterday about the American military's new strategy of arming some Sunni Arab groups in Iraq gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the river where the body of a kidnapped American soldier was found last month. It was the Euphrates, not the Tigris.

STENTIFORD - Ina, died peacefully on June 11, in her 69th year. Beloved wife of Chuck, loving Mother to Heather and Debbie, loving Sister to Alan and Gary, devoted Grandmother to Max, Hannah, Sophie, Carly and Samantha, cherished mother-in-law to Richard and Jeffrey. Ina was an accomplished internationally known award winning art quilter. She was a member of numerous quilting organizations and founding member of the Signature Art Quilters. We loved her dearly. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held Wednesday at noon at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

Q. How do they weigh greenhouse gas emissions? A. While it is possible to weigh a quantity of gas, by comparing the weight of an evacuated container to one filled at a known pressure, climate scientists do not rely on direct measurements. Instead, they use estimates based on the molecular weight of carbon dioxide; the weights of other greenhouse gases are converted to their greenhouse impact as compared with that of a ton of carbon dioxide.
Thanks to reader Scott L. for this link, which takes you to the Buy.com page for the TiVo Series 3.
In the Life's Work column in today's Thursday Styles section, Lisa Belkin writes about the challenges and import of the family dinner.

The quadrennial ritual of presidential debates has long followed a tried and true format.

Racing around our e-mails and clocking up the views on YouTube is an incredibly racy, well, steamy new video "I Got a Crush ... on Obama" by a student (Obama Girl) and a new Web site, barelypolitical -- uh-huh -- that teases it'll give us more info later.
On his first day in Africa, Will Okun, a teacher from Chicago, visits a school at a refugee camp in Rwanda.
In recent years, the 28.5 mile swim around Manhattan has become increasingly popular among relatively novice swimmers.
First aired on May 3, 2007 in Washington D.C. The ad was created to  coincide with President Bush's veto of the Iraq funding bill.
Betsy Hall and Pam Palumbo are taking a stand and calling their civil union a marriage.

The Assembly Democrats' steering committee -- a group of about 30 members picked by Speaker Sheldon Silver to help guide consensus on important policy for the Democratic majority -- met today to talk about congestion pricing for New York City.

A lot of people have begun to lose their appetite lately at the thought that their food travels, on average, 1,500 miles from farmer to dinner plate. Buying, instead, from local farmers looks increasingly appealing: We get fresher produce (and benediction from Alice Waters), while also preserving open space and protecting local jobs.
Everybody knows that "The Sopranos" is a savage critique of American society.

Above, President Bush's watch, on his wrist, today. On YouTube, an NBC video showing him pocketing it himself in Albania. After speculation -- in varying degrees of caution -- stretched across the Web and into The Lede on Tuesday, he deserves the last word on this. "I have never seen such a ludicrous story," Mr. Bush told reporters. "Unbelievable." (Photo: Ron Edmonds/AP)
Most readers have asked if the design of the house will be out of place on Anna Maria. For us, the answer is no.

So, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas has finally declared the struggle between his Fatah party and Hamas a "civil war." ­Is that, in itself, a sign of progress? Hugh Hewitt thinks it is, at least if it leads the mainstream media to follow his lead:
LOS ANGELES -- Steven Spielberg's exploratory phase is over: He's a Hillary Clinton man.
Cyprus, which plans to adopt the euro in January 2008, has been pulling out all the stops when it comes to marketing itself as a great location for property investors.

Senator John McCain's presidential campaign today circulated a video clip to reporters showing Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, reiterating at a May 2005 news conference his commitment to maintaining the state's laws that allowed women to undergo abortions.

It may be too early to begin a death watch, but there's more bad news ahead for Detroit's once-invincible auto show. Porsche will not have a display at the North American International Auto Show next January. Don't worry, Detroit, you'll always have winter.
Animals -- including this morning's runaway sheep -- appear to be running amok today.

Carl Icahn may believe (and he may be right) that his corporate agitations have created $50 billion in shareholder value over the past few years, as Fortune reported last month. But the larger question -- perhaps more important now than in years -- remains: Do the actions of activist investors benefit the rest of a company's stakeholders?
What is it about big investment banks and hedge funds? UBS closed its fund earlier this year, and Goldman Sachs' flagship fund, Global Alpha, has been on a 16-month losing streak.
Date: Wed, 13 Jun 2007 12:47:49 -0400To City EditorFrom: Al Baker, police bureau chiefSubject: on the sheep
So far, the Wasserstein effect is looking pretty muted.

I've had so many great bottles of 2005 Beaujolais that I'm having trouble containing myself. In fact, I'm about to buy a bunch, some for drinking this summer and some to age for a few years, which means my wine storage situation won't be able to contain itself either. Drink faster, right?

Herbert Muschamp, a former architecture critic for The New York Times, mused last December that the Trevi Fountain had been running for so long that it "wouldn't mind being stopped, for its life must be getting tiresome:"

Cisco isn't afraid to make surprising deals -- even big ones. In March, it announced a $3.2 billion acquisition of WebEx, causing several pundits to wonder why the company, which makes networking gear, would buy a videoconferencing firm. That deal came just after the much smaller acquisition of Tribe.net, a social-networking Web site that had long been eclipsed by MySpace, Facebook, and others.

Amid all the fuss over Stephen Schwarzman's $400 million paycheck, another interesting nugget in Blackstone Group's latest I.P.O. prospectus went largely overlooked: Goldman Sachs, which had previously been left out of the club of investment banks underwriting Blackstone's $4.7 billion public offering, has been added to the list.
The United States cemented its position Tuesday at the top of Group B with a convincing 4-0 drubbing of El Salvador in the Gold Cup.

In today's Dining section, I write about the proliferation of restaurants and dishes that promote eating with fatty, meaty abandon. This kind of eating often involves pork, and it often involves offal. The restaurants and dishes in question put a diner in touch with his or her most carnivorous, gluttonous, barbaric self, and they leave a diner with fingers slicked with grease and a belly filled, quite possibly, with belly (pork, lamb).
The Hamas party further consolidated its control of northern Gaza in Palestinian factional battles.
Chinua Achebe has won the Man Booker International Prize [NYT / Guardian], reportedly beating out writers like Salman Rushdie, Philip Roth, Alice Munro, Carlos Fuentes and Michael Ondaatje.

One of the things that is really bothering me these days is that "going green" is so often presented as an opportunity for making money. Yesterday we hear the potentially good news that the E.U. is planning a 1.6 billion Euro public project called Clean Sky to develop greener aircraft.

On Wednesdays, this blog will be the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the "celebrity playlists" on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

One of the bigger YouTube sensations so far can be credited to an ingenious combination of a two-liter bottle of Diet Coke and and a few Mentos. But the inspiration behind it stretches all the way back to the 1950s and Don Herbert, who died on Tuesday at 89.

A group of investors based in Italy made an informal offer on Tuesday to buy out Macquarie's 45 percent stake in Rome's airports for about 1.1 billion euros ($1.5 billion), The Financial Times reported. The Australian financial firm is considering whether to take the offer or to counter by buying the Italian group's 51 percent stake, the paper said.

While former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson stopped short of officially announcing his candidacy for president on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno last night, he made his intentions clear enough. Though he told the late night audience that he has "never craved" the presidency, he expressed an interest in the job. Mr. Thompson's supporters will more than likely have to wait until next month for an actual announcement.
The Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe beat such celebrated nominees as Philip Roth, Margaret Atwood and Ian McEwan to win the fiction prize.

The backlash against the tremendous wealth being created by managers of hedge funds and private equity funds may be gaining strength, The New York Times noted. On Tuesday, a former treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin, made a case for doubling the tax rate paid by private equity and hedge fund managers.

The Jones Apparel Group is nearing a deal to sell its Barneys New York luxury department store chain to a private-equity firm owned by the Dubai government, The New York Post reported, in a deal that may worth about $950 million.
With a single e-mail, a hedge fund chief, James Chanos, delivered all the ingredients of a Wall Street gossip item tailor-made for a slow week in mid-June.

The debate over whether the less-restrictive loans that banks have been handing out at an unprecedented rate to private equity groups will end in more bankruptcies is far from settled, as DealBook noted on Tuesday.

Venture-backed initial public offerings had their best month in years last month as 11 companies raised $1.6 billion from I.P.O.s on American exchanges. That figure represents the most money raised since August 2004 when the debut of Google raised that figure to nearly $1.9 billion, according to statistics released Tuesday by Thomson Financial and the National Venture Capital Association.

Barclays has drawn up contingency plans to restructure its all-share offer for ABN Amro, the Dutch bank, with a significant cash sweetener in case it is forced into a full-blown takeover battle, The Financial Times reported.

The Wall Street Journal, already roiled by a proposed takeover by Rupert Murdoch, will announce on Wednesday a major newsroom shake-up, including the reassignment and replacement of several top editors, The New York Times reported.
ComScore, an Internet market-research company, plans to raise as much as $80 million in an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing.
Ceridian's largest shareholder, Pershing Square Capital Management, has opposed the company's sale to Thomas H. Lee Partners and Fidelity National Financial, saying the offer is too low.

Yahoo said on Tuesday that about a third of its shareholders had voted against the re-election of one or more company directors. The vote against some directors had been recommended by three Wall Street advisory firms who complained about what they described as excessive executive pay.

Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission is planning to simplify licensing requirements to make it easy for hedge fund managers to set up shop there, HedgeFund.Net reported. The commission will speed up the licensing process and exempt some staff members of hedge fund firms from having to take exams. Firms that are already licensed or registered in the United States or United Kingdom will benefit from an expedited licensing process, the agency said.

As D.E. Shaw continues to ramp up its public persona -- increasingly taking an active role in pressuring companies to shape-up -- it seems the firm felt it needed someone to take care of its burgeoning new image.

Santander Central Hispano, Spain's biggest bank, may raise 4 billion euros ($5.3 billion) selling real estate assets including the bank's headquarters to provide funds for its banking business. The lender hopes to make a 1.4 billion euro gain by selling or signing lease-backs for 44 buildings in Spain, including its new headquarters at Boadilla del Monte outside Madrid, a spokeswoman for the bank told Bloomberg News on Wednesday.
In Columbus, Ind., the Frugal Traveler saves money on lodging by staying with a family he found through CouchSurfing.com.

A Milan judge has ordered four banks, Morgan Stanley, Deutsche Bank, UBS and Citigroup, to stand trial in connection with the 2003 bankruptcy of the Italian dairy company Parmalat, the banks said. Judge Cesare Tacconi set the date for Jan. 22, the four firms confirmed Wednesday.

The head of HSBC's Asian business, Michael Smith, unexpectedly resigned to become chief executive of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, signaling that ANZ will continue an aggressive expansion into Asia. Mr. Smith, 50, who worked for HSBC for 29 years, succeeds John McFarlane, who ran the bank for a decade.
Ford Motor confirmed Tuesday that it was working with financial advisers to sort out the future of Jaguar and Land Rover, which have been rumored to be up for sale for more than a year.

A dispute between Groupe Danone, the French multinational company, and a brash Chinese executive has escalated into a battle for control of the country's largest beverage maker, in what some observers are calling a cautionary tale.

IntercontinentalExchange resubmitted a proposal Tuesday to acquire Chicago Board of Trade Holdings, with enhancements that included allowing the Chicago board's shareholders to receive cash instead of stock.

Openads, a supplier of open-source online advertising software, has received $5 million in initial venture funding from a group led by Index Ventures. Openads' ad-server technology competes with DoubleClick, which Google recently acquired, but at a different end of the market, Reuters reported.
Morgan Stanley will pay $4.4 million to settle a class-action lawsuit with brokerage clients who bought precious metals and paid storage fees, according to a court filing.

A federal judge in Brooklyn approved an agreement Tuesday in which the former sales chief of CA, Stephen Richards, who pleaded guilty in an accounting fraud case at the company, will pay more than $29 million in restitution.

New Century Financial, the bankrupt housing lender, disclosed on Tuesday that it had fired its chief executive and an executive vice president and named its chief restructuring officer to the post of chief executive.

Brysam Global Partners, a private equity firm set up by two former Citigroup executives, has made its first investment, taking a $230 million stake in a Mexican financial services group. Brysam, which was started earlier this year by Robert Willumstad, former president and chief operating officer of Citi, and Marge Magner, former chairman and chief executive of Citi's global consumer group, will take a 28 percent stake in Ixe Grupo Financiero.

Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, and three other former company executives rested their defense on federal fraud charges Tuesday without taking the stand. Closing arguments are set for Monday.

Apparently, there has been a little too much family spirit at Commerce Bancorp. The bank, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said it would end contracts with companies owned by executives and their relatives by the end of the year, halting a practice that has drawn the attention of regulators.

Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, tried to turn the tables on his accusers on Tuesday. In a court filing in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Greenberg said testimony from three A.I.G. employees would discredit recent accusations by the State of New York.

Phytomedics, a developer of an arthritis drug based on extracts from the Chinese Thunder God Vine, has nabbed $9 million in Series B funding, an event that the Red Herring suggests could signal new market opportunities for plant-based medicines and a tempering of Big Pharma's suspicion of herbal remedies.
The Blackstone Group wants investors to save the date: The buyout shop's much-awaited initial public offering is set for the week of June 25, underwriters said.
St. John Hankin’s lacerating 1905 comedy, which is only now receiving its New York premiere,  is a coolly enthralling play about a timeless subject: failure.
This new play by the young British writer Nina Raine feels a bit like an episode of “Friends” set in an abbey.
The “are we there yet?” of a family trip is magnified — or condensed — into two acts in Anastasia Traina’s play.
This dark, scalding play by John Belluso is not remotely what you’re expecting.
Fresh off three straight victories in the Concacaf Gold Cup, the United States men’s soccer team rose 13 places to No. 16 in the FIFA world rankings.
After a cease-fire that quelled violence for nearly four years, war is again scarring Sri Lankan life.
Katherine Whiteside, the author of “The Way We Garden Now,” tests gloves while building a raised-bed potager.
Landlocked goldfish worth their weight in 24-karat and more.
Tyler Perry seems to have jumped into the tub of August Wilson’s politics, aiming to convince us that the problems confronting young black men and women today are issues of skin tone, not class.
Frederick Wiseman’s  clattery, shuffly, all-too-real documentary,  “State Legislature,” set in the state capital building in Boise, Idaho, appears tonight on PBS.
The mocking celebration of executive hubris on "Lil' Bush," the animated satire making its debut on Comedy Central tonight, feels awfully pre-2006-election.
Additional images from the Brooklyn waterfront, which the National Trust for Historic Preservation has declared an endangered site.
A look at productions by the Target Margin Theater company.
Additional images from the international art fair in Switzerland.

I am a Chicago high school teacher who (unfortunately) rarely travels or writes, on a journey to Africa with an award-winning international correspondent who reports with inspired, accessible, concise language and offers a breadth of knowledge from years of working and living in foreign lands. With so many experienced writers and entertainers sharing stories and reports from Africa, why in the world would you ever want to read my blog? I hope my daily photographs and stories will reach and relate to other uninformed young people who seek a fresh, unlearned and detailed perspective into the daily life and youth culture of sub-Sahara Africa.
Shopping, strolling and eating on a weekend tour of this Italian city.
Additional images from the exhibit "Projects 85: Dan Perjovschi" at the Museum of Modern Art.

Arrrgh, bad news: evidently, the ratings for "It's All Geek to Me" (my funny tech show) were low. So Discovery execs have decided NOT to broadcast the final 2 episodes on the Science Channel. Instead, they intend to put those two episodes, complete, here on the Web. (That's what they SAY. They're still not posted.)
Frank Bruni says that "these are times of bold temptation, as well as prompt surrender, for a carnivorous glutton in New York."

Every year, it seems, Mariano Rivera struggles for a bit and the fans and the news media wonder if he's finally lost it. It's a legitimate story, because some day, Rivera won't be Rivera anymore. But that day is not upon us.
A mood of cosmic desolation seeps like late autumn sunlight filtered through clouds in Aki Kaurismaki’s “Lights in the Dusk.”
One of the most ambitious tonal mash-ups in memory, “Noriko’s Dinner Table” is a domestic comedy, a bloody psychological thriller and a comment on the fragility of identity.
Harold Reynolds went to work Tuesday as an analyst for mlb.com, almost 11 months after being fired by ESPN in a disputed sexual-harassment case.
If Austria is known at all for wines, it is for whites. But the real excitement these days is in the discovery of its reds, most notably zweigelt and blaufränkisch.
A House committee chairman said that he would seek legislation to curb lending abuses if the central bank did not act quickly to do so.
The organizers of the Puerto Rican Day parade denounced the police for arresting more than 200 people at the parade on Sunday and forcing most of them to spend a night in jail.
Producers take heart: It just got a little easier to put your hands on an Oscar.
Questions will come via video submitted by ordinary people through the video-sharing Web site.
Confusion over what officials can legally tell one another has limited their ability to prevent the kind of violence that occurred at Virginia Tech, according to a federal report.

JERUSALEM, June 13 — Ehud Barak, a former prime minister of Israel, returned to the political scene as the new head the Labor party today, and Shimon Peres, the deputy prime minister and elder statesman of the ruling Kadima party was elected by parliament to the largely ceremonial post of president of Israel.
Proposed legislation aims to forcing penalties on China over its policy of suppressing the value of its currency to promote exports.
Scientists have uncovered the fossil skeleton of a robust bird-like dinosaur that lived 70 million years ago.
The subpoenas from  Congress intensify pressure on the White House over the dismissals of U.S. attorneys.

HANOI, June 13 — President Nguyen Minh Triet of Vietnam is bracing himself for criticism over his country’s human rights record when he travels to Washington next week, the first Vietnamese head of state to do so since the Vietnam War ended 32 years ago.
Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular driver in Nascar, announced Wednesday that he will race for Hendrick Motorsports beginning in 2008.
Indonesian police confirmed today that Abu Dujana, a major southeast Asia terrorist leader, had been arrested.
The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, faces the collapse of Fatah power in Gaza and a putative Palestinian state divided between Fatah and Hamas.
YouTube, MySpace and Facebook are all over the candidates’ home pages, but will  voters under the age of 25 going to turn out in record numbers?
The bombing came just over a year after a previous attack on the site unleashed a tide of sectarian bloodletting across Iraq.

A listing of results on Monday from the Prefontaine Classic track-and-field meet in Eugene, Ore., reversed the top two finishers in the men’s high jump. Tora Harris was first and Jesse Williams second.
Starter John Maine had the indignity of allowing home runs on three consecutive pitches, to the Dodgers’ Nos. 7-8-9 hitters, in the second inning, and the Mets never recovered.
Holding a 3-0 lead, the Spurs are a victory away from clinching their fourth N.B.A. title in nine years and solidifying their dynasty status.

A historic church has sued Consolidated Edison for $1 million, claiming that its 89-year-old pipe organ, one of the largest in the Western Hemisphere, was damaged by steam escaping from beneath the adjacent street and sidewalk.

An article yesterday about the high number of arrests at this year’s Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the estimated number of arrests at last year’s parade. The figure of 50 to 60 arrests last year was taken from an article that ran in The Times in 2006; the estimate did not come from the New York police in the course of reporting yesterday’s article. (The 2006 article cited “at least 50” arrests, but the Police Department disputes that figure, saying 151 people were arrested.) An article about the reaction to this year’s arrests appears today.
Chien-Ming Wang worked seven innings, riding a Bobby Abreu homer to beat Arizona and bring the Yankees’ record to .500 for the first time since May 9.
Blockbuster is offering lower-priced plans for online movie rentals to compete with Netflix.
Even if losing seven of eight makes Mets fans antsy, especially with the team’s schedule growing more daunting every day, it is just baseball to Manager Willie Randolph.
IntercontinentalExchange resubmitted a proposal to acquire the Chicago Board of Trade.

Helped by robust manufacturing, India’s industrial output rose a stronger-than-expected 13.6 percent in April from a year earlier, the government said. But the numbers heightened concerns that the Indian economy might be overheating, growing faster than the pace that can be sustained. It also fueled fears that the central bank might increase lending rates and take steps to restrain money supply growth to cool the economy. While the April growth was slower than the 14.5 percent rise in March, it was stronger than the 11 percent expansion forecast by economists polled by Dow Jones Newswires. The April data showed manufacturing expanded 15.1 percent in April, while electricity generation grew 8.7 percent from a year ago. Mining output rose 3.4 percent.

The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group hired Michael Smith, head of Asia for HSBC Holdings, as chief executive to drive expansion in Asia, where the bank plans to double investment. Mr. Smith, 50, who worked for HSBC for 29 years, succeeds John McFarlane, who ran the bank for a decade. “I’ve watched the Australian banks for a number of years and often wondered why they haven’t done more in Asia,” Mr. Smith said in an interview. ‘‘When a market like Australia becomes mature, you have to look for opportunities elsewhere and I really do feel there is a significant opportunity in Asia.”.

A European Union high court upheld several Anheuser-Busch trademarks and dismissed a challenge from its Czech brewing rival Budvar, the latest ruling in a century of disputes relating to the name “Budweiser.” Budejovicky Budvar asked the court to overturn 12 European Union trademark applications of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, contending they infringe on Budvar’s right under French law to the term Budweiser. The trademarks cover promotional goods including clothing, beer mats, neon signs and glassware. Budvar said it would consider an appeal after studying the verdict, which it said should have little effect on its beer business.

TeliaSonera, the Nordic region’s largest telecommunications operator, pushed its chief executive, Anders Igel, left, from his post, saying it wanted to make room for a more growth-oriented leader. Mr. Igel will leave on July 31 and will be succeeded temporarily by Kim Ignatius, the chief financial officer. The company said the decision was made at a board meeting a day earlier, where members concluded that TeliaSonera was entering a new phase and would benefit from a leader who could raise its “spirit and commercial drive.”.

The Seneca Indian Nation is seeking payment from New York State for a section of the Thruway that runs through the Cattaraugus reservation, tribal officials announced yesterday. The Seneca sent a bill for $2,156,000, calculating charges at the rate of $1 per vehicle and 28,000 vehicles per day back to April 15, when the tribe decided to rescind permission for the roadway. The announcement was the latest in a series of moves by Seneca officials since Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced his intention to collect tax on cigarette and gasoline sales to non-Indian customers on reservations. The Senecas say they are protected from the taxes by treaties. The governor’s office declined to comment yesterday.

A homeless man was sentenced yesterday to 23 years in prison for fatally shooting a bridge painter who asked him to move his belongings from a Grand Central Parkway overpass during a painting job in November 2004, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Boyd, 47, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on May 7, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Boyd admitted that when the painter, James Gaviglia, 38, of Middle Village, asked him to move his makeshift shelter from an overpass in Corona, he shot him repeatedly with a pistol, then lit a cigar and waited for the police, Mr. Brown said.

Ten days after four men were accused of plotting to destroy fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport, state legislators have introduced a bill that would allow the enforcement of more stringent security measures at similar pipelines across the state. The legislation — sponsored by Assemblyman Michael N. Gianaris, a Queens Democrat, and Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Rockville Centre Republican — calls for officials to review security at private pipelines that carry jet fuel and to make recommendations for improvements by the end of 2008. The state could then require companies to enact additional safeguards based on the recommendations. Roy Haase, a spokesman for Buckeye Partners, the Pennsylvania company that operates the tanks at Kennedy, said Buckeye employees “patrol every foot of the pipeline at least once per week.”.

A landscaper died yesterday morning when he fell into a cesspool while cutting a back lawn in Deer Park, the police said. The worker, Sergio Reyes, 34, of Central Islip, was working for a relative’s landscaping company and riding a stand-up lawnmower about noon when the cesspool collapsed, said Detective Sgt. Paul Dodorico of the Suffolk County police. Mr. Reyes and the lawnmower were found in the six-foot-deep cesspool by a co-worker who had been cutting the front lawn, the police said. Sergeant Dodorico said Mr. Reyes’s death appeared to be an accident. An autopsy was scheduled.

A former executive vice president of the nonprofit group 100 Black Men of New Jersey was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 21 months in prison for fraudulently obtaining $156,000 from the organization, federal prosecutors said. The former officer, Keith DaCosta, 44, of Newark, admitted using bank accounts affiliated with the organization for personal use, including hotel stays, meals and a $374 hat, and entering into leases for office equipment with his personal home health care company, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he was open to making the medical use of marijuana legal in New York, reversing a position he took during the campaign. It was unclear, however, whether the Legislature would pass such a bill. “There was a moment during a debate last summer, I think, where I spoke more negatively of it based upon what I understood the medical considerations to be,” the governor said. “I’ve taken a hard look at it over the past number of months, and I’m open to signing a bill if it’s properly structured.” The Democrat-led Assembly is expected to pass a bill before the session ends next week, but it is unclear whether it will be taken up in the Republican-led Senate. “It’s a bill that is under review, but it’s not right now on our radar,” said John McArdle, a spokesman for Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader.

A doctor who works at a clinic in Jamaica has been charged with insurance fraud, accused of billing insurance companies for tests that were never performed on victims of motor vehicle accidents, prosecutors said yesterday. The doctor, Alexander Israeli, 53, of Middle Village, was arraigned in Criminal Court on Monday night on charges of grand larceny and insurance fraud, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that Dr. Israeli billed insurance companies last year for $21,000 worth of neurological tests that were not performed. He faces loss of his medical license and up to seven years in prison if convicted, prosecutors said.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority appeared to have averted a possible summer strike on the Metro-North Railroad with the announcement yesterday of agreement on a new contract with the Teamsters Union, which represents track workers. It was the last of a series of union-authority agreements this year. Representatives of the authority and the union refused to disclose the terms of the agreement, which runs through mid-2010. Chris Silvera, secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 808, predicted that the local’s 600 members would ratify the agreement this month. Mr. Silvera and the authority’s executive director and chief executive, Elliot G. Sander, above, made the announcement at a news conference at Grand Central Terminal. Under federal rules that govern commuter railroads, the Teamsters could have gone on strike in July.

A salesman for a software consulting company has admitted stealing confidential company information and giving it to a competitor, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The salesman, Louis Giuffre, 46, of Lake Grove in Suffolk County, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court on Monday to interstate transportation of stolen property, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Giuffre admitted that while working for the consulting company, Netsoft, last summer, he sent confidential information to a rival company by e-mail, Mr. Garcia said. Prosecutors said the competitor ultimately won a contract that Netsoft had been trying to secure. Mr. Giuffre faces up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced in September, prosecutors said.
The highlight is a 7 percent across-the-board cut in the property tax rate, more than Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed in January.

A map on Monday with an article about fears that tourism in the Niagara Falls area will suffer when tighter border restrictions take effect mislabeled an island in the Niagara River between New York and Ontario. It is Goat Island, not Duck Island.

An article on June 4 about Abdul Kadir and Russell M. Defreitas, two of the four men accused of plotting to blow up Kennedy International Airport, referred imprecisely to Mr. Kadir’s role in the Linden Fund, a charity in Guyana, his home country. As a board member and former mayor of Linden, Guyana’s second-largest city, he used his contacts to help speed up the distribution of money and supplies sent to Guyana by donors in the United States, but he was not “in charge” of receiving and disbursing money and supplies.
Stephen Richards will pay more than $29 million in restitution as part of an accounting fraud at the company.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the shooting death of Rudolph Izzi, a loan shark and reputed mobster, included an erroneous reference in some copies to his place of residence. As noted elsewhere in the article, he lived in Brooklyn, not Staten Island.
A film review in Weekend on Friday about “Surf’s Up” misidentified the animal that ate Cody’s father. It was a killer whale, not a shark.

An obituary on June 5 about Samuel A. Garrison III, the chief Republican counsel to the House Judiciary Committee during the Watergate investigation, misstated the date of the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon. It was Aug. 9, 1974 — not Aug. 8, which was the date he announced that he would resign effective at noon the following day. Also, the obituary referred incorrectly to the three articles of impeachment passed by the Judiciary Committee. Only one article — not all three — charged Mr. Nixon with obstruction of justice. The others charged abuse of power and defiance of committee subpoenas.

An article on Monday about the Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan misstated the difference in length between this year’s parade and the one in 1958, which one paradegoer, Tony Flores, took part in as a Boy Scout from Brooklyn. The 1958 parade was eight blocks shorter, not “at least a dozen.”.

An article yesterday about the high number of arrests at this year’s Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the estimated number of arrests at last year’s parade. The figure of 50 to 60 arrests last year was taken from an article that ran in The Times in 2006; the estimate did not come from the New York police in the course of reporting yesterday’s article. (The 2006 article cited “at least 50” arrests, but the Police Department disputes that figure, saying 151 people were arrested.) An article about the reaction to this year’s arrests appears today on Page B3.

An art review in Weekend on Friday about group shows at New York galleries referred incorrectly to a show at CRG in Chelsea that includes the work of Colby Bird, who has a sculpture in one of the group shows reviewed, “In Defense of Ardor,” at Bellwether in Chelsea. The show at CRG is a two-man show of work by Mr. Bird and Joshua Fields, not a solo show by Mr. Bird.
Details of the complaints by police against the people arrested at the Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday outline a pattern in the way they were arrested, according to documents released yesterday.
Soccer.

With most of the 1.3 billion people in China sharing just 100 surnames, the Public Security Ministry is considering rules that would combine both parents’ family names to prevent so much duplication, state news outlets said. So few names by so many often sows confusion and must presumably hamper police work. “By adopting both parents’ names, 1.28 million new surnames will be added,” the Xinhua News Agency said.

Air and water quality in Chinese cities is worsening, according to a report of the Environmental Protection Administration. According to the agency’s latest survey, just 38 percent of 585 cities monitored enjoyed air quality that reached minimal national standards, down from 45 percent in a 2005 survey.

Poachers have shot the last two white rhinos in Zambia, killing the female and wounding the male, in a night operation at the heavily guarded Mosi-Oa-Tunya National Park near Victoria Falls, a spokeswoman for the Zambia Wildlife Authority said. The dead rhino’s horn was apparently removed.

Iran’s judiciary will complete its investigation of four Americans “within the next two or three days” and will then decide whether to free them or indict them on charges of acting against national security, said the judicial spokesman, Alireza Jamshidi. Several weeks ago, he said they had been charged with espionage, but he did not repeat that yesterday. At the same time, the foreign minister, Manouchehr Mottaki, warned that the United States would “regret” its seizure in January of five Iranian officials by American forces in northern Iraq whom the United States accuses of arming and financing militants. Three of the Americans, who all hold dual Iranian citizenship, are being held in Evin Prison in Tehran: Haleh Esfandiari, a Washington scholar; Kian Tajbakhsh, a New York social scientist; and Ali Shakeri, a California businessman. The fourth American, Parnaz Azima, a radio journalist, is free on bail but barred from leaving the country.

The Green Party has moved closer to a coalition accord with Fianna Fail, the party of Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, left, after the parties reached agreement on climate change, education and political reform, the Green Party negotiator, Dan Boyle, said in comments on RTE radio in Dublin. Negotiations between the parties resumed yesterday after talks collapsed on June 8. Mr. Ahern, in power since 1997, turned to the Greens after his party failed to win enough seats in the May 24 election to allow it to govern alone. Ireland’s new Parliament will meet tomorrow, with lawmakers selecting a speaker and prime minister.

TRENTON, JUNE 12 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine and the Democratic leaders of the Assembly and Senate said Tuesday afternoon that they had reached “broad agreement on the framework” for a new state budget and expected its official adoption well before the statutory June 30 deadline.
Shameka Christon scored 16 points to lead the Liberty to a 79-69 over the Washington Mystics Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.
A Queens jury, forced to render a stark judgment on a videotaped confession, yesterday found a day care worker guilty of raping and sexually abusing a 4-year-old boy in her care.
The Wall Street Journal announced a major newsroom shake-up, including the reassignment and replacement of several top editors.
A case of two Coast Guard cutters shows that earmarks to faith-based groups may not achieve their stated purpose.

ALBANY, June 12 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer expressed optimism on Tuesday about the chances of getting federal funds to carry out Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion-pricing plan, even as lawmakers continued to question its wisdom. The lawmakers also said it was unlikely to come up for a vote before the end of the regular legislative session next week.
Hundreds of people attended a memorial service for Mr. Halberstam at Riverside Church in Manhattan.
The second-quarter report, a record for the firm, potentially augurs a good week for Wall Street earnings reports.
Gary M. Rodkin is introducing updated twists on the company’s old portfolio to find new ways to please fickle consumers.
Commerce Bancorp will end contracts with companies owned by executives and their relatives, halting a practice that has drawn the attention of regulators.
The European Union is planning a public-private partnership to help its aviation industry develop greener and quieter aircraft.
The backlash against the wealth being created by managers of hedge funds and private equity funds may be gaining strength.
The cost of borrowing headed higher as yields on the 10-year Treasury note hit a five-year high, climbing to 5.248 percent.
Maurice R. Greenberg said testimony from three A.I.G. employees would discredit recent accusations by the State of New York.

A judge dropped all criminal charges against former Mayor Ron Gonzales of San Jose, who was accused of bribery in an alleged back-room deal with a trash-hauling company, court officials said. While the judge, John Herlihy of Santa Clara County Superior Court, said Mr. Gonzales and an aide, Joe Guerra, improperly concealed their dealings with the company, Norcal Waste Systems Inc., improper instructions given to the grand jury that indicted the pair required him to throw out the charges. “The court concludes that given the complexity of this case, the instructional errors, in their totality, undermined the grand jury’s determination of probable cause on all the charged counts,” Judge Herlihy wrote in his ruling. Mr. Gonzales, who was forced out of office last fall because of term limits, faced up to eight years in prison if convicted.

A prisoner serving 40 years for raping a 12-year-old girl in 1993 got his wish, but it was not what he intended. The prisoner, Culberson Henry, applied for a retesting of the evidence under a 2001 law allowing inmates claiming wrongful conviction to petition for DNA review. The request was granted last year and the results confirmed his guilt, reported Craig Watkins, district attorney of Dallas County, where 13 prisoners were recently exonerated after DNA testing. “Equally important,” Mr. Watkins said, it works the other way, too.

Carmine Carini had a decision to make. He was 47 years old. Nearly half that time he had spent in prison for the murder of a Brooklyn record shop owner, a man shot three times to the head and dumped from a car in the watermark style of a Mafia execution.
Turning products into integral elements of shows is new to contemporary advertisers, but it was actually a mainstay of marketing from the ’30s through the ’60s.
Don Herbert unlocked the wonders of science for youngsters of the 1950s and ’60s as television’s Mr. Wizard.

Pennsylvania will pay for security at the Flight 93 crash site to end a dispute over a donation box at the memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, the governor said. Michael Svonavec, who owns the land, said he installed the box to cover security costs at the site near Shanksville. But the box angered victims’ families, and the National Park Service covered it with a plastic bag. The governor, Edward G. Rendell, announced a $120,000 grant to pay for security for two years, saying the families should not have to raise the money themselves. “It also eliminates any need for donation boxes, which transformed this hallowed ground into something less dignified,” Mr. Rendell said.

More than 165 workers were detained to be processed for possible deportation after federal agents raided the Fresh Del Monte Produce food-processing plant and two offices of a staffing company in Portland. Three people were indicted on immigration, illegal documents and identity theft charges. An official at Fresh Del Monte Produce Company headquarters in Coral Gables, Fla., said the company could not comment until federal investigators provided it with more information. Mayor Tom Potter of Portland criticized the raids. The three arrests were understandable, Mr. Potter said, but “to go after local workers who are here to support their families while filling the demands of local businesses for their labor is bad policy.”.
A whale caught off the Alaskan coast had a weapon fragment embedded in its neck that showed it had survived a similar hunt — more than a century ago.
You have to tip your hat, literally, to the man who has robbed 17 banks in northern New Jersey since last fall.
With a black wrap covering his injured left wrist, Phil Mickelson played nine holes at Oakmont Country Club on Tuesday with diminished expectations.
Appeals by Malta and Sweden for help in sharing the burden of thousands of African and Iraqi refugees were rebuffed by other members of the E.U.
The medical school will use the money for research into and treatment of obesity, diabetes, cancer and the diseases of aging, especially Alzheimer’s.
“You Make Me Feel So Young” might seem a peculiar choice to open a memorial, but if the person being remembered is Kitty Carlisle Hart, it makes sense.

A new hiring site and an unrelated settlement herald what could be a big change in the way Mamaroneck deals with Hispanic day laborers who usually seek work from contractors at local streets and parks.

Of all the distinctive wrinkles of Oakmont, the home of this week’s U.S. Open, the club’s Church Pews bunker between the third and fourth holes have come to represent the course’s toughness, charm and eclectic soul.
New Century Financial fired its chief executive and an executive vice president and named its chief restructuring officer to the post of chief executive.
Conrad M. Black and three former Hollinger executives rested their defense on federal fraud charges without taking the stand.
American-led forces killed seven Afghan policemen and wounded five more in what Afghan police officials said was a case of mistaken identity.
A federal advisory panel has recommended that former workers at a nuclear weapons plant be denied immediate government compensation.
In every grade tested, the city had jumps, often in double digits, in the proportion of students scoring at grade level.
The former prime minister had earlier called for Prime Minister Ehud Olmert to resign over last summer’s inconclusive war against Hezbollah in Lebanon.
Naval investigators testified at a military hearing that  insurgent attacks complicated their inquiry into the killing of 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in 2005.
The Yankees have told Roger Clemens he can come and go as he pleases on the days he does not start, but Clemens was at Yankee Stadium Tuesday.
Warren Cromartie, a former Montreal Expos outfielder who became a fan favorite in Japan, will step into the ring Sunday in a pro wrestling event called Hustle Aid.
Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, has attracted national attention for his positions on illegal immigration.
While Cleveland Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown’s basketball résumé may be as short on playoff seasons (two) as that of his star, LeBron James, Brown does have experience in unfamiliar situations.
Two months after sexual assault charges against three former Duke University lacrosse players were dismissed, the prosecutor who brought the case is facing charges.
Ford said it was working with financial advisers to sort out the future of the two British brands.
State courts in Missouri and New York split on whether worker lawsuits claiming unpaid wages should be granted class-action status.
Morgan Stanley will pay $4.4 million to settle a class-action lawsuit with brokerage clients who bought precious metals and paid storage fees.
Google and Intel are leading a consortium of companies in an effort to reduce the amount of power wasted by personal computers.
The deputy secretary of state urged the Shiite-led government to complete political reforms intended to reconcile Iraq’s warring sects.
A soldier who served in Iraq and two other Texas National Guardsmen remained in jail as authorities expanded an investigation into human smuggling.
That so many Senate Republicans supported an attorney general that they cannot bring themselves to defend shows that politics is behind the insistence that he stay.
Roy L. Pearson Jr. sued his dry cleaner for $67.3 million over lost pants in a case that has been lampooned as an example of American legal excess.
Trinidad Coach Wim Rijsbergen has a team that includes only one player who went to Germany while 16 players have been barred from participating by the country’s soccer federation.
The Pentagon’s system for allowing citizens living abroad to vote is plagued with security and privacy problems.
Cancer experts have identified a set of health problems that may be symptoms of ovarian cancer, and they are urging women who have them to see their doctors.
As the Senate began debate on an energy bill, top Democrats were proposing to provide $10 billion in loans for plants that make diesel fuel from coal.
Hamas and Fatah sharply escalated their fight for supremacy in what is starting to look like a civil war.

If there is a billion-dollar gamble underlying Apple’s iPhone, it lies in what this smart cellphone does not have: a mechanical keyboard.
Among the priorities of Rudolph W. Giuliani were achieving energy independence and, in a new theme for him, overhauling the education system.
No longer in charge of writing spending bills since they lost their majority, House Republicans are unleashing indignation at pet projects.
Just three months before progress reports are due, Iraq’s leaders have failed to agree on nearly every key law.
Officials trying to stop a man with tuberculosis got little help from his father and his future father-in-law, a tuberculosis expert, according to e-mail messages.
Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular driver in Nascar, will announce Wednesday morning what team he will race for beginning in 2008.
Mitt Romney’s effort has been credited with helping vault him to the lead in some polls in Iowa and New Hampshire.
Astronauts and mission managers scrambled on Tuesday when a fire alarm went off on the Russian part of the International Space Station.
There is good reason to hope that Adm. Michael Mullen, nominated to take charge as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in September, will do a better job than his predecessor.

The discovery of vast numbers of migrating animals in Darfur is important because it creates the possibility of ecotourism, and a source of employment and wealth to help balance the oil rush in the region.
With the United Nations headquarters scheduled for renovations, governments make plans of their own.
Privacy is too important to leave up to the companies that benefit financially from collecting and retaining data.
The Knicks, who have not won an N.B.A. title in three decades, will open their preseason schedule Oct. 11 against Maccabi Tel Aviv, a club that has won 47 Israeli championships.
Recep Tayyip Erdogan took a strong public stance against his own country’s military incursion into northern Iraq to fight Kurdish rebels.
The Blackstone Group’s much-awaited initial public offering is set for the week of June 25, underwriters said.
A series of television commercials promoting the borough of 1.3 million will be on the airwaves starting June 25.
President Bush tried to assure Republicans that border security was a force behind his push for immigration change.
Tony Blair used one of his last speeches before he leaves office to settle scores with a press corps he holds responsible for hounding him.
Judges in The Hague found Milan Martic, who led a Serbian separatist rebellion in  Croatia in the early 1990s, guilty of multiple crimes.
South Africa’s public-service unions, leading a nationwide strike, accuse President Thabo Mbeki of betraying the nation’s vast lower class.
An experimental public high school that has had success in sending low-income students to college will go under the control of the University of Dayton.
The list of universities and colleges putting up green buildings, buying alternative energy and otherwise shelling out money to green their campuses gets longer every day.
A scenic Swedish town of 60,000 people last year took in twice as many Iraqi refugees as the entire United States, almost all of them Christians.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged nearly 130 points, as investors grappled with a seemingly relentless rise in bond yields.
A federal appeals court has rejected a new, intermediate category proposed by the Bush administration: “unlawful enemy combatant.”
Jamaican police said Bob Woolmer, the coach of the Pakistani team, was not murdered, as they had announced, but instead died of natural causes.
Five children died Tuesday in a fire after their mothers left them in the home overnight with a teenage baby sitter who has not been found.
Sudan set conditions for the deployment, insisting that a majority of the soldiers be African, which may hamper efforts to raise the force to full strength.
The heartening results last month on the annual reading tests in New York State and New York City, and the results on the math tests announced Tuesday, should be taken in perspective.

About a third of stockholders voted against the re-election of one or more company directors, heeding the advice of advisory firms.
The plan circulated by top Democrats would provide $10 billion in loans for plants that make diesel fuel from coal.

The United States added four Arab allies — Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman and Qatar — to its list of countries with the worst records of preventing people from being sold into the sex trade and servitude. In its annual report on human trafficking, the State Department also added Algeria, Equatorial Guinea and Malaysia to the list of countries with the lowest ranking. The others are Cuba, Iran, Myanmar, North Korea, Saudi Arabia, Sudan, Syria, Uzbekistan and Venezuela. Countries have 90 days to improve their records or face sanctions, including loss of American aid and support for loans from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. The administration can also choose not to impose sanctions.

ROBIN--Wilma. Wilma was the daughter of Edwin J Robin (architect) and Isabel Abeles Robin (weaver and fabric designer). She was the sister of Rosemary Robin Kaplan and sister-in-law of Seymour Kaplan, aunt of Sara, Daniel and Matthew. Greataunt of Jacob, Robin, Amy and Jesse. Wilma was a graduate of the State University of Iowa at Iowa City and did graduate work at New York University. She was an award winning book designer at Doubleday Dell and Delacorte. She loved books and was a great reader, making good use of the Hammond Public Library after moving. There will be a memorial service at the convenience of the family. Owens Funeral Home, Calumet Ave. and 119th St., Whiting, IN, in charge of services. Online condolences may be made thru owensfuneralhome.com

THE best way to understand this fortress town, on the Atlantic coast about 30 miles south of Tangier, is to let your eyes and your nose lead you through the narrow streets where only foot traffic is allowed. While visiting here for a few days, I sniffed my way through the warrens of the medina, built in the 14th century by Portuguese and inhabited later by Muslims and Jews fleeing the Spanish Inquisition. Today the town's population is international, with people from Spain and France buying quaint apartments as second homes. Morocco, at the end of the spice route in Africa, developed a fine cuisine known for its pungent spice combinations. In Assilah, as in much of the country, people eat seasonally, shop at the outdoor markets, buy live chickens to have slaughtered on the spot, feathers flying helter-skelter. (In the big cities, where health inspectors and supermarkets are taking over, this is a dying custom.) At one market I saw eggs gathered the same morning, carefully protected by strands of hay; lemons preserved in salted water; black and green olives from nearby orchards.

A former executive vice president of the nonprofit group 100 Black Men of New Jersey was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 21 months in prison for fraudulently obtaining $156,000 from the organization, federal prosecutors said. The former officer, Keith DaCosta, 44, of Newark, admitted using bank accounts affiliated with the organization for personal use, including hotel stays, meals and a $374 hat, and entering into leases for office equipment with his personal home health care company, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney.

KIM--Jung Ju, Ph.D, AIA. J.J. Kim, a devoted husband, father, and grandfather died peacefully Monday, June 11, 2007 in New York, NY, after a long battle with diabetes. He was 70. Dr. Kim, South Korea's first Ph.D. in architecture, came to the U.S. in 1956 to attend Pfeiffer College and then North Carolina State University. It was there that he met his wife of 44 years, Dr. Jin Young Choi, a Fulbright Scholar and professor of English literature. After earning his undergraduate degree at North Carolina State, he went on to earn a Masters of Science in Architecture from Columbia University and a doctorate in architecture at the University of Michigan. While in the U.S. his three children Caroline, Sharon and Eric were all born. After 19 years in the U.S. he returned to South Korea in 1975 as a faculty member of Chung Ang University and to found KCK, a private architectural firm. He joined Kukje International as a Senior Executive Vice President in 1978, where he pioneered South Korea's construction and real estate development in the Middle East and Asia. In 1987, he became President of Doo Yang Corporation. In 2003, he and his wife returned the U.S. to live in New York City with his children and grandchildren Cameron, Kai and Charlotte. A lover of art, design, music and Michigan football, he will be greatly missed. Services to be held at Central Funeral Home, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the American Diabetes Association or The Nature Conservancy are requested.
