Former partner in the law firm of Shea & Gould; Of Counsel to Dornbush Schaeffer Strongin & Venaglia. Memorial services to be arranged.

To the Editor: Re ''The Expanding Meatball Universe'' (June 6): Your article failed to mention the meatballs at Carmine's. It was this dish that ruined my two-year stint as a vegetarian. And what a way to go. I think there are at least seven different animals in those things.

An art review in Weekend on Friday about group shows at New York galleries referred incorrectly to a show at CRG in Chelsea that includes the work of Colby Bird, who has a sculpture in one of the group shows reviewed, ''In Defense of Ardor,'' at Bellwether in Chelsea. The show at CRG is a two-man show of work by Mr. Bird and Joshua Fields, not a solo show by Mr. Bird.

FOR someone who works in a restaurant, watching a rat try to become a chef might seem like just another day at work. For movie audiences, a rat with culinary aspirations might be more appealing. Especially if it's a rat that the chef Thomas Keller helped teach to cook.

To the Editor: ''The Price of Free Airwaves,'' by Michael J. Copps, a Federal Communications commissioner (Op-Ed, June 2), criticizing broadcasters' public service and election coverage, did a disservice to local radio and television stations. Broadcasters go to enormous lengths to fulfill our role as a lifeline during times of crisis. When a child is kidnapped, local stations make the difference between life and death by broadcasting Amber alerts, an initiative launched voluntarily by broadcasters that has resulted in the recovery of more than 250 children nationwide.

Google and Intel are leading a consortium of major technology companies in an effort to sharply reduce the amount of power wasted by personal computers and servers. In a separate development, Intel is expected to cut prices on some of its higher-end processors in July to make room for new power-saving chip technology expected in the second half of the year.
DRAZNIN--Irving, 94, Holocaust survivor, survived by children and grandchildren, Esther and Warren Feldman, Arthur and Sharon Draznin, Bari, Andrew, Haley, Ross, Annie, Marla, and Michelle.

GRUMAN--Beatrice. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Beatrice Gruman, beloved mother of Stuart Gruman, whose leadership as a member of the Electrical Division executive committee has strengthened our ability to serve those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

To the Editor: Re ''Judges Say U.S. Can't Hold Man as 'Combatant' '' (front page, June 12): The Justice Department's response to the ruling that Ali al-Marri must have his day in court has been to recount the allegations against Mr. Marri. If the evidence against him is so strong, why does the Justice Department seek to avoid the scrutiny of a trial? If the evidence is not so strong, it is all the more important that the evidence be tested in court.

LeBron James drove desperately to the basket with just under 15 seconds remaining and his Cleveland Cavaliers trailing by a basket. Running into San Antonio's best two defenders, Bruce Bowen and Tim Duncan -- the savvy veterans who have confronted him at every turn in these N.B.A. finals -- James spun to pass the ball to Anderson Varejao. Fans in Quicken Loans Arena let out a groan, as if their city's long history of sports suffering had led them to this inescapable moment of defeat. Wasn't James supposed to be over his unselfish passing phase at the end of games?

A group of local witches gathered late last month in La Plaza Cultural, a small garden at Ninth Street and Avenue C, to mark a relatively rare lunar event: the second full moon in the same month, sometimes known as a blue moon. The celebration featured readings and meditation as the witches formed a circle around candles.

An article on Monday about the Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan misstated the difference in length between this year's parade and the one in 1958, which one paradegoer, Tony Flores, took part in as a Boy Scout from Brooklyn. The 1958 parade was eight blocks shorter, not ''at least a dozen.''

DAVID--Stuart, 66, died Monday, June 11, in New York City after battling cancer for a year and a half with great attitude and style. Cherished and cherishing husband of Denise Demong, father of Francesca and Michael, and brother of Meryl Heaney and Lisa Nedell. He was beloved by many more as friend, nephew, cousin and uncle. Services Thursday, 11:30 am, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Palestinian Rivals Escalate Fighting Toward Civil War Gunmen of the rival Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah sharply escalated their fight for supremacy, with Hamas taking over much of the northern Gaza Strip in what began to look increasingly like a civil war. A1 U.S. Benchmarks for Iraq Unmet Iraq's leaders have failed to agree on nearly every law that the Americans have demanded as benchmarks, despite heavy pressure, the White House and top military commanders said. Many Iraqi and American officials now question whether any substantive laws will pass before the end of the year. A1 Cricket Coach Was Not Killed The coach of the Pakistani cricket team, who was found unconscious in his hotel room in Jamaica in March after his team was ousted from the Cricket World Cup, was not murdered as the police had previously thought but had died of unspecified natural causes, the police said. A12 Sudan to Allow Joint Peace Force After resisting for months, Sudan has agreed to a joint United Nations and African Union force of nearly 20,000 peacekeepers in Darfur, its western province and the site of one of the world's worst humanitarian crises, the African Union said. A3 Accidental U.S.-Afghan Clash American-led forces killed seven Afghan policemen and wounded five more in an exchange of fire that Afghan police officials said was a result of mistaken identity. A6 Europe Plans for Refugees Appeals by Malta and Sweden for help in sharing the burden of thousands of African and Iraqi refugees streaming into the European Union were rebuffed as the European Union's interior ministers clashed over how to solve the problem. A4 NATIONAL A13-19 Early Symptoms Found To Identify Ovarian Cancer Experts have identified a set of health problems that may be symptoms of ovarian cancer, and they are urging women who have the symptoms for more than a few weeks to see their doctors. The advice is the first official recognition that the disease does cause symptoms at earlier stages in many women. A1 Overseas Voting Problems Over the last six years, the Defense Department has spent more than $30 million trying to find an efficient way for American soldiers and civilians living abroad to vote in elections back home. But the Pentagon's Web-based system remains slow, confusing and plagued with security and privacy problems. A19 Panel Denies Ill Workers A federal advisory panel recommended that workers at a former nuclear weapons plant be denied immediate government compensation for illnesses the workers say they suffer as a result of years of radiation exposure at the plant. A13 Pittsburgh Fire Kills Five Five young children from two families died in an early morning fire in Pittsburgh after their mothers left them in the home overnight with a teenage baby sitter who has not been found, the police said. A15 Bush Lobbies Republicans Trying to revive a crippled immigration bill, President Bush visited the Capitol to try to assure wary Senate Republicans that border security was a driving force behind the immigration law. A16 Ohio School Wins Reprieve An experimental public high school in Dayton that has had success in sending low-income students to college will become a charter school under the control of the University of Dayton, the school district said. A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 City Spurs Big Jump On State Math Scores Math scores for students across New York State improved significantly in every grade this year, powered by sizable gains in New York City, according to results of the annual state math exam released by state officials. A1 A Lightning Rod on Immigration Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, injects himself into the issue of illegal immigration often and aggressively, and has been called ''arguably the most formidable elected official in Long Island history.'' A1 Budget Deal Offers Tax Break New York City taxpayers would get a larger-than-expected break on their property taxes under a $59 billion budget deal that city leaders announced. The pact, which comes weeks earlier than usual, would also use a record $4.4 billion surplus to eliminate taxes on clothing and shoes and increase library service to six days a week. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 The Cost of Borrowing Rises The cost of borrowing headed higher and drove the stock market down sharply. Yields on the 10-year Treasury note hit a five-year high, climbing to 5.248 percent as investors sold off notes and bonds. C1 Business Digest C2 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-7 Spurs Close in on Championship The San Antonio Spurs seized a 75-72 victory in the most ragged game yet of the N.B.A. finals. Holding a 3-0 lead, the Spurs are a victory away from clinching their fourth N.B.A. title in nine years. D1 OBITUARIES B9 Don Herbert Television's Mr. Wizard, who unlocked the wonders of science for youngsters of the 1950s and '60s, he was 89. B9 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: Silence in the Senate; good choice for the chiefs; watching your every move; a different Sudan. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman and Maureen Dowd. Crossword E2 TV Listings E11 Weather D8

To the Editor: Re ''One Last Family Gathering: You Eat, You Talk, It's Over,'' by Alessandra Stanley (The TV Watch, front page, June 11): I'm not mad at David Chase, creator of ''The Sopranos,'' for leaving Tony in a diner at the end, alive, and eating onion rings with Carmela and the kids (let's believe that Meadow makes it to her seat).
GRACE--Sylvia Myerson. She was a force of nature who impacted all who knew her. Her philosophy was ''It will all work out'', and my dear mother, it all did. Michelle

A doctor who works at a clinic in Jamaica has been charged with insurance fraud, accused of billing insurance companies for tests that were never performed on victims of motor vehicle accidents, prosecutors said yesterday. The doctor, Alexander Israeli, 53, of Middle Village, was arraigned in Criminal Court on Monday night on charges of grand larceny and insurance fraud, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that Dr. Israeli billed insurance companies last year for $21,000 worth of neurological tests that were not performed. He faces loss of his medical license and up to seven years in prison if convicted, prosecutors said.

A map on Monday with an article about fears that tourism in the Niagara Falls area will suffer when tighter border restrictions take effect mislabeled an island in the Niagara River between New York and Ontario. It is Goat Island, not Duck Island.

SAMUELS--Frances (Cohn), of Lido Beach, NY. Beloved wife of the late Sam, cherished mother of Mark I. and Ronald. Services 10 A.M., today, at Guttermans, Rockville Centre. Burial at Mt. Aararat Cemetery. Shiva at the family home through Tuesday, June 19.

Jazz at Lincoln Center will have a new executive director as of Oct. 1, the company announced on Monday. Adrian Ellis, president of AEA Consulting, will replace Katherine Brown, who is resigning after a decade with the organization. Mr. Ellis will be primarily responsible for operational and financial matters. Wynton Marsalis is the company's artistic director. At AEA, a management consulting company with offices in New York and London, Mr. Ellis has served clients like the National Gallery in London, San Francisco Opera, the Royal Shakespeare Company, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and the Frick Collection. In April 2006, Derek E. Gordon stepped down as president and chief executive of Jazz at Lincoln Center after a little more than a year in the job. ROBIN POGREBIN

Trinidad and Tobago went to Germany last summer as the smallest nation, in terms of population, at the World Cup. This year, the Soca Warriors came to the United States for the Concacaf Gold Cup with a prodigious headache. Coach Wim Rijsbergen has a team that includes only one player who went to Germany -- Densill Theobald -- after 16 players were barred from participating by the country's soccer federation. The problem is money.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he was open to making the medical use of marijuana legal in New York, reversing a position he took during the campaign. It was unclear, however, whether the Legislature would pass such a bill. ''There was a moment during a debate last summer, I think, where I spoke more negatively of it based upon what I understood the medical considerations to be,'' the governor said. ''I've taken a hard look at it over the past number of months, and I'm open to signing a bill if it's properly structured.'' The Democrat-led Assembly is expected to pass a bill before the session ends next week, but it is unclear whether it will be taken up in the Republican-led Senate. ''It's a bill that is under review, but it's not right now on our radar,'' said John McArdle, a spokesman for Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader. DANNY HAKIM

With a black wrap covering his injured left wrist, Phil Mickelson played nine holes at Oakmont Country Club on Tuesday with diminished expectations. He often flexed his hand. He hit no shots out of Oakmont's dense rough. He said that if a smaller tournament were beginning Thursday, and not the United States Open, he would most likely skip the event.

WOLF--Norton. On June 11, 2007, beloved husband of Joan, devoted father of Anne Price and James Wolf, and stepfather of David Lipton. Cherished grandfather of Nicholas Lipton and Michael Lipton. He was a noted advertising executive for 50 years in the metropolitan area. Funeral private.

Ten days after four men were accused of plotting to destroy fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport, state legislators have introduced a bill that would allow the enforcement of more stringent security measures at similar pipelines across the state. The legislation -- sponsored by Assemblyman Michael N. Gianaris, a Queens Democrat, and Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Rockville Centre Republican -- calls for officials to review security at private pipelines that carry jet fuel and to make recommendations for improvements by the end of 2008. The state could then require companies to enact additional safeguards based on the recommendations. Roy Haase, a spokesman for Buckeye Partners, the Pennsylvania company that operates the tanks at Kennedy, said Buckeye employees ''patrol every foot of the pipeline at least once per week.'' MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM

FRIEDMAN--Norma. Cherished wife of Morris, beloved mother of Ruth and Philip, died peacefully at home on June 10th after a long bout with Alzheimer's. She was a fashion writer who spent a decade at Vogue and Harper's Bazaar. Dedicated to community service, she volunteered for many years at the Helen Keller National Center in Port Washington and helped low-income students gain scholarships to college. Norma was known by all for her extraordinary warmth and compassion. In addition to her immediate family, she is survived by her adored neice and family, Lorna, Dale, Zachary and Seth, and by the many friends who loved her. A service will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, June 13th, after which the family will welcome visitors at home. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, her memory will be honored by donations to the Alzheimer's Foundation and the Helen Keller National Center. Norma was smart, witty, loving and beautiful. We miss her terribly.

Freshly picked, locally grown lettuces are treasures that are here for the summer. They deliver flavor and texture that most salad greens, having been shipped across the country, barely suggest. Even iceberg lettuce is worthy of the salad bowl when it is harvested from nearby farms. Yuno's Farm in Bordentown, N.J., brings young lettuces, barely forming heads, into several Greenmarkets all season. You will find red romaine, green romaine and frisée (top); green leaf (center); and French iceberg (bottom) that is crisp and sweet. The lettuces are $8 a pound (about four small heads) at Union Square on Mondays and Fridays, Dag Hammarskjold Plaza on Wednesdays and Abingdon Square on Saturdays.

WEBER--Jack. NCJW NY Section mourns the passing of Jack Weber, husband of Naomi Weber, our esteemed Board Member. Sincerest condolences to the family. Beatrice Kahn, Co-Pres. Beth Mitchell, Co-Pres. Judith R. Golub, Exec. Dir.

A listing of results on Monday from the Prefontaine Classic track-and-field meet in Eugene, Ore., reversed the top two finishers in the men's high jump. Tora Harris was first and Jesse Williams second.

Air and water quality in Chinese cities is worsening, according to a report of the Environmental Protection Administration. According to the agency's latest survey, just 38 percent of 585 cities monitored enjoyed air quality that reached minimal national standards, down from 45 percent in a 2005 survey. HOWARD W. FRENCH

The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote Thursday on whether to authorize subpoenas to gain access to Justice Department documents related to the National Security Agency's domestic wiretapping program, including a series of secret legal opinions. The vote comes a week after Democratic leaders on a House Judiciary subcommittee threatened to issue subpoenas for the same documents.

CBS Chairman Rebukes Dan Rather Dan Rather was branded as a ''sexist'' yesterday by Leslie Moonves, the chairman of CBS, for comments critical of Katie Couric, his successor as the anchor of ''CBS Evening News.'' The uproar began on Monday when Mr. Rather, speaking on MSNBC by telephone, said CBS had erred in handling the evening news broadcast by ''dumbing it down, tarting it up'' and emphasizing celebrities over war coverage in ''hopes of attracting a younger audience,'' The Associated Press reported. Although he referred to Ms. Couric as a ''nice person,'' he said ''the mistake was to try to bring the 'Today' show ethos to the 'Evening News.' '' Ms. Couric, in nine months as the first woman to anchor a network news broadcast on her own, has been unable to lift ''CBS Evening News'' out of last place among the evening news programs. ''Let's give her a break,'' Mr. Moonves said at an appearance in New York where he was asked about Mr. Rather's remarks and called them ''sexist.'' He said he ''absolutely'' had confidence in Ms. Couric and the course of CBS's evening news and added that it was imperative to reach younger audiences. Unless news programs find viewers younger than 60, he said, ''the evening news will die.'' Secret Clapton Concert In the Works Eric Clapton is to be paid $1.5 million to perform in late July at a private concert organized by a hedge-fund executive at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, Conn., according to an article to be published today by The Fairfield County Weekly. The account says that under terms of the agreement between the Creative Artists Agency, a promoter and the executive, ''no public press or announcement pre or post event is permitted.'' The agreement says the performance, to benefit the China Care Foundation, is expected to be attended by ''350 invitation-only guests.'' The host was identified as Raymond T. Dalio, the founder, president and chief investment officer of Bridgewater Associates, which has more than $30 billion in hedge-fund assets. Besides Mr. Clapton's fee for a 60- to 70-minute show, the agreement calls for a $1 million donation to ''a charity of Mr. Clapton's choice to be paid the night of the show.'' The weekly reports that neither Mr. Dalio nor agents at Creative Artists Agency responded to calls for comment. Nigerian Author Wins Major Award Chinua Achebe, below, of Nigeria, the Charles P. Stevenson Jr. Professor of Languages and Literature at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., was named the winner yesterday of the $118,500 (£60,000) Man Booker International Prize. The honor is awarded once every two years to a living author for a body of work that has contributed to international fiction. Nadine Gordimer, one of three members of the judging panel that chose Mr. Achebe, said his ''early work made him the father of modern African literature as an integral part of world literature.'' She added, ''He has gone on to achieve what one of his characters brilliantly defines as the writer's purpose: 'a new-found utterance' for the capture of life's complexity.'' Best known for his novels ''Things Fall Apart'' (1958) and ''Anthills of the Savannah'' (1988), Mr. Achebe, 76, will receive his prize and a trophy at a ceremony on June 28 at Christ Church in Oxford, England. Disney Goes Bollywood Walt Disney Studios and the Indian company Yash Raj Films entered an agreement yesterday in Mumbai to make animated films using the voices of Bollywood stars, Agence France-Presse reported. In a statement, the companies said the stars Saif Ali Khan and Kareena Kapoor would provide the voices for the first one, ''Roadside Romeo,'' a fully animated Hindi-language movie including song, dance and action sequences and scheduled for release next year. Ancient Temple Saved From Modern Builders The Italian police have saved an ancient Greek temple from burial beneath the foundations of a resort hotel under construction, The Associated Press reported; the building crew had dumped or looted artifacts and was beginning to pour concrete over the ruins. Members of the art squad of the Carabinieri paramilitary police said more than 50 artifacts, including columns and mosaics, had been excavated from the site, above, near Crotone in southern Calabria, to decorate a nearby hotel complex. Other pieces had been put in a dump to be reused as construction material. Gen. Giovanni Nistri, commander of the art squad, said further construction ''would have been the final tombstone for this temple.'' Farm Aid Comes To New York New York City will have a rural touch when Randalls Island becomes the site of a Farm Aid concert to benefit family farms, Reuters reported. Willie Nelson announced on Monday that ''Farm Aid 2007: A Homegrown Festival'' will take place on the island in the East River on Sept. 9. ''Farm Aid is coming to New York because your enthusiasm for family-farm food is keeping family farms on the land,'' said Mr. Nelson, who will perform with Farm Aid board members Dave Matthews, John Mellencamp and Neil Young. Since it was organized in 1985 Farm Aid has raised more than $30 million. The Randalls Island concert will be the first Farm Aid concert in New York. Footnotes The August Wilson play ''Radio Golf'' will close on July 1 after 64 performances and 17 previews at the Cort Theater on Broadway. The Paris Review yesterday announced the appointment of Matt Weiland as deputy editor, a new position. The announcement said the appointment reflected the magazine's growth under the editorship of Philip Gourevitch, who assumed the post in 2005. Mr. Weiland has been the deputy editor of Granta for four years.

Oko, a new frozen yogurt shop in Park Slope, Brooklyn, dispenses only two flavors for now, tangy plain and wild berry, but offers an array of toppings that include fresh raspberries, blackberries, strawberries, diced mango and pineapple, several kinds of nuts and chocolate bits. Cups are $3, $3.75 and $5. Assorted teas, hot and iced, including a lip-smacking ginger with Asian pear, are $3 to $4 for 16 ounces.

NEWMAN--Debra S. My dear Debra, Happy Birthday. Love and Hugs, Aunt Sharon $(6$)NEWMAN--Debra Sheryl, June 13, 1980 -October 1, 2002. Happy Birthday. Your spirit and zest for life are in our hearts forever. Love, Mom and Dad

GIFTS FOR FAITH-BASED GROUPS -- Over the past 20 years Congress has given almost 900 grants to faith-based groups through the use of provisions called earmarks, including two decommissioned Coast Guard cutters that were given to a mission group in California. But rather than use the vessels to provide medical care, as Congress had directed, the group sold them both. [Page A1.] YIELDS RISE, DRIVING SHARES DOWN -- The cost of borrowing headed higher as yields on the 10-year Treasury note, a key benchmark, hit a five-year high, and that drove the stock market down sharply. [C1.] NEW SERVINGS AT CONAGRA -- ConAgra Foods was built from dozens of acquisitions with brands that struggled to keep up with their competitors. But a new chief executive, Gary M. Rodkin, is trying to revive its brands with new products like Healthy Choice dinners that do not become mushy when microwaved, Orville Redenbacher popcorn that is low in sodium but still has a salty taste, and Chef Boyardee microwave-ready macaroni and cheese. [C1.] WOOING ASIAN GAMBLERS -- Casino operators in Las Vegas have become much more aggressive in wooing Asians both domestically and abroad, aiming not just at the newly wealthy from China, who in recent years have emerged as Las Vegas's best customers, but also Asian-Americans and recent immigrants from the Pacific Rim. [C1.] SIGNS OF A BACKLASH -- Robert E. Rubin, a Treasury secretary in President Bill Clinton's administration, made the case for private equity and hedge fund managers' paying more in taxes, a sign that the backlash against the tremendous wealth being created by managers of hedge funds may be gaining strength. [C3.] CHANGES IN JOURNAL'S NEWSROOM -- The Wall Street Journal, already roiled by a proposed takeover by Rupert Murdoch, will announce a major newsroom shake-up, including the reassignment and replacement of several top editors, officials there say. [C1.] A PHONE WITHOUT A KEYBOARD -- If there is a billion-dollar gamble underlying Apple's iPhone, it lies in what the cellphone does not have: a mechanical keyboard. The absence of a keyboard allows for a bigger screen, but the downside is that typing is done by pecking on the screen with thumbs or fingers. [C1.] FUTURE OF JAGUAR AND LAND ROVER -- Ford said that it was working with financial advisers to sort out the future of Jaguar and Land Rover, the two British brands that have been rumored to be up for sale for more than a year. [C3.] PROFIT GROWTH AT LEHMAN -- Lehman Brothers reported that its profit in the second quarter rose 27 percent, a record for the investment bank and potentially auguring a good week for Wall Street earning reports. [C4.] ENERGY BILL DEBATED IN SENATE -- The Senate began debate on a sprawling bill to reduce oil consumption, with top Democrats circulating a proposal to provide $10 billion in loans for plants that make diesel fuel from coal. [A16.] A DANONE DISPUTE IN CHINA -- A dispute between Groupe Danone, the French multinational company, and a brash Chinese executive has escalated into a battle for control of China's largest beverage maker. [C8.] INFLATION, BUT NO OVERHEATING -- Inflation in China reached a 27-month high of 3.4 percent in May, but the increases in consumer prices were heavily concentrated in food while figures for growth in the money supply and in loans suggested that the broader economy was not yet overheating. [C8.] GREENER PLANES, FROM EUROPE -- The European Union is planning a 1.6 billion-euro public-private partnership to help its aviation industry develop a generation of greener and quieter aircraft. [C8.] VOTE CRITICAL OF EXECUTIVE PAY -- Yahoo said that about a third of its shareholders had voted against the re-election of one or more company directors. The vote against some directors had been recommended by three Wall Street advisory firms that had criticized the compensation committee for awarding bonus and retention pay in the form of 6.8 million stock options to Terry S. Semel, Yahoo's chief executive, in a year when the company's shares dropped nearly 35 percent. [C3.] SAVING WEB SEARCH HISTORIES -- Google announced that it would cut back on how long it keeps the Web search histories of users, to 18 months from 24. [C3.] ART IMITATING ADVERTISING -- A coming television series about Madison Avenue, set in the days when sponsors' products were regularly woven into the plots of shows, is -- yes -- getting a sponsor whose product will be regularly woven into the plot of each episode. The series, ''Mad Men,'' will run on AMC, and be sponsored by the Jack Daniel's brand of Tennessee whiskey sold by the Brown-Forman Corporation. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] MOVIE TRAILERS FOR ADULTS -- Hollywood is retrofitting its rating system to give studios a chance to show racier trailers for movies online. [E1.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. RESTITUTION IN CA FRAUD -- Stephen Richards, former sales chief of the software maker CA, agrees to pay more than $29 million in restitution for an accounting fraud. (DOW JONES/AP) BLOCKBUSTER RENTAL PLAN -- Blockbuster is offering a lower-priced plan for online movie rentals as it competes with Netflix. It said it would cut prices $1 a month for customers who order movies online only. (AP)

Phil Mickelson may be the teddy bear of this United States Open, the player fans cannot help but embrace, but his gallery the first two days figures to be torn between two golfers. One of Mickelson's playing partners, Jim Furyk, grew up outside Lancaster, which is roughly 200 miles from Pittsburgh but near enough for him to be hailed like the boy next door. The Australian Adam Scott will round out the threesome.

To the Editor: Re ''Nasty, Unfinished Cold War Business'' (editorial, June 9):Ever since August 1945, mankind has known how to destroy itself with atomic bombs. How to avoid doing so must be at the top of every country's agenda, and our children and grandchildren must be kept aware of the danger.

To the Editor: Maureen Dowd notes that Oscar Wilde said that ''hypocrisy is the homage vice pays to virtue'' (''Outing the Out of Touch,'' column, June 10). The observation first came from the ''Maxims'' by the 17th-century duke La Rochefoucauld.

An article on June 4 about Abdul Kadir and Russell M. Defreitas, two of the four men accused of plotting to blow up Kennedy International Airport, referred imprecisely to Mr. Kadir's role in the Linden Fund, a charity in Guyana, his home country. As a board member and former mayor of Linden, Guyana's second-largest city, he used his contacts to help speed up the distribution of money and supplies sent to Guyana by donors in the United States, but he was not ''in charge'' of receiving and disbursing money and supplies.
TEMKIN--Meyer (Mike), June 13, 1926--June 13, 2005. I miss the ''sound'' of your voice. The quiet is deafening. Now, that's love! Liz

An obituary on June 5 about Samuel A. Garrison III, the chief Republican counsel to the House Judiciary Committee during the Watergate investigation, misstated the date of the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon. It was Aug. 9, 1974 -- not Aug. 8, which was the date he announced that he would resign effective at noon the following day. Also, the obituary referred incorrectly to the three articles of impeachment passed by the Judiciary Committee. Only one article -- not all three -- charged Mr. Nixon with obstruction of justice. The others charged abuse of power and defiance of committee subpoenas.

A homeless man was sentenced yesterday to 23 years in prison for fatally shooting a bridge painter who asked him to move his belongings from a Grand Central Parkway overpass during a painting job in November 2004, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Boyd, 47, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on May 7, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Boyd admitted that when the painter, James Gaviglia, 38, of Middle Village, asked him to move his makeshift shelter from an overpass in Corona, he shot him repeatedly with a pistol, then lit a cigar and waited for the police, Mr. Brown said.

When she was the pastry chef at the Union Square Cafe, Emily Isaac said, she always hoped to have her own bake shop, a dream Ms. Isaac, right, has now realized with Trois Pommes Patisserie in Park Slope, Brooklyn. A banquette in the window and a whimsical chandelier dangling from the soaring ceiling enliven the brick-walled shop, the better to showcase some riffs on popular snacks like whoopie pies and Oreos.

Roger Clemens is not a scheduled starter against the Arizona Diamondbacks this week, yet he was at Yankee Stadium yesterday, roaming the clubhouse and the field like any other teammate. The Yankees have told Clemens he can come and go as he pleases on the days he does not start, but Clemens is here now. ''Because it's in your contract and it gives you certain privileges, I think everybody assumed it was going to be on a regular basis,'' Manager Joe Torre said.

The Knicks, who have not won an N.B.A. title in three decades, will open their preseason schedule Oct. 11 against Maccabi Tel Aviv, a club that has won 47 Israeli championships. The event will benefit a charity for disadvantaged Israeli children, if not necessarily the Knicks themselves. ''I'm kind of hoping we don't embarrass ourselves too much,'' said Coach Isiah Thomas, whose team has had six straight losing seasons.

MASTELLONE--George J., M.D. He was born on March 19, 1914, in Manhattan, son of Antonio Mastellone and Flavia Franco Mastellone. He is survived by his beloved wife of 57 years, Florence Rasero Mastellone, of Williamstown, MA, his son George, of Arlington, MA, daughter Flavia, of New Ashford, MA, and three grandchildren, Nicholas, Emily and Michela. Predeceased by sisters Anne and Josephine, he is survived by his brother, Louis. He attended Brooklyn Technical High School, New York University and New York Medical College, graduating in 1939. He received his post graduate training at St. Peter's Hospital, Harlem Hospital, and the City Hospital of New York. He served in the Army Air Force from 1942 to 1946 as a Flight Surgeon and was discharged honorably with the rank of Major. He practiced Obstetrics and Gynecology for many years in Brooklyn, retiring in 1990 and had been Attending Physician at numerous hospitals including Kings County Hospital, Long Island College Hospital, Lutheran Hospital, and Victory Memorial Hospital. He served as President of the Medical Staff at Victory Memorial Hospital and as President of the Bay Ridge Medical Society. In 1999 he was honored by Senator Vincent J. Gentile in recognition of outstanding service to the community. There will be a mass at St. Ephrem's Church on Fort Hamilton Parkway at Bay Ridge Parkway at 10:30 a.m. on Thursday June 14th. Burial to follow at St. John's Cemetery. No flowers please.

MARX--Peter Maxwell, died on June the 11th, 2007, after a brief illness. Peter was born in New York City and attended Oakhurst Day School in Deal, New Jersey. He also attended Clark School on the Dartmouth College campus, Cornell University, The Citadel and Pennsylvania Military College. He was an Adjutant General's Aide in the U.S. Army. He was a broadway producer and produced three operas. Later in his career he joined Judson Realty and also studied at the Modern Psychoanalytic Institute in New York City. He is survived by his beloved wife of 42 years, ''Tommi'' Gwendolyn K. Marx. He leaves two nephews and one niece and their 10 children, 12 godchildren, and his very special cousins, Klee and John Zaricky of Lawrence, Kansas. Peter was always surrounded by many loving friends in New York, Maine, and Kansas. A memorial service will be held Monday, June 18 at 4:00 pm at 20 Heron Lane, Cumberland Foreside, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Animal Refuge League, PO Box 336, Westbrook, ME 04098. Services are being handled by Jones, Rich & Hutchins Funeral Home, 199 Woodford St., Portland, ME 04103.

CARMILLY - Rhoda. Died June 10th, 2007, at the age of 93. She was the beloved wife of Moshe Carmilly and devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was president of the New York Chapter of Hadassah, president of the Women's Organization of Congregation Shearith Israel and active in the Junior League of the Yeshiva Women's Organization. Graveside funeral was held on June 11th at Riverside Cemetery in New Jersey.

A group of philanthropists led by Joan and Sanford I. Weill plans to announce today that it has pledged $400 million to build research centers and to recruit senior scientists for Weill Medical College of Cornell University. The medical school, based in Manhattan, will use the money for research into and treatment of obesity, diabetes, cancer and the diseases of aging, especially Alzheimer's, which carries a special poignancy for Mr. Weill. His mother died of the disease more than 10 years ago.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority appeared to have averted a possible summer strike on the Metro-North Railroad with the announcement yesterday of agreement on a new contract with the Teamsters Union, which represents track workers. It was the last of a series of union-authority agreements this year. Representatives of the authority and the union refused to disclose the terms of the agreement, which runs through mid-2010. Chris Silvera, secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 808, predicted that the local's 600 members would ratify the agreement this month. Mr. Silvera and the authority's executive director and chief executive, Elliot G. Sander, above, made the announcement at a news conference at Grand Central Terminal. Under federal rules that govern commuter railroads, the Teamsters could have gone on strike in July. WILLIAM NEUMAN

Bush Lobbies Senate on Immigration Bill In an effort to revive a crippled immigration bill, President Bush visited the Capitol to try to assure Senate Republicans that border security was a driving force behind his push for changes in the law. The president pressed his case in a visit to the weekly Senate party luncheon -- his first since 2001 -- then appeared with Senators Trent Lott, left, and Mitch McConnell. PAGE A16 Overseas Voting Problems The Defense Department has spent millions trying to find an efficient way for Americans living abroad to vote in elections back home, but its Web-based system is plagued by problems. PAGE A19 Reversal on Coach's Death The Jamaican police said Bob Woolmer, the coach of the Pakistani cricket team who died during the World Cup tournament in Jamaica, was not murdered, as they had previously announced, but instead died of natural causes. PAGE A12 Dining Whole Hog A counterculture of chefs, perhaps reacting to decades of sushi and small plates and grazing, is serving fatty fare like deviled eggs on fried pork jowl. Critic's Notebook by Frank Bruni. DINING, PAGE F1 Big Ad Push by Romney Mitt Romney has stepped up what is already the most expensive early advertising push in a presidential campaign, an effort credited with helping vault him to the lead in the Republican field in some polls in Iowa and New Hampshire. He has spent $4 million on television advertising since February. PAGE A19 Property Tax Break Highlights Budget Deal New York City taxpayers would get a larger-than-expected break on their property taxes under a $59 billion budget deal that city leaders announced last night. The pact, which comes weeks earlier than usual, would also use a record $4.4 billion surplus to eliminate taxes on clothing and shoes and increase library service to six days a week. PAGE B1 Sudan Agrees to Peace Force After resisting for months, Sudan has agreed to a joint United Nations and African Union force of nearly 20,000 peacekeepers in Darfur, its western province and the site of one of the world's worst humanitarian crises. PAGE A3 Spurs Close In on Title San Antonio prevented the Cleveland star LeBron James from attempting a potential game-tying shot in the final seconds and held on to win, 75-72, in Game 3 of the best-of-seven N.B.A. finals. The Spurs lead, 3-0, with Game 4 tomorrow in Cleveland. SPORTSWEDNESDAY
MIZE--Paul Randall, died May 30th, 2007. Funeral service June 15th, 11am, Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue at 10th Street.

ANTAR--Danielle. Your 32nd Birthday. It has been 14 years, how I wish I can see you, hug you and kiss you, as I say Happy Birthday, hear you laugh and grin as you roll your eyes and say, ''Mommy I love you''. I cherish and keep that love and the memories within me. I miss your love, warmth, wisdom and all that made you you. I just miss you. Happy Birthday, Pumpkin. I love you so. Me.

To the Editor: Re ''Health Care as if Costs Didn't Matter,'' by David Leonhardt (Economix column, June 6): Mr. Leonhardt's inclusion of knee replacements in his examples of ''medically questionable care'' runs contrary to many published reports by the National Institutes of Health and other reputable organizations that reaffirm that knee replacements are highly successful surgical procedures that permit millions of disabled Americans to regain their lives and walk without pain.

To the Editor: Re ''Out From the Ethical Deep Freeze'' (editorial, June 7): I live in a small town in the upper Hudson Valley, and we manage to have a working ethics committee. No one is paid a penny for serving. The committee meets about 10 times a year.

STAVOLA--Joseph, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the untimely death of our former colleague Dr. Joseph Stavola and his wife, Jeanne Serocke. The Chief of Pediatric Infectious Disease at NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, and Associate Professor of Clinical Pediatrics at Weill Cornell Medical College from 1999 to 2005. Dr. Stavola was an outstanding clinical researcher and teacher, whose contributions to pediatrics, particulary in the area of pediatrics AIDS, will long be remembered. We express our heartfelt condolences to the Stavola and Serocke families. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College Cynthia Sparer, Executive Director Children's Hospital of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, and Senior Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of Women's, Children's and Community Health Services NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Gerald Loughlin, M.D. Chairman, Pediatrics Department, Weill Cornell Medical College and Pediatrician-in-Chief, Komansky Center for Children's Health at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center

The series finale of ''The Sopranos'' on Sunday did not break any ratings records for premium-channel HBO, but its final audience tally eclipsed much of network television's for last week. According to Nielsen Media Research, 11.9 million viewers tuned in to watch the 9 p.m. conclusion of ''The Sopranos,'' making it the most watched episode since the 2004 debut of Season 5 (12.1 million). Only NBC's Tuesday premiere of ''America's Got Talent'' drew more viewers (13 million) last week. The ambiguous ending of the ''Sopranos'' story, however, left some viewers searching for answers on the Internet. According to Yahoo! Buzz, ''The Sopranos'' was the No. 1 searched person or thing online on Sunday and Monday. Nielsen estimated that CBS and Fox shared the lead on Monday. CBS finished first in total viewers, aided by repeats of ''Two and a Half Men'' at 9 (9.3 million) and ''CSI: Miami'' at 10 (9.2 million). Fox posted a lead among adults 18 to 49, as the second installment of ''Hell's Kitchen'' at 9 outperformed its week-ago premiere. The episode attracted 8.8 million total viewers and the night's highest numbers in the 18-to-49 demographic. BENJAMIN TOFF

FINK--Ronni, on June 11, 2007. Beloved wife of Dr. Simon Fink. Mother of Dr. Scott Fink (Amy) and Alexander Fink (Beth). Beloved sister of Marjorie Feinstein (Norman). Funeral Wednesday, 1:00pm, at The Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

THE rhythms of life have changed so much that the idea of shelling peas for a weeknight meal is pretty much out of the question. A weekend leisure activity, perhaps, but for dinner on a Wednesday? Let's get real. Which is why it is so delightful that food vendors of all types, from market stands to supermarkets, now stock fresh spring peas, out of the pod, bright and not too starchy. When I first started seeing these a couple of weeks ago, I pounced, and combined them with crab to make a fast and quite tasty salad in less time than it would have taken me to shell the peas.

DiSALVO -- Nicholas A., D.D.S., Ph.D., Professor Emeritus of Dentistry within the Section of Growth and Development, Division of Orthodontics, at the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on June 8, 2007. Dr. DiSalvo received his D.D.S. and Ph.D. degrees from Columbia University in 1945 and 1952, respectively. Dr. DiSalvo was first appointed as a fellow in 1947 and became Assistant Professor of Dentistry in 1951. In 1958 he was promoted to the rank of Professor of Dentistry and was appointed as Director of the Division of Orthodontics. He served in that capacity for many years until his retirement in 1987. Dr. DiSalvo was active in organized dentistry and orthodontics, and chaired and served on many committees of the Northeastern Society of Orthodontists. He was President of the Society in 1973-74. He was also a long-time member of the Edward H. Angle Society of Orthodontists, Eastern Component and served as its President in 1973 and 1974. Our thoughts and prayers are extended to his wife Pauline, sons Donald and Alan, and to members of his extended family. A service was held on June 11, 2007 at the Coffey Funeral Home, Tarrytown, NY, which was followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Ira B. Lamster, D.D.S., M.M.Sc., Dean Thomas J. Cangialosi, D.D.S., Director, Division of Orthodontics Columbia University College of Dental Medicine

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Susan and Jeffery; to their children, Rachel and Edmund Solarsh and Rebecca Bogatin; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

ZETLIN -- Valentine Wolf, M.D., of Leonia, NJ, beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, died June 9. Dr. Zetlin was born March 8, 1912 in Paris. His father was the Russian revolutionary, poet and editor Mikhail Zetlin, founder of The New Review, a New Yorkbased Russian-language literary journal published until 2007. Dr. Zetlin earned his medical degree at Oxford in 1944. He joined his parents and sister in New York in 1948, where he completed his training in psychiatry. He began his private practice in 1952, and became Medical Director at the Lincoln Institute for Psychotherapy in 1960, a position he held for the remainder of his career. Dr. Zetlin was a linguist who spoke English, French and Russian fluently, and some German, Spanish and Italian. He loved reading and writing poetry, and listening to music, especially opera. He is survived by his wife, Sylvia KordowerZetlin, his children, Linda Baker, Karen Reiter, Louis Borodinsky, and grandchildren Sean, Elizabeth and Jessica Baker; his daughter, Minda Zetlin; and in France, his nephew Dr. Alain Krivitzky, nieces Catherine Mann and Natalie Dominique, and their children.

A salesman for a software consulting company has admitted stealing confidential company information and giving it to a competitor, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The salesman, Louis Giuffre, 46, of Lake Grove in Suffolk County, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court on Monday to interstate transportation of stolen property, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Giuffre admitted that while working for the consulting company, Netsoft, last summer, he sent confidential information to a rival company by e-mail, Mr. Garcia said. Prosecutors said the competitor ultimately won a contract that Netsoft had been trying to secure. Mr. Giuffre faces up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced in September, prosecutors said.

AUSTRIAN red wines are not the stuff of everyday drinking. That's mainly because they are not front and center in wine shops and on wine lists. But they should be. The wines in our tasting were generously food-friendly and also, at typically $20 a bottle or less, mostly wallet-friendly.

MOST of the time, my husband, Daniel, is an eager accomplice when it comes to my more outré culinary cravings. He has gamely sampled braised chicken feet in Chinatown, crispy tripe tacos in Hell's Kitchen and even the deep-fried Gummi octopuses I made one afternoon in an oil-ridden frenzy. But when it came to raw lamb kibbe for dinner, he put the kibosh on my plan. ''I was actually hoping for something cooked,'' he said.

An article yesterday about the high number of arrests at this year's Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the estimated number of arrests at last year's parade. The figure of 50 to 60 arrests last year was taken from an article that ran in The Times in 2006; the estimate did not come from the New York police in the course of reporting yesterday's article. (The 2006 article cited ''at least 50'' arrests, but the Police Department disputes that figure, saying 151 people were arrested.) An article about the reaction to this year's arrests appears today on Page B3.

According to a Washington Post - ABC News poll published earlier this week, Hillary Rodham Clinton's most consistent and enthusiastic female support is now coming from high school graduates with incomes of less than $50,000 a year. Young women like her best. Over age 45, college-educated, higher-earning women like her least. In fact, asked who they found most "honest," "trustworthy" and "inspiring," these women - Clinton's peers - expressed more of a kinship with Barack Obama.

Did an ocean once cover nearly a third of Mars? Researchers have long thought they saw the remnant of an ancient seabed on its surface, but they had a hard time explaining what happened to the oceanfront property. There were features that looked like remnants of shorelines, but they varied so much in elevation that it was hard to explain how they could have bordered the same sea.

Per who? No one will be asking that question much longer. The Norwegian novelist Per Petterson has beaten out a posse of big names to win the Impac Dublin award for his flinty book "Out Stealing Horses" (Graywolf Press), translated by Anne Born. It seriously impressed our reviewer, Thomas McGuane - he compares Petterson with the likes of Knut Hamsun and J.M. Coetzee. (Look for McGuane's review - it went to press last night - on Sunday, June 24.) The novel is about a man in his late 60s, living in rural solitude, who's forced to come to grips with both his past and what's left of his family.

When Minnesota became the first state to require drug makers to disclose gifts and payments made to the health care industry, the results were alarming. Doctors and other medical workers had received nearly $60 million in gifts from pharmaceutical companies over an eight-year period. Patient advocates and other groups that support lower drug costs cried foul, though many doctors said their prescription choices were not affected by the payments.

When the Corvette Racing team offered me a prime spot to watch the 75th running of the 24 Hours of Le Mans, I did the unexpected. I said no. Instead, I told the team I wanted to forgo the champagne and shrimp cocktail of the media lounge in favor of being put to actual work. I explained that I wanted to see what it's like to be inside a race team, and to write an article about being a member of the pit crew in the most famous endurance race in the world. To my surprise, they said yes!

The subprime mortgage market took a toll on Bear Stearns's second-quarter earnings, as the investment bank's profits fell 33 percent from the same period a year ago despite record revenue for the quarter, the firm said on Thursday.

Hertz Global Holdings said Wednesday that the offering by certain of its stockholders of 51.8 million shares of its common stock was priced at $22.25 a share. The shares are being sold by the private equity funds Clayton Dubilier & Rice, the Carlyle Group and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity. Hertz raised $1.32 billion from its initial stock offering, most of which paid for a dividend for owners Clayton Dubilier, Carlyle and Merrill Lynch.

The recent popularity of equity bridge loans, used to finance private equity deals, is worrying some analysts, regulators and even the investment bankers who arrange them. Goldman Sachs has told its mergers and acquisitions staff to avoid them, an unnamed banker who works there told Reuters. Another banker who arranges buyouts called equity bridges "really bad business."

The Securities and Exchange Commission voted Wednesday to end price restrictions on short selling, meaning that investors seeking to sell a share that they do not own will no longer be barred from doing so because the price of the stock is falling.

Following a report that the Jones Apparel Group is close to an agreement to sell Barneys New York, the fashionable clothing retailer, for $950 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, The New York Times put the price tag closer to $825 million.

After months of sharp bargaining and threats to relocate, J.P. Morgan Chase is expected to announce Thursday that it has struck a deal to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown, according to The New York Times.

A report on Wednesday that the pancake chain IHOP might be about to toss Applebee's International onto its menu in a $2 billion deal, left analysts skeptical that such a deal was really in the offing.

A buyout group led by Wesfarmers, Australia's biggest home improvement retailer, is seeking to raise about 12 billion Australian dollars ($10 billion) to pay for an offer for Coles Group, according to Bloomberg News. The group met with 11 international and domestic banks in Melbourne Wednesday about loans and a possible bond sale, Bloomberg reported.

Blackstone Group dominated the news with its upcoming initial public offering, but it was a busy week for some smaller private equity shops as well. Three buyout firms, Avista Capital Partners, VMG Equity Partners and Sterling Capital Partners, announced that each has closed a new private equity fund to invest in the middle market.
As the dog days of summer approach, some Silicon Valley venture capitalists and entrepreneurs decided to take their deal-making to the dodgeball court.

CDC, the government-owned fund that pioneered venture capital investment in Britain's former colonies, has hired Morgan Stanley to advise it on a possible initial public offering or sale, The Times of London reported.

Shares in Britain's Dobbies Garden Centres soared more than 17 percent after the Scottish entrepreneur Tom Hunter doubled his stake and said that he was considering launching a bid to rival that of the British supermarket chain Tesco.

Baron Guy de Rothschild, the patriarch of the French branch of the famous banking dynasty who rebuilt and expanded its Paris bank after it was seized during World War II and then saw it survive another government takeover in the 1980s, died Tuesday in Paris. He was 98.
The documentary “Unborn in the USA” is billed as a rigorously objective look at the anti-abortion movement, and that’s accurate — but only to a point.
“Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict” methodically traces the battle over turf from its biblical origins to the fragile present.
The documentary “Beyond Hatred” is an example of a film whose style doesn’t merely suit its story but amplifies its meanings.

The former chairman of the Wahaha Group and many of the company's top executives joined forces Wednesday to denounce their longtime partner, Groupe Danone, the French food and beverage giant, and threatened to form a company that would break away from its joint venture.
In the documentary “Czech Dream,” two students at the Prague Film Academy use state money to stage an elaborate consumer hoax.
Eartha Kitt stands out in the otherwise uneventful romantic comedy,  “And Then Came Love.”

Chicago financier Sam Zell made the rounds on Capitol Hill this week, drumming up support for a buyout of Tribune in an effort to pressure federal regulators to grant waivers necessary to own both newspapers and TV stations in Los Angeles and four other cities.

A drug developer, Logical Therapeutics, has raised $30 million in Series B funding, as venture capitalists eye an opportunity created by the spectacular fall of anti-inflammatory drug Vioxx three years back.

Michael S. Dell sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19. Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard sophomore at the time. A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.
Lehman Brothers said Wednesday it would merge two residential mortgage units, cutting 400 jobs.

The American International Group sued its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, and its former chief financial officer, Howard I. Smith, on Wednesday, becoming the sole plaintiff in a case seeking more than $1 billion in damages.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which is making a $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said on Wednesday that it planned to sell nine of its Fox-affiliated TV stations. The stations are generally in the smallest markets served by the News Corporation's 35-station television group.

Shanghai Automotive, China's largest carmaker, agreed to buy out its partners in a truck maker and an auto-parts venture for 1.48 billion yuan ($194 million) to combine and expand its commercial-vehicle operations.

Photos of performances at Spiegelworld, a blend of cabaret, circus and burlesque.
“Rise of the Silver Surfer” is an existentially and aesthetically unnecessary sequel to the equally irrelevant if depressingly successful “Fantastic Four.”

Today begins with a bad story, and ends with a good one. We had heard about a settlement of recent returnees from Josh Ruxin, our gracious host in Kigali and director of Rwanda's Millennium Villages Project. Millions of Rwandans left Rwanda in the decades of instability leading up to the genocide, and many settled permanently in surrounding countries. Some have since been forcibly sent back, including this group of about 2,000 people from Tanzania. The group we encountered had all been settled in Tanzania since the 1980s, and had established sustainable farms and small businesses. Many were even born in Tanzania and had never set foot in Rwanda. Last November, they were stripped of their belongings and chased out of their villages, and told to return to Rwanda. Rwanda has a right of return policy reminiscent of Israel. ("Rwanda will never turn away our own people," a Rwandan woman told us, "We are one people, and no matter where they come from, they belong with us.") The refugees, or more correctly, the returnees, were welcome into the country.

Separated by a panel of glass, I've sat next to a whole bunch of guys from my old baseball card collection, incluiding Bert Blyleven, Jerry Remy, Ron Fairly, Buck Martinez and the funniest guy in baseball (trust me), The One And Only Rex Hudler.

An article on Tuesday about industry lobbying to shape energy legislation gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the group that is running advertisements in favor of expanded use of alternative fuels. It is the Energy Security Leadership Council, not the National Commission on Energy Policy. The article also left an incorrect impression in some copies that John Rowe, the chief executive of the Exelon Corporation, an electric utility company that operates nuclear power plants, was connected to those advertisements. The article noted that Mr. Rowe, “coincidentally or not,” is a co-founder of the Energy Security Leadership Council.” In fact, he is the head of the National Commission on Energy Policy.
A report in the National Briefing column on June 7 about the opening of four public housing duplexes in New Orleans misidentified their location. It is the Upper Ninth Ward, not the Lower Ninth Ward.
Hyperion Resources, a closely held Dallas investment firm, said it might build an oil refinery in South Dakota to capitalize on record gasoline prices.

An article in Business Day on Friday about higher pork prices in China amid fears of rising inflation referred incorrectly to the time period in which pig prices increased 71.3 percent. It was in April compared with the same month a year earlier; the prices did not increase that much from March to April.

An illustration with a short article in Science Times on Tuesday about the effect that soot in snow has on warming in the Arctic incorrectly included a penguin. Penguins do not live in the Arctic; the northernmost penguins are those on the Galápagos Islands, around the Equator.

A front-page article on Sunday about the decline of the South Korean tradition of drinking after work referred incorrectly to Norske Skog, a paper company that acquired a South Korean mill whose hard-drinking culture changed under the new owner. It is Norwegian, not Swedish.

An article on Saturday about the conviction of a Brooklyn man, Gregory Zalevsky, for the 2004 murder of his girlfriend, Irina Ilyina, misstated their ages. He is 52, not 57, and she was 31 at the time of her death, not 34. (Both errors appeared in an article about his trial on June 2, and the incorrect age for Ms. Ilyina first appeared in an article about Mr. Zalevsky’s arrest on July 8, 2004.).
Corrections: For the Record

An article on Friday about a lawsuit filed by Robert H. Bork, the onetime Supreme Court nominee, against the Yale Club in Manhattan over injuries he suffered during a fall from a dais incorrectly rendered an account of the incident by Cricket Farnsworth, the office manager for The New Criterion magazine, which had invited Mr. Bork to speak at the club. Ms. Farnsworth said that Mr. Bork went on to deliver his speech after his fall; she did not also say that he managed to make his way back to the dais first.

Retail sales unexpectedly accelerated at the fastest rate in three years, lifted by rising incomes and a stock market that has doubled this year. Sales rose 15.9 percent from a year earlier to 715.8 billion yuan ($94 billion) after gaining 15.5 percent in April, the statistics bureau said. The gain was the biggest since May 2004 after adjusting for distortions caused by China’s Lunar New Year holidays.

The Shanghai Automotive Company, China’s largest carmaker, agreed to buy out its partners in a truck maker and an auto-parts venture for 1.48 billion yuan ($194 million) to combine and expand its commercial-vehicle operations. The operations being taken over, the Shanghai Huizhong Automotive Manufacturing Company and the Shanghai Wanzhong Automotive Components Company, will become part of a Shanghai Automotive unit, the SAIC Motor Corporation, Shanghai Automotive said. The automaker already owns half of both ventures. The move is in line with a government plan to combine the country’s automakers.

Volkswagen narrowed its North American first-half loss by reducing discounts and warranty claims and concentrating on sales of the most profitable models, the company said. Volkswagen’s sales have fallen this year in the United States as the company prepares new models for 2008. The company sold 91,743 vehicles in the United States in the first five months, a 4.4 percent drop from a year earlier. Sales in 2007 will be flat, Mr. Hallmark said.

The current-account surplus widened at the fastest rate in three years in April as exports rose and a weaker yen increased the value of investments abroad. The surplus expanded 50.3 percent, to 1.99 trillion yen ($16 billion), from a year earlier, as growth in exports to Asia and Europe helped offset a decline in shipments to the United States, the Ministry of Finance said. The trade balance climbed 34.7 percent. Exports climbed 7.3 percent from a year earlier, and imports advanced 3.2 percent.

A national conference that was to start today to help heal the wounds of 16 years of conflict in Somalia has been postponed for a third time, the organizing chairman, Ali Mahdi Mohamed, said. In addition, Mr. Mohamed said, some of the expected 1,000 delegates from clans and factions across the country would not have arrived on time and the meeting hall is not ready.

Cardinal Renato Martino, head of the Pontifical Council on Peace and Justice, said Roman Catholics should not contribute to the rights group Amnesty International because it had adopted a new policy calling for access to abortion services for women under certain circumstances. Amnesty reversed its longtime neutral stance on abortion in April and adopted a policy urging governments to ensure access to abortion services for women in cases of rape or incest or when pregnancy presented a risk to the woman’s life or health. A statement from the cardinal’s office said that the “inevitable consequence of this decision will be the suspension of any financing to Amnesty on the part of Catholic organizations and also individual Catholics.” Amnesty also issued a statement, saying it had never received any financing from the Vatican or from official Roman Catholic organizations.

Cambodian and international judges finally agreed on ground rules for trying the surviving leaders of the 1970s Khmer Rouge regime that left 1.7 million Cambodians dead. Cambodia and the United Nations created the tribunal last year under an agreement from 2003. Hopes to convene trials this year were dashed by disputes between Cambodian and United Nations-appointed judges over the past six months, mainly about trial guidelines. With a $56 million budget, the tribunal is supposed to complete its work within a three-year time frame. But the judges were sworn in last July, so the delays have meant that a year has already been lost without anyone even being charged.

A teacher in Changhe Township, in northwestern Dingxi City, has been sentenced to death for raping 18 third- and fourth-grade girls, the state news media reported. In 2005, another teacher in Changhe was sentenced to death for raping 23 fourth- and fifth-grade students, the Xinhua News Agency said. It said local officials would not say if the teachers were at the same school.
Google got into a tussle with eBay when it invited the auction site’s sellers to a party to promote Google Checkout, a service that competes with eBay’s PayPal.

German officials heatedly protested remarks made by Representative Tom Lantos, a Democrat of California who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, in which he described former Chancellor Gerhard Schröder as a “political prostitute” for taking a job with a Russian state gas company. The government spokesman, Ulrich Wilhelm, said the comment, made in a speech at the dedication ceremony for a victims of Communism memorial in Washington on Tuesday, was “unseemly.” The foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, said it had breached the bounds of decorum and was a “discredit” to Mr. Lantos. Mr. Schröder has been criticized within Germany for his new job, overseeing a pipeline project.

Siriporn Thaweesuk, left, the first woman in Thailand to win a world title fight, was released from prison three years before the end of her seven-year sentence for selling amphetamines as a reward for winning the World Boxing Council female light flyweight title for her country. Ms. Siriporn, or Samson Sor Siriporn, as she is known in the ring, defeated Ayaka Miyano of Japan for the title in a unanimous decision after a 10-round bout at the prison in April. She was told by prison authorities that they would release her early if she won. Ms. Siriporn, 25, will continue to train on the grounds of the prison north of Bangkok and live nearby in a house provided by the prison authorities. Her first defense of her title is set for late next month.

Watson’s eyes widened when he was told, incorrectly, as it turned out, that golfers would face disqualification if their putts rolled over the blue line separating the practice green from the ninth green.

When I wrote about Phil Mickelson for this month’s PLAY, I called him a favorite for the United States Open. I hadn’t reckoned on the clingy rough at Oakmont wringing out his wrist two weeks before the tournament began. A guy I know, a former club champ who can still knock the ball around, played in an outing there recently, and he came away physically intact but psychically maimed. The championship tees were roped off and the greens had yet to be given their pre-tournament shave. Even so, my friend disappeared into the rough, failed to break 100 and was shell-shocked for days.

With temperatures for summer activities likely to reach into the 80’s and 90’s around much of the country, it’s a good time to reflect on heat illness, which incapacitates thousands of athletes every summer and, in the form of heat stroke, can kill. Last year, the American College of Sports Medicine published new consensus guidelines about avoiding, recognizing, and treating heat-related illnesses. (Keep a tub filled with ice near the playing field, for instance.).

Two months after completing a 3,278-mile swim down the Amazon River, Martin Strel -- profiled by Ed Zuckerman in the June issue of PLAY -- is back in Slovenia and, according to his son, Borut, profoundly affected by the experience. “Martin has told me many times he is dreaming daily about the Amazon swim and just cannot forget it,” Borut wrote in an e-mail message. “It looks like this swim changed his life.” Strel is still drained from the Amazon swim, Borut says, and “cannot even train at half power.” Nevertheless, Strel is telling people he is reborn. “He feels like he did 20 years ago,” Borut says.

Forget about Lance and Landis. Let’s not talk about the Tour. The world’s toughest bicycle race -- the Race Across America --kicked off at noon on June 10, and it’ll go nonstop for the next week straight through to a time cutoff on June 22. The coast-to-coast course follows a 3,043-mile route on highways and county roads from Oceanside, Calif., to Atlantic City, and riders pedal around the clock, some forgoing sleep for days on end. Top solo riders average 350 miles per day and will finish after more than a week of near-constant motion. Relay teams of two, four, or eight racers average 500 miles a day. About 200 competitors -- including soloists and team riders -- are competing this year, the biggest showing ever for a competition now in its 26th year. As of today, lead solo riders like Jure Robic, Wolfgang Fasching, and last year’s winner Daniel Wyss, are expected to be spinning sleepless through the high plains of Kansas.

Temple, an outdoor pavilion, has a removable teak floor, a retractable fabric roof and curtain rods on all four sides for privacy. Jason Champion, the Cherry Hill, N.J.-based product designer who created the pavilion and the Goa collection of chairs, above, for Tidelli, an outdoor furniture company in Salvador, Brazil, said it could be used as a dining area, a lounge or even an airy guest room. The 10-foot-square structure ($17,465) and the swivel chairs ($1,275 each) have powder-coated aluminum frames covered in polyvinyl chloride, a material that contains recycled components. They come in six colors: white, black, beige, chocolate, orange and chartreuse. Information is available from Mr. Champion's company, Design Kollection, which is distributing the product in the United States: (941) 921-6780 or jason@designkollection.com. ELAINE LOUIE

T-Pain, the Florida soul singer whose obsessions include strippersand electronically processed, roboticvocals, has the best-selling album inthe country with ''Epiphany'' (Jive).Propelled by the hit song ''Buy U a Drank (Shawty Snappin'),'' the album is No. 1 on the Billboard chart, selling 171,000 copies last week, NielsenSoundScan reported. In a week of big new releases, Rihanna opened atNo. 2 with ''Good Girl Gone Bad'' (DefJam), which sold 162,000; Paul Mc-Cartney, with a new, Starbucks-affiliated record label -- and, naturally, heavy promotion at Starbucks stores -- reached No. 3 with ''Memory Almost Full'' (Hear Music). The country stars Big & Rich bowed at No. 6 with ''Between Raising Hell and Amazing Grace'' (Warner Brothers); Marilyn Manson reached No. 8 with Eat Me, Drink Me'' (Interscope); and the reggaetón star Daddy Yankee opened at No. 9 with ''El Cartel: The Big Boss'' (Interscope). Last week's No. 1, R. Kelly's ''Double Up'' Jive), fell to No. 4. BEN SISARIO

House Votes to Close Loophole in Gun Law The House voted to close a loophole in gun control laws that allowed the Virginia Tech gunman to buy firearms even though he had been committed to a mental hospital. The Senate is likely to follow suit, which would be the first time since 1996 that Congress has given full approval to a measure strengthening gun control. Taylor, the former political director, raising pressure on the White House to cooperate with their inquiry into the dismissal of nine federal prosecutors. PAGE A22 Bank Plans Downtown Tower After months of sharp bargaining and threats to relocate, JPMorgan Chase is expected to announce that it has struck a deal with the governor and the Port Authority to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown. PAGE B1 Hmong Split After Arrest A Hmong leader in the United States is accused of conspiring to oust the Laotian government. His arrest revealed a split between Hmong who fled Laos and those who grew up in this country. PAGE A20 A Froot Loops Remake Kellogg says it will phase out ads aimed at children under 12 unless the products meet nutrition guidelines, a move likely to require reformulating some popular products like Froot Loops and Pop-Tarts. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 A Fierce Figure, 70 Million Years Old An artist's impression of a birdlike dinosaur that lived 70 million years ago was released in Beijing. Scientists announced that they had uncovered its fossil skeleton in the Inner Mongolia region of northern China. PAGE A18 Baron Guy de Rothschild Dies The heir to the House of Rothschild banking family, who rebuilt its Paris bank after it was seized by France during World War II, was 98. In addition to his financial acumen, the baron was celebrated for the family wine, Château Lafite-Rothschild, and for his thoroughbred racehorses. PAGE A29 Only Age in Common Roger Clemens has made headlines with his midseason return to the Yankees, but David Wells, another 44-year-old pitcher, has stayed under the radar while pitching all season for the San Diego Padres.
