Bob Dylan Wins Asturias Prize Bob Dylan, right, was named the winner yesterday of the 2007 Prince of Asturias Prize for Art, given by the Prince of Asturias Foundation and named for its patron, Crown Prince Felipe of Asturias, heir to the Spanish throne, Agence France-Presse reported. The jury said, ''Austere in form and profound in message, Dylan marries music and poetry in a body of work that has set an example and influenced the sentimental education of millions of people.'' The $66,000 prize will be presented at a ceremony in October. Last year's winner of the prize for art was the Spanish filmmaker Pedro Almodóvar. Despite Honors, Misery for 'Company' ''Company'' may have won the Tony Award for best revival of a musical on Sunday night, but that accolade, along with honors from the Drama Desk, the Outer Critics Circle and the Drama League, won't prevent the final curtain from falling on it on July 1. At its closing, the show, a Stephen Sondheim and George Furth creation, directed by John Doyle and starring Raúl Esparza, will have played 247 regular performances and 34 previews at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. A stage adaptation of the Kurt Vonnegut novel ''Slaughterhouse-Five,'' adapted by Eric Simonson of the Steppenwolf Theater Company and presented by the Godlight Theater Company, is to have its premiere in September for a six-week run at 59E59 Theaters. Angela Lansbury, starring on Broadway in ''Deuce'' at the Music Box Theater, will receive the Edwin Booth Lifetime Achievement Award of the Players Club, on Gramercy Park, in ceremonies there on June 24. The Game Spurns Offer The rapper the Game rejected a prosecutor's offer yesterday to exchange a guilty plea for a sentence of time already served on a misdemeanor charge of impersonating a police officer, for which he was arrested last year in Manhattan, The Associated Press reported. Although the swap of the guilty plea for the time that the Game, 27, of Glendale, Calif., spent waiting to appear in court after his arrest would have ended the case, his lawyer, Jeffrey Lichtman, said outside Criminal Court in Manhattan: ''Why should he plead guilty to bogus charges for a non-jail sentence if he's innocent? And he is innocent.'' Judge James Burke scheduled a return court date of Sept. 20 for the Game, whose real name is Jayceon Taylor. In California he is facing charges of making a criminal threat and possessing a firearm in a school zone in an incident in February in Los Angeles. Mr. Lichtman said the Game would be on a concert tour of Europe for the next two months. Bach Books Add Up In the conclusion of a 55-year effort, German researchers have completed the final volume of a new collection of the complete works of Johann Sebastian Bach, The Associated Press reported. Christoph Wolff, director of the Bach Archive in Leipzig, said the Neue Bach-Ausgabe, or New Bach Edition, compiled by the Bach Archive and the Johann Sebastian Bach Institute in Göttingen, consists of 100 volumes. The first was published in 1953. The cantatas alone fill more than 40 volumes. Mr. Wolff said some contatas and several sonatas previously attributed to Bach had been determined not to have been written by him and were removed from the collection. He continued, ''More complicated is the content of 'The St. Luke Passion,' which as a whole has been found not to be authentic but still contains one chorus composed by Bach.'' He said the new collection includes 47 recently discovered pieces not found in Wolfgang Schmieder's Bach-Werke-Verzeichnis, or BWV, generally regarded by musicians and musicologists as the standard catalog of the composer's works.

An article on Saturday about the conviction of a Brooklyn man, Gregory Zalevsky, for the 2004 murder of his girlfriend, Irina Ilyina, misstated their ages. He is 52, not 57, and she was 31 at the time of her death, not 34. (Both errors appeared in an article about his trial on June 2, and the incorrect age for Ms. Ilyina first appeared in an article about Mr. Zalevsky's arrest on July 8, 2004.)

The Mets are not panicking. They are not scared. Yet the losses are stacking up in staggering fashion, 9 in 10 games with their 9-1 drubbing to the Los Angeles Dodgers on Wednesday night, and in small but distinct ways this dreadful stretch is starting to wear on them. Only the coaches watched the final few innings from the dugout steps. The players stayed inside the dugout, as if they were resigned to another loss and eager to leave this place as soon as they could. Who could blame them? The last time the Mets were at Dodger Stadium, back in October, they swept the Dodgers in the division series. They have not won here since. The Dodgers outscored them, 18-5, in sweeping the three-game series, and they bashed the previously indestructible Jorge Sosa, who had started the Mets' only two victories this month, for six runs and eight hits.
To the Editor: Re ''In Senate Vote, G.O.P. Fights Off Gonzales Rebuke'' (front page, June 12):

For the second consecutive week, ''America's Got Talent'' led NBC to a ratings victory on Tuesday, as the show's audience fell only slightly from its premiere a week ago. Nielsen estimated that 11.8 million viewers tuned in from 8 to 10 p.m. to watch the talent competition, with Jerry Springer as host. With the exception of the Olympics, NBC has not earned an audience that size in that time period since November 2005. Last week NBC's broadcast of the show attracted 13 million viewers from 9 to 11, a period that generally has more viewers. A repeat of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' led the 10 o'clock hour in total viewers (8.8 million), making the network No. 1 in every hour on Tuesday night. ABC ranked second over all among adults 18 to 49, with its coverage of Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals. BENJAMIN TOFF
To the Editor: Re ''The Poets of War,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, June 11):

HOSPITAL CARE CHARGES -- Stark evidence that high medical payments do not necessarily buy high-quality patient care is presented in a Pennsylvania hospital study. Of the hospitals that perform heart bypass surgery, the best-paid hospital received nearly $100,000 for the operation while the least-paid got less than $20,000. Both facilities had comparable lengths of stay and death rates. [Page A1.] SCALPING GOES PRO -- Some sports teams no longer provide paper tickets to their season-ticket holders, who instead simply swipe a credit card or driver's license to enter the arena. The electronic ticket systems have an important side benefit: they allow the team to control, and get a fee from, any reselling of a ticket. [C1.] KELLOGG TO CURB SOME ADS -- The Kellogg Company said that it would phase out advertising its products to children under age 12 unless the foods meet specific nutrition guidelines for calories, sugar, fat and sodium. Kellogg also announced that it would stop using licensed characters or branded toys to promote foods unless the products meet the nutrition guidelines. [C1.] SENATORS SEEK TO PENALIZE CHINA -- Four leading Democratic and Republican senators proposed legislation aimed at imposing penalties on China over its export practices and predicted that they would have the votes to pass it in Congress this year even if it was vetoed by President Bush. The Bush administration indicated it would oppose the bill, which appeared certain to aggravate tensions with China at a time when Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., above, has sought to use negotiation to change Chinese economic policies. [C1.] TEXT MESSAGES ON WALL STREET -- Wall Street's two self-policing groups are expected to release proposed guidelines for the regulation of written electronic communications, including internal and external exchanges, in rules that will probably cover text messages carried over cellphones, BlackBerrys and other devices. [C3.] PANEL REJECTS ANTI-OBESITY DRUG -- A drug made by Sanofi-Aventis that was once viewed as a possible magic bullet against obesity was rejected by a federal advisory panel because of worries that it causes neurological and psychiatric problems and increases the risk of suicide. [C3.] BANKS INDICTED IN PARMALAT CASE -- An Italian judge ordered Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley and UBS to stand trial on charges of market manipulation in the events that led to the multibillion-dollar bankruptcy filing of the Italian dairy company Parmalat in 2003. [C8.] THE GENUINE ARTICLE ON eBAY -- The online auction giant eBay says new rules to curb fraud have resulted in a 60 percent decline in the number of complaints from luxury goods makers that counterfeits of their products are being sold on the site. It also says that in the last four months it has banished tens of thousands of sellers who did not meet new, elevated standards. But other companies still complain about piracy on eBay. [C9.] Google and eBay got into a tussle at eBay's convention in Boston this week, when Google invited the auction site's sellers to a party to promote Google Checkout, a service that competes with eBay's PayPal. [C9.] TALKS TO SELL BARNEYS -- The Jones Apparel Group is close to an agreement to sell Barneys New York, the fashionable clothing retailer, for about $825 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, people involved in the talks said. [C1.] STARS AND STRIPES AND G.M. -- ''Buy American'' has always been an undercurrent in General Motors' advertising, but the theme has been showing up more forcefully of late, as G.M. uses the one adjective that competitors like Toyota and Honda cannot use. Advertising. [C5.] A VIDEO SITE IN THE POLITICAL ARENA -- YouTube, which is owned by Google, and CNN are co-sponsoring a debate among the eight Democratic presidential candidates next month, with questions asked via videos submitted by people through YouTube. The debate is a reflection of YouTube's impact on politics. [A26.] DEBATE OVER BLOGGING AT A GAME -- The eviction of a newspaper reporter from a baseball press box for blogging about a game while it was in progress has stirred a debate over legal questions surrounding First Amendment rights, intellectual property rights and contract law. [D5.] NBC IN HIGH SCHOOL -- NBC News will announce an online educational venture, intended as a supplement to high school courses in American history, government and English, that draws heavily on its film archives, as well as on its journalists. [E3.] PRIVATE FORESTS AT RISK -- Conservationists are concerned that large tracts of the nation's private forests are at risk of falling into mismanagement, being subdivided or being sold for development as aging landowners pass the land to heirs or buyers. Small Business. [C6.] RETAIL REPORT BOLSTERS SHARES -- Stocks surged, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its biggest gain in almost 11 months, after the bond market rallied and a report on retail sales exceeded economists' estimates. [C15.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The quadrennial ritual of presidential debates has long followed a tried and true format. A guy in a suit asks mostly predictable questions of other people in suits. The voter is a fixture in the audience, motionless until he or she gets to address the candidate, respectfully. Everything is choreographed.

An article in Business Day on Friday about higher pork prices in China amid fears of rising inflation referred incorrectly to the time period in which pig prices increased 71.3 percent. It was in April compared with the same month a year earlier; the prices did not increase that much from March to April.

A drug once viewed as a possible magic bullet against obesity was rejected yesterday by a federal advisory panel because of worries that it causes neurological and psychiatric problems and increases the risk of suicide. Although the drug, rimonabant, is already marketed in 37 countries, it is now unlikely that the Food and Drug Administration will approve its sale in the United States without additional safety data.

In addition to their sons, they leave behind her aunt Elizabeth Weed, and her husband Rick of Breezy Point, NY; his mother Sylvia Stavola and his sister Beth Ann Stavola, both of Hartford, CT; his brother John Stavola and his wife Patty, of Glastonbury, CT; as well as longtime family friend Ed Rak, of Dennis, MA; and many cousins and dear friends. Visiting hours will be Thursday, June 14th from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the following organizations: Hawthorne Country Day School, Heartsong, Autism Speaks and The Miracle League of Westchester.

An article on Friday about a lawsuit filed by Robert H. Bork, the onetime Supreme Court nominee, against the Yale Club in Manhattan over injuries he suffered during a fall from a dais incorrectly rendered an account of the incident by Cricket Farnsworth, the office manager for The New Criterion magazine, which had invited Mr. Bork to speak at the club. Ms. Farnsworth said that Mr. Bork went on to deliver his speech after his fall; she did not also say that he managed to make his way back to the dais first.

After a close brush with demolition and an arduous move from a Chicago suburb to a Pennsylvania forest, a 1957 house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright opens today for tours and overnight stays. Three years ago, Danic Homes, an Illinois developer, agreed to donate the house, below, to the Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy, a nonprofit group that arranged for it to be dismantled. Then all the pieces -- including mahogany siding and paneling, 1950s kitchen appliances and Danish teak furniture -- were packed into trailers. ''It was a major jigsaw puzzle,'' said Thomas Papinchak, a builder who said he spent ''close to seven figures'' buying and reassembling the components at Polymath Park, a 125-acre resort he owns in Acme, Pa., near Pittsburgh, which was already home to two 1960s houses designed by Peter Berndtson, a Wright apprentice. The Duncan House, named after its original owners, sleeps six and costs $385 per night for three people, then $50 per night for each additional person. For information: www.polymathpark.com. EVE M. KAHN

Most people discard chipped plates and never notice the way their kitchen drains look, but Joana Meroz, a Netherlands-based designer, treats these unwanted and unnoticed objects as a blank canvas. In her ''Ornamented Life'' collection, sold at the Future Perfect in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Ms. Meroz embellishes cracked porcelain plates (and cups, bowls and serving pieces) with gold dust and plant-like drawings, left and above, making the undesirable desirable again. In her hands, a stainless-steel drain stopper, bottom left, takes on the look of lace, thanks to precise laser-cutting (although with a diameter of about 2 3/4 inches, it may be a tad small for the average American kitchen sink). The Crackery collection starts at $18 for a cup, and the drain stopper is $72; at the Future Perfect, 115 North Sixth Street (Berry Street), Brooklyn, (718) 599-6278. RIMA SUQI

The eviction of a newspaper reporter from a baseball press box for blogging about a game while it was in progress has stirred a debate about First Amendment rights, intellectual property rights and contract law. The National Collegiate Athletic Association, which on Sunday ejected Brian Bennett of The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Ky., during the Louisville-Oklahoma State game at Jim Patterson Stadium in Louisville, contends it is merely enforcing long-established principles as they apply to a new technology.

''For most consumers, the fact that there is no connection between quality and cost is one of the dirty secrets of medicine.'' PETER LEE, the president of a California health insurance consortium. [A1]

German officials heatedly protested remarks made by Representative Tom Lantos, a Democrat of California who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, in which he described former Chancellor Gerhard Schröder as a ''political prostitute'' for taking a job with a Russian state gas company. The government spokesman, Ulrich Wilhelm, said the comment, made in a speech at the dedication ceremony for a victims of Communism memorial in Washington on Tuesday, was ''unseemly.'' The foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, said it had breached the bounds of decorum and was a ''discredit'' to Mr. Lantos. Mr. Schröder has been criticized within Germany for his new job, overseeing a pipeline project. MARK LANDLER

The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday the creation of a $2.5 million New York City Cultural Innovation Fund to promote new directions in the arts. Grants from $50,000 to $250,000 will be awarded for new creative work in the visual, performing and media arts that demonstrates an engagement with the issues shaping New York City's future cultural and civic agenda. The projects will involve partnerships that connect cultural institutions with universities and the private sector, or that present new solutions for longstanding limitations on cultural expansion. The foundation also named three advisers to the fund: Lowery Stokes Sims, former president of the Studio Museum in Harlem; David Thorpe, global director of innovation at Ogilvy Worldwide; and Andrew Zolli, curator of the annual Pop!Tech conference. Initial proposals are due on July 20. Grants will be announced in November. ROBIN POGREBIN
HERLITZ--Bruce S. Longtime resident of Larchmont, NY on June 12, 2007. Mourned by his family and friends.

ON a recent afternoon, Dr. Michelle Copeland, a plastic surgeon whose offices face the Metropolitan Museum of Art, clicked her computer's mouse as images of young men's torsos flickered across the screen. Unlike the ancient Greek statues of Herakles or the bronze discus throwers in the newly renovated galleries across the street, the young men in Dr. Copeland's digital images were a bit different: Rather than bearing the broad, flat chests of Greek athletes, their pectoral areas assumed a fuller, more feminine shape. The patients were found to have enlarged male breasts, a condition known as gynecomastia. While it is not a new disorder, more men are seeking treatment for it, and new statistics from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons show that the majority are adolescent boys.

An illustration with a short article in Science Times on Tuesday about the effect that soot in snow has on warming in the Arctic incorrectly included a penguin. Penguins do not live in the Arctic; the northernmost penguins are those on the Galápagos Islands, around the Equator.

The flow of illicit weapons from Iran to Taliban fighters in Afghanistan has reached such large quantities that it suggests that the shipments are taking place with the knowledge of the government in Tehran, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday. Mr. Gates said he had seen new intelligence analysis over the past couple of weeks ''that makes it pretty clear there's a fairly substantial flow of weapons'' from Iran across its border to assist insurgents in Afghanistan.

GARDENERS are as opinionated about gloves as they are about, say, whether pachysandra is good ground cover or a rampaging eyesore. Some swear by the cheapest throwaways; others have a beloved leather pair, improved, like a baseball mitt, through use. In any event, gardening gloves are as essential as a good trowel, protecting the hands against cuts (keep your tetanus shot up to date) and the blistering work of hoeing, shoveling and pushing a wheelbarrow uphill. And work it is. Gardening requires mild to moderate physical activity, and in summer, sweaty gardeners appreciate an afternoon shower as much as the tomatoes do. Some glove makers recognize this and incorporate features to increase breathability. Katherine Whiteside, the author of ''The Way We Garden Now,'' tested six pairs of gloves while building a raised-bed potager. She cautioned that ''no one pair of gloves is going to do the myriad of different tasks there are to do in the garden.'' That said, a pair of disposable latex gloves did not make the cut: ''Not one redeeming feature,'' she said. SUSAN GUERRERO

For two years, the United States has tried to choke off Hamas, the militant Islamic group that has been ascendant in Gaza and the West Bank, while throwing limited aid and support to Fatah, its more moderate Palestinian rival. Now, with Fatah, the party of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on the verge of collapse in Gaza, Washington is facing a shrinking menu of alternatives. ''We have limited options, and most of them are bad,'' said Martin S. Indyk, the former United States ambassador to Israel. America's options are limited in part because its role has been limited, with the Bush administration pursuing what for the most part has been a hands-off policy toward the Palestinians. In public comments on Wednesday, Tony Snow, the White House spokesman, said that the hope of averting a wider civil war remained largely in the Palestinians' hands.

THE American kitchen has been an aspirational space ever since electricity and post-World War I prosperity commingled in a nifty new appliance called the refrigerator. ''There are scads of ads from the 1920s showing people in tuxedos and evening gowns literally adoring their fridge,'' said Victoria Matranga, a historian of industrial design and the design programs coordinator at the International Housewares Association near Chicago. Then as now, Ms. Matranga said, owning the right appliance flagged your social status by showing off your understanding of technology and progress, not to mention your prowess as a breadwinner. The kitchen has also long been a very personal space, not just a place where we tell stories about who we are, but a highly functional theater for those stories (even if the stories have nothing to do with the preparation of food). Highly attuned to these fundamentals, the makers of appliances are well aware of how much the kitchen means to their customers, and so pour money and manpower into ethnographic, human science and brand identity research in an effort to learn more. (Money well spent, it seems: Americans forked over more than $15 billion on kitchen appliances last year, a 21 percent increase over the year before, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm.) This observational research is how LG learned that people were trying to jam their sports water bottles into fridge-door water dispensers and finding the standard cavity too small, leading the company to make dispensers in its new refrigerators more than 11 inches tall, the largest in the industry. And the same kind of research explains why Amana makes an oven with indented racks: its researchers noted a disturbing tendency of some bakers to scald their forearms when reaching deep in an oven to retrieve pans set at the back. Observing the human animal in its native habitat (as well as in company labs carefully constructed to look like home), corporate researchers study not only how many times these humans open their refrigerators (55 times a day, according to General Electric) and what might be the most intuitive and comfortable shape for their dishwasher handle, but how that dishwasher or refrigerator supports their idea of themselves.

An article on Tuesday about industry lobbying to shape energy legislation gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the group that is running advertisements in favor of expanded use of alternative fuels. It is the Energy Security Leadership Council, not the National Commission on Energy Policy. The article also left an incorrect impression in some copies that John Rowe, the chief executive of the Exelon Corporation, an electric utility company that operates nuclear power plants, was connected to those advertisements. The article noted that Mr. Rowe, ''coincidentally or not,'' is a co-founder of the Energy Security Leadership Council.'' In fact, he is the head of the National Commission on Energy Policy.

Dirk Westphal has elevated the status of the goldfish from pet to creature worthy of worship by putting its photo on, of all things, surfboards. Mr. Westphal, above left, a photographer and an avid surfer, makes the fully functional surfboards by hand in his Chinatown studio, where he photographs goldfish in tanks customized for that purpose. Most buyers treat the boards as decorative objects, Mr. Westphal said, hanging them on walls, as at right, or using them as room dividers. While they can be used for surfing, he doesn't recommend it. Considering the price -- $5,000 to $10,000 each -- and the damage that inevitably occurs during surfing, he said, ''you'd have to be insane to use one.''

After a flirtation with Senator Barack Obama, and maxing out his contributions to both Mr. Obama and former Senator John Edwards, Steven Spielberg threw his support behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president. Mr. Spielberg cited Mrs. Clinton's ''experience and strength'' in a statement posted on her campaign Web site. ''I've taken the time to familiarize myself with the impressive field of Democratic candidates and am convinced that Hillary Clinton is the most qualified candidate to lead us from her first day in the White House,'' he said. ''Hillary is a strong leader and is respected the world over. As president, she will bring America back together, rebuild our prestige abroad and ensure our protection here at home.'' DAVID M. HALBFINGER

In the amateur draft in June 1981, the Mets took a college outfielder named Terry Blocker with their first-round pick. Blocker would go on to have one hit for the Mets. With their fifth-round pick, the Mets drafted a high school shortstop named Steve Phillips and signed him for $42,000. Phillips never played in the majors. In the 12th round, the Mets drafted an 18-year-old right-hander named William Roger Clemens from San Jacinto College. Three times after the draft, the Mets' scouting director, Joe McIlvaine, attempted to see Clemens pitch. Three times, the game was rained out.

INTERNATIONAL A3-19 Shiite Holy Shrine in Iraq Is Bombed a Second Time Two explosions apparently set by Sunni extremists toppled the minarets that remained atop one of Iraq's most revered Shiite shrines after a devastating bombing last year. Appeals for calm by Shiite leaders seemed to head off a sectarian convulsion like the wave of killings that pushed Iraq toward civil war following the 2006 bombing. The Senate is likely to follow suit, in what would be the first time since 1996 that Congress has approved a measure strengthening gun control. Vang Pao, the most recognized leader of Hmong people in the United States, has revealed a split in the Hmong population that has sprung up in this country: between old and young, between those who fled Laos and those who grew up here. Nifong, had nothing to do with a private laboratory's decision to not disclose that tests had found DNA from at least four unknown men on the body and underwear of a stripper who accused the students of gang rape, the laboratory director said. The bank's planned 42-story tower would rise at the site of the soon-to-be demolished former Deutsche Bank building. Here I stand, weighted down in the sand again, about to enter another foreign territory. I'm marching into a world I have never seen, a world where I am the intruder. Instead of carrying a 40-pound rucksack, I wear a 40-pound aluminum tank. Rather than a crooked Kevlar, I wear a tight neoprene hood. My desert uniform is buried; on this journey I wear a 14-millimeter wetsuit. On my feet I wear booties and soon will don fins. My hands are gloved. Here, a regulator allows me to survive, rather than a protective gas mask. The temperature is 52 degrees, not 118. I carry a Riffe spear gun instead of an M16. I have a compass, a watch, and a plan in case I lose my buddy. My stomach is in knots, but from excitement instead of fear. We are on an underwater hunt.

One of my favorite things about Shea Stadium, and admittedly there aren't that many, is that 30-second segment featuring Jose Reyes and his Spanish Academy. With the Mets on a 10-game road trip, I haven't gotten my fix recently, so I asked Reyes for a Spanish word today.
Times reporter Sewell Chan introduces his new project, City Room, a blog about the New York City experience.
Is there anyone at this point who hasn't weighed in on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to impose weekday traffic fees in Manhattan?

After living in San Francisco, New York and Paris, I find that sometimes I have a tendency to take the history at my footsteps for granted. But recently I discovered handy guides to the city of Paris from Zevisit that are as portable as, well, my iPod.

One of the things I'm sure will be different about the new Yankee Stadium is the media parking. Right now, we're in the same lot as the players, and the beat writers park in the next row. It's a sweet deal, and it probably won't last.
Byron Calame's tenure as the public editor ended on May 6 with the publication of his final column.
After 94 years on West 43rd Street, The Times moved south to its new home on Eighth Avenue.
A coalition of antiwar groups is looking to make it a long, uncomfortable summer for 40 Republican members of Congress who are opposed to setting a timeline to end the war in Iraq.

In 1994, Rwanda was the scene of killings at a rate of 10,000 people per day, and bludgeoned bodies literally lined the streets. When the Rwandan Patriotic Front (the current government of Rwanda) took over, they found dead people, moribund services, crumbled houses, and decimated hospitals. Latrines and lakes were stuffed with bodies, and churches were filled by the bodies of thousands of parishioners whose killings were facilitated by their own ministers. There was no government to speak of.
Packed train stations and gridlock on every street are proof enough that we're less than one day away from the world's greatest 24 hour auto race.

Though the big news for the Blackstone Group on Thursday was a Senate bill that seemed to take aim at the private equity firm's initial public offering, Stephen A. Schwarzman had other things on his mind. Chief among them: He had just become a first-time grandfather -- two times over.
When the Assembly passed a bill last week that legalized the "medical use of marihuana," copy editors across the state did a double-take. Shouldn't that be spelled with a J?
First there was the official New York City memorabilia. Then there was the official New York City condom. Now there's the official New York City bike helmet.

An abundance of Fisking - described by Wikipedia as a "detailed point-by-point criticism that highlights errors, disputes the analysis of presented facts, or highlights other problems in a statement, article or essay" -­ was one of the original glories of the blogosphere, but the practice has fallen into disuse as an emphasis on briefer, pithier comments has blossomed. Marlo Lewis of Planet Gore is a throwback, however, and her current, very lengthy takedown of a speech by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid on energy policy is, whether one agrees with her or not, a masterpiece of the form. For those too hurried to take it all in, here's her point in a nutshell:

The Upper West Side north of 96th Street is experiencing a period of profound physical change. New luxury residential towers are rising 30 stories or more, twice the height of the 14- and 16-story buildings that have defined the neighborhood for a century. Small businesses are giving way to blocklong retail development.

This is my last working day in the old New York Times building, at 229 West 43rd Street, and since I've spent quite a bit of time here over the last 23 years, permit me a brief departure from our usual subjects.

Add yet another strange wrinkle to the imbroglio over Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's congestion pricing plan. In a letter sent yesterday, the chairman of the House Subcommittee on Highways and Transit urged Albany's "Big Three" to "carefully consider the expectation" that the $500 million in federal funds promised by the mayor will actually come through. Turns out the Department of Transportation may not have the proper authority to give up the goods.

As it attempts to fight an antitrust suit by the Federal Trade Commission over its proposed deal for Wild Oats Markets, Whole Foods Market has turned from the legal arena to the court of public opinion.
Hundreds of onlookers gathered to watch the raising of a gold and white Plymouth Belvedere to celebrate Oklahoma's 50 years of statehood.
"They kept raping me, even though I had maggots crawling out of me."
Ryan Adams performs a song from "Easy Tiger." (Courtesy of Lost Highway Records)
A 90-year-old actor looks back across decades of on-screen laughter and real-life adversity.

The initial public offering Thursday of BioFuel Energy was described in the Red Herring as "lackluster." But worse adjectives might be applied to the public debut of the ethanol maker. It cut its offering price several times in the weeks leading up to the I.P.O. It had filed to sell 9.5 million shares for between $16 and $18. It ended up selling 5.25 million shares at $10.50 each. After a bumpy first day of trading, the stock closed up a penny. And at midday Friday, they were trading at $10.37.

UPDATE, June 16, 2007, 9:44 a.m. Sadly, but hardly a surprise, the protective covering couldn't keep 50 years of groundwater away from the buried Belvedere. As The Associated Press reported this morning, "crews removed a multilayered protective wrapping caked with red mud, revealing a vintage vehicle that was covered in rust and wouldn't crank.''
Just how much of a hit would Blackstone Group take if, as two United States senators have proposed, it had to pay the same tax rate as other publicly traded companies?

Long Island City, on the waterfront at the western edge of Queens, is widely seen as the next frontier in the city's plan to remake the waterfront, with new housing developments within walking distance of the area's many transit stations. The area is still home to some of the city's largest public housing developments, and for many years, residents of the area had little access to public libraries. There were two makeshift branches of the Queens Library, shoehorned into uncomfortable spaces in the Ravenswood and Queensbridge housing projects. "They were apartment-sized," the director of the Queens Library, Thomas W. Galante, told me this morning.

Ray Rivera writes at our sib-blog, The Empire Zone, that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York will be in New Hampshire, the first primary state, tomorrow, "but not for the reasons you might think."Read full post.

Robert Kubica feels perfectly fine after that accident he had at the Canadian Grand Prix last week. But the Formula One doctors decided he should not race, for fear of the possible negative consequences to his head of another accident. He had suffered a minor concussion.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be in New Hampshire tomorrow -- but not for the reasons you might think.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Texas Pacific Group are hardly the only ones with a lot at stake in their $45 billion buyout of TXU, a transaction that has faced scrutiny from Texas lawmakers and still awaits a vote by TXU shareholders.
Buyout speculation sent Expedia.com's stock on a wild trip Friday. But for now, at least, it seems the travel Web site isn't going anywhere.
This is not your father’s Brooks Brothers suit.
There are fewer fireworks today at Round 2 of the State Assembly's look at the city's sustainability proposal. Round 1, you may recall, could have been called Congestion Pricing and Its Discontents.
In today's Web column, Carl Hulse writes:

On June 6, we shared the latest version of plans for the front elevation of our dream house, and on June 8 we showed you the upstairs, where the bedrooms and offices are situated. (Thanks for all the suggestions about how to solve problems with the bedroom floor; we'll address them next week.)

The world of American laddie magazines -- the publications featuring scantily clad starlets and frat-boy humor -- may have a new publisher in the game. Dennis Publishing has sold its American titles to the Quadrange Group in a deal worth between $240 million and $250 million, according to The New York Post's Keith Kelly.
Wall Street is relieved that inflation is under control. Consumers know it isn't.
A younger, postwar creative class is reviving a culture of small, hidden counter bars — with a decidedly modern spin.
Is Thursday's tax bill the beginning of the end for publicly traded private equity? Judging from the action in shares of Fortress Investment Group on Friday, probably not.

In what has very suddenly become the "old" New York Times building, on West 43rd Street in Manhattan, the Book Review office is on the eighth floor, worlds away from the humming, adrenalized newsrooms that occupied floors three and four. You have to look to find it. No signs guide you into the narrow hallway that leads inside. Nothing says: "You are here."

Here's something to see. The advertisement at left, for "Sister Carrie," Theodore Dreiser's first novel, ran in The Times exactly 100 years ago today: June 15, 1907. The book had first been published in 1900, of course, but it was barely promoted. This later edition, issued by B.W. Dodge & Company, is the one that really took off, putting Dreiser on the map.
Isn't he?

It seems to The Lede this morning that while there is a strong streak of procrastination in the American soul, it is generally not born of cynicism or shiftless avoidance but of a quintessential American what-me-worry optimism -- that there will always be a chance to catch up again, that whenever we get to it, it won't be too late. As a people, we hate the words "too late," and tend to get worked up about unfinished business and irretrievable loss -- perhaps accounting for two of our national appetites these days, for historic preservation and for increasingly grandiose memorials.
There was an interesting behind-the-scenes drama playing out yesterday as the Clinton campaign announced that Bill and Hillary Clinton were liquidating their blind trust, converting stocks into cash.
Do you use location-based services on your mobile while traveling? Share your tips and experiences.

Less than a year ago, few private equity firms were willing to step up to the table and acquire casino companies, in large part because of the extra regulatory hassle that came with owning a gaming operation. But since last year's deal for Harrah's Entertainment, casino buyouts are on a roll. Friday brought the latest deal: Penn National Gaming agreed Friday to be bought by Fortress Investment Group and Centerbridge Partners for about $6.1 billion in cash.
Editor's note: An earlier version of this article incorrectly identified Vaclav Klaus as the former president of the Czech Republic. He is the current president of that country.

In an attempt to clear Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's path toward the Democratic party's presidential nomination of any potential conflicts of interest, Bill and Hillary Clinton have dissolved a blind trust that once held millions of dollars of the couple's assets. The Times's Patrick Healy reports on the details of the Clinton's investments and on the politics behind the sell-off:
I may as well admit it: This item was submitted by a PR guy on behalf of his client. And since I've admitted that, I may as well just copy and paste his note.

The Blackstone Group agreed to sell 50 percent of an Atlanta building to Australia's Macquarie Office Trust, as the buyout firm offloads assets acquired in its $39 billion takeover of Equity Office Properties Trust.
Lawmakers are throwing some rain on Blackstone Group's parade, and it is bound to worry other buyout firms that were thinking of marching after it.

General Motors and bankrupt auto parts maker Delphi are "very close" to a deal with the United Auto Workers union that would help the supplier emerge from bankruptcy, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source.

Thomas O. Hicks, the owner of the Texas Rangers and a veteran of the leveraged buyout business, is seeking to raise $400 million for his "blank check" company, Hicks Acquisition. He is jumping into a crowded field: Nearly 100 blank check companies have held initial public offerings since August 2003, creating a small army of shell companies, each prowling for an acquisition target.

Germany will not let Cerberus Capital Management buy RAG, a major industrials group, even though the private equity firm is ready to pay up to 8 billion euros ($10.65 billion) for the conglomerate, a government official told Reuters on Friday.

Bank of America has postponed plans to take ABN Amro to court, preferring to wait until the Dutch Supreme Court rules on the Dutch bank's sale of LaSalle Bank, its American unit, a Bank of America spokesman said on Friday.

The auction for Home Depot's supply unit may finally be heating up. Two private equity consortiums are planning to table offers of about $10 billion each for the contractor-supplies unit of the world's largest home-improvement retailer, Bloomberg News reported.

Goldman Sachs's shares fell 3.4 percent Thursday after the giant securities firm reported that second-quarter profits were flat from a year ago. Despite the effects of the subprime mortgage slump, however, The Financial Times's Lex argued that Goldman "remains the best-positioned investment bank."
The New York Mercantile Exchange, the world's largest energy market, is exploring a sale to NYSE Euronext, Deutsche Borseor Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, Bloomberg News reported.

The Blackstone Group had also bid for U.S. apartment owner Archstone-Smith Trust in the weeks before Archstone agreed to acquired by affiliates of Lehman Brothers Holdings and Tishman Speyer for more than $15 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Delta (Two), a Qatar-backed property investment fund, raised its stake in British supermarket chain J Sainsbury to 25 percent by purchasing 732 million pounds ($1.4 billion) of stock.

MacDonald Dettwiler, a Canadian firm that makes components for the Space Shuttle, has denied reports that it is in talks to sell its surveillance and space business, but that hasn't seemed to quash analysts' speculation.
Two former undercover detectives, both suffering from devastating sickness, now rely on each other more than ever.
A hedge fund has called for the sale of Sunrise Senior Living, citing problems with management and accounting at the large U.S. owner of assisted-living and nursing homes.

The family that controls Dow Jones & Company has rejected a proposed plan prepared by its lawyers, asking them instead to seek stronger guarantees of editorial independence as a condition of selling the company to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, The New York Times reported.
The Federal Trade Commission reportedly wants to take a look at a few online advertising acquisitions, not just Google's planned deal to acquire DoubleClick.

Turns out it's been a pretty weird week for Rome, or at least the Rome of popular imagination. First a construction mishap cut off the water supply to a number of the city's captivating fountains, including the famous Trevi. Then, in the wee hours of Thursday, a man evidently captivated by something or other drove his Toyota Celica down the Spanish Steps.
While Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, has offered warnings about China's market, Indian indexes have hit new highs, drawing in foreign investors and Wall Street banks.
Bag Borrow or Steal, which rents high-end handbags and jewelry to consumers, has bagged a $15 million venture capital round that it will use to expand into new product categories.

Samsung Card, a leading Korean credit card issuer and the consumer finance unit of the Samsung Group, will raise 576 billion won ($619 million) from its initial public offering after fixing the price 6.7 percent above the top of the earlier indicated range.

Troubled music group Sanctuary has accepted a takeover offer from Universal Music Group. The firm, which manages James Blunt and Sir Elton John, announced this morning that Centenary, a division of Universal, has offered to pay 20 pence a share, valuing the company at 44.5 million pounds ($87.7 million).
An Indian tycoon, Vijay Mallya, is pursuing another takeover deal, soon after buying a stake in a rival airline, as well as a Scottish liquor company.

The solar thermal engine is heating up, again. Infinia, which makes a Stirling engine that can generate electricity or household heat by harvesting heat from the sun, has raised $9.5 million, the company said Thursday.

The chief executive of the Center for Venture Education offers a dismal assessment when it comes to the organization's track record for developing and training minorities and women as venture capitalists. "Our numbers are awful," the center's chief executive, Patrick Von Bargen, told The New York Times' Matt Richtel. "But they're better than in the industry" as a whole.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit Thursday against two lawyers, one a former enforcement official for the commission, charging that they had played important roles in a penny stock fraud that cost investors at least $160,000 in 2005. It appears to be the first time the commission has sought damages from lawyers who performed legal work in such cases but did not sell stock.
PTV Sciences, an Austin-based venture capital firm, says it has raised $190 million for a second fund that will invest in life and materials science companies.

The founding family behind British video game developer Codemasters Software has sold its ownership stake to Balderton Capital, while Goldman Sachs has invested 50 million pounds ($100 million) in the company.

A former employee of the accounting firm Ernst & Young pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit tax fraud Thursday, a month after similar charges were filed against four current and former employees of the firm.

Speedy Hire, a British tool-rental company, agreed to buy Finning International's Hewden Tools business for 115 million pounds ($227 million) to add branches and expand its range of drills, scaffolding and generators.

Shareholders of the Midwest Air Group elected three directors backed by a hostile suitor, AirTran Holdings, increasing pressure on Midwest's board to consider AirTran's $389 million takeover offer for the airline.
Panama, who will play the United States in the quarterfinals of the Gold Cup, is a prime example of a traditionally weaker Central American team that has elevated its level of play.

The Interpublic Group of Companies said Thursday that it had received a letter from federal regulators in a continuing investigation into earnings restatements by the company. The so-called Wells notice from lawyers at the Securities and Exchange Commission signals that its staff is likely to recommend civil action regarding possible S.E.C. violations.
What I'm wearing now, when the invite says "island," antidote to itsy-bitsy and more.
HBO’s “Conchords” is a summer fling of a series, but it is funny, at times very funny.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Players of interactive online games and the avatars, gear, spells, skills and identities they forge to represent themselves.
Here are some of my images and tales from my first day in Rwanda.
Additional images of the artist Eve Mosher drawing a chalk line along 70 miles of at-risk coastal neighborhoods in New York.
Ben Ratliff writes:
What is the recourse for a buyer whose new co-op came with a $2,500 assessment?
In “Nancy Drew,” the titular girl sleuth is decked out with air quotes and the full complement of knowing pop-culture accessories.
As a music document and as a labor of unabashed love, the nonfiction feature “Gypsy Caravan” could hardly be better; as a movie, it could stand some improvement.
In the ticklishly amusing satire “Fido,” the undead stagger along like stunned toddlers.
Since man first took to the sea, sailors have sought divine protection for their ships. The Fire Department began its yearly blessing ritual after the 9/11 terror attack.
Senator Harry Reid said Democrats would sacrifice their Fourth of July break, if necessary, to pass the suddenly revived immigration bill.

LONDON, June 15 — A British court sentenced seven men to a total 136 years in prison today who had been convicted or admitted to acting as accomplices to an Al-Qaeda terrorist planning spectacular attacks in the United States and Britain.
The attack signaled that the cycle of violence following the destruction of a Shiite shrine has not unfolded.
Michael B. Nifong's announcement came after admitting that he had “crossed the line” of ethical standards in some of the public statements he made.
Some blame gerrymandered districts for Congress's recent spate of ethical transgressors, but closer examination yields multiple explanations.
Hamas supporters marked their new control over Gaza by looting the symbols of fallen power as Fatah named a new prime minister likely to hold sway only in the West Bank.
NASA officials said that they fully expected engineers to resolve the problems, but that it could take days.
Democrats and Republicans in the House reached agreement Thursday night on how to handle the lawmaker pet projects known as “earmarks.”
Two days after 13 members of the Haitian national junior soccer team disappeared during a stopover in New York, all but one had returned voluntarily.
The president of New York City Transit fielded questions from the public at “Transit Talk” in the Atlantic Avenue subway station.
Two of the owners of the Preakness champion Curlin were indicted by a federal grand jury for conspiring to defraud their clients in a $200 million lawsuit settlement.

An article on June 4 about a new drug for liver cancer misstated the improvement in survival for patients who took the drug, compared with patients who took a placebo. The drug extended the lives of patients by about 35 percent, not 44 percent.

A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that senior federal officials would have to answer questions under oath in a lawsuit accusing them of personally conspiring to violate the rights of Muslim immigrants held in a federal detention center in Brooklyn after 9/11. The ruling, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, upholds most of an earlier decision by a federal judge in Brooklyn. The officials, including former Attorney General John Ashcroft and Robert Mueller, the head of the F.B.I., had asked for dismissal of the lawsuit, by Javaid Iqbal, a Pakistani immigrant, arguing in part that the government was entitled to take actions that might not have been lawful before 9/11. Although acknowledging some forms of government action in emergencies may exceed normal constitutional limits, Judge Jon O. Newman rejected the officials’ contention, saying some protections against some of the violations claimed, such as needlessly harsh confinement and ethnic discrimination, do not vary with surrounding circumstances. “The strength of our system of constitutional rights derives from the steadfast protection of those rights in both normal and unusual times,” he wrote.
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a reorganization of the newsroom at The Wall Street Journal misstated the middle initial of its managing editor. He is Marcus W. Brauchli, not Marcus E.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed four bills into law yesterday, including a bill renaming numerous streets that caused controversy when the City Council removed the name of a radical black activist, Sonny Carson, from the list. The mayor also signed the Safe Housing Act, giving the city broad new powers to go after slumlords and improve housing conditions. The act requires the Department of Housing Preservation and Development to identify 200 buildings each year with the worst histories of emergency repairs and uncorrected code violations and force their landlords to make repairs, or else the city will do it for them and bill the owners. If the landlord refuses to pay, the city can seize the property.

An article yesterday about a federal court ruling that overturned a Bush administration policy of counting hatchery fish when deciding whether federal protections are warranted for certain fish species misstated the location of the court. It is in Seattle, not Spokane, Wash.
An article on Wednesday about a house fire that killed five children in Pittsburgh incorrectly described the building. It was wood and shingles, not brick.

Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about new guidelines for federal review of personal data collected from Americans in terror investigations misstated the name of the agency that issued the guidelines. It is the Federal Bureau of Investigation, not the Federal Bureau of Information.

An article on the Street Scene page in Business Day last Friday about the International Network of Boutique Law Firms rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from the founder of the organization, Steven Spielvogel, who commented on his experiences as an associate at Sullivan & Cromwell. He said, “When I carried a Sullivan & Cromwell litigation bag and it said S.&C. on it, it was a rebuttable presumption that you were an amazing lawyer and brilliant” — not a “reputable” presumption.

The Albright-Knox Art Gallery says it raised $67.2 million by selling 207 older works in a series of controversial auctions. The last sale was held at Sotheby’s in Manhattan last Friday. The museum’s executive director, Louis Grachos, told The Buffalo News this week that the museum’s endowment for buying art grew to $90 million from $23 million. Among the highlights was $25.5 million paid on June 7 by a private European collector for the 2,000-year-old classical bronze sculpture “Artemis and the Stag,” a record auction price for a sculpture and for an antiquity. Museum members opposed to the sale tried unsuccessfully to block the auctions in court.

Law enforcement officials yesterday announced the arrests of 27 people accused of membership in the Bloods street gang. In two separate operations, state and federal authorities charged groups operating in Newark and Paterson. Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in Newark, said 13 people were charged with running a gun and drug business from two Newark housing projects. The state police also announced the arrest of 14 men they said were members of another branch of the Bloods, the Sex Money Murder set. They said three state leaders of the group were among those arrested.

An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about sperm cells misstated one dimension of such cells. The head of a mature sperm cell measures about 5 microns, or two ten-thousandths of an inch, not two-thousandths of an inch.

The West African man who lost his wife and four children in a Bronx fire in March that claimed 10 lives in all asked immigration officials yesterday to allow him to stay in the United States now that he has returned from burying his family in his homeland of Mali. The man, Mamadou Soumare, 48, is an illegal immigrant, and he received temporary travel permission for the trip. One of Mr. Soumare’s lawyers asked the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services to grant his case “deferred action” status, which removes the threat of deportation. A spokesman for Citizenship and Immigration Services said the request is being reviewed.

The State of the Art column in Business Day yesterday, about noise-cancellation headphones, referred incorrectly to the audio cord of the Bose QuietComfort 2 headphones. It can indeed be detached, with a sharp tug. The column also misstated the name of a set of headphones from Able Planet. They are called Clear Harmony with Linx Audio, not Solitude with Linx Audio.

The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Highways and Transit yesterday said the Bush administration was exceeding its authority by offering New York City up to $500 million for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposed congestion pricing plan. Representative Peter DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon, said he had “serious doubts” that the mayor’s plan qualified for federal financing under the funds the federal Department of Transportation is proposing to use. But Jeffrey N. Shane, the transportation undersecretary for policy, said the department had “ample statutory and regulatory authority” to authorize the money under several different programs. The federal money has been a major selling point in Mr. Bloomberg’s efforts to win approval for the program in the State Assembly.

Two Nigerian men have been convicted of conspiring to smuggle heroin into the United States after an investigation that stretched from Kabul to Manhattan, federal prosecutors said. The men, Emmanuel Obi Maduka and Chimdi Ibiam, were convicted on Wednesday in Federal District Court of conspiracy to sell heroin and smuggle it into the United States, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney.

An obituary on May 30 by The Associated Press about Barbara Cox Anthony, an heir to the Cox media fortune, incorrectly described the inheritance. Ms. Anthony and her sister, Anne Cox Chambers, and their older brother, James M. Cox Jr., all held equal interests in the company before the death of Mr. Cox in 1974, at which time the sisters received his share; they did not inherit the entire company from Mr. Cox.

An article yesterday about a federal court ruling that overturned a Bush administration policy of counting hatchery fish when deciding whether federal protections are warranted for certain fish species misstated the location of the court. It is in Seattle, not Spokane, Wash.

A report by Agence France-Presse in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the Rolling Stones’ performance at the Isle of Wight Festival on Sunday night referred incorrectly at one point to the history of their appearances in Britain. As the report noted elsewhere, their performance at the Isle of Wight was their first at a British music festival since 1976. It was not their first in Britain since then.

A Brooklyn teenager was indicted yesterday on charges that he had fatally stabbed a 20-year-old man because he was gay, prosecutors said. Omar Willock, 17, was charged with murder in the second degree as a hate crime, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Mr. Hynes said Mr. Willock is charged with stabbing Roberto Duncanson, 20, after shouting antigay remarks. Mr. Hynes said Mr. Duncanson tried to walk away, but Mr. Willock stabbed him four times.
Albany leaders agree to overhaul a law that many believe drives up construction costs, but deep divisions remain in other areas.
Ronald L. Rice, a New Jersey state senator, said yesterday that he would no longer block the governor’s nomination for chief justice of the State Supreme Court.

The Swiss National Bank raised its key interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point and raised its economic growth forecast for the year. Switzerland’s central bank said it decided at its quarterly policy-setting meeting to raise rates to 2.50 percent from the previous 2.25 percent. The increase, expected by analysts, was the ninth successive increase in recent years and puts the rate at its highest level since 2001. The move mirrors a decision last week by the European Central Bank, which raised its key interest rate from 3.75 percent to 4 percent. The Swiss central bank also raised its expectations for growth in gross domestic product this year to 2.5 percent from 2 percent.

China’s government reported industrial production growth unexpectedly accelerated in May, hours after Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, left, said further steps were needed to cool the country’s economy. Output rose 18.1 percent in May from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said, after gaining 17.4 percent in April. Mr. Wen said Wednesday that monetary policy needed “moderate tightening,” underscoring the failure of two interest rate increases this year to slow the economy. Record trade surpluses have pumped money into the financial system, stoking investment, inflation and a stock market boom. For the first five months, industrial production climbed 18.1 percent from the period last year, up from 16.6 percent growth for all of 2006.

Speedy Hire, a British tool-rental company, agreed to buy Finning International’s Hewden Tools business for £115 million ($227 million) to add branches and expand its range of drills, scaffolding and generators. Speedy, based in Newton-le-Willows, northwest England, will pay cash for the operation, part of the Hewden Stuart subsidiary of Finning, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia. The purchase will increase Speedy Hire’s annual revenue by at least 20 percent, to more than £400 million, the chief executive, Steve J. Corcoran, said on a conference call.

Russia’s economy expanded in the first quarter at the fastest pace in six years as production of building materials increased to keep pace with a construction boom and consumer demand remained strong. Gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 7.9 percent in the period, compared with 5 percent in the first quarter of 2006, the Federal Statistics Service said. The figure is not seasonally adjusted. Industrial output increased 7.9 percent in the first quarter of the year, compared with 4.1 percent in the period last year, according to the Federal Statistics Service.
Less than one of every five local funding requests by lawmakers made it into the amended state budget put forward by their leaders.
A group of East Harlem residents claims that city official did not follow their own guidelines requiring major projects to be approved by community boards.
Centenarian Kathryn W. Davis is donating $20 million to the effort to preserve of the Hudson River.

A court freed a leading Niger Delta militant who has been jailed on treason charges for nearly two years, raising hopes that a deal to end a spell of violence in the oil-rich region may soon be at hand. The militant, Mujahid Asari-Dokubu, was jailed after he declared war against the government over corrupt practices that stripped the Niger Delta of its oil wealth but failed to develop it, making the Niger Delta one of the poorest regions in Africa’s top oil producer. The release of Mr. Asari-Dokubu, a member of the influential Ijaw tribe, has been a top priority of militants in the Niger Delta, who have carried out a campaign of bombings and kidnappings that have crippled Nigeria’s oil industry, slashing output by 25 percent.

African nations agreed to a massive ivory sell-off and a nine-year freeze on further sales, moves that conservationists hoped would mean a reprieve for elephant herds from poachers and smuggling syndicates. The compromise, reached after heated negotiations lasting three weeks in The Hague, effectively called a truce in the recurring tussles between Africans wanting to cash in on stocks of accumulated tusks and those who fear that easing a 1989 trade ban will put more pressure on their dwindling elephant herds. The 171-member Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, or Cites, approved the deal in what the European Union called a milestone for the wildlife trade organization. The arrangement allows South Africa, Namibia, Botswana and Zimbabwe to empty government inventories in a single sale to Japan, which guaranteed not to re-export the raw ivory. Revenues from the sale are earmarked for conservation programs.

Bertie Ahern secured his re-election as prime minister for a third term, winning parliamentary support for a broadly based coalition that he said would ensure stable government for the next five years. The re-election, analysts say, was a personal and political triumph for Mr. Ahern, who, in deal-making since national elections on May 24, allied his centrist Fianna Fail party with legislators from both the left-leaning Green Party and the right-of-center Progressive Democrats. For the first time, the Green Party will get cabinet posts in an Irish government. The Progressive Democrats, who governed with Fianna Fail for the last 10 years, will have a much reduced role in the new coalition, having lost seats in the national election.

Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, said he would serve as chairman of the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa, a $150 million undertaking financed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Rockefeller Foundation. Mr. Annan made the announcement while speaking at the World Economic Forum in Cape Town. The alliance’s aim is to increase the productivity of millions of small scale farmers in Africa, where per capita food production lags behind population growth and a third of the population suffers from chronic hunger.

Banking authorities in the United States and Macao began transferring millions of dollars to North Korea to end a dispute that has stalled an agreement to dismantle the North’s nuclear programs, Macao government officials said. The money was transferred from Banco Delta Asia, a small family-owned bank in Macao, in the first step to return the money to the original account holders, the officials said. Under pressure from the United States, the Macao government in September 2005 ordered that about $25 million belonging to either North Korean state agencies or businesses with links to North Korea be frozen in the Macao bank. Diplomats working on putting into effect the agreement reached in February among North Korea, the United States, China, Japan, Russia and South Korea hope the transfer will at last revive stalled attempts to get the North to shut its nuclear facilities.
hockey.

Three Lexington lawyers illegally kept $65 million in settlement money that should have been distributed to their clients, according to an indictment for wire fraud issued by a federal grand jury in Covington. The money was part of $200 million settlement of a civil suit claiming that about 440 people had been injured by the diet drug fen-phen. The lawyers, William J. Gallion, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and Melbourne Mills Jr., were entitled to about a third of the settlement but took twice that, the indictment said. The lawyers have denied criminal wrongdoing.
The four women had been convicted of beating and stabbing a man who they claimed had taunted them because they were lesbians.

A federal jury convicted James F. Seale, a reputed Ku Klux Klansman, of kidnapping and conspiracy in the 1964 deaths of two black teenagers in southwest Mississippi. Mr. Seale, 71, had pleaded not guilty to charges related to the deaths of the teenagers, Charles E. Moore and Henry H. Dee, both 19. The men disappeared from Franklin County on May 2, 1964, and their bodies were found in the Mississippi River. Federal prosecutors indicted Mr. Seale in January, almost 43 years after the slayings. When he is sentenced Aug. 24, he faces life in prison on the two counts of kidnapping and one count of conspiracy.

A federal judge rejected a plea deal for a lawyer who admitted leaking the grand jury testimony of athletes to two newspaper reporters. A lawyer for the man, Troy Ellerman, left, argued for a 15-month sentence after Mr. Ellerman pleaded guilty to allowing the two San Francisco Chronicle reporters to view transcripts of the grand jury testimony of Barry Bonds and others embroiled in the government’s steroids investigation. Probation officers recommended 18 months. The judge, Jeffrey S. White of Federal District Court in San Francisco, said that both recommendations were too low and that Mr. Ellerman, as a lawyer, “should be held to a higher standard of conduct.”.

A Republican senator blocked a vote in the Judiciary Committee on whether to authorize subpoenas to the Justice Department to obtain secret legal opinions and other documents related to the National Security Agency’s program of domestic eavesdropping. The action by Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona will block the vote for a week. After the vote next Thursday, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the committee, can decide whether to issue the subpoenas or use them as leverage in negotiations with the Bush administration over access to the documents.

One worker died and another was missing after a column under construction collapsed on a newly opened bridge, sending nine workers plunging into the Bay of St. Louis, officials said. The workers involved in the accident on the U.S. 90 bridge, a two-mile span that partly opened to traffic last month, were employed by Granite Archer Western, the contractor for the bridge. Workers were pouring concrete on the north side of the bridge when a column form failed, said a spokeswoman for the State Transportation Department. Two of the bridge’s four lanes opened May 17, replacing a bridge that Hurricane Katrina destroyed. The bridge connects Bay St. Louis with Pass Christian to the east.

8 P.M. (TCM) NANCY DREW, DETECTIVE (1938) The latest version of the famous girl detective may be released in theaters today, but Emma Roberts won’t be the first to play the young crime solver. Turner Classic Movies runs a minimarathon tonight of films starring Bonita Granville, above at center, as Nancy Drew. In the first installment there’s a whole lot of kidnapping going on when an elderly woman who was supposed to deliver a check to Nancy’s father disappears. Nancy solves the campy caper, but only after she and her best friend are, of course, kidnapped themselves. The tribute continues at 9:15 p.m. with “Nancy Drew ... Reporter” (1939). At 10:30 Nancy comes to the aid of a family friend who is accused of murder in “Nancy Drew ... Trouble Shooter” (1939), followed at 11:45 by “Nancy Drew and the Hidden Staircase” (1939).

An article last Friday about second-home developments for amateur astronomers misstated the surname of a resident of Arizona Sky Village. He is Bob Sandine, not Kitzman. The article also misstated the name of the Connecticut town where he and his wife, Dr. Irene Kitzman, have their primary residence. It is Hamden, not New Hamden.

The Havens column on June 8 about Milford, Pa., misstated the occupation of the first owner of Grey Towers, an estate open to the public for part of the year. James Pinchot was a wallpaper merchant whose family was in the lumber business; he was not a local timber baron. (The estate was later used primarily as a summer home by his son Gifford.).

A Republican senator blocked a vote in the Judiciary Committee on whether to authorize subpoenas to the Justice Department to obtain secret legal opinions and other documents related to the National Security Agency's program of domestic eavesdropping. The action by Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona will block the vote for a week. After the vote next Thursday, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the committee, can decide whether to issue the subpoenas or use them as leverage in negotiations with the Bush administration over access to the documents. JAMES RISEN

An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about sperm cells misstated one dimension of such cells. The head of a mature sperm cell measures about 5 microns, or two ten-thousandths of an inch, not two-thousandths of an inch.

Equilibres Matthew Marks Gallery 523 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through June 30 Books, Editions and the Like Swiss Institute 495 Broadway, near Broome Street, SoHo Through July 14 The Swiss team of Peter Fischli and David Weiss have been on the job for more than 30 years, making art, making jokes and above all making do with whatever comes their way or catches their interest. In love with the facts, laws and randomness of existence, they have shown that resolute pursuit of the Duchampian/Johnsian ideal of using anything and inventing nothing leaves art at least as wide open as life itself.

To the Editor: In ''A Spectrum of Disputes'' (Op-Ed, June 11), Paul T. Shattuck and Maureen Durkin suggest that we cannot prove that there is an autism epidemic. This reminds me of the argument for the last 20 years that there was no ''proof'' of global warming.

Frank Bensel, an assistant club professional at Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., spent his opening nine holes on the leader board of the championship, only to see his round disintegrate in a maze of mistakes. Bensel shot even-par 35 on his opening nine. He closed with a nine-over 44 that left him numb.

Sweet Affliction Massimo Audiello 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through June 23 Alison Brady's strange photographs, seen here in her first solo show, seem to pick up where the sweetly kinky setup images of Jimmy DeSana (1949-1990) left off: not a bad place to start. But where Mr. DeSana's exploration of the body as sexual, abject and sculptural emphasized androgyny, Ms. Brady's work deals rather explicitly and hilariously with the female predicament.

HIGHER YIELDS TO HIT HOMEOWNERS The fallout from the increasing yields on the 10-year Treasury note -- a benchmark that influences many long-term interest rates, including home mortgages -- is likely to be widespread, and felt most immediately by homeowners and people looking to purchase a house. [Page A1.] MORTGAGE PROBLEMS PERSIST Delinquencies and foreclosures among homeowners with weak credit moved higher in the first quarter, but an industry report suggested that the problems have not extended into the larger pool of borrowers with stronger credit. [C1.] A TOLL ON WALL STREET The meltdown in the subprime housing market may be taking a toll on Wall Street firms. Goldman Sachs reported that profits were flat from a year ago, due to a weak mortgage market. And Bear Stearns reported a 10 percent drop in net income, excluding a one-time charge, also largely a result of the tepid mortgage market. [C7.] HANDOUTS FOR THE SUCCESSFUL A golf resort on the windy coast of Oregon benefits from a variety of state and local subsidies, the kind of indirect favors that influence the flow of money from the public to private interests and often serve to reinforce benefits for those who are already successful. [C1.] TAXES ON PUBLIC HEDGE FUNDS Two senators introduced legislation that could significantly increase taxes on publicly traded private equity firms and hedge funds, a move that could dampen interest as the Blackstone Group, the giant private equity firm, continues marketing its initial public offering to potential investors. [C1.] BOOM FOR VENEZUELAN BANKS President Hugo Chávez repeatedly vows to do away with capitalism in Venezuela. But it turns out that Mr. Chávez's economic policies have been generating a boom for those most capitalist of institutions -- Venezuela's banks. [C1.] THOMAS THE TANK ENGINE RECALL The toy maker RC2 Corporation pulled a number of its Thomas & Friends trains and accessory parts off the shelves after learning the red and yellow paint used to decorate more than 1.5 million of the toys contained lead. [C3.] PRICE INCREASES ARE MODERATED A double-digit jump in gasoline prices pushed up inflation at the wholesale level in May, but tame increases for most other goods suggested that price increases were largely contained and businesses would not react by raising prices. [C2.] DEMOCRATS PUT OFF ENERGY BILL Senate Democrats, facing their first significant battle over a wide-ranging bill aimed at reducing oil consumption, found themselves blocked by a Republican threat of a filibuster, and postponed all significant votes until next week. [A23.] LENDERS' TIES TO UNIVERSITIES Gifts and payoffs to universities and their officials by student lenders were far more pervasive than has been disclosed, and in some cases were demanded by university officials themselves in exchange for promoting lenders to students, according to a Senate report on the student loan industry. [A21.] CHINESE AUTOMAKER IN MEXICO A small Chinese automaker and its New Jersey partner are negotiating with Mexican officials to import Chinese-made pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, the first step toward building an assembly plant in Tijuana that could export vehicles to the United States. [C9.] TALKS TO BUY INDIAN AIRLINE An Indian tycoon, Vijay Mallya, is in talks to acquire a stake in SpiceJet, a publicly traded Indian airline backed by a Dubai investment fund and a group of investment banks. Mr. Mallya, left, is chairman of the UB Group, an airline and liquor conglomerate, and he also owns Kingfisher Airlines. Acquisition of SpiceJet would likely speed up consolidation in the money-losing Indian airline business. [C9.] HOT STOCK MARKETS IN INDIA India's stock markets are on a roll, surpassing even the rosiest forecasts, in part because of a young, wealthy, expanding middle class banking on India's aggressive corporate growth. [C4.] ROBOT CAR'S LATEST MODEL The team of Stanford University engineers that won $2 million in a Pentagon-sponsored robot car contest in 2005 unveiled its next-generation vehicle, which will maneuver in traffic without a human driver. [C3.] S.E.C. CHARGES LAWYERS The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit against two lawyers, one a former enforcement lawyer for the commission, charging that they had played important roles in a penny stock fraud that cost investors at least $160,000 in 2005.
