There's a lovely thing one can still do in parts of Buddhist Asia. You get up before dawn to buy food at the market. Then you line up with the villagers at the side of the road, taking care to remove your shoes. As the sun rises, a procession of monks in their brilliant orange robes emerges silently from around a corner. Each carries as a tub which the villagers --and you, if you wish -- fill with handfuls of fruit, sweets or rice as offerings.

We begin our news summary this morning with an issue that has definitely exercised Caucus readers. Adam Nagourney posted on the backstory of a memo, released "without attribution" by Senator Barack Obama's campaign but ultimately procured and re-released by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign, which included critical analyses of her finances. Today, The Times's Jeff Zeleny steps back to examine how this and other wrinkles affect the sheen on Mr. Obama's "new kind of politics."

Launching this week, Grand Harbor Grenada is one of several top-end resort projects underway on this Caribbean island. Located within the naturally protected bay of Egmont Point, one of the most attractive features of this resort are the private moorings available to owners. The 26 slips are available to owners on an annual lease basis and will accommodate boats of up to 60 feet.
It's looking more and more like that 10-second blackout at the end of "The Sopranos" was the dark silence inside Tony's capo.
Tiger Woods began the third round of the U.S. Open five shots off the lead. On Saturday, however, he moved into second place, shooting a one-under 69.
Couples line up at Queens Borough Hall every Friday   to tie the knot.
The Americans should have had a comfortable task of seeing off a weak opponent.  But poor finishing and farcical defending allowed Panama to make it more difficult for the United States.
Nobody will confuse the town of Buffalo, the setting for “Confessions of a Matchmaker,” tonight on A&E, with Hollywood, Manhattan or the castle on “The Bachelor.”
The Brogans of “Meadowlands,” a new series on Showtime, are a family in hiding, but it is the show’s prevailing philosophy that corrupt souls cannot mingle among us.
Two former undercover detectives in their early 40s look to one another as they confront serious illness in the wake of 9/11.
There was a time when movies like “DOA: Dead or Alive” lurked sheepishly at schoolboy height on video store shelves, spines straining to accommodate the charms of their actresses.
“Jhoom Barabar Jhoom” is a giddy romantic comedy with star power, wanderlust and a charming can-do, why-not-the-kitchen-sink spirit.
Farooq Kathwari, chief executive of Ethan Allen, discussed the international influence reflected in the company.
A panel ruled that Michael B. Nifong must be disbarred for ethical violations during his prosecution of a sexual assault case against three Duke lacrosse players.
José Reyes, Carlos Gómez and Oliver Pérez displayed the type of stellar play on Friday that the Mets had been sorely lacking.
The moves by Fatah seemed to solidify the split between Palestinians, and raised the risk of violence spreading to the occupied West Bank.
The blast suggested that Shiite militias south of Baghdad have rejected calls for restraint from leaders.
After the bombing, U.S. soldiers fired into a crowd near the scene, accidentally killing a man, the military said.
The Mets scored first for the seventh consecutive game, and this time their pitching held the lead until the end.
Candice Dupree had 24 points and 13 rebounds for the Sky, as the team matched its win total from a year ago.
Oliver Perez limited the Yankees to five hits in 7 1/3 innings to lift the Mets in the opener of the season’s second Subway Series.
Five soccer players for Haiti’s World Cup-bound youth team who mysteriously disappeared during a stopover in New York returned home, the government said.
The companies that insure a majority of Protestant churches say they receive upward of 260 reports a year of children being sexually abused by church personnel.
An organization of restaurants sued New York City, asking a court to outlaw a regulation that would require the listing of calorie counts on menu boards.

A man who killed six relatives and left their bodies in the basement while he partied and shopped pleaded guilty to murder and said he was praying for forgiveness. The man, Jesse D. Wise, 22, was sentenced to life in prison without parole. He avoided the possibility of execution, prosecutors said, because other family members asked the authorities not to seek it. Prosecutors said Mr. Wise fatally beat and stabbed his grandmother, two aunts, two cousins and an uncle over four days in April 2006 and hid their bodies in the basement while continuing to spend time in the home the family shared in Leola.

An Arkansas legislative panel passed a resolution expressing “profound regret” for the state’s role in slavery, following the lead of other Southern states. The panel, the Arkansas Legislative Council, which oversees legislative matters between sessions, approved an interim resolution asking forgiveness for the “wrongs inflicted by slavery and its after-effects.” The Legislature met in regular session earlier this year. Unless called into special session, it will not meet again until January 2009. “The last thing I want to see is for my children to have textbooks say that all Southern states that played in a role in slavery apologized except for Arkansas,” said Representative Steve Harrelson, Democrat of Texarkana, who co-sponsored the resolution.
Four dead dolphins have washed ashore with fatal bullet wounds and a fifth with lacerations on its pectoral fin, the authorities said.

A 5-year-old girl who was feared drowned with her grandfather on a boating trip startled searchers when she emerged from the woods — naked, scratched and holding mulberries. Crews had pulled her grandfather’s body from the Kankakee River in eastern Illinois hours earlier. The girl, Hannah Klamecki, who was dirty but unhurt, was taken to a hospital as a precaution. Hannah and her grandfather, David Klamecki, 62, were last seen Wednesday evening on the river near Momence, about 45 miles south of Chicago. The authorities believe the current swept the girl away from a small island where she and her grandfather had stopped to swim and to the shore of the mainland where she was found. She told searchers she had been wearing floats on her arms and pulled herself from the water with a branch. Hannah told her mother that she had taken off her bathing suit because it was muddy, the authorities said.
Sammy Sosa hit a grand slam for his 599th career home run last night and took another little hop toward history while leading the Texas Rangers to a 7-6 victory against the Cincinnati Reds.
Prior to Friday’s game against the Yankees, Mets Manager Willie Randolph  did not deny that he had moved Carlos Beltrán to second in the batting order as some sort of energy infusion.

An article on June 9 about preparations for President Bush’s visit to Albania misstated the position of Bernard Kouchner, the new foreign minister of France, before the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003. Although he advocated removing Saddam Hussein from power with pressure from Europe, the United States and other countries through the United Nations, backed by a continuing military buildup, he did not support the war.
This week’s dispute over State Attorney General Stuart J. Rabner, the nominee for chief justice of the State Supreme Court, was curious even for New Jersey politics.

A report on theater news in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday included incorrect information from the Godlight Theater Company about its plans to present a stage adaptation of Kurt Vonnegut’s “Slaughterhouse-Five” at 59E59 Theaters. It might be presented there this winter or next spring; it is not scheduled for September.

A sports article yesterday about two lawyers indicted in Kentucky on federal charges of conspiring to defraud clients in a $200 million lawsuit settlement with the maker of the diet drug fen-phen omitted the name of a third lawyer who was indicted. Melbourne Mills Jr. was also charged — but unlike the other two, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and William J. Gallion, he was not a part-owner of the Preakness champion Curlin. (Unaware of the sports article, the editors of the National Briefing column ran another one that omitted the lawyers’ horse-owning backgrounds.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a decision by the National Trust for Historic Preservation to declare Brooklyn’s industrial waterfront one of the country’s most endangered historic places misstated the nature of the roofing at the Domino Sugar Refinery in Williamsburg, which is within the area. None of the buildings are topped by a dome; the Revere Sugar Factory in Red Hook, which has been mostly demolished, had a dome.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about Accordionology, a festival this weekend at Barbès in Park Slope, Brooklyn, misidentified the bass player shown in the accompanying picture. He is Trevor Dunn, not Drew Gress. The entry also misidentified the title of the new album by Will Holshouser, who is playing in the festival. It is “Singing to a Bee,” not “Reed Song,” which was an earlier recording.

An article on May 25 about the influence of the war in Iraq on this year’s graduating class at the United States Military Academy referred incorrectly to Brig. Gen. William B. Kunzig Jr. of Minneapolis, an alumnus who was on campus for the annual alumni review. General Kunzig, 97, class of 1932, was the oldest living graduate at the ceremony, not the oldest living graduate of West Point. (According to the academy, that title belongs to Benjamin Whitehouse, 104, a retired colonel from Brewster, Mass., who graduated in 1927.).

A sports article yesterday about Justin Strzelczyk, a former National Football League player who was found post-mortem to have had early signs of brain damage that experts said was most likely caused by football concussions, misidentified the medical institution where Bennet Omalu, the doctor who made the diagnosis, is a clinical instructor of neuropathology. It is the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, not the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.
Corrections

A report in the Metro Briefing column on June 8 gave the wrong date in some copies for the start of audio podcasts on the New York Police Department’s Web site. The podcasts began in September 2005, not last November.

An obituary on Tuesday about Amy Sullivan, a former executive director of the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., misstated the history of the National Theater Institute, a program of the center, and referred incorrectly to it. The institute was founded in 1970, more than 30 years before Ms. Sullivan became executive director at the center. She did not create it, and it is not a summer program. She added a summer session.

Colombia is set to become the first Latin American country to give established gay couples the same rights to health insurance, inheritance and social security benefits as heterosexual couples under a bill passed by Congress and expected to take effect soon. Some states and cities in Latin America, among them Mexico City and Buenos Aires, have passed similar laws, but no other country in the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic region has done so at a national level, said Marcela Sánchez of the gay rights group Colombia Diversa. Congress’s lower house passed the bill, 62 to 43, late Thursday. The Senate passed a similar version in April. The two chambers must now agree on a unified text before sending it to President Álvaro Uribe, who backs it.

A senior adviser to President Vladimir V. Putin, Igor I. Shuvalov, added new intrigue to the question of who might succeed Mr. Putin when he steps down next year. Mr. Shuvalov, in remarks widely reported in Russia, told a conference at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington on Thursday that Mr. Putin might yet turn to someone other than one of the two aides routinely touted as his most likely successor: Sergei B. Ivanov and Dmitri A. Medvedev. “People talk about two candidates, possible candidates,” he said, according to the center, “but, you know, my president could trade another surprise, and maybe even late during this year you will know about another possible figure.” His remarks revived speculation in Russia about other political figures close to Mr. Putin who might yet emerge. Mr. Shuvalov emphasized that Mr. Putin intended to step down, saying he did not want Russia to follow other post-Soviet states, like Belarus and Turkmenistan, whose leaders changed their constitutions to retain authoritarian power.

In an effort to conserve energy, the government has urged office workers to abandon business suits in favor of T-shirts and other informal wear. The message was delivered in a week when air-conditioning in many government offices was turned off and inspectors sent to hotels and office buildings in Beijing to enforce new temperature guidelines.

The head of an investigation into the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, David A. Brown, said in a report that the force’s management and operations structure was “horribly broken.” Mr. Brown, the former head of the Ontario Securities Commission, was asked by the government to examine how the force had handled allegations that money was misspent by administrators of the pension and insurance fund. He concluded that officers who raised questions had been punished, that those responsible were not held to account and that an ostensibly independent investigation by Ottawa’s municipal police force, which found no wrongdoing, was effectively guided by the Mounties. He was particularly critical of the “autocratic leadership style” of the Mounties’ former commissioner, Giuliano Zaccardelli. Mr. Zaccardelli resigned this year after retracting some of his parliamentary testimony about the case of Maher Arar, the Canadian citizen deported to Syria by the United States after the Mounties provided erroneous information suggesting that he was a terrorism suspect.

A roadside bomb exploded near a vehicle carrying soldiers to the site of a gun battle between other soldiers and suspected Muslim insurgents in southern Yala Province. The explosion killed some soldiers instantly, and an unknown number of assailants then opened fire, leaving a total of seven soldiers dead. Soldiers are increasingly falling victim to roadside ambushes in the mainly Muslim south.

Switzerland opened the 21.5-mile Lötschberg Tunnel beneath the Alps, the world’s longest railway land tunnel and part of the country’s plan to shift freight traffic off the roads and speed up passenger transportation. It joins Frutigen near the capital, Bern, in the north with Raron in the Rhône Valley to the south, cutting travel time for trains crossing from Germany to Italy by about 90 minutes and bringing skiers to resorts like Zermatt more quickly.
Derek Jeter had a chance for some authentic, inside information about how another major league team planned to pitch him. Yet the Yankees’ shortstop didn’t want to listen.
At a disciplinary hearing, Michael B. Nifong apologized to three lacrosse players and their families.

The City Council unanimously approved a $59 billion spending package for the city on Friday.
A contractor was shot and critically wounded early Friday as he walked out of his house in the Whitestone section of Queens.
New Web sites have helped fuel the rampant mortgage fraud that has caused a huge spike in loan defaults.
A tax law quirk allows private equity firms to operate as partnerships and to pay lower tax rates than corporations.

A Dutch soldier was among the dead after the bombing near a NATO convoy in southern Afghanistan. Seven Afghan civilians and three Dutch soldiers were wounded.

7:15 P.M. (HBO) THE MUSIC IN ME: A FAMILY SPECIAL A bevy of young musicians from around the country, two of whom are pictured above, demonstrate the various cultural traditions they’re carrying on. The six featured in this special include an 11-year-old tin-whistle player, a 10-year-old mariachi singer and guitar player, and an 11-year-old classical composer. And two young girls discuss how playing the piano helped them survive cancer.

A sports article yesterday about two lawyers indicted in Kentucky on federal charges of conspiring to defraud clients in a $200 million lawsuit settlement with the maker of the diet drug fen-phen omitted the name of a third lawyer who was indicted. Melbourne Mills Jr. was also charged -- but unlike the other two, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and William J. Gallion, he was not a part-owner of the Preakness champion Curlin. (Unaware of the sports article, the editors of the National Briefing column ran another one that omitted the lawyers' horse-owning backgrounds.)

GELLMAN--Jerome I., 79, on June 14 of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, former longtime resident of Scarsdale, New York. Mourned by Florence, his wife of 55 years. Loving father of Elyse (Bill), Stephen (Wendy) and Ken (Melissa). Joyful and doting grandfather of Amanda, Lindsay, David, Alexa, Reese, Paige and Nathan. Devoted brother to Elaine and Melvin. Partner in Tucker, Gellman & Mulderig. Of Counsel to Cowan, Liebowitz and Latman. A man of great warmth, charm and humor. His family and friends will miss him dearly. Funeral on June 18, 2007, at 12:00 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY.

To the Editor: Atul Gawande's superb May 31 column, ''The Obama Health Plan,'' highlights correctable deficiencies in United States health care delivery and the need for political leadership as well as wisdom to correct them.

''Lil' Bush,'' Comedy Central's new animated political satire, had a solid debut on Wednesday, placing among the five most-watched series premieres in the channel's history and the best since ''Drawn Together'' in 2004. Nielsen Media Research reported that 2.1 million total viewers tuned in for the show at 10:30 p.m., just over half of them in the demographic of adults 18 to 49 (1.2 million). Also on cable at 10 p.m. on Wednesday, the third-season premiere of Bravo's ''Top Chef'' attracted 2 million viewers, an 8 percent increase over its second-season debut. And the fourth-season premiere of FX's ''Rescue Me,'' with Denis Leary, drew 2.8 million viewers, a decline of 18 percent from the show's third-season start. According to FX, those numbers are likely to rise considerably when DVR playback data is available in three weeks. On network television Thursday, Nielsen's estimates show that Fox easily led overall with ''Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?'' at 8 (9.9 million) and ''So You Think You Can Dance'' at 9 (10.6 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

The European Union extended firm support to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Friday and said it would continue humanitarian and financial aid in the Palestinian territories despite Hamas's seizure of control in Gaza. Calling Mr. Abbas ''the legitimate president of all Palestinians,'' the union's external relations commissioner, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, condemned the violence and called for national unity and reconciliation.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about Accordionology, a festival this weekend at Barbès in Park Slope, Brooklyn, misidentified the bass player shown in the accompanying picture. He is Trevor Dunn, not Drew Gress. The entry also misidentified the title of the new album by Will Holshouser, who is playing in the festival. It is ''Singing to a Bee,'' not ''Reed Song,'' which was an earlier recording.

The San Antonio Spurs' sweep of the Cleveland Cavaliers produced the N.B.A.'s least-viewed championship, with an average of 9.2 million viewers, as measured by Nielsen Media Research. The previous low, almost 9.9 million, was in 2003 when the Spurs defeated the Nets. Game 4 on Thursday night, won by the Spurs, 83-82, attracted 9.8 million viewers, the most for the series. But that was down 16 percent from the comparable game in the Dallas-Miami series last year. The Spurs-Cavaliers attracted less than half the highest-average viewership for the finals this decade -- the 18.9 million who tuned in to see the Los Angeles Lakers beat Philadelphia in five games in 2001.

Borrowing costs are on the march higher as a big sell-off in the bond market this week sent yields on Treasury notes and bonds to a five-year high. Homeowners and home buyers shopping for a mortgage are likely to feel the pain of the rising rates first and most intensely. The national average rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage jumped to 6.74 percent, up from 6.53 percent in early June.
To the Editor: In ''The Boy in the Coffin'' (column, June 9), Timothy Egan makes a fair point in calling a child's late teenage years ''the most hazardous time of their lives.''

''It has become increasingly apparent, during the course of this week, in some ways that it might not have been before, that my presence as the district attorney in Durham is not furthering the cause of justice.'' MICHAEL B. NIFONG, district attorney of Durham County, N.C., announcing that he will resign over his handling of sexual assault accusations against three former Duke University lacrosse players. [A1]

Roger Clemens could have been in Boston, in a matchup for the aged, going after Barry Bonds and the Giants with his best friend of his athletic old age, the pitch he calls Mr. Splitty. He could have had a pleasant, commuter-friendly night in Houston after facing the Mariners. But who more than Clemens knows that there is no fiercer and famous interleague baseball than the version played in New York, New York? Clemens is a man who lives unapologetically large, who consumes attention the way his beloved Hummers guzzle gas, whose competitive ego was made for the kind of seductions the Yankees do best. We may have kidded ourselves into thinking there was a serious, three-team competition for his partial-season services, but Willie Randolph didn't.

Consumers cast a worried eye on the bond market as mortgage rates rose, while investors rode a bullish wave to end the week. Blackstone's founders were poised for a big payoff as they prepared for an initial offering.

Shortly before Barry Bonds of the Giants played his first game at Fenway Park on Friday night, he answered many questions with platitudes. But he responded to one directly and forcefully. Would it be important to play in the All-Star Game on July 10 in San Francisco, two weeks before his 43rd birthday?

An obituary on Monday about the philosopher Richard Rorty misidentified the source of the quotation, ''There is no basis for deciding what counts as knowledge and truth other than what one's peers will let one get away with in the open exchange of claims, counterclaims and reasons.'' It was from Charles Guignon and David R. Hiley in the introduction to the book ''Richard Rorty,'' which they edited; it was not from Mr. Rorty.

If Bubba Watson were to win the United States Open, he would become the first Bubba in 107 years to do so. ''I made the cut,'' said Watson, a big-hitting left-hander from the Florida Panhandle. ''If making the cut is a Cinderella story, yeah, I did that.''

Many American food products are a mix of global ingredients, as foreign supplies often offer a cheaper alternative to those made in the United States. While the source of ingredients is typically kept private by companies, Sara Lee revealed the supplying countries for its new whole grain white bread. Nearly a third of the list came from foreign sources, meaning Sara Lee, along with many large food companies, faces the increasing task of ensuring that foreign suppliers meet the best possible safety standards. AMY SCHOENFELD

A sports article yesterday about Justin Strzelczyk, a former National Football League player who was found post-mortem to have had early signs of brain damage that experts said was most likely caused by football concussions, misidentified the medical institution where Bennet Omalu, the doctor who made the diagnosis, is a clinical instructor of neuropathology. It is the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, not the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a decision by the National Trust for Historic Preservation to declare Brooklyn's industrial waterfront one of the country's most endangered historic places misstated the nature of the roofing at the Domino Sugar Refinery in Williamsburg, which is within the area. None of the buildings are topped by a dome; the Revere Sugar Factory in Red Hook, which has been mostly demolished, had a dome.

The Blackstone Group, one of the world's largest private equity firms, is getting ready to go public and its co-founders, Steve Schwarzman and Peter Peterson, are getting ready to cash in on the company they founded 22 years ago with $400,000. Mr. Schwarzman, 60, will take home as much as $677.2 million, while his remaining 24 percent stake will be worth $7.5 billion if the deal is priced at $30, the middle of the range set by underwriters. (If it goes higher, he will be worth even more.)

To the Editor: ''Newspapers Trimming Classical Critics'' (Arts pages, June 9) is prompted by position eliminations or reductions in cultural reporting in major cities like Minneapolis-St. Paul, Atlanta and New York.

What's next, Marshmallow Fluff? The Kellogg Company announced that it would stop advertising some of its most popular products to children under the age of 12 unless the foods met new nutrition guidelines, such as having no more than 12 grams of sugar per serving. The new directive, which will be phased in over the next year and a half, affects some of the company's most popular products among children, including Froot Loops, Rice Krispies and Pop-Tarts.

Clarkson Cancels Tour Kelly Clarkson, the 2002 ''American Idol'' winner, has canceled her summer tour because of disappointing ticket sales, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The cancellation comes as Ms. Clarkson, right, is preparing to release her third album, ''My December,'' due out on June 26. She had been expected to kick off the tour with her performance at the Live Earth concert July 7 in East Rutherford, N.J., and conclude it in Phoenix. Her part in the international Live Earth event is now expected to be her only summer performance. Rollins Returns The veteran tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins, below, announced yesterday that he would perform at Carnegie Hall on Sept. 18, in commemoration of the 50th anniversary of his first performance there, when he shared the bill with Billie Holiday, Ray Charles and the Thelonious Monk Quartet featuring John Coltrane. Mr. Rollins, 76, will play the three songs he played half a century ago -- ''Moritat,'' ''Sonnymoon for Two'' and ''Some Enchanted Evening'' -- when his sidemen were the bassist Wendell Marshall and the drummer Kenny Dennis. This time, he will play the songs with Roy Haynes on drums and Christian McBride on bass. Spice Girls Redux? Mel C, the singer known as Sporty Spice who had long opposed a reunion of the Spice Girls, has changed her mind, The Associated Press reported, giving hope to those who want to see the girl group, which broke up in 2001, onstage once more. ''For the first time ever, there is some truth in the rumors,'' Mel C, 33, whose real name is Melanie Chisholm and who now bills herself as Melanie C, told BBC Radio. ''We've been discussing it and it could possibly happen.'' She added that if the Spice Girls reunite, it would be for only a brief time, as ''a final goodbye and a thank-you to all the fans all over the world.'' More Troubles for Lohan Lindsay Lohan, who recently checked herself into a substance abuse rehabilitation facility, is being sued by a Los Angeles man who alleges that the actress crashed her car into his van almost two years ago while she was under the influence of alcohol. The lawsuit by Raymundo Ortega also names the Ivy, a fashionable Los Angeles restaurant, as a defendant, saying the establishment served Ms. Lohan alcohol even though she was under age. The authorities have said that Ms. Lohan did not appear to be responsible for the crash, in Beverly Hills in October 2005. The Show Rolls On The producers of ''Xanadu,'' the Douglas Carter Beane musical based on the campy 1980 film, have announced a replacement for James Carpinello, who was forced to step aside after suffering a foot injury. Cheyenne Jackson will don the roller skates of Sonny, the leading male role, starting Friday. Mr. Jackson, who wore a pair of blue suede boots as the Elvis-like character in the musical ''All Shook Up,'' had played Sonny in earlier versions of the show. Now in previews at the Helen Hayes Theater, ''Xanadu'' was originally scheduled to open on June 26; a new opening date will be announced early next week. Sony Says 'Sorry' The Sony Corporation apologized yesterday to the Church of England for a computer game that features a bloody shootout inside an Anglican cathedral, The Associated Press reported. The church had demanded withdrawal of Resistance: Fall of Man, which includes a gun battle between a soldier and aliens inside a building that resembles Manchester Cathedral in northwest England. ''It was not our intention to cause offense by using a representation of Manchester Cathedral,'' said the letter to the Very Rev. Rogers Govender, dean of the cathedral. ''If we have done so, we sincerely apologize.'' A Sony spokesman said the letter included the offer of a meeting with church officials, which Dean Govender said the cathedral would accept. But he underlined the church's opposition to ''the gun violence seen in this portrayal of the cathedral.'' The church was particularly concerned because Manchester has a history of gang-related gun violence. In its letter, Sony said it did not accept any connection between the game and social issues in contemporary Manchester. Footnotes The national tour of the musical ''Spring Awakening,'' which won eight Tony Awards this year including best musical, will begin at the Curran Theater in San Francisco in the fall of 2008, Playbill reported Thursday. The production will be directed by Carole Shorenstein Hays. John Lithgow, below, will make his Royal Shakespeare Company debut in ''Twelfth Night'' in September, the BBC reported yesterday. Mr. Lithgow will play the part of Malvolio in the production, to be staged at the Courtyard Theater in Stratford-on-Avon. The Israeli historian Saul Friedlander will receive the top prize of the annual Frankfurt Book Fair for his narratives documenting the Holocaust, the German Book Trade association said on Thursday. Mr. Friedlander, 74, a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, is to be given the $33,000 peace prize during the annual book fair, Europe's largest, in October. Among his best-known works are the two-volume collection ''Nazi Germany and the Jews.'' Previous winners of the award include the Turkish author and Nobel laureate Orhan Pamuk and the former Czech president Vaclav Havel.

To the Editor: Your June 8 editorial ''The Shame of the Cherokee Nation'' accurately addresses the Freedmen's plight. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. proclaimed in his ''I have a dream'' speech that the Emancipation Proclamation ''came as a great beacon light of hope to millions of Negro slaves who had been seared in the flames of withering injustice.''

INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Rice and Hawks in Debate Over Iran, Officials Say A behind-the-scenes debate has pitted Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and her deputies against the Bush administration's few remaining hawks over whether the state department strategy has any hope of reining in Iran's nuclear program, according to officials. A1 Deferral of Palestine Statehood With the violence in Gaza City largely over, people worried not only about daily survival but also about how the round of deadly infighting, which killed a reported 116 people, postponed hope for an independent and unified Palestinian state. A1 Dozens of armed and uniformed members of the various security forces loyal to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, gathered in Ramallah's central Manara Square in a show of force. A7 The European Union extended firm support to Mr. Abbas and said it would continue aid to the Palestinian territories despite Hamas's seizure of control in Gaza. A7 Sunni Mosque Bombed in Iraq The bombing of a Sunni Arab mosque near Basra appeared to signal that the cycle of reprisals after the bombing of a Shiite shrine in Samarra had not entirely ended. Nifong of Durham County, N.C., announced his resignation as he faces disciplinary charges for his handling of a sexual assault prosecution against three former Duke University lacrosse players. A1 House Approves Security Bill The House approved spending of $37.4 billion next year by the Department of Homeland Security, calling for more spending than proposed by the Bush administration, including hundreds of millions in extra state and antiterrorism grants. A11 Acknowledging that the nation remains too vulnerable to terrorist attack by small planes and recreational boats, the Department of Homeland Security is considering new requirements to allow authorities to identify operators and passengers in millions of these vehicles as they ply the coasts and skies. A11 More Schools Use Mindfulness Mindfulness, a stress-reducing technique, while common in hospitals, corporations, professional sports and even prisons, is relatively new in the education of squirming children. But a small but growing number of schools are slowly embracing the concept. To the Editor: Re ''Palestinians at War'' (editorial, June 15): In its brutal, planned coup, Hamas has at once demonstrated its disdain for Fatah, truces, the rule of law and the disregard it has for the welfare of the Palestinian people. Yet you somehow believe that making more positive overtures can be an effective strategy for addressing the current situation.

A report on theater news in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday included incorrect information from the Godlight Theater Company about its plans to present a stage adaptation of Kurt Vonnegut's ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' at 59E59 Theaters. It might be presented there this winter or next spring; it is not scheduled for September.

Hopes were dashed for a big breakthrough in obesity treatment. In bad news for both the French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis and overweight Americans, a federal panel questioned the safety of a proposed new obesity pill. It appears that the Food and Drug Administration will not clear the pill, Zimulti, for sale in the United States. Zimulti helps people lose 5 percent of their weight, but with a downside. It also seems to bring on emotional problems, including suicidal thoughts, in a population already at high risk for depression: the obese.

To the Editor: Re ''The Divide in Caring for Our Kids,'' by Bob Herbert (column, June 12): The daily suffering by millions of American children from ordinary tooth decay is avoidable. Cavities can be prevented using cost-effective measures already available. Prevention and timely treatment save money and improve children's lives.

A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Wednesday, about complications surrounding David Beckham's arrival in the United States to play with the Los Angeles Galaxy, misstated the location of a game scheduled for Oct. 18 between the Galaxy and the Red Bulls that Beckham might miss. It will be in Los Angeles, not at Giants Stadium. (The teams will play on Aug. 18 at Giants Stadium.)

A senior adviser to President Vladimir V. Putin, Igor I. Shuvalov, added new intrigue to the question of who might succeed Mr. Putin when he steps down next year. Mr. Shuvalov, in remarks widely reported in Russia, told a conference at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington on Thursday that Mr. Putin might yet turn to someone other than one of the two aides routinely touted as his most likely successor: Sergei B. Ivanov and Dmitri A. Medvedev. ''People talk about two candidates, possible candidates,'' he said, according to the center, ''but, you know, my president could trade another surprise, and maybe even late during this year you will know about another possible figure.'' His remarks revived speculation in Russia about other political figures close to Mr. Putin who might yet emerge. Mr. Shuvalov emphasized that Mr. Putin intended to step down, saying he did not want Russia to follow other post-Soviet states, like Belarus and Turkmenistan, whose leaders changed their constitutions to retain authoritarian power. STEVEN LEE MYERS

To the Editor: Re ''The Guidebook for Taking a Life'' (Week in Review, June 10): The collateral martyrdom a suicide bomber is willing or anxious to inflict on the unsuspecting reflects a state of mind less religious than anarchistic.

An article on May 25 about the influence of the war in Iraq on this year's graduating class at the United States Military Academy referred incorrectly to Brig. Gen. William B. Kunzig Jr. of Minneapolis, an alumnus who was on campus for the annual alumni review. General Kunzig, 97, class of 1932, was the oldest living graduate at the ceremony, not the oldest living graduate of West Point. (According to the academy, that title belongs to Benjamin Whitehouse, 104, a retired colonel from Brewster, Mass., who graduated in 1927.)

The head of an investigation into the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, David A. Brown, said in a report that the force's management and operations structure was ''horribly broken.'' Mr. Brown, the former head of the Ontario Securities Commission, was asked by the government to examine how the force had handled allegations that money was misspent by administrators of the pension and insurance fund. He concluded that officers who raised questions had been punished, that those responsible were not held to account and that an ostensibly independent investigation by Ottawa's municipal police force, which found no wrongdoing, was effectively guided by the Mounties. He was particularly critical of the ''autocratic leadership style'' of the Mounties' former commissioner, Giuliano Zaccardelli. Mr. Zaccardelli resigned this year after retracting some of his parliamentary testimony about the case of Maher Arar, the Canadian citizen deported to Syria by the United States after the Mounties provided erroneous information suggesting that he was a terrorism suspect. IAN AUSTEN

KLIOT--Boris, age 84, born in Riga, Latvia was the only member of his family to survive the Latvian massacres of 1941. He survived four concentration camps and relocated to the United States after the war where he became a successful entrepreneur. As a founder, owner and CEO of Riviera Trading Corporation for over forty years, he was a retail visionary and pioneer in the accessory industry, setting many fashion trends in department chain stores through the United States and Canada. His success as a businessman allowed him to support a number of philanthropic causes. Boris will be forever remembered by his loved ones. He is survived by three sons: Michel with his mother Myra Sterling and his children Tamara and Josh, and Gene and Jason with their mother Jacqueline Kliot, Jason's wife Joana and their two children Hannah and Anton. Boris is also survived by his wife Josette Poux. Funeral Sunday at 11am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdan Avenue.

When the Englishman Paul Casey holed an 18-inch birdie putt at the ninth hole to complete his round of four-under-par 66, the golfers who were putting on the portion of the ninth green that is set aside for practice stopped what they were doing to applaud his effort. Casey had given the late starters an extraordinary target to shoot at. In the end, nobody came close to matching his score. The second-best round on Friday was Stephen Ames's 69.

An obituary on Tuesday about Amy Sullivan, a former executive director of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., misstated the history of the National Theater Institute, a program of the center, and referred incorrectly to it. The institute was founded in 1970, more than 30 years before Ms. Sullivan became executive director at the center. She did not create it, and it is not a summer program. She added a summer session.

WARNER--Stephen, 61, passed away on Thursday, June 14th, 2007. He will be missed and remembered with love by his wife Sena, his son David, his daughter and son-in-law Lindsey and Michael Bloomenthal, and his brother Dr. Robert Warner. He was a partner and active trial lawyer in the firm Warner Bernstein LLP. Services will be held Sunday, 10am at Riverside Chapel in Mount Vernon

In an effort to conserve energy, the government has urged office workers to abandon business suits in favor of T-shirts and other informal wear. The message was delivered in a week when air-conditioning in many government offices was turned off and inspectors sent to hotels and office buildings in Beijing to enforce new temperature guidelines. HOWARD W. FRENCH

Mets Manager Willie Randolph opened his pregame interview session with a response straight out of ''Sesame Street.'' Asked why Carlos Beltrán was moved up to hit second last night, Randolph said: ''His name starts with a B and it's the second letter in the alphabet. How do you like that?'' No, he was not serious, although that reasoning could also help to explain why Carlos Delgado returned to the cleanup spot.

To the Editor: Thanks and kudos to Maureen Dowd (''A Tale of Two Tonys, Exiting Tormented,'' column, June 13). Why the nerve of that Tony Blair, suggesting that the ''feral'' media ''hunts in a pack.'' And now, back to Paris Hilton. Al Lando Toronto, June 13, 2007

A sports article yesterday about two lawyers indicted in Kentucky on federal charges of conspiring to defraud clients in a $200 million lawsuit settlement with the maker of the diet drug fen-phen omitted the name of a third lawyer who was indicted. Melbourne Mills Jr. was also charged -- but unlike the other two, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and William J. Gallion, he was not a part-owner of the Preakness champion Curlin. (Unaware of the sports article, the editors of the National Briefing column ran another one that omitted the lawyers' horse-owning backgrounds.)

An article on June 9 about preparations for President Bush's visit to Albania misstated the position of Bernard Kouchner, the new foreign minister of France, before the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003. Although he advocated removing Saddam Hussein from power with pressure from Europe, the United States and other countries through the United Nations, backed by a continuing military buildup, he did not support the war.

To the Editor: Re ''Shelter Closes, Residents Move On and Fortunes Diverge'' (news article, June 12): Camp La Guardia was always a sad symbol of our city's failed strategy to deal with the systemic problems of homelessness. Its closing couldn't happen soon enough. And while shelter still remains a critical safety net, it's certainly no substitute for real, long-term solutions that address root causes.

APPLEBY--William. North Shore Country Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed former member William Appleby. We extended our deepest condolences to his family. N. Barry Ross, President Jeffrey Levy, Secretary $(6$)APPLEBY--William R., 92, passed away at home on June 14th. He is survived by his beloved wife Elinor, sons Peter, Richard, and John, by his daughter-in-law Stephanie Raia and his grandchildren Kyra, David, and Gabriel. He was treasured by his extended family including Jim, Susan, Chris, Nancy, Sarah, Eric, Breckin, and Frank Meyer. He is remembered as a loving husband to Elinor, and his late wife Gerda, a devoted father, and a doting grandfather. Billy was a lover of both the performing and fine arts, and a devoted supporter of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He lead a distinguished life and is remembered for his elegant style -never without a bowtie -and gentle nature. He will be missed dearly; may his memory be a blessing. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st, Sunday June 17th at 11:30am.
The Newark06 blog is no longer active.

Merit pay, or compensating teachers for classroom performance rather than their years on the job and coursework completed, found some support in the 1980s among policy makers and school administrators, who saw it as a way to encourage good teachers to work harder and to weed out the bad ones. But teachers saw it as a gimmick used by principals to reward cronies based on favoritism.
After more than a year, 1,909 posts and 11,000 reader comments (plus 91,771 blocked spam comments), The Empire Zone blog went on hiatus. But this is not a farewell to blogging.

While I was home convalescing in St. Pete, with my new dome, I did not do much of anything. I was still having serious problems with my sleeping and was going out to the local bars drinking excessively. My family would invite me and my wife out for family time and were told that I was not interested. My wife never even asked me if I wanted to go to any of these family functions. She seems to have been trying to separate me from my family.
The Yankees have been using Johnny Damon as their designated hitter lately, but they will not have a D.H. in the upcoming six-game road trip to Colorado and San Francisco.

Atheists like Sam Harris, Richard Dawkins and Christopher Hitchens believe (in Dawkins's words) that "there is nothing beyond the natural, physical world" and that "if there is something that appears to lie beyond the natural world, we hope eventually to understand it and embrace it within the natural."

Wire services in Italy and France report this evening in Italy that Gianfranco Ferre has died at the age of 62. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on Friday in Milan and was hospitalized. Ferre was for many years a leading designer in Milan, beginning his career in the mid 1970s after receiving a degree in architecture. There was always something over-the-top about Ferre's clothes-the white shirt collars always high and sculptural, the leather often laced and assertive, the coats swinging. I once began a review of a Ferre show, in the early 90s, with: "Diva, can you dig it?" His clothes had a great sexual energy, if you got your head into them, and I loved that he didn't seem to care a jot about trends and skinny models and so forth. His Dior period was not especially memorable, at least for me, and perhaps that's because he never seemed very happy there (living in the Plaza Athenee), and of course Dior in the early 90s was in transition, not the old style but not quite yet the new era of Galliano and Bernard Arnault.

That was an exceptional 24 Hours of Le Mans! The Audis bluffed their way through qualifying and suddenly as the race started, showed what they really had in the way of power and speed. Peugeot had no chance. So with a finish like this one, it's a little bit of a happy story for everyone:

Monday's column will be about the catastrophic warfare and chaos in Congo, told through a visit to a warlord (he calls himself "a liberator") in eastern Congo. I'm on satellite phone and not able to post much while in the Congo, but please post your comments below. You can also see the blogging of my companions for this trip, Will Okun and Leana Wen, at www.nytimes.com/twofortheroad.

Night racing in Formula One has been one of the big topics of the year, with the idea of doing a night race in Singapore or other circuits in Asia in order to bring the races closer to prime time in Europe, rather than having viewers have to wak up at between 4 and 8 in the morning to watch a race.
Leana Wen, who's traveling with Nick Kristof in Africa, reports on her visit to the mountain headquarters of a rebel leader in eastern Congo.

Tonight's the final installment of Subway Series 2007 (at least for the regular season). I'm sure the Mets are hoping for a better Father's Day outcome than this one from 1964. Fathers and sons at Dodger Stadium will be having fun today. Same goes for Fenway Park. What a great idea, a Father's Day catch at the ballpark.

When is a pain doctor a drug pusher? If you've read Tina Rosenberg's excellent article on Dr. Ronald McIver, you know the answer to that question posed on the cover of the Times Magazine: When a prosecutor and a few jurors think they know more about medicine than he does. It didn't matter that there was no evidence Dr. McIver intentionally dealt drugs -- he's serving a 30-year sentence for not meeting the jurors' standards of pain treatment.
Older actresses are finding a place on TV.
"We’ve just had the chance now to experience so many different environments, it’s been a real eye-opener."

Last night at dinner, we were joined by a young Italian woman who had been kidnapped and held hostage in Iraq, a story that received a good deal of world media attention. Less than 10 hours later in the Congo, Nick Kristof was advising Leana and me how to respond in case we were stopped by bandits or soldiers on our journey from the city of Goma to the mountains for an interview with "warlord" (media's words)/"liberator of my people" (his words) Laurent Nkunda. He is the leader of the Military Council for the Defense of the People, a rebel group that is amassing soldiers and arms in opposition to the current national government of Congo.
An exhibit in Stamford, Conn., called "Tossed and Found" features art made from castoff items.
Ángel Cabrera became the first player from Argentina to win the U.S. Open and the first to win a major since Roberto De Vicenzo won the British Open in 1967.
A breakdown of Palestinians of the West Bank and Palestinians of Gaza and the divisions within.
Steve Erlanger and Greg Winter discuss recent Palestinian violence.

As the head of timing and scoring for the Corvette Racing team, Melanie Correll never starts something she won't finish. This is especially true when it's the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Having worked for Corvette Racing since 2000, Correll records the lap times for every car, regardless of its category or whether it has been penalized or is headed down the pit lane behind her. She does this without breaks, catnaps or a single trip to the restroom. She is stationed in Corvette's pit stand on the main straightaway from beginning to end.
After 20 hours of racing -- and five fitful minutes of sleep for this bleary-eyed auto journalist -- the end of the 24 Hours of Le Mans is rapidly approaching.
Trabants, the rattletrap cars, have become perhaps the most enduring symbols of the former East Germany.
The increasing numbers of veiled Muslim women are fueling the debate over the role of Muslims in British life.
Images from Pascale Ferran's "Lady Chatterley."

At 5 a.m. in Le Mans, there is a mix of emotions, mostly of the sleep-craving variety. I've been put to work cleaning tires and shuttling them between the Corvette Racing team and Michelin's makeshift headquarters across the paddock. I knew it wasn't going to be glamorous, but after catching a glimpse of myself in a mirror, I realized that I look like I've spent a day in a coal mine. Brake dust is on my face, in my hair, in my ears, and under my nails. Whether I like it or not, I'll be bringing home a pound or two of Corvette brake dust as a souvenir.
Removing ink from the skin proves to be more difficult than applying it there.

An article on Page 48 of The Times Magazine today, about Dr. Ronald McIver, who is imprisoned for drug trafficking, gives an erroneous account of the trial testimony of one of his patients, Leslie Smith. Mr. Smith testified that he injected drugs that Dr. McIver prescribed; he did not testify that Dr. McIver sold the drugs.

An article in Arts & Leisure today about the playwright Douglas Carter Beane includes an outdated reference to the opening of “Xanadu.” The musical’s opening has been postponed, with a date still to be determined. It will not open on June 26.

Jeff Gerth and Don Van Natta Jr. resurrected first-class political journalism in their article (June 3). No character assassination, no political muckraking, no hidden agenda, just documented and verifiable statements regarding Senator Clinton and specifically her Senate voting record concerning United States military operations in Iraq. In this matter, the record clearly indicates that she did not ask herself the pertinent question about the best interests of this country, only what was best — or the least damaging — for her political ambitions. An even more pertinent question is how this mind-set would influence her decisions as president, a question voters should seriously consider, given that she may be the Democratic presidential candidate in 2008.

EVERY FRIDAY. By Dan Yaccarino. Henry Holt. $16.95. (Ages 3 to 7) “Friday is my favorite day,” a small boy tells us, because every Friday he and his dad go for breakfast together at the local diner. In cheerful gouache illustrations, they wave to passersby, watch shops open and buildings going up; “everyone is rushing, but we’re taking our time.” A note from the author tells us the book is based on his weekly ritual with his own son. It is also a valentine to good dads and neighborhood diners, and a reminder on Father’s Day that the “little traditions” are sometimes the best ones.

GRAHAM--Ruth Bell. Ruth was a great pioneer of faith and a full partner with her husband, Rev. Billy Graham, in spreading the Word and God around the world. Her many writings told a vivid story of living a life of commitment and service to the Lord. We mourn her loss as we also celebrate her exemplary life. American Bible Society

I am thinking about a visit to Sicily with my wife and kids (5 and 8). We've been to Italy, but not Sicily. We are thinking about spending a week in Taormina in a villa outside the city. I'd appreciate any thoughts. -- Bob Bertino, Duxbury, Mass. Several contributors to the Travel section have weighed in on the merits of Sicily, and Taormina in particular. Danielle Pergament, who recently wrote about Palermo (''In Palermo, Life Vibrates in a Fading Market''), says the hillside town of Taormina is her favorite place on the island, describing it as stunning but very touristy.

To the Editor: I feel that ''The Other Machu Picchu'' (June 3), in which Ethan Todras-Whitehill dismisses the ruins there as overrun by tourists, doesn't tell the full story. True, there are more visitors now than in the 1960's when I slept in a sleeping bag among the ruins. However, important sections had not yet been investigated and/or rescued from the wilderness.

MANY states nationwide are considering legislation to legalize the medical use of marijuana. Last week, one such bill cleared both houses in Connecticut (but at press time had not yet been signed by the governor), New York appears likely to follow suit and New Jersey has two bills with bipartisan support. Indeed, a number of states have had similar measures in play over the last year, in addition to the 12 that have already passed such laws. The picture is very different at the federal level, where marijuana is branded as an illegal drug. An amendment to a recent drug safety bill would require all purveyors of state-authorized medical marijuana to be subject to Food and Drug Administration regulation. The senator who introduced this amendment said that making any drug available without F.D.A. review or proof of safety and effectiveness would set a dangerous precedent that would threaten patient safety. Marijuana advocates have opposed the bill, because it would close medical marijuana cooperatives and create barriers to the use of the drug.

CLIGGOTT--Richard T., Sr., founder of Cliggott Publishing Company and a pioneer in the medical publishing world died at his home in Greenwich, CT, June 9th with his wife, Janet at his side. In 1970, Mr. Cliggott led a group of investors in the purchase of ''Consultant Magazine'' from Smith Kline and French to create Cliggott Publishing. From the start, Cliggott Publishing produced original, peer reviewed articles written by physicians for the purpose of advancing medical practice. Cliggott Publishing set the standard for editorial integrity and excellence. Soon after the inception of the company, three other journals were launched, the ''Journal of Respiratory Diseases'', the ''Journal of Musculoskeletal Medicine'' and the ''Journal of Critical Illness'', as well as a series of independently sponsored journals. Born in Andover, MA, April 14, 1928, Mr. Cliggott grew up on the Cape in Cotuit, MA. As a young boy during the depression years on Cape Cod, Mr. Cliggott helped support his family by working on farms doing everything from bailing hay to exercising horses. Upon graduation from Barnstable High he joined the Army, serving two years in Korea earning the rank of Master Sergeant. After the army he attended Worcester Academy. Worcester is where he developed his abilities to achieve in both academics and athletics. Mr. Cliggott devoted his life to the school motto, ''Achieve the Honorable'' He became driven to use his intellect, discipline and work ethic to become successful and make his family proud of him. Worcester Academy led Mr. Cliggott to Cornell University on an academic scholarship. For his leadership both in the classroom and on the athletic field he was admitted into the Honorary Quill & Dagger Society. While at Cornell, Mr. Cliggott played varsity baseball and football and in 1953 made Honorable Mention All American in football. During his summer months, Mr. Cliggott was a star player for the Cotuit Kettlers in the Cape Cod summer baseball league. Mr. Cliggott graduated from Cornell in 1953 and worked for the university in their development office. He left Cornell in 1955 and worked for Procter and Gamble where he received his sales and management training. In 1959, Medical Economics of Oradell, NJ hired him and introduced Mr. Cliggott to medical publishing. From 1970-1996 Mr. Cliggott developed Cliggott Publishing into one of America's most admired and respected medical publishing companies. In 1996, Mr. Cliggott sold the company and retired. Mr. Cliggott and his wife of 56 years, Janet, divided their time between their homes in Tequesta, FL and Greenwich, CT. An avid sportsman and outdoorsman, he loved golfing, boating, fishing, hunting and bird watching. Mr. Cliggott was a member of Cornell University's Laboratory Ornithology and the Cornell Plantation. As president of Greenwich Country Club he helped oversee the redesign of the golf course into a competitively challenging course. Mr. Cliggott was a true gentleman and a wonderful story teller with a great sense of humor. He was generous, always taking the time to make those he cared about feel appreciated by him. He was respected and admired by everyone whose lives he touched. Most of all he was devoted to his wife and loved spending time with his children and grandchildren. He is survived by his wife, Janet, his children and their families; Nancy and Bill Hansen and their children Bill, Ricky, and Joe; Dick Jr. and Monica Cliggott and their children Tom and James; Michael and Holly Cliggott and their son Andrew; Patricia and Doug Kent, and Tim Cliggott. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial donations to be made to Worcester Academy, Cornell University Plantations, or the Cornell University School of Ornithology

Sylvia Kaplan, right, 63, and her husband Ken, 66, New Jersey retirees from Green Cove Springs, Fla.: ''My husband had been dreaming of getting an RV for the last 20 some years, and I'd kind of been a workaholic, so when he said he really wanted to do this, I finally gave in a couple of years ago. I never thought I would like it, but I love it. It's a wonderful way to travel and see places. This was our first really big trip. We'd never been to California, or to a place in the United States where they had hot springs and that kind of climate, so we were really excited. We also love birding, and on this trip we added more birds to our list than we ever dreamed we would see. We've just had the chance now to experience so many different environments, it's been a real eye-opener.'' As told to Austin Considine

To friends and fans, Carmelo Anthony, a forward for the Denver Nuggets, is known as Melo. ''I do consider myself mellow,'' said Mr. Anthony, 23. ''But on the court, I'm not too laid-back.'' Hardly. In 2003, Mr. Anthony led Syracuse University to a National Collegiate Athletic Association title, joined the Nuggets after the National Basketball Association draft and became one of the league's top scorers. This year, he secured spots on the United States Olympic Team and the N.B.A. All-Star Team.

To the Editor: I just read ''For the Children, a Mother Revisits Her Sorrow,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, June 10). Our stories are so similar it took my breath away. Except for the fact that my son Peter never made it to college, he was the same kind of boy.

FOR two former undercover detectives in their early 40s who cheated death time and again, no day is ordinary, not anymore, and certainly not a day like this one on the shore of Long Island -- a day showered with sea spray and salt air; with clam bellies in a bucket at their sides and jigs tempting stripers in the surf; with sand and sky, wind and waves, straight talk about life and mocking chatter about death. As they keep a watchful eye for any wiggle of their 15-foot-long fishing poles, Ernest Vallebuona of New City, N.Y., and Michael Valentin of Ronkonkoma, N.Y., shoot the breeze about how, as partners in one of New York City's undercover vice squads, they easily adapted to the pace of street work -- long hours of waiting interrupted by spurts of dramatic action -- kind of like saltwater fishing, actually.
POLLOCK--Harold S., died on June 6th, 2007. Gloria Weiner deeply mourns the loss of her dear brother Hal. I will remember always the goodness of our life together.

A review on June 3 about ''Twisted,'' by Laurie Halse Anderson, misstated the given name in two references for a character in ''Speak,'' another book by the same author. As noted elsewhere in the review, it is Melinda Sordino, not Miranda.

What did Justin Verlander do the morning after he pitched the first no-hitter in Comerica Park in Detroit on Tuesday night? He went to Nordstrom and picked up a couple of suits, he told reporters. That's the closest thing to an endorsement that Mr. Verlander appears to have made. Even though he was the rookie of the year in the American League last year, he has essentially operated under the baseball radar. Sports commentators in Detroit have complained about his lack of national attention, which tends to lead to big commercial deals.

MANY states nationwide are considering legislation to legalize the medical use of marijuana. Last week, one such bill cleared both houses in Connecticut (but at press time had not yet been signed by the governor), New York appears likely to follow suit and New Jersey has two bills with bipartisan support. Indeed, a number of states have had similar measures in play over the last year, in addition to the 12 that have already passed such laws. The picture is very different at the federal level, where marijuana is branded as an illegal drug. An amendment to a recent drug safety bill would require all purveyors of state-authorized medical marijuana to be subject to Food and Drug Administration regulation. The senator who introduced this amendment said that making any drug available without F.D.A. review or proof of safety and effectiveness would set a dangerous precedent that would threaten patient safety. Marijuana advocates have opposed the bill, because it would close medical marijuana cooperatives and create barriers to the use of the drug.

To the Editor: I enjoyed ''The Art of Buying Art, With the Help of an Adviser'' (May 27). Although it was correct in stating that there are no formal certifications for the profession, it should be noted that the International Association of Professional Art Advisors does have standards that members adhere to. Members cannot have gallery affiliations, represent artists or own any inventory. These parameters avoid conflict of interest and the consultant/adviser represents the client's best interests in transactions. Suzy R. Locke Oakland, Calif., May 29 The writer, an art adviser, is a member of the International Association of Professional Art Advisors.

Q. I live in a rent-stabilized apartment, and last week I received a notice that all air-conditioners must have exterior brackets installed or the building won't be covered by its new insurance company. Shouldn't this be the responsibility of the landlord? A. ''Unlike most commercial leases, most rent-stabilized leases say nothing about tenants' complying with the requirements of the landlord's insurer,'' said Adam Leitman Bailey, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. ''So, unless this is a very unusual lease, insurance has nothing to do with the answer.''

ANDRES--Stephen C., of Upper Montclair, NJ, on June 16, 2007. Born April 7, 1921. Husband of Else, father of Steven, Tim and Robert. Grandfather of four, great-grandfather of two. He will be dearly missed with everlasting love. Visitation at the Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park St., Montclair, NJ, on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm with a Memorial Service starting at 3:30pm.

MANY homeowners with adjustable-rate mortgages, or ARMs, have taken advantage of low interest on fixed-rate mortgages in recent months to refinance into those less risky loans. But in the last few weeks, as rates on fixed-interest mortgages have risen, that decision has become more difficult for some borrowers, mortgage industry executives and analysts say. Many borrowers who took out ARMs in 2004 and 2005 with interest rates in the 5 percent range, for example, will soon face their first adjustment, and their rates are quite likely to rise to the high 7 percent range.

A record number of trees are expected to fall victim to gypsy moth caterpillars this year, according to the New Jersey Department of Agriculture, which predicts that 200,000 to 300,000 acres of trees will be defoliated by the pesky creatures. ''We're definitely in a population spike,'' said Jeff Beach, a spokesman for the Agriculture Department. Defoliated trees can survive, he said, but if they are stripped several years in a row they will most likely die.

To the Editor: Re ''Longtime Emblems of City Roofs, Still Going Strong'' (June 3): Another aspect of New York City's iconic water tanks worth considering is their sustainability. They are part of an overall water supply scheme that, in its simplicity, actually offers less expensive, more reliable and ''lower carbon'' solutions to the vital need for water than many cities can claim.

KLIOT--Boris. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Boris Kliot, beloved husband of Jacqueline and father of Michel, Gene, and Jason. Boris' devotion to Jewish philanthropy has strengthened our ability to serve those in need. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

Milestone Tracker Craig Biggio of the Astros is struggling in his quest for 3,000 hits. He is 11 away, but he hit .250 in April, .231 in May and is hitting .226 this month. Houston will be on the road for nine straight games beginning tomorrow, when it opens a three-game set at the Angels. Like Father, Like Son? Prince Fielder of the Brewers leads the National League in home runs with 24. His father, Cecil Fielder, was the American League leader while with Detroit in 1990 with 51 and tied for the lead with Jose Canseco of the A's in 1991 with 44. Helping Himself Carlos Zambrano of the Cubs hit his second home run of the season last Monday while also picking up his seventh victory. Zambrano has 12 career home runs (in 355 at-bats), second to Mike Hampton of the Braves among active pitchers. Hampton, who has hit 15 (653 at-bats), is on the disabled list and out for the season after elbow surgery. Five K Club Craig Monroe of the Tigers joined Andruw Jones of the Braves as the only other player to strike out five times in a game this season. Monroe did it Thursday against Milwaukee and Jones did it last month against Boston. Another Oakland Ace Dan Haren of the A's leads the American League with a 1.64 earned run average. The last Oakland pitcher to lead the A.L. with an E.R.A. under 2.00 was Vida Blue with a 1.82 in 1971. The A's open a three-game set at home against the Reds tomorrow. The Watch List Pirates shortstop JACK WILSON was on the bench for four consecutive games last week, with some speculating that a lack of hustle on defense had landed him there. After a meeting with team officials, Wilson, right, a former All-Star, played Friday and had hits in his first two at-bats. Although DAVID WEATHERS has performed reasonably well as closer for the Reds, his time in the position may be waning as EDDIE GUARDADO, owner of 183 career saves, is on track to return soon. Having been promoted to Class AAA while recovering from reconstructive elbow surgery, Guardado would solidify the Reds' bullpen and allow Weathers to return to his customary eighth-inning role. All eyes will be on the Brewers' Yovani Gallardo as he is scheduled to make his major league debut tomorrow against the Giants. Considered among the best pitching prospects in baseball, Gallardo struck out 110 batters in 77 2/3 innings for Class AAA Nashville. His call-up may be short, however, because the injured Chris Capuano is not expected to take more than 15 days to recover from a strained groin muscle.

To the Editor: Re ''For the Children, a Mother Revisits Her Sorrow,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, June 10): I just read the article about Ian Katz, and as I read it I inserted my name, Virginia, and my son's name, Peter.

The stock market rebounded and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed to its best weekly gain in several months, although bond yields also rose. A five-week surge in bond yields has concerned stock investors, leading to big losses the previous week. And last week, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note closed at 5.16 percent, up from 5.1 percent a week earlier -- and nearly half a percentage point higher than it had been at the beginning of the year. But on Friday, a relatively moderate report on inflation -- the core Consumer Price Index rose by 2.2 percent on an annual basis in May -- evidently calmed some concerns.
The Economic View column last Sunday, about income inequality in the United States, misstated the top marginal rate for federal income taxes. It is 35 percent, not 36 percent.

When it comes to his alma maters, E. Gerald Corrigan, former chief executive of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is a generous man. This month, he gave $5 million to his college, Fairfield University, the Jesuit institution in Connecticut where he got his undergraduate degree, majoring in economics, in 1963. Mr. Corrigan, 66, now a managing director at Goldman Sachs, serves on Fairfield's board of trustees.

An article in Arts & Leisure today about the playwright Douglas Carter Beane includes an outdated reference to the opening of ''Xanadu.'' The musical's opening has been postponed, with a date still to be determined. It will not open on June 26.
To the Editor: Re ''Concert Hall? How About Music Museum? [June 3]:

This is the time of year that music grows feet. From fall to spring the Metropolitan Opera sits at Lincoln Center and waits for its audience to come to it. This week, it is coming to a park near you. THE METROPOLITAN OPERA IN THE PARKS season will bring along a repertory that is beloved with a capital B, and the admission is free. A mobile stage and lots of loudspeakers do not make for a pristine listening experience, and the shows may be something like picnics and conversation, with opera as a kind of Muzak in the background. Also, don't look for much in the way of staging, costumes and production values. The rewards, on the other hand, are many. The most valuable is the crowd itself: a wondrous mix of the operatically inclined, the plain curious and people who just want a night under the stars and don't mind if music goes along with it. On Tuesday Gounod's ''Faust'' is performed at Prospect Park in Brooklyn. On Wednesday the Met makes its way to Cunningham Park in Queens, with ''La Bohème'' by Puccini on the program. On Friday it's ''Faust'' again at Brookdale Park in Bloomfield and Montclair, N.J. On Saturday the Met stays in New Jersey for a repeat of ''La Bohème,'' this time at Buccleuch Park in New Brunswick. The Met's parks series often uses the opportunity to try out singers who are either new to or not established in this country. Discoveries and surprises (good or bad) are part of the fun. You'll need a blanket, but tickets aren't required. All performances at 8, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; free.

To the Editor: In ''Cut and Run'' (Op-Ed, June 3), Jon Shure asserts that New Jersey is not well served by the subsidy policies the state employs to attract and retain businesses. Offsets in revenue do not yield promised gains. ''The better way to build an economy,'' he maintains, is to invest in ''roads, mass transit, schools, worker training,'' which will be ''there to pay dividends long after fickle companies split for the next great deal.''

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended June 2, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books. THE DIANA CHRONICLES, by Tina Brown. (Doubleday, $27.50.) The former New Yorker editor perceptively highlights the media's role in the sordid domestic drama that pitted the Princess of Wales against Britain's royal family. NINE, by Andrzej Stasiuk. Translated by Bill Johnston. (Harcourt, $23.) This Polish ''existential crime novel'' vividly evokes the scamming subsistence culture of the Warsaw underworld. LONG TIME LEAVING: Dispatches From Up South, by Roy Blount Jr. (Knopf, $25.) Literate, good-humored essays on Southern culture. THE PERFECT MAN, by Naeem Murr. (Random House; paper, $13.95.) The British-Indian hero of this novel comes of age in racist 1950s Missouri. THE AGE OF ABUNDANCE: How Prosperity Transformed America's Politics and Culture, by Brink Lindsey. (Collins/HarperCollins, $26.95.) Affluence breeds libertarianism, Lindsey argues. RELIGIOUS LITERACY: What Every American Needs to Know -- and Doesn't, by Stephen Prothero. (HarperSanFrancisco, $24.95.) A professor laments our declining knowledge of religion. THE SUSHI ECONOMY: Globalization and the Making of a Modern Delicacy, by Sasha Issenberg. (Gotham, $26.) Sushi, and particularly the bluefin tuna, as an example of ''good'' globalization. THE ZEN OF FISH: The Story of Sushi, From Samurai to Supermarket, by Trevor Corson. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) An often amusing history. THE COLLECTED STORIES, by Leonard Michaels. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Larky and profane, Michaels's sexually kinetic short stories stand alongside those of his best Jewish contemporaries, Grace Paley and Philip Roth. SYLVIA, by Leonard Michaels. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux; paper, $13.) A fictionalized memoir, first published in 1992, about Michaels's first wife, Sylvia Bloch, whose troubled life ended in suicide. TRAVELS WITH HERODOTUS, by Ryszard Kapuscinski. Translated by Klara Glowczewska. (Knopf, $25.) The only memoir by the Pole who was perhaps the world's best literary journalist.The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

KESSLER--Betty, passed away Wednesday, June 13, 2007. Born November 20, 1932, she was the daughter of the late Sidney and Leila (Hess) Kessler. Betty attended The University of Miami from which she received both undergraduate and Law degrees. At the time of her death she was a General Magistrate for the state of Florida in Family Court. She leaves behind her beloved, life long partner, Saundra Grace, and loving brother and sister Deborah and Richard Kessler. Services will be Sunday, June 17th at 11am at Temple Beth Shalom in Miami Beach. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Voices for Children Foundation, Inc., The Guardian Ad Litem Program, 1500 NW 12th Avenue Suite 117, Miami, FL 33136.

One of the reasons we need THE HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL, the traveling series of mostly documentary films that arrives in New York City on Friday, is the chance to see a film like ''Hot House,'' Shimon Dotan's study of Palestinan prisoners in Israel's highest-security jails. A detailed examination of prison life, ''Hot House,'' which has its New York premiere on June 25, includes interviews with many prisoners involved in suicide bombings. Most express no remorse for their deadly actions and reject the term ''terrorists'' in favor of ''freedom fighters.'' This politically even-handed film, which won a special jury prize at this year's Sundance Film Festival, suggests that the system which houses some 10,000 ''security prisoners,'' some of them for life, only fortifies the zeal of the terrorists who regard prison as an educational institution for the sharing of ideas and the development of strategy. It concludes that prison is an efficient incubator for future radical Palestinian leaders. The festival, at the Walter Reade Theater, opens with ''Mon Colonel,'' a film directed by Costa-Gravas and Jean-Claude Grumberg that offers another look back at the French-Algerian war. It closes next week with ''The Devil Came on Horseback,'' the portrait by Annie Sundberg and Ricki Stern of Brian Steidle, a former Marine Corps captain whose photographs of the Darfur killing fields awakened the world to mass slaughter that continues. Another outstanding selection is Alejandro Landes's ''Cocalero,'' which follows the rise of President Evo Morales of Bolivia, a grass-roots politician backed by impoverished coca farmers threatened by the American war on drugs. ''The Unforeseen,'' by Laura Dunn, investigates the battle between real-estate developers in Austin, Tex., and environmental activists. The uncomfortable truth revealed by these films is that there are no easy solutions to the world's ills; that for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction that may be delayed but is eventually felt. Friday through June 28, Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 496-3809, filmlinc.com; $11, $7 for members.
