EISENSTEIN--Enid Rosalinde June 17, 1953-May 12, 1977 Beloved Daughter Without you No rose can grow No leaf be green If never seen Your sweetest face, No bird have grace Or pow'r to sing Or anything be kind or fair And you nowhere Rebe Eisenstein, loving family and friends

The big openings of the international shows in Europe end this weekend, which means that in the United States all is still quiet on both the Eastern and Western museum fronts. But the middle of the country is delivering in three exhibitions that become more unusual as you move from South to North. THE KIMBELL ART MUSEUM in Fort Worth is playing it relatively safe with ''The Mirror and the Mask: Portraiture in the Age of Picasso, opening Sunday. What it lacks in daring it should make up for in important works by heavy hitters and, one assumes, interesting juxtapositions. The artists start with Picasso and Matisse and include Miró, Beckmann, Bacon and Dubuffet. Meanwhile, another city, another era. On Sunday the ST. LOUIS ART MUSEUM unveils ''Symbols of Power: Napoleon and the Art of the Empire Style, 1800-1815,'' a show of 140 decorative objects that will examine the way Napoleon and his designers countered the frivolities of the last royal style (Rococo) with a Neo-Classical revival. Simplicity was increasingly augmented with emblems of authority borrowed from Greek, Rome and of course Egypt, where Napoleon had his first foretaste of Waterloo, in the military sense, but triumphed archeologically. The exhibition has been organized with the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris; many of its works have never been exhibited outside France. On Saturday THE MUSEUM OF CONTEMPORARY ART in Chicago will take a highly focused look at some of the contemporary art coming out of Mexico. ''Escultura Social: A New Generation of Art from Mexico City'' takes its title from ''social sculpture,'' Joseph Beuys's encapsulation of his ambition to work in three dimensions -- with objects, video, installation and performance -- in ways that transform society. For nearly 20 years the artists in and around Mexico City have followed his cue with unusual alacrity. Including 18 artists, a collective, an architect and way too few women, this show will take a look at the efforts of the newest recruits.

John Corigliano: String Quartet No. 1, Other Works; Jefferson Friedman: String Quartet No. 2 Corigliano Quartet. Naxos 8.559180; CD. JOHN CORIGLIANO wrote his gripping String Quartet No. 1 (''Farewell'') for the Cleveland Quartet's final concert tour in 1995. The Cleveland's fading embers sparked the birth of the fiery Corigliano Quartet, which, incongruously, was founded in 1996 to champion the ''Farewell.''

As with most mergers, top executives at aQuantive stand to make a lot of money by cashing in stock and exercising options now that Microsoft has agreed to acquire the company for $6 billion. Brian P. McAndrews, the chief executive of aQuantive, an online advertising firm, is expected to make $134 million from the deal. Michael Galgon, the chief strategy officer, is set to make $44.6 million, according to the preliminary merger proxy filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week.

''There has never been a military commander in history who wouldn't like to have more of something or other. That characterizes all of us here. The fact is, frankly, that we have all that our country is going to provide us in terms of combat forces -- that is really it, right now.'' GEN. DAVID H. PETRAEUS, the top American commander in Iraq. TWEAKING TWINKIES The News -- Hostess, maker of Twinkies, Ding Dongs and other snacks, has begun offering Twinkies filled with banana crème. Behind the News I-- ntroduced in 1930, the sponge snack cake has become part of the national panorama, with more than 500 million sold a year. In 2000, it was included with the Bill of Rights and other items in the National Millennium Time Capsule ''to represent America.'' . Banana crème was used until a banana shortage in the 1940s forced a switch to vanilla filling. Hostess decided to bring it back after banana-crème Twinkies flew off shelves in a limited-time offer. LOW ON SYRUP The News -- Maple syrup production dropped 13 percent this year to 1.26 million gallons. Behind the News -- Maine was down 25 percent; Vermont, producer of more than one-third of the nation's syrup, was off by 2 percent. Uncooperative weather hurt the sap flow, with New England too cold and other areas too warm. Making matters worse, the sap's sugar content, averaging about 2.5 percent, was lower than usual, requiring more sap to make a gallon of syrup -- about 45 gallons, on average, or 5 gallons more than usual. CEREAL CRACKDOWN The News -- The Kellogg Company said it would phase out advertisements to children under 12 unless its products meet specific nutritional criteria. Behind the News -- Fruit Loops, beware. The world's largest cereal maker said it would reformulate its foods to reduce calories, sugar, fat and sodium or stop marketing them to children by the end of 2008. About half of the products Kellogg markets to children worldwide exceed the standards. As a result of the new policy, two advocacy groups have agreed not to sue Kellogg over its advertising to children. SUGAR ANXIETY The News -- The consumption of foods that are low in sugar or sugar free is rising as more consumers worry about sugar levels, a market study found. Behind the News -- The study by the NPD Group, a market research firm, found that 44 percent of consumers are extremely or very concerned about sugar in their food, the highest level since 1994. Consumers are cutting back as a result. Twenty percent ate low-sugar, sugar-free or artificially sweetened food at least once in a two-week period last year, compared with 14 percent in 2001, according to the study. TOUGH TALK The News -- A panel of medical experts said children at risk of becoming obese should eliminate sugar-sweetened beverages from their diets. Behind the News -- The recommendation was one of many by an American Medical Association committee on childhood obesity. The panel defined children at risk as having a body-mass index equal or above the 85th percentile but below the 95th, at which a child is obese. Doctors were urged to be frank with patients. ''We need to describe this in medical terms, which is obesity,'' one panel member said.

Haydn: Piano Sonatas (10) Marc-André Hamelin, pianist. Hyperion CDA67554; two CD's. YOU never know quite what to expect from Marc-André Hamelin. Last encountered in a treasurable recording of Albéniz's ''Iberia'' from Hyperion, Mr. Hamelin has based a highly productive career mostly on big Romantic and 20th-century works, often little known if at all.
A report last Sunday, about the marriage of Dara Beth Goldberg, misspelled the bridegroom's surname. He is Jonathan Michael Kaye, not Kay.

Tom Oreck, the chief executive of the vacuum cleaner maker founded by his father, David, has a whole lot of new floor space to keep clean. The younger Mr. Oreck paid $4.6 million this month for a 7,800-square-foot mansion in Nashville that was once owned by the Grand Ole Opry star Minnie Pearl and her husband, Henry Cannon. The home sits on 4.7 acres near the Tennessee governor's mansion. Mr. Oreck's purchase rekindled speculation that the company might move its headquarters from New Orleans to Tennessee, where it relocated some of its operations after Hurricane Katrina.

To the Editor: Re ''Income Inequality, Writ Larger'' (Economic View, June 10), which reported a study's finding that the top 1 percent of American earners reaped more than 17 percent of gross personal income:

HACKER--Dianne, died on June 6, 2007. Dianne was the daughter of the late Milton Sol Hacker, and Esther Cornez Hacker, who survives her at home. Additional survivors include her brothers Howard and Scott, niece Melissa and sister-in-law, Donna.

A message to those who have applied for -- and are eagerly awaiting -- passports: relax. The Departments of State and Homeland Security announced on June 8 that through Sept. 30, United States citizens traveling to Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean and Bermuda may enter and depart the United States by air as long as they have a government-issued photo identification and proof that they have applied for a passport. The Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative, which has required passports for all air travel outside of United States territories since Jan. 23, has created a record demand for passports, meaning longer processing and turnaround times. Details are at www.travel.state.gov. Want more ''Pirates of the Caribbean''? Hotels on Dominica, which provided some locations for the movies starring Johnny Depp (below), have created packages for pirate-crazy travelers. A seven-night experience offered by Calibishie Lodges (www.calibishie-lodges.com) includes visits to eight spots used in the movies; it is available for $599 a person, double occupancy, if reserved by June 30. A seven-day package offered by the Tamarind Tree Hotel and Restaurant (www.tamarindtreedominica.com) includes tours led by the driver for Gore Verbinski, the movie's director, starting at $1,615 a person, double, with all meals. Other pirate-themed packages are being offered by the Anchorage Hotel (www.anchoragehotel.dm), the Hummingbird Inn (www.find-us.net/hummingbird) -- ask at these two when you reserve -- and the Fort Young Hotel (www.fortyounghotel.com). American Airlines (www.aa.com) recently announced that all AAdvantage members must redeem or accrue miles at least once every 18 months to keep their accounts active. Starting Dec. 15, mileage accounts that have not changed in the previous year and a half will expire. HILARY HOWARD

IT'S not a lot. ''It doesn't take much time,'' says Ignatius Muscarella. It's not hard to do. Still, every Tuesday for many years now, Mr. Muscarella has given up his lunch hour to deliver surplus food to a soup kitchen. He is a 50-year-old lawyer who clerks for a State Supreme Court judge. Dressed in his work clothes -- starched white shirt, tie, suspenders, dark suit -- he rushes out of the courthouse here at 12:45, hops into his Hyundai Sonata, then drives to the back entrance of nearby Winthrop Hospital. He pulls a large cooler out of his trunk and hurries into the hospital kitchen, where Annette Cambria, the sous-chef, leads him into a walk-in freezer.

MANY states nationwide are considering legislation to legalize the medical use of marijuana. Last week, one such bill cleared both houses in Connecticut (but at press time had not yet been signed by the governor), New York appears likely to follow suit and New Jersey has two bills with bipartisan support. Indeed, a number of states have had similar measures in play over the last year, in addition to the 12 that have already passed such laws. The picture is very different at the federal level, where marijuana is branded as an illegal drug. An amendment to a recent drug safety bill would require all purveyors of state-authorized medical marijuana to be subject to Food and Drug Administration regulation. The senator who introduced this amendment said that making any drug available without F.D.A. review or proof of safety and effectiveness would set a dangerous precedent that would threaten patient safety. Marijuana advocates have opposed the bill, because it would close medical marijuana cooperatives and create barriers to the use of the drug.

Albany is now at the final four -- the final four days, that is, before this year's legislative session is scheduled to end. A lot can be done, undone or done badly in that time. Here is our list of what should be possible: No. 1 is still campaign finance reform. The bill now being considered is less than the good citizens of this state deserve, but it is far better than what we have now. Unfortunately, Senate Leader Joseph Bruno and his Republican majority are stalling. The Senate Republicans apparently don't want to give up the easy money, especially from limited liability corporations that are now the favored loophole for well-heeled contributors.

To the Editor: Re ''International Justice on Trial'' (editorial, June 10): The challenges judges need to rise to in trying war-crimes cases fairly and efficiently were evident at the opening of the trial of Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, which I observed for Human Rights Watch. But the significance of a trial of a former head of state associated with horrendous crimes shouldn't be obscured because the proceedings didn't open without a hitch.

To the Editor: Liz Harris Behling's point about the dangers of reviewing translations (Letters, May 20) is well taken. There is an inevitable dilettantism inherent in reviewing a translation of a language one may know poorly or not at all (and even one's reading knowledge of that language is likely to be far inferior to the translator's expertise). And the constraints of space rarely allow one to give proper credit to the translator. The translator certainly loses, and does not deserve to.

ON a drizzling Sunday morning last month, Adrienne Pincus hit the brakes on her bicycle as two riders -- one a close friend -- crashed on a rain-slicked road in Norwalk, Conn., near the start of the Bloomin' Metric, one of region's most popular cycling events. By the time Mrs. Pincus, 46, of White Plains, had stopped, her friend was lying in the road. Her helmet had flown off, and her head had hit the pavement so hard that blood soon began to ooze from both ears.

SEVIN--Malvin Peace. Daddy dear we miss you, your love and your guidance. Love you always, Irik and Jaar-mel $(6$)SEVIN--Malvin Peace. Remembering June 1946 with love-the wonderful memories of our happy days with your wisdom and counsel are always in my thoughts. Love you always, Audrey

An article on Page 48 of The Times Magazine today, about Dr. Ronald McIver, who is imprisoned for drug trafficking, gives an erroneous account of the trial testimony of one of his patients, Leslie Smith. Mr. Smith testified that he injected drugs that Dr. McIver prescribed; he did not testify that Dr. McIver sold the drugs.

In her Senate-floor speech, before the vote on the authorization of the use of force in Iraq, Senator Clinton warned about the dangers of acting unilaterally and emphasized the benefits of first obtaining authorization from the United Nations. But as she acknowledged, there was no language in the Senate resolution requiring the president to try to work with the U.N. And as an experienced lawyer, she should have known that if you don't have the language, you don't have the deal. Her vote is all the more inexplicable, given her prior vote against a substitute resolution, offered by Carl Levin, requiring precisely the diplomatic requirement she had advocated.

The Practical Traveler column on June 10 about sharing photographs online misspelled the surname of a man who chronicled the travels of his family around the world on SmugMug.com, a photo-sharing Web site. He is John Higham, not Highman.

Bosede Ikeolu Gbadegesin, a daughter of Felicia and Segun Gbadegesin of Mitchellville, Md., was married yesterday afternoon to Oreoluwa Adetunji Adeyemi, the son of Kemi and Solomon Adeyemi of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. Joel Ojelade, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in Memorial Chapel at the University of Maryland in College Park, Md. The couple have known each other since elementary school in Ile-Ife, Nigeria. Both of their families immigrated to the United States, and the couple met again as college students in Cambridge, Mass. She was at Harvard and he was at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Nature has some strange symbioses, and one of them involves a longtime and long-distance migratory bird, horseshoe crabs, eels and New Jersey. For thousands of years, the bird, the red knot, has been migrating north in the spring from Tierra Del Fuego, at the southern tip of South America, to the Arctic, where it nests and breeds, said John S. Watson Jr., deputy commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection.

Weil mentions the Finnish system of delaying academic learning until children are 7. We spent the year of my husband's sabbatical (1998-99) in Turku, Finland, where our 6-year-old daughter, who would have entered first grade here, was eligible only for a half-day kindergarten program. At first I was upset, but it proved to be a fabulous year for her, with almost no academic expectations but with a rich curriculum for creative growth as well as vigorous outdoor exercise every day. The teachers I spoke to thought it was actually damaging to children to teach reading and math before age 7 and that the early years were the appropriate time to stress the social and emotional growth also necessary for later school success.

The Rev. Dr. Elizabeth Sidar Hall, a Presbyterian minister, and Pamela Mary Palumbo were joined in a civil union ceremony yesterday. The Rev. Jean A. F. Holmes, a Presbyterian minister, officiated in Califon, N.J., at the home of Rev. Jean Johnston and Dr. Edward Johnston, who are friends of the couple. To the Editor: For thousands of New Yorkers not in the ''social scene,'' drug abuse and its inherent problems are far from invisible. A visit to any number of treatment programs across the city will clear up any misconception about the coolness of cocaine or harmlessness of recreational drug abuse.

BLUA--Elisabeth Farnum Green, 86, died after a long illness in Charlottesville, VA, on June 7, 2007. She was a graduate of Foxcroft School, Barnard College, and New York School of Interior Design. She is survived by her husband of 40 years, Piero Blua, of Charlottesville, two sons, Richard H. Wilmer IV of Arlington, VA and Stephen E. Wilmer of Dublin, Ireland, and three daughters, Margaret W. Bartlett of New Vernon, NJ, Natalie W. Blenk of London, England, and Christine W. Barkus of New York City, and by 10 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on June 22 at 10:30am, at St. Bartholomew's Church, New York City.

WEISELBERG--Ruth, of Great Neck, New York, on May 21st, 2007. Loving wife of the late Dr. Norman Weiselberg. Beloved mother of Dr. Stanley and Shannon Weiselberg and Drs. Lora and Saul Teichberg. Cherished grandmother of Jeremy, Kira, Kathleen, Samuel, Joshua (Kate), Jason, Jonathan, Lisa (Robert), Glenn, Matthew, Alexandra and Nicole. Greatgrandmother of Naomi and Andrew. Dear sister of Shirley Schaefer. Graduate of Queens College of the City University of New York, she retired after a career as a dedicated teacher in the New York City school system.

In only a few years, the Oakland Athletics expect to be doing business in a far different way than, as a low-revenue team, they have had to do it. ''If we can get a ballpark the way we're trying to do it, with the management talent we have,'' Lew Wolff said, ''we can have a consistent cash flow that would allow us to have a shot at being a little more like a dynasty like they used to have, at least a semidynasty.''
SMITH--Philip. Fathers day every day, always in our hearts. Michael and Jeffrey

Americans have to be outraged that any senator would vote to send the nation to war without reading the most relevant document: the 90-page 2002 National Intelligence Estimate. This report, available to all 100 senators, contained enough information to cause Bob Graham to doubt the threat to the United States posed by Iraq. He was one of only six senators to read the report. Clinton was not among those six; she opted for ''briefings'' instead. She voted, as did many others, for a disastrous foreign policy blunder based on the CliffsNotes version of a national intelligence report. Not very smart for one of the ''brainiest'' people in the Senate.

ARONSON--Norman Leonard, a former naval officer, entrepreneur, publishing executive, restaurant owner, died of cancer on Friday, June 15, 2007. He was 83 years old. His wife was the late Marcia Ross Rosey. Born in Washington, DC, he was the son of the late Herman and Bertha Miller Aronson. He attended Wharton Business School while serving as a Lt. in the U.S. Navy from 19421946. A graduate of Georgetown University Law School with a B.S. in Business and Publishing Administration, 1947, and a JD, 1949. He was Vice President of Esquire Magazine, NYC from 19511975. President and Publisher, Best Publications, Inc., and the Book of Bests, NYC; An avid cook and wine connoisseur, he was Entrepreneur, Investor, Founder, and President, The Kings Court Restaurants, Princeton, NJ and Charlottesville, VA. Previous owner of Johnny Bostons Restaurant, Trenton, NJ; President, The Service News Stands, Pentagon Bldg., Washington, DC; in 1990, he was a recipient of the ''Lone Sailor Award'' honoring veterans who became successful in their lives and careers while exemplifying the core values of honor, courage, and commitment. He was a member of the Nassau Club in Princeton, NJ and the University Club in Manhattan. Surviving are: his son, John Michael Aronson, Wellsboro, PA. His daughter, Susan Elizabeth Aronson Baratta , Naples, FL. His grandchildren, Michael, John Michael, and Ashley Baratta. To leave an online condolence, visit strauchfuneralhome.com

Jeff Gerth and Don Van Natta Jr. resurrected first-class political journalism in their article (June 3). No character assassination, no political muckraking, no hidden agenda, just documented and verifiable statements regarding Senator Clinton and specifically her Senate voting record concerning United States military operations in Iraq. In this matter, the record clearly indicates that she did not ask herself the pertinent question about the best interests of this country, only what was best -- or the least damaging -- for her political ambitions. An even more pertinent question is how this mind-set would influence her decisions as president, a question voters should seriously consider, given that she may be the Democratic presidential candidate in 2008.

SPARKMAN--John C., died May 13, 2007, at his home on Groton Long Point, CT. He is survived by his wife, Patricia, his daughter Susan Sparkman-Sperandio, his sons John Jr. and Paul, and three grandsons. He was a partner at Carter, Ledyard & Milburn. A memorial will be held September 6, at The New York Yacht Club.

In March fans eagerly awaiting the new ANIMAL COLLECTIVE album (''Strawberry Jam,'' due in September) got something else instead: ''Person Pitch'' (Paw Tracks), a spectacular solo CD from PANDA BEAR, one of the Animals. It might be the sweetest album yet to emerge from Animal Collective's gently discombobulated universe, a sunny collection of fractured ballads and exuberant splintered jam sessions. (Animal Collective fans, be honest: If someone had told you this was the band's new album, would you have known the difference?) This week Panda Bear embarks on an abbreviated United States tour. On Monday he is scheduled to play at the Bowery Ballroom; then, after shows in Philadelphia and his native Baltimore, he returns to the Bowery Ballroom on Saturday for the last of the four solo shows. Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111; sold out. Also on Monday night: the New York stop on the TRUE COLORS TOUR, organized to combat discrimination and to ''raise public awareness about the issues facing the gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender community.'' The lineup is an appealing mishmash: the American pop veterans Cyndi Lauper and Debbie Harry alongside the British pop veterans in Erasure; the spiky cabaret-punk duo the Dresden Dolls; the M.C. tag team of Margaret Cho and Rosie O'Donnell; and, maybe best of all, the dance-punk trio the Gossip, led by the bluesy yawper Beth Ditto. Though she's from Arkansas, she has become a rock star in Britain; expect her to act like one. Radio City Music Hall, (212) 307-7171; $51 to $205.50.

To the Editor: ''Hotel Check-In Policies; Early Arrivals and Late Departures Get Harder'' (Practical Traveler, May 27) by Michelle Higgins exposed a challenge facing hotels today that invest in advertising to win back guest loyalty but not in the tools and processes needed to meet the expectations raised by the advertising. Most hotel housekeepers punch a code on the guestroom telephone, which instantly makes the room show as ready in the hotel computer. Unfortunately, automation inspires cost-cutting, which reduces the number of supervisors patrolling the floors. Every morning, most hotels assign someone to knock on doors and inquire when guests plan to vacate, or to look for personal effects in empty rooms that signify a guest is planning to remain in the room until or past checkout time.

Lisa Curran's figure-flattering classic tank bathing suit has earned a following among women who dread shopping for a swimsuit. This year, Ms. Curran is endearing herself to this set with three new variations on the theme. Her shirred one-piece, which has a deep V-neck and exaggerated shirring down the front to hide imperfections ($150), hit stores this season and 5,000 suits quickly flew out the doors; the company re-cut the suit in new colors to meet demand. Her Retro one-piece (far right, $150) and Twisted Two-Tone (right, a 70s-inspired take on the classic tank, $148, all at Lisacurran.com) also sold out in a week and are being reshipped to stores. To be sure, these aren't the most daring get-ups around; Brazilian beach material they are not. Then again, neither are most bodies.

To the Editor: I am writing with considerable concern and disappointment with regard to your June 10 article ''The Hallelujah People.'' When your reporter interviewed me over the phone, I discussed Latino religion and the circumstances of new immigrants generally. With regard to the group Growing in Grace, about which I clearly admitted very little familiarity, I concluded that its significance within the larger picture of Latino religiosity was minimal, at best.
Players of interactive online games and the avatars, gear, spells, skills and identities they forge to represent themselves.

To the Editor: I just read ''For the Children, a Mother Revisits Her Sorrow,'' by Michael Winerip (Parenting, June 10). Our stories are so similar it took my breath away. Except for the fact that my son Peter never made it to college, he was the same kind of boy.

SCHIMMEL--Herbert D., on June 16, 2007, age 80, after a three year battle with cancer. Husband of Ruth Kessler Schimmel, beloved father of Eric P., Curt F., and Susan J. Goldstein. Grandfather of six. Service Monday, June 18, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

It's a good bet that whoever moves into the White House in January 2009 will offer the American people a more contemporary tableau of family life than the one we have witnessed for the last six years. George and Laura Bush seem to be an admirably well-suited and loving couple, the very model of a first family (minus a few untoward events involving the kids). They're a throwback couple, like Rob and Laura Petrie from ''The Dick Van Dyke Show'' -- one amiable and slightly buffoonish, the other tolerant and wryly exasperated. The fictional Laura (played by Mary Tyler Moore) was a lot goofier than the real one; but each knew her place, which was in the home, by the side of her man.

The same story can be told, or danced, many ways. That is one reason the ballet can be so exciting. AMERICAN BALLET THEATER may be especially exciting this week because it is entirely devoted to Kenneth MacMillan's version of ''Romeo and Juliet.'' Many of the company's stars will take their turns as the tragically star-crossed lovers. Among the performances of note: the American ballerina GILLIAN MURPHY makes her New York debut as Juliet, DAVID HALLBERG as her Romeo on Wednesday, and the Italian dancer ALESSANDRA FERRI gives her final performance with the company on Saturday night, with ROBERTO BOLLE, a guest artist also from Italy. Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m., Wednesday and Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, abt.org, $24 to $110. Portraying Romeo and Juliet is probably a common dream for the young dancers participating in this year's NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL BALLET COMPETITION. The hopefuls, who represent 17 countries, will present pas de deux in the first of four public performances on Wednesday night. The rounds continue through Saturday, and an international jury will hand out awards at a gala next Sunday. Wednesday through Saturday at 8 p.m., June 24 at 7 p.m., Rose Theater, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Broadway at 60th Street, (212) 721-6500, nyibc.org; $29, $19 students and 65+ on Wednesday through Saturday, $71.50 for the gala. SAVION GLOVER knows innumerable ways to make tap-dancing an always fresh and often surprising art. And with subtle changes in rhythm, timbre and dynamics, he will once again transform his tapping feet into a whole ensemble of percussion instruments in performances at the Joyce from Tuesday through July 14. Tuesday, Thursday and Fruday at 7:30 p.m., Wednesday and Saturday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $44.

Tiger Woods is not the only golfer on the leader board who will be stalking his third United States Open title Sunday. Lee Janzen, the champion in 1993 and 1998, was seven strokes back Saturday after his third consecutive three-over-par 73. He may have a lot of ground to make up, but it would be unwise to count out Janzen, who came back from five strokes down in the final round of his '98 victory. He steps onto the tight Open courses the way Clark Kent steps into a telephone booth: He seems to gain supernatural powers of concentration and the confidence that he can conquer even the most diabolical conditions.
YOUNG--John, April 8th, 1906 -June 17th, 1997. Loving husband, father and grandfather. Loved, remembered and revered by your family.

GELLMAN--Jerome I., 79, on June 14 of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, former longtime resident of Scarsdale, New York. Mourned by Florence, his wife of 55 years. Loving father of Elyse (Bill), Stephen (Wendy) and Ken (Melissa). Joyful and doting grandfather of Amanda, Lindsay, David, Alexa, Reese, Paige and Nathan. Devoted brother to Elaine and Melvin. Partner in Tucker, Gellman & Mulderig. Of Counsel to Cowan, Liebowitz and Latman. A man of great warmth, charm and humor. His family and friends will miss him dearly. Funeral on June 18, 2007, at 12:00 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY.

WOLF--Norton. The Officers and Membership of the East 62nd Street Association mourn the passing of our long serving and cherished President, Norton Wolf. $(6$)WOLF--Norton. On June 11, 2007, beloved husband of Joan, devoted father of Anne Price and James Wolf, and stepfather of David Lipton. Cherished grandfather of Nicholas Lipton and Michael Lipton. He was a noted advertising executive for 50 years in the metropolitan area. Funeral private.
To the Editor: Re ''A Pianist for Whom Never Was Never an Option'' [June 10]:

To the Sports Editor: ''For Cavaliers-Spurs, Where Have All the Viewers Gone?'' (June 14) attributes poor viewership of the N.B.A. finals to such elements as the small-market teams involved and NBA.com. One reason not considered is the N.B.A.'s inability to enforce rules with common sense. In the 1997 playoffs, Miami's P. J. Brown threw the Knicks' Charlie Ward over his shoulder. After the subsequent melee, the Knicks lost more players than the Heat and the series as well.

To the Editor: Bryan Burrough's laudatory review of Vincent Bugliosi's book on the Kennedy assassination (May 20) is superficial and gratuitously insulting. ''Conspiracy theorists'' -- blithe generalization -- should according to Burroughs be ''ridiculed, even shunned ... marginalized the way we've marginalized smokers.'' Let's see now. The following people to one degree or another suspected that President Kennedy was killed as the result of a conspiracy, and said so either publicly or privately: Presidents Lyndon Johnson and Richard Nixon; Attorney General Robert Kennedy; John Kennedy's widow, Jackie; his special adviser dealing with Cuba at the United Nations, William Attwood; F.B.I. director J. Edgar Hoover (!); Senators Richard Russell (a Warren Commission member), and Richard Schweiker and Gary Hart (both of the Senate Intelligence Committee); seven of the eight congressmen on the House Assassinations Committee and its chief counsel, G. Robert Blakey; the Kennedy associates Joe Dolan, Fred Dutton, Richard Goodwin, Pete Hamill, Frank Mankiewicz, Larry O'Brien, Kenneth O'Donnell and Walter Sheridan; the Secret Service agent Roy Kellerman, who rode with the president in the limousine; the presidential physician, Dr. George Burkley; Mayor Richard Daley of Chicago; Frank Sinatra; and the ''60 Minutes'' producer Don Hewitt. All of the above, à la Burrough, were idiots.

To the Editor: Re: ''A Sense of Anxiety a Shirt Won't Cover'' by Alex Kuczynski (Thursday Styles, June 14): As a plastic surgeon with a subspecialty in gynecomastia, I am dismayed at the tenor of your article.

To the Editor: Re ''Two More Weeks'' (editorial, June 10): A critical bill left off your list of those the Legislature should address before it recesses is the Family Health Care Decisions Act. If the bill is passed, loved ones could make health care decisions for those who lose the ability to do so.

To the Editor: Gak! Joe Queenan's essay ''Summer Bummer'' (June 3) defies a more eloquent response. As a high school senior who reads stacks of books for pleasure each summer, I have detested every summer reading list since fourth grade. Summer reading traditionally starts as politically correct angst and then evolves into increasingly opaque volumes of classics. Every year, the agony of struggling through this mass ultimately comes down to a single summer reading quiz in September. I empathize with any student who has to endure his or her English teacher's recitation of this article and subsequent declaration that, once and for all, it's all really for our own good and if The New York Times says so, then the system can't really be twisted and sadistic. The horror! The horror!

WHEN Eric Hoffstead, a homeless panhandler, asked a New Rochelle police officer for a dollar, he was promptly arrested for violating the state loitering law, which prohibits begging. But Mr. Hoffstead took issue with the charge, asking his court-appointed lawyer to challenge his arrest on the ground that asking for money is a form of speech protected by the First Amendment. Last month, he won his case. Judge Gail Rice of City Court dismissed the indictment, as well as a charge for possession of drugs, which the police would not have found on Mr. Hoffstead if he hadn't been detained for panhandling.

LYNCH--James. Born February 7, 1913, received a B.A. in Economics from Princeton University. He worked for the New York News as Treasurer and for the Chicago Tribune as Vice President. In World War II, he earned the Bronze Star as an Infantryman. His wife Alene Lynch died in 1991. They are survived by one of three sons and seven grandchildren.

Who were the Brooks brothers, anyway? The siblings recognized as the first family of American haberdashery were Edward, Elisha, John and Daniel. They followed their father, Henry Sands Brooks, into the business he founded in 1818 and, in a burst of fraternal feeling, changed the name from H. & D. H. Brooks & Company to the familiar Brooks Brothers. Which is starting to seem a little less familiar, as a new generation of designers puts its mark on the brand's storied style.

Handel: 'Il Trionfo del Tempo e del Disinganno' Le Concert d'Astrée, directed by Emmanuelle Haïm. Virgin Classics 3 63428 2; two CDs. TIME and Enlightenment may win the upper hand in ''Il Trionfo del Tempo e del Disinganno,'' Handel's allegorical oratorio, but beauty and pleasure are certainly the triumphant features of Emmanuelle Haïm's enchanting new recording.

Camp-bound kids are choosing sleeping bags and duffels in classic camouflage, with a stylish twist. Quiksilver scrawls its splatter-paint logo across a sleeping bag with an oversize camouflage pattern in camel, chocolate brown and black. Made of nylon with synthetic filler and a flannel lining, it has a matching drawstring carrying bag (far right, $61 at Space Kiddets in New York, 212-420-9878). Paul Frank's rectangular duffel is printed with camouflage cleverly shaped like monkeys; it has a detachable shoulder strap and is large enough to function as a camp trunk (right, $85, also at Space Kiddets). The cool factor of these two pieces has made them early-summer retail sleepers, so get them while they last. As with all things camouflage: now you see 'em, now you don't.

HIMMELMAN--Charles, died May 17, 2007. A veteran of WWII. He studied meteorology at Haverford College under a program run by the United State's Army. In 1947 he received his law degree from New York University and practiced law in New York City for 40 years. He is survived by his sister Claire Gaynor of NYC and his cousin Judy Richards of Sayville, NY. He will be dearly missed.

John Averill Thursby of Hamden and Richard VanBuren Thursby of Newport, RI. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 20, 2007, at 11:00am in the Spring Glen United Church of Christ, 1825 Whitney Ave., Hamden, Ct. Donations may be made to Bridges, 949 Bridgeport Ave., Milford, CT 06460. To leave condolences or for directions, please visit our website at www.georgejsmithandson .com

SOME husbands, if they remember, present their wives with a gift made of tin or aluminum on their 10th anniversary. Not Jeffrey Dishner. Instead, the chief operating officer of the Starwood Capital Group plotted -- with the help of Homebase Abroad, a luxury villa company that specializes in Italy -- to arrange a week in Tuscany last year as a surprise for his wife, Cathy, to be shared with more than two dozen friends and family members. ''I thought we were going to the Amalfi Coast on our own,'' said Mrs. Dishner. ''My husband told me we had to stop by the Tuscan home of a business associate for cocktails. We drove up this long driveway to this truly stunning villa. Then we were led around a corner to a pool and terrace filled with 28 of our closest friends all holding glasses of champagne. It was overwhelming,'' she said. That evening, Mrs. Dishner recalled, the group dined outside at a long table while a band played. Afterward, there was a private fireworks display. ''It was the most romantic and incredible atmosphere and a night I'll never forget,'' she said.

Sarah Elizabeth Kramer, the daughter of Rachel Schwartz and Dr. Peter D. Kramer of Providence, R.I., is to be married there today to Robert Jonathan Fenster, the son of Albert Fenster of New York and the late Mollyanne Marks and the stepson of Gail Sanger. Rabbi Wayne Franklin is to officiate at the Aldrich House, a 19th-century mansion that is used for public events. The bride, 25, and the bridegroom, 26, met at Harvard, from which they graduated, she cum laude and he summa cum laude.

Cherished aunt of Cristin, Meghan, Siobhan, James, Christian and Elena. Family will receive friends at the Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers on Monday 2-4 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Eugene's Church, Yonkers, on Tuesday at 10 AM. Interment at St. Mary's Cemetery, Yonkers.

Steve Stricker followed one of the worst shots of his round at the United States Open with one of the best of his career. After his shot from a fairway bunker landed well back in the middle of the 18th fairway, Stricker holed a lob wedge for a birdie to finish the third round Saturday with a two-under-par 68. He trails the leader, Aaron Baddeley, by four strokes. He stood at six-over 216, tied for seventh with Jim Furyk and Ángel Cabrera.

SHAPIRO--Arnold, 90 years old, passed away on June 15th, 2007. Beloved husband for 20 years of Muriel Abramson Shapiro. He was predeceased by his first wife, the late Dorothy Milton Shapiro. Beloved father of Douglas and Cynthia Shapiro and Marjorie Shapiro, and the late Joel Shapiro. Beloved father by marriage of Patricia and Alan B. Abramson. Beloved grandfather of Mark and Bridget Shapiro, Michelle Shapiro, Dr. Seth and Luisa Narins, Sara Narins, Josh Narins, Adam Abramson and Joshua Abramson. Graduate of Dartmouth College, class of 1937. While at his family business, Maryland Cup, he participated in the invention of the first machine-made ice cream cones and the ''Bendy Straw.'' $(6$)SHAPIRO--Arnold. Your presence in our lives for the last 20 years was a blessing. Your love for us, and ours for you was perfect. Your sweetness and kindness never faltered. You will live in our hearts forever. Alan, Patricia, Adam and Joshua Abramson
An article on May 20 about the Pan Asian Repertory Theater referred incorrectly in two references to Daniel Dae Kim, who has acted with the troupe. He is Mr. Kim, not Mr. Dae Kim.

John H. Hammergren has plenty of incentives to stay on as chairman and chief executive of the McKesson Corporation, the health care services giant based in San Francisco. But to pad his pension is not one of them. Mr. Hammergren, who after six years as the chief executive is only 48, could quit tomorrow and immediately collect full pension benefits as if he had worked until retirement. How large would that lump sum be? Almost $76 million. McKesson disclosed that obligation in its latest proxy statement, though it said it had accounted for only about $35 million of it.

DAVIS--Doris Rosenbaum (Dee Dee), 87, author and artist extraordinaire, died peacefully at home on June 14th. Her loving and beloved children, Laurie Gilkes and Peter Davis, her adored and adoring grandchildren Amy Gilkes Loe and Conner Davis, and her dear grandson-in-law Brad Loe miss her already. Fabulously feisty, she was surrounded by people who loved and respected her. She lived by her father's oft-quoted words, ''Let nothing disturb the harmony of your thoughts''. A memorial service is being planned. The family will be receiving guests at Dee's home on Sunday and Monday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY Hospice Care and to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center.

HBO does not want you to stop believing in HBO just because ''The Sopranos'' is no longer with us. The network is ensuring that we remain fed. Among its new series is a comedy called ''FLIGHT OF THE CONCHORDS,'' making its debut on Sunday at 10:30 p.m. It delivers the exploits of a two-man band from New Zealand that seeks its fortune in New York under the guidance of a manager who moonlights -- or, rather, daylights -- at the country's consulate in Manhattan. Approach with caution if sideburns constitute a look you cannot abide. ''MEADOWLANDS,'' a new series on Showtime also beginning on Sunday (at 10 p.m.) is not actually about the Meadowlands, which is to say it is not here to satisfy our New Jersey fetish. Like ''The Riches'' on FX, this show is about obscured identities, a family in hiding, criminal pasts, the secrets suburban developments harbor. If Jimmy Hoffa's body turns up by the final episode, disregard all of what's been said. The show will have been about the New Jersey Meadowlands after all. New seasons of ''THE 4400'' and ''THE DEAD ZONE,'' both on the USA network, also begin on Sunday, and Monday brings the debut of ''HEARTLAND'' (TNT, 10 p.m.), a new medical drama starring Treat Williams in which nothing as mundane as a knee replacement bogs the doctors down. Here, Mr. Williams plays an organ-transplant surgeon who must deal with the miseries of replacing failing kidneys -- and with a co-worker who happens to be his ex-wife.

NEIMAND--Samuel. June 8th, 2007. Born October 1st, 1917. Survived by his wife Pauline of 67 years, brothers Murray and Harry, his sister Sally, his children Jerry (Jane) Neimand, Judi (Jerry) Lerman, and Bonnie (Jeff) Sherman, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren.

The article only confirmed my conviction that Hillary Clinton's positions vacillate according to the polls of public opinion, making it impossible to discern how she truly feels about issues important to me, a liberal Democrat. Her approach, while arguably identical to that of the other candidates, is no more palatable to me than its polar opposite -- George Bush's ''stay the course'' refusal to listen to the electorate.

Gay Pride Week starts Sunday and ends with next Sunday's annual parade, making it easy to spend the entire week taking in gay-theme theater. On Sunday THE NEW YORK NEO-FUTURISTS are presenting the final show in a weekend-long run of ''Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind: Super Gay!'' This hyperkinetic troupe's M.O. is a race against the clock to present 30 very short plays --all written by company members, in 60 minutes. Audience members choose the order of the lineup by yelling out choices from a list they've been handed at the door. Standard rules apply this weekend, but the subject matter across the board will be, well, super gay. Sunday at 8 p.m., Kraine Theater, 85 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $20. Ever type your name into the search box in Google just to see what comes up? Citations for people who share your name. Jason Schafer, who wrote for ''Queer as Folk, uses ''ego surfing'' as a jumping-off point for his new play, ''I GOOGLE MYSELF.'' In it, a gay pornographic star, a stoner-mechanic-poet and a stalker share a common name in this production by Theater Askew that poses the question: How far might one go to be a top search term on Google? In previews, opens on Thursday, Under St. Marks, 94 St. Marks Place, East Village, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $18. Beginning Tuesday the NATIVE ALIENS THEATER COLLECTIVE will present its eighth annual series of original short plays about gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender issues. ''Short Stories 8: Urban View,'' will feature eight plays, chosen by the company's nine-member board from more than 100 submissions. Tuesday through Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., the Independent, 52-A West Eighth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $15 in advance, $20 at the door.

To the Editor: Re ''Cocaine, Hidden in Plain Sight'' by Melena Ryzik (June 10): The writer, as well as the clinical experts and club denizens she quotes, all miss a glaring truth about cocaine abuse. The legal system turns a blind eye to casual cocaine use because the users are part of an upscale, largely white, largely young population of social climbers. Crack users are perceived to be a largely poor, largely minority population with no social mobility.
FREELAND--Mark. Artist, musician, shaman, true star. Heaven is in for a treat. Rock on, alien brother. Nina Garfinkel and Steven Notis
GERSON--John. June 16th, 1923 to June 20th, 1997. Remembered each day with love.

Last week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York praised the Hertz Corporation for its decision to add 100 Toyota Prius hybrid vehicles to its Manhattan fleet of rental cars, and to donate $250,000 for environmental initiatives to the Mayor's Fund to Advance New York City. Mr. Bloomberg and Mark P. Frissora, the chief executive of Hertz, spoke at a press conference at the American Museum of Natural History to announce their new alliance.

An article on June 10 about the HBO series ''Flight of the Conchords'' referred incorrectly to the pilot. It was directed by James Bobin -- not Troy Miller, who is one of several executive producers of the show, along with Mr. Bobin.

GALLUP--Prudence Anne. On June 10. Not quite 65, much too young, an intellectual,highly literate, deeply curious, strongly opinionated, world traveller, cosmopolitan with a wonderful sense of humor. Mourned and missed by her brothers Allyn and Christopher and their wives Sheila and Chrystal, her nieces Marcy and Laurie, her nephew Christopher and their families, her partner Leeanne Lipston, and her many friends

FOR two former undercover detectives in their early 40s who cheated death time and again, no day is ordinary, not anymore, and certainly not a day like this one on the shore of Long Island -- a day showered with sea spray and salt air; with clam bellies in a bucket at their sides and jigs tempting stripers in the surf; with sand and sky, wind and waves, straight talk about life and mocking chatter about death. As they keep a watchful eye for any wiggle of their 15-foot-long fishing poles, Ernest Vallebuona of New City, N.Y., and Michael Valentin of Ronkonkoma, N.Y., shoot the breeze about how, as partners in one of New York City's undercover vice squads, they easily adapted to the pace of street work -- long hours of waiting interrupted by spurts of dramatic action -- kind of like saltwater fishing, actually.

KALTMAN--Martin, died on June 15th at the age of 92. He had homes in Old Westbury, NY and Key Biscayne, FL. He was a man of great vision, imagination and a pioneer of the modern Lithographic industry in New York. With fellow Brooklyn Tech graduate Max Verebay they started Kaltman Press in 1932 to print labels by the letterpress process. They remained partners for 66 years. When the LP record was invented in 1947, they started printing album covers. With the advent of lithography they joined with Jack Hecht in 1950 to create Queens Lithographing Corp. in Long Island City. With the growth of album sales in the sixties. Queens Litho printed all Beatles and Rolling Stones LPs and the company grew rapidly. During that period the company opened factories in Edison, NJ and Indianapolis. In 1964 the company displayed an operating printing press on the floor of Grand Central Station. The volume of music packaging exploded in the eighties with the introduction of the compact-disc and the company added a factory in Louisville to handle the growth. The company changed its name to Queens Group Inc. Packaging for Home Video, Video games and Software created the need for added capacity and the company built two factories in North Carolina. The company also produced high quality packaging for cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and private label. The company was sold in 1998 and is now part of International Paper. A philanthropist, Mr. Kaltman actively supported UJA-Federation, MOMA, Julliard School where he endowed a scholarship, NSUH-LIJ Health System and the Botanical Gardens in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx. Martin was a founder of American Friends of Boystown Jerusalem and his company donated a printing press to the school in Israel. He loved growing plants, flowers, trees, vegetables and studied Horticulture at SUNY Farmingdale, and helped establish The Gardens at Crandon Park in Key Biscayne. He was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle. Mr. Kaltman's first wife, the former Helen Reich, died in 1984. He is survived by his second wife, the former Rosalie Podoll, her children and grandchildren. His son Eric and wife Marnee of Old Westbury, NY, their children Dennis, Richard, Jodi, Jon, their spouses and eight greatgrandchildren. His daughter Gail Bates and husband Dennis of Marietta, GA, their children Stephanie, Robin, their spouses and four greatgrandchildren. Memorial contributions may be sent to Queens Botanical Garden, attention: Susan Lacerte, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing, NY 11355.

An article on June 10 about the recipients of prizes awarded by the William H. Johnson Foundation misstated the role of Steve Turner. He is a founder of the organization -- not the founder of the awards gala, which began as a foundation project. The article also omitted another founder. She is Victoria Dailey.

Beach cover-ups achieve a luxurious level, thanks to a line of summer dresses, tunics and pants by Taka. The bright, lavishly patterned clothes are made in super-fine woven cottons, so lightweight they can be worn as cover-ups over swimsuits, but opaque enough to be worn as street clothing. Look for beautiful hand-beaded detailing, braided camisole straps, microfringed hems and pants with elastic waists for yoga lovers or poolside lounging ($114 to $289 at Gatsbys in Great Barrington, Mass.; 413-528-9455). Made in Turkey -- the decorative embroideries represent regions of the country -- the clothes are the handiwork of village women whose cottage industry helps support their families.

To the Editor: ''Knocked Up'' is a comedy about a young woman who gets pregnant with a man she doesn't know. If she decides to have an abortion eight minutes into the movie, there isn't much of a comedy left. It is true that American movies seldom depict abortions -- but there are a lot of things American movies seldom depict. Like sex between unattractive people. Or life as we know it.

KAPLAN--Jetta, died June 11, 2007 at the age of 94. She is survived by her brother, George and his wife Frances, as well as a loving family that includes two nieces, two nephews, eight grand-nieces and nephews and nine great grand-nieces and nephews. She travelled extensively and tasted life joyously with her husband of 38 years, David, now deceased. We will miss her love, intelligence and tremendous spirit. Having taught us all how to take long deep breaths of air and of life, she will always be remembered for as long as we live.

To the Sports Editor: ''In a Stirring Belmont, the Filly Beats the Fellas'' (June 10) suggested a ''dismal record'' for fillies in the Triple Crown races. What is dismal is the number of filly entrants. Only 2.2 percent of the 1,690 Kentucky Derby entrants, 4.6 percent of 1,140 Preakness entrants and 2.2 percent of the 1,015 Belmont entrants were fillies.

Dexterrie Clemente Ramirez, a daughter of Terrie and Dexter Ramirez of Diamond Bar, Calif., was married yesterday to Robin Hom, a son of Ann Hsiung and Sandy K. Hom of Manhattan. The Rev. John Davis, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at University Parish, Church of St. Joseph in Manhattan. Ms. Ramirez, 29, is keeping her name. Last month she completed her first year at the City University of New York School of Law at Queens College, and is now a summer legal intern for Justice Lottie E. Wilkins of New York Supreme Court in Manhattan. She graduated from the University of California, Los Angeles, and received a master's degree in educational psychology from New York University.

I found it interesting that gender was not discussed. School and academics, in the early years especially, are geared more to the activity level of girls. Generally speaking, girls are capable of sitting quietly longer and are more interested in reading and paperwork than boys of the same age. (Of course, there are exceptions.) But carrying this forward to the middle-school years, it is so obvious that girls mature earlier, both physically and socially. I think we'd be doing society a favor by instituting a gender option of starting boys in kindergarten a year later than girls. In reality, with ''redshirting,'' that's what's happening. It's mostly boys who are given an additional year to mature.

To the Editor: Pervasive graffiti was the scourge that defaced the city when times were bad. Now, just as the city has reached a peak of prosperity and pizzazz, it is those monstrous sidewalk sheds that are defacing streets everywhere, not just in Manhattan (''The Great Midtown Cover-Up,'' June 10).

MANY states nationwide are considering legislation to legalize the medical use of marijuana. Last week, one such bill cleared both houses in Connecticut (but at press time had not yet been signed by the governor), New York appears likely to follow suit and New Jersey has two bills with bipartisan support. Indeed, a number of states have had similar measures in play over the last year, in addition to the 12 that have already passed such laws. The picture is very different at the federal level, where marijuana is branded as an illegal drug. An amendment to a recent drug safety bill would require all purveyors of state-authorized medical marijuana to be subject to Food and Drug Administration regulation. The senator who introduced this amendment said that making any drug available without F.D.A. review or proof of safety and effectiveness would set a dangerous precedent that would threaten patient safety. Marijuana advocates have opposed the bill, because it would close medical marijuana cooperatives and create barriers to the use of the drug.
PERLSTEIN--Harvey L. Daddy dear, our 47th Father's Day without you makes us so sad. We love and miss you. Audrey, Ellen and Suzanne

METZ--Eugene L., 90, a lifelong educator, died in Augusta, Georgia on May 30, 2007. Born in New York City in 1917, son of Herman A. Metz and Alice van Ronk Metz, he attended The Choate School (class of 1936) and Yale University (class of 1941). Due to a childhood bout with Polio, he was unable to join the WWII efforts. In 1942, he became headmaster at the Graham Eckes School in Palm Beach, Florida. After the war, he moved to Boston, Massachusetts and taught English at the Thayer Academy. On a trip to South America he met his future wife, Gloria Eastman in Quito, Ecuador. In 1952, the Metz family moved to Strasbourg, France, where Mr. Metz became a student advisor at the College of Free Europe. Later, in Paris, he became one of the directors of the Free Europe Committee, an institution whose purpose was to promote the ideas of western democracy to students from behind the Iron Curtain and Africa. In 1966, the family moved back to Quito, Ecuador where Mr. Metz worked on restoring his wife's family 400-year-old ''Hacienda Cusin,'' now a wellknown hotel near Otavalo. After his wife's death, he became Director General of the Colegio Americano de Quito, until 1979 when he returned to the United States, first to Boston and then to West Palm Beach. Except for a brief return to Quito as interim Director of the Colegio Americano from 1988 to 1991, he resided in West Palm Beach until early 2007. Mr. Metz was a cultivated man and engaging raconteur. His fair-minded attitude and sense of humor endeared him to his many friends and students. He will be remembered fondly by everyone who knew him. He is survived by his children, Victoria, Philip and Daniela, Edward and Eugenia and grandchildren Nicholas, Caroline, Isabella and Alexandra as well as many other family members in the USA, Ecuador and Europe.

To the Editor: As someone who grew up in the Highbridge section of the Bronx in the 1940s and '50s, I was very much touched by ''A Much-Loved Library, Locked for Two Years'' (June 3). For my friends and I who attended P.S. 11 or Sacred Heart, the local library was a destination of cool comfort on summer days when the streets were too hot to play in. During the school year the children's library, then on the 168th Street side, was where we went to research our earliest school assignments or borrow the books we needed for book reports.

Mike Mussina's spot in the rotation comes up twice on the Yankees' trip to National League parks at Colorado and San Francisco. That presents Manager Joe Torre with a problem. Torre has made the light-hitting Wil Nieves (.122 batting average) the personal catcher for Mussina. But Jorge Posada, the regular catcher, is batting .347. With no designated hitter allowed, how could Torre get Posada's bat into the lineup?

BONCOMPAGNI--Laetitia (Princess). It is with profound sadness that we note the passing of Laetitia Boncompagni of Rome, Italy on June 11, 2007. To the Editor: Regarding ''36 Hours: Moscow'' (May 27): I am an African-American male who has traveled frequently to Moscow. I am not sure why The Times would suggest the city as a travel destination. Moscow, if not all of Russia, is not a safe place for obvious members of minority groups. On my last trip to Moscow I was assaulted by a group of neo-Nazi skinheads. I was kicked, punched and spit upon by this group of six delinquents. The attack occurred on a Saturday afternoon, in a public place, with dozens of witnesses. The only person who came to my aid was another American, who was traveling with me.

I'VE done the math more than once over the past 38 years. The first time was in 1969. I was a typical unfocused, unkempt, underachieving and generally unrepentant sixth-year antiwar undergraduate at the University of Wisconsin. In a drafty cottage on Lake Kegonsa, with my brand new colicky son howling into my shoulder, I would pace across the messy living room, back and forth, my lips and fingers desperately trying to quantify how many years, months, days, minutes until the tiny screamer would be 18 and I'd be my free and easy hipster self again. It was immature -- I was immature -- and the arithmetic premature at best. In the 19 years that followed that July evening, as six more howling infants graced our sometimes graceless, and more often sleepless, lives, I calculated and recalculated and recalculated just how long it would be before that particular crying baby would fly the coop.
An article on June 3 about the city's clock master, Marvin Schneider, inaccurately described a 5,000-pound bell that rings hourly in the Clock Tower Building. The bell is bronze, not brass.

The Boîte column on March 25, about the Box, a nightclub on the Lower East Side, referred incorrectly to a song performed there by the Hungry March Band. It was one of their own compositions, not one by the Nigerian folk artist Fela. The band pointed out the error in an e-mail message sent on June 11.

FISHELSON--Dorothy of East Hampton New York passed away peacefully at home from pancreatic cancer on Saturday 16 June, 2007. Mrs. Fishelson was an active advocate of education and opportunity throughout her life. Most recently she served on the Board of Directors for the Child Development Center of the Hamptons, the Retreat (a shelter for abused women), League of Women Voters and the East Hampton Housing Authority. Born Dorothy Seidman on June 10, 1925 in the Bronx, she majored in Math at Hunter College and obtained her MS degree from Columbia University. She served on the Central Sewanhaka School District Board of Education for 15 years, eight of which she was president. She earned her central administrative certificate at 53 and served as Assistant Superintendent for Personnel at the East Meadow School District until her retirement in 1993. Mrs. Fishelson is survived by her three daughters Caren Gough, Barbara Fishelson and Hollis Fishelson-Holstine; her sister, Beatrice Wellens, her four grandchildren Farrah Zuckerman, Keith Gough, Megan Holstine and Kaya Kachigian; her nephew -Richard Wellens and her niece Lorraine Wellens. The funeral service will be held at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons (www.JCOH.org) on 11:30 am on Sunday, 17 June 2007.

I read Elizabeth Weil's article with interest (June 3). As the mother of a first grader who is a year younger than many of his classmates, I have struggled with issues of readiness, maturity and size. However, as a high-school teacher, I have had experience with the consequences of the decision to begin kids later. Increasingly, 12th-grade classrooms are filled with students at the tail end of their teenage years. I'm curious why articles that address this issue rarely look at it from the perspective of high-school students. At some point, do the benefits that accrue from delayed entry to kindergarten turn into deficits, as students find themselves graduating from high school at 19 and college at 23?

WHEN Lindsay Mathews gets angry, she puts it on a sign. In the last four years, she has directed her anger at the war in Iraq by creating some two dozen signs and hanging them outside her home in the Short Beach section.

To the Editor: Re ''After the Bomb,'' by William J. Perry, Ashton B. Carter and Michael M. May (Op-Ed, June 12): It is important that all generations of Americans face up to the implications of the detonation of a nuclear device in a major city. The horrors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki should be constantly on our minds.

To the Editor: Re ''Two More Weeks'' (editorial, June 10): A critically important bill left off your list of those the Legislature should address before it recesses is the Family Health Care Decisions Act (which you have supported in the past). If the bill is passed, loved ones could make health care decisions for those who lose the ability to do so.

A graphic last Sunday about health and safety issues misspelled the name of a new diagnosis for the shoulder pain caused by playing tennis on Wii, the video game console. It is acute Wiiitis, not Wiitis. The article also omitted the name of the journal that published the letter in which the diagnosis, and its name, was reported. It is The New England Journal of Medicine.

Dr. Maggie Blair Hymowitz and Dr. Scott James Sequeira were married last evening at the Rosecliff mansion in Newport, R.I. Anne M. Collins, a former clerk of the Newport County Superior Court, officiated. The bride, 29, will continue to use her name professionally. She will begin her residency in ophthalmology at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx in July. She graduated cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and received her medical degree from Boston University. She is a daughter of Harriet Ellen Hymowitz and Dr. Samuel S. Hymowitz of Manhasset, N.Y. Her father, a periodontist, works at Richmond Hill Dental Associates in Richmond Hill, Queens.

He is survived by his wife Cornelia and their eight children and 14 grandchildren. A funeral service was held on June 9, at the Church of St. Patrick, Huntington, NY.

ON a drizzling Sunday morning last month, Adrienne Pincus hit the brakes on her bicycle as two riders -- one a close friend -- crashed on a rain-slicked road in Norwalk, Conn., near the start of the Bloomin' Metric, one of region's most popular cycling events. By the time Mrs. Pincus, 46, of White Plains, had stopped, her friend was lying in the road. Her helmet had flown off, and her head had hit the pavement so hard that blood soon began to ooze from both ears.

Nifong, the North Carolina prosecutor who brought assault charges against three Duke lacrosse players, was disbarred after volunteering to give up his license. ''There is no discipline short of disbarment that would be appropriate in this case,'' an ethics panel said.
