Doctors, pharmacists, and emergency room personnel may one day have instant access to the medical records of patients in New Jersey. The State Assembly passed a measure on Monday that would create an electronic database and infrastructure to share patient information, which supporters say would save more than $700 million by eliminating unnecessary paperwork, tests and administrative costs. ''We will never achieve anything close to universal access to health insurance unless we save the costs that can be saved in health care by reducing all the redundant studies that we do and reduce the costs of performing transactions in health care,'' said Dr. Herb Conaway, a Democratic assemblyman from Burlington who was one of the primary sponsors of the bill. Mr. Conaway, a practicing physician, said that he believes an electronic system is more efficient for both patients and doctors.

In my Findings column, I report the possible sighting of a "true altruist," a being that some have argued is even rarer than the one sought by Diogenes (the ancient Greek eccentric who went around with a lamp, fruitlessly searching for an honest man).

Two of the leading Republican candidates for president have said this month that they will not participate in the Ames, Iowa, straw poll, a ritual showing of political strength in that early caucus state. Their decisions raised doubts about whether Iowa would maintain its importance in selecting the party's nominee.

May was good for political Web sites. An Internet researcher, comScore Inc., reports that traffic to such sites jumped 17 percent to nine million unique visitors last month, the highest rate of increase among the 110 categories that the company studies.
While the Obama Girl video became a mini-rage on YouTube last week, another kind of rock video was silently racking up the page views.
Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards and Eventful, the online site that lets users "demand" appearances by celebrities and candidates, kicked off a month-long contest today.
As Yahoo announced that Terry S. Semel was stepping down as chief executive of the beleaguered Internet giant, two questions arose: Is Yahoo in play? What now for the shareholder activists?
Forget about freedom fries. American businessmen have come to the Paris air show in full force.

A few weeks back a puff piece in a New Zealand newspaper extolled a trucking company that "has fostered an egalitarian culture and does not believe in hierarchy, bureaucracy or superiority." The same article also noted that company headquarters features this saying in bold text on a lobby wall: "The man on top of the mountain didn't fall there."
I survived 24 hours in the pits of the Corvette Racing team at the 24 Hours of Le Mans -- and had a beer poured on my head to prove it!

Got a minute? The Sopranos links got too heavy, and The Lede had to put them down next to the gabagool. We've got fun clicks, new theories and some statistics about the finale that is still a matter of heavy debate, especially about whether Tony lived or died.

A lot of liberals blame Colin Powell for persuading them to support the notion of getting into the Iraq war, but is Colin Powell also to blame for the Bush administration's inability to get the United States out of the Iraq war? In a roundabout way, yes, suggests Andrew J. Bacevich, a professor of history and international relations at Boston University, in The Boston Globe's "Ideas" section.In a long essay arguing for the abolishment of the position of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Bacevich says Powell is indirectly to blame for the nation's poor military leadership since he stepped down as chairman of the Joint Chiefs. Bacevich writes:
On the surface, the news coming out of Florida last week seemed so promising: "The Florida Legislature passed the biggest property-tax cut in state history," one report began.
Add one more thing to Kobe Bryant's long list of talents: he can send news coverage rippling across the Web with a simple change of a timestamp.
Senator Barack Obama disavowed the document his campaign aimed at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton last week, saying today that it was "stupid and caustic."

As shareholder activists grab the spotlight more often -- the most recent example being The Children's Investment Fund's pushing for a sale of ABN Amro -- one of the largest institutional investors in the United States has decided to hitch itself to itself to their star.

The former chief of Enron's high-speed Internet unit, who turned government witness and testified in the trial of Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, was sentenced Monday to 27 months in prison. Nearly three years ago, Kenneth Rice, 48, pleaded guilty to securities fraud and agreed to help federal prosecutors on other cases related to the energy giant's collapse. His sentencing was postponed as he cooperated with prosecutors.

As chatter rises over the prospect of a General Electric-Pearson bid for Dow Jones, many have been wondering how that combination could possibly trump News Corporation's $60-a-share offer. Most analysts and pundits see Rupert Murdoch's bid, worth about $5 billion, as too rich to be beaten. The septuagenarian media mogul could also open his wallet even wider, according to common wisdom.

United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon's op-ed article tracing the vicious ethnic conflict in Darfur to a drought that was caused "at least in part from climate change" may have sounded surprising to some observers.

Shares in Cadence Design Systems fell Monday following a report that buyout talks for the maker of chip design software have hit a wall. The stock was trading at $22.25 Monday afternoon, down 4.5 percent.

CIT Group, the New York-based financing firm, said Monday it would acquire Edgeview Partners, a mergers and acquisitions adviser whose clients include many buyout firms. CIT did not disclose the price it paid for Edgeview, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., but said in a press release that the deal was part of an effort to expand its offerings to the private equity industry.

Senator John McCain's presidential campaign stepped up its attacks on Republican rival Mitt Romney today, sending a March 2005 clip to this reporter that appears to highlight anew an apparent change in Mr. Romney's position today on taxpayer financing of embryonic stem cell cell research.

Presidential hopefuls have been traveling hat in hand to Greenwich, Conn., usually leaving with wads of hedge-fund money. But the town's own public golf course has been far less successful at prying cash out of the hands of Greenwich's well-heeled citizens.
UPDATE, June 19, 5:23 PM ET After a documentary leaked in a serious way over the weekend, the studio has decided to move up the opening. Michael Cieply tells it well.

A lot has changed since 2003, when Eliot Spitzer, then New York's attorney general, reached a settlement with Wall Street firms intended to bring more independence to their equity research arms, whose reputations were tarnished by questions about conflicted loyalties.
The news that Pearson and General Electric are thinking about making a counter-offer for Dow Jones raises the interesting question: Could an underbid succeed?

Private equity firms may be feeling unfriendly vibes from Washington these days, but the Supreme Court just gave Wall Street's investment banks a big hug. In a 7-1 ruling, the nation's highest court ruled that banks including Credit Suisse, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley are immune from antitrust lawsuits that alleged they conspired to drive up prices of initial public offerings in the late 1990's.
Iraq is now the second most unstable country in the world, outranked in that category only by Sudan, according to an annual survey conducted by Foreign Policy magazine.
Screens plans to go broke overestimating everyone's intelligence today, including its own.
A quick hike through this past Sunday's book sections.
As General Electric casts around for partners in a possible rival bid for Dow Jones, its chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, might want to keep five letters in the back of his mind: MSNBC.

For people like me who think they've seen everything in London, there is a gem lying hidden at the British museum: The Assyrian collection, which is accessed through two doors in a lobby between the Rosetta stone (seen that!) and the Elgin marbles (seen them too!). Racing from one to the other of these London big name exhibits, most first-time tourists would hardly notice the Assyrian halls.

I notice that in response to my post about the season opener of "Top Chef," one of its judges, Tom Colicchio, wrote in to quibble with the implication that the Bravo network has a hand in determining which contestants are eliminated and which make it deep into the competition.
Rudolph Giuliani, who has had close ties to Jewish leaders since he was mayor of New York City, met privately with Israel's Prime Minister Ehud Olmert today.
In the sad club of dwindling wildlife populations, the birds and the bees are joined by the tortoise, but not the hare, apparently.

Topps said Monday that it would postpone a vote on a $385 million buyout offer by two private equity firms, including one run by Michael D. Eisner, after a Delaware chancery court judge ruled that the baseball card maker must disclose more information about the deal. Topps said it would also allow a rival, Upper Deck, to make a tender offer to its shareholders, in accordance with the decision by Judge Leo Strine Jr.

It seems aimed squarely at the Blackstone Group, but last week's bill proposing to raise taxes on publicly traded buyout funds, if it were to become law, would probably cause many other firms to reconsider the idea of getting ticker symbols of their own. That could mean less of the transparency that many lawmakers were hoping to see in the industry, and might even result in less taxes for Treasury coffers, not more, Andrew Ross Sorkin wrote in his latest DealBook column in The New York Times.
The practice of collecting blood samples from Amazon Indians has aroused suspicions in Brazil. Joaquina Karitiana says researchers broke promises to her tribe.

Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce Tuesday that it will sell its American beverage business, which includes 7-Up, Dr Pepper and Snapple, according to The New York Times. Cadbury said in March that it would split its confectionary and soft drinks businesses, but had not determined whether it would sell the beverage business or spin it off.

I saw my first patient in the Congo today. Her name is Yohanita Nyiahabimana. She is a 41-year old woman who lives in the village of Malehe, about an hour from Goma. She was carried out of her house by her neighbors when they heard that we were coming. There she lay on some tattered blankets, all 50 pounds of her under the unforgiving African sun.

Goldman Sachs's alternative investment funds, including its hedge funds, experienced net inflows of zero in the latest quarter for the first time since the bank began reporting such data in 2004, the Financial News said. Last year, by comparison, the bank reported net inflows of $32 billion.
The Lede ended last week focused on digging up a 1957 Plymouth Belvedere in Tulsa, so why not start this one off with the relocation of an 1883 carriage house in Portland?
In his Web column today, Adam Nagourney writes about the Edwards campaign's recent swing through Iowa:
The immigration bill is scheduled to make its reappearance in the Senate by the end of this week but the outlook for its future depends on who you ask.

Buyout talks between Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, and two private equity firms appear to have stalled over price, The New York Times reported.

The Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people. Now, it will see if a new name can burnish its private bank's reputation in catering to the very rich.

James Simons, founder of the hedge fund Renaissance Technologies and a top earner in his field, is putting some of his cash into a new leveraged buyout fund, according to Long Island Business News. Mr. Simons, who led Alpha Magazine's list of the top 25 hedge fund earners, is the largest investor in a new $115 million leveraged buyout fund raised by Topspin Partners, the report said.

The campaign trail through Iowa was well-worn this weekend as many of the presidential candidates made stops in the state. Former Senator John Edwards is one of the hopefuls who have been crisscrossing Iowa in recent days, and as The Times's Adam Nagourney reports, for Mr. Edwards it is part of a strategy that reflects "just how much he has settled on this state as the place where his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination will rise or fall." But Mr. Edwards is running a different kind of campaign this time around than in 2004 when he lost the Iowa caucuses to Senator John Kerry:
Is private equity raining on short-sellers' parade?

BHP Billiton, the world's largest mining company, has revived plans for a $40 billion (£20.2 billion) takeover of Alcoa, according to The Times of London. The newspaper, without citing any named sources, said BHP is in the early stages of evaluating the merits of a takeover. BHP, based in Melbourne, "is not thought to have" formally approached Alcoa, the Times reported.

The hedge fund administrator GlobeOp is planning to make an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange. GlobeOp said it hoped to get $102 million for the 20.4-million-share offering. A Boston buyout specialist, TA Associates, and Mezzanine Management are offering the stock and will both retain a "significant holding" in GlobeOp after the shares are sold.

Finish Line, the footwear retailer, said Monday it had agreed to buy Genesco, which owns the teenager-focused Journeys sneaker chain and the Johnston & Murphy brand of dress shoes, for $1.5 billion, or $54.50 a share. The deal, which the boards of directors at both companies are supporting, came after Genesco rejected two bids from Foot Locker, the second of which was for $51 a share.
On the campaign trail with John Edwards in Iowa, where he has made the state the place where his candidacy will rise or fall.
David Maisel, the newly minted chairman of Marvel Studios, was until recently a little-known deal maker trained by the former kingpin Michael S. Ovitz.

The New York law firm Chadbourne & Parke is in preliminary merger discussions with the Watson, Farley & Williams law firm of London, Chadbourne's managing partner, Charlie O'Neill, told The American Lawyer magazine.

As Bear Stearns struggles with big losses at one of its hedge funds, MarketWatch notes that the troubled fund has ties to Everquest Financial, a company that filed plans for an initial public offering last month.

Shares in Imperial Chemical Industries of Britain, the maker of Dulux paints, rose 16 percent Monday after it rejected a 7.2 billion pound ($14.2 billion) takeover bid from Akzo Nobel, a Dutch rival and the maker of Crown paints.

After making an overture to Microsoft about a joint bid for Dow Jones, the General Electric Company, the parent of NBC, is now exploring that idea with Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, according to reports on Monday. The talks are still preliminary, and Rupert Murdoch's $5 billion offer for Dow Jones represents a "a very high threshold," The New York Times said. The Wall Street Journal quoted several sources describing the possibility of a deal as a "long shot."

Air Canada Technical Services will name a buyer as early as Monday, and signs point to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts edging out Lufthansa Technik Group of Germany in a close race, according to The Globe and Mail.

The French nuclear giant Areva has presented a cash bid worth 2.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.3 billion) for UraMin, a South Africa-headquartered company interlisted on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Areva said Friday it is bidding 7.75 Canadian dollars per share for UraMin stock, which closed Thursday at 7.94 Canadian dollars.

The battle for the British music group Sanctuary may not be over yet, with a London-listed investment bank, Crosby Capital Partners, preparing a counterbid to trump Universal Music Group's 20 pence-per-share offer, according to The Guardian. Crosby, which has offices in Hong Kong and London, has appointed lawyers from SJ Berwin to help make its offer for the troubled music group, which manages Sir Elton John and James Blunt, the report said.

Microsoft will take a stake in Shanghai-listed Changhong Electric and work with the firm to jointly develop entertainment products that can be accessed via the Internet, Changhong said. Changhong Electric said in a statement on Monday that Microsoft would take a 94-million-yuan ($12.3 million) stake in the firm by purchasing 15 million new shares.

Wachovia, which agreed last month to buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion, has been added to a federal lawsuit accusing large brokerages of moving customers' idle cash into low-yielding accounts to boost profits.

The Hain Celestial Group said Friday it had been informed by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the agency is conducting an informal inquiry into the company's stock option practices. Hain, the American company that makes organic and natural foods and personal care items, said it would cooperate with the investigation.

Consolidation in Taiwan's banking sector continues as a private equity firm, The Longreach Group, announced at the end of last week that it would invest 23 billion New Taiwan dollars ($694 million) to acquire 51 percent of the EnTie Commercial Bank.

In-Q-Tel, a private investment firm launched by the Central Intelligence Agency to support domestic intelligence agencies, has invested in an image sensor maker Pixim, the company said last week. The investment was part of a $15 million funding round announced in March that included Tallwood Venture Capital, Ridgewood Capital and the Mayfield Fund.

Unconfirmed reports Friday that the New York Mercantile Exchange is seeking a buyer at the same time that the Chicago Board of Trade is in the throes of a merger agreement re-emphasized what a tumultuous period this is for the world's financial markets, as they focus nearly as much on buying and selling each other as they do on trading products.

Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, a developer of treatments for diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, has signed deals with two private equity firms that will invest nearly $300 million into the 12-year-old publicly held company.

Ian Clarke, the computer scientist who sparked global controversy with his online system called Freenet, which was intended to make it possible to share information anonymously and to make it virtually impossible to be removed from the Internet once it was placed there, is at it again.

How would you feel about paying off your mortgage over the next 50 years? This week, a specialist broker in Britain called The Mortgage Lender announced it was developing a mortgage spanning half a century. The idea is that monthly payments are reduced to a more manageable level.
The New York premiere of Edward Albee’s “Peter and Jerry” is among the offerings in Second Stage Theater’s 2007-8 season.
This new series on TNT is an unequivocally sexy hospital drama. But there is also something distinctly retrograde about it.

This year two of Bonnaroo’s three headliners — Tool and the Police — came from way off the jam-band circuit.
A Palestinian man was killed Monday at the volatile and closed border between Israel and Gaza, after Palestinian gunmen opened fire on Israeli soldiers, officials said.
The split between Ségolène Royal and François Hollande threatens to complicate efforts by the Socialist Party to close ranks.
The changes were recommended by a panel formed after an unarmed man was fatally shot in Queens by the police.
The land has been sold for $110 million to the Nature Conservancy, a move that is intended to protect the land from future development.
Peter Braunstein was convicted on charges that he tied up, sexually molested and terrorized a former colleague.
The Supreme Court found that Wall Street investment banks could not be sued under antitrust law over losses in the crash of technology stocks seven years ago.

The decision freed up tens of millions of dollars in aid that has been frozen since the Hamas victory in legislative elections in early 2006.
U.S. and Iraqi troops began major military operations today against Al Qaeda forces near Baghdad, while in the south, U.S. troops battled Shiite militants.
North Korea could be ready to begin shutting its plutonium reactor within weeks, the envoy said.
American-led coalition forces were attacking a compound that officials said was a safe house for Al Qaeda fighters.

Elizabeth Edwards has always been a dominant figure in her husband’s political life; the news that she has been diagnosed with an advanced stage of cancer has also made her a riveting figure in her own right.
The Yankees finished their finest homestand in nine years with an 8-1 record and split the six-game season series with their crosstown rivals for the third straight year.
Iran accused Britain of insulting Islam by awarding a knighthood to Salman Rushdie, whose novel “The Satanic Verses” led to a fatwa against him in 1989.
A measure moving through Congress would require people in 27 countries, mostly in Western Europe, to register travel plans online 48 hours before departure.
Louisville (47-23), in its first series appearance, plays Tuesday in an elimination game against North Carolina, which lost last night to Rice, 14-4.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the way cancer doctors practice medicine misstated a title for Dr. Peter Eisenberg. He is a former director of the American Society of Clinical Oncology, not a current director. His term ended on June 4. The article also misstated the price of Avastin, a cancer drug. For an average lung cancer patient, it is $8,800 a month, not $8,800 a dose.
An article on Saturday about proposed new anti-terrorism regulations for small boats gave the wrong rank for the Coast Guard’s commandant, Thad W. Allen. He is an admiral, not a vice admiral.
An article on Saturday about proposed new anti-terrorism regulations for small boats gave the wrong rank for the Coast Guard’s commandant, Thad W. Allen. He is an admiral, not a vice admiral.
Don and Donna Byrnes of Bay Ridge are obsessed with the Mets and the Brooklyn Cyclones, whose season starts tomorrow.
The General Electric Company and Pearson are exploring a joint bid for Dow Jones & Company, people familiar with the talks said.

The cost of closing the 90-year-old Fort Monmouth Army post has more than doubled to almost $1.5 billion since a federal commission voted to close it in 2005, a new budget report showed. The report, the Army’s budget request for the 2008 fiscal year, obtained by The Asbury Park Press, attributed the spike to a 571 percent increase in the cost of moving the United States Military Academy Preparatory School to West Point and an 85 percent increase in the cost of military construction at Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland. The federal commission voted two years ago to shut down Fort Monmouth and to move most operations to Aberdeen by 2011. Compiled by John Sullivan.

An 18-month-old boy was killed when he was run over by a neighbor’s car in a Flatbush driveway yesterday shortly after 5 p.m., the police said. The boy was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The neighbor, who was backing the car out on East 26th Street near Avenue I, was unaware of the accident and drove away from the scene. It is unclear whether the toddler was being supervised when he was hit. No charges are expected to be filed against the neighbor, the police said.
Senator John McCain’s campaign may be paying the price for a career of positions alienating traditional big donors.

State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein called yesterday for the state to divest its pension funds of holdings in companies that do business with four countries on the State Department’s list of terrorist nations: Syria, Iran, Sudan and North Korea. Senator Klein, a Democrat who represents parts of the Bronx and Westchester, held a news conference in front of the United Nations to release a study that said New York State’s public-employee pension fund has about $12 billion invested in companies that have dealings with the nations. Last week, the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, said he would pursue possible divestment regarding Sudan, saying that “the genocide in Darfur is a challenge to our collective capacity to do good.”.

A driver lost control of his livery cab on Flatbush Avenue yesterday afternoon and drove onto the sidewalk, striking two teenage boys and a man, the police said. The accident occurred at 3:20 p.m. on the northbound side of Flatbush at East 29th Street. One teenager, 15, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center in extremely critical condition, the police said. A man with him, whose age was unknown, was in critical condition at the same hospital, while a 16-year-old was in critical condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. Alcohol was not a factor in the accident, and the driver was not charged yesterday afternoon, the police said. Neither the driver nor a passenger in the car was seriously injured.

A man who was shot by police officers on Saturday night after the authorities said he refused to drop a pellet gun that looked like a handgun remained in critical but stable condition yesterday at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. The man was identified as Luis A. Dominguez, 49, of Rosedale. The shooting occurred near his home shortly before 9 p.m., when several officers surrounded him and repeatedly ordered him to drop the gun before firing several shots, witnesses and the police said. Mr. Dominguez was shot in the torso, the police said. A lieutenant suffered a minor shoulder injury, and the police said yesterday it was unclear whether the lieutenant had been grazed by a bullet from a fellow officer. An investigation is continuing, the police said. A neighbor said Mr. Dominguez was prone to hostility when he had been drinking. “He kept going up the street, hiding behind a tree with the gun,” said the neighbor, Zita Young, 43. “I ran to the deli to get one of the guys to see if they could talk to him or help him. By that time we heard the gunshots go off. I wasn’t counting, but it was a lot.”.

Two men died and a third man was seriously injured in two motor vehicle accidents Saturday night and early yesterday, the police said. A 58-year-old man was killed when he drove a Mercedes-Benz through a fence and into a parked car at 3:45 a.m. yesterday at Pennsylvania Avenue near the Belt Parkway. In the other accident, a 27-year-old man was killed and his passenger, also a man in his 20s, suffered head and neck injuries when the motorcycle they were riding collided with a 1999 Ford Taurus at 10 p.m. Saturday at Rockaway Parkway and Church Avenue in Brownsville. The injured man was listed in stable condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. No charges were expected.
Minnesota’s $86 million teacher professionalization and merit pay initiative got a lift when teachers voted overwhelmingly to expand it in Minneapolis.
Ángel Cabrera, a former caddie from Cordoba, Argentina,  fended off Tiger Woods and Jim Furyk for his first major title.
President Nicolas Sarkozy’s governing party won a solid victory in parliamentary elections on Sunday, but in a surprise, it failed to trounce the opposition on the left.
Fissures in the autism community over the cause of the disorder have made their way into the Wright family, founders of the charity Autism Speaks.
A second United States Open title was in Jim Furyk’s grasp Sunday as he stood on the No. 17 tee, gripping his driver. Then, suddenly, it was out of reach.

People are hearing the Red Sox loudly and clearly this season while watching them succeed in somewhat unorthodox ways.
At the epicenter of a war pitting nomads against one of the biggest armies in Africa, villagers said they had been brutalized by government troops.
A mammoth explosion tore through a police bus in the heart of Kabul on Sunday, killing at least 24 people — 22 of them police academy instructors on their way to work.
Guillermo Mota was suspended for the first 50 games of the season for violating baseball’s policy on performance-enhancing drugs. And he, and the Mets, are still paying for it.

The newly created Big Ten Network, which the conference vows will satiate its universities’ fans and alumni, is the source of a dispute between the conference and Comcast.

Before he became an iconic player, simply putting the ball in play was an accomplishment for Derek Jeter.

Senate Democrats are seeking a major reversal of energy tax policies that would reverse incentives and benefits to the oil industry and instead underwrite renewable fuels.

Barry Bonds hit the 748th home run of his career on Sunday. He now trails Hank Aaron by seven in the chase for the major league record.

Andy Roddick won the Queen’s Club title Sunday, saving match point in the second set before beating France’s Nicolas Mahut in the final of the grass-court tuneup for Wimbledon.
Carl Edwards ended a 52-race Nextel Cup winless streak Sunday by holding off Martin Truex Jr. to win at Michigan International Speedway.

Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s traffic plan continues to cause controversy as complications arise.
A new plan for Coney Island still calls for a glass-enclosed water park, but the proposed luxury apartments have been replaced by hotels.

SCHIMMEL--Herbert D., on June 16, 2007, age 80, after a three year battle with cancer. Husband of Ruth Kessler Schimmel, beloved father of Eric P., Curt F., and Susan J. Goldstein. Grandfather of six. Service Monday, June 18, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.
Robert Tracy, a prolific dance writer, died on June 7 in Manhattan. He was 52. The cause was complications of infection with H.I.V., said his sister, Mary Ellen Tracy.

Two men died and a third man was seriously injured in two motor vehicle accidents Saturday night and early yesterday, the police said. A 58-year-old man was killed when he drove a Mercedes-Benz through a fence and into a parked car at 3:45 a.m. yesterday at Pennsylvania Avenue near the Belt Parkway. In the other accident, a 27-year-old man was killed and his passenger, also a man in his 20s, suffered head and neck injuries when the motorcycle they were riding collided with a 1999 Ford Taurus at 10 p.m. Saturday at Rockaway Parkway and Church Avenue in Brownsville. The injured man was listed in stable condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. No charges were expected. THOMAS J. LUECK

BANKING ON A NEW NAME -- Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people. But it is looking to the U.S. Trust name to help burnish its private bank's reputation in catering to the very rich. [Page C1.] MARVEL, THE MOVIE MAKER -- Hollywood's major studios have paid to license Marvel characters to create blockbuster franchises -- including the three ''Spider-Man'' hits -- but the company is no longer content to leave the actual moviemaking (and most of the profits) to the studios. [C1.] NEW HOPES AT AIRBUS -- Since the Farnborough International Airshow last summer, Airbus has changed chief executives twice and warned that delays with its A380 superjumbo jet would wipe out billions in earnings over the next four years. Now it is hoping another aircraft, the twin-engine A350, will be its salvation. [C1.] The United States Air Force has decided to push development of a new type of fuel to power its bombers and fighters, mixing conventional jet fuel with fuels from nonpetroleum sources that could eventually limit military dependence on imported oil. [C10.] A TABLE FOR MILLIONS -- For decades, restaurants have relied on the telephone to take table reservations and on piles of index cards -- or a maitre d'hotel's memory -- to collect information about diners and their quirks. At last, it seems, the restaurant business has gone unabashedly high-tech. [C1.] PLEASE KEEP THE PHONE ON -- Typically you are told to turn off your cellphone before a performance. But at a recent Saturday matinee of ''Spring Awakening,'' the Broadway musical that garnered eight Tony Awards last week, the audience was told to do just the opposite. [C8.] BLOCKBUSTER PICKS BLU-RAY -- Blockbuster will rent high-definition DVDs only in the Blu-ray format in 1,450 stores when it expands its high-def offerings next month, dealing a major blow to the rival HD DVD format. [C2.] A BETTER EBAY -- Under pressure from analysts and investors to jump-start growth in the company's core auctions business, Meg Whitman, left, chief executive of eBay, is making a series of upgrades intended to make the site more friendly to buyers. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C5.] CONDOM ADS REJECTED -- A commercial for Trojan condoms that features anthropomorphized, cellphone-toting pigs has been rejected by Fox and CBS. Advertising. [C6.] FREENET DEVELOPER WEIGHS IN -- In 2000, Ian Clarke started a global controversy by deploying an online system called Freenet to let people share information anonymously. With a new venture called Thoof, he has not given up on his original goal: to engender democracy by making it simple to share accurate information. [C11.] GORE TO ADDRESS ADVERTISERS -- The brightest lights in the advertising business are gathering in Cannes, France, this week for an annual celebration of the art of persuading consumers to part with their money. On Friday, Al Gore will come to town. [C8.] CASH INFUSION FOR DRUG MAKER -- Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, a developer of treatments for diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, is expected to announce today that it has signed deals with two private equity firms that will invest nearly $300 million into the publicly held company. [C2.] BUYOUT TALKS ARE SAID TO FALTER -- Buyout talks between Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, and two private equity firms appear to have stalled over price. [C2.] CADBURY EXPECTED TO SELL UNIT -- Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce that it will sell its American beverage business, which includes 7-Up, Dr Pepper and Snapple, according to people close to the company. [C2.]

An 18-month-old boy was killed when he was run over by a neighbor's car in a Flatbush driveway yesterday shortly after 5 p.m., the police said. The boy was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The neighbor, who was backing the car out on East 26th Street near Avenue I, was unaware of the accident and drove away from the scene. It is unclear whether the toddler was being supervised when he was hit. No charges are expected to be filed against the neighbor, the police said. JENNIFER 8. LEE

LYNCH--James. Born February 7, 1913, received a B.A. in Economics from Princeton University. He worked for the New York News as Treasurer and for the Chicago Tribune as Vice President. In World War II, he earned the Bronze Star as an Infantryman. His wife Alene Lynch died in 1991. They are survived by one of three sons and seven grandchildren.

Fabolous ''From Nothin' to Somethin' '' (Def Jam) The Brooklyn rapper Fabolous is known for rhymes that aspire to nothing more or less than cleverness. His voice is plain and conversational and smooth enough, and if he has any personality quirks he's keeping them to himself. You might even call him dull. But give him a hard backbeat or a soft R&B track, and he'll happily supply you with wordplay until the chorus comes around. He's a word nerd, and he likes nothing more than finding unexpected rhymes: ''Last seen in Brooklyn, they found him by a Bronx lot/Rifles on the roof -- yeah, we got him by a longshot.''

For a team that is having trouble scoring, the most welcome sight is a grooved fastball or a hanging curve. The Mets are as good at pummeling those pitches as any team. But batters cannot hit those pitches if they do not exist. And last night they were few and far between. Chien-Ming Wang, sinkerballer extraordinaire, compounded the Mets' frustration by inducing ground ball after ground ball over eight and two-thirds innings in the Yankees' 8-2 victory at Yankee Stadium. When he was not throwing his sinker, he was firing 95-mile-an-hour fastballs -- on his way to a career-high 10 strikeouts -- and leaving the Mets wondering exactly where that came from.

New York City could start charging residents for the right to park in their own neighborhoods under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan for ''congestion pricing.'' The proposal, which was introduced in the State Senate this month, would charge most drivers $8 to enter Manhattan below 86th Street from 6 a.m. and 6 p.m. on weekdays. To mollify people who live just outside the zone and who fear their streets would be turned into parking lots, the Senate bill would allow the city to issue permits so that most parking spots would be restricted to neighborhood residents.

Bon Jovi ''Lost Highway'' (Island) By now most interested parties have grown accustomed to the idea of a Bon Jovi country album. Last year the band had a No. 1 country hit with ''Who Says You Can't Go Home,'' featuring guest vocals by Jennifer Nettles of the Atlanta group Sugarland. The song's success earned Jon Bon Jovi an invitation to the Country Music Association Awards, where he voiced his appreciation for Nashville's songwriting tradition, looking only slightly out of place.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,510 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday: SONNENBERG, Kevin H., 42, Maj., Air Force; McClure, Ohio; 112th Fighter Squadron.

When the Assembly passed a bill last week that legalized the ''medical use of marihuana,'' copy editors across the state did a double take. Shouldn't that be spelled with a ''j'' instead of an ''h''? ''Marijuana'' is standard usage, but ''the public health law and the penal law have always spelled it with an 'h' ,'' explained Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, the sponsor of the bill. (The Senate version has not come up for a vote.) ''That's the official New York State statutory spelling.''

Argentine Wins U.S. Open Ángel Cabrera of Argentina won the United States Open with a final round of 69 in Oakmont, Pa. Tiger Woods, a two-time Open champion, was left to admire Cabrera's trophy when he fell short of forcing a playoff by one shot after missing a birdie putt on the final hole. Jim Furyk, who was trying to win his second United States Open title, tied Woods for second. PAGE D1 Yankees Roll Past Mets Alex Rodriguez hit a two-run homer in the first inning, and the Yankees never looked back in an 8-2 victory over the Mets, their 11th victory in 12 games. The Yankees' starter, Chien-Ming Wang, gave up two runs over eight and two-thirds innings as the teams split their six-game season series. SPORTSMONDAY Reservations on Demand Restaurants have gone unabashedly high-tech, with more than 7,000 worldwide now taking reservations over the Web. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Parking Fees in Traffic Plan? The fine print of the mayor's congestion pricing plan suggests that some people may have to pay to park near their own homes. PAGE B1 French Conservatives Win The conservative party of President Nicolas Sarkozy won a solid victory in parliamentary elections, but failed to trounce the Socialist opposition as had been predicted. The Socialists gained 36 seats and Mr. Sarkozy's party lost 45. PAGE A6 New Palestinian Government President Mahmoud Abbas swore in an emergency Palestinian government at his headquarters, as the split between Fatah and Hamas officials deepened. Meanwhile, rockets fired from Lebanon landed in Israel, but caused no casualties. PAGE A3 Gianfranco Ferré Dies at 62 The Italian fashion designer, noted for his signature ready-to-wear collection and for opening French haute couture to foreign-born designers, died in Milan. PAGE A17 Mostly Tie-Dyed Festival Although the reunited Police, featuring Sting, right, were one of several headliners from way off the jam-band circuit, the Bonnaroo music festival in Tennessee was, as usual, a basically hippie affair with long hair, peasant dresses and flowers everywhere. A review by Jon Pareles. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

KALTMAN--Martin, died on June 15th at the age of 92. He had homes in Old Westbury, NY and Key Biscayne, FL. He was a man of great vision, imagination and a pioneer of the modern Lithographic industry in New York. With fellow Brooklyn Tech graduate Max Verebay they started Kaltman Press in 1932 to print labels by the letterpress process. They remained partners for 66 years. When the LP record was invented in 1947, they started printing album covers. With the advent of lithography they joined with Jack Hecht in 1950 to create Queens Lithographing Corp. in Long Island City. With the growth of album sales in the sixties. Queens Litho printed all Beatles and Rolling Stones LPs and the company grew rapidly. During that period the company opened factories in Edison, NJ and Indianapolis. In 1964 the company displayed an operating printing press on the floor of Grand Central Station. The volume of music packaging exploded in the eighties with the introduction of the compact-disc and the company added a factory in Louisville to handle the growth. The company changed its name to Queens Group Inc. Packaging for Home Video, Video games and Software created the need for added capacity and the company built two factories in North Carolina. The company also produced high quality packaging for cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and private label. The company was sold in 1998 and is now part of International Paper. A philanthropist, Mr. Kaltman actively supported UJA-Federation, MOMA, Julliard School where he endowed a scholarship, NSUH-LIJ Health System and the Botanical Gardens in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx. Martin was a founder of American Friends of Boystown Jerusalem and his company donated a printing press to the school in Israel. He loved growing plants, flowers, trees, vegetables and studied Horticulture at SUNY Farmingdale, and helped establish The Gardens at Crandon Park in Key Biscayne. He was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle. Mr. Kaltman's first wife, the former Helen Reich, died in 1984. He is survived by his second wife, the former Rosalie Podoll, her children and grandchildren. His son Eric and wife Marnee of Old Westbury, NY, their children Dennis, Richard, Jodi, Jon, their spouses and eight greatgrandchildren. His daughter Gail Bates and husband Dennis of Marietta, GA, their children Stephanie, Robin, their spouses and four greatgrandchildren. Memorial contributions may be sent to Queens Botanical Garden, attention: Susan Lacerte, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing, NY 11355.

A man who was shot by police officers on Saturday night after the authorities said he refused to drop a pellet gun that looked like a handgun remained in critical but stable condition yesterday at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. The man was identified as Luis A. Dominguez, 49, of Rosedale. The shooting occurred near his home shortly before 9 p.m., when several officers surrounded him and repeatedly ordered him to drop the gun before firing several shots, witnesses and the police said. Mr. Dominguez was shot in the torso, the police said. A lieutenant suffered a minor shoulder injury, and the police said yesterday it was unclear whether the lieutenant had been grazed by a bullet from a fellow officer. An investigation is continuing, the police said. A neighbor said Mr. Dominguez was prone to hostility when he had been drinking. ''He kept going up the street, hiding behind a tree with the gun,'' said the neighbor, Zita Young, 43. ''I ran to the deli to get one of the guys to see if they could talk to him or help him. By that time we heard the gunshots go off. I wasn't counting, but it was a lot.'' MICHAEL WILSON
APPLEBY--William. Billy, I will miss your insouciant charm and loving friendship. Helene

Could congestion pricing become the next big campaign issue in the state? New York City's outer boroughs and suburbs, hotbeds of anti-pricing sentiment, are also home to many Senate Republicans who are considered vulnerable to a Democratic challenge. But congestion pricing is a key priority for Mr. Bloomberg, a Republican who has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to Republican senators.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the way cancer doctors practice medicine misstated a title for Dr. Peter Eisenberg. He is a former director of the American Society of Clinical Oncology, not a current director. His term ended on June 4. The article also misstated the price of Avastin, a cancer drug. For an average lung cancer patient, it is $8,800 a month, not $8,800 a dose.

Beloved mother of Abby Garfein and Eric Ober, children of her first husband Ralph Ober. Sister of Irving Sokoloff. Grandmother of Karen, Matthew, Nicholas, Barbara, Irene, Shelley, Phyllis and Erica. Great-grandmother of Hannah, Jacob, Jeremy and Diana. Mother-in-law of Jack Garfein and Lisa Anderson and sister-in-law of Mildred Sokoloff. On her last day, she won all her hands playing bridge with pals Shirley, Shula and Muriel. What could be better. She loved everyone and they loved her.

LEE--Joel S., distinguished scholar and brilliant Professor of Law, died April 15th 2007, at age 93. Following valiant service in the US Army in WWII, he earned his law degree at New York University. Satisfying his lifelong ambition to teach law, he joined the faculty at New York Law School. For 44 years he devoted his outstanding academic skills to the legal education of thousands of students. Many of his students became judges and successful attorneys. He is survived by his cousin, A.H. Lewis, and his devoted nurse and friend Patricia Standen. Contributions may be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer once memorably declared at a public meeting with top lawmakers that they were convening in ''my room'' with ''my rules.'' Last Monday, Mr. Bruno invited the governor to the lavish annual picnic for Senate Republicans that Mr. Bruno holds at his upstate farm. ''This is my tent,'' the majority leader was said to have quipped, ''my farm.''

A driver lost control of his livery cab on Flatbush Avenue yesterday afternoon and drove onto the sidewalk, striking two teenage boys and a man, the police said. The accident occurred at 3:20 p.m. on the northbound side of Flatbush at East 29th Street. One teenager, 15, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center in extremely critical condition, the police said. A man with him, whose age was unknown, was in critical condition at the same hospital, while a 16-year-old was in critical condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. Alcohol was not a factor in the accident, and the driver was not charged yesterday afternoon, the police said. Neither the driver nor a passenger in the car was seriously injured. MICHAEL WILSON

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Ethiopian Army Is Accused Of Brutality in Desert War As Ethiopia fast becomes the United States' closest ally in the Horn of Africa, an emerging concern for the Bush administration is the way the American-trained Ethiopian military operates inside its own borders, especially in its counterinsurgency campaign near the border with Somalia. A1 24 Die in Kabul Explosion A mammoth explosion tore through a police bus in the heart of Kabul, killing at least 24 people, 22 of them police academy instructors, in one of the deadliest insurgent attacks in Afghanistan since the fall of the Taliban in 2001. A1 Abbas Swears In New Rule The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, swore in an emergency government at his headquarters in Ramallah, reasserting his authority over the West Bank. A3 Sarkozy's Party Wins in France The conservative party of President Nicolas Sarkozy of France won a solid victory in parliamentary elections, but failed to trounce the opposition on the left as both the polls and politicians had predicted. A6 Body of Iraqi Editor Is Found The body of Falieh Mijthab, the political editor of a government-financed newspaper who was kidnapped three days ago by armed men in a Shiite neighborhood of Baghdad, was found in the city's main mortuary. A10 U.N. Peacekeepers to Darfur The United Nations Security Council and the Sudanese government hammered out the major details of a proposal to send more than 20,000 peacekeeping troops to Darfur, clearing the way for a joint force with the African Union, which will be led and paid for by the United Nations. A8 Terror in Indonesia Limited Long before the arrests of its two top militants last week, Indonesia's major terrorist group had been moving away from the tactic of large-scale attacks, according to experts. A7 Arms Inspection Unit Near End The United States and Britain have circulated a new proposal to the members of the United Nations Security Council to ''terminate immediately the mandates'' of weapons inspectors in Iraq. A11 Rising Radicalism in Venezuela A radical pro-Chávez group that leapt into the Venezuelan consciousness in recent weeks after defacing the headquarters of the country's only remaining opposition television network is one of 40 such groups based in a sprawling housing complex in Caracas. A4 NATIONAL A12-16 Autism Debate Strains A Family and a Charity Fissures that have long roiled the autism community have made their way into the Wright family, founders of the mega-charity Autism Speaks. Father and daughter are not speaking after a public battle over the pathology and appropriate treatment of the neurological disorder, familiar to thousands of families with autistic children. A1 McCain's Fund-Raising Stress Senator John McCain, who has spent decades fighting to minimize the influence of money on politics, is under extraordinary pressure to raise tens of millions of dollars in a hurry to prove his political viability. Mr. McCain's presidential campaign may be paying the price for a career of positions seemingly calculated to alienate constituencies that according to Washington custom should be prime sources of campaign cash. A1 Moth Threatens Crops Over the years, California has faced a number of threats to its agriculture, but sightings of the light brown apple moth, a native of Australia that voraciously feeds on flowers and fruits in nine counties, has state and federal officials in California worried and taking precautious measures to curb any chance of infestation. A16 Energy Tax Reversal Bill Senate Democrats are seeking a major reversal of energy tax preferences, with a bill that would raise about $14 billion from oil companies over 10 years and would shower about the same amount of money on new incentives for solar power, wind power, cellulosic ethanol and other renewable energy sources. A16 Edwards Campaigns in Iowa Four years ago, John Edwards came within a few thousand votes of victory in the Iowa Democratic caucuses. Mr. Edwards's latest trip to Iowa offers evidence of the extent to which the rhythms of Iowa Democratic politics have shaped his decidedly populist pitch to the left this time around A15 EDUCATION Teacher's Merit Pay Initiative Minnesota's $86 million teacher professionalization and merit pay initiative has spread to dozens of the state's school districts, and it got a lift last week when teachers voted to expand it in Minneapolis. A major reason it is prospering, Gov. Tim Pawlenty said in an interview, is that union leaders helped develop it and sell it to teachers. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Albany's Nightlife Suffers Under Tightened Rules About 15 years ago, Albany was full of bars and restaurants that were a second home to the lawmakers during legislative sessions. But Albany's political nightlife has suffered under new rules on fraternization and lobbyist spending and since Gov. Eliot Spitzer took office. A1 Coney Island Plan Revised The developer who wants to remake Coney Island's amusement district has a new plan: A looming 40-story tower planned for the Boardwalk is gone, as are hundreds of rental apartments and luxury condominiums, replaced by hotels. The new proposal has more of the rides and attractions that America's first resort was once known for. B1 After-School Programs Cut The after-school program at Lower East Side Preparatory High School, which provides students with extra hours of tutoring in any subject, is among 207 statewide that are about to run out of government support. Facing the financial crunch in New York City are 118 after-school programs serving almost 20,000 children. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Old Banking Name Renewed Taking advantage of its $3.3 billion purchase of U.S. Trust, Bank of America is expected to announce that the division serving its wealthiest customers will be called U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management. C1 Airbus Pins Hopes on A350 Production delays for the much-publicized A380 superjumbo has caused Airbus outsize woes. But it is another aircraft, the twin-engine A350, that Airbus hopes will grab the headlines at the Paris Air Show. C1 Table for Two With a Click OpenTable is making it easier for restaurants to manage reservations and improve customer service online. Some 7,000 restaurants around the world now use it, and hundreds more are signing on every month. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Two cheers on global AIDS: muddy waters; the best judges business can buy: Francis X. Clines on a veteran patrolling the home front. Column: Nicholas D. Kristof. SPORTSMONDAY D1-7 Fight Over Big Ten Network The Big Ten Athletic Conference and Comcast are headed for a clash over the cost of carrying the newly created Big Ten Network. The collegiate athletic conference vows the network will satiate its member universities' fans and alumni, but Comcast says the network is too expensive and too provincial to be broadly distributed. A17 Sir Wally Herbert The first man to walk across the icebound Arctic Ocean and, some contend, the first to reach the North Pole on foot, a feat long credited to Rear Adm. Robert E. Peary, he was 72. A17 Robert Tracy A prolific dance writer who wrote about dance, theater, music, art and film for newspapers and magazines including The New York Times, Vanity Fair, Dance, Elle and Vogue, he was 52. The White Stripes ''Icky Thump'' (Third Man/Warner Brothers) ''Rag and bone!'' shouts Jack White on the crucial track of the White Stripes' new record, ''Icky Thump,'' and he's calling for whatever you've outgrown, including the pop culture you've lost faith in.

Elizabeth Edwards was holding court in the sweltering basement at the Cedar County Courthouse in Tipton, where local Democrats fanned themselves under fluorescent light. Her husband, John Edwards, making his second run for the presidency, watched and winced as she quizzed her audience about what they knew of his biography. ''How many know how many members of his family went to college before he did?'' Mrs. Edwards inquired. The correct response emerged in murmured guesses from a few listeners: none.

GELLMAN--Jerome I., 79, on June 14 of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, former longtime resident of Scarsdale, New York. Mourned by Florence, his wife of 55 years. Loving father of Elyse (Bill), Stephen (Wendy) and Ken (Melissa). Joyful and doting grandfather of Amanda, Lindsay, David, Alexa, Reese, Paige and Nathan. Devoted brother to Elaine and Melvin. Partner in Tucker, Gellman & Mulderig. Of Counsel to Cowan, Liebowitz and Latman. A man of great warmth, charm and humor. His family and friends will miss him dearly. Funeral on June 18, 2007, at 12:00 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY.

Quiznos Sub, Denver, returned its creative account to Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, a unit of MDC Partners, which handled the assignment from 1998 to 2003. Spending was estimated at $80 million.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.54 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 4.85 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.42 percent.

''The Green Book: The Everyday Guide to Saving the Planet One Simple Step at a Time,'' by Elizabeth Rogers and Thomas M. Kostigen, will be published tomorrow. It offers hundreds of tips on conservation and short testimonials from such celebrities as Ellen DeGeneres, Robert Redford, Will Ferrell, Jennifer Aniston and Faith Hill. Some of the cost/benefit analyses offered for the tips have a high ''wow'' factor: for example, if over one year each flier's suitcase were packed 10 pounds lighter, a 747 could be fueled for 10 years. SHELLY FREIERMAN

WOOLSEY--Jeanette. We mourn the passing of Jeanette Woolsey of Brooklyn, New York, who died after a brief illness. Jeanette had a long career with Roytex, a garment manufacturer followed by an active retirement. Her wit, wisdom, and intelligence will be dearly missed. Donald, Linda, Jeffrey and Eileen Warner

WRIGHT--Mark, a Broadway stage manager long-associated with playwright Edward Albee and director Alan Schneider, died at age 77 on Wednesday, June 6, 2007 in Los Angeles, where he had lived for the past 20 years. Mr. Wright's first Broadway assignment as stage manager was the original production of Mr. Albee's ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' in 1964, followed by ''Tiny Alice,'' ''A Delicate Balance,'' ''The Lady from Dubuque'' and ''Malcolm,'' all directed by Mr. Schneider. He also stage managed Mr. Albee's ''Seascape,'' which the playwright directed. After a 40year career as a stage manager that included the Broadway premieres of James Prideaux's ''The Last of Mrs. Lincoln,'' Joe Orton's ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane,'' ''Noel Coward in Two Keys,'' ''P.S. Your Cat is Dead'' by James Kirkwood, Robert Patrick's ''Kennedy's Children,'' and Mark Medoff's ''Children of a Lesser God.'' Mr. Wright was coaxed out of retirement to stage manage the New York productions of Mr. Albee's ''The Play About the Baby'' starring Marian Seldes and Brian Murray, followed by the evening of one-acts, ''Beckett/Albee.'' A native Midwesterner, Mr. Wright was the son of the late Mark and Lucille Wright. He served in the Air Force. His brother Tom preceded him in death. Mr. Wright is survived by a niece Lisa Slabaugh and a nephew Tom Wright of Austin, Texas, as well as by his closest friend and caretaker, Dan Cavanaugh of Los Angeles. The cause of death was an incurable form of anemia.

The Times Literary Supplement, or TLS, that most venerable and high-minded of England's weekly book sections - Virginia Woolf and Henry James were contributors - has had a makeover. Thankfully, not all that much has changed. A long list of contributing editors has been added up at the front. The editor, Peter Stothard, now writes a small introductory note to each issue. (Did you know Stothard has a blog?) And the brilliant N.B. column, written by James Campbell, has been moved to the back page, so you no longer have to go foraging for it.
