The attack killed at least 61 people as a major coalition offensive against insurgents in and around Baghdad entered its second day.
The Broadway revival of Eric Bogosian’s “Talk Radio,” starring Liev Schreiber, will close Sunday after 150 performances at the Longacre Theater.
Monet’s 1904 painting “Waterloo Bridge, Temps Couvert,” sold last night for $31.7 million, before commission, at Christie’s International in London, Bloomberg News reported.

The New York premiere of Edward Albee’s “Peter and Jerry” and the world premiere of “Farragut North,” a dark political comedy by Beau Willimon, are among the offerings in Second Stage Theater’s 2007-8 season, the company is to announce today.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences opened its rolls slightly yesterday, extending invitations to 115 prospective members.

The jazz saxophonist Ornette Coleman, 77, collapsed onstage from heat stroke at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., on Sunday and was given intravenous fluids in a nearby medical tent before he was taken to Coffey County Hospital, Reuters reported.
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain yesterday appointed John Tusa chairman of the Victoria and Albert Museum.
A 23-year-old bass-baritone from the Shanghai Conservatory of Music has won the BBC Cardiff Singer of the World competition, the BBC reported.
After five decades on network television, Bob Barker appeared on CBS’s “Price is Right” Friday for the last time, ending 35 years as host of America’s longest-running game show.

Ringo Starr is going online. Beginning on Aug. 28 his EMI Music albums, including “Sentimental Journey” (1970), “Beaucoups of Blues” (1970), “Ringo” (1973) and “Goodnight Vienna” (1974) will be available for downloading, along with six Ringo Starr ring tones and “Photograph: The Very Best of Ringo Starr,” a career- and label-spanning 20-track collection of his solo recordings.
Michael Moore’s documentary about health care in the United States, “Sicko,” appeared then disappeared from the Internet as the weekend gave way to Monday, The Associated Press reported.

An article in Business Day on Friday about a Senate bill that would increase taxes on publicly traded equity firms and hedge funds gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a Democratic lawmaker from Montana who sponsored the legislation. He is Senator Max Baucus, not Bachus.

Two men were fatally shot about a mile apart in Jamaica early yesterday, the police said. One man, Charles Williamson, 27, of Williamsburg, Va., was shot in the head at 127-05 176th Street about 12:20 a.m., the police said. A half-hour later, the police said, Germaine Persaud, 21, of Queens, was shot in front of his home at 119-46 192nd Street by a man wearing a red bandana.

A teenager who fatally shot one boy and killed another at a summer block party was sentenced yesterday to 24 years in prison. The defendant, Vijai Dube, now 18, shot Harrichad Singh, 15, in the head and wrist in August 2005, and seriously wounded Shastra Sagar, 14, with a shot to the chest, the Queens district attorney’s office said in a statement. The teenagers were at a block party in South Ozone Park when Mr. Dube, a 10th grader at the time, fired a semiautomatic handgun. The police caught up with him two days later. He pleaded guilty last month to first-degree manslaughter. In a statement read at his arraignment he said that the two boys kept looking at him and talking, which made him think they were planning something, so he went home to get the gun and returned to the party. The boy he killed was a high school student trying to graduate early.
In one of his best starts this season, John Maine gave up only one run in seven and a third innings to lead the Mets to a victory against the Twins.
The State Supreme Court established ground rules for how a defendant could show mental retardation and secure a sentence of life imprisonment.

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Boston’s 1-0 victory against San Francisco referred incorrectly to the history of the interleague series between the Red Sox and the Giants. This was their first meeting since June 2004 — not since the World Series in 1912, the year they last played each other at Fenway Park.

Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about a vote by the New Jersey General Assembly to allow voters to decide whether all proceeds from a 1-cent tax increase approved last year should go to property tax relief for local governments referred incorrectly at one point to the type of tax that was increased. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was the sales tax, not the property tax.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about comments by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the United States would not alter its plans to deploy a missile defense system in Poland and the Czech Republic, despite a proposal by Russia that the United States instead use a radar base in Azerbaijan, referred incorrectly to the former status of Poland and the Czech Republic. They were Soviet satellite states, not Soviet states.

A headline and article in Business Day last Tuesday about a decision by TheStreet.com not to award prize money in the first round of its “Beat the Street” competition referred incorrectly to the reason for its action. Although TheStreet.com did say that some players used trading strategies that compromised the integrity of the system, it did not identify any of them or accuse any individual of “cheating” in the contest — including J. McKeown, who was leading the contest.

An article in The Magazine on Sunday about Dr. Ronald McIver, who is imprisoned for drug trafficking, gave an erroneous account of the trial testimony of one of his patients, Leslie Smith. And a correction in this space on Sunday again referred incorrectly to that testimony. The only point Mr. Smith made in his testimony was that he acknowledged injecting drugs prescribed by Dr. McIver. Mr. Smith never raised the issue of whether he himself sold any drugs that were left over to buy other drugs. And he never referred to Dr. McIver in the context of the leftover drugs — either that Dr. McIver sold them or did not sell them.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the Paris Air Show misstated Boeing’s manufacturing schedule for its 787. The plane will be rolled out at Boeing’s plant in Everett, Wash., on July 8; that is not the date for the inaugural flight.
Corrections

An article on Saturday about the unearthing of a 1957 Plymouth Belvedere and a time capsule, which had been buried in Tulsa., Okla, to commemorate 50 years of statehood, misidentified one of the items in the capsule. It was a 48-star flag, not a 46-star flag.

Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about the planned national tour of the musical “Spring Awakening” misidentified the director. The production will be directed by Michael Mayer, who won a Tony this month for his direction of the musical, not by Carole Shorenstein Hays. (Ms. Hays is president of SHN, which is bringing “Spring Awakening” to the Curran Theater in San Francisco in the fall of 2008.).

A music review in Weekend on Friday about Paul McCartney, at the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan, misidentified the instrument he played when he sang “Here Today.” It was an acoustic guitar, not a piano.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 2 about the expansion of Latin American companies into the United States misstated the relationship of one such company, Grupo Bimbo, with Wonder Bread. Grupo Bimbo makes and distributes Wonder Bread only in Mexico, where it has acquired the rights from Wonder Bread’s parent, the Interstate Brands Corporation. Grupo Bimbo does not own Wonder Bread. The error was pointed out by Grupo Bimbo shortly after the article appeared. This correction was delayed while another question about the article was researched.
Peter Braunstein, the former Women’s Wear Daily writer, was sentenced to 18 years to life in prison.

An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on June 13 about the fraud trial of Conrad M. Black misspelled the surname of an attorney for Mark S. Kipnis, a co-defendant. And a correction in this space on Friday also misspelled his surname. He is Michael Swartz — not Schwartz or Schwarz.

President Bush has nominated the demographer of Texas, Steven Murdock, to be director of the census, the White House said. Mr. Murdock would replace Louis Kincannon, who said last year that he felt he had lost the confidence of the Commerce Department, which oversees the Census Bureau, and would resign when a new director was confirmed. Mr. Murdock is a professor at the University of Texas at San Antonio.
The owners of a co-op on Sutton Place South have gone to court to block the city from seizing a swath of their emerald green backyard for a public park.

A federal judge has granted an indefinite stay of deportation to Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian Coptic Christian who faces repatriation for a murder charge in Egypt. Mr. Khouzam, 38, of Lancaster, had received a stay of deportation until June 18. Now, the stay has been extended until his case is concluded, court documents show. Mr. Khouzam fled to the United States nine years ago, claiming he had been detained and tortured because he refused to convert to Islam. He denies the murder accusation. After being freed from detention in 2006, Mr. Khouzam was detained again May 29, after the Egyptian government provided diplomatic assurances that he would not be tortured.
Senator Barack Obama said his campaign “made a mistake” last week when it distributed a document that some Indian-Americans found offensive.
The majestic ocean liner that carried millions of people across the Atlantic during its 40-year history has been sold to Istithmar for $100 million.
Electronic Arts will reorganize the world’s biggest video game publisher into four units, in an efficiency drive by its new chief executive.
The agreements with Merrill Lynch, ING Bank and Banca Monte Parma of Italy are related to the dairy group’s 2003 failure.
Robinson Canó, second baseman for the New York Yankees, recently donated an ambulance to a hospital in the Dominican Republic.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s “congestion pricing” proposal appeared unlikely to be resolved in the last week of the legislative session.
Both sides have agreed not to reveal details of the talks, which are aimed at establishing rules for Zimbabwe’s presidential election, scheduled for March 2008.
The company that recalled Thomas the Tank Engine wooden trains, which were contaminated with paint containing lead, is learning about crisis management.
The decision ending an embargo of the Palestinian Authority was a bid to bolster President Mahmoud Abbas.
Terry Semel will hand over the reins to Jerry Yang in Yahoo’s latest attempt to regain investor confidence.
China manufactured every one of the 24 kinds of toys recalled for safety reasons in the United States this year.
A team of international investigators infiltrated an Internet chat room used by pedophiles who streamed live videos of children being raped, rescuing 31 children.
The former chairman of Hollinger International has been on trial for three months on charges relating to obstruction of justice and tax fraud.
The Hamas takeover was partly fueled by weapons moved through tunnels below the town of Rafah.
Even as a drought strips many Florida lawns of their lushness, there are few takers for artificial grass.
The assault by more than 2,000 American troops  represents a more aggressive strategy of attacking several insurgent strongholds at the same time.
Advocates for the mentally ill are trying to secure voting rights while concern mounts about the rights and risks.

Abu Dujana, a high-ranking militant who was arrested June 9, told Tempo magazine that he did not approve of the 2003 bombing of the J. W. Marriott hotel in Jakarta and had no role in planning it. Abu Dujana, who is believed to head a military wing of the group Jemaah Islamiyah, said Noordin Top, another militant, had planned the bombing, which killed 14 people.

Vlastimir Djordjevic, an aide to the former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic, will appear in court in The Hague today to face charges of murder and persecution. Mr. Djordjevic, who was unexpectedly handed over to the war crimes tribunal on Sunday, had been living in Russia. He was arrested in Montenegro, where the police said he had arrived under a false identity. Mr. Djordjevic led Serbia’s security police during the 1999 Kosovo war. Prosecutors say he had a major role in deporting Kosovo Albanians. His arrest leaves four others on the run.

The Security Council approved a request from Lebanon’s prime minister to have the United Nations commission investigating the 2005 assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, help investigate last week’s killing of a legislator, Walid Eido. Mr. Eido died in an attack similar to the one that had killed Mr. Hariri, when a vehicle parked along the same road in Beirut blew up as his car passed. Like Mr. Hariri, Mr. Eido was opposed to past Syrian domination of Lebanon’s politics. Preliminary findings of the commission have implicated Syrian intelligence services in Mr. Hariri’s murder.

Pakistanis protested Britain’s award of a knighthood to the author Salman Rushdie, left, as an affront to Muslim sentiments, and a cabinet minister said the honor was a justification for suicide attacks. The religious affairs minister, Mohammed Ijaz ul-Haq, said in Parliament, “If someone exploded a bomb on his body, he would be right to do so unless the British government apologizes and withdraws the ‘sir’ title.” Mr. Rushdie once lived in hiding because of an edict issued in 1989 ordering Muslims to kill him over his novel “The Satanic Verses.”.

The Italian Coast Guard continued its search for bodies after a vessel carrying immigrants sank off the southern Italian island of Lampedusa over the weekend. So far 11 of the 14 bodies they saw have been recovered, according to a Coast Guard spokesman who said the nationality of the victims remained unknown. Lampedusa, south of Sicily, is one of the main destinations of immigrants seeking to enter Europe from across the Mediterranean.

The Italian oil company Eni said 27 people, including 11 soldiers, were being held hostage at one of its oilfield stations in Nigeria a day after the facility was overrun by militants. No one was killed in the attack on the station, known as Ogbainbiri. Eni said it was working with the local authorities to resolve the crisis. The invasion was apparently in response to the killing of eight people by troops guarding Ogbainbiri last week, security sources said.

Three soldiers were killed as the Lebanese Army’s battle against militants barricaded in a Palestinian refugee camp entered its fifth week, a senior military official said. The militants, members of Fatah al Islam, remain inside the camp, Nahr el Bared. The fighting has claimed more than 150 lives since it began May 20.
The fallout from the subprime mortgage industry could further constrict consumers with weak, or subprime, credit while helping to prolong the housing downturn.
Several hundred people, most of them Fatah supporters, have been camped out at the closed border between Israel and Gaza, saying they fear for their lives.
The Colorado Rapids U-23 team, a minor league soccer club in Boulder, Colo., is on a campaign to fight global warming.
The Supreme Court found that Wall Street investment banks could not be sued under antitrust law over losses in the crash of technology stocks seven years ago.
golf.
A new statement could have a very beneficial effect in alerting patients and doctors that ovarian cancer is present at an early stage when it is most treatable.
The Senate will tell us this week whether it really wants to do something about oil dependency and global warming or if it is just fooling around.
Many wonder if Newark’s largely poor and minority population will benefit from one of the most ambitious and expensive ventures in New Jersey in a generation.
Kenneth Rice, who turned government witness and testified in the trial of former Enron C.E.O. Jeffrey Skilling and company founder Kenneth Lay, was sentenced Monday to 27 months in prison.
The troubled European aerospace and military giant wants to land a $40 billion contract to provide refueling tankers to the United States Air Force.
Manager Willie Randolph continued to play down the seriousness of Carlos Beltrán’s injured left quadriceps before Monday night’s game against the Minnesota Twins.
The practice is compared to redlining in the mortgage industry, but some bankers defend it as a way to assess young borrowers with little credit history.
New York City students could earn as much as $500 a year for doing well on standardized tests and showing up for class in a new program to begin this fall.
Last week, the Audubon Society released a new report describing the sharp and startling population decline of some of the most familiar and common birds in America.
The $110 million sale to the Nature Conservancy is a move intended to protect the land from future development.
The changes were recommended by a panel formed after an unarmed man was fatally shot in Queens by the police.
Scouts say Johan Santana’s stuff remains exceptional but his command is slightly off, which may be some small consolation for a Mets team that needs all the help it can get.
IN SHIFTING CAREERS, a panel of career coaches and advisers answer reader questions at nytimes.com/smallbusiness.
With the space station’s computers working again, the six-man crew of the space shuttle Atlantis packed up and prepared to go home.
The bill is expected to return to the Senate late this week, but the storm raging around immigration shows no sign of abating.
The private equity firm said it had agreed to buy an Indian back-office company, Intelenet Global Services Ltd., for an undisclosed sum.
The former Giants and Washington Redskins linebacker LaVar Arrington was hospitalized Monday with multiple injuries after crashing his motorcycle.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer should use the summer to forge a solution on financing for after-school programs.
JPMorgan Chase has hired Gordon A. Smith from American Express to head its credit card unit.
The death of the children may well add to the crescendoing anger many Afghans feel about civilian casualties from American and NATO military operations.
Judge Oscar Magi delayed the trial to await a ruling on whether prosecutors overstepped their bounds and violated state secrecy laws as they gathered evidence.
An eight-hour trip on a giant freight ship through the Panama Canal costs an average of $30,000. Because my wife and I were on a tight budget, we went fishing for peacock bass instead.
The high-performance computer system is intended to increase the speed and accuracy of decision making in fields as diverse as security surveillance and Wall Street trading.
Townspeople in Potter, N.Y., have tried repeatedly to reverse a ban on alcohol after they made a sobering mistake two years ago.
Residents expressed concern about what the management change portends for one of New York’s more quirky cultural institutions.

A black bear pulled an 11-year-old boy from his family’s tent and killed him in a remote wilderness area near Timpanogos Cave National Monument. The attack on Sunday night was the first fatal mauling by a black bear in Utah history, researchers and federal officials said. The boy’s mother, stepfather and 6-year-old brother were sleeping when the bear ripped a hole in the tent and carried off the boy, who was still in his sleeping bag. Utah County sheriff’s deputies found the body about 400 yards from the tent. Wildlife officers killed the bear yesterday; an examination of the remains confirmed that it was the killer, The Associated Press reported.

A 13-foot totem pole fell on Sunday and struck and killed a 9-year-old boy on the first day of Boy Scout camp in Loysville, the police said. The boy, Tyler O. Shope, of Shermans Dale, died of head and chest injuries, said Michael Shalonis, the Perry County coroner. The boy was waiting outside the camp’s health lodge to have his health records reviewed at the time of the accident, officials said.
Even when it was not she who was talking, Elizabeth Edwards was often the center of attention in what was supposed to be John Edwards’s big splash across Iowa.
Bryan Petersen ended the longest game in College World Series history with a run-scoring single in the bottom of the 13th inning, giving California-Irvine a 5-4 victory against Cal State Fullerton.
North Korea has invited inspectors from the United Nations’ nuclear monitoring program, to visit for talks about verifying and monitoring a shutdown.

Sam Perlozzo was fired as Baltimore’s manager yesterday, the result of his inability to bring the last-place Orioles out of a lengthy slump that culminated in an eight-game losing streak. He was the first major league manager to be fired this year.
The commission heard the first official discrimination complaint filed to the state.
After an election loss, France’s Socialist Party was struggling to adjust to the news that its first couple — Ségolène Royal and François Hollande — had split up.
Gregory L. Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications, is accused of misleading investors by backdating stock option grants, among other things.
A plan to demolish the 29-story Cleveland Trust Tower has caused an outcry among architectural preservationists.
Hamburger chain Wendy’s International  said on Monday it would explore the possible sale of the company instead of other restructuring options.
Colin Fletcher’s ornate prose and prosaic tips on subjects like choosing the right hiking boots helped start the modern backpacking movement.
The action is part of a 10-state initiative to lower carbon dioxide output from power plants.
The Yankees are 13-3 and have scored 6.9 runs a game without Jason Giambi, who must decide by Thursday if he plans to cooperate with baseball’s investigation into steroid use.
The 2007 Failed States Index, produced by Foreign Policy magazine and the Fund for Peace, placed Iraq behind only Sudan among the world’s most unstable nations.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg expressed his frustration with the state of the nation, touching on campaign-style issues like the war in Iraq and immigration.
Most stocks fell Monday for the first time in four days after confidence in the home building industry dropped to a 16-year low.
Abu Omar, a militant Islamist fighting the Lebanese Army, is a charismatic leader in a Palestinian refugee camp near Sidon, in southern Lebanon.
Torrential rainfall flooded several towns in North Texas, killing four and stranding people on their roofs as they awaited rescue.
The $634.5 million in penalties and fines that Purdue Pharma agreed to pay to resolve a false marketing charge represents 90 percent of the profits it initially made from OxyContin.
Both Gannett and Dow Jones & Company are trying to capture more of the high-end consumer advertising market.
Also, Duke University announced an agreement to avoid legal action by three former lacrosse players falsely accused of sexual assault.
Google and Pacific Gas & Electric have unveiled their vision of a future in which cars and trucks are partly powered by the country’s electric grids, and vice versa.

The board of the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority elected a veteran state assemblyman yesterday as its president and chief executive. The legislator, Paul D. Tonko, 58, left, of Amsterdam, was first elected to the Assembly in 1983 and has served as the chairman of its Energy Committee since 1992. The authority, with an annual budget of $409 million, finances energy research projects and energy efficiency programs through a surcharge on utility bills. It will be up to Gov. Eliot Spitzer to call a special election to fill the remainder of Mr. Tonko’s two-year Assembly term; he was re-elected easily last November.

A man who learned acting in prison and appeared on a 2006 episode of “Law & Order” after his release was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in prison for a new series of robberies in which he threatened to blow himself up if his demands were not met. The man, David Wayne, 48, of Croton-on-Hudson, admitted in State Supreme Court that he had claimed to be wrapped in dynamite while robbing Westchester County stores and hotels last year. The “dynamite” was actually road flares. Mr. Wayne pleaded guilty in April to robbery.

A Bronx woman who was injured when her boat was struck by a 324-foot barge on Long Island Sound this month has been removed from life support, according to Newsday. The woman, Leibe Ociele Medina, 47, was on a fishing trip on a 24-foot boat off Sands Point on June 10 when a collision with a barge damaged the vessel, the police said. She was taken to St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, where she remained in a coma. A doctor told her family on Friday that she was brain-dead, her daughter, Yuli Conely, told Newsday for yesterday’s edition. The Coast Guard and the Nassau County police are investigating the collision.

A man who served as his own defense lawyer was sentenced yesterday to 32 years to life in prison for killing a companion. At his sentencing in State Supreme Court, the man, Gregory Zalevsky, 52, submitted a handwritten 29-page motion to vacate his conviction for the murder of Irina Ilyina, 31, a mother of two from New Jersey. Ms. Ilyina, who had been dating Mr. Zalevsky while seeking a divorce from her husband, was found smothered in Mr. Zalevsky’s Brighton Beach apartment in July 2004. In the courtroom, Justice Matthew J. D’Emic denied Mr. Zalevsky’s motion. Ms. Ilyina’s parents, sister and former husband asked for a long prison sentence, calling Mr. Zalevsky a “monster.” In a statement to the court, Mr. Zalevsky said he expected to be exonerated.

A real estate executive was nominated yesterday by Gov. Eliot Spitzer to become the next chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the governor’s office announced. The nominee, H. Dale Hemmerdinger, is a former chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission and president of the Hemmerdinger Corporation, a real estate development company, the governor’s office said. Mr. Hemmerdinger is also president of Atco Properties and Management, a member of the board of Valley National Bank and a trustee of New York University. If confirmed by the State Senate, he will succeed Peter S. Kalikow, a Pataki administration appointee who said recently that it was time for him to move on.

A woman sought for more than a year in the shooting of a Staten Island commune leader was arrested yesterday after getting off a train in Philadelphia, federal marshals said. The woman, Rebekah Johnson, has been charged with attempted murder in the shooting of the commune leader, Jeff Gross, who helped found the Ganas community. Ms. Johnson, 44, is accused of jumping from bushes at Mr. Gross’s home in May 2006 and shooting him in the chest and arm.

A school board that refused to provide complete minutes of board meetings has been ordered to pay $18,000 in penalties and legal fees after a newspaper sued. In January, The Press of Atlantic City sued the Pleasantville Board of Education in State Superior Court over records of five closed meetings last year. Last week, Judge Steven Perskie ordered the district to pay the newspaper $15,000 for legal fees and $3,000 in penalties. The cost to the district, including legal fees, came to just over $50,000, The Press reported.

A Selden man has been charged with causing a fire last week that destroyed three cars and damaged a fourth at an auto repair shop on Sunrise Highway, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The police said the man, Randy Galluzi, 38, was attempting to steal gasoline by using a cordless power drill to cut a hole in the bottom of a vehicle’s gas tank at Sonrise Automotive about 9:20 p.m. last Wednesday. The gas ignited, and although Mr. Galluzi was able to escape without injury, the draining gas spread the fire to other vehicles, the police said. Mr. Galluzi was charged with criminal mischief and petit larceny, the police said. He pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment in First District Court, according to the Suffolk County district attorney’s office.
John A. Rizzo’s confirmation hearing to become the C.I.A.’s general counsel will give the Democratic majority its first chance at a public airing of agency practices.
Television advertising has long been frowned on in the legal profession. But Spot Runner, an online advertising agency, is trying to change that.
For the first time in his career, Tiger Woods has posted second-place finishes in consecutive majors — a stretch that at the least reveals some vulnerability in the No. 1 ranked player in the world.
The Long Island Rail Road has a new president who is hoping to go beyond the rivalry and capture some of that Metro-North magic.
The Supreme Court has extended to passengers the right that drivers have to challenge a police decision to stop a car.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,515 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
Climate Counts, a new nonprofit group, will rank 56 consumer companies, grouped by industry, on how they measure greenhouse gas emissions, among other things.
The latest dogfight in the highly competitive airline industry is for bragging rights to the best night’s sleep in the sky.
The White House may have committed “extensive” violations of a law requiring that certain records be preserved, said Representative Henry Waxman.
The decision does not look likely to end a legal battle that has raised the question over whether a child can have two mothers.
Although no firm plans have been made for the Belmont Stakes winner Rags to Riches beyond her next scheduled start, it appears she may not face colts for the rest of the year.
Ms. Wasserstein’s larger-than-life personality provided inspiration for sprightly maternal characters in the plays of her daughter Wendy.
Mr. Walsh was a Tony-winning choreographer who also created the role of Bobby in the original production of “A Chorus Line.”
The latest travel news from around the globe.
The distinction between the “secularism” of Fatah and the Islamism of Hamas is really a distinction without a difference.

Captive conversation with someone on a plane can have some unexpected business or personal consequences that are downright karmic.
Terry Semel will hand over the reins to Jerry Yang in Yahoo’s latest attempt to regain investor confidence.

In a high-profile mea culpa the Smithsonian Institution issued a report saying that its Board of Regents had failed to provide the oversight that might have prevented extravagant spending by its former chief executive.
In the early 1930s, after a year in general medicine, my father  became one of the first trained radiologists in this country.
Evidence is mounting that the kingdom of Kush, in its ascendancy from 2000 B.C. to 1500 B.C., exerted control or at least influence over a 750-mile stretch of the Nile Valley.
Now you see “Sicko,” now you don’t, Ringo Starr goes digital, Bob Barker gives CBS a good goodbye and more culture news.
“The Kingdom,” a film about the F.B.I.’s pursuit of Islamic bad guys in Saudi Arabia, may show that buddy bonding and boisterous action can bridge the deepest cultural chasm.
The artist Spencer Finch takes viewers on a journey to demonstrate that even with light and eyes, vision doesn’t give you unmediated access to the world.
Readers respond to articles in Science Times with thoughts on scientific art, psychotherapy and “Silent Spring.”
With this “autobiography” of his family, Alexander Waugh demonstrates that he’s inherited the literary gene in spades, as well as a gift for very funny, coruscating prose.
An amateur video in which Kobe Bryant profanely expressed his frustration with the Los Angeles Lakers could become public by the end of the week and could be damaging.
The biggest name in tap won’t be found at the annual Tap City festival at the Duke on 42nd St.
Examining triboluminescence, better known as the Wint-O-Green Life Saver Effect, could provide scientists a way to better understand how things break.
The main character in this one-man play is a generic middle-American child of the baby boom, someone you have already heard from repeatedly in films and literature.
The Emerson String Quartet ended its long and busy residency at Carnegie Hall on Sunday fittingly, with Beethoven’s farewell to the medium but also with a new piece by Kaija Saariaho.
Airlines gave a big lift to the order book for the next generation Airbus A350, announcing contracts for 114 of the planes on the first day of the Paris air show.
A new study suggests the reason for  the association may be that antibiotics destroy not only disease-causing microbes, but also those that are helpful to the developing immune system.

8 P.M. (TCM) ON DANGEROUS GROUND Ida Lupino, born into an Italian theater family, acted in films steadily from the age of 13 and in the 1950s was one of the few female directors working in Hollywood. Turner Classic Movies is paying tribute to this actress, director, writer and producer throughout June; tonight a series of her performances will be showcased, starting with this 1952 drama about a police detective (Robert Ryan) who helps a blind girl (Ms. Lupino, above with Mr. Ryan) whose brother has been murdered. Next, at 9:30 p.m., is “While the City Sleeps” (1956); at 11:15 p.m. Ms. Lupino plays a widow terrorized by a deranged handyman in “Beware, My Lovely” (1952); and at 12:45 a.m. comes “Ladies in Retirement” (1941), an understated thriller about women living on the moors.
As a discharge planner, Alicia Tennenbaum is an advocate and troubleshooter for patients leaving the hospital.
Conditioned responses in cockroaches, polluted sand and self-healing materials.
It was a good choice to end the Brooklyn Philharmonic’s little concert at the South Street Seaport on Saturday night with Handel’s “Music for the Royal Fireworks.”
Webdenda.
Some economists have argued that there is no such thing as “pure altruism,” but a new study has spotted it in the brains of students.
In its more unfortunate passages, “Rain in a Dry Land” reinforces unpleasant stereotypes that some people still harbor about Africa.
A frequent candidate for the finest martial arts movie ever made, “The 36th Chamber of Shaolin” has at last been rescued from video bargain bins.
It is a staple in medicine cabinets everywhere, but does hydrogen peroxide really make a difference?
High scores on a hostility test were consistently associated with low scores on the measures of lung function for some groups in a recent study.
Regular aspirin use may significantly reduce the incidence of both cancer and heart disease, according to a large new study.
A new study suggests that few zoos consistently enforce hygienic practices to keep germs from spreading to humans.
Campaign Spotlight.
A new study suggests that new work-hour rules for hospital interns and residents have resulted in better care for patients.
Scientists have recently turned to trash in an effort to unearth organic alternatives to petrochemical plastics.
Finish Line will pay $54.50 a share in cash for Genesco, a 10-percent premium over Friday’s closing price of $49.50.
Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain’s largest specialty chemical maker, said today that it had rejected a takeover bid from Akzo Nobel worth £7.2 billion, or $14 billion, as too low.
CT scans and X-rays are revolutionary, but they carry risks, too, a new study suggests.
Is eating fortified foods any better than just taking the nutrients in pill form?
Barry Commoner has for decades been agitating to restore ecological balance to the biosphere, whether by outlawing nuclear testing or spreading the practice of recycling.
Some of us just know that we were born to be an entrepreneur or teach third grade; then there are the rest of us.
Light jets have major critics, but they are finding a niche among businesspeople for short trips of 300 to 400 miles.
The choice between new S.L.R. cameras from Canon, Nikon, Pentax, Olympus and Sony comes down to price, features and your existing lens collection.
Accessible but not acquiescent, gracious but guarded, or perhaps downright boring, Derek Jeter and Tim Duncan have a lot in common.
Six current players have been or will be the subject of a “Yankeeography” on the YES Network. The conspicuous omission is Alex Rodriguez.
Some newspapers reported last Friday that veteran umpire Bruce Froemming was retiring at the end of the season. But neither M.L.B. nor Froemming made such an announcement.
New York is unsurpassed when it comes to lawsuits, although even on that score other cities are trying to steal our thunder.
It is beyond unconscionable that you can have sick children in this country because medical treatment that could relieve their suffering is withheld by people with dollar signs in their eyes.
Kim Chan, like many character actors, has a face that is more familiar than his name.
Sarah Ruhl’s tenderhearted comedy opened at the Second Stage Theater in a rhapsodically beautiful production.
Children must be protected against the downside of that life-giving force, the sun.
