ARMSTRONG--Mary Margaret. May 1921-May 2007. Let Winter round me rave; And the next flowers that deck the Spring, bloom on my peaceful grave! (Robert Burns). Mary Margaret Armstong died Wednesday night, May 16th at the age of 85. It was an end to suffering, although peaceful at the last. At her request, she has been cremated and her ashes will be buried with those of her mother in Scotland with a Church of Scotland service. Margaret was a wonderful person and a good friend: I am sorry that she is gone, but watching her suffer was hard. She will be remembered fondly by all her who knew her. A Mass of Remembrance will be celebrated on Wednesday, June 20 at 9:30 am in the Holy Family Chapel at the Mary Manning Walsh Home and there will also be an annual Mass of Remembrance on Wednesday, November 14. Joyce Hitchcock.

An article on Saturday about the unearthing of a 1957 Plymouth Belvedere and a time capsule, which had been buried in Tulsa., Okla, to commemorate 50 years of statehood, misidentified one of the items in the capsule. It was a 48-star flag, not a 46-star flag.

I've been in the business of designing broadcast and recording studios for about 30 years, and since the beginning I've been traveling at least once a week. I've learned that the captive conversation between me and my seatmate can have some unexpected business or personal consequences that are downright karmic. About 20 years ago on a flight back to Dallas from New York, my seatmate was this tall long-haired guy. I was a little tired after winding up several productive days working on a project at NBC in Rockefeller Center, designing and overseeing construction of Edit 7, ''Saturday Night Live's'' primary audio post-control room. And I wasn't sure if I wanted to chat.

Democratic presidential candidates may come under scrutiny today and tomorrow from two important party constituencies: labor union members and liberal activists. More than 2,000 members of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees are expected to hear remarks today from Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and Joseph R. Biden, former Senator John Edwards, and other candidates.

GALLUP--Prudence Anne. On June 10. Not quite 65, much too young, an intellectual, highly literate, deeply curious, strongly opinionated, world traveller, cosmopolitan with a wonderful sense of humor. Mourned and missed by her brothers Allyn and Christopher and their wives Sheila and Chrystal, her nieces Marcy and Laurie, her nephew Christopher and their families, her partner Leeanne Lipston, and her many friends.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the Paris Air Show misstated Boeing's manufacturing schedule for its 787. The plane will be rolled out at Boeing's plant in Everett, Wash., on July 8; that is not the date for the inaugural flight.

Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain yesterday appointed John Tusa chairman of the Victoria and Albert Museum. Mr. Tusa, who will begin his four-year term on Nov. 1, is the managing director of the Barbican Center in London and was previously the managing director of the BBC World Service. He is the author of two books on the arts and has been the chairman of the advisory committee to the Government Art Collection, a trustee of the National Portrait Gallery and the Design Museum and deputy chairman of the English National Opera. He was knighted in 2003.

Two of the leading Republican candidates for president have said this month that they will not participate in the Ames, Iowa, straw poll, a ritual showing of political strength in that early caucus state. Their decisions raised doubts about whether Iowa would maintain its importance in selecting the party's nominee. But the candidates are showing that Iowa remains in their sights.

KALTMAN--Martin, died on June 15th at the age of 92. He had homes in Old Westbury, NY and Key Biscayne, FL. He was a man of great vision, imagination and a pioneer of the modern Lithographic industry in New York. With fellow Brooklyn Tech graduate Max Verebay they started Kaltman Press in 1932 to print labels by the letterpress process. They remained partners for 66 years. When the LP record was invented in 1947, they started printing album covers. With the advent of lithography they joined with Jack Hecht in 1950 to create Queens Lithographing Corp. in Long Island City. With the growth of album sales in the sixties. Queens Litho printed all Beatles and Rolling Stones LPs and the company grew rapidly. During that period the company opened factories in Edison, NJ and Indianapolis. In 1964 the company displayed an operating printing press on the floor of Grand Central Station. The volume of music packaging exploded in the eighties with the introduction of the compact-disc and the company added a factory in Louisville to handle the growth. The company changed its name to Queens Group Inc. Packaging for Home Video, Video games and Software created the need for added capacity and the company built two factories in North Carolina. The company also produced high quality packaging for cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and private label. The company was sold in 1998 and is now part of International Paper. A philanthropist, Mr. Kaltman actively supported UJA-Federation, MOMA, Julliard School where he endowed a scholarship, NSUH-LIJ Health System and the Botanical Gardens in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx. Martin was a founder of American Friends of Boystown Jerusalem and his company donated a printing press to the school in Israel. He loved growing plants, flowers, trees, vegetables and studied Horticulture at SUNY Farmingdale, and helped establish The Gardens at Crandon Park in Key Biscayne. He was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle. Mr. Kaltman's first wife, the former Helen Reich, died in 1984. He is survived by his second wife, the former Rosalie Podoll, her children and grandchildren. His son Eric and wife Marnee of Old Westbury, NY, their children Dennis, Richard, Jodi, Jon, their spouses and eight greatgrandchildren. His daughter Gail Bates and husband Dennis of Marietta, GA, their children Stephanie, Robin, their spouses and four greatgrandchildren. Memorial contributions may be sent to Queens Botanical Garden, attention: Susan Lacerte, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing, NY 11355. $(6$)KALTMAN--Martin. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Martin Kaltman, whose longstanding generosity helped make it possible for us to extend aid to those in need and build a strong Jewish community. A dedicated member of our community, he passed on his philanthropic ideals to his son, Eric, a valued and devoted supporter. We extend heartfelt condolences to Eric and his sister, Gail, & the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. $(6$)KALTMAN--Martin. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our devoted member. We extend our condolences to his family. Rabbi Michael A. White, Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Richard C. Laskey, President

The Security Council approved a request from Lebanon's prime minister to have the United Nations commission investigating the 2005 assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, help investigate last week's killing of a legislator, Walid Eido. Mr. Eido died in an attack similar to the one that had killed Mr. Hariri, when a vehicle parked along the same road in Beirut blew up as his car passed. Like Mr. Hariri, Mr. Eido was opposed to past Syrian domination of Lebanon's politics. Preliminary findings of the commission have implicated Syrian intelligence services in Mr. Hariri's murder.

HECHT--Harry Harris. Predeceased by wife Diane Paperny; father of Richard and Lisa (Howard) Lerner; grandfather of Steven, Shani, and Mark; loving brother to Norma (Bob) Apple and Jewel (Don) Spiegel. A ''great'' uncle. Sinai Chapels, 11:15am, 162-05 Horace Harding Expy.

SO the masked men of Fatah have the run of the West Bank while the masked men of Hamas have their dominion in Gaza. Some see this as a tolerable situation, maybe even an improvement, envisioning a secularist Fatah-run state living peacefully alongside Israel and a small, radical Gaza hemmed in by Israeli troops. It's always tempting to look for salvation in disaster, but in this case it's sheer fantasy. The Palestinian ruin was a long time in coming. No other national movement has had the indulgence granted the Palestinians over the last half-century, and the results can be seen in the bravado and the senseless violence, in the inability of a people to come to terms with their condition and their needs.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about comments by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the United States would not alter its plans to deploy a missile defense system in Poland and the Czech Republic, despite a proposal by Russia that the United States instead use a radar base in Azerbaijan, referred incorrectly to the former status of Poland and the Czech Republic. They were Soviet satellite states, not Soviet states.

An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on June 13 about the fraud trial of Conrad M. Black misspelled the surname of an attorney for Mark S. Kipnis, a co-defendant. And a correction in this space on Friday also misspelled his surname. He is Michael Swartz -- not Schwartz or Schwarz.

A headline and article in Business Day last Tuesday about a decision by TheStreet.com not to award prize money in the first round of its ''Beat the Street'' competition referred incorrectly to the reason for its action. Although TheStreet.com did say that some players used trading strategies that compromised the integrity of the system, it did not identify any of them or accuse any individual of ''cheating'' in the contest -- including J. McKeown, who was leading the contest.
BRODY--Benjamin, 87, died on June 17th, 2007. He is survived by his wife, Georgia, two sons, David and Samuel, and two granddaughters. Announcement of a memorial service is forthcoming.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences opened its rolls slightly yesterday, extending invitations to 115 prospective members. The additions would bring the film academy's voting membership to just under 6,000, and fell short of the maximum of 150 new members authorized by academy rules for the year. Among actors 16 invitees include Jennifer Aniston,Steve Carell, Daniel Craig and Christopher Plummer. Six directors invited to join included Peter Berg, Antoine Fuqua and Paul Greengrass.

A real estate executive was nominated yesterday by Gov. Eliot Spitzer to become the next chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the governor's office announced. The nominee, H. Dale Hemmerdinger, is a former chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission and president of the Hemmerdinger Corporation, a real estate development company, the governor's office said. Mr. Hemmerdinger is also president of Atco Properties and Management, a member of the board of Valley National Bank and a trustee of New York University. If confirmed by the State Senate, he will succeed Peter S. Kalikow, a Pataki administration appointee who said recently that it was time for him to move on.

The reporter had a question and, as usual, Derek Jeter gave an answer, if not exactly the one being sought. This was before the start of the weekend Subway Series and the reporter, from a New Jersey newspaper, asked Jeter about a letter he had written to the Rutgers women's basketball team -- which was honored at Yankee Stadium on Friday night -- in the wake of the Don Imus debacle.

SISKIN--Lillian, at 91 years. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence Siskin, passed June 16, 2007. Confidante, best friend, wonderful mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. We will miss you so much. Your loving daughters, Marilyn Merker (Dr. Charles Merker), Jeri Sapir (Robert Sapir), your son, David Siskin (Barbara Siskin), six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. $(6$)STERN--Jeffrey C. Jeff passed quietly after a valiant battle with ALS. His family and friends honor and cherish the memory of a man who always had a smile on his face. We love you Jeff, the Slavutin family. Services Tuesday, June 19, 11:15am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, NY, Amsterdam at 76th St.

To the Editor: Re '' 'Been There?' Sometimes That Isn't The Point'' (June 12): As a World War II prisoner of war, I find Sally Satel's conclusions about Vietnam veterans asking ''Been There?'' facile.

Most stocks fell yesterday for the first time in four days after confidence in the home building industry dropped to a 16-year low, renewing concern that the housing slump was not over. The deteriorating housing industry, combined with a six-week advance in bond yields, prompted concern that higher borrowing costs would restrain consumers and businesses.

DEYLIN--Judy, also known as Judith Secon and Judith Yedlin, died Sunday, June 17, 2007, at age 72. Judith was a graduate of Barnard College and a member of Actors' Equity and the Dramatists Guild of America. She will be remembered by her friends for her dedication to the art of the Drama and Song, her passion for social justice, her style, and her magnificent spirit. Donations in Judy's name may be made to The Actors' Fund.

The Italian Coast Guard continued its search for bodies after a vessel carrying immigrants sank off the southern Italian island of Lampedusa over the weekend. So far 11 of the 14 bodies they saw have been recovered, according to a Coast Guard spokesman who said the nationality of the victims remained unknown. Lampedusa, south of Sicily, is one of the main destinations of immigrants seeking to enter Europe from across the Mediterranean.

Senator Barack Obama said his campaign ''made a mistake'' last week when it distributed a document criticizing the support Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has received from Indian-Americans and companies that do business in India. ''The memo's caustic tone and its focus on contributions by Indian-Americans to the Clinton campaign was potentially hurtful, and as such, unacceptable,'' Mr. Obama said in a letter to Indian-Americans. The document, which referred to Mrs. Clinton as D-Punjab, caused a furor among Indian-American groups. Mr. Obama said he did not know about the memo, but added, ''I consider the entire campaign, and in particular myself, responsible for the mistake.''

Mimi has died, poor thing; cue the fireworks. Though a staple at Central Park concerts by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, fireworks often sit oddly on a program. How often can the Met offer the exultant ''Fidelio,'' after all, and how often does it offer the star-crossed ''Bohème''? And how often can the Philharmonic present Tchaikovsky's ''1812''? So it was a good choice to end the Brooklyn Philharmonic's little concert at the South Street Seaport on Saturday night with Handel's ''Music for the Royal Fireworks'' as accompaniment for a dazzling display of pyrotechnics by the Zambelli family, set off from barges in the East River. Not that Handel could have anticipated the firepower available to 21st-century revelers. Loudly amplified as it was, the music was no match for the bone-rattling percussion from the sky.

BLOOMBERG--Daniel, 89. Died June 16th, 2007. Loving partner of Betty Sandler, devoted father to Susan (Arthur) Landau, and Neil (Cathy) Bloomberg, beloved Papa Danny to Meredith, Rebecca, Ken, Leigh and Kay. For over 22 years, he lived his dream in Sarasota with Betty by his side. Predeceased by his wife, Frieda. He was heroic to the end and he will live in our hearts forever. Memorial contributions may be made to Tidewell Hospice, 5955 Rand Blvd, Sarasota 34238.

SERKEY--Renee J., June 18, 2007. Much beloved father of Robert and Richard; fatherin-law of Pauline and Louise; grandfather of Ethan, Rebecca, and Jakub; uncle of Peter, Deirdre, Tony, and Anglea. He will live in our hearts forever. Service Sunday, June 24, 1pm at ''Schwartz Bros.'' (Queens Blvd and 76th Rd), Forest Hills, NY.

Regular aspirin use may significantly reduce the incidence of both cancer and heart disease, according to a large new study, but other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids, have no effect. Researchers studied 22,507 postmenopausal women, following them for 10 years. All reported their aspirin and Nsaid use as part of a detailed physical and behavioral health questionnaire. None of the women had cancer or heart disease at the start of the study.
To the Editor: Re ''A Boycott Built on Bias'' (column, June 17):

A music review in Weekend on Friday about Paul McCartney, at the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan, misidentified the instrument he played when he sang ''Here Today.'' It was an acoustic guitar, not a piano.

FITZGEORGE--Harold J., 82, Korean Conflict hero, retired Chairman of Pennzoil Exploration and Production Company, died June 14 at his home in Vero Beach, Florida from complications of Parkinson's disease. Mr. Fitzgeorge (often known as Fitz) spent 29 years with Mobil Oil. Mr. Fitzgeorge served in the US Marine Corps in both World War II and the Korean Conflict. During his service in Korea, Fitz was a member of H Company, 3rd Battalion, 7th Regiment, 1st Marine Corps Division. He received a Purple Heart for being wounded at the battle of Chosin Reservoir and received the Bronze Star for valor for his action under fire. Harold James Fitzgeorge was born in Trenton, N.J. on June 15, 1924. He attended Rutgers and after the war, enrolled at Princeton University, graduating in 1948 with a Degree in Geology. After his service in Korea, Mr. Fitzgeorge worked as a field geologist and manger for Magnolia Petroleum which later became Mobil Oil. He received his M.B.A. from MIT in 1964. Mr. Fitzgeorge held senior positions with Mobil Oil Canada, where he played a major role in the development of the Alaska Pipeline, as well as serving as President of Mobil Oil Venezuela. In 1978, Mr. Fitzgeorge joined Pennzoil as President of Pennzoil Exploration and Production Company. He became chairman in 1981. He retired in 1984. Harold Fitzgeorge married Elizabeth (Bette) Weidel in 1945. (Bette Fitzgeorge died in 1987.) He is survived by the families of his four daughters, Barbara Carr of Norwalk, CT, Virginia Fisher of New Canaan, CT, Patricia Dunning of New York, and Elizabeth Brown of Charlottesville, VA, and his nine grandchildren. In 1999, he married Roberta Tefft of Vero Beach, Florida. A memorial service is planned for Saturday, June 23 at St. Aloysius Church in New Canaan, CT. The family requests that donations be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or the Harold J. Fitzgeorge Student Aid Fund, Princeton University.

O'BRIEN--Daniel Bryce, aged 61 years, of Wassaic, NY, and Aiken, SC, died peacefully on June 18, 2007. Danny graduated from Malvern Preparatory School in 1964 and earned a Bachelor of Science in Business from Georgetown University in 1968. In addition to being a great family man, Danny was truly a man of many talents. From his work for the Saudi Government in Washington, D.C. in the 1970s, to his successful real estate business in New York City in the 1980s, to the founding of three restaurants in the 1990s. Dan's fervor and enthusiasm drove his many successes. Danny's sense of commitment for business carried over to his passion for giving back to his community. He was deeply devoted to multiple charities and non-profit organizations including Union Settlement, Scenic Hudson, Shakespeare on the Hudson and his family's Troutwalk Fund. Danny is survived by his wife of 38 years, Wendy; two sons, Bryce and Topher; two daughters, Timoney Dunlap and Caroleana; and five of the best grandchildren, Findely and Bryce III, and Bela, Trent and Austin Dunlap. A private memorial service will be held at 4pm Thursday, June 21 at Troutwalk Farm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations may be made in Danny's name to Scenic Hudson, www.ScenicHudson.org Union Settlement Associates, www.UnionSettlemt.org and Part of the Solution, www.POTSBronx.org. Services have been entrusted to Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, NY.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 New American OffensiveOn Sunni Insurgents in Iraq The American military began a major attack against Sunni insurgent positions in Baquba, the capital of Iraq's Diyala Province, as part of a larger operation aimed at blunting car and suicide bombings that have thwarted political reconciliation. A1

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 2 about the expansion of Latin American companies into the United States misstated the relationship of one such company, Grupo Bimbo, with Wonder Bread. Grupo Bimbo makes and distributes Wonder Bread only in Mexico, where it has acquired the rights from Wonder Bread's parent, the Interstate Brands Corporation. Grupo Bimbo does not own Wonder Bread. The error was pointed out by Grupo Bimbo shortly after the article appeared. This correction was delayed while another question about the article was researched.

STERN--Jeffrey. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to his wife Ina and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May his memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President

Manufacturing is all but gone from New York. The information technology industry, while on a roll, does not quite have the Silicon Alley '90s buzz. This city is in danger of falling behind London as a financial capital. Thank goodness, we still have lawsuits. We are unsurpassed when it comes to them, although even on that score other cities are trying to steal our thunder. It is hard to top the administrative law judge in Washington who is demanding $54 million from his dry cleaner for misplacing a pair of his pants. This guy actually wept in court while telling of his loss. So sad.
There are two things here. There is poverty, and there is smuggling.

An article in The Magazine on Sunday about Dr. Ronald McIver, who is imprisoned for drug trafficking, gave an erroneous account of the trial testimony of one of his patients, Leslie Smith. And a correction in this space on Sunday again referred incorrectly to that testimony. The only point Mr. Smith made in his testimony was that he acknowledged injecting drugs prescribed by Dr. McIver. Mr. Smith never raised the issue of whether he himself sold any drugs that were left over to buy other drugs. And he never referred to Dr. McIver in the context of the leftover drugs -- either that Dr. McIver sold them or did not sell them.
YAMPOL--Hope Hardcastle, Director and Philanthropist, died June 17, 2007 after a long illness. She is survived by her brother Harold and family, and scores of loving friends.

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Boston's 1-0 victory against San Francisco referred incorrectly to the history of the interleague series between the Red Sox and the Giants. This was their first meeting since June 2004 -- not since the World Series in 1912, the year they last played each other at Fenway Park.

di MAYORCA--Enrica, affectionately known as Kicca to her many friends and Nonna to her seven grandchildren, died Saturday, June 16th, in Summit, New Jersey. Born in Milan, Italy, in 1935, Kicca spent her childhood and youth with her brother, Paolo, and her beloved sister Laura, playing competitive tennis and enjoying their parents country home in Alzate, Brianza. Kicca and her siblings gathered at Vill'Angela in Longone for many joyous years, strengthening the bonds of their growing families, which eventually included their seven children. Kicca deeply loved her nieces and nephews and was proud that the cousins remained close friends even though distance separated them. Kicca moved to the United States in 1968 with her husband, Giampiero di Mayorca, who was a microbiologist. They lived in Omaha, Nebraska, Chicago, Illinois, and moved to Summit, New Jersey in 1978, when her husband became the Chairman of the Microbiology Department at UMDNJ. Everyone who knew Kicca will remember her kindness. She was truly interested in others, always supporting her family and friends with thoughtfulness, warmth, humor and grace. Having earned her baccalaureate at the University of Grenoble in France, Kicca was able to extend her kindness and knowledge to Summit High School, where she volunteered, teaching French and working in the office. She was a mother and advisor to many of her and her childrens' friends, many of whom considered her their adopted sister and mother. Many other talents can be attributed to Kicca. She was an artist who decorated fine China with her own exquisite floral designs, a fabulous cook, whose Italian tomato sauce and pasta can never be forgotten or duplicated, a collector of art whose taste in interior design served as an inspiration to all, and a master bridge player who was most happy to teach difficult conventions and technical logistics. Her love of family was the force, which motivated her life. She is survived by her brother Paolo, her sister, Laura, her daughter Emilia Fabricant and her husband Bob, her son Marco and his wife Ashley, and her seven beloved grandchildren, Kicca, Maria, Matteo, Bobby, Caterina, Ethan and Federica. Anyone who knew Kicca will appreciate the simple truth in her grandson's poem to her, illustrated with a tiger, and written especially for her: Roses are red, violets are blue. No one has a bigger heart than you! A memorial service will be held at St. Teresa of Avila in Summit, New Jersey on Wednesday, June 20th, 2007 at 10:45 am. Arrangements by Paul Ippolito Summit Memorial, 7 Summit Ave., Summit, NJ (www.ippolitofuneralhomes .com). In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Maria Fund, c/o Katie McGrath, UM Cancer Center Development, 301 East Liberty, Suite 400, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48104-2251 to aid the University of Michigan's continued efforts to cure Leukemia.

Except for a plaque or a retired number in Monument Park at Yankee Stadium, there appears to be no greater confirmation of greatness for a past or present Yankee than to be the subject of a ''Yankeeography'' on the YES Network. Even being the august assistant to the traveling secretary, who slept on a shelf under his desk, seems like a hollow honor, as George Costanza learned.

It has been a long, lonely period for Jason Giambi. He has not played for the Yankees this month because of a foot injury, and he may not play again this season. In addition, Giambi must decide by Thursday if he plans to cooperate with baseball's investigation into steroid use. Lawyers for Major League Baseball and the players union continued to negotiate the parameters yesterday for a possible meeting with the former Senator George J. Mitchell. Commissioner Bud Selig asked that Giambi cooperate with Mitchell after Giambi tacitly admitted to using steroids. Indications were that Giambi was leaning toward meeting with Mitchell.

To the Editor: Yes, analytically oriented psychotherapy requires getting past such defensive resistance. I've ''been there'' dealing with the same questions till retiring from prison psychiatry a few years ago. There, an important subtext was the injustice of the ''justice'' system, but was rarely dealt with in therapy. With veterans, it's the unjustified killing. How do you deal with that?

Imagine that you are depressed and see a psychiatrist who explains that you have clinical depression and would benefit from an antidepressant. So far, so good. But then the doctor tells you there is a 60 percent chance that you'll feel better with this antidepressant and that it could take as long as four to six weeks to find out, during which time you'll probably have some side effects from the drug. I have just described the state-of-the-art pharmacologic treatment of major depression in 2007. Don't get me wrong; we have very effective and safe treatments for a broad array of psychiatric disorders. But in everyday clinical practice, we have little ability to predict which specific treatment will work best for you.
To the Editor: Re ''The Scarlet Letter'' (editorial, June 16):
IGNATOW--Archie. Special birthday memories. We miss you everyday. Remembered with love. Gene and three generations

Q.Is eating fortified foods (for example, orange juice enriched with calcium and vitamin D or flour with folic acid) any better than just taking the nutrients in pill form? A. ''If the same form of nutrient and daily dose is used, there should be no difference between nutrients taken in fortified foods and those taken in pill form,'' said Dr. Sheldon S. Hendler, co-editor of The Physicians' Desk Reference for Nutritional Supplements, the standard reference in the field. ''However, since most people prefer food to pills, regularly eaten fortified foods can provide a more reliable choice for following a particular vitamin and mineral regimen.''

SHAPIRO--Arnold. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Arnold Shapiro, beloved husband and father. The family's contributions have strengthened our ability to serve the Jewish community. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

Ringo Starr is going online. Beginning on Aug. 28 his EMI Music albums, including ''Sentimental Journey'' (1970), ''Beaucoups of Blues'' (1970), ''Ringo'' (1973) and ''Goodnight Vienna'' (1974) will be available for downloading, along with six Ringo Starr ring tones and ''Photograph: The Very Best of Ringo Starr,'' a career- and label-spanning 20-track collection of his solo recordings. ''Photograph'' will be available in CD and CD/DVD form, as well as digitally. The CD/DVD collector's edition includes seven previously unreleased film and video clips.
To the Editor: Re ''The First Domed City,'' by Timothy Egan (column, June 16):

Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about a vote by the New Jersey General Assembly to allow voters to decide whether all proceeds from a 1-cent tax increase approved last year should go to property tax relief for local governments referred incorrectly at one point to the type of tax that was increased. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was the sales tax, not the property tax.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, sounding every inch the presidential candidate he insists he is not, brought his message of pragmatic, nonpartisan leadership to California on Monday, telling a crowd of Google employees that the nation was ''really in trouble.'' In unusually stark terms, Mr. Bloomberg expressed his frustration with the state of the nation, touching on campaign-style issues like the war in Iraq, immigration, education, health care and crime before a crowd of more than 1,000 employees at the Google campus here.

I don't know if the air taxi model will work. But I do know that it flies. At 11:09 a.m. on a recent Thursday, with the pilot, Guenn Stevenson, and her co-pilot, Rick Hemphill, at the controls, the little Eclipse 500 very light jet took off with a sharp climb from the Boca Raton Airport. Both Ms. Stevenson and Mr. Hemphill are former airline pilots.

CONCERN OVER CHINESE-MADE TOYS There have been 24 safety recalls of toys this year so far and all of the toys have been manufactured in China -- a record that alarms consumer advocates, parents and regulators. Some contend the United States government is not doing enough to ensure safety of the toys. The recall last week 1.5 million Thomas and Friends railway toys made in China seems to have had little effect on the business of RC2, the Illinois company that built the trains -- some that were made with lead paint. [C1.]

To the Editor: Re ''She Calls It 'Phenomena.' Everyone Else Calls It Art,'' (June 12): Scientific visualization may indeed clarify ideas that are otherwise difficult to explain. For researchers working at the frontiers of science, this has yielded key insights and important advances in molecular biology, computational fluid mechanics, and industrial design.
WASSERSTEIN--Lola. To the lovely Lola, from your dancing partner and your laughing partner. I'll miss you. Love, Vuv

Vlastimir Djordjevic, an aide to the former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic, will appear in court in The Hague today to face charges of murder and persecution. Mr. Djordjevic, who was unexpectedly handed over to the war crimes tribunal on Sunday, had been living in Russia. He was arrested in Montenegro, where the police said he had arrived under a false identity. Mr. Djordjevic led Serbia's security police during the 1999 Kosovo war. Prosecutors say he had a major role in deporting Kosovo Albanians. His arrest leaves four others on the run.
SHORR--David. 2/21/18-6/19/92. 15 years. It seems like yesterday. Love always, The Family

Except for a plaque or a retired number in Monument Park at Yankee Stadium, there appears to be no greater confirmation of greatness for a past or present Yankee than to be the subject of a ''Yankeeography'' on the YES Network. Even being the august assistant to the traveling secretary, who slept on a shelf under his desk, seems like a hollow honor, as George Costanza learned.

To the Editor: Re ''Fateful Voice of a Generation Still Drowns Out Real Science'' (Findings, June 5): John Tierney does a disservice to Science Times readers with his piece about the influence of Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring.'' He uses a 45-year-old book review from a professor in agriculture who had specific motivations for the success of pesticides. And though the professor, I. L. Baldwin, accepted some problems with pesticides, he did not know in 1962 what we all know about chlorinated hydrocarbons now.

BOOTH--David B., age 82, Sociologist, Ph. D. Northwestern. Born in Chicago, died in Winsor, Ontario, Canada, on May 3, 2007. Survived by wife Ruth Drelich Booth, his children Tamara Booth and Donald Booth (Carmel Suttor), and two granddaughters.

Coke or Pepsi? McDonald's or Burger King? Amazon or Yahoo? Climate Counts, a new nonprofit group, wants consumers to think about more than taste or service when they make those decisions. It wants them to consider the companies' records in adding to or curbing climate change.
To the Editor: Re ''After the Bomb,'' by William J. Perry, Ashton B. Carter and Michael M. May (Op-Ed, June 12):

May was good for political Web sites. An Internet researcher, comScore Inc., reports that traffic to such sites jumped 17 percent to nine million unique visitors last month, the highest rate of increase among the 110 categories that the company studies. Among the big gainers: MoveOn.org, whose number of visits rose by 246 percent to around 689,000, spurred by a petition against gas price increases, while the news site Politico.com's sponsorship of the Republican debate May 3 helped fuel its 162 percent increase, to about 648,000 visitors.
Will Okun, who is traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, discussed his photographic style.

When Derek Jeter joined the Yankees, he was given No. 2 -- probably, he guesses, because he was skinny and it was the smallest jersey size. The last player to wear it before him was infielder Mike Gallego.

Oliver Perez is not much of a basketball fan. But he was sitting alone on a clubhouse couch at about 5:30, watching on ESPN Classic the replay of Game 6 of the 1993 N.B.A. Finals. The Chicago Bulls clinched their third consecutive championship that night in Phoenix, and the big shot, a three-pointer by John Paxson, came with 3.9 seconds left. Perez looked as if he had never seen it before, and he said, "Wow" over and over and over again.

A few years ago you could dismiss an actor for attempting to put his or her name on anything other than a movie or a TV show. Two bullet-proof exceptions were Paul Newman (spaghetti sauce) and Elizabeth Taylor (perfume). They had, in addition to talent and looks, a massive store of goodwill with the American people that exempted them from scorn. Now, all the roles have been if not quite reversed then shuffled: average Joes get to become divas (thanks to "American Idol"), musicians are statesmen (Bono), designers are artists (Hedi Slimane), bloggers are the new tastemakers, and actors are making jeans. Actors have a hard time winning our approval as designers, in part because the new tastemakers can so readily make them the object of our contempt (I cite the catalog of red-carpet disasters on Go Fug Yourself), and in part because we suspect that the mastery of one craft doesn't presume an ability to master another without demeaning both.

I have never cried much. In fact, I could probably count on one hand how many times I had really cried, as an adult, up until the time I came home from Iraq. During my tour, I couldn't even shed a tear at my mom's memorial service. I felt cold and numb because of everything going on around me. Not callous, just gifted at compartmentalizing emotions. I've cried more in the last year than I have in a lifetime. But here's the catch. They have all been tears of joy, in moments where I am simply overwhelmed and feel so very lucky to be home with my kids.

Call me shallow, but I am fond of those little extemporaneous rules, like Murphy's Law or the Peter Principle, that allow us to recognize and ridicule familiar patterns of social behavior. And I'd like to propose one of my own.
The fate of Bear Stearns' beleaguered subprime-securities hedge fund was up in the air Wednesday afternoon, as at least one major lender has begun auctioning off its collateral.
I can hear the music pulsating in the thick Congo night, inviting me. "Come over, dance, drink, have a good time, enjoy life." But I am scared to leave the hotel at night.

When it comes to New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg and whether he'll actually make a bid for the White House, the only point of agreement among some prominent bloggers is that the billionaire mayor has the resources to mount a serious campaign.

In the latest twists in the Dow Jones saga, the company said on Wednesday that its board of directors has taken the lead in negotiating with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. The move may push the publisher of The Wall Street Journal closer and faster to a sale.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Senator John McCain acknowledged here today that fundraising has "been very tough,'' but said that his brand of retail politics does not demand huge sums of money this early in the campaign.

We went back to HEAL Africa to visit Yohanita, the 41-year old woman we had found in the village of Malehe to be suffering from infection and severe malnutrition. I was relieved to see that she was lying in bed, fully conscious, and able to speak in full sentences. Feza, the girl who came down from the village, was at her bedside and feeding her some porridge and potatoes, which Yohanita was eating in big spoonfuls.
The familiar lines of debate over video games and violence are front and center again after Britain's banning of "Manhunt 2," but Nintendo's Wii may be changing the landscape.

Bloomberg, good for the Democrats? First Read, the blog of the NBC News political unit, speculates that a Michael Bloomberg presidential candidacy would help the Democratic nominee in November 2008: "Why? It's simple -- the South. The irony of a Bloomberg candidacy is that it could make the Democrats more competitive in the South because their 35 percent base vote in the South is made up of die-hard Democrats."
Melena Ryzik of The Times reports on the Public Theater's party for Shakespeare in the Park.
Jeffrey Gettleman travels with the Ogaden National Liberation Front, a  separatist rebel movement in eastern Ethiopia.
Et tu, Goldman Sachs?
Alison Smale, of the International Herald Tribune, discusses the events in the world this week.
Not everyone approved when we took Yohanita, a severely malnourished woman, from her village to the hospital. Dr. Lisa Dillabaugh, a Pediatrics resident, posted an opposing view:
It's just 925 days and about 10 hours until Michael R. Bloomberg's second term as mayor of New York is over, but who's counting?

When the package arrived in the mail, it seemed like an unexpected present.Inside was something wonderful: The large-format renderings of our dream home from Allison Ramsey Architects. Up until this point, we had been viewing the plans on our computer or on printouts. They were serviceable, but hardly exciting.
Rachel Louise Carson was born 100 years ago, in 1907, and her classic "Silent Spring" (1962) turns 45 this year. Tributes have been popping up everywere.
Have private equity firms found a new place to spend their overflowing buyout funds?

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The McCain campaign has taken delight this year in highlighting Mitt Romney's shifting stances on abortion, immigration, and several other issues. So the Romney campaign was quick to note an apparent shift by John McCain.

The London Stock Exchange may finally have found an acceptable partner: the stock market on Wednesday confirmed that it was in talks with Borsa Italiana of Milan about a possible merger. "London Stock Exchange Group PLC confirms that it is in discussions with Borsa Italiana SpA. to establish whether a merger of the two businesses can be agreed," the exchange said.
Speculation is once again mounting that private equity firms are circling Marsh & McLennan, the big insurance conglomerate.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 6 column, "What a Mess."
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 13 column, "Between Dust and Deliverance."
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 20 column, "Behind the Masks."

Beset by shrinking advertising revenues, newspaper companies have been flailing to find solutions to prop up their income. One solution that McClatchy, the company that bought Knight Ridder last year, is now entertaining: selling its stake in CareerBuilder, the job search Web site. McClatchy, one of the nation's largest publishers, co-owns the site along with Tribune and Gannett.

My Thursday column is about a woman in an eastern Congo village whom we found, starving to death -- a war casualty as much as any other. You can also find video about the case, and Will and Leana's blogs about it, at www.nytimes.com/twofortheroad. Please post your comments here.

I've often been asked why I write so much more about Darfur than Congo, since far more people have been killed in Congo. After all, fewer than half a million have probably died in Darfur, compared to 4 million in Congo.

There are two new managing directors in Credit Suisse's investment banking group. The firm said in an internal memo that Tom Delbrook, previously the vice president of finance at the shipping giant UPS, would join the firm's general industrial and services group, covering the transportation, shipping and logistics industries out of New York.
From the guy sitting two cubes away from The Lede, all the way to the International Space Station, 'tis the season for inexplicable computer meltdowns.

This win-a-trip journey is supposed to take weeks, but I've been a bit concerned that we might end up stuck here in our Congo hotel washing dishes for weeks. The problem is that you can't use credit cards in Congo, of course, and so everything revolves around cash. I brought my supply of $100 bills, well secreted, but it turns out that nobody here takes U.S. currency from 1999 or earlier.
In her web column today, Robin Toner writes:

The troubles at Bear Stearns have shown that even bulge-bracket investment banks can find themselves in a jam when their investments go south. But Bear is just dealing with a troubled hedge fund -- what would happen in a broader market collapse, or a worldwide liquidity crisis?

Yet another reason to avoid putting too much stock in any assessment of the horse race, more than six months before the voting begins in the Iowa caucuses: It may have very little relationship to the ultimate outcome.
Original documents and images from the Charles Becker case.
Tiny Guadeloupe has a chance to knock off Concacaf power Mexico in the Gold Cup tournament which is garnering large audiences at the stadiums and on television.

Morgan Stanley has added to its real estate ambitions, announcing Wednesday that it has raised $8 billion to invest in the field and intending to spend almost half of that in Japan. With those funds, the investment bank has now raised the world's largest global real estate fund, according to Bloomberg News -- topping rivals like the Blackstone Group, which took private Equity Office Properties, the nation's largest office landlord.
Canada, the only team besides Mexico and the United States to win the Gold Cup, finds itself in the position to shake things up in the Concacaf pecking order.

Last week's surprise out of Washington -- a bill that could jack up the tax rate for publicly traded private equity firms -- does not seem to be much of a concern for the Blackstone Group's underwriters. Or Fortress Investment Group's shareholders, for that matter.

Delphi and the United Auto Workers union are expected to announce as early as Wednesday a tentative labor agreement that could move Delphi, the nation's largest auto supplier, closer to emerging from bankruptcy, The Detroit Free Press reported, citing unnamed hourly workers and people close to the negotiations.

Christian Wiman - an occasional contributor to The Book Review, and a poet, critic, essayist and the recently-married editor of Poetry magazine - writes about his battle with incurable cancer of the blood in the new issue of The American Scholar. It's a devastating essay about poetry, about falling in love, about grief and about faith.

On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the "celebrity playlists" on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

Here's a totally unscientific but not unimportant measure of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's evolution from Iraq war supporter to antiwar partisan in the last year: She was booed more lightly and gently at this morning's Take Back America gathering of liberal activists than she was a year ago.

The billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian has withdrawn his efforts to acquire two of MGM Mirage's top Las Vegas properties, the casino operator said on Wednesday. Mr. Kerkorian, MGM's largest shareholder, had been pursuing the Bellagio (where he likes to stay when he's in town) and the City Center, but told the company's board Tuesday that his Tracinda vehicle was pulling its offer.

Rybka ran away from the field to win the 15th World Computer Chess Championship in Amsterdam from June 11 to 18. The championship was organized by the International Computer Games Association. Final standings and games can be found here at the ICGA's Web site.

The imminent publication of a book of poetry gets front page treatment in The Wall Street Journal today. "Poems From Guantánamo: The Detainees Speak" gives readers "an unusual glimpse into the emotional lives of the largely nameless and faceless prisoners there," the paper explains.

This is still CNN: Joshua Levy, co-founder of the blog techPresident, which tracks the role of the Web in the 2008 campaign, is disappointed by the rules for the two presidential debates co-sponsored by CNN and YouTube (the first one will feature the Democratic candidates next month in Charleston, S.C.). Because all of the questions will come from YouTube videos created by Internet users, the debate is being advertised as "a revolution in citizen participation in presidential politics," Levy notes.

With a trip through California this week that has resembled a political campaign swing and an announcement late Tuesday that he is leaving the Republican party, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg has managed to fuel rumors that he is edging closer to a run for president even as he reiterates that he has no plans to do so.

Nuveen Investments, a money manager catering to wealthy investors, agreed on Wednesday to be acquired by a group led by Madison Dearborn Partners for about $5.75 billion, as private equity finds itself plunging deeper into financial-services deals.
The house may be a fixer-upper but Park Place outside London reportedly has been snapped up for a mere £42 million -- or about $84 million.

Commissioner William J. Bratton has received a new vote of confidence at the Los Angeles Police Department as investigations simmer away concerning his officers' harsh tactics at an immigration protest.

The story of Ajaz Rahim, a former executive at Faysal Bank in Pakistan, and his friend Hafiz Muhammad Zubair Naseem, a Credit Suisse banker who American prosecutors allege provided Mr. Rahim with insider information for stock trades, is a timeless tale of hubris and aspiration.

As industry watchers tried to divine whether Yahoo would be put in play following the the resignation of Terry S. Semel as the Internet giant's chief executive, The New York Times suggested that another radical proposition is being whispered inside and outside the company: stop trying to beat Google at its own game.
Morgan Stanley, appearing to rise above the mortgage-related woes that have hurt some of its rivals, said Wednesday that its net income increased 40 percent in the latest quarter.

As financial services becomes a hot sector for leveraged buyouts, Cerberus Capital Management has hired a longtime bank executive to run the division in charge of those businesses. Alvaro de Molina, formerly Bank of America's chief financial officer, will run that unit, a Cerberus spokesman confirmed to Financial News.

The wait for one of the most eagerly awaited initial public stock offerings of the year got a couple of days shorter Tuesday. The Blackstone Group will price its initial offering Thursday night, according to the Web site of Morgan Stanley, one of the underwriters. The offering was originally scheduled to begin sometime next week.

As Bank of America's chief executive, Kenneth Lewis, sees it, private-equity firms will enjoy "unprecedented" access to financing for at least a few more years before a deal "goes bad" -- but that his own firm has begun to reconsider private-euity loans.

When the Federal Trade Commission announced its decision this month to try to block the $565 million merger of Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets, the move left some analysts and industry observers scratching their heads.

UBS, the biggest money manager for the wealthy, widened its lead over Citigroup and Merrill Lynch last year as rising stock markets attracted new funds, according to consulting firm Scorpio Partnership.
Franklin Raines, the ousted chief executive of Fannie Mae, said regulators are withholding documents that may show a deliberate attempt to drive down the mortgage-finance company's stock.

Symbion Health, an Australian health care company, accepted a new, higher bids for its vitamins and pharmacy businesses, paving the way for a buyout of the company for 2.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.4 billion). Ironbridge Capital and Archer Capital matched a rival bid by Sigma Pharmaceuticals to clinch the Melbourne-based company's recommendation, according to a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange Wednesday.

An effort to save a troubled hedge fund at Bear Stearns hit a major hurdle Tuesday when Merrill Lynch signaled that it would move forward with plans to auction $850 million in subprime securities that had been held as collateral, The New York Times reported.
PetroChina is planning the nation's biggest share sale this year to raise as much as $6 billion in Shanghai for overseas acquisitions, increased oil drilling and refinery construction.

Lehman Brothers said on Wednesday it plans to raise $500 million in an initial public offering of a fund that will invest in a pool of private equity funds. Lehman Brothers Private Equity Partners is set to launch on the Euronext in Amsterdam in late July.

Investcorp said Tuesday it had held the first closing of a new private equity pool at $620 million. Officials from Investcorp declined to comment beyond the firm's announcement about the vehicle, Investcorp Private Equity 2007 Fund LP, but The Deal.com reported that the pool has a $1 billion target.
The Dutch conglomerate Stork is in talks with London buyout shop Candover regarding a possible takeover worth about 1.45 billion euros ($1.9 billion).

Despite some high-profile setbacks in its target market of mobile virtual network operators, Visage Mobile closed a $10 million fifth round of venture capital, bringing total investment in the six-year-old company to more than $80 million to enhance boost its subscriber management services.
A solar cell and module maker Advent Solar, said on Tuesday it had secured more than $70 million in a series D funding to ramp up production at its four-month old production facility.

It was an enormous betrayal by his former associates - and not any act of criminal fraud - that led Conrad M. Black to the Chicago courtroom where, if convicted, he could face the rest of his days in prison, lawyers for the media baron said in their closing arguments.
David Pogue tests a few of the latest digital S.L.R.s.
Google has acquired an online slide presentation company, Zenter, filling out its web-based office software portfolio with an application similar to Microsoft's popular PowerPoint.

Royal Philips Electronics said Tuesday it was offering about $688 million for Color Kinetics, a lighting company based in Boston, with the support of the company's management. Philips, based in Amsterdam, is the world's largest lighting company, while Color Kinetics makes light-emitting diode systems for professionals.

Barclays, the British bank that is bidding for ABN Amro, is considering dropping its eagle logo because of concerns by ABN Amro that it could remind some clients of the Nazi regime, The New York Times reported.

Shopaholics in Asia never have to travel very far to reach a gleaming shopping mall. But nothing quite beats the mile-long strip of 6 large shopping centers in central Bangkok connected by an outdoor walkway. The "skywalk" as it's called opened two years ago but is not publicized and few foreign visitors seem to know about it.The "Skywalk" is open from 6am to midnight
The hippie revival has little of the impetus that drove the first wave, if you can remember those times.
Jason Hawes runs his own vigilante team on the Sci Fi reality show “Ghost Hunters.”
Although it isn’t the provincial place it once was, this Portuguese fishing town still has plenty of traditional charm.
A look inside the Quinta da Carolina and its vineyards in the Douro region of Portugal.
Additional images from the Wellcome Collection in London.
A weekend in Bali, what could be the perfect tropical retreat.
I think I just met him. His name is Jackson Holliday and he's 3 years old.
The term “sports film” doesn’t do justice to “White Palms,” a punishing, beautiful drama about a troubled 30-something Hungarian gymnast.
“Manufactured Landscapes” is an absorbing if unsettling documentary about the work of the Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky.
The sweeping story of the Mondavis’ ascent has been told many times, but never in as clear and detailed a fashion as in a compelling new book.
Laura Albert, the writer known as JT Leroy, took the witness stand today at her civil fraud trial in Manhattan.
If the proposal goes forward, Tony Blair would represent the “quartet” of world powers  in talks between Israelis and Palestinians.
The move effectively pushed the contentious debate surrounding the research into the 2008 campaign.
Christopher R. Hill said that the talks were back on track now that a dispute over $25 million in frozen North Korean assets has been resolved.
Lawrence M. Small raised less private money for the museum last year than his predecessor did in 1999.
“I’ve got the greatest job in the world and I’m going to keep doing it,” the mayor of New York told reporters.
A report shows, in block-by-block detail, that a  big storm would likely flood large swaths of the city.
Officials said that at least 30 insurgents were killed on the first full day of an aggressive push in Diyala Province.
In an escalation of violence today, Israel attacked rocket launchers in Gaza and clashed with Palestinian militants.
The government filed charges against former President Enrique Bolaños for covering up human trafficking in his administration.
The transitional government offered amnesty to former members of a radical Islamic group that ruled much of the country’s south last year.
European Parliament legislators offended vodka purists by backing a proposed definition of vodka that says it must be made from grain or potatoes.
The U.N. Human Rights Council marked the end of what critics called a disappointing first year by abolishing independent rights monitors for Belarus and Cuba.
Mike Mussina worked six innings and allowed three runs, but the Yankees simply could not hit against the Rockies’ Josh Fogg.
After falling behind 5-0 in the second inning, the Mets turned an uphill battle into an impossible one by committing four errors.
The company missed expectations as sales fell 2.2 percent at stores open at least 16 months in its Red Lobster chain.
The 2.6 percent rise in second-quarter earnings overcame weak pricing in the Caribbean and higher fuel costs.

An Asbury Park man who survived two shots to his chest in April was shot to death on Monday. The man, Derek L. Grier, 30, had been shot in April as he sat in his car. A suspect has been arrested. Early Monday morning, Mr. Grier was fatally shot outside the Elks Lodge on Comstock Street. Peter Warshaw, the first assistant Monmouth County prosecutor, told The Asbury Park Press that a possible link between the shootings was being investigated.

A judge has ordered the euthanization of two dogs that nearly ripped off a man’s ear in a June 10 attack in Dix Hills. The judge, Stephen Hackeling of First District Court, found yesterday that the two Rottweilers, a 10-year-old and a 1-year-old, were dangerous, but spared a third dog, 5 years old, that was also involved in the attack. The dogs’ owner, James Mazzone, 44, has 30 days to appeal. The police said Joe Mortensen, 22, was walking his dog with a friend when they were attacked by the three dogs. One of Mr. Mortensen’s ears was nearly severed.

A state highway maintenance worker was killed yesterday afternoon when he was struck by wheels that came loose from a flatbed tractor-trailer, the state police said. The worker, Eduardo Jimenez, 23, of Woodbridge, was doing landscaping work along the southbound lanes of Route 287 about 1 p.m. when he was struck by the tandem wheels, said Sgt. Jeanne Hengemuhle. Mr. Jimenez had worked for the Transportation Department since 2005, state officials said.

Former Mayor Sharpe James will retire from his job with Essex County College at the end of the month, The Star-Ledger reported yesterday. Mr. James, 71, was appointed a year ago to lead the college’s Urban Issues Institute, with an annual salary of $150,000. The college president, A. Zachary Yamba, told The Star-Ledger that Mr. James, left, informed the school about a month ago that he would retire on June 30. He said Mr. James had not been asked to leave and had not given a reason for his resignation. Federal authorities are investigating Mr. James’s actions during his last several months as mayor. He served for 20 years before deciding not to run last year.
The law would have allowed residents 18 or older suffering from multiple sclerosis, cancer, AIDS and other diseases to grow marijuana in their homes with a doctor’s recommendation and a state permit.
RedZone Capital purchased Dick Clark Productions, the TV production company, for $175 million.

The parents of a man killed in the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center were scheduled to appear in a Brooklyn courtroom this week to determine how to divide the $2.9 million death benefit. The victim, Kenneth Caldwell, a technology manager, was single and had no will, so his mother, Elsie Goss Caldwell, became administrator of his estate. His father, Leon Caldwell, has claimed part of the estate, but Elsie Goss Caldwell has disputed the claim, arguing that he had had little contact with their son throughout his life. Leon Caldwell’s lawyer did not return a telephone call for comment yesterday. The parents are scheduled to appear in court today.

The Tiffany & Company Foundation announced yesterday that it would give $1 million to each of three nonprofit organizations working in Lower Manhattan: the National Parks of New York Harbor Conservancy, which promotes access to parks around New York Harbor; the Battery Conservancy, which is building an ocean-themed ride in the Battery; and Friends of the High Line, which supports a park that is set to open next year on an abandoned overhead train track that runs from Gansevoort Street to 20th Street. The gifts are connected with Tiffany’s plan to open a store at 37 Wall Street in October. The main store is on Fifth Avenue at 57th Street.
The private equity firm BC Partners will buy the world’s largest commercial satellite operator, in a deal that values the company at about $5 billion.

A 40-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman were found dead of gunshot wounds in a single-family house on Riverside Drive on Monday afternoon, the Morris County prosecutor’s office said yesterday. There were no signs that anyone had broken into the house, the prosecutor, Michael M. Rubbinaccio, said. While the victims’ identities were withheld pending notification of next of kin, neighbors identified the man as Charles A. Kondakjian, a handyman whose wife died recently. Adam DeFalco, whose brother lives on the same block, said that Mr. Kondakjian had been keeping company with a young woman, and that the two would occasionally visit the neighborhood deli together. Investigators towed a silver Mountaineer sport utility vehicle, which neighbors said had been there all weekend, from the driveway yesterday.

The developer of a multifamily house on Maple Street near Kings County Hospital Center was charged with bribery yesterday after offering a building inspector $1,000 to overlook a safety violation, city investigators said. The man, Vauguens Michel, 49, was charged with bribery and rewarding official misconduct, according to the Department of Investigation. Rose Gill Hearn, the investigation commissioner, said that Mr. Michel offered the bribe to an inspector who had found shoring work on the site to be inadequate. The inspector reported the offer to the Department of Investigation, Ms. Gill Hearn said.

A 12-year-old girl was struck and killed by a New Jersey Transit train yesterday afternoon, railroad officials said. Dan Stessel, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit, said the transit police thought the girl, who was not identified, was playing with four or five friends on the tracks east of the Avenel Station. Mr. Stessel said the spot was near an overpass where Route 1 and 9 cross the tracks, but was not near any ground-level crossings. “The engineer sounded the horn and applied the emergency brakes, but was unable to stop in time,” he said. The girl was struck just before 2:30 by a train on its way from Hoboken to Bayhead. None of the 250 passengers were injured when the brakes were applied, Mr. Stessel said.

A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about a report from the Smithsonian Institution saying that its Board of Regents failed to provide proper oversight reversed the identities of two Smithsonian officials. Roger W. Sant, chairman of the Board of Regents’ executive committee, was second from the left, and Cristián Samper, the Smithsonian’s acting secretary, was third from the left.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some copies on June 10 with an article about Ivory Coast’s political fragility misidentified a religious structure built in Yamoussoukro, the official capital, by Félix Houphouët-Boigny, the longtime president, whose death in 1993 helped to precipitate events that led to a civil war. It is a basilica, not a mosque.
A music review on Monday about “Don Giovanni,” at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden in London, referred incorrectly to Erwin Schrott, who portrayed the title role. He is a bass, not a baritone.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the various factors that will offset New York City’s 7 percent across-the-board cut in property taxes referred incorrectly in some copies to a state law that limits the amount that the assessed value of a house can rise each year. It can rise no more than 6 percent in a year or 20 percent over five years — not over three years.

A chart yesterday about the number of television appearances made by presidential candidates in 2006 and 2007 omitted the time frame during which the numbers were tracked. The data was through June 10 of each year.
The former Dallas Cowboys quarterback will step down as chief executive of The Staubach Company.

An article on June 10 about a dispute between Vermont and a group of Civil War re-enactors over possession of a cannon referred incorrectly to a decision by former Gov. Mortimer Proctor about what to do with the cannon in the 1960s. He entrusted it to the re-enactors group itself, the Second Battery Vermont Light Artillery — not to James Dassatti or Richard Fifield, both of whom led the battery at different times. Also, the article misidentified the type of clothing that Ronald Crisman, who runs the Vermont Veterans Militia Museum and Library, wore to a legislative hearing on the current dispute. He wore contemporary clothing, not a Civil War uniform.

An obituary on Friday about Kurt Waldheim, the former diplomat and president of Austria, misstated the level of support he had in 1981 in his unsuccessful bid for a third term as secretary general of the United Nations. Although he retired from the United Nations after failing to win a unanimous vote of the five permanent members with veto power, his candidacy did indeed win some support, including that of the United States and the Soviet Union; it did not lack support entirely. Also, the obituary misidentified the chancellor of Austria whom Mr. Waldheim served under as foreign minister, from 1968 to 1970. He was Josef Klaus — not Bruno Kreisky, who became chancellor in 1970.
Corrections: For the Record

A sports article Monday about tense negotiations over the Big Ten Network’s placement on cable systems misstated the financial terms of a new 10-year contract that the Big Ten has with ESPN and ABC. It is worth $1 billion, or an average of $100 million a year — not a total of $100 million.

An article in The Arts on Saturday about a project in which the artist Eve S. Mosher is drawing a chalk line 10 feet above sea level in areas of New York City that could be threatened by flooding linked to global warming misstated the estimate of how often flooding at that level could occur, according to research by NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies at Columbia University. In a worst-case scenario, the 10-foot line could mark the zone for flooding that would occur every 19 years, on average, by the decade of the 2050s — not every eight years, on average, by the year 2050.
ALBANY, June 19 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer and top lawmakers agreed Tuesday to toughen penalties for driving while intoxicated and to create a homicide charge aimed specifically at drunken drivers.

An obituary on Friday about Kurt Waldheim, the former diplomat and president of Austria, misstated the level of support he had in 1981 in his unsuccessful bid for a third term as secretary general of the United Nations. Although he retired from the United Nations after failing to win a unanimous vote of the five permanent members with veto power, his candidacy did indeed win some support, including that of the United States and the Soviet Union; it did not lack support entirely. Also, the obituary misidentified the chancellor of Austria whom Mr. Waldheim served under as foreign minister, from 1968 to 1970. He was Josef Klaus -- not Bruno Kreisky, who became chancellor in 1970.

A 40-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman were found dead of gunshot wounds in a single-family house on Riverside Drive on Monday afternoon, the Morris County prosecutor's office said yesterday. There were no signs that anyone had broken into the house, the prosecutor, Michael M. Rubbinaccio, said. While the victims' identities were withheld pending notification of next of kin, neighbors identified the man as Charles A. Kondakjian, a handyman whose wife died recently. Adam DeFalco, whose brother lives on the same block, said that Mr. Kondakjian had been keeping company with a young woman, and that the two would occasionally visit the neighborhood deli together. Investigators towed a silver Mountaineer sport utility vehicle, which neighbors said had been there all weekend, from the driveway yesterday.

STERNBERG--Mary, age 92. Born in Brooklyn, New York on August 13, 1914, died in Lenox, Massachusetts on June 17, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Leo Sternberg. Adored mother of Amy Mann (Jeffrey) and Daniel Sternberg (Deborah), loving grandmother of Jessica Gutteridge (Corin), Rachel Rosan (Seth), Julia Sternberg and Sam Sternberg and greatgrandmother of Rafe, Lily, Lucas and Benjamin. She will be forever remembered by her family and friends as a woman of warmth who embraced all that is good in the world around her. Services Friday, June 22nd, at 1 pm, at Finnerty & Stevens, 426 Main Street, Great Barrington, MA.

RONAYNE--Robert J.P., known to all as Bob, was a licensed professional engineer with a 33 year distinguished career of public service. He began his career as an engineering technician with the New York State Department of Transporation in 1965. First assigned to the New York City Region and later to the Albany main office where he served in many capacities in construction, design and innovative engineering computerization. In addition to directing many highway and bridge projects, he also lectured extensively on the subject of advanced design around New York and internationally. He then became the Executive Director of the one billion dollar Route 9A Reconstruction Project in Manhattan, NYSDOT's largest project. Subsequently, Bob moved to the City of New York's Department of Transportation as Deputy Chief of Structures and retired as Deputy Commissioner and Chief Engineer with responsibility for over 800 bridges and 5000 miles of City Highway. Bob is a graduate of Newark College of Engineering and was an active member of the American Society of Professional Engineers, The New York Association of Transporation Engineers, The Albany Society of Engineers, and the Moles. Bob was preceded in death by his sister, Mary Helen. He is survived by his daughter Michele, his sister Patricia, his brother Michael and his grandsons Duncan and Devin. Visiting Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9pm, at M.J. Smith Sons Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Service Friday, 11am at Greenwood Crematory. A going away party will be held at Laura's Restaurant, 1235 Prospect Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11218. Food will be served.

Joe Girardi, a former Yankees player and coach, sounded enthusiastic yesterday after meeting with the Baltimore Orioles about their vacant managerial position. It would be surprising if he is not offered the opportunity to succeed Sam Perlozzo, who was fired Monday. ''I wouldn't have interviewed for the job if I wasn't serious about it,'' said Girardi, last year's National League manager of the year with Florida. ''I'm interested. Obviously, there's a process, and they're going through it right now.''

Roger W. Sant, chairman of the Board of Regents' executive committee, was second from the left, and Cristián Samper, the Smithsonian's acting secretary, was third from the left.

UNTIL not long ago, the term ''bean salad'' was rarely used without being preceded by the word ''three,'' and the three-bean salad was usually a staple of the bad salad bar. But the world of real bean salads can extend the range of your repertory. That you have dozens of possibilities when it comes to beans and scores of dressings means that your salad can take on many flavors.

The developer of a multifamily house on Maple Street near Kings County Hospital Center was charged with bribery yesterday after offering a building inspector $1,000 to overlook a safety violation, city investigators said. The man, Vauguens Michel, 49, was charged with bribery and rewarding official misconduct, according to the Department of Investigation. Rose Gill Hearn, the investigation commissioner, said that Mr. Michel offered the bribe to an inspector who had found shoring work on the site to be inadequate. The inspector reported the offer to the Department of Investigation, Ms. Gill Hearn said.

Someone in the new management told Stanley Bard yesterday to stop hanging around the front desk of the Chelsea Hotel, which he has run for 50 years, more or less. He had come to work a bit later than his usual 5:30 a.m., but Mr. Bard, 73, does not have an actual job any more. He was shelved this week. That Mr. Bard lingered in the hotel even yesterday suggested that the New York of $1,000-a-square-foot real estate has not quite completed the extinction of the city of funk.

SERKEY--Rene J., June 18, 2007. Much beloved father of Robert and Richard; fatherin-law of Pauline and Louise; grandfather of Ethan, Rebecca, and Jakub; uncle of Peter, Deirdre, Tony, and Angela. NEW YORK chefs have been flaunting peas, fava beans and ramps on their menus since March, but as every farmers' market devotee knows, it's all a great big spring vegetable charade. By the time the vernal equinox hits, we're desperate to trade brussels sprouts for asparagus, but the really divine local produce is still months away. So it goes year after year, supping on sugar snaps at restaurants (which FedEx them from afar), buying wintered-over leeks and potatoes at the farmers' market until May. And with a particularly cool and rainy April, this year's spring harvest was frustratingly delayed.

Los Angeles ON Thursday, on the summer solstice, the Sun will celebrate the year's lazy months by resting on the horizon. The word solstice derives from the Latin ''sol'' (sun) and ''sistere'' (to stand still). The day marks the sun's highest point in the sky, the moment when our shadows shrink to their shortest length of the year. How strange to think that these mundane friends, our ever-present familiars, can actually go faster than the sun's rays.
ZORN--Iris Segal. 6/20/98. ''Not a day goes by'' ''Not a day'' Love, Joe

KANNER--S. Lee, retired New York Times editor and author, died June 18 at age 91. His beloved wife Elsie died March 2. They leave three devoted children, Andrea Wasserman, Steven Kanner and Ellen Kanner; seven grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Funeral at 10 am, June 20, at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

Chocolate's flavor differs depending on the source of the cacao used for it. Choctál, a company in Pasadena, Calif., makes four ultrasmooth chocolate ice creams that show off their individual origins and personalities. The Costa Rican is smoky with hints of licorice and spice. The San Dominican has coffee overtones, and the Ghanaian is flagrantly rich. Kalimantan, from Borneo, is the most intensely bitter of the lot. A Madagascar vanilla is very good, though less distinctive than the chocolate varieties. The ice creams, around $6 a pint, are sold at Zabar's, Jefferson Market and Westside Market.
