European Parliament legislators offended vodka purists by backing a proposed definition of vodka that says it must be made from grain or potatoes. But to the horror of traditionalists, they said vodka could also be made from ingredients like sugar beets, apples and raisins, as long as vodka bottles were properly labeled. Countries in the so-called vodka belt, which includes Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland and Sweden, wanted a definition that would allow vodka to be made only of grain, potatoes and molasses.

Mac Morgan, an American bass-baritone who sang on radio, television and the stage from the 1940s to the 1970s and who was later chairman of the voice department at Boston University, died on June 12 in Carrollton, Ga., where he lived. He was 89. He died of complications of an appendectomy, said his daughter Anne Morgan. Mr. Morgan sang with City Opera and with touring companies like the Goldovsky Opera Theater and the NBC Opera Company.

Viviana Alcazar hovered at her mother's hospital bed, feeling the alternating tugs of ambition and obligation, knowing which one would prevail. It was late 2002, and she was a year into community college and daring to think of transferring to a university. Meanwhile, her mother, Elisa, had stomach cancer and was scheduled for an operation and chemotherapy and given a prognosis full of question marks. There was no real choice to make. Just as Elisa Alcazar had worked all those years in the deli, at McDonald's, cleaning houses, all for Viviana to have a life and an education in America, now it was the eldest daughter's time to sacrifice.

A music review on Monday about ''Don Giovanni,'' at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden in London, referred incorrectly to Erwin Schrott, who portrayed the title role. He is a bass, not a baritone.

BRESCIA--Monica Ann, a long time resident of Yorktown Heights, NY, died on June 16, 2007, at Hudson Valley Hospital Center in Peekskill. She was 70. Mrs. Brescia, who was born in NYC, worked as a homemaker. She was educated in Queens and graduated from the Mary Louis Academy in 1953. On July 28, 1956, she married Michael Brescia, M.D. at St. Pascals Baylon in Queens. Mrs. Brescia lived in Yorktown Heights for the past 42 years. Locally she was a parishioner at St. Patricks Church. Mrs. Brescia will be remembered for her vibrant approach to ordinary activities of daily life and film, sports and theatre. She is survived by her loving husband of 50 years, Dr. Michael J. Brescia, six children; Dr. Michael L. Brescia, Dr. Mark J. Brescia, Dr. Andrea M. Brescia-O'Brian, Mrs. Monica Mekeel, Christopher Brescia, Esq., and Mrs. Marissa Viggiano, RN, along with nine grandchilren; Sara, Haley, Presley, Maggie, Clinton, Michael, Sofia, Timothy and Robert. Calling hours are Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Clark Funeral Home in Yorktown Heights. The funeral mass is Thursday, 10am at the new St. Patrick's Church in Yorktown Heights. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461, 718-863-6900

The parameters of Jason Giambi's potential meeting with baseball's steroid investigators could leave the head detective George Mitchell with a strategic decision: Does he place the lug on the couch or in a hot seat? Giambi would prefer a therapy session. His team of negotiators are trying to map out an office visit -- probably a 50-minute hour -- that would limit Giambi to answers about his own 'roid-world experience without violating the clubhouse code by snitching on teammates.

WHEN a fistfight breaks out between two men in the office, you have to figure that the ill feeling between them runs deep. Especially if they are brothers and business partners who are duking it out in front of their horrified employees.

The Human Rights Council, created to be an improvement on the discredited Human Rights Commission, which seldom exposed notorious rights violators, marked the end of what critics called a disappointing first year by abolishing independent rights monitors for Belarus and Cuba. The Geneva-based council did maintain monitors for 10 countries, including Cambodia, Myanmar North Korea and Sudan, and agreed to new rules obliging all 47 member states to have their rights records scrutinized.

NEWELL--Martha Hill, faced her final curtain call June 6th with dignity. A resident of Westminster Canterbury, Richmond, VA; she was 85. Born July 26, 1921 to Marshall Nelson Newell and Jessie Beatrice Hill in Richmond, VA. She was educated at Collegiate School (1939), St. Mary's Junior College in Raleigh, NC; received her undergraduate degree from William and Mary and master's degree from Richmond Polytechnic Institute (1950). Martha moved to New York in 1955 and stayed for forty years. A member of The Dramatists Guild she was employed by The Girl Scouts of America as their events chairwoman and by publishing firms as a book editor and writer (mainly W H Sadlier) while THRIVING in the middle of a vibrant theatre life. Martha returned to Richmond in 1995 to continue writing, producing, and directing her own plays. A party is being held in her honor 7pm, July 9, The Barksdale Theatre, Richmond, VA.

A 12-year-old girl was struck and killed by a New Jersey Transit train yesterday afternoon, railroad officials said. Dan Stessel, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit, said the transit police thought the girl, who was not identified, was playing with four or five friends on the tracks east of the Avenel Station. Mr. Stessel said the spot was near an overpass where Route 1 and 9 cross the tracks, but was not near any ground-level crossings. ''The engineer sounded the horn and applied the emergency brakes, but was unable to stop in time,'' he said. The girl was struck just before 2:30 by a train on its way from Hoboken to Bayhead. None of the 250 passengers were injured when the brakes were applied, Mr. Stessel said.
To the Editor: Re ''Over an Open Mike, Young Voices Speak in Verse'' (news article, June 12), about the poets from P.S. 321 in Brooklyn:
$52/SQ. FT. approximate annual rent $312,000

1 tablespoon unsalted butter 1 bunch radishes, trimmed and quartered lengthwise 1 1/2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil 1 red onion, halved lengthwise and thinly sliced 3 thyme sprigs (optional) Pinch sugar Kosher salt 2 garlic cloves, very thinly sliced 1 bunch scallions, trimmed and halved lengthwise 1/4 cup white wine 1 bunch asparagus (about 1 pound), trimmed and cut into 1-inch lengths 1 bunch Swiss chard (preferably red), leaves torn into bite-size pieces, stems cut into 1-inch lengths 1/2 pound sugar snap peas, trimmed 1 cup vegetable or chicken broth Freshly ground black pepper 1 cup shelled fresh or frozen peas (about 1 pound in the shell) 1 small head Boston lettuce, torn into bite-size pieces 6 tablespoons grated Parmesan Cornmeal-herb dumplings (see recipe), or prepared polenta or buttered noodles. 1. Heat butter in a large skillet over high heat until sizzling. Add radishes and cook on one side until dappled golden brown, about 5 minutes. Turn radishes and sear for 3 minutes more. Transfer to a bowl.
$2.6 MILLION 191 Hanse Avenue
To the Editor: Re ''Erasing Tattoos, Out of Regret or Simply to Get a Fresh Canvas'' (front page, June 17):

SHAFFAR--Willard. Passed on June 17, 2007 of cancer. Retired technical director in the theater. Services will be held Friday, June 22, 7:30pm at West End Presbyterian Church, 165 West 105th St. New York, NY. 212-663-2900. Donations can be made to the American Cancer Society in his name.

A sports article Monday about tense negotiations over the Big Ten Network's placement on cable systems misstated the financial terms of a new 10-year contract that the Big Ten has with ESPN and ABC. It is worth $1 billion, or an average of $100 million a year -- not a total of $100 million.

Kenny Anderson, who spent 14 seasons as a point guard with nine N.B.A. teams, was named the first coach of the Continental Basketball Association's Atlanta Krunk. Anderson, 36, will return to the city where he led Georgia Tech to the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament in 1990 as a freshman.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some copies on June 10 with an article about Ivory Coast's political fragility misidentified a religious structure built in Yamoussoukro, the official capital, by Félix Houphouët-Boigny, the longtime president, whose death in 1993 helped to precipitate events that led to a civil war. It is a basilica, not a mosque.

GARLAND--Sylvia Dillof; 88, peacefully passed away at her home on June 16th. She is survived by her beloved husband Albert, daughter Margaret, son Paul and wife Elizabeth, and her grandchildren, Victoria, Natalie and Ian. She was a partner in Hofheimer, Gartlir, and Gross, member of the Board of Trustees of New York Law School and the Fitness and Character Committee of the NY Bar. She led a distinguished life and took great pride in her family and the practice of law. Her family and friends will miss her dearly.

To the Editor: Madeleine May Kunin has her heart in the right place (''A Math Lesson on College Loans,'' Op-Ed, June 13), but calling for more government in the student loan market just doesn't add up.

PRO BASKETBALL SPREWELL LIBEL SUIT DISMISSED A state appeals court in Manhattan dismissed Latrell Sprewell's libel suit against The New York Post over its account of how he broke his finger nearly five years ago. The 5-0 ruling by the state Supreme Court's Appellate Division reversed a lower court ruling that said Sprewell's case could proceed. Sprewell, who was with the Knicks in 2002, sued The Post and the reporter Marc Berman that year over articles published on Oct. 4, 7 and 8. The articles suggested that Sprewell had broken his right little finger in a fight on his boat in a Milwaukee marina in September 2002. (AP)
To the Editor: Re ''Adult-Only Froot Loops'' (editorial, June 16):

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the various factors that will offset New York City's 7 percent across-the-board cut in property taxes referred incorrectly in some copies to a state law that limits the amount that the assessed value of a house can rise each year. It can rise no more than 6 percent in a year or 20 percent over five years -- not over three years.
To the Editor: Re ''New Lyrics for Israel'' (Op-Ed, June 18):

DETROIT RETHINKS ITS POSITION American automakers have reversed years of stalwart opposition to any legislation to increase fuel economy standards, and are now willing to accept a modest increase in mileage standards in the hopes of silencing calls for even tougher targets.

My grill is not tricked out with special accessories, but I've found that a rack for shellfish comes in handy. I discovered it in ''The Summer Shack Cookbook'' by Jasper White (W. W. Norton, $35). Mr. White has high praise for the stainless steel grate, which cradles the shells to retain the juices. It also prevents burnt fingers, a hazard encountered when clams and oysters are removed from the grill once they open. The grate comes in three sizes, for 6 to 52 shells, and is sold at greatgrate.com, $9.95 to $39.95. A similar rack, which has convenient metal handles and holds 30 clams or oysters, is new from Steven Raichlen, $19.99 at barbecuebible.com. Both racks can also be used in the oven.

Salt 1 cup all-purpose flour 1 cup cornmeal 1 teaspoon baking powder 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper 2 tablespoons chopped mint 2 tablespoons chopped chives 1/2 cup buttermilk, more if needed 2 large eggs, beaten. 1. Bring a large pot of heavily salted water to a boil. Combine dry ingredients in one bowl and the herbs, buttermilk and eggs in another. Stir the wet into the dry until just combined into a very thick batter (if it is doughlike, add more buttermilk).
To the Editor: Re ''Diagnosis: Conflict of Interest,'' by Daniel Carlat (Op-Ed, June 13):

To the Editor: Michael Goldfarb (''Where the Arts Were Too Liberal,'' Op-Ed, June 17) correctly points out many of the factors contributing to Antioch College's demise. But he does less to explain why we should care or why events at this small college once again earned national and international attention.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Bush threw his weight behind President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Tuesday, using an Oval Office meeting with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel to declare Mr. Abbas ''the president of all the Palestinians'' and praise him as ''a reasonable voice among the extremists'' in the Middle East. The very public embrace of Mr. Abbas, a leader who has occasionally received cool treatment from the White House, underscored the intensity of the administration's effort to isolate Hamas and shore up the new Fatah-led emergency government Mr. Abbas has established on the West Bank. Mr. Bush's comments were his strongest declaration of support for Mr. Abbas to date.

SHIERS--Paul W., age 90, at his home in Park Ridge, NJ, on June 16, 2007. A Broadway singer and stage manager, he spent 30 years with CBS TV. Married 67 years to Vivian Smith. Services, Becker Funeral Home, 201-664-0292.

Potluck dinner at the Rock Lodge Nudist Club in Stockholm, N.J. The club, which traces nudism on the site back to the Depression, draws members from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania and allows visitors only on weekends. Some members own cottages on the club's wooded property around a private lake. This was a weekend dinner for members and guests early in the season.

Microsoft has agreed to make changes to its Windows Vista operating system in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of Vista is anticompetitive, lawyers involved in the case said on Tuesday. The settlement, reached in recent days by state prosecutors, the Justice Department and Microsoft, averted the prospect of litigation over a complaint by Google that Vista had been designed to frustrate computer users who want to use software other than Microsoft's to search through files on their hard drives.

An article on June 10 about a dispute between Vermont and a group of Civil War re-enactors over possession of a cannon referred incorrectly to a decision by former Gov. Mortimer Proctor about what to do with the cannon in the 1960s. He entrusted it to the re-enactors group itself, the Second Battery Vermont Light Artillery -- not to James Dassatti or Richard Fifield, both of whom led the battery at different times. Also, the article misidentified the type of clothing that Ronald Crisman, who runs the Vermont Veterans Militia Museum and Library, wore to a legislative hearing on the current dispute. He wore contemporary clothing, not a Civil War uniform.

An article in The Arts on Saturday about a project in which the artist Eve S. Mosher is drawing a chalk line 10 feet above sea level in areas of New York City that could be threatened by flooding linked to global warming misstated the estimate of how often flooding at that level could occur, according to research by NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies at Columbia University. In a worst-case scenario, the 10-foot line could mark the zone for flooding that would occur every 19 years, on average, by the decade of the 2050s -- not every eight years, on average, by the year 2050.

A typical Thomas the Tank Engine story is a little morality play about hubris. The stories take place on the fictional Island of Sodor, where train cars with faces and personalities go about their work. Almost inevitably, one of the trains tries to run too fast or pull too many boxcars and ends up in a big mess. By the end of the story, though, he comes to understand what he has done wrong. As the last line of ''A Big Day for Thomas'' puts it, ''Thomas had already learned not to make the same mistake again.''

Gaza City THE events in Gaza over the last few days have been described in the West as a coup. In essence, they have been the opposite. Eighteen months ago, our Hamas Party won the Palestinian parliamentary elections and entered office under Prime Minister Ismail Haniya but never received the handover of real power from Fatah, the losing party. The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, has now tried to replace the winning Hamas government with one of his own, returning Fatah to power while many of our elected members of Parliament languish in Israeli jails. That is the real coup.

After struggling with what was described as one of the most difficult decisions in her three-year tenure, Gov. M. Jodi Rell vetoed a measure today that would have legalized the use of marijuana for certain medical conditions. In a statement, Mrs. Rell, a breast cancer survivor, said, ''I completely sympathize with the well-intentioned goal of alleviating pain and suffering, but legal alternatives are available.''

The Tiffany & Company Foundation announced yesterday that it would give $1 million to each of three nonprofit organizations working in Lower Manhattan: the National Parks of New York Harbor Conservancy, which promotes access to parks around New York Harbor; the Battery Conservancy, which is building an ocean-themed ride in the Battery; and Friends of the High Line, which supports a park that is set to open next year on an abandoned overhead train track that runs from Gansevoort Street to 20th Street. The gifts are connected with Tiffany's plan to open a store at 37 Wall Street in October. The main store is on Fifth Avenue at 57th Street.

Tangy goat cheese is a far cry from cajeta, the sweet Mexican caramel, though both start with goat milk. A farm in West Pawlet, Vt., that makes goat cheeses has added cajeta ($5 for 8 ounces) to its inventory. You can be sure it was not made when the farm was founded in 1864 by Consider Bardwell, who started the state's first cheese cooperative. Nor, for that matter, were the buttery Dorset, an aged, washed-rind, cow's milk cheese of great complexity ($17 a pound), or the aged, washed-rind Manchester ($22 a pound), a smooth mountain-style goat cheese that hints at sharpness.

ANGELINO--Helen Weston. Loving matriarch and lifelong New Yorker. Hard working for almost 100 years. Gifted in so many ways. A talented seamstress and a superb, intuitive cook of healthy Italian dishes, beautifully presented. A believer in moderation in all things. With her husband, Francis, she ministered to many sick and lonely friends and relatives. She was compassionate and forgiving, and will be remembered by all that she touched. She leaves behind three children, eight grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 2-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 11am at St. Joseph's RC Church. 404 E. 87th St. Entombment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery.

Referee Benito Archundia's decision to disallow a last-ditch Canadian equalizer helped send the United States advance to the Gold Cup final but left the Canadians fuming. Did Archundia get it right, or did he blow the call? Who are the best and worst referees at this year's tournament, and why?

Formula One made the cover story of Nature magazine today, as the highly respected science journal investigates Max Mosley's green future for the sport. The cover has the headline: "HOW GREEN IS THIS?" with a photo of a McLaren and a Ferrari racing. Inside, the headline reads: "Formula 1 racing: Power games"

In my Friday column, I discuss Universal Express, a penny stock that is issuing billions of shares of stock each quarter. Those shares are evidently being sold in the market, and the cash enables the company to stay in business. A federal judge has ruled that those sales are illegal, but that has not stopped them.

Riffing off his Two Americas campaign theme, John Edwards took aim at the financial services industry in a speech tonight in New York, where he blamed a lack of industry regulation for the demise of the American Dream.
HIALEAH, Fla. - Rudolph Giuliani often talks about how dictators, bullies and tyrants need to be confronted and challenged.

In a recent study on birth order and intelligence, Norwegian researchers report that eldest children have higher I.Q.s than their younger siblings. Why would that be? There are as many guesses as there are scientists. "Virtually anyone who has a sibling is a birth-order theorist," says Dr. Frank Sulloway, an expert on family dynamics at the University of California, Berkeley. Dr. Sulloway answered readers' questions about the study and its implications; his answers appear below. [Editors' note: questions are no longer being accepted.]
The Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden re-opens after a $2.5 million renovation. The one-acre garden is in the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
Highlights of the Paris air show, including Lockheed Martin's Joint Strike Fighter.

ATHENS, Ala., -- Senator Jeff Sessions, the Alabama Republican, is one of President Bush's staunchest opponents on legislation to overhaul the nation's immigration laws. But that didn't stop Mr. Bush from traveling to Mobile today to raise money for Mr. Sessions' reelection campaign.
Leana Wen, who is traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, followed up on the care of Yohanita.
The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Sicko," Michael Moore's documentary on the American health insurance industry.

Ségolène Royal was the first woman from a major political party to run for President of France. She was the first French cabinet minister to give birth while in office. And now she has become the first French political figure to break up with her boyfriend - Socialist party head Francois Hollande, her concubin, according to French law, and the father of her four children - on the public airwaves.
The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Lady Chatterley," a French take on D. H. Lawrence's racy novel.
He's baaaack.
Do you suppose it's possible today, somewhere in America, to graduate from high school with one's virginity intact? Everything would seem to point away from the possibility.
Can you believe that someone posted the ending of Harry Potter on the the Web?
They did it.

The Supreme Court decision in Tellabs today drew praise from trade groups for banks and trial lawyers. That alone should be an indication that it is anything but definitive in its effect. Even the Tellabs case may yet survive and go to trial, depending on how lower courts assess the facts in light of today's opinion.

Billionaire investor Nelson Peltz bought a 3 percent stake in Kraft Foods, a person with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News, confirming a report by CNBC. The company's shares jumped 6.6 percent, the most in 11 months.

Nicole Kaplan has been the executive pastry chef at the Italian restaurant Del Posto since January. She made her reputation with the work she did before then at Eleven Madison Park, where she spent seven years and where her desserts were one of the restaurant's standout attractions.

Lehman Brothers consistently ranks high in Wall Street's investment-banking league tables, but it was the sisters at Lehman who dominated day one of this year's J.P. Morgan Corporate Challenge. The annual footrace in New York's Central Park is historically so crowded with Wall Streeters that Banker's Ball dubs it the "Bankerthon."

The instant reviews of "Sicko," Michael Moore's new movie, are beginning to trickle onto the Web. Eric Alterman, who has taken his "Altercation" blog from MSBNC.com to Media Matters, calls it "by far Moore's best film: good humored, compelling, and, amazingly, it's actually fun."

The most bizarre experience on this trip so far has been the visit to General Laurent Nkunda. It's hardly an everyday occurrence to go to the military camp of an actual "warlord" who is accused of raping and massacring thousands. (He prefers to be referred to as "liberator of the people", and denies all allegations against him.) That a journalist well known for opposing him had just been assassinated in the Congo, and that General Nkunda made several references to our security, made us apprehensive during the interview and cautious in subsequent reporting.
The Yankees travel to San Francisco after today's game in Denver, and there they will face Barry Bonds, who needs eight home runs to break Hank Aaron's record of 755.

Stephen P. Schaible, formerly a managing director and head of global energy banking at Citigroup, will join Evercore Partners in September as a senior managing director, where he cover the energy and chemicals sectors out of New York, Evercore said Thursday.
The annual spectacle let's racegoers find creative diversions with hat-styles from elegant to outlandish.

Yet more politicians have taken aim at the Blackstone Group's forthcoming initial public offering on the eve of its pricing. In a letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission Thursday, Henry A. Waxman, the Democratic chairman of the House Oversight Committee, and Dennis Kucinich, a Democratic congressman from Ohio and a presidential hopeful, warned that the I.P.O. may present "new and undisclosed risks.''
Director Michael Winterbottom dissects a scene from "A Mighty Heart," starring Angelina Jolie.
After an unusual spike in news about islands, The Lede takes a tour from Japan to New York.
As the Senate prepares to open another major debate over Iraq next month, a dispute is percolating in an unlikely corner: two Democrats who both voted against going to war.
One potential white knight for Dow Jones has ridden into the sunset.

Skull and Bones spent what must have been an excruciating day or so on news sites across the Web this week when The Associated Press put out a story about the Apache quest to retrieve Geronimo's remains, a legend fortified with a few pieces of evidence.

There is a lot of skepticism surrounding the idea that News Corporation will trade MySpace for a 25 percent stake in Yahoo. Reports of the talks, which the Tech Confidential blog describes as having the distinct smell of a "well-timed leak," are said to be very preliminary, and Yahoo may decide that it's not interested.
Many of us have come to rely on cell phone text messaging to ask and answer all sorts of everyday questions - things like: "Want 2 meet 4 coffee?" or "U going 2 the pty @ 8?"

When impressionist painter Vincent Van Gogh retreated to Auvers-sur-Oise for the last chapter of his life, he found a village of stone farmhouses with thatched roofs, golden wheat fields and the gentle green Oise river. He was so inspired by the luminous light and bucolic landscape that in a frenzy he created 70 paintings in more than two months before shooting himself and dying in an attic of a small hotel, L'Auberge Ravoux.

Even as the Blackstone Group prepared to price its initial public offering Thursday night amid heightened scrutiny from Washington, one of its major rivals was considering stepping into the limelight. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has hired Morgan Stanley and Citigroup to prepare a possible I.P.O. later this year, people familiar with the matter told DealBook. The news was first reported by CNBC's Charles Gasparino.

Bill Dedman, an investigative reporter with MSNBC.com, posted a set of articles online today about journalists who have contributed to candidates, political parties and political groups. He combed through federal filings of contributions to campaigns and organizations, and here are his findings:

The Supreme Court on Thursday imposed a strict standard that investors must meet to keep alive their lawsuits alleging securities fraud. In an 8-1 decision, the justices said that courts must weigh possible innocent explanations for defendants' conduct at the very start of a securities fraud case. Doing so can lead to early dismissal of investors' lawsuits.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins became the first catcher to win the American League's batting title when he hit .347 in 2006. Mauer edged Derek Jeter of the Yankees, who hit .343.

What happens when you book a romantic weekend - and end up sharing the resort with a noisy conference? Have you been denied services because of a large group, or clashed with one, while staying at a hotel or resort? Share your experiences here.
Melena Ryzik of The Times reports on the Public Theater's party for Shakespeare in the Park.

Readers seem to love it when they hear about tech "experts" like me getting trapped in technical hell. Seems to be a form of schadenfreude, that delicious German word meaning, "taking pleasure in other people's misfortune."
New shows in New York include "Behind the Lid" and "Radio."

As state governments consider selling toll roads, airports and bridges to close budget gaps, UBS is bolstering its team of investment bankers that advise on such deals. The Swiss firm said Wednesday it hired three bankers for its infrastructure group ahead of what it expects to be a rise in privatizations in the United States.
A flea-market-style restaurant, carefully curated and more.
Daydream designs for the lazy afternoon ahead.
A wealthy businessman proposes buying a major provider of business news, setting off fears among its employees that their editorial integrity would be compromised.

Munich has been rated the world's No. 1 most livable city in a new ranking by Monocle magazine, featured in a special section in today's I.H.T. Here, specially for Globespotters, Matthias Pfeffer, head of Focus TV in Munich, takes a slightly wry look at what makes the city of ''laptops and Lederhosen,'' great beer, punchy espressos and Adolf Hitler's first putsch such a magnet today..............:

As Screens has pointed out before, you can learn much from the sloppy comments section on YouTube. Consider, for example, the notes that follow one version of Senator Hillary Clinton's take-off on the last scene of "The Sopranos."
In a pinch, David Pogue re-discovered Pando, a Web-based file-sharing program.

I was born in West Virginia - my grandfather, Archie Garner, was a coal miner - and throughout my life I've followed West Virginia writers as closely as I've followed the fortunes of the nearby Pittsburgh, Pa. sports teams.

Alex Rodriguez is on pace to hit 65 home runs, the most since steroid testing began in 2003, and the most by any player not associated with the steriod scandal. At PLAY, that got us thinking: Will 61, Roger Maris's record before Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa surpassed it in 1998, again become a benchmark (albeit unofficial) for home runs in a season? Should it?

DES MOINES -- Years before he became known as the squeegee-busting mayor of New York and ages before his name became forever linked with Sept. 11, Rudy Giuliani made his reputation fighting the mafia.
Tony Blair: British prime minister was considered a World Bank chief candidate, and now he's up for the job of Mideast envoy?

Even with the chain of events pieced together by the police so far, it's hard to comprehend the flash violence that broke out in an East Austin, Tex., parking lot on Tuesday. Even the police chief was shocked, and his expression of that -- "This is an anomaly for Austin" -- could've applied to the nation as well.

Need help making sense of the strange week that has unfolded around New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg? Fortunately, a set of stories gets beneath the surface of the mayor's unexpected announcement and cryptic statements of recent days.
Mary McCarthy, were she alive, would be 95 today - she was born on June 21, 1912.

Institutional Shareholder Services has recommended that shareholders of Lear reject Carl C. Icahn's proposed $36-a-share offer for the auto parts supplier, lending serious opposition to the shareholder activist's bid.

The London Stock Exchange is planning to offer about 1.5 billion euros ($2.01 billion) for Borsa Italiana, Reuters reported Thursday citing an unnamed source. The deal would value the Borsa, which is privately-owned by Italian banks, above the 1.2 billion to 1.4 billion euros valuation placed on it last year when the Milan-based bourse planned for an initial public offering.

As Wall Street workers consider new guidelines on how and when to use their BlackBerrys, Paris has taken the issue a bit further, deciding that the ubiquitous hand-held devices may pose a threat to French national security.

The high-stakes game of brinksmanship began early yesterday on Wall Street, and continued throughout the day. Bankers traded telephone calls, frenetically negotiating the fate of Bear Stearns two hedge funds.

Looking at the potential bidders for Dow Jones & Company - Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and a joint effort by General Electric and Pearson - some reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision a choice between "trash or slash." And they are wondering which might be worse.
Atticus Capital, the hedge fund manager with more than $14 billion in assets, reiterated its opposition to Barclays proposed $68.2 billion euros ($91.4 billion) deal to buy Dutch bank ABN Amro.

Federal prosecutors are close to bringing criminal charges against as many as a dozen current and former Wall Street employees in connection with a kickback scheme involving loans of stocks and bonds to hedge funds and short sellers, BusinessWeek reported. So far, federal prosecutors have reportedly secured guilty pleas from three confidential witnesses in the case.
For private equity chiefs, the other shoe -- and a much bigger one -- may be about to drop in Washington.
The Luxottica Group, the world's biggest eyewear maker, said Wednesday that it would buy the American sunglasses maker Oakley Inc. in an all-cash deal worth about $2.1 billion.
Alcan, seeking to fend off a $27.7 billion hostile bid from Alcoa, has given BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto Group access to its financial data, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.

Deutsche Bank and four hedge funds including GLG Partners were fined a combined 6.25 million euros ($8.4 million) by France's market regulator after an insider trading investigation into a Vivendi Universal securities sale in 2002.
Lone Star Funds, the buyout firm whose attempt to sell Korea Exchange Bank last year was blocked by a legal dispute, offered an 11.3 percent stake in the company for as much as $1.1 billion.

Private equity player Madison Dearborn Partners' $6.3 billion deal for municipal bond fund Nuveen Investments may gladden the hearts of investors, but it doesn't have debt analysts cheering, BusinessWeek noted.

Newspaper and broadcasting giant Gannett led a $10 million fourth round of venture funding in mobile advertising company 4Info. 4Info, based in Palo Alto, lets people get news and other information via text messaging on their mobile phones.

Just one day after the management shake-up at Yahoo, the company's board was called on to make a decision that had nothing to do with the resignation of Terry S. Semel as chief executive or the appointment of the co-founder Jerry Yang to succeed him.

Man Group, Europe's largest publicly traded hedge fund, said Thursday it expects its United States brokerage to price its shares at $36 to $39 each when they list on the New York Stock Exchange. The price range values the entire business at as much as $5 billion.
Executives from four large private equity firms went to Parliament on Tuesday and defended the low British tax rate imposed on their profits.

Bell Canada, the target of at least three possible privatization bids, said Wednesday that it was discussing a possible merger with Telus, the leading phone company in western Canada. If combined, Bell, which is based in Montreal, and Telus, based in Vancouver, would have a market capitalization of C$53.2 billion ($50 billion) based on Wednesday's stock prices.

Federal regulators tentatively agreed Wednesday to ease an accounting requirement for foreign companies that trade on United States exchanges. The move comes amid concerns that U.S. stock markets are losing out to overseas competitors due, in part, to what critics see as a overly-burdensome regulatory environment.
The merger of the United States brokerage industry's two major watchdogs finally has a name: the Securities Industry Regulatory Authority, or SIRA.

Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, sued 16 current and former executives and directors Wednesday, seeking to hold them liable for a results restatement and a $1.64 billion regulatory settlement he considered unnecessary.

Allied Capital, a business development company, said Wednesday that it had settled a four-year investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into its valuation practices. Allied, which provides debt and equity financing for middle-market companies, settled the S.E.C.'s informal investigation without admitting or denying agency allegations, according to Allied and the S.E.C.
Whole Foods Market, the largest American natural-foods grocer, agreed yesterday to sell 35 of Wild Oats Markets' stores to the private equity firm Apollo Management.
A list of U.S. hospitals with the lowest and highest mortality rates for patients treated for heart attacks or heart failure, according to a governmenatl analysis.
Images from Documenta 12, an international art show in Kassel, Germany.

The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East, working on behalf of the diplomatic "quartet" of world powers to help the Palestinian president build the institutions and apparatus necessary for a viable state.
“What do you do when nothing is left?” is the question that drives “The Real Dirt on Farmer John.”
“Longing” intrigues because it presents an outwardly decent man falling equally in love with two women but eschews simplistic judgments.
A Stephen King short story is adapted and brought to the screen in “1408,” more psychological thriller than outright horror.
Images from the Heritage Book Shop in Los Angeles, which is set to close.
The Old City of Damascus, the Silk Road bazaars of Aleppo and the ruins of ancient Palmyra attest to Syria's Bronze Age, classical, biblical and Islamic history.

Sometimes, you watch a game and go talk to the pitcher, and you can't believe he's describing what you just saw. Esteban Loaiza was like that; he would give up 6 runs in 5 innings and talk about how he actually pitched pretty well.
Hmmm, let's see... what shall I cover in my column next week?
ESPN’s “The Bronx Is Burning” focuses largely on the fractious Billy Martin-Reggie Jackson-George Steinbrenner psychodrama in 1977.
A firefighter fell from the roof of a burning building in Brooklyn, officials said.
The difference in I.Q. between siblings was a result of family dynamics, not biological factors.
The Senate voted this evening to require cars and sport utility vehicles to get 35 miles per gallon by 2020.
The Supreme Court decision dealt a blow to investors suing companies over accusations of fraud by setting a legal standard that makes it easier to get shareholder lawsuits dismissed.
Atlantis will stay in orbit at least a couple of extra hours today after rain showers delayed the landing.
Today, five soldiers, three Iraqi civilians, and an Iraqi interpreter were killed by a roadside bomb in a northeast neighborhood of Baghdad.
Closing ranks against Hamas, Egypt has invited Israeli, Palestinian and Jordanian leaders to a summit next week.
In the first visit by a senior U.S. official in nearly five years, America’s chief nuclear negotiator was in Pyongyang today in an effort to speed up nuclear negotiations.
The London Stock Exchange said it was discussing a possible merger with Borsa Italiana in its latest attempt to head off expansion of the combined New York Stock Exchange and Euronext.
Deutsche Telekom agreed with the Ver.di union on terms to transfer 50,000 workers to jobs that pay less, paving the way to end five weeks of strikes at the company.
The Chinese legislature plans a review next week of the Finance Ministry’s plans for a bond issue to raise money for a new state-run foreign investment fund, the government said.
Jeff Francis allowed only five hits and a run over seven innings to throttle a Yankees offense that had scored 19 runs in beating the Mets on Saturday and Sunday.

Officers conducted a widespread manhunt in Brooklyn last night after a woman, identified by an official as a police officer, was sexually assaulted in Bay Ridge, the police said. The assault occurred near 95 Bay Ridge Avenue around 7 p.m., they said.

Two soldiers from New Jersey have been killed in combat in Iraq in the past week, the Defense Department said yesterday. Farid Elazzouzi, 26, of Paterson, a specialist in the Army, was one of three soldiers killed last Thursday in Kirkuk when an explosive detonated near their vehicle, the department said. He was assigned to the 2nd Battalion, 35th Infantry Regiment, 3rd Brigade Infantry Combat Team, 25th Infantry Division, Schofield Barracks, Hawaii. A sergeant in the Army, Eric L. Snell, 35, of Hamilton, died on Monday in Balad of wounds from small-arms fire in Baghdad, the department said. He was assigned to the 3rd Battalion, 61st Cavalry Regiment, 2nd Brigade Combat Team, 2nd Infantry Division, Fort Carson, Colo.
The Mets’ latest debacle came courtesy of the Minnesota Twins, who scored the last five runs of the game to send them to their 14th loss in 18 games this month.
Sammy Sosa, playing for the Texas Rangers following a year out of baseball, hit a 1-2 pitch into his team’s bullpen in right-center field for his 600th career home run.
The world’s biggest eyewear maker said it would buy the American sunglasses maker Oakley Inc. in a deal worth about $2.1 billion.
Bell Canada said it was discussing a possible merger with Telus, the leading phone company in western Canada.
T.G.I. Friday’s is finding that less food translates into more customers and, perhaps, bigger profits.
Jason Giambi, who tacitly admitted that he used steroids in an article in USA Today last month, does not want to answer questions about what other major league players might have done.

An article in Business Day yesterday about International Lease Finance Corporation’s order for Boeing 787 Dreamliners misstated the size of the company’s provisional order for Airbus A350s before the plane’s 2006 redesign. The order was for 16 planes, not 12.

An obituary on May 30 by The Associated Press about Barbara Cox Anthony, an heir to the Cox media fortune, incorrectly described her inheritance. And a correction in this space on Friday misattributed the error. Ms. Anthony and her sister, Anne Cox Chambers, and their older brother, James M. Cox Jr., all held equal interests in the company before the death of Mr. Cox in 1974, at which time the sisters received his share; they did not inherit the entire company from Mr. Cox. The error was introduced by an editor, not by The A.P.

An article on Saturday about the bombing of a Sunni Arab mosque near the southern Iraqi city of Basra misstated the name of the mosque. (The error was repeated in an article on Sunday about violence in Iraq.) It is the Talha Bin Obeidallah Mosque, not Talha Bin al-Zubair.

A dance review yesterday about the American Ballet Theater’s production of “Romeo and Juliet,” at the Metropolitan Opera House, misidentified the dancer who portrays Paris. He is Gennadi Saveliev — not Jared Matthews, who is Benvolio.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on June 11 about the dedication of Cole Porter’s childhood home in Peru, Ind., as a bed and breakfast and museum, referred imprecisely to the financing of the restoration of the house. It was financed by tax-deductible funds accepted by the Ole Olsen Memorial Theater in Peru, not by the theater’s own funds.

A picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a Sports of The Times column, about the success of famous players at the United States Open, included incorrect information from The Associated Press about the golfer shown hitting out of sand at the 1953 Open. It was an unidentified golfer; it was not Ben Hogan, who won the tournament. (Research by The Times and by The A.P. failed to produce an identification.).

An article on May 26 about Rochester’s economic decline referred imprecisely to the number of universities there and misstated the percentage change in population over the past three decades. There is one university, the University of Rochester, within the city limits, not six. (The other five are in suburban Rochester). The population decline was 26 percent, not 40 percent.

A front-page article on June 11 about the reaction of Mormons to the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney, who is a Mormon, referred imprecisely to Mr. Romney’s position on gay rights. While he opposes gay marriage and civil unions, the article should not have said he has embraced an “anti-gay agenda.”.
The questions surrounding Anne Milgram’s nomination to attorney general focus on whether she can bring stability to an office that has undergone its share of tumult recently.

An article in Business Day last Thursday about eBay’s fight against fraudulent auctions misstated the name of a trade group that provided information about illegal software sales on the site. The group is the Software and Information Industry Association, not the Software Industry Association of America.

Because of an editing error, an article in the Dining section yesterday about restaurants run by pastry chefs misstated the dates that ChikaLicious (203 East 10th Street), one of the first such restaurants in New York, will close for renovations. It will be closed from July 2-5; it is not closed now. The article also misspelled the name of a new place the restaurant’s owners will be opening. It is ChikaLicious Puddin’, not Pudding.
Rescue workers searched in the southern Catskill town of Colchester after flash floods washed away several homes, a dozen vehicles and a bridge.
Shameka Christon scored 22 points as the Liberty overcame a 17-point deficit Wednesday night and beat the Connecticut Sun.
TENNIS.

The United States and European countries on the Security Council circulated a new resolution calling for independence for Kosovo, the breakaway province of Serbia, and delaying carrying out the plan for four months, but Russia, whose objections to a previous version led to the revision, rejected it. Kosovo has welcomed the plan and has threatened to declare independence on its own if the United Nations does not act, but Vitaly I. Churkin, Russia’s ambassador, called it “unacceptable.”.

A doctor from Tamil Nadu faces possible criminal charges after letting his 15-year-old son perform a Caesarean section in a bid to win a place in the Guinness book of records. Dr. K. Murugesan told a local newspaper that he had been training the boy for several years and insisted that he had done nothing wrong. Investigators were looking for the mother and child.

Japan has changed the name of the island of Iwo Jima, the site of one of World War II’s most horrific battles, to its prewar name at the urging of its original inhabitants, who want to reclaim an identity they say has been hijacked by high-profile movies like “Letters From Iwo Jima” and “Flags of Our Fathers.” The name Iwo Jima was a mispronunciation by Japanese Naval officers of Iwo To, which uses the same characters. The misnomer stuck, much to the islanders’ dismay. The revision may have little effect among nonislanders, however. “It was Iwo Jima to us when we took it,” said Maj. Gen. Fred Haynes, 87, a retired marine who was in the regiment that raised the American flag on Mount Suribachi in 1945, a moment immortalized in a photograph by Joe Rosenthal. “We’ll recognize whatever the Japanese want to call it but we’ll stick to Iwo Jima.”.
As fresh demonstrations broke out in Pakistan and Malaysia, the British government defended its decision to award a knighthood to the author Salman Rushdie.

A group of nearly 100 Western and Afghan aid agencies criticized foreign troops for not doing more to prevent civilian deaths in their hunt for the Taliban. The group, which said about 1,500 civilians had been killed in the last 17 months, also criticized the Taliban for hiding among civilians.

Three Canadian soldiers were killed when a roadside bomb tore through their vehicle in southern Afghanistan, according to NATO officials and the Canadian government. Additionally, two Afghan drivers died when their convoy was attacked by the Taliban, said Ghulam Jalani, deputy police chief of Zabul Province.

China has overtaken the United States as the top emitter of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas, because of surging energy use in its economic boom, a Dutch environmental agency said. Other experts have estimated that China will not surpass the United States until as late as next year. “But whether it is 2006 or 2007 is not the key issue,” said Fatih Birol, chief economist of the International Energy Agency. “What is key is that China is becoming the world’s top carbon dioxide emitter.”.

Mob-related killings in Italy have fallen to their lowest level in decades, the Italian government reported. Homicides attributed to organized crime numbered 121 last year, compared with 340 in 1992. Interior Minister Giuliano Amato attributed the decline to stronger law enforcement, as well as a shift by the Mafia toward less-violent activities, like money laundering.
The Mets were plenty frustrated about their 9-0 loss to Minnesota and four errors, even if their defensive lapses were the exception to what has otherwise been a strong season in the field.

ALBANY, June 20 — A torrent of bills and amendments are swirling through the halls of the Capitol as the legislative session here comes to a close. Some are big bills, like campaign finance or same-sex marriage legislation, loudly debated and widely pondered. Some are small bills, often championed by a lone and lonely lawmaker, like a proposal to name the Concord the official state grape.
The choice among new S.L.R. cameras from Canon, Nikon, Pentax, Olympus and Sony comes down to price, features and your existing lens collection.
The news media’s obsession with polls and the horse-race aspect of the presidential campaign may have very little relationship to the ultimate outcome.
Jessie Davis, 26 and nearly nine months pregnant, has not been seen for a week, and investigators have no suspects.
Some at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision between potential bidders a choice between “trash or slash.”
But questions remain about how successful the bank was and whether it had merely delayed the inevitable.
Unrest in Diwaniya reflects a new landscape in which Shiite groups no longer look to politics to allocate power.
A new report says estimates of coal reserves are unreliable and the U.S. may not have nearly as much coal as is popularly believed.
Maurice R. Greenberg sued 16 current and former executives and directors to hold them liable for a results restatement.
The largest U.S. natural-foods grocer agreed to sell 35 of Wild Oats Markets’ stores to the private equity firm Apollo Management.
The Tracinda Corporation said it was ending negotiations on the possible purchase of MGM Mirage’s Bellagio hotel-casino and its CityCenter project.

ALBANY, June 20 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer was trying to reach a broad deal Wednesday to end the legislative session by linking together three contentious issues, people with knowledge of the negotiations said. The issues included his own campaign finance reform plan, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing proposal and a measure to grant pay raises to lawmakers.
The little-known tax break has allowed wealthy financiers to cut their total income tax bills by billions of dollars.
With all the challenges out there, Europe needs a strong union and the United States needs a strong European partner.
All day a firehouse in Charleston, S.C., was a center of gravity in a stricken city, its normal camaraderie stretched far beyond brotherhood.
A prosecutor recommended charging a mother with the deaths of five children who were left alone, not with a baby sitter as the woman claimed, on the night of a house fire.
A crowd beat a man to death on Tuesday after a vehicle he was riding in struck and injured a 4-year-old child in Austin, the police said.
The presidential candidates for both major parties ought to heed Michael Bloomberg’s comments about how Americans want nonpartisan solutions to nonpartisan problems.
Tim Finchem, the commissioner of the PGA Tour, said yesterday that the organization may institute a policy on performance-enhancing drugs, including testing, by the end of the year.
Fighting was heavy in parts of Baquba on Wednesday as American troops continued an effort to rid the city of insurgents believed to be part of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.
Atlantis’s heat shield is safe to return to Earth, mission managers decided, a day before the space shuttle was planned to land in Florida.
Across history, Washington has been unfairly stuck in political limbo as a nonstate, with critics arguing there’s no relief possible under the Constitution.
Americans will need to keep a close eye on which legislators favor the most promising stem cell research and which try to impede scientific progress.
An evangelical minister who has developed social service and youth programs in poor neighborhoods was named Los Angeles’s first antigang czar.
Federal agents arrested 81 suspected illegal immigrants on Tuesday in a raid at a manufacturing plant in the Poconos.
A computer malfunction at United Airlines halted all departures systemwide for two hours, forcing the delay or cancellation of nearly 300 flights, the airline said.
Gov. Rod Blagojevich signed a bill into law moving up the state’s primary to Feb. 5, a move certain to help Senator Barack Obama.
The Bush administration dispatched its top negotiator for one-on-one talks about the North’s nuclear arsenal.
Carlos Gómez has been more consistent on offense this month than either of the more famous Carloses on the Mets: Beltrán and Delgado.
A plan to build the world’s first supersonic business jet is the latest sign that business jets are becoming the fastest-growing segment of the aerospace industry.
The 13 men deciding the case of an ousted chief justice could well decide the outcome of Pakistan’s political crisis.
Troy Tulowitzki, a rookie who wears No. 2 because of Derek Jeter, said the Yankees’ rare trip to Coors Field helped motivate him to make the team out of spring training.
The discovery of a photograph of four popular high school students giving a stiff-armed Nazi salute has intensified a bitter racial divide in La Jara, Colo.
Wal-Mart failed to get approval for a bank. But the giant discount chain is effectively building one anyway.
If Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg runs for president, the question of whether he can simultaneously campaign and run New York City will arise.
The Bush administration postponed rules that would require passports for United States citizens re-entering the country from Canada, Mexico, Bermuda or Caribbean countries.
In block-by-block detail, a report shows that despite improvement, a big storm would still be likely to flood large areas of the city.
Coming off the shortest start of his career five days ago, Robert Woodard shut down Rice for six-plus innings Wednesday to help North Carolina remain in the College World Series with a 6-1 victory.
Roland G. Fryer Jr. has the challenge of helping to narrow the racial gap in achievement in the city’s schools.
The business development company said it had settled a four-year investigation by the S.E.C. into its valuation practices.
The electronics retailer reported a $54.6 million first-quarter loss and withdrew its financial guidance for fiscal 2008 as it cut jobs and revamped.
The company forecast earnings growth in fiscal year 2008 below the company’s long-term target of 10 percent to 15 percent.
Home-delivery rates will increase 3 percent to 4 percent and the newsstand cover price will increase to $1.25, from $1.
Federal government agencies have risked exposing millions of Social Security numbers to identity thieves by including the numbers in federal liens notices, a report says.
The guidelines are the most extensive effort yet to address a vexing issue surrounding the rapidly expanding field of nanotechnology.
Laura Albert, the writer known as JT Leroy, took the witness stand Wednesday at her civil fraud trial in Manhattan.

Julián Tavárez pitched seven scoreless innings, switching to cruise control after the visiting Boston Red Sox homered three times in the first two innings on the way to routing the Atlanta Braves, 11-0, last night.
The conquest of the Gaza Strip by Hamas has frightened Arab leaders because it was characterized by the same dynamics that have been agitating the region.
A Madison Avenue executive turned soldier found a mission among the impoverished children of Iraq.
Kazakhstan’s lower house of Parliament was dissolved Wednesday in preparation for early elections.
Mr. LeMessurier became a hero to other structural engineers when he detected and repaired a potentially catastrophic flaw in the Citicorp building in Manhattan.
Federal regulators tentatively agreed to ease an accounting requirement for foreign companies that trade on U.S. exchanges.
The acquisition of Rivals.com is intended to bolster Yahoo’s position as an online destination for sports fans.
With another World Cup approaching, the U.S. women’s soccer team is now captained by Kristine Lilly, who is a month shy of 36 in chronological years but seemingly ageless in soccer years.
Already serving a one-year suspension from the N.F.L., Pacman Jones will face two felony charges stemming from a strip club disturbance in February that led to three people being shot.
Rarely has there been as documented an outpouring of that support as the 92 letters Rudolph W. Giuliani wrote for Dennis E. Szybala during four months in 1981.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,524 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Jeremy Stenberg has not competed in a freestyle motocross event since falling out of the sky during the Dew Tour last June. His serious accident has given other riders reason to pause.
The question is not whether the court will overturn more, but how often, by what standard and in what terms.
The move effectively pushed the debate surrounding the research into the 2008 presidential campaign.
If the proposal goes forward, Tony Blair would represent the “quartet” of world powers in talks between Israelis and Palestinians.

The former president of the Orleans Parish School Board pleaded guilty in federal court to taking $140,000 in bribes from a political operative thought to be the older brother of Representative William J. Jefferson.
About 10,000 YouTube videos will be available for the iPhone’s introduction, according to Apple’s statement.
Larry Brown, the most successful coach on the market, is quietly pining for another chance in the N.B.A. The problem, it seems, is that the league is not so eager to give Brown that opportunity.

A 24-year-old man was stabbed to death shortly before 3 a.m. yesterday outside a strip club on Steinway Street in Astoria, the police said. The man, who was identified as Jason Brown of Bay Shore, in Suffolk County, was pronounced dead on arrival at Elmhurst General Hospital, the police said. He had been stabbed several times in the torso by another man during a dispute outside the strip club, Club Riviera, the police said. The assailant escaped, the police said, and no weapon was recovered.

A Bronx man fell to his death on Tuesday night as he tried to escape through a window when police officers arrived at his door with an arrest warrant, the police said yesterday. The man, James Harris, 42, of 1900 Grand Concourse, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said that Mr. Harris was being sought on charges of trademark counterfeiting and that he tried to escape when officers knocked on the door of his fourth-floor apartment.

An appeals court judge yesterday denied a stay of sentence for a former State Supreme Court justice convicted of corruption charges and ordered him to begin serving his 3-to-10-year prison term. The former judge, Gerald Garson, was convicted in April of accepting bribes to manipulate the outcome of matrimonial cases in his Brooklyn court. At his sentencing on June 5, Mr. Garson’s $15,000 bail was revoked, but his lawyers won a temporary reprieve that afternoon. They argued that Mr. Garson, 74 and ailing, should remain free while he appealed the verdict on the grounds that the evidence was insufficient. In documents filed with the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Second Department, prosecutors argued that the verdict was supported by “overwhelming evidence,” and yesterday, in a one-page decision, Associate Justice Edward D. Carni revoked the temporary stay.

Passaic County authorities have formed a task force to find the people who planted pyrotechnic devices at Wayne Valley High School last week, leading to an evacuation. Surveillance tapes from the school show two hooded people putting the devices in two lockers at the school on June 12. The face of one person on the videos is obscured by what appears to be a white ski mask; the other appears to be talking on a cellphone.

A Suffolk County man accused of robbing five banks on Long Island in the last three months pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment in First District Court, the Suffolk County district attorney’s office said. The man, Steven P. Bertuglia, 34, was arrested on Tuesday night as he sat in his car in Mount Sinai, the Suffolk police said. In addition to being charged with robbing five banks, he is suspected of robbing others on Long Island and in New York City, Connecticut and New Jersey, the police said.

A Bronx mother has pleaded guilty to manslaughter for failing to obtain medical attention for her 4-year-old son after he was beaten by her live-in boyfriend, prosecutors said yesterday. The mother, Aleshia Smith, 28, admitted in State Supreme Court on Tuesday that she had “recklessly caused the death” of her son, Quachaun Browne, in January 2006 by not immediately seeking medical help, the Bronx district attorney’s office said. Ms. Smith will be sentenced to 2 ½ to 7 ½ years in prison in July, prosecutors said. The boyfriend, Jose Calderon, 19, has pleaded not guilty to murder charges. Prosecutors said Mr. Calderon beat the child over a period of several days because he had broken a television set.

Two lesbians from Ocean Grove have filed a complaint with the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights, claiming that the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, a Methodist organization, illegally discriminated against them when it denied their request to rent the boardwalk pavilion for their civil union ceremony in September. In the complaint, filed on Tuesday, the women, Harriet Bernstein and Luisa Paster, note that the pavilion is regularly used for weddings of heterosexual couples. The division will investigate to see if there is sufficient evidence of discrimination; if so, the case will be referred to an administrative law judge. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A Queens man was charged yesterday with fatally shooting a man in the street after an argument in a nearby bodega, prosecutors said. The man, Sherwin Thompson, 20, of 119th Avenue in South Jamaica, was charged with murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Thompson repeatedly shot Germaine Persaud, 21, about 1 a.m. on Monday as Mr. Persaud stood in front of his house on 192nd Street.

The Westchester County executive has proposed installing a system of barriers that would automatically block access to the Bronx River Parkway in case of flooding or other emergencies. At a flood strategy meeting of local officials yesterday in White Plains, County Executive Andrew J. Spano, left, suggested installing gates at the parkway’s access points with electronic controls to allow simultaneous activation. His chief adviser, Susan Tolchin, said the proposal was part of a $1 million bond authorization sent to the County Legislature last month. She said the county, which has control only over the Bronx River Parkway, would like to work with the state on similar measures for flood-prone roads like the Saw Mill and Hutchinson River Parkways.
When Michael Bloomberg switched his party affiliation from Republican to independent on Tuesday, he coyly opened the door for a historic election in 2008.

John D. Feerick, chairman of the State Ethics Commission, said yesterday that he had selected Herbert Teitelbaum, a New York lawyer, as executive director of the commission. He also said he would recommend Mr. Teitelbaum for the same post at a soon-to-be-created public integrity commission combining the existing ethics and lobbying commissions. When the merger takes place, David Grandeau, the executive director of the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, will probably be out of a job. “I met with John Feerick about a month and a half ago, once, and it was very clear to me that he was intent on choosing someone other than me,” Mr. Grandeau said. Mr. Teitelbaum is a senior partner in the New York office of Bryan Cave. His wife, Ruth J. Abram, founded the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which has lobbied extensively in Albany. Mr. Feerick said that he was “enormously impressed” by Mr. Teitelbaum and that a spouse’s work should not be held against a candidate.
In Long Beach, N.Y., the group known as the Friday Workshop has been in continuous existence as a book discussion group for about 50 years.
Nuveen Investments agreed to be acquired for $5.75 billion by investors led by the private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners.
Curt Schilling, who is 6-4 and nearly pitched a no-hitter against Oakland on June 7, will be placed on the 15-day disabled list Friday with what the club is calling a sore right shoulder.
Stocks were forced to give up early gains, driving the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 140 points.
The board is expected to formalize its support for Robert B. Zoellick, President Bush’s nominee for president of the World Bank, on Monday.
The move hopes to raise Mexico’s tax collection rate to offset future declines in oil revenue.
The merger of the U.S. brokerage industry’s two major watchdogs finally has a name: the Securities Industry Regulatory Authority, or SIRA.
Guillermo Coria, a professional tennis player from Argentina, said Universal Nutrition made a contaminated multivitamin that led to a positive steroid test six years ago.
Carlos Ghosn said the Japanese automaker’s board members will forgo their bonus pay to take responsibility for poor performance.
The apparel company said it would reorganize into two units and name Andrew Warren as its chief financial officer.
Kazuo Matsui has rebounded from his high-profile failure with the Mets with a .318 batting average and 12 stolen bases in 32 games for the Rockies this season.
New research suggests that estrogen pills may offer some heart benefits for certain younger women who have had hysterectomies and start taking the pills in their 50s.
A report said that the Environmental Protection Agency did not accurately report the results of a residential cleanup program in 2002 and 2003.
An influential Hamas leader in Gaza warned that Fatah’s effort to repress Hamas in the West Bank could lead to Fatah’s downfall there as well.
Dr. Franklin’s accomplishments included helping pinpoint the first noise known to have come from another planet and inventing a watch for use on the moon.

The review of election procedures comes after a nominee’s withdrawal left them with only one candidate for the office of president-elect, a member of the Kansas school board who supported its efforts against the teaching of evolution.
Members of Congress have complained that American Airlines got a break worth almost $2 billion without proper scrutiny.
The suit involves the public financing of an association that provides therapeutic and rehabilitative services for troubled youth by steeping them in Christian teachings.
The strike by powerful labor unions is President Umaru Yar’Adua’s first major challenge since taking office three weeks ago.
ASIA.
Commercial penalties worth more than $3.4 billion each year were urged against the U.S. for its failure to comply with a W.T.O. ruling.
A growing cluster of companies in the Northwest are looking to capitalize on educational needs.

ALBANY, June 20 — Teresa R. Sayward did not hesitate when she rose from her seat on Tuesday night to address her colleagues in the State Assembly. An observant Catholic from a small, conservative upstate town, she had rarely shared the story of her son, Glenn, 42, and his struggle to come to terms with his gay identity decades ago.
It was the first time an international tribunal had ruled on the conscription of children who were forced into combat or marriages during an armed conflict.
Officials at Bangor International Airport asked the Maine Troop Greeters to stop serving food last month because of concern about liability and food safety.
The artist who has been intriguing bikers and joggers with driftwood sculptures along the Hudson River in Manhattan has been identified.
Eliminating federal subsidies to American cotton growers could modestly improve the incomes of millions of poor cotton farmers in Africa, a new study suggests.
Child labor is a daily fact of life in China, experts say, and one that the government, preoccupied with economic growth, has traditionally turned a blind eye to.
The president of Turkmenistan said that he was willing to expand his relations with Washington and with American businesses.
Libya accuses the foreign medical workers of intentionally infecting hundreds of children with the virus that causes AIDS.
Mr. Schiff,  defense editor of the newspaper Haaretz and author of numerous books, was a household name in Israel.
Antonio Aguilar was the film star and ranchera singer who was considered the undisputed master of his genre for decades.

For freegans, the consumer economy is a sham, and rooting through trash is the decent way to make a home.
Carlos Dengler, better known as Carlos D., the bassist and keyboardist for the moody New York band Interpol, is out of his self-described hedonist phase.
Private donations to the Smithsonian Institution declined under its former chief executive, Lawrence M. Small, an independent committee said in a scathing report.
Without gloss or production values, Rosie O’Donnell keeps giving her view online.
The Archos 605 Wi-Fi portable media player, which will be available later this summer, has a 4.3-inch touchscreen, built-in PDF and photo viewer.
Sony is kicking things up a notch with its Vaio CR series of fashion-forward, customizable laptops in five colors.
The $40 Sansa Shaker MP3 player comes with an onboard speaker, making it possible to share audio files with everyone at the table.
Motorola’s H9 Miniblue headset is so small that it resembles a large hearing aid, with everything fitting inside the ear.
Downloading movies over a high-speed Internet connection offers the promise of convenience, but promise is the operative word for this new method.
Taking a page — albeit a tinier one — from the iPhone’s design is a new test version of the Opera Mini browser for cellphones.
The summer may be loaded with blockbusters, but it’s now becoming crowded with more adult fare that usually opens in the fall.
