It’s not until the last of five shorts that the second series of Marathon 2007 displays any true inspiration.

10 P.M. (A&E) STREET THIEF (2006) Are we watching a real thief as he successfully plans and carries out his break-ins? Or is this just an extremely realistic portrayal of a fictional character named Kaspar Carr? The director Malik Bader (playing Kaspar, above) has fielded such questions since this “filmed record” of a Chicago burglar amazed audiences at the 2006 Tribeca Film Festival. (Shortly before the event one of the film’s producers was arrested on charges of armed robbery and kidnapping in connection with a truck hijacking.) Tonight the film, fictional or otherwise, makes its television debut.
Susanna Moore’s latest novel, “The Big Girls,” set in a women’s prison, has stirred the critics into a lather of moral indignation.
Morgan Stanley said Wednesday that its net income increased 41 percent in the latest quarter, setting a record for the securities firm.
“Gay Life,” a 45-minute cycle of six songs, received its New York premiere in a new arrangement for two tenors and piano.
Linder is the nom d’art for Linder Sterling, a British artist, musician and performer who was born Linda Mulvey in Liverpool in 1954.
Even before Hurricane Katrina the Preservation Hall Jazz Band had been reviving.
Henry Wellcome, an American who made his fortune in pharmaceuticals,  collected anything associated with human or animal health with the idea of eventually creating his own Museum of Mankind.
Could the arts be Tony Blair’s brightest legacy as he steps down as prime minister on Wednesday?
June is beach-read month, and a number of this month’s new releases would do nicely under a beach umbrella.
Trying to impose order on a family’s clutter sets the memories free.
A trickle of style setters are embarking on a latter-day magical mystery tour, revisiting the hippie aesthetic of their mothers or grandmothers and giving it a brash new spin.
What is the most economical way to wallpaper a room?
Thomas Perry is known for good reason as a careful, incisive writer of psychological crime stories.
Twenty-five years after Princess Grace’s  death, her children are commemorating her life by exhibiting some of her most personal possessions.
At American summer camps, foreign visitors learn English (and give tips on writing love letters).

An article last Thursday about six home kitchens misstated the age for Simone Leigh, an artist whose kitchen is decorated with found objects. She is 39, not 46. The article also misstated the location for Jill’s, a restaurant owned by Jill Pettijohn, whose home kitchen was featured. It is in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, not Red Hook.

Q. One of my old-fashioned bleeding hearts has several branches with variegated leaves. I don’t think it’s disease; the plant looks very healthy. But it’s near a five-year-old clump of mixed pinks and whites. Could they have cross-pollinated to give me a new variety?

An article on June 7 about Philip Johnson’s Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., misspelled the surname of the archivist of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, who was a visitor to the house. He is David Vaughan, not Vaughn.
First look at only the West hand in the diagramed deal.

Wimbledon starts on Monday, and once again John McEnroe will provide television commentary. McEnroe won Wimbledon three times, alternately displaying exquisite shotmaking and tantrums so demonstrative that the London tabloids labeled him “Superbrat.” In early 2000, Julian Rubinstein wrote about McEnroe for The Times’s Sunday magazine, looking at what drove McEnroe on and off the court. From PLAY Magazine’s suggested reading list:.
Next week, Will Leitch of Deadspin.com makes his debut as a regular contributor to the PLAY e-mail newsletter, spinning his unique brand of commentary on the oddities and follies of the sports world.

Alex Rodriguez is on pace to hit 65 home runs, the most since steroid testing began in 2003, and the most by any player not associated with the steriod scandal. At PLAY, that got us thinking: Will 61 again become a benchmark (albeit unofficial) for home runs in a season? Should it?.

The unlikely hotspot for tennis this summer is Vermont, better known for ski racing than pros acing. But Stowe’s 360 tennis courts (in a “Sound of Music” setting) easily outnumber ski trails, and on July 14 and 15, the Topnotch Resort and Spa in Stowe hosts the Fed Cup semifinal between the United States and Russia. The women’s tournament is expected to draw Serena Williams, Venus Williams and Maria Sharapova. Tickets are scarce, but guests staying at the Topnotch can still buy passes at prices from $75 to$225; lower-priced rooms are sold out, but villas starting at $1,100 per night are available. Finally, those craving strawberries and cream at Wimbledon, June 25 to July 8, can catch courtside seats through the Stowe-based Gram Slam Tennis Tours. Last-minute packages including hotels, admission, meals and more start at $3,625 for four nights.

So you’ve been hearing about Dale Earnhardt Jr. changing race teams, effective at the end of this Nascar season, but you don’t know what the fuss is about? The main reason this is such a big deal, as always, is money.

A year after the world’s best soccer teams convened in Germany to crown a World Cup champion, 12 teams from North and Central America and the Caribbean came to the United States this month to determine the top team in the fourth-best footballing region of the world. This is the world’s most popular sport dialed down a few notches. The tournament, called the Concacaf Gold Cup, is the red-headed stepchild of regional soccer tournaments. It lags behind the glamorous European Championship, the more prestigious Copa America (which starts June 26 in Venezuela) and it may even trail the African Cup of Nations in terms of excitement and talent.

What does it take to win the ultra-cycling competition Race Across America? Try 8 days, 19 hours, and 33 minutes. Try 3,043 miles on a bike, with little or no sleep, day after pedal-cranking day. That’s what Jure Robic, a 42-year-old Slovene competitor, endured to win the solo division in this year’s race, which started in Oceanside, Calif., on June 10; Robic reached the finish line in Atlantic City Tuesday morning, and the race as a whole wraps up tomorrow. Thirty solo competitors and several teams with up to eight riders switching off signed up for this year’s race, which ran through vast stretches of desert, mountains, Great Plains, and endless American roadways. By now, most cyclists have finished or dropped out.
At a time when affluent dog owners coddle their pets with massage, antidepressants and spa vacations, it’s not surprising that dogs have the equivalent of personal trainers.
Wal-Mart’s decision would extend the reach of its retailing empire into the bank accounts of its shoppers.
College bound? It might be time to rethink that crushing financial burden and look into a new calling plan.
Some manufacturers are beginning to use natural and earth-friendly fibers and plastics. Julie Kleinman, the director of programming for the Yoga Works chain of studios, tries them out.
Whidbey Island in Puget Sound has attracted artists, writers, gardeners and other creative fugitives from the mainland since the hippie days of the ’60s.
The world economy may be tough on your industry but look on the bright side: you could be French.
Just as Tiger Woods is chasing Jack Nicklaus’s record of 18 majors, he’ll also be measured against Nicklaus as a family man.
The image of Lindsay Lohan passed out in a car over Memorial Day weekend may have stalled her acting career, but it has done wonders for hoodie sales at American Apparel.
High school pranks may be as old as high school, but it seems that the standard of excellence is being raised at the same time that society’s tolerance level is being lowered.
Aides to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York have laid the groundwork for a potential independent run for president.

On a typical day, Troy Johnson, chief clerk of the New York County Board of Elections, busies himself making sure voters are registered, absentee ballot requests are answered and the copious records inside the board’s 10th-floor office downtown on Varick Street are scrupulously maintained.
Executives from four large private equity firms went to Parliament and defended the low British tax rate imposed on their profits.
Vijay Mallya plans to bring Kingfisher Airlines, known in India for its saucy flight attendants and top-notch service, to the U.S. and Europe as soon as next year.
Rudolph W. Giuliani helped Michael R. Bloomberg get elected; now they could face off as presidential candidates.

At the newly opened Diane Von Furstenberg’s store in the meatpacking district, the style remains a classic; as chic, wearable and, at least within the realms of designer clothing, as affordable as ever.
Makeup artists can build an audience without ever leaving home.
Watching dozens of beauty videos on YouTube, I learned makeup and hair tricks that I’m embarrassed to admit I didn’t know.
In the American West, the closer you get to the border, the more voters back politicians who are looking for middle ground on immigration reform.
In villages throughout eastern Congo, people like Yohanita Nyiahabimama are dying by the thousands — of a deadly mixture of war and poverty.

COHEN--Claudia. The Board and staff of ACRIA, the AIDS Community Research Initiative of America, are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our dear friend Claudia Cohen. Claudia served on the Board and then the National Advisory Council of ACRIA, working tirelessly and with great enthusiasm to improve the lives of people living with HIV and AIDS. She was loved by many and will be sorely missed.

PLOTSKY--Jeanette, June 16, 2007 in Corrale, NM at 98. Daughter of Louis and Sophie Willion, sister of Ruth Popkin and the late Adele Goldman, wife of the late Irving Plotsky, mother of David and Mary, grandmother of Jordan, Abe, Katy, great-grandmother of Asher, beloved sister-in-law, aunt. She devoted her life to family and friends, loved good food and music, believed in justice for all. Donations to ImpeachBush.org

There were seven empty seats on the N.B.A. coaching carousel when it reached maximum velocity in late May. The whirling has nearly stopped, and six coaches have settled into place -- one reliable old hand, two less-proven retreads and three virtual rookies. Notably missing from the merry-go-round is the only free-agent coach with a Hall of Fame bust, an N.B.A. championship and an N.C.A.A. title. Larry Brown remains ensconced, out of sight and out of mind, in a front-office cubicle in Philadelphia.

HIGHER TAXES FOR FINANCIERS Leaders of the tax-writing committees in Congress are considering a new proposal to end a little-known tax break that has allowed wealthy financiers who run private equity firms and hedge funds to cut their total income tax bills by billions of dollars, aides to lawmakers said. [Page A1.] Britain is joining the effort to try to increase the taxes paid on profits made by private equity firms. [C5.]

REISIN--Seymour, of New York City died June 15, 2007. Beloved husband of Joan Wooters - Reisin. Devoted father of Stephanie (August), Emily (Emin), Michael, and his dog, Mala. Retired Dean of Continuing Education, Bronx Community College/ CUNY. Served as assistant principal and teacherin public and private schools in New York, Washington, D.C. and Maryland. Graduate of City College, 1950. During a parallel political career Sy was Executive Secretary of the student division of Americans for Democratic Action; Acting National Secretary of American Friends of Vietnam and member of the National Board of the League for Industrial Democracy. During the 1950s Sy worked with Spanish Refugee Aid to deliver medical equipment to adherents of the defeated Loyalist forces in Barcelona. In the same decade the American Embassy ordered Sy to leave Yugoslavia thereby thwarting his efforts to provide financial aid to the family of Milovan Djilas. In the 1960s, Sy developed and implemented the sustained picketing efforts at the Yugoslav government offices in New York City to protest the imprisonment of Milovan Djilas. In 2005 Sy assisted in the editing of ''Freedom's Sword'', Gilbert Jonas's award-winning history of the NAACP. The 1200 page Anthology and Source Book of the National Student Association, published in February 2006 by the American Council on Education, includes two essays by Sy, one a history of the Students for Democratic Action; the second an historical analysis of communist efforts to control American collegiate student organizations. During his career as an educator, Sy was a recipient of the New York City Public Service Award for Professional Achievement; The New York State Scholarship Award for Social Studies Teachers; and the B'nai B'rith Award for Human Relations. Sy was a member of the National Association of Scholars and The Historical Society. He also served on the Advisory Boards of the Rosen Scholars Fund and the Houston based American Festival of the Arts. A memorial service will be held on June 27, 2007, at 11am at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to New York University Medical Center, Hematology Research Fund, c/o Dr. Kenneth B. Hymes, 530 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

NOETHER--Herman D., age 94, Ph.D. Harvard, Born in Germany (Karlsruhe) September 21, 1912. Died June 19, 2007. Survived by his wife of 64 years Dorit Low Noether, his children Margaret Noether Stevens, Thomas Eric Noether, Evelyn Noether Stokvis, his six grandchildren Alexis, Julia, John, Alex, Michael, and William, and his childrens' spouses Steve, Marcia and Jack. He is fondly remembered by his family and friends as a gentle man with an open, generous spirit. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, a donation be made to the Community Food Bank of New Jersey (www.njfoodbank.org) in his name; a local charity where he volunteered his time. He will be remembered at a service planned for Thursday, June 21, 11:00am at the Unitarian Church in Summit. Services are by The Dangler Funeral Home, Summit, NJ.
To the Editor: Re ''Brooklyn Waterfront Called Endangered Site'' (Arts pages, June 14):

An article on May 26 about Rochester's economic decline referred imprecisely to the number of universities there and misstated the percentage change in population over the past three decades. There is one university, the University of Rochester, within the city limits, not six. (The other five are in suburban Rochester). The population decline was 26 percent, not 40 percent.

There is a growing cluster of companies in the Northwest looking to capitalize on educational needs. Learning.com makes computer software programs that help elementary school students learn science, math, languages and social studies. ''We help teachers by integrating our program with the school's curricula,'' said William J. Kelly, founder and chief executive of the company, based here.

EMMER--Harlee, beloved sister of Elyse Emmer (and Jack Carden), daughter of the late Sidney and Mildred Emmer, devoted friend to an army of admirers. Brilliant, passionate, generous, a lover of beauty and a true New Yorker. Service Friday at 11:00am, Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam and 91st.

Borough Food & Drink, a restaurant emphasizing local ingredients and suppliers from the New York region, opens today in the space that once housed Rocco's on 22nd Street, briefly but widely known for its role in the 2003 reality TV show ''The Restaurant.'' This time around, Jeffrey Chodorow, the owner, has hired the chef Zak Pelaccio to cook in surroundings created by Mark Zeff, a New York-based designer, who was inspired by old-fashioned food halls and delis. Mr. Zeff, right, said he scoured flea markets and antique shops in Pennsylvania, upstate New York and Long Island to furnish the restaurant with vintage industrial pieces like the 1940s French tool trolleys used as coffee tables, far right.

COTTONE--Lillian, on June 19th, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Jim. Devoted mother of Richard, Robert and the late Philip. Cherished mother-inlaw of Vera and Carole. Loving grandmother of Marc and Chris, Heather and Marc and Bari and the late Richard. Great-grandmother to Angela, Dina, Michelle, Olivia, and Mia. Services will be private. ''She will be greatly missed''.

Two lesbians from Ocean Grove have filed a complaint with the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights, claiming that the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, a Methodist organization, illegally discriminated against them when it denied their request to rent the boardwalk pavilion for their civil union ceremony in September. In the complaint, filed on Tuesday, the women, Harriet Bernstein and Luisa Paster, note that the pavilion is regularly used for weddings of heterosexual couples. The division will investigate to see if there is sufficient evidence of discrimination; if so, the case will be referred to an administrative law judge. Compiled by John Sullivan

To the Editor: Thomas L. Friedman (''A Boycott Built on Bias,'' column, June 17) says the British University and College Union's proposed academic boycott of Israeli universities is based on false logic and motivated by anti-Semitism.

Michael Angelo, the owner of the Wonderland Beauty Parlor, remembers that when he first heard about Flavor Paper, a New Orleans wallcovering company, he thought the name cried out for a scratch-and-sniff wallpaper. Mr. Angelo's hair salon in the meatpacking district is now Flavor Paper's New York showroom, and he recently got the chance to design that wallpaper. The Fruit Cocktail Collection is a series of Mylar wallcoverings with scratch-and-sniff images and names like Cherry Forever, above, and B-A-N-A-N-A-S, top. (The scent is applied using slurries, the microcapsules of fragrance used in perfume strips.) Available for $375 to $525 per roll at the Wonderland Beauty Parlor, 418 West 13th Street (Ninth Avenue), (212) 524-2800 or flavorleague.com.
MILLER--Robert Douglas, June 21, 1970-June 21, 1996. Remembered with love, today and everyday. Mom, Dad and Rachel
ASIA CHINA: INVESTMENT FUND PLANS BOND ISSUE

Gov. Eliot Spitzer was trying to reach a broad deal Wednesday to end the legislative session by linking together three contentious issues, people with knowledge of the negotiations said. The issues included his own campaign finance reform plan, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's congestion pricing proposal and a measure to grant pay raises to lawmakers. But the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, cast doubt on whether an accord could be reached by the end of the session on Thursday.

PINCHASICK--Arthur (Pinky) We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend. He will be missed beyond words. Lisa and Steven Birbach Sherrie and Jerry Birbach $(6$)PINCHASICK--Arthur (Pinky) Beloved husband of Fran, devoted father of Carl, Steven and daughter-in-law Lori. Dear brother to Marilyn, adoring grandfather of Matthew, Katie, Allison, Jared and Michael. His courage in dealing with his illness was an inspiration to his family and friends. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to The American Kidney Foundation.

A dance review yesterday about the American Ballet Theater's production of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' at the Metropolitan Opera House, misidentified the dancer who portrays Paris. He is Gennadi Saveliev -- not Jared Matthews, who is Benvolio.

An article in Business Day last Thursday about eBay's fight against fraudulent auctions misstated the name of a trade group that provided information about illegal software sales on the site. The group is the Software and Information Industry Association, not the Software Industry Association of America.

A doctor from Tamil Nadu faces possible criminal charges after letting his 15-year-old son perform a Caesarean section in a bid to win a place in the Guinness book of records. Dr. K. Murugesan told a local newspaper that he had been training the boy for several years and insisted that he had done nothing wrong. Investigators were looking for the mother and child.

PARROTT--Thomas A., of Washington, DC and Fishers Island, NY, after 92 wonderful years, passed away peacefully June 14, 2007. He was with the CIA for 24 years and served as Assistant Deputy Director for National Intelligence Programs. Earlier in his career with the CIA he was the Deputy Chief of the Soviet Division of the Clandestine Services, a Base Chief in Germany, Assistant to the Director of Central Intelligence, Allen Dulles, and held an unprecedented assignment to the White House that included the period of the Cuban Missile Crisis. During WWII, Mr. Parrott served with the Army in North Africa and Italy. He was awarded the Soldier's Medal (the Army's highest decoration for heroism not in actual combat), the Legion of Merit, and honored by Italy with the Order of Sts. Maurizio and Lazarus (at the time the oldest order of nobility in Europe). He retired from the Army Reserve as a Colonel. After retiring from the CIA in 1973, he was active in many charitable and community organizations. He served on the Board of the Washington Hospital Center as Vice-Chairman, was one of five founding directors of the National Rehabilitation Hospital, was an officer of the Citizens Association of Georgetown, served on the boards of the Foundation for the Preservation of Historic Georgetown, the Hospice Care of D.C. and was on the original Board of the City Tavern Club. He graduated from Princeton University in 1936 and had lived in Washington, D.C. since 1949. Tom Parrott is survived by his loving wife of 67 years, Barbara, of Washington, his daughters, Cynthia MacNair and Susan Crary, his son-in-law Horace Crary, Jr. and three loving grandchildren, Gardner, Nicholas and Ian Crary, all of NYC. His son, Tommy, predeceased him. Tom Parrott's sharp mind, wit, loyalty and love will be deeply missed. Services will be held at Arlington National Cemetery September 28 at 11:00am. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Rehabilitation Hospital, Attention: Communication & Development, 102 Irving St. NW, Washington, DC 20010.

In the furniture world, chairs get all the glory. Tables are often taken for granted, covered up with books or cloths. But a new venture by Emanuela Frattini, a New York-based architect, and her husband, Carl Gustav Magnusson, the former design director for Knoll, just might change that. Articolo (articolo.com), their online retail store, sells nothing but tables, all created exclusively for them. Of the 29 modernist offerings, 12 were designed by Ms. Frattini; the others are by Mr. Magnusson, James Irvine, Ross Lovegrove, Hans-Jörg Ruch, Christoph Böninger, Neil Frankel, Gianfranco Frattini (Ms. Frattini's father), Marta Laudani and Marco Romanelli. The Böninger aluminum table, above, is $325.

For at least a generation, press critics have complained bitterly about the news media's obsession with polls and the horse-race aspect of the presidential campaign. The constant focus on who is ahead is a pointless distraction, those critics argue, from what should be the real substance of the campaign, like what the candidates would do as president. But there is another reason to avoid putting too much stock in any assessment of the horse race, more than six months before the voting begins in the Iowa caucuses: It may have very little relationship to the ultimate outcome.

On Saturday, three private gardens in the Bronx will be open to the public for the first time when the Garden Conservancy's Open Days program comes to New York City. One of them, the Byrns Garden, an acre and a half above the Hudson River, culminates in a limestone quarry, top and left, mined in the 1820s. The quarry, which has 25-foot cliff walls, is planted with ferns, hostas and a rare variegated aralia. The garden also has paired 100-foot perennial borders and a woodland path that follows a stream and a waterfall. The other private gardens are a terraced property with a sculpture collection and a one-acre site with a vegetable and cutting garden and espaliered apple trees. The gardens are within walking distance of one another, and will be open from noon to 4 p.m. Admission is $5 a garden. Information: (888) 842-2442 or gardenconservancy.org/opendays.

A picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a Sports of The Times column, about the success of famous players at the United States Open, included incorrect information from The Associated Press about the golfer shown hitting out of sand at the 1953 Open. It was an unidentified golfer; it was not Ben Hogan, who won the tournament. (Research by The Times and by The A.P. failed to produce an identification.)

An article in Business Day yesterday about a federal court decision that upheld the patent on Plavix, a blood thinner marketed by Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, misstated the potential financial damages that the Canadian drug maker Apotex might have to pay the companies for selling a generic version last year. The potential damages could be $500 million to $600 million, not $500,000 to $600,000.

The United States and European countries on the Security Council circulated a new resolution calling for independence for Kosovo, the breakaway province of Serbia, and delaying carrying out the plan for four months, but Russia, whose objections to a previous version led to the revision, rejected it. Kosovo has welcomed the plan and has threatened to declare independence on its own if the United Nations does not act, but Vitaly I. Churkin, Russia's ambassador, called it ''unacceptable.''
To the Editor: Re ''The Pangs of Family Mealtime Guilt,'' by Lisa Belkin (''Life's Work'' column, Thursday Styles, June 14):
''A billionaire is like a mastodon: He gets everyone's attention. The thing that people hate most in politics is a wild card. Well, he's a really big one.''

GELFAND--Monroe. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Monroe Gelfand, husband of Rae Gelfand, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. June Walker, National President Morlie Levin, National Executive Director

To an ordinary person, the summer might mean barbecues, baseball games and trips to the beach. To a photography nut, however, it means longer days of sunlight, brighter subject colors (beach balls, bathing suits) and more people who don't have to be told to ''Smile!'' Nothing has turned more ordinary people into shutterbugs than recent price drops in digital S.L.R. (single-lens reflex) cameras. These big, black, interchangeable-lens cameras may not fit in your pocket, and they may scream, ''I'm a tourist'' when hanging from your neck, but their photos blow those little shirt-pocket cams out of the water. Digital S.L.R.'s turn on instantly, can take three shots per second, offer optional manual controls, go for weeks on a battery charge and have zero shutter lag. In short, they're awesome.
To the Editor: Re ''Kellogg to Phase Out Some Food Ads to Children'' (Business Day, June 14):

John D. Feerick, chairman of the State Ethics Commission, said yesterday that he had selected Herbert Teitelbaum, a New York lawyer, as executive director of the commission. He also said he would recommend Mr. Teitelbaum for the same post at a soon-to-be-created public integrity commission combining the existing ethics and lobbying commissions. When the merger takes place, David Grandeau, the executive director of the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, will probably be out of a job. ''I met with John Feerick about a month and a half ago, once, and it was very clear to me that he was intent on choosing someone other than me,'' Mr. Grandeau said. Mr. Teitelbaum is a senior partner in the New York office of Bryan Cave. His wife, Ruth J. Abram, founded the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which has lobbied extensively in Albany. Mr. Feerick said that he was ''enormously impressed'' by Mr. Teitelbaum and that a spouse's work should not be held against a candidate.

An obituary on May 30 by The Associated Press about Barbara Cox Anthony, an heir to the Cox media fortune, incorrectly described her inheritance. And a correction in this space on Friday misattributed the error. Ms. Anthony and her sister, Anne Cox Chambers, and their older brother, James M. Cox Jr., all held equal interests in the company before the death of Mr. Cox in 1974, at which time the sisters received his share; they did not inherit the entire company from Mr. Cox. The error was introduced by an editor, not by The A.P.

Americans' anxiety level over competitiveness with other nations has grown in recent years. A large number of Americans appear to believe that the United States will not be able to succeed in an open world market, and they argue in favor of reducing our exposure to the outside. Paradoxically, when many of the people in these same competitor nations look at our economy, they are rather anxious about us.

A front-page article on June 11 about the reaction of Mormons to the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney, who is a Mormon, referred imprecisely to Mr. Romney's position on gay rights. While he opposes gay marriage and civil unions, the article should not have said he has embraced an ''anti-gay agenda.''
JACOBSON--Bernice and Sidney. Two years ago today. You will live in our hearts and souls forever. Your loving and adoring family

To the Editor: That the eighth graders in New York City's schools have not shown the same ''Good News on Math'' (editorial, June 15) as lower grades is neither surprising nor a cause for discouragement.

MILLER--Jeanette died peacefully June 19, 2007. Mother of Richard L. Miller, Linda Miller and Joan Bass. A wonderful woman blessed with nine grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Graveside funeral at United Hebrew Cemetery, S.I. Shiva Sunday-Tuesday, NYC.

To the Editor: As Bob Herbert advocates in ''When Dollars Trump Compassion'' (column, June 19), we should, of course, insure and provide medical treatment to all children. But without universal health care, children could grow up to become uninsured adults. And adults with untreated chronic or serious health conditions could be unable to care for their children, whether the children are sick or healthy.

An article in Business Day yesterday about International Lease Finance Corporation's order for Boeing 787 Dreamliners misstated the size of the company's provisional order for Airbus A350s before the plane's 2006 redesign. The order was for 16 planes, not 12.

WASSERSTEIN--Lola. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are saddened by the death of the beloved mother of our beloved playwright, Wendy, who was happy to see Wendy's plays off Broadway, on Broadway and at Lincoln Center. We send condolences and love to Lola's entire family. John Beinecke, Chairman, Andre Bishop, Artistic Dir., Bernard Gersten, Exec. Prod.

A Queens man was charged yesterday with fatally shooting a man in the street after an argument in a nearby bodega, prosecutors said. The man, Sherwin Thompson, 20, of 119th Avenue in South Jamaica, was charged with murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Thompson repeatedly shot Germaine Persaud, 21, about 1 a.m. on Monday as Mr. Persaud stood in front of his house on 192nd Street.

Three Canadian soldiers were killed when a roadside bomb tore through their vehicle in southern Afghanistan, according to NATO officials and the Canadian government. Additionally, two Afghan drivers died when their convoy was attacked by the Taliban, said Ghulam Jalani, deputy police chief of Zabul Province.
To the Editor: Re ''What Hamas Wants'' (Op-Ed, June 20):

MARMOR--Benjamin, 93, Jackson Heights, NY, died on June 19th. Beloved husband of the late Louise Tulchin Marmor, father of Neil Marmor, Susan and David Smolin, Michael and Gloria Marmor, Bonnie and Steve Goldstein. Cherished grandfather to Craig and Peter Smolin, Nicholas and Daniel Marmor. Contributions in his memory may be made to Greenwood House, 53 Walter St., Ewing, NJ 08628.

The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East, representing the diplomatic ''quartet'' of world powers, administration officials said Wednesday. The appointment would be the most visible attempt at laying the groundwork for a Palestinian state since President Clinton wrangled with Yasir Arafat and Ehud Barak during the waning hours of his administration in 2001.
To the Editor: Re ''Some Colleges to Drop Out of Rankings by Magazine'' (news article, June 20):

Toby Keith is No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with ''Big Dog Daddy'' (Show Dog Nashville), though in what has become a familiar pattern for the music industry, record sales were low across the board. ''Big Dog Daddy'' sold 204,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The Brooklyn rapper Fabolous reached No. 2 this week with his new ''From Nothin' to Somethin' '' (Def Jam), selling 159,000 copies. Paul McCartney's ''Memory Almost Full'' (Hear Music), last week's top seller, fell to No. 3 with 107,000, a decline of 34 percent. DJ Khaled's new ''We the Best'' (Koch) reached No. 8, and ''The Traveling Wilburys Collection'' (Rhino) opened at No. 9.

I WAS initiated young into the cult of clutter. Opening a drawer in my childhood kitchen meant finding birthday cards sticky from a leaking pen, a recipe for moussaka never made, bits of yarn and a Hot Wheels car missing a door. Occasionally, my mother attempted organization by topic (Vacation Ideas, Children's Vaccinations, Restaurants to Try), but she never got hanging files, so the folders slipped and slid over one another. Dad had a secretary at work to organize his papers, and at home he directed seasonal weekend purges that inevitably threw Barbies out with the bath water. Years later, my mother continued to reprimand him for discarding my Malibu Skipper and Francie. She didn't care about the potential ''fortune he'd thrown away,'' as she put it; it was the principle of the matter. How could he have tossed his daughter's dolls? After all, she had kept her favorite, circa 1934: a porcelain creature with patches of scratchy woolen hair and hinged joints that made her heavy limbs flop creepily against my skin when I picked her up.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 U.S. Urges Blair to ServeAs Envoy on Mideast Peace The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to work on behalf of the United States, the United Nations, the European Union and Russia to help the Palestinian president build the institutions and apparatus necessary for a viable state. Officers conducted a widespread manhunt in Brooklyn last night after a woman, identified by an official as a police officer, was sexually assaulted in Bay Ridge, the police said. The assault occurred near 95 Bay Ridge Avenue around 7 p.m., they said.

A Bronx man fell to his death on Tuesday night as he tried to escape through a window when police officers arrived at his door with an arrest warrant, the police said yesterday. The man, James Harris, 42, of 1900 Grand Concourse, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said that Mr. Harris was being sought on charges of trademark counterfeiting and that he tried to escape when officers knocked on the door of his fourth-floor apartment.

Tom Glavine's 8-year-old son, Peyton, was watching the Mets' game Tuesday night and did not like what he saw. He asked his father why David Wright, after making his second error of the game, threw his glove in the dugout. ''Tell him it slipped,'' Wright told Glavine.

Because of an editing error, an article in the Dining section yesterday about restaurants run by pastry chefs misstated the dates that ChikaLicious (203 East 10th Street), one of the first such restaurants in New York, will close for renovations. It will be closed from July 2-5; it is not closed now. The article also misspelled the name of a new place the restaurant's owners will be opening. It is ChikaLicious Puddin', not Pudding.

CITARELLA--Michael, 84, of Dobbs Ferry, NY died June 20, 2007 of cancer. His business life, spent in the field of wines, was highly regarded by the industry. He retired from William Grant & Co. in 1994. Married 56 years to Colleen (nee Welch), father of six, grandfather of 12. Funeral Service 9:30am Saturday, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry. Visiting 2-4 and 7-9pm, Friday. Any remembrance gifts to Memorial Sloan Kettering would be appreciated.

RUBINSTEIN--Annette ''Teta'', June 20th, 2007 at 97. Our beloved aunt and greataunt, brilliant teacher, writer, marxist critic, lifelong passionate activist. Child prodigy, school principal and independent scholar, taught English and American Literature in US, China and East Europe. Invented new course every semester for NY Brecht Forum, her last class in the warmth of her home just three weeks ago. We deeply miss her wit and wisdom, love and latkes, and poems for every occasion. David, Monika, Daniel, Alina Eisenbud

A Bronx mother has pleaded guilty to manslaughter for failing to obtain medical attention for her 4-year-old son after he was beaten by her live-in boyfriend, prosecutors said yesterday. The mother, Aleshia Smith, 28, admitted in State Supreme Court on Tuesday that she had ''recklessly caused the death'' of her son, Quachaun Browne, in January 2006 by not immediately seeking medical help, the Bronx district attorney's office said. Ms. Smith will be sentenced to 2 1/2 to 7 1/2 years in prison in July, prosecutors said. The boyfriend, Jose Calderon, 19, has pleaded not guilty to murder charges. Prosecutors said Mr. Calderon beat the child over a period of several days because he had broken a television set.

Most people associate the name Levolor with thin metal-slat blinds. But recently the company expanded its repertory to include cordless Roman shades. The new window coverings come in a wide selection of stripes, patterns and solid colors, in widths up to 144 inches to fit extra-wide windows. They are available in two styles: flat, for a contemporary house, and a more billowy style, for a traditional one. They lift up and down, and can be opened from the top and the bottom, to provide privacy as well as light. For an average-size window, 31 inches wide and 64 inches tall, the cost is $189 to $302. For local retailers: (800) 538-6567 or www.levolor.com. Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

A Suffolk County man accused of robbing five banks on Long Island in the last three months pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment in First District Court, the Suffolk County district attorney's office said. The man, Steven P. Bertuglia, 34, was arrested on Tuesday night as he sat in his car in Mount Sinai, the Suffolk police said. In addition to being charged with robbing five banks, he is suspected of robbing others on Long Island and in New York City, Connecticut and New Jersey, the police said.

The Hatch Lounger, made in France, is covered in synthetic suede in a choice of five colors and filled with polyolefin foam and polystyrene beads; $289 from (818) 219-2182 or hatch-bbag.com.

A 24-year-old man was stabbed to death shortly before 3 a.m. yesterday outside a strip club on Steinway Street in Astoria, the police said. The man, who was identified as Jason Brown of Bay Shore, in Suffolk County, was pronounced dead on arrival at Elmhurst General Hospital, the police said. He had been stabbed several times in the torso by another man during a dispute outside the strip club, Club Riviera, the police said. The assailant escaped, the police said, and no weapon was recovered.

''Loyalty'' is a word that has long defined Rudolph W. Giuliani's leadership style. But rarely has there been as documented an outpouring of that support as the 92 letters Mr. Giuliani wrote for Dennis E. Szybala during four months in 1981. The letters of recommendation fill a folder in the National Archives, where 62 boxes of Mr. Giuliani's files from his days in the Justice Department were released last month.

An article on Saturday about the bombing of a Sunni Arab mosque near the southern Iraqi city of Basra misstated the name of the mosque. (The error was repeated in an article on Sunday about violence in Iraq.) It is the Talha Bin Obeidallah Mosque, not Talha Bin al-Zubair.

ZAFERES--Thomas Andrew. The passionate life, husband, father, a brother, a friend. In the remains of the day, we are left better, thanks for his talent and loving goodness. July 6, 1934 to June 9, 2007.

An appeals court judge yesterday denied a stay of sentence for a former State Supreme Court justice convicted of corruption charges and ordered him to begin serving his 3-to-10-year prison term. The former judge, Gerald Garson, was convicted in April of accepting bribes to manipulate the outcome of matrimonial cases in his Brooklyn court. At his sentencing on June 5, Mr. Garson's $15,000 bail was revoked, but his lawyers won a temporary reprieve that afternoon. They argued that Mr. Garson, 74 and ailing, should remain free while he appealed the verdict on the grounds that the evidence was insufficient. In documents filed with the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Second Department, prosecutors argued that the verdict was supported by ''overwhelming evidence,'' and yesterday, in a one-page decision, Associate Justice Edward D. Carni revoked the temporary stay.

MY daughter graduated from high school last week. As she heads to college, my husband warned me that we face four years of a crushing financial burden, with enormous regular payments that he fears could lead to bankruptcy. And I don't mean tuition.

BENDINER--Esther Shapiro. We honor Esther Shapiro Bendiner who died on Saturday, June 16, 2007 at the age of 94. Wife of the late Elmer Bendiner, mother of Winifred and Jessica, grandmother of Gabrielle, she was an activist, community organizer, valued friend and fierce defender of equal rights for all.

BRODY--Benjamin, 87, died on June 17th, 2007. He is survived by his wife, Georgia, two sons, David and Samuel, and two granddaughters. Memorial service Saturday, June 30, 5:30pm, The Penn Club 30 W 44th St.

ROMANELLI--Nedda, 91, passed away on June 20, 2007. A woman of valor, she was the widow of Umberto Romanelli who died June 30, 1997. She is survived by three loving children, Rosanna Frank of Chappaqua, NY, Joseph Romanelli of Jerusalem, Israel and Daniel Romanelli of Malibu, CA. She was born in Italy and came to the United States in 1939. She and her husband operated the C'a D'Oro restaurant in midtown Manhattan for 28 years. She will be sorely missed by her children, her seven grandchildren and her seven great-grandchildren. May her memory be a blessing forever.

In Berlin, one good way to beat the heat is by jumping into Ploetzensee, one of the city's many fine lakes. Ploetzensee is small, understated and central - set back in woods from the busy Seestrasse thoroughfare in Berlin-Wedding about 7 kilometers (4.2 miles) northwest of the Brandenburg Gate. Named after a red-eyed carp called a Ploetze, the lake has been a popular bathing spot with beach and snack bar for more than 150 years.

While the offering was clearly a success by most measures -- it priced at the high end of the expected range at $31, opened 18 percent higher at $36.55 and recently traded at $35.95 -- the relatively modest jump seemed to leave many observers underwhelmed. The stock closed the day at $35.06.

I did not think Rome's main airport, Leonardo Da Vinci (a.k.a. Fiumicino) could get more frustrating or disorganised. But it has achieved that feat today: Suddenly, unannounced, as of yesterday, check-in for flights to Paris, Brussels (and a few other Europen cities) are leaving from the Domestic Departures Terminal, Terminal A. Oh, but it's not that simple: Only flights on Alitalia, KLM and Air France have moved. The rest remain in the European International Departures Terminal, Terminal B.

A tournament in Foros, Ukraine, a town not far away from Yalta on the Crimean Peninsula, has attracted some of the world's best players. The tournament, sponsored by Aerosvit Ukrainian Airlines, began June 17 and runs through the end of the month. Among the participants are Peter Svidler of Russia, ranked No. 9 in the world, Vassily Ivanchuk of Ukraine, No. 12, Dmitry Jakovenko of Russia, No. 18, and Alexander Onischuk, tied for 39, who is originally from Ukraine but is now a United States citizen and was the 2006 U.S. champion.

Moving to placate lenders and stabilize what has become an embarrassing situation for the investment bank, Bear Stearns said Friday that it would provide a secured loan of up to $3.2 billion to one of two troubled hedge funds. Bloomberg News described the loan as the biggest bailout since 1998; The New York Times said it was a tacit acknowledgment that Bear's portfolio managers "made brash bets on a mortgage market that has been jarred by a rising delinquencies and foreclosures."

The reform package, which Mr. Obama pledges to enact on his first day in office, includes a strict provision barring political appointees who leave their position from lobbying the executive branch for the remainder of the administration.

Bank Austria Creditanstalt, a unit of UniCredit, bid $2.2 billion to acquire AO ATF Bank of Kazakhstan to tap an oil-related boom in the former Soviet Union. Bank Austria said that it had agreed to buy at least 85 percent of the bank, which is based in Almaty and has corporate and retail operations, and that it hopes to acquire the remaining shares. ATF Bank has 110 branches and assets valued at 6.3 billion euros ($8.4 billion) and a market share of 11.8 percent. Austria Creditanstalt is based in Vienna, and UniCredit is based in Milan.

The Jefferies Group said it had acquired the Putnam Lovell investment banking business, a provider of merger advice to asset managers and broker dealers, from National Bank Financial Group of Canada. Terms were not disclosed. Jefferies, an underwriter and merger adviser to midsize companies, said this is the fifth industry-focused M.& A. group it has acquired in less than five years. The purchase will expand Jefferies’ ability to make deals in the asset management sector.

The London Stock Exchange was considering making a bid of $2 billion to acquire Borsa Italiana, the operator of the stock exchange in Milan, two people close to the companies said. The two exchanges discussed a potential merger and were set to continue discussions today, a spokesman for Borsa Italiana said. The spokesman, Alessandro Pavesi, said the proposal from the London exchange is the only one being considered. Both exchanges have fended off takeover approaches in the last year, and a merger might help them avoid a takeover in the future, said Rupak Ghose, an analyst at Credit Suisse in London. “It is not surprising that the L.S.E. is looking at different alternatives to become larger and hence avoid becoming acquired,” Mr. Ghose said in a note to investors.

Lone Star Funds, the buyout firm founded by John Grayken, plans to sell a stake in Korea Exchange Bank for as much as $1.1 billion after its move to divest entirely was derailed last year by a legal dispute. Lone Star is offering 73.1 million shares, or 11.3 percent of Korea Exchange, for 13,150 to 13.750 won ($14.19 to $14.84) a share, according to an e-mail message sent to fund managers by the Credit Suisse Group, the investment bank arranging the sale. Shares in Korea Exchange fell 1.7 percent, to 14,600 won, up 14 percent this year. Lone Star, based in Dallas, has struggled for two years to sell the controlling stake it bought in 2003 as Korean prosecutors contend that the firm purchased the shares at an artificially low price. The sale of part of the Seoul-based bank would allow Lone Star to return money to investors while the case is pending and retain a majority stake.
Take-Two Interactive Software said it would temporarily suspend the release of Manhunt 2 because of a ratings controversy.
The state police superintendent has disciplined the trooper, Robert J. Rasinski, though he declined to specify the punishment.
Tom Glavine is struggling after 21 exceptional major leauge seasons and The Mets, who have lost 14 of their last 18 games, are in a free fall that is threatening to redefine their season.

The Keeping Score column on Sunday, about new baseball research into hitting and fielding trends that can help assess the impact of pitchers, referred incorrectly to the status of the journeyman Glendon Rusch. He is recovering from a blood-clot scare last season, and is not pitching now; he is not out of the game because he “appears to have run out of employers to disappoint” with his statistically below-average pitching.

A picture caption with a sports article in some copies on Wednesday about the Rockies’ 3-1 victory against the Yankees misstated the score after Kaz Matsui crossed the plate for Colorado in the fifth inning. It was 2-1, not 2-0.

An article on May 9 about a new course at the State University of New York at Stony Brook on how to be an informed consumer of print, broadcast and Internet journalism misspelled the surname of a vice president of the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, which helps finance the course. He is Eric Newton, not Newtown. The error was pointed out by Mr. Newton in an e-mail message this week.
An article last Friday about declining populations of once common birds misidentified one shorebird in decline. It is the common tern, not the greater tern.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, long a cloistered and opaque agency, took a big step yesterday toward opening itself to greater public scrutiny by tentatively approving changes to overhaul the way it awards contracts, works with lobbyists and makes decisions affecting the airports, bridges, ports and tunnels it operates.

Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about the defense editor of the newspaper Haaretz who was considered the dean of Israeli military correspondents misstated his surname at one point. As the article noted, he was Zeev Schiff and in subsequent references he should have been identified as Mr. Schiff, not Mr. Haaretz.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about the success of the New York Athletic Club’s elite women’s running team misstated a team member’s collegiate achievements. Julia Stamps Mallon was named an all-American at Stanford six times, not twice.

A sports article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by the tennis player Guillermo Coria against a nutritional supplement company that he blames for his positive steroid test referred incorrectly to an arrangement in professional basketball designed to ensure safe and pure supplements for athletes. The N.B.A. players union, not the league itself, has such a deal with a supplement maker.

ALBANY, June 21 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s first legislative session was coming to a fractious close on Thursday night, as he and top lawmakers failed to reach agreement on a wide range of issues as they rushed to finish business for the summer.
A brief report in the Off the Menu column in the Dining section on Wednesday, about the opening of the restaurant Muse in Water Mill, N.Y., misstated the telephone number. It is (631) 726-2606.

An obituary on June 13 about Don Herbert, who appeared on television in the 1950s and ’60s as Mr. Wizard, misstated the name of the institution in Princeton, N.J., with which the physicist Frank Wilczek was affiliated in 1990, when he was interviewed about informal approaches to teaching science and praised Mr. Herbert. It is the Institute for Advanced Study, not Studies.

An article on Sunday about the disbarment of Michael B. Nifong, the district attorney in Durham County, N.C., misstated the surname of a North Carolina State Bar lawyer who made closing arguments in the ethics trial of Mr. Nifong. He is Doug Brocker, not Doug Brock.

A sports article on April 8 about Michigan State’s 3-1 victory over Boston College to capture the N.C.A.A. men’s ice hockey championship misidentified the player who scored the only goal for the Eagles. It was Brian Boyle — not Brock Bradford, who had the assist. The reporter pointed out the error this week.
The Oakland Athletics cut ties with designated outfielder Milton Bradley, who was expected to play an important role this season.

NEWARK, June 21 — The fight was brief. The mayor of Newark, Cory A. Booker, floated like a butterfly, bouncing around a bit in oversized gloves. But it was 14-year-old Shakor Jackson who stung like a bee.
track and field.
The city’s department of health said that the number of smokers in New York City had declined by 240,000 in the last five years.
The vice president suggested abolishing a National Archives unit that objected to his resistance to oversight.

A parade in Jerusalem in favor of gay rights passed off largely peacefully despite vocal opposition and protests by ultra-Orthodox citizens. The police arrested a man they said was carrying a homemade bomb he said he intended to put along the route. Some 2,500 people marched, according to the police, half the 5,000 that had been expected.

Prime Minister John Howard announced drastic measures to tackle the rampant sexual abuse of children cited in an officially commissioned report on Aboriginal communities in the far north, including a ban on the sale of alcohol and restrictions on access to pornography. “This is a national emergency,” Mr. Howard told Parliament. He also announced tight controls on welfare payments for Aborigines, which would be linked to a child’s school attendance. Families will also be required to spend at least half their welfare on essentials like food. Mr. Howard also called on state governments to send the police to the Northern Territory and offered to pay their expenses.

The Civil Guard said it had found a car loaded with explosives in southern Spain. A spokesman said in a telephone interview that the car was found in Ayamonte, a popular tourist area close to the border with Portugal, and that the explosives were apparently in the process of being transported and were not rigged to a detonator. The radio station Cadena Ser put the amount at 220 pounds. The paramilitary Basque group ETA formally ended a 15-month cease-fire on June 5 and put Spain on the alert for possible terrorist attacks, particularly in southern areas frequented by tourists.

A total of 97,207 people were killed or disappeared in the 1992-1995 war in Bosnia, according to a three-year study by the Sarajevo-based Research and Documentation Center. The center, which describes itself as independent and nonpartisan, said it had names for all the dead cited in its study. It said that close to two-thirds of the casualties, 64,036, were Bosnian Muslims, followed by Serbs, 24,905, and Croats, 7,788, while 478 were of other nationalities. Almost half of the casualties died in the first year of the war. Of the total dead, 57,523 were directly involved in the war and 39,684 were civilians.

Prime Minister Shinzo Abe delayed the critical upper house election by a week, to July 29 from July 22, by extending Parliament’s current session by 12 days, in what was seen as a desperate move to regain popular support and dampen widespread anger over the government’s admission that it had misplaced payment information for millions of pensioners. Polls show that support for Mr. Abe and his Liberal Democratic Party has fallen dangerously low among potential voters, with the main opposition Democratic Party scoring higher in some polls. A significant defeat could put pressure on Mr. Abe to step down as party leader and prime minister, though his party would keep the prime minister’s post through its control over the lower house.

A group of clerics, the Pakistan Ulema Council, said they had given Osama bin Laden the title Saifullah, or sword of Allah, in response to the British government’s decision to give Salman Rushdie, the author of “The Satanic Verses,” a knighthood. The chairman of the council, Tahir Ashrafi, said that since Mr. Rushdie, who is considered a blasphemer by many Muslims in Pakistan, had been given the title “Sir,” then Mr. bin Laden, a holy warrior in the eyes of the council, should be given a parallel title. The gesture was a more lighthearted reaction to the honor for Mr. Rushdie than the noisy protests of demonstrators in some cities of Pakistan. On Monday, Pakistan’s Parliament passed a resolution condemning the knighthood and said it should be withdrawn.
John Edwards’s use of a tax-exempt organization to finance travel and employ political staff was unusual among national candidates.
ABC News said it lost its bid because the network was  unwilling to make a “high six-figure deal” with the Hilton family.
The company’s initial public offering was priced at $31 a unit, but its archrival Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is said to also be planning an initial offering of its own.
About 80 men and women Thursday placed mats on a traffic island during the morning rush and quietly demonstrated their yoga skills.
NANTUCKET, Mass., June 21 — A New York man was convicted on Thursday of stabbing to death a Manhattan woman three years ago on this affluent island two days after she ended their relationship.
Ron Kind, a Democratic representative from Wisconsin dairyland, is making a name for himself as a crusader for big changes in farm policy.
The long-secret documents detail domestic spying, assassination plots and other actions from the 1960s and early 1970s.
For the first time in nearly two decades, the federal government has released a list of hospitals where heart patients are most likely to die.
With taxes on private equity and hedge funds front and center, many in the industry are looking to Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, for help.
The increasing numbers of veiled Muslim women are fueling the debate over the role of Muslims in British life.
The decision dealt a blow to investors who want to sue companies and executives because of suspected fraud.
In trying to bring insurgent- controlled areas around Baghdad under control, U.S. troops have found dozens of bombs buried beneath the road, some big enough to destroy an Abrams tank.

TRENTON, June 21 — Despite an unexpected objection from a lone legislator that surfaced a week ago, the New Jersey Senate on Thursday confirmed Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s choice for chief justice of the State Supreme Court.
Several residents of Colchester recounted seeing a wave as high as four or five feet appear from nowhere on Tuesday night, followed by others.
The House voted narrowly to reverse a ban on contraception aid to groups overseas that offer abortions, a pillar of President Bush’s foreign aid policy.
Most of the American deaths were caused by roadside bombs, which were used in three of the five attacks.

Concluding that police officers are sometimes too detached from the communities they serve, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday the start of a new program of intense training in community relations for cadets at the Police Academy.
Students who participated in a federally financed school voucher program did not perform significantly better academically but their parents were satisfied anyway.
Many criminologists and law enforcement officials are debating whether the violent-crime data signal a significant national trend.
London’s mayor notched up the vitriol to the point of wishing harm, even terminal harm, to Washington’s envoy.
The Spitzer administration is seriously considering a revamped proposal that would include additional exhibition space but cost $4 billion, more than twice the previous estimate.

Eight conservation groups led by the National Wildlife Federation announced plans to sue several shipping companies that operate in the Great Lakes, accusing them of discharging polluted water without the permit required under the federal Clean Water Act. The release of untreated ballast water, water held in the ballast tanks or cargo holds of ships to provide stability, introduces nonnative species that could harm the lakes’ ecosystem, the groups contend.
G.E. and Pearson have decided not to make an offer for Dow Jones, leaving Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation as the only bidder.

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential hopeful, called for a “new course” in the battle against global terrorism in a speech to the American Enterprise Institute’s World Forum in Colorado. Mr. Romney urged what he described as “a new type of Marshall Plan” that would deliver economic aid, public health aid and other assistance to Islamic states struggling to resist violent extremists. He also called for the creation of a special military unit that would work with other governments to combat terrorists.

The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said that former Attorney General John Ashcroft told the panel in a closed session that the Bush administration was sharply split over the legality of the domestic eavesdropping program. Representative Silvestre Reyes, a Texas Democrat who leads the panel, said that it was clear to him that “there was enormous debate in the administration about the legal basis” for the program. Also, the Senate Judiciary Committee authorized, but did not issue, subpoenas to Mr. Gonzales and to the custodian of records for the president’s office to turn over all documents related to the eavesdropping program.

Thomas S. Robertson, a professor of marketing, has been named dean of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, university officials announced. Dr. Robertson, left, is currently the executive faculty director of the Institute for Developing Nations at Emory University in Atlanta. Dr. Robertson taught from 1971 to 1994 at Wharton. He will succeed Patrick Harker, who will become president of the University of Delaware.

Prosecutors plan to file misdemeanor vehicular manslaughter charges against a graduate student who was driving when David Halberstam, the Pulitzer Prize-winning writer, was killed in a car crash south of San Francisco. A crash investigation showed that the student, Kevin Jones, 26, made an illegal left turn into the path of a car that had the green light. That car crashed into the passenger side of the car in which Mr. Halberstam, a former reporter for The New York Times, was riding, according to the San Mateo County district attorney’s office.
Senator Johnny Isakson of Georgia wants to add a squalid little amendment to the immigration bill so as to benefit a corporate constituent.
Each year Bob Wills teaches hundreds of people who work on the subway tracks how to do their jobs without getting hit by a train.
The tension between art and commerce has formed the not-so-subtle subtext at the fraud trial of Laura Albert, the talented yet troubled writer also known as JT Leroy.
AstraZeneca, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Schering-Plough must pay damages for overcharging on certain drugs.
Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah will meet with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and the Jordanian and Israeli leaders.
A treatment that involves slipping billions of copies of a gene into the brain seemed to improve symptoms without causing side effects.
Hunter Mahan’s round at the Travelers Championship was one stroke off the course record at River Highlands in Cromwell, Conn.
In a large study, the difference in I.Q. between siblings was a result of family dynamics, not biological factors.
Vice President Dick Cheney suggested shutting down a government office that wanted to oversee his office’s handling of classified information, documents show.
The W.H.O. plan calls for the creation and improvement of laboratories to detect and monitor drug-resistant cases throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) — A 43-game hitting streak in the minor leagues does not warrant a place in Cooperstown or a multimillion-dollar contract extension. It did, however, help get Brandon Watson another shot at the big leagues.
Congress has reacted to the college loan scandal with several strong proposals that would go a long way toward ending corruption.
Lockheed Martin’s $600 billion Joint Strike Fighter program is only now moving off the drawing board and into first flight.
A 59-year-old Pennsylvania man was arrested on charges that he molested at least six children within sight of the school where he was a crossing guard.
Governments and companies tend to become so seduced or intimidated by China that they won’t hold it to high standards of human rights and business ethics.
The New Jersey Legislature passed a bill Thursday that set ambitious goals for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases.
The contract electronics manufacturer posted a 90 percent drop in quarterly net profit, but earnings excluding special charges were higher than expected.
It is eBay’s second attempt to break into the Chinese market after the collapse of the company’s EachNet venture, and the first with a local partner.
General Motors plans to use Tiger Woods instead as a pitchman in companywide ads for products like OnStar.
The Bush administration’s theory of the “unitary executive,” which has no support in American history or the Constitution, is a formula for autocracy.
Paul J. McNulty said that he did not know the extent of the White House role in the ousters of federal prosecutors when he testified in February.
Robert E. Diamond Jr. would be crucial to making a merger between Barclays and ABN Amro work.
The 17-man race crew of team New Zealand is looking outside of its borders in hopes of achieving success in the America’s Cup.
The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation hopes to gain insight into how virtual worlds are used by young people.
In the history of baseball’s amateur draft, only two players taken with the No. 1 pick have failed to make the major leagues. Matt Bush will do anything not to be the third.
The family that helped create the Pequot tribe’s casino wealth says the tribe has shunned it in recent years.
The defendants’ lawyers sought to exclude the interview because it would prejudice the jury against their clients, who are charged with conspiring to assist jihad overseas.
The two-time candidate said his decision would depend on whether he could round up enough volunteers and lawyers to get him on the ballot in all 50 states.
Japan has one of the oldest systems of higher education in Asia, but its universities are scrambling to find new ways to attract students.
Marketers of alcoholic beverages are joining the list of purveyors of consumer products that are devoting ad budgets to digital media.
Kenny Lofton was stuck between second and third base, seemingly a sure out for the Texas Rangers in the bottom of the ninth inning.
Geikel Conyedo, a catcher at Perth Amboy High School, has overcome seemingly insurmountable obstacles on his journey to New Jersey from Cuba.
Mr. Friendly was the co-producer of hit television shows including the rambunctious “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In” and the frontier saga “Little House on the Prairie.”
Spiraling costs and opposition from powerful lawmakers led to the decision to terminate the multibillion-dollar program.
Talks collapsed when the U.S. and the European Union fell out with India and Brazil over plans to cut agricultural subsidies and tariffs.

New York City’s chief marketing officer, Maureen J. Reidy, resigned yesterday to become chief operating officer of IMG Fashion, which puts on Fashion Week shows. Ms. Reidy had been responsible for sponsorship deals for the city and attracting major events, like the 2004 Republican National Convention and the 2008 Major League Baseball All-Star Game. George A. Fertitta, chief executive of NYC & Company, the city’s marketing and tourism promotion agency, has not decided how to replace Ms. Reidy, a spokeswoman said.

A Long Island City man has been indicted on hate crimes charges in connection with the mugging of two elderly women in March, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Jack Rhodes, 44, of Vernon Boulevard, was indicted on charges of burglary, robbery and assault as hate crimes, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, adding that prosecutors believe that Mr. Rhodes chose his victims because of their advanced age. Mr. Brown said Mr. Rhodes repeatedly punched a 101-year-old woman while mugging her in the vestibule of her building on Highland Avenue in Jamaica Hills on March 4. She suffered a broken cheekbone. He also repeatedly punched an 85-year-old woman during a robbery in her 170th Street building about half an hour later, Mr. Brown said. She was cut and bruised by the attack. Mr. Rhodes pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court.

A former judge was given a second reprieve on his prison sentence yesterday and allowed to enter an alcohol detoxification program. The former judge, Gerald P. Garson, 74, was convicted of accepting bribes to manipulate matrimonial cases in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. This month, Justice Jeffrey Berry of State Supreme Court sentenced Mr. Garson to 3 to 10 years, but after the hearing, an appellate court judge gave Mr. Garson a temporary stay to file an appeal. This week, the appellate court judge ordered Mr. Garson to begin his sentence and revoked the stay. But yesterday, Justice Berry, responding to defense arguments that Mr. Garson would probably die in prison without treatment for alcoholism, allowed Mr. Garson to attend a detoxification program until July 5 before beginning his sentence.

The police yesterday continued their investigation of the sexual assault of an off-duty police officer who was attacked at knifepoint by a masked man in her Brooklyn apartment on Wednesday night. The woman, whose name, age and rank were not released, had just gotten off work when, shortly after 6:30 p.m., she was attacked by a man who investigators believe broke into her Bay Ridge apartment through a rear window where an air-conditioner had been installed, the police said. The man grabbed her from behind, sexually assaulted her and then fled, possibly through the same window, the police said. The woman called another officer from her precinct to report the attack. It was not known if she knew her attacker or if he knew she was an officer.

In their case against a bouncer accused of killing a 24-year-old graduate student, prosecutors yesterday gave defense lawyers four boxes of evidence described as medical reports and hair and fiber analyses. The defendant, Darryl Littlejohn, 42, has been charged with the murder of Imette St. Guillen, a student at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Ms. St. Guillen’s body was found bound and strangled in a remote part of Brooklyn in February 2006, a day after she had visited a bar in SoHo where Mr. Littlejohn worked. No trial date has been scheduled. Prosecutors in Brooklyn are waiting for their counterparts in Queens to try Mr. Littlejohn first, on separate and unrelated kidnapping charges.

A state trooper was indicted yesterday on charges that he stole drugs that had been seized by the police and sold them. The trooper, Brian Holmes, 41, of Elizabeth, faces 13 charges, including official misconduct, theft and drug trafficking, prosecutors said. Trooper Holmes has been suspended without pay since May 2006, shortly after his partner, Moises Hernandez, pleaded guilty to aiding members of a drug ring. Mr. Hernandez is serving a 24-year prison sentence. Theodore J. Romankow, the Union County prosecutor, said the charges against Trooper Holmes involve the theft of cocaine and Ecstasy pills seized in police operations in 2002.

A convicted sex offender has been accused of violating his parole terms by creating a profile on the social networking site MySpace.com without his parole officer’s permission, the state attorney general’s office said yesterday. The offender, William Santos, 21, of Waterbury, was taken into State Correction Department custody this week, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said. Mr. Santos, who was convicted of second-degree sexual assault against a minor, will remain in custody at least until the Board of Pardons and Paroles holds a hearing, which has not yet been scheduled. MySpace recently provided law enforcement officials in all 50 states with the names of more than 5,000 people identified as sex offenders who had created profiles on the site.
Jim Nussle, an advocate of smaller government, used his position as the chair of the House Budget Committee to direct tens of millions of dollars to his district.

A Metro-North train derailed yesterday afternoon, shutting down service between Bridgeport and Waterbury and causing several injuries, a railroad spokeswoman said. The train was headed north from Bridgeport with about 40 passengers when it left the tracks about 1:45 p.m., about 45 minutes before it was due to arrive in Waterbury. The train’s locomotive and three cars did not tip over, said the spokeswoman, Marjorie Anders. Ms. Anders said two crew members and two passengers were taken to hospitals with neck and back injuries described as not life-threatening. About 250 people use the Bridgeport to Waterbury line each day; it makes six trips in each direction. Buses were being provided until service could be restored.

Sunni residents in Baquba had little trust for the Shiite-dominated army being reintroduced into the city.
The Environmental Protection Agency’s recommendation was the first since 1997 for ground-level ozone.
After Frankie Hejduk and Landon Donovan scored, the United States again nearly frittered away its lead and a spot in the Concacaf Gold Cup final.
A Supreme Court ruling would make it more difficult for defendants to challenge their sentences.
The economy should expand modestly in coming months as a healthy job market continues to trump weakness in housing prices.
The Supreme Court rejected the claim by a high school football powerhouse in Tennessee that its coach’s recruiting violations were a form of free speech.
The mystery of the Mungiki, a secret society that is part Sicilian Mafia, part Chicago street gang, is sweeping across Kenya and taking a lot of lives with it.
Merrill Lynch assuaged concern of a looming credit crisis and the latest government report on the economy showed growth was accelerating.
Janette Sadik-Khan is the tactician behind the congestion pricing concept being championed by the Bloomberg administration.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,526 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
The extradition would continue a trend under President Felipe Calderón, who has shipped 21 drug dealers to the U.S. this year.
Mr. Shoulders, a city boy who gained renown as the Babe Ruth of professional rodeo, rode bucking broncos and snorting bulls to a record 16 world-championship titles.
Mr. Medress was a founding member of the 1960s doo-wop group the Tokens, known for their sole Top 10 hit.
The space shuttle Atlantis’ mission, originally scheduled for 11 days, has entered its fourteenth day.
After cutting their division deficit to seven and a half games a week ago, with the loss, the Yankees have fallen 10 ½ games behind the Boston Red Sox.
Four networks manage to increase their rates as they complete their upfront sales.
Our enduring reluctance to acknowledge the complexity of the abortion issue has only prolonged and hardened the debate.
Thomas the Tank Engine and his fellow trains are serving up important lessons about regulating environmental poisons in the global economy.
When American G.I.’s returned from the Vietnam War, some tried to smuggle home the skulls of Vietcong and North Vietnamese soldiers.
Jason Giambi is believed to be the first active player to work with George J. Mitchell’s steroids investigation.
Joe Girardi turned down the opportunity to become the next manager of the Baltimore Orioles on Thursday, saying it was not in the best interest of his family at this time.

Woody Allen gets his night at the opera, Lucian Freud painting sets record, the J. Paul Getty Museum names a curator and more culture news.
Maybe they don’t miss Rosie so much after all: The ratings boost that Ms. O’Donnell had helped to give “The View” as a co-host has not subsided in her absence.

This modest show provides a powerful reminder of the hardships, psychic stresses and physical dangers that men and women endure on the front lines.
His latest large-scale work, which premiered at the Angel Orensanz Foundation on Wednesday, confirmed the depth and vitality of Bill Dixon’s art.
In Wednesday’s program of Mahler and Strauss, the musicians went through the motions in their particularly elegant way.
The show in Kassel, Germany, sustains its reputation for being an idiosyncratic, concept-driven affair.
A combination of hard and delicate pieces by Branford Marsalis and Joshua Redman left the crowd in happy exhaustion at Town Hall on Wednesday.

8 P.M. (Sci Fi) STARGATE SG-1 Over and out: Sci Fi’s longest-running original series comes to an end after 10 seasons, leaving the SG-1’s (played by Beau Bridges, Ben Browder, Lou Gossett Jr. and Amanda Tapping, among others) to explore galaxies we earthlings can only imagine. For mourning viewers, two “Stargate SG-1” films are reportedly in the works. Tonight, the Asgard, facing extinction, decide to hand over all their knowledge and technology to the team. But will there be time enough to stop the Ori?.
Savion Glover offered a technically brilliant, if somewhat dry, series of dances in his program, “Invitation to a Dancer,” at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday.
The ballet superstar brings his wide-ranging and eclectic interests to the stage in a tribute to Hell’s Kitchen, the neighborhood of his multidisciplinary center, this weekend.
After a comprehensive refurbishing, the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden at the New York Botanical Garden is presenting its largest and most varied collection ever.
Reviews of David Lamelas at Maccarone, Mr. at Lehmann Maupin, Melvin Martinez at Fresh Paint and more.

Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation remains the sole bidder for the company, owner of The Wall Street Journal.
Although the 95-year-old sculptor’s repertory is nothing if not well known, it looks as fresh as ever.
Two of Zaha Hadid’s sculptures will be featured at separate events: at London’s Serpentine Gallery in July and as part of “Mobile Art,” a traveling pavilion.
Bowing to a dog-crazed public, Christie’s is holding its first New York sale on Friday dedicated to dogs in art: 95 paintings and sculptures dating from the 17th century to the present.
Andrew Ferguson counts the ways Americans love Abraham Lincoln in his hilarious, offbeat tour of shrines, statues, cabins and museums dedicated to the 16th president.
