The case of Universal Express shows how hard it can be for the commission to halt what it views as a fraud.
The 2007 Tour de France starts July 7, and Versus, which has rights to the race through next year, is faced with carrying the elite event of a sport whose credibility is at a nadir.
Firefighter Daniel F. Pujdak fell to his death yesterday while trying to save an artist’s loft less than two miles from the three-story aluminum-sided house in Greenpoint where he was raised.
Buoyed by rapidly rising demand and aggressive financing from banks, even the youngest companies are ordering new planes.
Christopher R. Hill said he wanted to speed up six-nation talks aimed at dismantling North Korea’s nuclear program.
How does “Mayor Gotbaum” strike your ear? You never know.
A five-day event inspired by the fable of the stone soup is a retreat from the doldrums of daily life, off the grid and blissfully in the middle of nowhere.
Readers respond to recent articles in the Escapes section.
Rose Month events at the New York Botanical Garden conclude this weekend with free tours of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden and question-and-answer sessions with experts.
An old-fashioned town that’s not stuck in the past but hasn’t abandoned it either. Mixed in with antique farms and a covered bridge is a comfortable assortment of coffee shops and boutiques.
With hiking, water skiing, kayaking and biking, the town is hoping to be America’s capital of extreme sports.
Nearly 400 players took sides for Dark Angel, a 26-hour “scenario” paintball game based, in part, on the television show of the same name.
Surfing competitions from Long Beach, N.Y., to Waikiki during the dog days of summer.

Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about Independence Day celebrations misstated the given name of the British general who surrendered to American forces at Yorktown, Va. He was Charles Cornwallis, not George.
American schools are awash in moral instruction — on sex, multiculturalism, environmental awareness and so on — and basically none of it works.

To the Editor: Re ''Bush Vetoes Bill Removing Stem Cell Limits, Saying 'All Human Life Is Sacred' '' (news article, June 21):

BLACKSTONE SETS ITS PRICE The Blackstone Group set the price of its eagerly awaited initial public offering at $31 a unit, at the top of its range, raising $4.13 billion. But its archrival in the world of private equity, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is planning an initial offering of its own, people briefed on the matter said. NO BID FROM G.E. AND PEARSONGeneral Electric Company and Pearson, the British publisher, have decided not to make an offer for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, leaving Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation as the only bidder for Dow Jones. [C1.]

A group of clerics, the Pakistan Ulema Council, said they had given Osama bin Laden the title Saifullah, or sword of Allah, in response to the British government's decision to give Salman Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic Verses,'' a knighthood. The chairman of the council, Tahir Ashrafi, said that since Mr. Rushdie, who is considered a blasphemer by many Muslims in Pakistan, had been given the title ''Sir,'' then Mr. bin Laden, a holy warrior in the eyes of the council, should be given a parallel title. The gesture was a more lighthearted reaction to the honor for Mr. Rushdie than the noisy protests of demonstrators in some cities of Pakistan. On Monday, Pakistan's Parliament passed a resolution condemning the knighthood and said it should be withdrawn.

New York City's chief marketing officer, Maureen J. Reidy, resigned yesterday to become chief operating officer of IMG Fashion, which puts on Fashion Week shows. Ms. Reidy had been responsible for sponsorship deals for the city and attracting major events, like the 2004 Republican National Convention and the 2008 Major League Baseball All-Star Game. George A. Fertitta, chief executive of NYC & Company, the city's marketing and tourism promotion agency, has not decided how to replace Ms. Reidy, a spokeswoman said.
To the Editor: Re ''Eating Beyond Sichuan,'' by Nina Zagat and Tim Zagat (Op-Ed, June 15):

Film News Marc Forster, who directed ''Monster's Ball'' and ''Finding Neverland,'' will direct the next James Bond film, Reuters reported. The untitled film -- the 22nd in the Bond franchise -- will again star Daniel Craig as 007 and is scheduled for release next year. Mr. Forster will develop the script with Paul Haggis (''Crash''). ... The second ''Narnia'' film, ''The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian,'' won't be out for another year, but the director for ''Narnia'' No. 3 has already been chosen: Michael Apted, 66, known for his ''Up'' documentaries tracing the lives of a group of Britons in seven-year increments (''28 Up,'' ''35 Up''). His film, ''The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader,'' is to be released in 2009, The Associated Press reported. ... Jim Broadbent, 58, who won an Oscar for best supporting actor in ''Iris,'' will join the cast of the next ''Indiana Jones'' movie, The Associated Press reported. The film, starring Harrison Ford and directed by Steven Spielberg, began production this week and is due in theaters on May 22, 2008.
''I was born here, I've never been to Bangladesh. I certainly don't feel Bangladeshi. So when they say, 'Go back home,' where should I go?''
A brief report in the Off the Menu column in the Dining section on Wednesday, about the opening of the restaurant Muse in Water Mill, N.Y., misstated the telephone number. It is (631) 726-2606.

Rose Month events at the New York Botanical Garden conclude this weekend with free tours of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden and question-and-answer sessions with experts. In addition ''All About Roses,'' tomorrow from 10 a.m. to 4:45 p.m., will feature three two-class sessions on their growth and care; each session is $31 ($28 for members) and registration is required: (718) 817-8747.

An article on Sunday about the disbarment of Michael B. Nifong, the district attorney in Durham County, N.C., misstated the surname of a North Carolina State Bar lawyer who made closing arguments in the ethics trial of Mr. Nifong. He is Doug Brocker, not Doug Brock.
An article last Friday about declining populations of once common birds misidentified one shorebird in decline. It is the common tern, not the greater tern.

As Roger Clemens threw his warm-up pitches before the bottom of the first inning, a fan in the front row at Coors Field held up a sign chiding the Yankees for paying ''$28 million for a dinosaur.'' During the course of a remarkable 24-year major league career, it rarely has been wise to doubt Clemens, who has more victories than any other living pitcher. But the fan went home happy Thursday because the Colorado Rockies chased Clemens in the fifth inning en route to a 4-3 victory and a three-game sweep of the Yankees.

An obituary on June 13 about Don Herbert, who appeared on television in the 1950s and '60s as Mr. Wizard, misstated the name of the institution in Princeton, N.J., with which the physicist Frank Wilczek was affiliated in 1990, when he was interviewed about informal approaches to teaching science and praised Mr. Herbert. It is the Institute for Advanced Study, not Studies.

Getty Names a Curator Nearly two years after the resignation of its embattled antiquities curator, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles has named a successor: Karol Wight, a 22-year veteran of the Getty. Ms. Wight, 48, a specialist in ancient glass, has risen from intern to associate curator to acting curator, a post she assumed in October 2005 when Marion True resigned over what the museum said were improprieties involving a real estate deal. (Ms. True has also been on trial in Italy since November 2005, on charges of trafficking in illegally excavated objects.) In a statement issued Wednesday the museum said that Ms. Wight had a major role in last year's reopening of the Getty Villa in Pacific Palisades, Calif. And as the Greek and Italian governments have laid claim to dozens of items in the antiquities collection, the Getty said, Ms. Wight has dealt with the issue ''with steadfastness and calm authority -- and a very clear vision for the future.'' She will oversee a staff of eight, the permanent antiquities collection and related exhibitions and programming at the villa, the museum said.

A former judge was given a second reprieve on his prison sentence yesterday and allowed to enter an alcohol detoxification program. The former judge, Gerald P. Garson, 74, was convicted of accepting bribes to manipulate matrimonial cases in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. This month, Justice Jeffrey Berry of State Supreme Court sentenced Mr. Garson to 3 to 10 years, but after the hearing, an appellate court judge gave Mr. Garson a temporary stay to file an appeal. This week, the appellate court judge ordered Mr. Garson to begin his sentence and revoked the stay. But yesterday, Justice Berry, responding to defense arguments that Mr. Garson would probably die in prison without treatment for alcoholism, allowed Mr. Garson to attend a detoxification program until July 5 before beginning his sentence.

Far too many literary adaptations wear the fancy dress of high culture prestige or bind themselves into corsets of reverence. Pascale Ferran's ''Lady Chatterley'' is different, and not just because it is a costume drama whose main characters frequently appear unclothed. It is hardly a canonical or faithful rendering of D. H. Lawrence's once-scandalous novel -- Ms. Ferran based her film on an earlier, less notorious version of the book and made Lawrence's earthy English lovers profess their amours en français -- but who needs that anyway? This ''Lady Chatterley,'' winner of five César awards in France, feels bracingly fresh, vital and modern. It is easy to forget just how modern Lawrence was, and remains. Even books that were daring in their day have a way of becoming respectable with the passage of time, as they are folded into the educational curriculum and the other machinery of middlebrow culture. Ms. Ferran restores Lawrence to the present partly by placing his themes in the service of her own sensibility.

Bank Austria Creditanstalt, a unit of UniCredit, bid $2.2 billion to acquire AO ATF Bank of Kazakhstan to tap an oil-related boom in the former Soviet Union. Bank Austria said that it had agreed to buy at least 85 percent of the bank, which is based in Almaty and has corporate and retail operations, and that it hopes to acquire the remaining shares. ATF Bank has 110 branches and assets valued at 6.3 billion euros ($8.4 billion) and a market share of 11.8 percent. Austria Creditanstalt is based in Vienna, and UniCredit is based in Milan.
ART Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

CELEBRATESTORY Once upon a time, a young woman moved to a giant metropolis, where she hoped to become an actress. But after studying abroad, she discovered a different, almost magical way to captivate audiences young and old. When she returned to the city, she began to use her new power, spreading happiness to its neighborhoods and around the world. More than 40 years later, the mayor declared a day in her honor. A fairy tale? Not really. The woman is Diane Wolkstein, the power is storytelling, the city is New York, and today is indeed Diane Wolkstein Day. But the real festivities begin tomorrow, when she leads off CelebrateStory, a free marathon of tale telling in Central Park.

To the Editor: Contrary to the June 17 Op-Ed article ''Periodically at the Table,'' by Cameron Stracher, missing family dinners is not only Dad's loss. Far more important, it is a loss for the children.
Correction Appended The end of the Lance Armstrong era was not fated to be easy for Versus.

Dance Theater Workshop Picks a Chief Dance Theater Workshop, flourishing artistically but struggling financially, has named Stephen Greco as its executive director. Mr. Greco, 56, has worked as a marketing and branding consultant for corporations and arts institutions, and is a journalist. He is editor at large of Trace, an arts and culture magazine, and has written for The New Yorker, The Advocate and Dance Magazine, among others. He is on the boards of the Kitchen and the Japan Society, and has been a member of the New York Dance and Performance Awards Committee, or Bessies, since 1985. Mr. Greco, whose tenure begins July 2, replaces Marion Koltun Dienstag, who resigned in April. CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

In their case against a bouncer accused of killing a 24-year-old graduate student, prosecutors yesterday gave defense lawyers four boxes of evidence described as medical reports and hair and fiber analyses. The defendant, Darryl Littlejohn, 42, has been charged with the murder of Imette St. Guillen, a student at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Ms. St. Guillen's body was found bound and strangled in a remote part of Brooklyn in February 2006, a day after she had visited a bar in SoHo where Mr. Littlejohn worked. No trial date has been scheduled. Prosecutors in Brooklyn are waiting for their counterparts in Queens to try Mr. Littlejohn first, on separate and unrelated kidnapping charges.
WASSERSTEIN--Lola S., the partners and staff of Newmark Knight Frank extend their heartfelt condolences to the Wasserstein family on the loss of a beloved family member.

'MEMORY COMES FROM DARK EXTENSION' Hints of Surrealism flit through Richard Tuttle's handsome and lovingly assembled small relief sculptures at Sperone Westwater. But Minimalism is the touchstone, as it has been throughout this 66-year-old artist's long, distinguished career as an improvisational objectmaker. In July 2005 he was honored with a retrospective that toured nationally. There is a poetic vision running through the present show, resulting in artworks that look both beautiful and intriguing. Each construction is made from simple materials (typically paper, plastic, wood, wire, foil, paint, pencil) and affixed to the wall with a miniature brace that projects it forward. From a distance the sculptures seem to be floating, like pieces of space debris. Up close you are reminded of the unstable scaffoldings of Picasso's object constructions and papiers collés (collages of pasted paper) and the delicate wood relief sculptures of Hans Arp. A consistent, individual technique links the approximately 60 works here: geometric shapes are cut from paper, folded in unusual ways, painted and then combined intuitively with other elements to create objects governed only by the limits of the artist's imagination. Neither labored nor facile, their grace, humility and dainty-poetic detail elicit depths of pleasure from the viewer. This is an inspiring, memorable show. (Through June 30, Sperone Westwater, 415 West 13th Street, West Village, 212-999-7337, speronewestwater.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

Chicago THE White House visit today by President Nguyen Minh Triet of Vietnam will take place just a few miles from the resting place of some of his countrymen. When American G.I.'s returned from the Vietnam War, some tried to smuggle home the skulls of Vietcong and North Vietnamese soldiers. The graffiti-covered skulls served as ashtrays, candle holders and trophies. Six skulls were seized by the Customs Service. They remain in limbo, relegated to a drawer on the campus of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

Stocks rebounded yesterday from their worst day in two weeks after Merrill Lynch assuaged concern of a looming credit crisis and the latest government report on the economy showed growth was accelerating. Advanced Micro Devices and Nvidia, a producer of graphics chips, posted the biggest gains in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Exxon Mobil climbed the most in the Dow Jones industrial average, initiating a rally in oil and gas company shares.

Joe Girardi has turned down an opportunity to become the next manager of the Baltimore Orioles. Girardi told the team that accepting the position would not be conducive with his family situation. ''At this time, it's just not right for my family,'' Girardi said. ''There was interest from them. I interviewed. But it just wasn't right for my family. That's the gist of it.''

A Long Island City man has been indicted on hate crimes charges in connection with the mugging of two elderly women in March, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Jack Rhodes, 44, of Vernon Boulevard, was indicted on charges of burglary, robbery and assault as hate crimes, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, adding that prosecutors believe that Mr. Rhodes chose his victims because of their advanced age. Mr. Brown said Mr. Rhodes repeatedly punched a 101-year-old woman while mugging her in the vestibule of her building on Highland Avenue in Jamaica Hills on March 4. She suffered a broken cheekbone. He also repeatedly punched an 85-year-old woman during a robbery in her 170th Street building about half an hour later, Mr. Brown said. She was cut and bruised by the attack. Mr. Rhodes pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court.

An article on May 9 about a new course at the State University of New York at Stony Brook on how to be an informed consumer of print, broadcast and Internet journalism misspelled the surname of a vice president of the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, which helps finance the course. He is Eric Newton, not Newtown. The error was pointed out by Mr. Newton in an e-mail message this week.

For four years, Vice President Dick Cheney has resisted routine oversight of his office's handling of classified information, and when the National Archives unit that monitors classification in the executive branch objected, the vice president's office suggested abolishing the oversight unit, according to documents released yesterday by a Democratic congressman. The Information Security Oversight Office, a unit of the National Archives, appealed the issue to the Justice Department, which has not yet ruled on the matter.

Is it too early for a movie about the short, charmed life and horrible death of Daniel Pearl? It's a fair question, raised in echo of those voices that several years ago worried if it were too early for a movie about Sept. 11. Like all those who died that day, Mr. Pearl was a casualty of Islamist hatred of Western civilization. And, much as with those other terror victims, his murder has now inspired a mainstream movie meant to entertain as much as to instruct and enlighten, a movie that will be seen by some as vulgar proof of that same civilization's willingness to turn a buck on everything, including tragedy. And make no mistake, despite its pseudo-documentary grit and the imprimatur of the midcult art-house director Michael Winterbottom, ''A Mighty Heart'' is a precision-tooled Hollywood machine. Based on the memoir by Mariane Pearl, it was bankrolled by a studio division and comes attached to two of the biggest stars in the world, Brad Pitt, who served as one of its producers, and his partner and the film's heat-seeking star, Angelina Jolie. For some, these boldface names will be reason enough to snigger. But snigger too loudly and you may miss that ''A Mighty Heart'' is effectively fashioned, as jolting as it is polished, as well as a surprising, insistently political work of commercial art.

HELFAND--Margaret, The Board and staff of the American Institute of Architects New York Chapter are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our friend and colleague Margaret Helfand, FAIA. Margaret served as President of the AIA New York Chapter in 2001 and was instrumental in creating the Center for Architecture. As co-chair of New York New Visions, she led the AIAs Lower Manhattan assistance efforts. A Fellow of the AIA and winner of the prestigious Rome Prize, at the time of her death she was co-chair of the Center for Architecture Advisory Council. She was loved and respected by all and will be sorely missed.

FOR decades, Thomas the Tank Engine and his fellow trains have been teaching children important life lessons. Now the plucky locomotives -- especially the haughty and sometimes naughty James the Red Engine -- are serving up important lessons about regulating environmental poisons in the global economy. Last week, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission announced that a toy maker, RC2 Corporation of Oak Brook, Ill., was recalling some 1.5 million Thomas & Friends wooden railway toys because their bright red or yellow coatings contain lead.

Corrections Appended AS they always have -- and absolutely must -- during Rose Month at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, fanciers of the queen of flowers will stop, stoop and smell the roses, inhaling the splendor of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden throughout the month of June. But this year visitors will discover a 1.04-acre garden that has been redefined. After undergoing a comprehensive, six-month, $2.5 million refurbishing, the rose garden is presenting its largest and most varied collection ever: 3,373 plants in 621 varieties.

Prime Minister Shinzo Abe delayed the critical upper house election by a week, to July 29 from July 22, by extending Parliament's current session by 12 days, in what was seen as a desperate move to regain popular support and dampen widespread anger over the government's admission that it had misplaced payment information for millions of pensioners. Polls show that support for Mr. Abe and his Liberal Democratic Party has fallen dangerously low among potential voters, with the main opposition Democratic Party scoring higher in some polls. A significant defeat could put pressure on Mr. Abe to step down as party leader and prime minister, though his party would keep the prime minister's post through its control over the lower house.

FOR CHILDREN CHESS SERIES (Sunday) The Chess and Checkers House in Central Park has frequently been used for just about everything but chess and checkers -- it's been a visitors' center and a card shop -- but Renée Yarzig, who runs nonprofit chess programs, is trying to return it to its original purpose. At each event in her new Summer Chess Lecture/Simul Series there, running monthly through September, a grandmaster will give a talk about chess and then take part in what is called a simul: boards will be set up for participants, and the grandmaster will move from board to board, playing one move at a time. But while the simul is limited to the first 30 players with a rating of 1,000 or more who register, families can enjoy their own games at the house's 24 stone tables. From 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., midpark, south of 65th Street; free. Registration advised: (917) 822-3141, crossgenerationchess.com.

TORRE--John S., 83, of Ft. Myers, died Sunday June 17. Services at St. Charles Cemetery on Monday June 25.

It has become a journalistic cliché and therefore an inevitable part of the prerelease discussion of ''Sicko'' to refer to Michael Moore as a controversial, polarizing figure. While that description is not necessarily wrong, it strikes me as self-fulfilling (since the controversy usually originates in media reports on how controversial Mr. Moore is) and trivial. Any filmmaker, politically outspoken or not, whose work is worth discussing will be argued about. But in Mr. Moore's case the arguments are more often about him than about the subjects of his movies. Some of this is undoubtedly his fault, or at least a byproduct of his style. His regular-guy, happy-warrior personality plays a large part in the movies and in their publicity campaigns, and he has no use for neutrality, balance or objectivity. More than that, his polemical, left-populist manner seems calculated to drive guardians of conventional wisdom bananas. That is because conventional wisdom seems to hold, against much available evidence, that liberalism is an elite ideology, and that the authentic vox populi always comes from the right. Mr. Moore, therefore, must be an oxymoron or a hypocrite of some kind.

To the Editor: Re ''For 2 Years, Bloomberg Aides Prepared Way for Independent Bid'' (front page, June 21):

A picture caption with a sports article in some copies on Wednesday about the Rockies' 3-1 victory against the Yankees misstated the score after Kaz Matsui crossed the plate for Colorado in the fifth inning. It was 2-1, not 2-0.

POTOMAC THEATER PROJECT After 20 years of producing theater in and around Washington, the Potomac Theater Project is hoping to call New York City home again. An earlier incarnation of the group, the New York Theater Studio, was active here from 1977 to 1985. The company is ready for new challenges, said Cheryl Faraone, one of the three co-directors (with Richard Romagnoli and Jim Petosa), and New York will provide that. Being distinctive and relevant in a town full of theater companies is no easy feat, but Ms. Faraone said she was optimistic. ''Somehow the shape of the work we do and the voices that interest us are not replicated very much,'' she said, adding that the company focuses on ''socially provocative plays.'' The 21st repertory season, through July 14, includes ''No End of Blame: Scenes of Overcoming,'' above, a drama by Howard Barker about the censorship of art, and ''Politics of Passion: The Plays of Anthony Minghella,'' comprising three one-acts: ''Cigarettes and Chocolate'' ''Hang Up'' and a scene from the film ''Truly, Madly, Deeply.'' Beginning on July 3, the company will also present a free ''After Dark'' series featuring new works in various stages of development -- from readings to full productions -- following regular performances on selected evenings or on an otherwise dark night. Highlights from the series include ''Iphigenia 3.0,'' a one-act play described as ''inspired by and pillaged from the works of Charles L. Mee,'' and ''Jude's Law,'' by Lisa Velten Smith, about a female fight club out to change opinions about which is the dominant sex. The company's name might make it seem like a visiting troupe (''We have this horrible habit of geographic instincts to naming,'' Ms. Faraone said), but if all goes well New York is going to be home for a while. (''Politics of Passion,'' now in previews, opens Tuesday, and ''No End of Blame'' begins previews tomorrow for a Wednesday opening, Atlantic Stage 2, 330 West 16th Street, Chelsea, 800-838-3006, BrownPaperTickets.com; $18. Schedule: www.potomactheatreproject.org.) STEVEN McELROY

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about the success of the New York Athletic Club's elite women's running team misstated a team member's collegiate achievements. Julia Stamps Mallon was named an all-American at Stanford six times, not twice.

PARROTT--Thomas A., of Washington, DC and Fishers Island, NY, after 92 wonderful years, passed away peacefully June 14, 2007. He was with the CIA for 24 years and served as Assistant Deputy Director for National Intelligence Programs. Earlier in his career with the CIA he was the Deputy Chief of the Soviet Division of the Clandestine Services, a Base Chief in Germany, Assistant to the Director of Central Intelligence, Allen Dulles, and held an unprecedented assignment to the White House that included the period of the Cuban Missile Crisis. During WWII, Mr. Parrott served with the Army in North Africa and Italy. He was awarded the Soldier's Medal (the Army's highest decoration for heroism not in actual combat), the Legion of Merit, and honored by Italy with the Order of Sts. Maurizio and Lazarus (at the time the oldest order of nobility in Europe). He retired from the Army Reserve as a Colonel. After retiring from the CIA in 1973, he was active in many charitable and community organizations. He served on the Board of the Washington Hospital Center as Vice-Chairman, was one of five founding directors of the National Rehabilitation Hospital, was an officer of the Citizens Association of Georgetown, served on the boards of the Foundation for the Preservation of Historic Georgetown, the Hospice Care of D.C. and was on the original Board of the City Tavern Club. He graduated from Princeton University in 1936 and had lived in Washington, D.C. since 1949. Tom Parrott is survived by his loving wife of 67 years, Barbara, of Washington, his daughters, Cynthia MacNair and Susan Crary, his son-in-law Horace Crary, Jr. and three loving grandchildren, Gardner, Nicholas and Ian Crary, all of NYC. His son, Tommy, predeceased him. Tom Parrott's sharp mind, wit, loyalty and love will be deeply missed. Services will be held at Arlington National Cemetery September 28 at 11:00am. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Rehabilitation Hospital, Attention: Communication & Development, 102 Irving St. NW, Washington, DC 20010.

Freud Painting Sets Record A painting by Lucian Freud sold for $15.5 million at auction in London on Wednesday night, a record price for a work by a living European artist, the BBC reported. The painting, a 1992 portrait of Mr. Freud's friend Bruce Bernard (a picture editor of The Sunday Times magazine in London who died in 2000), was part of a sale of postwar and contemporary art at Christie's from the collection of Elaine and Melvin Merians, New Yorkers with a taste for School of London artists like Mr. Freud, Frank Auerbach and Francis Bacon. The price, which includes commission, far exceeded Christie's estimate of $9 million to $11 million.

MERMAID PARADE How do hundreds of creatures with no feet march on the Coney Island Boardwalk? Find out tomorrow at 2 p.m. when Coney Island becomes a burlesque Atlantis. The Mermaid Parade, in its 25th year, has become one of New York's annual rites of summer. A lineup of mermaids, Neptunes and freaky sea creatures and underwater musical ensembles are joined by antique cars and motorized floats. The parade route starts at West 10th Street and the Boardwalk, near the parachute jump. It heads along the Boardwalk to West 16th Street and proceeds to and then along Surf Avenue back to West 10th Street, passing such staples as Nathan's, Astroland and the Cyclone roller coaster. There will be 1,500 to 2,000 participants and several hundred thousand spectators, said Dick Zigun, founder of Coney Island U.S.A., a nonprofit group that runs the parade and fancies itself the guardian of the area's culture. The group runs burlesque shows and a sideshow school as well as the Coney Island Tattoo and Motorcycle Festival and the vaunted Creepshow at the Freakshow.

Thomas S. Robertson, a professor of marketing, has been named dean of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, university officials announced. Dr. Robertson, left, is currently the executive faculty director of the Institute for Developing Nations at Emory University in Atlanta. Dr. Robertson taught from 1971 to 1994 at Wharton. He will succeed Patrick Harker, who will become president of the University of Delaware.

In Praise of a Soul Label Isaac Hayes, Booker T & the MGs, Mavis Staples, Eddie Floyd and William Bell will be performing at the Orpheum Theater in Memphis tonight in a 50th-anniversary tribute to Stax, the celebrated Memphis soul and R&B record label that put them -- and many other performers -- on the map. Stax, which was bought by Concord Records when it purchased the Fantasy label three years ago, has been reactivated. Angie Stone and the band Soulive are among the new Stax signings taking part in the concert, a benefit for the Stax Museum of American Soul Music in Memphis.

A parade in Jerusalem in favor of gay rights passed off largely peacefully despite vocal opposition and protests by ultra-Orthodox citizens. The police arrested a man they said was carrying a homemade bomb he said he intended to put along the route. Some 2,500 people marched, according to the police, half the 5,000 that had been expected.

Milton was a retired Lt. Col. in the Army Reserves. Memorial contributions may be made to John's Hopkins Children's Center, 100 N. Charles St., Baltimore, MD 21201, Suburban Hospital Foundation, 8600 Old Georgetown Rd., Bethesda, MD 20814, or Recording for Blind and Dyslexic, National Headquarters, 20 Roszel Rd., Princeton, NJ 08540.

The London Stock Exchange was considering making a bid of $2 billion to acquire Borsa Italiana, the operator of the stock exchange in Milan, two people close to the companies said. The two exchanges discussed a potential merger and were set to continue discussions today, a spokesman for Borsa Italiana said. The spokesman, Alessandro Pavesi, said the proposal from the London exchange is the only one being considered. Both exchanges have fended off takeover approaches in the last year, and a merger might help them avoid a takeover in the future, said Rupak Ghose, an analyst at Credit Suisse in London. ''It is not surprising that the L.S.E. is looking at different alternatives to become larger and hence avoid becoming acquired,'' Mr. Ghose said in a note to investors.

CELEBRATING THE FOURTH To the Editor: It is surprising that ''Where It All Started'' (Ahead, June 15), on Independence Day celebrations, does not mention Bristol, R.I., whose Fourth of July celebration was established in 1785 and is said to be the oldest continuous celebration of its kind in the country. This small town of less than 25,000 people plays host to more than 100,000 visitors lining the streets for its patriotic parade. The celebration includes a visit from a Navy ship, concerts, a drum and bugle corps competition, fireworks and other festivities.

A sports article on April 8 about Michigan State's 3-1 victory over Boston College to capture the N.C.A.A. men's ice hockey championship misidentified the player who scored the only goal for the Eagles. It was Brian Boyle -- not Brock Bradford, who had the assist. The reporter pointed out the error this week.
HERSHMAN--Jerome (Jerry) died on June 19, 2007. His contributions to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and National Music Association will always be appreciated.

A total of 97,207 people were killed or disappeared in the 1992-1995 war in Bosnia, according to a three-year study by the Sarajevo-based Research and Documentation Center. The center, which describes itself as independent and nonpartisan, said it had names for all the dead cited in its study. It said that close to two-thirds of the casualties, 64,036, were Bosnian Muslims, followed by Serbs, 24,905, and Croats, 7,788, while 478 were of other nationalities. Almost half of the casualties died in the first year of the war. Of the total dead, 57,523 were directly involved in the war and 39,684 were civilians.

The Civil Guard said it had found a car loaded with explosives in southern Spain. A spokesman said in a telephone interview that the car was found in Ayamonte, a popular tourist area close to the border with Portugal, and that the explosives were apparently in the process of being transported and were not rigged to a detonator. The radio station Cadena Ser put the amount at 220 pounds. The paramilitary Basque group ETA formally ended a 15-month cease-fire on June 5 and put Spain on the alert for possible terrorist attacks, particularly in southern areas frequented by tourists.

The No. 2 official in the Justice Department said Thursday that he told the truth in February when he testified at a Senate hearing that the White House had limited involvement in the dismissal of federal prosecutors, an assertion that proved incorrect. The official, Paul J. McNulty, who is stepping down as deputy attorney general this summer, told a House Judiciary subcommittee that when he testified on Feb. 6 he did not know the extent of the White House role in the ousters, but conceded that his testimony was incomplete.

Woody Allen Gets His Night at the Opera The Los Angeles Opera is going Hollywood. Woody Allen will make his opera debut next year when he directs the final third of Puccini's ''Trittico,'' scheduled to open the company's 2008-9 season. Mr. Allen will direct ''Gianni Schicchi,'' the comic portion of ''Il Trittico,'' and William Friedkin, the Oscar-winning director of ''The French Connection'' and ''The Exorcist,'' will return to the opera stage to direct the first two parts, ''Il Tabarro'' and ''Suor Angelica.'' Mr. Allen's longtime collaborator, Santo Loquasto, will design the production, and James Conlon, the company's music director, will conduct. Also included in the Los Angeles Opera's 2008-9 season will be the United States premiere of ''The Fly,'' by Howard Shore, to be directed by David Cronenberg, who made the 1986 horror film based on the 1957 George Langelaan short story. EDWARD WYATT

A little while ago, a national study authorized by Congress found that abstinence education programs don't work. That gave liberals a chance to feel superior because it turns out that preaching traditional morality to students doesn't change behavior. But in this realm, nobody has the right to feel smug. American schools are awash in moral instruction -- on sex, multiculturalism, environmental awareness and so on -- and basically none of it works. Sex ed doesn't change behavior. Birth control education doesn't produce measurable results. The fact is, schools are ineffectual when it comes to values education. You can put an adult in front of a classroom or an assembly, and that adult can emit words, but don't expect much impact.

He is survived by his wife Barbara Friedman; son, Michael Friedman; son and daughterin-law, Andrew and Loretta Friedman; daughter, Grace Sardonicus; brother, Lawrence Friedman; sister, Leona Rutter; and his grandchildren, Camillo Friedman; Anthony Friedman; Satya, Surya, Anjaneya, Ariel, Jasper and Tao Sardonicus. Funeral services will be held at 1:30pm, June 22, at Roberts Funeral Home, Ocala, FL. Burial will be in Bushnell National Cemetery in Florida. Memorial contributions may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

He is recovering from a blood-clot scare last season, and is not pitching now; he is not out of the game because he ''appears to have run out of employers to disappoint'' with his statistically below-average pitching.

The police yesterday continued their investigation of the sexual assault of an off-duty police officer who was attacked at knifepoint by a masked man in her Brooklyn apartment on Wednesday night. The woman, whose name, age and rank were not released, had just gotten off work when, shortly after 6:30 p.m., she was attacked by a man who investigators believe broke into her Bay Ridge apartment through a rear window where an air-conditioner had been installed, the police said. The man grabbed her from behind, sexually assaulted her and then fled, possibly through the same window, the police said. The woman called another officer from her precinct to report the attack. It was not known if she knew her attacker or if he knew she was an officer.
To the Editor: Re ''The Supreme Court's Bonus Babies,'' by David Lat (Op-Ed, June 18):

McDEVITT--Janet. On June 21, 2007, at the Cabrini Hospice. Jan was an employee of the Museum of Modern Art. Loving sister of Lester McDevitt. She is also survived by her many loving friends. Donations may be made to the Cabrini Hospice or National Public Radio.

Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about the defense editor of the newspaper Haaretz who was considered the dean of Israeli military correspondents misstated his surname at one point. As the article noted, he was Zeev Schiff and in subsequent references he should have been identified as Mr. Schiff, not Mr. Haaretz.

LOEWENSTEIN--Martha J., passed away on June 4th, 2007. Daughter of the late beloved parents Frieda and Solomon; sister of her deceases special scholar Norma Loewenstein Drabkin and Regina Loewenstein; survived by surrogate daughter Patricia Arrington and a number of cousins. Her career embraced primary responsibility for administrative procedures at The American Committee of the Weizmann Institute of Science, proceeded by similar activities at the consulate general of Israel, The Jewish Welfare Board of Hadassah. Burial will be a private ceremony. Memorial will be held on June 28th at 5:30pm at Dorot on 171 W. 85th St., NYC.

Music at the Met Museum Chamber concerts programmed by Itzhak Perlman and an extensive piano recital series are among the highlights of the 54th concert season at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It opens Sept. 30 with Simon Trpceski, the first of 11 pianists in the PianoForte series, also featuring Ivan Moravec, Hélène Grimaud and Gabriela Montero. Mr. Perlman will perform in three concerts with students of the Perlman Music Program; the museum says this is the first New York chamber series he has conceived and programmed. Other performances include a violin series with Janine Jansen and Hilary Hahn; the Beaux-Arts Trio's final New York concert; and Patti Smith, with poems and songs ''for the young at heart'' by Hans Christian Andersen, William Blake, A. A. Milne and Rudyard Kipling.

How does ''Mayor Gotbaum'' strike your ear? You never know. You just might have to get used to the sound of that. We are referring to Betsy Gotbaum. She is the city's public advocate, a job that has all the glamour of a stop sign and about as much power as a blackout. There are students of municipal government who would lose not a minute's sleep were the position to disappear, convinced as they are that it richly deserves the obscurity it often enjoys.
To the Editor: ''Millions of Missing Birds, Vanishing in Plain Sight,'' by Verlyn Klinkenborg (Editorial Observer, June 19), stirs me to share an experience and a question that follows from it.

NEW YORK ASIAN FILM FESTIVAL Just weeks before it was ready to rip, the inspiring and often inspired New York Asian Film Festival lost one of its main sponsors. The event's organizers responded to this bummer news the way you would expect cinephiles partial to fists of fury and killer action to react: ''We will not let this festival die.'' Happily for New York, they're sticking to their blazing metaphoric guns. Starting tonight one of the city's most flavorful events will be unleashing myriad feature-length and short films from China, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Thailand and Pakistan, the last represented by what's being billed as that country's first ''gore flick.'' In this genre-oriented festival, the Hong Kong action master Johnnie To (here with his sizzling gangster smack-down ''Exiled'') and that art-house cult by way of Korea, Park Chanwook (''I'm a Cyborg, But That's Okay''), earn pride of place alongside less-familiar names like Tetsuya Nakashima, from Japan (''Memories of Matsuko,'' above), and Ryu Seung-wan, from Korea (''City of Violence''). In the nearly unclassifiable pop-melodrama ''Memories of Matsuko,'' a lovely, lonely soul endures disgrace, murder, prostitution and one wretched boyfriend after another by disappearing into a kaleidoscopic fantasyland of her own feverish imagination, one as influenced by MTV as by ''The Wizard of Oz.'' Very bad things also await the five teenage boys who grow up at cross purposes in ''City of Violence,'' which combines the usual pulp basics (violence and sentimentality) with some rock-em, sock-em fight choreography. (Through July 8, IFC Center, 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village, 212-924-7771, $11; Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan, 212-715-1258, $10; subwaycinema.com) MANOHLA DARGIS

A sports article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by the tennis player Guillermo Coria against a nutritional supplement company that he blames for his positive steroid test referred incorrectly to an arrangement in professional basketball designed to ensure safe and pure supplements for athletes. The N.B.A. players union, not the league itself, has such a deal with a supplement maker.

With Senate leaders preparing to give the immigration bill a second shot this week, the topic dominates this Sunday's breakfast menu. ABC's "This Week with George Stephanopoulos," for instance has Senator Edward M. Kennedy (as in "McCain-Kennedy"), one of the staunchest proponents of the compromise immigration legislation. Senator Jeff Sessions, an ardent foe of the bill, will also be there.

A leafy green avenue of trees leads to the private entrance to the estate, which comprises a rustic farmhouse set in approximately 29 hectares of land.

Barry Bonds is now six shy of Hank Aaron’s record, but his home run was only a footnote in the victory for the Yankees, who got four hits from Alex Rodriguez.

Barry Bonds and Alex Rodriguez may never be easy for baseball fans to embrace, but they showed Friday night that they will always have one another.

Corrections: For the Record

An article in The Arts on Thursday about the new Wellcome Collection museum in London referred imprecisely to the work of the Nobel Prize winner James D. Watson, who led the inaugural ceremony. He was a discoverer of the structure of DNA, not of DNA itself.

An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday, about two musicals being performed this weekend by the Our Time Theater Company, misidentified the site. It is the Cherry Lane Theater, at 38 Commerce Street in the West Village — not the Theater Studio on East 24th Street in Manhattan, where the company was originally scheduled to perform.

An article in Weekend on June 15 about a deal between the Menier Chocolate Factory theater company in London and the producer Bob Boyett that gives Mr. Boyett first rights to transfer the company’s shows to Broadway referred incompletely to the transfer of the company’s revival of “Sunday in the Park With George” next winter. The Broadway revival will be a Roundabout Theater Company production. Boyett Ostar Productions, Mr. Boyett’s producing partnership, will be an associate producer; it is not bringing over the revival by itself.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about the weekly Billboard album chart misstated last week’s ranking of Paul McCartney’s new album, “Memory Almost Full,” which was No. 3 this week. It was No. 3 last week as well, not the top seller. (The No. 1 album last week was T-Pain’s “Epiphany.”).

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about a decision by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to quit the Republican Party — an announcement that further fueled speculation about his plans for a presidential run in 2008 — referred imprecisely in some copies to a constitutional requirement for presidential candidates. The Constitution says only that the president must be “a natural-born citizen,”’ not that the president must have been born in the United States. The provision is generally regarded as barring naturalized citizens, not those born elsewhere to American parents.

A picture caption on Thursday about a search for missing people after flash floods in the Catskill town of Colchester gave an incorrect surname from The Associated Press in some copies for a firefighter carrying a child to safety, and it misstated his title in other copies. He is Steve Chesney, not Hecht, and he is the fire chief of Roscoe, N.Y., not an assistant fire chief.

An article on Wednesday about a warehouse fire that killed nine firefighters in Charleston, S.C., misspelled the surname of a man who was rescued from the building. He is Jonathan Tyrrell III, not Tyrell.

The TV Sports column yesterday, about coverage of the Tour de France by the cable network Versus amid the doping scandals in cycling, misstated the surname of a race commentator in some copies. He is Paul Sherwen, not Sherwood.

The suspended Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones surrendered in Las Vegas and posted $20,000 bail on felony charges resulting from a strip club melee that preceded a triple shooting. Jones and two companions are accused of attacking and threatening employees inside the Minxx strip club during N.B.A. All-Star Weekend shortly before someone opened fire outside the club and wounded three people, including a bouncer who was paralyzed.

The cars of the defending Nascar champion Jimmie Johnson and the series points leader Jeff Gordon failed inspection yesterday at Infineon Raceway in Sonoma, Calif. Each driver was barred from all activity, including qualifying. Nascar said the No. 24 and No. 48 Chevrolets, both owned by Hendrick Motorsports, had modifications to the front fenders that were deemed illegal during morning inspection. The Hendrick crews will be allowed to fix them and they can race in tomorrow’s Toyota/Save Mart 350, although they will have to start from the rear of the 43-car field. Gordon is the defending race winner.

A former aide to Rutgers women’s basketball coach C. Vivian Stringer has been sentenced to three years in prison for stealing from the coach.Dawn Weniger, 35, of South Brunswick, N.J., took $75,760 from Stringer’s credit cards and bank accounts to buy clothing and pay for other personal expenses, according to authorities.Weniger became Stringer’s administrative assistant in 1999 and was later named director of basketball operations. She was fired in 2005 after Stringer discovered the thefts, the authorities said.

Tyson Gay sliced through a headwind for a 9.84-second clocking last night in Indianapolis in the most one-sided 100-meter victory at the U.S. track and field championships since electronic timing began 32 years ago.Gay broke the meet record in the second-fastest 100 ever run into a headwind. The only one faster was Maurice Greene’s 9.82 at the 2001 world championships. Gay ran into a wind of 1.12 m.p.h., Greene’s was 0.45 m.p.h. Gay’s time was easily the world’s fastest this year.

Arizona police pulled over Chicago Bears defensive tackle Tank Johnson early yesterday morning, the latest legal trouble for a player already suspended for the first eight games of the 2007 season. The police in Gilbert, Ariz., pulled Johnson over at 3:30 a.m. and cited him for “being impaired to the slightest degree,” Sgt. Andrew Duncan, told The Chicago Tribune in a story posted on its Web site. Johnson had been going 40 miles an hour in a 25 m.p.h. zone when the officer “made observations that led him to believe Johnson was impaired,” Duncan said. Earlier this month, Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, suspended Johnson for eight games for violating the league’s toughened personal conduct policy.

The United States will be without the regular starters Landon Donovan, DaMarcus Beasley, Clint Dempsey and Carlos Bocanegra when it plays a full-strength Argentina next week at Copa América in Venezuela. Coach Bob Bradley went almost exclusively with young players in compiling his roster for the 12-nation championship. Of the 22 players, 16 have made 10 or fewer appearances for the United States team. Fourteen are under age 25. The military hearings used to decide whether to hold Guantánamo detainees relied on incomplete and outdated information, screened by officers who were under intense pressure from their commanders to conclude that the detainees should be held, a reserve military intelligence officer and lawyer who had a role in the process said in an affidavit filed yesterday in a federal appeals court. The sworn affidavit, the first from an insider who is critical of the Pentagon process, was portrayed by detainees' lawyers as a crack in the military's disciplined defense of the procedures used to declare detainees properly held as ''enemy combatants.''

KOVACS--George. We were graced by your spirit, humor and generosity and will carry your memory always. The Board, Staff, Fellows and Alumni of The TEAK Fellowship KOVACS--George, a caring man, passed away peacefully on Friday morning. His kindness and humor will be greatly missed and never forgotten, by his wife, Barbara; his children, Peter, Liz and Ruth; his grandchildren, Jamie, Cathy and Joe, and all who knew him. He founded George Kovacs Lighting over 50 years ago. Under his leadership this innovative company transformed the lamp industry. Donations may be made to the TEAK Fellowship. He and Barbara have put their hearts and souls into this organization that gives many young people a chance to succeed. Service Sunday, 2pm at the ''Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

FREILICH--Ruth, age 101, the Matriarch. Died June 21. Mom to Ted, gramma to Chuck, Shani, Dani, Yael, James and Tim and big gramma to the dozen greatgrandchildren. Private family burial. Shiva Sunday, Monday at Ted's. Donations UJA.

It was just an organizational meeting for Senator Barack Obama's New York volunteers, but the gathering this month jammed every pew of a church in the East Village, and the crowd spilled over into not one but two overflow rooms. All told, 710 people showed up, even though the closest they would get to Mr. Obama, the Illinois Democrat and presidential candidate, that night would be to view a campaign screening of a biographical DVD. They cheered wildly anyway. Many had already formed their own volunteer groups in New York: Brooklyn for Barack, NYC4Obama, the Audacity of Park Slope. Quite a few already had Web sites, neatly designed logos, newsletters and regular meetings.

Fifteen former ticket takers at the Eiffel Tower were given suspended prison sentences and fines for embezzling $940,000 from ticket sales. The company that manages the Eiffel Tower discovered the scam in February 2002 after receiving an anonymous letter from one of 27 employees at the ticket office.

The TV Sports column yesterday, about coverage of the Tour de France by the cable network Versus amid the doping scandals in cycling, misstated the surname of a race commentator in some copies. He is Paul Sherwen, not Sherwood.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about the weekly Billboard album chart misstated last week's ranking of Paul McCartney's new album, ''Memory Almost Full,'' which was No. 3 this week. It was No. 3 last week as well, not the top seller. (The No. 1 album last week was T-Pain's ''Epiphany.'')

To the Editor: In ''Can a Vision Save All of Africa?'' (Talking Business column, June 16), Joe Nocera highlighted the importance of sustainable projects. While his emphasis on long-term thinking is on target, his concerns about malaria as the ''disease du jour'' should not overshadow the reality that significant accomplishments are being made in the fight against malaria.
To the Editor: In ''A Maid's Escape Plan in Malaysia'' (photo, June 18), you featured a domestic worker in Malaysia escaping an abusive employer through a 15th-story window.

To the Editor: The blood extraction practices described in ''In the Amazon, Giving Blood but Getting Nothing'' (front page, June 20) amount to taking advantage of unsophisticated people in the developing world for the benefit and material gain of individuals and companies in the developed West.

RAND--Rita, died peacefully on June 22, 2007 at her home in New York City. Born in Kansas City, MO in 1918, and raised in Tulsa, OK she attended Tulsa Central High and Goucher College. She is predeceased by two husbands, Ralph Gore and Alfred Rand and her sister Marilyn Krulwich. She is survived by her sister Josephine ''Tubby'' Stayman, her two daughters Sara Stone and Laura Ross, and a stepson Kenneth Rand, seven grandchildren, and five great - grandchildren. A strong, courageous, vibrant, and spirited woman, who loved her family and her friends, she will be deeply missed. Funeral services at 10am on Sunday, June 24, 2007 at Park Avenue Synagogue in the Appleman Chapel, 87th St. and Madison Ave. The family will be receiving visitors Sunday - Tuesday. Contributions in her memory may be made to New York Service for the Handicapped and Park Avenue Synagogue. RAND--Rita. The Board of Directors and Staff of the New York Service for the Handicapped - Camp Oak hurst are deeply saddened at the death of Rita Rand, a loyal and devoted Board Member since 1965. To her family go our heartfelt condolences. Marilyn Friedman, President Marvin A. Raps, Exec. Dir.

John Barrasso, a Republican state legislator and an orthopedic surgeon, was appointed by Gov. Dave Freudenthal to replace Senator Craig Thomas, who died June 4. Mr. Barrasso, 54, a two-term state senator, was one of three contenders whose names had been submitted to the governor by the Wyoming Republican Party. The governor, a Democrat, was required under Wyoming law to select a candidate from the same party as Mr. Thomas, a Republican. Mr. Barrasso's appointment takes effect immediately. Although Mr. Thomas's term was set to end in 2012, Mr. Barrasso will face a special election in 2008 to keep the interim Senate seat. He has indicated that he intends to run.

A picture caption on Thursday about a search for missing people after flash floods in the Catskill town of Colchester gave an incorrect surname from The Associated Press in some copies for a firefighter carrying a child to safety, and it misstated his title in other copies. He is Steve Chesney, not Hecht, and he is the fire chief of Roscoe, N.Y., not an assistant fire chief.

HIS ideas and opinions aside, nobody has done more than Lawrence Lessig to help people understand the profound effects of technology on the laws governing intellectual property. He is, as Wired magazine called him in 2002, ''the Elvis of cyberlaw'' (wired.com). But now, Mr. Lessig, a professor at Stanford Law School, is leaving the building, or at least the room. ''I have decided to shift my academic work, and soon, my activism, away from the issues that have consumed me for the last 10 years,'' he announced this week on his blog (lessig.org/blog) and last week in a speech at the iCommons Summit in Croatia (available via youtube.com).

IT has been a long, sometimes painful process, but over the years, I've learned to separate from my books. Years ago, each one was a little gem that I wanted sitting on my bookshelf even if I had no intention of reading it again. If I lent one to a friend, it was with great hesitation, with my name prominently scrawled inside the cover and after a few months I would start dropping gentle reminders.

Witnessing the draw at Wimbledon feels like an hour at the bingo parlor. Blank grids are distributed. Coins with numbers, each representing a player in the field, are drawn from a basket. A man at a microphone calls out the results, and onlookers quietly fill in the blank spots. A screen on the wall tracks it all. Results are not completely random, of course. In men's and women's singles, the 32 seeded players are spread across specific portions of the grids, ensuring that the top two, for instance, can not meet until the final. Once the seeded players are positioned, the 96 other names are placed around them.
CECHINI--Vincent. 6/23/06. ''Soar through the skies.'' Forever, Diane

Britain's largest labor union urged ''concerted and sustained pressure upon Israel,'' including ''an economic, cultural, academic and sporting boycott,'' to force its withdrawal from Palestinian areas. The union, called Unison and grouping 1.3 million public service employees, also called on the British government to oppose the sale of arms to Israel. The calls were made in a motion approved at Unison's annual conference in Brighton demanding the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza with its capital in Jerusalem The resolution followed similar calls for pressure on Israel from British labor unions representing journalists and college teachers. British and American Jewish organizations condemned the latest boycott call.

To the Editor: ''Off the Street and in an Apartment, but Unable to Escape Homelessness'' (news article, June 11), while riveting, perpetuates an antiquated stereotype of homeless people as beyond help and even desirous of remaining homeless.

The mayor's lips are pursed. The tuxedo-and-gown dinner crowd in the Pierre hotel ballroom has fallen still, just a few spoons rattling along the rims of dessert plates. At the very front of the room, the spotlight has settled on Michael R. Bloomberg. Someone is reading an award citation for his work as mayor. Mr. Bloomberg oscillates. He bounces on his toes, nods his head. His eyes appear to be pinned open. Though he has not uttered a word, Mr. Bloomberg's body seems to all but scream: Get me out of here. It is easy to watch him going through the motions of the routine antics of public officialdom -- the giving of plaques, the issuing of proclamations, the receiving of medals -- and believe that he shows up only because, somehow, if just through body language, he can sneer at the ceremony. That the soul of a punk-rocker has been wrapped in custom-tailored suits.

Stevie Wonder, Aretha Franklin and Carlos Santana said on Thursday that they would participate in a concert to raise money to build a memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the National Mall in Washington, The Associated Press reported. Quincy Jones, Russell Simmons and Tommy Hilfiger are organizing the so-called Dream Concert, set for Sept. 18 at Radio City Music Hall. Other scheduled performers include Robin Thicke, Bebe Winans, Cece Winans and Jessye Norman, with Al Roker to appear as a presenter. The foundation working to build the memorial has raised $79.5 million of the $100 million needed to complete and maintain it. The memorial will occupy a space on the Tidal Basin between the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials.

MOUNT HOOD, Ore. Most Americans don't own a summer home on Cape Cod, or a McMansion in the Rockies, but they have this birthright: an area more than four times the size of France. If you're a citizen, you own it -- about 565 million acres.

Diplomats from the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations -- what is known as the quartet -- will meet Tuesday in Jerusalem, a day after Israeli and Palestinian leaders meet with leaders of Egypt and Jordan at the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheik, Russian, Israeli and United Nations officials said. Both meetings are being held to discuss the impact of the seizure of power in the Gaza Strip by Hamas on the region and on the Israeli-Palestinian relationship. At the meeting in Egypt, Israel is expected to offer to release to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and his new Fatah-led emergency government much of the Palestinian tax money it refused to pass on to a Hamas-led government.

The Superman Tower of Power ride at Six Flags Kentucky Kingdom outside Louisville malfunctioned Thursday, severing both feet of a 13-year-old girl, state safety officials and a park spokeswoman said. As patrons of the ride hurtled toward the ground at more than 50 miles per hour, a frayed cable snapped and cut off the girl's feet, said Bill Clary, a spokesman for the Kentucky Division of Regulation and Inspection. The ride was immediately shut down, as were similar rides at three other Six Flags parks, said the Six Flags spokeswoman, Wendy Goldberg. Mr. Clary said inspectors would remain on the scene until they understood what had happened and how to ensure that it not happen again.
HINES--Joyce Rose. In loving memory of our dearest, beautiful sister. You are with us in our hearts -always. Jane and Mike

Günter Grass, the Nobel Prize-winning German writer, will give his first reading in the United States of his memoir, ''Peeling the Onion,'' at the 92nd Street Y Unterberg Poetry Center on Monday evening at 8. Mr. Grass, 79, will read passages in German, and the actor Michael Stuhlbarg will read them in English. Afterward, the Israeli writer and journalist Amos Elon will interview Mr. Grass, who came under fire last year for his belated admission that he had served in Hitler's elite Waffen-SS, despite having long claimed to have been an ordinary soldier. Some critics accused Mr. Grass of making the revelation at that time in hopes that it would increase the sales of his memoir. The English translation of the book is being published in the United States this month.

EVANS--Bob. The Rogosin Institute's Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of Bob Evans. Mr. Evans was a significant benefactor and friend who helped advance The Institute's research in diabetes and cancer. He was a caring and generous human being whose dedication to improving health care will always be remembered. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the entire family, friends and all those at Bob Evans Farms.

CUNNINGHAM--Thomas Edward, born Brooklyn, NY. Died April 27, 2007 at Roscommon Hospital, Ireland. Funeral private at Clonbonny Cemetery, Lanesborough County, Roscommon. Survived by his wife Maeve, his brother William and family.

Chitoshi Akizuki wasn't sure whether he would travel from San Jose to San Francisco this weekend to watch Hideki Matsui and the Yankees play the San Francisco Giants. But he will be there in spirit. He always is.

An article in Weekend on June 15 about a deal between the Menier Chocolate Factory theater company in London and the producer Bob Boyett that gives Mr. Boyett first rights to transfer the company's shows to Broadway referred incompletely to the transfer of the company's revival of ''Sunday in the Park With George'' next winter. The Broadway revival will be a Roundabout Theater Company production. Boyett Ostar Productions, Mr. Boyett's producing partnership, will be an associate producer; it is not bringing over the revival by itself.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about a decision by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to quit the Republican Party -- an announcement that further fueled speculation about his plans for a presidential run in 2008 -- referred imprecisely in some copies to a constitutional requirement for presidential candidates. The Constitution says only that the president must be ''a natural-born citizen,''' not that the president must have been born in the United States. The provision is generally regarded as barring naturalized citizens, not those born elsewhere to American parents.

An article in The Arts on Thursday about the new Wellcome Collection museum in London referred imprecisely to the work of the Nobel Prize winner James D. Watson, who led the inaugural ceremony. He was a discoverer of the structure of DNA, not of DNA itself.

Service Sunday, 10am at Wien & Wien, Hackensack, NJ. For information, 800322-0533.

An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday, about two musicals being performed this weekend by the Our Time Theater Company, misidentified the site. It is the Cherry Lane Theater, at 38 Commerce Street in the West Village -- not the Theater Studio on East 24th Street in Manhattan, where the company was originally scheduled to perform.

The byline for the Wednesday crossword puzzle misstated the given name of one of the creators. It was constructed by Bonnie L. Gentry -- not Bobbie -- and Victor Fleming.

WOLF--Philip A., on June 20. Husband of Thelma, father of Roberta, Edward and Ann, father - in - law of Richard Goldsteinand Betty Ginsburg, grandfather of Leah, Sarah and Zena Wolf, friend, colleague and cousin to many. Funeral service Sunday at 11:00am at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre. He will be remembered as a kind and honorable man. WOLF--Philip/d. With great sorrow we mourn the loss of our friend and associate, Phil Wolf. At Muss Development for over 22 years, and prior there to, Phil was instrumental in the planning and construction of numerous projects in and about New York City. His most notable achievement resulted in the development of Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza and The New York Marriot at The Brooklyn Bridge. HELFAND--Margaret, The Board and staff of the American Institute of Architects New York Chapter are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our friend and colleague Margaret Helfand, FAIA. Margaret served as President of the AIA New York Chapter in 2001 and was instrumental in creating the Center for Architecture. As co-chair of New York New Visions, she led the AIAs Lower Manhattan assistance efforts. A Fellow of the AIA and winner of the prestigious Rome Prize, at the time of her death she was co-chair of the Center for Architecture Advisory Council. She was loved and respected by all and will be sorely missed.

Germany faces a heightened threat of terrorist attacks because of its military involvement in Afghanistan, government security officials here said Friday. The danger level, they warned, was comparable to the months before the 9/11 attacks in the United States. Three German residents, believed to be radical Islamic militants, were arrested in Pakistan in recent days, according to the German Federal Criminal Police. Officials here suspect them of traveling to the border region between Pakistan and Afghanistan to enter terrorist training camps.

BEAR--Charles B. The Board and Staff of The New 42nd Street are deeply saddened to learn of the death of our beloved Founding Board Member Charles B. Bear. He helped forge this organization, providing enlightened guidance and spirited encouragement. The Charley Bear Green Room in our Rehearsal Studios celebrates his concern and sensitivity for the well being of artists. Marian S. Heiskell, Chairman Cora Cahan, President

Norman Hackerman, a noted chemist and a former president of both the University of Texas at Austin and Rice University, died June 16 in Temple, Tex. He was 95 and lived in Austin. The cause was heart failure, his son, Stephen, said.

More than 3,000 people, among them French and American intellectuals, anthropologists and social scholars, have signed an online petition protesting France's new Ministry of Immigration, Integration, National Identity and Co-development. The petition, from the Internet-based research center terra.rezo.net, which focuses on issues related to migration, objects to the very idea of the ministry, saying that even its name could foster ''governmental xenophobia leading to stigmatize the foreigner as a problem, a risk, and possibly a threat to integrity or national identity.''

Seth Schiesel, who played Manhunt 2, a violent video game that has been effectively killed by ratings boards, says he found the Adult Only rating from the Entertainment Software Rating Board, an independent industry group, "entirely reasonable." But after watching "Saw II," "Hostel" and "Saw III," he also writes that "movies seem to be way ahead of games in delivering top-notch gore."
I had some time tonight to respond to comments. Here are some of the topics addressed:

It's 4 a.m. and I've got the cruise control set to 85 m.p.h. I'm listening to Black Rebel Motorcycle Club, my new favorite band, and swigging Dr. Pepper the way farmers down in Columbia chew on cocoa leaves to wake themselves up. Rolling the window down doesn't help any, either - the warm breeze coming in is soft as a downy pillow. I'm crossing over the Tehachapi Pass on Highway 58 out of Bakersfield, a windy old road lit only by the headlights of my car. By dawn I'll be passing through Joshua Tree National Forest, leaving California behind for the bright lights of Las Vegas. Of course, every one of those Vegas light bulbs will be turned off by the time I get there. The remnants of last night's light will have left the earth's thin atmosphere and pushed out toward Venus.

At 15, Donald Young was the youngest player to reach the top spot in junior tennis. This spring, just as he was about to turn 18, he was No. 335 in the world. Will the future of American tennis ever get here?
The United States retained the CONCACAF Gold Cup in stunning fashion Sunday, by rallying from a 1-0 deficit to defeat Mexico in a pulsating match at Soldier Field in Chicago.
American commanders pointed to a variety of problems with the Iraqi forces, including a shortage of trained troops and a lack of basic supplies.
Treasury chief Gordon Brown replaced Tony Blair as leader of the governing Labor Party on Sunday.
Ali Hassan al-Majid, known as Chemical Ali, oversaw a campaign that killed tens of thousands of Kurds in the 1980s. Two others were also sentenced to death today.

Ricky Hatton landed a left hook to the body in the fourth round last night in Las Vegas, dropping Jose Luis Castillo to one knee and ending what had been a brawl between the world’s top 140-pounders. Hatton remained undefeated in 43 fights and retained his International Boxing Organization light-welterweight title.
An 18-year-old wanted in the fatal shootings of three young men in front of a Brooklyn apartment building this month has surrendered to the police.
Freshman pitcher Jorge Reyes held North Carolina to three runs in six and a third innings, putting Oregon State in position to win the title on Sunday night.

On Friday night, the BMX dirt bike athlete Stephen Murray was injured while attempting a double backflip. He was taken to a hospital for surgery and was in critical but stable condition.

Sanya Richards failed to make the 400-meter team for the world championships yesterday, finishing fourth in the event on a damp track at the United States track and field championships in Indianapolis. The loss broke a string of 18 outdoor victories in the 400 for Richards. Dee Dee Trotter won the 400 in a personal-best 49.64 seconds. Natasha Hastings was second in a college-record 49.84 and Mary Wineberg third at 50.24. Trotter came from third on the final turn to pull away.In the men’s 400, Angelo Taylor edged LaShawn Merritt at the finish. Taylor, the Olympic champion in the 400 hurdles, won at 44.05 to Merritt’s 44.06.

The onetime Olympic champion Marion Jones, her career shadowed by doping suspicions, says in court documents that she is deep in debt, The Los Angeles Times reported yesterday. Citing recent court records, the newspaper said that Jones claimed she lost a $2.5 million home in North Carolina to bank foreclosure last year. Jones has “total liquid assets throughout the world” of about $2,000, according to her deposition in her breach-of-contract lawsuit against the veteran track coach Dan Pfaff, The Times said.
Senator Barack Obama said that the religious right had “hijacked” faith by exploiting issues like abortion, same-sex marriage and school prayer.
After deals with ABC and NBC fell through last week, Paris Hilton will now give her first post-jail interview to Larry King on CNN on Wednesday night.

Kei Igawa’s performance for the first four innings on Friday showed Yankees Manager Joe Torre enough to give Igawa more starts.
Three children died, trapped in the wreckage of a car, after their mother crashed as she was being chased by police.
A suburban Chicago man was charged with eight counts of first-degree murder after being found shot near the bodies of his wife and children.
A federal judge appointed by Ronald Reagan said that it was a mistake to let the executive branch alone decide which people to spy on in security cases.
Eight American servicemen and one British soldier were reported Saturday to have been killed in Iraq, bringing the four-day death toll to at least 25.

If Taiwan is to participate in the 2008 Olympic torch relay, it will be on Beijing’s terms. Beijing Olympic organizers gave no hint yesterday that they would negotiate with Taiwan over the politically sensitive issue.The route proposed by Beijing organizers has the torch arriving in Taiwan from Vietnam on April 30, 2008, and going to China-controlled Hong Kong and Macau. Many in Taiwan have pushed for a route that takes the torch through Taiwan via Asian countries other than China.

I read with interest Paul Tough’s article (The Money Issue, June 10). The criticism of Ruby Payne’s books as entrenching classism seems, at the very least, to take a partial view of her work and how it may be used. If it is used merely to teach students how to mimic middle-class behaviors, then some of the criticism may be justified. QMy family lives in a co-op at the end of a dead-end street. In the warmer weather, with parental supervision, the children (including my daughter) play outside our building. Some of the other residents in our co-op are unhappy with the noise the children make and are trying to stop them from playing outside the building. One resident has proposed stopping playtime at 7 p.m. I know a co-op can make whatever house rules it wants, but can it ban children from playing on a public street?

Having lost the immunity that protected him from prosecution while in office, Jacques Chirac, the former French president, has refused to testify in a political dirty tricks scandal that sought to discredit Nicolas Sarkozy, the current president. The scandal involved false documentation that seemed to show large sums of money, presumably bribes, passing through secret bank accounts held by Mr. Sarkozy and others. Mr. Sarkozy said at the time that the scandal had been orchestrated to ruin his chances for the presidency.

Contemporary playwrights seldom aim middlebrow, but theaters still need lighter works to balance out their seasons. Hence the recent ransacking of the Broadway attic in search of retro-chic warm-weather wear. The Roundabout, which had a hit two Junes ago with ''The Constant Wife,'' is clearly hoping for another with John van Druten's ''OLD ACQUAINTANCE,'' in which two writers, friends since childhood, find themselves competing over a husband, a daughter and literary success. Though it has not been revived on Broadway since its premiere in 1940, when Jane Cowl played the ''serious'' Village novelist and Peggy Wood the matronly purveyor of trash, it became an echt ''women's picture'' in 1943, with Bette Davis and Miriam Hopkins, and was remade in 1981 as the ecch ''Rich and Famous,'' with Jacqueline Bisset and Candice Bergen. Now the hysterics and bons mots are in the capable hands of Margaret Colin and Harriet Harris. Let the (beautifully dressed) catfight begin! In previews, opens Thursday, American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org; $51.25 to $86.25.

Then Igawa changed into his spikes and went back outside to work in the bullpen on mechanics. Asked later what was bothering him, Igawa said, ''Nothing.''
