In theory, just about anything can be deep-fried, as long as it's reasonably solid and has a high combustion point. And a surprising variety can then be placed in your mouth, though sometimes a little courage is required. As we move into the heart of the county and state fair season, America's deep-fry pioneers are once again pushing the envelope and plundering every aisle at the supermarket in search of fresh items that can be breaded, impaled on a stick and submerged in hot oil.

WHEN shopping for a wedding gift it might be more important to know if some couples prefer Sassicaia or Haut-Brion Blanc, rather than if their dinnerware is patterned or plain white. For wine lovers, a special bottle -- or a case for that matter -- makes a welcome gift. But the wine won't last forever, so why not include an accouterment that can be used for many bottles and years to come? If something in crystal suits the newlyweds, consider a classic gift, like stemware that was designed in the early 1900s and is still in production by the Austrian company that originally made it. For the more modern tabletop there are contemporary pieces that work just as well as their predecessors, like chillers and buckets in shiny stainless steel.

A subway conductor was shot and killed and two of his friends were wounded after a dispute outside a fried chicken restaurant in East Harlem early yesterday, the police and witnesses said. The man who shot them continued firing as he ran from the scene and was himself shot and critically wounded by police gunfire, according to the police. The suspect, Daniel Israel, 20, was in critical but stable condition yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, and both of the other wounded men were treated and released, according to a hospital spokesman and the police.

WHEN the piano rocker Ben Folds was invited to play the opening night of the Boston Pops this spring, the orchestra managers laid down a few ground rules: No swearing; avoid songs with risqué subject matter; don't comment on politics. This was supposed to be a gala evening of Champagne and hors d'oeuvres, not beer and groupies. They warned Mr. Folds that he would not be playing to his typical audience. But then, he said with a laugh, ''I get up there, and there's a fistfight.'' The scuffle that erupted between two concertgoers in the balcony of Symphony Hall on May 9 -- a dispute over noise, it seems -- quickly became fodder for late-night comedians, as well as a widely swapped YouTube clip. Oddly, the brawl didn't take place during Mr. Folds's set but while the orchestra was playing selections from the score to the film ''Gigi.''

Ernie Morris was at Rucker Park in the summer of 1957 when a giant named Chamberlain crushed a team of all-stars that included Cal Ramsey, a rugged rebounding machine from New York University who later played for the Knicks. ''Wilt Chamberlain just about tore the place down,'' Morris recalled from a seat behind a basket at Rucker Park on 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, where he watched last Monday's season opener of the Entertainer's Basketball Classic.

The Twenties were just starting to roar when New York and New Jersey agreed to quit feuding over their mutual waterway, the one with the Statue of Liberty in its center. The two state governments created what is now called the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The treaty gave each governor the right to appoint half the agency's board members. Since then, this strange organizational bird has been running the port, and over time has taken on the Lincoln and Holland tunnels, the George Washington Bridge, various bus terminals, and the Newark, La Guardia, Kennedy and Teterboro airports. The authority, which also owned the World Trade Center, now controls most of the complicated downtown reconstruction project, including the Calatrava PATH station, the memorial, the Freedom Tower and the foundations for other skyscrapers.

THIS month, a jury convicted Khemwatie Bedessie, a 38-year-old day care worker, of raping and sexually abusing a 4-year-old boy she had been babysitting -- crimes she confessed to committing. She faces 25 years in prison. But the basis for her conviction, a videotaped confession, is highly dubious. Indeed the Bedessie case, like so many others before it, points out the need for legislation that would prevent confessions from being the sole reason for a conviction and that would require the police to videotape all parts of an interrogation, including the lead-up to a confession that could have been obtained by coercion.

PARIS ANNETTE MESSAGER remembers feeling lonely when she set out to become an artist in her 20s. The role models before her were all men: not only the greats of the past but also her father, an amateur painter, and her boyfriend, Christian Boltanski, already a heralded new talent when they met in 1970.

ONCE upon a time, the most valuable secret formula in American business was Coca-Cola's. Today, it's Google's master algorithm. In the search business, however, there's no rival to play the role of Pepsi. Yahoo is the closest but still a distant No. 2, and Google earns more profits in a single quarter than Yahoo does in a year. This may have had a bearing on the recent departure of Yahoo's chief technology officer, its chief operating officer and, last week, its chief executive.Microsoft, an even more distant No. 3 in the search competition, can't keep up with Google, even with $28 billion of cash in its pockets at the end of March.

WEST END AVENUE as it labors northward toward 96th Street presents a sort of humdrum tone -- not nearly so distinguished as the blocks below 86th Street, with their bursts of Dutch- and Flemish-style architecture. But the stretch from 96th to 105th Streets is a perfect little laboratory of the design, decay and renewal of the apartment house of the 1910s. According to the 1916 guide ''Renting a Furnished Apartment,'' West End was favored by the prosperous. It described ''expensive baby carriages with their precious freight, rolled along by white-capped maids'' as a common sight there.

MERGER planning has a great deal in common with those big premarriage discussions. In both cases, each side needs to be clear-eyed about the other's strengths and weaknesses, to find areas where the partners can work together and other areas where they could each use some personal space. Just as couples are supposed to talk about financial expectations, companies are expected to project spending needs and growth opportunities. And, of course, there should be a discussion about whether a name change will occur.

Mike Piazza, the popular former Met, will not play for the Oakland Athletics this weekend during their series against the Mets at Shea Stadium. He is on the disabled list with an injured right shoulder. But Piazza made an appearance and received a warm ovation before last night's game, when he took the Athletics lineup card to home plate to meet with the umpires and with Sandy Alomar Sr., the Mets' third-base coach who was performing that duty for the home team.

AFTER a decade in power, Tony Blair steps down as prime minister of the United Kingdom on Wednesday to a chorus of yawns from his countrymen and hisses from most of his Labor Party colleagues. Well, if his former friends and voters don't have a good word for him, I guess it's up to one of us from the Conservative opposition to state the obvious: Tony Blair was a remarkable prime minister.

The halls of Congress have been looking like the floor of the Detroit auto show in recent days. All manner of Detroit executives have found their way to Washington to lobby lawmakers on efforts to raise automobile fuel economy standards.
WHITESIDE--George A., Jr., Ph.D., 72, of Milan, Italy died June 14th in Argentina. Dedicated teacher, Eliot scholar, much loved friend and relative, courageous man.

The Ivy League sure does have some generous professors. First Peter Singer of Princeton tells us that we rich Westerners are morally obligated to give away most of our income to the world's poor. Now Lant Pritchett of Harvard is telling us we should give away our countries!

SOMETHING terrible happened last week in terms of legal protections for stockholders. The terrible thing came out of the present administration, and I simply cannot understand how it could have gotten it so wrong, except on the basis of the machinations of one of our favorite subjects, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary. The loyal reader will recall that a few months ago, I wrote in this space about a stunning decision by the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals involving Enron. In that decision, the judges reversed a federal district court and threw out a case against the investment banks that are accused of helping to make the Enron fraud possible.

The computer appears to be well on its way toward total entertainment domination in the home. As evidence, look at new data from comScore Inc.: more than 70 percent of Internet users streamed video online in March this year. Television, movies, music and more -- it's all there in that box, awaiting full integration. Zippier technology is driving more people to stream video online. A few years ago, if you wanted to see a video, the screen would taunt you with the words ''buffering ... buffering ... buffering ...'' until you lost interest or forgot what you wanted to look at. Now, you are more likely to achieve instant gratification.

LET'S try to get this straight: NBC Universal, which is part of General Electric, was until last Thursday taking a hard look at buying Dow Jones in partnership with Pearson, publisher of The Financial Times. Another potential partner in the deal was the Hearst Corporation, which owns Smart Money magazine in conjunction with Dow Jones and some cable channels with NBC. The News Corporation, meanwhile, whose $5 billion offer to buy Dow Jones prompted the others to look at a rival bid, has also been talking about another possibility: merging its MySpace social networking business into Yahoo, according to two people briefed on the talks. Elsewhere, the News Corporation and NBC Universal are partners in an unnamed new Internet video venture. Confused?

In the land of milk and honey, it is time for peanuts and hot dogs -- the Israel Baseball League makes its debut Sunday night when the Petach Tikva Pioneers play host to the Modi'in Miracle. A high demand for tickets has moved organizers to double the seating capacity at the Yarkon Sports Complex to accommodate a projected 2,000 spectators expected to attend. The game will be televised live in Israel by the local sports channel, whose broadcasters will handle the play-by-play in Hebrew. The game will also be broadcast in English in the United States next Sunday on PBS affiliates in New York, Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles and West Palm Beach, Fla.

MY epiphany came when I told a friend I was going to a chamber music concert, and she -- well-educated, well-heeled, operagoing -- made a throwing-up gesture into her hand. For Gil Morgenstern, a violinist and concert presenter, the epiphany came when an acquaintance informed him that the two most boring words in the English language were ''chamber music.''
To the Editor:

As a librarian who has Lemony Snicket books on the shelves, I would like to make a recommendation to Daniel Handler about what to do with his money (Lives). He obtained this great wealth because children value his humor and storytelling abilities. But his stories would not have been successful if children could not read or have access to books. My advice is to give his money back to where it came from: schools, libraries, literacy campaigns. I am sure there are more than enough needy causes to lighten his wallet, but this narrow criteria would make his decision-making process easier

Gillian Cirila Chiong and Nicholas Mitchell Sahadi were married yesterday in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University. The Rev. Walter Lawrence, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. The couple met at Georgetown, from which they graduated. The bride, 27, is an associate specializing in private banking at JPMorgan Chase & Company in New York. She is a daughter of Jane Ayers Chiong and Winston Rosales Chiong of Newton, Mass. Her father retired as a professor of economics at the University of Massachusetts. The bride's parents own and operate three math and reading after-school centers in Massachusetts.

AS an American journalist based in China, I knew there was a good chance that at some point I'd be detained for pursuing a story. I just never thought I'd be held hostage by a toy factory.

One of the first milestone moments in Rick Hendrick's storied Nascar career came in 1985, when he was a fledgling racecar owner and was handed a $1 million sponsorship check. ''I showed it to my dad and I said, 'Did you ever in your wildest dreams think somebody would pay us a million dollars to race?' '' said Hendrick, who grew up on a tobacco farm in rural Virginia and spent some weekends helping his father race on dirt tracks in the South.

IN November 2005, a group of marines killed 24 Iraqi men, women and children after Sunni Arab insurgents detonated a roadside bomb in Haditha that killed one infantryman and wounded two others. Marine officers assumed the Iraqi deaths occurred during combat and were justified, if regrettable. More than a year later, in December 2006, the Marine Corps charged three enlisted men with murder in those deaths, as well as four officers with dereliction of duty in failing to determine exactly how and why the Iraqis were killed. All have said they did nothing wrong.
RINGLER--Dr. Milton, on your birthday and anniversary, deeply loved, sorely missed, now and forever. Your family

Lowenstein ignores the fact that in order for his hypothetical hamburger establishment to make a profit, somebody working for the company needs to flip the burgers. If we are truly to address inequality, the wage of the hamburger flipper must more closely approximate that of the C.E.O., regardless of the relative levels of education of each. This may mean increasing the minimum wage, encouraging greater unionization or perhaps even establishing limits on the ratios between the percentages of the profit that employees at different levels within a company are receiving as compensation for their labors.

HIGH-DEFINITION television sets grow ever more sophisticated, but the colors on many of the screens are still created the old-time way: with tubes or bulbs that give off white light that is filtered into primary colors and remixed. Now, several manufacturers are replacing these bulbs with lasers and light-emitting diodes, or L.E.D.'s. These lasers and L.E.D.'s do not beam white light, but rather its three basic building blocks: red, green and blue. Beams are emitted in a narrow band of wavelengths very close to those of single, pure colors, giving off the brilliant, saturated red of a blazing sunset or the shimmering, luminous blue of a rainbow.

DOWNSIZING may be a chilling concept nearly everywhere, but not in the workshop of George Luhrs, a machinist in Shoreham, N.Y., with an affinity for the very small. Mr Luhrs has built a single-cylinder engine you could lose in a pocketful of nickels and dimes. The piston of Mr. Luhrs's itsy-bitsy engine rides in a cylinder whose bore is just 1/8-inch across. The engine's stroke -- the distance that the piston travels up and down inside the cylinder -- is only 5/32 of an inch. The spark plug? You could lay seven of them across the face of a dime and still see F.D.R. peeking through.

OF all the tasks in the mortgage industry, few are as hard as the one faced by James Maher. His mission: make title insurance sexy. Mr. Maher, the executive vice president of the American Land Title Association, an industry group representing title insurance companies, said that changes taking effect on many title insurance policies may not reach the sexy threshold but they might just make title insurance interesting enough for borrowers to consider it more carefully.

THE misconduct that cost the prosecutor in the Duke lacrosse case his career certainly seemed to call for a severe penalty: he withheld evidence from the defense, misled the court and inflamed the public. Yet other prosecutors found by the courts to have done similar things have almost never lost their jobs or their licenses to practice law. Even in the aftermath of prosecutorial wrongdoing that helped put innocent men on death row, discipline has been light or nonexistent.
ART Robin Pogrebin

The funeral is 11:00 am on Sunday, June 24, 2007 at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 20955 Biscayne Boulevard, Aventura, Florida 33180, (305) 935-3939.

MERGER planning has a great deal in common with those big premarriage discussions. In both cases, each side needs to be clear-eyed about the other's strengths and weaknesses, to find areas where the partners can work together and other areas where they could each use some personal space. Just as couples are supposed to talk about financial expectations, companies are expected to project spending needs and growth opportunities. And, of course, there should be a discussion about whether a name change will occur.

To the Editor:

Even when Brian Bannister, below, looked sharp for the Mets at the start of last season, going 2-0 with a 2.89 earned run average before injuring his hamstring, he walked 17 batters in 28 innings. The trend slowed somewhat this season, when in his first seven starts for the Royals, Bannister was 0-3 with a 4.55 E.R.A. and 12 walks in 33 2/3 innings. But since June 1, Bannister has walked six batters in five starts. The results: four wins and a 3.00 E.R.A.
To the Editor:

KALTMAN--Martin, died on June 15th at the age of 92. He had homes in Old Westbury, NY and Key Biscayne, FL. He was a man of great vision, imagination and a pioneer of the modern Lithographic industry in New York. With fellow Brooklyn Tech graduate Max Verebay they started Kaltman Press in 1932 to print labels by the letterpress process. They remained partners for 66 years. When the LP record was invented in 1947, they started printing album covers. With the advent of lithography they joined with Jack Hecht in 1950 to create Queens Lithographing Corp. in Long Island City. With the growth of album sales in the sixties. Queens Litho printed all Beatles and Rolling Stones LPs and the company grew rapidly. During that period the company opened factories in Edison, NJ and Indianapolis. In 1964 the company displayed an operating printing press on the floor of Grand Central Station. The volume of music packaging exploded in the eighties with the introduction of the compact-disc and the company added a factory in Louisville to handle the growth. The company changed its name to Queens Group Inc. Packaging for Home Video, Video games and Software created the need for added capacity and the company built two factories in North Carolina. The company also produced high quality packaging for cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and private label. The company was sold in 1998 and is now part of International Paper. A philanthropist, Mr. Kaltman actively supported UJA-Federation, MOMA, Julliard School where he endowed a scholarship, NSUH-LIJ Health System and the Botanical Gardens in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx. Martin was a founder of American Friends of Boystown Jerusalem and his company donated a printing press to the school in Israel. He loved growing plants, flowers, trees, vegetables and studied Horticulture at SUNY Farmingdale, and helped establish The Gardens at Crandon Park in Key Biscayne. He was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle. Mr. Kaltman's first wife, the former Helen Reich, died in 1984. He is survived by his second wife, the former Rosalie Podoll, her children and grandchildren. His son Eric and wife Marnee of Old Westbury, NY, their children Dennis, Richard, Jodi, Jon, their spouses and eight greatgrandchildren. His daughter Gail Bates and husband Dennis of Marietta, GA, their children Stephanie, Robin, their spouses and four greatgrandchildren. Memorial contributions may be sent to Queens Botanical Garden, attention: Susan Lacerte, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing, NY 11355.

I read Jason DeParle's article with keen interest. Having lived as a Peace Corps volunteer in Nepal from 1985 to 1987, I was swept up with the fantasy of finding a stupa (a Buddhist religious monument) in Cincinnati or a terraced rice paddy in the Sierras. Though this was clearly not the intent of Lant Pritchett's borderless economics, it certainly would be mine. I would gladly forfeit half my annual salary if by giving up the cultural desert of strip malls, interstates, megachurches and Starbuckses, we instead could savor the smells, sights, sounds and flavors of the Nepalese -- not to mention hundreds of other ethnicities -- in a much more organic and integrated fashion.

The top-ranked men's player, Roger Federer, has won Wimbledon four years in a row. If he wins again, he will be the fourth men's player to win five consecutive titles, joining W. C. Renshaw (1881-86), H. L. Doherty (1902-6) and Bjorn Borg (1976-80). Renshaw and Pete Sampras (1993-95, 1997-2000), each with seven victories, are the only men to win more than five times. THE BIG THREE Roger Federer has won 10 Grand Slam titles, and the world's second-best player, Rafael Nadal, has won three (all at the French Open). Third-ranked Andy Roddick has one Grand Slam title, the 2003 United States Open. Only one other player ranked in the ATP's top 15, No. 6 Fernando González, has even appeared in a Grand Slam final. González lost to Federer in the Australian Open final in January.

Once upon a time -- from the mid 1960s into the early 1980s -- the Baltimore Orioles had the best organization in baseball. This is what they have now: By losing at least 41 of their remaining 89 games, they would become only the fourth team in history to have 10 successive losing seasons after a first-place finish, joining the Pittsburgh Pirates (en route to their 15th consecutive losing season after a 1992 first-place finish), the Boston Red Sox (15 losing seasons after 1918) and the Philadelphia Athletics (10 losing seasons after 1914).

POST--Sheldon 9/5/36-6/25/88. Founder Chelsea Pines Inn. Lover, uncle, friend. Proud gay Jew who fought for our rights but lost in the battle against AIDS. Please join my spouse Tom Klebba and me as we recall each of them on Gay Pride Day, especially Gary Olde, Peter Monette, Mark Fuschetti, so many others gone too soon. ''Sometimes people leave you halfway through the wood but no one is alone'': Stephen Sondheim. Rest well, Sheldon and know you and all of them will live on within us. Jay Lesiger

Political candidates and trial lawyers will do and say whatever it takes to win (Matt Bai). John Edwards happens to be both. He has made statements railing against subprime lending but recently made half a million dollars consulting for a hedge fund involved in subprime lending. He charged $55,000 to give a speech on poverty to university students.
Correction Appended London

The police officers hopped from their vans and cars with shouts of ''Hands up,'' ''Don't move,'' and ''Get on the ground.'' Someone in the crowd of young people yelled, ''Nobody run'' -- and nobody did, witnesses said. The teenagers were frisked, forced up against a fence or a wall, or pushed to the asphalt. Those watching said the mood was almost subdued as the handcuffs went on, the loudest sound the whir of a television news helicopter hovering above. ''None of us understood what was going on,'' said Dana Hollis, whose teenage daughter was arrested. ''Everything just happened so fast.''

Rose Marie Bravo, 56, stepped down last week from the board of the Burberry Group, the British luxury-goods brand known for its trademark plaid patterns and trench coats, once worn by Humphrey Bogart and Audrey Hepburn.

The stock market fell sharply last week as the subprime mortgage crisis spilled over into the broad financial markets. Two hedge funds run by Bear Stearns ran into trouble because of their heavy exposure to subprime mortgages. While the company was prepared to bolster one of the funds with its own money, the problems at Bear Stearns raised broader concerns about the possibility of write-downs of securities backed by subprime mortgages at other institutions.
Colorado Springs Apolo Anton Ohno is a man comfortable competing in spandex, given the second-skin uniform of a short-track speedskater, but on this occasion, he pleaded for wardrobe control.

LOS ANGELES PATTON OSWALT, claiming to be moderately drunk, was onstage at one of his favorite haunts, Largo, a small cabaret on Fairfax Avenue in West Hollywood, unleashing one of the elaborate tirades that have become his comedy trademark, describing the aesthetic horrors of entering the orange-furniture, fluorescent-light nightmare that is Yoshinoya Beef Bowl, a Japanese fast-food chain he says must be a front for some sort of international crime syndicate.

Sometimes, Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins, the first catcher to win an American League batting title, misses the frantic and physical side of football. Mauer, naturally, was a high school quarterback. ''You miss throwing those deep routes or those deep outs,'' Mauer said, his eyes peeking upward as if he were watching a spiral sail. ''That's what I really enjoyed.''

LOEWENSTEIN--Martha. The leadership and staff of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourn the passing of Martha Loewenstein, a former longtime employee, valued member of the Board of Directors, and dear friend to the American Committee for over 50 years. In addition to her wisdom and energy, Martha's many gifts to the Weizmann Institute of Science included an endowment fund and a Reference Section established in her honor at the Wix Library on the Institute's campus in Rehovot, Israel. We send heartfelt condolences to Martha's friends and family. As Martha's life was for a blessing, so may her memory be. Robert B. Machinist, Chairman American Committee Norman D. Cohen, President American Committee Martin S. Kraar, Exec. V.P. American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, Pres., Weizmann Institute

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Bosede Ikeolu Gbadegesin and Oreoluwa Adetunji Adeyemi referred incorrectly to the academic honor given to the bride by Harvard, from which she holds both bachelor's and law degrees. Although she did indeed graduate magna cum laude as an undergraduate, she did not do so as a law student.
The Habitats article last Sunday, about the home of two designers in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misspelled the husband's name. He is Jan Habraken, not Habranken.

Ernie Morris was at Rucker Park in the summer of 1957 when a giant named Chamberlain crushed a team of all-stars that included Cal Ramsey, a rugged rebounding machine from New York University who later played for the Knicks. ''Wilt Chamberlain just about tore the place down,'' Morris recalled from a seat behind a basket at Rucker Park on 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, where he watched last Monday's season opener of the Entertainer's Basketball Classic.

LEE--June Lai Ngo Lunn. June Lee died in San Francisco on June 7. Predeceased by her husband Charles (Chuck), she is survived by daughters Gwendolyn (Bruce), Cynthia and Sylvia, grandsons Matthew and Alexander, sisters Lucy New, Helen Wong and Thuey Fong Lok, and brother Edwin Len. Retired in 1990 as Chief Clerk for the U.S. Probation Office of the U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York. Donations may be made to The American Diabetes Association.

Mike Piazza, the popular former Met, will not play for the Oakland Athletics this weekend during their series against the Mets at Shea Stadium. He is on the disabled list with an injured right shoulder. But Piazza made an appearance and received a warm ovation before last night's game, when he took the Athletics lineup card to home plate to meet with the umpires and with Sandy Alomar Sr., the Mets' third-base coach who was performing that duty for the home team.

AS befits the boss of America's best-known contact lens maker, Ronald L. Zarrella, the chief executive of Bausch & Lomb, has always had a keen eye for the fine print. Even as the big picture at his company became blurred -- by such things as accounting scandals that delayed public filings for years, a devastating recall of its flagship lens solution and a 90 percent drop in earnings from 2004 to 2006 -- legal minutiae in his contract guaranteed him an outsize pay package. In addition to granting performance bonuses and potentially lucrative options, Bausch gave its prized chief executive other perks, like $81,452 worth of personal travel on the corporate jet last year.

REISIN--Seymour, of New York City died June 15, 2007. Beloved husband of Joan Wooters - Reisin. Devoted father of Stephanie (August), Emily (Emin), Michael, and his dog, Mala. Retired Dean of Continuing Education, Bronx Community College/ CUNY. Served as assistant principal and teacher in public and private schools in New York, Washington, D.C. and Maryland. Graduate of City College, 1950. During a parallel political career Sy was Executive Secretary of the student division of Americans for Democratic Action; Acting National Secretary of American Friends of Vietnam and member of the National Board of the League for Industrial Democracy. During the 1950s Sy worked with Spanish Refugee Aid to deliver medical equipment to adherents of the defeated Loyalist forces in Barcelona. In the same decade the American Embassy ordered Sy to leave Yugoslavia thereby thwarting his efforts to provide financial aid to the family of Milovan Djilas. In the 1960s, Sy developed and implemented the sustained picketing efforts at the Yugoslav government offices in New York City to protest the imprisonment of Milovan Djilas. In 2005 Sy assisted in the editing of ''Freedom's Sword'', Gilbert Jonas's award-winning history of the NAACP. The 1200 page Anthology and Source Book of the National Student Association, published in February 2006 by the American Council on Education, includes two essays by Sy, one a history of the Students for Democratic Action; the second an historical analysis of communist efforts to control American collegiate student organizations. During his career as an educator, Sy was a recipient of the New York City Public Service Award for Professional Achievement; The New York State Scholarship Award for Social Studies Teachers; and the B'nai B'rith Award for Human Relations. Sy was a member of the National Association of Scholars and The Historical Society. He also served on the Advisory Boards of the Rosen Scholars Fund and the Houston based American Festival of the Arts. A memorial service will be held on June 27, 2007, at 11am at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to New York University Medical Center, Hematology Research Fund, c/o Dr. Kenneth B. Hymes, 530 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

CUMMINGS--Edwin ''Ned'', 79, of Accord, NY, died June 21, 2007. Born February 13, 1928, he was the son of the late Edwin and Marjorie (Gould) Cummings. Survivors include his wife, Betty, and sister, Nancy Thurber of Greenport, NY. Visiting hours are Tuesday June 26th from 5-8pm at H.B. Humiston Funeral Home, Kerhonkson, NY. Services are Wednesday, June 27th, 11am, at The Federated Church of Kerhonkson.

Cindy Yan, 30, an information technology consultant from Queens: ''We flew down from São Paolo to this place called Florianópolis. We wanted to experience Carnival as a local. Which means going to the beach. It was beautiful there. The people were just really nice, and you didn't have to be afraid of getting kidnapped. Everyone in São Paolo had put fear in us: 'You have to be careful, don't go off by yourself.' So I'm glad I was in an island setting and I could go off on my own -- if I wanted to go surfing, I'd go surfing. This must be my third attempt. I got up on my board, but I fell into the water again.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

DIAMOND--Harold M., of Monroe Township, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died Wednesday (June 20), three weeks prior to his 93rd birthday. Senior Draftsman by trade, NY Hiking Club past president and active leader in the Rossmoor Community where he resided the last 27 years, he epitomized the term Gentleman. Beloved husband of the late Minette Diamond. Devoted brother of Kenneth, Lawrence, the late Charles and the late Belle Rockway. Dear uncle to five nephews and one niece. Great-uncle to nine nieces and nephews. Services were under the direction of the A.S. Cole Funeral Home, Cranbury, NJ.

IF you can find him, Vincent Tibbett is precisely the sort of well-connected cultural liaison any emerging filmmaker should want to know. An employee of the Sundance Channel, he is as easily recognizable for his shaggy haircut and assertively casual attire as he is for the crowds of aspiring artists who follow him around, hoping to chat him up about cinematic trends, get him to evaluate their movies or simply score his e-mail address. But if Mr. Tibbett seems a bit harder to pin down for a lunch date than the average in-demand tastemaker, that's because he doesn't exist on our plane of reality. He is an electronic avatar found only in Second Life, the popular online virtual community.

ARONSON--Norman Leonard, a former naval officer, entrepreneur, publishing executive, restaurant owner, died of cancer on Friday, June 15, 2007. He was 83 years old. His wife was the late Marcia Ross Rosey. Born in Washington, DC, he was the son of the late Herman and Bertha Miller Aronson. He attended Wharton Business School while serving as a Lt. in the U.S. Navy from 19421946. A graduate of Georgetown University Law School with a B.S. in Business and Publishing Administration, 1947, and a JD, 1949. He was Vice President of Esquire Magazine, NYC from 19511975. President and Publisher, Best Publications, Inc., and the Book of Bests, NYC; An avid cook and wine connoisseur, he was Entrepreneur, Investor, Founder, and President, The Kings Court Restaurants, Princeton, NJ and Charlottesville, VA. Previous owner of Johnny Bostons Restaurant, Trenton, NJ; President, The Service News Stands, Pentagon Bldg., Washington, DC; in 1990, he was a recipient of the ''Lone Sailor Award'' honoring veterans who became successful in their lives and careers while exemplifying the core values of honor, courage, and commitment. He was a member of the Nassau Club in Princeton, NJ and the University Club in Manhattan. Surviving are: his son, John Michael Aronson, Wellsboro, PA. His daughter, Susan Elizabeth Aronson Baratta , Naples, FL. His grandchildren, Michael, John Michael, and Ashley Baratta. To leave an online condolence, visit strauchfuneralhome.com

Eight American servicemen were reported to have died in Iraq on Saturday, bringing the four-day death toll to at least 23 as insurgents continued to use huge roadside bombs to rip through combat vehicles. The deadliest attack on Saturday killed four American soldiers in combat northwest of Baghdad. Insurgents detonated a roadside bomb near the soldiers' vehicle. An Iraqi working as an interpreter for the Americans was wounded.

KOVACS--George, a caring man, passed away peacefully on Friday morning. His kindness and humor will be greatly missed and never forgotten, by his wife, Barbara; his children, Peter, Liz and Ruth; his grandchildren, Jamie, Cathy and Joe, and all who knew him. He founded George Kovacs Lighting over 50 years ago. Under his leadership this innovative company transformed the lamp industry. Donations may be made to the TEAK Fellowship. He and Barbara have put their hearts and souls into this organization that gives many young people a chance to succeed. Service Sunday, 2pm at the ''Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. $(6$)KOVACS--George. Our dearest friend who will light up the heavens as he lit up our lives with his goodness and humor. We shall miss him. Paolo and Ellen Giusti Abbott and Marsha Krieger Fred and Sally Tawil Burton and Marcia Yawitz $(6$)KOVACS--George. We were graced by your spirit, humor and generosity and will carry your memory always. The Board, Staff, Fellows and Alumni of The TEAK Fellowship

MANNES COLLEGE THE NEW SCHOOL FOR MUSIC holds a rich series of seminars, minifestivals and institutes. This week it presents its first SUMMER INSTITUTE OF ART SONG IN SPANISH, to promote Spanish song in a genre dominated by German lied, French chanson and Italian aria. In addition to coaching sessions and master classes, there are public concerts. The first is Tuesday evening, with the focus on works inspired by the poet Juan Ramón Jiménez. The composers include Rodrigo, Mompou, Falla, Lorca, J. L. Turina and Julio Gomez. The performers are the pianist Jorge Robaina, the guitarist José María Gallardo del Rey (also represented as a composer) and the mezzo-soprano Nan Maro Babakhanian, the institute's director. At 6 p.m., Queen Sofia Spanish Institute, 684 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 628-0420; $15. On Wednesday, a flamenco concert takes place at the Mannes Concert Hall, serving double duty as part of the school's guitar institute, which is running at the same time. Jake Peavy (9-1), a 26-year-old right-hander for the San Diego Padres, leads the National League with 110 strikeouts and a 1.98 earned run average, and is tied with the Los Angeles Dodgers' Brad Penny and Philadelphia's Cole Hamels for the most victories. Peavy, Penny and Hamels are scheduled to pitch today. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

SERBAROLI--Joseph A., on June 21, 2007. Beloved husband of Agnes, devoted father of Francis and his wife Bernadette and Joseph and his wife Marie-Jose. Cherished grandfather of Adrienne, Elise and Alessandra, loving brother of August and the late Judith and the late Alexander. US Army 1941-1945. He loved God, his family and his country. To the Editor:

ONLY a year after it raised the age limit for collecting what is known as the kiddie tax, Congress has done so again. As a result, many families are facing the prospect of significantly higher-than-expected taxes when it comes time to sell investments held in a child's name to pay college costs. But because the kiddie tax provisions of the new law, which President Bush signed on May 25, are not effective until Jan. 1, some families may be able to limit the tax damage by selling some holdings of older students before year-end.

FRIEDMAN--Frances Karo, July 18, 1920 -June 24, 2005. Another year has passed and our loss, loneliness, and love is as intense as ever. We greet you each morning and bid you goodnight at bedtime. We love you always. Anita and Oscar

SCHIFFMAN--Saul S., 93, of Verona, died peacefully on June 19, 2007, at The University Hospital, Newark. He was born and raised in Passaic and lived in Verona for the past 36 years. He retired from Tenney Engineering, Inc., where he held executive positions for over 50 years. He was husband of the late Lillian Schiffman, (nee Gold). Surviving are his sons, Dr. David Schiffman of Rhinebeck, NY, and Robert Schiffman of Short Hills, NJ; grandchildren Caren Gibson of Atlanta, GA, Glenn Schiffman of Short Hills, NJ, and Dr. Robyn Schiffman of Shorts Hills, NJ; great - grandchildren Jack (James) Schiffman, Avery Schiffman, Lily Schiffman and Cody Schiffman, all of Short Hills, NJ. Anyone wishing to send a tribute can do so at: Millburn-Short Hills Volunteer First Aid Squad, Inc., P.O. Box 226, Millburn, NJ 07041.

GERO--Jean, passed away June 20, 2007 at 88, beloved wife of Louis (deceased). Loving mother of Donna (David) Schweid and Doreen (Dick) Berman. Doting grandmother to Brad (Tina), Jamie and Eric. Proud greatgrandmother to Zachary. She will be loved and missed by all. Graveside service Sunday, at 11:00am, Riverside Cemetery, NJ.
To the Editor: I was very excited to see Matt Gross's Frugal Traveler blog focus on Nashville recently, but I feel that it was given short shrift.

AFTER Claire Varrelmann announced that she was pregnant, she created three registries for her four baby showers. Ms. Varrelmann, 28, who lives in Stoughton, Wis., started off with a shower given by her best friend from college, held in her husband's hometown of Clear Lake, Iowa, and attended primarily by women on his side of the family.

ALTHOUGH Bear Stearns announced on Friday that it would shore up one of its two faltering hedge funds that are heavily exposed to the subprime mortgage mess, the move did little to instill confidence in an already fearful market. Even after Samuel L. Molinaro Jr., Bear Stearns's chief financial officer, said in a conference call that his firm would lend the fund up to $3.2 billion to conduct an orderly liquidation, questions continue to swirl around the implosion of the funds, how they could have lost so much value in such a short time and why the firm's risk management professionals seem to have been AWOL in recent months as subprime mortgage loans plummeted in value.

Last night's tense 1-0 Mets victory over the Oakland Athletics at Shea Stadium included the untimely ejection of Paul Lo Duca in a ferocious temper tantrum, excellent pitching by both starters and a game-winning double by David Wright in the bottom of the ninth inning. Although the result was cheered loudly by most of the 52,920 fans on an ideal summer evening, it was not praised by Willie Randolph, the Mets' manager, even though it marked the team's first consecutive victories since the last week of May.

WOLF--Philip. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Philip Wolf, husband of Thelma Wolf, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. June Walker, National President Morlie Levin, National Executive Director
To the Editor:

As Oakland's Jack Cust prepared to play the Mets this weekend and the Yankees next weekend, he was more than simply a New Jersey guy who needed 10 years and a circuitous route to cross the Hudson River to the bright lights of the big ballparks in the big city as an established major leaguer. Cust has 10 home runs, exactly double his career total in the major leagues before this season. At 28, Cust, an outfielder and designated hitter, has finally established himself on a major league roster after playing for 10 minor league teams and also -- oh so briefly -- for four teams in the majors.

Sonny Vaccaro, the former marketing executive for Nike, Adidas and Reebok, is finally taking a summer vacation. He is closing his ABCD Camp, the signature summer showcase for high school basketball players that he has run since 1984. The move will have a far-reaching impact on college recruiting this summer and beyond. Ever since Vaccaro, 67, started running high school all-star games in 1965 and later made his name by signing Michael Jordan to Nike in the early 1980s, he has emerged as one of the more controversial and polarizing figures in college athletics.
SIMON--Jay S. 3/6/37-6/24/06. To the love of my life. I am truly blessed. Jo-Ann

Loving and beautiful wife of Gregory Rathe; daughter of Janet and Tom Van Valey; daughter-inlaw of Adelle and Robert Rathe; sister of Christine; sister-in-law of Toby and Sandy Florman; adored aunt to Zachary, Frankie and Eric. Services Sunday, June 24, 2pm at United Nations Chapel, 44th and First Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers please make donations LOVE www.leaveoutviolence-us.org.

Sometimes, Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins, the first catcher to win an American League batting title, misses the frantic and physical side of football. Mauer, naturally, was a high school quarterback. ''You miss throwing those deep routes or those deep outs,'' Mauer said, his eyes peeking upward as if he were watching a spiral sail. ''That's what I really enjoyed.''
To the Editor:

INVESTMENT newsletter editors are markedly less optimistic about the stock market now than they were late last year, when the Dow Jones industrial average was a thousand points lower. This suggests that the bull market may run a while longer, according to the market timing theory known as contrarian analysis. The theory is based on the historical tendency of investors to be wrong about the stock market's direction, especially at major turning points. Investors tend to assume that what has happened will keep happening: they become progressively more bullish as the stock market rises, and increasingly bearish as it declines. Market tops are reached when there are very few bearish holdouts; most everyone who could be tempted to invest in the stock market has already done so -- leaving little cash on the sidelines to propel equities higher.

JAY LENO The Republican Party here in California has obtained a special visa to hire a Canadian to be the state deputy political director because they say they can't find a qualified American to do the job. So apparently, working for Republicans is one of those icky jobs that Americans just don't want to do.

WITH their two growing children sharing a bedroom, Asa and Micael Holmstrom decided it was time to look for more space. Not that Filip, 6, and Felicia, 7, couldn't have continued to share. But Filip is autistic, and ''being autistic also means sometimes you don't want to sleep,'' Mrs. Holmstrom said. He often rises at 3 or 4 a.m. ''It's hard for Felicia,'' Mr. Holmstrom said.

Hildy Kuryk, the daughter of Judith Frisch Kuryk and David Kuryk, both of New York, is to be married this evening to Jarrod Neal Bernstein, a son of Roberta and Edward Bernstein of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Menashe is to officiate at Sky Studios, a loft in New York.

In the theater district, Broadway playhouses are getting pressure from all sides. All around them, developers are knocking down walls and blasting bedrock to lay foundations for office towers, stores and high-rise condominiums. If the newcomers are not careful, they could lop off part of a historic theater, like the Lunt-Fontanne on 46th Street.

The eight seniors were not allowed to wear caps and gowns or to march up to receive their diplomas, but when their photographs were flashed across a screen Friday night at the graduation ceremony, they got the biggest cheers. They were among 19 seniors at Hendrick Hudson High School here who were charged with placing false bombs, a felony, after entering the school on a Sunday night and leaving dozens of duct-taped alarm clocks as an end-of-school prank. They were also barred from the graduation ceremony, which was held at the Franklin D. Roosevelt campus of the Veterans Affairs Hudson Valley Health Care System here.

Taiwan's small circle of international supporters -- countries that have diplomatic relations with the 23 million inhabitants of the island known as the Republic of China instead of the 1.3 billion of the People's Republic across the Taiwan Strait -- got a little bit tighter earlier this month when Costa Rica announced that it was switching its allegiance to China. The move by Costa Rica, a Central American nation with four million people, was the eighth defection from Taiwan's side since 2000, following in the small footsteps of Chad, Senegal, Grenada, Vanuatu, Dominica, Liberia and Macedonia. Roughly 170 countries recognize China, while Taiwan retains just 24. The battle has not been entirely one-sided. This year, St. Lucia, a Caribbean island nation, made the switch from China to Taiwan.

OFTEN derided as disease-ridden ''rats with wings,'' pigeons are little loved by many urban dwellers. Sakura Adachi, a furniture designer in Milan, is not among the haters; she admires pigeons for their ability to create private nooks in public spaces. That avian talent inspired her to create a bookshelf called the Cave, which allows readers to curl up in a form-fitting seat, surrounded by their beloved books. The Cave features a blob-shaped, human-size recess at its base. Sitting in this upholstered niche is supposed to make a reader feel secluded -- akin to being lost among a college library's dusty stacks -- but still remain visible to passers-by.

IN the last few months Brad Paisley and Toby Keith, two of country music's biggest stars, have returned (if they ever left) to the place they call home: country radio. They have millions of fans and two very different reputations: Mr. Paisley excels at sweet love songs, while Mr. Keith is still best known as a pro-troop rabble-rouser. But neither one can resist a good joke -- or, for that matter, a bad one. And this spring both of them came out cracking. Mr. Paisley's current hit, ''Ticks,'' from his album ''5th Gear'' (Arista Nashville), seems to have taken him by surprise. He never shot a proper video for it, but the song nevertheless climbed up the country charts, thanks to a pickup line that has already earned a place in Nashville infamy: ''I'd like to check you for ticks.'' It's the kind of come-on you don't soon forget, especially once you hear Mr. Paisley expand on it. ''Ooh, ooh, you never know where one might be,'' he sings, and what woman could resist a man that thorough?

ODD things come out of the woodwork when you move offices, as The New York Times did recently. Among the items unearthed were a number of unusual, even bizarre CDs: a testament to humankind's ability to master the unlikeliest of instruments and to carve the classical music audience into the tiniest of niches. Hearing these CDs provided the thrill of listening to fantastically accomplished practitioners of the esoteric. Some are great musicians to boot. Here is a dog's breakfast of recordings saved from the mover's purgatory. KALEVI AHO: CONTRABASSOON, TUBA CONCERTOS (Bis Records) Mr. Aho is an accomplished Finnish composer with a penchant for large works and concertos. Here he plumbs the depths, writing for two of the lowest instruments in the orchestra. Somewhat sadistically, he also writes into the upper registers, although the really low notes are the most thrilling. While written on a large scale, the concertos have many chamber music passages and moments of interplay between the soloist and other instruments.

He has carpeted Grand Central Terminal with one of his patterned graphics and covered gallery walls in silver insulation panels that people can mark up. He makes large-scale panels of plastic-foam footprints by stepping in acid and walking across the surface. Now RUDOLF STINGEL is having his first solo museum exhibition in the United States, at the Whitney Museum of American Art. The show, which opens Thursday, surveys Mr. Stingel's career -- his unorthodox materials also include rubber and painted aluminum -- and features a new site-specific work. The exhibition represents something of a return to the Whitney for Mr. Stingel, whose work was part of the museum's 2006 Biennial. He has also created installations for the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, which organized this exhibition. Through Oct. 14, (212) 570-3676, whitney.org.

HOBBS--Suzanne Herz Holland, 75, passed June 21. Grad of Cleveland Heights High School, UF, Cooper Union. Graphic artist, wrote for TV. Survived by brother Ralph Herz, Jr., M.D. (Elizabeth), son Neil Holland, daughter Hillary Holland, grandchildren, nieces Taria and Saskia. Will be missed for her wit, intellect, and kindness.

Podcast: Scheduled to appear this week are Katie Roiphe (above), the author of ''Uncommon Arrangements''; Bill Geist, the author of ''Way Off the Road''; Dave Itzkoff on science fiction; and Dwight Garner, senior editor, with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host.
To the Editor:

In sports that require athletic skill, an aging star's decline is easy to understand. In chess, though it can be exhausting, it seems strange to see champions struggle as they age. How champions past their prime confront their decline says much about who they are. Three great champions, Garry Kasparov, Anatoly Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi, have taken three different paths.

ANYONE who follows technology or military affairs has heard the predictions for more than a decade. Cyberwar is coming. Although the long-announced, long-awaited computer-based conflict has yet to occur, the forecast grows more ominous with every telling: an onslaught is brought by a warring nation, backed by its brains and computing resources; banks and other businesses in the enemy states are destroyed; governments grind to a halt; telephones disconnect; the microchip-controlled Tickle Me Elmos will be transformed into unstoppable killing machines. No, that last item is not part of the scenario, mostly because those microprocessor-controlled toys aren't connected to the Internet through the industrial remote-control technologies known as Scada systems, for Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition. The technology allows remote monitoring and control of operations like manufacturing production lines and civil works projects like dams. So security experts envision terrorists at a keyboard remotely shutting down factory floors or opening a dam's floodgates to devastate cities downstream.

ONE hot July in 1923 Sara Murphy, the model for Nicole Diver in F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Tender Is the Night,'' posed for Picasso on the French Riviera. ''Picasso adored her,'' reports John Richardson, his biographer. He was not alone. The fun-loving Sara, whose engagement photograph graced the cover of Town & Country magazine, attracted quite a few artists and novelists. Fitzgerald ''was madly in love with her,'' her grandson John Donnelly said in an interview, adding that in the family there were whispers of an affair with Ernest Hemingway. ''Grandmother would go down to Key West for visits,'' he said. ''Grandfather didn't go along. He didn't like Hemingway. He thought he was a bully.''

Le Mans, France SOMEONE told me that there is no sleep better than the sleep after the 24 Hours of Le Mans. But 23 hours into the race, which took place last weekend on 8.4 miles of public roads about an hour and a half southwest of Paris, no one on the Corvette Racing team was close to dozing.

SOME Porsche purists are still horrified that the sports car company branched out into sport utility vehicles. But let's get real: if a Porschephile's transportation needs call for an S.U.V., why should she, or he, have to shop elsewhere? The newly redesigned Porsche Cayenne, which first appeared as a 2003 model, remains a study in contrasts. It is, with apologies to 914 devotees, the ugliest Porsche ever. Yet, for an S.U.V., it is comparatively handsome. Maybe that is why it appeals to so many women.

As if baseball in San Francisco needed another sideshow, Robin Williams was asked to recite the Giants' starting lineup Saturday. Standing in the dugout during batting practice, Williams did his best to make the Giants' lineup sound entertaining. He called Barry Bonds ''Boom Boom.'' He referred to Pedro Feliz and Omar Vizquel as ''Pedro Vizquel.'' He required several takes.

It is Roger Federer's tournament to lose, the expectation that comes with winning Wimbledon four times in a row. A fifth consecutive victory would match Bjorn Borg's modern men's record for consistency and put Federer two Wimbledon championships behind the career leaders, including Pete Sampras. It would also give Federer 11 Grand Slam titles, the same as Borg and three short of Sampras's mark. But it will not get him any closer to winning the French Open. And as Wimbledon begins Monday, the chatter is not so much about whether the top-seeded Federer will win again, but what it really means if he does.

BENDINER--Esther Shapiro. We honor Esther Shapiro Bendiner who died on Saturday, June 16, 2007 at the age of 94. Wife of the late Elmer Bendiner, mother of Winifred and Jessica, grandmother of Gabrielle, she was an activist, community organizer, valued friend and fierce defender of equal rights for all.

Coming to a theater near, well, Yankee Stadium: Darryl Strawberry and Jim Leyritz in ''The Boy of Steel,'' a one-act play set at the stadium. Strawberry and Leyritz, who were teammates on the Yankees' 1996 World Series championship team, will make their acting debuts in the play that is based on the book of the same name by Ray Negron, a special assistant for the Yankees.
To the Editor:

The fog is rolling in at the Needles, and so are the phantoms. Wave off the cloud bank forming offshore and wave off the 156 years, and there would be America sailing into view with its vast cotton sails, its sensibly slender bow and a big lead.

Nels Cline Singers Free-bop, indie rock and chamber pop knock about with arresting results on ''Draw Breath'' (Cryptogramophone), the third album by the Nels Cline Singers. Led by the guitarist Nels Cline, the group includes no actual singers, just Devin Hoff, a bassist, and Scott Amendola, a drummer. But as the band name and album title both suggest, there's a vocal imperative at work here, a sense of respiring and descanting as one. This technique derives from avant-garde jazz, and at specific moments -- notably the first section of ''Mixed Message,'' a bristling group improvisation -- the lineage feels explicit. Elsewhere experimental rock provides a clearer context. (Check ''Mixed Message'' again, this time for the raucous last five minutes.) ''Confection'' could sit companionably on a Sonic Youth album; ''Squirrel of God'' is a stormy-turned-sunny rumination with percussion by Glenn Kotche, Mr. Cline's colleague in Wilco. And given the various strains of abrasiveness on the album, it seems worth noting that the centerpiece is a glimmering waltz called ''The Angel of Angels,'' one of the prettiest and most radiant offerings of Mr. Cline's career.

SIEGEL--Herbert also known as ''The Merchant Prince of Sag Harbor'' passed away peacefully on Friday, June 22, 2007. Herbert is survived by the love of his life of over 66 years Claire Siegel, his three children Shelly, her husband Paul, Allan ''his Shicksa goddess-Lisa'' and Jed and his wife Jane. Herbie loved Paul (his schmuck son-in-law) and Jane like his own children and took great pride in all of his families accomplishments. Grandchildren Jocelyn-the Brats, David, Danielle, Stephanie, Alec and Ashley, Jessica and Howard and great-grandchildren Zoe and Brady and his French grandchildren Angel and Roxanne. Unfortunately, none of Herbies card games have survived him, however they are anxiously awaiting his arrival and have saved a spot at the table for him. Born on Faile St. in the Bronx he often said that he was going to end up there. A kind and generous man, he never got angry and never said no to his family. He had great wisdom and was always the voice of reason. He was fiercely anti-war, and had no trouble pronouncing those that initiated war as putzes. An avid boater and fisherman, Herbie sunk every boat he owned and was often found rooting for the fish. Herbert Siegel started his work career on Coney Island selling soda and melting ice cream on the beach. He later had a short stint as a weight guesser. He won the Irish Sweepstakes and bought himself a car, gave his father and best friend money to open up businesses and by weeks end he had blown his winnings. Herbie and his wife Claire opened up Young America Antiques in Sag Harbor where they sold ''one of a kind'' Americana to a growing list of friends. Never without a piece of chocolate, a smile and a funny comment, Dad will be missed by all of those lucky enough to have known him. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Long Island Alzheimers Foundation, www.liaf.org or The Animal Rescue Fund of The Hamptons www.arfhamptons.org.
KOENIGES--Martin C., 79, passed peacefully on June 11, 2007. He is survived by his wife Terrance and his sons Michael and Quinn. In memory, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders.
DOEMLING--Mary Jane Horan. Died June 24, 2002. Requiescat in pace. Son William Horan Doemling
The danceable exhilaration of ANDY PALACIO's music hides a mission: to preserve the Garifuna language and culture of Central America's Caribbean coast.

After years of being at the top of the retail heap, denim is finally on the wane. This summer, casual dresses are fashion's new version of jeans and a T-shirt. In knits and weaves, these cool little numbers are flirtier than denim, breezy to reach for and easy to pack. Here are seven great ways to while away a summer weekend.
SMALL-SCREEN SIRENS Better Nickname, Please

impatient and angry, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Saturday accused the United States military and its NATO allies of carrying out ''careless operations'' that lead to civilian casualties, asserting that ''Afghan life is not cheap and should not be treated as such.'' His remarks, made on the front lawn of the presidential palace, came in response to a week in which more than 100 civilian deaths have been reported from airstrikes and artillery fire against the Taliban.

ONCE upon a time, the most valuable secret formula in American business was Coca-Cola's. Today, it's Google's master algorithm. In the search business, however, there's no rival to play the role of Pepsi. Yahoo is the closest but still a distant No. 2, and Google earns more profits in a single quarter than Yahoo does in a year. This may have had a bearing on the recent departure of Yahoo's chief technology officer, its chief operating officer and, last week, its chief executive.Microsoft, an even more distant No. 3 in the search competition, can't keep up with Google, even with $28 billion of cash in its pockets at the end of March.

London TO mark Tony Blair's departure as Britain's prime minister, the Downing Street kitchen coven of opinion masseurs, social soothsayers and political weather forecasters decided that he should make a farewell trip around this sceptred isle in a lap of honor, taking in schools, hospitals, art centers, nature reserves and barracks, giving ''real people,'' as politicians like to refer to them, a chance to say thank you and get their backs patted and shoulders squeezed.

Rachel Kolman Marshak, the daughter of Anita S. Kolman and Marvin L. Marshak of St. Louis Park, Minn., was married last evening to Roger Lee, a son of Denise and Michael Lee of White Plains. Rabbi Norman M. Cohen officiated at the Congregation Bet Shalom in Minnetonka, Minn. The couple met at Stanford, from which she graduated with a bachelor's degree and he received a doctoral degree in computational mathematics.
Graffiti Secrets Q.Every time I see graffiti scribbled on a fence or a building, I wonder:Does the Police Department keep a record of the city's worst graffiti vandals? And who's graffiti slob No. 1?

For all those New Zealand fans who partied through the night in Port America's Cup, then woke up hoping that Alinghi's crew might suffer from rust or the jitters, it turned out to be a disappointing afternoon. Even without Russell Coutts at the helm and even against a rebuilt, reinvigorated team that dominated the challenger series, Alinghi was still able to pick up where it left off in 2003 by beating Emirates Team New Zealand by 35 seconds Saturday in the first race of the best-of-nine America's Cup match.

Iran is in the throes of one of its most ferocious crackdowns on dissent in years, with the government focusing on labor leaders, universities, the press, women's rights advocates, a former nuclear negotiator and Iranian-Americans, three of whom have been in prison for more than six weeks. The shift is occurring against the backdrop of an economy so stressed that although Iran is the world's second-largest oil exporter, it is on the verge of rationing gasoline. At the same time, the nuclear standoff with the West threatens to bring new sanctions.

KIRSHENBAUM--S. Joy, 80. Died on June 9, 2007 in Pittsburgh, PA. With her late husband artist Morris Kirshenbaum; founded Ivy School of Art, a mainstay of Pittsburgh cultural life for two decades. Survived by children Ava and Art Doppelt of Winter Park, FL, Lyn Kirshenbaum of Philadelphia, Susan Kirshenbaum and Jack Ostrofsky of San Francisco, Adam Kirshenbaum of Pittsburgh; grandchildren Aminda and Odilia Kirshenbaum; sisters Frieda Lerner of Cincinnati and Barbara Weinberg of Marietta, GA; brother-in-law Bernie Kirshenbaum and Carole Katz of Pittsburgh; and nieces, nephews, cousins and their families.

DESPITE recent events hinting at its resuscitation, the Cold War pretty much conked out for good 18 years ago. For music fans in the former Eastern bloc, the demise of the old regime brought about an unexpected benefit: the arrival of rock and techno music festivals on a huge scale previously reserved for May Day celebrations. More recently, Western festivalgoers have begun to take notice of these concerts, drawn not only by the acts, but also by the alluring ticket prices and the unfettered enthusiasm of the audience.

NEW ORLEANS defines who I am. I'm passionate about St. Augustine, the high school I attended. I grew up poor, in the Ninth Ward, in a rough neighborhood that was wiped out by Hurricane Katrina. Dad was a carpenter, but job opportunities were few and far between. He did what he had to do, including waiting tables at formal balls in the hotels. My mother was everything from a domestic to a teacher. They sacrificed to make sure my four siblings and I had opportunities. They also took in 27 foster children over the years.

He no longer brags about his dating exploits or shows off his impolitic side. He has largely reined in his temper with reporters and loosened his manner with voters. But Michael R. Bloomberg, New York's once-improbable mayor, would still be a highly unlikely presidential contender. A zealot for privacy, he slips away to Bermuda on weekends to practice his golf game. Divorced with a steady companion, he frequently indulges a louche sense of humor, joking at a dinner one night that if Salma Hayek joined him at the official mayor's residence, he might actually live there. And he still likes to end his evenings with a nightcap out, leading to the occasional public admission of having had perhaps a merlot or two too many.

The first party bus pulled up to Gypsy Tea, a club on West 24th Street, around midnight. Out spilled dozens of teenagers, in jeans and sundresses. They lined up in front of the door, where several security people stood guard. They waited. And waited. And waited. The club was not packed; it was empty. But the promoter and the bouncers would not let the young people inside, waving them off with vague lines about ''setting up.''

SUSSMAN--Rachel (nee Stroh) 91, died peacefully on June 23rd in NYC. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 57 years, Leo Sussman, in 1991. Born in Mielec, Poland, she moved to Vienna, Austria, in 1934 upon her marriage. After Germany's annexation of Austria, the couple escaped Nazism via Switzerland and Portugal, arriving in New York in December 1941. Together they founded Renette Foundation Corp. Working side-by-side, never a day apart, theirs was a strong and loving marriage; each reinforced the other's talents. The murder of her parents and her sister during the Holocaust was a trauma that gripped her until her last days. In 1997, she had a monument erected in Mielec in their memory and in that of their fellow Jewish victims. Although she gave outstanding service to her community and she supported various hospitals and yeshivas in the U.S. and Israel, she often requested anonymity and usually shunned recognition. But her legacy will live on through all those who benefited from her compassion and generosity. Anyone in need, whether personal or institutional, could always touch her heart. She will be missed and mourned by her nephews and nieces, Jack and Rachelle (Lily) Goldstein, Bruno and Harriet Goldstein, Jacques and Yvette Oliary, Miriam Millet and their families; her cousins, Jack and Edward Stroh, Sylvia Harvath (nee Berger) and their families. Services will be held at West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West 76th St., on June 24th at 11am.

THE long-scheduled meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers is a highlight of the calendar this week, but with no change in rates expected, investors may focus instead on subprime mortgages, where rates have been changing for the worse. An index that tracks the subprime market hit a low last week as a group of Wall Street banks participated in an attempt to rescue two hedge funds that suffered severe losses in them.
Even nonskiers can enjoy ski resorts in the summer when the focus is not just on the mountains but music as well.

Bobby Richardson saw his picture in The New York Times on Thursday and had to tell the story behind it. ''The thing I remember when McCovey came up, I was down in my position, ready, and the N.L. ump said, 'Hey, Rich, can I have your cap for my little cousin?' '' Richardson said Friday via cellphone, after arriving in San Francisco for this weekend's reunion of the players from the 1962 World Series.

BEAR--Charles B. The Board and Staff of The New 42nd Street are deeply saddened to learn of the death of our beloved Founding Board Member Charles B. Bear. He helped forge this organization, providing enlightened guidance and spirited encouragement. The Charley Bear Green Room in our Rehearsal Studios celebrates his concern and sensitivity for the well being of artists. Marian S. Heiskell, Chairman Cora Cahan, President
BRODSKY--Judith. Too short a past left us with wonderful memories. Forever loving... Grace and Ruth

Coming to a theater near, well, Yankee Stadium: Darryl Strawberry and Jim Leyritz in ''The Boy of Steel,'' a one-act play set at the stadium. Strawberry and Leyritz, who were teammates on the Yankees' 1996 World Series championship team, will make their acting debuts in the play that is based on the book of the same name by Ray Negron, a special assistant for the Yankees.

When you watch a baby being born, after a difficult pregnancy, it is so painful and bloody for the mother it is always hard to tell the truth and say, ''Gosh, that baby is really ugly.'' But that's how I feel about the energy legislation passed (and not passed) by the Senate last week. The whole Senate energy effort only reinforced my feelings that we're in a green bubble -- a festival of hot air by the news media, corporate America and presidential candidates about green this and green that, but, when it comes to actually doing something hard to bring about a green revolution at scale -- and if you don't have scale on this you have nothing -- we wimp out. Climate change is not a hoax. The hoax is that we are really doing something about it.

BY this late date we should know the fix is in when the White House's top factotums fan out on the Sunday morning talk shows singing the same lyrics, often verbatim, from the same hymnal of spin. The pattern was set way back on Sept. 8, 2002, when in simultaneous appearances three cabinet members and the vice president warned darkly of Saddam's aluminum tubes. "We don't want the smoking gun to be a mushroom cloud," said Condi Rice, in a scripted line. The hard sell of the war in Iraq -- the hyping of a (fictional) nuclear threat to America -- had officially begun. America wasn't paying close enough attention then. We can't afford to repeat that blunder now. Last weekend the latest custodians of the fiasco, our new commander in Iraq, Gen. David Petraeus, and our new ambassador to Baghdad, Ryan Crocker, took to the Sunday shows with two messages we'd be wise to heed.
Roger Lowenstein's article was interesting and provocative because he writes about income inequality but avoids demonizing the market economy.
To the Editor:

The Dominican boys in the back of the freshman English class at the high school in Washington Heights were making fun of the timid African-American girl, Queen Bond. One of the boys got down on one knee in front of her as if he were Romeo -- they had been studying ''Romeo and Juliet'' -- and delivered the final crushing insult. ''He was saying something about that I smelled,'' recalled Queen, now 17. ''I just put my head down. I started crying.''

FROM an island in Maine, Susan Minot arrived in New York for the annual Yaddo benefit last month in a pair of silver sandals. She brought as her unofficial date her sister Eliza, who wore a matching pair that Ms. Minot said she had given her a few years back. It was one of those Minot moments, as recognizable as an overloaded boat bag to readers of ''Monkeys,'' the autobiographical novel that established her high-WASP literary reputation and spawned several books by her siblings.

President Bush has turned the executive branch into a two-way mirror. They get to see everything Americans do: our telephone calls, e-mail, and all manner of personal information. And we get to see nothing about what they do. Everyone knows this administration has disdained openness and accountability since its first days. That is about the only thing it does not hide. But recent weeks have produced disturbing disclosures about just how far Mr. Bush's team is willing to go to keep lawmakers and the public in the dark.

IN January last year, Terrence L. Johnson was standing outside the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem when a tall, lithe woman who looked like a runner leapt out of a yellow cab. ''I thought, 'Wow, she's incredibly gorgeous,' '' he remembered. ''Then I thought, 'Wait a minute, I think I know her!' '' It was Jill Suzanne Gibson, whom he had met in 2000 at the Summer Leadership Institute at Harvard Divinity School in Cambridge, Mass., where Mr. Johnson was working after earning a master's degree there. Now 36, Mr. Johnson recalled that she was tenacious, aloof (which he liked) and challenging.
Colorado Springs Apolo Anton Ohno is a man comfortable competing in spandex, given the second-skin uniform of a short-track speedskater, but on this occasion, he pleaded for wardrobe control.

Alex Rodriguez leads the major leagues in home runs, runs and runs batted in. His average in June is .440. He has reached base in 10 of 12 plate appearances this weekend, and he launched a 458-foot home run to center field to tie the score in the ninth inning Saturday. ''He's been there for us, no question,'' Manager Joe Torre said. ''He's so different this year. He seems to be in such a rhythm now.''

RAND--Rita, died peacefully on June 22, 2007 at her home in New York City. Born in Kansas City, MO in 1918, and raised in Tulsa, OK she attended Tulsa Central High and Goucher College. She is predeceased by two husbands, Ralph Gore and Alfred Rand and her sister Marilyn Krulwich. She is survived by her sister Josephine ''Tubby'' Stayman, her two daughters Sara Stone and Laura Ross, and a stepson Kenneth Rand, seven grandchildren, and five great - grandchildren. A strong, courageous, vibrant, and spirited woman, who loved her family and her friends, she will be deeply missed. Funeral services at 10am on Sunday, June 24, 2007 at Park Avenue Synagogue in the Appleman Chapel, 87th St. and Madison Ave. The family will be receiving visitors Sunday - Tuesday. Contributions in her memory may be made to New York Service for the Handicapped and Park Avenue Synagogue. $(6$)RAND--Rita L. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted and longterm congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President
Sometimes it takes a foundry to produce a word.

Midsummer nights bring free Shakespeare in Central Park, and two productions are under way. The Boomerang Theater Company is staging ''All's Well That Ends Well'' on Saturdays and Sundays through July 22 near 69th Street, and the Public Theater's ''Romeo and Juliet'' is running nightly through July 8 at the Delacorte Theater, near the Central Park West entrance at 81st Street. If you're looking for a bite beforehand, try these restaurants.

Once upon a time, in a world we can hardly imagine anymore -- an era before steroids, before ''Moneyball,'' before 12-man pitching staffs -- any middle-of-the-lineup batter worth his millions knew that going 3-0 in the count gave him a chance to do real damage. Reluctant to issue a pass, pitchers would fire a fastball somewhere near the middle of the plate. Batters still let about 90 percent of those pass for strike one or ball four. Like Goldilocks, they were looking for something not too high, not too low, not on the corners, but just right. But if this ''cripple pitch'' did cross the hitter's power zone and the score was close, and an extra-base hit could be a game-changer, he would let 'er rip.
