A federal vaccine court in Washington is confronting the contentious and highly emotional issue of whether early childhood vaccinations might have caused autism in thousands of children. Virtually every major scientific study and organization that has weighed in on the issue has seen no link. But many parents of afflicted children remain unconvinced. Their lawyers will try to prove that some 4,800 children were harmed by the mass vaccination campaigns that protect the nation's youngsters from potentially devastating childhood illnesses. There seems little doubt that the child at the center of the first of the cases -- Michelle Cedillo of Yuma, Ariz. -- has classic symptoms of autism: impaired social interaction, limited ability to communicate, and unusual repetitive behavior. Her mother says she developed a high fever a week after she received the vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella at the age of 15 months and soon after could not speak and was unresponsive.

SILLOWAY--Stuart F., 100, of Rye Beach, NH, died on June 8, 2007 at the Portsmouth Hospital in Portsmouth, NH. Mr. Silloway graduated from Newburyport High School in 1924, Rutgers Prep School in 1925 and Wesleyan University in 1929. Mr. Silloway retired in 1971 as CEO of Investors Diversified Services in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Prior to that he had been President of Harriman Ripley & Co., President of Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corp. and V.P. Finance for Mutual Life Insurance Co. He Chaired the United Negro College Fund for the State of Minnesota in 1970-1971. Mr. Silloway had been a Director of the following: First Security Corp., Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corp., El Paso Company, Mutual Life Insurance Co., Northern Natural Gas, American Petrofina Inc., Newmont Mining Corp., Jostens Inc., Wesleyan University and several Investors Diversified Services boards.

The stones at Machu Picchu seem almost alive. They may be alive, if you credit the religious beliefs of the ruler Pachacuti Yupanqui, whose subjects in the early 15th century constructed the granite Inca complex, high above a curling river and nestled among jagged green peaks. To honor the spirits that take form as mountains, the Inca stoneworkers carved rock outcrops to replicate their shapes. Doorways and windows of sublimely precise masonry frame exquisite views. But this extraordinary marriage of setting and architecture only partly explains the fame of Machu Picchu today. Just as important is the romantic history, both of the people who built it in this remote place and of the explorer who brought it to the attention of the world. The Inca succumbed to Spanish conquest in the 16th century; and the explorer Hiram Bingham III, whose long life lasted almost as many years as the Inca empire, died in 1956. Like the stones of Machu Picchu, however, the voices of the Inca ruler and the American explorer continue to resonate.

WHEN they befriended each other in a high school class on French New Wave cinema, Alex Kurtzman and Roberto Orci vowed that some day they would write intimate, character-driven films in the style of Jean-Luc Godard. ''We were totally gung-ho to make really revolutionary independent movies,'' Mr. Kurtzman said in a recent conversation. ''We wanted to throw $50,000 into some movie and just make it.'' Sure enough, Mr. Kurtzman and Mr. Orci, both 33, ended up as screenwriters -- for movies that cost roughly 1,000 to 3,000 times as much. And while their scripts may deal with the knotty details of relationships, they are usually concerned with, say, the bonds between on-the-lam lovers who discover that they're clones, or a squad of hulking robots able to transform themselves into all manner of motor vehicles.
TRAKIS--Peter C. Oct. 7, 1965June 24, 1998. Forever in our hearts and thoughts. Love, Mom and Dad

AS the sun set on Staten Island's south shore, a Tibetan Buddhist named Gyatso carried a crate of live shellfish down to the harbor. Squatting on a rock, his sneakers perilously close to the water, he submerged the crate, and then tossed the marine snails, one by one, into the sea. As he did so, he murmured the words ''Om mani padme hum,'' the mantra of compassion, for liberation from all negative karmas. ''The best news,'' Gyatso said of the snails, ''is that they are saved from the frying pan.''

Last month, Congress set a deadline for the American commander in Iraq, declaring that by Sept. 15 he would have to assess progress there before billions more dollars are approved to finance the military effort to stabilize the country. The commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus, said in recent days that his report would be only a snapshot of trends, strongly suggesting he will be asking for more time. But even before he composes the first sentences of the report, to be written with the new American ambassador in Baghdad, Ryan C. Crocker, the administration is commissioning other assessments that could dilute its findings about the impact of the current troop increase. The intent appears to be to give President Bush, who publicly puts great emphasis on listening to his field commanders, a wide range of options.

SOMEWHERE ON LIFE'S HIGHWAY It was a truly ecumenical moment last week when the Vatican brought the people of the world together to contemplate the one thing that we all increasingly have in common: the joys of sharing the road with idiots multitasking while their kids watch ''The Little Mermaid'' on the car video system.
DANCE Jennifer Dunning

Kei Igawa was in a foul mood Saturday, storming into the Yankees' clubhouse after a morning workout, firing his sneakers in his locker, crumpling up some paper that was left on his chair and throwing it aside. Then Igawa changed into his spikes and went back outside to work in the bullpen on mechanics. Asked later what was bothering him, Igawa said, ''Nothing.''

June 18: The New York Public Library held its annual corporate dinner at its main branch on Fifth Avenue. The evening, which honored Stephen Schwarzman, was attended by 400 guests and raised $2.2 million.
To the Editor:

Jennifer Sarah George and Major Kenneth George Heckel were married yesterday at the OceanCliff Hotel in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Ara Jizmejian, an Armenian Evangelical minister, officiated. Mrs. Heckel, 33, is a candidate for a master's degree in mental health counseling at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. She graduated from Notre Dame and is the daughter of Paula T. George and William Elias George of Greenville, R.I.
To the Editor:

When she moved into her retirement condominium on a golf course, Eleanor Weiner admired the lush, pristine views of the fairways and greens, a landscape she never had to mow or maintain. Not long after, as she prepared dinner, a golf ball shattered the kitchen window, whistled past her head and crashed through the glass on her oven door. Ms. Weiner retrieved the ball from her oven and stalked outside to confront the golfer who had launched the missile. ''He told me that's what I get for living on a golf course,'' said Ms. Weiner, who has lived for a dozen years alongside Rancho Las Palmas Country Club near Palm Springs, Calif. ''That was the first time I heard that, but it surely hasn't been the last.''

A top leader of Hamas, which last week routed its rival, Fatah, from Gaza, called for talks on Saturday to re-form a power-sharing Palestinian government. But Fatah leaders, looking forward to a meeting of regional leaders on Monday that excludes Hamas, rebuffed the offer. ''There will be no dialogue with Hamas,'' Reuters quoted Hussein al-Sheikh, a senior Fatah official, as saying.

The Twenties were just starting to roar when New York and New Jersey agreed to quit feuding over their mutual waterway, the one with the Statue of Liberty in its center. The two state governments created what is now called the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The treaty gave each governor the right to appoint half the agency's board members. Since then, this strange organizational bird has been running the port, and over time has taken on the Lincoln and Holland tunnels, the George Washington Bridge, various bus terminals, and the Newark, La Guardia, Kennedy and Teterboro airports. The authority, which also owned the World Trade Center, now controls most of the complicated downtown reconstruction project, including the Calatrava PATH station, the memorial, the Freedom Tower and the foundations for other skyscrapers.
POP Jon Pareles

MILLER--Jeanette. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Jeanette Miller, beloved mother of our devoted member Richard L. (Amy) Miller. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier

HIGH-DEFINITION television sets grow ever more sophisticated, but the colors on many of the screens are still created the old-time way: with tubes or bulbs that give off white light that is filtered into primary colors and remixed. Now, several manufacturers are replacing these bulbs with lasers and light-emitting diodes, or L.E.D.'s. These lasers and L.E.D.'s do not beam white light, but rather its three basic building blocks: red, green and blue. Beams are emitted in a narrow band of wavelengths very close to those of single, pure colors, giving off the brilliant, saturated red of a blazing sunset or the shimmering, luminous blue of a rainbow.

Fifty years would be time enough in the national memory to qualify the Dodgers' departure from Brooklyn as a mythical event, were it not that it actually happened. I know it did; I was one of the kids it happened to. The story lasts, in part, because it portrays innocent victims like me and an oversize villain named Walter O'Malley. Yet it recounts only half of New York's baseball heartbreak in 1957. The New York Giants also pulled up their deep roots that year, but memories seldom invoke their own calculating principal owner, Horace Stoneham. It turns out, in fact, that Stoneham was much more coolly committed to moving from the city than was the infamous O'Malley.

time Hong Kongers sometimes call themselves the ''people beneath Lion Rock,'' after the ragged peak that looms over the peninsula joining Hong Kong to mainland China. At the mountain's base is the leafy suburb of Kowloon Tong. It has never been a big tourist draw, but in the decade since territorial control returned to China, this quintessentially Hong Kong neighborhood has had many more visitors -- and important changes.
To the Editor:

INVESTMENT newsletter editors are markedly less optimistic about the stock market now than they were late last year, when the Dow Jones industrial average was a thousand points lower. This suggests that the bull market may run a while longer, according to the market timing theory known as contrarian analysis. The theory is based on the historical tendency of investors to be wrong about the stock market's direction, especially at major turning points. Investors tend to assume that what has happened will keep happening: they become progressively more bullish as the stock market rises, and increasingly bearish as it declines. Market tops are reached when there are very few bearish holdouts; most everyone who could be tempted to invest in the stock market has already done so -- leaving little cash on the sidelines to propel equities higher.
Chapter 12

Jean Wilson Galbraith, a daughter of Sarah Galbraith and J. Alan Galbraith of Washington, is to be married this evening to Jeremy Bruce Tobacman, a son of Dr. Joanne Tobacman and Dr. Larry Tobacman of Burr Ridge, Ill. Judge David S. Tatel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, for whom the bride was a law clerk in 2004 and 2005, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the Harvard Club of Boston. The bride, 30, and the bridegroom, 29, met at Harvard, from which they graduated, and where the bridegroom received a doctorate in economics this month. They began dating after they saw each other again at their five-year college reunion.

To the Editor: Regarding ''The Other Machu Picchu'' by Ethan Todras-Whitehill: Having just returned from 10 days in Peru, I was amused by Mr. Todras-Whitehill's story of Choquequirao, in which he quotes an archaeologist describing it as ''an Inca site you can visit without a 60-person Japanese tour group and two tour guides with umbrellas and megaphones.''

Charlotte Martin, a daughter of Martha Bacon Martin and David B. H. Martin of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Mark Powers Smith, a son of Mary Smith Wiatr of Woodbury, Conn., and Wilford A. Smith of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Oran E. Warder performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Alexandria. Mrs. Smith, 32, is a candidate for a master's degree in psychological counseling at Teachers College of Columbia University. She graduated from Brown.

WITHIN the hothouse atmosphere of last month's Cannes Film Festival, the Italian actress Asia Argento was a weather system unto herself, creating pockets of turbulence wherever she went. Ms. Argento, whose first name is pronounced ''AH-zee-ah,'' is one of those rare actors whose mere presence instantly makes a movie less predictable. She had three films in the festival, and in each one, handily conquered scenes that would reduce most performers to nervous wrecks or laughingstocks. In Catherine Breillat's ''Old Mistress,'' playing a Spanish courtesan entangled with a pretty-boy aristocrat in 1830s Paris, she consummates the affair by hungrily lapping the blood off her wounded lover's chest. They later have tearful sex next to their dead baby's funeral pyre.
To the Editor:

Every time he approached the third-base line on the way to the mound Saturday night, the Oregon State freshman right-hander Jorge Reyes bounded across the dirt as if it were piled high with hot coals. That is the most obvious of Reyes's multitude of superstitions, which include tapping seven acupuncture points on his forehead and chest before every inning, and wearing the same shorts on days he pitches. Oregon State Coach Pat Casey has watched Reyes leap this way for almost two months, since he put him in the rotation in April. Casey had more experienced pitchers to start against North Carolina in Game 1 of the College World Series final, but chose to stick with Reyes, who was 2-0 this postseason with a 1.42 earned run average.

ANTIGRAVITY Boots sound like equipment for X-Men, and they look that way too, raising the wearer -- at rest -- 16 inches off the ground on a sleek fiberglass rod that curves like a parenthesis from a ''footprint'' no larger than that of a high-heeled shoe. The daredevils who wear them charge onstage to a techno beat, rocket 12 to 15 feet skyward and do backflips, landing like high-pressure pistons on concrete and rocketing off again. Just watching can give you an adrenaline rush. More than once the impact has smashed the floor. ''The boots are light; they're springy,'' said Christopher Harrison, the founder of AntiGravity, a New York confederacy of dancers, gymnasts and aerialists. ''They're not cumbersome. They make you feel superhuman. They allow you really to leap and jump. You can run up and down stairs. You feel like a gazelle. The only thing you can't do is stand still.''

AFTER much fanfare, legislation creating real estate investment trusts in Britain, one of Europe's biggest property markets, took effect on Jan. 1. Almost immediately, nine of the country's largest real estate companies converted to REITs, while five others made the switch soon after and a handful more plan to follow suit by year-end. In the months leading up to the big debut, expectations ran high, with the hope that Britain's already-strong commercial real estate industry would further flourish. A REIT market, after all, could attract more investors globally and make it easier for the local companies to raise capital. (The corporate structure gives real estate investment trusts favorable tax treatment in exchange for disbursing most of their income to shareholders as dividends.)

The suggestion posed by Lant Pritchett that we at least consider a ''giant guest-worker program'' was thought-provoking. But one of the short interviews in your feature ''Money Talks'' really got to me. It is pathetic that any teenager in America thinks it's appropriate to spend ''like, four digits'' if you ''want a really nice classic bag.'' Maybe Gabby, and perhaps her parents, should spend some time with the goat herders in Nepal.
SMALL-SCREEN SIRENS Better Nickname, Please

To the Editor: I fondly read Evan Rail's ''One More for the Road'' (May 20). It reminded me of when I was a college student in Cologne. My first few days there were spent at a pension in the heart of the city. Downstairs was a bierstube, where Cologne's signature beer, Kölsch, was served in small, cylindrical glasses. What still astonishes me is that German businessmen wearing suits would come into the stube in the morning and down one small glass of Kölsch on their way to work.

AFTER a decade in power, Tony Blair steps down as prime minister of the United Kingdom on Wednesday to a chorus of yawns from his countrymen and hisses from most of his Labor Party colleagues. Well, if his former friends and voters don't have a good word for him, I guess it's up to one of us from the Conservative opposition to state the obvious: Tony Blair was a remarkable prime minister.

Late last spring, Republicans in this West Texas oil town called for a boycott of Doña Anita's Mexican restaurant, a retaliatory step against its owner, Luz Reyes, for closing shop and showing up at a rally against proposed new penalties for illegal immigrants. But President Bush's three best friends here defied the boycott and went to the restaurant, Mr. Bush's favorite when he lived here, regardless. One of them, the president's close confidant and former commerce secretary, Donald L. Evans, told Ms. Reyes: ''Luz, you didn't do anything wrong. We love you.''

NICYPER--Raymond Seymour, industrial and graphic designer, artist and developer of numerous design and graphic arts tools and products, died June 16 at the age of 88. He loved jazz and his love of jazz pervaded every aspect of his life, from his early years playing piano in his creative and harmonically complex style through his final years when his love of listening to jazz consistently brought joy to his life. He graduated from Pratt Institute in 1942, having been president of his class for two consecutive years. He worked a short time as a designer at Boeing Aircraft in Seattle, Washington, before enlisting in the Army Air Forces, where he served as a Captain in Air Force photo reconnaissance and intelligence units. He was awarded bronze stars and received numerous other commendations for his ''untiring and painstaking efforts''. Following World War II, he spent several years as a designer and art supervisor at companies including McGraw Hill, Donald Deskey Associates and Lehigh Engineering. He then founded Graphicraft, Inc., which became his vehicle for creating and marketing many tools and aids for arts and design industries. He lived most of his life in Weston, Connecticut, as a devoted husband and father of two sons. He is survived by his sons Mark and Dean, three beautiful granddaughters and his sister Muriel. He will be remembered by all for his creativity, tireless work ethic and never-ending sense of humor.

NEW ORLEANS defines who I am. I'm passionate about St. Augustine, the high school I attended. I grew up poor, in the Ninth Ward, in a rough neighborhood that was wiped out by Hurricane Katrina. Dad was a carpenter, but job opportunities were few and far between. He did what he had to do, including waiting tables at formal balls in the hotels. My mother was everything from a domestic to a teacher. They sacrificed to make sure my four siblings and I had opportunities. They also took in 27 foster children over the years.

GREENSBURG, Kan. It is morning in Greensburg, population uncertain. The sun rises from the flat-line horizon to cast light upon the tidy curbside piles of debris that had been homes, the untidy piles of brick that had been downtown, the denuded trees that now look like pale hands reaching skyward.

The cameramen shuffled backward through a Capitol Hill corridor, as reporters from Tokyo and Paris strained to capture the campaigner's every word. An entourage of handlers, with cellphones to their ears, kept the scrum moving toward the door. A van was waiting, its engine running. ''Keep moving, people,'' one aide barked. ''Keep moving. We've got to go.'' Barack Obama in the House? Perhaps Fred Thompson?

Voice of the Faithful, the lay group formed in response to the sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church, is calling for the Vatican to review the requirement that priests be celibate, saying the policy may have played a role in the scandal. The position represents a shift in the approach of the organization, which has avoided raising such controversial issues. It comes as Voice of the Faithful faces a budget deficit from a drop-off in large donations and finds itself at a crossroads in direction.

THEY'RE big, they're sleek, they come from La Crosse, Wis., and they're the reason New York City Center will have its first summer season since Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia designated the former space of the Ancient Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine a performing arts center in 1943. At 350 tons of cooling capacity, the two Trane electric centrifugal chillers newly installed in the basement are part of a $10 million, four-year overhaul that means Patti LuPone and Boyd Gaines can star in ''Gypsy'' in the previously stifling theater from July 9 through 29. ''The myth that everyone leaves New York in the summer'' is just that, said Arlene Shuler, City Center's president.

IF a death notice had been drafted for the Florsheim Group in 2001, the year that the company went on life support, it might have read something like this: A well-known company, whose shoes outfitted generations of American boys and men for school, work, weddings and funerals for most of the 20th century, died yesterday. Once a small, profitable and highly regarded family business, Florsheim, owned for the past 50 years by outside investors, succumbed to loads of debt, lackadaisical vision and outdated styling. Florsheim, 110 years old, is survived by a slew of much hipper brands.

The ambiguous state of ROBERT ALDRICH's critical reputation can be summed up by noting that the very first essay in Richard Roud's authoritative two-volume work ''Cinema: A Critical Dictionary'' is devoted to Mr. Aldrich, whose name therefore appears on the cover of the first volume. But the essay itself, by Andrew Sarris, is more concerned with debunking Mr. Aldrich, then and still probably best known as the director of ''Kiss Me Deadly'' and ''What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?,'' than with canonizing him. Mr. Roud himself goes on to note that ''Sarris's pessimism about Aldrich's career was only too graphically confirmed'' by Mr. Aldrich's work in the late 1960s and '70s. '' 'Ulzana's Raid,' 'The Emperor of the North Pole,' 'The Longest Yard' and 'Hustle,' '' Mr. Roud writes, ''are so many steps on the downward path.''

Johan Santana of the Twins needed only 92 pitches to defeat the Mets on Tuesday, 9-0. Charles Barrett holds the record for the fewest pitches in a nine-inning game with 58. He did it for the Boston Braves against the Reds in 1944.

As a high school senior, David Lee was a high flyer who, like any teenager, loved the thrill and the theatrics of making highlight-reel dunks. He is now a burgeoning star for the Knicks because of a far more basic skill -- rebounding. Lee offered a simple lesson to the 100 high school players attending the National Basketball Players Association's annual camp this weekend.

You could spend an entire week or two at the JACOB'S PILLOW DANCE FESTIVAL in the Berkshires simply roaming expanses of lush green and peering into the windows of the small white outcroppings of buildings where student and professional dancers study and rehearse. But there are actually performances as well this week. Starting on Wednesday, COLEMAN LEMIEUX & COMPAGNIE, a modern dance troupe from Montreal, will present ''The Dome,'' a piece by Ted Shawn, who founded the Pillow in 1933. The program also includes a premiere and two repertory pieces by James Kudelka, including the delicious ''Fifteen Heterosexual Duets.'' The company also has eight performers aged 8 to 11. AURÉLIA THIERRÉE, from France, will perform this week as well, in ''Aurelia's Oratorio,'' which combines puppetry, dance and theater. And there is the usual complement of free lectures, exhibitions and performances throughout the rolling festival campus. Coleman Lemieux & Compagnie, Ted Shawn Theater, Wednesday through Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 p.m.; $45. Aurélia Thierrée, Doris Duke Studio Theater, Thursday and Friday at 8:15 p.m., Saturday at 2:15 and 8:15 p.m., Sunday at 5 p.m.; $28. George Carter Road, Becket, Mass., (413) 243-0745, jacobspillow.org.
For my final post here, I'd like to give you a little tour of the last year and half of my life. It covers a lot of ground, so hang on.

For some loyal denizens of YouTube.com -- including the politically attuned -- the site's recent redesign that replaced users' picks for the most viewed or highly rated videos with editors' choices in subject categories like news and politics, is akin to dictatorship.

Barton Gellman, one of the best reporters around, has a superb and illuminating series in The Washington Post about Dick Cheney. While Cheney himself didn't talk, lots of people around him did -- underscoring Cheney's central role in the Bush administration's most demented policies. The series shows that Bush is still the boss -- it's not as if Cheney is secretly pulling the strings -- but that Bush tends to operate at a level of general goals. Cheney is a master of operations, and uses that role to translate general aims into specific (and usually horrifying) policies.
The public discourse about evolution has been so dominated by politics and religion that it can seem as if the science behind it has been frozen since the time of Darwin.
Clips from Christie Whitman's testimony before a House subcommittee.

With the Cardinals playing the Mets tonight at Shea Stadium, and in the spirit of Tony La Russa, the man entrusted with managing the National League team on July 10 - and remember, this year it counts - here is one man's guess as to how the 32-man roster will shake out. There are no requirements as to how many pitchers, infielders, outfielders, etc. ... must be on a roster, so the manager often picks more players from a particularly strong position and fewer from a weaker one. For instance, I could see La Russa picking two additional shortstops but only one more second baseman.
Sean B. Carroll discusses the science of evolution and the field of evo-devo.

Passengers mill in the aisles and fan themselves aboard a 50-seat Comair jet that was stranded on a ramp at Kennedy International Airport for four hours, while David Ollila, whose company makes miniature video cameras, talks to his office in Michigan and films from the scene. Video courtesy of V.I.O. Inc.

Editor's note: An earlier version of this article included a paraphrase of President Bush's remarks at a 2004 press conference. That passage has been replaced by a direct quote from the White House transcript.

Is wild the word? How can yesterday's races in Champ Car and Nascar be defined? I did not see the Nascar race, but the race at the Infineon Raceway road course in Sonoma, California does give some food for thought, and I wrote a few words about Juan Pablo Montoya's first Nascar victory elsewhere.
Alessandra Ferri's farewell performance of Romeo & Juliet with  Roberto Bolle. Videography by Nan Melville.
Holy Caesar!

A study that has dominated most e-mailed lists since Friday, when eldest siblings found proof that they "had a slight but significant edge in I.Q.," was punctured with one tiny, microscopic hole today in Britain. Georgia Brown, a two-year-old with an I.Q. of 152, is the youngest of five children, a British newspaper reported.
In his Web column today, Patrick Healy catches up with former New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, who has his own newsletter and has started a series of issue-related forums pegged to the 2008 campaign cycle.

Our builder, Johnny, had pledged to work up an estimate. In the meantime, my biggest concern was refining the plan for the top floor. Like readers of this blog, I thought this floor needed modifications.

The Supreme Court dealt a huge blow to the McCain-Feingold campaign finance act today, loosening "the restrictions on what companies and unions can spend on television advertisements just before elections." The Republican co-sponsor of the act, John McCain, wasn't pleased, saying, "It is regrettable that a split Supreme Court has carved out a narrow exception by which some corporate and labor expenditures can be used to target a federal candidate in the days and weeks before an election."
The number of companies affected by naked short selling keeps growing -- at least in the minds of some.

One of my first memories of baseball was watching the 1984 All-Star Game at Candlestick Park. I was 3 years old at the time and naturally didn't remember much from it. But my dad taped it, as he did most baseball All-Star Games when I wasn't old enough to stay up late to watch them, and a few years later, I would pop the tape into the VCR and watch the player introductions over and over and over. Occasionally, I'd watch a few innings before I got bored and went off to play with Legos or something.
Just how much would Congress's proposed tax increase cost Fortress Investment Group?
Following a crime in Austin that shocked the nation is a familiar, deafening silence for murder investigators from Toronto to Newark.

An obscure government study of audit quality -- in audits that are not regulated by much of anybody -- has found that most audits conducted in 2002-'03 were not of sufficient quality to be relied upon.
The New Yorker's John Cassidy this week takes a close look at the mystique of hedge funds, and, in a way, sees an industry that would rather not let you look behind its curtain.
We've had a run of gorgeous early summer days here in New York - bright, crisp and uncharacteristically dry. It seems like an ideal time for a seasonal warning about drinking white wines too cold.
Todd Thomson, the former head of wealth management at Citigroup and onetime heir apparent to former Citi chief Sandy Weill, is still being a bit secretive about his next move on Wall Street.
“Tarzan” is closing, and Molly Picon, the Sweetheart of Second Avenue, is the subject of a new exhibit in New York.

The private equity industry is not just sitting back and waiting for Congress to raise their taxes. The Private Equity Council, a less-than-year-old trade group representing many large buyout firms in the United States, has hired big guns from the lobbying world to defend their interests in Washington.
The weekend was rich with news about battles between humankind and various creatures of the wild.
"Can you take me back to the U.S. with you?"

Doral Financial, the Puerto Rico-based bank that is facing bankruptcy, said that it will turn to a buyout offer led by Bear Stearns, after a rival offer from its second-largest shareholder was withdrawn.

Echoing concerns "among some veteran game journalists" flagged by Game Politics, a great blog about the video game industry, The New York Times's reviewer, Seth Schiesel, found the adult rating of Manhunt 2 "entirely reasonable."
Jim Roberts, editor of digital news, is answering questions June 25 through 29.
In Nascar, Juan Pablo Montoya recovered from an awful qualifying session and gambled on fuel in the closing laps at Infineon Speedway to win his first Nextel Cup (soon to be Sprint Cup) race.

Though some suggested its opening-day jump wasn't big enough, especially considering the Hollywood-like atmosphere around the event, the Blackstone Group's $4.1 billion initial public offering on Friday was generally seen as a success.
A quick hike through this past Sunday's book sections.
Over the weekend, signs grew that Prime Minister Tony Blair was getting closer to securing his next job offer, and so did opinions about whether he should get it.
Bear Stearns's recent hedge-fund troubles could affect more than just the investment bank's reputation. They could jeopardize its independence as well.
A timeline of major findings in evolutionary science.
During the summer of 1999, Stephen King - then recuperating from being hit by a van - read the second and third Harry Potter books and they became, he wrote, "a kind of lifeline for me."
It is do or die - again - for the immigration legislation in the Senate as Congress heads into its final days before the Fourth of July break.

In a reprise of the 2004 flap between Senator John F. Kerry and the handful of American bishops who sought to deny him communion because of his support for abortion rights, church leaders are now setting their sights on a 2008 Republican presidential hopeful and lifetime Catholic, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, and advisers for Dow Jones and its controlling Bancroft family were close Sunday night to agreeing on terms designed to protect The Wall Street Journal's newsroom independence if the company accepts a takeover bid from Mr. Murdoch, according to The New York Times.
General Electric's NBC Universal with Pearson and Hearst until recently considering partnering for Dow Jones. News Corporation-MySpace-Yahoo. News Corp.-NBC. Universal.

This week, Jason Binn's Niche Media, whose titles include Gotham and Los Angeles Confidential, is expected to announce a merger with Greenspun Media Group of Las Vegas - which publishes Vegas, Wynn and Venetian Style, among other magazines - and the Ocean Drive Media Group, which publishes Ocean Drive and Ocean Drive Español and several other magazines, The New York Times' David Carr reported.

GLG Partners, one of Europe's largest hedge funds, will go public in the United States through a $3.4 billion merger with an investment company, Freedom Acquisition Holdings, according to The New York Times.

Shaw Group, an engineering services provider, said Friday its Shaw Capital unit and an investment company, Alinda Capital Partners, had agreed to create a joint venture to pursue a variety of projects. The venture, called Shaw Infrastructure Investments, will pursue energy, transportation, infrastructure, water, wastewater and related projects.

For some Wall Street veterans, the Blackstone Group's debut on the New York Stock Exchange Friday may have sparked flashbacks to the 1980s, notes USA Today. "The publicity is creating a déjà vu all over again," John C. Coffee, an expert in securities law at Columbia University, told USA Today. "To anyone who was around Wall Street in the '80s, Blackstone reminds them of the powerful role of Drexel Burnham. They were also masters of the universe."

After a nine-month investigation, a bipartisan Senate subcommittee is expected to issue a report Monday detailing how a single hedge fund, Amaranth Advisors, dominated the North American natural gas market last year, causing high prices and extreme volatility that ultimately led to the company's stunning collapse.
